column2: ALBANY, March 4 -- Democratic legislators became alarmed today over the possibility that they would be asked to vote in favor of transferring New York's publicly owned transit lines to an independent authority that would be required to operate them without any tax subsidy.

The National Broadcasting Company and Life magazine are planning to present more than seventy radio and television programs to acquaint New York parents and taxpayers with all aspects of the local school system.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 5 (AP) -- Snow and bitter cold heaped misery on homeless thousands in northern Japan last night and early today in the wake of one of the heaviest earthquakes of the twentieth century.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Surplus Manpower Committee completed work today on six more surplus labor areas, making a total of ten, marked for special consideration in the placing of Government contracts.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 4 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board opened today its hearing into the crash here last Jan. 22 of an American Airlines Convair that killed twenty-three persons aboard the plane and seven residents in their homes.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 4 -- Sharply rising prices have caused a flurry of concern in public and government quarters here. The upward trend has been continuous for months and has caused hardship for low-income and salaried groups.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson proposed today an impartial investigation to show that Communist charges that the United Nations forces are using germ warfare in Korea are "nonsense" and "entirely false."

A group of professional actors who have been studying at the American Theatre Wing offered showcase performances yesterday afternoon and last night at the President Theatre. The presentation was for invited audiences, consisting largely of stage and television producers and agents.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A Senate subcommittee questioned Edward H. Foley Jr., Under Secretary of the Treasury, for twenty minutes today about the interest he took in pending tax cases and, after the closed session, announced that "no investigation was ordered and none asked."

MADRID, March 4 -- The Falange party, totalitarian in doctrine and structure, today announced its support for a policy of collaboration with the United States after nearly twenty years during which it had relentlessly fought the Western concept of democracy.

The New York Trio, which is in residence at City College, paid its respects to a colleague from Sarah Lawrence College at its concert at Town Hall last night. The colleague was Andre Singer, a composer born in Hungary and educated in Austria, and his Opus 32, composed last year, received its baptismal performance.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- Florida's record-breaking racing season continued at Gulfstream Park today where new attendance and betting records were set at the opening of the final forty-one days.

Five hundred members of Local 1478, Marine Warehouse Workmen's Union, walked off the Linden Avenue Army pier in Jersey City last night in a wildcat strike. The walkout was believed to have resulted from the ban last Monday night on employment of some unionists on near-by docks on the charge that they were hoodlums.
Thousands of demonstrating workers shut down to a considerable degree the operations of the nation s two largest electrical producers yesterday by walking off their jobs early or by brief stoppages.
OTTAWA, March 4 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's socialist party charged today that Canada and her North Atlantic Allies have gone overboard on rearmament in a "disasterous and irresponsible" way.

The whereabouts of a 70-year-old Chinese laundryman remained a mystery yesterday and there was uncertainty about the disposition of thirty-six packages of laundry left with him by West. Side customers. It all started on Feb. 4, when Richard Lee posted a sign on the window of his store at 410 West Fifty-sixth Street that read: "Close out. Please call for your laundry as soon as possible."

The revival of Gluck's "Alcestis," in English translation by John Gutman, last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, was memorable, indeed unique, for the performance of the name part by Mme. Flagstad. She will appear in this role four more times this season.

Well-known women, including Mrs. Ellen Tuck Astor and Mrs. Ira Haupt, are serving on the tableaux committee for the Ciro Ball, the annual spring dinner dance and entertainment for the benefit of the New York Infirmary. Mrs. Astor and Mrs. Eugene W. Ong head the executive committee for the event, which will be held on the night of April 15 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The caseload of the city's Municipal Courts has gone up sharply in the last five years, William Lyman, President Justice of the Municipal Court, asserted yesterday in his annual report.

A stepped-up drive to sell more Dutch flower bulbs to this country's 30,000,000 home owners and suburban dwellers was announced yesterday by the Associated Bulb Growers of Holland. Walter Roozen, international advertising director of the group, told newsmen at the Netherland Club here that sales in this country are still small in comparison to per capita purchases in other countries.

Although the booklet is small enough to fit into an apron pocket, "Foreign Food Ventures," a new publication by Swift Co., presents recipes from all parts of the globe. The collection is a good one, for it includes typical dishes likely to be of interest to the American housewife -- polenta from Italy, sukiyaki from Japan, Norwegian anise cookies and Mexican corn meal tortillas.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4 -- Columbia rallied late in the final quarter to defeat a stubborn Yale quintet, 62 -- 56, on the Payne Whitney court tonight.

Dr. Arthur M. Master, president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, announced yesterday that a subcommittee of the society had been formed to investigate the case of Dr. Walter P. Schrieber, who was World War II Chief of Medical Science for the German Army.
DETROIT, March 4 (AP) -- General Motors plants in the United States built 351,681 cars and trucks in the first two months of this year.
Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires retained the lead by defeating Muguel Aleman of Cuba in the eighth round of the international chess tournament yesterday, according to a report from Havana.

At dawn today, while most of the city still sleeps, the Rev. Adrian Buisson will get up from his couch in the buff-colored Spanish church at 624 West 156th Street. He will put on the Augustinian cassock and go down to morning Mass.

The Long Island Lighting Company, which serves one of the fastest growing territories in the nation, announced yesterday that expenditures for new construction in 1952 will approximate $41,000,000, with some variation depending upon deliveries of materials.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Wednesday, March 5 -- The Mayor of Tuckahoe, Milton A. Gibbons, and Mrs. Mary Beary Hayes, daughter of a one-time Yonkers police captain, were found guilty early this morning of conspiring to violate gambling laws.

In his second day as a Government witness in the anti-trust investment banking trial at Federal Court here, Harold L. Stuart, Chicago financier, declared that his firm could have managed hundreds of millions of dollars in underwritings if he had known about the issues in advance of their sale and had opportunities to purchase them.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 4 -- Seventy foreign students who are studying at the University of Bridgeport under a Mutual Security Agency program expressed bitterness today over arrangements for their stay here, particularly because only seventeen of their number had obtained employment.

Moving to the front after 2 minutes 30 seconds of the first quarter, New York University's basketball team easily defeated its traditional foe, City College, 84 to 47, at the N. Y. U. Alumni Gymnasium last night. It was the thirty-seventh meeting between the schools in a series begun in 1914.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Senate approved without dissent today a bill to include a new Westchester highway running from Elmsford to Rye through White Plains within the state highway system despite the opposition of the City Council of White Plains.

JERUSALEM, March 4 -- The Government's estimates of 168,450,000 Israeli pounds for the fiscal year starting April 1 will cover the whole ordinary budget of the state, including the entire security appropriation. This will be the first time Israel's ordinary budget, including security costs, will be balanced by internal revenue.

The storm-battered Liberty ship Rachel Jackson arrived in New York at 4 P. M. yesterday -- her superstructure and deck a shambles of crushed steel, smashed ventilators and lifeboats and twisted metal cargo booms and ladders.

Real recovery was staged yesterday by the stock market. The re-entry of buyers and the absence of pressure allowed prices to reclaim most of their losses of the last two weeks and score the best advance since mid-1951.
The armed forces need 3,763 more nurses before July 1 and getting them has become the No. 1 priority in all recruiting activities.

A lusty March snow storm scudded across the Midwest yesterday with a cold wave following in its path. The storm disrupted transportation and forced school closings in many areas from Kansas City to northern Michigan.

We have allowed our Federal Government to wind up the spiral of prices until things cost too much and taxes are too high. Suppose now we let loose this tight-wound spool and get back what we know is sensible.

DOVER, N. H., March 4 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee returned to New Hampshire today to further his campaign for support as the Democratic Presidential nominee a few hours after the party's state organization had launched a movement to get out the vote for President Truman next week.

Down 12 points with slightly more than twelve minutes to go, the New York Knickerbockers fashioned a spectacular comeback, drew even with the champion Rochester Royals in regulation time and proceeded to win in overtime, 92 -- 90, last night at Madison Square Garden.

The Continental Oil Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income for 1951 of $41,292,692 after charges, taxes and tangible drilling costs, depreciation and depletion. This was $4.25 each on the 9,716,916 capital shares outstanding.

As of late, there has been a great deal of interest expressed by many groups and many individuals concerning the inequities in our present antiquated election laws. Many people have advocated various reforms. The most important task ahead for all of us who are interested in representative government, I believe, is to continue to stir up the interest of the citizens in voting.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- Casey Stengel got his first glimpse of his wealth of young talent in battle array today. What he saw must have been highly satisfying to the Yankee skipper as Billy Martin, one of his outstanding candidates for the second base job, smacked a grand-slam home run for Frankie Crosetti's Crows.

The Continental Oil Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income for 1951 of $41,292,692 after charges, taxes and tangible drilling costs, depreciation and depletion. This was $4.25 each on the 9,716,916 capital shares outstanding.

As of late, there has been a great deal of interest expressed by many groups and many individuals concerning the inequities in our present antiquated election laws. Many people have advocated various reforms. The most important task ahead for all of us who are interested in representative government, I believe, is to continue to stir up the interest of the citizens in voting.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- Casey Stengel got his first glimpse of his wealth of young talent in battle array today. What he saw must have been highly satisfying to the Yankee skipper as Billy Martin, one of his outstanding candidates for the second base job, smacked a grand-slam home run for Frankie Crosetti's Crows.
Following is the text of an address by President Truman yesterday aboard the radio transmitter ship Courier, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

An investment banking syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. will make a public offering today of 100,000 shares of $100 par value 5.36 per Cent cumulative preferred stock of El Paso Natural Gas Company. The shares are priced at $100 a share.

DES MOINES, March 4 -- A Federal investigator reported today that officials of the Des Moines University of Lawsonomy bought war surplus machinery and other equipment for $3,691 and resold it to private buyers for about $120,000 to make a profit of 3,000 per cent.

PARIS, March 5 -- An indoor exercise involving senior officers under the command of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and national representatives of the Atlantic Treaty nations connected with that command will be held in Paris between April 7 and 11 on General Eisenhower's order, an official announcement said today.

Reports from all parts of the country leave little doubt that the shortage of nurses is getting worse. A series of articles in this newspaper shows that the need for nursing service is expanding rapidly, but that the supply of nurses is not. Enrollment in nursing schools dropped 5.7 per cent in 1951 and many nurses are leaving hospitals for better jobs elsewhere.

Issues of new industrial securities with a market value of more than $160,000,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. The major issues represent debentures and common stock of the American Tobacco Company and bonds and convertible debentures of the Inland Steel Company. The offerings are as follows:

New trends in silhouette and fabric were shown yesterday by Rosette Pennington, 20 East Fifty-sixth Street, in the Waldorf-Astoria's Empire Room. An over-all theme of simplicity and wearability, plus the fastidious use of fluid lines was evident in coats, suits and dresses.
The build-up of the national defense machinery should be completed by the end of 1954, and thereafter the nation may look for a drop in the budget of approximately $20,000,0000,000,.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, accused the New Hampshire Secretary of State today of violating the law by failing to rotate the names of candidates in the state's Presidential preference primary.

With the nursing shortage growing more acute, leaders of the profession are coming to the conclusion that the only practical way to get more nursing service lies in using the present nurse supply more efficiently.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore acknowledged today that the Truman Administration's policy toward Communist and Nationalist China in 1946 had been "closely similar" to his own thinking and proposals.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 27:

ST. LOUIS, March 5 -- Testimony linking James P. Finnegan, former Collector of Internal Revenue, with negotiations for a $565,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the American Lithofold Corporation was given in Federal court today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Department of Justice refused today to give to a House Judiciary subcommittee, appointed to investigate it, a list of all cases sent to it by other Government agencies in the last six years in which prosecutions had been declined.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 6 -The United Nations delegates at Panmunjom yesterday handed the Communist armistice negotiators an additional list of 174 Allied soldiers believed captured in the Korean war and asked confirmation of their identity and information concerning their whereabouts.
Nine hundred employes of the Liebmanh Breweries have pledge to make blood contributions tomor: I row in the Rheingold plant at 36 /Forest Street, Brooklyn, the Red [Cross announced yesterday.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 5 -- Gov. Earl Warren announced his entry into Oregon's Presidential preferential primary today as a sharp controversy broke over his charge of twenty-four hours earlier that "the independent oil crowd" in California was pouring money into a campaign of "vilification" to beat him in this state's primary of June 3.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The way was being cleared today for action in both houses of the Legislature early next week on the Erwin-Travia bills, which would bar the use of the regular funds of labor unions for political activities and would set up a strict procedure for the raising of special funds that could be used for political purposes.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Assembly Ways and Means Committee, in a surprise move, killed tonight the compulsory automobile insurance program which had the backing of Governor Dewey and the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicles.

The Senate and House Judiciary Committees have just reported out the McCarran and Walter omnibus bills, respectively, which recodify and revise existing immigration, naturalization and nationality laws. Our laws in the past, in seeking to limit the number and select the kind of immigrants who may enter, have imposed undemocratic, racist concepts and have prevented many active supporters of democracy from coming here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 -- The Soviet member of a United Nations group of twelve news experts proposed today a set of standards for the press that would direct journalists to combat war propaganda, expose fascism and promote friendly relations among nations.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Boncrist Farm's Ginger D., favored at $7.10, raced to expectations when she captured the sixth and best event on Gulfstream Park's second program of the meeting this afternoon. It was a $3,000 overnight test for fillies and mares, named for the Atlantic City Racing Association.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in an unanimous decision rendered Feb. 26, has upheld the power of city magistrates to adjudicate cases involving violations of the Smoke Control Law, it was disclosed yesterday.
ALBANY, March 5 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature today on the Long Island Transit Authority and a letter from the authority's members, addressed to him:

SEOUL, Thursday, March 6 (AP) -- Allied and Communist raiders tested each other's defenses in the eastern Korean hills yesterday and found that both sides had become well fortified in the twilight war.

The Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse "whodunit" comedy, "Remains To Be Seen," is in its last weeks. The attraction will terminate its New York engagement at the Morosco Theatre on Saturday evening, March 22, registering a total of 198 performances.

A wildcat strike that has tied up Army piers at Caven Point and Claremont Terminal since Monday night spread to all Jersey City piers yesterday as conferees representing the city, the union and the employing stevedores sought unsuccessfully to reach an agreement. The group will meet again today in the office of Mayor John V. Kenny.

PARIS, March 5 -- The twelve European nations in the North Atlantic Treaty Organizations should lose no time in organizing a combined program to inform their peoples more fully about the aims and day - to - day developments in the Atlantic pact, in the opinion of some of the ablest and most experienced United States officials serving overseas.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 5 -- The death roll from yesterday's train wreck at the Pavuna River, twenty miles from Rio de Janeiro, continued to mount today as public and press called for emergency measures by the Government to improve conditions on suburban railroads.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The Salary Stabilization Board today authorized the Dodgers and the Giants to raise their payrolls above the ceilings set by a special ruling last month.

PARIS, March 5 -- How to get more dollars for the reserves of the European Payments Union in a time of continuing dollar shortage will be the major problem to be discussed at a meeting tomorrow of the managing board of the union.

The names of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold E. Stassen will be filed today at Trenton, before the midnight deadline for the New Jersey Presidential preference primary on April 15.

The continued presence in a city prison cell of James J. Moran, ousted city official who was sentenced Tuesday to a term of fifteen and a half to twenty-eight years, kept alive yesterday a belief that the prisoner might yet decide to reveal links with other persons in the $500,000-a-year fuel oil extortion racket.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Legislature moved half-way toward abolishing the state's sixty-five-year-old ban on the manufacture and sale of colored oleomargarine today, as the Assembly approved an enabling bill by a 90-to-52 vote.

CAIRO, March 5 -- Premier Ahmed Naguib al Hilaili Pasha has issued a decree as military governor, empowering the Ministry of the Interior to return to his native place or normal residence anyone who is found to have no proper reason for being where he is.

The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company went deeper into the red last year. The transit company's annual report issued yesterday shows a net loss of $1,722,877 for 1951, compared with a loss of $1,312, 590 in 1950.

Delayed by heavy traffic on their way to Pier 88, North River, eight Europe-bound passengers, among them a Mexican family of six, were left behind yesterday as they arrived at the pier only to see the French Liner Ile de France moving slowly out into the river.

Fordham's six-game winning streak ended last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory when Johnny Bach's Rams lost by 64--56 to Manhattan, Ken Norton's Jaspers, in front virtually all the way, ended their basketball season with a 12-and-9 won-lost record.

The National Association of Manufacturers recommended yesterday reductions in the 1953 Federal budget totaling more than $14,800,000,000 and reported that an indicated deficit of $14,400,000,000 thereby could be averted.

MOSCOW, March 5 -- The Supreme Soviet, the highest legislative body in the Soviet Union, met today for a session that will consider the 1952 state budget, which will help to provide concrete financial indications of how the Soviet Government assesses its defense needs in the light of the present world situation.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Securities registrations that ran to $6,459,333,000 in the fiscal year ending last June 30 show that industry's raising of new capital continues at a high rate, Donald C. Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, reported to Congress today.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Governor Dewey requested the Legislature today in a special message to broaden the powers of the Long Island Transit Authority so it could effect a reorganization of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, preferably under private ownership but under public ownership if necessary.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Representative Joseph R. Bryson, Democrat of South Carolina, said President Truman had indicated today that he would support for President any Democrat he felt could beat Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

The presentation of evidence before the Public Service Commission on requested rate rises for the New York Central Railroad ended yesterday. At the state agency's offices, 233 Broadway, Commissioner Paul E. Lockwood directed proponents and opponents of the rises to file briefs not later than March 26.
JACKSON, Miss., March 5 (UP) -- A Federal jury freed five former law officers today of charges that they had violated a Negro's civil rights by trying to beat a robbery confession out of him.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 5 -- Today's practice game produced the first casualty of the Dodger's training season. Duke Snider sprained his left ankle running to third base in the third inning and had to be helped off the field.

Top fashion themes from the French and Italian spring and summer offerings have been garnered by David Nemeroff, chairman of the board of Russeks, for that store's collections. A large portion of the styles was presented last night on the Kate Smith evening hour over the NBC-TV network.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Establishment of a coordinated national blood program under the Office of Defense Mobilization was announced today by Charles E. Wilson, director of the agency.

Records in gas sales, operating revenues and gas reserves were recorded in 1951 by the Northern Natural Gas Company. The report released yesterday showed record operating revenues of $39,988,000 in 1951, against $32,786,000 in 1950.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Senator Arthur Wicks of Kingston, majority leader, made it clear today that Yonkers would not be allowed to tap the income from the Yonkers Raceway, a harness track, to help the city meet its financial obligation.

Six Massachusetts municipal housing authorities sold yesterday $7,700,000 of state-guaranteed housing bonds due from April 1, 1953, to April 1, 1992, at bids ranging in interest cost from 2.114 to 2.113 per cent.
Offerings of new public utility securities with a market value of more than $19,100,000 will be offered today to investors by underwriting syndicates.

Elmer F. Quinn, Democratic leader in the State Senate, and two other Democratic office-holders from Manhattan urged Mayor Impellitteri and other members of the Board of Estimate, in a letter yesterday, to oppose an increased transit fare and continuation of the 3 per cent sales tax.

An increase last week of 1,022,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 142,787,000 barrels, compared with 141,765,000 a week earlier and 138,582,000 a year ago.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 5 -- Eyewitnesses to the crash of an American Airlines plane here last Jan. 22 that took the lives of twenty-three passengers and crew members and seven residents in their homes appeared bfore the Civil Aeronautics Board's investigating panel today but shed little, if any, new light on the accident.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Small manufacturing companies suffering from cutbacks in materials will have a high priority rating when the National Production Authority begins distributing the recent "windfall" of about 30,000,000 pounds of aluminum and 20,000,000 to 25,000,000 pounds of copper, officials said today.
ATHENS, March 5 (AP) -- Strong pressure from various quarters was brought today on the Government of Premier Plastiras to suspend the executions of eight persons condemned as Red spies.
LONDON, March 6 -- This week Monday morning was bluer than usual for London's commuters. They had to pay 20 per cent more to ride to work.
BOSTON, March 5 -- Princeton assured itself of at least a third-place tie in the Pentagonal League by defeating Harvard, 4 -- 1, at the Arena tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The Defense Department reported today that United States casualties in Korea totaled 106,298 through last Friday, an increase of 306 over the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The Defense Department made public today the names of 144 United States fighting men for whom United Nations negotiators have asked an accounting from the Communists. The Army had seven other names that could not be checked immediately.
Spring accessories provided as much interest as the fashions in Bloomingdale's presentation of costumes from the Green Room yesterday.
Aid given to 177 agencies that operated 325 health and welfare programs last year was recounted yesterday in the thirty-first annual report of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

The state Legislature is taking favorable action on Governor Dewey's recommendation that the salaries of judges in the State Court of Appeals be increased from $28,000 to $32,500. As $28,000 is not an insignificant salary in government, one can assume that both the Governor and the Legislature believe the Court of Appeals to be a peculiarly demanding job requiring men of high caliber; also that they believe $28,000 is no longer adequate compensation.

In one of the most critical pairings of the international chess master' tournament, Miguel Najdorf of Argentina played a careful game with Samuel Reshevsky of New York which resulted in a draw after twenty-five moves, according to a report from Havana yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 5 -- A recommendation of the Greenwich High School Student Council that smoking be permitted before and after school and also during the lunch hour in a limited area near the school building was rejected last night by the Greenwich Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A subcommittee agreed today to seek what would amount to a Senate vote of confidence in its investigation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's fitness to hold his present office.

Many people feel that getting a haircut is an unpleasant chore, particularly if they have to wait while Tony, or one of his counterparts, takes care of other customers. A. N. Spanel, founder of the International Latex Corporation, Dover, Del., is no exception.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Surplus labor areas marked for special consideration in the placing of Government contracts will not get any price differential for the present.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, praised Britain today for her efforts to defeat communism in Malaya by "imaginative and progressive" political and economic guidance as well as by military action.

LONDON, March 5 -- At their first plenary session since the Lisbon meeting of the Atlantic powers, the North Atlantic Council Deputies considered today the appointment of a secretary general for the treaty organization.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Senate, by a strictly party vote of 32 to 23, passed and sent to the Assembly today a bill that would bar special elections to choose Mayors and Presidents of City Councils in the state's cities.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, formally gave the House of Representatives the information today that President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill, at their recent conference, made no commitments to send United States troops anywhere.
The stock market had a timid rise yesterday. Profit-taking in the afternoon produced a shading in values, leaving the composite index of THE NEW YORK TIMES up only 0.68 point.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Leo V. Lanning, State Veterans Affairs Director, reported today that many New York State veterans and members of their families were failing to take advantage of state tax exemptions provided for real property purchased with their retirement pay or other "eligible funds."

A new military radar that charts a 60,000-foot air flight, pinpoints a four-foot kite seventy miles away and prints the results for immediate or later use -- a device that some day may be used for civilian safety in the air -- was described here yesterday at the convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

The Best Curtain Company bought the seven-story store and loft building at 146-48 West Twenty-eighth Street from Robert, Dave and Melvin Zuckerman and will occupy 15,000 square feet and the store for a factory outlet. Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., was the broker.
Capt. Andrew Anderson, a mariner who restricts himself to three-and-a-half hours sleep a day while at sea, has been appointed master of the Isbrandtsen Company freighter Flying Cloud.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A Government official said today that steel should be "relatively free" of allocation controls in nine to ten months. Frank T. McCue, assistant to the director of the National Production Authority's iron and steel division, made the forecast at a hearing of a House Small Business subcommittee.

CINCINNATI, March 5 (AP) -- John M. Hancock of New York resigned today as director of the Kroger Company. Mr. Hancock was named last week in a Federal anti-trust suit charging he held dual directorships in competing food companies. The other is the Jewel Tea Company.

CINCINNATI, March 5 -- A report on a long-range study shedding light on the manner in which certain chemicals produce cancer, offering the prospect for the synthesis some day of chemicals with anti-cancer action, was presented here today at the closing session of the National Cancer Conference.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock "clarified" yesterday his ruling on Monday that would have permitted seven of the sixteen secondary Communist leaders to travel the country during their trial for conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government.

The three-story garden type apartment house at 3 Fox Lane in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Walter L. Rothschild to the 3 Fox Lane Realty Corporation represented by Allan Berlam, attorney. Farber-Wittman, Inc., was the broker.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 -- John Wayne, in addition to his one-picture-a-year, straight salary contract with Warner Brothers, has just concluded a separate deal with the studio whereby he and Robert Fellows will produce one additional film a year.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Federal Judge Walter L. LaBuy has withheld decision pending filing of briefs in the Government's civil anti-trust suit against the huge du Pont industrial empire.
Although wool and cotton were lower, most commodity futures prices rose yesterday in the New York market.

BERLIN, March 5 -- East Germany completed early today another step in its methodical plan to reduce its strategic dependency upon West Germany and West Berlin when it shut off all deliveries of electricity to the Western sectors of this city.

GENEVA, March 5 -- Andre Philip, French Socialist, told the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe today that the world should cease banking on another great depression in the United States in formulating economic policies.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Assembly today gave initial approval to a proposed constitutional amendment that would strip the Legislature of its power to authorize construction of stream-regulating projects in the 2,400,000-acre Adirondack forest preserve.

River Edge House, a thirteen-story apartment building for seventy-five families on plot 102 by 68 feet at 33 East End Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-first Street, has been purchased by Jacob Glass Sons, operators, for cash over mortgages amounting to $775,000 in a deal negotiated by Abbott Adams, Inc., brokers.
EAST ORANGE, March 5 -- Mayor Charles H. Martens, whose thirty-four consecutive years in office constitute a national record for mayors, announced today that he would not run for another term.
ACCRA, Gold Coast, March 5 -- Kwame Nkrumah, African politician who left prison in February, 1951, to lead the Gold Coast's first elected government, today became the country's first Prime Minister.
TOKYO, Thursday, March 6 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,180, for Wednesday's operations:
ALBANY, March 5 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts:

MANILA, March 5 -- Filipino Senators broke the thirty-five-day political logjam that all but paralyzed legislation in the upper chamber by electing Quintin Paredes, former Resident Commissioner to Washington as Senate President.
Three prison guards on trial in Bronx County were found guilty yesterday of accepting bribes from a prisoner so that they would "forget" that the inmate has narcotics in his possession.

Paramount's "A Place in the Sun," directed and produced by George Stevens from a scenario by Michael Wilson and Harry Brown based on Theodore Dreiser's novel "An American Tragedy," was voted the best film of 1951 in the twenty-ninth annual poll of film critics of the nation's newspapers, magazines, syndicates, wire services and radio stations conducted by The Film Play Daily, trade publication.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Grain futures generally showed a strong undertone although buyers were still cautious in following the bulges, which also met considerable profit taking. Advances were paced by corn which was decidedly strong, traders evidently accepting the reports that the movement of wet corn was nearing an end at full face value.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Ellis Arnall, in his first official appearance since his appointment as director of the Office of Price Stabilization, today labeled those seeking decontrol of prices "just short-sighted, not subversive."
Senator Austin Erwin, Republican, and Assemblyman Anthony J. Travia, Democrat, are sponsoring three bills in the New York Legislature to regulate political activity by labor unions.

The extension of the North Atlantic alliance to the shores of the Aegean and Black Seas has been dramatically demonstrated by the visit of General Eisenhower to Turkey and Greece. These two countries had already been welcomed to the alliance of free Western nations at Lisbon; General Eisenhower's visit underscores the importance which the other allies attach to them as bulwarks of their right flank.
As a frequent user of the Sixty-ninth Street Ferry, running between Staten Island and Brooklyn, I feel somewhat obligated to point out a potential source of danger and tragedy.

Shlomo Z. Shragai, the first elected Israeli Mayor of Jerusalem, received yesterday on his arrival at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, an ovation from representatives of the city and from delegates of rabbinic and Jewish communal organizations.

Unable in two recent meetings to agree on a proposal to join a national labor union, thhe United States Customs Inspectors Association of the Port of New York has decided to take an individual poll of its membership, it became known yesterday.

One National Amateur Athletic Union champion won and another lost in the Eastern Golden Gloves amateur boxing championships that drew 7,454 spectators to Madison Square Garden last night. The event was a welfare promotion of The Daily News.
ATHENS, March 5 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower received warm welcomes in Salonika and Athens today upon his arrival in Greece from Turkey.

DES MOINES, March 5 -- Alfred W. Lawson of Detroit, 82-year-old founder of the Des Moines University of Lawsonomy, described dealings in war surplus machinery by the "school" as legitimate today. He said that criticism in Des Moines had caused Federal inquiries into the resale of the machinery and how the institution obtained exemption from Federal taxes as an educational institution.

It is costing at least 13.9 cents to provide the city-run subway and bus service for which the city charges a basic dime fare and for which the average rider in fact pays 9.5 cents under current fare set-ups. For the year starting July 1, the cost is due to climb above 15 cents.

The United States in 1951 more than tripled the amount of merchant tonnage on order or under construction in its shipyards, with 1,251,190 gross tons listed in January of this year, compared to 406,070 tons in January, 1951.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- As Bill Dickey's Colonels polished off Frankie Crosetti's Crows by 3 -- 2 today for the second successive afternoon in the Yankees' intracamp series, one item struck Manager Casey Stengel quite forcibly. His pitchers are still ahead of the hitters.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- An amendment to the Housing Act of 1949 designed to encourage slum clearance everywhere -- particularly in New York -- was introduced today by Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York.

JERSEY CITY, March 5 -- In an attempt to ease one of the worst traffic bottlenecks in New Jersey, the Tonnele Avenue traffic circle here will be remodeled, it was announced today by Ransford J. Abbott, State Highway Commissioner. Bids for the improvement, to cost in excess of $100,000, will be taken next Tuesday at the highway department offices in Trenton.
LONDON, March 5 -- The vast flocks of starlings that fly into Trafalgar Square and the West End of this city every day at sundown to roost have been outlawed by Westminster City Council.

Two masked and armed robbers stole $25,000 from a Brooklyn housing development office yesterday afternoon in a hold-up that took less than five minutes, including a pause to aid a woman who had fainted.

ALTHOUGH the sportsmen who have been fighting to preserve the Beaverkill and Willowemoc, two of the finest trout streams in the East, have won a victory in the Assembly, there will be little in the nature of a celebration until the Senate has followed the lead of the lower house.
A wealth of detail enriched Sally Milgrim's spring custom order presentation viewed yesterday at this shop. Applique, trapunto, cutwork and insets of shell tucking embellished pure silks and wools.

MADRID, March 5 -- A group of Roman Catholic youngsters forced their way into a Protestant chapel in Seville last Monday night, beat up the pastor and attempted to set fire to copies of the Bible and hymn books.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Assembly Committee on Education reported out favorably today a bill designed to ameliorate the criticism that has resulted from the 1950 law exempting the children of Christian Scientists from classes in hygiene and health that conflict with religious beliefs.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Truman declared today that he was making every effort to hasten the time when the Czechoslovak people would again be free.

A small collection of new furniture, some pieces of which look as if they had been engineered rather than designed, are displayed by Philip Enfield in his new showroom at 50 East Fifty-third Street. The pieces are available through decorators.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Evidence was presented today that clients of the New York law firm of Newbold Morris, director of President Truman's inquiry into corruption in the Government, had engaged extensively in transporting cargoes of oil and other important supplies to and between Iron Curtain countries.
The current measles epidemic will continue through the spring, with an increase in the number of cases, Dr. John F. Mahoney, Commissoner of the Health Department, predicted yesterday.
DETROIT, March 5 (AP) -- Jake La Motta, former middleweight champion, and his one-time employe, Eugene Hairston, battled to a draw in a sizzling ten-round slugfest before 10,039 fans tonight.

Among the many causes for automobile accidents one of the most common is failure to signal turns. Not all cars are equipped with mechanical directional signals, and drivers without them often consider it an unnecessary extravagance to inform other motorists of their intentions.
Representatives of vocational school teachers and city civil service workers appeared at City Hall yesterday to resume their appeals for wage increases.

Word that Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, had been designated by a tailor's organization as one of the ten best-dressed men in America came as a shock yesterday -- to the designee as well as his associates. Some of the latter suggested that the self-conscious president accept this as "a tribute to the clothing manufacturers with shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange."

DURHAM, N. H., March 5 -- The nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as a man "sought out" as best fitted for the Presidency was advocated tonight by Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Ford Foundation, in an address at the University of New Hampshire.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The principal argument to be used in an attempt to persuade Mayor Impellitteri to agree to a Republican plan for transferring New York's rapid transit system to an independent authority is that any resulting fare increase would be less than the rise that would be required under continued city operation.

This newspaper published yesterday an interesting and informative array of figures and charts assembled by Will Lissner of THE TIMES staff, which added up, in his words, to the conclusion that "the United States has undergone a social revolution in the last four decades, and particularly since the Thirties."

The last-minute distribution of gifts for charity or philanthropies by large companies, often without time for adequate study of the causes or the institutions being aided, has led many companies to consider establishing their own gift foundations operated as a separate unit, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- The Commerce Clearing House reported today that tax collections by states increased 108 per cent in the last ten years -- but only 15 per cent in terms of 1941 dollars. Tax collections by the forty-eight states in 1951 totaled $10,316,077,405.

VIENNA, March 5 -- The Austrian Parliament reached a compromise today over whether Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, former Fascist leader, should be permitted to regain his extensive properties under the restitution law, designed to compensate victims of nazism.

Tighter dollar exchange supply in Brazil, reflected in a current slowing down of payments for imports from the United States, indicates at least temporary economic difficulties for the South American country, members of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau learned yesterday in a round-table meeting in the Statler Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- Vice Admiral C. W. Fox, chief of naval materiel, said today that the use of a single supply catalogue by all the military services would result in heavy savings.

A token sale of new 3-cent stamps commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of the American Automobile Association was carried on here yesterday under a somber sky while a keen March wind whipped against vender and purchaser.

ALBANY, March 5 -- A series of bipartisan bills creating additional judgeships in New York City to be divided between the two major parties have been quietly killed in legislative committtees at the direction of Governor Dewey with the warm approval of Mayor Impellitteri.

FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT was the author of some galvanically controversial pieces that appeared in Collier's when William L. Chenery was head man there and Mr. Roosevelt was President of the United States. Another contributor was Winston Churchill, who once wrote and rewrote a $1,500 article about the King of Spain five times before all hands were pleased -- thus making his fee for that particular effort $300 a draft, still considered fair pay.
LONDON, March 5 -- Balancing of books in advance of next Tuesday's budget was the main cause of further moderate recovery on the stock markets here today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- W. A. (Dub) Pagan of West Palm Beach advanced into the semi-finals of the South Florida golf championship today with a 5-and-4 victory over George Rasmussen of Palm Beach.

The producers of "Women of Twilight," the British drama that opened Monday night at the Plymouth Theatre, are seeking $150,000 in damages from the Scenic Artists Union, Local 829, which has been picketing the attraction.

NEW HAVEN, March 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and his supporters staged a show of political strength here tonight in territory supposedly held in trust for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower by a friendly Republican state administration.

The new isonicotinic acid compounds still represent an unknown quantity in the treatment of cheronic tuberculosis, it was emphasized here last night before a gathering of 200 of the city's leading tuberculosis specialists.

Rejection of the Universal Military Training Bill by the House of Representatives is a heavy blow to the long-range security of the United States. While the Administration fought hard for the measure it was not -- and should not have been -- a party matter. On the final tally 155 Republicans lined up with eighty-one Democrats to recommit the bill, against the 131 Democrats, only thirty Republicans and one Independent who tried to save it.

The Administration's $10,500,000,000 foreign aid program for the coming fiscal year may be too great a burden for American economy to bear and may do more harm than good by depreciating the value of the dollar and creating a spirit of dependency among our allies, John G. Forrest, Business and Financial Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday.

BOSTON, March 5 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers scored 35 points in the third quarter tonight and then fought off a Baltimore rally to edge the Bullets, 88 -- 82, in a National Basketball Association game.

Testifying in the anti-trust investment banking trial at Federal Court here, Harold L. Stuart, Chicago financier, said yesterday that he called in 1939 for a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission to require a Wisconsin company to sell its bonds through competitive bidding because the utility's parent company did not advise him of the impending borrowing.
ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. L, March 5 -- A 30-year-old mother, who believed that she was mentally unbalanced, garroted her three children in her bedroom today and then hanged herself in the attic.

Henry Traeger, M. D., gave a debut piano recital last night in Town Hall, and posed a few critical problems thereby. What standards to adopt? Dr. Traeger, who is on the staff of Beth Israel hospital in Boston, plays the piano very well -- for a non-professional.

The pseudonymous S. Traven, author of such novels as "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre" and "The Bridge in the Jungle," has a new novel on Knopf's list for April 18. In "The Rebellion of the Hanged," the mysterious author, whose true name and whereabouts somewhere in Mexico are unknown to his publisher, tells a story about the oppressed workers in a mahogany camp in tropical Mexico at the outset of the Mexican Revolution.

BUENOS AIRES, March 5 -- After listening to a twenty-seven minute address by President Juan D. Peron tonight on how Argentina's 1952 economic plan is to be fulfilled, the business and financial community was still in the dark as to what direct steps would be taken to stem the tide of inflation and to restore the nation's credit in international trade.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax scandals voted unanimously today to call Joseph D. Nunan Jr., former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and three other New Yorkers, once in high tax posts, for questioning behind closed doors.
Prices of active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 15 to 24 points yesterday.

When the Grand Street Settlement holds its seventh annual all-day bazaar Sunday, one of the most popular features will be the international cafe. Past success makes this prediction quite certain, since the chefs who have presided over the kitchen in other years will be in charge again.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., March 5 (AP) -- The Endicott-Johnson Shoe Company announced today a lay-off system under which 1,100 employes will work alternate weeks and receive state unemployment insurance benefits for each "layoff." The system will go into effect on Monday at two plants.

In a letter published on Feb. 25 in THE NEW YORK TIMES Gridley Adams, in referring to what I believe is the Covenant of Human Rights, made some broad and sweeping statements which are completely erroneous. He said:

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- An indignant group of domestic producers of aluminum greeted Manly Fleischmann, Administrator of the Defense Production Administration, and his aides today when they met the Government men to discuss plans for increasing aluminum supplies.

Well known women are helping to further the success of the performance of "One Bright Day" on the night of March 21 at the Royale Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., March 5 -- A 13-year-old schoolboy was held for the grand jury on a first-degree murder charge tonight in the killing of Lyde Kitchner, 12, who was found strangled on Nov. 29 in a wooded area near her home on Hauppauge Road, Smithtown Branch. He was taken to the Suffolk County jail in Riverhead.

NAPLES, Italy, March 5 -- Exercise Grand Slam, which for the last nine days and eight nights, kept more than 200 United States, British, French and Italian warships and hundreds of aircraft engaged in a realistic simulated war designed to test their ability to cooperate effectively against a common enemy, ended today.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 5 (UP) -- Commonwealth Court ruled today that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had the right to withdraw from Pennsylvania's April 22 Presidential preference primary.

An alert truck driver caused the capture yesterday of two hold-up suspects after they had fled a lower Manhattan office building with loot totaling $5,000 in cash and jewelry from employes of a wire company.

TORONTO, March 5 (UP) -- Sid Smith and Tod Sloan regained their scoring magic tonight to keep the Toronto Maple Leafs in contention for second place in the National Hockey League with a 6-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens before 14,052 fans.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, confirmed today that he had been the one who had cleared Oliver Edmund Clubb of being a security risk, overruling the State Department's Loyalty and Security Board which had found against the veteran career diplomat.

Special Sessions Justice Frank Oliver announced yesterday that he would retire April 6, his seventieth birthday, with "goodwill and good wishes to all and with the deepest gratitude to my native city of New York."

TOKYO, Thursday, March 6 (AP) -- Relief and repair crews on skis and horse-drawn sleds struggled through driving snows yesterday to restore communications and aid victims of northern Japan's heaviest earthquake in half a century.

LONDON, March 5 -- Britain's rearmament program, prepared by the recent Labor Government and adopted by Prime Minister Churchill and his Conservatives, received an overwhelming endorsement in the House of Commons tonight after a debate only slightly less bitter than the one last week on foreign affairs.

Retail dry goods sales this spring will fall below levels of last year because of reduced defense spending and continued slack consumer demand, members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association's executive committee were told yesterday.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 5 (UP) -- First Repeater, owned by Jane Greer, film actress, went out on the pace today and stayed there to score a two-length victory in the $15,000 added Christopher J. Fitzgerald Handicap at Santa Anita.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation increased its sales last year to $176,625,380 from the 1950 volume of $135,662,863, lifting the pre-tax net to $14,958,216 from $13,628,564.

Stockholders in the nation's second-largest automobile manufacturing concern, the Chrysler Corporation, are being asked to grant options on 400,000 shares of the company's common stock to fifteen salaried officers and key employes. Action on the proposal is scheduled for the annual meeting to be held in Detroit on April 15.
PARIS, March 5 -- Antoine Pinay, Minister of Transport and Independent party leader, will ask the French National Assembly tomorrow to endorse him as Premier. The odds apparently were against him.

Reference is hereby made to your recent editorial regarding the primaries in New Hampshire. In that editorial you allege that it is in the interest of democracy and the welfare of the country that there be a change of Administration.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Jack Burke Jr., the Texan who has won the last three Professional Golfers Association tournaments, is favored in the $10,000 St. Petersburg open which starts tomorrow. A field of 182 will begin play in the seventy-two-hole event at 7 A. M. (E. S. T.), and after two days the field will be cut to the top sixty.

Nine five-story buildings with 162 apartments and nine stores at 1353-61 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, have been sold by Sam W. Teichman and others to the Bowilk Realty Corporation. The property, which has a total assessed valuation of $342,000, was sold subject to a mortgage of $124,000, and a purchase money mortgage of $75,000 was executed at the closing.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senator Ernest W. McFarland of Arizona, Democratic leader in the Senate, said today that he might be willing to clear the Universal Military Training Bill for consideration despite its setback yesterday in the House of Representatives.

GUATEMALA, March 5 -- The sale of the United Fruit Company's Tiquisate plantations at public auction was postponed today for a week at the request of the lawyer representing the farm workers' union, which had put in a legal claim against the property for $650,000 in wages that it contended was due the workers.

Morris Schilt, 55-year-old supervisor of the men's college department in the clothing store of Finchley, Inc., at 564 Fifth Avenue, gave up a pay rise of $25 a week and promotion to general manager to go back to his former position.

Three Washington Heights boys who accidentally had locked themselves in a large windowless closet in the ruins of a burned-out parochial school were freed by the police yesterday after twenty-five hours Without food, heat or water, and with no light except the brief flickering of three small candles. They were reported in good physical condition, but received standard treatment for shock.

In assaying the accomplishments of the recent NATO conference in Lisbon your learned correspondent Anne O'Hare McCormick pronounced it to be "the most fruitful international conference since the war." Its sessions "went smoothly because the participants were learning to work together and beginning to understand the infinitely complex questions they have to deal with."

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 5 -- Leo Durocher today announced his starting line-up for the first of the exhibition games against the Indians at Tucson next Saturday, and, in addition to giving the first authentic indication of his plans for the championship season, provided an example of what the departure of Eddie Stanky means in the Giants' scheme of things.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Increasing concern is being expressed in American quarters over a series of events in Greece, which, it is feared, may tend to disrupt the unity and morale of the Greek people and Greece's ten-division Army, which has just been brought into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 6 -- John S. Dole, chairman of the Fairfield County Traffic Council, which represents about a dozen organizations, announced tonight that the council's executive board would meet on Sunday in Westport to consider the New England Thruway report.
A dinner dance to celebrate the fifty-fourth anniversary of the North Carolina Society in New York will be held this evening in the grand ballroom of the Plaza.

At Metropolitan Hospital, on Welfare Island, we are in need of volunteers. Metropolitan is a general city hospital with about 1,100 beds. It is situated on the northern end of the island, a two-minute ferry ride from East Seventy-eighth Street.

The Kremlin can stop putting out ntermittent nonsense about "American wage slaves starving while stockholders grow gloated on dividends.'' Yesterday the Eastman Kodak Company paid out about $20,000,000 -- not rubles -- to about 49,000 employes in the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee decided today not to press for floor action on the Universal Military Training bill it had reported to the Senate. The House on Tuesday voted, 236 to 162, to shelve a companion bill for this session.

ROME, March 6 -- Vatican authorities are considering a plan to re-create a small papal merchant marine. If the plan is approved, the papal flag may again fly within this year on the high seas, from which it disappeared eighty-two years ago when Italian troops wrested what remained of the pontifical states from the papacy.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- An advisory panel was named today to assist the Congressional Atomic Energy Committee in connection with atomic plant expansion Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut and committee chairman, announced that Lewis L. Strauss, former Atomic Energy Commission member, would head the panel.

OTTAWA, March 6 -- The announcement that Britain has been building atomic weapons for some time will make a far greater impression on the men in the Kremlin than the phantom divisions paraded in Lisbon, George Drew, Opposition leader, told the House of Commons today when he moved a vote of no confidence in the Government.
Election of Col. Edward F. Brown and Glenn Gundell as vice presidents of the National Dairy Products Corporation was announced by L. A. Van Bomel, president, following a board meeting here yesterday.

The Inter-Diocesan Committee on Legislation, representing the six Episcopal Dioceses in the State of New York; at its meeting in Albany on Jan. 29 took action favoring the bill to grant to children's courts jurisdiction over children needing psychiatric care.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Rising quotations for onions brought a warning to the industry from the Office of Price Stabilization today that the O. P. S. stands ready to impose price ceilings if necessary to halt any further price advances. A regulation fixing a ceiling price of $3.70 for the standard fifty pound sack of onions, f.o.b. Laredo, Tex., has been drawn up, officials said.

The Northern Pacific Railway disclosed yesterday in its annual report for 1951 that it has fee title or mineral rights, including gas and oil, on 3,200,000 acres of land within the Williston Basin in North Dakota and Montana. The road explained that this acreage is on either side of its main line for fifty miles in North Dakota and sixty miles in Montana.

BOSTON, March 6 (AP) -- Dr. Robert E. Lincoln, sponsor of what he called a "new system of medicine," was asked today to resign from the Massachusetts Medical Society after that organization said its inquiry failed to support claims made on behalf of Dr. Lincoln's therapy.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A proposed expansion plan that would add 150,000 short tons to the supply of aluminum turned out by the industry received a cool reception today at a meeting of government and general industry experts held here by the Office of Defense Mobilization.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Representative Lindley Beckworth, Democrat of Texas, asked Price Director Ellis Arnall today to seek an understanding with Canadian officials not to raise Canadian newsprint prices without prior consultation with United States officials.

CAIRO, March 6 -- The Ministry of Education is drafting a law that will prohibit student political activity and membership of students in political organizations, the newspaper Al Zaman reported today.
Sugar prices broke into new high ground for the season yesterday and provided the feature of futures trading in New York commodity markets.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The United States 4,946 national banks had deposits of $94,000,000,000 at the end of the last year, the Government reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Eight more areas, including New York, are ready for referral to Government purchasing officers with instructions to give them special consideration in placing contracts.

HONG KONG, March 6 -- Red China's war on "law-breaking" merchants, shopkeepers and industrialists, which began as a campaign to remold their "decadent bourgeois thought" is now reported to have taken on the aspect of a new terror in which the state is collecting large sums of extra revenue from harassed middle-class groups.

BUENOS AIRES, March 6 -- Pointing out that 95 per cent of the hard currencies earned by Argentina is derived from the export of their production, the Confederaciones Rurales Argentinas (Argentine Farmer's Confederation) has asked President Juan Peron for an exhaustive survey of agricultural production costs and revision of prices for their products.

PARIS, March 6 -- Expert observers here doubt that any new government can avoid devaluation of the French currency. One reason for the deficit with the European Payments Union is the high price level in France, which has hampered exports.

A desperate prison break attempt, in which a Department of Correction guard and a courtroom officer were marked for death and General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen might have been a victim, was forestalled last Monday in the City Prison.

The treatment of women prisoners in New York State will be set back fifty years if a bill now before the State Assembly is permitted to pass. This bill would allow the Commissioner of Correction to transfer women prisoners from Westfield State Farm at Bedford Hills, the state's only prison for women, to the Albion State Training School for mental defectives.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 6 -- A $65,000,000 privately financed expansion program for the Kaiser Steel Corporation was announced today by Henry J. Kaiser, the president.

The stock market lost its forward momentum yesterday. The timidity of the Wednesday rally after the sharp recovery of Tuesday caused a lightening of demand which left the composite rate only 0.03 point higher. Stocks that declined outnumbered those with increases.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 6 -- Harold Lorentson, 13 years old, of 290 Jericho Turnpike, Smithtown Branch, was placed in a "civil section" of the Suffolk County jail here this morning after the police charged that he had strangled a 12-year-old schoolgirl classmate, Lyde Kitchner, on Nov. 29 near her home at Smithtown Branch.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Truman urged Congress in a special message today to authorize $7,900,000,000 for weapons and materials in the coming fiscal year to strengthen other nations in their fight against "plans of the Soviet rulers to dominate the world."

THIS is "reservation" time for those planning opening day or ice-out excursions, and reports from a number of New York and New England fishing resorts indicate that bookings are arriving earlier than usual and that a "first-come-first-served" policy will be followed.

Princeton's polo team fought off a gallant Stanford University trio last night to gain the final round of the national intercollegiate indoor championship tournament at Squadron A Armory. A finalist last year, Princeton eliminated the favored West Coast trio by 13 -- 9.

The principles of the Golden Rule under which the J. C. Penney Company began its business fifty years ago has paid off handsomely. Starting operations under the name of "Golden Rule Stores" with first-year sales of $28,000, the nation-wide department store chain's business for the first time last year passed the billion-dollar mark.

Record sales of $211,928,000 last year, up 24.3 per cent over the 1950 volume of $170,455,000, were reported by the National Cash Register Company. Net income, however, was down 3.8 per cent, largely as a result of a 78 per cent rise in taxes, Stanley C. Allyn, president, told stockholders yesterday.

LACONIA, N. H., March 6 -- Despite all his experience as a campaigner, Senator Taft still remains one of the worst baby-kissers in contemporary American politics. After his first speech in Daniel Webster's home town of Franklin, N. H., this morning, somebody handed the Senator what appeared to be a male-type infant in a green and red snow suit.
Luncheon meetings are being held in the Empire Room of the Woldorf-Astoria by the committee for the annual spring dinner dance for Madison House. The dance will be held on March 29 in the Biltmore.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- Miss Mary Lena Faulk, the defending champion, defeated Miss Marjorie Lindsay, the medalist and a United States Curtis Cup player from Decatur, Ill., in the feature quarter-final match of the Florida East Coast women's golf tournament today. The Thomasville (Ga.) entrant won, 3 and 2.
PARIS, March 6 -- Antoine Pinay, business man and former Minister of Transport, won endorsement as Premier by a vote of 324 to 206 today to the surprise of the National Assembly.

The American Institute of Marine Underwriters presented a gold medal and citation yesterday to Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen for his courageous but futile efforts to save the Isbrandtsen Company freighter Flying Enterprise in January.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6 -- The most intensive Giant batting drill since training camp opened ended today under a broiling sun with Manager Leo Durocher singing the praises of Davey Williams, the Dallas youth who will be stationed at second base when the exhibition campaign against the Indians gets under way Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -The Army said today that someone "believed to be a Soviet agent" had stolen the diary of a United States general and the Communists were using excerpts to "prove" that the United States was plotting World War III.
Bonnie put air cargo employes of Pan American World Airways at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, in two dithers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended March 1 totaled 755,624 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 72,256 cars or 10.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 30,237 cars or 3.8 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 181,175 cars or 31.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The John Ericsson Society will hold its annual Monitor dinner dance this evening in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza. The society, composed of Swedish-American residents of New York, is named for the inventor and designer of the gunboat Monitor, and the fete will celebrate the anniversary of its battle with the Merrimac on March 9, 1862.

Today's new film is "Something to Live For," a Paramount drama featuring Ray Milland, Joan Fontaine and Teresa Wright, at the Normandie. George Stevens directed and produced from a scenario written by Dwight Taylor. Richard Darr.

Sales finance companies entered the money market as heavy borrowers during the last week and accounted for another sharp increase in business loans by New York City banks. It was the fifth consecutive week during which borrowings by business and industry showed a rise, the total being enlarged by $39,000,000 to an outstanding figure of $7,929,000,000.

The city went overboard by $2,600,000 last year in its ferryboat operation, and municipal officials are considering the advisability of doubling the 5-cent fare on the run between the Battery and Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- One of the longest Congressional cross- examinations on record neared its end today in the ninth day of Prof. Owen Lattimore's appearance before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

The freshness of a painter's approach to textile design is demonstrated in a collection of eight fabrics that Macy's will introduce on Monday. The project, the result of a collaboration between Associated American Artists and Riverdale Manufacturing Company, has a central theme: "Pioneer Pathways."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6 -- Prof. William E. Doering, a member of the Columbia University faculty since 1943, has been named Professor of Organic Chemistry at Yale University, Edgar S. Furniss, provost of the university, announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, was invited today by the House Rules Committee to introduce a resolution "censuring" two Supreme Court justices for testifying on behalf of Alger Hiss.
PARIS, March 6 -- France's crises have failed as yet to uncover a reliable majority but they are proving prolific in the discoveries of new and able men.

Held back because of his adjourned tenth-round game, Miguel Najdorf of Argentina was passed yesterday by Erich Eliskases, also of Argentina, and Nicolas Rossolimo of France in the international chess masters tourney, according to a report from Havana.

NAVAL AIR STATION, Jacksonville, Fla., March 6 -- A marked improvement in anti-submarine tactics and techniques has been demonstrated so far in Convex III -- the Navy's coastal convoy exercise, which started on Feb. 27 and will continue until March 20.

The 1952 Soviet budget military appropriation will exceed even the level of 1940, before Hitler's attack on the Soviet Union. The appropriation is almost exactly twice the corresponding 1940 expenditures of 56,800,000,000 rubles and exceeds even the 108,400,000,000 rubles spent for military purposes during 1942, the first full calendar year of Soviet praticipation in World War II.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- The "good-luck" putter that launched Jack Burke Jr. on golf's keenest current winning streak helped him again today as he fired a 66 to tie for the first-round lead in the $10,000 St. Petersburg open.

The National Citizens Committee for Eisenhower, a political group backing General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for President, canceled a series of political broadcasts over the National Broadcasting Company television network yesterday because of a lack of funds to pay the time charges.

BERLIN, N. H., March 6 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio barnstormed into snowy New Hampshire today to carry his fight for the Republican Presidential nomination into the small towns of the Granite State.
DETROIT, March 6 (UP) -- Marty Pavelich scored in the last period to give the Detroit Red Wings a 2-to-1 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight in a game that ended in confusion.

The thing that makes Friday the best day of the week -- which it is -- is not Friday itself but the promise of Saturday. It makes little difference what the weather is like on Friday; today will be a fine day no matter what the sun decides to do.
LACONIA, N. H., March 6 -- The boldest Taft supporter in the New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign is Senator Robert A. Taft himself.
Two developments brought the New York Curb Exchange into the news yesterday.

A history of the decorating style periods in this country from the latter part of the eighteenth century is traced in the new spring exhibition that opens today in the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street.

A 27-year-old Polish woman pronounced herself completely cured yesterday by American physicians of a severe limp and a skin infection caused by Nazi "human guinea pig" experiments practiced on her about ten years ago.
The State of Tennessee announced yesterday that it would receive bids April 3 on $5,000,000 of improvement bonds.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Acting with unusual dispatch, the Assembly Ways and Means Committee approved unanimously today the amendments to the Long Island Transit Authority Law that Governor Dewey requested in a special message sent to the Legislature yesterday.

Succulent brown-crusted fritters are worthy of the housewife's consideration in view of reduced prices of fats and oils and seasonally low egg prices. To vary Lenten menus or brighten any meal during windy March, they're an answer to the left-over problem -- whether they be fruit, vegetable, meat or fish fritters.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress on the Mutual Security Program for the fiscal year to end June 30, 1953:

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 6 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ended today its three-day hearing into the crash of an American Airlines Convair here last Jan. 22 without arriving at any official cause of the accident, which took the lives of twenty-three passengers and crew members aboard the plane and seven residents of Elizabeth in their homes.

The Wage Stabilization Board approved yesterday a 2.5 per cent wage increase negotiated last fall for 340,000 workers in the electrical industry as the General Electric Company was offering its 210,000 employes still another increase of 1.36 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Although union shop elections are no longer required by the Taft-Hartley Law, a union that makes a union shop contract with an employer without filing non-Communist affidavits is still not entitled to any protection against the encroachments of a rival union.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 6 -- The Dodgers' plan to pitch Johnny Podres, 19 - year - old southpaw, against the Braves in Miami Saturday went awry today when it was revealed the boy had injured himself in yesterday's practice game.

ATHENS, March 6 -- The Greek Army's need for more tanks and artillery, especially anti-aircraft, and, above all, for more money was believed to have been the first among the topics discussed at the conference of the Greek General Staff this morning attended by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and members of his staff.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; "Elektra," Metropolitan Opera, 8:45; "Rigoletto," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30; Alfred Zega, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30; Harry Mayer, pianist, Greenwich House Music School. 8:30; Vivien Harvey, pianist Cooper Union Auditorium, 8:15; Concert of Chamber Music, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30: Jazz Concert. Central Plaza, 111 Second Avenue. 8:30: Jazz Concert, Stuyvesant Casino. 140 Second Avenue 8:30.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The Erwin-Travia bills to curb labor union contributions to political parties advanced further in the Legislature today as Louis Hollander, state president of the Congress of Industrial Organization, characterized the legislation as "machine politics at their worst."

A customs enspector, hot on the trail of contraband, such as opium or heroin, came up with eight pounds of pungent salami instead yesterday. Inspector William F. White was examining on Pier 97, North River, the baggage of John Bohling, an iron worker of 194-08 Thirty-seventh Avenue, Flushing, Queens, who had just returned from a visit to Germany aboard the Swedish American liner Gripsholm.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, turned against members of his own House committee today and took sides with the Justice Department in a dispute over Government records.

The Australian Government has decided to reinforce British strength in the Middle East by sending a regular jet-fighter wing to that area, it was announced here yesterday. The move means that there will be no regular Royal Australian Air Force fighter squadrons left in Australia for her own defense.

The last of the indoor season's regularly scheduled track and field meets here, the fifth annual Pioneer Club Games, will find every college and club in the metropolitan area represented tonight at the 369th Regiment Armory, Fifth Avenue and 142d Street. The opening event is listed for 7:30.

Sol A. Rosenblatt, the lawyer accused of using undue influence to be made residuary legatee in the contested will of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, a granddaughter of J. Pierpont Morgan, was shot in the left thigh early last evening as he was about to enter his Park Avenue apartment.

LONDON, March 6 -- Former Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee today called a meeting of the Labor party for next Tuesday to deal with the widened party breach caused by the Bevan faction's defiance of voting orders in the House of Commons.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd of La Jolla, Calif., reached the final of the women's singles in the Caribbean lawn tennis championships today by defeating the defender, Miss Althea Gibson of New York, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday and final prices were 9 to 25 points net lower than on Wednesday.

LONDON, March 6 -- About 38,000,000 ($106,400,000) will be spent in Britain on the construction of new fighting ships in the fiscal year beginning next month, the First Lord of the Admiralty, J. P. L. Thomas, estimated today.
