WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Two blueprints for bringing Federal expenditures and revenues more closely into line were issued today, one by the United States Chamber of Commerce and the other by Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois.

My attention has been called to a letter written by Paxton Blair, printed in THE NEW YORE TIMES March 3, in which he expresses his views upon the pending bill for the licensing of private nursery schools.

CHICAGO, March 6 (UP) -- The New York Rangers, fighting for a Stanley Cup play-off berth, beat the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 5 to 3, for undisputed fourth place in the National Hockey League, breaking a tie with the Boston Bruins.

Some would say that the trip-hammer piano concerto of Jean Rivier, which Monique de la Bruchollerie played for the first time here last night with the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, had no music in it. And in this they would be nearly right.
Operations of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation last year resulted in record sales and earnings before taxes, Theodore E. Mueller, president, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- The financial "plight" of Great Britain, France and a number of other countries will be the chief controlling factor in international trade this year, business me were told today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- Besides that of naming the centerfielder or group of centerfielders to replace Joe DiMaggio, Casey Stengel has another problem on his hands calling for a solution if the Yankees are to crash through for their fourth straight flag.

A strike that had tied up Army piers at Caven Point and Claremont Terminal in Jersey City and had reduced work at other docks in that city since Monday came to an end last night as the result of a compromise agreement.

Robert S. Bruns, vice president of the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, said yesterday the company desired to drop its suit to restrain the Town of Rye, N. Y., from enforcing its zoning ordinance against the building of a natural gas station.

ROME, March 6 -- The spring meeting of the Atlantic Passenger Conference, attended by representatives of eighteen of the worlds greatest steamship companies, decided today not to increase passenger fares on North Atlantic routes.

TOKYO, Friday, March 7 -- The Chinese Communist radio charged this morning that United States planes had extended germ warfare to Manchuria, dropping diseaseladen vermin at points along the Korean border and on Liaotung Peninsula.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Government of Yemen today denied reports that Wendell Phillips, head of an archeological expedition to Yemen, had been detained with his party and that the party had escaped under gunfire from the King of Yemen's guard.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., said yesterday that union men on the city's nine private lines had called for a strike tomorrow but that he had rejected the demand.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- A select House committee ended an eighteen-month investigation into the purity of foods today amid signs that it probably would recommend legislation to require pretesting of cosmetics and chemical foods.

A new television picture tube that is always in focus and needs no warm-up time after being turned on was discussed here yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

In his message to Congress, followed up by an address to the nation, President Truman has presented the most powerful and persuasive arguments yet made for continuing our military and economic aid to our allies and friends abroad as an essential part of a larger program to avert a new world war and preserve peace, to enhance our own national security, and to save our civilization.

President Truman reminded us recently that four years have passed since the Communists obliterated freedom in Czechoslovakia. And his declaration on March 5 that he was making every effort to hasten the time when the Czechoslovak people would again be free will be heartening to those Czechs who are trying to keep alive in their native land the democratic ideals to which their republic was devoted.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The Assembly unanimously passed today a bill that would extend the jurisdiction of the State Commission Against Discrimination to cover civil rights violations in such public places as hotels, restaurants, stores, hospitals and theatres.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Robert W. Dudley, Washington attorney who was indicted for perjury in a Reconstruction Finance Corporation influence case and who is involved in the current investigation of the Casey ship deal, figured in another attempt to purchase twenty Government ships and operate them under a foreign flag.

OSLO, Norway, March 6 -- A half-dozen Americans are among twenty-seven individual candidates for the 1952 Nobel Peace Prize announced today by the Norwegian Nobel Committee. Four institutions -- one of them American -- also were named.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 6 -- The Yugoslav Government's new minimum wage policy was published today. The highest minimum hourly wage for an industrial worker was fixed at 30 dinars, or 10 cents calculated at the official rate of exchange of 300 dinars to $1.

Sophie, designer for Saks Fifth Avenue, gave expression to her feeling for fashions, spring and summer 1952, yesterday afternoon in the Salon Moderne, her special domain. Hers is a broad point of view that encompasses many style moods.

A 23-year-old apprentice printer was booked early this morning on a burglary charge after his estranged girl friend, a blonde bathing suit model, turned over to the police yesterday afternoon jewelry that she said was worth $50,000.

Mayor Impellitteri announced last night that he would confer with Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore on city finances in Albany on Sunday if Mr. Moore's health permitted. The Mayor indicated the conference would not include Democratic legislative leaders.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Government tightened commercial export regulations on United States blood plasma today.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Government eased today building controls on housing, commercial, highway and school projects.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- Brandy Punch fooled the handicappers at Gulfstream Park today when he picked up 120 pounds and captured the Golden Beach Purse, giving the consistent 7-year-old son of Milkman his third purse in eight engagements this winter.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- The Soviet budget for 1952, providing 113,800,000,000 rubles (approximately $28,000,000,000 at the official exchange rate) for defense purposes -- slightly less than one-quarter of the total -- was presented tonight to the Supreme Soviet, which is the Soviet Union's Parliament.

This may come as a shock to marketing people who have prided themselves on their ability to advance with the times. Russell H. Colley of McKinsey Co., management consultants, says that industry's ability to move goods into consumers' hands is at least ten years behind its faculty to produce them.
ALBANY, March 6 -- The long fight against the state's ban on the manufacture and sale of precolored oleomargarine came to an end today as the Senate approved a repeal measure by a vote of 35 to 17.

SUSAN YORKE, a Vassar girl who spent her childhood in the Orient and who now lives in Buenos Aires, writes about love as if it were a mental illness. Whether her characters are unfortunate psychopaths who feel an emotion which can, by stretching the term, be called love, or whether they are just people who love psychopathically is an unanswerable question. What

ATHENS, March 6 -- The office of Premier Nicholas Plastiras issued a statement tonight expressing "surprise" over a Washington dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday reporting activities in Greece of a "Palace Guard." The statement declared it untrue that King Paul had sought to "rule" rather than be content to "reign."
Times Square was like a boulevard yesterday as the new ban on parking there went into effect to deprive motorists of 125 spaces formerly available for one-hour parking.

ST. LOUIS, March 6 -- James P. Finnegan, while Collector of Internal Revenue, visited a top official of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in Washington concerning an R. F. C. loan to American Lithofold Corporation and identified himself as representing the company, a witness testified in Federal Court today.

Stephen Kelen D'Oxylion, president of the month-old Corso Jewelry Corporation, jewelry manufacturers at 15 West Forty-seventh Street, was arrested last night on a charge of receiving, part of $30,000 in gems allegedly stolen from a neighboring jeweler.
Following is the text of President Truman's radio and television appeal to the nation for the Mutual Security Program, as transcribed last night by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Butter prices, which were slashed earlier in the week by chain stores, have been cut 8 cents a pound by most independent dealers, bringing the city-wide average to 89 cents a pound. The City Department of Markets predicted yesterday further declines over the week-end. It also noted a penny decline in the cost of margarine, now 32 cents a pound.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- Jerry Coleman pivoted sharply and the ball streaked out of his hand toward Phil Rizzuto at second for the start of a double play. He glanced over at the sidelines where Casey Stengel was gesturing violently to warn him not to risk getting the ball away too fast.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- Humphrey Bogart is listening to offers from both Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Paramount, but he isn't free at the moment to make a quick decision because under his long-term contract with Warner Brothers he is due to make his next picture there.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- During the week ended March 5 member bank reserve increased $77,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Members of the Merchant Marine Committee of the House of Representatives by-passed their chairman and called a meeting of the committee in Washington yesterday to press for action on long-range merchant marine legislation.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 6 -- A shore-line route for the proposed $108,500,000 New England Thruway between Greenwich and New Haven was recommended today by a Chicago engineering firm in a report to Gov. John D. Lodge.

BONN, Germany, March 6 -- The expansion of the military units of the East German People's Police into an army close to 400,000 men is accepted here as one of the probable consequences of the inclusion of West Germany in the European Defense Community.

Methods to remove theatregoing obstacles faced by commuters and thereby attract potential customers were discussed by showmen at a meeting held yesterday afternoon in the office of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, 488 Madison Avenue.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 6 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted today Keith M. Beaty of Charlotte, an associate of former Assistant Attorney General Thenom Lamar Caudle, for attempting to evade payment of Federal income taxes.

A syndicate headed by Bernard Friedman sold the 110-family garden apartment building at 690-700 East 139th Street, the Bronx, to Abe Mathews, who resold it to Walter Berger for cash above mortgages of $252,000. The property is assessed at $300,000. Anne Inselstein was the broker.
Eight sealed bids for the capital stock of the Schering Corporation, former German-owned pharmaceutical manufacturer, were opened yesterday at the Office of Alien Property, 120 Broadway.

The long arm of coincidence was was practically wrenched out of its socket in the telling of the opening story on a new adventure called "The Unexpected," which had its premiere at 10:30 Wednesday over N. B. C. television. The yarn was a fatuously tricky little job that defied all the laws of reason and probability.

The savory main dish suggested for the Sunday dinner menu is round steak smothered in onions. Though steak prices are still far from reasonable, the round is waste-free and goes further than other varieties because of its leanness. If braised, the meat will be as tender as more costly cuts.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Ellis G. Arnall, the Federal Price Stabilization Director, seeking stronger price-control machinery for the next two years, charged today that the Capehart amendment to the 1951 Defense Production Act had caused $750,000,000 in price increases in seven months.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Federal Communications Commission reported today that television now has become the principal source of revenue for the broadcasting networks and that the television broadcasting industry made a profit, for the first time, in 1951.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., March 6 -- Smoky, the 4-year-old biting Dalmatian mascot of Protection Engine Company of this community's Volunteer Fire Department, was convicted of bad behavior by fifty members of the company tonight and received the not-so-sereve sentence of being turned over to the Bide-a-Wee Home for Dogs in Wantagh, L. I.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The Assembly Ways and Means Committee voted unanimously last night to kill Governor Dewey's bill providing for compulsory motor vehicle inspection at state-operated stations, a report filed by the committee showed today.

SYRACUSE, March 6 (AP) -Robert Villemain, French middleweight, knocked out Joey De John of Syracuse at 2:37 of the ninth round of their scheduled ten-rounder before an overflow crowd of 9,500 tonight. Villemain weighed 164 pounds, De John 163 1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Truman conferred for fifteen minutes today with Newbold Morris, the New York Republican to whom he has assigned the task of rooting out corruption in the Federal Government.

The 1952 budget of the Soviet Union, announced yesterday, gives us some most illuminating information. For this year the direct military appropriation is slated to be almost 114,000,000,000 rubles, a peacetime record some 18 per cent above last year's figure, which had been the previous peacetime high.
GENEVA, March 6 -- For the first time since the end of World War II unemployment is becoming a serious social and economic problem in the countries of northwest Europe.

United States Attorney Myles J. Lane charged yesterday that Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock's order directing the Government to "blueprint" its case against sixteen secondary Communist leaders would make it difficult "to try similar cases in the future."

Concerned over the effects on children of civil defense activities and the atmosphere such measures help create, several specialists in work with youngsters organized this week a group temporarily known as the Committee on War Tensions in Children.

Holding that free parking on the streets coupled with the failure of the police to enforce parking rules tended to keep the public garage industry financially depressed, an arbitrator yesterday granted 4,000 garage workers a bare 4 per cent wage rise but ruled out a five-day week and other benefits.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 6 (AP) -- Ford Konno, Ohio State's muscular Hawaiian swimming sensation, won the 1,500-meter grind at the opening of the Western Conference meet tonight in an almost incredible record-breaking time of 18:11.5.

Ernie Durando, hard-punching middleweight from Bayonne, N. J., will face Paddy Young of Greenwich Village tonight in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden. The fight has developed into one of the most attractive clashes of the season and is likely to draw a crowd of 10,000.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 6 (AP) -- Joey Maxim of Cleveland, light heavyweight champion, took a unanimous decision tonight in a ten-round non-title bout with Ted (Tiger) Lowry of Boston. Maxim weighed 184 pounds, Lowry 179.

The gay, pretty look of the first violets of spring keynotes a group of coordinated bedroom ensembles now on display at B. Altman Co. Stark white and robin's egg blue and some greens are used to complement the purple color. They are found on crisp chintz fabrics in a solid, a stripe and a print of a bunch of violets.

Senators voting against President Truman's proposal to reorganize politics out of the Internal Revenue Bureau will have to bear a heavy responsibility if they succeed in defeating it. The President's plan does not go far enough and it comes at a very late date indeed, but it does move in the right direction.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The constitutionality of the state's "vagrancy" law was challenged before the Court of Appeals today by a New York City resident claiming to be one of 652 persons arrested as "vagrants" during Mayor Impellitteri's 1950 pre-election round-up.

The British-built 1952 Rover "75," a six-cylinder, four-door sedan, was announced yesterday and will go on display March 17 at Rootes Motors, Inc., 505 Park Avenue. The city-delivered price, exclusive of sales tax, is $2,697, including heater.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -The Federal Communications Commission ordered an investigation today into the Western Union Telegraph Company's failure to sell its international telegraph facilities.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The Office of Price Stabilization announced today that New York, Chicago and Los Angeles are among 139 cities and towns in which it will begin a survey March 17 to determine how its "mark-up" ceilings are working out in the grocery trade.

The Department of Justice's antitrust legal division was charged in Federal Court here yesterday with ignorance of the facts in the four-year-old investment banking suit, with failure to question "a responsible witness" in a way that would support the charges, and with trying to win the case by bringing economic pressure to bear on the defendants through a long trial.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The Office of Price Stabilization announced today that New York, Chicago and Los Angeles are among 139 cities and towns in which it will begin a survey March 17 to determine how its "mark-up" ceilings are working out in the grocery trade.

The Department of Justice's antitrust legal division was charged in Federal Court here yesterday with ignorance of the facts in the four-year-old investment banking suit, with failure to question "a responsible witness" in a way that would support the charges, and with trying to win the case by bringing economic pressure to bear on the defendants through a long trial.
CONCORD, N. H., March 6 (AP) -- Other developments affecting New Hampshire's pivotal voting next week included these:

PORTLAND, Ore., March 6 (AP) -- A three-man contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination looms in the Oregon primary election May 16. Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court was entered today, and Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois is expected to be added before the filing deadline at 5 P. M. tomorrow.

In your fine editorial of March 4 on a City Transit Authority you gave support to the sound idea of a single body to operate all the transit facilities, so as to benefit from the revenues from bridge -- and presumably tunnel -- tolls, parking meter and off-the-street-parking receipts, and the revenue from bus lines now in private ownership.

One of the first attempts in this country by a family agency to help solve the emotional problems of families by providing group therapy for children and parents is being undertaken by the Community Service Society.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -Cyrus Eaton, Cleveland industrialist, said today he contributed $30,000 in 1950 to organized labor's effort to prevent the re-election of Senator Robert A. Taft.
TRENTON, March 6 -- The names of four Republicans were entered tonight in the New Jersey Presidential preference primary as the deadline for filing nominating petitions was reached.

New York accorded municipal honors yesterday to Shlomo Z. Shragai, the first elected Israeli Mayor of Jerusalem, and presented to him a scroll that emphasized his role as one of "the guiding spirits of the Zionist movement."

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Congressional leaders predicted today that President Truman's new $7,900,000,000 foreign aid request would be cut drastically. Representative James P. Rich ards, Democrat of South Carolina, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives, said the Administration would do well to hold reductions to $1,000,000,000 and emphasized he was not proposing that as a ceiling.

It is characteristic of France's political artistry that when a certain result is demanded the politicians can somehow manage to bring it about. Obviously, the inclination of a majority in the National Assembly was to defeat Antoine Pinay, but, since the consequences would have been serious, enough Gaullists broke the party ranks to vote Pinay in as Premier.

Full production and record sales last year enabled the St. Regis Paper Company and its consolidated subsidiaries to increase earnings over 1950 despite the higher tax bill, Roy K. Ferguson, president and chairman, declared in the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.
LONDON, March 6 -- Prices continued to advance quietly in nearly all parts of the Stock Exchange here today, the advance being accompanied by a slight increase in volume of business.

Helene Dubner moved about her duties as hospital attendant in Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn last night, happy in the thought that her career dream -- she wants to be an American nurse -- can now come true. For six years after the Germans took Poland Miss Dubner was shunted from one concentration camp to another -- from the Lodz ghetto to Oswiecim (Auschwitz), to Sasel, and finally to the death camp at Bergen Belsen.

The Namm Store in Brooklyn, which is adjacent to Frederick Loeser Co., now near the end of its liquidation process, has bought Loeser's name, goodwill and trade-marks. Beginning Monday, Namm's will be known as Namm-Loeser's, Inc.
Junior high school students agreed yesterday that the adult way of life contributed frequently to juvenile delinquency.

Always a collection of refined, quiet distinction, the Henri Bendel spring custom order designs, viewed yesterday at this shop, 10 West Fifty-seventh Street, were underscored by a meticulous sort of crisp fashion-rightness. Easily discernible were such leading trends as the profuse use of white, the waist-deep collars and "spring-swept" skirt silhouette of slim front and sides with wide pleats or gathered folds for jutting back flare.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Two unidentified trustees of China International Foundation, Inc., a philanthropic movement headed by Newbold Morris, President Truman's director of inquiry into corruption in Government, were cited today as having records of activities with "Communist-front" organizations.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks, Republican of Kingston, majority leader, enlivened a drab debate on the question of permanent personal registration today by reciting a poem composed to the tune of the college song, "Betty Coed."

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, March 7 (AP) -- Sabre jets patrolling MIG Alley over Northwest Korea shot down one Communist MIG jet yesterday and damaged another. Small but fierce ground clashes erupted on the central and eastern battle fronts.

Sales of the General Electric Company, world's largest manufacturer of electrical equipment, broke all records in 1951. Aggregating $2,319,348,000, they showed an 18 per cent increase over 1950 sales of $1,960,429,000.
BALTIMORE, March 6 -- A block of temporary bleachers crashed in splinters at Baltimore's Fifth Regiment Armory tonight, bringing injury to a listed 277 persons.
CHICAGO, March 6 -- Exponents of socialized medicine in this country are on the run, Dr. John W. Cline of San Francisco, president of the American Medical Association, asserted tonight.
TOKYO, Friday, March 7 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,181, for Thurday's operations:

We rejoice this morning over the Legislature's approval of the sale of colored margarine in New York State. When a bad law gets on the books it takes a long time to get it off. This form of prohibition went back to 1893 in New York. Federal law imposing tax discrimination, first imposed in 1886, was repealed in January, 1950, after a battle of many years.

Charged with defrauding the Department of Welfare of $2,556 by collecting relief checks while employed over an eighteen-month period, a Far Rockaway butcher and his wife were paroled yesterday pending a trial in the Queens Court of Special Sessions.

The Board of Estimate averted a showdown vote yesterday on the proposed construction of a new third tube for the Lincoln Tunnel by deferring action to April 24. Mayor Impellitteri announced that he would appoint a committee to confer with the Port of New York Authority, proposed builder of the new facility, on the several plans now under consideration.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6 (UP) -- Three baseball club owners today scheduled a meeting in Los Angeles March 15 in an attempt to iron out difficulties which cropped up after the Pacific Coast League ruled against major league teams playing exhibitions in its parks.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A Senate small business subcommittee, studying Government procurement and disposal of machine tools, has subpoenaed Alfred W. Lawson of the Des Moines University of Lowsonomy, who is alleged to have profited highly from dealings in surplus Government machinery.

The knack of televising opera, if that is the word for the comprehension and projection of such a complicated matter, has come to the National Broadcasting Company. Last night's "Barber of Seville" was a delight to both the eye and the ear.

BOSTON, March 7 (UP) -- A selection committee tonight voted a four-team play-off to select the Eastern representatives for the National Collegiate A. A. hockey tournament at Colorado Springs, but at least one college refused to participate.

LONDON, March 7 -- Dr. L. Griffiths Pugh, a prominent English physiologist and member of the Medical Research Council, will accompany Eric Shipton's party of mountain climbers who are leaving London later this month for Cho-Oyu in the Himalayas as a trial expedition for a major assault on Mount Everest next year.

May I offer strong support for your editorial of March 5 relating to the recent Supreme Court decision in favor of the constitutionality of the Feinberg Law. The conclusion seems clear, however, that more comment is called for than a passive acceptance of a fait accompli and a word of caution as to the potential dangers within the law in question.

The action of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee in killing the bill for compulsory motor-vehicle inspection is an unwarranted rebuff to Governor Dewey, who backed the measure, and a backward step in the campaign to cut the mounting highway toll.

BALTIMORE, March 7 -- Postponement of the trial of six Maryland Communist leaders or former leaders was denied today as one was expelled from the party for "defeatism" toward the Smith Act, under which all were indicted last August.

The stock market climbed a bit higher again yesterday under the leadership of the railroad issues. Momentum of the carriers moved prices in this division to the best level since last May but prime industrial stocks were marked only by minor changes with interest in them at a minimum.

Summonses for Times Square jaywalkers are being considered by Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley, he disclosed yesterday. He said he was thinking of giving police authority to enforce the newly installed "Walk" and "Don't Walk" signs, which are now only warning signals.

Applications will soon be made for increased retail rates in those areas where present rates are the lowest, the National Fuel Gas Company revealed in its annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday. In the first instance, L. A. Brown, president, declared, such applications will involve sales to at least 75,000 customers.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 (AP) -- Twenty-three men and women were indicted today on charges of conspiracy in a huge, coast-to-coast heroin racket. The New York peddler, Waxey Gordon, was described as the kingpin.
DALLAS, March 7 (AP) -- Magnolia Oil Company said today it will know within a few days whether an oil well it has drilled in Louisiana is the world's deepest producing oil well.

ALBANY, March 7 -- The Assembly approved and sent to the Senate today a bill that would require airplane flights over New York City to follow waterways whenever possible. The bill would apply also to flights over Buffalo.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7 -- Thirteen African and Asian countries agreed tonight to put the Tunisian case before the United Nations Security Council as a threat to international peace and security.

BERLIN, March 7 -- Samuel Reber, political adviser to John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, said here tonight that the Western Allies were ready to consider any "real" offer from the East leading to the reunification of Germany and a peace treaty.

Today's new film is "The New China," a feature-length documentary in color produced jointly by the Chinese People's Republic Film Studios of Peking and the Central Documentary Film Studios of Moscow, at the Stanley. The offering is divided into five sections -- "South China," "The Yangtze,'' "Hangchow," "New Shanghai'' and "New Peking."

Recommittal of the Universal Military Training bill in the House last Tuesday does not justify proponents of the measure in throwing up their hands in despair and abandoning the cause for this session of Congress. We would urge the chairmen of the Senate and House Armed Services Committees to reflect that the battle for a U. M. T. law may be needlessly lost if they faint-heartedly give up the fight now without further struggle.

CONCORD, N. H., March 7 -- The New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign has produced something new: a black market in radio time. The Taft and Eisenhower camps are advertising so much that Station WLNH in Laconia hasn't another one-minute advertising spot available until after election day.

The Consumers League of New York for Fair Labor Standards would like to call attention to a bill currently before the State Legislature which we believe is badly needed -- namely, the Halpern-Preller bill, to establish a $1 per hour statutory minimum wage.

Locally at least, this has been a winter almost without snow, almost without ice. For some this twin lack has formed a sunny kind of winter, since it has meant no hours of tiresome shoveling, no picking the way, as though over eggs, along a sidewalk made glassy by the cold that follows winter rain.

Scoring by default because of the absence of Capt. J. J. Araiza of Mexico in the international chess tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club, Samuel Reshevsky of New York gained his eighth point to move into third place, according to a report from Havana yesterday. His total is 8 -- 3.

Prices swept upward in the sugar market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday and volume was 61,600 tons, the highest since Sept. 27, 1949, when sales were 105,750 tons. Early in the day actual sugars were sold to a refiner at 6.1 cents a pound.

ATHENS, March 7 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, former Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces and now head of the main Opposition party, the Greek Rally, said today that he attributed "no importance" to a dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Washington, dated Wednesday, dealing with United States officials' worry over antipathy between him and King Paul and an alleged royal tendency, fostered by a "Palace Guard," to act unconstitutionally.

GENEVA, March 7 -- Britain and other members of the sterling area are determined to reach a balance in their international accounts by the second half of 1952 "at latest," Henry Hopkinson, Secretary for Overseas Trade in the British Government, said here today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended March 4, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 111.4 per cent of the 1947-49 average, was 1.6 per cent below the level of January, 1952, and 3.1 per cent below the January, 1951, index.

The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that analysis of its February operating figures showed trains were on time for an efficiency index of 99.42 per cent. With a schedule of 15,996 hours, "total lateness of all trains of only ninety-two hours and thirty-one minutes" was reported.

DETROIT, March 7 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production this week will total 109,087 units, Ward's Automotive reports said today. The agency counted 84,350 cars and 24,737 trucks in the total. Last week the factories built 86,450 cars and 24,910 trucks.

LONDON, March 7 -- A special meeting of the Labor party Executive Committee has been called for next Thursday to try to patch up the rift between the supporters of Clement R. Attlee's leadership and the followers of Aneurin Bevan.
RICHMOND, Va., March 7 (AP) -- A special three-judge Federal court unanimously upheld today the constitutionality of Virginia laws requiring separate public schools for whites and Negroes.

Passage this week of the state law to allow manufacture and sale of pre-colored oleomargarine is welcome news to many New York housewives for whom it means elimination of the time-consuming chore of home-yellowing the butter substitute.
Combined net sales of the Electric Storage Battery Company increased about 25 per cent last year to a record $114,310,646 from the $91,734,045 volume for 1950, the annual report disclosed today.
CONCORD, N. H., March 7 -- The outlook and strategy of the New Hampshire Presidential primary elections have altered radically in the last twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -The International Materials Conference said today that it might be able to remove controls from zinc by next July because of the free world's rapidly increased supplies of the important defense material.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 7 (AP) -- Jack Granger, chunky Syracuse sophomore from Massena, N. Y., scored the first knockout and was the first man to reach the finals in the twenty-ninth Intercollegiate Boxing Association championship tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Senate Rules Committee voted, 8 to 3, today to challenge Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in the Senate for his attacks on a subcommittee that had been investigating his right to retain his seat.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7 -Manager Leo Durocher kept his Giants under wraps in a two-hour drill today for tomorrow's first clash with the Cleveland Indians of the American League at Tucson.

Time was when the prime producer could concentrate on output and the sale of his product to the manufacturers using it to make other products. He paid little attention to what happened after that, assuming that the character of the demand was pretty stable and goods would somehow be absorbed by markets.

PARIS, March 7 -- The question to how to retaliate against Soviet official discourtesy was one of most important issues reviewed here this week at the conference of United States diplomats from Moscow and other Eastern European capitals.

After a five-month inquiry into the problem of monopoly in professional boxing, a Federal grand jury recommended yesterday that the Government file a civil anti-trust suit to end restraints of trade in the promotion and broadcasting of championship matches.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 7 -- Newark Airport "should be retained and operated" as a civil and military field because of its economic and military value to the country, Brig. Gen. Robert Copsey of the Air Force told a Joint Legislative Committee here today.

Frank Costello, the gambler, won a four-day postponement yesterday of a hearing to determine whether he must testify for the prosecution at the trial of a New Jersey detective charged with protecting gamblers.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 8 -Highway officials of eleven northeastern states and the District of Columbia urged the Government today to allocate sufficient controlled materials so that the various highway departments could let contracts for all projects scheduled.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -President Truman promised a reluctant Congress today that "ultimate decay of the Soviet slave world" surely would follow the building of political, economic and military positions of strength throughout the free world, united under the Mutual Security Program.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- An almost flawless 65, seven strokes under par for the sandy Lakewood golf course, catapulted Cary Middlecoff of Memphis into the lead today in the $10,000 St. Petersburg open tournament.

A mild-mannered, gray-haired retired schoolteacher, whose shabby four-story brownstone house at 218 West 122d Street became a haven for fifteen to forty dogs and cats, resisted for two hours yesterday efforts by the police and others to enter the building.

Dean Rusk, who retired three months ago as Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, appealed last night to the American people to realize that the complexities of the world situation made a clear and consistent foreign policy difficult of achievement.

The Soviet Government is spending almost as much on efforts to jam the Voice of America radio broadcasts as the United States is spending on its whole world-wide broadcasting program, Wilson Compton, administrator of the new International Information Administration, said last night.

Alfred Zega billed himself as a baritone for his debut recital in Town Hall last night, but his voice had the lightness and some of the range of a tenor. His program was pleasantly unhackneyed and he sang with innate musical feeling.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 7 -The Brooklyn baseball club made its most expensive leap into the bonus player field today by signing Danny Lynk, 18-year-old infielder, to a Montreal contract for an amount "in excess of $25,000."
The following is a round-up of new products may be of interest to homemakers.

HONOLULU, March 7 -- Four Hawaii veterans and a 61-year-old Gold Star Mother were ready to take off tonight for Dallas, Tex., and Washington, as a "Connally Caravan" to protest remarks concerning the comparative Americanism of some Hawaii citizens made on the Senate floor Monday by Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, during debate on taking up the Hawaiian statehood bill.
NEW DELHI, India, March 7 (Reuters) -- Wholesale commodity prices continued to slump throughout India today as panicky speculators unloaded holdings onto a sagging market.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 8 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,182, for Friday's operations:

Jim Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, yesterday outlined plans for a meeting between world light heavyweight champion Joey Maxim and middleweight king Ray Robinson. Stating that Maxim was in favor of the match, Norris added "The whole thing is now up to Robinson, who may have some other commitments."

Wall Street was rife with rumors this week that new action on sterling is imminent. More specifically, there were rumors that Sir Robert Makin, sent by the British Treasury to plug the sterling drains in the Middle East, had been notably successful in Kuwait and that the British Government has been building up a sterling defense fund by selling some of the American securities released when it paid off its 1941 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 (AP) -- Arthur Rubin, bulky cue star from Brooklyn, came from behind today in the closing inning to defeat Joe Chamaco of Mexico City, 50 to 47, in a first-round match of the world three-cushion billiard tournament.

Irwin Steingut, leader of the Democratic minority in the State Assembly, declared yesterday after a City Hall conference with Mayor Impellitteri that none of the Democratic members of the Legislature would agree to any state program for solving the city's financial problems that involved a transit fare increase.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 7 -President Truman arrived today for his usual March work-rest vacation after an uneventful flying trip of 3 hours 32 minutes.
LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- A special committee of the International Sugar Council has approved a draft of a new international sugar agreement.

In an unusual action attesting to the heated feelings over the three-pronged controversy involving its governing body, the council, and two union officials, the membership of Actors' Equity Association set aside its scheduled order of business at yesterday's regular quarterly meeting to examine the merits and demerits of the matter.
The Brooklyn College basketball team snapped Iona's seven-game winning streak with a 59-57 triumph last night at the Flatbush gym.

SUPERIOR, Wis., March 7 (AP) -Gov. Earl Warren of California declared tonight that leadership of the world had been thrust upon the United States and "we must accept it." He added that "only under a Republican Administration can the nation handle such a responsibility."

LONDON, March 7 -- The structure of Britain's cost-of-living index, which has been regarded as unrepresentative for some time, will be modified and brought slightly more up to date, according to a White Paper presented to Parliament today by the Cost-of-Living Advisory Committee.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 7 -All factions in the New England Thruway controversy in Fairfield County today chorused agreement on one facet of the thruway survey report of the H. W. Lochner Co. firm of Chicago: that tolls should be charged.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- As the Yankees completed the preliminary stage of their training campaign today, preparatory to launching the exhibition season tomorrow against the Cardinals at Al Lang Field, all eyes focused on the rival camp.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 7 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Long was ousted as Louisiana's Democratic national committeeman yesterday and replaced with an outspoken critic of President Truman. It was the second political setback in sixteen days for the Governor, whose brother, the late Senator Huey P. Long, once ruled Louisiana.
HAYS, Kan., March 7 (AP) -- The backers of Senator Taft smothered the "favorite-son" movement for General Eisenhower in Kansas today by making a clean sweep of the Sixth District convention here.

About five years ago, a wholesale grocer whose store was in Yonkers moved to a farm in LaGrangeville, fifteen miles from Poughkeepsie, for reasons of health. The grocer, Percy Tompkins, had suffered a serious heart attack and his business had to be abandoned.

Momentous decisions will be in the making this week-end as New York City and state officials ponder the question whether it is practicable and desirable to put the New York transit system and possibly other public facilities under Authority management. It is a tacit tribute to the respect in which he is held that Commissioner Robert Moses will become a dominant figure in these talks, to be held here and in Albany.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- The grain markets showed a strong undertone again today, displaying an ability to absorb substantial profit taking sales without receding more than fractionally. On such setbacks there was persistent commission buying.

The 1951 Viking Fund awards were presented last night to three American scholars at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel after the sixth annual award dinner of the Wenner-Gren Foundation for Anthropological Research.

Loew's Woodside Theatre, the buff brick movie house at Roosevelt Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, Woodside, Queens, has been bought by St. Sebastian's Roman Catholic Church, Woodside Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, Queens.

A chemical test that predicts the sex of an unborn child with an accuracy of nearly 100 per cent is reported in the current issue of Science, official publication of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

BALTIMORE, March 7 (AP) -The Sonja Henie ice show bleachers that collapsed and injured about 275 persons here last night were under eight times as much weight as the supports could hold, city inspectors said today.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today a $970,192,000 deficiency money bill for a dozen Federal agencies.

Permit me to comment on just two of Vera Kaspar's ill-informed and sometimes contradictory statements in her letter, published in THE TIMES of Feb. 19, regarding the dismemberment of the Austro-Hungarian Empire "without replacing it by something better," and her approval of the deportations.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 7 -- The forces of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower rallied on two fronts tonight to meet the effects of a personal invasion of New Hampshire by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in a bid for victory in the nation's first primary next Tuesday.

CAIRO, March 7 -- The prosecution's sixty-five-page report on the great riots in Cairo on Jan. 26, which resulted in extraordinary loss of property and serious loss of life, was issued today. It placed administrative responsibility for what happened on Fuad Serag el-Din Pasha, Minister of Interior in Mustafa Nahas Pasha's Wafdist Cabinet, and on his assistants in the Ministry.

The executive committee for the luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop, to be given on March 27 in the grand ballroom of the Plaza, will meet on Wednesday in the home of Miss Louise Edgar, 1050 Fifth Avenue, to discuss ticket sales and the selection of favors to be distributed at the event.
SAIGON, Indo-China, March 7 (AP) -- French naval commandos attacked and destroyed today 150 junks believed to be carrying supplies from Communist China to Communist-led Vietminh forces.

The bulk of the increased 1952 Soviet military budget will be used for raising the output of guns, tanks, planes, atom bombs and other weapons, thus requiring still further conversion of Soviet industry to direct armament production, United States Government specialists believe.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -Representative F. Edward Hebert accused the Pentagon today of holding back at least 211 names from the list of public relations officials it had supplied to the House Armed Services subcommittee he heads.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 7 -- The Australian Goverment's decision to attach a fighter wing of the Royal Australian Air Force to the British garrison in the Middle East is a practical recognition of Australia's responsibilities in that area and a logical outcome of her participation in the Middle East Command, agreed to in principle last October.

ALBANY, March 7 -- The Federal Communications Commission has agreed to allocate three television channels in New York exclusively for noncommercial educational and cultural programs, Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Education Commissioner, notified Governor Dewey and legislative leaders today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Illinois Bell Telephone Company, of Chicago, applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the registration of $25,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series C, due April 1, 1984. The bonds will be offered for public sale at competitive bidding.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 7 (UP) -J. L. Morrill, president of the University of Minnesota, called upon the Big Ten Conference today to set a "good example" by supporting the American Council on Education's athletic code.

BOSTON, March 7 -- The first major break in the textile industry labor front came late today when the American Woolen Company and A. F. L. representatives signed labor contracts for two mills at undisclosed terms. A third contract affecting workers at the Shawsheen Mills, Andover, is expected to be closed tomorrow in Lawrence.
Michael Risavy has been named department manager for all house-wares divisions of Bloomingdale.

LOS ANGELES, March 7 -- Serious and unnecessary delays in the atomic energy program were charged tonight by Dr. Kenneth S. Pitzer, who for more than two years directed research for the Atomic Energy Commission.

A move by several Bronx and Queens Councilmen to win approval by the Council's committee on state legislation for a change in the number of votes cast by members of the Board of Estimate failed yesterday.
Considerable uncertainty surrounds going prices to be developed at public bidding next week for five new issues of public utility bonds totaling $65,300,000.
LONDON, March 7 -- Thanks to a mild winter, Britain has been able to cancel orders for a "large part" of the coal that was to have been imported from the United States this year.
BUENOS AIRES, March 7 -- The Socialist party today displayed an unexpected solidarity in the face of conciliatory moves on the part of President Juan D. Peron.
Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed slightly irregular yesterday, 13 points lower to 17 points higher than on Thursday.

HONG KONG, March 7 -- Fifteen Chinese Communist officials in Shanghai -- including Li Yu, secretary general of the local party organization and alternate member of the National Central Committee -- have been dismissed from their posts in a continuing purge of "bureaucratic, undisciplined and corrupt" party elements.

Residents of communities hard by lumber camps are bracing themselves for increasingly formidable week-end invasions by lumberjacks. The deep woods loggers are working harder during the week and to anyone who is acquainted with their lore this means they drink harder and fight harder on Saturday night.

We in America should be chary and loath in pointing adverse fingers at the countries of Western Europe, especially France and Britain, for what some regard as their unwillingness or reluctance to assume their full obligations in preparing defense measures.

ALBANY, March 7 (AP) -- The following winter sports conditions at New York points were reported to the State Commerce Department: Armonk -- One inch fluffy on two inches granular snow; skiing fair to good.
BONN, Germany, March 7 (AP) -President Theodor Heuss of West Germany assailed the "racial hatred" of the Nazis and "injustices" of the post-war denazification program as well.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., March 7 -- Fairleigh Dickinson College of Rutherford upset the University of Buffalo, 63 -- 55, and St. Peter's College of Jersey City defeated Panzer College of East Orange, 83 -- 62, to gain the final of the District 31 National Association of Intercollegiate Basketball playoffs at the Fairleigh Dickinson gym tonight.

" Caesar," a biography of the world-conqueror and lawgiver, by the French historian and scholar, Gerard Walter, will be published March 24 by Scribners. Taking his facts from contemporary sources and quoting from eye-witnesses to the principal events, the author attempts to portray the character of Caesar and that of his time.
LONDON, March 4 -- Completely furnished and equipped homes and trailers are among the chief attractions at this year's Ideal Home Exhibition, which opened here today.
MEXICO CITY, March 7 -- The political struggle for the support of Gen. Lazaro Cardenas by three of the leading candidates in Mexico's current Presidential campaign has come into the open.
The "help-wanted" sign was flashed before a New York University conference yesterday by large retail store operators.

Events today: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 2; "Fledermaus," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; "Rigoletto," Salmaggi Opera. Brooklyn Academy, 8:30; "Rigoletto," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30; Philharmonic-Symphony, conductor, Szell, piano soloist.
MADRID, March 7 -- The Spanish press accused Britain and France today of opposing the United States policy of collaboration with Spain "to preserve their monopoly" on American aid.

Max Goldstein has purchased the two-story dwelling at 18 Arleigh Road in Great Neck, L. I., from Robert M. Wellwood. Trylon Realty was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Thirty cream-topped pies smashed against the grimacing faces of student leaders yesterday afternoon as New York University staged its fourth annual "Pie Fling." Three hundred shouting students crowded the steps of the Gould Memorial Library on the University Heights campus, 181st Street and University Avenue, as willing victims in green slickers faced the soggy onslaught.

OMAHA, Neb., March 7 -- Senator Robert A. Kerr, of Oklahoma, opening his campaign in the Nebraska Democratic Presidential primary, said today that President Truman had given him "no assurance of any kind, and I am convinced he has given it to no one else."

ALBANY March 7 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the Bronx County Trust Company, 2804 Third Avenue, the Bronx, has been authorized to issue five-year installment 4 per cent registered debentures due March 1, 1957, in the aggregate of $400,000.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson heads the list of persons in public life who will receive the annual Page One Awards of the Newspaper Guild of New York. Special posthumous recognition was accorded this year to the lifelong services of the late Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, and the late Harold L. Ickes, who for many years was Secretary of the Interior.
The National Shipping Authority yesterday ordered sixty of its vessels, all Liberty-type ships, returned to Reserve Fleet sites upon their arrival back in this country.

VIENNA, March 7 -- The Communists, who have had so little success politically in Austria since 1945, have recently been making serious inroads on Socialist strength in the trade unions. Their success has been particularly pronounced in heavy industry, which, since 1947, has been almost completely nationalized and under Socialist direction.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 7 -District Attorney Lindsay R. Henry filed a petition with Judge D. Ormonde Ritchie of the Suffolk County Children's Court today charging Harold Lorentson, 13-year-old school boy of Smithtown, with juvenile delinquency.
The variety of art exhibitions now on view should appeal to the most diverse number of gallery-goers.

On Feb. 29 you printed Deputy Correction Commissioner Louis A. Nolfo's letter, hoping that no publisher will print the life story of William Sutton, on the ground that it would glamorize the bank robber and cause weak people with criminal tendencies to commit crimes.

JERSEY CITY, March 7 -- The School of Business Administration of St. Peter's College here has chosen the Most Rev. Karl J. Alter, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Cincinnati, as the winner of its Rerum Novarum for 1952.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, 69-year-old Chicago City Health Commissioner, was reported today to have been named in a grand jury true bill charging malfeasance in office in the horse meat scandal.

Educators need not worry about the effects of comic books and television if children are subjected to good teaching in their schools, a report submitted to the twenty-sixth annual conference of the Secondary Education Board declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Truman Administration has no intention of recalling General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower from Europe to testify before Congressional committees in support of its $7,900,000,000 foreign aid appropriation request, on which hearings will begin shortly.

PITTSBURGH, March 7 (AP) -- Admiral Ben Moreell, chairman of the board of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, today labeled the Eric Johnston standard for price ceilings when applied to steel as "unfair, impracticable and a breach of good faith by the Federal Government."

Mrs. Judith Epstein, honorary president of Hadassah, spoke at a Sabbath Eve service last night conducted by women at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West Sixty-eighth Street. Rabbi Edward E. Klein presented a Purim cantata.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 -- Vittorio Gassman, who was starred in "Bitter Rice" and other Italian features, will make his American film debut in "The Glass Wall," the first undertaking of the newly organized independent company, Shane-Tors Productions.

The projects in New York City approved by the National Production Authority include the two-story arcade building to be erected by Webb Knopp, Inc., on Thirtythird and Thirty-fourth Streets west of Saks-34th store at an estimated cost of $4,020,000.

Two Swedish American Line officials, both of whom joined the company more than thirty-five years ago, have retired, it was announced yesterday. They are George E. Hanson, passenger traffic manager for this country, and Arne Rutquist, landing agent.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 (AP) -- The third United States Circuit Court of Appeals was asked today to remand for further hearing before the Federal Power Commission a decision dividing transmission of natural gas into New England between two companies.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected a request of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company for a general investigation of rail, rail-bus, and all-but commutation services in the New York metropolitan area "to determine the respective places of each service in the future improvement of the commutation services."

Edward Alleye Sumner, industrialist and a former director of the American Radiator Company, left a gross estate of $4,567,626 and a net of $4,131,028, according to an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday. Bequests of $215,443 were left to charity.

Reorganization of Alexander Smith, Inc., in the last year and considerable expansion in its operational scope have led to reduction in the number of top management officials and other personnel. William F. C. Ewing, president, emphasized yesterday that this situation is "100 per cent normal for a company which has an announced policy of over-all modernization improvement and expansion into new fields."

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 7 -- William Fite Burrow, a Dallas, Tex., attorney and Democrat, appealed for support here tonight for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in next Tuesday's Republican primary election, in a radio talk over Station WFEA.

Taking cognizance of rumors that Government stabilization authorities are about to propose a $3-a-ton price increase in steel, Clarence R. Randall, president of the Inland Steel Company of Chicago, asserted yesterday that such action would be a "maneuver" to pave the way for a steel wage "by proposing a prior and insufficient price increase."

NAVAL AIR STATION, Quonset Point, R. I., March 7 -- Two masked men with snub-nosed automatics stole $100,000 in cash this morning from two messengers for the Quonset Point Naval Air Station Credit Union and got away.
BONN, Germany, March 7 -William H. Draper Jr., roving Ambassador for the Mutual Security Agency in Europe, expects to return to the United States shortly.

A consent decree acceptable to four large manufacturers of carbon dioxide and dry ice and an affiliated patent holding company, ending a civil anti-trust action, was entered yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Leo F. Rayfiel.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board asked Congress today for authority to curb unethical transactions in airline tickets.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -President Truman instructed all Government departments and agencies today not to comply with a request of a House Judiciary subcommittee for a record of all civil or criminal cases referred to the Department of Justice within the last six years in which action was declined.

Detectives reached several dead ends yesterday as they attempted to track down the gunman who shot Sol A. Rosenblatt, attorney and $200,000 legatee under the bitterly contested will of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee.

Apartment house properties figured in three real estate transactions in Brooklyn in deals reported yesterday in that borough. The parcels are at 2-24 Hinckley Place, 12-14 Clark Street and 348 Ninetieth Street.

ROME, March 7 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower conferred with Randolfo Pacciardi, Italian Defense Minister and Gen. Efisio Marras, Chief of the Italian General Staff, during a brief stopover he made in Naples today on his way back to Paris by plane.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 7 -- Members of the Drake Road-Edgewood Association, including persons with incomes under $5,000 not computing tax on page 3, will attend an "income tax eve" ball for the calendar year 1951 next Friday night in the bare-walled gymnasium of the Edgewood School on Roosevelt Place.

At the end of Day Care Week it is a good time to take stock of what the city's day-care program is accomplishing and what remains to be done. The day-care centers which receive public funds are operated by non-profit agencies; 84 per cent of their expenses are financed by the city.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -President Truman urged tonight adherence to "the principles of freedom of conscience and religious toleration" and said without them "the spirit of justice will perish and with it all the other cherished institutions of democracy."

America's prospects in the Olympic sprint events to be held at Helsinki next summer took on a brighter appearance last night following an impressive performance by Andy Stanfield of the Grand Street Boys Club in the Leon Purchase Memorial 60-yard test at the 369th Regiment Armory.

MacDILL FORCE BASE, Tampa, Fla., March 7 -- All sky trails lead today to this Air Force base, where "four-headed monsters" are learning to fly the eighty-three-ton, 600-mile-an-hour B-47 jet bomber -- the plane "that flies like a bird and lands like a truck."

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- Spartan Valor, handicap champion of the Florida winter racing season, had the colic today and the $25,000 Gulfstream Park Handicap became a wide open affair with eleven scheduled to compete tomorrow in the richest race of the meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Rufus E. Miles Jr., assistant administrator of the Federal Security Agency, said today that the first grants to aid community facilities would be made within the next ten days in critical defense areas under the Defense Housing and Community Services and Facilities Act of 1951.
PARIS, March 7 -- The village of Tignes, high in a valley of the French Alps near the Italian frontier, is going to die a week from Saturday.

LAWRENCE, Kan., March 7 (AP) -- The Kansas Jayhawks, led by Clyde Lovellette's 33 points, clinched at least a tie for the Big Seven conference basketball championship by beating Kansas State's Wildcats, 78 to 61, tonight.

TRENTON, March 7 (AP) -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur took himself out of New Jersey's Presidential popularity poll today. In a letter to New Jersey's Secretary of State, the general said that his name had been entered in the poll yesterday without his consent.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today a dip of 0.2 per cent in retail food prices between Feb. 15 and Feb. 25. In the thirty-day period before that there was a food price drop of 2.1 per cent, which will be reflected in the next consumers' price index figure about two weeks hence.

Mayor Impellitteri purchased yesterday a $1,000 State of Israel Independence Bond at ceremonies held at City Hall. It was sold by Benjamin Abrams, chairman of the Greater New York Committee of the bond drive.

ST. LOUIS, March 7 (UP) -- The Government rested its case today in the trial of James P. Finnegan, former Internal Revenue Collector and political friend of President Truman, charged with bribery and misconduct in office.

HAVANA, March 7 -- The urgent need for economic development of Latin-American countries through their own efforts was emphasized at the third meeting of the Central Bank Experts of American Nations, which ended today.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 7 -- An underground organization of the Communist party in Los Angeles was revealed today by a Government witness at the trial before United States Judge William C. Mathes of fifteen California Communists charged with conspiracy to advocate the overthrow, of the Government by force and violence.

CICERO, Ill., March 7 -- The first witness in the trial of Police Chief Edwin Konovsky of Cicero testified in Criminal Court today that the Cicero police had made no attempt to curb rioters in race disturbances here last July.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it had fixed for a group of airlines new rates of mail pay that would save the Post Office Department more than $11,000,000 this year.

FRANKFURT, Germany, March 7 (UP) -- Espionage agents who photographed the diary of a United States major general last year may have had access to other "top-secret" military information. United States Army authorities said tonight.
MUNSAN, Korea, Saturday, March 8 -- Allied truce negotiators accused the Communists today of secretly holding American prisoners of war in Manchuria.

More ships of every class from ore-carriers to passenger liners are needed for the American merchant marine before the nation's maritime resources can attain complete mobilization, Vice Adm. Edward L. Cochrane, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, declared last night.

A 51-year-old admitted bookmaker in Brooklyn was held yesterday in Kings County Court in $10,000 bail as a material witness in the District Attorney's investigation of a payment of $2,000 allegedly made by the gambler to two city detectives.

Dr. Liston Pope, chairman of the Congregational Christian Council for Social Action, which has been charged by a national group of Congregational Christian laymen with "trying to put the church into power politics," is scheduled to speak at 6:30 P. M. Thursday at the annual dinner of the Laymen's Fellowship of the New York City Congregational Church Association.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 7 (UP) -Brookfield Farms' Intent headed a field of eleven thoroughbreds named today to go to the post in tomorrow's $50,000 San Juan Capistrano Handicap, closing feature of the fifty-day Santa Anita meeting.

Judge Harold R. Medina expressed disappointment in Federal Court here yesterday at the announced intention of the Government to conclude next Monday the direct examination of Harold L. Stuart, Chicago financier, as a prosecution witness in the antitrust investment banking trial.

Paddy Young, Greenwich Village middleweight, punched his way to victory over Ernie Durando of Bayonne, N. J., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The decision in Young's favor was unanimous, but the triumph was by no means an easy one.

Parents were taken to task yesterday for their neutrality in the selection of reading matter for children. The complaint was made at ceremonies at which the American Library Association presented awards for the best-written and best-illustrated children's books of 1951.
Ownership of the Schering Corporation, former German pharmaceutical manufacturer, was transferred yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.

Five professional home economists from the Ryukyu Islands, south of Japan, arrived in New York last night for a five-day visit. They are here on an exchange project sponsored by the Army and administered by the Institute of International Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 7 (AP) --Ohio State's Buckeyes ran away with five of the six final events and racked up 70 points to 32 for second place Michigan State in surging toward their fourth consecutive Big Ten swimming championship tonight.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 7 (AP) -- Substitute Dick Johnson connected with a leaping one-hand toss to beat the final gun and give Duke a 90-88 semi-final victory over West Virginia tonight in a thrilling Southern Conference basketball tournament game. Duke's Dick Groat outscored West Virginia's Mark Workman, 31 -- 15, in the heralded battle of the All-America players.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -Small aluminum users and big aluminum producers told the Senate Small Business Committee today that there was enough aluminum on hand to permit relaxation of controls.

THE anti-firearms dreamers seem to progress quite naturally from the "ridiculous to the ridiculous," and apparently a few of the more intelligent members of the New York Senate were dozing when the latest bit of silly legislation was brought up, for the Panken Bill managed to get by the Upper House.

PARIS, Saturday, March 8 -- After long-drawn-out negotiations lasting through the night, Premier Antoine Pinay was believed to have reached a compromise early today to permit formation of the first Right-Center Cabinet for France since World War II.
LONDON, March 7 -- Prices continued a fairly general advance on the stock markets here today as the volume of business showed a further moderate increase.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7 -- Republican leaders of twenty-one Midwestern and Rocky Mountain states converged here today for a strategy conference, and Senator James H. Duff of Pennsylvania converged right along with them to do some intensive campaigning for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Dr. Liston Pope, chairman of the Congregational Christian Council for Social Action, which has been charged by a national group of Congregational Christian laymen with "trying to put the church into power politics," is scheduled to speak at 6:30 P. M. Thursday at the annual dinner of the Laymen's Fellowship of the New York City Congregational Church Association.

Twelve members of the Police Department received at ceremonies in headquarters yesterday medals, letters of commendation and cash awards of $25 to $50 for acts of heroism in saving persons from drowning. The awards were made by the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York.

With a triple-header making up the program, play in the fifteenth annual national invitation basketball tournament starts at Madison Square Garden tonight. The first capacity crowd of the season is expected to be on hand for the competition which begins at 6 o'clock.

The Soviet Union is making progress in strengthening its relatively sparse railroad network in Siberia and Central Asia. Several important links of the South Siberian Railroad have been completed or are nearing completion, and the highly strategic Mointy-Chu line will apparently soon go into operation, giving for the first time a direct line between the Karaganda coal basin and Central Asia.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Dewey today sent to the Senate for confirmation the nomination of the Rev. Canon Sydney R. Peters of Bay Shore, L. I., as a member of the Board of Visitors of Pilgrim State Hospital in Brentwood. Mr. Peters is rector of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church in Bay Shore.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Admiral William M. Fechteler, Chief of Naval Operations, declared today that unless the United States maintains command of the seas, "important strategic materials in which our country is not self-sufficient cannot be imported and the real secret weapon of America, its industrial might, cannot function even in peace time."

THE TIMES is singularly blind to the fact that communism in America operates in important part through front organizations. "Fringe" organizations may be a planned or an accidental detail. You leave much room for assumption that "front" and "fringe" organizations are of the same stripe, and that membership in either of them is of little or no consequence.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 7 -- President Getulio Vargas has ordered a presentation of estimates within fifteen days for urgent measures to remove the conditions that caused a disastrous train wreck near Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 7 (UP) -- The Ohio Public Utilities Commission today ordered the Western Union Telegraph Company, in effect, to halt all racing wire service in the state.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Mayor Impellitteri's bill that would have enabled New York City to impose a county real estate tax for raising $100,000,000 in new revenues has been killed by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, along with eighteen of the twenty-one other measures introduced to carry out the Mayor's fiscal program.

Probably even the bitterest opponents of the Taft-Hartley Act concede that the machinery provided by it for determining collective bargaining representatives by employe elections promotes one of the law's main objectives -- the minimization of industrial strife which "interferes with the normal flow of commerce."

New Yorkers stepped out of New York in snowtime into "Holland in Tulip Time" at the Bronx Park yesterday when 5,000 tulips opened in the New York Botanical Garden's new show. As the snow fell gently against the high glass dome of the garden's main greenhouse, first-day visitors to the exhibition enjoyed the simulated Maytime inside while sniffing the pleasantly pungent odor of the multi-colored tulips.

DES MOINES, Ia., March 7 (UP) -- Johnny Bright, Drake's star Negro halfback and No. 1 draft choice of the Philadelphia Eagles, said tonight he had signed a contract to play with the Calgary (Alta.) pro football team.

Plans for altering the twelve-story apartment building at '630 Park Avenue into smaller units were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by Frederick Brown to a syndicate headed by Sol Henkind, operator.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, March 8 (AP) -- United Nations airmen and ground forces in Korea had a light day yesterday with the exception of Marines on the eastern front, who drove off five North Korean thrusts north of the "Punchbowl," an oval mountain rim nineteen miles north of the Thirty-eighth Parallel and twenty miles inland from the east coast.

WASHINGTON, March. 7 -- A surplus World War II tanker, now under investigation for transporting vital oils between Communist-held ports under Russian charter almost up to the outbreak of the Korean fighting, was represented to a Senate inquiry today as having served as an important medium through which Naval Intelligence pierced the Iron Curtain for information it wanted.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee, with Prof. Owen Lattimore on the stand ready for his tenth day of cross-examination, suddenly called off proceedings today until Monday.
LONDON, March 7 -- So many indignant protests have been made against the higher bus and subway fares introduced in London this week that Prime Minister Churchill himself has had to take notice.

Pierre Sancan, the French pianist who is touring tile United States in a special exchange between the Jeunesses Musicales de France and the National Music League, made his first New York public appearance last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at a concert sponsored by the League.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The National Production Authority approved today the construction or remodeling of thirty-five commercial structures with a total estimated value of $17,857,447 in New York City and northern New Jersey.

Samuel Blumenthal, 30-year-old Brooklyn bookmaker who is accused of accepting a $100 bribe to alter his testimony during the first-degree murder trial of Benedict Macri, pleaded guilty yesterday to perjury in the first degree.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- President Truman, in an open letter today to the Senate, characterized the fight over his plan to reorganize the Internal Revenue Bureau as a test of "whether Senators are more interested in their political patronage than in good public service."

Eleven years ago Moss Hart's "Lady in the Dark" seemed like an original and penetrating musical drama. There is no reason to change that opinion now. For the Equity Library Theatre performance, put on this week-end at the DeWitt Clinton Community Center, is alive and fascinating, and one of the keenest pieces of stage work an Equity Library troupe has contrived.

ALTOONA, Pa., March 7 -- Daniel (Dutch) Lamont, 42 years old, a wealthy Altoona bookmaker under indictment in New York on charges of complicity in an alleged basketball "fix," was fined $250 and costs today under the Pennsylvania Uniform Firearms Act.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Government's selling price for general purpose (GR-S) synthetic rubber was reduced today to 23 cents a pound from 26 cents effective on shipments after 12:01 A. M. tomorrow, by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Plans for altering the twelve-story apartment building at '630 Park Avenue into smaller units were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by Frederick Brown to a syndicate headed by Sol Henkind, operator.

PAT FRANK, who wrote "Mr. Adams," that top-drawer fantasy about the last fertile male in the A-bomb Era, is dead serious in "Hold Back the Night." He dedicates his latest novel to the United States Marines.

THE quondom constable of Crockett, Calif. (pop. about 5,000) is currently playing romantic interest opposite Academy Award winner Judy Holliday in her new Columbia picture, "The Marrying Kind," and thereby hangs one of those tales of quick transition from obscurity to stardom which brings delight to the picture industry and a faintly incredulous wonder to the public.

THERE is no mystery in the cultivation of dwarf trees. Those seen at florists' in small dish gardens are generally the Ming trees, which are fashioned from dead tree material. But there are many natural specimens that lend themselves to dwarfing.

THE C. B. S. Radio Network, whose busy vice presidents in charge of programming have been working overtime to refute the argument that radio is moribund, offers these recent actions to bolster its case:

The "stretch-out" in aircraft procurement for the armed services still leaves the industry stretched in the seams of its manufacturing capacity in several respects, both nationally and locally. A report from the Aircraft Industries Association reveals that the current payroll is $2,500,000,000 a year, more than double its pre-Korean total.

THE National Recreation Association has issued a sixty-four-page magazine devoted to the subject of summer vacations. The object is to give a list of interesting vacations for the moderate-income group. The publication contains information about the vacation opportunities in national, state and local recreation areas throughout the country and describes the accommodations they have to offer.

CAIRO, March 8 -- Beirut, out to make its new international airport the center of Middle East air traffic, has challenged Cairo's right to be the inter-regional air communications center and Cairo is making a last minute effort to stage a comeback at the international aeronautics meeting in Paris.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Federal marshals, sided by the police at Columbus, Ohio,. today served a subpoena on Alfred W. Lawson, 82-year-old founder of the Des Moines University of Lawsonomy, Ordering him to appear Monday at a Senate inquiry into dealings in surplus Government machinery.

THE Civil Aeronautics Board approved last week final details of a proposed merger of Inland Air Lines and Western Air Lines. While Western and Inland are important to the people and the areas they serve, neither is of much national importance.

APPROXIMATELY 200,000,000 records were sold in the United States last year. The figure of necessity is a rough estimate, for an investigator soon gets the impression that a record manufacturer would rather betray his mother than reveal his sales. But if manufacturers won't disclose totals, they are at least quick to admit that the vast bulk of this spate of disks consists of popular music.

HERE we have the testament of a woman of infinite zest and invincible confidence -- the story of a long life and many activities told in a fashion in which both qualities are faithfully revealed from childhood to old age.

IN a conversation with Olin Downes, recounted in a recent piece, Sir Thomas Beecham expounded a strange view about the dimensions of the theatres for which Mozart wrote his chief operas and the size of the orchestras Mozart had at his command.
