THE sharp distinction usually made these days between the artist who is skilled in some one of the fine arts and whose desired goal is a gallery show and the practical designer who is responsible for endowing objects for everyday use with esthetic qualities seems a twentieth century digression. There was a time when artist and designer were one and the same.

Those interested in health and welfare cannot help but have variant reactions to the recent dramatic announcement of the spectacular therapeutic results achieved thus far in the experimental use of the new isonicotinic acid hydrazide in tuberculosis.

WHAT Karl Marx in the Eighteen Fifties called "capitalism," as a term of opprobrium, has developed since his time very differently on the two sides of the Atlantic. This fact is not generally recognized. Nearly everybody knows that the many relations among human beings that make up social and economic life are quite different in, for example, Texas from what they are in Bavaria or Italy.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- Spokesmen for the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., accused the steel industry today of using "high-pressure propaganda" in the bitter labor-management fight over the union shop.

HONG KONG, March 8 -- A delayed Chinese Communist dispatch that became available here today said epidemics of "such contagious disease as measles, smallpox, influenza, pneumonia and relapsing fever" had broken out in "some areas" of Shantung and Hopeh Provinces in North China and in North Anhwei, abovet the Yangtze River in east-central China.

Erased from the calendar last year because of the coaches' strike, the Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships returned to the boards yesterday and again Boys High demonstrated its superiority. The Red and Black posted 38 points to win the crown for the sixth consecutive time.

Two mild upsets got the fifteenth annual National Invitation college basketball tournament off winging last night at Madison Square Garden, with Louisville and Seton Hall the slight favorites suffering elimination. Dayton, the only choice to prevail, routed N. Y. U., 81 -- 66, after Western Kentucky had conquered Louisville, 62 -- 59, and La Salle had outscored Seton Hall, 80 -- 76.

NEW HAVEN. IT was a chilly day and growing late in New Haven. In less than four hours "Flight Into Egypt," a new drama by a new playwright, George Tabori, would have its first public performance at the Shubert Theatre, and the opening at the Music Box in New York was only two weeks away.

Arnold Schuster, the sharp-eyed clothing salesman whose tip to the police led to the arrest of William Francis (Willie) Sutton, the nation's top bank robber, was shot and killed last night in Brooklyn.

The development of electronic and analytical instruments has opened up a new world. Some of the amazing equipment now used by industry required years of painstaking work to carry it from a mere idea to a planning board, through agonizing laboratory research and testing to a "pilot" model.

ON the basis of a recent and earnestly non-comprehensive survey linking such disparate points as Rego Park, Queens; East Fifty-eighth Street, Manhattan, and Times Square, it can be stated with reasonable certainty that the pedestrian views the 1952 automobile and its driver with no more alarm than usual.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, its chairman, announced today that the Senate Preparedness subcommittee would make an inquiry into the effect on national airpower of the "stretchout" of airplane production President Truman wrote into his budget estimates for the fiscal year 1953.

More and perhaps better speedboat championships are springing up, as growing things should do in the spring. One of the new ambitious plans would put a regatta fixture out near the end of Long Island this August and give the veteran and rugged fraternity of old-style outboard hydroplane dare-devils a race meet to their liking.

THE recorded repertoire is expanding at too rapid a rate. Fortunately, this expansion is not the one of the fat boy in the "Pickwick Papers." It is the kind that befalls the sorcerer's apprentice in Goethe's poem, and therefore, though it may occasionally be disconcerting, it is exciting.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- Casey Stengel, flashing a preponderance of playing talent, gave Eddie Stanky, making his debut as the Cardinals' new skipper, a rather bad time today as the Yankees crushed the Redbirds, 11 to 5, in the season's exhibition inaugural at Al Lang Field before an overflow gathering of 7,211.

The 16-year-old son of an executed former leader of Murder Inc., was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court for illegal possession of a loaded revolver. He was Frank Abbandando of 1060 East Ninety-second Street, Brooklyn. His father, Frank (The Dasher) Abbandando, died in the electric chair at Sing Sing ten years ago for a gang murder.

A STATEMENT in Herbert Asbury's critical review of Lloyd Morris "Incredible New York" has left me angered. I quote: "He (referring to New Yorkers) views with a tolerant and forgiving eye the shenanigans of the John F. Hylans, the Jim Walkers and the Bill O'Dwyers.

Construction, development and exploration costs of United Gas Corporation totaled $113,310,000 in 1951, according to the annual report released yesterday. This was far more than in any previous year and is almost equal to the aggregate expenditures for these purposes in the four preceding years.

I AM writing to correct what I consider to be a misstatement in Peter Quenneil's review of Noel Anna's "Leslie Stephen.'' There Mr. Quennell states that the reputation of Stephen's books has "experienced a slow decline," and includes in his list "The History of English Thought in the Eighteenth Century."

ST. MARGUERITE, Que., March 8 -- Miss Lena Gale, 23-year-old Stowe, Vt., salesgirl, turned in a sparkling performance today, but her victory in the slalom failed to give an Eastern United States team the advantage over a Canadian group in the fourteenth annual international Alpine classic.
Alastair Bradley Martin of Glen Head, L. I., won the national amateur court tennis championship yesterday for the fourth time and for the third in succession.

THERE were 23,000 automobiles in service in the United States fifty years ago when representatives of nine motor clubs met in Chicago to form an organization to promote the general welfare of the motorist. Today there are 52,000,000 motor vehicles licensed in this country and the American Automobile Association, which was established on March 4, 1902, and is celebrating its golden anniversary, has 3,500,000 members.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 8 (UP) -- Catcher Henry House and first baseman Vic Wertz blasted home runs today to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 7-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies in a Grapefruit League opener.

PARIS, March 8 -- The extreme complexity of the French Cabinet crisis has resulted in a growing belief among the party leaders that definite stability cannot be reached without a change in France's present Constitution.
PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- An improved mechanical heart was used successfully on a human being for the first time in America yesterday, Pennsylvania Hospital announced today.
THE NEW YORK TIMES on Feb. 10 and 17 carried letters supporting the Amerika Haus program in Germany and decrying reductions in the program.

NEAR BURMESE BORDER, Northern Thailand, March 8 (AP) -- Chinese Nationalist troops who have taken refuge in northeastern Burma are being supplied regularly through an opium-for-guns smuggling arrangement in Thailand.

CONCORD, N. H., March 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio wound up a Whirlwind three-day tour of New Hampshire tonight at the state capital with the assertion that his campaign in Ohio two years ago would refute the "obvious fallacy" that he could not win next November.

SEOUL, Korea, March 8 (AP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet declared today that the Chinese and Korean Reds had built up a force of about 900,000 men in Korea but that there was no indication of a spring offensive.
PUTTING America on wheels has been a joint enterprise of the automotive and petroleum industries.

WALTHAM, Mass., March 8 -- There was rejoicing in this community this week. It appeared that the Waltham Watch Company, the pioneer manufacturer for which Waltham is famed, finally was emerging from its years of legal and financial difficulties.

Charles Edison, former Democratic Governor of New Jersey, announced yesterday his support of Senator Robert A. Taft for the Republican Presidential nomination as lively contests were forecast in both Republican and Democratic parties in New Jersey's April 15 primary election.

This country's private schools reject the idea of "an easy path from the cradle to the grave" and strive instead to maintain a freedom-loving society that offers "risk, opportunity and a scope for the imagination," Dr. John F. Gummere, chairman of the Secondary Education Board, declared yesterday.

CONCORD, N. H., March 8 -- New Hampshire voters, their ears ringing from last-minute campaign oratory, will go to the polls on Tuesday to conduct the nation's first Presidential primary, with the eyes of the country, if not of the world, upon them.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 -- Officers of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union have recommended that all locals call off a twenty-four-hour coastwise work stoppage scheduled for Monday. They acted in view of unanimous approval by the pension panel of the Wage Stabilization Board of a pension plan negotiated between the union and the Pacific Maritime Association last June.

MORE than 1,700,000 Americans today are enjoying benefits of mobile living and it is this public acceptance of trailer coach homes that has made it a billion-dollar industry. In addition, trailer park construction is increasing at the rate of more than 2,000 new parks a year, with present figures showing about 9,000 parks in the country representing an estimated investment of $200,000,000.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Supreme Court, in upholding the New York Feinberg Law this week, drew even finer the line between what members of the American Communist party can and cannot do.
This is the escapist season at City Hall. Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate are groping through the subway tunnels again looking for a politically painless way out of their transit ills.

Although only eighteen openings exist, 1,000 applications for admission to the Hunter College Elementary School, Sixty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue, have been received so far, Dr. Florence Brumbaugh, principal of the school, announced yesterday. The registration period will close on Saturday.

RICHMOND, Va., March 8 -- The decision of a special three-judge Federal Court upholding the constitutionality of Virginia's law for "separate but equal" schools for White and Negro pupils will be appealed to the United States Supreme Court, it was announced today.

To appreciate March completely one should go away for a time; away to a hospital, say, where neither wind nor weather, sunrise nor moonset, can really penetrate. Then come back to March, and even its temperamental gusts, its snow and sleet and slush and rain are full of wonder.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- A congressional investigator said today a law was needed to stop some producers and processors from putting poorly tested and possibly harmful chemicals into the nation's food supply.

" Parsifal" will be discussed tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. by Dr. Curt Sachs, music historian, in the ninth lectures of a series on Richard Wagner at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The tenth and the last lecture, on "Die Meistersinger," will be next week.

OKLAHOMA CITY -- Oklahoma's contribution to the country's slowly developing system of express toll roads, the eighty-eight-mile Turner Turnpike, is expected to be ready for transcontinental motorists some time in December.

HE term "creeping thyme" usually brings to mind flagstone walks interplanted with some form of this herb. Although these small thymes are widely used for this purpose and with charming effect, there are other places and ways in which they may be planted.

State legislatures plan new laws to guard against the hazards of flammable textiles. This development, it was pointed out last week, will prove disturbing to manufacturers and processors of fabrics who would like to see Federal statutes enacted first, with state laws written in the same vein.
Michael J. Quill threatened without reservation yesterday to call a subway strike if the city's transit system were placed under control of a transit authority.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- The historic wills of seven signers of the Declaration of Independence along with those of other men who helped found this country were put on public display for the first time today as part of the sesquicentennial anniversary of the Philadelphia Bar Association.

With a victory over Eleazar Jimenez of Cuba in 55 moves, Nicolas Rossolimo of France took the lead yesterday in the international masters tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club with a score of 9 -- 2, according to a report from Havana.

THE car pool, an invention of the automobile age that was forcibly made national policy in the early days of World War II, has become a habit with hundreds of thousands of commuters. It has advantages -- companionship, comfort, and a sense of dignity which cannot be maintained on public conveyances.

CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- Feed grains rolled higher for the fifth straight session on the Board of Trade today. It took them a little while to get going, but once they started they rang up gains extending to more than a cent.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- A powerful retail lobby group seeking a so-called "fair trade" law allegedly is using "coercive pressure tactics" on newspapers and magazines in their Campaign, a review of Congressional testimony disclosed today.
DES PLAINES, Ill., March 8 -- The old-timers in Carl Krogh's store looked suspiciously at Leroy Stevens when he walked in. But before he left they bought him a beer.
TORONTO, Ont., March 8 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, catching the play-off fever early, downed the league champion Detroit Red Wings, 6 to 3, tonight before 14,080 National Hockey League fans.
Art patronage by the Government was opposed yesterday by Russell Lynes, assistant editor of Harper's Magazine, at the fifth annual Barnard College Political Council Conference.

IT was the rarest of rare bargains. For the trifling sum of $18,000 Frank Farrell and Big Bill Devery, a couple of ex-bartenders, bought the New York Yankee franchise in the American League. Strictly speaking, it was the Baltimore franchise they purchased for transfer to New York. The mightiest of all baseball dynasties thus was founded.

DURING the last fifteen years there has been a remarkable development in the high schools of the country. Driver education has become an important course of study. In 1932, the number of schools providing this instruction could be counted on the fingers of both hands.

SWEET peas have been cherished annuals for generations. The advent of early-flowering types sees them being grown more widely and with greater assurance of success. In cool climates and coastal areas this flower presents few difficulties as a rule.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Truman's request to Congress this week for a $7,900,000,000 contribution toward strengthening the free world against communism is headed for some drastic legislative pruning unless the Mutual Security Program can be reduced to language that politicians understand.

IT was inevitable that somebody, some day, would get around to tallying the "obscenities" (as Hemingway would call them) in "From Here to Eternity." Dr. Harold L. Morris, a Detroit surgeon, is the man who performed this pathological study, with obvious distaste, and he is now able to report that there are thirty-seven terms not generally used in drawing room conversation, which appear some 1,781 times throughout the book.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., March 8 -- Fairleigh-Dickinson College defeated St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 69 -- 50, tonight to win the District 31 National Association of Intercollegiate Basketball play-off. The Rutherford team will leave tomorrow by plane to represent the district at the national tournament in Kansas City.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 8 -- Republican leaders of twenty-one Midwestern and Rocky Mountain states began work today on a "grass-roots" organizational program aimed at marshalling the farm vote and at writing an effective farm plank for the party's national platform.
ONE of the world's least-known countries, the independent Himalayan kingdom of Nepal, has suddenly become an uneasy bastion of the free world against the creeping encroachment of communism.

AIR FORCE MISSILE TEST CENTER, Cocoa, Fla., March 8 -- This base, which deals in its everyday routine in the language of superlatives and the visions of tomorrow, already has produced -- although it is only half finished -- an imposing array of records.

HARDLY any field of writing seems so receptive to new talent as the mystery novel. In the past two years more than seventy first novels have appeared -- of which relatively few have been followed by seconds and thirds.

BONN, Germany, March 8 - William in Draper Jr., roving Ambassador for the Mutual Security Agency, declared today that the plan for West German sovereignty was tied up in a "package deal" with the plan for West Germany's military and financial contribution to Western defense.

AFTER half a century of road building and surfacing, the United States has not enough good roads for its motor traffic. Almost anywhere one drives today one can see unmistakable evidence of basic defects in the highway system. These defects go back to those hectic years wher we surfaced as quickly as possible the roads we inherited from the horse.

Three thousand student journalists from all parts of the United States and several foreign countries will assemble at Columbia University Thursday for the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.

Senator Ellender of Louisiana has called on Secretary of Agriculture Brannan to raise the level of price supports on cotton above the 90 per cent of parity now in effect. Otherwise, he says, the cotton farmer may not come through with the 28,000,000 acres that the Department of Agriculture has set as a goal for the coming year.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 9 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,183, for Saturday's operations:
My responsibility as a conscientious citizen caused me to read with close attention Cabell Phillips' article "The High Cost of Our Low-Paid Congress" ( Feb. 24).
HAMILTON, Ont., March 8 (AP) -- Bill Mack of Michigan State sped to an easy victory in the Emmett Scarlett Memorial Trophy mile race tonight, showing the way to a field of seventeen.

" SODA SPRINGS, Idaho, June 13, 1903 -- The first automobile to invade Soda Springs rounded the corner at Whitman's store just at sundown Tuesday night, and with a toot that sounded like a young foghorn, whizzed up Dillon Street and stopped at the Indanha Hotel."

ATLANTA, March 8 -- Southern Natural Gas Company sought Federal approval this week of a proposed $76,317,300 construction program which would extend its pipelines to more than fifty new Southeastern cities and increase its delivery capacity to 1,020,000,000 cubic feet daily.

A Republican in Washington said recently: "The Democrats are going to investigate the Democrats right out of office." What he meant was that the investigations of corruption have been marked by sharp conflicts between the Democratic Administration and committees of the Democratic-controlled Congress.

MORE than any other music, improvised jazz depends on recordings. Its popularity, its stylistic development, its very form has been determined by disks. In return it provides a fruitful field for the record industry.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 8 -- The White House implied today that it would give data on specific cases to the Chelf Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives investigating the Department of Justice but remained adamant toward a demand that would involve the surrender of hundreds of thousands of files.
Lovers of Bach, Beethoven and Brahms can now step up and hear the recorded strains of the maestros at large discounts.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 8 -- Without passing judgment on the literary, agricultural, ornithological or meteorological aspects of the above, it can be taken for granted after the events of the past week here that the unknown author was at least a good political reporter.

An exhibit of the products of "leisure-time learning," showing the creative work of students attending the Board of Education's five Youth and Adult Education Centers, is being held at the Sachs Quality Store, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

JOHN S. (BUD) PALMER, who is handling the television play-by-play commentary on the National Invitation Basketball Tournament at Madison Square Garden, should know whereof he speaks. He was an all-America cage star at Princeton University and later captain of the New York Knickerbockers, the local professional team.

" HIGH fidelity" as a term has existed for over fifteen years in the public eye, yet with very few exceptions it has never been heard by the public ear. This unfortunate misnomer has been applied to various equipment and records until it is now a banal expression.

The Wiltwyck School for Boys in Esopus, N. Y., will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Flight Into Egypt," a new play, with Paul Lukas in the leading role, on the night of March 17 at the Music Box Theatre. Mrs. Louis G. Cowan is chairman and Mrs. Paul Friedman, vice chairman, of the benefit committee.

TREES are the backbone of any good landscape picture, whether natural or manmade. Such an important investment surely needs protection. The home gardener who prefers to do as much of his own work as possible can accomplish a certain amount of pruning, spraying, feeding and surgery.

BEFORE the reader opens "I Live Again" his eyes are caught by the American colors, the red, white and blue jacket that frames a head that wears a crown. All the upheavals of humanity that have leveled kingdoms and terrorized people live in that face.

BEETHOVEN considered himself lucky when an orchestra in Paris played one of his complete works. In his time one movement from a symphony apparently represented the total calculated risk a conductor was willing to take in presenting such novel sounds to his audiences.

Scoring four goals in the fourth chukker, the spirited New Mexico Military Institute riders captured the national intercollegiate indoor polo championship last night by halting Princeton, 10 to 8, in the final at the Squadron A. Armory.

TO make the rounds of the theatres in Dallas and Houston is to suspect that the noble idea of stimulating drama from a base on Broadway is not only impractical but supercilious. It cannot he done. For the New York base is out of touch with the manners and intellectual points of view of these communities, and probably of a great many other communities in America as well.

NEW DELHI, March 8 -- The past few months have seen a remarkable improvement in relations between India and the United States. This improvement has been reflected in press comment, speeches by public figures and private conversations, all of which had tended previously to be critical of United States policy, sometimes to an extreme.

Compulsory periodic examination of motorists is an idea that is gaining headway among highway safety experts who are appalled at the volume of accidents despite country-wide efforts to curb the toll of fatalities and injuries. While defects in automobiles can be remedied through established procedures, the human element that involves drivers in disasters has increased and flourished.

THE combination of automobile and airplane, once a cartoonists's pipedreams, is now a tangible reality. The Airphibian, described as a flying car, is scheduled for a demonstration flight at La Guardia Field the middle of this month and will be on display at the International Motor Sports Show at Grand Central Palace from March 29 to April 6.

At the recent meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, Z. W. Bartlett, C. C. Lee and R. H. Feierabend, all of the Freeport Sulphur Company, described a method of mining sulphur in tidewater areas full of brackish or sea water.

Dr. Theodore Brameld of New York University has informed the Red Bank, N. J., Board of Education that he will not cash the check the board sent him for a lecture that was canceled until he received an opportunity to "deliver the lecture from a public school platform."

Engaged in a furious battle for survival in the National Hockey League race for a play-off spot, the New York Rangers oppose the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden tonight The game will mark the final local appearance of the colorful Habitants in regular league campaign and promises to attract a crowd of 15,000 fans.

Red Cross chapters in the New York area will draw attention to the past accomplishments and future needs of the Red Cross Nursing Service during the current 1952 fund-raising campaign by observing on Wednesday the nineteenth anniversary of the birth of Jane A. Delano, its founder.

MIAMI, March 8 -- The Dodgers got off on all their wrong feet today as they opened the exhibition season at Miami Stadium by taking a 5-2 beating from Tommy Holmes' collection of Boston Brave rookies.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Official acknowledgment this week that Secretary of State Dean Acheson had reversed an unfavorable security ruling by his loyalty and security board brought the harsh light of Congressional inquiry once again on the already bruised and battered State Department loyalty-security program.

The art of making records and the business of selling them have had a half-century of ups and downs. The voice and popularity of Enrico Caruso did more than any other factor to give records their first big push, and in the past few years the long-playing disk has opened tremendous new vistas.

ALTHOUGH Americans probably would have become the world's most energetic automobile tourists even if the major oil companies had never launched their free touring information bureaus to encourage gasoline consumption, the service has certainly given added impetus to motoring in this country.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senators opposing President Truman's plan for reorganization of the Internal Revenue Bureau seethed with resentment today over his suggestion that they were more interested in their own political patronage than in clean government.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 8 -- Four years ago in the fateful year of 1948, President Truman was in these sunny parts at this season, pondering the imponderables in the climactic battle of his political career. One can find interesting parallels between then and now.

NEW ORLEANS, March 8 -- Oil Capitol, a speedy thoroughbred when he's in the mood, came from fourth place in the stretch today for a neck victory in the $25,000 added New Orleans handicap, the final and richest event of the Fair Grounds racing season.

HOBOKEN, N. J., March 8 -- A short, stocky man whose youthful face belies his 58 years as he operates the freight elevator on the Holland - America Line's Fifth Street pier here, carries in his wallet, six colorful bits of ribbon and their metal appendages, treasured reminders of four years of service in World War I.

A RULING without precedent in Government procedure -- to the effect that importation of reproductions of foreign stamps in their original colors does not violate Federal law if the stamps have been demonetized and are therefore no longer obligations of the foreign countries which printed them -- has been issued by the Bureau of Customs of the Treasury Department.

Ar the Chicago automobile race on Thanksgiving Day, 1895, one of the entrants, a model built by the pioneering Duryea brothers, Frank and Charles, came to the starting line equipped with the new pneumatic tires for automobiles. Just before the race got under way, a spectator dug a knife into one of the tires.

Religion in modern poetry will be the theme of the spring lecture series, open to the public, sponsored by the Protestant Graduate and Faculty Group of Columbia University. Prof. Stanley Romaine Hopper of Drew Theological Seminary has been invited for the lectureship.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- "That fellow can throw pretty good, Case," drawled Bill Dickey, offering his appraisal of one of the Yankee rookies.

SOMETHING is going to have to be done about the sad state of casting on many of the hour and half-hour drama programs in television. Fine as many of the individual presentations are, too many shows have developed a disconcerting tendency to rely on "type" casting and use a relatively small group of artists over and over again.

How can Dr. Parker, when penning his letter attacking vegetarianism in your issue of Feb. 24, have forgotten the great mind of the late George Bernard Shaw as a foremost example of the fact that vegetarianism is no bar to clear thinking?
WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- The Voice of America told Iron Curtain countries today the United States Government did not endorse Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow's call for an attack on Russia.

TRAFFIC in the city of New York is a complex problem affecting the lives of some eight million people. Some think that Mark Twain's comment about the weather applies to traffic, "Everybody talks about it, but nobody does anything about it."
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Doris III took over the lead in the St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race tonight as a diminishing wind slowed the early pacesetter, the ketch Ticonderoga.

AROUND 1715, one James Brydges, Duke of Chandos. Marquess and Earl of Carnarvon, and Paymaster of His Majesty's Forces, was accused but not convicted of stealing eighteen million pounds from the public treasury.

A bronze plaque will be placed on a private dwelling at 426 Henry Street, Brooklyn, on March 26, to mark the birthplace of Jennie Jerome (later Lady Randolph Churchill), the mother of Winston Churchill, Prime Minister of Great Britain.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- Pennsylvania deadlocked Cornell for second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League with a 76-62 triumph over the Big Red tonight in the second game of a Palestra twin bill. Villanova upset St. Bonaventure, 66 -- 59, in the opener.

The Atomic Energy Commission has awarded to Cyril E. McClellan, at present associated with the Westinghouse Corporation, the sum of $7,500 for a process for which a patent application was filed in December, 1942, and which deals with the separation of isotopes. He is the first applicant whose claim for compensation has been acted on favorably by the commission.

The annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will be held on March 19 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre under the chairmanship of Mrs. Kneeland L. Green. Guests have been requested to bring packages of useful and decorative articles suitable for resale later at the Spence-Chapin Corner Shop at 974 Lexington Avenue to raise funds for the beneficiary.

The premium price that foreign-grown cotton has enjoyed over the American staple since soon after the outbreak of the Korean war is vanishing rapidly. In the last month there has been, a drop of 10 to 15 cents a pound in most foreign markets.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- Charles (Lucky) Luciano, one-time New York vice overlord, was "definitely" behind an international narcotics smuggling ring cracked in San Francisco, a Government official said today.

MILWAUKEE, March 8 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California stepped up today the tempo of his Presidential nomination campaign with criticism of the Democratic Administration for its "failure to provide national leadership."

READJUSTMENT continues to mark business and industrial developments, reflecting both the immediate trend to live off inventories in the consumer goods field, and the "stretch-out" of armament expenditures over a longer period.

Present "lockstep" educational procedures delay the development of critical skills sorely needed in this period of national emergency, Dr. Henry Chauncey, president of the Educational Testing Service, declared recently in his annual report.

A gradual swing away from the liberal arts and humanities is occurring on the American college and university campuses. Greater stress is being placed on the natural and applied sciences, and on professional subjects in general.

An unusual program in which mothers of small children will be able to attend a variety of afternoon courses without being distracted by the problem of hiring baby-sitters is being offered this spring at the City College School of General Studies.

SAIGON, Indo-China, March 8 (AP) -- Vietnam Chief of State, Bao Dai, tried to woo back 1,000 armed dissidents of the Caodaist religious sect and also to win over some Communists by broadening his Cabinet today.

SECAUCUS, N. J., March 8 -- The big boss of Tammany Hall (a local tavern) and owner of one of this town's thirty-five pig farms, 39-year-old Henry B. Krajewski, has come out as the poor man's representative in this year's Presidential election.

A single piece of machinery four stories high, the world's largest crusher, will be built by the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company to process taconite, a low-grade iron ore. It will be used in a plant to be erected at Babbitt, Minn., on the Mesabi range.

The books of the Board of Assessors showing the tentative assessments for the mammoth $9,000,000 Laurelton sewer in Queens will be opened for inspection beginning tomorrow. The total levy covers one of the widest areas of the city ever subject to this type of assessment.

HONG KONG, March 8 (UP) -- Three Canadian nuns, convicted at a Communist mob trial of "murdering" hundreds of Chinese babies in a Canton orphanage, said today the infants had died of disease and starvation.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 8 -- Middlesex County, one of the Democratic strongholds in New Jersey, this week lost the services of a man who has guided its destinies since 1929.
BALTIMORE, March 8 (AP) -- Milwaukee jumped to an early lead, but had to fight off a fourth-quarter rally to beat the New York Knickerbockers, 103 -- 99, tonight.
MESA, Ariz, March 8 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs opened their exhibition season today with a 5-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians' "B" team before 4,000 fans.

Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a relatively narrow range last week and ended the five-day trading period on Friday with net losses of 41 to 60 points. The distant May and July deliveries slipped into new low ground for the season.

NEW YORK CITY'S acute parking problem is second in gravity only to its financial dilemma. The two are closely related and, at the moment, no permanent solution for either is in sight New York is not alone in its delayed discovery that finding a place for all the automobiles that come into the city is an almost insurmountable problem.

MORE nonsense is written about the food-and-population problem than about any other subject that should be treated scientifically. The popular books on this very important matter are full of misstatements, bad reasoning, sentimentality, propaganda and hysterics.

John Patrick Carroll-Abbing, who, faced with the same problem a thousand times multiplied, took homeless boys wandering in alleys and caves of post-war Italy, and by similar techniques gave an army of marauding little gangsters shelter and hope.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 8 -- The Giants' annual spring exhibition campaign against the Cleveland Indians of the American League got under way here this afternoon before an overflow gathering of 6.065 natives and tourists, but with something less than satisfactory results.

NOW that motorists heading south or west have a choice between new turnpikes and the ordinary main roads, questions like these naturally arise: How much time can I save on the pike? Is is worth the toll? What are the facilities along the pikes? What are the advantages and disadvantages of pikes and regular highways?

LOS ANGELES -- This city's growing freeway system, a major boon to the nation's most motor-riding and motor-ridden metropolis, is currently a spaghetti-like tangle of superhighways and pieces thereof, and will undoubtedly confuse tourists as it does the most practiced drivers among Angelenos themselves.

This statement in a wall-label of a newly opened exhibition, "Posters by Painters and Sculptors," at the Museum of Modern Art, explains the show's raison d'etre and its purpose.

Mayor Impellitteri departed yesterday for new Albany conferences on city finances, still upholding as "best" his original $200,000,000 extra revenue plan, including a $100,000,000 county real estate tax and increased state aid. He maintained that his proposals, most of which had been killed at Albany the day before, could still be revived, and said he had no "second best" alternative as yet.
ALBANY, March 8 (AP) -- Albany political writers sang tonight about futile crime investigations, the Republican Presidential deadlock and President Truman's attitude on the 1952 race.

JERSEY CITY, March 8 -- A thirty-one-language testament of democracy will be recorded here Wednesday night at the Jersey City Philharmonic Orchestra's benefit concert for the Crusade for Freedom, a privately financed propaganda organization.

Four hundred Irishmen, including wives and friends, joined last night in the ballroom of the McAlpin Hotel to wish a fellow-Dubliner, Rabbi Theodore Lewis, a hearty "Cead Mile Failthe" (100,000 welcomes).

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 (UP) -- The incomparable Willie Hoppe won his second straight victory in defense of his world three-cushion billiard championship today as turned back Irving Crane, Binghamton, N. Y., 50 -- 33, in forty-four innings.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Based on current collections the "annual revenue from the new gambling tax will be slightly over $9,000,000 instead of the $400,000,000 that members of Congress hoped for when they passed the law last year.
New York lawyers will be urged to act next Tuesday on proposals to end jurisdictional conflict between the National Labor Relations Board and the New York State Labor Relations Board.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A wide covering commercial sponsorship of radio and television network broadcasting of the Republican and Democratic national inventions was made public here today.

IN the six years of his literary life Gore Vidal has had one of the strangest careers ever endured by a young writer of talent. As the 26-year-old author of seven serious novels dealing with a remarkable variety of subjects, he is easily the most precocious, versatile and prolific member of the newest generation of novelists now under 30.

DAHLIAS and cannas are noted for their stunning bloom, which stands out in gardens as well as flower shows in late summer. Further, both may be started indoors during March for earlier bloom outdoors.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senate leaders are planning to bring up for debate within the next ten days a bill to increase the pay of the armed forces in time for the new rates to go into effect in April. Senators are receiving a mounting tide of complaints from the families of service men and, in an election year, such grievances receive particular attention.

Activity continued steady in the wholesale market here last week, resident buying offices reported. Orders and reorders were noted in all departments for summer items. Easter purchasing has been completed and only reorders and fill-ins on specific items will be needed.

AS rural New Hampshire goes to "March meetin'" this Tuesday, a date calculated back in colonial times to fall between winter's last snowstorms and the first mudtime thaws, 223 independent Yankee republics (towns, some say) will fix their attention on local matters like well-holes, white pine blister rust and the annual budget.

LONG before the advent of the automobile the problem of moving horse-drawn and other vehicles in an orderly and safe manner plagued engineers. Detailed studies of accidents to horses, tests of durability of various types of pavements and traffic counts were being made in the nineteenth century.

Reports on mobilization of community resources for rehabilitation of alcoholics will be made by the National Committee on Alcoholism at its sixth annual meeting next Wednesday in the Statler Hotel. The session will be open to the public.

MANILA, March 8 -- Philippine recovery is turning into a success story not paralleled in the Far East. If the Manila share of the $1,019,000,000 Asian aid allotment recommended by President Truman is kept at the present modest level of $32,000,000, it will see this Government well on the way toward economic and military security in 1953.

HANOVER, N. H., March 8 -- With Paul Brandt throwing in 17 points for Columbia, Lu Rossini's basketball team eked out a 58-55 victory over Dartmouth in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game before a near-capacity crowd of 1,800 at Alumni Gymnasium tonight.

" GARDENING for Everyone" will be the theme carried out in four floors of exhibits when the International Flower Show opens at Grand Central Palace, Forty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue, a week from today.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- How French engineering and United States machinery were combined under the Mutual Security Program to make possible the quantity production of a jet fighter plane said to outperform the famed Sabre jet was told today in a routine announcement by the Mutual Security Agency.

THE Colorado mining town of Aspen, which has been the site of a combined music school and festival for the last three summers, will have another double-barreled event of the same kind this year. The school session, which will run for nine weeks, will open on June 30 and the eight-week festival will open June 7.

NEWARK, March 8 -- A first-degree murder verdict against three youths, with mandatory death penalties against two and a recommendation of life imprisonment for one, for the shooting of Special Policeman James Law in a hold-up last Nov. 9 was returned by a County Court jury this afternoon before Judge Joseph F. Conlon.

By a 6-3 decision the Unites States Supreme Court last week upheld the constitutionality of New York State's Feinberg Law. Litigation on this controversial measure began soon after its adoption by the State Legislature in the summer of 1949.

With two messages to Congress and a major radio address, President Truman last week began the great national debate over the Mutual Security appropriation for 1952. Formal Congressional consideration of the President's request for $7,900,000,000 will begin this week.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A degree of optimism was expressed here today that a House subcommittee investigating the Department of Justice would eventually receive department files on specific eases despite President Truman's instructions yesterday to of-date is not to comply with the subcommittee's request for data.

LOOKING to its summer activity, Ballet Theatre has hit on the plan of forming a unit of suitable size and character to make a tour of the summer theatres. A company of thirty, headed by John Kriza, will present three different programs consisting chiefly, but not exclusively, of works by American choreographers, composers and designers.

OF all the things United States visitors in Europe can do and see, there are three which seem to have the greatest appeal year after year. These are (1) listening to a debate during a regular session of Parliament in London; (2) attending a papal audience at the Vatican or the Pope's summer residence; (3) visiting a fashion show staged by one of Paris' world-famous couturiers.

Wischmeier was fatally injured by a truck. Mr. Bliss was the first and Miss Wischmeier the millionth person killed by an automobile in the United States.

"Toll him I'll wait," said Creel to the receptionist, "if he will guarantee that he'll still be editor twenty minutes from now."

IN the half century that the automobile has cast its spell over American life, automobile insurance has risen to a first rank in the fire and casualty insurance world. Fire insurance for other than motor vehicles, once the biggest part of the property insurance business, is now trailing automobile coverage by a big margin.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 9 -- The Communists negotiating at Panmunjom for a truce in Korea renewed today charges that the United Nations had tampered with the political faith of prisoners in South Korean stockades.

MANY listeners who started to collect records in the Thirties arid were weaned on the Weingartner Beethoven and Brahms interpretations, underwent a nostalgic feeling on learning that Columbia is restoring them to circulation.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 8 (AP) -- Four Big Ten indoor track and field records were blasted today, two of them by Illinois in a surge to its second successive team championship.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 8 -- Bob Wheeler's goal with five minutes left gave Brown a 4-3 victory over Princeton in a hard-fought season's finale for both hockey teams today.
BERLIN, March 8 -- Among the troubles beating against it with increased pressure, the East German Communist regime faces a strange dilemma -- the decline of the Sorbs.

OUR recent European holiday, a leisurely three months' meandering in our own car along the highways of England, France and Italy, cost us $4,232.25, excluding purchases of souvenirs. This includes the expense of shipping ourselves and the car across the Atlantic. Eliminating the item for ocean transportation, the cost of the 4,000-mile Continental tour averaged about 68 cents a mile, including meals and hotels, which accounted for the bulk of our spending.

New Hampshire is a small state, any way it is measured. Even if it were flattened out, which no lover of beautiful mountains would consider for a moment, it would still not cover a vast area. Its population is roughly one-third of 1 per cent of the national population.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 8 -- With Chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, J. Edgar Hoover, taking a personal interest in the case, a careful combing of the Rhode Island underworld was launched today by the F. B. I. in connection with yesterday's $100,000 hold-up of the Quonset Point Naval Air Station Credit Union.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 8 -- Hunter Lott of Philadelphia, who has dominated the national squash racquets doubles championship picture for the past decade, and G. Diehl Mateer Jr., also of Philadelphia, began their joint effort to regain the national doubles crown at Greenwich Country Club and Greenwich Field Club today.

MADISON, Wis., March 8 -- Wisconsin's basketball team tonight scored its second major upset of the week, downing Illinois' Big Ten champions, 58 to 48.

SHORTLY before World War I I made my first records in Europe, playing the piano into the acoustic horn for a singer in a group of German lieder. At the time, we thought the results were fabulously true to life. Succeeding years have brought constant improvement in recording techniques until today, amid all the highly touted wonders of ultra-frequencies and dynamic contrasts, the ultimate seems to have been achieved.

PUBLISHED in good time for careful reading and study before the coming spring shooting season of abundant sunlight and long days, Ansel Adams' "Natural-Light Photography" (New York: Morgan Lester, $3), just out, should be read by all photographers seriously concerned about craftsmanship.

THIS year more than one and a half billion dollars will be spent in motels in this country by travelers who have discovered that motels are no longer dens of vice, primitive cabins with outdoor plumbing, or places where "nice" people don't stay.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., March 8 -- A "Cinderella" dog took best of breed tonight in the twentieth specialty of the Cocker Spaniel Club of Long Island. He was the 2-year-old light buff, Ch. Maddie's Vagabond's Return, belonging to Madeline E. Pequet of Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report agreed informally today to recommend a $10,000,000,000 cut in President Truman's $85,444,000,000 budget for the 1953 fiscal year, which begins next July 1.

Government defense planners who had drafted proposals for augmenting sharply the nation's supply of aluminum during the rest of this decade ran into a tide of opposition when they broached their program last week to industry and government groups.

ANNOUNCEMENT of new photographic shows for March include an exhibition of prints by Eugene Atget, the famous French photographer, from the collection of his work owned by Berenice Abbott. The show will continue through March.

But even more satisfactory is to have an enemy write a book which sells by millions, is translated into all civilized tongues, makes its author famous almost overnight -- and attaches to his name doctrines he does not hold and gets him a reputation totally undeserved.
LONDON, March 8 (Reuters) -- Three goals by Jackie Milburn today swept Newcastle United into the semi-finals of the English soccer cup competition, well on the way to repeating last year's triumph.

FRANCONIA, N. H., March 8 -- Edi Mall, Eastern Slopes Ski Club, set a trail record of 2:03.8 for the mile and four-tenths course in the eighteenth annual Hochgebirge downhill race today. Toni Matt held the previous record of 2:05.6, established in 1941 without control gates.

THE Santa Fe Trail, now one of the most traveled highways in this country, originally extending from Independence, Mo., to Santa Fe, N. M., has a history going back to the days of the Spanish conquistadors.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill prohibiting the sale or possession of hypodermic needles and similar instruments used for administering narcotics except on prescription for legitimate medical needs.

BASIC in all discussion of the role of the privately owned automobile, whether in peace or war, is recognition of its increasing utility, passing from the luxury category to that of household necessity and mass transportation medium.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 8 (Reuters) -- Emergency import cuts of 80 per cent in many consumer items were announced by the Government today in a drive to make ends meet in Australia's international trade.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., March 8 -- Mr. Davis acknowledged at his home here today that he had made the recommendation clearing Mr. Clubb "because in my best judgment and conscience he was not a security risk."

HONG KONG, March 8 -- A five-day military exercise involving headquarters practice in coordinating the combined operations of Royal Army, Navy and Air Force units with those of the Hong Kong police force and multiple civil defense agencies was launched here by the British military command on Friday against an "imaginary foe."

A HALF century of motoring in this country will be reviewed by the American -- Automobile Association in a display at the National Antiques Show opening tomorrow at Madison Square Garden and continuing through next Sunday.

ALTHOUGH Broadway press agents don't usually go in for some of the wilder superlatives so frequently flung around, and indiscriminately, by their brother tub-thumpers in the Hollywood halls, there are two stage productions coming for which special dispensation might be in order.

AN interesting new chapter in the annals of cooklore has been jointly written by Katherine Burton and Helmut Ripperger in their "Feast Day Cookbook." This is not just a directive for American eating holidays; it is the story of the feast days of the Christian church, their origin, the various customs with which they are observed in many lands and the traditional foods connected with each occasion.

There are in this country, securities dealers estimate, more than $5,000,000 of Japanese dollar bonds which look all right but, because of certain developments during World War II, are not good delivery in any market. Because interest is not being paid and because they have not been offered for sale, their holders are sometimes ignorant of this fact.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- In an angry inquiry session devoted to typists' chairs, rivets and shoes, House of Representatives investigators accused the military services today of "disgraceful" buying policies.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 8 (AP) -- North Carolina State rallied in the third quarter tonight to beat Duke, 77 -- 68, and win the Southern Conference basketball tournament for the sixth straight year. A sellout crowd of 12,400 watched the Wolfpack clinch a bid to the Eastern National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament to be held here in two weeks.

THE truly amazing quality of the color photography in the factual film "Royal Journey," now at the Embassy Guild, should arouse everyone in picture business to a renewed realization of the boon that movies have in their ability to throw color onto the screen.
MADRID, March 8 -- Unconfirmed reports have been circulating for weeks that nine men said to belong to an anarchist organization were executed in Barcelona Feb. 17.

BESIDES the four tires, spare and steering wheel, cars nowadays are equipped with, and sometimes weighted down by, accessories. There are two kinds: accessories before and after the fact. The fact, of course, is the car itself. The ordinary purchaser of a new car usually wants one that is "stripped" of all extras except a radio and heater.

" We don't want to see a ghetto for the Negro and Puerto Rican populations in the Bronx," said William S. Jackson, executive secretary of the Bronx Branch of the Urban League of Greater New York, who yesterday received the Norma and Murray Hearn Award for distinguished social service at the second annual conference of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University.

THIS is to assure the first twenty-five ladies who will arrive at the Roxy on Tuesday morning that the gifts of Ciro's "Acclaim" perfume they will receive are not regular procedure. They are but one facet of the management's celebration of the theatre's twenty-fifth anniversary.

IT was, apparently, a safe world, a secure world, those last decades of the nineteenth century and the opening one of the twentieth -- especially for little Agnes Barron, born in 1874, in Paris, of Irish parents whose immense fortune came from Mexico.

ARTHUR HONEGGER is a composer best discovered in Europe. In America his name is familiar enough to most musicians, but the same can hardly be said for his music. In Europe he has a large and devoted following and on the occasion of his sixtieth birthday, this March there have been a number of special events in his honor.

Two employes of a trucking concern were arrested here yesterday for the theft of one of their own trucks loaded with $30,000 of coffee, and four grocery men were charged with receiving part of the stolen cargo.

I read with interest the letter of Feb. 17 on "Sharing Newsprint" by Gunnar Leistikow, in which Mr. Leistikow stated that the free press of Western Europe, "to which the United States Government gives so much moral support," is in dire danger because "American importers buy up newsprint at prices with which European consumers cannot compete."

Re Cabell Phillips' "The High Cost of Our Low-Paid Congress" (Feb. 24): I find it impossible to sympathize with the alleged financial plight of Congressmen who in the main have shown little concern for the financial problems of their under-$15,000-a-year fellow-citizens.

The country will spend almost $3 billion on research and development of discoveries during 1952, and more than half will be spent by the Government. About $1,250,000,000 will be financed by all other sources, including institutions, universities, foundations and industry.

After protracted and arduous negotiations lasting far into the morning hours yesterday, French Premier Antoine Pinay succeeded in forming a Cabinet of middle-of-the-road and conservative elements. Whether this Cabinet will stand or disappear into the mists will be determined by the test vote next Tuesday.

Although Santa Claus manages to drive a double tandem team of eight reindeer and deliver all his presents in a single night, his assistants must start their work a whole year ahead. Right after Christmas they set about the design, manufacture and display of next season's wares.
Railroad, oil and television issues set the pace yesterday as the stock market extended gains selectively and closed irregularly higher in the heaviest Saturday trading in seven weeks.

GENEVA, March 8 -- The director of the United States Governments economic activities in Europe reminded the European Governments today that, bad as their troubles were, Western Europe had much to be thankful for.

IN Ovid's legend a King of Cyprus called Pygmalion created a marble statue which came to life and married him. In Mrs. Shelley's romance a scientist called Frankenstein created a mechanical monster which came to life and murdered him. And in plain fact a doctor called Doyle created a private detective who came to life and swallowed him up.

Net profit of Deere Co. and subsidiaries, manufacturers and distributors of machinery and equipment, for the quarter ended Jan. 31, last, amounted to $7,610,611, equal to $2.35 a common share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $3,103,588, or 85c, for the quarter ended Jan. 31, 1951.

The streets of Greenwich Village echoed with gunfire last night as three patrolmen chased and felled a man in front of 23 Jane Street. A few minutes earlier, the police said, he had held up a taxicab driver and had taken his car "to pull a big job."

A NOBLE dish, a rich and savory stew, thus Thackeray extolled Marseille's famous seafood concoction in "The Ballad of Bouillabaisse." And though the English novelist's eleven-stanza poem may not provide the home cook with a workable recipe for preparing this "hotchpotch of all sorts of fish * * * green herbs, red peppers, mussels, saffron, soles, onions, garlic, roach and dace," it does include a timely suggestion.

THE rubles are rolling in merrily in Soviet film box offices these days as millions of Ivans and Nadyas flock to see Tarzan swing from tree to tree, battle the beasts of the jungle, and call his mate with his famous yodel.

The first full week of trading in the securities markets during March, following the bleak record of February, brought an improvement in activity. Prices firmed with the increasing tempo and investment banking enjoyed its best week of business this year.

THE revival in English of Gluck's "Alcestis" last week at the Metropolitan proved to be one of the most distinguished accomplishments of the season. The central reason was Kirsten Flagstad's Alcestis. The role is so remarkably hers, so characteristic of her own artistic personality and temperament, that one wonders why she waited so many years to undertake it.

IN one of the essays and reviews included in Graham Greene's "The Lost Childhood" he makes this arresting observation: "Every creative writer worth our consideration, every writer who can be called in the wide eighteenth-century use of the term a poet, is a victim: a man given over to an obsession."

BALTIMORE, March 8 (UP) -- Damage suits asking more than $500,000 were filed today against Sonja Henie and others connected with her ice review as a result of a grandstand collapse that injured 275 persons. Many more damage cases were expected to be filed next week.

With reference to "Kashmir -- Report on a Coveted Valley" (Feb. 3), its author, Michael James, obviously carried his Pakistani prejudices into the story. See his reference to a coup d'etat by Sheikh Abdullah.

THE Automobile Club of New York goes back to Dec. 15, 1925. When it was organized, bulky traffic control towers stood in the middle of Fifth Avenue; by April, 1929, when the last of these towers, which had been erected in 1920, were removed because they were obstructing traffic, the club had 15,000 members and was even then busy seeking solutions for the pressing traffic problems that confronted New York City's motorists.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- Jack Burke Jr. of Houston had a fourth straight golf tournament conquest almost clinched tonight in the St. Petersburg open. The consistent Texan, playing a near-perfect tune with his irons and putter, toured the 6,233-yard Lakewood Country Club course today in 65, seven under par. That gave him a fifty-four-hole total of 200 and a six-stroke lead with eighteen holes to go.

The University of Pittsburgh, with 99 points, won the Eastern Collegiate swimming championship at New York University's John J. Quigley Memorial pool last night. The Panthers scored six first places mainly on the efforts of Roger Gainsford and Jim Zentgraff, to defeat Rutgers, the defending champions.

JERUSALEM, March 8 -- Israel will press for swift payment of German reparations during the next four, five or six years at the reparations and restitution conference with West Germany that will begin in Brussels sometime between March 17 and 20, Dr. Nahum Goldmann said today.

PERHAPS the golden age of motoring began no longer ago than the opening of the Jersey Turnpike, perhaps its beginning still lies in the future. Certain it is, however, that the adventurous age of motoring already is over. It ended, for all practical purposes, as the whistles and horns blew in the first day of the first year of the Twenties.

ALTHOUGH it has been said often enough not to be true, it is nevertheless true that some of our best talent and vitality have gone into the writing of criticism. A solid witness is herein produced. Charles I. Glicksberg's AMERICAN LITERARY CRITICISM (Hendricks House, $5) is an anthology spanning forty years of analysis and evaluation, beginning with James Huneker's "Literature and Art" (1910) and ending with Lionel Trilling's "Art and Neurosis" (1950).

THE Three A's, by which the American Automobile Association is familiarly known, is a three-headed aggregation of motorists set up at three levels -- local clubs, state associations, and the big national association. The history of the New York State Automobile Association closely parallels that of the national body.

Colored helmets will be introduced soon for civil defense volunteers, to identify them with the particular emergency division to which they belong. This was announced yesterday by the City Office of Civil Defense, which said the insignia on the present white helmets were difficult to see at a distance.

CONCORD, N. H., March 8 -- The gloves are now off in the fight between General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, in the New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign.

Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, told an audience here yesterday that the Federal budget could be cut $10,000,000,000, nearly half of it from the military, without endangering the nation's security.

CAST in much the same pattern as the traditional fairy tale, this is the story of David, a Welsh boy who sets out to find a mysterious inheritance from his grandmother. A musician and the grandson of a musician, David sings and fiddles his way through strange adventures in Eastern Europe (obviously all this happened before the Iron Curtain dropped).

SARASOTA, Fla., March 8 -- Rookie Ralph Brickner and Veterans Maurice McDermott and Randy Gumpert limited the Cincinnati Reds to two hits today as the Boston Red Sox opened their exhibition schedule with a 5-0 victory. It was the first time the Red Sox had beaten a National League rival since the first game of their exhibition schedule in 1950.

PARIS, March 8 -- When General of the Army Eisenhower visited Turkey and Greece this week he found in existence the two largest land armies of NATO in Europe, more than thirty divisions of hardy, well-trained soldiers schooled in the use of standard modern equipment.

TOMORROW "The Johns Hopkins Science Review" celebrates its fourth anniversary as a weekly program on television. (WABD -- Du Mont, 8:30 P. M.). In four years on the animated screens the program has brought into the nation's living room a series of half hour demonstrations of contemporary scientific developments covering the entire alphabet of science from Aeronautics to Zoology.

Not so many years ago only physicians knew what cerebral palsy was. Because of the educational and medical activities of the United Cerebral Palsy Association the term is better known. Yet the process of education has only begun. In cerebral palsy control of some muscles is impaired or lost -- an impairment or loss that affects about seven out of every 100,000 in the population.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 8 -- Miss Mary Lena Faulk, 23-year-old Thomasville, Ga., golfer, won the Florida East Coast women's tournament today for the second straight year.

ALTHOUGH most vegetables are rather sensitive to cold weather, early spring seems to be best suited to the needs of table greens. For the most part, they thrive under conditions that would discourage less hardy plants, and because of rapid growth, they quickly outstrip most weeds.

THE contemporary dilemma of mushrooming demand and diminishing supply is one that troubles conservationists in recorded music as sorely as those in many other fields. If long play disks continue to multiply at their present frantic rate how long can it be before the normally accessible literature of serious music is completely exhausted?

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 8 -- The Brigade of Midshipmen of the United States Naval Academy presented a bronze plaque to the corps of cadets of the United States Military Academy today as a token of friendship and admiration for the corps' record of service to the nation.
GENEVA, March 8 -- It would be foolish exaggeration to say that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization had come of age, but it has at least become an organization.

Like many other types of companies, advertising agencies are haunted with the spectres of inefficient help, rapid turnover in employes and the inability of ecutives to keep pace with the rapidly-changing business scene. The larger agencies, though, have gone to considerable pains in their efforts to eliminate the "bogymen."

CAIRO, March 8 -- Egypt has settled down to a rather restless internal peace under careful control of its young Minister of War and Interior, Mortady al-Maraghy Bey, who saved Alexandria on Jan. 26 from the type of street revolts that took place in Cairo.

Members of the New York chapter of the Knights of Columbus contributed 183 pints yesterday to the American Red Cross Blood Program. The donations were made at the Manhattan Blood Donor Center, 70 West Fortieth Street, in an all-day operation.

MANILA -- The Philippines' tourist industry figuratively if not literally rolled out its best plush carpet a few weeks ago when the cruise liner President Cleveland dropped anchor in Manila Bay for a day-and-a-half visit.

Department store sales continued last week to show unfavorable comparisons with 1951, but merchants were cheerful over the outlook. It was pointed out by trade observers that just a year ago scare buying was in its last flurry and Easter business was near its height.

A VERMONTER himself, Mr. Allen has written his story of South Carolina's Wade Hampton and his Confederate legion with justice and fairness to North and South. Stressing the decency and courage of the soldiers of both sides, he tells a well-paced story of the Brothers' War.

The continuing influence of the Nazis was stressed as a threat to civilization yesterday morning by Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein in a sermon at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- A study of military budgets showed today that the Defense Department had spent $68,300,000,000 in the four peacetime fiscal years through 1950 and in the fiscal year 1951, the first year of the Korean conflict. Its estimated expenditures in the current year are $38,900,000,000.

DOROTHY CARUSO, who was married to Enrico Caruso, the tenor of ever-green memory, in the last years of his life, has written an unconventional autobiography. The book jacket describes it as "impressionistic," and it is a series of sensitive, sharply etched images of moments in her life. Its burden may be fairly described as Mrs. Caruso's search for her essential inner life.

Drs. Stephen Rothman and Calvin J. Dillaha, two dermatologists of the University of Chicago, present in the Journal of Investigative Dermatology preliminary findings of patients treated with cortisone for forms of baldness technically called alopecia areata and alopecia totalis.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 8 -- Heavyweight George Kartalian stamped a sensational finish on the Intercollegiate Boxing Association tournament tonight with a first-round knockout of Virginia's Joe Mehalick to assure Syracuse its fourth successive team championship.

Good news for the drys and bad news for the liquor industry came to light yesterday when it was disclosed that the Bureau of Internal Revenue is resigned to collecting taxes on 34,000,000 fewer gallons of hard liquor this year than last.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., March 8 -- Three hats are in the ring for this city's mayoralty, which is being vacated by Charles H. Martens after thirty-four consecutive years in office. Two Republicans, H. Cecil Berry and William M. McConnell, have filed petitions of candidacy for their party's nomination in the April 15 primary, as has John P. Marinaro for the Democratic nomination.

RICHARD COEUR DE LION; his lovely queen, Berengaria; the chivalrous Saladin and his equally chivalrous nephew; an Irish knight and his blind brother -- these are the romantic figures which people this tale of the Third Crusade.
