OF the four operas available in new recordings two are always with us in the theatre -- Boheme and Aida, while the other two -- Spontini's La Vestale and Purcell's Dido and Aeneas -- turn up only at odd intervals.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Government's check-writing machines will start pouring out $200,000,000 next week in 1952 insurance dividends for about five million veterans and service men.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 8 (UP) -- Four Chilean news men were released by police today after a former Cabinet minister dropped charges of defamation against them.

PERHAPS twenty-two years after Lawrence's death, the last of his camp followers has chronicled the last malicious report of the quarreling red beard and the flying crockery: in any event, the number of recent and forthcoming critical studies indicates that Lawrence's writings are finally being read for their own sake.

The task of recruiting chaplains to serve the New York City Group of the New York Wing of the Civil Air Patrol, which was begun last September, has presented "an acute problem" to the Rev. George Boardman, New York City Group chaplain, he said yesterday.

AN apt student of the game of bridge will learn in his first six months that it is costly to give declarer a ruff-and-discard. Then -- still assuming that he is an apt student -- it may take him ten years to learn that there are times when it is quite profitable to give declarer a ruff-and-discard.

Strange and varied are the wondrous things that can be done with the twenty-six letters of the alphabet. In addition to producing great literature and television scripts, the individual letters can be used to make building blocks for children, distinguish one type of milk from another and speed the flow of critical materials into defense industry.

ALTHOUGH Chestnut is a squirrel, he wears clothes, lives in a house, strays regularly into mischief and in general behaves exactly like any 5-year- old boy you know. For instance, there is the time when, feeling "very happy and very silly," he did everything backward (remember the boy in Ruth Krauss' "The Backward Day"?).

LITTLE more than half a century ago, when the automobile consisted of a one-cylinder horseless carriage built by the Duryea Brothers and driven by them through the streets of Springfield, Mass., sometimes as fast as 5 miles an hour, life in America was comparatively peaceful.

WHY did Europe lag in the development of long-play? When Columbia brought out the long-playing record in the summer of 1948, Europe was in no condition to follow suit. Two more years passed before even one European company made any attempt to introduce the revolutionary innovation.

A GREAT many things besides music have been put on records from a clap of thunder to science, history, the drama, poetry, religion and sports, through a lesson in Serbo-Croatian. You can be tone-dear, not know a C-major chord from a catcher's mitt and still get a lot of fun, instruction and pleasure from records.
A 53-year-old Fire Department Battalion Chief was killed and a lieutenant and three firemen were injured last night when an intense blaze swept a Harlem tenement.

HOW good is television? How bad? This season is a particularly opportune time to take a careful look at the medium which in six years has grown from a novelty to a habit for 50,000,000 people. Most of the big stars whom the public wanted to see have made their TV debuts.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., March 8 -- Playing host to twenty-three New Jersey schools in their new Lavino Fieldhouse, Lawrenceville today captured prep schools honors in the thirty-first annual state swimming meet with 107 points, while Trenton High led the high school division with 85. One national record and four state marks were established.

THIS pleasant book starts with a fine idea. When you reach 50, drop everything and go far away for a year on a second honeymoon. Sell your house and car and life insurance, if necessary. That's what the Musselmans did, and it wasn't easy.

Current food prices have raised the question in the mind of the average housewife: "Why are prices so high? Who is getting the extra pennies, dimes and dollars I push across the store counter daily?" In most cases she places the blame on the closest targets -- the store owner and the food producer, frequently overlooking higher living standards and inflation.

Mr. Toscanini's return to the podium as conductor of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall yesterday evening was another token of the extraordinary vitality and authority of this sovereign musician whose years only seem to increase his power as an interpretive artist.
KLEIN SCHEIDEGG, Switzerland, March 8 (AP) -- All eight occupants of a United States Air Force C-47 that crashed into the Jungfrau peak yesterday are dead, a search party reported here tonight.

TOKYO, March 8 -- A parliamentary row that may reach considerable proportions is now brewing here over the degree of academic freedom and the freedom of speech and the press that will be allowed after Japan again becomes a sovereign and independent nation with the ratification of the San Francisco peace treaty.

Professor Neil P. Bailey (Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute) has made it possible to predict what will happen within such fast machines as aircraft turbines, jet-engine compressors and guided missiles. The theories of classical thermodynamics cannot predict what will happen in a heat-power machine at high speeds because of ever higher temperatures and speeds.

COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY'S Festival of Contemporary American Music, which was allowed to lapse last year, will be revived in April. Due to rising costs, however, it will only be a shadow of its former self. It will last but two days, it will not include an opera and there will be only one public concert.

Five years ago this Wednesday President Truman propounded before a solemn Congress a new and momentous idea in American peacetime foreign policy -- the Truman Doctrine. He said: "We [must be] willing to help free peoples maintain their free institutions and their national integrity against aggressive movements * * *.
Representatives from forty-nine colleges will participate at the annual meeting of the Model United Nations General Assembly to be held at Barnard College, on April 7-9.

RECORD users in the not-too-dim past had one ready remedy for phonograph or disk ailments -- change the needle. At the sound of an unmusical rattle or rasp vigilant music lovers promptly administered new steel needles. It was a nuisance, but it also was a healthy habit.

IT is not easy to spiral upward from the cold water flats and sidewalk society of a city slum. Poverty is predatory, not proud. It is a state of no-privilege from which only the ruthless and tough have a fighting chance to escape. If you want to be the man on top, you learn early to get along with petty crime, the rackets, hoodlum rule. and casual brutality.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 8 -- Crafty Admiral, making his first start since Feb. 16, led all the way today to win the $28,850 Gulfstream Park Handicap at Gulfstream, but had to survive a claim of foul to gain the winner's share.

In a little room on the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the two great bugaboos of old age -- loneliness and a place to live -- are daily reduced to life-size proportions and frequently routed entirely.

ROME, March 8 -- In a speech to Lenten preachers this morning Pope Pius rebuked men of Italian Catholic Action for not heeding the exhortation he addressed to them more than five years ago when he urged them to create "a front as strong as granite" against the rising corruption of social and economic life.

MOST observers agree that installment buying has contributed materially in helping the automobile industry achieve the important position it holds in the nation's economy today. By enabling more families to purchase cars, the installment plan created a demand which stimulated production. Increased production, in turn, led to lowered costs which brought cars within the financial reach of still more families.

Sixteen Girl Scout troops from the Murray Hill and Gramercy Districts held a pre-birthday celebration yesterday at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, birthplace of President Theodore Roosevelt. Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., is honorary president of the Girl Scouts of Greater New York.

NEW PALTZ, N. Y. -- Students, faculty members and year-around residents of this college town are vying with one another in learning how to drive safely. Twenty-eight students of State Teachers College are putting in two hours a week in a twenty-week, non-credit course run on an elective basis.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Spring is always the best time to see the desert country of southern Arizona and parts of New Mexico and California, but not since 1941 has there been the promise of such a spectacularly colorful sight as this year.

WESTERN man has gone there [the tropics] mostly as an exploiter, as a trader, occasionally merely as a traveler and a tourist; but always he has gone weighed down with the burden of his own queer civilization.
ITHACA, March 8 -- Yale's track team defeated Cornell, 61 1/6 to 47 5/6, in their twentieth indoor meeting in Barton Hall tonight.
ITHACA, March 8 -- Yale's track team defeated Cornell, 61 1/6 to 47 5/6, in their twentieth indoor meeting in Barton Hall tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Nathaniel P. Davis, retired Foreign Service officer, recommended to Secretary of State Dean Acheson that Oliver Edmund Clubb be cleared of security charges despite an unfavorable ruling by the State Department's Loyalty and Security Board.
Last week two New Hampshiremen stood on a street corner and watched a political caravan, followed by two busloads of newspapermen, roll through. When it had passed, one said to the other:

THE publishers of this first novel announce on the jacket that the author "has been called 'a new John O'Hara'," but they do not say who called him that. Perhaps this omission is based on the precedent of anonymity set by the Delphic Oracle, but on the other hand, it may indicate an understandable reticence on the part of whoever made the statement, which has little or no basis in fact.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The United States will place sharp travel restrictions on Soviet diplomats and representatives in this country early next week. At or about that time seven other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, who maintain diplomatic missions in Moscow, also will impose travel limitations on the Russians.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 8 -- Dr. James L. Hanley, Superintendent of Schools, said today that the schools would open Monday, even if a teachers' strike began.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 8 -- Dr. James L. Hanley, Superintendent of Schools, said today that the schools would open Monday, even if a teachers' strike began.

A FULL-DRESS review of communism and its effect on the course of world history from 1917 to the present is being attempted by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "The Hoaxters." Dore Schary, studio chief, personally is supervising the picture which is being assembled from factual footage obtained from newsreel, government and other sources in this country and abroad.

By enabling more families to purchase cars, the installment plan created a demand which stimulated production. Increased production, in turn, led to lowered costs which brought cars within the financial reach of still more families.

Sixteen Girl Scout troops from the Murray Hill and Gramercy Districts held a pre-birthday celebration yesterday at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, birthplace of President Theodore Roosevelt. Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., is honorary president of the Girl Scouts of Greater New York.

NEW PALTZ, N. Y. -- Students, faculty members and year-around residents of this college town are vying with one another in learning how to drive safely. Twenty-eight students of State Teachers College are putting in two hours a week in a twenty-week, non-credit course run on an elective basis.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Spring is always the best time to see the desert country of southern Arizona and parts of New Mexico and California, but not since 1941 has there been the promise of such a spectacularly colorful sight as this year.

The Adams, a twenty-three-story apartment hotel, and the adjoining four-story residence at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street have been sold by S. H. Reisner and Michael Gottlieb to Leo Kossove for investment. The deal involved about $2,000,000 and was negotiated by Spear Co., brokers.

CONCORD, N. H., March 9 -- Gov. Sherman Adams, leader of the Eisenhower forces in the state, kept his political sleeves rolled up today during an otherwise relatively quiet hiatus before Tuesday's Presidential primary. The Governor asserted that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio had "hit below the belt" during a three-day campaign tour of the state in search of Republican support for the nomination in July.
A surprise strike of 5,000 engineers, firemen and conductors crippled railroad service in the Midwest yesterday and threatened to tie up other parts of the nation's rail network.

A program for more than $100,000,000 in increased state aid and tax revenues to meet rising city costs for the year starting July 1 won backing yesterday from the Commerce and Industry Association, representing 3,700 concerns. This compared with city pleas to Albany that $200,000,000 would be needed.

Grant Johannesen, who made his first appearance with the Philharmonic-Symphony Saturday evening, played Chopin's Second Piano Concerto. The program, conducted by George Szell, also contained Beethoven's "Leonore" Overture No. 3 and Elgar's "Enigma Variations."

The Canadiens of Montreal saw to it that the Rangers did not get a single goal in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. At the same time, the Flying Frenchmen contrived to beat the Blues often enough to carve out a 2-to-0 triumph.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 (AP) -- Japan's woman star, Miss Masako Katsura, scored her first victory in the world three-cushion billiard tournament today when she defeated Herb Hardt, Chicago, 50 -- 42, in fifty-six innings.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 9 -- The United States and Israeli Governments are negotiating an agreement designed to put the United States on an equal footing with the Soviet Union in importing books, periodicals and newspapers into this country.

BOSTON, Monday, March 10 -- About 1,600 drivers and mechanics of the Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway Company went on strike shortly after midnight today, leaving 350,000 bus riders to seek other means of transportation.

Visitors to the Exhibit of Contemporary Art, which opens today at Ludwig Baumann, might devote some of their attention to the large collection of new furniture and accessories that form settings for the works of art.

A city-wide civil defense exercise will be held the night of April 3, when the city's 579 air raid sirens will blare forth a warning and "atomic bombs" will be dropped in Upper New York Bay and the Bronx. All civil defense forces will be mobilized for the test.

On George Washington's Birthday a conference was organized in the nation's capital by Congressmen O. K. Armstrong and C. J. Kersten on psychological strategy in the cold war. I attended, together with a substantial number of political exiles from countries behind the Iron Curtain.

" Music Talent in Our Schools," a series of seven broadcasts over radio station WQXR, will begin its second year next Sunday. Seventeen pianists and four violinists, all students of high schools in the Metropolitan area, will be heard there on each program from 1:30 to 2 P. M. weekly.

The health of Victor Moore is such that the 76-year-old comedian will have to forego the celebrated role of Alexander Throttlebottom, the vice president no one knows, in "Of Thee I Sing," scheduled to arrive May 1 at the Ziegfeld.

NEW DELHI, India, March 4 (By Airmail) -- New hope for victims of heart and lung diseases that they can lead active and useful lives, without risk of passing the fatal limit of exertion fixed by their condition, is held out by a noted Indian surgeon in a paper presented today before the All-India Association of Physicians, meeting in Hyderabad.

LONDON, March 9 -- Although the specter of the budget, now only two days away, continued last week to haunt the stock markets, the prospect has become less fearsome and the markets have managed to stage a respectable recovery.

The ninth and last performance at the Metropolitan Opera of "Fledermaus" this season took place Saturday evening. Three singers were new to their roles there, although two of them had, along with the conductor, Tibor Kozma, been featured in the company's road production for several months.

There is no such thing as a luxury. That is the advertising man's credo. That's why the butter industry is downright unhappy over the use of the word "butter" to mean something we can do without. Years ago an unknown economist hit on the phrase "guns or butter" to describe the hard choice facing the public in a war economy.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The State Temporary Rent Commission, in its annual report to the Legislature today, denounced the courts for interpreting the emergency rent laws in what it called violation of the intent of the Legislature.
Three fresh-as-spring mother-daughter outfits are offered today through Patterns of The Times.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Lower corporate dividend payments to stockholders coupled with smaller income of farmers contributed to a drop in personal income in January to an annual rate of $257,300,000,000, about $1,300,000,000 below the record high pace of December, 1951.
For the first time since the war, the shipbuilding industry in this country has topped the 100 mark in the number of vessels under construction or contract in a month. This occurred in February.
A new device to replace the Geiger counter in the search for uranium hidden beneath the surface of the earth has been developed by the Atomic Energy Commission.

The League of Composers last night wound up its regular season literally with a musical comedy finale in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art. The work in question was "Boston Baked Beans," a skit to music by Gail Kubik, but most of the program was in a similarly light or "cute" vein.

AMSTERDAM, March 9 -- The stock market was irregular last week, with trading marked by an early fall to just over 3 per cent in the premiums on dollar securities and a slight recovery to 4 per cent before the week-end. The bond market also showed recovery.

March 10 marks the thirty-second anniversary of the installation of the first traffic signal towers in New York City. An achievement of Dr. John A. Harriss, who invented and installed and maintained the towers at his own expense, this innovation in street traffic history is deserving of recognition and public acclaim today, when prevailing chaotic traffic conditions in our city streets present a challenge to the thinking abilities of the authorities.

The murder of Arnold Schuster, the man who spotted Willie Sutton, became immediately one of the most outstanding crimes of our day. The universal sense of shock and outrage was a natural reaction, and it may prove a salutary one. It would be quite unfair at this stage to blame the police in any specific way for what happened.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, created by President Truman last December, formally begins its work of fact-finding at a two-day hearing this week on the need for aid to medical education.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- Although the Cardinals, who already seem to be responding to the exhilirating leadership of Eddie Stanky, turned the tables on the Yankees today to win the second game of their spring series, 3 to 1, the defeat seemed to fall lightly on Casey Stengel.

TOKYO, Monday, March 10 -- United Nations' delegates at Panmunjom bluntly informed the Communists today they did not intend to "sit and listen" to enemy charges of bad faith in the question of a prospective exchange of prisoners in the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Karl R. Bendetsen, Assistant Secretary of the Amy, told leaders of three striking railroad unions tonight that the national interest demanded service without interruption and announced that the government was considering "appropriate action" if the strike continues or spreads.

Many of the personality problems we face in daily life can be relieved by "taking God along with us when we leave church," the Rev. Dr. Ernest R. Palen said yesterday in a sermon at the Middle Collegiate Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.
A student's long-forgotten letter, discovered in an attic after almost half a century, led to a fiftieth anniversary luncheon yesterday of the St. Francis Xavier College class of 1902.

Increasing concern has been voiced in many quarters recently over the conduct of forums and discussions on television. All too often, especially in the heat of an election year, these programs have seemed more concerned with staging a circus or a fight than in calmly exploring an issue or adding to an audience's store of information.

From his vantage point, Thomas Chippendale of St. Martin's Lane must look down with envy at the glamour and fanfare given nowadays to furniture and furniture making, such as the giving over of such a colosseum as Madison Square Garden for the eighth annual National Antiques Show that opens today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, demanded today that the Navy say whether it condoned the shipment of war materials to Communist China just before the Korean war.

CLEVELAND, March 9 -- Following is the text of a joint statement issued here today by heads of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen and the Order of Railway Conductors:
TRENTON, March 9 (AP) -- New Jersey Democrats apparently are leaning toward Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois as their 1952 favorite if President Truman declines to seek re-election.
Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy, senior United Nations truce delegate, said yesterday that the Communists would continue to stall on a Korean armistice until "we force them to come to terms."

" Conquest by Terror: The Story of Satellite Europe," by Leland Stowe, has been scheduled for April 28 publication by Random House. It is a report on Russia's progress in Sovietizing the Eastern European states and a factual "demonstration that the techniques of Communist conquest are applicable to all free nations."
J. Harvie Williams in his interesting letter to THE TIMES postulates a neat political theory that recent trends do not bear out.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The National Civil Service League issued a statement today saying that the public will be "justified in questioning the motives" of every Senator who opposes President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Governor Dewey will ask the Legislature in a special message tomorrow for an appropriation of $250,000 for an engineering survey of bomb shelter needs in congested urban residential areas and the costs of providing for them.

LONDON, March 9 -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of the rebellious left wing of the Labor party, threw down the gauntlet to the party bosses tonight. He said they must accept his policy or go along without him.

Two important events in this week's art program are the Whitney Museum's annual exhibition of sculpture, water-colors and drawings, opening to the public on Thursday, and another annual, opening tomorrow at Portraits, Inc. -- the fifty-second exhibition of the American Society of Miniature Painters.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 9 -- Eight races were squeezed in for the dinghies off the Larchmont Yacht Club today, despite none too much breeze.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 9 (UP) -- Three thousand cheeering students watched a midnight fire destroy a $72,000 academic building at the University of Virginia today and got doused by fire hoses after somebody hit a fireman with a bottle.

Supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft for the Republican President nomination, confident that their candidate is well in sight of his goal, have decided not to embark on any large-scale drive for delegates in New York State.

BONN, Germany, Monday, March 10 -- One-sixth of the West German electorate, voting yesterday in the new state in southwest Germany, displayed strong, but still indecisive opposition to remilitarization.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, announced today that a portion of Christiansted, largest and oldest settlement on the Island of St. Croix in the Virgin Islands, had been designated as the Virgin Islands National Historic Site.

Lack of the kind of machine tools needed to make jet engines, par- ticularly in the automotive industry, is the principal bottleneck in aircraft manufacture, according to Harold R. Boyer, chairman of the Aircraft Production Board. On leave as director of production engineering for General Motors Corporation, he exempts the automotive industry from blame for the situation.

Four residents of New York are among the twelve winners of Rome Prize Fellowships this year, James Kellum Smith, president of the American Academy in Rome, announced here yesterday. The total value of each fellowship is about $3,000, including stipend, travel allowance, free studio and residence at the academy in Rome.
Children of Greenwich Village stepped in yesterday to help keep the Village a traditional haven for the struggling artist.

Pursers and purser-pharmacist mates aboard East Coast cargo and passenger ships have won an increase in basic wages, vacations and welfare benefits, it was learned yesterday. The agreement was reached in long negotiations with owners and operators represented by the American Merchant Institute.

In Washington today a subcommittee of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report, headed by Representative Wright Patman of Texas, begins a fresh exploration into the controversial issue of Treasury-Federal Reserve relations. The question, as Mr. Patman puts it, is whether the Federal Reserve should not go further in the direction of accommodating its policies to those of the Treasury.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, second largest domestic producer of copper, achieved a new high record in sales and production last year, enabling it to increase earnings to the second highest in its history even though taxes absorbed nearly half the company's profits.
Sounds resembling chuckles were heard yesterday over a general din at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels as workmen raced to make everything ready for the opening today of the American Toy Fair.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 9 -- For the 125 teen-agers of the Hempstead High School Symphony Orchestra the customary lunch is a packet of homemade sandwiches and a container of milk, voluntarily downed in ten minutes to make more time to practice together.

CONCORD, N. H., March 9 -- One of the tragedies of the New Hampshire Presidential primary was the sudden disappearance from the campaign of a citizen named Chauncey Himmelman. He decided a week ago Wednesday to present his name to the voters, asking them to write in Himmelman for President.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, his campaigning in New Hampshire's Republican primary ended, declared today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's weakness as a Presidential candidate lay in the many issues on which he has not taken a stand.
ALBANY, March 9 -- Following is the text of the letter delivered today by Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, to Mayor Impellitteri:

Geography has intrigued individuals from earliest times. In fact, much of the history of the world can be traced back to geographical inquisitiveness which led explorers to sail out to find new lands. Not all of those interested in geography went on these expeditions. Some stayed at home but continued to express that interest by doing research in map-making, geography and exploration.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- Warren Giles, the new president of the National League, is a Pleasant man and has a ready and willing smile, but he was deadly serious the other day when he addressed the St. Louis Cardinals in their clubhouse. One of the orders he issued was that the no-fraternizing rule be strictly enforced, even though it had been winked at in the past.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- No more Army recruits from the mainland will be shipped to Hawaii for basic training, Senator Lyndon Johnson, Democrat of Texas, announced today.
Frederick J. Tenuto, a prime suspect in the slaying of Arnold Schuster, once committed a murder as a favor to a friend.

A new convent and retreat home for laywomen was dedicated yesterday afternoon for the Roman Catholic order of Mary Reparatrix at 14 East Twenty-ninth Street Cardinal Spellman officiated. The new building replaced five old brownstone residences used by the order for many years.
CONCORD, N. H., March 9 -- The two "sleepers" in the New Hampshire primary are General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and Harold E. Stassen.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, told Mayor Impellitteri and Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore in a five-hour conference here today that it would be unsound and impractical to give the authority control over New York's deficit-plagued rapid transit system.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 9 -- The dog show of the Saw Mill River Kennel Club at the County Center today, the one without group or best in show competition, had about 10 per cent greater attendance and, with 836 dogs, a slightly smaller entry than a year ago.

A new program, to be called "Presidential Timber," and designed to provide for each of the declared candidates of the two major political parties a chance to present their views to the electorate, will be part of the C. B. S.-TV network coverage of the election beginning on Friday, April 4, at 10:30 P. M.

One fact ought to be made clear at the start in any discussion of the railway stoppage which yesterday morning closed the western lines of the New York Central system and halted yard operations in the St. Louis terminal. This fact is that the public is in no position to judge the basic issues which led to the strike.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- Rosalind Russell, now touring in the play, "Bell, Book and Candle," will return in June to start a new film, her first since "A Woman of Decision," released in 1950. "Never Wave at a WAC" is the title of the picture to be made by Independent Artists, the producing company owned by the star and her husband, Fred Brisson, in association with R. K. O. Radio Pictures.

PARIS, March 9 -- A British proposal to reduce the budget of the European Marshall Plan Council by 60 per cent is being resisted by the French and other Continentals who contend the Council still has important functions in coordinating the European economies even though the Marshall Plan will be wound up next June.

The New York Rovers dropped a 3-2 overtime decision to the Eastern Hockey League's front-running Johnstown (Pa.) Jets yesterday before 4,289 fans. It was the seventh straight setback for the last-place Rovers and the triumph assured the Jets of at least a tie for the title.

The British Labor party is having its troubles these days, thanks to the rebellious, dynamic and rather demagogic Aneurin Bevan. The powerful, monolithic party that took power with a landslide in 1945 had become worn out by 1950 and began cracking at the seams in 1951, when Bevan and two other Ministers resigned and the Tories later came back to power.

The Lasker Goldman Corporation, on a bid of $1,629,235, has been awarded the general contract for the construction of the Junior-Senior High School Building in West Hempstead, L. I., according to Brown's Letters, Inc.
The International Harvester Company has announced that its system of precision control has saved it $10,000,000 in labor and material losses in four years in its twenty-one plants.

MEXICO CITY, March 9 -- The Mexican Government has turned down a new mural it had commissioned from Diego Rivera especially for the forthcoming exhibition of Mexican art in Paris because the painting is too violently pro-Communist and anti-American.

Verdi's "Don Carlo," which was revived at the Metropolitan Opera last season, will have its first performance of the present one during the nineteenth week, which begins next Monday. Set Svanholm will sing his first Admetus in "Alcestis" and Jerome Hines his first Colline in "La Boheme" during the week.
CHICAGO, March 9 -- A much more confident tone prevailed in grain futures the latter part of last week.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Jack Burke kept golf's hottest winning streak alive today by winning the $10,000 St. Petersburg open tournament with a record-shattering 266.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, March 10 (UP) -- The Eighth Army disclosed today that the Fortieth Division, a California National Guard unit, had gone into action on the Korean battle line. The division is holding a sector of the central front south of battered Kumsong.
Six new films, including importations from England, Italy and Austria, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
Purchases of apartment houses by investors formed the bulk of Bronx realty deals reported over the week-end.

Final figures for United States exports of cotton textiles in 1951 show shipments of 807,388,000 square yards, the Textile Export Association of the United States reported over the week-end. Exports last year were the fifth largest in the industry's history, and were exceeded only in 1920, 1947, 1948 and 1949.

A sprawling steel mill in Youngstown, Ohio, lights the sky with eerie color as its furnaces roar. A housewife in Westchester turns the burner of her gas range and prepares the family meal. Each relies on natural gas -- the fuel that may melt copper to a molten fluid, temper steel, or fry the eggs for breakfast.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A Senate Labor subcommittee has approved amendments to ease the Taft-Hartley law for unions in the construction industry, but labor rivalry seems likely to doom the bill.

The Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in a sermon in the cathedral yesterday deplored "the low estate" of the study of the humanities in liberal arts education today. He said this decline indicated "a shocking stage for any civilization to reach -- when things are more important than people."

PARIS, March 9 -- The economic and financial program of Antoine Pinay, Premier, has been received with considerable favor in business circles and on the Paris Bourse because it is based upon favoring free enterprise and because he has promised an amnesty to those who have hidden capital.
TOKYO, Monday, March 10 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,184, for Sunday's operation:

The "eternal significance" of the Gospel of Jesus was stressed in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. W. A. Visser 't Hooft of the Netherlands, who is general secretary of the World Council of Churches.

Recently I listened to the grave disappointment of responsible prospective foster parents eager to adopt a displaced European child but unable under any circumstances to obtain a youngster because there were "too many requests, not enough children."
STE. MARGUERITE, Que., March 9 -- Canadian skiers maintained their lead and won the women's international alpine ski events by placing seven competitors in the first ten in the downhill today.

Sixteen Zionist organizations, in a joint proclamation issued yesterday, called on their combined membership of a million members to support the United Jewish Appeal because it held the "unique and irreplaceable responsibility" to take care of the resettlement and rehabilitation of Israel's record influx of immigrants.

VIENNA, March 9 -- The Russians, who have been complaining bitterly about Austrian opposition to their expansion of Russian-administered former German external assets in East Austria, have begun to interfere with the westward movement of goods across their zonal demarcation line.

Nicola Rossolimo of France had a bye today in the international tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club in the twelfth round, but held first place with a score of 9 -- 2, according to a report from Havana.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 9 -- With a $1,500,000 publicity campaign being planned to encourage the people of the United States to drink more coffee, Brazilians have been shocked to find one of their own official publications decrying its use.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- The average family's grocery bill should drop in the next few months, out there was no way of knowing how much, Government officials said today.

A sharp break in British sterling which carried the spot pound off to $2.78, the official support price, and widened discounts on forwards more than a full cent at the bottom of the decline, jarred an otherwise even market in that unit most of last week. All of the action piled up Friday afternoon after London had closed.

VIENNA, March 9 (AP) -- Vienna reports said today that Rudolph Slansky and a score of other purged Czechoslovak Communist "traitors" recently had been taken to Moscow and there forced to "confess" for a possible mass trial.

FRANCONIA, N. H., March 9 -- The Dartmouth "A" team beat the Dartmouth freshman team by 40 points to win the Hochgebirge ski races today. Edi Mall, winner of yesterday's downhill captured the slalom for a clean sweep.

ZURICH, March 9 -- Swiss concerns engaged in foreign trade recently were warned by authorities here of the serious consequences of the growing practice of "switch" operations in Office of European Economic Cooperation countries because of the scarcity of dollars in Europe.

SEATTLE, Wash., March 9 -- A picture of a Federal Government using "tactical maneuvers," "expansion schemes," and "other practices" with a view not only to controlling the generation and transmission of electric power in the Pacific Northwest but to dictating its end use as well was drawn today by Frank McLaughlin, president of Puget Sound Power and Light Company.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 9 -- President Truman today summoned Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the Air Force, for a two-hour conference on "important matters." The White House would give no hint of the problems discussed.

The start of the National Invitation Tourney at Madison Square Garden before Gotham's largest crowd of the season shared attention with startling developments elsewhere in college basketball over the week-end.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Saturday, Feb. 23, an Associated Press release appeared entitled "Cross Burned at Harvard Outside Negroes' Rooms."

TOKYO, March 9 -- The Japanese Government has shied away from a treaty with Nationalist China closely following the lines of the San Francisco agreement with the United States and has prepared its own draft for submission through the delegation now negotiating in Taipei, it was revealed today.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Truman is a poetry lover. His affection for verse covers a wide field from the classics to nursery rhymes.

LONDON, March 8 -- Although the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is continuing its efforts to bring about a resumption of operations in the Iranian oil industry, no prospects of early success have yet been seen in London.
Fabrics with designs typical of the countries represented are in a new spring collection available through decorators at F. Schumacher Co., 60 West Fortieth Street.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 -- Playing some bad baseball and collecting only eight hits off three Boston pitchers, the Dodgers lost to the Braves again today, 6 -- 2, thereby making no great hit with 9,673 fans at Miami Stadium.

The Christian Church is not just a human fellowship, but "the grip of God upon our hearts," the Rev. Dr. Merrill C. Johnson, New York district superintendent of the Methodist Church, declared in a sermon yesterday. He spoke at the Park Avenue Methodist Church, 106 East Eighty-sixth Street.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 9 -- The Giants made their first home-run of the year today, a wallop over the fence by Monte Irvin. They made their first twin killing with the new combination of Alvin Dark and Davey Williams. They did a lot of hitting and they got some fancy pitching from Jim Hearn.

The American Bureau of Shipping's Medal of Valor has again been awarded, after a nineteen-year interval. This time, the technical classification society will honor Capt. Hendrik Kurt Carlsen, master of the Isbrandtsen Line cargo ship Flying Enterprise, which sank off the English Channel on Jan. 10.

The report of the New York City Park Department entitled "Eighteen Years of Progress" has just reached me. It is a record of remarkable achievement, for which the people owe a debt of gratitude to Commissioner Robert Moses for honest, intelligent and devoted administration of public office.

Whether the killer of young Arnold Schuster, whose tip had led to the arrest of William Francis (Willie) Sutton, was an underworld accomplice of the notorious bank robber or a trigger-happy psychopath with an animus against police informers was a question that puzzled the Police Department yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, March 9 -- The big question in the steel trade last week was "How goes steel?" The answer was inconclusive for a good reason -- no one can know so long as the Government controls distribution.

HAVANA, March 9 -- The American yacht Ticonderoga, a seventy-two foot ketch sailed by John Hertz Jr. of New York, was the first across the finish line in Havana Harbor at 7:36:15 tonight in the nineteenth annual St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race to set a record of 31 hours 36 minutes 15 seconds.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 9 -- Political and military experts of the six European Defense Community nations, who have been working in Paris for more than a year drafting the European army treaty and its annexes, have set the end of the first week in April as the deadline for completing their task.

TOKYO, Monday, March 10 (UP) -- The United States Far East General Headquarters will be moved from downtown Tokyo to the former Japanese War Ministry buildings in the western section of the city, it was learned today. The move, to take place this summer, is to be part of a general shift of United States military facilities to rural areas of Japan.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., asserted today that by a misuse of the lower tax rate on capital gains, textile and other companies were finding it more lucrative to liquidate mills, throwing workers out of jobs, than to continue normally profitable operations and pay regular income taxes.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 9 -- One of the greatest collections of Chinese literature in the western world, the Gest Oriental Library, of which Princeton University became custodian in 1948, will have its first public showing tomorrow.

The publication of the names of relief recipients in Indiana, the state that led the way to Congressional sanctioning of such publication, has accomplished little or nothing, in the judgment of Maurice O. Hunt, administrator of the Indiana Department of Public Welfare.

ROME, March 9 (AP) -- The shrine of Fatima's official newspaper says photographs published as showing the miracle of the "revolving sun" at Fatima, Portugal, in 1917 actually were taken several years later, "during an atmospheric effect at sunset."

BERLIN, March 9 -- One-time Brig. Gen Bernhard Ramcke, Adolf Hitler's best-known paratroop leader, demanded here today that the Western Allies make a "clean sweep" of the past by freeing German war criminals under a general amnesty before there was "any talk" of a West German defense contribution.

LA JOLLA, Calif., March 9 (AP) -- Tom Brown of Berkeley, Calif., seeded sixth, provided an upset in the quarter-finals of the La Jolla Beach and Tennis Club's eleventh annual invitation tournament today.

CAIRO, March 9 -- The 135 persons charged with a variety of crimes, from murder to looting, during the Cairo riots Jan. 26 will come to trial one by one this week before military tribunals. A number of other persons have not been listed for trial as their cases are still being prepared.
A professorial chair in Yiddish Language, Literature and Culture Will be established at Columbia University this fall.

PAUL SMITHS, N. Y., March 9 -- Silas Dunklee, a young school teacher who took the winter off to practice for the Olympic team, today won the National Class A cross-country ski race at Paul Smiths College in 1:30:03.

MADRID, March 9 -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville, issued today a strong denunciation of Protestantism, urged the Spanish people to beware of that "heresy" threatening the Roman Catholic faith and sharply criticized President Truman for his "dislike of the Spanish people."

BONN, Germany, March 8 -- One day last summer the wife of a Protestant minister in a small town in the Taunus mountains near Frankfurt organized a club and called it the Housewives' and Mothers' Club.
Purim -- one of the most festive of Jewish holidays -- begins at sundown tonight and ends at sunset tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- If you have not made out your Federal income tax return yet, relax. You are in distinguished company. Neither has President Truman. And John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, whose Internal Revenue Bureau annually urges taxpayers to get their returns in early, completed his late last week.

In his small East Side studio, Joseph Trovato is already happily engaged in creating an assortment of Easter eggs designed to delight his small-fry patrons. Gaily decorated with the symbols that herald the coming holiday, the oval confections range from four to twelve inches in diameter.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 9 -- "The United States has a vital stake in the economic development of Southeast Asia," Martin W. Wilmington, Instructor in Economics and International Relations at Pace College, New York, said here today.

COLUMBIA, S. C., March 9 (AP) -- Steve Wadiak, All Southern Conference halfback at the University of South Carolina the last two seasons, was killed in an auto accident today. Mr. Wadiak, 24 years old, died in University Hospital at Augusta, Ga., shortly after the car in which he was riding overturned five times.

The Samuel Finley Breese Morse Gold Medal for the encouragement of art has been presented to Peter Dalton, sculptor of Nyack, N. Y., by the National Academy of Design, Lawrence Grant White, president of the academy, announced yesterday.

The cold-blooded killing of Arnold Schuster, Brooklyn clothing salesman whose tip led to the arrest of bank robber William Francis (Willie) Sutton, was described yesterday by United States Attorney Myles J. Lane as a "challenge of the underworld to decent government."

A "National Big Day," aimed at stimulating sales of the State of Israel $500,000,000 Independence Bond Issue, was staged yesterday with rallies over the country, a series of telephone broadcasts from headquarters here, and home visits by volunteer salesmen.

Man can be modern and still be sensibly religious, the Rev. Dr. Bradford E. Gale, minister of the First Church (Unitarian) in Salem, Mass., declared yesterday in a sermon at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

SOESTDIJK, the Netherlands, March 10 -- In her rambling white palace amid the meadows and woodland of the central Netherlands, Queen Juliana is hard at work writing speeches. She will deliver at least six of them during her sixteen-day state visit to the United States next month with her husband, Prince Bernhard.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 10 -- A jury was chosen today to hear the case of five alleged "second string" Communist leaders or former leaders and a party attorney on charges of conspiring to teach the violent overthrow of the Government. It was the first day of the trial.

Thoroughbred racing officials, noting the record-breaking attendance and betting at several winter tracks, gave credit yesterday to the crackdown on bookmakers and increased public confidence in the sport.

A group of Queens and Nassau County civic leaders met with a special subcommittee of the House Committee on Foreign and Interstate Commerce yesterday at the New York headquarters of the Department of Justice, 70 Columbus Avenue, to discuss the low flying of aircraft over Long Island.

The Commodity Exchange was "back in business" yesterday with resumption of trading in hides, restricted to the liquidation of open positions on March 31, 1951, and stopped completely since Oct. 30. Rubber trading was resumed a week ago. Only the relatively inactive metals futures markets are missing from the old list. Tin is still traded spasmodically.
HONG KONG, March 10 -- Communist dispatches reported today medical teams were now being organized throughout Red China to go to Korea to help combat disease among Chinese and North Korean troops.

Gross operating revenues of the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation in 1951 increased to $39,511,000 from $30,862,000 in the preceding year, a gain of 28 per cent, according to the pipeline's annual report forwarded to stockholders yesterday.

HAVANA, March 10 -- Former President Fulgencio Batista ousted President Carlos Prio Socarras today in a coup d'etat similar to the one that made General Batista this island's strong man from 1933 to 1944.
MIAMI, Fla., March 10 -- In the wake of two straight setbacks by the Braves, there were no recriminations by Manager Chuck Dressen and today's three-hour Dodger workout at Miami Stadium was routine.
DALLAS, March 10 (AP) -- James G. Patton, president of the National Farmers Union, today accused the rival Farm Bureau Federation of obstructing legislation beneficial to family farmers.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 10 -- Two convicts who broke out of a Boston jail last night narrowly eluded capture this morning on the Merritt Parkway near here. They fled into the woods when their stolen get-away car was forced to the side of the road by a state policeman.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate's permanent investigating subcommittee was told today that the. United Tanker Corporation, whose officers insist that it is under American control, was a "dummy" organization that really was controlled by Chinese.

Japan's first post-war airline has been termed an outstanding success. Named the Nippon Koku Kabushiki Kaisha, it is also known as the Japan Air Lines Company. It was set up last October to provide air service between key cities on the four main islands.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- The Red Sox, wearing something of a new look, as was their new skipper, Lou Boudreau, who stoutly insisted on directing his forces despite a painfully swollen face, engaged in their first joust of the year with the Yankees today.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 10 -- The Brookmeade Stable's heavily backed Suggested and the Almar Stable's despised outsider, Joi B. ran a dead heat in the sixth and best race at Gulfstream Park today.
HAVANA, March 10 (AP) -- General Batista gave himself the title "Chief of the Revolution."
Mrs. Vincent. R. Impellitteri, speaking as an experienced rider of the subway circuits, gave her opinion yesterday that the fare should be increased.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The United States ordered all Soviet personnel and their families in this country today to stay within a twenty-five-mile radius of Washington and New York, unless they gave advance notice of plans to travel elsewhere.

The Department of Justice is planning to ask for a court order restraining the three railroad brotherhoods which called a strike on the New York Central lines west of Buffalo and halted yard operations in the St. Louis terminal from extending the walkout and directing them to order the 5,000 engineers, firemen and conductors to restore service.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 10 -- Nine jurors were selected in Bergen County Court here today as the trial of Michael Orecchio, former county chief of detectives, began on a thirty-two-count indictment alleging that he permitted bookmakers and dice game operators to operate freely in this area.

Leonard A. Keyes, retired vice president of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., testified yesterday before Surrogate William T. Collins that the late Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, a granddaughter of J. P. Morgan, had not been considered a normal person and should have had a guardian.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson. Democrat of Colorado, expressed the hope on the Senate floor today that the majority leadership would not bring the controversial bill to authorize a start on Universal Military Training to the floor for debate.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Navy said today that some of its major ships-reconversion jobs were being done at Eastern yards because of the inadequate capacity of the West Coast.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association will seek to prevent a small group of colleges from monopolizing the television networks in football this fall by spreading the games on the widest basis possible.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, upheld unanimously today the validity of New York's weight-distance tax on heavy trucks, but recommended an early Court of Appeals review of the 1951 law.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -- The Isbrandtsen Company won a Supreme Court victory today in its fight against freight rate practices of other steamship concerns in the North Atlantic trade.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A band of Hawaiians descended on Washington today to rebuke Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, for having said he was a better American than many persons living in Hawaii.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -- American corporations paid out $750,000,000 in cash dividends in January, Department of Commerce figures indicated today.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, predicted yesterday a "new wave of physical violence" against Protestants in Spain as an aftermath of a pastoral letter issued in Madrid on Sunday by Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Seville.

Cuba has for many years been setting a bad example for Latin-American government. There is no use sugar-coating the Cuban pill. From the dictator, Machado, through "Sergeant" Batista, Grau San Martin, Prio Socarras and now back to Batista, the record is one regime after another characterized by corruption, gangsterism, inefficiency and political favoritism.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- A United Nations body of twelve news experts approved today a "key" first article for a code of ethics for journalists. It calls on newsmen to be "factually" accurate in reporting information and to see that facts are not "wilfully distorted" or "deliberately suppressed."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore testified today that to his best recollection he never had met twenty-five of a list of 100 persons put to him with the suggestion that they had been pro-Communists with whom he had associated.

Prominent women headed by Mrs. Theodore E. Stebbins, chairman, and Mrs. William L. Hanley, vice chairman, and including Mrs. George de Forest Lord and Mrs. Frederick A. O. Schwarz, are aiding in the sale of tickets for the performance of "Jane," with Edna Best and Basil Rathbone in the leading roles, on the night of April 17 at the Coronet Theatre.
WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Tuesday, March 11 (AP) -- A surprise midnight election gave General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower all seven votes in this tiny mountain ski village today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 10 -- Union County Judge Edward C. McGrath today dismissed a charge of opposing enlistment in the military forces against Calvin Detilippis, a veteran of World War I of New Market, N. J., a former employe of the General Motors Corporation plant in near-by Linden.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Canadian Chemical and Cellulose Company, Ltd., of Toronto, applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to sell 1,000,000 shares of common stock of no par value.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -- Senator Tom Connally accused Senator Robert A. Taft today of trying to "buy a few slimy votes" for the Republican Presidential nomination by accusing him and other administration leaders of inviting the Korean war.
Selling in the railroad issues invited realizing in other sections of the stock market yesterday, with the result that the entire list drifted to a lower level.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Department of Defense announced today that in the seven months ended Jan. 31 it had obligated $21,300,000,000 for the procurement of major equipment, supplies and construction. Orders for "hard goods" such as planes, tanks and ships amounted to $17,700,000,000.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger ruled yesterday that the Government would not have to specify evidence in 361 pamphlets, newspapers and books turned over at his direction to the sixteen secondary Communist leaders who will go on trial March 31 for conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government.
PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania today told its stockholders that installing more telephones doesn't necessarily mean higher earnings.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Louis Hollander, president of the State C. I. O. Council, declared today that the C. I. O. would defy the Erwin-Travia bills in the event of their enactment and "spend in abundance to defeat legislators voting for it."

As one of the many organizations concerned with legislative practices at Albany the Women's City Club of New York wishes to congratulate THE NEW YORK TIMES on the way it has focused public attention on the meagerness of the legislative accomplishments so far this session in the light of the previously suggested adjournment date of March 15.

LONDON, March 10 -- In recent weeks Israel not only has heard hints from Cairo that Egypt might like a peace settlement but has received direct although discreet and informal soundings on the subject.

Plans were filed yesterday for the thirty-story office building which the Tishman Realty and Construction Company will erect on the east side of Park Avenue, between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets, at an estimated cost of $5,000,000.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of laws making membership in the Communist party at any time ground for deportation of an alien.

GUATEMALA, March 10 (Reuters) -- The United Fruit Company has reached an agreement with Guatemalan union representatives over back wage claims of 3,700 aid-off employes, but final approval has been delayed until tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Newbold Morris, the Special Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Administration's campaign to clean up corruption in the Federal Government, appointed Morton Baum of New York as his deputy Special Assistant today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A committee of five, made up of representatives from the State Department, the General Services Administration and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will begin negotiations with tin suppliers from abroad tomorrow.

The suburbanite who enjoys his theatre but who is harassed by a midnight milk train after an evening on Broadway has been granted a welcome respite. Sixteen producers have decided to adopt a 7 o'clock curtain on Monday evenings, to become effective Sept. 8.

Vince Martinez, 1511/2 pounds, Paterson, scored a technical knockout over Sal Di Martino, 1511/4, Hartford, Conn., in the feature at the St .Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 1,215 saw Martinez notch his ninth triumph in succession when Referee George Walsh stopped the battle in 2:27 of the sixth of a listed eight-rounder.

The cry for law and order with which former President Fulgencio Batista launched his new coup in Cuba yesterday is a cry that has resounded repeatedly since the downfall of President Gerardo Machado, who ruled dictatorially, in 1933.

The Small Defense Plants Administration, recently formed to help the small business man by putting him in touch with the right agency to get contracts and to save his time, is in danger of going out of business.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -- Harvey M. Matusow of Dayton, Ohio, a former F. B. L informer, said today that Red youth organizations had burned important messages after 1948 in case Congress were to outlaw the Communist party.

The State of Montana received no bids yesterday on an offering of $15,000,000 of veterans' bonus bonds held by the National Voluntary Credit Restraint Committee to be inconsistent with the effort to curb inflationary borrowing during the present period of defense build-up spending.

HANOVER, N. H., March 10 -- There is no honest way of estimating whether General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower or Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio will win the nation's first primary election in New Hampshire tomorrow, and what is worse, there is not even any agreement here on what constitutes victory or defeat.

KEY WEST, March 10 -- In a message notable for its political overtones in a Presidential campaign year, President Truman today warned farmers against "reactionaries" who, he said, wished to slash farm price supports and other Federal agricultural subsidies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- New Zealand's administration of the United Nations trust territory of Western Samoa has been characterized by consistent efforts to frustrate the aspirations and efforts of the population to achieve independence and self-government, the Soviet delegation charged today during the closing phase of the Trusteeship Council's review of the annual report from the territory.

The prospects of the European army project, the keystone of the Western defense plans, have brightened considerably as far as Germany is concerned because of a clear-cut victory scored by the Government coalition in local elections in which German rearmament and German integration into a European community were the main issues.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Acting on behalf of its 2,900 members and 30,000 persons employed by its members, the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., protested today to the Securities and Exchange Commission against that agency's plans for collecting a $50 registration fee from brokers and a "head tax" of $10 for each officer, partner and salesman in a brokerage office.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- In an unusual effort to influence Senate action, Representative Cecil R. King of California, chairman of the House investigation into tax scandals, bid in a nation-wide radio address tonight for approval of President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Traffic was tied up briefly in the Grand Central area at the peak of the morning rush hour traffic because of a fire in the basement of the Bowery Savings Bank, 110 East Forty-second Street. Two employes of the bank were overcome by smoke.
A spring fashion collection that included custom made originals, imports from Paris and a showing by Fontana of Rome was presented yesterday at Bonwit Teller.

First-day attendance of buyers at the American Toy Fair set a new record yesterday with a registration of 3,500. The forty-ninth annual trade exhibit, under the sponsorship of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., Inc., set new records also in number of exhibitors and variety of new products and designs.

MONTREAL, March 10 (Canadian Press) -- C. D. Howe, Minister of Trade, said today that dollars and sterling must be made convertible if North Atlantic countries were to become trading partners as well as military associates.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- In an open challenge to the International Materials Conference, the Republican leadership in the House of Representatives set up four committees today to investigate the authority and effect of what it called this "mysterious, extralegal" organization.

The National Antiques Show, bigger than ever, opened in Madison Square Garden yesterday for a run through Sunday, a day longer than previous annual stands. With more space this year, the show sprawls for formidable disstances, as leg-weary patrons found after a few hours of trying to make the rounds on concrete paving.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 11 -- The Soviet Union has armed or is arming both the North Korean and Chinese forces facing the United Nations in Korea with a wide variety of weapons, the headquarters of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Defense Production Administration announced today that it had approved certificates of necessity for accelerated tax amortizations involving the production of 425,000 short tons of contained nitgrogen. Ten facilities, which are to be built at an estimated cost of $114,534,646, are involved.

KANSAS CITY, March 10 (AP) -- Fairleigh Dickinson College of Rutherford, N. J., was eliminated by Indiana State, 79 -- 72, in the first round of the National Association of Intercollegiate Basketball tournament tonight.

CAIRO, March 18 -- Achmed Hussein, chief of the extremely nationalistic Egyptian Socialist party, went on trial secretly this morning for deliberate efforts to disturb the public peace in his newspapers Isterikiya and Misr al Fatat.

A new American myth is apparently affecting a good many people. The myth is simple. If Senator Taft predicts a solid delegation in his favor from Florida or Oklahoma -- as he has -- and then a sizable number of the delegates turn out to be for Eisenhower, the result is labeled a blow to Eisenhower.
At least twelve deaths in the city last year were caused by carbon tetrachloride a nonflammable chemical used in cleaning fluids, Assistant Health Commissioner Jerome Trichter announced yesterday.
LONDON, March 10 -- Britons learned today how well off they were in 1951. They will know tomorrow how badly off they may be in 1952.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The jail sentences for contempt of court imposed on six lawyers by Federal Judge Harold R. Medina for their tactics in defending eleven Communist leaders in the nine-month New York trial were upheld by the Supreme Court in a 5 to 3 division today.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter President Truman sent today to James G. Patton, president of the National Farmers' Union, on the occasion of that group's golden jubilee celebration at Dallas, Tex.:

Unless the New Hampshire Republicans at their primary today reveal such slight interest in General Eisenhower's willingness to be their Presidential candidate as to damage heavily or doom the drive in his favor, his managers should profit by the lesson in practical politics that Senator Taft taught them in the last two weeks.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -- Dairy industry representatives asked Congress today to lift price controls from all dairy products and said it would result in only "moderate" prices increases.

HANOVER, N. H., March 10 -- The area to watch in the nation's first Presidential primary election of 1952 here tomorrow is Strafford County, in the southeastern part of the state. It has voted the same as the nation in every Presidential election since 1892, when it went against Grover Cleveland.

BUENOS AIRES, March 10 -- Jose G. Espejo, secretary general of the Confederation of Labor, declared today that not a single share of La Prensa was individually owned now. Speaking at the opening meeting of a conference of the confederation's central committee, Senor Espejo indicated that the unions had completely repaid the Government loan for purchase of the newspaper confiscated from its former owners by an act of Congress.

TAMPA, Fla., March 10 -- It would be nice, indeed, if Bill Bevens made a big league comeback with the Cincinnati Reds this season in defiance of the oft-repeated but not always accurate sports axiom: they never come back.

The Port Authority's huge $10,000,000 union motor truck terminal on the lower West Side, use of which has been declining steadily, has been closed "temporarily" pending reorganization of platform operations.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Dewey signed today the controversial Metcalf-Hatch animal research bill to make possible the requisitioning of doomed dogs and cats for use in medical experiments.

New state-wide telephone rates, which will add 25 cents a month to the cost of residential service and 75 cents a month to business service, effective Friday, were approved yesterday for the New York Telephone Company by the State Public Service Commission.

Assurance that the current abundance of oranges will continue through this month has been offered by Miss Dorothy Skinner, representative of the New York Fruit Auction Corporation, who has just returned from a tour of the citrus districts of Florida.

Women shoppers and office workers in the neighborhood of Pennsylvania Station complained yesterday of an unusual number of holes and runs in their nylon stockings. Some suggested that a gas in the midtown atmosphere might be disintegrating the hosiery.
The uptown retail stores are beginning this week to display their imports from abroad. Yesterday morning Henri Bendel led off with a considerable collection from France, Italy and Britain.
Nicholas Rossolimo of France retained a slight lead yesterday with a score of 10 -- 2 in the international tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club according to a report from Havana.
The spring and summer collection of Howard Greer, California designer, who appeared in person, was presented late yesterday afternoon at Jay Thorpe.

Nine major changes in the laws governing the securities industry were proposed yesterday by Edward T. McCormick, president of the New York Curb Exchange, at a hearing held in Federal Court House, Foley Square, by the subcommittee of the House of Representatives Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce now investigating the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Customs, Immigration and Public Health officers were busy from early morning to well after dark yesterday processing 4,704 passengers, who arrived from Europe, the Mediterranean and the Caribbean on nine passenger liners and transports.
Striking Midwest railroad workers ignored an Army back-to-work appeal yesterday and Federal attorneys prepared to seek a court order in Cleveland today to end the tie-up.

All America is watching the New Hampshire primaries today. Here is the first direct test at the ballot box between the two leading candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination; and, rightly or wrongly, the results will be expected to provide some gauge of their respective national strength.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- More than 85 per cent of all farms in the United States now have electric service, Claude R. Wickard, Rural Electrification Administrator, reported today. Addressing 4,000 delegates to the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association's tenth annual meeting here, Mr. Wickard predicted that "within two or three years, if materials are available, the backbone lines to serve every farmer who wants electricity will be in service."

PARIS, March 10 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle refused today to give support to any parliamentary combination and declared that the situation in France now required "a real national union around a man" to revise France's constitution and reorganize the north Atlantic alliance on a global basis.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Dr. Martha M. Eliot, director of the Children's Bureau in the Federal Security Agency, supported today a bill sponsored by Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, that would provide a more comprehensive medical care program for enlisted men's families than the Emergency Maternity and Infant Care Program set up in World War II.

The possibility that the city's ambulance service may be operated by a central agency was seen yesterday when heads of departments concerned met in the office of Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

Navy skippers who once recorded with pride enemy "kills" by having miniature submarines and airplanes painted on their ships are pointing today with equal satisfaction to the growing totals of blood donations made by their crews. These are symbolized on a chart in the Military Sea Transportation Service headquarters in Brooklyn by rows of tiny bottles.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- United States officials watched closely today Gen. Fulgencio Batista's seizure of power in Cuba. But there was no apparent urge to act quickly or drastically in response to the coup.

TRENTON, March 10 -- The New Jersey Legislature returned from recess today to receive twenty bills prepared by the Legislative Commission to study narcotics, which provide severe penalties, including possible life terms, for engaging in the narcotics traffic.
Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday that he "resented" having the name of President Truman brought unnecessarily into the investment banking anti-trust trial in progress at the Federal court here.

Insurance company employes with Geiger counters succeeded on Saturday in locating a small quantity of radium salts, worth $1,000, in a vast garbage dump on Staten Island, where they had been searching for several days. An equal amount is still missing, and the hunt is being continued.
Timed to supply a fresh touch for spring and summer table settings is the new and extensive collection of Hallcraft dinnerware, designed by Eva Zeisel for the Hall China Company.
MADRID, March 10 -- The Roman Catholic Church in Spain severely criticized the Government today for having allowed a later closing time for places of entertainment throughout the nation.

Acetate textile yarns have been reduced to bring the price of fabric components into line with the depressed soft-goods market, it was learned yesterday. Cuts range from 10 to 15 per cent on fine deniers and 3 per cent on the heavier deniers.
By the close of next year all pollution of the city's bathing beaches and adjacent areas by untreated sewage will have ended, the city Board of Health was told yesterday.

BOSTON, March 10 -- Drivers and mechanics of two lines went on strike today in the most widespread bus walkout in New England history. Both groups demand a funded pension plan paid for by the companies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- The Armed Forces Radio Service today announced the addition of a new program, "Way Back Home" designed to bring "everything but the actual smell of home" to military personnel in overseas service.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 10 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Robert Menzies told Australians today that the Government's import-slashing plans would save the country well over half a billion dollars a year. The new controls cut Australia's imports in half. affecting both dollar and sterling products.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 10 -- Voters of New Hampshire tomorrow will mark ballots in the nation's first Presidential preference primary of the 1952 campaign. They will vote not only for candidates for delegates to the national conventions but also to express their preference for candidates seeking the Presidential nomination of the their parties.

TRENTON, March 10 -- State budget bills totaling $212,555,475, an increase of $315,928 above recommendations of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, were offered today to the New Jersey Legislature by the Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee.

Arnold Schuster, whose tip led to the capture of William F. Sutton, the bank robber, in Brooklyn on Feb. 18, was buried yesterday as municipal and private reward offers for arrest and conviction of his killer mounted.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Charges of attempted Treasury Department coercion of the Federal Reserve Board into "rigging the market" for Government securities marked the opening today of a joint Congressional investigation into national monetary policy.

LOS ANGELES, March 10 -- Waist-length Spencer and fencer jackets shared with brief, snug-waisted twenty - two - inch length jackets in suits shown today in the first of the Press Week events sponsored by California fashion creators.
CLEVELAND, March 10 (AP) -- The Continental Press, race and other sports news wire, announced today that it was discontinuing its operations at the close of business Wednesday.

THE inflexibility of the migratory bird regulations under the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has resulted in considerable heated comment from wildfowlers, whose complaints are now augmented by the shorebird enthusiasts who insist that the comeback of the Wilson snipe in several areas justifies an open season in some states.

LONDON, March 10 -- With buyers holding off in view of tomorrow's budget, selling pressure occasioned by the end of the bookkeeping account, bad news from Korea and Australia's import curbs, there were declines in most stock market prices here today.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 10 -- The earthwork here that has withstood nature since the Revolutionary War promised tonight to survive as well against human encroachment.

The Palace Theatre unfolds its latest two-a-day variety today at 2:40 P. M., including such talent as Olsen and Johnson and their comedy revue, Jose Greco and his Spanish Ballet troupe and Jackie Miles, night-club comedian. Altogether fifty-three performers will appear in the program.
ATLANTA, March 10 (UP) -- Tornadoes lashed Louisiana today as the Weather Bureau had forecast. One twister struck squarely in the "target area" of the forecast.

TRENTON, March 10 -- Republican state leaders demurred today to a suggestion from the county chairmen that the organization take a definite stand among the Republican Presidential candidates prior to the April 15 preference primary.

Columbia just about eliminated Cornell from the running in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race last night by easily defeating the Big Red, 67 -- 46, in the Lions' University Hall gymnasium. The setback dropped the Ithacans from a second-place tie with Penn into third place and the best they can do is finish in a first-place tie, a long-shot possibility, indeed.

TORONTO March 10 (Canadian Press) -- Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., and its wholly owned subsidiaries had net earnings in 1951 of $12,997,877, compared with $12,623,833 in 1950, an increase of $374,044.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Admiral William M. Fechteler, Chief of Naval Operations, urged the Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives today to approve authorization of a second aircraft carrier of 60,000 tons and a second submarine to be powered by nuclear fission, as part of the Navy's new building program.

Nothing but a bad performance can deprive the most representative pages of Brahms of the beauty of their subdued coloring and the innate romanticism of the music. And the performance of the C minor trio at the concert of the Musicians Guild last night in Town Hall was delightful, of the highest musicianship, sensitiveness of phase, and admirably adjusted ensemble.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 (UP) -- Although daily newspaper circulation in the United States remained high, thirty-seven morning and Sunday newspapers went out of existence during 1951, according to the eighty-fourth annual Directory of Newspapers and Periodicals published today.
