TOKYO, Tuesday, March 11 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,185, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, the defending champion, brushed aside another challenger for his title tonight when he defeated Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, Calif., 50 -- 37, in the world three-cushion billiard tournament.

THE American Revolution, says Lynn Montross, was fought in "the most temperate age of warfare ever known in modern history." The horrors of the religious wars of the seventeenth century seemed to be outgrown. The horrors of the total wars of the twentieth century would have seemed inconceivable to the men who fought at Saratoga and Cowpens.

La Salle of Philadelphia conquered fourth-seeded St. John's, 51 -- 45, and won the fancy of everyone in attendance at the national invitation collegiate basketball tournament last night at Madison Square Garden. St. Bonaventure, No. 2 on the preferred list, outlasted Western Kentucky, 70 -- 69, and won considerable applause for their efforts.

LOS ANGELES, March 10 -- In a flurry of chronological questions the defense in the Smith Act trial, of fifteen California Communists in Federal district court succeeded today in obtaining admissions of uncertainty about dates in the testimony of the fourth prosecution witness in the six-week proceeding.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 20 to 39 points higher than last Friday.

Holders of I. G. Farbenindustrie internal German securities who have not yet presented claims for validating their holdings must do so by March 31 or run the risk of forfeiting the right of revalidation in the future. Since application has to be made with credit institutions in the area of the German Federal Republic or in West Berlin, it is necessary for unvalidated claims to be presented without delay.
Play in the National invitation basketball tournament will be continued tonight at Madison Square Garden as St. Louis opposes Dayton at 7:45 P. M. and Duquesne meets Holy Cross.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- The schooner Tropicair and its all-girl crew were sighted by the Coast Guard late today after having been unreported for hours in the St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race.

David Evins, shoe designer, presented yesterday his spring and summer collection at an informal showing in the I. Miller Salon, 689 Fifth Avenue. Credited with many "firsts" in shoe designing. Mr. Evins has added substantially to this list in his latest group.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- The Cardinals ended the Braves' spring training streak at two games today, handing the Tribe an 8-5 setback before a crowd of 2,354. Two runs off Murray Wall in the top of the ninth clinched the Red Birds' victory.

After many years with Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., the $10,000,000-a-year Dodge Auto account has gone to Grant Advertising, Inc., Chicago, it was learned yesterday. The Dodge truck account remains with Ross Roy, Inc., Detroit. Dodge is a division of the Chrysler Corporation, which also places Airtemp, Cycleweld and its Stoker division advertising through Grant.
The effects of the events in Cuba on transportation were not pronounced here yesterday.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Republican legislative leaders, seemingly with the approval of Governor Dewey, were considering today a "make-shift" solution for New York City's financial crisis. This followed rejection of a proposal that the city turn its deficit-ridden transit system over to the self-supporting Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 11 (AP) -- The Soviet draft of a proposed treaty with Germany suggested final establishment of Germany's frontiers in accordance with the Potsdam Declaration of 1945 and a pledge by Germany that she would not enter any coalition aimed at any power that had fought against Germany in World War II.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Bills were introduced in the Legislature today to give pension increases to retired public employes in the state pension systems who are receiving less than $1,200 a year.

Spain's contribution to the world's musical culture is far less well known than that of Germany, Italy and France, but the New Music Society demonstrated last night at the Museum of Modern Art that Spain has been, and continues to be, the source of much charming and delicate music.

Everyone knows, of course, that the winter is the best time in which to take a vacation. It is the best time in which to take a winter vacation, at any rate, just as the summer generally is known as the best time for taking a summer vacation.
HAVANA, March 10 (UP) -- Gen. Fulgencio Batista announced the cancellation of the Presidential election set for June 1.

Harry Gross, the bookmaker, refused to testify against his alleged associates in the Police Department because he "did not want to be on the receiving end of bullets," his attorney asserted yesterday in support of the gambler's appeal before the Appellate Division, Second Department, for a reduction in his twelve-year prison sentence. Decision was reserved.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, predicted today that in 1956 the Presidential candidates would be named in state primaries "by the rank and file party members" throughout the country.

An appeal for a relaxation of the Federal curbs on aluminum to permit limited tonnages to be used to develop and test new products in terms of potential markets was sounded yesterday by Edward C. Manix, general sales manager of Nichols Wire and Aluminum Company.

GENEVA, March 10 -- On the desk of every European minister of economic affairs there lie today, if clipping services are functioning properly, four items of news from four different parts of the world, the net effect of which, if such men could follow their reason, would be to make them all close up and go fishing.
HOUSTON, Tex., March 10 -Senator Taft declared here tonight that the main issue between theI Republican party and the Truman/ Democrats was "liberty againstt socialism."
ALBANY, March 10 -- Westchester and Nassau Counties appeared tonight to have won their fight for additional revenues from the Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways, respectively.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 10 -- The Cleveland Indians blanked the Giants, 4 to 0, today. It was the third straight setback for the National League Champions by the club which Manager Al Lopez expects to steal some of the Yankees' thunder in the American League this year.

ST. LOUIS, March 10 -- In contradiction of an earlier witness and of a letter signed by himself, Robert J. Blauner, president of the American Lithofold Corporation, testified today that James P. Finnegan never received any "legal fees" from the company.

After a chase last night in front of Madison Square Garden, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested Arthur Raymond Kimball, 28 years old, of Petersburg, Va., and charged him with murder.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 11 -- The Soviet Government, in identical notes to the United States, Britain and France, submitted last night an outline of a proposed peace treaty for Germany, which it proposed be made the subject of a four-power conference at the earliest moment.

DACCA, East Pakistan, March 10 -- Pakistan has won her first victory over the Communists as a result of an outbreak of violence here from Feb. 21 to 23. Government officials and foreign observers here agree that the bloody riots proved to Pakistan that there is a real Communist threat and that the government has shown that it can handle it, at least on the scale of the trouble that broke out two weeks ago.

Sales and earnings of the Celanese Corporation of America last year failed to reach the record highs established in 1950, mainly because of lower textile operations in the second half of the year. The chemical and plastics divisions, however, attained a high level of production and sales, Harold Blancke, president, told stockholders in the annual report issued yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, March 10 (UP) -- The Los Angeles County sheriff's office and the local press worked together today under a newly established program for speeding news transmission.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, March 11 (AP) -- Allied Sabre jets shot down seven Russian - built Communist MIG's and damaged three yesterday in overcoming the foe's attempts to protect his harassed supply lines.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 10 -- The Providence Teacher's Union, A. F. L., representing about 800 of the city's 1,100 teachers, went on strike this morning, closing most of the city's sixty-six school buildings.

BONN, Germany, March 10 -- Allied officials, particularly those of the United States, expect now that Western Germany's subscription to the European army and her ratification of the contractual agreement abolishing the Occupation Statute will be completed within two months.

We are disappointed that Commissioner Robert Moses has rejected the idea of putting the New York City transit system under the management of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. He remarks that "it must be apparent that the real purpose of any such expansion of the functions of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is to raise rapid transit fares."

A solemn mass of requiem was offered at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning for Charles S. Hand, Manhattan Borough Works Commissioner, former newspaper man and onetime secretary to the late Mayor James J. Walker, who died on Friday at the age of 66. The rites were attended by 1,000 persons.

C. Wright Mills, Associate Professor of Sociology at Columbia University and author of "White Collar," has undertaken to write a new sociological study of American society for Oxford University Press. Tentatively titled "The American Elite," the book will discuss the people who direct policy and exercise power.

Membership rolls of the sixty-seven larger religious bodies in this country increased from 53,397,575 to 85,319,274 in the twenty-four-year period between 1926 and 1950, it was shown yesterday in a statistical report prepared by the Central Department of Research and Survey of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

One hold-up man was killed, another was wounded and a police sergeant suffered a serious bullet wound last night in a pistol battle that followed an attempt to rob a liquor store at 235 East Sixty-ninth Street, near Second Avenue.

Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan voided yesterday a two-year contract between the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, and New York newspaper publishers on the condition that the union return wage gains estimated at $800,000.

A syndicate of investment banking houses headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, Kidder, Peabody Co. and Drexel Co. will place on the market today all of the common stock of Schering Corporation, a pharmaceutical enterprise, which formerly was German-owned and has just been sold at public bidding by the United States Attorney General through the office of the Alien Property Custodian.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Generous precipitation in the Southwest covering the dry areas as well as other sections caused a little selling of wheat early in the session today on the Board of Trade, but the effect of the welcome moisture was unexpectedly small, prices turning strong later.

There has just come to my desk a copy of the rather lengthy statement issued by the national executive committee of the Socialist party of India and published in the Hindustan Times of Feb. 27, reviewing the results of the general elections. This statement, together with news dispatches summarizing the Indian vote, calls attention to certain facts which have been misunderstood or misinterpreted in the United States.

ST. LOUIS, March 11 -- James P. Finnegan, former Collector of Internal Revenue here, took the witness stand today in Federal court and denied that he received $5,000 for representing a St. Louis hotel in a claim against the Government.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- An effort to clarify the status and authority of Newbold Morris, Special Assistant Attorney General in charge of the campaign to clean up corruption in the Federal Government, will be made by the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, announced today.
PARIS, March 11 -- Premier Antoine Pinay's new right-center Cabinet obtained approval from the National Assembly today by a vote of 290 to 101.
BONN, Germany, March 11 -- The Soviet proposal to the Western Allies to negotiate a peace treaty with a united Germany was quickly brushed aside today by West German and Allied leaders.

LONDON, March 11 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler gave Britain today her first nonSocialist budget in the post-war period. It marked a new approach to the solution of the economic problems that have beset this country for the best part of a decade.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, today ordered more Government contracts funneled into New York and twelve other Eastern and Midwestern areas where the defense program has created serious unemployment.

BOSTON, March 11 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins gained undisputed possession of fourth place in the battle for a National Hockey League play-off berth by defeating the league-leading Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 2, at the Garden tonight.

A Harlem grocery store owner, who demonstrated two weeks ago that he was unafraid of hold-up men by chasing three of them away with one shot from his pistol, fatally wounded one of two armed thugs who tried to rob him at 7:30 o'clock last night in his shop at 100 East 117th Street. The dead man's accomplice got away.

A bill pending before the State Legislature is causing a panic in the liquor industry. The proposal to increase the New York City tax on gross sales from one-fifth to one-half of 1 per cent is being termed by wholesalers and importers as a "definite threat to our existence."

Police Commissioner George P. Monoghan called eight policemen to his office yesterday morning to compliment them for their shooting and bravery in two incidents in the last week that resulted in the killing of one armed robber and the wounding of two others.
LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- Johnny Williams won the British national and Empire heavyweight titles tonight by outpointing Jack Gardner in fifteen rounds.

ALBANY, March 11 -- A bill designed to strip W. Kingsland Macy, former Republican chairman of Suffolk County, of his last source of local political patronage received final legislative approval in the Senate today. It now goes to Governor Dewey for his approval.

Richard F. Weil Jr., vice president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., and president of Macy's New York, is relinquishing his duties and titles with the latter organization, effective at once, it was announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of the corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Office of Price Stabilization will hand to a steel industry committee tomorrow for its comments a proposed regulation for raising steel prices under the Capehart Amendment to the Defense Production Act.

Forty-six aliens, who entered this country illegally as stowaways or ship-jumpers or who have proved undesirable for other reasons, were deported yesterday by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

Prompted by Foreign Minister Chou En-lai, the Peiping radio is charging that between Feb. 25 and March 5 nearly 450 American planes dropped infected animals and insects in Korea, Manchuria and some northern Chinese provinces and thus started epidemics of measles, smallpox, influenza, pneumonia, relapsing fever and bubonic plague.

HONG KONG, March 11 -- The thirty-one man "comfort mission" appointed by the Chinese Communists in Canton to visit Hong Kong to "comfort" the Chinese victims of a squatters' settlement fire has announced cancellation of its projected trip to this British colony.

With four of their remaining six games booked for local ice, the New York Rangers will seek to regain their winning touch at home when they skate against the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League battle tonight at Madison Square Garden.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that employment in its United States plants decreased in the second half of 1951 "because of government curtailment of automobile and truck production."

Joseph H. McConnell, general chairman of the Salvation Army's 1952 appeal, reported yesterday that a total of $550,933 had been collected so far in this city. The goal for the campaign, wihch is scheduled to end April 1, is $1,250,000.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- Federal Judge Edward A. Tamm acquitted Rocco Fischetti of Chicago today of contempt-of-Congress charges that arose from his refusal to answer questions before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.
Traina Norell's spring collection was presented yesterday by Saks Fifth Avenue in the Waldorf-Astoria's Starlight Roof.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Half a million papers, letters and documents once held by the late President William Howard Taft and other members of the Taft family have been presented to the Library of Congress, the library announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 11 -- Yale's unpredictable basketball forces salvaged some balm from a disappointing campaign by upsetting Pennsylvania tonight, 91-64, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League clash.

Volume in the No. 6 domestic sugar contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange set a record for the second time in a week yesterday, at 92,150 tons, the highest since Sept. 27, 1949. Last Friday the volume was 61,600 tons.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 -- Beautiful fabrics with accent on surface interest or texture, on newness of design, on washability, sanforizing, and resistance to wrinkling stand out as much as do the fashions themselves in the late spring and summer dresses and play wear shown here today.

No reader can fail to appreciate the deep sincerity of your editorials of March 6 and 8 on the House of Representatives and the U. M. T. bill, but I believe they need some additions to present that whole story to which the real majority of the House is entitled on this issue.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Formation of a joint state-city commission to formulate a long-range solution for New York City's recurring fiscal problems may be proposed tomorrow when Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and Mayor Impellitteri resume their discussions of stop-gap measures to tide the city over its immediate crisis.

Continued substantial growth in volume of production, manufacture and sales during 1951, accompanied by a generally stable price structure, brought gross and net earnings of the Skelly Oil Company above the previous year, the thirty-second annual report showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Dr. Luis Machado, Cuban Ambassador to the United States for the last year and a half, said today he had declined an offer to continue representing his country under the Batista revolutionary regime.

One of the country's most frequently decorated ship masters, Commodore Harry Manning, has been appointed to command the 990-foot superliner United States, John M. Franklin, president of the United States Lines, announced here yesterday.

"Golden Boy," the third offering in the American National Theatre and Academy's series of five plays, will be presented at 8 o'clock this evening at the ANTA Playhouse under the supervision of Robert Whitehead, managing director.

LONDON, March 11 -- For the average British family what the new Conservative budget has done is to shift some of the burden from the taxpaying head of the household to the housewife who pays the daily bills.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 11 (AP) -- Premier Marshal Tito said today the Soviet Union had been arming its satellite countries in Eastern Europe with jet planes in recent months.

EDMONTON, Alta., March 11 (AP) -- The Rev. Anthony Petrin, a Roman Catholic missionary who got lost while seeking help for his downed church plane, was found tonight only a quarter mile from where the plane landed.

TRENTON, March 11 -- A special Federal grand jury here investigating rackets in Bergen County returned indictments today for income tax irregularities against a former assistant prosecutor and a man identified as "a well-known gambler."

Ivan Alexandrovich Filippov, Pravda's senior correspondent in this country, was in a quandary yesterday. Would he or would he not be allowed to continue his extensive travels throughout the United States, which have provided the basis for much of his reportage these past two years?

The schools of Farmingdale, L. I., were forced to close yesterday because of an unusually high number of pupil absences that were attributed to respiratory illnesses. In other sections of the metropolitan area the situation was reported as ranging from normal to "serious," but no danger of a virus or influenza epidemic was seen. Absenteeism in the city's schools was said to be "not unusual for this time of year."

LONDON, March 11 -- The fact that the Moscow radio immediately broadcast the text of the Soviet note to the Western powers urging the quick conclusion of a German peace treaty indicated that it was probably more a propaganda move than an effort to reach an agreement, diplomatic circles here observed today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- In commemoration of the ninety-fifth anniversary of the founding of the New York Infirmary, 321 East Fifteenth, Street, New York, and to honor its founder, Dr. Elizabeth Blackwell, Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat of New York, introduced today a bill for a commemorative five-cent stamp in her honor. Dr. Blackwell founded the hospital in May, 1857.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Navy reported today it had developed a guided missile that could seek out and destroy an enemy plane three to four miles away.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Determined to get to the bottom of "bad faith" charges by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, against the Federal Reserve Board, joint Congressional committee investigating monetary policy called today for all documents bearing on the inter-agency feud.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A minority report of the Senate Committee on Government Operations declared today that reorganization of the Bureau of Internal Revenue was "the cornerstone of the current drive to eliminate corruption and inefficiency from Federal tax administration."

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, offered a resolution today to the Senate Foreign Relations committee to invite General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to testify before it in relation to the $7,900,000,000 foreign aid bill.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Senate approved by 33 to 21 today a bill that would permit voters to express their preferences for Presidential candidates when they ballot April 22 for delegates to the national nominating conventions.

MEXICO CITY, March 11 -- Diego Rivera, who revels in the controversy surrounding his painting, rejected today as "improper" and "puerile" the official reasons given for excluding his new mural from the Paris exhibition of Mexican art to be sponsored by the Mexican Government late this spring.

Total assets of the New York Life Insurance Company topped the $5,000,000,000 mark for the first time last year. At the close of 1951 the nation's third largest insurance concern reported assets of $5,092,877,631, compared with $4,907,729,002 at the end of 1950.

LONDON, March 11 -- The stock markets were almost idle today while awaiting details of the budget, which were not announced until after the Exchange closed. Prices again tended to drift lower during the morning but recovered and generally closed steady at or around yesterday's levels.
S. Arnold Witte has been appointed manager of the legislative division of the Government Affairs Department of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 11 -- Meeting record crop goals in 1952 will no more than enable the United States to hold its own on the food production line, a Federal agriculture official warned today.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 11 -- A major effort to bring General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower home and put Paul G. Hoffman, former Marshall Plan chief, in charge of his campaign developed tonight in the wake of the New Hampshire primary election.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- On the eve of the date marking the entry into their fiftieth campaign in the American League, the Yankees tonight annouced the results of a poll naming the greatest players in the club's history.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Dan A. Kimball, Secretary of the Navy, denied today that the Navy ever "approved" leasing of United States tankers to Soviet interest for hauling oil to Communist China in I949-50.
A lower court injunction that restrained the city from barring trucks more than thirty-three feet long from the Washington Market area was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division.

DALLAS, March 11 (AP) -- James G. Patton was assured another term as president of the National Farmers Union when he was re-nominated today without opposition. The formal election is tomorrow. The 50-year-old Denver man has been president of the organization since 1940.
The cotton futures market was moderately active yesterday and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 8 to 32 points net higher than on Monday.
A thermostat-controlled record player that automatically calls down to the landlord when the upstairs apartment gets too cold convulsed 200 spectators in a Brooklyn court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- Representative Carl Vinson said today the House Armed Services Committee would order the Navy to parcel its new $1,144,883,000 shipbuilding program fairly among naval yards on the East, Gulf and West Coasts.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A Senate investigator was sent to New Hampshire today to look into reports that scurrilous literature had been circulated in the Presidential primary campaigns there.

PATERSON, N. J., March 11 (AP) -- Four small children were killed tonight in a fire that swept through two apartments of a frame building at 27-29 Peach Street. Fire Chief G. Hobart Strathearn said the blaze apparently was started by youngsters playing with matches.
Deputy Foreign Minister Jacob A. Malik of the Soviet Union arrived here yesterday and confided to newspapermen that he liked snow better than rain and Moscow better than Paris.

SEOUL, Wednesday, March 12 (AP) -- Allied planes dealt a knock-out blow yesterday to a large Red base only thirty miles from the truce town of Panmunjom, leaving it in a sea of flames. More than 200 planes poured flaming jellied gasoline, bombs and machine-gun fire on the sprawling base near Sinmak.

TORONTO, March 11 -- International commodity arrangements, as proposed in a recent report of the United Nations on "Measures for International Economic Stability," would be contrary to the historic attitude of the United States toward open competition and monopolies, Felix E. Wormser, vice president of the St. Joseph Lead Company, declared here tonight.

THE catch records seem to have been tumbling at Bimini this season, especially on blue marlin, but the bonefish specialists will be interested in the score rung up last Friday, when one angler took thirty-one of these scrappers, the largest an 8-pounder.
HAVANA, March 11 -- Cuba returned slowly to normal today as Gen. Fulgencio Batista, who yesterday overthrew the Prio Socarras Administration in a swift coup, organized his Government.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- The Cardinals made it two straight over the Braves today, winning, 3 to 0, behind the two-hit pitching of Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell, Kurt Krieger and Will Schmidt.
A young man is dead, killed in gangland fashion, presumably because he recognized Willie Sutton and reported the robber's whereabouts to authorities.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 11 -- Ted Williams was stretched out on the rubbing table in the Red Sox clubhouse, dozing peacefully away. This tourist, going from the bright sunshine into the shadows of the clubhouse, did not see him in the deserted room. Suddenly there was a wild whoop as the long, lean figure of the Boston slugger bounced off the table, a big grin on his face and hand outstretched in welcome.
Erratic March played one of its pranks on the city yesterday.

A father and his two sons who had pleaded guilty to collecting $2,184 in unemployment insurance funds while they worked as longshoremen were sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to workhouse terms up to ninety days.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt of Durham, N. C., posted a 68 today to win low pro honors in the annual pro-amateur golf tournament at La Gorce Country Club. Two foursomes tied for team honors with 58's.

MIAMI, March 11 (AP) -- Max Kahlbaum's Miss Tinka, a 4-year-old daughter of Heliopolis, had all the speed in the Orange Blossom Purse at Gulfstream Park today and won over seven other fillies and mares with only mild urging by Jockey Lee Harris.
LONDON, March 11 -- Two million Britons heard today the sort of good news that taxpayers everywhere like to get -- news that they will be exempted from income tax.

Spokesmen for the laboratories of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., sole manufacturer of the nylon used in women's stockings, reported from Wilmington, Del., yesterday that under special weather conditions soot in the city streets could disintegrate nylon hosiery.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Newbold Morris, the Truman Administration's special investigator of corruption in government, denounced today the laws that permitted fast, huge profits in surplus ship deals and told the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee that when he finished his job here Congress would get legislation designed to "correct" them.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- The Fifth Biennial National Plastics Exposition, a five-day show under the sponsorship of the Society of the Plastics Industry, Inc., opened this afternoon at Convention Hall.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 11 -- Mansfied D. Sprague, speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives, resigned today as state chairman of the Connecticut Republican faction supporting Gen. of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidential nomination.

The exciting race in the New Hampshire Presidential primary must strengthen the conviction of General Eisenhower's supporters that their candidate has much vote-getting ability in the face of tremendous odds. It must also bolster their determination to fight harder than ever to make sure that the Republican nomination not be lost to Senator Taft by default.

The American Bach Society came into its own last night, for its fourth public concert at Town Hall fulfilled the promise that the intelligent, enthusiastic and serious group has never quite been able to live up to before.

Securities underwriters are occupied with the marketing of new issues of public utility securities totaling $88,800,000. Banking syndicates will place on the market today three new issues of bonds and common stock totaling $37,000,000.

HAVANA, March 11 -- Trophies were awarded today at the International Yacht Club in Havana Harbor to the winning yachts of the nineteenth St. Petersburg to Havana yacht race despite confusion caused by the swift coup with which Gen. Fulgencio Batista overthrew the Prio Sacarras Administration.
MIAMI, Fla., March 11 -- Gathering all his Dodger players in the Miami Stadium clubhouse before today's workout, Manager Charley Dressen gave the little speech he had planned to make some time ago.
Production of raw steel by domestic mills in February amounted to 8,645,000 net tons, the greatest amount ever achieved in that short month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The rising costs of medical education have placed the medical schools of this country in a precarious financial position, a noted medical educator told the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation today.

BOSTON, March 11 -- The deadline for the filing of candidacies for delegate and alternate from Massachusetts to the national conventions was reached at 5 P. M. today, with 333 seeking 210 available places.

Public clamor for capture of the killer, or killers, of Arnold Schuster, who gave the tip that led to the arrest of William F. Sutton, the bank robber, goaded the city police yesterday, but they seemed nowhere near an arrest in the case.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performances of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet on March 27 at the Warner Theatre and "Don Juan in Hell" on April 1 at the Plymouth Theatre, which have been taken over to raise funds for the Vocational Advisory Service.

DETROIT, March 11 -- A staff member of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., told the Committee on Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives today that no more than 175 Communists, with the help of 2,000 sympathizers, controlled the union's largest local, representing 50,000 Ford Motor Company employes at the River Rouge plant.

LONDON, March 11 -- Information was received here tonight that the North Atlantic Council Deputies were thinking of offering the post of secretary general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to Gen. Lord Ismay, British Secretary for Commonwealth Relations.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- Harold L. Ickes, who died Feb. 3, left an estate of $80,048 in personal property plus valuable real estate in Illinois, his will showed today.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The state's sixty-six-year ban on the manufacture and sale of yellow oleo-margarine will end on July 1.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 11 -- Bergen County was pictured today as a gamblers' paradise between 1947 and 1950, when Michael Orecchio was chief of detectives in the office of Prosecutor Walter G. Winne. This characterization was given by Deputy Attorney General David Harris as the prosecution opened its case against the former official, who is on trial here for failing to act on gambling complaints.

GUATEMALA, March 10 (Reuters) -- Employes of the United Fruit Company's Pacific Coast banana plantations today ratified an agreement signed by the company and the union attorneys, ending a six-month dispute which had imperiled the company's multi-million-dollar Guatemalan holdings.

Following up a similar move by their East-German puppets a month ago, the Soviets have now issued a formal call for a new four-Power conference to reunite Germany under one Government and to draft a German peace treaty for submission to a larger conference of all interested states, including Germany.

SALSBURG, Austria, March 11 -- Over Heinz Silomon's objection that his confession had been obtained under duress, his statement that he had supplied the Czechoslovak Intelligence Service for three years with information about United States military affairs in Austria was read today before the United States Civil Affairs Court which is trying him for espionage.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The John K. Fairbank, Professor of History at Harvard University, today accused the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, of which Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada is chairman, of employing procedures similar to those used by the Communist Russians.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- The Government has tracked down some "clandestine" radio stations in the Western Hemisphere operated by foreign intelligence agents.
The status of the Midwest railroad strike remained muddled early today.

A message of congratulations from President Truman and the visit of Dame Leslie Whateley, director of the World Bureau of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts, marked the start yesterday of the nation-wide Girl Scout organization's fortieth birthday observance.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- The House passed a bill today that would force the Executive Branch of the Government to make available to Congress information on all persons employed in the future by certain Government agencies.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Assembly today approved inclusion in the state highway system of a new highway passing from Elmsford through White Plains to Rye, over the opposition of two Republican Assemblymen from Westchester. The bill now goes to Governor Dewey.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The issue of compulsory automobile inspection was revived today when the Senate Finance Committee reported out favorably a bill introduced by Senator Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens, that would require semi-annual inspections at state-operated stations.

"Here Comes the Band," a recorded radio series featuring famous brass bands in each of the free countries of Western Europe, will make its debut over WJZ on Sunday from 12 noon to 12:30 P. M. The Grenadier Guards of England will be heard on the initial broadcast.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -The United States challenged the Soviet Union tonight to prove it wanted a treaty with a unified Germany by allowing a United Nations Commission to supervise an all-German free election.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Wednesday, March 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower early today had captured the nation's first Presidential primary by taking both the Republican popularity and delegate tests from Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Pope Pius XII has expressed confidence that American Roman Catholic "will respond with ready generosity" to the $5,000,000 appeal of the Bishop Fund for war victims. The drive will begin March 16, and end on Laetare Sunday, March 23.

Proceedings at Carnegie Hall last night were comfortably familiar. Eugene Ormandy was back at the head of his Philadelphia Orchestra after giving way to guest conductors, at least in New York, during the past two months. Nathan Milstein was the violin soloist, and the program was all Brahms.

PITTSBURGH, March 11 -- The nation's casualty insurance companies were urged today by Alfred J. Bohlinger, Superintendent of Insurance of New York State, to consider adoption of a rating plan which would reduce the cost of insurance for careful drivers.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 -- The Federal District Court trial of fifteen California Communist functionaries was stirred into a minor commotion today by defense suggestions that a Government witness was testifying under threat of Mann Act prosecution and also that he had falsified an insurance application.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- General satisfaction among officers of the Maritime Administration and officials of the shipping industry was expressed here today over the endorsement by the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives last week of legislation to relax provisions of the original bill involving Government shipping subsidies.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 11 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe and his Chief of Staff, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, will fly to Frankfurt tomorrow to attend for a day the first top-level military planning conference organized in the Central Defense Sector of the Allied command.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- With the slogan "Take the Shackles Off Production," the Corn Belt Livestock Feeders Association sounded today the first demand at current Senate hearings for outright removal of price controls.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, 69 years old, president of the Chicago Board of Health, was indicted today on six counts of nonfeasance in office and one of misfeasance in connection with the horse meat racket.
LONDON, March 11 -- The rival factions of the British Labor party in the House of Commons patched up their quarrel today. They covered over the rift in their ranks but did not heal it.

Proper diet, a life-long "must," often is neglected by men and women in their sixties and seventies. It is to aid this age group in developing and pursuing good eating habits that the United States Department of Agriculture has just released the booklet, "Food Guide for Older Folks."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 (AP) -- Plans to televise the fifteen-round middleweight championship fight between Sugar Ray Robinson, the titleholder, and Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu here Thursday night were canceled today.

If it is not naive to say so, you can have a very good time at the Palace with the present show. Those two obese mountebanks, Olsen and Johnson, occupy the second half with a carnival selected from their ample repertory. To quote a frisky program, Olsen and Johnson, to say nothing of Marty May, who has most of the talent, provide an enjoyable "escape from the current escape entertainment."

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 12 -United Nations delegates negotiating an armistice in the Korean war today again turned down a Communist proposal to exchange all prisoners after an armistice on the basis of lists already handed over by both sides.

Despite adverse conditions in the textile industry last year, Textron Incorporated increased sales by 12 per cent and earnings by 51 per cent over 1950, Royal Little, president, reported in the twenty-fourth annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A statement that $3,500,000,000 could be cut from current Air Force appropriations without endangering its program, and a charge that the Joint Chiefs of Staff finally had to toss a coin to determine the relative combat importance of airplanes, ammunition and warships, have been put before a Senate subcommittee by Roswell L. Gilpatric, Under Secretary of the Air Force.

Because the present speed limit of 25-miles-an-hour on major through routes is "unreasonable, unnecessary and unenforceable" a test program with higher limits will be started today on Horace Harding Boulevard and Union Turnpike, Queens.

By filing a tariff schedule with the Public Service Commission at Albany yesterday, the New York Telephone Company took the final formal step necessary to put into effect on Friday the state-wide rate rises approved by the commission on Monday.

Consolidated net income of the General Telephone Corporation and subsidiaries for 1951 was $5,529,000, an increase of 34 per cent over the $4,136,000 reported for 1950, according to the company's annual report being forwarded to stockholders today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 12 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1186:

CAIRO, March 11 -- The leaders of the Wafd party, which has a majority in both houses of Parliament, took the party into opposition to the Government today. The announcement was made by Mustafa Nahas Pasha, former Premier, and president of the Wafd.

An amendment that would have made women as well as men eligible to be delegates of the American Kennel Club failed to receive the three-quarters majority necessary for enactment at the annual meeting of A. K. C. delegates in the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- John D. Small, chairman of the Munitions Board, told investigating Congressmen today that he had won a battle with the armed services to get more civilian authority in military buying policies.

Score one for printed media and radio. The sales promotion division of the Retail Dry Goods Association has just completed a study which shows that, compared with other advertising tools, television has yet to prove its effectiveness as a productive retail advertising medium.

Public response to the demands of the Collectors of Internal Revenue in this city and vicinity has quickened appreciably in the last few days. It is estimated that half of the income tax returns for 1951 have been filed. The deadline is midnight Monday.

Garment cutters, office workers, telephone operators and lodge members were among the groups who donated blood yesterday at Red Cross centers or at stations set up at their own headquarters. Members of Local 10, Garment Cutters, International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, made their donations at union offices, 218 West Fortieth Street.

Members of the New York City Bar Association rejected last night a proposal that would permit the National Labor Relations Board to turn over to the State Labor Relations Board labor disputes not strictly inter-state in character. The voting took place at the regular stated meeting of the association at the Bar Association building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.
Four key executives were elevated yesterday by directors of the Radio City Music Hall Corporation, according to G. S, Eyssell, president of Rockefeller Center, Inc., and chairman of the Music Hall.

Two representatives of the United States in the international masters' tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club clashed in the fourteeth round and, as a result, Samuel Reshevsky, former national champion, advanced to the top of the standing with 11 points yesterday after defeating Israel A. Horowitz of New York in forty-nine moves, according to a report from Havana.
LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- The British Board of Trade published today the full list of goods R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, banned from import into this country under open general license.

Complaints of serious violations of wage stabilization regulations were filed here yesterday against five local ship repair contractors in the first formal action of its kind by the Second Regional Wage Stabilization Board.

The General Electric Company reduced suggested list prices of five 1951 refrigerator models $30 to $55 yesterday. The company gave no reason for the action but trade sources said the cuts were made to move heavy inventories.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- State ownership of lands beneath bays, harbors and other navigable inland waters was unanimously affirmed by the Senate today.

The A. S. W. Rosenbach collection of Shakespeare folios and quartos, famous around the globe, has been sold for considerably more than $1,000,000. A history-making event in the book world, the transaction was the first to take from these shores a collection of books long recognized as being without peer in rarity and quality.

ROME, March 11 (UP) -- Details of the private life of Pope Pius XII, who will celebrate the thirteenth anniversary of his coronation tomorrow, were disclosed today by the Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, in a special article on his daily routine.
MEXICO CITY, March 11 -- Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, who was ousted as President of Cuba, is expected to arrive in Mexico by plane within the next day or two.

Federal appropriations for civil defense discriminate against New York State, which was forehanded in its programs, the New York State Civil Defense Commission charged yesterday in calling for amendment of the law which "penalized" programs carried out before the effective date for reimbursement.

Frank Erickson, nationally known gambler, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in Brooklyn Federal Court to an indictment charging him with income tax evasion. He was accused of cheating the Federal Government of $146,498 in taxes for 1945 and 1946.

With the city's proposed overnight street parking tax apparently headed for legislative approval, a check yesterday showed that implementing it would pose gigantic administrative problems, with many opponents of plan holding that it was unworkable and unequitable.

The International Boxing Club yesterday signed Lester Felton, 23-year-old Detroit welterweight, to oppose unbeaten Johnny Saxton of New York in the ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden Friday night.

BAYONNE, N. J., March 11 -- The Naval Supply Depot here is waging a relentless war on waste as it carries out its principal job of providing equipment and material for the fleet and for other naval installations.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 11 (AP) -- An Indianapolis wire service supplying horse racing information to bookmakers in Indiana, southern Michigan and northern Kentucky for the last half century will close.
The waistline, placed at the hips or under the bosom, provided much of the interest yesterday in Bergdorf Goodman's collection of sixty-five French and Italian imports.

Today's new film is "Boots Malone," a Columbia drama about horse racing with William Holden, Johnny Stewart, a juvenile newcomer; Stanley Clements and Basil Ruysdael, at the Paramount. William Dieterle directed from the script by Milton Holmes, who also produced.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- Defense expenditures should continue to climb for the rest of 1952, but "there is still no clear ground for expecting a sharp recovery of private business," the National Electrical Manufacturers Association was told today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- Gary Cooper has teamed with Mark Robson to play the starring role as Mr. Morgan in the director's independent production of the chapter entitled "Mr. Morgan" from the James Michener book, "Return to Paradise."

Three of the bigger figures in the world of comedy -- Jack Benny, Bob Hope and Red Skelton -- were represented on television this past Sunday, and it was Mr. Benny who handily walked off with the honors.

Acting in concert with a number of other Western Governments, the State Department has announced special regulations covering travel by Soviet diplomats and correspondents, other than those attached to the United Nations, in this country. Under the new ruling these representatives of Moscow must give advance notice of any plans to travel in this country outside a radius of twenty-five miles about New York and Washington.

E. I. duPont de Nemours Co., Inc., attained last year the highest production and sales in its 150-year history, but record taxes reduced earnings 28 per cent, or $87,000,000, from the 1950 net, according to the annual report to stockholders issued yesterday.

With Mayor Impellitteri ill with a chest cold and confined to Gracie Mansion all day yesterday, his City Hall office announced that he would leave Grand Central Station at 9 o'clock this morning for Albany and further fiscal conferences with Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore.

In all the discussion about one-way and two-way avenues is nobody going to speak up for the ordinary people who use these streets? I mean the men and women going about their daily business who must go along the avenues a distance too far to walk, so they have to take buses.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Government lists 2,625 full-time employes in public relations and publicity activities, plus part-time workers equivalent to another 1,007 full-time press agents.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 11 -- The Yankees were still in a free-swinging mood today as they toppled Lou Boudreau's Red Sox for the second successive afternoon, 7 -- 6.

ROME, March 11 -- The United States Government will continue its policy of close cooperation and friendship with the Italian Government "as long as it remains free and truly representative of the will and feelings of the Italian people,"

Leonard A. Keyes, a retired vice-president of J. P. Morgan, Inc., was the only witness yesterday in the suit brought by Mrs. Mabel S. Ingalls, who is seeking to have the will of her sister, Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, denied probate on the ground that she lacked testimentary capacity.

Seventy - two prominent Americans, including eleven United States Senators, will send a message direct to the Russian people today urging them to return to the principles of the Democratic Provisional Government of 1917.

To come home on the day of the New Hampshire primaries is to miss the first full impact of the contrast between the United States and Europe. For this time it happens that on both shores of the Atlantic the main topic of conversation is the same, and the returning traveler feels that in a lighter atmosphere and under wider skies he is merely resuming where he left off on the other side.

PARIS, March 11 -- French officials were greatly surprised by those parts of the Soviet note that advocated a German national army and a German armament industry. Until now Moscow has professed to oppose both, notably in its note to the French in December, 1950, accusing the Western powers of violating the Potsdam Agreement for demilitarizing by seeking to create a Germany army and to irestore the Ruhr arsenal.

GENEVA, March 11 -- The secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe defended itself vigorously today against allegations by an Eastern bloc spokesman that it had shown bias in favor of the United States and had distorted facts about the Soviet Union in its economic survey for 1951.

Plans are being advanced at frequent meetings at the Waldorf-Astoria for the fiftieth annual ball of the Ninth Assembly District Republican Club on the night of March 24 in the Grand Ballroom of the hotel.

BALTIMORE, March 11 (AP) -- A former Communist linked Philip Frankfeld today to a Red plot of twenty years ago to infiltrate the United States armed forces as a springboard to violent revolution. The witness, Paul Crouch of Washington, said he and Frankfeld were members of the Young Communist League in New York City in the early Nineteen Thirties and shared that assignment.

A suggestion the other day by a person described as manager of the urban traffic division of a top electrical company has attracted the attention of our confirmed countryman, Hezekiah Cobb. A little way down in the story this gentleman, whose natural concern is the muddle into which events not too clearly foreseen have involved modern road transport, made an arresting statement.

Duquesne, No. 1 on the national invitation college basketball tournament seeded list, showed 14,112 court fans why last night at Madison Square Garden. Dudley Moore's Dukes from Pittsburgh, sporting a regular-season record of 21-and-1, the best among the nation's major colleges, made an impressive move into the semi-finals with a hard-earned 78-68 victory over Holy Cross.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- A Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives apporved a bill today to create twenty-three new judgeships.
Far more buying was done at the Leather Show, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, than at the 1951 fall showing.

At the request of the Department of Justice the Federal District Court in Cleveland has temporarily restrained the engineers', conductors' and firemen's Brotherhoods from continuing or enlarging their three-day strike on the New York Central lines west of Buffalo and in the St. Louis Terminal yards.
One of the newest and most modern trains in the world pulled out of Pennsylvania Station at precisely 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning and sped through the rain on its first test run to Washington.

HOOKSETT, N. H., March 11 -- Five "big city" reporters who came to the Hooksett town meeting to learn about grass roots democracy stayed today to be elected honorary Hog Reeves. A Hog Reeve, the reporters were told upon being formally sworn in, is duty-bound to retrieve stray hogs and return them to the owner.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- More selling was encountered in grain futures today, but while prices receded from early highs, declines were mainly a matter of fractions. On such dips there was surprising demand in all pits, considering the fact that prices have been working steadily upward for about six days.

Salesmen of toys grew weary yesterday from writing orders as the second day of the-forty-ninth annual American Toy Fair continued to draw a record number of buyers. A registration of 2,000 brought the two-day total to 5,500.

Renewed buying in the railroad issues enabled the stock market to rally yesterday after Monday's setback. Part of the previous losses evaporated under renewed demand which spread from carriers to a variety of other sections, notably the radio-television stocks.

ELIZABETH SPENCER'S second novel, "This Crooked Way,"* is so good it is a pity that it isn't better. There is brilliant writing here, an emotional tension and a sinister suggestiveness which kindle the imagination. Miss Spencer can convey the special atmosphere of a place or of a situation with poetic power. She can create characters who walk right out of her pages trailing Mississippi mud and cotton husks all across your living room rug.

Robert Merrill, American baritone, who was dropped by the Metropolitan Opera last April when he did not show up for the spring tour, returned to the fold last night and sang the role of the Count di Luna in the season's third presentation of Verdi's "Il Trovatore."

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 11 -- Three reverses in a row at the hands of the Indians, one of them a shut-out, and a frigid rain which washed out a scheduled resumption of hostilities here, did not dim the perspective of Leo Durocher, Giant leader, today.

DETROIT, March 11 (UP) -- George Di Re and Jack Gordon, both of Chicago, advanced to the second round today of the national indoor doubles handball championships with a 21-7, 21-8 victory over John Carr, Des Moines, and Leonard Dueball, Detroit.

Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, sentenced to death as atom spies for the Soviet Union, petitioned the United States Court of Appeals yesterday for a rehearing. The court recently upheld their conviction of conspiracy to commit espionage.

WASHINGTON March 11 -- The Marine Corps, traditionally an organization of volunteers, said today it hoped to end its dependence upon Selective Service draftees in filling its ranks and to return to voluntary recruiting July 1.

An impressive tribute to a large and valuable body of women who have worked hard and successfully to bring about the economic rehabilitation of uprooted and underprivileged Jewish people throughout the world has been paid in messages from President Truman, Governor Dewey and Mayor Impellitteri on the occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the women's branch of the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training.
The Appellate Division unanimously upheld yesterday the constitutionality of amendments to the police pension laws requiring thirty-day notice before retirement.

Martin G. Olsen of 4617 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, the 36-year-old bank teller who took $38,224 of his employer's funds when he went to lunch on Jan. 29, was indicted in absentia yesterday by the Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury for embezzling the money from the Chemical Bank and Trust Company's branch at 50 Court Street, Brooklyn.

In one of the biggest fur robberies here in recent years, mink pelts valued by their owner at a minimum of $150,000 were stolen some time Monday night from a showroom in the center of the fur district, only a block from the West Thirtieth Street Station House.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The failure of the House Committee on Appropriations to provide supplemental funds for the Small Defense Plants Administration and its recommendation "that the agency be liquidated at once" have laid a "paralyzing" hand on the program to aid small business, Telford Taylor, head of the agency, advised Congress today.

Hattie Carnegie's individuality speaks through every line in her spring and summer collection. Even though she is one of the devotees of the Paris couture, her collection, seen yesterday afternoon, is refreshingly free from influences overseas.

William A. Tierney, 27-year-old suspended patrolman, denied yesterday in General Sessions that he had brutally assaulted Robert Cox of 9 Elm Street, Lynbrook, L. I., who is suing the city for $150,000 damages as the result of a beating he said he suffered at the policeman's hands on New Year's Day in 1951.

Defense counsel in the investment banking anti-trust suit began yesterday the cross examination of Harold L. Stuart, Chicago financier, whose sponsorship of compulsory, public sealed bidding for bond issues has been a recurring consideration in the four-year-old action being tried in Federal Court here.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Office of Price Stabilization for the first time today fixed export ceiling prices on general purpose (GR-S) synthetic rubber.
Commodity markets staged a general decline yesterday, with wool irregular and only rubber futures moving against the trend.

SONOMA, Calif., March 12 (UP) -- This historic little town where the California republic was born went into welcoming action today when a Chinese family moved into a $12,000 home in the Hillview tract, the only Orientals in an otherwise all-Caucasian area of about forty new houses.

Don't worry about any radio or television comedians' bright remarks about March 15 being "Go Broke Day." Because this year nobody has to pay his income tax, or even file a return, by March 15. What is more, nobody who fills out the short form (1040 A), which is limited to persons earning no more than $5,000, need make any payment for at least thirty days -- in some cases, three months.

The five and a quarter mile ferryboat ride down New York Harbor from the Battery to Staten Island for a nickel fare, long acclaimed as the biggest travel bargain, was found yesterday to be only a second best buy.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Alabama Power Company of Birmingham asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to sell $12,000,000 worth of first mortgage bonds at competitive bidding. The bonds will have a maturity of not less than thirty years The company intends to use proceeds of the sale to provide a portion of the funds necessary for property additions and improvements.

HAVANA, March 12 -- Crowds gathered at the Presidential Palace and military planes roared overhead this afternoon as Gen. Fulgencio Batista made his first appearance in the capital since Monday's successful coup. He arrived here from the Camp Columbia military headquarters nearby.
PARIS, March 12 -- Premier Antoine Pinay's effort to put France financially on her feet was aided greatly today by a decision of the European Payments Union to grant a $100,000,000 credit to France.

The news that the Wafd party in Egypt has broken with the Government of Hilaili Pasha, and that dissolution of Parliament and new elections are to be expected soon, has significance for all of us. The Wafd is the only organized political machine in Egypt and without it no parliamentary government is possible.

STRASBOURG, France, March 12 -- A training school for the leaders of a future cultural and intellectual reconquest of Soviet-dominated Eastern Europe has been in session since November in a graceful eighteenth century chateau at Robertsau, a few miles outside this capital city of Alsace.
Duquesne will meet La Salle and St. Bonaventure will oppose Dayton tonight at Madison Square Garden in the semi-finals of the national invitation basketball tournament.

I should like through the medium of your influential paper to make an urgent appeal to the State Department and missionary organizations in the United States to consider the advisability of opening centers of higher learning in Togoland, West Africa, similar to the American colleges and universities in China and Beirut.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 12 -- With a rip-roaring last-quarter drive, Princeton defeated Columbia, 70 to 65, at Dillon Gymnasium tonight to clinch the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League title and a berth in the National Collegiate A. A. championship tournament.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- The Soviet Government has established a new price index system for calculating gross industrial production, prices and labor productivity. In general it is based on the reduced wholesale prices placed in effect in heavy industry last Jan. 1.

HAVANA, March 12 (UP) -- Dr. Prio Socarras, ousted President, was reported today to have refused to sign his resignation, as de manded by the new Government. This resulted in delaying his departure for Mexico.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Jubilant Eisenhower and Kefauver supporters dominated the Washington political scene today to the discomfiture of angry Taft and silent Truman backers.

NEWARK, March 12 -- Two youths were sentenced today to death in the electric chair the week of April 20, and a third to a life term in prison, for the hold-up slaying of Special Policeman James Law last Nov. 29. The sentences were imposed by County Judge Joseph F. Conlon, who presided at a two-week trial of the defendants that ended in their conviction by a jury last Saturday.

JERUSALEM, March 11 -- A campaign to persuade young American Jews with industrial skills to devote a year or so of their lives to Israel will be launched by Jewish organizations in the United States in the near future, Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, said today.

In its first report since it became an operating company, the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reported yesterday gross operating revenues of $39,302,881 for the ten months ended Dec. 31, 1951. Net income for the same period, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, aggregated $5,380,115, equal to $1.21 a share on the utility's outstanding common stock.
Alcoholism has many causes but it has no cure, it was emphasized here yesterday at the sixth annual meeting of the National Committee on Alcoholism, Inc., at the Statler Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Air Force today disclosed that a contract had been awarded to the Boeing Aircraft Corporation to start work toward building a plane to fly on atomic power.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has about eighty-five aircraft factories and more than twenty-eight engine plants, and probably produced 22,000 airplanes -- half of them fighters -- last year, Aviation Age, a technical and trade magazine, said today.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Backing three rookie hurlers up from Milwaukee with a fifteen-hit attack, the Braves defeated the Reds, 7 to 5, today.

ALBANY, March 12 -- A bill making it a misdemeanor to publish or sell comic books dealing with fictional crime, bloodshed or lust that might incite minors to violence or immorality was approved in the Assembly today, 141 to 4. The bill now goes to the Senate.
Defiant railroad strikers ended their revolt against a Federal court injunction last night, clearing the way for restoration of full service on the New York Central system today.

NEW DELHI, India, March 12 -- India's annual two-day spree of rowdy fun, in which all classes from Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru down through the lowest village levels participated, formally ended at noon today with the traditional spectacular outburst of high spirits denoting the official advent of spring.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Senate completed the first legislative passage today of a proposed constitutional amendment that would bar stream control projects in the State Forest Preserve without a state-wide referendum.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Assembly approved today an appropriation of $49,470 to buy land in Virginia so that the Civil War battle monuments of the old Brooklyn Fourteenth Regiment and two Manhattan Zouave regiments can be incorporated into the Manassas National Battlefield Park.
EINDHOVEN, The Netherlands, March 12 -- Dr. Arnold J. Berman yesterday received a one-year suspended sentence for putting his pain-racked 52-year-old brother, Jan, out of his misery two years ago.
One of the new eighty-five-passenger airliners that will be put into coach service between the United States and Europe on May 1 was demonstrated yesterday by Pan American World Airways.
The economy in cost and time of Japanese floral arrangements was stressed yesterday as the key to bringing them into American homes.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- With Southern Democrats leading the fight, opponents of President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue denied today that it was needed or designed to curb corruption.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Business men who served without compensation to help the United States set up its defense production program were honored here today with a special luncheon and the presentation of "certificates of service."

Urgent pleas for a suitable tin purchase agreement between the United States and Bolivia were made yesterday in a joint statement by the South American country's associations of large, medium and small tin producers. Today, after a hiatus that began Oct. 10, negotiations will be resumed in Washington.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The fathers of two American dead today received the Medals of Honor won by their soldier sons on Korean battlefields.

Underwriting syndicates will offer to investors today new issues of securities totaling more than $52,000,000. Included are $22,800,000 of new public utility bonds, $19,000,000 of public utility preferred stock and more than $10,000,000 of common stock of a natural gas pipeline company. The offerings are.

The most controversial collection to be presented by Parisienne couturiers in several seasons are those of this spring, according to Bettina Ballard, Fashion Editor of Vogue. This statement was lucidly summarized by Mrs. Ballard in her report on Paris trends and a showing of French imports at the Fashion Group luncheon held yesterday in the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Prof. John K. Fairbank, a trustee of the Institute of Pacific Relations, conceded today that the Communists probably had tried to infiltrate the organization but added:

W. Stanley Moss, wartime secret agent, who told some of his experiences in "Ill Met by Moonlight," has a new book on Macmillan's list scheduled for April 15 publication. In "A War of Shadows," Mr. Moss begins with his new assignment in Crete, from which he moves to the mountains of Macedonia and ends with his parachuting into the Siamese jungle to establish surrender headquarters in an Oriental boom town.

An increase last week of 2,169,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 144,956,000 barrels, compared with 142,787,000 a week earlier and 139,429,000 a year before.

Counsel for Alger Hiss contended yesterday that it had substantial evidence that the Woodstock typewriter, which was the crux of the Government's perjury case against the former State Department official, "is a fake machine."

The Frances Langford-Don Ameche television series, presented over the American Broadcasting Company network on Mondays through Fridays from 12 noon to 1 P. M., will be canceled following tomorrow's performance. The network said it was disappointed with the program's rating and was dropping the show by "mutual agreement" with two sponsors, who had purchased fifteen-minute time periods.

The decisive results of the New Hampshire primaries will inevitably have an important effect on the Presidential campaign in both the Democratic and Republican parties. New Hampshire is a small state and fewer than half of its 300,000 eligible voters participated in the balloting.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 12 -- There were 366 cases of malaria reported last year in New Jersey, but 360 of them were listed by military establishments and only the remaining six by civilian authorities, Wallace T. Eakins, chief of the Bureau of Grants-in-Aid, New Jersey State Department of Health, Trenton, reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Amendments to the Social Security Act in 1950 brought old-age and survivors' benefits to 1,100,000 more aged persons, widows and orphans in 1951, Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, said in an annual report today to the President and Congress.

LONDON, March 12 -- General Lord Ismay, a British soldier with vast experience in military planning, strategy and administration, was appointed tonight to the new post of Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 12 -- Four passengers and the stewardess aboard the National Airlines plane that crashed here last Feb. 11 recounted their versions of the accident today to an inquiry panel of the Civil Aeronautics Board investigating the mishap.

LOS ANGELES, March 12 -- The possibility of Communist sabotage of United States war planes was discussed at a Communist meeting here in 1950, it was testified today at the United States District Court trial of fifteen California party functionaries.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 12 -- Paul Waner, an expert in his line, was giving tips on hitting to the slew of fine young rookies the Boston Braves have in camp. He offered this suggestion to one and that to another until he came to Ed Matthews, a powerfully built youngster of 20. Matthews, a left-handed swinger, stepped smoothly into a pitch and sent it screaming over the fence. Waner shook his head in astonishment

ALBANY, March 12 -- Senator William F. Condon, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance, moved today to force life insurance companies to use a uniform method in reporting allocation of agency expenses to the State Insurance Department.

For her thirty years service as a voluntary instructor in home nursing and allied subjects, Miss Jeroline Winfield of Yonkers received a gold Red Cross pin at a ceremony last night marking the ninetieth aniversary of the birth of Jane A. Delano, founder of the American Red Cross Nursing Society.

EL PASO, Tex., March 12 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, apparently little daunted by his New Hampshire primary setback and a West Texas sand storm, resumed tonight his attack on the Truman Administration.

The Union Pacific Railroad Company effected a net reduction of $10,942,394 in its funded debt last year, according to the road's 1951 report to stockholders. At the year-end, total funded debt was $204,453,789, compared with $215,396,183 on Dec. 31, 1950.

MADRID, March 12 -- The Spanish Government announced today that it had authorized the formation of political parties in Spanish Morocco. Although no specific reference was made to any party the measure obviously was designed to permit freedom of activity to Moroccan nationalistis under the guidance and control of Spanish authorities.
Awards totaling $783,835 for research in heart disease this year were announced yesterday by the board of the Life Insurance Medical Research Fund.

GENEVA, March 12 -- The committee on freedom of association of the International Labor Office has dismissed a complaint against the Government of the United States of violation of trade union rights in the administration of the railroads.

DETROIT, March 12 -- The international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., tonight ordered officers of Ford Local 600 to appear before it Friday morning to show cause why an administrator should not be appointed to take charge of the local union.

CAIRO, March 12 -- The prosecuting attorney, concluding his plea in the first of a long series of trials before a special military tribunal trying those charged with murder, arson, destruction and looting in the riots of Jan. 26, stated today that the accused persons "belonged to a dangerous clique of criminals who had been at work for some months to prepare insurrection in Egypt."
The City of New Orleans announced yesterday that it will take bids on April 2 on $4,500,000 of grade separation bonds dated May 15, 1952, and due Nov. 15, 1953 to 1981.

The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York opened its campaign last night with the announcement that pledges here to date had exceeded $7,000,000 toward the nation-wide goal of $151,500,000 sought in behalf of Jewish needs throughout the world, with special emphasis on Israel.
A dramatic spring fur story was told by B. Weinstein of 7 East Fifty-Seventh street at her showing at the Plaza Hotel yesterday of custom-made clothes and French and Italian imports.

Federal mediators sought yesterday to induce employes of two Brooklyn ship repair concerns to return to work after a halt was ordered by union officials in retaliation against a salary rollback ordered by the Wage Stabilization Board.

MADRID, March 12 -- The newspaper Arriba criticized editorially today a pastoral letter by Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville, who last Sunday denounced what he called the "Protestant danger" in Spain and the "leniency" of the Spanish Government for non-Catholics.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12 -- The United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of Information virtually completed work today on a universal code of ethics for journalists.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- The Cardinals scored in the fifteenth inning to edge the Red Sox, 7 -- 6, today in a three hour and fifty-five minute marathon exhibition contest.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Newbold Morris, the Truman Administration's special investigator of corruption in Government, turned bitterly and angrily on his Congressional critics today.

The Government of Premier Pinay, having obtained a grudging endorsement by the National Assembly, has set to work on a problem the successful solution of which may well determine France's future role in world affairs and its ability to honor the obligations it has assumed in Europe and in Asia.

NEWINGTON N. H., March 12 -- This southeastern New Hampshire town and seven surrounding communities adopted resolutions at town meeting's yesterday condemning the proposed establishment of an Air Force jet bomber base, a recapitulation of voting returns showed today.
WASHINGTON, Mach 12 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that negotiations with Madrid for the use of Spanish military bases by United States armed forces would get under way soon.

Larger shipments resulting from expanded manufacturing facilities were forecast for 1952 by Charles J. Stilwell, president of the Warner Swasey Company, Cleveland machine tool manufacturers, at the annual meeting there yesterday.

" Golden Boy" is just as penetrating as it ever was. Perhaps the performance is even more overwhelming. For Mr. Odets has directed the revival of his own play, which opened at the ANTA Playhouse last evening, and the acting is superb. Most of the players are old Group Theatre graduates, working again at one of their most memorable triumphs. For them, as well as for the public, the revival is worth-while.
The American Nurses Association commends THE NEW YORK TIMES for rendering a great service by publishing the timely articles by Harold Faber on the critical shortage of nurses.

The play-off schedule of the National Hockey League was tentatively drawn yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Commodore. Although there are only ten days left of the regular campaign, only one team has a position clinched in the league race. That outfit is the Detroit Red Wings, which is certain to finish in first place.

THIS morning's books present two ways of looking at America. One is "How We Elect Our Presidents,"* a garland of Will Rogers' timeless observations on the Presidential saturnalia, as entertaining and as penetrating as they were when first uttered in this newspaper and elsewhere a number of familiarly raucous campaign years ago.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- The defending champions, Morton Bright, Atlanta, and Gordon Bullock, Ponte Vedra Beach, defeated Dr. E. G. Brittain, Somerville, N. J., and H. Dixon, Boonton, N. J., 3 and 2, today in the opening of match play in the national seniors' best-ball golf tournament.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 12 -- Weary counters in New Hampshire finished today tabulating the Presidential primary triumphs of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Office of Price Stabilization disclosed details today of its enforcement drive against violators of ceiling regulations. The agency announced it had moved against eighty-three alleged violators during the week ended last Friday.

No one would think so from the score, but the New York Rangers were a little worried at one time in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
