But, Bill Cook's skaters got over the attack of jitters and went on to set all sorts of records in trouncing the last-place Chicago Black Hawks, 10 to 2.
Now and then the city dweller who passes through the countryside on a summer day may see a field of solid white, so solid that for the moment it seems like a sheet of snow left over from the winter.

Two new films will arrive in town today. "The Marrying Kind," a Columbia romantic comedy, starring Judy Holliday and Aldo Ray, is at the Victoria. George Cukor directed and Bert Granet produced from an original script by Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin. John Alexander, Sheila Bond, Madge Kennedy and Rex Williams are among the principals.
LONDON, March 12 -- The new budget was well received on the Stock Exchange today, although in the process of adjustment to its probable effects the first price movements were lower.

MIAMI, March 12 -- The Dodgers struggled into their first exhibition game triumph tonight on three unearned runs in the eighth inning to beat the Phils, 10 -- 9, before 5,169 cash customers at Miami Stadium.

James J. Moran, convicted Fire Department official, is scheduled to start this morning for Sing Sing Prison to serve a term of fifteen and one-half to twenty-eight years, but General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, left the door ajar to permit him to soften the term within a year should Moran talk.

The Japanese-flag Nippon Yusen Kaisha Line will use freighters built since the end of World War II on the service it plans to establish in late May or early June between the Far East and Europe, Shinsuke Asao, president of the company, said yesterday.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 12 -- For some of the humiliation heaped upon them the other day by the Giant B team in Mesa, the Cubs got revenge today at the expense of Leo Durocher's regulars.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower declared here tonight that he was "deeply touched" by the outcome of the New Hampshire primary, which resulted in his victory over Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio.
The strategy of the Eisenhower forces in the East yesterday was to focus attention on the New Jersey preferential primary April 15 as the next item in their program.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -A revolutionary method of predicting the weather is being tried out at the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton University.

Times have changed when great treasures go from the United States to Europe, instead of the other way around. But there is nothing wrong with this. Shakespeare belongs to the ages and to the world. If some of his quartos and First Folios and first editions are in Switzerland instead of here, we need not feel badly.
ALBANY, March 12 -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, upheld unanimously today the validity of the special grand jury investigating gambling and political corruption in Saratoga County.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Assembly today voted approval of two bills authorizing the state to levy a 15 per cent admissions tax on the state's six harness racing tracks. All harness meetings at state or county fairs are exempted.

NOW that the channel bass are being taken in the Hatteras pound nets, past performance insists that the schools will be surfacing in the vicinity of Oregon Inlet by All Fools' Day, which should then bring the fish within reach of the surfcasters by mid-April.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Truman's chief economic adviser, Leon Keyserling, told a Congressional committee investigating monetary policy today that proposed heavy cuts in defense expenditures were not necessary to keep the nation's economy strong.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Over solid Democratic opposition, the Assembly adopted today a resolution for final adjournment of the Legislature next Wednesday at 5 P. M.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Three measures recommended by a special committee headed by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore to give fast-growing school districts in the suburban areas more state financial assistance and to encourage the merger of school districts adjoining small cities with the city districts were approved in the Assembly today.

The five-story brick and limestone residence on lot 20 by 100 feet at 114 East Sixty-fifth Street, near Park Avenue, has been purchased by Irwin Glass, artist and portrait painter, who plans to occupy the house after remodeling, including construction of a northlight studio.

Operations of the Studebaker Corporation in 1951, its 100th year as a business enterprise, resulted in record sales of $503,308,866 but net income fell to $12,623,130 from $22,506,829 in the preceding year, Harold S. Vance, the chairman and president, said yesterday in the annual report to stockholders.

They rolled out the red rug in Conference Room 5928 in the Grand Central Station yesterday for 77-year-old James Patrick Mahoney -- fondly known as Jim to his colleagues and legions that have scurried for trains.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of its founding last year with the largest sales and earnings and a record for growth in facilities, the annual report told stockholders yesterday.
Overlook Hospital in Summit, N. J., announced yesterday its affiliation with the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center in New York.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady yesterday 23 to 43 points net lower than on Tuesday.
The first surprise test of the state's Civil Defense communications system was made at 11:45 o'clock last night.

Ordering by stores and dealers at the forty-ninth annual American Toy Fair was maintained at a brisk rate as the annual trade showings continued to set buyer attendance records. For the third successive day, buyer-registration ran well ahead of last year and reached a total of 7,000 yesterday.
PARIS, March 12 -- Jean Letourneau, Minister for the Associated States of Indo-China, emphasized today France's intention to remain in Indo-China and defend it against Communist domination.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Police Chief Erwin Konovsky of suburban Cicero, accused of misconduct in his handling of riots there last July, was cleared today by a jury's verdict, returned at the direction of Judge Frank Leonard of the Cook County Criminal Court.

A police guard was assigned yesterday to Dr. S. M. Fialka, the neighborhood physician who heard the shots that last Saturday night killed Arnold Schuster, the young man responsible for the arrest of William F. Sutton, the bank robber.

Blood donors contributed 1,405 pints to Red Cross bloodmobiles and at centers throughout the city on Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. Special mention was made of a group of garment cutters, members of Local 10 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, who went to their headquarters, 218 West Fortieth Street, after working hours to donate 178 pints of blood.

In the semi-final round of the city Catholic High School Athletic Association basketball tournament St. Ann's Academy defeated Holy Trinity High, 62 -- 54, and All Hallows turned back Manhattan Prep, 63 -- 32, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

LOS ANGELES, March 12 -Pale tones of powder blue, pink, champagne, contrast with black, navy and brown combined with white in the collections of the affiliated fashionists shown here today. The darker colors also appear frequently in prints on pale grounds and in pipings and sheer frocks over pastels, especially over champagne and suntan tones.

Controller Lazarus Joseph was appointed yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri as chairman of a city committee to receive the members of the United States Olympic team when they visit New York next July en route to Helsinki, Finland, where the games will be held.

Adrian's spring and summer collection, shown yesterday at Gunther Jaeckel's, is one of fascinating fabrics. It is a riot of color and design, a mass of moving and floating drapes. Gossamer silks make evening gowns of beauty. In the most romantic ones the skirts billow, whether long or short, sleeves are puffed and draped to set off the decolletage in an airy framework.

A new plan which will enable New York City teachers to participate in school policy and seek official redress from grievances has been proposed by a special Board of Education committee. The plan stresses the rights of teachers to resolve their complaints through direct negotiations and impartial arbitration, if necessary, as well as to contribute to educational and administrative policy.

LONDON, March 12 -- The victories of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, in the New Hampshire primaries were reported calmly today in British newspapers.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- A weaker tone dominated the grain markets through the greater part of today's session, but accumulation broadened on the setbacks, which were due mainly to profit-taking sales and some local pressure based on the theory that a recession is overdue.
Color has been used imaginatively to blend traditional and modern in furnishing three model apartments in the newly completed nineteen-story house at 60 Sutton Place South.

For lunch in a leisurely way, but not for a hurry-up snack, a modest restaurant called Sans Gene opened recently at 32 West Thirty-seventh Street. Unpretentiously located in a millinery district block, it offers Italian, French and American food at prices equally lacking in pretension.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 5, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

CHICAGO, March 12 (UP) -- Jimmy Carter, the lightweight champion, attacking relentlessly, won a ten-round split decision in the Chicago Stadium tonight over his top-ranked challenger, Luther Rawlings.

It is good that yesterday, the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Russian revolution that overthrew the Czar, was marked so widely here and abroad. The world needs to be reminded that between Czarism and Bolshevik tyranny Russia had a brief eight months of freedom under a representative regime supporting the same ideals as those we defend today.

In an obvious effort to force Mayor Impellitteri's hand in reviving the city's dormant program for installation of new parking meters, City Council President Rudolph Halley asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to place the question on its calendar for an early meeting. The next regular meeting of the board will be next Thursday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- The Yankees today celebrated the forty-ninth anniversary of their entry in the American League by deftly polishing off Red Rolfe's Tigers, 4 to 1. But on another count it was a rather dark day for Casey Stengel.

Ruth Diehl, soprano soloist of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, gave a program last night at Town Hall. Though she has been heard as an oratorio soloist in the meanwhile, the recital was the first one she has given here since her debut in the same auditorium ten years ago.

SUPERIOR, Wis., March 12 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen said tonight he had "never seen a candidate spend so much and win so little" as did Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the New Hampshire Republican primary.

KEY WEST, March 12 -- While none of the news of the New Hampshire primaries brought any comfort to the Truman camp, the President declared today that the results would have absolutely no influence on him as he pondered the question whether he would seek renomination.

BOSTON, March 12 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., leader of the Presidential campaign for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, described today reports of a movement to put Paul G. Hoffman, former Marshall Plan chief, in his post as without basis and said they probably had arisen as a result of spotty Eisenhower strength in early returns from the New Hampshire primary yesterday.
I write you at the request of my chief, Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, relative to your editorial of March 5 entitled "Mr. Wilson on the D. P. A."
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers gathered by The Associated Press on the outcome of the primary elections in New Hampshire Tuesday:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12 -- About to depart for Bolivia, where he will represent Secretary General Trygve Lie in the five-year United Nations technical assistance program. Dr. Carter Goodrich of Columbia University said today that a major objective of the project was to improve living standards for the Indians, who make up about 75 per cent of the population, and to incorporate them further in the Bolivian economy.

The Whitney Museum will open to the public today its 1952 exhibition of sculpture, drawings and water-colors. In a brief foreword to the catalogue, Hermon More, director, observes that the museum in its annuals makes not attempt to give an exact cross-section, but rather to represent various styles and tendencies, with emphasis on what the museum belives to be the most significant developments in contemporary art.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- A subcommittee of the House of Representatives on military waste completed its hearings on Defense Department buying today and F. Edward Hebert, Democrat of Louisiana, said the group, of which he is chairman, would approve, probably Friday, a bill requiring all the services to buy from a single catalogue.

Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad declared yesterday a dividend of 1 per cent, or 50 cents a share, payable April 21. This is the 231st dividend voted by the road, continuing its record of never having failed to provide a return to stockholders in any year since 1847.

After having considered the matter since last June, the New York State Racing Commission yesterday announced the adoption of a "consolation double" rule for the racing season which will open at old Jamaica two weeks from next Tuesday.

The Liberal party denounced yesterday the so-called Walter bill to revise and codify the immigration laws. The House of Representatives is scheduled to consider the measure today. Enactment of the bill, the party said, would be a "backward step" and would impose restrictions "entirely foreign to the democratic process."

The time has come to banish gloomy thoughts and smile regardless of Cuban revolutions, intermittent ulcers and the trimming taken at last night's poker game. Spring is really coming. The first harbingers of the glorious season will dazzle the vision of residents of West Yellowstone, Mont., some time this month.
An attempt to settle the row that has hamstrung the administrative functions of Actors Equity Association met without success at a meeting of the association's council on Tuesday.

When William Seabrook, now advertising manager of the Holland-America Line, lived in his native England he drew a series of caricatures of famous sea captains for a weekly shipping paper. He loved the work, but it didn't pay well, so he quit and came to America to obtain employment in a different field.

While one of his closest rivals in the international masters tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club played to a draw in the fifteenth round, Samuel Reshevsky of New York yesterday improved his standing at the head of the field of twenty-three contenders by defeating Carlos E. Guimard of Buenos Aires in thirty moves, according to a report from Havana.

British sterling gained 7/8 of a cent yesterday in the foreign exchange market here in response to the bidding of commercial interests impressed by the proposed British budget's move to shrink subsidies to consumers and to furnish tax incentives for increased productivity.

A prison term of two and a half to five years was imposed yesterday in Kings County Court on Joseph F. O'Brien, the first former policeman convicted of giving false testimony on his financial status to the Brooklyn rackets grand jury.
The stock market managed to pull out of a slump yesterday and, in a late rally, pushed prices ahead to lift the composite rate 0.57 point.

LONDON, March 12 -- The Labor party opposition attacked R. A. Butler's "incentive" budget today as an instrument of class warfare. Leading the attack, Hugh Gaitskell, who was Mr. Butler's predecessor as Chancellor of the Exchequer, charged that it was designed primarily to "take from the poorer people and to give to the wealthier."
John M. Lockhart and William E. Carter, vice presidents of the Kroger Company, have been elected directors.

The nation's proved reserves of liquid petroleum last year increased 2,700,000,000 barrels to a new peak of 32,200,000,000 at the year-end, according to a joint statement issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute and the American Gas Association. Natural gas reserves increased 8,200,000,000,000 cubic feet to 193,800,000,000,000.

Industry requires legislative action by Congress to protect itself against permanent "bureaucratic domination," according to the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York. The association, in a letter to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, urged enactment of statutory provisions for suspension or abolition of price controls.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, March 13 (AP) -- A North Korean battalion, supported by artillery and mortars, attacked last night along a two-and-one-half-mile front. The veteran United States Twenty-fifth Division stopped the Reds cold.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Dewey said today that his confidence in the ultimate nomination of General Eisenhower as the Republican candidate for President had been greatly strengthened by the general's New Hampshire victory.
WHITEMARSH, Pa., March 12 -- Residents were warned today to stay off the streets in the evening because of the rabid fox menace.
The shipping industry in the Port of New York has urged Governor Dewey to veto a measure now before him increasing harbor pilotage fees.

Four 12-year-old Boy Scouts from Troop 1, White Plains, in a mock rescue of a fifth member yesterday on "Biltmore Beach," used a new method of artificial respiration they said was "so easy even girls could do it."

TOKYO, Thursday, March 13 -- The Peiping radio charged today that United States military and political leaders, because of their conduct in Korea, were guilty as war criminals under international law as established by the Nuremberg and Tokyo tribunals that sentenced German and Japanese militarists after World War II.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 12 -- Thirty-three persons were burned to death and forty were injured following the collision of a truck and a bus yesterday near Salvador, in the state of Bahia in eastern Brazil. Most of the victims were said to be refugees from parched areas of the northeast who were en route south to look for jobs.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The National Labor Relations Board, in the first action of its kind, revoked a certification of a parent national union as the bargaining representative for a group of employes because the local union active among the employes had not filed non-Communist affidavits for all its officers when the certification was issued.

RANGOON, Burma, March 12 -- Independent Burma will consolidate her status as a sovereign democratic nation this week by installing the first Government in the country's history responsible to a completely elected parliament.

The Metcalf-Hatch Act to permit the requisitioning of unwanted animals from public pounds for medical experiment would be nullified by an amendment approved by the Senate Finance Committee yesterday, according to the New York State Society for Medical Research. The society was the original sponsor of the bill that was signed by Governor Dewey on Monday.

DOVER, N. H., March 12 -- New England's infallible election barometer for sixty years -- Stratford County -- was right as usual today on the Republican side of the nation's first Presidential primary. But it missed on the Democrats.

Under cross-examination by defense lawyers in the investment banking anti-trust trial here, Harold L. Stuart, Chicago financier and Government witness, described yesterday how he turned down a request of the National City Bank of New York during the first World War to take charge of the National City Company, defunct underwriting affiliate of the commercial bank.
WALKER VALLEY, N. Y., March 12 (AP) -- An exploding kerosene stove turned a mountain home into a furnace early today, taking the lives of eight persons -- six children and their mother and father.

ST. LOUIS, March 12 -- The defense lost its battle today to prevent the cross-examination of James P. Finnegan, former Collector of Internal Revenue, on Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to the American Lithofold Corporation.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Senate approved unanimously and sent to the Governor today a bill to broaden the jurisdiction of the State Commission Against Discrimination to include jurisdiction over complaints of discrimination involving hotels, restaurants and other places of public accommodation.

Innovations in design and increased visibility are among the advances in the 1952 Ambassador and Statesman models presented yesterday by the Nash motors division, Nash-Kelvinator Corporation. The cars were styled by Pinin Farina of Turin, Italy, well-known in the foreign custom car field.

ROME, March 12 -- Italian industry has been asked to submit bids by the end of April for the manufacture of $150,000,000 worth of military supplies under the United States Government's offshore procurement program, William H. Draper Jr., chief of the Mutual Security Agency in Europe, said during a press conference at the United States embassy here this morning.

FRANKFURT, Germany, March 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and other top Allied army men discussed problems of military preparedness today at a secret conference at near-by Bad Nauheim, under the chairmanship of Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin.

A heart-warming report issued recently by the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind stated that its experimental project of finding private homes in which a blind person may live almost as a member of the family, instead of spending his life in an institution, had been eminently successful.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 12 -- The Midwest pondered a new question today as the final results of the New Hampshire primary rolled in. It was: "How strong is Senator Robert A. Taft in the country's big farm belt where the 1948 Presidential election was won and lost?"

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 12 -- A civilian who complained in 1949 of extensive bookmaking activity in Lyndhurst, N. J., was told curtly by local and Bergen County officials not to bother them, according to a critical letter from Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons introduced today at the trial of Michael Orecchio, former county chief of detectives. Orecchio is charged with thirty-two counts of laxity in enforcing gambling laws.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 12 -- The impressive victories of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee in yesterday's New Hampshire primary election were expected here tonight to have important repercussions in the fight for the Republican and Democratic Presidential nominations at Chicago in July.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Hoof and mouth disease has been eradicated in Mexico and if no new outbreaks occur between now and Sept. 1, the quarantine which has been in effect for almost five years will be lifted, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

FRANKFURT, Germany, March 12 -- General Eisenhower expressed gratification with the results of the primary vote but insisted today he was "too busy" with his military job to give it much thought other than to feel pride that the voters had "honored him."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- Bill Mauldin's famous GI's of the last war, Willie and Joe, are going to be recalled to active duty by Universal - International in "Back at the Front," which, considering the turn of world events, comes as a natural sequel to the studio's "Up Front," released last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 (AP) Sugar Ray Robinson, fighting for the first time since he regained the middleweight crown last September, will defend his title tomorrow night in a fifteen-round bout with Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu.

New York City's civil defense drilling for a possible atomic attack "means nothing until it has carried out a practice evacuation," Hanson W. Baldwin, military editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and Mayor Impellitteri said tonight that they had made "progress" toward a solution of New York's financial problems for the year ahead in a five-hour conference here this afternoon. They declined to supply any details about the "progress."
TOKYO, Thursday, March 13 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,187, for Wednesday's operations:

Buying continued heavy yesterday, the final day of the fortieth Leather Show of the Tanners Council of America, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Confirmations were placed on volume orders exhibitors said.

Frequent clashes between counsel yesterday marked the contest of the will of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, Morgan heiress, by her sister, Mrs. Mabel S. Ingalls. She has charged fraud and undue influence by Mrs. Satterlee's lawyer, Sol A. Rosenblatt, and her psychiatrist, Dr. Richard H. Hoffmann.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Clem D. Johnston of Roanoke, Va., appearing on behalf of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, asked the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today to permit wage, price and rent controls to die next June 30, when the Defense Production Act expires.

Proposed mergers of airlines and interchanges of service, put forward in presumed conformance with the policy for better integration under the sponsorship of the Civil Aeronautics Board, are meeting with numerous difficulties. The merger between Northwest and Capital Airlines, in which a pre-hearing conference indicated the board's desire for speed, has been complicated by the proposal of Northeast Airlines and Delta Airlines to buy Capital's southern routes between New York and New Orleans.
James J. Fox, suspended detective linked with three men in an alleged burglary ring, was accused yesterday as a would-be extortionist by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

LONDON, March 12 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden met the United States and French Ambassadors today for a preliminary discussion of the Soviet Union's proposals for four-power discussions on a German peace treaty. A full consultation among the three Western occupying Powers and the German Federal Republic will be held before a reply, is sent to Moscow.

SALZBURG, Austria, March 12 -- The United States information center in Salzburg was cited today by Heinz Siloman, on trial here for espionage on behalf of the Czechoslovak intelligence service, as the principal source of the information he furnished to the Czechoslovaks.

DUBLIN, March 12 -- Drastic reduction of imports from the United States and a reduction of foreign travel allowance from 50 ($140) to the British level of 25 were announced tonight by Finance Minister Sean MacEntee in the Dail Eireann (Parliament).

LIMA, Peru, March 12 (UP) -- A Government bill readjusting the service of Peru's foreign debt was approved today by the Chamber of Deputies. Designed to re-establish the country's foreign credit, the bill was opposed only by the Socialists.

Revenues from concessions, rentals and advertising in stations, cars and buses of the New York City Transit System totaled $4,949,818 last year, according to a report made public yesterday by the Board of Transportation. The total, a record, was $185,642 more than in 1950.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 (UP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, using all his cunning learned in a decade as a fighter, finished fast to retain his world middleweight crown, tonight with a unanimous fifteen-round decision over Challenger Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today selected Penn State, Dayton, Duquesne and St. John's to compete in the N. C. A. A. basketball championship.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Democratic leaders have decided to make another attempt this session to obtain approval by the House of Representatives of a Universal Military Training program.

NEWARK, March 13 -- Chance and the alphabet figured today in the placing of names on the voting machines that will be used when New Jersey voters go to the polls April 15 in their first Presidential preference primaries.
A 24-year-old sheet metal worker sentenced to thirty to sixty years as a second felony offender made a bold attempt to escape from custody yesterday in Kings County Cemt.
TRENTON, March 13 -- The playing of bingo, now illegal in New Jersey, was defended at a legislative hearing today as an innocent pastime to which even "heaven" could not object.
PASSAIC, N. J., March 13 -- A hundred families still were waiting tonight for swollen rivers in the Passaic Valley flood area to subside sufficiently to let them return to their homes.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 13 (AP) -- The venerable Augusta Country Club course, a par 72-layout without a soft touch hole, was too tough for the girls of the titleholders golf tournament today and only Mrs. Babe Zaharias of Tampa, Fla., got neighborly with par.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today blamed a pilot's poor judgment for the crash of a C-46 airliner last Dec. 29 near Little Valley, N. Y.

The investigating committee of Congress can perform one of the most useful functions of government, searching out facts and opinions, probing evidence of wrongdoing and illuminating dark corners. When it sticks to its proper business, and does so within the framework of fair procedure and a decent regard for the rights of its witnesses, the investigating committee deserves the respect and cooperation of all citizens.

ROME, March 13 -- L'Osservatore Romano, Vatican City newspaper, said today that, if photographs it published last November purporting to show the wonder of a "revolving sun" near the shrine of Fatima, Portugal, in 1917, were not authentic, its editors were deceived.

Top-group players in the international tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club who finished their games in the sixteenth round were victorious yesterday and maintained their ranking among twenty-three competitors, according to a report from Havana.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 13 -- Everything clicked for the Detroit Tigers in 1950 as they challenged the Yankees for the pennant right up to the final fortnight of the campaign. Nothing clicked for them last year as they faded to an undistinguished fifth. Which way will they jump this time?
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- By a 53 to 37 vote, the Senate today gave final Congressional approval to President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Criminal as well as civil contempt action is being sought by the National Labor Relations Board against the Israel Putnam Mills, Wilsonville, Conn., and its agent, Michael A. Bergin, for refusal to obey a court order to bargain with the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O. A petition by the labor board for criminal contempt is rare.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Harvey M. Matusow, of Dayton, Ohio, a former Federal Bureau of Investigation informer, said today the Communist party tried to get as many members as possible into the employ of organizations like the Institute of Pacific Relations.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Public elementary schools everywhere in the state except in New York City are facing an unprecedented shortage of elementary school teachers, Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Commissioner of Education, said today. The shortage amounts to 1,746 and affects virtually every community outside of New York City, he asserted.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, March 13 -- The Shakespeare crest on a great yellow banner floated from the flagpole of the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre here today to mark the opening of the "summer" repertory season that runs until Nov. 1.
An Easter bonnet for a poodle, to match identically its owner's Easter bonnet, and a man's gray felt hat were included in the spring millinery fashion show at Martin's in Brooklyn yesterday.

Loan demands from business and industry here subsided last week after five consecutive weekly increases. Repayments of previous borrowings by tobacco and finance companies, cotton dealers and utility operating companies more than offset moderate needs of the metal products and chemical industries.

The adjective "misinformed" in your editorial on U. M. T. is disturbing. We are now accustomed to hearing that all who disagree with some of our ultra-patriotic organizations are labeled "un-American." However, surely all who differ with THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial policies are not "misinformed."
CHARLESTON, S. C., March 13 (UP) -- A three-judge Federal court today reaffirmed its decision that segregated schools are constitutional.
Shipments of rayon and acetate yarn and staple in February totaled 81,500,000 pounds, a decline of 10 per cent under January, the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., announced yesterday.

With food rationed at below basic subsistence level and at least one-fourth of its people housed in tents and makeshift huts, Israel is now emerging from "the most desperate winter season of its history," Rudolf G. Sonneborn, national chairman of the United Israel Appeal, said yesterday in a quarterly report to the appeal's board of directors.
TORONTO, March 13 (Canadian Press) -- Iron ore from Labrador and Quebec is expected to start moving to steel mills by the summer of 1954, a year ahead of schedule.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The Court of Appeals unanimously ruled today that false pre-marital promises of "love and affection" or a marriage for money were not sufficient grounds for annulment on the basis of fraud.

An increase of 16 per cent lifted sales of the Borden Company last year to a record $732,056,671 from the $631,114,120 volume for 1950, but a 22 per cent larger tax bill reduced the net income to the lowest level since the war, Theodore G. Montague, president, told stockholders and employes in the annual report to be released today.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 13 -- Encouraged by the victory in the New Hampshire primary of the man who wasn't there, the Minnesotans-for-Eisenhower organization launched a drive today for a write-in vote for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in next Tuesday's Presidential primary.
PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- The route of a thirty-three-mile extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike to the Delaware River for connection with the New Jersey Turnpike was announced today.

Tolls collected from motorists in 1951 not only provided the entire $18,153,933 record net revenue of the Port of New York Authority but cushioned the airport, truck and bus terminal deficits by $311,494, the bi-state agency's financial report showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told the Senate Banking Committee today that his organization would support an extension of the existing wage stabilization program, but would review its position unless Congress made a real effort to insure equality of sacrifice under controls.

The curtailed service on the Third Avenue Elevated Line, announced earlier for night hours, week-ends and holidays, will begin tonight. The service will be cut out between City Hall station, Manhattan, and 149th Street, the Bronx, but will continue on a twenty-four-hour-a-day basis north of 149th Street to Gun Hill Road, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, March (AP) -- Following is the text of the United States note to the Soviet Union proposing an abbreviated treaty with Austria:

ALBANY, March 13 -- Opposition of Queens and Erie County Republican legislators appeared today to have insured the defeat for this year of the Travia-Erwin bills that would restrict the financial expeditures that labor unions can make for political campaign purposes.

BOSTON, March 13 -- A projected strike of 18,000 textile workers in twenty-one American Woolen Company mills was averted today by an agreement between management and union representatives to extend their present contract a month to permit continuation of discussions toward a new one.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 714,247 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The United States, Britain and France proposed to the Soviet Union today an abbreviated treaty with Austria that would end fourteen years of occupation and restore that country to full freedom and independence.

LOS ANGELES, March 13 -- A crisp, cool, fresh look characterized most of today's press week showings, sponsored by California fashion creators and including numbers from twelve designers of sports, play, and street wear fashions.

This is truly the Air Age. The modern way to prospect for minerals is with the airplane. In a search for more iron ore for the nation's hungry blast furnaces, flying prospectors have been making magnetic maps with the help of an invention known as the magnetometer, according to the current issue of Steelways, published by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A wage policy that will permit increases up to 15 cents an hour in the building and construction industry in 1952 was announced today by the Wage Stabilization Board.

GENEVA, March 13 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross has offered to investigate as a strictly impartial body, the "real causes, nature and extent of the epidemics which are stated to have occurred in North Korea."

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 13 -- Two hundred and fifty-four letters, notes, complaints, newspaper clippings and reports, all taken from the seized files of Michael Orrechio, former chief of Bergen County detectives, were produced by Deputy Attorney General David Harris in today's hearing in the trial of Orrechio, who was charged with thirty-two counts of misconduct in office.
The slow burn that tobacco people have been experiencing for years over high taxes has burst into a flame and the industry is now ready to take specific action.
Well over half of New York City's taxpayers had filed their Federal income tax returns when the offices of Internal Revenue Collectors closed for the day here at 6:30 o'clock last night.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The question whether Administration leaders would be able to restrain the growing demand in Congress for the return of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to testify on the Mutual Security Program loomed large in hearings today.

American politics, from local to national levels, is the subject of a book by Raymond Earl Baldwin, Associate Judge of the Supreme Court of Errors in Connecticut. Macmillan will publish the book April 22 with the title "Let's Go Into Politics."

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Temporary help in the form of additional newsprint for papers in expanding defense areas will be extended by large publishers of the country in the second and third quarters of this year, the Newspaper Industry Advisory Committee advised officials of the National Production Authority today.

Sir Alexander Korda, British film producer, has concluded an agreement with Thomas-Todd Productions, Inc., headed by Lowell Thomas, the radio commentator, and Michael Todd, the Broadway producer, whereby he secures rights to produce and exhibit films in the Eastern Hemisphere to be made by the new Cinerama process.

Young women, headed by Miss Edith Sterrett and Miss Virginia V. Martin and including Mrs. A. Preston Moore, are serving on the junior committee for the fourth annual spring frolic and tea dance in behalf of the Humane Society of New York to be held on the afternoon of April 25 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

LIMA, Peru, March 13 (AP) -- A new oil act was in effect today to give Peru a 50-50 cut of all profits from oil which is produced by foreign interests. President Manuel Odria, who signed the act last night, said it aims at eventually making Peru a great oil-exporting country.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 13 -- Judge Frank J. Donahue took under advisement today arguments by counsel for Dirk J. Struik of Belmont, Mass., and Harry Winner of Malden, Mass., that indictments charging the two men with advocating or plotting to overthrow the Government were illegal and that their constitutional rights had been ignored. The arguments were presented on motions to quash the indictments.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Truman approved today a recommendation of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation's highest military planning group, that the Philippine-Formosa area be placed under the direct command of the commander in chief of Pacific naval forces.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 13 -- John Marshall and Wayne Moore put across a record-breaking one, two slam for Yale in the 1,500-meter free-style as the twelfth annual inivitation individual championships of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League, involving 218 entries from thirty-two colleges, opened tonight.

The Navy will have planes flying from its carrier decks off Korea by fall that will be fully capable of "taking" the Russian-built MIG, it was asserted here yesterday by Rear Admiral T. S. Combs, chief of the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- President Truman charged today that the Federal power program now was the target of "one of the most vicious propaganda barrages in history," aimed at "restoring the unlimited right of private monopoly to exploit this nation's water-power resources."

Musical comedy probably is the least represented form of theatre on television, but last week Felix Jackson, producer of the Schlitz Playhouse, took an important step toward rectifying this oversight. His production of "Haunted Heart" (9 P. M. Friday over C. B. S. video) was a welcome change of pace and an example of the sort of professional experimentation that TV needs.
Two Bronx business officials and three other men were arrested yesterday as part of an alleged robbery and burglary ring that had been operating in the Bronx, Manhattan and Queens.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. March 13 -- A United Nations body of news experts urged today that a global conference of journalists be called to revise and adopt a universal code of ethics for news men and radio and film writers.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Eisenhower - for - President headquarters tonight made public an excerpt from a letter from General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower giving assurances that he would not be a "wild maverick" and ignore the "rank and file of any organization."
The number of city detectives assigned to work exclusively on the Arnold Schuster murder case was increased from 175 to 200 by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan yesterday.

OSSINING, N. Y., March 15 -- The arrival of James J. Moran as a prisoner here today was a study in timeless, impersonal procedure. New York's former First Deputy Fire Commissioner arrived with seven other convicts at 11:15 A. M. Chief Guard Jacob J. Capria of the Department of Correction got a receipt for them and the van headed back to New York.
TOKYO, Friday, March YD (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,188, for Thursday's operations:

The National Shipping Authority announced yesterday, on the anniversary of its establishment a year ago, that another sixty reserve fleet of vessels no longer needed for emergency transport would be taken out of active service and returned to stand-by status.

BONN, Germany, March 13 -- In a burst of speed, made dramatic by the Soviet note proposing a German peace treaty, the Western Allied High Commissioners and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer have virtually completed the contractual agreement for West German sovereignty.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 13 -- Intervention by the Soviet and Iraq delegations to the Trusteeship Council brought a reversal today of a ruling by the president, Sir Alan Burns, rejecting a request of James R. Lawson of New York to be heard on conditions in Somaliland.

The freighter Steel Age of the Isthmian Steamship Company joined the post-war Merchant Marine Naval Reserve yesterday in ceremonies held at the company's Erie Basin terminal in Brooklyn, Capt. John J. Mockrish, U. S. N., representing the Third Naval District's Merchant Marine Naval Reserve program, presented the blue pennant, emblematic of membership and signifying that more than one-half of the ship's officer personnel are members of the reserve, to Capt. William Gillespie, the vessel's master.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Ada Barnett Stough, executive director of the American Parents Committee, testified today that her organization had written to groups in every state and had come to the conclusion there was a great need for Federal funds for the maternity care of wives of service men in the lower pay grades.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Evelyn L. Hopkins' Three Rings, one of the top stakes winners of the past few seasons, slid farther down the scale as he suffered a stinging defeat against so-so company in the featured Salerno Purse at Gulfstream Park today.

CINCINNATI, March 13 -- Representatives of three of the largest Presbyterian groups in the United States have voted here to recommend to their General Assemblies that the efforts of the three organizations in the fields of evangelism and stewardship be pooled.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 13 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that the chances for a Korean armistice had decreased because the Communists had raised doubts recently that they really wanted to call off the war.

Charges that the Council for Social Action of the Congregational Christian Churches sought to put the church in "power politics" and had espoused socialism "under the cloak of the social gospel" were emphatically denied last night by Dr. Liston Pope, dean of the Yale Divinity School and chairman of the council.

Evidence of wide-spread black market operations in potatoes was uncovered by agents of the Office of Price Stabilization in a series of surprise investigations at city wholesale markets ending just after daybreak yesterday.

The stock market found difficulty yesterday in maintaining its forward pace. Despite the fact that more stocks advanced than declined, the composite rate slipped 0.46 point. This reflected weakness in three of the components of the industrial section included in THE NEW YORK TIMES index.
There is urgent need for Spanish-speaking volunteers who will give part-time services as interpreters for the Puerto Rican patients at the Welfare Island Dispensary, 535 East Eightieth Street.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 13 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight that "it still looks, today, as though I will have enough, delegates" to win the Republican Presidential nomination at Chicago in July.

BALTIMORE, March 13 -- The third day of the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal Court here ended today with the prosecution continuing to elicit testimony from ex-Communists that the party preaches violent revolution.

The immense sincerity and vision of a great interpreter was the source of the exceptional impression made by Bruno Walter's performance of the Brahms "Song of Destiny" and the "Requiem" with the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, the Westminster Choir and soloists last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Highway safety is being seriously retarded by conflicting local conditions and selfish interests in New York and eighteen other states, delegates to the National Committee for Traffic Safety meeting were told here today.

MONTREAL, March 13 (UP) -- The second-place Montreal Canadiens, scoring once in every period, defeated Toronto, 3 -- 1, tonight before 14,476 fans to take a 5-point lead over the third-place Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, March 14 (AP) -- The heaviest Communist artillery fire in weeks fell yesterday on allied positions along the Korean battlefront.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Government has devised a secret system to prevent enemy planes from riding in on a radio beam in the event of a sudden air attack. The project, set up by the Air Force in conjunction with the Federal Communications Commission, goes by the code name "Conelrad."

CAIRO, March 13 -- The union groups of Cairo's two universities, Fuad al Awal and Ibrahim Pasha, both with several thousand membership, voted today to oppose any alliance with "Anglo-American imperialists."

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- With General Lucius D. Clay going abroad to talk politics to General of the Army Eisenhower in the new light cast by the New Hampshire Presidential pri maries, the principal topic of the conversation could well be this:

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Administration opened its case for a $7,900,000,000 Mutual Security Program today with warnings from the nation's foremost spokesmen on foreign and military affairs that the full amount was needed to shield the United States against the Kremlin's plans of world domination.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The Senate passed and sent to the Assembly for concurrence today a bill that would declare as abandoned property dividends left unclaimed with stock brokers for five years after June 30, 1946, making the effective date last June 30.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Department-store sales in the United States during the week ended March 8 fell 16 per cent below sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by cities follow, in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

NEW ORLEANS, March 13 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals has dismissed charges of parole violation against two former members of the Capone gang. Thus once again Louis (Little New York) Campagna and Charles (Cherry Nose) Gioe won their fight to stay out of prison.

A drive to raise $100,000 for a Girls Town, a school and home for adolescent girls who need psychiatric and social help, was started last night with a $100-a-plate dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The dinner, under the auspices of the Permanent Committee for the Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency, was attended by more than 300 civic, religious and business leaders.

A number of the art exhibitions that opened this week are devoted to portraiture. These, along with twenty famous paintings by Grandma Moses at the American British Gallery, make up a program of varied interest.
CHICAGO, March, 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of the message President Truman sent today to the annual convention of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association:

ALBANY, March 13 -- The Halpern bill to set up a compulsory automobile inspection system was passed unanimously by the Senate today and the prospects that the bill would get through the Assembly next week brightened as the opposition of the New York State Automobile Dealers Association was withdrawn.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the names of those who filed notices of intention to appear at a hearing the commission will hold tomorrow. The hearing is on the commission's proposed rule requiring payment of registration fees of $50 by securities dealers and of a "head tax" of $10 each for specified employes of such establishments.

MONTREAL, March 13 (UP) -- Canada produced 457,835 tons of newsprint in February, an increase of 3.4 per cent a working day over the same month last year, the Newsprint Association of Canada reported today.

The management of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, in its proxy material for the annual meeting to be held at Topeka, Kan., on April 24, urges that stockholders vote against proposals submitted by four holders of common shares.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Following is the 53-to-37 vote by which the Senate today refused to kill President Truman's plan for reorganization of the Bureau of Internal Revenue (affirmative votes of forty-nine Senators were required to kill the plan, which now becomes effective at midnight tomorrow:

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., March 13 -- The United Nations has arranged to help governments in the fields of crime prevention and prison reform by establishing an "international network" of correspondents throughout the world who will supply the latest data on this subject.

CEDARHURST, L. I., March 13 -- Drilling of the first of a series of underground outposts in the fight to protect Nassau County's water sources has begun here. The potential enemy, against which the deep observation wells will serve as sentries, is the briny Atlantic Ocean.

KEY WEST, March 13 -- President Truman remained outwardly serene today in the wake of the bad news from New Hampshire, but members of his staff were denouncing the Democratic leaders who persuaded him to enter the "popularity contest" primary against his better judgment.

Johnny Saxton, undefeated welterweight from Brooklyn, will oppose Lester Felton of Detroit in the main event of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Felton is a replacement for Johnny Bratton, who withdrew from a meeting with Saxton because of an injured hand.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Three bar associations joined today in opposing Senate confirmation of the nomination of David Northon Edelstein to be a Federal judge for the Southern District of New York.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 13 -- Mosquitos of the present generation are several times harder to kill with DDT than were their ancestors when the chemical was first used for that purpose in 1943, Dr. Harry H. Stage of the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine, United States Department of Agriculture, reported today. He spoke at the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the New Jersey Mosquito Extermination Association.
MADISON, Wis., March 13 -- Gov. Earl Warren and Harold Stassen bucked a March snowstorm today in their quest for Wisconsin delegates to the Republican National Convention.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- President Truman believes there are "a great many reasons for optimism" today, chief among them a feeling that, with communistic aggression blocked, our children "will live in peace."

Liberal receipts of dressed broilers, fryers and roasting chickens have resulted in lower price tags. Broilers and fryers, down 4 cents, are now selling at 45 cents a pound, and roasters, off 2 cents, are tagged at 53 cents, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.
CONCORD, N. H., March 13 (UP) -- General Eisenhower thanked New Hampshire Republicans today for what he termed his "astonishing" victory in Tuesday's primary.

The suspension yesterday by Fire Commissoner Jacob Grumet of a high-ranking deputy fire chief on shakedown charges provided an insight into the methods by which former First Deputy Fire Commissioner James J. Moran, convicted friend of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, took money from some firemen as his cut in graft they collected.

It is not "too late" for Blyth Co., Inc., a defendant in the investment banking anti-trust suit here, to explain to a non-defendant trade rival, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., why a 1920 promise of a major participation in Pacific Gas and Electric Company financing thirty years ago was not fulfilled.

Dollar sales of the General Motors Corporation, the country's largest producer of motor vehicles, declined only 1 per cent last year from the record level achieved in 1950. The net income, however, dropped 39 per cent as the domestic and foreign tax bill moved up slightly to a record $1,141,000,000, or more than twice the corporation's net profit.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 13 -- Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, two-piano team of European origin, made their European debut here tonight after seventeen years and more than 800 concerts in the United States.

TOKYO, Friday, March 14 -- United Nations negotiators on an armistice in Korea proposed today that the disputed question of an exchange of war prisoners be referred back to staff officers to determine whether any ground for agreement could be found between the opposing viewpoints on the vital but deadlocked issue.

The opening barrage in what is expected to be a hard uphill battle to win Congressional approval for continuing the mutual security program to the tune of $7,900,000,000 for the coming fiscal year was fired yesterday when four top-ranking officials appeared before a joint session of Senate and House committees and urged the appropriation of every single dollar asked.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The Assembly Rules Committee introduced a bill today to set up a state commission to protect the interests of the state in television channels expected to be allocated soon for educational purposes.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 13 -- The United Nations has ruled that its regulations do not prevent an employe from revealing the names of persons who had helped him get his job.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, preparing last night to fly to Paris, said he would talk as much politics to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower "as he will let me," and added: "But I think he is smart: enough to know that my advice in that field is not very good."

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 13 -- A New Hampshire leader of the Taft-for-President movement said tonight he had urged the Ohio Senator to withdraw as a candidate for the Republican nomination and back General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Canadian Fund, Inc., an investment company organized by the Calvin Bullock organization, announced yesterday that it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed initial public offering of 800,000 shares of stock intended to be underwritten by a syndicate of banking houses headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Dominick Dominick.

LOS ANGELES, March 13 -- Los Angeles Communists have worked within nursery schools, churches and other organizations in recent months in an effort to "sway the masses" toward the Communist line, it was testified today at the Federal District Court trial of fifteen functionaries of the California Communist party.

STRASBOURG, France, March 13 -- This ancient Gothic city, witness and victim of a thousand years of French-German enmity, is imbued with the spirit of a united Europe and is an active candidate to become its first capital.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 13 -- Faced with strengthening opposition to the proposed Freeport-Roslyn Expressway, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors today postponed for one year all action on advancement of the $4,000,000 project.

Two checks were paid to the Office of Alien Property yesterday, completing the transfer of the Schering Corporation, former German-owned-pharmaceutical manufacturer, to new ownership headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The $100,000,000 horse meat industry was brought under specific price control regulations for the first time today by the Office of Price Stabilization.

The Erie Railroad is making a study of its passenger operations to determine whether further savings can be made "consistent with public needs." According to the road's annual report for 1951, 168,018 unprofitable passenger train miles were eliminated last year, producing savings of about $200,000 a year.

Excited at the prospect of tomorrow's visit from the President of the United States, 3,520 student journalists assembled yesterday at Columbia University for the opening sessions of the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.

Judge Harry N. Graves, presiding judge of the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, who turned down a request on Monday for an appeal on the decision on the conviction of a Texas theatre manager for showing the film "Pinky," yesterday changed his mind and signed the necessary papers, it was announced by the Motion Picture Association of America.
Variety store operators were advised yesterday to adopt suitable supermarket techniques as the best means of meeting growing competition from the latter.

Despite the untimely fate Cheryl Crawford's production of "Flahooley" encountered on Broadway last spring, a few die-hards wistfully clung to the hope that the E. Y. Harburg-Fred Saidy-Sammy Fain musical would rate another chance. Without further ado, let it be known that their missionary work hasn't been in vain.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Albert Cohen, Federal tax agent, who said he has been grilling taxpayers for thirty-two years, testified today he became so rattled when questioned about his own finances that he forgot he had $12,000 cash in a safe deposit box.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 13 -- The Rio de Janeiro police announced today they had captured a Communist agent in the act of mimeographing subversive leaflets addressed to the armed forces. He had a long mailing list, they said.
PARIS, March 13 -- Premier Antoine Pinay today won a vote in the National Assembly of 301 to 101 for the first two steps proposed by him to clear up the French financial crisis.
GLASGOW, Scotland, March 13 -- Mounted police wielded their batons for the first time in twenty years today in an effort to control 20,000 soccer fans.

BERLIN, March 13 -- Klement Gottwald, President of Czechoslovakia, headed back to Prague last night after three days of speechmaking in Berlin, during which he and his host, Wilhelm Pieck, East German President, expressed hope that a unified Germany would be oriented toward the Soviet Union.

The affirmation of the New York State Feinberg Law by the United States Supreme Court already has produced a burst of editorial comment, adverse as well as favorable. Your own editorial of March 5 takes a gloomy view of this decision. May I be permitted to point out some flaws in your premises and conclusions on this highly polemical subject?

A NUMBER of frostbite-proof trout fishermen, unable to await the opening of the regular trout season, have indicated their intention of participating in the "unusual and exciting" rainbow trout fishing to open (so far as is known), in the Finger Lakes area on April 1, come rain, hail or snow.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The Court of Appeals, in a four-to-three decision, today ordered a new jury trial to determine whether the theft of $10,000 from a safe deposit box was owing to negligence of the Manufacturers Safe Deposit Company.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board granted New York Airways, Inc., formal permission today to operate a helicopter service in the New York metropolitan area during the next five years. The service would provide passenger taxiing among airports and the development of short-haul traffic between suburban communities.

A late winter snowstorm -- of the wet-flake variety -- started early yesterday afternoon, but lost its punch several hours later when it dissolved into rain. There were thunderpeals at the height of the storm but they were so distant as to be unheard by many busy citizens.

Chicago announced yesterday it would receive bids March 26 on $18,950,000 of bonds. Of the total, $13,000,000 will be sewer and highway obligations dated Jan. 1, 1947, and due Jan. 1, 1953 to 1966. The rest will be bonds for various purposes dated Sept. 1, 1951, due Jan. 1, 1970, and callable Jan. 1, 1955 to 1969.

MESA, Ariz., March 13 -- A wind that howled out of the north, kicking up dust and carrying rain, abruptly interrupted the renewal of hostilities between the Giants and Cubs today without dimming the luster of the first victory for the New York regulars this year.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The chairman and two members of the old Maritime Commission swore today that they had not been sufficiently informed by the principals before they had approved surplus ship deals that made $450,000 in fast profits for a group headed by Joseph E. Casey, onetime Democratic Representative from Massachusetts.

DETROIT, March 13 -- Carl Stellato, president of Ford Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., suspended two members of his personal staff today and discharged the editor of his union's weekly newspaper, Ford Facts, in a train of events arising from the Congressional inquiry into Communist influence in the labor movement here.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The Assembly today approved a bill giving sweeping powers to the State Athletic Commission to chase racketeers and chiselers out of boxing and to guarantee safety for boxers and honest contest for fans. The measure passed, 134 to 9, over scattered Democratic opposition.
PARIS, March 13 -- Don Jaime, Duke of Segovia and eldest son of the late King Alfonso XIII of Spain, said here tonight he had begun an action to claim the Spanish throne.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 (AP) -- Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, Calif., gave a sensational performance today when he defeated Irving Crane, Binghamton, N. Y., 50 -- 23, in twenty-three innings, in the world three-cushion billiard tournament.

A. M. Perlman, Inc., one of the largest distributors of printed rayon dress fabrics, will suspend operations in the converting business on April 1, it was announced yesterday. A. M. Perlman, president of the company, will devote all of his time and effort to the operation of three finishing companies and two textile plants manufacturing gray goods.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., March 13 -- Posses followed animal footprints through woods and housewives watched garbage cans for furry marauders today, but the "Pleasantville bear" that residents had reported seeing yesterday was not apprehended.

MEXICO CITY, March 13 -- Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, deposed Cuban President who arrived here by plane today with two former Cabinet officials, indicated tonight he would try to return soon to Havana to oppose Gen. Fulgencio Batista, who led a successful revolution against Dr. Prio Socarras' Government Monday.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Corn and oats futures had the spotlight on the Board of Trade today and both showed a sharp recovery from the setbacks of yesterday. Unfavorable weather over the corn belt, and reports indicating small country offerings stimulated buying.
GENEVA, March 13 -- Five Swiss Alpinists left Geneva by air today on the first lap of a journey that they hope will end at the top of Mount Everest.
LONDON, March 13 -- A rally by British Government securities enabled the stock markets to settle down today after yesterday's post-budget upset.

To appease the tax-struck head of the house, the diplomatic home cook will no doubt divert her attention to cutting the food budget. Serving economical fish dishes is one effective, yet palatable, method of scattering the March 17 gloom.

One hundred and fifty tenants of Stuyvesant Town appealed yesterday at a City Council committee hearing for passage of a local bill that would in effect freeze rents at the Oct. 1, 1951, level for middle-income housing projects receiving some form of subsidy from municipal, state or Federal agencies.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 (AP) -- A plague of mad foxes, described as probably the worst in Pennsylvania's history, has aroused widespread uneasiness in scores of villages, towns and rural regions of Pennsylvania.

Secretary Acheson's announcement that new negotiations for the use of Spanish military bases by United States armed forces will soon begin should not cause surprise or excitement. There is nothing new in the statement except that the first stage of the exploratory studies begun last July has finally been completed.

TOKYO, Friday, March 14 -- The Peiping radio last night reiterated its charges that the United States conducted germ warfare in Manchuria and in North Korea and announced that the "China Peace Committee," meeting at Peiping, had voted to establish its own investigating body. According to the committee's resolution, the mission's task would be to verify the American "crime."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 13 -- Admiral Lynde D. McCormick, Supreme Allied Commander in the Atlantic area, left Brussels today after what he described as a satisfactory exchange of views with the Belgian joint chiefs of staff on defense problems of Belgium and of his command. The admiral was accompanied by his deputy, British Vice-Admiral Sir William Andrewes, and other members of his staff.

NEWARK, N. J., March 13 -- Several bombing threats, all of which proved unfounded, were made against six schools and a bus terminal here today. At the same time, it was learned that similar incidents had occurred in other communities in the state.

Relations between parents and teen-age children might be eased considerably, Dr. Leona Baumgartner said this week, if adults recognized adolescence as a phase of growth and were as willing to "make allowances" as they were during their children's infancy and pre-school years.

MIAMI, Fla., March 13 -- For the second straight game at Miami Stadium, the Phils tonight produced a grand-slam home run, but again finished second, the Dodgers winning, 8 -- 7, when Gil Hodges' ninth-inning single scored Wayne Terwilliger from second base.

Saks Thirty-fourth set its audience to guessing yesterday with a showing of French and Italian millinery imports and American-made copies so faithfully reproduced that those present were mystified when called to say which was which.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Legislation to deny pension rights to public officers or employes who refused to testify before grand juries or to waive immunity against criminal prosecution was passed unanimously today by the Senate and sent to the Governor.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 -- Bing Crosby will go to France late this summer to make a picture for Paramount, "Little Boy Lost."

JACQUETTA HAWKES' "A Land"* is a lyrical subjective and occasionally gushy prose poem in celebration of her native island, Britain. Since Shakespeare wrote John of Gaunt's magnificent speech in "Richard II" English writers have been striving to find words adequate to express the emotion they feel at the mere thought of the white cliffs of Dover or the stone cottages of the Cotswolds.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 13 -- Three more passengers who survived the crash of a National Airlines plane here Feb. 11 described the fatal flight today before an inquiry panel of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 13 -- Walter Moreira Sales, a Brazilian financial expert, has been picked as the new Ambassador to the United States and will be proposed to the Brazilian Senate by President Getulio Vargas within the next few days, according to press reports here.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13 (UP) -- Bob Parker of New Orleans staged a late recovery today to eliminate top-seeded Dale Morey of Dallas in the first round of the New Orleans Country Club invitation golf tournament, 3 and 1.

The copies and adaptations of French spring suits and coats that were previewed at Bond's yesterday had much to offer fashion-wise and budget-wise. With the exception of fabrics, the lines and detailing were repeated almost faithfully to those of the originals, which also were shown.

The legislative season nears a close, the pace quickens, but as usual there is plenty of unfinished business. The adjournment target, originally set for tomorrow, has now been pushed into late next week, a wise but perhaps insufficient concession to circumstances and responsibilities. The members have shown real backbone on several hot issues. We hope they haven't exhausted all their courage.
Commodity futures markets here moved irregularly yesterday, those that gained about equaling those that lost.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- More than adequate stocks of thirty-seven selected essential consumer durable goods were found in retail stores in January, the National Production Authority said today. The report is based upon a survey made by the Bureau of Labor Statistics on behalf of the Civilian Requirements Office of the N. P. A. and for the Office of Price Stabilization.

Although two seeded teams were in the semi-final last night at Madison Square Garden, there will be none in tomorrow night's final of the fifteenth annual National Invitation College Basketball Tournament. The Nos. 1 and 3 quintets, Duquesne and St. Bonaventure, were defeated conclusively by La Salle and Dayton, respectively, before 17,131 fans.

A tug of war is going on, with increasing intensity, between tenants and landlords in New York's middle and upper-bracket apartment areas over the trend toward substituting self-service elevators for those manned by house employes.

Stockholders of the American Metal Company, Ltd., at a special meeting to be held immediately after the annual meeting on May 1, will be asked to approve an increase in authorized common stock to 5,000,000 shares from 2,000,000 and approve a two-for-one split of the common stock, Harold K. Hochschild, chairman, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- A White House adviser today rated money policy as seventh in a list of eight factors he said had brought a lull in inflation over the last nine months.

PARIS, March 13 -- For the first time in three years, the Western powers are considering the advisability of modifying their common policy toward Yugoslavia. It is understood that there is no thought of suggesting any form of interference in that country's internal political affairs, but consideration is being given to the possibility of requesting Belgrade to coordinate its foreign policy on certain issues with that of the West.

The steamship industry yesterday urged modification of a proposed bill on narcotics control, now under consideration by the State Senate, that provides for seizure and forfeiture of a vessel unlawfully used to conceal, convey or transport narcotics.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Republican leaders were reported willing today to approve a constitutional amendment increasing New York City's real estate tax limit from 2 to 2 1/2 per cent of full valuation as part of a program for solving the city's financial problems in the fiscal year that begins July 1.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 13 (UP) -- Tommy Bolt, pro from Durham, N. C., and Johnny Dawson, amateur of Palm Springs, Calif., drew special invitations tonight to play in the Masters Golf Tournament here April 3-6.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 4 to 15 points lower yesterday than on Wednesday, with a moderate volume of business.

Three new films will arrive in town this morning. "Deadline, U. S. A.," a Twentieth Century-Fox newspaper drama, featuring Humphrey Bogart, Ethel Barrymore, Kim Hunter, Ed Begley, Paul Stewart and Martin Gabel, is at the Roxy.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13 -- The Yankees, who with their amazing band of youngsters have been laying a heavy hand on the Grapefruit Belt the past week, carried their devastating work down the East Coast today by bowling over Jimmy Dykes' Athletics, 11 to 6.

LONDON, March 13 -- Aneurin Bevan, Laborite rebel, tried to prove to the National Committee of the Labor party today that everybody was out of step except him and his followers. He failed to convince the committee but again escaped punishment for stepping out of line on the party's rearmament policy.

HONG KONG, March 13 -- The key parts of the mystery surrounding the recent death of Lu Tso-fu, general manager of the Ming Sung Industrial Company and one of China's leading private business men, were cleared up today.

Red Cross bloodmobiles and donor centers in the metropolitan area received 1,197 pints of blood on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday. The largest group donation to bloodmobiles was 171 pints made by the New York Life Insurance Company, 51 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Defense Transport Administration asked the Defense Production Administration today for allotments of sufficient steel, aluminum and copper to maintain rail, motor, water, and port facilities equal to the demand of them.

LONDON, March 13 -- Alarm over the effects on the United Kingdom of Commonwealth countries, import cuts dominated today's debate in the House of Commons on the budgetary proposals of R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, for restoring the balance of this country's economy.

MOSCOW, March 13 -- Soviet physicists, particularly specialists in extremely complex fields of light and optical phenomena, and in the study of the atomic structure of crystals, won top honors today in the annual award of Stalin Prizes for outstanding scientific work in the last year.

LAUREL, Md., March 14 (AP) -- A picket line marched today befor the gates of Laurel Race Track, which is scheduled to open its spring meeting a week from Saturday. Nine or ten members of Parimutuel Operators Local No. 297, affiliated with an A. F. L. building service employes' union in Baltimore, picketed the park.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -Legislation to permit the Federal National Mortgage Association to guarantee mortgages on thirty-seven additional defense and military housing projects in seventeen states has been introduced by a group of Senators.

Frederick Brown announced yesterday his resale of 1172 Park Avenue, the southwest corner of Ninety-third Street, to the Park-93d Corporation, Sandor S. Hirsch, president. The property consists of a fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building on plot 100 by 105 feet and a four-story building with frontage of twenty-one feet at 70 East Ninety-third Street which protects the light of the larger structure.

A pool of some general-purpose machine tools is available for defense contractors in the Eastern Air Procurement District of the Air Materiel Command, it was announced by its New York offices at 655 Madison Avenue yesterday. The tools, described as all serviceable, are in warehouses where they may be inspected by contractors after screening their needs against the lists available at the office.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- Broderick Crawford likes the story of political skulduggery that Frank Seltzer, independent producer, will dramatize in "The Kansas City Story," and, since the star is under contract to Columbia, it now appears likely that Seltzer will work out a deal to make the picture at the studio.
Entirely too little has been said concerning the effect of Fair Deal policy on the long-range economic planning of America's young families.
Six of the art exhibitions here demonstrate that artists' conceptions of what a picture should be are highly individual.

ST. LOUIS, Saturday, March 15 -- A Federal jury early this morning convicted James P. Finnegan, former Internal Revenue collector here, on two charges of misconduct in office. It acquitted him on a third count of misconduct and also acquitted him on two counts of taking bribes.

MADISON, Wis., March 14 (UP) -- The Madison Capital Times today carried a half-page advertisement signed by eight citizens, including Secretary of State Fred Zimmerman, attacking Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 (AP) -- An obviously slowed-up Sugar Ray Robinson, still possessed of his middleweight title after last night's hard fight with Carl (Bobo) Olson, looked forward today to two scheduled spring bouts -- but not much more, thank you.
Dr. Ernest Mangold has joined the research staff of Darby Food Corporation, division of Arrow Laboratories, Inc.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed with prices not far below the best levels of the day, 41 to 74 points net higher than on Thursday.

BUTLER, Pa., March 14 (UP) -- Three gunmen invaded the mansion home of a coal operator today, whipped his wife with a pistol and threatened her three children for thirty minutes. They fled after looting a safe of $131,630 in cash and an unestimated amount of securities.
