CHICAGO, March 15 -- Parts of a United States Army colonel's report on the massacre of 14,000 Polish soldiers in Katyn Forest, near Smolensk, Russia, that was held secret until this week were read into the record of an investigation by a Congressional committee today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Army's program of armory construction for its Organized Reserve Corps received new impetus today with the release by the Bureau of the Budget of $9,000,000 for construction of twenty-five more armories throughout the country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of using germ warfare in Korea and China and drew an immediate angry reply from the United States that the charges were "false, unwarranted and uncorroborated."

A borrowing of $55,000,000 in the public market by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company will be the feature of interest in the market for new securities next week. The California utility will take bids Tuesday on the big issue.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 14 -A propeller that was in reverse pitch and another that was fully feathered (not turning) caused the crash of a National Airlines plane here last Feb. 11 that killed thirty-three persons on the plane and in their homes.

Despite the decline in dress shirt activity and the many statements by industry leaders that sports shirts are the things of the present and also of the future, Seymour J. Phillips, president of Phillips-Jones Corporation, manufacturer of Van Heusen shirts, contended in an interview yesterday that dress shirts were the basis of the industry and will grow in strength as such.

Women headed by Mrs. Newbold L. Herrick, chairman, and Mrs. William S. Norton 2d, vice chairman, are active in the plans for the seventy-fifth anniversary campaign fund luncheon to be given on March 25 at the Biltmore by the trustees of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan, presiding at a ceremony in the trial room at Police Headquarters yesterday, promoted fourteen lieutenants and acting captains to the rank of captain, and seven other officers to posts of inspector, deputy and assistant chief inspector.

Three hurdles, each higher than the other, confronted the Atlantic Council when it decided at Lisbon to reorganize the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and appoint a Secretary General to direct it. The first difficulty was to find a man qualified for this pioneer job.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Legislation to supplant the present three-member Civil Service Commission with a single administrator for the State Department of Civil Service was revived today as the Senate Finance Committee reported out favorable a bill to achieve this purpose which had been recommended by the so-called Little Hoover Commission.

TRENTON, March 14 -- The New Jersey Parole Board announced today a list of State Prison inmates eligible soon for parole consideration. Joe Adonis, 48, Bergen County gambling figure, and an alleged associate, Salvatore Moretti, 47, were on the list.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 14 -- Making what fun they could out of the country's annual March headache, a hundred motley-clad residents of this far-from-down-at-the-heels suburban community held an admission-free "Income Tax Bawl" tonight in the undecorated gymnasium of the Edgewood School on Roosevelt Place.

The United States Public Health Service Hospital at Vanderbilt Avenue and Bay Street, Clifton, S. I., where several thousand merchant marine and war veterans are being cared for, began yesterday a campaign against ambulance chasers who visit the hospital.

ALBANY, Calif., March 14 (AP) -- The racing program at Golden Gate Fields was canceled after the second race today on account of a wind and rain storm. The card was called off when the jockeys refused to accept further mounts.
MOSCOW, March 14 -- Stalin prizes were awarded today to three of the Soviet Union's top designers of military aircraft, including the specialist group that produced the famous MIG-15.

CINCINNATI. March 14---A six-I ty-member commission represent-I ing three of the largest Presbyterian organizations in the nation concluded its sessions here today with a unanimous recommendation that the General Assembly of each of the three groups ratify the cornr-sion's plan for merger.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 14 -Representative Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, former Republican national chairman, believes that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower may return to the United States in May.

LONDON, March 4 -- Further appreciation of sterling against the dollar improved sentiment on the Stocks Exchange today. It reduced a little more investment demand as well as some "bear" closing which helped the markets to finish the week on a firm note.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Testimony that the Department of Justice is investigating the legality of bargain-sale purchases of forty-seven surplus Government ships, with the intimation that the Government seeks to recover them, was given today as the Senate's tanker-sale hearings ended after four weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The refurbished White House will be open to receive Queen Juliana of the Netherlands and her husband, Prince Bernhard, when they fly here April 2. The longdebated question was answered with finality and in the affirmative by an authoritative source today.

ALBANY, March 14 -- A supplemental budget bill calling for appropriations of $12,782,846 and a bill appropriating $654,500 for special legislative committees and commissions, a total of $13,437,346, were introduced jointly today by Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo and Assemblyman D. Mallary Stephens of Putnam, both Republicans, as chairmen of the Legislature's fiscal committees.
MUNSAN, Korea, Saturday, March 15 (UP) -- Following is the text of the announcement today by the Second Logistical Command on the riot in the prison camp on Koje Island:

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- Leon H. Keyserling, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, conceded today that the Administration might be able to save as much as $3,000,000,000 a year in the military budget with better planning.
DALLAS, March 14 (AP) -- A faction demanding immediate ceasefire in Korea lost a bittle convention floor fight at the National Farmers Union fiftieth annual meeting today.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, declared yesterday that the United States did not have enough trained specialists to plan and carry out its foreign policy. He emphasized that this country's leadership should not rest on military and economic strength alone.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -Economic aid allocations of $600,000,000 to Great Britain and $400,000,000 to France under the new Mutual Security Program drew a verbal broadside from Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, today as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee began scrutinizing the $7,900,000,000 proposal.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- The Ninth United States Circuit Court of Appeals here paved the way today for a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing into sale of Washington Water Power Company stock to three eastern Washington Public Utilities Districts.

A proposed city fiscal program calling for new revenues in 1952-1953 of $144,000,000 above the current $1,330,000,000 city budget was put forward last night by City Council President Rudolph Halley. The increase estimated by Mr. Halley was $60,000,000 less than the $204,000,000 in new funds sought by Mayor Impellitteri.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore asserted today that he had not told a previous Senate investigation of a 1945 China policy recommendation to President Truman because he had "forgotten the whole business."
SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- About 4,000 members of the union walked off their jobs this morning at West and Gulf Coast ports, tying up twenty-three ships.
Spring fashions for tall girls, with special attention to flatteringly proportioned details, were presented yesterday at the Tall Apparel Shop, 37 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PEARL HARBOR, March 14 -- A big Navy troopship is under quarantine here today and thirteen members of her crew are in Tripler Army Hospital as the result of an outbreak of diphtheria aboard while the transport was at sea between the United States mainland and Hawaii.

NOW that the Legislature has passed the bill to protect the Beaverkill and Willowemoc, two of the most important trout streams of the state, the measure will go to the Governor. In view of the unified efforts by sports and conservation groups to insure the passage of the bill, there is a reasonable chance of its becoming a law.

The New York Knickerbockers, with a chance to tie for second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association, will engage the Syracuse Nationals in the feature game of a matinee double-header at Madison Square Garden today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -John D. Small, Munitions Board chairman, denied heatedly today that a coin was tossed to decide whether the Army, Navy or Air Force was to get first chance at funds for priority defense projects.

HANOVER, N. H., March 14 -History repeated itself at Dartmouth College yesterday when the rowing club's boathouse collapsed under the weight of three feet of snow on its roof, destroying five eight-man shells valued at $6,000, oars valued at $2,000 and the boathouse valued at $2,000.

LONDON, March 14 -- Admission to Britain will be refused to foreign members of the executive council of the Communist-sponsored World Federation of Scientific Workers to attend the meeting scheduled for a week from Sunday, the Home Office confirmed today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- The Barnes Foundation filed an answer today to the legal action in which The Philadelphia Inquirer asked the Montgomery County Court in near-by Norristown to require the foundation to admit the general public to the celebrated modern art collection established by the late Dr. Albert Coombes Barnes.

One of the purposes of bringing better mental health to people is to destroy unreal barriers that people erect in defense against fear. A bill now in the State Senate granting to Children's Courts jurisdiction over children needing psychiatric care is commendable in essence except for the clause that reads:

SEOUL, Saturday, March 15 (AP) -- Allied planes blasted front-line targets in clear weather yesterday but heavy clouds spared the wobbly Red transportation system in North Korea from new aerial blows.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 14 -Minnesotans for Eisenhower rallied their forces for a new vote drive today after the state's Attorney General handed down a ruling that "write-in" votes must be counted in Minnesota's Presidential primary election next Tuesday.

Referring to your article captioned "Courts Reproved for Rent Rulings," one does not have to be an expert in real estate to see the political "thinking" actuating those who are responsible for the report.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that reorganization of the Bureau of Internal Revenue would start early in April with New York and Chicago as "pilot districts."

BERLIN, March 14 -- The Communist large-scale purge of "unsuitable" books in Eastern Germany, now being quietly investigated by United States officials here at the request of the State Department, has reached the very roots of communism -- Marx and Engels themselves.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the labor contracts between Pacific Coast ship owners and the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union canceled on the ground they contained illegal hiring arrangements favoring the union's members.

Actors Equity Association announced yesterday that its position as "the leader in the current attempt to effect a merger of all the performer unions has been "adversely affected" by unauthorized and incorrect statements "widely circulated in the Equity membership" and also by statements that have appeared in the press.

Usually blase cab drivers stepped on their brakes and passers-by on Park Avenue came to an abrupt halt yesterday as they realized that the Roman statues decorating the Park Avenue entrance of Hunter College were not marble figures, but young women arrayed in their interpretation of Roman dress.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 14 (UP) -- Immigration authorities sent a 21year-old Purple Heart veteran of Korea back to Mexico as a "wetback" today, despite protests from the girl he planned to marry.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., March 14 -- A warning that the Communists are steadily increasing their relative advantage over the free world in armaments while this country's principal increase is in the national debt was sounded here today by Stuart Symington, who recently resigned as head of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- United States Exports behind the Iron Curtain have dwindled to a thin trickle but the drop in Communist sales to this country hasn't been as drastic.

STOCKHOLM, March 14 (Reuters) -- Wood-pulp manufacturers in Sweden, Norway and Finland, Britain's biggest suppliers, have agreed to scale down their prices to the maximum set by Britain as a condition for granting them import licenses.
PARIS, March 14 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and his Chief of Staff, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, conferred today with French Premier Antoine Pinay and Defense Minister Rene Pleven.

Your issue of March 9 reports that spokesmen for the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., accuse the steel industry of attempting pressure upon the Wage Stabilization Board to refuse their demand for a closed shop. They allege a flood of mail and telephone calls from Congressmen and industry sources to the board.

VIENNA, March 14 -- Elimination of an offer to buy back Russian-confiscated "German external assets" in Eastern Austria for $150,000,000 and deletion of a clause limiting the strength of the future Austrian army were the chief differences noted here today between the former draft of the Austrian state treaty and the abreviated treaty proposed by the three Western Occupying Powers.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Dr. Morton L. Levin, Assistant State Health Commissioner in charge of medical services, estimated tonight that 100,000 residents of the state would suffer acute heart attacks within the next twelve months. He said the majority would recover and from one-half to two-thirds would be able to resume work.

New Yorkers would pay higher rates for taxicab rides under a bill introduced into the City Council yesterday and referred to the committee on general welfare. The proposed fare increase would amount to 10 cents for the first mile and 5 cents for each additional mile.

In South West Asia and the Middle East, American-built aircraft have joined the fight against the destructive desert locust. Planes built in this country also have searched Saudi Arabia's arid regions for new water sources and have conducted aerial mapping projects in the Republics of Liberia and Bolivia, in Africa and South America.

The 3,520 student journalists atending the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association settled down yesterday to a full schedule of business meetings on the Columbia University campus.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Truman's attack Wednesday on the private power industry drew a retort today from the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

BONN, Germany, March 14 -- Repeated Communist insistence on attempting to confirm the Oder-Neisse line permanently now as Germany's eastern border is doing more to stir German national feelings about territories lost in World War II than any other cause, according to many political experts here.
Increased sales of foreign toys in this country were achieved by the second International Toy Exhibit, which closed yesterday at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 14 -The text of a bilateral military assistance agreement between Brazil and the United States, under negotiation here since Jan. 3, has been completed and awaits only the approval of President Getulio D. Vargas and the Brazilian Congress before being signed. It is not yet known when such approval will be forthcoming.

MADRID, March 14 -- At 6:30 o'clock this morning five Spanish anarchists, condemned to death on Feb. 7 by a military court for crimes, including murder and armed robbery, were executed in the Camp de La Bota prison in Barcelona.

OXFORD, Mich., March 14 -- A brigade of housewives who stood bravely between the sharp teeth of buzz saws and their beloved maple trees won the first Battle of Washington Street today. Circuit Judge George B. Hartrick issued a temporary order restraining a construction company hired by the state to cut down the huge maples in a road-widening project.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- William J. Grede, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, asked the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today to let the Defense Production Act die June 30, on the ground that price, wage and rent controls were unnecessary and ineffective.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The House Appropriations Committee recommended savings of nearly $1,400,000,000 today in the operation of the mere than two dozen independent offices of the Government during the fiscal year that starts July 1.

DETROIT, March 14 -- The international executive board of the United Automobile Workers. C. I. O., sat in judgment for nine and a half hours today on the elected officers of Ford Local 600, accused of violating the union constitution by collaboration with Communists, and then went into closed session to chart a ruling.

MADISON, Wis., March 14 -- The shadow of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower fell across the campaign paths of Gov. Earl Warren and Harold E. Stassen today as they continued to beat through Wisconsin's snow drifts for delegates to the national convention next July.
St. Ann's Academy defeated All Hallows, 57 to 53, to win the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball championship before 1,200 fans at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.
Elaborate plans have been made to protect President Truman when he comes here today to address 3,300 student editors at a luncheon meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The formal signing of a ten-year lease here today between the New York theatrical producing team of Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers and the Munsey Realty Company has brought about the re-establishment of the National Theatre as a legitimate drama house after more than three years as a motion-picture theatre.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 14 -- Taft Republicans in Louisiana held control of the State Republican Central Committee today but gave ground, under court order, to forces supporting General Eisenhower for President.

Nineteen persons, including a "big time" bookmaker and a Park Avenue surgeon, have been indicted here on charges of evading a total of $1,610,705 in Federal income taxes, United States Attorney Myles J. Lane reported yesterday.

The largest St. Patrick's Day parade in 270 years is expected in this city on Monday. More than 100,000 marchers, from pre-school-age children to octogenarian William Corrigan, sixty years a-marching with the Ancient Order of Hibernians, are scheduled to begin their fifty-two-block walk north on Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth Street at noon.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The international economic conference scheduled to convene in Moscow April 3 was stamped today by Secretary of State Dean Acheson as "a strategem to lure unsuspecting men of good reputation to participate in order to misuse their names and their public standing."

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet thwarted yesterday the immediate retirement of Deputy Chief Nathan Perlman, who was suspended Thursday on charges involving the shakedown of a Bronx merchant and the payment of a $1,000 bribe to former First Deputy Fire Commissioner James J. Moran, now serving a Sing Sing sentence for extortion and conspiracy.
WASHINGTON, March 14--Government attempts to delay the start of a nation-wide steel strike failed today and, under present plans, the industry will start cooling furnaces on Thursday.

More than two hundred baffled city detectives and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents continued without tangible result yesterday their search for the murderer of Arnold Schuster, 24 years old, who led the police to William F. Sutton, fugitive bank robber, last month.

DANVILLE, Va., March 14 -- Fears recently expressed by Southern concerns which export flue-cured tobacco to Great Britain that her economic plight would curtail imports of American leaf have been more than justified, according to companies here which do a large overseas business.

began I Fifteen accountants ex-] mimng yesterday thous, ands of in-] i i voices in the offices o/ ninetee, nI i wholesalers accused in over-ceilingI 'price deals in potatoes after sur[prise investigation carried out byl agents of the Office of Price StaI bilization before daybreak Thursday.

Today's events: "La Boheme" at 2 o'clock and "Die Meistersinger" at 7:30, Metropolitan Opera; Philharmonic-Symphony young people's concert, Igor Buketoff, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 11; Boston Symphony, Leonard Bernstein, conductor; Patricia Neway, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Concert Artists Guild, Steinway Hall, 4; Composers' concert, Carl Fischer Sky Room, 5.

Perhaps the most unusual sweets to appear especially for St. Patrick's Day are coconut cream bonbons dusted with cinnamon so they resemble Irish potatoes. These confections, with a delightful, not-too-sweet taste, are being offered in Gimbels new street-floor candy department.
BOSTON, March 14 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois said today that he did not think that "a man could run for two jobs in good conscience," and that his one ambition was to be re-elected.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -For the second day in a row a suspended New York tax official refused to answer House investigators whether he ever had taken a bribe, and a $3,500-a-year tax clerk estimated he had spent $18,350 last year.

An exercise based on the flying of blood plasma to Korea and subsequent evacuation of the wounded by air will be carried out at Sea Gate, Brooklyn, at 11 A. M. tomorrow with the cooperation of the Coast Guard, Marine Corps reservists and the Brooklyn Chapter of the Red Cross.

GENEVA, March 14 -- The Communist Governments' unceasing campaign to convince Western Europe that the United States, not the Communist bloc, is responsible for the decline in East-West trade was met head on today by Robert E. Asher, United States delegate to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.
ALBANY, March 14 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported these conditions at New York ski centers:

ALBANY, March 14 (AP) -- Legislative leaders and the United States Trotting Association reached a "compromise" today on a bill that gives the State Harness Racing Commission the czar-like powers now held by the U. S. T. A. over the sport in New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 (UP) -- The veteran Willie Hoppe, playing some of the most brilliant billiards of his long career, defeated Miss Masako Katsura of Tokyo, 50 -- 31, in the world three-cushion billiard championship tournament tonight.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 14 -- Today's court session at the trial of Michael Orecchio, former chief of the Bergen County Prosecutor's detectives, dealt with procedures in the handling of complaints and tips that came into the Prosecutor's office.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- A third "pilot" project will be set up to test the reorganization procedure over a widely scattered, more sparsely populated area. This district is expected to embrace Wyoming, Nebraska, Kansas, New Mexico, Colorado and Utah.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -Edward H. Foley, Under Secretary of the Treasury, said today he could not understand complaints by a Philadelphia Federal judge that the Justice and Treasury Departments failed to cooperate in a grand jury investigation of rackets.

Conservative action may minimize further inflation of values, Louis W. Dawson, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, told members of the New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers yesterday at their annual conference at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, March 14 (UP) -- Just when Britain was about to sink into post-budget melancholy, along came unexpected American aid today in the shapely person of Miss Sharon Koehnke -- who does not wish to be called "The Gorgeous Gussie of table tennis."

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- A nonpolitical $15,000-a-year District Commissioner will be in charge of all Federal tax operations in New York and Chicago. The New York Commissioner will have three deputies and the Chicago Commissioner one.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- John Marshall, out to duplicate his 1951 triple, bagged his second title and Dick Thoman scored impressively in the Payne Whitney exhibition pool tonight as Yale continued its domination of the twelfth annual individual invitation championships of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 14 (UP) -- Eighteen pygmy bushmen who came here to have their first look at white man's civilization, shrugged today and said they'd go back to the bush -- thank you.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Truman has established an "order of succession" among the seventeen ranking civilians at the Pentagon "to insure the continuity of operations of the Department of Defense in the event of disaster.
The National Health Council ended its thirty-second annual meeting here yesterday with delegates and board members uncertain as to what would be its future role in the nation's health program.

The big prize that eluded them a year ago will be within the grasp of the Dayton Flyers at Madison Square Garden tonight when the Ohioans face La Salle of Philadelphia in the final of the fifteenth annual National Invitation college basketball tournament.

The number of competitors in the international tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club, cut to twenty-one through the retirement of Gen. Manuel Soto-Larrea and Capt. J. J. Araiga, the Mexican representatives, was reduced further by the death yesterday of Juan Quesada, one of the eight Cuban entries, according to a report from Havana.

The police discovered last night that a Harlem funeral chapel was being used for a big dice game. It was, they said, a "floating game," one that operated on whatever premises seemed safe from prying eyes.

The Twentieth-Century Fund, a non-profit research agency in the field of economics, finance and social problems, recently asked the office of the President of Czechoslovakia if it should continue to send free material on Fund publications. The reply from "the Chancellory of the President of the Czechoslovak Republic" was: "Referring to your enquiry we wish to inform you that we have to decline your offer to continue to send studies and announcements of new publications."

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores for February were 3.6 per cent higher than for the corresponding 1951 month, according to a compilation of figures for forty-four companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The extra Leap-Year day last month gave it one more business day than in February last year.

Politicians used to have a slogan, "If you can't beat 'em, join 'em." Acting on that principle the New York City Youth Board has made a new approach to the problem of teen-age gangs in Brooklyn and, according to modest first reports, the technique seems to be working.
Commodity trading slowed down for the week-end yesterday and prices showed no trend. Rubber, hides and coffee moved higher. Sugar, cocoa and wool lost ground. Vegetable oils were mixed.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark March 15 (AP) -- The Danish Foreign Office is considering a strong formal protest against a Hollywood adaptation of the life of Hans Christian Andersen now in production at the Goldwyn studios. Danny Kaye is starred as the famous Danish fairy tale man.

Starting their eleventh year of cooperative advertising, the savings banks of New York State have increased their budget for 1952 by 50 per cent. Their aim is to sell more people on opening savings bank accounts. The kick-off ad of this year's campaign sets the theme: "Get Ready for the Thrill of Your Life -- Open a Savings Bank Account Today."
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 14 (AP) -Mrs. Babe Zaharias, a serious, studious golfer, topped the Titleholders field again today.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 14 (AP) -- The Delaware Power and Light Company announced today net income for 1951 of $2,735,348, equal to $1.68 a share of common stock, compared with $3,169,063 and $1.95 a share the year before.

The appointment of Dr. Foster S. Brown as president of the State University Teachers College at Oswego, N. Y., was announced yesterday by Charles Garside, acting president of the university. It was approved by the university's trustees at their regular monthly meeting at 522 Fifth Avenue.

Although the reasons are not clear, fish nets made of nylon twine seem to catch three to twelve times as many fish as those made of natural fibers. The possible reasons for this phenomenon are the translucidity of the nylon which causes the fish to overlook the trap, or the fact that the color of the nylon acts as a lure.
The following is a round-up of new products of interest to homemakers.

The little road through the Adirondack forest is no highway: a bulldozer made it by pushing its way straight through the woods for fifteen miles. In winter the way is frozen hard and is easily passable. In spring and summer it is muck and mud and impossible to travel.

New Delhi, India, March 14 -- The Japanese industrial mission that arrived Wednesday on a five weeks' study tour had informal discussions with Indian Government officials today. The talks related to projects in which Japanese capital, equipment and technical assistance would be immediately available.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -The Rev. Dennis J. Comey, arbitrator of waterfront trouble, averted today a third shutdown of the Port of Philadelphia, which has been closed to dry cargo shipping for nine days by disputes within the last two months.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Spokesmen for securities dealers protested today that proposed registration fees on investment brokers and dealers are "socialistic" and amounted to "double taxation."

HONG KONG, March 14 -- With political workers still processing tens of thousands of confessions and accusations in Red China, the Peiping Government has promulgated a new decree prescribing graduated penalties for all the big, medium and little "tigers" bagged by the state in its double-barreled drive against "corruption."

The boxing program at Madison Square Garden last night was marred by a main bout that was one of the worst in the history of the arena. In it Johnny Saxton, the undefeated welterweight from Brooklyn, was named the winner by a disqualification over Lester Felton of Detroit in 1:31 of the Sixth round.

ATHENS, March 14 -- The United States Ambassador, John E. Peurifoy, stepped into Greece's internal political arena today and in doing so appeared to win more praise than dispraise and more applause for clarifying the position of the United States in a Greek local issue than cries of protest against him for interference.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Grain trading was largely of local professional character today, the price course being choppy in all pits within a moderate range except for rye, which was independently strong on reports that Germany is in the market for large quantities of rye and grain sorghums.
ALBANY, N. Y., March 14 (AP) -The state set today a deadline of March 26 for carriers to pay the new weight-distance tax on big trucks.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Senate took up the Japanese peace treaty today in an atmosphere of harmonious bipartisanship and with ratification by a substantial majortiy in prospect.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Alabama's "regular" Democratic organization has asked the Supreme Court to reverse a State Supreme Court ruling that barred an advance pledge by electors to be chosen on the Democratic ticket in that state that they would support the party convention nominees for President and Vice President.

CLEVELAND, March 14 (AP) -Fred Wilt sprinted into the lead on the back stretch of the last lap and won the mile run tonight at the Knights of Columbus indoor track meet. The sweetness of the victory was marred by the absence of Don Gehrmann of Milwaukee, who withdrew from the meet at the last minute, pleading that his wife was ill.

Reduced factory operation caused by Government restrictions on the use of such raw materials as steel, copper, nickel and zinc was largely responsible for the drop in sales and earnings last year of the International Silver Company, Evarts C. Stevens, chairman, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

The final rush to file Federal income tax returns was well under way yesterday. All over town people stood or sat in lines at tax bureaus, post offices and banks, waiting for help in filling out forms. Today is March 15, ordinarily the last day for filing, but because it is a Saturday, tax offices will close at 5:15 P. M., and taxpayers will get a day of grace.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 14 -Willie Mays' first home run of the year, a three-run blast over the left-field wall in the fourth inning, highlighted the Giants' 6-1 victory over the St. Louis Browns today before 2,017 fans. Rogers Hornsby's men scored their only run off George Spencer with two down in the ninth.

" America and the Mind of Europe," edited by Lewis Galantiere, a composite report on the post-war European mind with particular reference to what Europeans today are thinking about the United States, will be published Monday by Library Publishers.
CLEVELAND, March 14 (AP) -One ore firm executive believes the coming iron ore shipping season, planned as the biggest in history, may not even reach last year's mark.

WASHINGTON iV[arch 14 o2P--' A prosecutor in' the Litchfield, t England, prison - camp brutality trials of 1936 today asked for a Senate investigation of the American Battle AIonuments Commission (A. B. M. C.).
New York University scored the opening triumph as the fifty-fifth annual intercollegiate fencing championships got under way yesterday in the flag-draped Columbia University gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission dismissed today a series of applications relating to proposed delivery of natural gas by Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, Shreveport, La., to the City Gas Company, Phillipsburg, N. J.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- A universal code of ethics for journalists was adopted today by a United Nations body of twelve news experts.

CHAMONIX, France, March 14 (UP) -- The Olympic skiing champion, Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence of Rutland, Vt., tied for third place today in the women's downhill event, which opened the famed Kandahar competition.

Amateur and professional gardeners augmented by carpenters, plumbers, painters and electricians are working at full speed today to prepare the thirty-sixth International Flower Show for its opening tomorrow. When the doors of Grand Central Palace open at 2 P. M., the public will be able to see this show on Sunday for the first time.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 15 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,189, for Thursday's operations:

Congress has now completed action on President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue. Any time for this action would have been good, but the Senate's vote on March 13 came at a particularly opportune time. It may have eased to a certain extent the sufferings of millions of citizens who haven't been quite sure that their hard-earned dollars were being scrupulously handled by the tax collector.
Almost pathetically overlooked by its diminished public, the Third Avenue Elevated took another step toward oblivion last night.

Gen. Fulgencio Batista, Dictator of Cuba, with some previous experience at his job, has directed his Cabinet to study the labor "problem." What is the labor "problem" in a dictatorship? The leaders of the free, democratic Cuban Federation of Labor are apparently in hiding or may have fled the country.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 14 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, ended his western campaign tour here tonight with a hammering attack against his three favorite targets in the Truman Administration.
I have read with a great deal of interest your editorial of March 11 "Another Cuban Revolt." I read it with special interest because I am a Cuban and have followed Cuba's history closely.
RANGOON, Burma, March 14 -- Burma is going through an encouraging phase in the Government's efforts to suppress Communist and other rebel groups within the country.

PITTSBURGH, March 14 (AP) -- The head of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation says the steel industry "must stand fast in our position" that wages can't be increased without a compensating boost in prices.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -Charles O'Gara, 34-year-old Assistant United States Attorney who touched off the explosive Internal Revenue Bureau inquiry here last year, resigned today.
UNITED NATION, N. Y., March 14 -- Following is the text of the draft international code of ethics for journalists approved today by the United Nations Subcommittee on Freedom of Information:

Ginger Rogers, who, after an absence of twenty-one years returned to the Broadway theatre last fall for a run in "Love and Let Love," is considering another try in the legitimate field during the next theatrical term.
Part of the famous collection of needlework formed by the late Mr. and Mrs. De Witt Clinton Cohen in their travels, are on exhibition and sale at Ginsburg Levy, 815 Madison Avenue.
The statement issued yesterday by Rudolph Halley, City Council President, on the city's fiscal crisis follows:

The stock market made another of its sudden shifts yesterday, this time rallying after the laggard performance of Thursday. Price improvements were highly selective, with best gains reserved for the oils and railroads, while the steels and motors turned softer.

BERLIN, March 14 -- The East German Government appealed to the Western powers and the West German Bundestag today to accept the Soviet proposal for a German peace treaty that would permit the creation of a limited German army.
Distribution of several weekly magazines to newsstands in the New York area was impeded yesterday by a strike of warehousemen and clerks of the American News Company.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The Assembly approved and sent to the Governor today legislation to declare as abandoned property dividends left unclaimed with brokers for five years after June 30, 1945.

In the twenty-one months between the setting up of the State Temporary Rent Commission and the end of January, 170 landlords, mostly in lower Manhattan, applied for permission to substitute self-service elevators for those operated by employes, a check of borough rent offices showed yesterday.
Religious leaders will intensify their interest in the performance of works of mercy among the aged needy here the coming week.

Secretary of the Army Frank Pace Jr. acknowledged last night a growing lack of confidence in the Federal Government and suggested, as one remedy, the formation of a nation-wide citizens "watch dog" committee.

MIAMI, Fla., March 14 -- The Yankees defeated the Dodgers in a seesaw battle, 6-5, before 9,664 fans in Miami Stadium tonight. It was their fifth straight victory and the sixth of seven played in the grapefruit league.

NEWARK, March 14 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will have first place on the voting machines in ten of the twenty-one counties in New Jersey, with Senator Robert A. Taft heading the ballot in nine counties and Harold S. Stassen in two, Republican partisans were advised today.

The suspension of two sentences that could have meant thirteen years in state prison was granted yesterday by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen to Edward J. Donnelly, 48-year-old former fireman who admitted being "a bagman" in the $500,000-a-year fuel oil shakedown manipulated by James J. Moran.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 14 (AP) -- Penn State dominated the quarter-final round of the forty-eighth annual Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championships tonight at Lehigh University as the Nittany Lions advanced six matmen into the semi-final round.

BERLIN, March 14 -- The East German Government appealed to the Western powers and the West German Bundestag today to accept the Soviet proposal for a German peace treaty that would permit the creation of a limited German army.

NEWARK, March 14 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will have first place on the voting machines in ten of the twenty-one counties in New Jersey, with Senator Robert A. Taft heading the ballot in nine counties and Harold S. Stassen in two, Republican partisans were advised today.

The suspension of two sentences that could have meant thirteen years in state prison was granted yesterday by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen to Edward J. Donnelly, 48-year-old former fireman who admitted being "a bagman" in the $500,000-a-year fuel oil shakedown manipulated by James J. Moran.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 14 (AP) -- Penn State dominated the quarter-final round of the forty-eighth annual Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championships tonight at Lehigh University as the Nittany Lions advanced six matmen into the semi-final round.

Irvington House in Irvington-on-Hudson will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Flight Into Egypt," on the night of April 1 at the Music Box Theatre. Mrs. Milton B. Eulau and Mrs. Lester Eisner Jr. are co-chairmen of the ticket committee for the benefit, and Mrs. Robert W. Sarnoff is one of the co-chairmen of the program committee.

At 2 o'clock this afternoon the first visitors will start their annual tour of the International Flower Show. All signs of last-minute preparations will be gone, and the fact that the four floors of Grand Central Palace were bare less than a week ago will seem incredible. Spring bulbs, perennials, annuals and flowering trees will appear as though the best days of spring and summer had been kaleidoscoped into one week.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, March 16 (AP) -- Allied planes killed an estimated 116 of the enemy on Korea's eastern front yesterday while ground fighting slowed to a virtual halt. The air strikes were in the Satae Valley and northwest of the "Punchbowl."

Boys High captured the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship yesterday by defeating Thomas Jefferson High, 59 -- 50, at Brooklyn College. The game was a play-off in the City P. S. A. L. tournament.

Will the grass roots support measure or men? Let us not take the platforms too seriously; but we can hopefully expect that the statements of policy will say what they mean and then mean what they say. Let the planks be broad and solid and not two-inch stuff. However, as one politico said: "A platform is meant to stand on -- not to run on."
PARIS, March 15 -- When Antoine Pinay's rather conservative Government began its perilous life this week, not many Frenchmen had confidence in its success.

The second annual ball of the St. Nicholas Society will be held on April 14, Easter Monday, in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Henry LeRoy Finch is president of the St. Nicholas Society, which maintains many traditions of Colonial times.

ALBANY, March 15 -- One hundred and eighty representatives of upstate tuberculosis, public health and heart groups formally organized the New York Heart Assembly today in an effort to promote state-wide cooperation in the battle against heart disease.

ARTUR Schnabel made a great many records and a number of his admirers have formed a committee with the aim of getting all the late pianist's recordings back in print, preferably on long-playing disks.

AFTER a lifetime of testing dwarf tree fruits here and abroad, I have arrived at fairly definite conclusions as to which are the most choice varieties. Naturally I refer only to my own favorites. In this way I escape the fate of having to select the "best varieties."

Considerable time has passed since the opening of Congress and original consideration of the mine safety bill. Many people are just as adamant for and against the bill now as they were when it started. The Neely bill, with amendments recommended by Oscar Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, passed the Senate Labor Committee, but so far there has been no further action on it.

CHAMONIX, France, March 15 (AP) -- Under snow conditions so perfect that the first twenty contestants broke the existing record, Fritz Huber of Austria won the men's downhill race in the international Arlberg Kandahar ski tournament today and William Beck of the United States scored a surprising fifth place.

FRANKFURT, March 15 -- Now would be the time for the Soviet leadership to study those Pavlovian experiments once again, the ones on conditioned reflexes. Nowadays no one jumps at the sound of the bell, experience having shown that the proffered plate bears no food.

IN this autobiographical novel, a Baptist preacher's son turns time backward and remembers a year in Sharonville, Ky., when he and his brother Joe were very young. Sharonville, in spite of the usual vicissitudes that beset a preacher's family, was a "place of pleasant bread," and the two boys, with Mother to brighten the rather dour corner where Father was, enjoyed their position of prominence in the small community.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson's relationship with Congress is a bit easier these days than it was a few months ago, but mainly in the sense that a battalion coming out of the line is less fiercely engaged than one going in.

WHEN the lady in charge of such things asked Jamie McRuin to state his wishes, he gave, as the one most important, that he should have a son who could speak Gaelic. Al Lewis may have met the lady also, although that is not part of the provable record.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 -- Yale ended its indoor track campaign today by defeating Dartmouth, 61 1/3 to 47 2/3, in the Coxe Memorial Cage.

TODAY will see the last two performances by the New York City. Ballet at the City Center until next fall after its return from an extended European tour. Jose Greco and his Spanish Ballet continue this week as one of the headliners on the bill at the Palace Theatre, presenting numbers from their regular concert program.

BURLINGTON, N. J., March 15 -- Winged Mercury, who has been outdistancing traffic, horse and automobile for seventy-one years here on the corner of High Street, finally had his wings clipped by a passing grocer's truck today.

Fifteen large gardens on the main floor set the pace for the International Flower Show. Ranging from April bulbs to August annuals, the plantings will remain the same throughout the seven days. On other floors however, new exhibits will be found each day.

An exciting feature of today's fashions is that the interest may be centered at either the front or the back of the skirt. Fullness is frequently pushed to the back leaving the front slim and straight. Or, in the reverse order, if the designer elects to provide an exciting entrance for her model, she will make the exit less conspicuous.

OVERCROWDING has become a serious problem on major highways throughout the country, according to A. C. Clark, deputy commissioner of the Department of Commerce's Bureau of Public Roads. Conditions are gravest on streets in urban areas land on the principal connecting highways between cities.

THERE'S a lady about town these days, enjoying herself immensely, name of Lady Browning. Her more familiar and more familiarly familial name is Daphne du Maurier. She's present for a number of seasons, perhaps the most important being the nice fact that her newest novel, "My Cousin Rachel," is the Literary Guild's selection for this month, at the same time that all hands -- author and organization -- are celebrating the Guild's twenty-fifth anniversary.

The Board of Estimate, in an unusual Saturday session, voted unanimously yesterday to create twenty-nine new positions of capain in the Police Department. The posts will be filled immediately by the last twenty-nine candidates on a civil service list that expired at midnight last night.

A. A. Milne in "New Explorations in Baker Street" (March 9) takes note of Dr. Watson's seeming confusion as to the actual location of a wound sustained during his years of service in India. The notion is advanced that neither the shoulder nor the leg sustained this injury but, instead, that it was the good doctor's head which the bullet grazed.

LOS ANGELES, March 15 (AP) -- A driving, windswept storm hit southern California from the north today, flooding homes in some areas, jamming traffic, causing one death and bringing a snow slide in the Sierra Nevadas that smashed part of a tungsten mill and flattened four houses.

DETROIT, March 15 -- The United Auto Workers, C. I. O., took over early today the operations of Ford Local 600 when it named a six-member administrative board to govern its 50,000 members at the River Rouge plant in Dearborn.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- A Government reform group told Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, today that his department needed a legislative overhauling.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 15 (UP) -- Whirling Bat, a bay son of Whirlaway, showed some of the speed that made his daddy one of America's top thoroughbreds as he opened the Lincoln Downs meeting today with a five-length triumph in the Inaugural Handicap.

Enrollment for the spring term at New York University has declined 4 per cent since last year, Dr. Elwood C. Kastner, registrar and supervisor of admissions, reported yesterday. Enrollment for the full 1951-52 academic year is expected to approximate 64,500, as compared with 68,170 last year, a decline of 5.4 per cent.
New York taxpayers, or at least some of them, are taking their time about settling their income taxes with the Government.

In a bond market dominated increasingly by the private placement of prime-risk debt with small groups of large insurance companies, what happens when a big issue of bonds of a top-ranking American industrial enterprise is distributed publicly to investors for the first time?

THE dinosaur grew and grew until there wasn't enough vegetation on earth to support it, whereupon it became extinct. Probably bridge tournaments will not have to be discontinued simply because they have grown so large, but one of their present problems can be attributed to growing pains.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 15 -- Penn State College won its second Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association team championship in a row by crowning three individual champions and scoring 33 points tonight. Syracuse finished second with no champions but 17 points.

SOMETHING over a century ago, when the American West was known only to American Indians, and a few heroic American trail-blazers, and a handful of European gentlemen explorers who used it as a vast park of curiosities where they might hunt strange creatures and stranger landscapes, the whole region was marked on maps as "The Great American Desert."

THIS study considers two questions: the permanent need for spiritual values in human life, and the power of such values to create new forms of expression when the old forms have lost their hold on the intellects, the wills and the emotions of men.

Representatives of 1,800 Girl Scout troops in Greater New York attended yesterday the annual "birthday" rally for the benefit of the Juliette Low World Friendship Fund. Proceeds are used to help Scouts abroad.

TOKYO, March 15 -- The joint Japanese-American working committee spelled out this week to the Japanese people some things that the administrative agreement between the two Governments and retention of United States bases here after the peace treaty will mean to them. In so doing the group moved a step toward allaying fears that the military occupation would merely be continued under another name.
MEXICO CITY, March 15 -- The painter, Diego Rivera, lost another round today in the controversy caused by his new mural, a huge canvas entitled "Nightmare of War and Dream of Peace."
Customs collections at this port fell sharply last month, despite a substantial increase in the number of ships and the amount of tonnage handled in the harbor, over the comparative period last year.

LAST Wednesday was the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the Japan Travel Bureau. An exhibition of Japanese dolls in the windows of American travel bureaus and the presentation of books and other gifts to the Chambers of Commerce of large cities in the United States, including New York, are marking the anniversary month.

THE professionally endorsed practice of planting roses for landscaping and functional purposes, rather than confining them to a formal garden, has received the enthusiastic support of the small home owner. This move toward the more casual, informal use of roses has been on the rise for years.

PARTICULARLY timely because the perennial agitation for Hawaiian statehood is currently hotter than ever, Eugene Burns' biography of King David Kalakaua quite objectively describes the inglorious course by which the turbulent Polynesian archipelago achieved the status of a United States territory.

President Truman, deeply tanned by the Key West sunshine, was probably seen by more out-of-towners than New Yorkers yesterday during his four hour and forty minute visit here to address the Columbia Scholastic Press Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE new 8,000-ton freighters now plying from Antwerp via Rouen and Le Havre to New York (Brooklyn docking), were a great surprise. I had always wished to cross the Atlantic on a freighter. Now that I have done so, I have lost some illusions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 15 -- Statisticians of the United Nations reported today that there had been a "marked and widespread" fall in death rates over the last twenty years. Couple that with increased birth rates, the experts said, and nineteen countries could expect to double their population within twenty - eight years.

ALL the rough rules so fashionable at the moment are broken by Mrs. Turnbull's tender new novel. It is buoyant with health and happiness despite the dramatic fullness with which it reports life and death in the village of Ladykirk.
Those who favor Government control of the professions are now eyeing the legal profession, Howard L. Barkdull, president of the American Bar Association, declared here yesterday.

AUTHOR of "To Tell Your Love" and other excellent novels for teen-agers, Mary Stolz tells here a different kind of story for younger children. It is a freshly imagined tale of the last elf in Ireland, for, so the story goes, the elves melted away when people stopped believing in them.

PARIS, March 15 -- Introducing his drive to bring down French prices, Premier Antoine Pinay announced today, effective Monday, a cut in the price of milk from 48 to 44 francs a liter. The Government also intends to release for sale a stock of 1,100 tons of Danish butter with the object of forcing French butter prices down.
DAYTON, Ohio, March 15 -- Who is going to wear the six shoulder insignia bearing the seal of the President of the United States?

SEVERAL morning and early afternoon television programs shortly will disappear from the airwaves. This may be a portent of hot weather programming curtailment to come or it may be a buckling under economic stresses and strains.

Individuals who have donated packages of rummage or articles suitable for resale in a four-week Thrift Gift Drive of the Play Schools Association have been invited to attend a party to be given by Princess Artchil Gourielli on Tuesday afternoon in her home at 625 Park Avenue.
Capt. Malachi Ephrath is a quiet, 28-year-old shipmaster who takes problems in stride in five languages.

POSTMASTER General Jesse M. Donaldson made available last week a photograph of the design of the 3-cent stamp which will be issued on May 15 preliminary to "a celebration which the people of the Columbia Basin are planning for May 22 to June 1 in observance of the first integrated portion of the big million-acre Columbia Basin reclamation project."

TELEVISION came to Hollywood last week in search of a story and, coincidentally, it became known that a major motion-picture studio had solved a story dilemma by purchasing a drama originally written and shown on television.

EDMONTON, Alberta, March 15 (Canadian Press) -- N. E. Tanner, Minister of Mines, annonuced last night that the first large-scale exploratory work toward extracting oil from the Athabasca tar sands in north-eastern Alberta will start this summer.
PANAMA CITY, Fla., Feb. 26 (Delayed) -- One of the smallest and most obscure naval stations in the nation, situated near here, is working on one of the Navy's biggest jobs.

ALBANY, March 15 -- The validity of the special election scheduled for April 1 in the Thirty-second Congressional District was challenged today by three Albany soldiers who charged that the right to vote had been denied them.

GENEVA, March 15 -- Every one of the countries expecting to participate in the European Defense Community, with the possible exception of Italy, is taxing its people at or above levels usually accepted as the limit that can be borne continuously by a non-totalitarian economy in peacetime.

WHILE New York's musical life has been holding to its established pattern, with the solo recital a dominant feature, a marked change has been coming about in other parts of the country. Manager after manager confirms the trend: in the last four or five years there has been an increasing swing to what is known as the "group attraction."

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The United States for the first time in its history has awakened to the prospect of an over-population problem, not unlike that which has troubled older countries in Europe and Asia.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- A clinical study of vacation architecture and planning at its modern best which might well influence the development of recreational centers even in staid New England has been a major project of students at the Harvard Graduate School of Design this winter, with Block Island as the laboratory.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The annual award of Stalin Prizes in literature, music and the arts -- numbering 102 this year, and totaling 4,000,000 rubles -- was accompanied today by sharp criticism of Soviet playwrights for their failure to develop realistic productions bearing on contemporary themes.

MR. HARRY GOLDGAR in his letter about my review of T. R. Henn's "The Lonely Tower" is somewhat confused in his memories of Yeats' autobiographies. "Yeats' theory and practice of poetry," he writes, "'owed much' to the theory and practice of Mallarme and the symbolists."

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- Senate investigators turned their attention today from profitable surplus ship sales to a deal involving a California aluminum plant on which Frank Nathan, Pittsburgh gambler, got a $57,000 "finder's fee."

Eisenhower supporters in New York said yesterday that Paul G. Hoffman probably would replace Arthur Vandenberg Jr. as chairman of the national Citizens for Eisenhower organization, which has headquarters at 51 East Forty-seventh Street.

MANY gardeners shy away from the botanical names of plants because, at first glance, they seem so formidable and unpronounceable with their Greek and Latin derivations. Yet anyone who can talk glibly of sulfanilamide or streptococci should have no trouble with parthenocissus or kolkwitzia.

THE introduction of fertilizers that dissolve in water is changing the whole approach to plant feeding. Liquid feeding is an old horticultural practice, but the application of liquid manure is giving way to the use of these more concentrated chemicals.
BOBBY JONES, a grandfather, will be 50 tomorrow.

HARRISBURG, Pa,, March 15 -- A German shepherd from Switzerland, Ch. Gretel V. Waidberg, owned by the Giralda Farms of Madison, N. J., became best in show tonight in the seventeenth all-bred show of the Harrisburg Kennel Club.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers and of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was asked by the Wage Stabilization Board today to delay for at least two weeks the start of a threatened country-wide steel strike scheduled to begin next Sunday at midnight.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Income tax returns of Attorney General J. Howard McGrath are expected to be requested by a House Judiciary subcommittee in its investigation of the Justice Department.

The National Federation of American Shipping challenged yesterday the factual accuracy of evidence presented in support of the St. Lawrence Seaway at recent hearings of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations.

TO win wars, a nation must win battles. To win battles, a nation must have a nucleus of competent military leaders who are dedicated to their profession, and to the lifetime service of their country. Because the founders of this nation had the foresight to establish a military academy, and later a naval academy, the United States has had such military leadership whenever it was needed.

Despite General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's New Hampshire primary sweep, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio still held a margin among the delegates already chosen for the Republican Presidential nominating convention, an Associated Press round-up indicated yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 15 -- A wide-open Republican primary election that will necessitate the longest party ballot in years was in prospect today for Union County. Every major state or county office except one will be contested, and a record registration points to a heavy vote.

Two items which have never been listed on the agenda of the Korean truce talks but have nonetheless exerted a potent influence on the negotiations are: first, the East-West propaganda battle for world opinion; and second, the relative military strength of the United Nations and Communist forces in Korea.

Last week the Administration's $7.9 billion foreign-aid program for fiscal 1953 started down the long road through Congress. On Thursday three committees -- Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services and House Foreign Affairs -- opened hearings on the program.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 15 -- The New Jersey Parks and Recreation Association, headed by Frederick C. Sutro of this city, has called upon all citizens to oppose state Senate Bill 68, which would open the Ocean County section of the Route 4 Garden State Parkway to commercial use as a freeway.

New Hampshire and After The first returns on the Presidential derby of 1952 came in last week. There was New Hampshire and, more important, its aftermath. They raised political interest and speculation, already unusually high for so early a stage of the campaign, to a new pitch of intensity.

The Port of New York Authority last week authorized construction contracts estimated at $265,000 in connection with an over-all $4,800,000 program for two new cargo terminal buildings and two new wharves at Port Newark.

Alban Berg's extended concert aria, "Der Wein," was the highlight of the Boston Symphony's final Carnegie Hall concert of the season yesterday afternoon. Patricia Neway was the soprano soloist, and the orchestra was conducted by Leonard Bernstein.

Members of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York will give a reception Wednesday afternoon in their headquarters at 122 East Fifty-eighth Street for Col. Francis Russell Stoddard, former governor of the society, an authority on Pilgrim history and author of the new publication, "The Truth About the Pilgrims."

RUTLAND, Vt., March 15 -- The United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's downhill championship held on Sunset Schuss at Pico Peak today, was captured by Lena Gale of the Mt. Mansfield Ski Club in a field of thirty-seven contestant.

A SPECIAL committee set up by the American Council on Education has been looking over the courses offered these days in colleges throughout the country. Its scrutiny is focused particularly upon the mental riches placed at the disposal of undergraduate athletes, the result of certain unhappy exposures in the realm of varsity sport.

IN appearance and manner Kim Hunter is the kind of informal, sensible looking young matron often glimpsed airing an offspring or exploring delicatessen shelves in the Bohemian sector of lower Manhattan. She also happens to be one of the busiest young actresses in America.

The Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton has an electronic computer that will deal mathematically in a few eye-twinklings with the variables that must be considered if we are to predict the weather with real accuracy. There may be as many as fifty of these variables, which include not only temperature, humidity, barometric pressure, direction and velocity of the wind but the earth's rotation, gravity and mountain barriers.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The defeat of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the New Hampshire primary not only has increased the chances of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination but also has encouraged the supporters of Gov. Earl Warren of California and of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

PERENNIALS have been changing gradually and almost imperceptibly since the first kinds were taken from their native fields and woodlands many years ago. Today, however, popular demand for easy gardening, prolific bloom and long-lasting cut flowers has considerable influence on selection of varieties.

Aggressive promotion at the manufacturing level can spell the difference between an average and an outstanding season, according to J. David Haft, president of the House of Swansdown, Inc., one of the largest producers of women's coats and suits in the country.

Indication that the current taste for the dark and decorated coupe-shaped plate is a positive step in the development of the dinner set may be seen in the dozen examples pictured at the left. As arranged by Helen Sprackling of the Franciscan Library of Ceramics they trace the chronological development of this object from a four-day-old "trencher" of bread through wood and pewter (large enough to serve two) to Wedgwood's earthenware.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Treasury Department disclosed tonight that it had blocked the accounts in the United States of the central bank of issue of East Germany, the Deutsche Notenbank in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, reported today that the armed services would need a "substantial" number of men this year, indicating a sharp step-up in draft calls this summer.

YOU and I care for actions, not words, except when we are doing the talking, but there is one thing which distinguishes our own rare lapses into oratory. We like to call a spade a spade. Others may get entangled in catchwords or lose themselves in a maze of verbiage. We always know what we mean, and say it, because we use this method of calling a spade a spade.

After deliberations lasting several months the Ford Foundation has decided to continue its activities designed to help Soviet refugees to become integrated as useful citizens of the non-Communist world. It announced yesterday new heads of the East European Fund, the foundation's subsidiary conducting work in this field.

AS wars went in the nineteenth century, the Civil War was a comparatively healthy one. Nearly three-fourths of the first British force to the Crimea died of disease; one in ten men died of disease and wounds in the Mexican War. The annual mortality rate of the Civil War was only 7.2 per cent.
In an atmosphere of soft lights and sweet music, the orchestra leader fixed his gaze on a slim young man dancing with a pretty girl. He signaled to the youth and said:

Unit costs, rising faster than the phenomenal increase in volume, are compelling the airlines to make minor increases in fares. It was learned yesterday that members of the Air Transport Association are preparing joint tariffs to add $1 to the cost of each ticket, abolish the 5 per cent reduction on round trip tickets and the midweek and family fares reductions.

IN a summer season, when soft was the sun, the child John Masefield, like Piers Plowman, was taken up Malvern Hills. There (where some of the earliest English verse began) he first relished what he had been told was "good air." It was clear, pellucid, with a northern ecstasy:

Department store sales last week again were down statistically. Dollar volume was 17 per cent below that of the like 1951 week, and merchants cited a number of factors. The comparative week last year marked the last phase of the scare-buying wave begun in late December, 1950.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 -- Wayne Moore foiled John Marshall's bid for a repeat triple victory tonight in a thrilling wind-up to the twelfth annual invitation individual champion ships of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League. From six feet behind at the 300-yard mark, the stocky Yale junior from Nichols, Conn., came cruising home under forced draft to beat his classmate and roomie from Australia by a stroke in the 440-yard free-style.

NEW home owners, dreaming of ornamental borders, flourishing vegetable plots and flagstone terraces, often find that a mortgage-weighted budget creates a gap between what they would like to have and what they can afford.

BONN, Germany, March 15 -- The State Government of Bavaria, following direct intervention by John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, has agreed to pay 19,000,000 Deutsche marks [$4,523,900] for claims by the Jewish joint restitution successor organization regarding heirless Jewish property in that state.

The Institute of Design of Illinois Institute of Technology announced a new graduate program leading to the degree of Master of Science in Art Education. This program will offer primary and secondary schools as well as college teachers the most advanced techniques for the training of students at all age levels in art and design.

IF you are fortunate enough to have dogwood, rhododendron, arbutus or gentian growing on your property, you're not guilty of a misdemeanor if you pick it. That may appear to be a superfluous statement, but there seems to be a widespread belief that certain shrubs or flowers must never be picked -- no matter where they happen to be growing.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 16 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,190, for Saturday's operations:

NEW CITY, N. Y., March 15 -- There will be contests in four of the eleven Rockland County village elections next Tuesday, with a fifth contest possible through a write-in vote for police justice in South Nyack, where all candidates but one have been removed from the ballot by court order.

OTTAWA, March 15 -- Canada's defense production effort has been substantial and on the whole satisfactory during the last year, C. D. Howe, Minister of Defense Production, told the House of Commons yesterday.

Activity in the wholesale market here last week was generally slow, with some reorders in various departments for spring merchandise, resident offices reported. Stocks were well in hand and stores were determined to keep them that way.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The chief Republican tax spokesman in the House of Representatives, Daniel A. Reed of New York, promised voters today that he would move to cut taxes next year if they returned his party to power in the November elections.

Programs for the Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood, Mass., has been announced by the Boston Symphony. As in previous years, the main concerts in the Music Shed will be divided into Series A, B and C. There also will be concerts by a chamber orchestra in the Tanglewood Theatre.

What happens when labor-management relations become too dependent on Government was demonstrated again last week when 5,000 Midwest railroad workers struck in a vain effort to end the three-year-old contract dispute between the carriers and the railroad brotherhoods.

The national elections of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., covering the deep seas, the Great Lakes and the rivers, will open on April 1, with 281 candidates contesting for the 108 elective posts in the union.

ALBANY, March 15 -- New York was empowered to take title to the historic Brooklyn Academy of Music and develop it into a permanent civic and cultural center under a bill signed into law today by Governor Dewey.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 15 -- Darmouth's basketball team scored a startling upset over Cornell, 72-65, in the final game of the season for both teams tonight.
MASON CITY, Iowa, March 15 -- A fight to the finish has shaped up for control of Iowa's twenty-six delegates to the Republican national convention in Chicago.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 15 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge of Connecticut will give the keynote address for the tenth annual Middlebury College Conference to be held March 22 and 23. He will speak here Saturday morning, March 22.
St. Vincent's Hospital will celebrate a St; Patrick's Day anniversary today with a birthday cake to mark its five-year-old "share the nurse plan" for private and semi-private patients.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., March 5 (AP) -- United States curling rinks withstood a determined threat by Canadian entries today to win the two-day Gordon international Bonpiel medal, 287 -- 264.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15 -- Yale shattered a Harvard zone defense with a 22-point spree in the third period and went on to defeat the Crimson by 71 -- 51 tonight at the Harvard indoor building before 1,200 fans.

Arthur C. Ebbinger, president of the Brooklyn baking company bearing his name, announced last night the settlement of a strike that began March 6, caused a shutdown of the company's plant at Bedford Avenue and Albemarle Road and forced the closing of its forty-two retail stores in Brooklyn.

Grosvenor Neighborhood House at 321 East Forty-ninth Street will be the beneficiary of the performance of "One Bright Day" on the night of March 25 at the Royale Theatre. Mrs. John S. McCook and Mrs. Sidney Mathews are co-chairmen of the committee in charge of the sale of tickets for the benefit and among their aides is Miss Clara F. Workum.

Crews of three radio patrol cars made an unsuccessful search of the Victoria Theatre, Broadway and Forty-sixth Street, last night after the police had received an anonymous telephone call that a bomb would be exploded there.
The nation's electric power and light industry is set for a record-breaking year.
INDIAN pudding, apple pandowdy, shoo fly pie, baked beans and brown bread are among the typically American dishes that owe much of their distinction to one ingredient, molasses.

Women headed by Mrs. John F. X. Finn, chairman, and Mrs. William C. H. Georgi de Mallerais, vice chairman, are working for the success of the annual Loyola luncheon and card party four the benefit of the Jesuit Seminaries to be given on March 27 in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.
EVIDENCE that brotherhood is indeed wonderful was revealed last week through the news that the Weinberg family is preparing to produce an independent feature film titled, "Angels, Devils and Women."

IF you like the harp, or if you ever wondered just what that romantic instrument really sounds like, you have a rare opportunity to satisfy yourself this morning. The disk is called simply The Harp, and it consists of a recital by one of today's masters, Edward Vito (Sounds of Our Times, ten-inch).

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 15 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower "will take no part" in the formation of any political organization in the United States or in the selection of persons for such an organization, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, a leading Eisenhower supporter, declared here today after conferring with the Supreme Commander.

While the United States has "a deep responsibility" to apply moral law, or "the law of love," to international relations, it nevertheless must guard against permitting emotion to lead to "wholesale benevolence," Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont warned yesterday.

Here on the banks of the Mississippi ninety miles upstream from New Orleans, it is heartening to see the medical officers at the United States Public Health Service Hospital, through research and controlled clinical studies, attack one of mankind's earliest afflictions -- Hansen's disease or leprosy.

A PATCH of herbs outside the kitchen door is an old-fashioned idea which, fortunately, is back in style again. Modern gardeners are quick to realize that grandmother's herb row was not only practical from a culinary standpoint, but pleasing to the eye.

LONDON, March 15 -- The underlying economic problem before Britain, which Chancellor Richard A. Butler's budget was intended to solve, was how to carry a burdensome rearmament program on top of an already overstrained economy without running hopelessly into debt with the rest of the world and without bringing on a runaway inflation at home.

IT is about ten years since the enormously popular and profitable practice of recording the entire score of Broadway's successful musical shows was initiated. Decca paved the way with its "Oklahoma" set, and nearly every musical of any consequence -- the principal and sad exception was Marc Blitzstein's "Regina" -- has had extensive attention from the record-makers.

The show went on and on over at a television studio of the National Broadcasting Company yesterday and at the end of sixteen and a half hours, sixty performers had collected $1,148,419 for a proposed New York cardiac hospital.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (UP) -- Diane Halprin, not yet 7 years old, made music history at the Academy of Music today when she appeared as violin soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra.

The Syracuse Nationals, first-place winners in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association, presented no great problem to the Knickerbockers at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. Helping the New York club close its regular home campaign, the upstaters went down to a 97-90 defeat after trailing most of the contest.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- St. Augustine's Fred Francis and W. I. Drysdale scored an upset 1-up nineteen-hole victory today over favored Al Ulmer and Tommy Aycock, veteran Jacksonville linksmen, in the senior best-ball golf tournament final.

Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires was back in first place in the international masters' tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club after drawing his adjourned fifteenth-round game with Herman Steiner of Los Angeles yesterday, according to a report from Havana.

With a bow in the direction of the International Flower Show, which opens this afternoon, the Museum of Natural History revealed yesterday its secrets of transforming cotton, wax, nylon and plain old crepe paper into blossoms scarcely detectable from anything the Grand Central Palace display can offer.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Has inflation lost its steam? It has, at least for the present.

A gratifying part of the Eisenhower victory in the New Hampshire primary last week was the size of the vote. In spite of bad weather the turnout was record-breaking. General Eisenhower was chosen as the favored candidate by a larger part of the electorate than is usually vocal.
