Women represent a "great source of qualified talent" that could alleviate the shortage of engineers in this country, Beatrice A. Hicks, president of the Society of Women Engineers, said yesterday.

BELGRADE, March 15 -- The display of goods in the shops of Belgrade frequently creates the illusion among newcomers that there has been a substantial improvement in the economic situation. What the visitor is seeing is the end product of the American raw materials aid program, supplemented by similar programs from Great Britain and France.

BERLIN, March 15 -- The East German Government said tonight, in an announcement released through its Ministry of Foreign and Domestic Trade, that East German dollar accounts in the United States were blocked last Tuesday by order of the Treasury Department.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- With both political parties stepping up the tempo of their drives for delegates to the national conventions in Chicago in July, the filing deadlines today had passed in all states but two -- California, where the limit is April 9, and South Dakota, where the time is May 3.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- State Department officials reacted enthusiastically today to the signing of a military aid agreement with Brazil. They described the pact as "an important step forward" in carrying out the collective defense of the Western Hemisphere.

ONE of the slight considerations to be taken into account by the makers of motion pictures is the dimly annoying fact that some of their patrons have a knowledge of the subjects of their films. Somehow there's always somebody in a movie audience who is an expert about the picture's subject -- or maybe just thinks he is -- and this is the wise somebody of whom the producer must beware.

LONDON, March 15 -- Chris Chataway of Oxford, Brit/ Olympio prospeot, ran the fatest mile o the year in Europe and nLhed in a ded heat for first in the three mile race today as Oxford dted Cambridge. 6g---58, in their seventy-seventh -nual trsk and field meet.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 16 -- The Communists lodged a bitter protest today on rioting in a South Korean prison camp that resulted last week in the death of twelve prisoners and injury to twenty-six others. The enemy demanded that the United Nations give a guarantee against a repetition of the fatal incident.

JUST six months ago we reported in this column on a paper presented at a family conference which drew a distinction between "permissive" and "traditional" attitudes toward child rearing and strongly inclined in favor of the former.

A requiem mass for Thomas J. Patterson, retired city Budget Director, was celebrated yesterday in St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church, 135 East Ninety-sixth Street. More than 200 persons, including many public officials, were present.

WHEN it was announced a few weeks ago that Queen Juliana of the Netherlands would visit Washington from April 2 to April 5, the mythmakers promptly floated the canard that the Queen had carefully avoided arriving on April 1, All Fools Day.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 15 -- Mrs. Mildred Zaharias appeared today to be on her way to a new Titleholders golf tournament scoring record. Her score for the third round was 73, best of the day. Her fifty-four hole total of 220 leads by setven strokes on the Augusta Country Club course.

ALFRED DUGGAN'S civilized mockery removes the rust from still another chapter of ancient history in his second novel. Blandly he uncovers the dark skulduggery which brought a Saxon invasion to fifth-century Britain and elevated one Cerdic Elesing to dominion over Wessex, cradle of English kings.

Government figures just released show that Federal excise tax collections from liquor sales during January dropped a full 52.3 per cent below those collected a year ago. In January, 1951, $211,528,000 was taken in, while this January the collections totaled only $100,780,000 -- a drop of $110,748,000.

CHILDLESS adults are not to take fright when little boys hiss like untended steam boilers and break into gibberish that seems without earthly connotation. The symptoms merely indicate a sharp trend among small-fry from Westerns to interplanetary consciousness.

EVERYONE has heard the old Texas saying: "There's no law west of the Pecos." A California countepart runs: "There's no law above three thousand feet." There is a variant: "Look out for any town when the roadsign shows the figure for the altitude bigger than for the population."

THIS department has so often acclaimed George Harmon Coxe as one of the most solidly professional craftsmen in the mystery field that it's a great pleasure to announce his new and well-earned honor: unanimous election to the post of national president of Mystery Writers of America, Inc.
An outstanding sale of antique Oriental rugs, collected by Quill Jones, recently retired New York dealer, will be held on Friday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

TWO of the best known trains in the East, the Pennsylvania's Congressional between New York and Washington and the Senator between Boston, New York and Washington, will take to the rails tomorrow, completely reconstituted with shiny new streamlined cars incorporating many new facilities.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A Senate subcommittee will try to get answers next week to some delicate questions raised by the reality of Communist-dominated unions in defense plants and how to deal with them.

BECAUSE of the grand scale on which they are staged, the big city flower shows must be regarded as a kind of spectator sport by most gardeners. It is fun to look at an impressive exhibit put together by a dozen workmen and supervised by a half-dozen others.

ROYAL BRUTON, local tycoon of the village of Devon, South Carolina, does not yield easily to change. But the Old Order meets opposition in 1932. Jay, Royal's favorite son, defies his father; marries for money, and quits Bruton Spinning, the family cotton mill.

NEW ORLEANS, March 15 (UP) -- The owners of a $2,907,257 Army-built engineer depot that was sold as surplus for $205,000 denied today that they were making a "huge profit" from rent being paid by the Air Force.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 15 -- A television projector and receiver that provide "programs" featuring live blood cells are being used in the Bureau of Biological Research at Rutgers University for research into the nature of leukemia.

THOSE rumors about Shirley Booth's being in the new Arthur Laurents play, "The Time of the Cuckoo," are herewith and forthwith confirmed. Locked in the vault of the producing team of Robert Whitehead and Walter Fried is Miss Booth's signed contract, her signature affixed before her recent departure for Hollywood, where she is to make the film version of William Inge's play hit, "Come Back, Little Sheba."

THIS new book by a writer whose stories of wild animals have been eagerly read takes place in the mining country of Colorado. To earn money for college, two high school graduates form a partnership to pack ore and lumber for a copper mine high in the Rockies. Roy has the experience and some burros; Frank has a few dollars, intelligence and the will to learn.

THE camellia, long "the aristocrat of Southern gardens," is well on its way to nationwide prominence. Its popularity has spread to the West Coast, and to the Northeast, where it is being grown in greenhouses, trial plantings outdoors in sheltered areas, and as a pot plant.
MIAMI, Fla., March 15 -- Last night the Yankees were complaining about the hardness of the Miami Stadium infield and suggesting that it needed sprinkling.
In the first operation of its kind in New York Harbor and probably in any port in the world, two passenger liners exchanged identities last week in all but name and flag.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 15 -- The United States may ask the United Nations to conduct an investigation of Soviet charges that the United States has launched germ warfare in Korea and China.

Fresh strawberries in June, a bunch of grapes off the vine in September, gooseberry preserves on the shelf in winter -- even the home owner with limited acreage can enjoy these delicacies. It is not difficult to find space for these and some of the other small fruits.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 15 -- Scantily financed but fired with renewed enthusiasm by the results of the New Hampshire primary, Minnesotans for Eisenhower worked through volunteers and word-of-mouth advertising today to get out a write-in vote for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Republican Presidential primary Tuesday.

TWENTIETH - CENTURY America is coming to recognize its debt to Thomas Jefferson, the towering figure of late eighteenth and early nineteenth century America. The fifth volume in the great Princeton project for the publication of Jefferson's papers is reviewed on this page.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- A proposal for a survey of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization by a nonpartisan commission was approved today by a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee.

In the presence of an enthusiastic ex-editor of The Gleam, the newspaper of the Independence, Mo., High School, 3,300 student journalists ended yesterday the business of their twenty-eighth annual convention, the largest ever conducted by the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.

FRANCIS X. ]USCH, who was Corporation Counsel in Chicago twenty to twenty-five years ago, has squeezed six outstanding American trials into these two volumes without giving an impression of tightness.
NEWARK, March 15 -- Harold J. Adonis is being "sought" by both state and Federal officials here for questioning about gambling in Bergen County.

While the recent ruling of the Wage Stabilization Board on pension and profit-sharing plans, which virtually freed them from inflation controls, has met with general approval, certain sections of the order are causing concern for administrators and may have to be adjusted.

Americans know too little about the world they have been called upon to lead, an English map maker said here last week, because their atlases are not good enough and they are not taught geography as well or as much as they should be.

AT some time or other the average home owner daydreams about growing his own vegetables, or at least trying his luck with a few of his favorites. Too often the idea never becomes reality, usually because the gardener feels he does not have enough space.

THE Russians play chess with a wizardry that suggests they invented the game. This is a claim they have not yet made, but a hint that they might be thinking along these lines is contained in a report sifting through to Radio Free Europe.
A group of Atlantans paid tribute to Bob Jones last night at a fiftieth birthday party at the Peachtree Golf Club.

THREE weeks ago I blew my top over the current issue of The Hopkins Review. There have been a lot of letters, chiefly in thanks for my exasperation with much of the stuff printed in our avant-garde quarterlies.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 15 -- Eight months ago the sun was warm over this part of Korea when officers of the United Nations Command and of the Communist armies first met to arrange terms for a cease-fire. This week, at Panmunjom, spring came back again and magpies pecked in the muddy rice fields under the warm sun of another year; but peace still had not come to Korea.

WHEN George VI died on Feb. 6, Marion Crawford, his children's former governess and author of "The Little Princesses" and "Mother and Queen," was finishing a book about Princess Elizabeth, the Heiress Apparent.

WINNER of the Jack and Jill magazine prize contest, this is a story of Egypt when Khufu (or Cheops) was building his great pyramid at Gizeh. Like ancient Egyptian wall paintings it is brightly colored, full of interesting detail and action and, too, the characters are for the most part portrayed in the flat.

Editors and representatives of twenty-seven newspapers in sixteen states and the District of Columbia will meet at Columbia University tomorrow for a two-week seminar to consider their common problems. The meetings were arranged by the American Press Institute.

The term "collapsible corporation" came into use for the first time in the Revenue Act of 1950. This was described as a device for converting ordinary profits into capital gains, whether derived from liquidation or otherwise. Prior to this act there was no statutory provision for taxing collapsible corporations as such.

The deliberations of four scholars, gathered on the mezzanine floor of the Henry Hudson Hotel yesterday to consider archaeological excavations in Jericho, were conducted to the tune of an entirely unrelated television show group rehearsing, "Joshua fit de battle ob Jerico, Jerico, Jerico!"

Mrs. Robert W. Dowling, president of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, will give a cocktail party tomorrow afternoon in her home, 990 Fifth Avenue, for the committee planning a benefit at the premiere of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet March 25 at the Warner Theatre, Mrs. H. Alwyn Inness-Brown is chairman of the executive committee.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15 -- The new Italian luxury liner Augustus reached Rio de Janeiro early this evening on her maiden voyage to round out the Italian Line's air-conditioned express service to South American ports.

PARIS, March 15 -- Deputies of the eighteen countries that are members of the Council of Europe began a series of meetings here today to prepare the agenda for the meeting of the Council's Committee of Foreign Ministers, which will be held in Paris starting Wednesday.

VEGETABLE gardening has changed quite a lot since some of us were first permitted -- or persuaded -- to lend a hand with the hoe. Modern knowledge of genetics has enabled seed growers to develop improved varieties. Almost equally great advances have been made in commercial quick-freezing, canning and the fast distribution of fresh produce from specialized vegetable growing areas.

The International Boxing Club decided yesterday to omit Johnny Saxton from any immediate ring programs under consideration. The Brooklyn welterweight, winner of all twenty-five of his professional fights, was so unimpressive in his victory over Lester Felton in Madison Square Garden on Friday night that Matchmaker Al Weil abandoned intentions of putting him in with Johnny Bratton.

Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet Union's Deputy Foreign Minister, has managed to reach a new low in falsehood and fantasy even for him. In a committee of the United Nations he has now associated his country with formal charges that the United States is using germ warfare in Korea and China.

THE ladies of the Greenwood Federation of Garden Clubs in South Carolina had no difficulty in interesting the little girls from the children's home in gardening activities. After the showing of a colored garden movie, a member of the institution's staff told a club representative that the children were so eager to have flowers of their own to grow that they were starting geraniums in tin cans.

TIGNES, France, March 15 -- This Alpine village, condemned to death by drowning behind a new hydroelectric dam, won a forty-eight hour stay of execution today, principally because its 500 mountaineer citizens refused to accept the sentence and outfaced their executioners.
MADISON, Wis., March 15 (UP) -- State aid to fourteen public schools having Roman Catholic nuns as teachers was cut off today by George Watson, State Superintendent of Public Instruction.
The home furnishings industry needs a doctor again.

The Long Island Rail Road will offer special reduced round-trip fare for groups of five or more adults or children who wish to attend the International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace. The show will be held for seven days, beginning today.

Cotton price movements in the domestic trading market were irregular last week. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange opened firm, then turned downward until the final day's session, when they staged a marked recovery.

THE wheel has gone full cycle. Once more the attention of the entire country -- and of the world as well -- will be centered on the proceedings of our two great political parties when they meet in their national conventions at Chicago in July to write their platforms and name their Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates.

MAJOR factors in the business picture continued to show a degree of drift last week in the pattern which has been familiar since the first of the year. Chief interest centered in whether the passing of the income tax deadline tomorrow will bring an improved psychology.
If New York Curb Exchange plans work out, the common stocks of Japan's leading corporation will be traded on its floor, perhaps before the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The Truman Administration and the American Medical Association were at odds again today over Federally financed medical aid -- this time over a proposal to pay medical bills for wives and infants of service men.

LOMETA, Tex., March 15 (UP) -- Twenty-five hundred men of the Eighty-second Airborne Division made a practice jump for the biggest Army-Air Force maneuver in history today and medical officers reported twenty-five cases of broken bones and thirteen sprains.

ALTHOUGH Briar, a gold-and - white collie, early learned to herd cattle on the hills of Ireland, she was intended to be a show dog. Bought by the owner of a famous American kennel, she was unhappy, sulked in the show ring and so was sent off to a farm in Maine.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 15 -- The magic name of the Kentucky Derby today drew a list of 167 nominations for this year's version of the internationally known turf classic.
Undismayed by a two-pronged Senate attack, Newbold Morris said here last night that he had no intention of resigning and termed the criticism "part of the attempt to destroy my character."

Plans are being advanced for the luncheon in behalf of the Lots For Little Shop to be given on April 22 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. William C. O'Keeffe heads the benefit committee.
COLORADO SPRINGS, March 15 (UP) -- Favored Michigan did as was expected tonight, using its manpower to down Colorado College, 4 -- 1, and keep its National Collegiate Athletic Association title.

AN INCREDIBLE span of sixty - three years separates Richard Strauss' Violin Concerto, Op. 8 and his Oboe Concerto. The former, a student work, was completed in 1882, the latter in 1945. Both have just been released on a Urania disk, with Siegfried Borries playing the violin, Erich Ertel, the oboe, and Arthur Rother conducting the Symphony Orchestra of Radio Berlin.

A SECURE place in the family is every child's foundation for strength and confidence. With gentle rhythm, easy rhyme and quiet illustrations Inez Hogan reminds children, in stories of five animal families, of their own safe place in the pattern.

HAVANA -- The rattle of machine guns and the crash of rifle fire in midtown Havana last Monday, when the coup d'etat by Gen. Fulgencio Batista ousted the administration of Cuba's President Carlos Prio Socarros, disturbed but failed to affect the tourist season in Havana to any serious degree.

LIKE her earlier work. Louise Townsend Nicholl's "The Explicit Flower" is delicate and precise. Her favorite themes, as always, are drawn from religion, art and physical nature. Probably none is more successful than "Tavistock Square," her little elegy for Virginia Woolf, with its charming evocation of Mrs. Woolf's voice in the perfect setting, the novelist's own room.

BOSTON, March 15 (UP) -- The Democratic State Committee pressed a fight today to keep Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee out of the Massachusetts primary as his supporters charged that forces of President Truman were "afraid of any open contest."

The house need not lack flowers while they can be picked in the garden. Bulbs in spring, roses from June to October, annuals from summer to frost are the chief sources of supply. Leaves and foliage, too, are plentiful during these seasons. A few of their own leaves are often nice with daffodils, violets and roses, but leaves of another sort might be used occasionally to work out a change in design.

The vernal equinox will be here this week. Next Thursday, in fact, shortly before noon; Thursday morning will still be winter, officially, and Thursday afternoon will be spring, by the calendar. And daylight that day will be approximately the same length as darkness.
Greater concern over scoffers at religion than over Communist attacks upon it was expressed in a sermon yesterday morning by Rabbi Julius Mark at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

A worried mother walked into the Catholic Charities Guidance Institute one morning last October with her 10-year old daughter. She explained hesitatingly that the school doctor had referred her daughter, Jane, to the institute because she stuttered so in class.

Lawrence's lines, a poet almost abnormally sensitive to visual beauty, and a passionate woman sometimes unable to distinguish the English rivers and rocks she knows from her own bloodstream and bones.

ONLY the soft, sure hands of a woman could take hold of so delicate a topic as the effect of love on public affairs. Male writers have given thought to the subject, of course, but their ultimate reaction is typified by that book of Robert Benchley's, "Love Conquers All."

The last in a series of ten lectures on Wagnerian operas will be given tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street Dr. Curt Sachs, music historian who has been conducting the series and who has been lecturing on music at the library for thirteen years, will speak on "Die Meistersinger."
ROME, March 15 -- By 148 to 97, the Senate approved today Italy's entry in the Schuman plan to pool Europe's coal and steel under a fifty-year treaty.

SEATTLE, March 15 (AP) -- A superior judge has found the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards in contempt of court for failing to explain why it had not turned $298,000 in defense bonds over to a receiver.
LIFE in a Nova Scotia deanery. circa 1905-7, provides the setting for this gentle, rambling first novel by Basil Partridge, a retired advertising man of Toronto.

NINA FOCH is a young actress who ran away from a long-term movie contract in Hollywood because television offered better opportunities -- at least in her particular case. One film role after the other typed her as a crisp, sophisticated blonde who always lost the hero to another woman in reel seven -- most recently in "An American in Paris."

TROY, N. Y., March 15 -- Iona of New Rochelle entered the quarterfinals of the national Catholic basketball tournament by beating Gannon (Pa.), 68 -- 52, in a first-round game tonight. LeMoyne of Syracuse advanced by eliminating Providence, 67 -- 63.

BETWEEN the excesses of the "impressionist" among contemporary photographers and the work of the technical extremists lies the happy medium wherein the craftsman strives only to suit the technique to the subject.
Negro education has made tremendous strides in the South in the last ten years.

SUGGESTIONS last week that La Guardia and New York International Airports be shut down and their activities shifted to MacArthur Airport near Lake Ronkonkoma in Suffolk County were undoubtedly made in good faith and in the belief that such a change could be made without too much trouble.

Did Picasso nod, or what? Why -- especially for a natural history -- did he give the grasshopper eight legs? God never made a grasshopper with eight legs. No insect has more than six legs, unless some abnormal aberration has set in.

JUST under the brow of a New Hampshire hilltop sits a small house. Windows are narrow and tight against winter winds -- all but one. One wide pane looks north across neighborly hills to a broad-topped mountain. With such a view there is no need to hang a landscape painting on the living-room wall.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 15 (AP) -- Harold John Adonis, former aide to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, was mistakenly arrested here Thursday when he apparently was confused with Joe Adonis, the gambler, to whom he is not related.

A TEACHER of modern European history at Smith and Bennington Colleges presents in this slender volume what Norman Thomas, in his introduction, accurately describes as a "brief, concise and perceptive story of the rise of modern communism" in the twentieth century.

La Salle's over-all excellence paid off in the national invitation tournament final at Madison Square Garden last night. Probably the most underrated quintet of the twelve college teams in the fifteenth annual post-season competition, Ken Loeffler's Explorers, who grew in stature with each game, easily routed Dayton University, 75 -- 64, and, in addition to picking up the marbles, gained a berth in the forthcoming Olympic trials.

TREADING the twin theatrical tightropes of writing and producing is an acrobatic feat that Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse have been performing on Broadway for the past dozen years. So far, they have done it with the grace of veteran circus artists, and have slipped just as rarely.

Coming across the Atlantic during the next two months just to race from Newport to Bermuda are seven yachts. They were listed yesterday among thirty-two entries announced by Ernest A. Ratsey, race chairman and former commodore of the Cruising Club, which will conduct the event together with the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club.
After ten years of research, medical scientists have produced from the red cells of human blood what is considered a substitute for, and adjunct to, blood plasma.

ARTHUR WATKINS, the astute and articulate executive secretary of the British Board of Film Censors, achieved a long-cherished personal ambition when the "X" certificate for films was introduced just over a year ago.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 15 -- A close race between Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for this state's Republican support was developing today as the Ohioan's 4-to-1 lead was cut to a narrow margin of two delegates to the party's state convention.

TORONTO, March 15 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, getting a three-goal performance from Sid Smith, kept in the fight for second place tonight by defeating the New York Rangers, 5 -- 2, in a sluggish National Hockey League game before 13,314 fans.

The charge of the Chinese Communists that between Feb. 25 and March 5, in many flights, 448 planes of the United States Army in Korea started epidemics by dropping infected animals and insects in Korea and Manchuria and on Northern Chinese communities will be greeted with derision by bacteriologists.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 15 -- Interest in national politics has over-shadowed flurries of activity in the campaigning for home-rule elections to be held next Tuesday in forty-seven of Nassau County's incorporated villages.

Another step in the construction of the Harlem River Drive, which will complete the city's arterial system, was taken last week with the award of a contract for building of a bulkhead wall from 135th Street to 138th Street.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Army said today its economy drive had "caught on amazingly well" and one big reason was that its personnel, heavy taxpayers themselves, were as anxious as anybody to cut costs.

THOSE who some time ago had their first pleasurable encounter with a cartoon youngster named Gerald McBoing Boing -- you remember, he couldn't talk but made a hit on the radio by simply going "boing boing" at the right moments -- will be interested to learn that their hero is to be on the screen again before long.
A nation-wide "inventory" of 300,000 Air Force Reservists not now on active duty will be conducted late this spring.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 15 -- Brookmeade Stable's Sky Ship, an 11-to-1 shot, matched G. S. Smith's Handsome Teddy stride for stride through the stretch today to win the $20,000 added Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park by a head.

TREES are an integral part of our way of life. No better proof can be found than in the magnificent specimens which frame old homes in New England, Maryland, Virginia and many another state. The small modern home may not be surrounded by acres of land but it needs trees -- even one or two -- fully as much.

" MORE like a good hotel than an asylum," said wealthy, charming Lacy Corrigan when they brought him to Lazy Lodge. And Lacy's first impression proved accurate. The "thoroughly pleasant Bedlam" of this pigeonhole-defying psychiatric comedy is indeed fiction's coziest plush-lined snake pit so far.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury; Marshall Field, and Jacob S. Potofsky, general president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, are among the prominent Americans who have declined invitations to attend next month's Moscow International Economic Conference, which Secretary of State Dean Acheson yesterday termed a Soviet "stratagem" to misuse the names of prominent "men of good reputation."

IT is not easy for the beginner to pick and choose the best among the crop of garden books available. Some are ponderous tomes, others more down- to-earth and still a few others gems beyond price. But there are many that will serve as an excellent guide to the tyro gardener.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 15 -- Mobility, Inc., at 10 Heather-bloom Road here, has deceptively simple aims: such as to teach a banker to write, to teach a housewife to peel a potato, to teach a secretary to type.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A powerful, coordinated drive to wipe out locusts in the Mddle East, which has been plagued by them since Biblical times, was announced today by the Technical Cooperation Administration.

THE definition of Franz Kafka's (and Max Brod's) nationality and language has been further bedeviled in your "Letters to the Editor." American conceptions of nationality and its relationship to citizenship do not apply in Central European countries, and both Richard Sullivan, your reviewer, and C. B. Weitlanner, a reader, have obscured the facts by trying to fit them into our mold.

In a match that was productive of the keenest kind of team play, the Ramapo Polo Club gained the semi-final round of the Eastern 12-goal indoor championship tournament last night by halting Squadron A, 12 to 8, at the Squadron A Armory.

Margaret L. Colt's article, "The Small Town Under Big Pressures" (Feb. 24) inspired me to hitchhike more than 350 miles to West Newbury. Mass., to witness my first town meeting. 'Twas an experience well worth the trip.

ABE BURROWS, the playwright, play doctor, director, songwriter, piano player, radio and television writer, and radio, television, nightclub, summer - hotel and house - party performer, is essentially a Renaissance-type man who thinks fruitfully in the historical present, communicates in a rich vulgate and, in moments of excitement, lapses into words like "teleological" or references to Carlyle, Sir William Osler, Horace, Max Beerbohm, James Stephens and Dr. Morris Fishbein, which he did the other day.

WASHINGTON -- The curve of foreign travel by United States citizens finished on an upward swing in 1951 and there were early signs that this trend will carry on through 1952, Government authorities on travel indicated here last week.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 15 -- At the Southern end of the New Hampshire-Key West political axis it looks more and more as if the country will not learn what Harry S. Truman plans to do until convention time in Chicago next July. This, despite the President's statement in December that he would announce his decision before the Republicans meet.

LONDON, March 15 -- Col. Sir Guy Lowther of the Eighth Hussars, who recently told the men who manufacture the Centurion tank that the United States Patton tank in Korea proved to be "a pansy" by comparison, made it clear today that the remark was all in fun.

THE New Hampshire preferential primary has raised a number of provocative questions regarding the use of television in political campaigns. On the basis of what a viewer saw prior to the victories of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Estes W. Kefauver, the impact of the medium may be felt in several ways not heretofore fully appreciated.

LONDON, March 15 -- That sardonically topical musical travesty on American politics, diplomacy and philosophy, "Call Me Madam," had a successful opening tonight before a select and selected audience of Londoners who recently have become more critical of, if not allergic to, American musical shows of the modern genre.

THE second series of radio programs, "Music Talent in Our Schools," inaugurated last year by THE TIMES and WQXR, begins this afternoon and will continue through six more Sundays. This series exerted such constructive effect last season that it has now been organized as an annual educational activity.

In George Copeland's interesting piece about the old Frisian language ("'Friesland Free'" March 2) one all-important point seemed omitted: Frisian is the "official" connecting link between English and the Germanic tongues of the Continent.

THE popularity of the detective story is one of the many things which a great many people View With Alarm. The old argument that Woodrow Wilson consumed them in great numbers and that therefore they must be intellectually respectable has worn rather thin from overuse.

President Truman urged the youth of the nation yesterday to support his foreign and domestic program and promised them that if it succeeded they would "live in the most peaceful time the world has ever seen."

BUFFALO, N. Y., March 15 (AP) -- Fred Wilt of the New York A. C. won the Regimental Mile at the 174th Armory games in 4:10.1 tonight, but he had to share the spotlight with record-breakers in the National Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor track and field championships.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- Wheat shook off the lethargy which has characterized it most of this week and advanced briskly on the Board of Trade today. Feed grains firmed and soybeans, particularly the distant contracts, scored sharp gains.

AGAINST the dunes of New Jersey's Long Beach Island, Frances McGuire sets a salty tale of fishermen's fun and mystery. Going fishing with Joe Swenson was one of the most exciting things that had ever happened to Johnnie, for Johnnie was boat-crazy, and big, bronzed Joe, skipper of the Betty, was his hero.

THE gigantic telescope on Palomar Mountain is only 4 years old, but already it has inspired an impressive body of literature, and the wonder of it is not fading. Few of the pilgrims (150,000 per year) come away without a compulsion to tell about what they have seen.

LONDON, March 15 -- A Vicar of the Church of England, writing this week to The Times of London, declared that there was "absolute poverty" among the English clergy and that "not a few of them have barely sufficient to meet the cost of their daily bread."

MIAMI, March 15 -- "It's just like flubbing a golf shot," said Peewee Reese, a par-shooter himself. "The damage is done and there's no sense worrying about it any more. You merely make certain that the next shot is a good one."

The advent of the atomic age has resulted in many innovations. Not the least of these has been the storing of vital records by many corporations in suburban spots which would not be likely targets of an enemy attack or which are so well concealed as to minimize the chance of bombing.

SOME of the most dramatic splashes of garden color can be realized through the liberal use of the big four in bulbs: lilies, tuberous begonias, gladiolus and dahlias. Each has its own individuality which, properly exploited, can emphasize both the design and beauty of the garden from June until frost.

LONDON, March 15 (Reuters) -- Tommy Lawton, star international center forward bought by Brentford from Notts County for $42,000 last night, today led his new club to a 3-1 triumph over Swansea. The victory was the first for Brentford in Britain's soccer competition in nine weeks.

TO the property owner, a lawn can be either a distinctive addition to the house and grounds or nothing more than a necessary evil. A good thick carpet of turf is not, as many will have it, a matter of luck. Rather it is a matter of fairly constant and regular attention from one spring to the next.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 15 (AP) -- Iranian and officials of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development today staved off for at least another day any breakoff in dickering to get Iran's oil production going again.
DES MOINES, March 15 (AP) -- A Hawaiian-born couple, who had made a $500 down payment on a house in West Des Moines, received the money back today and was advised not to move in.

The Optical Division of the Amateur Astronomers' Association will be addressed next Thursday evening by F. W. Swann of the Eastman Kodak Company. Mr. Swann's subject will be photography in astronomy. The meeting will be held in the Roosevelt Memorial Hall of the American Museum of Natural History, entrance on Central Park West.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- The Braves hammered eighteen hits today and thumped the Red Sox, 12 -- 2, in the year's first meeting between the Boston baseball clubs. This was the seventh straight exhibition loss for the Sox.

TOMORROW millions will be wearing a sprig of a little green three-leaved plant, and perhaps a million times the question will be asked, "Is it really shamrock?" Of no plant in history has the identity been so much and so strenuously debated.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H., March 15 -- Roaring down from the snow-buried summit of Wildcat Mountain at breathtaking speed, Ralph Miller, Dartmouth's 18-year-old freshman ace, today captured the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's downhill championship at the White Mountain National Forest.

Policemen investigating the unsolved murder of 24 - year - old Arnold Schuster, whose "tip" led to the arrest of William Francis (Willie) Sutton, bank robber, tried a new tactic yesterday in an effort to break out of the blind alley into which their fruitless detective work has led thus far.

CAIRO, March 15 -- Premier Ahmed Naguib al Hilaili Pasha accused the Wafd party, which holds a majority in the Egyptian Parliament, of campaigning to have the present state of martial law lifted "in order to revive sedition."

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15 -- A military assistance agreement for Brazilian-United States cooperation in defense of the Western Hemisphere was signed this morning, completing one more link in the inter-American defense system.

City Council President Rudolph Halley charged yesterday that the State Legislature's refusal so far to grant city requests for $63,800,000 in increased state aid was aimed at forcing a city financial crisis next year -- a Mayoralty election year.

The House Veterans Affairs Committee began last week the arduous task of whipping into shape a G. I. bill that would offer educational opportunities to Korean veterans. During the last month and a half, representatives of major educational, veteran and Government groups testified before the committee.

Though the scallop fisheries of Massachusetts, from which, every year, come scallops worth $6,000,000, is not complaining of hard times or any scarcity, the Massachusetts Division of Marine Fisheries, directed by Frederick W. Sargent, thought it well to prepare for a day when sensible regulations might be necessary.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, continuing his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination here in July, was the guest of honor tonight at a dinner staged by the Bob Taft Clubs of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The receptive attitude of General of the Army Eisenhower toward the national nomination of the Republican party has, as the first result of the New Hampshire primary, taken on a positive quality, and by practical standards the general can now fairly be said to be "running" for President. This positive quality has been contributed by these developments:

Gangster - fiction writers long ago planted the myth about a "code of the underworld." Succeeding generations of the same literary school tenderly nourished the myth, and romantic readers have cherished and perpetuated it.

IN the first week of the current month, Peggy Ashcroft arrived here in Terence Rattigan's new play. "The Deep Blue Sea." This was an exciting occasion, for rumor had whipped up expectation while the piece was on the road. Nor was expectation disappointed; but it is to be hoped that Rattigan realizes just how much he owes to his leading lady.

GARDENERS look forward to the beginning of spring on Thursday. And it should begin, for the six more weeks of winter predicted when the groundhog saw his shadow on Feb. 2 are ended. There are other signs that the hope is well founded.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 15 -- Pennsylvania's Ernie Beck scored 23 points and the Quakers defeated Princeton's newly crowned Eastern Basketball League champions, 63 -- 60, tonight.

THE demand for certain types of shrubs has changed as greatly during the past ten years as the architecture of homes. The advent of the ranch-type house with its picture window, patio or low porch has created a need for new and unusual kinds of shrubs.

CAMDEN, S. C., March 15 (AP) -- Mister Mars, a gelding owned by Mrs. Amory S. Carhart of Warrenton, Va., scored an asset victory by a nose in the King Haiglar Steeple-chase today. The 1951 Virginia Gold Cup winner just beat the heavily-favored Done Sleeping in a head-and-head stretch duel.

Machine tools manufactured abroad and offered for sale in this country to meet a serious shortage will be displayed in Chicago, beginning tomorrow, at the twentieth annual meeting of the American Society of Tool Engineers.

American manufacturers of shoes have been requested to design all the footwear for the Second Annual International Fashion Show, which will introduce apparel designed and produced in seventeen foreign countries and in five areas of the United States.

NEWARK, March 15 -- The first-place position given by County Clerk Russell Gates on the voting-machine ballot to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the preferential primary on April 15 became a sharply controversial subject today among Eisenhower and Taft partisans in New Jersey.

AN Army officer who has seen much service in Eastern Asia, Colonel Rigg was a prisoner of the Red Chinese forces for several months in 1947. His book goes far beyond the knowledge he then gained. It is packed with an astonishing amount of valid current detail and historical background.

EVERY year well over three million persons come to the New York Public Library for the answers to questions as diverse as the recipe for plum jam and the formula for synthetic musk. Here, with a little patience, you can consult the original prompt books of David Belasco's plays or a copy of Grimm's Fairy Tales in braille.

RENO, Nev., March 15 (UP) -- Two suspects in the daylight Redfield safe burglary were arrested in Milwaukee tonight and the Federal Bureau of Investigation here announced that all "four perpetrators" of the $1,500,000 theft had been seized.
In my opinion, no parallel can be drawn between the real refugee and what in Aline B. Louchheim's article "Tabori's Flight Into Reality" is called the "psychological refugee."

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board, over the strong objection of its industry members, recommended today an average hourly wage increase of 14.4 cents for about 11,500 employes of two Wright Aeronautical plants in Wood Ridge, N. J.

HONG KONG, March 15 -- Drought and urgency of spring plowing have led Communist authorities in East China to order suspension of part of their purge campaign against "corruption, waste and bureaucratism" in Shantung Province.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 15 -- Major mosquito control problems in New Jersey last year were encountered in tidewater areas of the state, with the counties of Cape May, Ocean, Hudson, Bergen and, to a lesser degree, Union and Essex most affected.

APPARENTLY because it was about to take off for a long European tour and would not be around its home theatre again until next fall, the New York City Ballet put the big pot into the little one for its farewell season and gave us five new ballets.

Outside the weather was crisp and sunny, but indoors the survivors of the blizzard of '88 swapped tales of mountainous snows and the privations they had known -- tales that get taller as the years go by.

JANE JONQUIL and her parents, in this third book about them, are still sharing nonsense, back talk, and snackeroos, as well as easy and durable affection. Jane is good enough to ask her mother and father to tell her about their childhoods, and accepts her father's explanation about the difficulty of committing horrible deeds if you've been brought up right.

THE celebration of Arturo Toscanini's eighty-fifth birthday on March 25 makes it appropriate to note that the maestro is simply the oldest, greatest and most prominent living practitioner of a craft which seems to lend itself to longevity.
ALBANY, March 15 (UP) -- The following conditions at New York skiing centers were reported to the State Commerce Department today:

A QUARTERLY magazine, Aperture, which will be "devoted to serious thinking in photography," is being launched in San Francisco. It will be edited and published by Minor White. At the start, the format will be 6 by 9 inches, each issue will contain five or six fine reproductions and two or three articles and the subscription rate will be $4.50 a year.

VIENNA, March 15 -- The apparent disappearance of Premier Antonin Zapotocky of Czechoslovakia from public life for three weeks has given rise to reports that he too may have fallen victim to the purge that seems to have become chronic within the Czechoslovak Communist party.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States charged today that "billions of United States tax dollars" were being spent for the construction of a "gigantic waterways system in France."

RANGOON, Burma, March 15 -- A plump, attractive, middle-aged woman, Mrs. Ba Maung Chein, has become the key figure in a new effort by the Government here to settle the three-year-old Karen revolt against the central authorities.

CORRECT grading of the home grounds is essential to appearance and to easy maintenance. Carefully worked out changes in the "lay of the land" make even the smallest property more attractive and usable. No amount of fine planting, however, will conceal an inefficient job.

One of the first advertising agencies in this country was founded in 1850 by Samuel M. Pettingell. Its offices were at 119 Nassau Street here and at 10 State Street, Boston. It appears, however, that Samuel had trouble convincing merchants of the time that advertising paid off and he spent considerable money advertising himself and his services in the newspapers of the day, while extolling the virtues of the infant business.

MAPLE trees, like apple, cherry, peach and other fruit trees, are usually good for two crops of tourists a year: one in the spring and the other in the fall. Yet the maple differs from the fruit trees in that it produces its crop first, then five or six months later attracts sight-seers with a brilliant display of vari-colored foliage.

THE arid little Sheikdom of Kuwait, on the Persian Gulf, is now the scene of a fabulous oil development, with production being stepped up at a very rapid rate -- as a direct result of the stoppage of oil from near-by Iran.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 15 -- Connecticut Republican are having a difficult time trying to agree on a nominee for United States Senator to oppose the Democratic incumbent, Senator William Benton, in the November election.

THE important thing about the saints is that they were neither supermen nor angels but simply human beings. According to Catholic theology, they remain human in heaven, but by the time they reach the altars and suffer the indignity of plaster statuary. this basic humanity is often obscured.

ALTHOUGH Judy Garland has departed, taking with her the devotion of the populace, the Palace is still a welcome haven of entertainment. This is a genuine contribution to the content of the town. For vaudeville is pleasant and informal, and the theatre will never be complete unless we have a good variety house to drop into casually.

ATHENS, March 15 -- A suggestion that United States Ambassador John E. Peurifoy had interfered unduly in Greek internal affairs was contained in a statement published today by Sophocles Venizelos, acting Premier and head of the Liberal party.

Sometimes the water in the kitchen tap tastes a little flat. And the quality of plum jelly and maple syrup and canned peas varies a bit. To stop the water from being too much one way or the other and to control the quality of canned foods, a tall, spare man, looking much like the college professor he once was, has devised a number of machines applying well-known principles of chemistry.

RAYMOND DEJAEGHER, a Belgian, served as a parish priest at An-kwo, a county seat on the Hopeh plain some 200 miles south of Peiping, most of the twenty-two years he was in China. When his territory was abandoned by the Nationalists early in the Sino-Japanese "incident," he saw the Chinese Reds move swiftly into the vacuum.

By this time there must be at least a dozen artificial kidneys in occasional use here and abroad. The latest is the invention of John R. Guarino and Louis J. Guarino, who describe it in the current issue of Science. Both are connected with the Brusch Medical Center, Cambridge, Mass., and the Pan-Engineering Company, New York City.

VIENNA, March 15 -- William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent who was sentenced to five years' imprisonment last June for alleged espionage, testified in court in a Prague trial that ended today, the Prague radio reported. He appeared as a witness, the report said, against twelve of his alleged accomplices accused of the same crime.

DES MOINES, March 15 -- If any Presidential candidate or would-be candidate is setting prairie fires with his own particular flaming brand of farm policy, the blaze is not big enough to be discernible today.

MOTORISTS who have a few hours to spare while heading through western Pennsylvania on the turnpike can relieve the tension of highspeed driving by taking a side trip that is both scenically and historically interesting.

OF all the practitioners in the art of giving away money none, since the records of history began, can match William Averell Harriman. In the course of the past twelve years, Mr. Harriman has supervised the giving away of some 25 to 30 billion dollars worth of American goods and money to a score of past Allies, current Allies and potential Allies not to mention three of four ex-enemies and enemies-to-be.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 15 -- Twenty incorporated villages of Westchester County will go to the polls on Tuesday to elect local officials. Only nine will have contests; even in these the tumultous controversies common in past years generally are missing.
New York University's fencers rallied at the last moment to win the three-weapon title in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships at the Columbia University gymnasium yesterday.

ABOUT 11 per cent fewer books have been published during the first two months of this year than in January-February, 1951, an actual title decrease of 126. This does not necessarily mean that business is off, but it could mean that publishers are getting choosier.

THIS year, at last, Americans with both little time and little money will be able to take a vacation in Europe. Low-cost trans-Atlantic air-coach service is scheduled to begin May 1, and budget travelers can also travel cheaply and comfortably after they arrive in the Old World.

Yesterday's stock market followed Friday's pattern, extending gains selectively and closing irregularly higher in moderately active trading. Oil and railroad issues again advanced, while the steel, motor and chemical groups lagged and closed unchanged to fractions lower.

Four universities will cooperate this summer in a program to encourage better teaching of family financial security in the nation's high schools and colleges. These institutions -- Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Connecticut and Southern Methodist -- will hold "workshops" during the summer months of 1952.

CONTRARY to the belief of most amateurs, annual and perennial flowers have a definite, if subtle, relationship to each other in the garden. True, they are two distinct groups of plants, but they need not always be treated as though there were a family feud between them.

It all starts quite harmlessly. One soft summer day the gardener realizes that a particular flower in his border stands out above all the rest. Soon he is growing it almost to the exclusion of any others.

ST. LOUIS, March 15 -- James P. Finnegan, former Collector of Internal Revenue convicted on two charges of misconduct while in office, will seek a new trial, his lawyers announced today. If their motion is denied by Federal Judge Rubey M. Hulen, they intend to appeal the case, they said.
THIS year marks two important anniversaries in Brazilian literary life: the thirtieth anniversary of a revolution and the fiftieth birthday of a poet.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Navajos' Washington attorney has given his approval to the present Indian Bureau regime, headed by Commissioner Dillon S. Myer.

LONDON, March 15 -- The Conservatives who now constitute the Government of Britain promised during the last campaign that one of their first acts would be to restore the nationalized iron and steel industry to private ownership.

MONTREAL, March 15 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins, battling to make the Stanley Cup play-offs, shut out the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 0, before 14,487 fans tonight to increase their fourth-place lead to 3 points over the Rangers in the National Hockey League.

GUATEMALA, March 15 -- United Fruit Company officials were of officially notified this morning by Economy Minister Manuel Noriega Morales that last Saturday's labor agreement between Guatemalan banana union representatives and the company was ratified by his office last night.

GLORY, concluded a Pennsylvania private, "consisted in getting shot and having your name spelled wrong in the newspapers." There was reason for his cynicism in that winter "of unrelieved gloom," 1862-63.

AN unusual event takes command of this superior World War II novel at the start and makes a well-written story -- up to a suspense point -- worth retelling. While returning to its base in northern Italy an isolated B-24 bomber is attacked by three German fighter planes.

ANYONE who has a flower garden has surely watched bees come and go, and perhaps has even thought of his garden as a source of honey. This is not as far-fetched as it may sound. For honeybees (Apis mellifera) are sold by the pound, with approximately 5,000 to the pound.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 15 -- A three-run rally in the ninth against the Giants' rookie southpaw, Vince DeLorenzo, gave the St. Louis Browns a 5 to 2 victory before 3,485 fans today.

THIS has not been a happy season for sculpture. The nation-wide survey at the Metropolitan, selected on the basis of photographs, produced only a modicum of outstanding work. Then the museum and the show itself and "modernistic" art in general were unwisely and unwarrantly attacked by a conservative group within the National Sculpture Society, causing a wholly misleading conception of contemporary work to be spread about.

Offering a wide variety of products from fishing flies, jams, smoked salmon, traditional tweeds, bacons, hams, ales, stouts and whiskies to champion bloodstock horses, gypsum wallboard and tulip bulbs, the Republic of Ireland is embarking on an intensive dollar export drive.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 15 -- The success story of Peter B. Putnam, 31-year-old instructor in history at Princeton University and author of two books, is a special one, for he has been handicapped by total blindness since his third year as a student at the college where he now teaches.

RIGHT now gunsmiths are putting the finishing touches on the rifles that will, it is hoped, bring new laurels to American shooters at the two international matches scheduled this summer, the International Shooting Union matches at Oslo, Norway, and the Olympic matches at Helsinki, Finland.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 110,308, to compare with 118,928 a year ago, a decrease of 7.2 per cent. For this year to date Pennsylvania Railroad loadings total 1,081,995, against 1,104,051 last year, off 2 per cent.

THE Edwards family of London was planning a trip to America, when we first met them in "Lucy's League." Here is the story of that trip: the voyage on the Queen Elizabeth, their brief stay in New York and the summer on Cape Cod, which John and Lucy called the happiest of their lives.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, warned yesterday that 800,000,000 persons living under Soviet discipline were "ready to march on the free world," with the United States as their first target.

HERE are two maps of Europe. They each show a central "community" with an important boundary to the east. One of them is the region involved in the defense of Western Europe against communism today, the area of the nations contributing to and to be covered by the Western European Army, now in process of formation.

The income tax deadline has given a new meaning to the Ides of March scarcely less ominous than the old one. The date has been something to beware of since Shakespeare made the world familiar with it and gave political orators a telling phrase.

EVERY attempted suicide confronts the psychiatrist with questions which occur to him automatically and at once. Was the suicide due to a transient panic or to one which will recur? Was it due to a passing moment of depression or to one which carries a lasting threat of repeated similar attempts?

In Washington, London, Paris and other world capitals last week, diplomats, generals and economists spent a great many hours trying to uncover the full implications of the latest clue to Soviet military strength: the arms appropriation in the 1952 Soviet budget adopted last week-end by the Supreme Soviet.

Tommy Piper, 10-year-old, filth-grade student at the Campus School, laboratory school of the Lock Haven (Pa.) State Teachers College, was one of the 3,000 school children who heard President Truman's speech yesterday. Tommy, a grandson of William Piper Sr., president of the Piper Aircraft Corporation, is a reporter on The Campus, his school paper.

THE Edwards family of London was planning a trip to America, when we first met them in "Lucy's League." Here is the story of that trip: the voyage on the Queen Elizabeth, their brief stay in New York and the summer on Cape Cod, which John and Lucy called the happiest of their lives.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, warned yesterday that 800,000,000 persons living under Soviet discipline were "ready to march on the free world," with the United States as their first target.

HERE are two maps of Europe. They each show a central "community" with an important boundary to the east. One of them is the region involved in the defense of Western Europe against communism today, the area of the nations contributing to and to be covered by the Western European Army, now in process of formation.

The income tax deadline has given a new meaning to the Ides of March scarcely less ominous than the old one. The date has been something to beware of since Shakespeare made the world familiar with it and gave political orators a telling phrase.

EVERY attempted suicide confronts the psychiatrist with questions which occur to him automatically and at once. Was the suicide due to a transient panic or to one which will recur? Was it due to a passing moment of depression or to one which carries a lasting threat of repeated similar attempts?

AN unusual event takes command of this superior World War II novel at the start and makes a well-written story -- up to a suspense point -- worth retelling. While returning to its base in northern Italy an isolated B-24 bomber is attacked by three German fighter planes.

KANSAS CITY, March 15 (AP) -- The Southwest Missouri State Bears of Springfield outhustled and outshot the Murray (Ky.) Thoroughbreds, 73 to 64, tonight to win the National Association of Intercollegiate Basketball championship and a berth in the Olympic play-offs.

Economic developments both here and abroad were of special interest to financial markets last week. A railroad strike which threatened a serious interruption to the nation's industrial activity ended before too much damage had been done.
The "Lisbon miracle" has glossed over but not cured the dangerous crisis which has arisen in NATO as the result of three grave errors in American judgment. These were:

An appeal to the United Nations and to Jordan to open the road to Mount Scopus in Jerusalem and to permit the Jewish people to worship at the Wailing Wall in the old section of Jerusalem was made last night by Shlomo Z. Shragai, Israel's first elected Mayor of the new city of Jerusalem.

The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York, said yesterday that "we know a great deal more today about nature and it laws than did Plato or Aristotle or Shakespeare, but who is to say we are wiser?"

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Every morning there are 7,000 new faces at American breakfast tables. Practically none of the added eaters draws up a chair and tucks away a stack of hotcakes or a plate of ham and eggs. Most of them get that first breakfast from breast or bottle, but they all help to increase a population that is eating 13 per cent more per capita than was eaten a dozen years ago.

Sales of the National Dairy Products Corporation passed the billion-dollar mark for the first time in its history last year, reaching $1,042,260,000, compared with $909,939,000 the year before. Total tonnage of products sold also climbed to a new high, L. A. Van Bomel, president, reports in the twenty-ninth annual statement to be mailed to stockholders today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- Parents and teachers cannot hope to "teach" children moral values, university professors in three different fields emphasized yesterday. Such values, they said, develop in response to varied and subtle influences. They cannot be "learned" once and for all, but must be constantly re-examined by every individual as he, and the world, changes.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 16 -- Miss Vivien Kellems, head of a cable grip company, tonight began a new tax fight against the Federal Government with the announcement she had refused to pay an $81 Social Security contribution for self-employed persons.

TEHERAN, Iran. March 16 -- The attempt of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to get Iranian oil flowing again to the West broke down tonight in a deadlock with the Iranian Government.

The straw boss and the big boss do not always agree. The Research Institute of America has come to this conclusion after compiling the findings of identical questionnaires sent to 2,000 executives and an equal number of supervisors in industry.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 16 (UP) -- South Africa began three weeks of festival this weekend to celebrate her 300th birthday, despite racial tension more severe than any in her history and the possibility of new race riots.

Arturo Toscanini has established a new box-office record at Carnegie Hall. The advance sale for his March 29 Beethoven program to aid the New York Infirmary has reached $64,000, surpassing the $58,000 record he set at a concert for the Infirmary four years ago.

BERLIN, N. H., March 16 -- Charles Tremblay, Dartmouth's co-captain, today established a new Eastern ski jumping record of 256 feet When he topped the amateur division of the White Mountain invitation tournament on the Nansen S. C.'s 80-meter hill.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The freedom to strike in private employment often is limited by factors other than laws, and the key factor is the anticipated Government reaction, a labor expert said today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Mutual Security Agency has urged all suppliers of goods to nations benefiting under the aid program to make sure that colorful agency emblems are put on every item, from tractors to bags of fertilizers, as a repeated reminder that the United States is a friendly nation.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 6 (UP) -- The chairmen of Minnesota's two major political parties predicted today that Harold E. Stassen would win the state's Republican Presidential primary Tuesday and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey would win the Democratic primary.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Joseph D. Nunan Jr. of New York, Commissioner of Internal Revenue from 1943 to 1947, will face House tax investigators at a closed hearing Tuesday.

Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., decided yesterday to keep the Government and the steel industry guessing on whether the union would go along with Federal proposals for a sixteen-day delay in its strike plans.

RANGOON, Burma, March 16 (AP) -- The new Cabinet of Premier U Nu was sworn in today before the recently elected President, Ba U. The Cabinet replaces the Provisional Government that had ruled Burma since she gained independence in 1948.
SYRACUSE, March 16 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers scored a 90-84 victory over the Syracuse Nationals, champion of the Eastern Divsion, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

BUENOS AIRES, March 16 -- The first serious attempt at introducing "corporative, fascism" into the Argentine legal structure and thus providing the framework for the syndicalist state frequently evisaged by President Juan Peron has been successful in Presidente Peron Province, Socialist leaders declared today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 16 -- The campaign of the Yugoslav Communist leaders to restore discipline inside and outside the party is gaining momentum. Its purpose is to combat the growth of Western ideas that have weakened the party's control over the universities, the arts and letters.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 16 -- Janitorial services in students' rooms at Princeton University will be suspended as of next September to effect a savings of $75,000 a year, it was announced today by George A. Brakely, vice president and treasurer of the university.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 16 -- A program to send eight leading members of the Princeton University faculty each year to cities over the country to give public lectures has been established by a bequest of $120,000, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

PITTSBURGH, March 16 -- The all-time high in steel output last week drove another nail in the coffin of the Controlled Materials Plan for steel. How long it will take for the Defense Production Authority to bury the body no one in the trade professes to know.
A cold northwest wind with gusts as high as forty miles an hour kept Long Island Sound's dinghy skippers in their clubhouses yesterday.

TRENTON, March 16 -- Attention of New Jersey Republicans will turn tomorrow to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's conference wtih state and county Republican leaders and his expected announcement of support of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the party's Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, declared today that he "cannot hold out any hope for a reduction in taxes next year or the year following."

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 16 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins declared here today that the United States was developing armaments that "completely astounded even the most sanguine planner" but he warned at the same time against placing total reliance on super weapons.

BORDENTOWN, N. J., March 16 -- Three sisters, 60 to 67 years old, scored a crushing victory last midnight over a wandering soldier of 20 who stumbled into their old fieldstone home at Smithville, near Mount Holly, and shattered the quiet of their sleep by turning on the radio for a starter.

A buoyant market in British sterling which lifted tile spot pound to $2.81 1/8, highest since devaluation in September, 1949, and narrowed discounts on forwards on an average of 2 1/2 cents, stamped the action of that unit last week as the strongest in years.

New York State has developed the "most complete emergency press and radio set-up ever devised in this country" to instruct its citizens what to do in the event of an atomic attack, Milton V. O'Connell, deputy director of the State Civil Defense Commission, reported yesterday.

In a statement denouncing Council President Rudolph Halley's city financing proposals as a "political campaign document," Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday that the city's revised needs for the fiscal year beginning July 1 would be $224,500,000 more than the present budget.

BERLIN, March 16 -- United States action in blocking East German dollar funds in New York is aimed at involved financial transactions by which the funds probably are used to procure strategic materials for Communist China from Western Europe and South America.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 16 -- Signs that the Government's month-old economic program was succeeding in at least two of its objectives -- increasing exports and reducing consumption -- have accumulated here during the last week.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Walter Baer, senior partner of Julius Baer Co., of Zurich, Switzerland, commented here tonight on the blocking of American assets of the bank. Through his attorney, George W. Ball, Mr. Baer made this reply:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- Loretta Young will star in Universal - International's "Magic Lady." The screen play, written by Ketti Frings, deals with a modern young mother who loses her husband and her child when the husband discovers that his wife had once served time in prison.

Four million New Yorkers and nonresidents who had sources of income in this state last year will have to file state income tax returns by April 15, the State Department of Taxation and Finance said yesterday. The number has grown from 1,800,000 in the last ten years.

It is a wise and prudent man who knows, now that April is within hailing distance, where lies the fishing tackle he put away -- carelessly, like as not -- at last summer's end. Undoubtedly Raymond R. Camp, the Wood, Field and Stream editor, had this in mind when he wrote the other day: "It might be the time for a reminder on the spring fishing.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 16 -- Finance Minister Mohammed Ali presented yesterday Pakistan's fifth budget to Parliament and announced the reduction of taxes and customs duties. The estimated budget surplus was seen here as proof of Pakistan's economic soundness and was hailed by the public and business as opening the way for badly needed national construction.

The Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross joined Marine reservists and Coast Guardsmen yesterday in a demonstration on a Brooklyn "battlefield" to spur blood donations and general support of the Red Cross in the Manhattan Beach, Brighton Beach, Sea Gate and Coney Island areas.

Walter Winchell, columnist and radio commentator, was taken ill just before his scheduled broadcast over the American Broadcasting Company network at 9 o'clock last night. His office explained that he had returned to work too soon after a "serious attack of virus infection."

A spectacular fire broke out last night in an eleventh-floor apartment of the Master Hotel, a twenty-nine-story, residential-type structure containing 300 apartments at 310 Riverside Drive at 103d Street. Three of the eleventh-floor tenants were affected by smoke and were taken to the Knickerbocker Hospital.
CHICAGO, March 16 (UP) -- Goalie Terry Sawchuk scored his twelfth shutout of the season today as Detroit tripped the Black Hawks by 4 -- 0 for the twelfth consecutive Red Wing victory on Stadium ice.

A budget-balancing move by the Police Department took $500 yesterday from the annual pay of twenty-one acting captains to help provide the $500 increases for twenty-nine new captains whom Commissioner George P. Monaghan had appointed on Saturday night.
A few weeks ago Patterns of The Times presented several spring coat styles to wear in the Easter parade. Today, two smart Easter suit patterns are sketched in several versions each.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- The Big Ten will hold spring football practice this season -- an issue with the American Council on Education's stern sports control program that was ignored today by Western Conference presidents.

ATHENS, March 16 -- United States Ambassador John E. Peurifoy's declared opposition to the setting up of a straight proportional system of elections here and Acting Premier Sophocles Venizelos' implied resentment of Mr. Peurifoy's seeming interference in Greece's internal matters were argued warmly today.

Erich Itor Kahn and Morton Feldman shared the Composers' Forum concert Saturday evening at the McMillin Theatre. Mr. Kahn's Three Piano Pieces (1936-40) and "Ciaconna dei tempi di guerra" were played by Beveridge Webster, while the composer himself acted as accompanist for Uta Hagen, soprano, in Four Pieces on Medieval German Poems.
Developments in Europe and Asia last week indicated that the perennial spring crisis -- if it comes -- is more likely to occur in the Orient than in the West.

Cloudy skies and enough bite in the wind to induce brisk marching were forecast yesterday for the annual St. Patrick's Day parade, which starts at noon today "rain or shine" on Fifth Avenue at Forty-fourth Street
BOSTON, March 16 (UP) -- Boston's battling Bruins beat the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 1, in a rough National Hockey League game tonight.

Evidence that retailers can prosper by determined and orderly promotion of quality branded products rather than relying on sporadic price cutting maneuvers was offered yesterday by the Brand Names Foundation.

Grant Johannesen, American pianist, who was heard eight days ago with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, gave a recital last night at Town Hall that was marked by the merits the artist has consistently shown in the eight years he has been playing here.

Newbold Morris, director of President Truman's inquiry into corruption in government, said yesterday that his inquiry would shift into high gear tomorrow when special questionnaires are scheduled to go out to all but the lowest echelons of Federal administrative employes.

Any citizen who offers to sacrifice his private interests and take a thankless job in Washington these days must expect to have his character looked into by one or more Senatorial committees. It seemed for a while as though Newbold Morris, slated for one of the most thankless jobs conceivable, would come out of this ordeal in pretty good form.

In yesterday's issue of this newspaper Michael L. Hoffman summarized reports on taxation from TIMES correspondents in the six countries participating in the negotiations for a European army. These reports emphasize what is true of every European nation as it reels under the first impact of the financial burden of rearmament.

After a season's absence from the repertoire, Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" was presented Saturday night at the Metropolitan. The performance, splendidly conducted by Fritz Reiner, introduced two gifted German tenors to this country, Hans Hopf, who was the Walther of the cast, and Richard Holm, heard as David.
Overseas Tankship (U. K.) Ltd. has reported here that the 12,000-deadweight ton tanker Caltex Calcutta was launched last Tuesday in Sunderland, England.
PARIS, March 16 -- One of the most important decisions in United States political history is being pondered in the suburbs of Paris and probably will be made within the next two to four weeks.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, March 17 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets shot down three Communist MIG's in flames Sunday, probably destroyed two others and damaged eight in three dogfights.

One of the largest airlifts in maneuver history will start this week when thousands of men of the Thirty-first Division will be flown from South Carolina to Texas to participate in the country's biggest post-war Army-Air Force maneuvers -- Exercise Long Horn.
PARIS, March 16 -- For the first time since October French exports have ceased to decline. In February they went to 70,500,000,000 francs, compared with 67,500,000,000 in January.

Helen Maggia, French-born and Italian - educated mezzo - soprano who lives in New Jersey, gave her first recital in Town Hall Saturday night before a sizable audience. To the accompaniment of Paul Ulanowsky, she presented a program that was pleasantly leavened with unfamiliar selections, and a voice that had potentialities.

BONN, Germany, March 16 -- The United Nations commission to study the possibility of holding all-German elections arrived in the West German capital today. So did an emissary from the Parliament in the Soviet Zone to the West German Parliament appealing for support of the Soviet proposal for a peace treaty conference.

Bert Matthews, who will be 68 years old in July, has delivered fish, cut meat, peddled flowers and headed up a team of eight indomitable Cockney rat catchers in the post of Rodent officer of the Borough Council of Hampstead, London.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 16 (AP) -- Ernie McCulloch and Lois Woodworth made the championships of the Harriman Cup ski races an all-Canada event today.
A second change at the top executive level in the organization of Macy's New York was disclosed over the week-end.

UNITED NATIONS, New York, March 16 -- Children of the drought parched states of Northeast Brazil are receiving, as famine rations, supplies of powdered milk sent in by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund. The need is so drastic fund workers report, that in some instances ten babies are now sharing the ration originally intended for one.
TOKYO, Monday, March 17 -- The Communists tentatively accepted yesterday a United Nations proposal for a "package settlement" of five disputed issues in the armistice negotiations in the Korean war.

DETROIT, Mich., March 16 -- Five minor officers of Local 600 were removed from office today as the first action of a board named by the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., to take over administration of the local covering 50,000 members of the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant.

The huge margin by which traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike has exceeded estimates should be food for thought to planners of the other expressways projected hereabouts. Travel on the new 118-mile Turnpike, open only six weeks, is already 159 per cent above officially estimated loads.

The Democratic party leaders in this city gave conditional approval over the week-end to a new city tax package that has emerged from conferences between Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore, representing the State Government, and Mayor Impellitteri.

MIAMI, March 16 -- According to all baseball theorists, it is virtually impossible to replace a suddenly departed 20-game winner. Yet the Dodgers hold the secret hope that they already have the replacement for Don Newcombe. They've had him all along but never realized how good he was until the second play-off game with the Giants last October.
