RIO DE JANEIRO, March 16 -- An epidemic of yellow fever, which had been believed virtually eradicated in Brazil, has broken out in the State of Sao Paulo and is causing grave anxiety to the Brazilian authorities. Deaths reported to date total thirty-seven in twenty-one localities and the state Government has made an immediate special grant of $250,000 to fight it.

Statistics are commonly thought to be dull, but there is little that is dull about the announcement that the Soviet Government, at long last, has given up calculating and planning industrial production in terms of so-called "1926-1927 prices" and has shifted to valuation in terms of current prices -- units termed "1952 permanent prices."

Aneurin Bevan, the British labor leader who resigned from the Clement Attlee Cabinet last year, has written a statement of his views on the modern world which Simon Schuster plan to issue next month. Entitled "In Place of Fear," the statement will contain Mr. Bevan's opinions on foreign policy, his basic belief in political liberty and his disagreements with Communist doctrine.

CINCINNATI, March 16 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, after again expressing complete confidence that he would win the Presidential nomination on an early ballot at the Republican convention opening July 7 in Chicago, devoted the day in his home city to rest and a strategy conference.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., March 16 -- The body of David Brocker, 37-year-old state game warden who disappeared Nov. 17 while hunting ducks and looking for poachers, was found today in Split Rock Pond, Rockaway Township, by Boy Scouts on a camping trip.
Following is the statement of Mayor Impellitteri on the city financing proposals by Council President Rudolph Halley, together with Mr. Halley' s rejoinder:

After more than fifteen years, Congress is getting around to a full check-up on how present-day administration of the Securities and Exchange Commission jibes with what the lawmakers intended. This inquiry is long overdue, because what Congress was most concerned about in the Thirties -- a means for enabling investors to have ready access to all the significant facts surrounding new issues of securities -- has never been realized.

The fine "Message to the Peoples of Russia," which appears in THE TIMES of March 12, must have the approval and support of all who oppose totalitarianism and who hope and pray for the restoration of peace and sanity to a distraught world.

Although Courtney Burr and Malcolm Pearson have the highest regard for each other, the partners have decided to go their separate ways in the same office both have been occupying. A difference of opinion stemming from the Lenore Coffee-William Joyce Cowen dramatization, "The Willows," brought about the separation.

Woman's page "fluff" and the sob-sister story were denounced yesterday by members of the Lucy Stone League and four leaders in journalism and education who spoke at the league's open forum at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- The Braves walked to a thirteen-inning 3-2 victory over the Cardinals today when rookie right-hander Harland Coffman passed Jack Daniels on a 3-2 pitch with the bases jammed.

The men's clothing industry has started to work its way out of the slump of the last nine months of 1951, according to an analysis of January production figures made by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 16 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner, slugging outfielder of the Pirates, signed a new one-year contract for $75,000, the Pittsburgh club said today. Terms were not revealed, but Kiner said he got a pay rise and was satisfied.

RENO, Nev., March 16 (UP) -- A 36-year-old French-Canadian woman, sixth and possibly most important suspect in the $1,500,000 robbery in Reno of L. V. Redfield, was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today in Arizona. The F. B. I. said she had some of the Redfield loot in her briefcase.

GREAT NECK, L. I., March 16 -- Learning can be fun, the children in this fast-growing suburban community have found. Modern teaching methods have brought ease and informality into the classroom. Report cards have been replaced by progress reports.

World premieres of six brief songs by Anton Webern, famous twelve-tone composer, were presented last night by the Forum Group of the International Society for Contemporary Music. These were the climax of the event, which was devoted to music of subtly shifting textures and advanced design.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 16 -- The Communists demonstrated here tonight against dealing with Germans as Israel's official delegates to reparations talks with Bonn took off for London. The delegation will hold a preliminary discussion with non-Israeli Jewish groups that also have claims against the Germans.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 16 (AP) -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath, in a cryptic speech here tonight, implied that "race and religion" were involved in current Washington investigations.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The American Chemical Society announced tonight the appointment of a sixteen-member committee on manpower to survey chemical manpower needs and to formulate a program to assure an adequate supply of qualified chemists and chemical engineers.
Three new films, including an import from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

CHATTANOOGA, March 16 -- The Southern Association of Science and Industry released today the first edition of its new Southern Industrial Directory designed to assist Southern business and industrial groups in maintaining the region's swift pace of economic progress.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- The city's television audience today caught the last ten minutes of a two and a half hour operation for peptic ulcers. It was the first glimpse televiewers have had of a major surgical operation over an open network.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that President Truman and other advocates of public power were "trying to toss all Americans into the arms of socialism."

LONDON, March 16 -- All London's newspaper reviewers took kindly to "Call Me Madam," which opened at the Coliseum last night. The critical consensus put it somewhere below the ecstatically-received "Oklahoma," and well above "South Pacific," which won only qualified approval.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Champion Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, the boxer belonging to Dr. and Mrs. R. C. Harris of Santa Ana, Calif., put his strong white feet on the victory trail tonight after faltering in some recent efforts.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 16 -- President Truman has tentative plans for a meeting here soon with Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the Democratic National Committee -- a meeting that would have some bearing on Mr. Truman's plans for the main Jefferson-Jackson day dinner in Washington on March 29.

Increased demands for services this year have made it necessary for the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., of 207 Fourth Avenue, to seek $250,000 in contributions, a rise of 14 per cent above gifts received last year. The organization's thirty-first annual report, just published, tells of aid given last year to 177 agencies that operated 325 health and welfare programs.

PANAMA, March 16 (UP) -- The foreign "mystery man" being held by the Panamanian secret police said today that he was a fugitive from captivity aboard a ship run by a global smuggler of narcotics guns and gold.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 (AP) -- Arthur Rubin of Brooklyn defeated Irving Crane of Binghamton, N. Y., 50 -- 42, in fifty-seven innings, in the world three-cushion billiard tournament today.

Of special interest among this week's art exhibition is tomorow's exhibition at the Curt Valentin Gallery of oils and water-colors by Lyonel Feininger in honor of this distinguished artist's eightieth birthday.

The negative appeal is "in" this season. Now the Kaywoodie Company, pipe manufacturer, is joining the ranks. The Kaywoodie pipe, the maker will say in mass consumer magazines this week, supplies "the throat-easiest smoke of them all."

The Administration's foreign aid program, with an estimated cost for the 1953 fiscal year of close to eight billion dollars, is now under Congressional scrutiny. Hearings have already opened in the Senate committees on Foreign Relations and Armed Services and in the House Foreign Affairs group.

NEW DELHI, India, March 16 -- The negotiations for a treaty of commerce, navigation and friendship between India and the United States are approaching the final stage after several years of intermittent discussion. Expectations now are that the long-awaited agreement may be signed within thirty days.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 (UP) -- The Indians captured two games from Pacific Coast League teams today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A Senate Internal Security Subcommittee today called upon the "rank and file" members of the United Public Workers of America to shake off the organization's "Communist leadership."
MOSCOW, March 16 (AP) -- The newspaper Trud declared today that the recent New York Central rail strike proves "progressive workers" are determined to get "what belongs to them."

The intervention -- if it may be called that -- of American Ambassador Peurifoy in Greece's political dispute opens up all sorts of possibilities. The Ambassador was technically within the limits of diplomatic propriety when he said in Athens on Friday that the United States Government believed the retention of Greece's electoral system "would have a disastrous effect upon the efficient use of American aid in Greece."

ZURICH, March 16 -- Keen regret is felt among leading financial experts of Switzerland that the European Payments Union should have felt unable last week to seize what promised to be an opportunity for consolidating the Intra-Office of European Economic Cooperation trade debts.

SAIGON, Indo-China, March 16 (AP) -- French Union forces have launched a new series of heavy attacks against thousands of Communist-led Vietminh guerrillas who have infiltrated the vital Red River delta -- France's strategic bastion around the northern city of Hanoi.

LONDON, March 16 -- In the few days which have elapsed since introduction of the budget, the city and stock markets have made a valiant attempt to assess its effect upon the economic situation of the country as a whole and the investment picture in particular.

The caliber of candidates for the Christian ministry today is higher than it has been in twenty-five years and theological students have crowded most seminaries beyond their capacity since World War II, the Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary, said in his sermon in James Memorial Chapel there yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, March 16 -- If a bipartisan agreement can be reached on New York City's financial problems -- and it appeared probable tonight that it could be -- the way will be cleared for adjournment of this year's session of the Legislature by Thursday.

Man's tendency to "memorialize" the miracles of God must not dim his eyes to the spiritual power and love that lies behind these external manifestations, Dr. Daniel L. Marsh, chancellor of Boston University, said yesterday in a sermon at the Park Avenue Methodist Church, 106 East Eighty-sixth Street.
LOS ANGELES, March 16 (AP) -- Two bombs, placed in front of two homes and set off simultaneously by timing devices, damaged the structures early today and shook the neighborhood. No one was injured.
The New York Rovers didn't look like the last-place team in the Eastern Hockey League yesterday afternoon as they whipped the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 10 -- 2.

LONDON, March 16 -- A "lamentable" waste of the carrying power of merchant ships due to port delays was described today in the 1951 report of the Liverpool Steamship Owners Association. The report said, however, that "excellent results" had been achieved in turning ships around in United States ports.
The television marathon of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis is bound to go down in the records as a remarkable performance -- theatrically, financially, physically and psychologically.
TOKYO, Monday, March 17 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,191, for Sunday's operations:

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, a monotonously efficient, cool player, won the titleholders tournament today with 299 strokes and proved again she was the best in women's golf.
A veteran detective who prowls the Lower mid-Bronx in overalls and work shirt was cited for four acts of heroism in general orders issued yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

Three New York doctors are among the twenty-one medical school faculty members receiving grants as Scholars in Medical Science from the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, 14 Wall Street. They are Dr. Gordon W. Douglas, New York University College of Medicine; Dr. Ralph L. Engle, Cornell University Medical College, and Dr. Calderon Howe, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

AMSTERDAM, March 16 -- French banks again have retransferred to Dutch private banks balances they transferred to the Netherlands Bank at the end of February to window-dress the French position with the European Payments Union.

Two measures designed to improve the vital inland waterway leading from New York to Oswego on Lake Ontario and to Montreal via Lake Champlain were being considered last week by Congress and the New York State Legislature.
Laurance S. Rockefeller has made a gift to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York to make possible a study of the administration of laws relating to the family in this city.

CHAMONIX, France, March 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence, Olympic double winner from Rutland, Vt., had to be content with second place in the combined event today as Austria dominated the sixteenth Arlberg Kandahar ski tournament.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 16 -- Pepi Gabl, coach of the Austrian women's ski team in the world games of 1950 and now head of the Mount Mansfield Ski School in Stowe, Vt., today captured the concluding event of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association Alpine championship, the slalom.

Tomorrow evening at the Plaza members and guests of Les Amis d'Escoffier will sit down to the gourmet society's annual spring dinner. Judging by a rehearsal of this six-course repast that a representative of this department attended last week, the men (women are not invited) will dine in a manner that best may be described as magnificent.

Two measures designed to improve the vital inland waterway leading from New York to Oswego on Lake Ontario and to Montreal via Lake Champlain were being considered last week by Congress and the New York State Legislature.
Laurance S. Rockefeller has made a gift to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York to make possible a study of the administration of laws relating to the family in this city.

CHAMONIX, France, March 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence, Olympic double winner from Rutland, Vt., had to be content with second place in the combined event today as Austria dominated the sixteenth Arlberg Kandahar ski tournament.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 16 -- Pepi Gabl, coach of the Austrian women's ski team in the world games of 1950 and now head of the Mount Mansfield Ski School in Stowe, Vt., today captured the concluding event of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association Alpine championship, the slalom.

MIAMI, Fla., March 16 -- A two-run homer by George Shuba and a three-run blast by Wayne Belardi off Johnny Sain gave the Dodgers five runs in the sixth inning today and sent them on to a 7-5 victory over the Yankees in Miami Stadium.

Eighty-six Ohioans who have traveled 555 miles because they like the theatre will arrive in Pennsylvania Station this morning for a five-day round of Broadway shows, television broadcasts, sightseeing, and -- since the group is weighted on the distaff side -- shopping.

I wish to refer to your editorial of March 5 entitled "Puerto Rico's Constitution." It is certainly true, as you say, that the adoption of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and its ratification by the Congress should have a good effect throughout Latin America.
CHICAGO, March 16 -- Two outstanding developments gave added momentum last week to buying of all grains, both stemming from Government announcements.

Samuel Reshevsky regained first place yesterday in the international tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club, according to reports received from Havana. The New Yorker outmaneuvered Francisco Planas of Havana in a King's Indian defense to win in 34 moves and then went on to vanquish Nicolas Rossolimo of France in 52 moves.

Mayor Impellitteri won yesterday a last-ditch postponement of a strike that threatened to cut off cooking and heating gas for 120,000 families in the Coney Island and Kings Highway sections of Brooklyn.
A new type of ticket machine will be placed in service by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad at its Grand Central windows tomorrow morning.

Auxiliary Bishop Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday that members of the Roman Catholic Church in this country "believe in the First Amendment to the Constitution" and "do not want an established church in the United States."

BALTIMORE, March 16 -- The difference between the morals taught to children by their elders and the actual life these elders live -- including Government scandals, tax evasions and "fixing" of traffic tickets -- is contributing to the increase of delinquency in America, Dr. Robert V. Seliger, executive director of the National Committee on Alcohol Hygiene, Inc., declared today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) -- Italy plans to disregard initial setbacks and press its fight for extradition of two former American soldiers charged with the wartime slaying of their commander, it was revealed today.
An expert 'cello-piano duo made its Town Tall debut late yesterday afternoon. The performers, Heinrich Joachim and his wife, Renata, pleased a goodly number of listeners with an unhackneyed program.

All the New York Rangers have left now is the much abused mathematical chance. Bill Cook's skaters collapsed after building up a good early lead against the Toronto Maple Leafs in Madison Square Garden last night, and the fast-skating sextet from the North carved out a 4-to-2 decision over the home forces.

ON June 19, 1815, a tired British soldier sat down to write a letter to his family. "The three days fight is over," he wrote. "I am safe, this is sufficient." The battle he was about to describe had no name as yet. All the soldier knew was that it had been fought near a village called Waterloo.

The Philadelphia Nationals, champions of the American Soccer League, defeated the New York Americans, 2 to 1, at Croke Park, yesterday to gain the Eastern final in the annual National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Soccer Football Association.

Nearly 90 per cent of a typical cross-section of New York City machine and metalworking plants now has idle facilities. Almost 60 per cent of that group is operating at half or less of their capacity. These findings, announced yesterday were based on a survey just completed by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.
I congratulate you on your excellent editorial entitled "Day Care and State Aid." It gave a clear picture of day-care programs in New York City as well as the problems which we must still meet.

History swallows up more and more of New York City's elevated railroad system. The Third Avenue line has just made its last night run from City Hall to 149th Street in the Bronx, and will be quiet also on week-ends and holidays, a mixed blessing depending on whether one is a passenger or a bothered neighbor.
NEW MARKET, N. J., March 16 -- An early-morning fire here today burned to the ground the 100-year-old First Baptist Church.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren of California, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said today he would not turn any delegates he wins in the California, Oregon and Wisconsin primaries over to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower or any other candidate in the party convention in July.
The only hopeful clue in the Arnold Schuster murder suddenly proved fruitless late last night.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 16 -- The Irish - American Society of Nassau, Suffolk and Queens proved here today that there were now enough Hibernians on Long Island to stage their own impressive parade in honor of St. Patrick.

CAIRO, March 16 -- Egypt is in the process of learning, according to reports from the cotton market, about the Soviet Union's practice of interpreting agreements and bargains in a fashion that has so often baffled and occasionally enraged international negotiators.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 16 (UP) -- A leader of the Minnesota campaign for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower demanded last night that two national Eisenhower leaders resign "before they run the movement through the grass roots and into the ground."

City dwellers and suburbanites, eager for their first glimpse of spring, thronged the four floors of Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty - seventh Streets, yesterday from 2 to 10 P. M. It was the opening day of the thirty-sixth International Flower Show.
Two items of interest to homemakers, a demonstration of the hand-screen process of printing decorating fabrics and a display of new Craig bed coverings, will be shown at Lord Taylor's this week.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) -- House investigators reported additional shortages of Government-owned grain tonight and said they had prodded the Government into more rigorous prosecution of the private warehouse men responsible.

The two-story factory at 39-55 Clay Street, 1119-37 Manhattan Avenue and 32-38 Box Street in Brooklyn has been sold by A. Richards LoCurto to the Surrey Holding Corporation, represented by Herdling Scharf, attorneys. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids March 25 on $14,036,000 of notes for the financing of Astoria Houses, a state-aided project. The notes will be dated April 21 and will fall due Oct. 20.
The Government took the lead in the opening round yesterday in its fight to break up the alleged monopoly in promotion of professional boxing.

MOSCOW, March 17 (AP) -- The Soviet press carried reports from North Korea today that "certain Western jurists," as eyewitnesses, had confirmed Communist charges that the Americans were using germ warfare there.

BISHOP, Calif., March 17 (UP) - Thirty-three persons, including an infant who had been buried under fifteen feet of snow for two hours, were rescued today from a mill basement where they took refuge from an avalanche.

LA CROSSE, Wis., March 17 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, campaigning for the Republican Presidential nomination, opened his final drive today for the support of Wisconsin's thirty convention delegates.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and subsidiaries established new records last year in sales, earnings, taxes, payrolls, dividends and capital expenditures, along with a new peak in ore produced, John F. Thompson, chairman and president, reported yesterday in his annual statement to stockholders.

Herbert A. Post, Inc., wholesale distributor of paper and packaging and shipping supplies, will move its offices and warehouse from Manhattan to Astoria, Queens, where it has leased the recently completed one-story building at 31-09 Twentieth Road from the Z. R. Operating Corporation.

President Philip Murray of the United Steelworkers of America (C. I. O.) has advised the Wage Stabilization Board that the union's policy committee will meet on Thursday to consider the board's request for a sixteen-day postponement of a possible strike which was originally set for next Sunday night.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- Wally Westlake singled, stole second and went home on a wild throw to first in the eleventh inning today as the Cardinals defeated the Phillies, 6 -- 5.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Republican and Democratic legislators agreed at separate party conferences tonight to support in its entirety a bipartisan $234,800,000 stop-gap financial program for the City of New York. It had already received tentative endorsement from the city and state administrations and the conditional backing of city Democratic leaders.
May I join Allene P. McCulloch in congratulating you on your forthright editorial on the proceedings before the McCarran committee.
The thirty-sixth International Flower Show, now being held at Grand Central Palace, made another break with tradition yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- R. K. O. Radio Pictures Corporation today filed suit for a declaratory judgment in Superior Court in Los Angeles asking to be relieved of any "demands" for damages made by Paul Jarrico, screen writer, in connection with the film "The Las Vegas Story."

Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, who recently defeated President Truman in the New Hampshire Democratic primary, inferentially ruled out yesterday both the President and Vice-President Alben W. Barkley as candidates for re-election on the grounds that they are too old.

Decked out in a huge Royal Swedish Airforce type overcoat with a white fur collar, Dick Button, world and Olympic figure skating champion, arrived at Idlewild Airport at dawn yesterday. He was accompanied by his mother.

CAIRO, March 17 -- The Government, which had withdrawn official support from cotton in an effort to get the price of the Egyptian output down to a level at which export could be resumed, compromised somewhat on the issue today.

Apparently lugging gold about the Wild West in the old days was a much safer business than the motion pictures would have one believe, for today Wells Fargo Co., a pioneer in that occupation, celebrates its hundredth anniversary.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- The Defense Department issued a call today for 19,000 draftees in May.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., March 17 -- A leading Protestant spokesman on international relations warned here today against the development in this country of a "national mind-set" that would automatically reject peace with the Soviet Union "even if Russia were to abandon its methods of coercion, infiltration, and false propaganda."

Ninety-five thousand St. Patrick's Day marchers awakened the echoes in Fifth Avenue yesterday, stepping to pipe skirl, to fife and to drum. Cruel wind tore at their banners and plastered their capes to their backs. It drove off a good part of the more than 1,000,000 persons who came out to watch.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Senate passed and sent to the Governor tonight the Morgan-Brydges bill designed to compromise the dispute that has been raised as a result of a 1950 law that exempted the children of Christian Scientists from classes in hygiene and health that conflict with religious beliefs.
" Flight Into Egypt," a first play by George Tabori, British novelist, will have its Broadway premiere this evening at 8 o'clock at the Music Box.

Buying continued at a record pace yesterday at the American Toy Fair as it started its second week. The show, which is under the sponsorship of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., will end tomorrow at the McAlpin and New Yorker Hotels and at private showrooms.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Treasury Department tomorrow will partly lift its order blocking the United States of the bank of Julius Baer Co. at Zurich, Switzerland, to allow the firm to carry on "its normal activity," it was announced here tonight.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 18 -- Communist staff officers at Panmunjom asked today for additional time to study United Nations questions regarding their ultimate intentions for an exchange of prisoners after an armistice in the Korean war and indicated that the decision had been passed to a higher level of command.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 18 (AP) -Eighth Army tactical summary issued at 6 P. M. Monday (4 A. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

ATHENS, March 17 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, leader of the opposition Greek Rally, today introduced a motion of censure in Parliament against the Government. He charged general ineptitude and maintenance of an army leadership that "had not the confidence of the Greek people."

To avoid any possible charge by American manufacturers that they are dumping their product here, Japanese glove producers will reduce exports of wool knits to the United States by 33 per cent, according to Samuel Shapiro, president of the Smart Set Glove Company, Inc., a leading importer who has just returned from Japan.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 17 -- Connie Mack should have been wearing black instead of green on this St. Patrick's Day after witnessing what happened to a team wearing the proud symbol of the Athletics.

LONDON, March 17 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard Universitiey, urged today that the United States and Britain establish a joint commission to prepare for a resumption of partnership in technical matters, including nuclear physics, similar to the military Combined Chiefs of Staff in World War II.
KEY WEST, March 17 -- President Truman tells in a book published today how you can fall in a creek, as he did, and get wet from ankles to neck without dousing your head and feet.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Artists Equity Association, an organization that figures largely in sponsoring and judging exhibitions in museums throughout the country, was denounced, in the House of Representatives today as "the latest link" in a chain of a Moscow-inspired conspiracy to communize.

TRENTON, March 17 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll swung virtually all of New Jersey's organized Republican strength behind General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight with the declaration that General Eisenhower was his personal choice for the Republican nomination for President.

ALBANY, March 17 -- For the second time in three weeks, Governor Dewey lashed out tonight against advertising and other interests that are opposing a bill to prohibit billboards within 500 feet of the State Thruway.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 17 -- A dice casino for whose operation Joe Adonis received a two-to-three-year jail sentence last May was personally investigated in 1948 by John E. Selser, then First Assistant Prosecutor for Bergen County and subsequently Adonis' trial counsel, according to testimony here today in Bergen County Court.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Monroe Davis Dowling, Collector of Internal Revenue for the upper Manhattan district only since last August, was dismissed today on charges of irregularities in his own income tax return.

NEW DELHI, India, March 13 (By Airmail) -- In struggling with this country's vast food problem, which is aggravated periodically by floods, droughts, locusts and sometimes earthquakes, Indian officials and scientists have come upon another menace that is less spectacular but more inexorable than the others.

Garet Garrett, journalist, novelist and economist, has combined the three fields of endeavor in his forthcoming book, "The Wild Wheel," that Pantheon Books will publish April 28. Mr. Garrett presents a picture of "the rise and fall of Laissez Faire" in America with the story built around the rise of Henry Ford.
KEY WEST, March 17 -- The Emerald Isle and Key West, the United States' southernmost isle in an emerald sea, were linked today by the most felicitous sentiments.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- President Truman's proposal for limiting Congressional service to twelve years drew a vigorous dissent today from members of both major parties -- particularly from those who would be affected.
Harry Gross' twelve-year sentence for bookmaking and conspiracy to violate the gambling laws was upheld unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department. There was no opinion.

Members of the National Association of Waste Materials Dealers were told yesterday that economic changes in the next few years probably would be moderate. More than 1,000 members began a three-day meeting, the group's thirty-ninth annual convention, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- Benjamin V. Cohen, United States representative to the United Nations Disarmament Commission, told an academic convocation in the Dropsie College for Hebrew and Cognate Learning today that tolerance offered the only hope of civilized survival.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Washington officials believe that Iranian spokesmen overstated the gloominess of oil settlement prospects when they said in Teheran yesterday that international negotiations "are now ended."
Hattie Carnegie reflected her own discriminating taste in her choice of French imports, presented yesterday at her Forty-ninth Street salon. From thirteen desingers, thirty-six costumes were shown.

Reflecting the record sales of $183,686,264 attained by the Richfield Oil Corporation last year, net earnings were the highest in the company's fifteen year history, even though taxes took $16,550,000 more than in 1950, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- By way of letting the Senators know that life promises to be no better for them this year than it was in the last, unless they care to make some changes, the Yankees flattened Bucky Harris' squad today, 8 to 5.

The traffic laws and the parking problem are such that doctors are unable to attend many of the ill and injured unless they double park for the twenty to thirty minutes required. Yet beer trucks, laundry trucks and delivery trucks of all descriptions are unmolested when they double park and block traffic.

Young women headed by Miss Sandra Stralem and including the Misses Peggy Polikoff and Judith Paige are serving on the junior committee for the annual series of theatre benefits known as "Five Enchanted Evenings." The last for this season will take place on the night of March 31 at the performance of "One Bright Day" at the Royale Theatre.
LONDON, March 17 -- An unusual amount of close and serious study was being given in London today to the Soviet Union's proposals for an early peace treaty with Germany.

The rapid dieselization of the nation's railroads in the last six years has given the oil industry another good customer. According to a compilation by the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference the railroads last year used nearly 2,500,000,000 gallons of diesel fuel, up 25 per cent above the previous year.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 17 -- It was an Irishman's dream come true when James Earley, veteran street sweeper and Gold Star father, awoke on this St. Patrick's Day and became Mayor of the brass-manufacturing center of the world.
MEXICO CITY, March 17 -- The fuss between Diego Rivera and the Mexican Government was reaching the point of a national scandal today with a good deal of help from the incensed painter.
GENEVA, March 17 -- Tremendous waste is occurring in the international movements of steel, according to qualified steel experts here.

Labels and price tags were about the only positive means of distinguishing between Gimbels' millinery copies as shown yesterday and the original French or Italian creations. Sixteen imports, along with their American-made twins, were presented to the public at 12:30 and 5:30 P. M. on Gimbels' fourth floor. Each copy was priced at $12.50.

Air Force recruiting headquarters at 39 Whitehall Street sparkled with St. Patrick's favorite color yesterday when thirteen young women in green skirts or dresses were sworn into the blue uniformed ranks of the women in the Air Force.

LAST Tuesday the voters of New Hampshire made political news. This Tuesday the present tenant of the White House is making more, for he has authorized the publication of a precedent-blasting book about himself. It is called "Mr. President."* It is written by William Hillman, a radio reporter who enjoys Mr. Truman's complete confidence.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- The Government said today that about 300 surplus World War II airplanes had been resold illegally by private parties and some have gone to Soviet satellite nations.

Eighteen thousand persons filled Madison Square Garden last night for the Purim Victory Festival under the sponsorship of the Greater New York Committee for State of Israel Bonds. Besides witnessing an elaborate pageant telling the story of the Purim holiday, they heard Golda Myerson, Israeli Minister of Labor, declare that Israel was "closer to economic self-sufficiency" than at any time since it attained statehood four years ago.

LONDON, March 17 -- Continued strength of the pound sterling today had beneficial effect on prices of British government securities, but, reflecting general dullness, prices were well below the day's best at the close. Average gain in gilt edged issues was less than 2 shillings sixpence.
PARIS, March 17 (AP) -- Laurent Dauthuille, a leading French middleweight, tonight hammered out a ten-round decision over Norman Hayes, Boston Negro.

Iran, like Korea, is providing an example of the necessity for Westerners to cultivate Eastern patience. The Iranian oil dispute is entering its second year; the nationalization of the industry dates from May 1, 1951; the refinery at Abadan ceased functioning on Oct. 4, when the British technicians were driven out. Mission after mission has gone to Iran, talked and come out.

It is time for the voters of this country to be more practical in their choice of a President. In the first place, no citizen should feel a residual obligation to any political party. The accomplishments, as well as the failures, of the Democratic Administration have created new problems for the Federal Government.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 17 -- In the final week of the baseball season last September, Casey Stengel nodded his head slowly and remarked, "Wanna know somethin'? The best job of managin' bein' done in the major leagues right now is that bein' done by my old pal, Jimmie Dykes."

A small unkempt Italian laborer, guarding his life savings of $22,000, slept from Wednesday night until yesterday morning in Grand Central Terminal hoping that someone who spoke Italian would approach him and help him solve his problem.

Shareholders of the Giant Portland Cement Company at their annual meeting yesterday approved an increase in capital stock from 1,200,000 to 2,500,000 shares. John A. Philbrick, president, said the company has no immediate plans for issuing additional stock.

KEY WEST, March 17 -- The Merry Mac of Indianapolis, a snappy mahogany cabin cruiser, picked its way among submarines and other warcraft here this morning, bringing Frank E. McKinney, Democratic National Chairman, as a guest of President Truman.

The stock market encountered rough going yesterday and barely managed to maintain a steady course. Some of the oils attracted attention but the general section of the list showed little response. In the slowest dealings in two weeks the composite rate fell 0.73 point, but this was due mainly to the softness in the few of the principal components included in the industrial section of THE NEW YORK TIMES index.

WINTER PARK, Fla., March 17 -- A $100,000 damage suit brought against Rollins College here by Dr. Paul A. Wagner, deposed president, has been settled out of court for $50,000, according to a statement issued jointly today by the college and Dr. Wagner.

Three women were elected trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at the March meeting of the board yesterday. They are the first women to serve as trustees of the museum. Two men also were elected. The five new members are:

ALBANY, March 17 -- A bill authorizing the Interstate Sanitation Commission to undertake a tristate study of smoke control and air pollution in the metropolitan area and underwriting half the cost of the venture was passed unanimously in the Assembly tonight.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 15 (By Airmail) -- A warning of the condition of South Africa's defense force, which is contracting to buy arms and equipment from the United States, has been sounded by Lieut. Gen. G. E. Brink, World War II commander of the South African First Division.

The Brooklyn Dodgers and Cleveland Indians may introduce big league baseball "Down Under" with a two-month tour of Australia, beginning next November, Manager Abe Saperstein of the Harlem Globetrotters basketball team said yesterday.
The happy combination of contemporary and traditional furnishings is demonstrated in several of the seven new model rooms that will go on view today at Sloane's.

Mae Williams, mezzo-soprano, who was a member of the cast of "Porgy and Bess," gave her first New York recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. She proved to be an attractive young singer who needs considerably more experience for the development of her gifts.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 17 -- Volunteer political workers were busy today on a last-minute "write-in" campaign for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as Minnesota prepared for its first Presidential preference primary in thirty-six years.

Representative Charles J. Kersten, Republican of Wisconsin, said here yesterday that "if we do not assume the risks of defending truth and justice, we cannot ensure peace." Addressing a meeting of the American Regional Union, International Federation of Free Journalists, in Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street, Representative Kersten said he felt this country should adopt a foreign policy aimed toward the "liberation" of the Soviet satellite countries.

TREVISO, Italy, March 17 -- The first joint exercises ever held under simulated war conditions by the Western Allied land and air forces in Southern Europe opened today in the mountains and plains near the Italian-Yugoslav frontier at and around Udine.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee rejected today a proposal to invite General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to give his views on the $7,900,000,000 mutual security program.

Sol A. Rosenblatt, an attorney and residuary legatee of a $200,000 estate under the contested will of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, was discharged last night from the New York Hospital. He was shot in the thigh under mysterious circumstances on March 6 as he was about to enter his apartment house at 525 Park Avenue.

LA JOLLA, Calif., March 17 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly -- wearing a shamrock at her belt and a green ribbon in her hair -- scored a convincing victory today in the final of the eleventh annual La Jolla Beach and Tennis Club's invitation tournament.

One of the best kept secrets in the advertising field in some years is out. Young Rubicam, Inc., has the yet-to-be-announced Kent cigarette account and has been working on it for months, it was learned yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, March 18 (AP) -- About 1,000 Chinese Communists launched six pre-dawn assaults across a four-mile sector of the western front today but Allied troops stopped them cold.

Net income of Consumers Power Company for the twelve months ended Feb. 29 amounted to $19,625,500, equal to $2.63 a share on 6,176,693 common shares, according to the report released yesterday. This compares with $20,105,286 or $2.98 each on 5,615,176 shares in the twelve months ended Feb. 28, 1951.

THE fly fishermen who have been urging the establishment of "fly fishing only" stretches on some of the New York water have won their point after many years of effort, but this "point" takes in only ten of the 750 miles of water controlled by the Conservation Department.

The letter published in your columns on March 6 and written by an American in Switzerland, Willard Johnson, is most timely. It should have echoes and, let us hope, practical consequences. Everyone is aware of the bitter friction which makes it difficult at present for Americans and Europeans to understand and to like each other.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- General buying of wheat futures was in evidence on the Board of Trade this morning, a reflection of the bullish forecasts of export business announced Saturday. Other grains and soybeans registered early gains also, but in all pits the buying force was soon dissipated and the markets receded on profit taking.
Police Department and Coast Guard helicopters divided rescue honors yesterday as four youths in two separate craft got into trouble with rough water and freezing winds in Jamaica Bay.
A cheese new to most Americans -- Lithuanian farmer's cheese -- made its debut yesterday at Phil Alpert's open-air Cheeses of All Nations shop, 235 Fulton Street.

Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, skipper of the ill-fated cargo ship Flying Enterprise, yesterday became the third recipient in a quarter of a century of the American Bureau of Shipping's gold valor medal. The award was made at a brief ceremony in the offices of the bureau, 45 Broad Street.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Government told contractors today to go ahead with new commercial building, starting on July 1 -- provided there is not a steel strike. The explanation was that there are now "substantial" steel, copper and aluminum stocks on hand.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, asked the Senate Banking Committee today to extend the Defense Production Act with strengthened controls over prices, rents and credit for two years from next June 30, when the existing law will expire.
BOSTON, March 17 (UP) -- Sandy Saddler, 130 3/4 pounds, of New York knocked out Tommy Collins, 130 1/2, of Boston tonight in the fifth round of a scheduled ten-round bout.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, announced today that he would ask the Senate Judiciary Committee, of which he is chairman to approve a bill that would require Senate confirmation of anyone appointed by President Truman as a special investigator or a Special Assistant Attorney General to clean up corruption in the Government.

I take this opportunity to tell you how courageous and significant, in our judgment, were the editorials on universal military training which appeared in the March 6 and the March 8 issues of your newspaper. For those of us who believe deeply in the basic virtues of this training program, these editorials are both heartening and timely.

While Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires drew a bye for the nineteenth round of the international tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, whose match with the Argentine had been postponed until April 4, gained a point yesterday to strengthen his hold on first place, according to a report from Havana.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned steady yesterday and closing prices on active months were 47 to 59 points net higher than on Friday.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Tuesday, March 18 (AP) -- The United States plans to double its military advisory group this year to speed the training of 500,000 troops for the defense of this Nationalist Chinese stronghold, American experts said today.

Red Cross blood donor centers and bloodmobiles collected 2,135 pints of blood Friday and Saturday, including donations from 109 prisoners in Brooklyn City Prison, who were rewarded with steak dinners. Yesterday bloodmobile units made collections at the Naval Supply Corps School in Bayonne, N. J., and at the North Fork center, Riverhead, N. Y., the Red Gross reported.

The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company charged at a Public Service Commission hearing yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company had been overcharging the road for electric power since Aug. 1, 1949.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17 -- The Soviet Union was challenged today to allow foreign correspondents to verify at first hand some of the Soviet scientific and industrial achievements reported by Moscow newspapers.

There is no prospect that rayon textile prices will change sufficiently in the foreseeable future to require Office of Price Stabilization ceilings, Sylvan Gotshal, counsel to the Textile Distributors Institute, said yesterday. The price agency regulations, he said, have no meaning whatsoever in the present market.

CONCORD, N. H., March 17 -Official returns in the nation's first Presidential preference primary, held, last Tuesday in New Hampshire, showed tonight that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower led Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, 46,661 to 35,838, in the Republican popularity contest.

Any misgivings as to the ability of a London bus driver to hold his own in New York traffic were laid at rest yesterday in a series of chauffeur tests given here by the Motor Vehicle Bureau. Unruffled by the right-side-of-the-street driving and the swirl of lower East Side travel, a group of bus men and crew personnel from Britain qualified for licenses "without popping a button," as on remarked.
ALBANY, March 17 (UP) -- The following winter sports conditions were reported today to the New York State Department of Commerce:
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- The Government issued a new set of rules today designed to keep the nation's grocers from deceiving customers or running one another out of business.

A two-installment story of the unhappy Odyssey of a pair of hairy rhinoceroses was disclosed yesterday with the arrival here of the American President Lines ship Schuyler Otis Bland. The tale amplified a bare notice two weeks ago that the beasts had died at sea while being brought to New York from the Far East.

DETROIT, March 17 -- A six-member administrative board appointed by the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., today took over the physical property of Local 600, covering 50,000 employes of the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -Senator Pat McCarran took the first step today to test in the courts whether an American working or formerly working for the United Nations can refuse to answer a Congressional committee if United Nations rules forbid answers.

COLUMBIA, S. C., March 17 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes today denied that President Truman had read a letter to him Jan. 5, 1946, criticizing him for not reporting to the President on the Moscow conference.

BONN, Germany, March 17 -- Unless Soviet authorities in East Germany soon permit them to carry out their mission there, members of the United Nations Commission on All German Elections said today they would abandon the investigation project.

The Seatrain Lines, Inc., has Petitioned the United States District Court in Trenton to restrain the Association of American Railroads and major rail lines in the East from boycotting the steamship company's Savannah-New York service pending the hearing of an anti-trust suit against the railroads.

CLEVELAND, March 17 (AP) -- Don Gehrmann, the famed miler, was suspended today for failing to run in a Cleveland track meet Friday night, but the National A.A.U. secretary indicated that Gehrmann could be reinstated quickly.

VIENNA, March 17 -- The first intimation to appear in the press of a Soviet satellite that the satellites were dismayed by Moscow's proposal to recreate a German national army after a treaty had been signed was contained in the Sunday edition of the Budapest newspaper Magyar Nemszet.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., March 17 -- An interracial public health program to develop cooperative relationships among medical health experts and social scientists as part of a broad attack on the economic and cultural ills of the South was formulated here today at the opening session of a regional institute of public health.
The Police Department started "reshuffling" detective commands yesterday as the aftermath of last-minute promotions from a civil service list for captains that expired Saturday midnight.

Martin H. Feinman, pioneer merchandiser, designer and manufacturer of modern furniture, predicted last night that in ten years at least 75 per cent of all furniture manufactured in the United States would be well-designed modern, keyed to casual living. Speaking at a testimonial dinner in his honor in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Mr. Feinman also said it would be difficult for the consumer, regardless of income, to purchase traditional furniture in a decade.
The New York Yankees have purchased the block bounded by Gerard and River Avenues, East 162d and 164th Streets near the Yankee Stadium in the Bronx for a parking lot to be used by basefall fans.

A Queens gravedigger was arrested yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and charged with having mailed a threatening letter to Arnold Schuster, the Brooklyn clothing salesman who was shot dead after he had pointed out William F. Sutton, the bank robber, to the police.

Daniel Kornblum, director of the city's labor relations division, will try today to avert a strike by 500 members of Local 21381, Funeral Directors, Embalmers and Undertakers Federal Union, A. F. L., at midnight March 31.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- Richard A. Thompson, badly hurt in a spill during the fourth race at Gulfstream Park, underwent surgery tonight and his condition was reported "very critical."

CAIRO, March 17 -- The state visit tomorrow of Syrian Chief of State Col. Fawzi Selo to King Talal of Jordan brings to an end one of the great feuds of the Arab world that divided the Levant republics from the Hashemite Kingdoms of Iraq and Jordan.

TOKYO, Mareh 17 -- The Soviet mission, once the largest in Tokyo, faces the possibility of being closed down, either by the Japanese Government or by action of the Western Powers, after the ratification of the San Francisco Peace Treaty restores sovereignty to this nation, according to well-based reports circulated in Tokyo.

TIGNES, France, March 17 -- This ancient village, high in the French Alps, which had refused to be negotiated out of existence under the threat of man-made floods from a new hydroelectric dam, submitted to the force of arms early today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17 -- Preliminary comments of Trusteeship Council members today on the annual report on the trust territory of New Guinea indicated that Australia, as the administering authority, may be censured because of her failure to raise the royalty rates on gold exports.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter from General Eisenhower to the nineteen members of Congress. It is addressed specifically to Representative Hope.

GENEVA, March 17 -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe unanimously approved today a resolution asking the United Nations secretariat to continue efforts to develop "practicable possibilities" for East-West trade in Europe.

Well over $1,000,000,000 in Federal income tax returns, both individual and corporate, was received yesterday by the three collectors' districts here as the annual parade of taxpayers, extended beyond its normal March 15 deadline, wound up on St. Patrick's Day.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A week-old letter from General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to a group of political supporters, released on receipt here today, ruled out for "the immediate future" his return home to campaign actively for the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Two Republican Senators who ordinarily stand far apart on foreign affairs proposed nine reservations to the Japanese peace treaty and the three associated Pacific security pacts today.

RANGOON, Burma, March 17 -The new Burma Government expects to give the country's 12,000,000 peasants greatly increased control over their own economic affairs under a program it is planning to apply progressively during the next few years.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 17 -- As a result of the New Hampshire primaries, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower now is "active" in American politics "whether he likes it or not," Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Ford Foundation and an active political supporter of the Supreme Commander said here today.

MADISON, Wis., March 17--Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, opened another week of campaigning for Republican Presidential delegates in Wisconsin today with an attack on Senator Robert A. Taft's foreign policy record in the last seven years.

SOUTH SALEM, N. Y., March 17 -- Henry A. Wallace, apparently the "Mr. X" of President Truman's newly published biography, charged today that Mr. Truman had put false accusations against him into the book to promote its sale, arouse talk, remove from the President's neck "the curse of the [Alger] Hiss 'Red Herring'" and regain the support of "certain voting blocs."
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- John D. Small, chairman of the Munitions Board, said today that Communist-dominated unions offered a real threat to the nation's industrial security.

American releasing rights to "No Resting Place," a British-made drama directed by Paul Rotha, have been acquired by Classic Pictures, it was announced by Max J. Rosenberg, president of the distributing company. Michael Gough, Eithne Dunne and Noel Purcell of the Abbey Theatre head the cast of the import, which was produced by Colin Lesslie from a script on which he collaborated with Rotha and Michael Orram.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- One of the secrets of the nation's productive and military might is on display at the International Amphitheater this week. It is the tool industry, which makes the machine behind the machine that turns out the artitcles of every-day use and of war.

DUBLIN, March 17 -- In sunny, spring-like weather. Dubliners turned out by the thousands at noon today to view the biggest national industrial parade yet staged in the Irish capital for St. Patrick's Day. Just now, as the government is urging the Republic to import less and produce more, the parade underlined the present economic trend.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- One of the secrets of the nation's productive and military might is on display at the International Amphitheater this week. It is the tool industry, which makes the machine behind the machine that turns out the artitcles of every-day use and of war.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, the defending champion, lost his first match in the 1952 world three-cushion billiards tournament tonight when he was upset by Ray Kilgore, San Francisco, 50 -- 47, in fifty-three innings.
The city will face a huge mass protest if it goes ahead with its proposed overnight parking and auto use taxes, the Automobile Club of New York warned yesterday.

The leasing of large space on the tenth floor of the Chanin Building at 122 East Forty-second Street by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company was announced yesterday by Henry L. Chanin of the Chanin Organization. Cushman wakefield, Inc., were the brokers.

Striped, checked and printed corduroy, tissue-thin pinwale corduroy and beautifully colored velvets and velveteens, some with a frosty or iridescent look, promise an interesting fashion story for fall.

Many long hours and a vast sum -- Benjamin Fine estimated the dollar total the other day at $5,213,525,854 -- will go this year into the operation of the nation's public schools where more than 26,000,000 pupils are learning, among other things, the art of communication.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 -- Stockholders of the American President Lines held their annual meeting this afternoon, but there was not the fireworks that attended last year's session.
LOS ANGELES, March 17 -- This certainly was a great day for the Irish or, at least, for the lads of Hibernian strain on the Giants.

PHILADELPHIA, March l7 -- William F. Meade, former Republican City Chairman, denied today that he was shot by Miss Virginia Carroll, who was his companion when he was wounded mysteriously early yesterday morning.

Most landlords in the state who sought rent increases through voluntary agreements with tenants under regulations established March 15, 1951, were turned down by the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission, State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick reported yesterday.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Following is a summary and explanation of the proposed program for balancing New York City's 1952-53 budget prepared by the research staff of Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore, one of the chief architects of the suggested solution :
BRADENTON, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- The Braves made it two straight over the Red Sox today behind the four-hit pitching of Max Surkont and Chet Nichols, winning, 2 -- 1, before 2,541.

Representatives of various branches of the legitimate theatre, attending the monthly luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk yesterday, reiterated their intention of going along with plans to institute the 7 o'clock curtain next fall.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Wage Stabilization Board is almost certain to avoid a strong recommendation on the union shop issue in the steel dispute at this time in the interest of giving labor and management another opportunity to bargain it out.

HAVANA, March 17 -- The belief that the United States had a hand in the military coup of last Monday, when Maj. Gen. Fulgencio Batista overthrew the constitutional Government of Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, is held by high-ranking members of the Prio Socarras Administration who for the present must remain anonymous.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- The Braves made it two straight over the Red Sox today behind the four-hit pitching of Max Surkont and Chet Nichols, winning, 2 -- 1, before 2,541.

Representatives of various branches of the legitimate theatre, attending the monthly luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk yesterday, reiterated their intention of going along with plans to institute the 7 o'clock curtain next fall.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today $9,181,912 of common stock of industrial corporations, including $4,537,500 of outstanding shares of the Publicker Industries distillery enterprise, and both new and outstanding stock of a California manufacturer of precision instruments.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Contracts were signed and the Illinois Athletic Commission gave its approval today to a middleweight championship bout between Ray Robinson, the titleholder, and Rocky Graziano in Chicago Stadium April 16.

Paul Arizin, top-scorer in the National Basketball Association, yesterday was named "Pro Player of the Year," by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association. Arizin, the former Villanova star, now sparking the Philadelphia Warriors, will receive the Sam Davis Memorial Award at the association's annual dinner at Leone's March 30.

Of nine investment banking syndicates which bid yesterday for the purchase of $6,000,000 of bonds of the Southwestern Gas and Electric Company, two underwriting groups came up with the same proposal -- a dollar price of $1,001.50 for each bond, with the issue to bear interest of 3 3/8 per cent.
Except for cottonseed oil, commodity futures here appeared neglected yesterday. Volume fell and prices drifted.

State financial aid to public libraries, initiated by legislation in 1950 with the support of Governor Dewey, has been very helpful in some parts of the state, and much appreciated. But experience has demonstrated some defects in the law; county-wide organization of library service, and even the crossing of county lines to increase the availability of good books to every resident, has not made progress as rapidly as hoped for.

Steel production, if continued without interruption, is scheduled to set a new high of 2,127,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This is an increase of 13,000 tons over the previous peak of 2,114,000 tons scheduled to be made last week.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Wage Stabilization Board is almost certain to avoid a strong recommendation on the union shop issue in the steel dispute at this time in the interest of giving labor and management another opportunity to bargain it out.

HAVANA, March 17 -- The belief that the United States had a hand in the military coup of last Monday, when Maj. Gen. Fulgencio Batista overthrew the constitutional Government of Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, is held by high-ranking members of the Prio Socarras Administration who for the present must remain anonymous.
LONDON, March 18 -- Lord Tedder, Marshal of the Royal Air Force, praised President James B. Conant of Harvard today for having spoken "so wisely and frankly about the misuse of nationalism."
HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., March 18 -- Eleven Rockland County villages held elections today, six without contests.

Two teacher organizations announced yesterday they would oppose the so-called Christian Science law even if it is amended by a compromise bill that the State Senate passed and sent to Governor Dewey on Monday night.

BONN, Germany, March 18 -- The United Nations Commission for a study of all-German election possibilities is deliberately stalling and publicizing its presence in Germany in an effort to give the Soviet Union a chance to change its mind and permit a survey in East Germany.

LONDON, March 18 -- Group Captain George Ward, British Under Secretary for Air, acknowledged today that the air defenses of Britain, once able to withstand the full force of the Luftwaffe, would now be "woefully inadequate" were it not for the presence of United States and Canadian squadrons in the country.

Port of New York Day will be observed tomorrow for the nineteenth consecutive year, and it will be highlighted again by the traditional signal flag and ships' whistle tribute. The day is proclaimed annually by the Mayor, at which time attention is directed to the important role of the port in the city's welfare.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 18 (AP) -- Venezuela is set for another record-breaking oil production year in 1952. Expansion programs planned by oil companies will raise both crude and refined output above the 1951 peaks.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, an old critic of the Administration on Asian policy, called on the Senate today to strike down reservations to the Japanese treaty proposed by two fellow Republicans.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson told Congress today that the cost and duration of mutual security aid to the United States' allies would be determined by the size and direction of the Communist threat to the free world. He added that advance calculations of the cost were out of the question.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The reorganization of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's Presidential campaign headquarters now has been completed.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The United States submitted to Communist Rumania today a volume of eighty-nine documents intended to prove that the Bucharest Government had violated the human rights guarantees of its peace treaty.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 18 (AP) -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh charged today that President Truman had refused to help Iran get an American loan unless British proposals for settling the British-Iranian oil dispute were accepted by Iran.

A syndicate of sixty-two under-writers headed by the First Boston Corporation will place on the market today a new issue of $55,000,000 of first mortgage and refunding bonds of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company. The bonds, due Dec. 1, 1985, bear interest of 3 3/8 per cent and are priced at 101.92 to yield 3.28 per cent.

Government counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial admitted in an off-the-record courtroom colloquy yesterday that that part of the complaint charging defendant banking houses with inventing the modern syndicate has been disproved by the testimony of Harold L. Stuart, Chicago financier and witness for the Government.

Several dinners will be given in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria and in private homes Friday evening before the performance of "One Bright Day" at the Royale Theatre for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, today of following a tactic of "hit-and-run" charges in which European friends of this country saw "the tactic of Hitler."
Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet will preside at the departmental trial today of Deputy Chief Nathan Perlman, who was suspended last Thursday after being ordered back from a vacation in Florida.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Legislation permitting the City of Yonkers and five counties to levy a 15 per cent admissions tax on harness racing tracks within their boundaries was approved unanimously by the Assembly today and sent to Governor Dewey for his signature.

ALBANY, March 18 -- J. Edward Conway and Miss Louise C. Gerry, the two Republican members of the State Civil Service Commission, announced today their endorsement of a Dewey bill to abolish the commission and vest administration of the Civil Service Law in a single Personnel Commissioner.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 18 (UP) -- Gift Silver, a colt that never entered a race, yet finished third, could write an intriguing chapter in the history of the Kentucky Derby, May 3.

Continuation of the forced limitation or squeezing of corporate income, which, it said, had accompanied inflation over the last decade, could "prove as dangerous to the future prosperity of our country as the threat of aggression from abroad," the United States Steel Corporation said yesterday in its annual report to stockholders.

RANGOON, Burma, March 18 -- Government spokesmen strongly repudiated today opposition charges made in parliamentary debate here yesterday that Burma's recent acceptance of continued United States economic aid infringed Burma's independence and made the country a satellite of the United States.
A series of model rooms, just installed at McMillen, 148 East Fifty-fifth Street, will afford New Yorkers their first opportunity to study examples of post-war French decorative arts.

LOS ANGELES, March 18 (AP) -- Ending a threat by some major league teams to bolt from Californa's spring training grounds, representatives of six big league clubs agreed today to go along with the Pacific Coast League ban against them playing each other in Coast League parks next year.

With Monday marking the deadline for completing Federal tax returns on 1951 incomes, receipts here had run far above last year, but could not be fairly compared because of the extra two days filing period this year and the increase in first corporate income tax installments from 25 to 35 per cent.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The loss of the freighter Flying Enterprise and Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen's magnificent effort to save his ship were dismissed today by Red Fleet, organ of the Soviet Navy, as the unnecessary result of secret United States Defense Department orders designed to conceal the fact that the ship was carrying parts for a V-2 flying bomb and other forbidden armaments made in West Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Government announced today it is going to pay 33.8 cents a pound, nearly 10 cents above ceiling, to get production of about 6,372,000 pounds of prime lake copper.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- Army Intelligence has urged revival of the wartime regulation under which soldiers overseas were forbidden to keep personal diaries, it was disclosed today. The recommendation is an outgrowth of the stolen diary case involving Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow, former United States military attache at Moscow.

PITTSBURGH, March 18 (AP) -- Manufacturers Light and Heat Company, large western Pennsylvania gas company, disclosed today it has contracted with Gulf Interstate Gas Company for the construction of a $120,000,000 pipeline from the Gulf Coast of Texas to Huntington, W. Va.

GENEVA, March 18 -- The lackadaisical attitude of Italian Government departments toward organizing the emigration of Italians to Latin America is causing international migration officials grave concern.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Construction of United States air bases in North Africa was characterized as "one sordid mess" today by the chief Congressional investigator of the $455,000,000 projects, Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Members of the American Society of Tool Engineers were told today that metals so hard that they cannot be machined by conventional methods, including use of tungsten carbide, are being shaped by a new electro-mechanical process.

PARIS, March 18 -- Paul G. Hoffman, former head of the Marshall Plan, has decided to request a three-month leave of absence from the Ford Foundation, which he heads, in order to devote all of his time to campaigning for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's nomination as the Republican Presidential candidate.

Manufacturers are being bombarded with advice to expand their markets and to test new products in preparation for an era of tough competitive selling. Many wish to do so but face the problems of where to secure the needed additional salesmen and how to obtain the money needed for effective market testing of new products.

LONDON, March 18 -- A high United States source said today that the March 10 Soviet note on Germany might be the first concrete evidence that the Western policy of negotiating through strength was beginning to pay dividends.

After a temperate debate, marked by the nearest approach to bipartisan harmony achieved thus far in respect to a Far Eastern issue, the Senate is due to vote this week on ratification of the Japanese treaty and the related security pacts. The character of the debate, in which Senators from both parties praised the treaty as a milestone in a new American approach to world peace, has made approval certain.
At 8 o'clock this evening, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse will introduce "One Bright Day" at the Royale.

BALTIMORE, March 18 -- Two Government witnesses testified today in the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal District Court here that they were informers for the Federal Bureau of Investigation while they were members of the Communist party.

NEWARK, March 18 -- A conference to consider the reopening of Newark Airport to military aircraft, particularly to warplanes destined for North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations, has been called for next Monday. The meeting is scheduled for 10:30 A. M. in the Newark City Hall.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 18 (AP) -- The National Economic Council proposed a new foreign capital law today giving advantages to certain types of investments. The draft of a bill recommended to President Getulio Vargas by the Council classifies such investments and provides for contracts with the Government on the terms.

PASADENA, Calif., March 18 -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, associate director of the Ford Foundation, said tonight that Mr. Hoffman's announced intention of taking a leave from the Foundation presidency to aid General Eisenhower's campaign was news to him.

Mrs. Alben W. Barkley, wife of the vice President and a vice president herself of the American Heart Association, was the guest of honor yesterday at the opening of a portrait exhibit at the Grand Central Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

The Taft and Eisenhower campaign forces will have a showdown in the selection of Republican convention delegates in the Sixteenth Congressional District, which embraces all of Staten Island and part of lower Manhattan. This situation developed yesterday as petitions were filed before the deadline with the Board of Elections. The issue will be decided on Primary Day, April 22.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Half the counties in this country do not have the protection of a full-time health department, Dr. Thomas D. Dublin, executive director of the National Health Council, told the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation today.

Hearn's presented an around-the-clock round-up of spring fashions yesterday under the title, "More Fashion Than Dollars." Shown were suits and Easter bonnets, pastel coats, coat and suit ensembles, silk suits and late day and evening fashions.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Assembly today approved, by the minimum number of votes necessary for passage, a bill that would enable savings banks to invest a certain portion of their assets in common and preferred stocks. The vote was 76 to 62, cutting across party lines.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- A United Nations body of news experts today condemned the suppression of the Argentine newspaper La Prensa as an infringement of freedom of the press.

Ordinarily, he would have been out of place. It was, after all, a luncheon-meeting of the Track Writers Association and he never had put a shot, thrown a javelin or run a mile in his life. Yet, there he was yesterday gracing Leone's main table and doing a grand job of "selling" for the United States Olympic Committee and that group's Sport Carnival, which will be staged Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

" Inside Our Schools," an ambitious series of broadcasts designed to familiarize New Yorkers with their school system, offered yesterday morning its first major undertaking: a three-hour visit by television to a public school in session.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A parade of witnesses from the meat and livestock industry appeared before the Senate Banking Committee today to demand that price and wage controls be allowed to lapse with the end of the Defense Production Act next June 30.

The report in THE TIMES of March 15 that Secretary of the Army Frank Pace Jr. acknowledged in his address to the Four Freedoms Foundation, Inc., the existence of "a growing lack of confidence in the Federal Government" is an interesting reflection of concern among federal officials.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Senate approved unanimously today a bill appropriating $400,000 in state aid for county and city library systems and speeding up the method by which state-aid payments are made. Introduced by Senator Walter Van Wiggeren, Republican of Herkimer, the bill originally carried an appropriation of $650,000. It goes to the Assembly for concurrence.

CAIRO, March 18 -- Two former Cabinet Ministers, both prominent members of the Wafd party, which holds a majority in Egypt's Parliament, have been arrested and placed under enforced residence at their estates.
CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- Stockholders of Wilson Co., meat packers, were assured today that their company's operations were "in the black" for the first quarter of fiscal 1952.

More persons are living longer today than ever before, homes are smaller, household help is hard to find and expensive when found. These circumstances, Mrs. Edith M. Stern said yesterday, combine to create a problem for many families out of what should be a natural phase of the life cycle, the care by mature children of their aging parents.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Legislation to permit the Long Island Transit Authority to file a plan of reorganization with the Federal Court for the Long Island Rail Road, with a view to lifting the commuter line out of bankruptcy at the earliest possible date, was approved in the Senate today by a vote of 38 to 14.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 18 (AP) -- President Truman abruptly pulled out of California's Presidential primary today, a week after losing to Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee in New Hampshire.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 18 -- Eleven Suffolk County villages held elections today. In five, candidates were unopposed.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 98 additional battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 17 killed, 70 wounded, 2 missing in action and 9 injured. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):
An engineer who started the dynamos for Columbia University's new uptown plant in 1898 explored last night the mechanical mysteries of nuclear fission.
