Samuel Reshevsky, leading by 1 1/2 points, moved closer to victory yesterday in the international tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club when he defeated Erich Eliskases of Argentina, according to a report from Havana. It was the first loss charged against the Austrian-born South American representative, who in January won a tournament in Uruguay without being defeated.

WASHINGTON, March 18-- Senator Homer Capehart, Republican of Indiana, asserted today that just before the Potsdam Conference of August, 1945, President Truman had observed that he was more afraid of England and France than of Russia.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- The House Rules Committee postponed action on pending "fair trade" bills today after one member denounced "high pressure" tactics of retail lobby groups supporting the legislation.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 18 -- New York's police and other law-enforcement officials and some of its underworld characters figured prominently in testimony here today at the trial of Michael Orecchio, former Bergen County chief of detectives, who is accused of misconduct in office.

Dade County, Fla., sold yesterday $2,500,000 of hospital bonds due from April 1, 1954 to 1973 to a banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. at a bid of 100.0699 for interest of 4 per cent and 2 1/2 per cent, an interest cost of 2.62 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1.40 per cent to 2.70 per cent.

There are two easy tests of the genuineness of the Soviet proposal for early four-Power negotiations for an all-German peace treaty. One is the Kremlin's response to the offer of the Western Powers for an Austrian settlement on terms that represent four-Power agreement on every issue save that of the disposition of the so-called German assets.

Brazil probably will soon relax restrictions recently imposed on remittances of foreign investment earnings with a plan said to have been rejected by the United States in 1948, members of the Export Managers Club were told yesterday at their thirty-fifth anniversary "get-together" convention.

MINNEAPOLIS, Wednesday, March 19 -- With an amazing write-in vote, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower ran a strong second to the favored Harold E. Stassen in returns early today from Minnesota's first Presidential preference primary in thirty-six years.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 13 points lower to 14 points higher than on Monday.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Amendments to the State Business and Commercial Rent Control Laws were approved by the Senate today over the protests of three Queens Democrats, who said there was no longer any need for commercial and business rent protection.

The Soviet Government does not like American press reporting on the U. S. S. R. This is made clear again by the remarks of V. M. Zonov, the Soviet representative on a United Nations group of news experts. Mr. Zonov says that dispatches from American correspondents in Moscow are "garbled, changed and processed" when they arrive here.

BERLIN, March 18 -- Four of Hitler's top lieutenants now serving sentences at Spandau Prison after their trials at Nuremberg soon will be tried by a denazification court here, the West Berlin Government said tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Eric Johnston, now foreign aid adviser to the Government, called today for a full-scale campaign to promote private investments abroad and take some of the foreign spending burden off American taxpayers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- Paramount is importing from England a trio of young actresses to play lead roles as the three sisters in "Pleasure Island" who live on an isolated South Pacific island with their parents and have their first contact with white men of their own ages when a detachment of United States Marines lands.

When railroad management, union and Government spokesmen gather in Cleveland on Friday for the Federal Court argument on making permanent the present temporary injunction restraining the engineers, firemen and conductors from repeating their recent strike the parties may well consider the time opportune for ending the nearly-three-year-old dispute.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Legislation designed to strengthen the hand of the State Athletic Commission in dealing with criminal elements in boxing was approved by a vote of 52 to 2 in the Senate today and sent to Governor Dewey for his considerations.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 18 -- Renewed suggestions in Republican quarters that General Eisenhower return to conduct an active campaign well before the Republican National convention received a negative White House response today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- United Nations officials were reported today to have asked the Supreme Allied Command in Tokyo for its opinion as to whether the World Health Organization should be invited to conduct an investigation of Communist charges that the United States is using germ warfare in Korea and China.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- This tourist went sight-seeing at Al Lang Field the other morning and blinked in astonishment upon glimpsing a stocky, left-handed pitcher in a Cardinal uniform. He looked natural enough but there was the disturbing feeling that something wasn't in focus. Suddenly a great light dawned. The familiar figure in Redbird trappings was Max Lanier, who had been traded to the Giants in the Eddie Stanky deal.
Supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft in New Jersey said yesterday that they were not surprised at Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's declaration in favor of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

JERUSALEM, March 18 -- Housing of a superior type to the standard dwellings being mass-produced for immigrants in Israel will be erected for professional persons and technicians, according to a decision taken here by the Executive of the Jewish Agensy for Palestine.

The shades of Victor Hugo and Leonardo da Vinci are being pressed into service for Communist propaganda this year in major campaign aimed at proving that Stalinism is the legitimate guardian of and heir to the best of the world's culture.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- The Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives unanimously approved today a $1,144,883,000 Navy shipbuilding and modernization program, including another super aircraft carrier and a second atomic submarine.

A news item in THE TIMES of March 15 should cause much concern to every citizen who is interested in improving the administration of justice. I refer specifically to the report that the Ways and Means and Senate Finance Committees have before them a bill which would reduce the budget of the Judicial Council of the State of New York from approximately $49,000 to $30,000.

A new group of furniture units, fully assembled, completely finished and ready to use, is now available at Klaus Grabe, Inc., 719 Lexington Avenue. This group was designed by Marc Berge and includes chests and cabinets that may be arranged in high, low or long arrangements to meet individual space requirements.

With carrots and beets from winter-growing areas now at the peak of production, the cost of these colorful nutrition-packed vegetables has been cut almost in half. Price tags have dipped from a December high of 19 cents to a dime a bunch.

A No. 11 London double-decker bus rolled up Madison Avenue yesterday on the right-hand side of the road instead of following its normal left-hand route along Buckingham Palace Road to Charing Cross, leaving a wake of double-takes.

Two more books dealing with American politics are scheduled for early publication. On Friday, the Washington Book Company will issue "The Greatest American Sport," by Lincoln Shakespeare, a discussion of the role of the Electoral College and George Washington's influence on it.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Pentagon must revise quickly its armed services procurement policies if a critical unemployment situation is to be avoided in the clothing industry, particularly in Connecticut, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, a vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C. I. O., told members of Congress and armed services officials today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 18 -- A witness to an attempted hold-up, who was to appear in court next Friday against a suspect, was blown to pieces today with his wife by a bomb that had been attached to the starter of his delivery truck.

Travel by Thermostat The winter's travel season is drawing to an end now, to be followed in due course by the spring travel season, and then by that of summer. The palms of the south and the ski trails of the north presently will be giving way to the blossoms of the Shenandoah, and those in turn to the bobbing sails off Cape Cod and Nantucket.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 (UP) -- Willie Hoppe, the world champion, was beaten for the second consecutive night tonight as Joe Procita of Los Angeles defeated him, 50 -- 41 in forty-eight innings, in the world three-cushion billiard championship tournament.

Immediate expansion of the facilities of the Windham Children's Service by a third was announced yesterday by its president, H. Pelham Curtis, at the annual meeting at the Marguery Hotel, 270 Park Avenue. The service maintains the only emergency foster homes for New York City Protestant children. Last year 66,768 days' care were given to 588 children in the most extensive program in the agency's history.

Judge Jacob Panken of the Domestic Relations Court expresses alarm in his letter published in THE TIMES of March 12 that a pending legislative proposal which would provide psychiatric treatment to unstable children would require that the psychiatrist, "whenever practical, be of the same religious faith as the child."

The spread between the cost of producing gas and the rates the Consolidated Edison Company charges its customers in Westchester County was cited here yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing in support of the county's petition for lower rates.

LONDON, March 18 -- Prices continued to recede in nearly every sction of the Stock Exchange today. Budgetary implications and persistence of rumors of large new capital issues combined to depress industrial shares. In mining markets base metal shares were affected by the reduction of the price of lead.

Mrs. Charles C. Loehmann is chairman and Mrs. Jean Pierre Millon and Mrs. Theodore W. Stemmler, co - chairmen, of the committee planning the tea dance and cocktail party on the afternoon of April 24 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery.

Only a few years ago, in many communities, women teachers lost their jobs if they married. Time has brought some changes, however, and at the Mills College of Education, 66 Fifth Avenue, young women preparing for teaching careers often marry even before they are graduated.
A program for mobilizing school resources to combat and prevent juvenile delinquency has been recommended to the Board of Education by the Association of Assistant Superintendents.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- Joseph D. Nunan Jr., former Internal Revenue Commissioner, was questioned by House tax scandal investigators for several hours today and was reported to have refused to answer some questions.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- A Senate subcommittee was told today that Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson is setting up a Machine Tool Commission to tackle problems of machine tool shortages and conflicting demands for the limited supply.

Students of economics, for the sake of the growth and welfare of the country, must make every effort to change the capital gains tax, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared in an address yesterday before the Economic Club of Chicago. He recommended that the holding period be cut from six to three months and that the tax itself be "reduced as soon as it is feasible."

HONG KONG, March 18 -- Full-fledged socialism for China in ten to twenty years is foreseen by Teng Tzu-hui, vice chairman of the Central-South region, if the Chinese Communists achieve "total victory" in their present two-front domestic war on "decadent capitalists" and "corrupt" government elements.

Instead of starting to build 10,581 new apartments under a Federally aided program for the coming fiscal year, the city will be able to begin only 2,000 if the recommendations of a House committee are adopted by Congress, Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday.
POINT BARROW, Alaska, March 18 -- A Navy expedition reported today it had found ice frozen to a depth of 10,000 to 20,000 feet by the 40-degree-below-zero temperatures at the top of the world.

Describing his career from high school days, Harry S. Truman refers to himself on the very first page of the new book "Mr. President" as "window washer, bottle duster, floor scrubber * * * timekeeper * * * employe of a newspaper * * * bank clerk * * * farmer * * * public official" and, finally, as President of the United States of America.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 18 -- Manager Chuck Dressen borrowed Don Zimmer, highly rated young shortstop, from the Fort Worth Cats today to play shortstop in place of the absent Pee Wee Reese and the varsity Dodgers beat the Cats, 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- A dealer in Government bonds proposed today that Series E Savings Bonds be replaced by "Savings Certificates" bearing an interest rate that would be adjusted every six months to prevailing economic conditions.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Sammy Snead, unmindful of strong March winds that played freakish tricks with many a golf ball, stroked a 2-under-par 70 today to take the first-round lead in the $10,000 Seminole Pro-Amateur Tournament.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 18 -- North Carolina Republicans today elected as delegates-at-large to the Chicago National Convention two who want Robert A. Taft for the party's Presidential nominee, one believed to be for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and one not yet committed.

The powerful derrick of the salvage barge Challenger reached down into the East River early yesterday and easily lifted the 85-foot tug Marion Meseck from the bottom off Pier 8, where she had rested since about 7:30 P. M. Sunday.

Flexibility has been restored to the Government bond market and the Federal Reserve System has been able to regain a real measure of initiative in controlling the volume of member-bank reserves as well as inducing member banks to borrow for needed reserves. This is one of the highlights of the annual report for 1951 to the stockholders of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, signed by Allan Sproul, president of the bank.

There will surely be a shortage of blood for tranfusions if ever an atomic bomb is dropped on any of our cities. Hence the current interest in "blood substitutes" or "blood extenders," as physicians prefer to call them, because there is no substitute for whole blood. Extenders play so important a part in medicine that hospitals are willing to try any new one of promise.
CINCINNATI, March 18 -- Charles E. Wilson, Defense Mobilization Director, called on the aircraft industry tonight to double its jet plane output this year by a "stupendous effort" of production.
Hy Buller of the Rangers became the first rookie in the team's history to be voted "the most valuable player" by the New York Hockey Writers Association yesterday.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Friends of President Truman found clear evidence today, in his withdrawal from the California primary, that he is taking personal charge of political strategy as it affects himself.

Arrangements of cut flowers on the upper floors of Grand Central Palace are as much a part of the thirty-sixth International Flower Show as are the display gardens on the first floor. The gardens, however, remain in full bloom for the week, while flower arrangements change each day.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., March 18 -- In a steady drizzle of cold rain Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, continued today his fourteen-day tour of this state in his final drive to win in the April 1 primary its thirty Republican delegates to the National Convention in Chicago next July.

Plans to back legislation to revise immigration laws and bring 100,000 displaced persons in Italy to this country to replenish the dwindling agricultural labor market were made yesterday by members of the American Committee on Italian Migration.
Contributions to scholarship and the arts were made by 125 members of the Hunter College faculty last year, according to the newly published Faculty Year Book of 1950-51.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- Vic Raschi, making his spring exhibition debut, turned in an excellent job of pitching today, but the Yankee ace right-hander by no means had the stage to himself.

BOSTON, March 18 (UP) -- Boston's story book "Kraut Line" came back as a unit to pace the Bruins to a Stanley Cup play-off berth tonight, with Bobby Bauer and Woody Dumart assisting Milt Schmidt on his 200th goal and helping the Bruins to gain a 4-0 victory over Chicago.

HAVANA, March 18 -- The appointment of a provisional President to govern with a Council of State, consisting of twenty prominent citizens, is about to be announced, according to high-level and well-informed political figures of Cuba.
George V. Allen, United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia, said here last night that the United States was getting "high value" in return for its aid to Yugoslavia.

Irene of New York gives a new look this season to the simple youthful silhouette. In a collection of late spring and summer millinery designs viewed yesterday at 16 East Fifty-second Street, she utilized organdy and hair braid, combined velvet with alpaca, fashioned cutwork velvet crowns and brought forth dramatic wide brims and tiny silhouettes of pastel velvet.
Charles Weiner has been appointed branch store divisional manager of home furnishings and men's wear at the Fresh Meadows store of Bloomingdale Bros.

Surrogate William T. Collins reserved decision yesterday after both sides rested in the contest to set aside the will of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, granddaughter of the late J. P. Morgan. The surrogate said he would hand down a decision at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow on a motion to dismiss the proceedings, which have been before him since Feb. 27.

The Brooklyn Museum will open to the public today its sixth annual national print exhibition. Some 200 examples have been assembled, about half of them employing color. One noticeable factor in the exhibition is the presence of large prints.

Performances of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on the afternoon and evening of April 18 at Madison Square Garden will aid the work of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center, 173 East 112th Street. Choice seats at both performances have been taken over by persons active in behalf of the philanthropy to raise funds for the East Harlem center.

With two exceptions, major commodities were lower in price here yesterday. One was rubber, which gained 50 to 74 points on the Commodity Exchange, where trade buying overcame commission house selling. Only two deliveries, September and December, were actually traded. These rose, respectively, 70 and 55 points. Volume was 420 tons.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Assembly defeated today 83 to 54 a bill that would have required the State Workmen's Compensation Board to include a statement of its findings of fact and conclusions as to the law with its decisions on all appeals.

Four squadrons of airships, organized in the Navy's first postwar Fleet Airship Wing, are participating in Convex III -- the anti-submarine convoy exercise along the Atlantic Coast, which will be concluded tonight.

The General Electric Company touched off yesterday what may be the beginning of the first round of television receiver price cuts this year. The company reduced suggested list prices of its sets $20 to $90.

HASTINGS, Neb., March 18 -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma bid for the farm vote today as he traveled through snow and rain across south central Nebraska in his contest with Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee for Nebraska's delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

LOS ANGELES, March 18 -- The Federal Government's second major court test of the application of the Smith Act to the Communist party, which initially was expected to take no more than two months, now threatens to be as protracted as the original thirty-nine week trial of eleven top party leaders in New York in 1949.

PARIS, March 18 -- James C. Dunn, who arrived by air from Rome today to assume his post as United States Ambassador to France, will represent the United States in the Allied talks tomorrow on the Soviet note proposing peace in Germany.

Former Broadway plays will be televised over Channel 9 in a new type of dramatic series in which each play will be presented five times weekly on consecutive evenings, beginning April 14. Each week will bring a new production to be presented on Monday through Friday, 7:30 to 9 P. M., under the title of "Broadway TV Theatre."

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 19 -- United Nations and Communist negotiators moved somewhat closer today on the determination of "ports of entry," at which both sides would be permitted to bring in replacements of troops and equipment and where neutral inspectors would be stationed after an armistice in the Korean war.

Net income of the Aluminum Company of America for 1951 amounted to $39,301,308, equal to $7.53 a common share, on total revenues of $539,615,017, A. V. Davis, chairman, and I. W. Wilson, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.
If all-out war should come tomorrow, we could reach maximum production of arms and planes in about a year, Manly Fleischmann, National Production Administrator, asserted yesterday.

Three prospective jurors were seated in Queens County Court yesterday at the trial of William F. Sutton and Thomas Kling on two-year-old indictments that accused them of having stolen $63,942 from the Sunnyside branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company in Queens on March 9, 1950.

A Brooklyn woman, who ignored twelve traffic law charges that included three speeding tickets, was ordered yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh to refrain from driving again under penalty of spending forty days in the workhouse.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Grain futures showed a reactionary tendency today, with rains in the Southwest forcing sales of wheat. Corn was relatively steady, but oats were under pressure, the demand much slower than recently. Rye inclined to rally on moderate buying, but was held in check by the easier tendency in other grains.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., March 18 -- The Giants flashed some more smart pitching today in an overtime battle with the Pirates before 1,463 chilled onlookers, but, because George Bamberger fouled up the script, the National League champions bowed to Billy Meyer's Buccaneers, 3 to 2, in eleven innings.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The fact that business abandoned its policy of inventory accumulation at the end of last year has been a major factor in the abatement of inflationary pressures, the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce asserted today.

A seres of moves to enlarge the capacity of New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to handle the airline traffic diverted from Newark Airport and to improve the safety factor and cut down noise by use of preferential runways was announced last night by Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas L. J. Corcoran dismissed yesterday a suit to prohibit New York City from engaging in court-sanctioned wiretapping. The suit had been brought by Harold Black, an artist, and had been supported by the New York Civil Liberties Union.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A special three-judge court has held the criminal penalties section and other parts of the Federal Lobbying Act unconstitutional.

Marvin Markowitz, a 19-year-old messenger, who a year ago had described to the police how a hold-up man had used brutal technique" in robbing him of a $7,577 payroll, turned out to have been one of the robbers in the case himself, the police declared yesterday.

BOSTON, March 18 -- The deadline for filling vacancies among candidates for delegates and alternates on the ballot in the Massachusetts Presidential primary on April 29 passed today at 5 P. M. without any additions.

Paolo Crescenzo, the retired Italian railroad laborer who slept in Grand Central Terminal for five nights guarding his life savings of $22,000 and waiting for someone to tell him how to get a ship back to Italy, spent yesterday in the terminal's Travelers Aid Society office.
The bipartisan stop-gap financial program for the city drew critical comment from business, real estate and civil service spokesmen yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to deny to Newbold Morris, appointed by President Truman to investigate corruption in Government, powers to subpoena witnesses and records. Mr. Morris has called such powers essential to the success of his inquiry.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., March 18 -- The general secretary of the World Council of Churches said here today that despite lack of official contact with religious groups behind the Iron Curtain, there was ample evidence of their loyalty to their faiths.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., March 18 -- Public health programs are essential for the conversion of human and natural resources and the wider distribution of opportunity, Dr. Howard W. Odum, sociologist, declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The House of Representatives voted by voice today to give permanent residence in the United States to the man who assassinated Peter Woykow, Soviet Ambassador to Poland, in 1927. The authorizing legislation now goes to the Senate.
REPORTS from New Brunswick prophets indicate an early ice-out this season, which should be pleasant news for those who make an annual trip to the Miramichi for the "spring" salmon fishing.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 18 -- Forty-seven Nassau County villages held elections today, thirty-nine of them uncontested.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- Representatives of Australia and Iraq clashed at the Trusteeship Council session today over the extent to which the council was empowered to interfere in the administration of a trust territory.
MEXICO CITY, March 18 -- With songs, speeches and demonstrations Mexico celebrated today the fourteenth anniversary of her expropriation of foreign oil companies.

Enabling action permitting the State Legislature to adopt that part of the Albany bipartisan stopgap $234,800,000 financial program for the City of New York requiring home-rule sanction here was taken yesterday by the City Council after approval by its State Legislation Committee.

LISBON, Portugal, March 18 -- A station of Radio Free Europe was formally opened today in the village of Gloria, forty miles northeast of Lisbon. This should dispel the rumors that accumulated during the last six months regarding the broadcasting post, sometimes even described as a secret Communist station.
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 19 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,193 for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time).

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Northern Natural Gas Company, Omaha, Neb., received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to renew, for a period of nine months from March 22, a $42,000,000 line of credit it now has with eight commercial banks.

The police, faced with many thefts of jewelry in midtown hotels in recent months, had a new kind of problem yesterday. A tray containing jewelry worth $13,300 and $4,600 in cash, disappeared from a safe deposit box in the cashier's cage in the Ambassador Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, they announced.
One thousand city employes, including 500 from the Department of Welfare and 500 firemen, will donate blood to the Red Cross today.

Today's new film is "The Bad Lord Byron," a British-made drama based on the life of the poet, with Dennis Price, Linden Travers, Joan Greenwood and Sonia Holm, at the Seventy-second Street Trans-Lux. David McDonald directed and Aubrey Baring produced the J. Arthur Rank presentation, which is being released by International Film.

The Texas Company, which began operations in 1902 in Beaumont, Tex., with a capitalization of $3,000,000, will celebrate its fiftieth birthday on April 7 with assets exceeding $1,500,000,000. Noting that the company had paid cash dividends each year since 1903, the annual report said yesterday that the fifty-year development "is a demonstration of what can be accomplished under a system of free, competitive enterprise."

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Industry members of the Wage Stabilization Board proposed today that the board recommend a "package" settlement of 13.7 cents an hour in the steel dispute. They said public members told them that was too low.

The $234,800,000 stop-gap financial program for New York City now formalized and put before the Legislature is a product largely of fiscal ingenuity. It is cleverly inventive rather than basically sound. It smacks of putting a new and larger mortgage on the aging homestead.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Democratic legislators and representatives of the New York City administration are balking at a proposed constitutional amendment dealing with the city's real estate taxing powers that is included in the suggested stop-gap solution to the city's financial crisis.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Industry members of the Wage Stabilization Board proposed today that the board recommend a "package" settlement of 13.7 cents an hour in the steel dispute. They said public members told them that was too low.

The $234,800,000 stop-gap financial program for New York City now formalized and put before the Legislature is a product largely of fiscal ingenuity. It is cleverly inventive rather than basically sound. It smacks of putting a new and larger mortgage on the aging homestead.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Democratic legislators and representatives of the New York City administration are balking at a proposed constitutional amendment dealing with the city's real estate taxing powers that is included in the suggested stop-gap solution to the city's financial crisis.

CONCORD, N. H., March 18 (AP) -- The New Hampshire Attorney General was asked today to remove two Kefauver delegates from winning positions in last Tuesday's primary on the ground that they are Republicans.

Although cleared of complicity in the mysterious slaying of Arnold Schuster, a 62-year-old gravedigger was held yesterday in bail of $15,000 on a charge of mailing a threatening letter to the youth who brought about the capture of Sutton.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 18 -- Twenty incorporated villages of Westchester County elected mayors, trustees and other local officials today. Eleven of the polls were uncontested.

TIGNES, France, March 18 -- The flooding of this ancient Alpine village by the dammed waters of the Isere River, publicized as imminent and inevitable by the French Government in an effort to force the town's inhabitants to leave, actually is a carefully controlled operation that could be arrested at any time if lives were in danger.

The Detroit Edison Company, one of the nation's leading independent operating utilities, and the Dow Chemical Company, a major company in the organic and inorganic chemical field, have joined hands experimentally in developing atomic energy for the production of electric power.

Paul G. Hoffman, who is scheduled to take over the leadership of the Eisenhower - for - President drive, returned yesterday morning from conferences with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower at Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, with the word that the general "is now thinking as a candidate."

MINNEAPOLIS, March 19 -- Some wrote it just "Ike." Some wrote him in as "Izenour." Others made it "General Ike." Some came up with "Ikenhoner." A few copied from newspaper clippings the full name: General Dwight D. Eisenhower.

After about one act of fooling around with inconsequential humor, Sigmund Miller gets down to business in "One Bright Day," put on at the Royale last evening. The president of a pharmaceutical company has to decide a tough moral point.

To some children, modeling in McCreery's spring fashion show at a luncheon in the Pierre Hotel yesterday was as much fun as the circus, the theme on which the show closed. To others it seemd a fairly timorous experience.

The city's Department of Hospitals, which pioneered in the tests of the promising new anti-tuberculosis drug will greatly expand these clinical investigations as the result of a large increase in the availability of the hitherto scarce chemicals, it was learned yesterday.

A children's playground on the site of the old Claremont Inn has been completed and is open for public use. It is in the small park directly north of Grant's Tomb. The city now has 572 playgrounds in operation, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, March 19 -- Further proof of man's existence in the Western Hemisphere at least 12,000 years ago has been uncovered by Mexican archaeologists whose discovery was hailed today by a United States scientist as "the most important of its kind ever made in the Americas."

As Mayor Impellitteri began his annual "budget retreat" yesterday, indications were that in the fiscal year beginning next July 1 the city, despite much-discussed economies and a general policy of not filling vacancies where possible, would have a record budget totaling close to $1,500,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, said today his support in the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination would go to the winner in New Jersey's April 15 primary.

" The State of Latin America," a new work by German Arciniegas, has been scheduled for April 21 publication by Knopf. It is a survey of our neighboring republics and describes the struggle between dictatorship and democracy in those countries.

LONDON, March 19 -- The British Labor party acted today to strengthen the machinery for making its representatives in the House of Commons follow the party line laid down by the majority. The move was aimed at preventing Aneurin Bevan and his followers from straying off the reservation, as they did recently after a rearmament debate when they voted against the Government despite orders from their leaders to abstain.

Two large state-aided, low-rent housing projects were advanced yesterday when the City Planning Commission at City Hall approved plans for a $5,175,000 second section of Albany Houses in Brooklyn and the new $15,900,000 Mill Brook Houses in the Bronx.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 19 (AP) -- The appointment of three new varsity football assistant coaches was revealed today by Bob Hall, chairman of the Yale University Board of Athletic Control.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- The Senate today ordered contempt prosecution against Abram Flaxer, president of the United Public Workers Union, who was accused of being a "recalcitrant" witness before the Senate Internal Security Committee.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 19 -- A constitutional amendment, adopted today in the lower house of Parliament by a vote of 74 to 10, provides that, with the approval of a two-thirds Parliamentary majority, a treaty in conflict with basic Dutch law shall take precedence when it serves to promote "the development of the international legal order."

ALBANY, March 19 -- Governor Dewey agreed today, in conferences with legislative leaders, to clear the way for final legislative approval tomorrow of the $234,800,000 stop-gap financial program for the City of New York and thus to permit a final adjournment of this year's session of the Legislature immediately thereafter.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Assembly approved and sent to Governor Dewey today a bill broadening the powers of the Long Island Transit Authority so that the agency might get the Long Island Rail Road out of bankruptcy and promote its reorganization under private management.

Deputy Fire Chief Nathan Perlman denied all charges of misconduct arising from the alleged shakedown of a Bronx merchant in March, 1950, as he went on trial yesterday before Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet in the Municipal Building.

Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Howland Green Wilks, daughter of the late Hetty Green, noted woman financier at the turn of the century, left an estate of approximately $95,000,000 according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. She died Feb. 5, 1951.
NEW ORLEANS, March 19 (UP) -- Henry Frnka, head coach at Tulane University since 1946, quit football today.

The Westchester Street Transportation Company, Inc., an affiliate of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation, overestimated its expenses for this year in connection with its petition for an increased fare, according to testimony yesterday before the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 19 -- A postal inspector sent a letter in August, 1947, to Prosecutor Walter G. Winne of Bergen County informing him that letters addressed to Frank Erickson, the gambler, were being received at the Cliffside Park, N. J., Post Office in a mail box rented by another person.

SUPERIOR, Wis., March 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, assured the farmers of western Wisconsin today that, if elected President, he would favor the extension of the rural electrification program to a point where "you can finally take over its operation completely."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- Vincent Hallinan, attorney for Harry Bridges, and a proposed Presidential candidate for the Progressive party, won a last-minute stay today of a six months' jail sentenced imposed for his tempetuous conduct during the labor leader's perjury trial nearly two years ago.

Suits for $500,000 each were filed in Supreme Court here yesterday against R. H. Macy Co. and Abraham Straus, charging that the department stores are conspiring to force smaller competitors out of business by cutting prices on phonograph records.

Louis A. Scofield, vice president in charge of Westchester operations of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, has been elected a trustee of the Union Dime Savings Bank, according to J. Wilbur Lewis, president of the bank.

LOCKLAND, Ohio, March 19 -- A warning that Russian progress in jet plane production had far exceeded United States expectations and that American industry would have to make a supreme effort this year or lose ground in the air power race was sounded here today by two Air Force leaders.

After an ownership of about ninety-five years, the northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas and Thirty-eighth Street has been sold by Edgar M. Church, trustee of the estate of John P. Nesmith, to David S. Meister, operator.

Increasingly heavy taxes have cut this country's venture-capital potential while at the same time raising the need for it by squeezing surplus earnings out of the corporations, Edward T. McCormick, president of the New York Curb Exchange, told the National Association of Cost Accountants in Boston yesterday.

LONDON, March 19 -- Twenty or thirty Britons, including some members of Parliament, may be going to Moscow next month for the Communist-sponsored International Economic Conference, which has been blacklisted by British industry and labor.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires will enter the final round of the international masters tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club tied for first, according to a report from Havana yesterday.
One of the visiting double-decker buses from London narrowly escaped running aground under the Third Avenue elevated line at Forty-ninth Street yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- Malcolm Bryan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank at Atlanta, said today that dictatorship would result if Congress ever gave the President control of the central banking system.
CHICAGO, March 19 -- A laboratory model of a new type wrist watch powered by a tiny "energy capsule" was shown publicly for the first time today at the Elgin National Watch Company.

SHAW AIR FORCE BASE, S. C., March 19 -- A fifty-plane aerial train stretching over a 1,000-mile route started today to fly combat-equipped elements of the Thirty-first (Dixie) National Guard Division to their first full-scale maneuvers since the group entered Federal service fourteen months ago.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 19 (AP) -- Carlton Oval was picked today as a site for the 1956 Olympic Games. The selection must be approved by the Olympic Committee.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 19 -- A write-in vote for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Presidential preference primary, Minnesota Presidential preference primary, running to more than 100,000 ballots, surprised political observers in the state today.

PARIS, March 19 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, proposed today to the Foreign Ministers Committee that in the future the Council of Europe should get the role as coordinator of the specialized European agencies such as the Schuman plan for a coal and steel merger and the European Defense Community.

Public Service Commission hearings on the Long Island Rail Road's move for penny-a-ride fare increases ended yesterday afternoon in an unusually harmonious atmosphere. The commission's attorney even had a good word to say for the quality of the evidence presented by the line in support of its request, though he emphasized that the sufficiency of this evidence was something for the commissioners to evaluate.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Oceanic Steamship Company filed in United States Court of Claims here today suit for $5,653,557, which the company seeks under a 1946 settlement of the Government's liability on its wartime use of the steamships Mariposa and Monterey. The Oceanic company is a subsidiary of the Matson Navigation Company.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 19 -- Nebraska backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, astonished and elated the Minnesota primary results, weighed today the advantages and disadvantages of a similar write-in campaign for him in this state's April 1 voting.

LONDON, March 19 -- Prime Minister Churchill's agreement with President Truman to sell tin to the United States at a fixed price is a subsidy by British taxpayers to United States consumers and Malayan suppliers, Maurice Edelman, a Laborite, asserted in the House of Commons today.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers across the nation on the outcome of the Minnesota primary Tuesday, as gathered by The Associated Press:

Charles Berwind Harjes, son of Mrs. Seton Porter and a stepson of the chairman of the board of the National Distillers Products Corporation, died yesterday after collapsing on the street at Forty-sixth Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, the police reported.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., March 19 -- The dispute over the ownership of the Timber Point Club, scene of many Republican bean feasts in years past, has been settled in his favor, former Representative W. Kingsland Macy announced today.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 19 -- Johnny Rutherford, the so-called "right-handed Preacher Roe," emerged today as Manager Chuck Dressen's leading rookie pitcher as the Dodgers beat the Reds, 3 -- 2, before 2,443 fans.

Ten prospective jurors were in the jury box in Queens County Court yesterday at the end of the second day of the bank robbery trial of William F. Sutton and Thomas Kling before Judge Peter T. Farrell.

" The Long Watch," a comedy drama having for its locale a Naval Air-Sea Rescue Base off the coast of California and dealing principally with WAVES stationed at the base, opens at the Lyceum Theatre this evening at 8 o'clock under the auspices of Anthony B. Farrell and Charles Coburn.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 19 -- Frank E. McKinney, Democratic National Chairman, expressed the belief today that President Truman would not seek renomination if he attained permanent peace in Korea.

The board of directors of the Nassau County Classroom Teachers Association wishes me to express to you its unqualified agreement with your editorial of March 5 commenting on the Supreme Court decision upholding the Feinberg Law.

An extensive study of "the cost and responsibility of pier occupancy" in the Port of New York is being made by the Department of Marine and Aviation in an effort to make pier renting more attractive to the city's customers.
JERUSALEM, March 19 -- Prime Minister David Ben Gurion reacted tonight to the recent peace feelers from Cairo by saying, "We have no reason to quarrel with Egypt."

ALBANY, March 19 -- The bill to alter the administration of the State Civil Service Department by replacing the three-member Civil Service Commission with a single administrator was killed unexpectedly in the Senate today.

The Hopestand Realty Corporation has obtained a mortgage loan of $1,100,000 from the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company on the fifteen-story Stanhope Hotel at 995 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of East Eighty-first Street.

BUENOS AIRES, March 19 -- General Juan D. Peron and Dr. J. Hortensio Quijano will be formally invested on Friday as President and Vice President of Argentina for a six-year term beginning June 4. The date was set this morning by the chairmen of Argentina's twenty-five electoral boards.

We note with approval that the New York Senate and Assembly have unanimously approved extension of the Joint Legislative Committee on Racing to study the question of legalizing some off-track betting. The measure does not require the Governor's signature.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Senate preparedness investigating subcommittee reported today that the rearmament program had so far produced "a small number of guns and a great amount of butter, with a considerable number of lollipops thrown in."

Rumors that Monroe D. Dowling, ousted district Collector of Internal Revenue, might have been "framed" because of resentment over his efforts to clean up tax delinquencies and inefficiency were cited here yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in a demand for a full Federal inquiry.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will support grower prices of 1952 crop peanuts at a national average of at least $239.40 a ton. This is about $9 more than last year's support average.

Record volume in all company operations and large post-war expansion of facilities resulted in a net income of $161,622,159 last year, highest in the history of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and an increase of about 26 per cent over the $128,216,683 earned in 1950, despite the $40,000,000 larger tax bill.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 12, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Morning Freiheit, Yiddish-language Communist newspaper published here, was tricked into publishing last Saturday a poem attacking Stalin.

Maurice Van Praag, who joined the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in 1916 as a horn player and became personnel manager in 1922, announced yesterday that he would retire from the orchestra at the end of the season.

New issues of public utility and aviation securities valued at more than $40,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings include $22,000,000 of convertible preferred stock, $12,990,000 of common stock and $6,000,000 of bonds. The flotations are as follows:
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed 31 to 57 points net higher than on Tuesday in active trading.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- An officer of the University of Lawsonomy, Des Moines, Iowa, swore today that a $150,000 profit on machine tools bought from the Government went for university expenses.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Plans for a $100,000,000 International Finance Corporation to attract private equity capital under Federal auspices into the underdeveloped areas of the world were disclosed today as the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives looked further into the $7,900,000,000 Mutual Security Program.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., March 19 -- Public health programs must be kept in "delicate balance" with basic cultural changes or else there is the danger they may contribute to economic disruption, political unrest and even social chaos, Dr. John J. Hanlon, international expert in public health, warned today.

Appliance, radio and television retailers using shady gimmick merchandising and unethical if not fraudulent advertising are in for a hard time. This heartening news came out of Memphis the other day when Mort Farr, president of the National Appliance and Radio-Television Retailers Association, let go with a furious tirade against "gyps" in the trade.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Senate approved and sent to the Governor today a bill to permit savings banks to invest a limited amount of their assets in common and preferred stock.

David E. Grant, retiring president of the American Brazilian Association, was made a Commander of the Order of the Southern Cross, the highest honor granted to a foreigner by the Brazilian Government, at the association's twenty-fifth annual dinner last night.

Nemesia, schizanthus, cineraria and several other colorful annuals made their entrance at the thirty-sixth International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday. These flowers are not easily grown in suburban gardens, at least to the perfection of these greenhouse-tended ones, but many other displays at the show have adaptable ideas in their design and planting.

CLEVELAND, March 19 (UP) -- A doctor's certificate testifying that Mrs. Don Gehrmann was ill the night her husband failed to appear at a track meet here arrived at the local Amateur Athletic Union headquarters today and James Lee, the secretary, said he would accept it.

' "Pardon My French," a roman-I tic comedy with Paul Henreid andi .%Ierle Oberon, which was filmed onI location on the French Reviera,] has been scheduled to open on[ Monday, March 31, at the Baronet[ Theatre, it was announced yester-I day by the distributors, United! Artists. The offering was pro duced for Cusick International Films by Peter Cusick and Andret Sarrut Bernard Borhaus directed[ from an original screen play by Roland Kibbee.

A MILLION young Americans are the principal characters in this morning's books.* They are taking a variety of chances with life and death in what formerly passed as picturesque places. That should make these volumes two of the most widely interesting and appealing books of the year. One is the Army's pictorial record of the war against Italy and Germany in the Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Grain futures were under pressure of long liquidation most of the session today, but commission absorption expanded moderately on the setbacks, giving the market fair recoveries from the early low spots.
Frank Shields yesterday notified the United States Davis Cup committee that he would not be available to serve as captain of the American international tennis team again in 1952.

Hides moved irregularly on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, selling off in early trading in sympathy with allied markets, then recovering on a wave of commission house buying and short covering. The rally recaptured all but 10 points of the early losses and the market closed 8 to 18 points lower on volume of thirty-one lots.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- No delegates pledged to General Eisenhower may be included in the bloc that will represent Minnesota at the outset of the Republican National Convention of 1952. The ballot which Republicans were handed at the state primary yesterday contained no names of citizens committed to vote for the General if they were elected as delegates.

With the Federal wage control program facing its crucial test in steel, industry, labor and Government officials studied the record of the Wage Stabilization Board yesterday and arrived at conflicting estimates of its success in its first fourteen months of activity.
TRENTON, March 19 -- The method of financing the New Jersey Turnpike was sharply attacked in the State Senate today when a bill to authorize construction of a cross-state spur came up for passage.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 19 (UP) -- Miss Pat O'Sullivan, the defending champion, and Miss Mae Murray, 1951 finalist, led a field of favorites advancing in the fiftieth North and South women's amateur golf tournament today and will meet in match-play tomorrow.

While the proposal for prorating subway fares according to distance traveled sounds logical indeed, as advanced by Norman C. Norman in his letter of March 14, there is one consideration which should make the New York City commuter a "special case,"

American home cooks who rate cinnamon high in their kitchens (only pepper is more popular in this country) will welcome the news that trade embargoes on imports from Communist China have not cut off supplies.
MANILA, March 19 -- A volcano erupting under the sea about seventy miles off the northeastern tip of Luzon has thrust its crater and cone an estimated 250 feet above the surface of the water.
The stock market showed no new tactics yesterday and ended lower when selling outstripped buying by a narrow margin.

A state prison sentence of two to three years was imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Harold A. Stevens on former Detective Robert M. Hinds of 39 West Twelfth Street, who pleaded guilty to the beating of Mrs. William Rufus Boyd of 350 East Fifty-seventh Street, last July 1.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 19 (UP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower listened "jovially" today to news of Minnesota voters who, by the tens of thousands, wrote in his name as their choice for the Republican Presidential nomination in the state's primaries.
AIKEN, S. C., March 19 (AP) -- Horses trained by William Post made a fine showing at the Aiken Trials today.

JERSEY CITY, March 19 -- A warehousemen's union official was arrested this afternoon in the beating of a Lodi, N. J., metals company employe. Five longshoremen, termed "undesirables" by local police, filed suit against city public safety officials for an injunction to prevent police interference with their employment at a local pier.

With a "few thousand" Federal income-tax refunds being processed daily, the Third Internal Revenue District under Acting Collector Bruce E. Lambert expressed hope yesterday that that outgoing part of its annual job might be completed by the end of May. The office, covering Manhattan north of Thirty-fourth Street, emphasized there was no alphabetical pattern in the flow.

PARIS, March 19 -- It is understood that the British are now disposed to drop their proposal for a 50 per cent cut in the budget of the European Marshall Plan Council and are willing to accept the 28 per cent cut agreed on by the Continental members.
PITTSBURGH, March 19 (UP) -- The nation's major steel producers adopted a "hold back" attitude today on plans to cut production in advance of the strike deadline set for Sunday midnight.

The first loan to a small business concern in the New York-New Jersey area by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on recommendation from the Small Defense Plants Administration was granted yesterday. It was for $100,000, and went to the Dural Rubber Company of Flemington, N. J.
The Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, reported yesterday that record figures had been achieved in the past year in membership and in units.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Seventy-three local housing authorities in twenty-four states will call for sealed bids for a total of $167,093,000 of new Housing Authority bonds to be opened at 2 P. M., eastern standard time, April 15, the Public Housing Administration has announced.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican of New Jersey, told a former motion picture executive today that business men should be jailed for the kind of entertaining his company had provided for a revenue agent handling its $20,000,000 tax appeal.

TROY, N. Y., March 19 -- Marquette, checking a belated counter-attack, overpowered Iona, 66 -- 59, in a national Catholic invitation basketball tournament quarterfinal tonight. The victory advanced the second-seeded Hilltoppers into Friday's semi-finals against St. Francis of Brooklyn, defending champion.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee opened the way today for the House to act on legislation to keep Federal hands off state laws that bar price-cutting of trade-marked merchandise.

East Asia is a beleaguered region, Robert Aura Smith, of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday at the sixth session of the annual in-service course for teachers on "Understanding the News About Foreign Affairs."

TREVISO, Italy, March 19 -- At the end of Exercise Lake Garda, which in the last three days has seen command posts of Allied land and air forces of Southern Europe engaged in a simulated war against an "enemy" advancing from the east, Admiral Robert B. Carney of the United States Navy, Commander in Chief of Allied Forces Southern Europe, stressed tonight the urgent necessity of getting new equipment and weapons to Italy without delay.
There is an increasing possibility that the American Federation of Labor will endorse a Presidential candidate this year for the first time since 1924, it was indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- The Defense Department reported today that United States battle casualties in Korea stood at 106,671 last Friday, an increase of 213 over the previous week's report.
TOKYO, Thursday, March 20 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,194, for Wednesday's operations:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- The establishment of a new United Nations body to handle matters relating to freedom of the press was recommended today by a group of news experts from twelve nations.
ALBANY, March 19 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts:
RENO, Nev., March 19 (AP) -- Indications that the Redfield burglary case was cracking wide open came today with the arrest of an eighth suspect and the first announced confession.
The Legal Aid Society, "the poor man's lawyer," handled in 1951 more than 50,000 cases for the first time in its seventy-six-year history, Timothy N. Pfeiffer, president, reported yesterday.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Dinner Hour put in one of his stronger efforts as he turned back eight other platers in the main event at Gulfstream Park today.

In comparing the French and Italian originals with their reproductions at a fashion preview for the press at Ohrbach's yesterday, one could scarcely tell the difference except by the price tags. The moderate-priced reproductions, which Ohrbach's will make available to customers Monday, have been copied line for line from the originals.
ALBANY, March 19 -- Boxing promoters will be required to provide medical insurance and death benefits for their fighters if Governor Dewey signs a bill passed unanimously by the Senate today.
A city-wide civil defense drill scheduled for the evening of April 3 will feature the use of various types of emergency communications equipment to transmit messages in the "disaster" area.

MADISON, Wis., March 19 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee opened his bid for delegates to the Democratic National Convention in Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's home state today with a blast at "McCarthyism."

The decor of that oft discussed room in contemporary homes, the kitchen, will improve only when the equipment designed for it is improved, two speakers agreed at a Home Fashions League luncheon meeting in the Roosevelt yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- The Soviet Union went before the United Nations Disarmament Commission today to demand a formal condemnation of the United States for "wide" use of germ warfare in Korea and China.

LONDON, March 19 -- British Government securities were strengthened on the stock exchange here today by continued firmness of the pound sterling and reduction of Britain's deficit within the European Payments Union. In late trading some British funds lost part of their gains but mostly finished with a net gain of about 2s 6d (35 cents).

BALTIMORE, Md., March 19 -- A young Virginia housewife who served as an undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the Communist party for six years testified today in the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal court that Communist policy called for party control of all basic industries.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 (AP) -- Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, Calif., vaulted into the lead for the world three-cushion billiards championship tonight when he defeated the Japanese woman star, Miss Masako Katsura of Tokyo, by 50 -- 18 in 52 innings.

Printing of the latest revised standard version of the Holy Bible in English, under Protestant and Eastern Orthodox auspices, entered its final stages yesterday. A brief ceremony was held at the printing plant of the American Book-Stratford Press, 75 Varick Street, which is one of three American concerns handling the job.

A policeman arrested his 17-year-old brother-in-law yesterday after the boy had allegedly stolen his service revolver and, with three other teen-agers, held up two Bronx cab drivers, the police reported.

PASADENA, Calif., March 19 -- Monte Irvin's second home run of the exhibition campaign enabled the Giants to beat the White Sox by 4 -- 3 today. Tossed into the general melange was another demonstration of fancy five-inning pitching by Larry Jansen and some fleet base-running by Willie Mays.

While new modification of export controls aimed at preventing transshipment of strategic goods to communist areas will exempt all shipments valued at $500 or less, effectiveness of the security curbs will be tightened through joint action of the United States and eleven other countries beginning April 7, a Government trade official declared yesterday.

MADRID, March 19 -- The Spanish Government was understood today to have informed Washington that one of the basic premises for a successful conclusion of an agreement defining the terms of Spanish-United States collaboration should be a United States pledge to aid and defend Spain in case of aggression.
PARIS, March 19 -- Jean Letourneau, Minister for the Associated States of Indo-China, said today that there was no news from France's embattled Far Eastern territory that justified the least alarm.

Federal mediators brought to an end yesterday a twelve-day walkout of 200 men employed by two Brooklyn ship repair concerns. The walkout was an outgrowth of an order by the Wage Stabilization Board rolling back allegedly over-the-ceiling wage rates.

ALBANY, March 19--A bill designed to increase the eventual pension allowances of Mayor Impellitteri and other officials or employes of the City of New York who served in World War I received the approval of the Assembly Rules Committee tonight.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Assembly today approved two bills extending for a year the state's emergency rent controls over business and commercial property in New York City and easing the conditions under which owners might recover possession of rented space. The bills now go to the Governor.
WITH U. S. SECOND DIVISION, Korea, March 19 (AP) -- The men of the Second Division have been assured that the people at home realize that fighting is still going on in Korea.
Welfare Department employes donated 267 pints of blood to the Red Cross yesterday in their seventh mass contribution, but inclement weather reduced the number of pledges.
TORONTO, March 19 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens downed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 0, tonight before 14,581 fans to tighten their hold on second place in the National Hockey League.
A 40-year-old woman, who threatened to jump from the roof parapet of a five-story apartment building, was rescued yesterday because of a brief last-minute show of concern for her children.

An extensive group of furniture for the living, dining and bedrooms, by the Whitney Furniture Company, is now at Bloomingdale's. These pieces combine traditional design with modern and a casual, comfortable appearance is the result. Both case goods and upholstered pieces are available.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- A Government planting survey indicated today that farmers may fall short of a record production goal urged by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan.

A Federal Union of the Atlantic democracies will be formed by 1965, Clarence K. Streit, president of Federal Union, predicted last night in a progress report on the first thirteen years of his organization, broadcast over a nation-wide network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will present its Oscars tonight to a great variety of the movie industry's artists, craftsmen and technicians. Awards will be given for the best movie costuming of the year, for the best feature documentary, the best short documentary, the best original story, the best story adaptation, the best musical scoring, the best original song, the best foreign language film, and so on late into the night.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Senate agreed late today to cut short its largely desultory debate on the Japanese peace treaty and to proceed tomorrow to a series of decisive votes.

The board of directors of the New York County Lawyers Association has recommended to the United States Senate Judiciary Committee confirmation of President Truman's appointment of Judge David N. Edelstein as a United States Judge for the Southern District of New York.

A RETURNING tourist finds things a lot different in New York, including the weather. After saturating himself in sunshine and ballplayers, he has to get acclimated. This is a lot more difficult for one coming from Florida than it would be for one returning from Arizona or California, where conditions have been a trifle "unusual" -- if gloating Florida headlines are to be believed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- A six-man conciliation committee will undertake next week to determine whether R. K. O. Radio Pictures acted in accordance with the basic contract agreement between producers and the Screen Writers Guild in removing the name of Paul Jarrico from the screen play credit on the film "The Los Vegas Story."

MINEOLA, L. I., March 19 -- A conference of county, township and village engineers with Federal Housing Administration officials here today to "develop street improvement standards" found Nassau's requirements higher than those set forth by the F. H. A.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- Five monkeys and three mice have been catapulted by rocket up to eighty miles above the earth, higher than any living thing has ever gone.

Roy Lee Reddick, the 29-year-old former convict wanted in the investigation of the bomb-slaying of a New Haven, Conn., couple on Tuesday, was seized last night outside a Harlem hotel by police of two states.

The astonishing triumph of General Eisenhower in the Minnesota primary is, without exaggeration, a political miracle. The results in New Hampshire a week ago had already indicated the amazing depth of General Eisenhower's appeal to the ordinary citizen. What has now happened in Minnesota is something unique in American political history.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 19 -- A conference will open here tomorrow to determine how much and in what way West Germany should pay as a measure of compensation for the victimization of the Jews by Hitler's Third Reich.

MORE than sixty big game hunters from a score of states and several Canadian provinces received awards for outstanding trophies last night at the presentation dinner of the Boone and Crockett Club, held at the American Museum of Natural History.

CHICAGO, March 19 (UP) -- Drifting snows throttled rail and highway traffic across the Sierra Nevadas in the Far West tonight, while across the nation there were these other weather developments on the eve of spring:

The current world-wide Communist effort to exploit figures like Victor Hugo, Leonardo da Vinci, Nikolai Gogol and Avicenna for Stalinist propaganda verges on the comic. Within the contexts of their times and cultures, these great figures were free men using the light of reason to help humanity toward a better future.

The Wage Stabilization Board has announced it will make public today its recommendations in the controversy between the United Steelworkers of America (C. I. O.) and the steel companies. Although the board's proposals to President Truman on how the dispute should be settled are not binding they will be the basis for further negotiations toward a final settlement.

ATHENS, March 19 -- The United States Embassy entered unwillingly yesterday into Greece's parliamentary disputes when, to clear up an apparent misunderstanding, it issued a statement suggesting that Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, leader of the opposition Greek Rally party, had gone too far in his attack upon the army's topflight officers.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 19 -- The austere life to which Eddie Sawyer has committed them this year certainly has done something to the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Senate Elections Subcommittee tonight denounced "scurrilous literature, using the Communist smear," which it asserted was aimed at General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the New Hampshire primary elections.

A further increase last week of 1,209,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 146,165,000 barrels, compared with 144,956,000 a week earlier and 141,007,000 a year ago.

Many highway construction programs in the country are designed for protection against atomic attacks, Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, New York State Director of Civil Defense, said yesterday. By-passing of cities and extension of routes into dispersal areas, where increasing numbers of industrial plants are being built, were laid to growing apprehension of widespread destructive effects, particularly in congested districts.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 19 -- Although it is now unable to move all the items produced in a defense economy, the selling profession soon may be called upon to save the nation's economy, speakers warned today at the opening of the three-day annual spring meeting of the Association of National Advertisers.

BONN, Germany, March 19 -- While Chancellor Konrad Adenauer is in Paris for the talks of the Foreign Ministers Committee of the Council of Europe, members of his Foreign Ministry, including Prof. Walter Hallstein, State Secretary for Foreign Affairs, are under bitter attack by the press, radio and the Opposition Socialist party.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- Government agents have begun an investigation of a contract held by a former Air Force publicity man to operate an Air Force research project, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee heard testimony today that serious shortages of Government grain stored in warehouses in the Southwest had been fully reported to officials of the Department of Agriculture prior to last October and that an appeal had been made for assistance in investigating them.

A tract of five acres on the north side of Caledonia Road, 588 feet west of Deer Park Avenue, in Dix Hills, Huntington, L. I., has been sold by Alice Mason Johnson to Robert Angle of Greenwich, Conn. Title was insured by the Security Title and Guaranty Company.

It can be argued that it does no good to keep calling the Soviet satellite states to account for their persistent violation of the most elementary human rights. Perhaps not; yet the United States has signed treaties with Rumania, Hungary and Bulgaria guaranteeing that these rights will be protected.

ALBANY, March 19---A bill i that would authorize the State Thruway Authority to regulate the erection of billboards and other advertising devices along the cross-state expressway was approved today by the Assembly without debate.

The more than 200,000 stockholders of the Cities Service Company received good news yesterday. Gross income and net earnings reached new highs in 1951, totaling $835,565,000 and $57,177,000, respectively. Earnings on the company's common stock were equal to $14.71 a share, an increase of 14 cents over 1950. Gross income was up $133,322,000.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 300,356 shares between Feb 15 and last Friday, it reported yesterday. On the former date the total was 2,478,431 shares and on the latter, 2,178,075.

BOSTON, March 19 (AP) -- Bob Cousy tossed in 31 points as the Boston Celtics, maintaining their high-scoring pace, defeated the New York Knickerbockers tonight, 105 -- 94, in the opener of the best-of-three National Basketball Association play-offs at the Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Professional politicians here were much more impressed today with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's showing in the Minnesota primary election than with his victory last week in New Hampshire.

My pamphlet on tax loopholes which was recently published by the Public Affairs Institute was intended to explain to the public how our tax laws are operating in practice. Your editorial of Feb. 26 entitled "Tax 'Loopholes'" is obviously based on the brief press release summarizing the pamphlet, and as a consequence gives a distorted picture of some of my views.

Judge Harold R. Medina, who is presiding over the investment banking anti-trust trial here, said in Federal Court yesterday that 95 per cent of the Government's charges of conspiratorial use of the syndicate system by the defendants have been disproved.

A healthy pattern of buying was reported at the American Toy Fair, which closed yesterday at the McAlpin and New Yorker Hotels and private showrooms throughout the city. Orders were spread over all lines rather than merely on metal items as they were last year.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, said today he hoped to wage a vigorous national campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Throngs of New York City dwellers and their suburban counterparts have been reaping refreshment of the spirit this week from the Flower Show, that annual descent of beauty and aroma on Grand Central Palace. Probably the experts would say that the exposition has its ups and downs in quality.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Public members of the Wage Stabilization Board proposed today a settlement of the steel dispute on terms reported to be worth about 20 cents an hour.

Doctors, nurses and medical students at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital let their professional hair down yesterday to show why they sometimes have paint on their fingers or mutter about the availability of plumbing equipment.

LOS ANGELES, March 19- -4.rgtmaents that nlost of the testi-i mony so far presented in the trial of fifteen California Communist functionaries should be stricken from the record as inadmissible were presented by their counsel in Federal District Court today.
Sheldon Steckel of the Macy Corporate Buying Office has been made buyer of women's and misses' budget coats and suits for Macy's San Francisco, effective April 1.

The International Paper Company and its subsidiaries achieved last year the highest sales in its history with output of paper, board and pulp at a new high record. Pre-tax earnings also set a new peak, but the net income after taxation declined to $56,819,172 or $6.28 a share from $66,647,151 or $7.38 a common share earned in 1950, the annual report noted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Wisconsin Power and Light Company of Madison fried a financing plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission today in connection with the utility's construction program. The concern asked permission to sell:

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- For the second week in succession triple damages sought by the Office of Price Stabilization from violators of its ceiling regulations exceeded $1,000,000, Edward P. Morgan, enforcement director, said today.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 20 -- Allied and Communist staff officers at Panmunjom reached agreement today on ten "ports of entry" -- five behind the lines of each opposing army -- through which replacements of men and equipment will be permitted to move after an armistice in the Korean war.

Regulations affecting the importation of cotton linters, waste, second hand burlap and other fabrics used in baling cotton products will be revised and published in The Federal Register within the next few weeks, C. V. Maudlin, Washington representative of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, disclosed yesterday,

The last day of winter roared out in soggy style yesterday with wind-swept snow, rain and sleet coating the metropolitan area with a wet blanket. Weather Bureau charts indicated that today -- the first day of spring -- would become fair and characteristically mild.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Sam Snead turned on the steam in the final nine-hole lap today to win the pro division of the $10,000 Seminole golf tournament.

The Martinu "Military Mass" was performed for the first time in New York and the Vaughan Williams "Tudor Portraits" were heard for the first time in America at the concert given by the Schola Cantorum and the Yale Glee Club last night in Carnegie Hall.

A lot came too late for the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. They beat the Boston Bruins, 6 to 4, in the National Hockey League game, but the victory didn't help the Blues in the standing. They are fast in fifth place, and there they will be when the campaign ends on Sunday night.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 19 (UP) -- A smoking Navy fighter plane glided into a golf course fairway here today, killing two woman golfers.

Spring fur designs and a collection of ready-to-wear originals by Bernard Newman were shown yesterday at Bergdorf Goodman. Both were given the deft understated quality characteristic of this designer's fashions.
ALBANY, March 19 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower appeared likely tonight to win at least seventy-nine of New York's ninety-six delegate votes for the Republican Presidential nomination.

MADISON, Wis., March 19 -- A move to eliminate Gov. Earl Warren of California and his slate of delegates from the April 1 Wisconsin Presidential primary ballot, was started here today by a Milwaukee supporter of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

BONN, Germany, March 19 -- In a formal agreement the United Nations Commission received today "full diplomatic privileges and immunities" to carry on an investigation in West Germany to determine whether it would be possible to conduct free secret elections.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 19 -- After a winter of bountiful rains and mild weather. Israel is looking forward to bumper crops and some easing of food shortages.

PARIS, March 19 -- It was expected tonight that a draft of the Western Powers' reply to the recent Soviet note proposing a peace treaty for a united Germany would be agreed upon tomorrow by Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister; Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and James C. Dunn, United States Ambassador to France.
