After Capt. George Ward, British Under Secretary for Air, reported to the House of Commons that the Royal Air Force was inadequate either to defend the country or play its part in the defense of Europe on the Atlantic lifeline, the air estimates were approved without a dissenting voice.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Motor vehicle deaths in New York totaled 2,101 last year, the first time since 1946 that the figure has exceeded 2,000. James R. MacDuff, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, reported today. The previous year's death toll was 1,996.

Women headed by Mrs. Robert W. Dowling, president of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, and Mrs. Henry Steeger are active in the plans for the supper party to be held in Rendez-Vous of the Plaza after the premiere performance of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet Tuesday night at the Warner Theatre for the benefit of the service.

Joseph C. Workman, retired police captain, was joined yesterday in Kings County Court by four members of his family -- wife, daughter, son and a brother -- in denying charges of perjury in connection with his financial affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Ellis G. Arnall, Director of Price Stabilization, told the Senate Banking Committee today that the steel companies would receive, under present policies, one price increase under the Capehart Amendment and possibly another under the "fair and equitable" formula, if needed, after wage rises to permit industry to earn 85 per cent of its average of the three best of the years 1946, 1947, 1948 and 1949.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 19 -- All Brazilian troops were reported alerted tonight for possible trouble from the Communists after an abortive raid on an army ammunition dump in Natal. No form of martial law apparently had been ordered.
TOKYO, Friday, March 21 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,195, for Thursday's operations:
The American Committee for Cultural Freedom announced yesterday that it would hold a conference on the subject, "In Defense of Free Culture," at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on March 29.

The late winter days upstate have been turning up as perfect this year as man can remember. In the snow-covered land the nights are clear and cold with low temperatures. By day the sun sends the thermometer up above forty.

Completing their schedules with a victory apiece in the twenty-third and final round of the international tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club last night, Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires tied for first and second places, with scores of 18 1/2 -- 3 1/2, according to a report from Havana.

PITTSBURGH, March 20 (AP) -Truck traffic began rolling into Pennsylvania at a near-normal rate tonight following a stoppage that had spread through five states in protest against Pennsylvania's 45,000-pound gross weight law for trucks.

PORT- OF - SPAIN, Trinidad, March 19 (UP) -- An oil company executive said today that several companies soon will begin drilling off the shore of Trinidad as there are definite indications of "gigantic'' submarine deposits.

An all-male jury was sworn at 6:25 P. M. in Queens County Court in Long Island City yesterday to hear evidence against William F. Sutton and Thomas King on a two-year-old bank robbery indictment. Selection of the jury took three full court days and a session last night. Close to 100 talesmen were examined.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 20 -- The extraordinary write-in vote for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Minnesota Republican primary, added to his victory in the New Hampshire state ballot, has induced him to "re-examine" his position on American Presidential politics.

Foreign Secretary Eden has voiced his opposition to a move to convert the Council of Europe into a federal institution with legislative and executive powers over all the fifteen member nations. He proposes instead that the Council should become the supervising and coordinating agency to assure the proper functioning of the supra-national Authorities being created for the Schuman Plan, the European army and similar projects.

" The Defense of Western Europe," a new book by Drew Middleton, chief NEW YORE TIMES correspondent in Germany, has been scheduled for April publication by Appleton-Century-Crofts. The author, with the cooperation of General Eisenhower and his staff, describes our attempts to integrate the defense of Western Europe so "we can wrest the initiative from the Russians.

The Gulf Oil Corporation last year had a consolidated net income of $i40,071,000 after charges and taxes, equal to $6.17 each on the 22,690,500 capital shares outstanding, according to the 1951 annual report issued today. This compared with $111,140,000, or $4.90 a share, in 1950, and with $153,539,000 in 1948, the company's record earning year.

Custom originals by Stein Blaine, 13 West Fifty-seventh Street, were presented yesterday in the Plaza's Terrace Room. Rich textured fabrics in muted colors that blended with elegant furs were noted throughout the collection of town suits and dresses for day and evening.

PARIS, March 20 -- A draft of the Western Powers' reply to the Soviet proposal for a German peace treaty was discussed tonight with Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the West German regime. It will be further discussed tomorrow by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary; Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, and James C. Dunn, United States Ambassador to Paris, but officials said that the draft would not be final until approved by the three Governments.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson warned the Defense Department today that the Senate Preparedness subcommittee, of which he is chairman, was going to "clean out some people" unless the department cleaned house on its North Africa air base project.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., national manager of the Presidential campaign for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, confirmed today the reorganization of the campaign's high command with Paul G. Hoffman as chairman of the Citizens for Eisenhower Advisory Committee.

What the Socialist party failed to sell to the American people in it public ownership proposals of 1920 is being accomplished by "more subtle and resourceful proponents of the same doctrines," Senator Herbert R. O'Conor of Maryland asserted here last night.

The potential market of the chemical industry is large enough to absorb the added capacity generated by defense requirements, Kenneth H. Klipstein, assistant administrator of the chemical, rubber and forest products bureau of the National Production Authority, said yesterday.

The Pentagon was criticized sharply yesterday for failure to cooperate in the placing of defense contracts. Telford Taylor, administrator of the Small Defense Plants Administration, charged that military procurement agencies had failed since last December to follow through on a Congressional directive that could have been executed within ninety days by any group of "reasonable men."

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Senate heavily defeated today five efforts to write in reservations and then approved the Japanese peace treaty intact by a vote of 66 to 10. It went for ward then in a brief night session to approve the three associated Pacific security pacts binding in mutual defense the United States and Japan, the United States and Australia and New Zealand and the United States and the Philippines.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- The greatest future wealth of the Pacific Islands should come from the sea, former United States Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah today told the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The 175th regular session of the Legislature adjourned for the year tonight after both branches had approved, by substantial bipartisan majorities, a series of eight bills embodying the $234,800,000 stop-gap financial program for the City of New York that had been agreed upon in conferences between city and state officials.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "Don Juan in Hell" on the night of April 2 at the Plymouth Theatre in behalf of the New York Botanical Garden. Mrs. George K. Livermore and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell head the committee in charge of the arrangements. After the performance, a supper party will be given in the Carnaval of the Sherry-Netherland to assist the same beneficiary.

Sales of the Allis-Chalmers Manfacturing Company rose 33 per cent last year, but taxes were up 86 per cent to $56,314,892, resulting a $703,000 decline in profits, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
MARSHFIELD, Wis., March 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio announced his withdrawal today from the April 15 New Jersey preferential primary.

Today's new film is "Smoke Jumpers," a Twentieth Century-Fox melodrama in Technicolor, formerly titled "Red Skies of Montana," featuring Richard Widmark, Constance Smith and Jeffrey Hunter, at the Globe. Joseph M. Newman directed and Samuel G. Engel produced from a script by Harry Kleiner and a story by Art Cohn.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Brannan made an urgent appeal to farmers today to plant more livestock feed grains this year than a survey indicated they planned to grow. Unless they do so he said, serious shortages of meat, eggs and milk may develop.

A house in which the windows need almost never be opened will go on view Sunday in the new Heathcote Heights housing development at New Rochelle, N. Y. The first house in the group is completely air-conditioned, as the other seventy-four will be.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 20 -- Two separate but simultaneous sets of meetings on Jewish claims against the German nation will begin here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Bartholomew A. Brickley, trustee of the International Hydro-Electric System of Boston, filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell upward of $26,000,000 worth of the assets of I. H. E. S. and of the Eastern New York Power Corporation.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 20 -- The largest post-war Soviet shipbuilding contract to the Netherlands -- five refrigerator vessels of 2,540 tons each, especially equipped to transport fish -- has been placed with three Dutch shipyards.

Although we all love our Navy and admire its gallantry, we are entitled to be more reserved about its art. "The Long Watch," which was acted at the Lyceum last evening, with Bull Halsey conning from an orchestra seat, is the work of Capt. Harvey Haislip, who knows his way around naval communications rooms.

Gil Turner, Philadelphia's undefeated welterweight, who is aiming for a title match against Kid Gavilan, is a solid favorite to defeat Don Williams of Worcester, Mass., in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Ralph Coxhead, United States Air Force pilot on special leave from the Sampson (N. Y.) Air Base, won the Metropolitan Senior 150-yard backstroke race at the Downtown Athletic Club last night. The former Colgate swimming star churned the distance in 1:40.5

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, complained today that credit curbs usually had been "too little and too late" to dampen postwar inflationary pressures.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 (AP) -- Humphrey Bogart, gin-loving vagabond in "The African Queen," and Vivien Leigh, faded beauty of "A Streetcar Named Desire," won Hollywood's top Academy Awards tonight, while "An American in Paris" scored one of the biggest upsets in "Oscar" history by being named the best picture of 1951 and winning seven other honors.

The evolution of the modern underwriting syndicate continued yesterday to occupy defense counsel cross-examining Harold L. Stuart, Chicago financier and Government witness in the investment banking anti-trust trial here.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A recommendation that men in the armed forces receive an orientation course on how to get along with women in the military was made today by the Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the Services.
Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, took "selfish property owners" and "pressure groups" to task yesterday for increasing the traffic burden by overbuilding in mid-Manhattan.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., March 20 -- The first serious musical composition inspired by atomic energy had its premiere here last night. Clarinets played a theme based on the atomic number of uranium, while oboes were Geiger counters.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Following are the votes of New York City members of the Legislature on the Sales Tax and Overnight Parking Bills:
The first men's squash racquets team to come to this country from overseas since 1938 arrived yesterday when the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth brought in the Cambridge University squad from England.

A joint committee of American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations unions, formed hopefully and with wide publicity just two months ago to end raiding and cross-picketing here, fell apart yesterday in the face of its first major test

Fish prices hit the lowest level of the month this week-end on a number of popular kinds. Increased receipts brought 4 to 5-cents-a-pound declines on five varieties, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today a new engine had been developed that would make the United States-built F86 jet fighter superior to the Russian MIG-15.

QUEBEC, March 20 (Canadian Press) -- The annual report of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., issued today for the year ended Dec. 31. 1951, shows a net profit of $8,568,558, equal to $3.91 a share, compared with $9,237,564 in 1950, equal to $4.22 a share.

A complete reorganization of the bureau of design and construction of the Board of Education so that it can handle as expeditiously as possible its expected 1952 peak load of $70,000,000 of school construction and modernization was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- The Yankee attack was still spluttering today, but after struggling for more than three hours the Bombers jammed three runs across in the fourteenth inning to topple Eddie Stanky's Cardinals, 5 to 2, in their second extra-inning engagement in three days.

Why doesn't television do more ballet, not just a wisp now and then in a variety show, but on its own and with some degree of regularity? With all the super-charged emotionalism that is to be found on the home screen, including the violence of murder mystries and the frantic buoyancy of the commercial announcers, surely a good many viewers would welcome, by way of contrast, the visual serenity and beauty of the classical dance.

PARIS, March 20 -- Premier Antoine Pinay's effort to get prices down as part of his anti-inflation program received a helping hand today from department stores, which marked down prices on selected items of everyday use.
DETROIT, March 20 (UP) -- Gordie Howe set a Detroit record for goals scored in one season as he tallied twice to lead the Red Wings to a 7-3 victory tonight over the fifth-place New York Rangers.

A recheck of the locker situation at the Park Department golf courses yesterday showed that the scarcity was not what it had seemed last Feb. 22. At least 686 season lockers still were available, though last month the department had announced the supply had been oversubscribed and drawings would be held to select the successful applicants.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -Secretary of State Dean Acheson told the House Foreign Affairs Committee that Communist gains in India had created "a very dangerous situation," making it necessary to compress into four years a technical assistance program that normally would require at least ten.

Rubber futures sold off sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, losing 80 to 95 points on volume of 660 tons. September opened at 36.25 cents a pound, its final Wednesday figure, dropped to 35.25 cents and closed at 35.3 cents.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20 -- Roman Fair, owned by William G. Hells Jr., had a narrow call in winning the Tamiami purse, top event on Gulfstream Park's card today.

The railroad industry's economic methods and standards of passenger service were sharply criticized last night by Robert R. Young, chairman of the Federation for Railway Progress. The principal speaker at the fifth anniversary dinner of the federation held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Mr. Young, who also is chairman of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, offered a detailed program to rescue the industry from its distress and from threats of bankruptcy and government ownership.
If some day the dreaded mental illness known as schizophrenia is conquered, an 80-year-old retired Boston lawyer will have no small share in the victory.

Despite the fact that the Architectural League's exhibition of mural painting is more varied than usual, the Gold Medal Jury decided this year to withhold the Gold Medal. It did, however, award three honorable mentions, for merit in organizing form, line and color and in relating design and subject to architectural surroundings.

The steels took a new lease on life yesterday on the stock market as financial circles thought a settlement of the wage negotiations within the industry appeared a possibility. This injected an optimistic factor into the day's proceedings and allowed stock prices to show an advance which spread out to most of the major divisions. The composite price average rose 0.64 point.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Bruno Walter, conductor, Kirsten Flagstad, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; "Don Carlo," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "La Boheme," City Opera, City Center, 8:15; Liederkrantz Singing Society, Lauritz Melchior, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Benno Moiseiwitsh, piano, Town Hall, 8:30.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 20 -- Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, declared here tonight that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio had "given himself a most serious body blow" in his Presidential quest by his withdrawal from the New Jersey primary April 15.

Following Frank Shields' announcement that he would not be available to serve as Davis Cup team captain again in 1952, Sidney Wood yesterday came out with the recommendation that a business manager be appointed instead of a nonplaying captain.

BUENOS AIRES, March (20) -- Textile manufacturers who had protested they could not operate under newly established price ceilings and must lay off workers have been warned by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry that the Government will seize and run all plants where production is stopped or workers are dismissed.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Dewey today signed a bill that permits the City of Yonkers and five counties, including Nassau, to levy a 15 per cent admissions tax on harness racing tracks within their boundaries. This will be in addition to an existing 20 per cent Federal tax and a new 15 per cent state tax that the Governor is expected to sign soon.

LAUREL, Md., March 20 -- Conservatism will be the keynote for Larry MacPhail in his role as president of the Bowie Race Track. The squire of Glenangus Farms stressed that point today in a mass interview that followed the unveiling of a life-sized bronze statue of Billy Barton, famous steeplechaser of three decades ago.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today $19,500,000 of bonds and debentures representing new financing in behalf of the Province of Nova Scotia, Canada, and of the Narragansett Electric Company, a Rhode Island public utility enterprise. The offerings are as follows:

TAMPA, Fla., March 20 -- Chris Van Cuyk, young southpaw who towers 6 feet 6 1/2 inches, burst into Manager Chuck Dressen's personal Hall of Fame today by hurling a five-hit shut-out as the Dodgers made it two straight over the Reds by a 4-0 score at Plant Field.

TOKYO, Friday, March 21 -- Communist negotiators at Panmunjom asked additional time today to outline areas in which neutral truce controllers might operate around designated "ports of entry" in Korea during an armistice.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -- Janet Leigh will walk alone as far as other feminine competition is concerned in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "The Naked Spur." The actress will be the only woman in the melodrama -- the story of a manhunt -- in which only five characters will be involved.
WINCHESTER, Va., March 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Westwood Beverly Byrd, 35 years old, only daughter of Senator and Mrs. Harry F. Byrd, died unexpectedly this afternoon in Winchester Memorial Hospital.

Kirsten Flagstad sang the Wagner Wesendonck songs with Bruno Walter's piano accompaniment and the Immolation scene from Goetterdaemmerung, with Mr. Walter directing the orchestra, at the Philharmonic - Symphony concert last night in Carnegie Hall. This was the first of the three final concert appearances with orchestra that Mme. Flagstad will make in this city.

LONDON, March 20 -- Labor party members of the House of Commons formally challenged today several of the tax increases and changes made in the Conservative Government's first budget. In every instance the Government won by majorities of 22 to 32 votes.

United Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in 1951 amounted to $14,266,867, equal to $4.06 a common share, compared with $13,204,128, or $3.73 a share, in the preceding year. The corporation's earnings last year represented a return of 3.4 per cent on sales totaling $417,211,980, the financial statement pointed out. In 1950 the return was 4.9 per cent on sales of $269,255,388.
The goat leaps no more in the postered windows of the city's alehouses, taverns and delicatessens. The vats that once were filled with bock are filled with lighter beers.

TOTOWA, N. J., March 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Richard, the New Haven, Conn., couple who set out Saturday to make a cross-country trip by foot and wheelchair, will finish their journey by air, thanks to the generosity of persons who were moved by their story.

A tract of six and three-fourths acres fronting about 540 feet on the south side of Jerusalem Avenue, about 100 feet west of Orchard Street, in North Bellmore, L. I., has been sold by Mrs. Minnie Finck to Oscar M. Maier, who plans to improve it with houses in the medium price bracket.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A measure designed primarily to cheek the flow of wetbacks across the Mexican border into this country was signed today by President Truman.

MADISON, Wis., March 20 -- A new Eisenhower emphasis in the Wisconsin Presidential primary campaign of Gov. Earl Warren of California was evident tonight as Governor Warren returned to continue his canvass for delegates. The primary date is April 1.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- S. Beryl Lush, president of the Lush Cotton Products Company, announced tonight that he had called off his proposed trip to attend the International Economic Conference in Moscow.

ANN DAVISON'S "Last Voyage"* is an extraordinary story of stubborn and fool-hardy courage and disaster at sea. Few firsthand accounts of personal adventure which I have ever read can touch it for sheer nerve-racking tension and pitiful drama. Mrs. Davison and her husband, Frank, deliberately sought an adventurous life; but the adventures they met on the ketch Reliance were far more than they had bargained for. And they ended tragically.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- A United Nations body of news experts voted today to set up a permanent twelve-man committee with authority to make on-the-spot inquiries concerning the exercise of press freedom in any part of the world.
The Morningside Committee on Cooperative Housing made public yesterday further details on the $12,500,000 project it announced last October for the Morningside-Manhattanville area.

Albert and Arthur Lewis, father and son, have gone into the producing business with "Three Wishes for Jamie," a musical starring Anne Jeffreys and John Raitt. The fruit of three years' labor, their initial venture will be presented at 8 o'clock this evening at the Hellinger.

Gen. Albert Orsborn, chief of the International Salvation Army, arrived here yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth to participate in four district congresses of the organization. The sessions will be held in New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Atlanta.
A cross-country chase for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship starts tonight on four fronts, with Kentucky the favorite, according to the United Press.
William J. Helt has been appointed general sales manager of Belmont Radio Corporation, Chicago, effective next Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 708,826 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 5,421 cars, or 0.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 36,302 cars, or 4.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 16,708 cars, or 2.3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Three million tablets of the new anti-tuberculosis drug were offered free yesterday by the Schering Corporation of Bloomfield, N. J., to tuberculosis hospitals and sanitaria in the United States and Canada of more than 100-bed capacity.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- During the week ended March 19, member bank reserves increased $1,257,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

As the nation goes about its task of building its defenses, a process usually accompanied by economizing and curtailment of services, the welfare of the nation's children must not be forgotten, members of the board of directors and national council of the American Parents Committee agreed yesterday.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 20 (UP) -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin replied today to recent charges in the United States Senate that Puerto Rico's industrial development program was luring old-established United States factories here with lower wage scales and tax exemption.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 20 -- A small and little publicized war has been going on in the Arakan Province of Burma, just across the frontier of East Pakistan, for the last two years. Burmese Moslems are fighting Buddhist Communists.
The Sudeten German problem discussed in a letter by H. F. March in THE TIMES of March 8 calls for some comments regarding several statements that I regard as misleading.
Jerry O'Grady, of Pinkerton's New York Racing Service, told yesterday of the agency's preparations for the opening of the New York turf campaign at the Jamaica track a week from Tuesday.

LOS ANGELES, March 20 -- A former Negro college football star, a nominal member of the Communist party in Oakland, Calif., since 1948, was unmasked in United States District Court today as an undercover operative for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

PARIS, March 20 -- The Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe agreed in principle today to the proposal made by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, for integration of the Schuman plan assembly with the Council of Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a new plan for reorganization of the Wisconsin Central Railway Company. It proposes substantially increased capitalization by comparison with previous plans.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 20 points lower yesterday after a moderate volume of business.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -An economy-minded House of Representatives approved a proposed reduction of $174,272,500 in the Atomic Energy Commission's budget today and voted new and drastic cutbacks in the public housing program.

PLEASE don't bother wasting your time in shedding tears over the sad plight of Charles Dillon Stengel, whose Yankee team is slowly disintegrating before his very eyes. Joe DiMaggio has followed Tommy Henrich into retirement. Bobby Brown is gone and Jerry Coleman is going. But the Ol' Perfessor is so undismayed that a fellow, who spent a couple of weeks living with the Yankees, finds Stengel's quiet confidence contagious.

A spectacular five-alarm fire of undetermined origin burned out a five-story brick department store warehouse on the east side of Fifth Avenue between Fourteenth and Thirteenth Streets early this morning.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 20 -- Reports that the United States Government may review some of the basic premises of its 3-year-old policy of aid to the Yugoslav Government have caused something of a sensation in Belgrade.
The State of Connecticut announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on April 2 an issue of $59,000,000 of housing notes dated April 21, 1952, and due April 21, 1953.

A merger of the Kalamazoo Stove and Furnace Company with Maremont Automotive Products, Inc., of Chicago is under consideration, A. L. Blakeslee, president, told shareholders at a meeting yesterday in Kalamazoo. A special meeting has been called for April 1 to vote on the proposal.

The afternoon performance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on April 18 at the Madison Square Garden will aid the Allen-Stevenson School Burn-the-Mortgage Fund. Mrs. Herbert C. Bernard and Mrs. Joseph C. Rennard are co-chairmen of the committee in charge of the sale of tickets.

THE fresh water enthusiasts are not the only impatient anglers influenced by the recent flashes of spring weather. For the flounder fishermen have been showing on Great South Bay in greater numbers during the past week, and some of them have been taking fair catches of fat flatfish.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey declared yesterday that the only reason Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio had withdrawn from the New Jersey preferential primary was the collapse of the Taft for President drive as a result of the New Hampshire and Minnesota votes for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.
CHICAGO, March 20 -- The grain futures market had an irregular trend today, weak in the forepart of the session, scoring a rally later, but meeting free selling pressure at the close.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 20 -- Tension was evident in Rio de Janeiro tonight as President Getulio Vargas still refrained from intervening in what was called here "the military crisis."
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 20 -- The Supreme Court of South Africa delivered judgment today declaring invalid the act placing Colored voters on a separate electoral roll.

ROME, March 20 -- "Tremendous progress" in building the West's defenses in the Mediterranean was reported today by Admiral Robert B. Carney, American Commander in Chief of Allied Forces in Southern Europe, in a speech analyzing the strategic importance of that sea in the event of another war.

" Cheescake" is a photographer's term for pictures showing legs. The term and what is pictured have long been popular. It was inevitable, therefore, that a hosiery manufacturer should use the name for his product. The Gotham Hosiery Company mulled the matter over a year or so ago and came up with "Cheescake '51" for a Gold Stripe nylon promotion.
ST. PAUL, Minn., March 20 (AP) -- Record sales and net profits at the second highest level in the company's history were reported today by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company.

PARIS, March 20 -- France, West Germany and the Saar agreed today before the Council of Europe's Ministers' Committee to take up their dispute on the Saar in direct negotiations. It was decided that a committee would be sent into the Saar in the meantime to be sure that free elections could be held there in the fall.

Three Long Island horticultural societies competed in the International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday. The show, which is under the joint auspices of the Horticultural Society of New York and the New York Florists Club, will continue today and tomorrow.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The Assembly Rules Committee failed to report out today a bill introduced by Senator Walter Van Wiggeren, Republican of Herkimer, that would have made $400,000 available in additional state aid for libraries.

Tired of picket lines and mass delegations seeking quick approval of wage agreements, the Regional Wage Stabilization Board served notice yesterday that it would not yield to "pressure tactics" in carrying on its activities.

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will increase production "tremendously" with the easing of material restrictions, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Abrams, president. He confirmed reports that television prices had been reduced and that the company would feature a seventeen-inch mahogany veneer table model set for $179.95.

TOKYO, Friday, March 21 -- The United States Senate's ratification of the Japanese peace treaty will be followed here by a series of legal actions including large-scale amnesty of the remaining victims of the purge and prisoners sentenced under the "Potsdam" ordinances based on Occupation directives.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 20 (Reuters) -- The Commonwealth Bank of Australia notified all trading banks today they must not issue further letters of credit and remittances on imports from North America unless the goods involved are already on their way in ships.

Publication of the Department of Agriculture's 1952 crop-production goals is a timely reminder that spring planting time is not too far distant and that already many farmers have begun the preliminary work required for the production of the nation's food, fiber, and other farm products.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The Assembly Rules Committee, in the closing hours of the 1952 legislative session today, killed the Administration- backed Halpern bill to set up a compulsory automobile inspection system at state-operated stations.

LONDON, March 20 -- British funds, again helped by the improvement of pound sterling, continued to rise slowly on the Stock Exchange today. Gains of 2s 6d (35 cents) were made by undated long and medium term issues.

LONDON, March 20 -- In an open letter published in today's Manchester Guardian, Salvador de Madariaga, former Spanish diplomat, accuses Aneurin Bevan of contributing to the intellectual and moral chaos weakening the West by Mr. Bevan's speeches last weekend attacking the United States rearmament policy.

BONN, Germany, March 20 -- In an unusual report telephoned to his aides here, United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy hailed Dr. Adenauer as a "statesman" for his role in the agreement on the investigation commission for the Saar elections.

BERLIN, March 20 -- The United Nations commission to investigate conditions for free elections in Germany arrived yesterday on the doorstep of East Germany, and decided to make one final effort to gain admittance to that region.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The United States refused a request for a $120,000,000 loan to Iran, the State Department said today, on the ground that the Teheran Government had the opportunity to get "adequate revenues" from its oil resources and that the United States was already under a heavy financial burden trying to bring about a "stable and lasting peace."

More than 4,600 passengers, the largest number to sail for Europe so early in the spring, are scheduled to depart today from Hudson River piers. Their departure, passenger traffic officials contend, will usher in the busiest trans-Atlantic ship travel season of the post-war era.

FRANKFURT, Germany, March 20 (AP) -- Vladimir Komarek, the mystery man of the William N. Oatis trial, was located today. He said Mr. Oatis was an innocent newsman "caught in the gears of the Communist police machinery."
Following are the texts of a statement issued by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in Wisconsin, and a rejoinder by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey at Trenton:

Reminiscent of Japanese designs both in appearance and in versatility of use are some of the pieces in a new collection of living room furniture called Match-Makers, designed by Edmond J. Spence for the Warren Furniture Manufacturing Company.

A 4-year-old girl and her 13-month-old brother were killed yesterday afternoon when a Queens bus and a private car, out of control after a collision, ran onto a sidewalk where adults and children were standing. Seven persons were injured, including the children's mother, whose condition was critical.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -The Government appealed today to manufacturers of aviation gasoline to "do everything possible" to increase the production of the fuel.

The four-story factory building and adjoining one-story structure at 130-132 Greenpoint Avenue, Brooklyn, have been sold by Family Properties, Inc., to Ruth Lesser, represented by David Groberg, attorney. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The ground floor of both buildings is occupied by a branch postoffice.

A letter from President Truman congratulating the National Council of the Churches of Christ on its resettlement of 60,000 displaced persons since 1948 was read last night to 200 church dignitaries and world relief officials at a dinner in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Judge Luther W. Youngdahl of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, dismissed today the contempt of Congress case against William L. Patterson, executive secretary of the Civil Rights Congress.

VIENNA, March 20 -- A purge has apparently begun among ministerial experts of the Hungarian foundry and machine industry and is likely to spread to the building and trade ministries. The first victim seems to be Gyula Karadi, who since Dec. 11, 1951, had been Deputy Minister for the Foundry and Machine Industry.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Charles E. Wilson, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, denied tonight that the Government has "retreated from the goals of our security which we set for ourselves after the Communist hordes swept down from China to join the imperialist aggression against Korea."

St. Vincent's Hospital, Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street, is playing host to four sets of twins, three of them born in a twenty- four hour period Monday and Tuesday, a hospital record, Sister Loretto Bernard, hospital administrator, announced last night.

KEY WEST, March 20 -- President Truman expressed regret in a news conference today that the Senate Judiciary Committee had denied subpoena powers to Newbold Morris, investigator of corruption in government. The President added that Mr. Morris would stay on the job nevertheless.

Surrogate William T. Collins yesterday upheld the will of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, granddaughter of the late J. P. Morgan, saying he had found no proof of fraud or undue influence, and directed that the disputed document be admitted to probate.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 20 (UP) -- Miss Pat O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., holed a four-foot putt on the twentieth hole today to eliminate her room-mate, Miss Mae Murray of Rutland, Vt., in the fiftieth North and South women's amateur golf tournament.

BURBANK, Calif., March 20 -- The Giants won their "rubber" game with the Browns today, 4 -- 3, but they had to go ten innings before they reached the 500 mark with six victories in twelve exhibition games.

Two tail hotels, a hospital and a small church in the Tudor City area are dispiritedly completing drastic structural changes that have been necessitated during the last year since the city began work on a streamlined Forty-second Street approach to the United Nations headquarters.

The camel is giving way to the modern diesel-electric locomotive in the transportation revolution that is sweeping oil-rich Saudi Arabia. As a result, Arab youths, many of whom had been brought up as camel herders, are training as railroaders to operate the 350-mile Saudi Arabian Government Railroad, opened formally last October.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 20 -- Repudiating Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, President Truman declared emphatically today that the attainment of peace in Korea would have no influence on him in deciding whether he should seek renomination.
BALTIMORE, March 20 -- The prosecution today closed its case in the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal court and the case was recessed until Monday.

The total of outstanding business and industrial loans by New York banks last week was the highest on record. While the demand for new loans was considerably less than in the same week of last year, the aggregate outstanding rose to $7,967,000,000. A year ago the figure was $6,849,000,000. The spiral in money lending is mounting despite efforts of the Government to restrict borrowings.

The record of New York's 1952 Legislature contains its disappointments but, with due regard to the intended limitations on its assignments and the politics of a Presidential election year, there is a rather substantial sum of achievements. It cannot be said that these were come by easily, or that many of them will be called momentous in the long view of history.

Some time ago a group of artists was invited to a rehearsal of the Philharmonic-Symphony. The results of that visit have been shown at Carnegie Hall in a number of paintings depicting Mr. Mitropoulos and his colleagues going about their jobs. This concern of artists with musicians and their instruments is in a long and honored tradition going back to Biblical times at least.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Southern members of Congress protested today any change in Government competitive bidding policies to relieve unemployment. They testified before a panel of the Office of Defense Mobilization, seeking a solution of unemployment in Northern textile manufacturing centers.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Wage Stabilization Board recommended tonight that the steel industry settle its wage disputes on the basis of a "package" increase estimated by public members at 18.8 cents an hour for 1952.

TRIESTE, March 20 (UP) -- Twenty thousand Italian nationalists demanded tonight that the Western powers return all of Trieste to Italy, in a huge unauthorized rally marked by bitter clashes between the police and demonstrators.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, March 21 (AP) -- Fifty-four United States Sabrejets tangled with 105 Communist MIG's yesterday in two swirling battles high over Northwest Korea.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- "And then the justice," said the Melancholy Jacques in the course of his sour description of the seven ages of man, "in fair round belly with good capon lined." With these words Shakespeare certified the feeling then and now that to attain a seat on the bench is the acme of social security.

French and Italian imports of thirty-eight costumes and American-made copies were shown yesterday at Macy's. The collection reflected highly selective fashion sense. The translations lost none of their chic in the process of adaptation, though in some instances fabrics were substituted for greater wearability.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- "And then the justice," said the Melancholy Jacques in the course of his sour description of the seven ages of man, "in fair round belly with good capon lined." With these words Shakespeare certified the feeling then and now that to attain a seat on the bench is the acme of social security.

French and Italian imports of thirty-eight costumes and American-made copies were shown yesterday at Macy's. The collection reflected highly selective fashion sense. The translations lost none of their chic in the process of adaptation, though in some instances fabrics were substituted for greater wearability.

A flat denial that he is "Mr. Big" in this port, and the declaration, moreover, that he has never known of "any Mr. Big" were voiced last night by William J. McCormack, Manhattan industrialist and stevedore.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -Senator Owen Brewster, Republican of Maine, defended under oath today an exchange of $10,000 in checks with Henry W. Grunewald. mystery fig-ure in the current tax investigation, by saying it was a cover-up for secret primary help.

Additional agreements on minor points were reached yesterday in the eight-month-old truce talks in Korea and the United Nations said that it might be willing to engage in "secret" negotiations in an attempt to break the deadlock over war prisoners.

Spring, the perennial ingenue, made her entrance yesterday with a performance that was adequate if not memorable. There were flowers to mark the debut but mainly of the kind that bloom on hats and lapels -- and most of them were rain-sprinkled before the day was over:

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 20 -- Much dull and unimaginative present-day advertising is attributable to the growth in recent years of a number of factors that stifle creativeness, Julian L. Watkins, group head and representative of the J. Walter Thompson Company, told the second day sessions of the annual spring meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Homestead Hotel here.

DARRINGTON, Wash., March 20 -- Three starving dogs trapped 4,000 feet high on a narrow mountain ledge fought savagely for their lives today against screaming attacks by flights of hungry bald eagles. Men could not help the dogs, but could watch the primitive battle above the clouds through binoculars.

Andrew J. Kelly, a former deputy Internal Revenue Collector in the Freeport, L. I., office, pleaded guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to an indictment charging him with accepting, a $1,000 bribe to adjust a Government tax claim.

YONKERS, March 20 -- A 49-year-old former patrolman of the Westchester County Parkway police was arraigned here today on two charges of second degree murder in the fatal shooting of two brothers last night near a local tavern.

Senator Estes Kefauver made history in New England concerning a new technique in American politics. It was something new here in New Hampshire, but it had been used before in Tennessee in 1948 when he threw out the Crump machine in Memphis which had ruled for forty years; at the same time running 100,000 votes ahead of President Truman.

BONN, Germany, March 20 -- Erich Koehler, former president of the Bundestag and a leading member of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic party, said today that allegations of an unusually large Nazi infiltration of the Foreign Ministry were "partly right and partly wrong."

Although the Aeolian Trio made only its second appearance here, it drew quite a crowd to Town Hall last night. Apparently the audience found what it was listening for; it gave the musicians a warm reception.

CINCINNATI, March 20 -- The 845 employes of The Cincinnati Enquirer are competing with The Cincinnati Times-Star Company as prospective buyers of The Enquirer, 111-year-old newspaper, which is this city's only morning daily.

Coconuts and pineapples from Puerto Rico, where the season is reaching its peak, are in good supply in local markets now. The rich white-meated coconut is 10 to 12 cents a pound in the shell. The green-topped, hexagonally scored pineapple that lends itself to attractive serving as well as luscious eating is selling in one large chain store at 39 cents for a large specimen, 21 cents for a small size.

Fifty-two new members were welcomed into the Twenty-five Year Club of Presbyterian Hospital at a dinner last night in Bard Hall, 50 Haven Avenue. Founded six years ago, the club now has a membership of 263 drawn from trustees, personnel and staff.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (U.P.) -- Hyman S. Kraft, one of the authors of the Broadway musical "Top Banana," refused to tell House investigators today whether he had ever been a Communist.

Burlington Mills Corporation has acquired the stock interest of Charles L. Gerli, president and Jackson E. Spears, vice president, in National Mallinson Fabrics Corporation, it was announced yesterday. The stock was acquired on a price basis of one share of Burlington Mills Corporation common stock for each share of National Mallinson Corporation common stock.

Affidavits, grand jury minutes and court testimony by Joseph C. Workman were read into the record yesterday in Kings County Court as the prosecution sought to discredit the retired police captain's testimony that he was unaware of Harry Gross' bookmaking activities in 1949.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- In the midst of reports of growing sentiment throughout Illinois in favor of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as Republican nominee for President, the executive committee of the Eisenhower-for-President organization here was apparently undecided today on the advisability of urging voters to write in the general's name on the ballots in this state's April 8 preferential primary.

Cal Snyder, executive secretary, of the Realtors Washington Committee, will speak at the spring conference of the Westchester County Realty Board on Monday night at the Roger Smith Hotel in White Plains. Peter C. Doern Jr. is chairman of the conference committee.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Two former employes of the Department of Agriculture who were dismissed for alleged inefficiency in handling grain storage operations that at times involved commodities worth as much as $400,000,000 told the Senate Agriculture Committee today that they were not inefficient and should not have been discharged.

The New York City Opera Company, which has gone through something of an upheaval during the past winter, opened its spring season on schedule at the City Center last night. Joseph Rosenstock, who replaced Laszlo Halasz as the general director of the company, was in command in the pit, and he conducted a lively performance of "Der Rosenkavalier."

KALIMPONG, India, March 20 -- That the Chinese Communists, after consolidating their hold on the "roof of the world," might gradually launch an expansionist drive toward India by proclaiming Chinese "historical" claims over Nepal and Bhutan, is the opinion of a number of Tibetan traders who have arrived here lately.

KALIMPONG, India, March 20 -- That the Chinese Communists, after consolidating their hold on the "roof of the world," might gradually launch an expansionist drive toward India by proclaiming Chinese "historical" claims over Nepal and Bhutan, is the opinion of a number of Tibetan traders who have arrived here lately.

Large purchasers of textiles and apparel have "overplayed" the timing aspect of fall purchases, according to a leading converter of synthetic fabrics. To gain price advantages, they have been staying out of the market. But in doing so, he asserted, they will be compelled to sacrifice a good part of their sales volume through inability to obtain enough quality merchandise.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 21 -- Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister, said here today that the Arab states must have satisfaction on the problems of the Arab refugees and the frontier with Israel before they cooperate in a Middle East defense pact.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 22 -- Spring's advent was celebrated here last night at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Hotel with an international fashion revue in the ballroom.

Not too many Schumann players are active today, nor is Schumann's piano music as popular as it used to be. With Chopin, it once was the bread and butter of the concert pianist; and Benno Moiseiwitsch, who played the first of his two all-Schumann recitals last night in Town Hall is definitely of the old school.

TROY, N. Y., March 21 -- Marquette, second seeded, brushed aside the defending champion, St. Francis of Brooklyn, 79 -- 57, in the semi-final of the National Catholic Invitation basketball tournament tonight before 4,000 fans.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 21 -- An unusual organization here observed its first anniversary this week. It is the Bachelor Dads, a group of young men who play "dad" to the children at the day nursery operated here by the Children's Day Care Association, Inc.

PARIS, March 21 -- Secretary Lovett, when referring before the House Foreign Relations Committee to Chinese in Indo-China, must have meant Chinese technicians who are in the ranks of the Vietminh, it was declared here tonight in official circles.
TRENTON, March 21 (AP) -- The New Jersey Senate gave Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's 1952 legislative program strong backing today as it passed six of his major proposals.
CLEVELAND, March 21 (AP) -- Federal Judge Emerich B. Freed today refused to allow the Securities and Exchange Commission to proceed with action to revoke the broker-dealer license of Otis Co.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 21 (AP) -- The host and three-time champion, Louisiana State University, took a one-point lead over runner-up South Carolina at the end of the semi-final round of the Southern Invitation Boxing tournament tonight.

Giuseppe Verdi's brooding opera of the Inquisition, "Don Carlo," was brought to the boards of the Metropolitan Opera last night for the first time this season. Its reception ranged from deep silence during the frightening appearance of the Grand Inquisitor to perfervid -- and largely localized -- enthusiasm for the principal singers.

St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn dethroned McBurney School last night in the twenty-seventh annual Athletic Association of Private Schools swimming championships in the Columbia University pool. It was the first team victory for the Franciscans since 1939.

DYERSBURG, Tenn., March 21 (UP) -A third tornado hurled a killing punch straight at this West Tennessee city tonight shortly after two twisters had killed at least four persons and injured an estimated forty-six others in outlying communities.

Today's events: "Die Meistersinger" at 1:30 P. M. and "La Boheme" at 8:30, Metropolitan Opera; National Orchestal Association, Leon Barzin, conductor, Mischa Elman, violin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Oberlin Orchestra, Town Hall, 3; Wagner College Choir, Sigvart Steen, conductor, Town Hall, 5:30; "La Traviata," City Opera, City Center, 8:15; Members of the Philharmonic Symphony, Mario Cortez, conductor, Carlos Ramirez, baritone, Hrach Yacoubian, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Virtuosi di Roma, Renato Fasano, conductor, Town Hall, 8:30.

DARRINGTON, Wash., March 21 (AP) -- Two of three cougar hounds trapped on a 4,000-foot mountain ledge for fifteen days were dead when found today and the third dog was believed making its own way to civilization.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Aroused by an "abusive" and "outrageous'' attack on the Government of this country contained in a Polish Embassy press statement early this month, the United States ordered the Communist-controlled Warsaw Government today to stop immediately the issuance here of "all publications" except routine press announcements.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 21 (AP) -- Pat O'Sullivan today moved along the path she hopes will lead to a third straight North and South golf title, but medalist Mary Lena Faulk and the Curtis Cup player, Grace DeMoss, were sent to the sidelines.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate tonight a sharply reduced appropriations bill to finance operations of the White House, Atomic Energy Commission, Veterans Administration and other independent offices in the 1953 fiscal year, which begins next July 1.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 21 (UP) -- Jockey Richard A. Thompson died today of injuries suffered in a racing spill at Gulfstream Park Monday.

Today, the last day of the International Flower Show, will bring no let-up in flower arrangement competition. New entries this morning in classes for arrangements and table settings may be seen from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. at Grand Central Palace.

A state witness came down from his chair in Queens County Court in Long Island City late yesterday afternoon and, in dramatic quiet, laid his hand on William Francis Sutton's shoulder to identify him as the leader of the gang that stole almost $64,000 from the Sunnyside branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company in Queens a little over two years ago.
Five one-man shows of paintings and a group display are among the exhibitions on this week's art program.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore was accused today by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee of having given "significant untruths" in his long testimony and of deliberate contempt of his interrogators.

KANSAS CITY, March 21 (AP) -- The Kansas Jayhawks, powered by Clyde Lovellette's record-equaling 31 points, defeated Texas Christian University, 68 -- 64, tonight to join St. Louis University in the final of the N. C. A. A. district play-offs.
LONDON, Saturday, March 22 -- Ceylon's Prime Minister D. S. Senanayake was believed to be near death early today in Colombo as a result of a fall from his horse Friday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 21 -- The Brazilian police and military authorities have taken special measures to forestall any Communist plans for disturbances between now and March 25 which is the thirtieth anniversary of the party in Brazil, the head of the political police said today.

Newbold Morris, President Truman's special investigator of corruption in Government, said last night that he had not halted his compaign to have subpoena powers granted to him. He described the subpoena as an "indispensable tool for any investigator."

Traffic' or Broadway between Kenmare and Prince Streets was halted by the police last night while firemen, summoned on two alarms, fought a fire on the third and fourth floors of a six-story loft building at 99 Spring Street, between Broadway and Mercer Street.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, through exchange of stock, acquired yesterday the business and properties of the Kellogg Switchboard and Supply Company, which will be operated as a division of I. T. T. Kellogg stockholders previously approved the plan, which called for 1.44 shares of I. T. T. capital stock to be distributed for each share of Kellogg stock held.

PANAMA, March 21 -- The directors of the Inter-American Press Association made it clear today that the case of La Prensa of Buenos Aires was never going to be dropped by the free press of the hemisphere until the newspaper had been restored to its rightful owner, Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz.

WAUSAU, Wis., March 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican candidate for his party's nomination for the Presidency, tonight called on the party to "meet head-on the propaganda pouring out from Washington at public expense through the satellite Administration supporters in press and radio."

HELSINKI, Finland, March 21 (Reuters) -- A 12-hour Government crisis ended here tonight when a group of right-wing rebels in the Agrarian party agreed to accept proposals from Premier Urho Kekkonen to give relief to low-paid workers hit by the Government's anti-inflation program.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- For the ninth day in succession mass meetings were being held today in cities, towns and villages all over Russia protesting that the United States was employing bacteriological weapons in Korea and Manchuria.

STOWE, Vt., March 21 -- The greatest array of alpine skiers seen in this country since the world championships were staged at Aspen, Col., in 1950, was busy today testing the rigorous Nose Dive Trail and getting the best line possible for national championships and international races scheduled for this week-end.
Following is the text of a statement by the steel industry yesterday in response to recommendations by the Wage Stabilization Board:
MIAMI, March 21 -- The Dodgers tonight lost to the Senators by giving Bucky Harris' athletes six unearned runs for an 8 -- 2 triumph.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Dr. Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, predicted today a modest revival of inflationary pressures this year, but he warned that the stage might be set for a serious business reversal in the years ahead.

MADISON, Wis., March 21 -- The Wisconsin Supreme Court today denied a petition of a Milwaukee taxpayer to strike the names of Gov. Earl Warren of California and his slate of thirty delegates from the April 1 Presidential primary ballot in this state.

Joseph C. Workman, 48-year-old retired police captain accused of making false statements in a financial questionnaire for the Brooklyn grand jury investigation into police corruption, was found guilty early today on two counts of perjury in the first degree. A blue-ribbon jury in Kings County Court returned its verdict at 1:45 A. M.

Business men are people. Most of them like sports as much as their employes. The Eastern Corporation, large Bangor, Me., paper and pulp manufacturer, is basing an unusual advertising program on the appeal of athletics for enthusiasts.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 22 (AP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway declared yesterday Japan's "greatest problem" was the threat of strong Russian miiltary forces already assembled north of this island nation.

The Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice disclosed its intention here yesterday to broaden its four-year-old suit against seventeen investment banking houses to include the charge that the price-fixing and price-maintenance practices of the defendants infringed the Sherman anti-trust statute, wholly apart from the bearing of such practices on the over-all conspiracy charged in the Government's original bill of complaint.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad last year increased its long-term debt $2,703,890 to $136,260,132, according to the road's 100th annual report issued yesterday. Funded debt decreased $2,038,450, but equipment obligations outstanding were up $4,742,340.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 21 -- Only those media that have failed to capture the interest and imagination of the public will be vitally hurt by television. This conclusion was shared here today by the speakers at the spring meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Homestead Hotel.

TRENTON, March 21 -- A plea for the reopening of Newark Airport "at once" was made at a special legislative committee hearing here tonight by Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, chairman of the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee.

BONN, Germany, March 21 -- In an angry outburst against the French interpretation of the Saar agreement reached only last night in Paris, highest sources of the West German regime asserted tonight that they did not recognize the existing Saar Government and did not concede the ultimate political independence of the Saar from Germany.

In Cleveland the other day the Trailer Coach Manufacturers Association concluded its fifteenth annual exhibition of "homes on wheels" by showing the latest improvement in these models, a two-story number that has three bedrooms and comes equipped with a full-length front porch that is removable for traveling.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Leaders of the Illinois movement supporting General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower decided today not to organize a campaign to have the general's name written in on the Republican ballots in the Presidential preference primary, April 8.

BUENOS AIRES, March 21 -- In a ceremony at the Chamber of Deputies Gen. Juan D. Peron and Dr. J. Hortensio Quijano were proclaimed today President and Vice President of Argentina for a 1952-58 term by Dr. Luis M. Allende, president of the Appeals Court of Cordoba.

The time-table for the city-wide drill on Thursday evening, April 3, when two assumed atomic bombs are to be "exploded," one of them under water, was announced yesterday by the Office of Civil Defense.
Underwriters made good progress this week in keeping marketing machinery in order for the big succession of debt and equity flotations looming up for the spring.

Sonja Henie canceled yesterday a scheduled New York production of her ice revue because she could not post a $1,000,000 bond. The show, the first here under her own aegis, was to have opened next Wednesday in Kingsbridge Armory for a two-week run.

Yesterday, the first full day of spring, was a fulfillment for New Yorkers of all poetic tributes to the season. The weather was balmy -- 63.7 degrees was the day's high, at 5:50 P. M. -- the sun shone brightly, and hats and overcoats were left disdainfully at home.

The humble home owner who manages to keep a couple of jumps ahead of his mortgage payments soon may be sporting a swimming pool on his property like a Hollywood movie star or a Wall Street mogul. A Maspeth, Queens, manufacturer, the Bilnor Corporation, is marketing a Vinylite plastic sheeting lawn swimming pool priced within the means of most middle-income families.

ATHENS, March 21 -- The Plastiras-Venizelos Government won the confidence of the Chamber tonight by 132 votes against 114. There were nine abstentions, all from the Eda, the party of the extreme Left.

DETROIT, March 21 -- Republican leaders here, impressed by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's write-in strength in the Minnesota primary this week, are convinced that the general will have the support of at least half of the forty-six-member Michigan delegation to the Republican national convention.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 22 -United Nations negotiators at Panmunjom turned down today a "formalized version" presented yesterday by the Communists of an earlier Red proposal on the exchange of prisoners after an armistice in Korea.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 21 -- The nation's elementary school principals were urged here today to continue their serious study of the problems now confronting American education so they can deal more competently with justifiable complaints as well as with dangerous and unwarranted attacks.

A reciprocal agreement with the Illinois Boxing Commission is to be signed soon, Robert Christenberry, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission disclosed yesterday. The New York body already works hand-in-hand with Connecticut, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Michigan, Canada and Cuba and has cooperative arrangements with New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

Concern has been expressed from time to time in both the editorial and public columns of THE TIMES regarding the relatively low salaries paid the personnel of our municipal courts. Quite as essential to the operation of these courts as the magistrates and probation officers, but rarely mentioned, is the juror -- the most underpaid of them all.

London's three red buses continued yesterday to bring smiles of friendly astonishment to the faces of New Yorkers who glimpsed them on their goodwill tour. All the local folk were momentarily startled at the sight of the lumbering double-deckers -- the people at City Hall, where Mayor Impellitteri and a group of British and American officials gathered to greet the vehicles, and along Centre and Lafayette Streets, and Fourth, Park and Madison Avenues.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, March 22 (AP) -- Thirty-one United States Sabre jets tangled with seventy-five Communist jets over "MIG Alley" in northwest Korea late yesterday, the United States Fifth Air Force announced. One MIG probably was destroyed and two others were damaged in the fight over Sinanju.

PADUCAH, Tex., March 21 (UP) -- A B-45 light jet bomber crashed in a ravine twenty miles west of here today, killing four crewmen and exploding with such violence that fragments of the aircraft were found a mile and a half away.

The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. has designated the Rev. Dr. Franklin Clark Fry, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, as its official representative on April 29 at the dedicating of the first completed buildings and the campus of the Japan International Christian University at Mitaka, near Tokyo.

The annual report of the Curtis Publishing Company and its consolidated subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a reduction in net income to $4,849,921 last year from $6,212,354 for 1950, despite increased operating income.

Why must Eisenhower come home to chase after the Presidency? Are we not tired of those that do, as if it is a great glory to ardently seek instead of a great responsibility to accept with humility and resolution?

Vice President Alben W. Barkley joined the select group of "fall guys" yesterday. Through the long afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the Vice President, seated on a raised platform as guest of honor, saw himself lampooned in a series of sketches and skits at the annual monthly luncheon of the Circus Saints and Sinners.

Eighty-eight Buckeyes -- from Chillicothe, in Ross County; from New Lexington, in Perry; from McArthur, in Vinton; from Carroll, in Fairfield, and other Ohio points -- prefaced yesterday their return home with a bus tour of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The General Electric Company declared today that Congress must use "all its legislative power to eradicate dangerous Communists from positions of power or influence in labor unions."

The reassuring statements from many quarters that children will not beharmed by the violence depicted in comic books and on radio and television, shows are without foundation, Ralph E. Pickett, Associate Dean, School of Education, New York University, said yesterday.

Bruce E. Lambert, new Acting Collector of Internal Revenue for upper Manhattan, who succeeded former Collector Monroe D. Dowling last Monday, said yesterday he had not discovered any irregularities in Mr. Dowling's conduct of the office.

Record sales and earnings were achieved last year by Ingersoll-Rand Company, manufacturers of air and gas compressors, rock drills, oil and gas engines, pumps, pneumatic tools, air-conditioning, refrigeration and mining machinery.

PARIS, March 21 -- Two notable reports affecting Western Europe's economic future will be submitted to the Marshall Plan council Thursday when the member states will be represented by cabinet ministers.
GUATEMALA, March 21 -- The Anti-Communist Civic Committee announced in a manifesto today the main goals of a demonstration it had organized for Sunday.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -With a lull in inflationary pressures, the Consumers Price Index fell 0.6 per cent from mid-January to mid-February, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Jean Dalrymple has bought a new comedy, "October Gal," written by Charles Robinson, whose Broadway credits also include "Sailor Beware," "The Flying Gerardos" and, lastly, "Apple of His Eve," a collaborative effort with Kenyon Nicholson.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 22 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,196, for Friday's operations:

A fight over the site of a new factory for Israel is shaping up among five cities. An American company planning to build in Israel first considered Tel Aviv, then broadened its outlook to include Rehovoth, Natanya and Haifa. Yesterday the Mayor of Jerusalem, here on a visit, put in a bid for the factory.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Jack K. Woll, chief of the foreign and used machinery section of the National Production Authority, said today that imported machinery reaching the United States "is now playing and in the future will play an even more pronounced role in defense."

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- Secretary of the Army Frank Pace Jr. relieved today Army engineers in charge of air-base construction in North Africa and promised that he would shut down the program if the shake-up did not prove "adequate."

Despite the recent Senate refusal to act on outright repeal of drastic import quotas imposed last August on cheese and other dairy products, importers voiced hope yesterday that the ban would be lifted through dropping the curbs from the present Defense Production Act, of which they are a part.
The following household hints, which may be of use to the home laundress, have been received from various sources:

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 21 -- Claude B. Hutchison, who arrived here ten days ago to head the Mutual Security Agency program in Pakistan has resigned his post. He left by air for the United States today.

The City Charter states first, among the duties of the Mayor of New York, that he shall "communicate to the Council, at least once in each year, a general statement of the finances, government and affairs of the city, with a summary statement of the activities of the agencies of the city."

Recent letters this department has received from some of its readers include an informative comment on Mexican food from a New Jersey housewife and several questions that indicate a growing interest in homemade breads. These and other items from the reader mail bag are discussed today.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Including the seven bills designed to enable the City of New York to balance its budget for the next fiscal year, the Legislature left a total of 1,049 proposed laws with Governor Dewey when it ended its 175th regular session yesterday, according to a tabulation made today.

PARIS, March 21 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, chief of staff to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, North Atlantic Treaty Organization commander, left by plane tonight for Wash ington. He is determined to make a personal effort for the nomination of British Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery or Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin of France as General Eisenhower's successor when the NATO commander eventually retires from his present position.

EVEN the woodchucks appear to have been stirred by the touch of spring weather during the past week, for three reports have come in from areas within a hundred miles of the city on early foraging chucks, and the more ardent varminters are checking over their rifles.

Most commodity futures prices were mixed or lower here yesterday, with the biggest declines in hides and wool. Tin reacted to Bolivian price negotiations by jumping 200 points on a single Commodity Exchange deal.

BOSTON, March 21 -- The Massachusetts Democratic State Committee today abandoned its attempt to bar a slate of delegate candidates pledged to Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, from appearing on the ballot at the April 29 Presidential primary.

Punched dizzy by Gil Turner's whirlwind offensive, Don Williams did not answer the bell for the eighth round of the scheduled ten-rounder at Madison Square Garden last night. Turner, unbeaten now in thirty professional fights, was a 1-to-3 favorite and the Philadelphia welterweight showed 5,254 fans why.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 21 -- A three-run homer by Tookie Gilbert gave the Giants a 5-2 victory over Mel Ott's Oakland Oaks before a father-and-son crowd of 10.550 tonight.

The Wage Stabilization Board majority (public and labor, industry dissenting) has proposed to settle the steel labor-management dispute on terms that appear to be generous to the employes. The industry members insist they are too generous by far. Whatever the short-term or long-range effects of the Board's recommendations, it is not for us to say what wage may be a "fair" or logically "correct" one for a man standing in front of a blast furnace.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 21 -- The Yankees, whose grand offensive suddenly seems to have lost itself in the Citrus Belt, still weren't knocking down any fences today as they bowed to Red Rolfe's Tigers, 3 to 1, to the cheers and taunts of the onlookers.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Securities and Exchange Commission said today he "assumed" a proposed distribution of Washington Water Power Company common stock to American Power and Light Company shareholders would "wash out" a proposed plan to sell the Washington utility.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 21 -At least 116 persons were killed by tornadoes that cut a long swath through Arkansas and hit neighboring areas of Tennessee and Missouri late today.

A chemical engineer and an apartment superintendent had to crawl through smoke on their hands and knees yesterday to rescue two small boys from a burning apartment on the Lower East Side. The younger child was found unconscious under a bed where he had hidden in terror from the flames.

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., which has won a United States Supreme Court decision against two North Atlantic steamship conferences on the contract rate system, is now carrying the fight to all such groups.

HONG KONG, March 21 (Reuters) -- Business circles here forecast today an easing of Hong Kong's trade depression following the United States removal yesterday on its eighteen-month-old ban on raw cotton shipments to the colony.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Duquesne broke a 39-39 tie with a fourth quarter surge to defeat the Ivy League champion Princeton quintet, 60 -- 49, tonight to gain the final round of the N. C. A. A. regional basketball tourney at the Chicago Stadium.

Roman Toran, youthful champion of Spain, yesterday played his twenty-second-round adjourned game with Nicholas Rossolimo of France to a draw, thereby winning a share of the prize money in the international tournament at the Capablanca Chess Club, according to a report from Havana.
VIENNA, March 21 (AP) -- Communist Czechoslovakia, whose workers already have seen a great drop in their living standards, announced today a new "austerity" program to provide for defense.

Shareholders of Loew's, Inc., are to meet in New York on April 29 to vote on a plan to divest the corporation of its theatre-operating properties, as ordered by a Federal count on Feb. 6. The meeting will take the place of the annual meeting, originally scheduled for Feb. 28.

Two Brooklyn longshoremen were ordered held in "protective custody" last night when they each failed to raise $25,000 bail after having been detained by Kings County Judge Samuel Leibowitz as material witnesses in a "loan shark" case involving another longshoreman. The third man was accused of preying on fellow workmen by lending them money at an interest rate of l0 per cent.

LAUREL, Md., March 21 -- Expectations are great for a most successful opening of the 1952 Maryland racing season tomorrow. The thoroughbred sport will open at the Laurel race track where a 33-day meeting under the combined operations of Bowie and Laurel will be conducted. This will be the first major racing meet in the East.

Lloyd B. Marsh, Secretary of State of New Jersey, informed Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio yesterday that he might withdraw from the April 15 New Jersey primary in accordance with his expressed wish and set a Monday deadline for formal action by the Senator.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Mar. 21 -- A reckless yearling mongre! whose throat was cut by the blades of an airplane propeller owed his life tonight to an elderly Labrador retriever, which donated a pint of blood for an emergency transfusion.

LONDON, March 21 -- The stock markets here ended the week on a rising note despite the usual weekend restraints on business. A further advance by British Government securities and the publication of several good company statements prompted a slightly better demand for leading industrials.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Railroads, motor carriers and shippers launched a joint campaign today to reduce loss and damage to freight shipments when more than 600 representatives of transportation agencies and shippers attended a luncheon meeting in the Palmer House.

LONDON, March 21 -- Prime Minister Churchill, whose political opponents are much divided among themselves, had to put down rumors of dissension in his own party today, rumors started by The Daily Herald, the Opposition newspaper.

ALBANY, March 21 (AP) -- Material shortages caused a 30.4 per cent cutback in the amount of contracts awarded in 1951 for highway construction or rebuilding, a Public Works Department report showed today.

ROME, March 21 -- The Italian Government called the attention today of the United States and British Governments to the gravity of incidents that occurred yesterday in Trieste and to the urgent necessity that they indicated of settling the qusetion of the Free Territory without delay.
