Wayne Moore, national 440-yard free-style outdoor titleholder, won the Captain Steve Stavers Memorial 440-yard race in an invitation swimmnig meet held at the New York Athletic Club pool last night. American Legion Post No. 754 of New York City sponsored the meet.

An appeal for the united spiritual strength of Christians and Jews in the United States to aid in the setting up of brotherhood ties with victims of communism has been made by officials of Crusade for Freedom, which operates Radio Free Europe.

Even the lowly foundation soils get "spring fever." When they do, they fail to make safe beds for roadways. Unless these segments of earth are properly based, they break out in "boils" that disrupt highways, create accident hazards and cause many thousands of dollars' worth of damage.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer was enjoying the last laugh today, having surprised the movie colony by capturing the best picture of 1951 award with "An American in Paris" last night at the twenty-fourth annual Academy Award presentations.

For those who read the front pages the big news out of Cuba recently may have seemed to be the Batista revolution, but to chess fans that event paled before the brilliance of the Havana Tournament, just concluded. One need not accept such a partisan evaluation of matters to agree that the caliber of the players and the quality of the play made the tourney one of the outstanding post-war events in the chess world.
The stock market yesterday alternated between strength and weakness and ended with no definite conclusions price-wise.

Farmers in many a land, including not only our own but those of the Middle East, North Africa and South Asia, have fought on unequal terms for many generations against the invasion of locusts. We don't hear so much about such pests in our own time and place, but there are men still living who do remember when the locust came, destroying the work of many weeks in a single day or night.
Patterns of the documentary type, predominantly floral in motif, make up a new collection of matching wallpapers and fabrics available at Le Boff, 48 West Forty-sixth Street.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 21 (AP) -- Lew Worsham and Pete Cooper whittled six strokes off par to share the first-round lead in the Jacksonville open golf tournament today. Each had a 66.

Federal Judge Edward Dimock granted permission yesterday to four of the indicted secondary Communist leaders to travel to various parts of the country, purportedly to seek evidence for their coming trial. He also approved their making speeches and collecting funds.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 21 -- Walter G. Winne, superseded Prosecutor of Bergen County, testified today that he had continued to refer gambling complaints to police chiefs in four towns, although he had received reason to be dissatisfied with the actions of the police heads on previous complaints.
OMAHA, March 21 (AP) -- Two separate campaigns to encourage write-ins in Nebraska's April 1 primary were announced, almost simultaneously, today.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Grain futures here received fair support from commission houses on early recessions, but there was no disposition to follow rallies and the general tone was weak at the close. Further long liquidation was in evidence at times in all pits, and buying was discouraged by the absence of export sales, by the generally favorable tenor of crop news, and by the indifferent speculative demand.
How much longer will the voters of New York State tolerate the annual legislative log-jam in Albany?
Prices of cotton futures dipped 14 to 29 points yesterday in a moderate volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Government attorneys filed a brief today in support of a motion to include 186 relatives of the du Pont family as defendants in an anti-trust suit against the du Pont industrial empire.
MILWAUKEE, March 21 (AP) -- Bowlers from thirteen states and Canada will open the forty-ninth annual American Bowling Congress tournament tomorrow across forty alleys.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 21 -- The United Nations sent direct messages to the enemy in Korea today offering to help fight epidemics in Communist-held North Korean territory.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 -- Recent Communist party teachings that American women should be ready to "take up arms" for the achievement of a Socialist revolution, to be achieved "overnight" with possible foreign assistance, were testified to today in the Federal District Court trial of fifteen California party functionaries.
OTTAWA, March 21 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exporters today requested the Canadian Government to lodge "strong formal protests" against import restrictions imposed by Australia and New Zealand.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 21 (AP) -- Favored St John's caught fire in the last half to defeat North Carolina State. 60 49, and Kentucky swept past Penn State with comparative ease, 82 -- 54, tonight in the N. C. A. A. Eastern Regional basketball play-offs.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- An expansion program designed to add 32,000,000 kilowatts to the 75,000,000 current output of class one utilities of the country was announced today by the Defense Production Administration. The program is scheduled to be completed by the end of 1954.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 21 (AP) -- The Marlboro Stud Farm's Jet Master, third highest-weighted sophomore on John B. Campbell's Experimental Handicap weights, failed dismally In his long awaited 1942 debut before 13,619 at Gulfstream Park today.

The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation has offered to purchase a number of hydro-electric power sites and properties of the Eastern New York Power Corporation and the International Hydro Electric System for $8,500,000, Earle J. Machold, president of Niagara Mohawk, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Any long-term agreement to buy aluminum from Canada will be submitted to Congress for approval, Manley Fleischmann, Defense Production Administrator, said today.
Track, figure skating, fencing, weight lifting and gymnastics will be on view at Madison Square Garden tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 21 -- A pair of dismal stone lions with numbered tags around their necks stood guard today outside the home of the late Hetty Green's daughter, the fabulously wealthy Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Howland Green Wilks, as hundreds of curious persons penetrated the dark and long forbidden interior to peer and wonder.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Testimony of William Power Maloney, New York attorney and former Special Assistant to the Attorney General of the United States, before a House subcommittee will be sent to the Department of Justice for determination of possible perjury.
In your editorial of March 14 on "Morris Talks Back" you say:

RANGOON, Burma, March 21 -- Excitement over the presence of Chinese Nationalist troops in Eastern Burma has diminished in recent weeks, but the refugee Kuomintang forces continue to be the cause of great official and public concern.

The Board of Transportation has under consideration a plan to eliminate service on nine bus lines and one trolley route in Brooklyn on Saturdays and Sundays, it was disclosed yesterday. If the plan is put in effect, a board spokesman said, it will aid the program for an over-all forty-hour week for transit employes, beginning July 1.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- John L. Rogers, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, informed President Truman by letter today that he had applied for retirement effective April 30.

The steel industry denounced yesterday the Wage Stabilization Board's proposal for an 18.8-cent wage and benefit "package" for steel workers and then met with Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, to discuss higher prices.

Sixty-seven Consolidated Edison electrical employes, blood donors to the Red Cross, hired a truck to take them to the bloodmobile at the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local No. 3, 130 East Twenty-fifth Street.

PARIS, March 21 -- The French Government today approved measures designed to bring peace to its troubled protectorate of Tunisia and simultaneously faced a new problem at the other end of its North African empire in the form of home rule demands from the Sultan of Morocco.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., March 21 -- William C. Coghlan, 20 years old, of East Patchogue, whose work as a Brookhaven civil defense auxiliary policeman enabled him to learn police routine, has admitted ten recent burglaries in this area, the Brookhaven Town police said today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 21 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan announced tonight that his Government intended to introduce legislation to place the supremacy of Parliament beyond doubt. This legislation would protect the courts against the "danger" of testing the validity of acts of Parliament and would be retroactive to the date of the coming into operation of the Statute of Westminster in December, 1931, he said in a statement.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 21 -- Members of the New England Council held an "old-fashioned New England town meeting" today and voted against award of Government contracts on any basis other than low bidder, regardless of so-called "distress areas." New England has been so described at the present time.

The Greentree Stable's Guillotine, 1949 Futurity winner who captured the Lincoln's Birthday Handicap during the recent Santa Anita meeting, has been assigned the top weight of 126 pounds for the Paumonok Handicap, opening day feature at Jamaica on April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today gave interested parties until April 4 to request a hearing on the debentures financing proposal of the Columbia Gas Company. Columbia has proposed the sale of $60,000,000 of debenaures, Series "C," due 1977.

New York State is in grave danger of losing its newly formed liberal arts college, after two short but very successful years of existence. Champlain College was established as the first liberal arts unit of the State University plan.

The general board of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. postponed action yesterday on a strong denunciation of racial segregation on the ground that "more time was needed for study."

Three to six months ahead of schedule, sandhogs have holed through on the first link of the twenty - five - mile East Delaware Tunnel, which will help insure New Yorkers against any future water shortages. It will be the feeder line for the main reservoir in the sprawling up - state Delaware Water Supply System.

GOLFE DE JUAN, France, March 21 (UP) -- A red-faced Rear Admiral A. K. Doyle of the United States Sixth Fleet acknowledged today that a sea-going dice game had taken precedence -- temporarily -- over naval security in his Mediterranean command.

An illuminating gas explosion that killed a 72-year-old invalid woman in her ninth floor apartmnt at 240 Central Park South caused momentary panic in the Columbus Circle area last evening as reports spread that the city had been "bombed."

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Representative Graham A. Barden, Democrat of North Carolina and chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor, said today he would seek legislation to establish in the Office of Education a clearing house of information dealing with the education programs of different Government agencies.

The Supreme Court of South Africa in a unanimous judgment has invalidated Prime Minister Malan's election act that would have placed persons of mixed blood (the Cape Colored) on a separate election roll, thus denying to them equality of franchise. This decision is a severe blow to the Prime Minister's "apartheid" (segregationist) policies and program and may well bring about the fall of the Government.

PORTLAND, Me., March 21 -Maine Democrats served notice today that whatever the signs and portents elsewhere, their ten votes at the national convention in July at least tacitly would be committed to President Truman.

Believing in the tradition of operetta, the makers of "Three Wishes for Jamie" have given it the full treatment. The production, which opened at the Mark Hellinger last evening, is elaborate and expensive, and it is densely populated with young people in gay costumes. John Raitt, who has a beautiful voice and has become a first-rate romantic actor, sings the leading role of a young Irish lover.
The steadily dropping freight market reached a new low last week, but vessel owners and brokers believe that the bottom has been reached and that a leveling-off of the market can be expected.

MONTREAL, March 21 (Canadian Press ) -- Don McEwen, University of Michigan track star from Ottawa, ran away from his field tonight to win the two-mile run at the Canadian Legion indoor track meet in record time.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The possibility of American intervention in Indo-China along with other United Nations units was suggested today by Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, in hearings on the $7,900,000,000 Mutual Security program before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- A Pennsylvania business man, George Setman of Quakertown, said today that many textile towns in his state were "drying up" because Southern mills were outbidding them for defense contracts.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 21 -- Papers were filed in Supreme Court here today in seven suits seeking $12,000,000 from fifteen broadcasting companies, officials of the companies, news commentators and news compilers. Justice Frank H. Coyne reserved decision on a motion by eleven defendants for merger of the suits.

Members of the executive committee headed by Miss Louise Edgar, chairman and Mrs. Robert Clifford Wilson, co-chairman, are being aided by Mrs. Arthur T. Whitney and Mrs. Stanley M. Rumbough Jr., in the plans for the luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop to be given on Thursday in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

SEATTLE, March 21 (UP) -- A Superior Court jury awarded $2,000 damages tonight to a seaman who said he was chained "like a wild animal" to the bridge of the freighter Clyde L. Seavey and displayed as a curiosity to Siamese native women sneaked aboard.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 21 -- This country's "preposterous" prison system, in which the offender and the community "both lose," needs complete revision and reconstruction, Dr. J. P. Shalloo, an authority on penology, declared here tonight.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 21 -- The attempt to rule Governor Warren off the ballot in Wisconsin recalled the removal of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower from the Minnesota primary ballot. The Minnesota primary was held last Tuesday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 21 -- The claims of Israel and the world Jewish community against Germany for the material losses of Jews under the Hitler regime will receive "most careful consideration," a representative of the West German Government said here today at the opening sessions on German reparation talks.

PARIS, March 21 -- The reply to the Soviet note on a German peace treaty was further discussed here tonight by representatives of the three Western powers after Secretary of State Dean Acheson had cabled new suggestions based on yesterday's draft.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it is in the market for foreign-grown extra long staple cotton for military stockpiling.

Mayor Impellitteri put in the third day of his "budget retreat" yesterday at the Municipal Building office of Budget Director Abraham D. Beame, in his study of departmental 1952-53 requests to compensate for his late start this year.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson informed Congress today the International Materials Conference (I. M. C.) "has gone far to put an end to the chaotic scramble for raw materials."

" EVERYONE writes novels nowadays, but nobody tells stories." Isn't that a familiar cry? Don't we hear it applied to the novel of the Nineteen Fifties every time a pundit pontificates or whenever one of those whither-are-we-drifting meetings considers the lamentable state of contemporary literature? Will any one idea be aired more frequently at a dozen writers' conferences this summer?

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 (AP) -- Kinrey Matsuyama of Tokyo moved into a three-way tie for the world three cushion billiard championship today by defeating Joe Procita of Los Angeles, 50 -- 26. The match went 53 innings.

Action by the United States Treasury in recent weeks in freezing certain accounts of a Swiss bank has brought out details of the battle being conducted to prevent critical supplies from reaching Communist China, now at war with the United Nations.

A congresssional inquiry into the splitting of ocean vessels is being planned by a merchant marine committee under Senator Warren G. Magnuson of Washington, according to reports from Washington last night.
MIAMI, March 22 -- The Red Sox got all the breaks today and beat the Dodgers, 5 -- 2, at Miami Stadium.

" I have found in my long political career," a Congressman (Walter Pierce of Oregon) once observed, "that the strongest argument * * * my friends can make in my behalf is, 'He's going to win. You might as well get on the bandwagon.'"

I Have so often noticed that the suffering which is most difficult, if not impossible, to forgive is unreal, imagined suffering. There is no power on earth like imagination, and the worst, most obstinate grievances are imagined ones.

A need for speedy action to save the city from losing thousands of dollars a day on one item in the new state-city plan for balancing next year's city budget was pointed out here yesterday by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.

NEW DELHI. WITHIN the next four years, history in Asia will reach a turning point. It will be a turning point not for Asia alone, but for the whole world. The pivot of this historic point is India. Within these coming four years democratic India must prove to her own and Asia's millions whether or not democracy can solve the staggering problem of an Asian people.
Regarding Dr. Mario A. Pei's "Six Languages in One World" ( Feb. 24):
The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., has warned its sporting members to quit the gaming tables and put away some money in the face of decreased shipping opportunities.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 23 -Communist propaganda sources turned loose their heaviest guns today against the proposals by Secretary of State Dean Acheson and Benjamin V. Cohen, United States delegate to the United Nations, that the International Red Cross make an impartial investigation on charges of germ warfare in Korea and North China.

Behind the start last week of the printing of the Revised Standard Version of the Holy Bible lies a promotion and advertising story of considerable magnitude. Involved initially is a budget of $500,000 -probably the largest ever allocated to the promotion of a book before it has even been printed.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 22 -- When Senator Tom Connally snapped at Mutual Security Administrator W. Averell Harriman recently over the amount of foreign financial aid this nation should allocate, Texas voters saw something more than a man who felt that the public purse strings were too loose.

AS spring marches northward, motorists anxious to find an excuse to get out into the country will find a sizable number of blossom tours and pilgrimages to historic homes and gardens in the seaboard states from the District of Columbia up to Maine.

HERE Harvey Wish, whose first volume. "Society and Thought in Early America," covered the period through the Civil War, continues the social and intellectual history of the American people from 1865 almost to date. This is a large order in any case.

WHEN the new seed catalogues arrive, the novelties are apt to receive first attention. Seasoned gardeners quite often study them with mixed feelings -- suspicion and hope. Of those offered this year, a number that were grown in our test garden merit commendation.

The Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York at its annual meeting last week reelected Charles F. Kellers, president of James Williams Blue Line, Inc., to head the organization for another one-year term. At the same time, G. Rogers Bleakley and Leroy A. French were reelected vice president and treasurer.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey was accused yesterday by John D. M. Hamilton, Eastern campaign manager for Senator Robert A. Taft, of seeking the Republican Vice Presidential nomination as a reward for his support of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower against the Ohioan.

Cross-examination of a state witness in the William Sutton-Thomas Kling trial on bank robbery charges held jurors and spectators spellbound yesterday in Queens County Court in Long Island City. It bothered the witness but did not shake him.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Our consciences will not let us rest unless we do all in our power to save the epidemic victims in China and Korea, Communist or non-Communist, a national conference of Men's and Women's Club representatives was told today by Dr. James T. Shotwell, noted historian and educator.

Yachting, cruising and pleasure boating will have some improvements and refinements this season. A welcome addition to every cruiser is Chart No. 363 which Rear Admiral R. F. A. Studds, director of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey, has just made available.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 22 -- Center Bob Zawoluk led an amazing St. John's of Brooklyn team to a brilliant 64-57 victory over favored Kentucky tonight in the title game of the Eastern N. C. A. A. regional play-offs. Zawoluk set a new N. C. A. A. individual scoring record with 32 points.

NEXT to walking or riding a bicycle, the least expensive way to go sight-seeing in most cities is by streetcar or bus, provided you know where you are going. Promoters of local tourism in Los Angeles and Copenhagen, Denmark, recognized that obvious fact at about the same time recently and are now offering visitors free maps and well-documented brochures telling them how to get about town on their own.

DURING the last few years I have published in the Saturday Review several articles on styli for the reproduction of phonograph records. My investigations convinced me beyond doubt that diamond is the best material for this purpose.

Off the tip of Luzon in the Philippines a submarine volcano has thrust a crater 250 feet above water. And so geographers will have to mark a new little island on their maps. A mountain with a summit rising 9,200 feet from the sea floor is still spouting smoke and ashes.
Dr. Rufus D. Smith, provost of New York University since 1934 and a member of the faculty for Thirty-seven years, announced yesterday he would retire on July 1.

ELBA, Italy -- The last time anyone outside of Tuscany seems to have heard of the island of Elba was the day Napoleon left it, accompanied by a good part of the local male population, to reconquer the world. But it is still there, not far south of Pisa and just off the coast from the Pisa-Rome highway, very much as the Emperor left it in 1815.

The strength and the weaknesses of the Wage Stabilization Board were equally evident last week in the tug-of-war that led to the board's formula for averting a steel shrike and in the haggling over steel prices that followed it.

LAST week I regretted lack of space to deal with the reaction to my outburst against the pallbearers of literature, as I think we may justly designate too many members of what is known as the avant-garde. What is amusing, when it is not simply irritating, about the avant-garde is that it has fallen victim to the very attitudes which it feels consecrated to combat.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The State Department professed official ignorance today over reports that John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy adviser, would break with the Administration, but associates and other observers suggested that hints of Mr. Dulles' departure had been in evidence for many weeks.
The Defense Production Administration's long-range proposal for augmenting the country's aluminum supply has become a real "hot potato."

THE use of potted plants to decorate roof gardens, porches, breezeways and terraces is keeping pace with the popularity of these outdoor living areas. And pot gardening, or portable gardening as I think of it, also has unlimited possibilities for maintaining succession of bloom in the established garden, large or small.

GULFPORT, Miss, March 22 (AP) -- Jake Fondren established himself today as the man to beat in the $6,000 Gulf Coast invitation golf tournament by shooting a 69 for a three-quarter mark total of 206. The tourney is being played over the 6,006 yard Great Southern course.
Rodney Lynn Berkheimer will be 2 years old on Tuesday, but it was not to celebrate his birthday that he arrived here yesterday in an Air Force C-47 from Jacksonville, Fla.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- General Eisenhower's surprise showing in Minnesota this week, coming after his victory in New Hampshire, dispelled any lingering doubts about the competitive ability of the Ike-for-President movement.

ROME, March 22 -- Francesco Maria Domenido, Foreign Under Secretary in Charge of Emigration, denied emphatically today that there had been any undue delay on the part of Italian authorities in organizing emigration of Italians to Brazil as had been charged by international migration officials in Geneva.
OTTAWA, March 22 (Canadian Press) -- TransAtlantic shipping rates on Canadian grain have fallen off from last year, but they are still higher than the top rates of any other post-war year.

New York City's annual budget is a document that runs to as many as 140 out-size pages. It covers expenses for materials ranging from postage stamps to helicopters, and salaries of employes ranging from the Mayor's ($40,000) down to that of a female attendant in the Welfare Department ($1,800).

KEY WEST, Fla., March 22 -- President Truman is planning to fire a broadside at the Republican party in his Jefferson-Jackson Day speech in Washington next Saturday night, laying down the lines of party battle, but is not expected to announce his own plans regarding another bid for the presidency.

PORTLAND, Me., March 22 -- Fourteen delegates to the Democratic National Convention at Chicago July 21, unpledged and uninstructed but favorable to the nomination of President Truman if he is a candidate, were elected today by a handful of Maine party adherents at the quadrennial state Presidential convention.

SINCE growth of lawn grasses commences during the warm sunny days of March, there is only a limited time in which to complete necessary spring care. New white feeding roots start before the green color appears in the blades of grass. Condition of the soil, density of the turf and the purpose for which the lawn will be used are all factors to consider when planning the spring program.

May I, as a Swiss living in the United States, correct some of the misleading statements made by Michael L. Hoffman in his "An American in Cartel Land" ( March 9)? Speaking as an American living in Switzerland, he claims that "because of the cartel system used by the small Swiss entrepreneurs, as consumers we have about as much effective freedom of choice as if we lived in Moscow."
A last-minute stay of deportation was granted yesterday to a Yugoslav alien for an investigation of his assertion that he feared execution if returned to his homeland.

RAILROAD tickets printed while the customer waits went on sale last week in Grand Central Terminal when two new ticket-selling machines were put into operation at the windows of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

No world records were broken in the clock-conscious sport of track, but the performances, particularly Don Gehrmann's 1 minute 51 seconds for 880 yards, were highly commendable last night. However, the Olympic sports carnival had more to it than the half-dozen track events and the United States Olympic Committee could not have dreamed up a better show case than the one presented at Madison Square Garden.

MADRID, March 22 -- During forthcoming negotiations with the United States for a bilateral agreement on military and economic co-operation, the Spanish Government is expected to suggest that Washington undertake to obtain recognition of the terms of the agreement by other Western powers, particularly France, Spanish military circles said today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 22 -- Louis Bromfield, long noted as a novelist and more recently as a progressive farmer, left Sao Paulo today after a month's visit to Brazil during which he came to be regarded here as a sort of high priest of agriculture after telling the press that in agriculture the Brazilians were "in the condition of United States in 1850."

RICHMOND, March 22 -- Rayon plants in Virginia are curtailing production as the market for rayon goods continues depressed. One major producer this week started separating workers from their jobs and another will lay idle four weeks in April.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The National Rifle Association's annual intercollegiate team championship was won tonight by the University of California.

THIS is a wonderful story to read aloud, time and television permitting. It is the tale. in an expert translation, of two Chinese families who are drum-singers and stubbornly continue to perform all through the Chungking period of the Sino-Japanese war.

I WAS very much interested in Mr. C. L. Sulzberger's review of Prof. L. S. Stavrianos' book "Greece: American Dilemma and Opportunity." Since I succeeded Professor Stavrianos in his position in the Office of Strategic Services, anything I might write in support of the general thesis of his book might be construed unwarrantedly as an indication of what the general attitude of the O. S. S. was.

THERE is a small exhibition of unusual interest at China House. It features a discriminatingly chosen group of bronzes, carved jades and small sculpture, all dating from the Chou Period, those centuries immediately preceding the establishment of the Empire in 221 B. C.

IN "The Grass Harp," which New Yorkers will see for the first time at the Martin Beck Theatre on Thursday evening. Truman Capote, novelist-turned-playwright, is dealing with real characters out of his own childhood.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- A new struggle is building up between the United States and the Soviet Union over a last-remaining chink in the Iron Curtain.

LONDON. IN the few, crowded months since he became Britain's Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs -- his third tour of duty in the post in sixteen years -- Anthony Eden has seldom found a morning when he could buckle down to the routine of a man with a desk and a daily timetable.

MONTREAL, Que., March 22 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens clinched second place in the National Hockey League tonight by holding the Detroit Red Wings, league champions, to a 3-3 tie in a wide open, aggressive game before 14,716 fans, the largest crowd of the season at the Forum.

Cotton prices weakened in the latter half of last week after showing considerable strength earlier. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the five-day trading session with net advances of 65 to 85 points from the level of the previous week, which registered net gains of 49 to 90 points.
DYERSBURG, Tenn., March 22 (UP) -- Doctors fought today to save the blonde 3-year-old girl in the oxygen tent at crowded Baird-Brewer Hospital.

ST. LOUIS -- An atmosphere of optimism rarely seen in postwar photographic trade conventions marked the twenty-seventh annual convention and photographic trade show held here last week by the Master Photo Dealers' and Finishers' Association.
AFTER some of the recent films made especially for television, there seems to be a strong inclination in some quarters to jump to the conclusion that Hollywood is going to be the death of TV.

WASHINGTON, March, 22 (AP) -- The Veterans' Administration reported today that a record $3,614,000,000 was loaned to veterans in G. I. home loans during 1951. The previous record was $3,286,000,000 in 1947.

Before the era of good conversation gave way to the audio-visual entertainments, Bernard G. Richards asked many questions. Much of his time now, as director of the Jewish Information Bureau, 103 Park Avenue, is consumed in answering them.

A NEW company named Command Performance has just recorded David Saperton in a pair of disks devoted to a large group of Godowsky paraphrases on the Chopin Etudes and two Strauss waltzes -- Artist's Life and Fledermaus.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 22 -- Connecticut Democrats appear destined to have one of their most harmonious state conventions in years when they meet in Hartford June 13 and 14. They are expected to renominate Senator William Benton for a full six-year term. They also will elect twenty-two National Convention delegates.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: While deciduous trees are leafless, dormant sprays should be applied. They reduce trouble from scale insects during the coming months. Various kinds may attack apple and other fruit trees, shrubs such as lilac and forsythia, bittersweet and euonymus vines. Apply an oil spray or a fungicide before buds open to avoid burning foliage.

ANOTHER proposal to pry a few additional dollars from the angler, through the initiation of a salt-water fishing license, was discussed at the recent North American Wildlife Conference held in Miami, Fla., but the mail reaching our desk on this subject indicates that the proposal will receive considerable opposition.

Airplanes that travel faster than sound must be cooled if their passengers are not to fry within them because of the heat generated by air friction. The heat developed by any flying body -- bullet, aircraft or space rocket -- rises roughly in proportion to the square of its speed. If the velocity of a speedy plane is doubled, the rise in temperature of the aircraft will therefore be increased four times.
MIAMI, March 22 (AP) -- Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that he and President Truman were "in perfect agreement and absolute accord."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 22 (AP) -- Up to 25 per cent of all revenues from Belgian exports to member countries of the European Payments Union will be blocked for six months, according to a Government decree to be published tomorrow in the official journal.

IN his heyday, James Branch Cabell was, as he says, "spoken of with fervor, upon every Sunday morning, almost as often as Jehovah." Newspaper critics ranked his satirical attacks on American puritanism and materialism with the best of Lucian, Swift, Congreve, Pater, Wilde and Anatole France.

THE outstanding event of the week is, of course, the New York debut of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet at the Warner Theatre. But the week contains other novelties, also. The Choreographers' Workshop is producing a number of new ballets at the "Y" this afternoon, and on Saturday evening at the same place, Nina Fonaroff is presenting a new dance-drama in two scenes and an epilogue, lasting nearly an hour.
In a photograph illustrating General Bradley's article, "Bradley, '15, Looks at West Point" (March 16), the caption says that the cadets are standing at parade rest.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 22 -- Hampton Stable's Alerted lasted just long enough to score a head victory over C. B. Bohn's Why Not Now today in the $10,000 added Appleton Handicap at Gulfstream Park before 17,660 fans.

City Council President Rudolph Halley declared yesterday that a new underworld leader was successfully challenging the reign of Frank Costello. The new boss, whom he described but refused to name, is "more clever and much more dangerous" than Costello and is succeeding in his efforts to revitalize the old criminal organization, Mr. Halley said.

Warning that the critical shortage of nurses and nursing service undoubtedly will become more acute, Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, proposed yesterday wider training of nurses in all categories to offset vacancies over the country.

In an address in Chicago last week Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, thrust an apparently unsuspecting head into a Donnybrook Fair of the economists. He made the statement that "an investment of $16,600 per employe is required to operate an industrial concern today."

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- A special rackets grand jury will start a wide inquiry next week into prostitution and shakedowns in the nation's capital, Charles M. Ireland, United States Attorney, said today.

An unusual program of recorded music at the New York Public Library on Tuesday at 8:30 P. M., jointly presented with the Hymn Society of America in the Central Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will offer hymns of many kinds. There will be metrical psalms, folk hymns and spirituals, gospel hymns, old harp singing, blues hymns and idealized arrangements of hymns.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 22 (AP) -- Williams' well-balanced team won five of ten first places today to defeat ten other schools for the championship of the New England Intercollegiate Swimming Association.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -When the United States Ambassador in Greece, John E. Peurifoy, told the Greek people the other day what kind of election laws he thought they should have, he was immediately condemned for intervening in the internal affairs of another nation.

TROY, N. Y., March 22 -- Marquette ended the upsetting tactics of unseeded St. Francis of Loretto, Pa., to win the fourth national Catholic invitation basketball tournament, 76 -- 64, tonight before 5,000.
JACKSON, Miss., March 22 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the text of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's speech before a joint session of the Mississippi Legislature today:

Weeping willows are great amber fountains beside the ponds, and along the watercourses at least a dozen varieties of lesser willows glow red and russet as though some secret incandescent fluid coursed their stems. Willows respond to the season in a wondrous way for all to see.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 22 (AP) -- Bradley Glass, N. C. A. A. heavyweight champion, won in his division tonight as expected, and advanced to the final Olympic wrestling trials next month. Upsets, however, marked the other divisions in the Third District tryouts.

BOSTON, March 22 -- The surprising success of the Minnesota write-in campaign for General of the Amy Dwight D. Eisenhower this week spurred his Massachusetts supporters to new efforts in the Presidential primary here on April 29.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Earl J. McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education, in his annual report today, made the new high estimate that 130,000 additional teachers would be needed annually and 600,000 new classrooms must be built by 1957 if the expanding school population was to be accommodated.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 22 -- An Air Force sergeant whose Southern accent was his undoing was held for the grand jury here this morning after admitting a series of thefts from fraternity houses over the last four months at Rutgers, Cornell and Syracuse Universities and Hobart College.

TOKYO, March 12 -- Japanese officials who have been checking the tidal-wave alarm system put into operation during the earthquakes early this month are tightening some loose emergency precautions, but they are satisfied that they have developed a plan to prevent heavy loss of lives.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- Nearing the end of the first quarter, factory employment in this city and state remains below a year ago, but average wage income now is estimated at about 3 per cent above last March, although take-home pay is less, partly on account of higher taxes.

American success stories recite in true Horatio Alger fashion the rise to fame and riches of the immigrant boy, generally an orphan, who arrives on these shores at a tender age with less than $10 to his name. He works hard and long and becomes a millionaire.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- The Mutual Security Agency took issue today with a United States Chamber of Commerce statement that billions of dollars were being poured into a Franco-Swiss seaway and power project that the French had refused to finance.

VIENNA, March 22 -- Eight months after he received a ten-year sentence for alleged espionage William Oatis, former head of The Associated Press Prague bureau reappeared in the same court last week as a witness against twelve of his alleged accomplices.

ORADELL, N. J., March 22 (AP) -- Walter Fischer, a plumber who services homes in this suburban community is conducting free classes for women in plumbing repairs. And he thinks they are likely to do a better job of fixing a leaky faucet than the men.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 22 (AP) -- Louisiana State University won three finals, while its closest competitors knocked one another out of the running tonight, to win the Southern invitation boxing tournament. This was L. S. U.'s fourth S. I. B. T. championship.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, chief of staff to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, returned today to report "the tide is flowing our way" and to urge Congress to back the Administration's $7,900,000,000 foreign aid program.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 22 -- The Yale University Art Gallery will place on exhibition next Tuesday fourteen recently cleaned early Italian pictures from the Jarves collection. Called "Rediscovered Italian Paintings," the exhibition will include works from the thirteenth century through the early sixteenth century and will remain open through May 18.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 22 -- After a paper deluge of more than 100,000 write-in votes, Minnesotans are enjoying a quiet chuckle over the astonishment for themselves and the nation that their Presidential primary caused this week.

CAIRO, March 22 -- Premier Ahmed Naguib al Hilaili and Foreign Minister Abdel Khalek Hassouna Pasha met today for an hour and a quarter with the British Ambassador, Sir Ralph Stevenson and his deputy, J. W. Creswell, to resume the British-Egyptian negotiations regarding the future of the Suez Canal Zone base and the Sudan.

THE most important single influence on the American novel today is the inexpensive reprint. It is the tail that's wagging the dog, if you'll excuse a bad pun. Many trade publisher's are now taking on new authors only if they can sell the reprint rights in advance of publication.

Brother Alphonsus Fidelis, for fifty years a member of the teaching order of the Brothers of Christian Schools, was honored yesterday at a dinner given at Manhattan College by 150 of his friends. The 68-year-old teacher has been on the staff of Manhattan College since 1924.

PIONEERING isn't what it used to be in these United States but in Alaska the United States Government is opening up thousands of acres of virgin lands to settlement under circumstances suggesting that frontiers remain.

John Foster Dulles, leading Republican foreign affairs expert who was the architect of the Japanese Peace Treaty, will inform President Truman this week that he no longer will be a policy adviser to the Administration on foreign affairs.

BENJAMIN A. JAVITS, brother of New York's Republican-Liberal Representative in Congress, has chosen a somewhat misleading title for an otherwise intriguing pamphlet. What he has to say has really nothing to do with the political campaign about to start.

MADISON, Wis., March 22 -- A week of the most intensive campaigning yet seen in the Wisconsin Presidential primary contest closed here today with a new surge of hope among the boosters of General of the Army Douglas Mac-Arthur, who have been conducting a rather forlorn and disspirited drive for support till now.

Although the oil industry has met the demand for fuel oil this winter with only temporary spot shortages here or abroad, there is a growing conviction that output soon must be increased if requirements next season are to be met.

Foreign students at the University of Washington have a "mutual assistance pact" with American fellow students in an unusual study program set up to help the visiting students speak better English. Under the program an American student works with a foreign student as a volunteer individual tutor.

LAUREL, Md., March 22 -- The horse racing season in Maryland opened today, the earliest start in the history of the thoroughbred sport in these precincts. The Laurel race course was the mise-en-scene of the presentation, and the sponsors were the owners of the Laurel course and the owners of the Bowie track.

PERHAPS only a few times to the occasional reviewer comes a book that makes him want to exult, "This is it." Here is that book in the realm of understanding emotions. Few novels have conveyed with such clarity the deeper emotions that make up living.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, notified the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration today of his opposition to a proposed Senate test of a subcommittee's authority to investigate him.
Blood contains a substance known as prothrombin. If bleeding follows an injury, prothrombin gives rise to another material, thrombin.

Warm, moist air that comes in conflict with an upper zone of cooler and dryer air creates an unstable atmospheric condition that helps bring on tornadoes, such as those that have been buffeting the South.
Your constructive and understanding editorial on the subject of France in a recent issue struck a most sympathetic chord.

CONDENSING a novel is a ticklish business and not always a satisfying one, but in the case of Ruth Moore's popular "Candlemas Bay" the operation is justified. The adult novel has been shortened and its chronological order slightly rearranged, thus eliminating leisurely flashbacks.
BERLIN, March 22 -- The United Nations commission to investigate conditions for free elections in Germany asked East German leaders today not to block the unity of their country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 22 -- Just before the United Nations Disarmament Commission opened for business here last week, a young Soviet affairs expert in the United States delegation sent his chief a gloomy note. The Russian papers, the specialist said, had been going hot and heavy on the theme that the United States was letting loose germ warfare in Korea and China.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 22 -- The public understands little about parole, chiefly because of the failure of parole personnel to spread the story of their work, Alfred R. Loos, new chairman of the New York State Board of Parole, - declared today.

STOWE, Vt., March 22 -- Ernie McCulloch, 26-year-old chief instructor at Mont Tremblant, Que., and 20-year-old Andrea Mead Lawrence of Pico Peak at Rutland, Vt., double Olympic gold-medal victor in Norway, today gave convincing demonstrations of skiing technique and ruggedness in topping the men's and women's fields in the United States and American international downhill title races.

It is the duty of good citizens to examine the acts and policies of their Governments. It is the privilege of an American citizen to challenge those acts and policies publicly if he is convinced that they are wrong. It is possible, however, to do a disservice to the public duty and to make a doubtful use of privilege by overstating a case.

Thirty smiling little girls from East Harlem and South Bronx, ranging in age from 7 to 14 and all new Camp Fire Girls, were welcomed into the organization yesterday at a friendship party held by five four-year veterans of the movement.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 22 -- Nineteen years ago this month, fifty doctors braved a late winter blizzard and met in a small room at the Nassau County Sanatorium in Farmingdale to form the Nassau Tumor Clinic.

The appointment of Col. Benjamin B. Talley as Division Engineer of the North Atlantic Division, Corps of Engineers, was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Lewis A. Pick, Chief of Engineers. He will succeed Col. Frederick F. Frech, who is retiring this month after thirty-five years of Army service.

Prof. H. H. Wilson of Princeton University's Department of Politics charged here yesterday that the forces attacking academic freedom in American schools and colleges were seeking the "subversion of the democratic process."
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 22 -- Senator Tom Connally's plaintive warning that our Allies cannot go on forever counting on American aid finds many an "amen" in Europe.

Attacks against modern education and modern art that repudiate the "basic idea of American society -- freedom" -- by anyone from the President of the United States to war veterans and "conservative sculptors" were denounced yesterday by Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College.

GOODLAND, Kan., March 22 (AP) -- A March blizzard, the worst of the winter, swept across northwestern Kansas, Nebraska and Iowa today, disrupting telephone and telegraph communications and blocking highway travel.

BONN, Germany, March 22 -- A Foreign Office spokesman, personally authorized by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, denied today that the Chancellor had approved the idea of "Europeanization" of the Saar under the auspices of the Council of Europe.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense, will speak at a luncheon of the New York City Cancer Committee, beginning the 1952 Cancer Crusade, next Sunday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The committee has a quota of $1,394,301 of the $16,000,000 national goal.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The barriers faced by Newbold Morris in his drive to purge the Government of corruption appear to be getting more numerous and harder to jump. The course he must run is becoming more tricky, and doubts are being expressed in some quarters that he will be able to run it.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The Young Lawyers section of the State Bar Association held its annual meeting here today. More than 100 attorneys less than 36 years old from throughout the state attended.

The International Flower Show ended the first seven-day run in its thirty-six-year history when it closed at 10 P. M. last night. Opening on Sunday instead of Monday was an innovation this year, but it will be a permanent part of plans for future shows.

ATLANTA, March 22 -- A great majority of the Southern delegates to the Republican National Convention in Chicago will cast their ballots for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, it was predicted here today in a formal statement issued by Eisenhower supporters from eleven Southern states.

The 104th Engineers Armory in Teaneck, N. J., will be bulging with dogs today. The occasion is the thirteenth all-breed event of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey, which has attracted 991 dogs from twenty-three states and the District of Columbia.
OMAHA, Neb., March 22 (UP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today that Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, "talks with a forked tongue."

JACKSON, Miss., March 22 -General of the Army Douglas MacArthur charged today that the "wastrel policies" of the National Administration were "leading us toward a Communist state with as dreadful certainty as though the leaders of the Kremlin themselves were charting our course."

With the annual tourist rush to Europe off to an early start, New York piers will soon again be cluttered with old-world souvenirs. Many of them are bought abroad as antiques but are actually as contemporary as a television console.

WHEN Ty Cobb was a ball player he scorned the obvious and the orthodox. The unexpected was his dish. He hasn't changed much now that he's become an author. His two-part magazine article, "They Don't Play Baseball Any More," had to be geared along controversial lines in order to attract attention.

FRANKFURT, Germany, March 22 -- The Royal Dutch Airlines plane that Queen Juliana of the Netherlands planned to use April 2 on her state visit to the United States, crashed explosively in a rain-fogged landing attempt today and killed forty-four of forty-seven persons on board.
Somewhere in Japan tomorrow, Eugene F. Moran Sr., chairman of the towboat concern identified by his name and the dean of harbor men in the Port of New York, will celebrate his eightieth birthday.

CAMPAIGN years bring out a spate of campaign biographies of Presidential candidates (and sometimes of a President who may succeed himself) and 1952 is no exception. "Mr. President" is not one of these. It is a real and revealing piece of political literature.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson has acted very properly in banning virtually all Polish Embassy publications here in retaliation for the embassy's offensive press release of last March 3 accusing this country of using "poisoned weapons inherited from Goebbels."

MORE than ordinary merit marks Gordon Sager's slick novel of adventure (his third). His story has suspense and speed, his characters are sharply defined, his dialogue sparkles with urbanity, and his setting, which is Venice, achieves something of the glow and substance of reality.

IT is not news that James P. Warburg disagrees with our foreign policy. He has been tireless in his efforts to convince us that we are leaning too heavily on military muscle and not heavily enough on the crusading vigor of our democratic ideals in our contest with the Soviet Union.

As a result of requests received at City Hall from New York men serving in the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force, 100 official flags of the City of New York are flying over United States troops on the Korean battlefront.
The death toll from the waves of tornadoes that swept six Mississippi Valley states had passed the 200 mark early today. An estimated 2,500 persons were injured.

GENEVA -- In the high mountains of Europe skiing is not a monopoly of the winter vacationist. People who can get away in March and April will find snow in good condition at many places, and there is nothing to prevent even conventional summer tourists from enjoying "winter" sports if they seek out the high areas where snow lasts into June.

ON Thursday the first of the seasonal plantings in the Channel Gardens at Rockefeller Center, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, will go on view. More than 4,000 hyacinths in shades of pink, blue and white will be used in the opening exhibit and will be set off by four fifteen-foot weeping willow trees.

With the start of the local college baseball season little more than a week away, officials of the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference announced a forty-two-game program yesterday. The opening tests are listed for April 5 when New York University plays at Brooklyn and St. John's sees action at City College.

ATHENS, March 22 -- John Panopoulos, General Director of Police attached to the Ministry of the Interior, described today as "entirely genuine" a letter received from Nickos Ploumbides, in which the latter, a well-known Greek Communist and member of the party's executive committee or politburo offered to appear before the authorities in Athens provided he received assurances that the life of his fellow-Communist, Nicholas Beloyannis, would be spared.

PARIS, March 22 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer warned yesterday that the Soviet proposal for unification of Germany and negotiation of a peace treaty with that country was an appeal to German nationalists aimed at delaying integration of Europe and upsetting European defense.

THE frequentation by women of pool halls, even when they are called "billiard academies," is something to which Americans in general are not accustomed. Yet such sights may become commonplace -- bringing a new day to the American pool-hall scene, and the movement for equality of the sexes as well -- if the billiard-playing prowess of a 38-year-old Japanese woman sets the example some experts seem to think it will.

A formal closing and the customary banquet were dispensed with by the Capablanca Chess Club of Havana, sponsoring the international tournament, out of deference to the memory of the late Juan Quesada, according to Israel A. Horowitz, one of the five representatives of the United States, who returned by plane from Cuba, yesterday.

TO the names of Margaret Irwin and Alice Harwood should now be added the name of C. E. L'Ami as a historical novelist who writes with distinction of that old England which was ruled by the Plantagenets and the Tudors.

Total planning for both civilian and defense needs in health took a step forward recently when Charles E. Wilson announced the development of a coordinated National Blood Program in the Office of Defense Mobilization. Participating organizations will include the American National Red Cross and affiliated blood banks, the Department of Defense and the Federal Civil Defense Administration.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 22 -- The Brazilian Army's Security Police have arrested as a Communist agent the sergeant-chauffeur of the Chief of the Superior (Combined) General Staff, Gen. Pedro Aurelio de Goes Monteiro, it was revealed today.

TOKYO, March 22 -- Japanese and the foreign colony here watched this week with interest -- and some surprise -- the unfolding before the United States Senate of the debate that preceded ratification of the San Francisco treaty and the accompanying security agreement between Japan and the United States.

In his article "Hopes -- and Doubts -- About Germany" (March 9), Drew Middleton says that "the West has sought to teach Germany that such [cynical] diplomacy * * * does not pay." Yet in the many letters I have received from Germany, one of the most repeated accusations has been that we are employing just such a cynical policy.

PIANO compositions by four American composers are played by Bernhard Weiser on a twelve-inch New Editions disk. Harold Shapero, a young man of talent, contributes his Sonata No. 1, a simply textured, cheerful, shapely and brief work composed in 1944.

FORT HOOD, Tex., March 22 -- The Army's ever-present domestic "enemy" known as Aggressor, soldiers specially trained as hostile forces for maneuvers who wear foreign-type uniforms and bear names of distinctly foreign origin, was hastily purged today on the eve of a large-scale air-ground exercise here.

FOR every newcomer who gets a break in Hollywood there are roughly ten nursing bitter disappointments. The percentage may not be materially affected by a new policy adopted at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which is designed to give the untried an opportunity to prove themselves, but, at least, youth now will have something more tangible than lip service on which to pin its hopes and ambitions.

NOW that Ed Sullivan's "Toast of the Town" television show is all wrapped up in presenting stories of famous people in the theatre, this is probably as opportune a time as any to present the Ed Sullivan story.

WITCH - HUNTING -- the quaint old-fashioned kind in which the quarry were aged females who cooked up evil brews and mumbled incantations -- is the focal topic of this novel. Newly come to her guardian's home in Pendle Forest, Margery Whitaker found Lancashire split down the middle, half Puritan, half papist.

The personal history printed below explains how four noted actors -- Charles Laughton, Charles Boyer, Agnes Moorehead and Cedric Hardwicke -- reached their fairly drastic decision to step out on a stage and simply read to people. A young man named Paul Gregory helped speed the decision, and also rounded up the quartet for their New York return engagement of "Don Juan in Hell." starting next Sunday.
Year-around commuters are buying homes at such distances from New York that many summer renters will have to go farther this year than ever before for their green pastures.

WHAT the artist creates on the fringe of momentous events often lives on while the events themselves become matters of only limited, historic interest. But in our own busy day we seem to recognize this truth less than ever, and it is a rare occasion managed by enlightened auspices that welcomes the services of the creative artist, even on the decorative fringe.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senator lator H. Alexander Smith, Republi,can of New Jersey, urged Senator iraft in a telegram today to reconIsider his decision to withdraw from the New Jersey plnlary.

DAVE HAMILTON loves ranching, his brother Stuart is crazy about geology, and Ned, a school friend with personal problems, has mechanical leanings. When these young would-be specialists head westward in their old yellow convertible for a summer's work on a Wyoming ranch, they find conflict and mystery to keep things moving fast.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Jim Bredar led Illinois to a 74-to-68 triumph over Duquesne before 13,641 Chicago Stadium fans tonight to move the Big Ten champions into Tuesday's semi-finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tourney.

Some time ago, this newspaper greeted the opening of the College of Free Europe in Strasbourg's historic Chateau de la Robertsau as a beacon of hope for young students from behind the Iron Curtain who risked their lives for a chance to learn in freedom. Now comes news that the venture is well along the way to living up to its early promise.

HUGO WOLF, who died in 1903, is still rather unknown in America. Except to the very limited public addicted to song recitals, he is even unfamiliar to the majority of music lovers. I remember that when I gave my first Hugo Wolf recital in 1938 the hall was rather empty, though ten years later it was possible to fill it with an entire Wolf program.
If anyone cares to put 100,000 empty milk containers end-to-end, the Board of Education reports, he would find that the cartons used daily in the city's schools would stretch thirteen miles.

William J. Heffernan, after serving as a Democratic district leader in Brooklyn for forty-four years, has decided to quit. He thinks the political pace today is a little too strenuous for a man almost 80 years old.

SON of the late Antarctic explorer, Peter Scott is recognized in ornithological circles as an authority on waterfowl. He is director of the Severn Wildfowl Trust in Gloucestershire, where more species of swans, ducks and geese are assembled in semi-captivity than anywhere else in the world.

BOULDER, Colo., March 22 (AP) -- Southern California, with 53 1/2 points, led tonight halfway through the finals of the tenth National Collegiate A. A. gymnastics championships at Colorado University.
DETROIT, March 22 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation's newest ore carrier, the steamer Cason J. Callaway, was launched today at the River Rouge yards of the Great Lakes Engineering Works.
SEATTLE, March 22 (AP) -- The nation's top badminton stars will match strokes here next week for national titles with one of the keenest rivalries in the game likely to reach a climax.

The New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association, down one game in their best-of-three series with the Celtics in the Eastern division play-offs will meet the Boston five in the second test at Madison Square Garden this afternoon. Power Memorial and Bishop Loughlin are listed in a preliminary game at 1:30.
TAMPA, Fla., March 22 (AP) -The major league baseball season should produce just about the best freshman crop of the last ten years.

" LET them who can afford the luxury tax, be good. Let the rest, like me. be smart. We haven't got time for anything else. We're caught in a non-stop rollercoaster." With these breathless words begins this breathlessly titled novel. One might think the young lady speaking is a new version of Brett Ashley.

It may be many months before holders of defaulted German dollar bonds can dispose of their investments in public exchanges here. In the meantime, however, a market is being established here for certain internal securities -- industrial, public utility and banking stocks -- of the former German Reich. And a market exists in Switzerland for many of the defaulted government and corporate dollar bonds of pre-war Germany.

IT looks as though almost everybody is personally concerned with the professional career and advancement of Judy Holliday. Ever since this young lady showed up on the screen in "Adam's Rib" and walked away with that tidbit while Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy twirled their thumbs, folks have been telling their department, with the gleam of hot discoverers in their eyes, that this alumna of Julia Richman High School is the greatest actress on legs.
LINCOLN, R. I., March 22 (UP) -- Whirling Bat made it two in a row at Lincoln Downs today when he defeated Simms by two and a half lengths in the Old Stone Mill Purse.

Keeping a close check on the opposition from the outset, the New York Athletic Club trio of Archie Young, Zenas Colt and Johnny Pflug rode into the final round of the Eastern 12-goal indoor polo championship tournament by topping Al Parsells' Ramapo Polo Club, 7 -- 6, in the feature match of the weekly double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.

MERCHANTS are not the least bit unhappy over the fact that business volume is making no new records. Some said privately last week that sales were "normal" and store inventories were "healthy." In so many words, merchandise, helped along by aggressive advertising and promotional efforts, is moving at a satisfactory rate.

I READ with particular interest Mr. Downes' final paragraph in his article concerning "Music Talent in the Public Schools." He writes that what the judges found "disappointing and even alarming, was the bad level of teaching."

SACEUR is a word coming out of Paris these days, but it isn't the name of a new French sauce. It is part of the battle of brevity being carried on in the Pentagon, which has a special committee charged with the responsibility of finding out what's in names and how names can be abbreviated.

COMMERCIAL production of blueberries is centered around New Jersey and other coastal states. However, with the development of varieties adapted to other soils, there is new hope for uplanders. If the home owner has always wanted to grow blueberries but felt he had the wrong soil for them, this might be the time to reconsider.

CLINTONVILLE, Wis., March 22 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, carried his fight for the support of Wisconsin's thirty convention delegates into the northeastern section of this agricultural and cheese-making state today with a dogged attack on the Democratic Administration.

Boys High of Brooklyn defeated Bayside, Queens winner, 60 -- 49, and Seward Park of Manhattan eliminated Taft, Bronx titleholder, 61 -- 51, in the semi-final round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament at Sunnyside Gardens, Queens, yesterday.

" The vernal equinox is located on the celestial equator in the comparatively starless region just south of the Square of Pegasus." So the text reads. The earth last Thursday morning reached a point in its orbit where the sun, a very important star, was seen in this comparatively starless region, and it was thus definitely established that spring had arrived.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- A throw - run seventh - inning outburst-against Rookie Paul Stuffel carried the Boston Braves to a 5-3 victory over the Phillies today before 1,811 fans. It was the Braves' ninth triumph in the Grapefruit circuit.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 23 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,197 for Saturday's operations:

Settlement of a strike of warehousemen against the American News Company was held up last night by rank-and-file sentiment for a contract for one year rather than two, which had been agreed upon tentatively by union and company officials.

There are two categories of issues in the Korean truce talks: subsidiary and major. For bargaining purposes, the Communists frequently scramble the two groups. The United Nations truce delegates have had constant difficulty during the nine-month negotiations in unscrambling them.

THE abundance and comparatively low cost of eggs suggest custard in its infinite variety as one of the desserts of the moment. Basically a mixture of eggs and a liquid, usually milk, this concoction may be simply sweetened and flavored with vanilla.

Well-known women of society will appear in tableaux that will be a feature of the April in Paris Ball on April 9 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of French Hospital here and various Franco-American philanthropies.

CORVALLIS, Ore., March 22 (AP) -- The Santa Clara Broncos upset the Wyoming Cowboys, 56 -- 53, tonight to gain the National Collegiate Athletic Association finals. Oklahoma City whipped U.C.L.A., 55 -- 53, in the consolation final of the Western regional tourney.

The futility of power of the successful when devoted to selfish personal ends was the theme of Rabbi Louis I. Newman in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

A program to improve Western Europe's distribution systems, both is an aid to unified defense and to meet problems affecting possible economic integration, is being stepped up through studies by the distribution commission of the International Chamber of Commerce.

THE larch has a personality all its own. Although most conifers are evergreen, the slender, horizontal branches of the larch are bare of foliage at this time of year. Orange brown in color, the small, willowy twigs that hang down from the main branches respond to the slightest breeze. Thus March winds bring graceful motion to any landscape where a larch tree grows.

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- Grains held within narrow limits on the Board of Trade today. After a slightly lower opening, the market attempted a rally. This carried most contracts above the previous close by large fractions, but the best gains were not maintained through to the close.

ALBANY, March 22 -- One of the bills left with Governor Dewey when the Legislature adjourned for the year Thursday will, if signed, permit the City of New York to return to prior owners thirteen churches and synagogues it obtained in a recent blanket tax foreclosure.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 22 -- Advertising in all media will be heavy this year, it was indicated last week at the annual spring meeting of the Association of National Advertisers in the Homestead Hotel, Hot Springs, Va. Both advertising and marketing executives recognize that they have been handed the "ball" in the game to maintain the American economy and are actively mapping plans to win the contest.

Growing attacks on the public schools, together with the increasing pressures by various community groups, have combined to make the position of school superintendent both challenging and hazardous, according to a report issued by the American Association of School Administrators.

I have just read Mr. Marek's article in the March 9 TIMES entitled "Too Much, Too Fast" and I cannot but feel indignant. For several years now I have read in periodical after periodical the articles of artists and critics bemoaning the fate of this mass media age where only a few artists are heard in a few works reproduced with monotonous regularity on records, concert hall, movies, radio, television, etc.

A GOOD basic soil mixture is the most important phase off city gardening. High temperatures accompanied by drying winds and surrounding heated surfaces place a heavy demand upon the moisture content. Yet, at all times, the water supply must be adequate to meet the needs of both plants and soil.

No section of the country has made more gestures of welcome and encouragement to industry in recent years than the South. That these local lures had real merit is amply illustrated by the first edition of the new Southern Industrial Directory. In 1951 the South added an average of one new multimillion-dollar plant for each working day.

A zoologist of the College of Agriculture of the University of California reported that the state's native gopher is such an assiduous gnawer that it has to grow a replacement of almost one inch of tooth per week.

The team of International Class skippers that will go to Bermuda next month for the week of racing there has been determined. The members will be Coruy Shields, George Hinman, Bill Luders and Sam Barton.

BERTIL A. RENBORG, Chief of the Postal Administration of the United Nations, made available last week the world organization's stamp-issuing program for 1952. In prospect are a postcard, an air letter sheet, a stamped envelope and two commemoratives.

Greater political and educational opportunities for women and removal of legal discriminations are among the recommendations the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs is making to the United States delegation to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women.

ALTHOUGH his admiration for Thayer's painting is boundless, Nelson White presents his subject candidly and thoroughly. He doesn't shield or obscure the artist's confused existence -- both in his art and private affairs.

CAN a young German refugee make friends in an American high school? In Colin Lochlons' latest story Willi Baedecker tries to find an answer to this question. His first pleasure in school is marred by the ridicule of his classmates, who don't make allowances for his formal speech and European manners.

A BIRD-WATCHER sometimes is asked this question -- what do you see in birds? It can be an embarrassing question to ask; a difficult one to answer. Ruth Thomas, however, does the latter very nicely in an often moving yet restrained little book -- her story of a brown thrasher, who for ten years made his home among the climbing roses in her Arkansas garden.

AN array of horses, from a beautiful red mare to the little wild Exmoor ponies, are the principal characters in this simple story of English farm life, a sequel to "The Friendly Farm." The most important horse is Prince, owned and trained by Ben, the gypsy boy.

While I am in full accord with Mr. Downes' suggestion for "a school for teachers, examined and trained for adequate service to the pupils and their art," I am not in agreement with WQXR's "Talent in Our Schools" to counteract the current poor standards of music education in our country.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, 64-year-old ruler of billiards, retained his world three-cushion championship tonight when he defeated Kinrey Matsuyama, 50 to 37, in sixty innings.

Plans are being advanced rapidly for the Ciro Ball, the spring dinner dance on behalf of the New York Infirmary, to be held on the night of April 15 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Ellen Tuck Astor and Mrs. Eugene W. Ong are co-chairmen of the executive committee.

Largely because of comparison with the earlier Easter Week of last year, department store sales here continued in the minus column. Trade observers estimated dollar volume at 13 per cent under that for the comparable 1951 week. Pre-Easter sales during the week last year produced a 6 per cent gain over the comparable 1950 week.
