WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Administration is prepared to revise industry earnings standards set up more than a year ago if such a step is needed to allow steel producers compensatory price advances in the wake of wage increases recommended by the Wage Stabilization Board.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 22 -- Pat O'Sullivan, the smiling slugger from Orange, Conn., and 19-year-old Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., today scored impressive North and South golf tournament semi-final victories.

With reference to the controversy about the size of orchestra for Mozart, permit me to utter my humble opinion that it is nonsense to use a greatly abbreviated orchestra in an opera house of the Metropolitan's proportions. The probable reason for the use of small orchestras in Mozart's time was that then large orchestras were not usually available, and the auditoriums themselves were small.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 22 -- This city has devised a new system for catching up with motorists who ignore parking tickets and who remain anonymous because Stamford has kept no motor vehicle registration records.

FEW writers have worn so well over the years for this reviewer as has Langston Hughes. There have been more important writers, perhaps, or others who worked a broader canvas, but few have been so versatile or as workmanlike.

A THEORY OF PRICE CONTROL. By John Kenneth Galbraith. Harvard University Press. 81 pp. $2. This is probably the first attempt by a qualified economist to establish a definitive theory of price control. Professor Galbraith, deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration in charge of price control during the recent war, is eminently qualified.

DURING the early part of the garden season, perennials are the main source of cutting flowers. They augment the spring bulbs and fill the gap between these early blooms and the summer annuals. In autumn, too, when annuals are shabby or have succumbed to an early frost, perennials provide fine blossoms for bouquets in the home.

A JURY of eight met in a hotel room late last month to select from several hundred entries those which would receive Citations of Merit in the 1951 award competition sponsored by the American Institute of Decorators. The award winners, which will be announced at the twenty-first annual conference of this organization, to be held in New York City this week, are pictured here.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- Two Missouri political friends of President Truman will be questioned next week in the investigation of the Government's multimillion dollar grain shortage, it was learned today.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 22 -- Doug Ford, former amateur star from Harrison, N. Y., drove to the half-way lead in the Jacksonville open golf tournament with a seven-under-par 137 today.

The steel industry and the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., will resume negotiations this week on an individual company basis in an ef fort to reach agreement before the union's strike deadline on April 8.

TO use the Henry James phrase, Phyllis Bentley likes to look upon the stories of her native Yorkshire as "the pattern in the carpet" of her writing. In her novels she has spanned three centuries of Yorkshiremen and Yorkshire ways, and now, in these seven short stories, she offers a similar panorama of "life, love and death" in West Riding.
DENVER, March 22 (UP) -- Caterpillar Diesels of Peoria, Ill., upset the Phillips Oilers of Bartlesville, Okla., 66 -- 53, to win the National Amateur Athletic Union basketball tournament tonight.

TRIESTE, March 22 (AP) -- Demonstrators shouting for the return of Trieste to Italy clashed with the police today for the second time in forty-eight hours. As a result, 106 persons, including fifty-one policemen, were injured and sixty-one others were arrested.

THE cloud of yellow bloom on forsythia is a welcome verification of spring. Yet sometimes it seems that forsythia is given space to the exclusion of other shrubs that could add year-around interest and beauty to the property. There are many deciduous shrubs which are valuable for very early bloom or flowers at some other unusual time, or for their fall fruit and foliage.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, March 23 (AP) -- Allied infantrymen smashed a company-size Communist attack in western Korea yesterday. An Eighth Army spokesman said the enemy fled in disorder.

TOKYO, March 22 -- Violence and bloodshed have drawn world attention to the small mountainous island of Koje off the southern coast of Korea, where the United Nations detains Communist prisoners of war. There twice within one month -- most recently on March 13 -- prisoners were killed by Allied guards during outbreaks in the barbed-wire compounds.

A SUCCESSFUL playwright is not necessarily a good biographer. Nor does it follow that he can qualify as a social historian; even less as an art critic. On all counts Mr. Behrman with "Duveen" has hit the jackpot in reverse.

ONE of the productions of the Metropolitan Opera's 1952-53 season will be the original version of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff," in English translation, with a new orchestration of the score by Karol Rathaus.

Taxpayers are fortunate in having recourse to a tribunal like the United States Tax Court for the settlement of tax controversies. Years of experience in this specialized field have qualified the judges of that court to administer tax laws with a marked degree of understanding and equity.

THE recent closing of "Two on the Aisle" at the Hellinger after 279 performances, stirs the dolorous thought that producing revues seems to have become the riskiest of show business ventures. RECENTLY a party of scientists, poking about in the vaults of the British Natural History Museum, made the significant discovery of 192 mummified Egyptian cats -- just where other scientists had mislaid them forty-five years ago. This would never have happened to a dog with his bone -- or a cat with a ball of twine.

AMONG the more unusual flowering plants which may be grown indoors for their colorful flowers are dwarf garden dahlias. Seed sown in early March will produce flowering plants by late May or early June. single packet of either the mixed Unwin or Coltness hybrids produces an interesting assortment of color and form.

GARDENERS who are lucky enough to own a coldframe can be harvesting lettuce and other greens, young onions and radishes by the middle of April. This is possible if seed is planted in the frame as soon as feasible, or certainly before March ends.
SOME bridge players like honor-trick valuation, some prefer a point count, and there are many arguments about the relative merits of the two-methods.

LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- Arsenal, the glamour team of English soccer, which has hopes of winning the league title and the Football Association Cup, drew even with Manchester United in the league standing today. Trailing by a goal at halftime, Arsenal rallied to defeat Middlesbrough, 3 -- 1.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- The Senators took advantage of three errors by the Athletics today to score a 5-1 victory in an exhibition game at Connie Mack Stadium.

BERLINERS this spring, at their own request, are going to hear a concert of contemporary French music, if present plans are followed through. THIS is a brief, tender little story about an old French priest named Father Louis, who a hundred years ago lived at a mission in Brownsville, Tex. For thirty years Father Louis made two trips yearly to the upriver country of the Rio Grande, carrying the sacraments to scattered settlers in the brush country and returning with marriage, confirmation and baptismal certificates.

An effort will be made to change procurement policies in a fashion to employ the skills made idle here by slackness in the building and soft goods trades.

The projected transfer, announced last week, of Vice Admiral C. Turner Joy from Japan to the Naval Academy and the recent transfer of responsibility for the Formosa-Philippine area in the Pacific to Admiral Arthur W. Radford reflect the imminent going into effect of the Japanese peace treaty, naval officers said yesterday.

ALTHOUGH motor vacations have become more popular than ever in this country, and in recent years have become established as a year round activity, the traveler in an automobile still faces inconveniences on his trips, it was brought out at the recent annual meeting of the American Automobile Association's National Touring Board in Washington.

ST. LOUIS -- keystone Camera Company was the only exhibitor at the Master Photo Dealers' and Finishers' convention here last week to make announcements in the medium-price amateur movie bracket. ALBANY, March 22 -- Twenty-five joint legislative committees authorized to spend a total of $639,500 will study such diverse subjects as comic books, insurance rates, horse racing and multiple dwellings during the fiscal year that begins April 1.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 22 (UP) -- James S. Pope, executive editor of The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, yesterday rejected a request from the Jefferson County grand jury not to publish names of witnesses appearing before the jury in criminal cases.

ONE of the most striking evidences of new vitality and broadening expression in the field of art is to be found in the revival of interest in graphic work. For three years Dr. G. M. Ridenour of the National Sanitation Foundation has been seeking the answer to the question: Is a washed dish or garment as clean as it looks? The answer is usually "no."

More American colleges and universities than ever before are now offering courses to state, county and local officials and others interested in public administration. THE Black Hills of South Dakota, though they are a late entry on the list of tourist attractions, probably have more visitors each summer than any other spot in America, if one leaves out such standard attractions as the Grand Canyon and Niagara.

Duchess Di Lanza decides to remove the contented playboy from the battlefield, by sending him on a harmless and well-paid mission beyond the Iron Curtain.

KANSAS CITY, March 22 (AP) -- All-America Clyde Lovellette hit a record-breaking 44 points tonight in pacing the University of Kansas Jayhawks to a 74-to-55 victory over St. Louis University in the National Collegiate Athletic Association regional play-offs.

The World Jewish Congress estimated yesterday that the Jewish population of the Americas had risen from 1,200,000 in 1900 to 6,000,000 in 1951, while that of Europe had fallen from 8,900,000 to 2,700,000 in the same period.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 22 -- Princeton University received $631,860 from its twelfth annual fund drive among alumni, parents and friends. The total, which was announced today, set a record as did the percentage of alumni who contributed.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -Three railroad unions whose strike was halted by a court order two weeks ago filed counter-suits today declaring they were not Government employes. They contended further that if they were the Government should seize the railroads' profits as well as their properties.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Eighty-second Congress, with at least four months remaining for further whetting of investigative appetite, already has out-investigated even the most inquisitive-minded of its predecessors, records indicated today.

Taft supporters in New Jersey began to join forces yesterday in support of Carl E. Ring of Rutherford for the United States Senate as a means of protesting against the alleged "double-cross" of Senator Robert A. Taft by Alfred E. Driscoll, New Jersey's Republican Governor.

ROVANIEMI, Finland -- In the tropics, when the days are muggy and one feels irritable and rather like going out and taking a kick at a palm tree, it is good to dream of cool lakes and Lapland, that lovely region of fells and rivers and reindeer inhabited by the Lapps, stretching across the top of the Scandinavian peninsula through Norway, Sweden, Finland and some distance into the U. S. S. R.

WASHINGTON -- A sizable number of tourists from New Jersey, New York and points north will speed down the New Jersey Turnpike the first week in April to Washington and the annual Cherry Blossom Festival.

PARIS, March 22 -- The Western powers' reply to the Soviet Union's proposal for a German peace treaty will be completed in London in the light of comment by Secretary of State Dean Acheson on the draft discussed in Paris during the last few days by the foreign ministers of Britain and France and the new United States Ambassador to Paris, James C. Dunn.

LYONEL FEININGER celebrated his eightieth birthday last July. He is a tall, spare, dignified man, with a long, ovoid head and beautifully transparent white skin that stretches over high cheekbones. The gauntness of his face, the gentle expression in his blue eyes and the quiet grace of his hands reinforce his likeness to one of the figures on the west portal of Chartres.

TRENTON, March 22 -- Women's organizations of New Jersey are making their final legislative fight this year for an equal-pay-for-equal-work bill before they try a new tactic to gain their objective. A court test case, based upon the constitutional equality guarantee, may be the next move.

Financial markets were overshadowed last week by the steel wage controversy. Tension mounted until Thursday when the strike threat was lifted after the Wage Stabilization Board recommended a substantial wage increase for the steel workers.

CINCINNATI, March 22 -- A corporation being formed by the 845 employes of The Cincinnati Enquirer will seek to enter as a "friend of the court" the hearing April 28 in United States District Court on the proposed sale of The Enquirer to The Cincinnati Times-Star Company.

The salamander, a lizard-like creature, is a favorite with experimental biologists because of its remarkable power of regenerating lost parts. Cut off a salamander's leg and a new one grows. The salamander is hatched out in water, spends its youth on land, then takes to the water again to breed, age and die.

Many barges have been built of aluminum for service in the tropics.

TAMPA, Fla., March 22 -- The Yankees once again became the Bombers of old today as they battered Luke Sewell's Reds, 11 to 8, before a gathering of 3,446 Tampans who doubtless had hoped for something better from their favorite Cincinnatians, who have made this their training base these many years.

S. it supplies the essential raw material for 40 per cent of industry and contributes more to the national income than any other manufacturing industry. Steel prices determine the prices of goods from diaper pins to battleships.

PRINCE ALBERT was charmed with it. William Makepeace Thackeray sat up all night to finish it. Edward FitzGerald, translator of "The Rubaiyat," thought so highly of Marian Halcombe, "the brave girl in the story," that he named a herring-lugger in her honor.

WHILE everything Dr. Lawrence S. Kubie wrote in your section last Sunday is true as ideal practice in psychiatric care, let us be fair to Joseph Kramm, the author of "The Shrike." Mr. Kramm does not depict doctors and nurses as they ought to behave, but as they often do.

CHARLESTON, S. C. -- People who like birds will go a long way to look at them. One of the best places to do just that is Bulls Island, a part of the Cape Romain Wildlife Refuge near here. It has a great many birds, both migratory and native, and is just inaccessible enough to be a little out of the ordinary.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 22 (AP) -- A senior official of the government-owned Trans-Australia Airlines said today he was barred from entering the United States last month and was held a prisoner by United States immigration authorities in Honolulu for thirteen days without explanation.

MOSCOW, March 22 -- The Literary Gazette today linked statements taken from the diary of Maj. Gen. Robert Grow, former United States military attache in Moscow, with charges that the United States was employing bacteriological weapons in Korea and North China.

An analysis of the first preliminary global data on 1951 trade between Communist and non-Communist countries, made available by the United Nations Statistical Office, indicates the Soviet bloc's desperate need for raw materials and machinery from non-Communist countries.

THE village of West Parsley (which is not to be found by that name on any map but which is none the less real and representative) last week elected village officers. So did most of the 500 and more other incorporated villages in New York State.

A GENERATION ago it was the fashion to ridicule people who kept diaries. They were suspected of being too self-conscious and naive; the egotism that is inseparable from a diary was pronounced offensive. Besides, were not most diaries rather stilted and affected -- rather Victorian ?
Making its first appearance in New York, the Oberlin Orchestra under the direction of David R. Robertson, gave a concert yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

THE annual game of musical chairs is over. The last of the vacant conducting posts among the larger orchestras has been filled, for last week the Buffalo Philharmonic appointed Izler Solomon as its "resident conductor" to replace William Steinberg, who is going to the Pittsburgh Symphony.

Leo M. Cherne, in "Biggest Question on TV Debates" (March 2), writes: "The printed word is still the bedrock on which intelligent analysis and study must rest." Goethe, from his own experience, reached a similar conclusion:
SOMETHING new in television programming will be offered New York viewers beginning on April 14 when WOR-TV will raise the curtain on "Broadway TV Theatre."
MILWAUKEE, March 22 (UP) -- "Joe Bowler" rolled a "shadow ball' tonight to open the 49th American Bowling Congress championship tournament at the Milwaukee Arena.
Governor Dewey gave a verbal slap yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri's administration, charging it with needing "new brains" and implying that it plagued the state too much with its financial problems.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 22 -- The household effects and furniture of a woman who was worth $95,000,000 attracted 400 persons at an auction today in the twenty room, granite faced home of the late Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Howland Green Wilks.

The Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association issued yesterday a three-year forecast indicating new peaks in urban and rural gas appliance sales by the end of 1954. Sales of domestic gas ranges in the next three years will exceed 7,000,000 units, the group estimated.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, today turned over the the Department of Justice the findings of a Senate subcommittee studying affairs of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

Developers of the home communities springing up throughout the metropolitan area are being required to install most of the essential improvements without cost to the municipalities, except for a widespread failure to provide street trees and recreational areas, the Regional Plan Association reported yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 23 -- The sick, the lame and the blind are numerous among Israel's immigrants. Some are concentration camp survivors; more, from the ghettos of the Middle East and North Africa, have tuberculosis and skin and eye diseases.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, expressed belief today that if the Korean peace negotiations were not soon terminated on an honorable basis "the American people will demand the application of new means and new methods to the war in Korea."

The Metropolitan Opera enters its next to last week of the season next Monday evening. The first "Parsifal" since 1950 and the season's final performances of "Aida," "Alcestis," "Meistersinger" and "Trovatore" are listed.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Army said tonight no more orders recalling individual reserve officers to active duty would be issued for the rest of this year, with "very few exceptions."

ALBANY, March 23 -- The State Water Pollution Control Board disclosed plans today for a pilot research program aimed at cleaning up the waters of Moriches Bay on Long Island and making them fit for navigation, swimming and shellfish growing.
LOS ANGELES, March 23 -- The withdrawal of President Truman from the California Democratic primary left the state's role in the Presidential sweepstakes in a ferment this week-end.

The United Nations has offered the services of its World Health Organization to help in the fight against epidemic disease in North Korea and Communist China. There is little likelihood that the offer will be accepted since the mere presence of United Nations doctors, like the presence of investigators of the International Red Cross, would promptly blow to bits the Communist-fabricated charge of germ warfare.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 23 -- Brazil's seaports form one of the most critical bottlenecks in her economic development, and the Joint Brazil-United States Economic Development Commission is giving priority to a plan calling for $40,000,000 in loans from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Export-Import Bank for port improvement, Finance Minister Horacio Lafer has stated here.

Eighty - two master contract bridge pairs played the first of two sessions yesterday afternoon in the first scheduled event of the twenty-sixth annual Eastern States Contract Bridge Championships. Simultaneously, 132 non-master pairs completed the first session of the non-master pair championship.

When the Senate last week ratified our Pacific defense pacts, as a related part of the ratification of the Japanese peace treaty, it took a significant forward step. We are moving toward a clearer understanding of the basis upon which peace has to be preserved and liberty defended.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- American Red Cross headquarters announced today that 100 doctors, nurses and staff personnel from all sections had been rounded up for emergency relief duty in the six-state tornado area.
ELKO, Nev., March 23 (AP) -- Snow squalls hampered the dramatic Nevada "haylift" to hungry cattle today, but the weather could not stop Army buldozers from pushing through snow-jammed ranch roads.

The highlight of this week's art exhibitions in the National Academy's 127th annual exhibition of paintings, sculpture and prints, opening at the academy on Thursday. An unusual show opening today at the Museum of Modern Art is that of a sculptural model of a children's playground, designed by the sculptor, Noguchi and Julian Whittlesey.
DETROIT, March 23 (UP) -- Gordie Howe closed his most brilliant National Hockey League season as a Red Wing tonight by scoring three goals as Detroit routed the Montreal Canadiens, 7 to 2.

DETROIT, March 23 -- Carl Stellato, president of Local 600 of the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., demanded today that Walter P. Reuther, president of U. A. W., remove the six-man administrative board that the union's executive board recently placed over the local and its 50,000 members at the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant.

CAIRO, March 23 -- The Egyptian Government announced tonight that the present Chamber of Deputies had been dissolved as of tomorrow. Elections have been set for May 18, and run-off elections in districts where no candidate receives a majority for May 22.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Trade in grains was on a more normal basis last week on the Board of Trade in that the wheat futures took their normal place as the most active grain, with corn second and oats third. Recently the oats trade has been larger than normal, compared with the major cereals.

PARIS, March 23 -- United States encouragement for the organization of a single European market for agriculture was proffered today by Paul R. Porter, director of the European office of the Mutual Security Agency.

Each business day hundreds of thousands of paper bags filled with merchandise are carried from this city's stores by shoppers. The stream of bread bags, candy bags, millinery bags, notion bags, grocers' bags and all other types of bags is prodigious.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 23 -- Leonard Katz of Akron, Ohio, was elected president of the Young People's League of the United Synagogue of America at the closing session of the group's silver jubilee convention here today.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad and stormy petrel of finance for many years in his opposition to Wall Street banking interests, has acquired an investment but not controlling interest, in the Marine Midland Trust Company, a banking concern which, through holding company management, owns a group of smaller banks in upstate New York.

Lillian Braverman bought for investment from a client of Salzman Kaplan, attorneys, the four-story building containing sixteen apartments and occupying a lot 40 by 90 feet at 3166 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, for cash over mortgages amounting to about $40,000.
LONDON, March 23 -- The stock markets are still in the process of sorting themselves out as a result of the problems posed by the budget.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 23 -- Milovan Djilas of the Yugoslav Politburo informed Communist organizations throughout the country today that the restoration of party discipline, which Premier Marshal Tito had hinted last week might involve the expulsion of 100,000 party members, was to be conducted without police action such as is practiced in the Soviet Union.

The attempt to run the Federal Government on an unbalanced budget during the present inflation-threatened period takes away much of the appeal of a good-sounding proposal that comes up repeatedly -- that some new monetary "authority" or "advisory board" could go far toward ending official conflict over money management.

ROME, March 23 -- Pope Pius XII reaffirmed today the right and duty of the Church to teach and interpret divine law not only as it affects the behavior of individuals but also in its bearing upon public, economic and social life and upon the actions of all lawful authorities, both at home and abroad, in peace and in war.

PARIS, March 23 -- Concluding a two-day conference here today, executives of the British Labor and French Socialist parties decided to seek a meeting with the German Socialists to arrive at a common policy of European Socialists on chief problems of the day, notably on German participation in the West's defense.

After an increase in January, the city's welfare caseload decreased in February because of "a substantial pick-up" in employment in the apparel trades, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Doug Ford lived up to the nickname "king of the ground hogs" when he kept his ball low in a strong wind today for a 2-under par 70 that enabled him to remain in front in the Jacksonville Open golf tournament.

Bill Mosienko led the Chicago Black Hawks to victory over the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night in the final game of the regular National Hockey League season. The right wing scored three goals in record-breaking time as the cellar-dwelling Hawks subdued the fifth-place New York sextet. 7 to 6.

Recently 350 men and women, representing seventy-five trade unions, met in Harlem's Hotel Theresa to organize on a national basis the Negro Labor Committee, U. S. A. A local committee had been in existence for about fifteen years and had done a quietly effective job, but now it was decided to broaden objectives and the area of the committee's operations.

Six of the eight teams that will compete in the United States Olympic basketball tryouts, which will start on Saturday at Madison Square Garden and Kansas City, already have been determined. The remaining two berths will go to the finalists in the National Collegiate Athletic Association title tournament at Seattle this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 (UP) -- Lou Sleater, a rookie left-hander, came within a bunt of a no-hit, no-run masterpiece today as the Browns blanked the San Francisco Seals, 2 -- 0, in the second game of a double-header before 5,872 fans.
ST. LOUIS, March 23 (AP) -- A record production year resulted in a total operating revenue of $246,266,000, a new high, for Anheuser- Busch, Inc., in 1951.

The marionette and puppetry art, which has enjoyed such a flourishing revival in children's programs on television, in many instances is becoming distressingly standardized. Variations on Burr Tillstrom's two superb creations, Kukla and Ollie, are to be found under many different aliases.
Ten new films, including importations from England, Italy and Mexico, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

LONDON, March 23 -- Hector Prud'homme of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, on his way back to New York after a fruitless mission to Teheran, said tonight it was clear that there would be no deal at present between the bank and the Iranian Government for the resumption of operations in the Iranian oil industry.

The city is seeking a $25,000,000 increase in assessed valuations on the New York Central Railroad for its use of Park Avenue, which might yield an extra $750,000 a year in special franchise taxes, starting July 1.

OMAHA, Neb., March 23 -- The glitter and glamour of Nebraska's "all star" Presidential primary of four years ago is missing this year. But there is a discernible Undercurrent of sentiment suggesting that the April 1 voting returns may be more meaningful in pointing the way toward nomination of Presidential candidates than were the well-ballyhooed results of 1948.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- The Library of Congress displayed a report today that showed Russia had once considered a scheme to link Siberia and Alaska by means of a fifty-six-mile tunnel under the Bering Sea.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Navy told Congress today that "the trend of issue of paperweights in the Navy is definitely downward * * * as the commissioning of new units decreases in numbers."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- More than half of the 3,500,000 Americans in the armed services and the 200,000 United States civilians now living overseas are expected to lose their right to vote in the forthcoming Presidential election unless many states change the laws and regulations now covering absentee voting.
THE HAGUE, March 23 -- World tin ore production in January was 13,300 long tons against 14,000 in December, the International Tin Study Group reported today.

STOWE, Vt., March 23 -- Competing under the most difficult conditions, rolling fog, intermittent rain and sleet and over an icy "fall-line" course, Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence, 20-year-old Pico Peak housewife, today captured the national slalom and Alpine combined crowns, which added to her downhill triumph yesterday gave her a clean sweep of the women's skiing titles for the second time since 1949.

After an ownership of twenty years, the Roger Williams Hotel at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-first Street has passed to new control through sale of the controlling stock interest in the Roger Williams Hotel Corporation to a group of hotel operators represented by Irving S. Freedman, attorney.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 -- Two hundred years ago on Tuesday Benjamin Franklin and a group of friends, realizing the need and advantages of having mutual protection against destruction of property by flames, founded the Philadelphia Contributionship for the Insurance of Houses from Loss by Fire.

Foes of communism and totalitarianism, including such figures as Cardinal Mindszenty, would be barred from the United States if the McCarran and Walter immigration bills were adopted as now written, Senator William Benton, Connecticut Democrat, declared here yesterday.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 23 (UP) -- Flaming determination carried St. John's to the victory it wanted most last night over mighty Kentucky, the nation's No. 1 team, coach Frank McGuire of the Redmen said today.
A place on the ballot in New York for the Progressive party's candidates for President and Vice President was assured yesterday when the American Labor party announced its endorsement of the slate.
NORWICH, N. Y., March 23 (AP) -- A committee representing cities, villages and counties along the route of the New York, Ontario Western Railroad will press for continuance of the bankrupt line.
Truck dispatching, like railroad dispatching, has become a science.

A strike that would have cut off cooking and heating gas for 1,000,000 families in Brooklyn and Queens was averted yesterday when 1,800 employes of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company voted to accept a wage increase of $5 a week and other benefits.

Gaffney Associates, Inc., sold the six-story apartment house for sixty-six families on plot 130 by 100 feet at 19 to 25 East 213th Street, the Bronx, for cash over a first mortgage of $110,000. The sale was the first involving the building since it was erected in 1928 and was negotiated by Pearce, Mayer Greer, brokers.

ROME, March 23 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi began a swing today through the southern Italian provinces, thus opening a campaign for the municipal elections that will be hold in central and southern Italy in two months. The decree calling for the elections has not yet appeared in the Official Gazette, but it is considered certain that they will take place on May 25.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 23 -- The official newspaper of the Serbian Communist party, The Party Worker, which is urging local officials to force the pace of social rehabilitation of numerous backward minority groups inhabiting many districts of Yugoslavia, reported in its current issue the survival of certain groups whose lives are still regulated by some of the most savage customs and superstitions of the ancient and medieval worlds.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Dave Philley singled with the bases loaded in the ninth inning today and enabled the Athletics to beat the Senators, 3 -- 2, and snap a six-game losing streak.

Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore was honored yesterday for his services to education at the annual education meeting of the Times Square Club held at the Astor Hotel. The club is composed of Master Masons, present or former employes of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Food store advertising moguls may be brought up short next Wednesday night when Max Buck, sales and advertising manager of Kings Super Market sounds off before a dinner of the Metropolitan Advertising Men in the Hotel Bedford.
VIENNA, March 23 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia's Parliament meets tomorrow to approve a new budget that is expected to make that country a major fortress along Russia's 2,000-mile military front in Europe.

PITTSBURGH, March 23 -- Despite a few jittery periods last week the steel industry managed to operate at 102.5 per cent of rated capacity, up half a point from the previous week. In the past, the industry has usually started four days in advance of a strike deadline to get iron out of its blast furnaces and steel from the open hearths to prepare them for banking.
GUATEMALA, March 23 -- Anti-Communists held a great and peaceful demonstration here this morning, and everyone seems to be wondering tonight why the Communists took it so tamely.
LONDON, March 23 -- Two members of the former Labor Government stanchly defended Britain's rearmament program tonight against the attacks of the Labor party's left-wing led by Aneurin Bevan.

Those who have a sentimental fondness for the designs utilized in the English eighteenth century Neo-Classic period might favor a new pattern on sterling silver called Wedgwood. Made by the International Silver Company, the design appears on both flatware and hollow ware pieces.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- The Yankees engaged the Phillies today for the last time this spring and so far as the Bombers are concerned it will be quite all right if they don't ever see them again. Unless, of course, it should be in next October's world series.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 23 (UP) -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur stood today where he was born seventy-two years ago and told 5,000 persons, "For me, the shadows are deepening."

While endorsing the basic concepts of the new zoning proposals on which City Planning Commission hearings begin tomorrow, the Regional Plan Association called yesterday for improvements to cut down further on congestion in overcrowded Manhattan.

GULFPORT, Miss., March 23 (AP) -- Pat Abbott became the first golfer in the six-year history of the Gulf Coast invitational tournament to defend successfully his title by stroking a steady 1-over-par 72 today to win with 279. The Memphis pro picked up $900 in first prize money.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today he would ask the Senate Judiciary Committee to decide whether Attorney General J. Howard McGrath and Newbold Morris should be summoned to tell under oath "the inside story" of how Mr. Morris was chosen to conduct the Federal investigation into corruption in Government.

MANCHESTER, England, March 23 -- Beneath the normal industrial hum of this soot-blackened British textile manufacturing center there is growing anxiety and uneasiness. Fear of idle looms and silent mills is increasing among manufacturers and workers as the curve of unemployment and part-time work rises.

After two weeks of consultations among themselves and with the German Government, the United States, Britain and France have now agreed on the "scope and conditions" of their reply to the recent Soviet note proposing a new Big Four conference to draft a peace treaty with a reunited and rearmed but neutralized Germany.

MILWAUKEE, March 23 (AP) -- Ray Scherbarth, Milwaukee commercial artist, took over first place in the singles event of the forty-ninth annual American Bowling Congress tournament today with a 670 series. He holds a 10-pin lead over Henry Classen, Oshkosh, Wis., in the meet which began yesterday.
Canada, our northern neighbor, is coming of age industrially. Not only in oil, but also in iron, titanium, uranium and lucrative new industries. Canada is beginning to move -- and move fast!

KEY WEST, Fla., March 23 -- Ignoring the bitter protests of the Soviet Union, President Truman began assistance today to refugees from behind the Iron Curtain who would be enrolled in the defense system of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

MADISON, Wis., March 23 -- After a week-end of bucking the snow and sleet storm that covered Wisconsin, the campaign teams of the major candidates for the Presidential nomination entered in the Wisconsin primary were making final preparations today for the home-stretch week leading into the April 1 primary.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- High Administration officials have started already to plan for the liquidation of present emergency control agencies. No target date has been fixed by anyone but gradual disbanding of the agencies created by the Defense Act of 1950 and continued by subsequent renewals of the legislation is expected to start around this time next year.

FORT LEE, N. J., March 23 -- A spectacular fire destroyed today the old Paragon movie studios in this city, once the film capital of the world, with at least $1,000,000 in damage to stage and television sets stored in the barnlike buildings.

DALLAS, Tex., March 23 -- More than 7,000 persons attended the opening yesterday of the sixth annual Greater Dallas Home Show sponsored by the Home Builders Association of Dallas. Early crowds today indicated a larger attendance for the second day.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., March 23 -- Race Chairman Al Webb's Rascal, piloted for most of the term by his 11-year-old son, Skipper, was awarded the Riverside Yacht Club winter-dinghy sailing championship today after stormy weather had forced cancellation of the scheduled season-ending regatta. Bill Ryan's Thistle was named spring series champion.

ZURICH, March 23 -- As the United States Treasury so far has given no specific reason for suddenly blocking all the assets in America of the Swiss banking house. Julius Baer Co., of Zurich, all official quarters in Switzerland declare it would be premature to express any views because they are all apt to seem like resentful criticism.

The New York Knickerbockers conquered the Boton Celtics, 101 -- 97, in a loosely played game before 8,329 fans at Madison Square Garden yesterday to even the series in their National Basketball Association play-off. The deciding contest will be staged in the Boston Garden Wednesday night, and the winner of that one will meet the Syracuse Nationals.

Books by and about Winston S. Churchill, Britain's Prime Minister, are scheduled for publication during the next two months. Houghton Mifflin will issue on April 22 "In The Balance, Speeches 1949 and 1950," by Mr. Churchill. Edited by Randolph S. Churchill, the volume presents the temper of the Prime Minister's thoughts on many questions.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 23 -- This is the story of a little country church that has a hole in its ceiling. It is also a story that shows that while life has changed in many ways in eight-four years, in one way it hasn't: a community can still have a quiet faith in its future.
MILAN, Italy, March 23 (AP) -- Six hundred international educators and other experts said today they did not know what effect Hopalong Cassidy and Buffalo Bill were having on young people.

Norma Holmes, young pianist from Rochester, N. Y., gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall Her program included two works that won prizes in the composition contest held last year by Mu Phi Epsilon national music sorority.

PARIS, March 23 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will clear the way for his early return to the United States with a nation-wide United States television report to the American people on April 2, sources close to the general said tonight.

LONDON, March 23 -- The Federation of Chambers of Commerce of the British Empire reported today that "encouraging results" had been obtained from a campaign to reduce delays in handling cargo in empire ports.

A Lenten find, but a bargain at any time, is the home-made codfish cakes prepared and sold at the 40-year-old Swedish Delicatessen, 424 Amsterdam Avenue. Priced at 4 cents each and ready every Wednesday and Friday morning in the Lenten season, they contain shredded codfish, potato, allspice, eggs and butter.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 23 -- The two Jewish delegations starting negotiations here with the West German Government for material recompense for losses and costs borne by Jews under the Hitler regime have very different technical problems before them.

PANAMA, March 23 -- The board of directors of the Inter-American Press Association ended today a session that started here last Friday after it had admitted twenty-nine new members and had rejected the application of a Communist publication, Hoy of Havana.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 23 -- Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, asserted upon his arrival for a conference with President Truman tonight that he did not know how the steel dispute would be settled, but hoped a strike could be averted as it would have a "frightful" effect on the mobilization program and the economy.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 23 -- Thomas E. Murray of New York, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, was named today as the 1952 recipient of the Laetare Medal, awarded annually since 1883 by the University of Notre Dame to the outstanding United States Roman Catholic layman.

" Dark Legend," the first entry of a promised series at the intimate President, 247 West Forty-eighth Street, will make its bow at 8 o'clock this evening after a quintet of previews there. The author is Helene Fraenkel, a newcomer to Broadway, who fashioned her plot from the book of the same name by Dr. Frederic Wertham, psychiatrist.
Allegations that the New York waterfront is a racket-ridden center of crime were vigorously denied yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 23 (UP) -- A mysterious "intermittent contact" that might have been caused by an unidentified submarine was detected by United States ships during the Navy's recent secret Caribbean maneuvers, Rear Admiral Marshall R. Greer reported today.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 23 (AP) -- Miss Barbara Romack rallied after dropping the first three holes today to battle her way back to a 2-and-1 victory over Miss Pat O'Sullivan in the final of the fiftieth North and South golf tournament.

PETE WHISENANT is a colorful rookie outfielder with the Boston Braves. Any number of clubs were hot on his trail as soon he was graduated from high school, but the husky youngster was wary. The bonus rule was about to go into effect at that time and any athlete receiving more than $6,000 would get the "bonus player" designation along with all the restrictions such a label caused.

An alarming number of teachers is leaving the profession for higher paid jobs and being replaced with less qualified personnel, a Columbia University Teachers College study of school systems in suburban New York and New Jersey shows.

Cardinal Spellman officially opened the thirty-third annual fund appeal of New York Catholic Charities yesterday when he pontificated at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The goal of the appeal this year is $2,414,522.
CHICAGO, March 23 -- Longs did a lot of liquidating last week in March grain and soybean contracts, and the price trend was irregularly downward much of the period.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Ten Senators and sixty-nine Representatives have called on Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, to "reappraise" plans to build a new quartermaster research center at Natick, Mass., which is twenty miles southwest of Boston.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, graying emporor of billiards, still sat on his world three-cushion billiard throne today but hinted he may end the reign that has extended uninterrupted since 1947.

GOA, Portuguese India, March 22 -- Communist propaganda in India emanating from the Soviet Union and Red China appears to be making progress, but in a curious fashion -- two steps forward one step back. While overtures from behind the Iron Curtain on the economic and cultural fronts seem to be gaining headway with the masses the Reds are apparently losing heavily among the more responsible leaders of the country.

BALTIMORE, March 23 (UP) -- William J. Sebald, United States diplomatic chief in Tokyo with the rank of Ambassador, said here tonight that Soviet communism posed both external and internal threats to Japan's security.

Communicants of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, voted at two regular services held yesterday morning to withdraw from the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. because the council's general board, meeting here on Friday, had postponed action on racial segregation.

BERLIN, March 23 -- The United Nations commission to investigate conditions for free German elections concluded its effort in Germany today but decided to wait, probably until the end of April, before reporting failure.

JOSEPH DUVEEN, says S. N. Behrman, was "the most spectacular art dealer of all time." After reading his book, "Duveen,"* I am certain that no one will disagree with that statement. Duveen was indeed spectacular, a one-man phenomenon who dominated the strange world of art merchandising in his time as completely as Joe Louis dominated heavyweight boxing in his, Mr. Behrman's book about Duveen is a hugely amusing collection of extraordinary and often hilarious anecdotes.

At the suggestion of the President, the State Department is issuing today an eighty-page pamphlet designed to reduce to simple terms the principles and aims of the foreign policy of the United States. Mr. Truman has written a foreword explaining that he ordered the booklet written because many Americans are discussing foreign policy, "what it is and what it should be."

SEBRING, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Allen R. Rankin of Columbus, Ohio, won the national senior amateur match-play golf championship tody for the third time. He defeated Eugene Pittman of Washington, 1 up.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- The Salary Stabilization Board announced today that it had launched a nation-wide crackdown on industrial firms accused of "pirating" scarce engineers at illegal salaries from rival companies.
High-rising waistlines, the subject of every important fashion story of the season, highlight the fashions offered today by Patterns of The Times.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 23 -- Harvard University announced today receipt of $2,239,896 in gifts during the final quarter of 1951. Of this amount $1,273,910 was for capital and the remaining $965,986 for current use.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 23 -- Mordechai Oren, high - ranking member of the Mapam party, who told delegates to the Communist World Federation of Trade Unions last December that Israeli soldiers would never fight against the Soviet Union, has been arrested in Prague, the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced today. He is charged with acts against the security of the state and overstaying his visa.

TOKYO, Monday, March 24 (AP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, a rugged but cultured man of battle, wants Americans to be patient while his United Nations Command staff haggles with the Communists over peace in Korea.

The death of Arnold Schuster brings to light again a problem which, I think, concerns all New Yorkers -- the absence of the old-time "cop on the beat." Every thinking citizen of the city realizes that our Police Department is undermanned and overworked; nevertheless, it is a pitiful municipal government which economizes on police protection.

Peace negotiations between the free nations of the world and those dominated by the Communists are necessary to avoid the "deadly menace" of a third world war, Pastor Martin Niemoeller, German church leader, told a congregation here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- The Government announced today that it had revised its rules for the renegotiation of war contracts to take into account the risks a contractor runs of saturating his post-emergency market by accepting defense orders.
Proposals intended to provide for more efficient fire protection for the city, with possible savings running into the millions, were made public yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A new plan for bringing stenographers and clerical workers, now said to be in very short supply, into the labor market was started today in four cities by the Department of Labor and ten national women's organizations.

The aptly named Virtuosi di Roma, under Renato Fasano, made its only local appearance of the season on Saturday evening in Town Hall. The group consists of eleven strings (one of them doubling on the viola d'amore), an oboist and a harpsichordist-pianist. Each of them appears to be a virtuoso; heard together, they produce the most musical of sounds.

Fira Benenson's spring dresses, now being shown at Lord Taylor, emphasize a pleasing fashion combination, namely elegance of design and fabric. To easy, basic silhouettes made of carefully selected fabrics were added subtle, deftly handled details that gave the collection an over-all look of femininity.

A recent dispatch from Germany to THE NEW YORK TIMES quotes the lament of an anonymous Bonn spokesman about Germany's economic plight. Germany's condition, according to this anonymous spokesman, is such as to seriously affect her ability to meet Jewish claims for material losses suffered by Europe's martyred Jewry under the Third Reich.

The Rev. G. Clare Backhurst has been elected rector of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, to succeed the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Shoemaker, Albert O. Stark, senior warden, announced at the morning service yesterday.

MIAMI, March 23 -- Collecting fifteen hits, including four home runs, and four doubles the Dodgers overwhelmed the Red Sox, 14 -- 2, today before 10,013 fans. A lucky double by Ted Williams helped the Bosox to their only runs.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 23 -- Sal Maglie and the left-handed Roger Bowman collaborated today in a 3-hit shutout of Mel Ott's Oakland Oaks and the Giants scored their fifth victory in a row. The score was 5 -- 0.

Rescue workers moved into six Mississippi Valley states yesterday after a series of week-end tornadoes had taken at least 233 lives, caused 1,107 injuries and wreaked property damage estimated in the millions.

TOKYO, Monday, March 24 -- United Nations and Communist truce negotiators in Korea apparently were in agreement today that "confidential" sessions might give staff officers more leeway in working out a compromise on the deadlocked issue of how to exchange prisoners of war.

The foreign exchange market dropped off in volume and price range last week. So far as this applied to British sterling and the Canadian dollar, it did not materially affect either price-wise. Current high levels were maintained. An incident of the sterling market was the fractional narrowing of the spread on forwards as related to the spot rate.

The shades of Mme. Pompadour, an Indian maharajah, medieval lords and ladies and ancient Egyptians will begin today a sort of ghostly chess tournament in the shadow of the Third Avenue "El." The visitor, walking through the glassed door of 937 Third Avenue, near Fifty-seventh Street, will find as fanciful as Alice's -- $30,000 worth of rare chess pieces on display for the next two months at the Julius Carlebach Gallery.

As you say editorially, any citizen who accepts even a "thankless job" in Washington must expect to have his character looked into, in this case by a Senatorial committee. Doesn't it follow, naturally, that questions, unpleasant and even embarrassing, will be asked? I therefore cannot understand why Newbold Morris so bitterly and heatedly resented these questions, resorting even to abuse of his questioners (which, incidentally, you did not see fit to criticize).

The untimely death of the Prime Minister of Ceylon has robbed the whole of the free world of a vigorous leader and a stanch friend. Mr. Senanayake typified the strong bond that can exist between East and West and showed in his own career that nationalism can be deep and genuine and at the same time constructive and cooperative.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation last year had a consolidated net income of $81,898,490 after charges and taxes, equal to $6.78 each on the 12,077,604 capital shares held by the public, according to the annual report for 1951, issued for publication today.

PARIS, March 23 -- The most striking thing about the report of the European Payments Union, which has just been issued, is that, with the exception of France and Britain, all other countries in the Union show a surplus. The most remarkable showing is that of West Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Truman declared today that United States foreign policy was a positive program for peace and freedom. It is "turning back the threat of communism," he said, and the nation is not just sitting by "waiting to put out fires when trouble starts in some faraway place."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The seemingly minor matter of whether to award an Army contract for 1,200 microscopes to an Italian or an American company has become a major issue to the Army, State Department, Mutual Security Agency, several legislative committees and the Republican Senator from New York, Irving M. Ives.

A plea for unity and cooperation among all Christians in fighting the corruption and moral sickness in our community was made yesterday in a sermon by the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
TOKYO, Monday, March 24 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,198, for Sunday's operations:

DE PERE, Wis., March 23 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, moved into eastern Wisconsin today to carry on his two-week pre-primary bid for the support of this state's thirty convention delegates.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period March 17 to 23 are given in the appended tabulation:

BONN, Germany, March 23 -- The Saar issue is again inciting rebellion in Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's government coalition and giving the Socialist opposition badly needed ammunition for another frontal assault on the Government.
Studies of longshore labor in the port of New York show that the number of regular workers as distinguished from extra and occasional waterfront laborers is steadily increasing.

In spite of having experienced recently "many tough moments of chagrin because of the proved corruption of some of its members," as a Mayor's Management Survey consultant remarks, New York City's Fire Department has a fine record of doing its job. Money spent in making such a service first class is an investment in lives and property saved.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Senator Robert A. Taft's campaign chairman in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination declared today that the Ohioan's candidacy had been strengthened in the last two weeks, "despite a lot of sound and fury by the stop-Taft forces."

The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., disclosed yesterday that it expected to win for its 500,000 members in steel fabricating plants wage increases similar to those recommended by the Wage Stabilization Board for the union's 650,000 members in the basic steel industry.

AMSTERDAM, March 23 -- Dutch foreign trade in February showed an expected decrease. Imports were 725,000,000 guilders against 800,000,000 in January and exports 643,000,000 guilders against 746,000,000.

Your issue of March 15 carries an article on the Adirondack forest under "Topics of The Times." Articles of this kind written in New York papers usually belittle both the men working in the woods and the management of woodlands, but your article has made splendid progress in belittling only the management.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors showed its songful side in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. Three of the four contemporary compositions were primarily lyrical in conception, only Piston's Trio being of a developmental, motival nature.

Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" was the New York City Opera Company's presentation yesterday afternoon at the City Center. Camilla Williams had the title role and lesser parts were in familiar hands. Thomas P. Martin conducted.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The National Production Authority today announced that metals have been allocated for 1,458 plant expansion projects in the April-June quarter, representing total building costs of more than $7,000,000,000.

Today's teen-age miss is copying the chic of her older sister. In a recent showing at Martin's of Brooklyn, many of the season's highest fashions had been adapted for this younger-age group. Here was the spencer jacket, high-waisted Empire line, middy look and full-skirted stiff silk coat.

FORT HOOD, Tex., March 23 -- Forced off its timetable by bad weather, the Eighteenth Air Force today ordered its fleet of troop-carrier aircraft on a round-the-clock schedule to complete its airlift of the Thirty-first (Dixie) Division from South Carolina to this site of the forthcoming Exercise Long Horn.

MADRID, March 23 -- Lincoln McVeagh, United States Ambassador-designate to Spain, arrived here today by automobile from Lisbon. He will be received tomorrow by Alberto Martin Artajo, Spanish Foreign Minister in a preliminary conversation during which he will request an audience with Generalissimo Francisco Franco to present his letters of credence. In all likelihood the audience will take place Thursday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 23 -- The last of three volumes indexing all the books printed between the years 1641 and 1700 in England, Scotland, Ireland, Wales and British America, as well as English books published elsewhere during that period, has just been completed after twenty years of research.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- In the role of stand-in for his superior, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Chief of Staff to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, will urge Congress tomorrow to support the Administration's $7,900,000,000 foreign aid program.

The Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, spiritual director of the Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Society of New York, protested yesterday against the Metropolitan Opera's presentation of Verdi's "Don Carlo" on the ground that it depicted a Roman Catholic cleric as an accomplice in an assassination.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 23 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's plan to introduce legislation to override the appeal court's verdict that the entrenched clauses of the constitution are binding would open the doors of Parliament to the use of force or fraud in procedure, according to Julius Lewin, constitutional lawyer and senior lecturer at Witwatersrand University.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman, showing a group of women reporters through the refurbished White House today, neatly sidestepped the same question ruled out by her husband when he was tour conductor recently for the male White House correspondents.

TEANECK, N. J., March 23 -- Ch. Rancho Dobe's Storm, the majestic black and tan Doberman pinscher owned by Mr. and Mrs. Len Carey of Greenwich, Conn., became the best-in-show winner of another major all-breed competition tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration is planning to require builders to submit copies of detailed plans and specifications to veterans who purchase homes under G. I. home loans while the houses are still in the prospective construction stage.

A vacant irregular plot about 195 by 180 feet on the west side of Beach Twenty-fifth Street, between Far Rockaway Boulevard and Beach Channel Drive, in Far Rockaway, Queens, has been sold by Yetta Goldenberg to Forest-Shire Apartments, Inc., for improvement with eight dwellings.

Three men died instantly yesterday when they were struck down at the northwest corner of Broadway and 207th Street in an accident involving a heavy tank truck, a lighter truck and two automobiles. The mishap, in which three women were injured, occurred at 3 P. M., only a few minutes before the intersection was thronged by children released from schools in the Inwood section.

BUFFALO, March 24 (AP) -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, former director of the National Bureau of Standards, said tonight a number of distinguished scientists had been kept out of the United States by the workings of the Internal Security (McCarran) Act.

The flush money market, whose sway over the March quarterly tax remittance period has confounded most professional observers, continues to show considerable vital tenacity. A tendency last week for yields on Treasury bills to rise did not carry through yesterday, with the result that long bills are still on a yield basis of about 1 1/2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's special message on immigration sent to Congress today:

Out of a Congressional investigation yesterday came statements by officials of the New York Stock Exchange that activities of the Securities and Exchange Commission have not reduced trading volume and that the laws that it administers are eminently desirable.

BONN, Germany, March 24 -- Federal Germany cannot and must not recognize the present Government of the Saar, a spokesman for the Christian Democratic Union, leading party in the Government coalition, declared today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Supreme Court paved the way today for another trial of William W. Remington, former Government economist, on new charges that he perjured himself concerning Communist party associations.

Tommy Ryan Eboli's petition to regain his license as a boxing manager was dismissed on technical grounds yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder. The court also threw out a motion by attorneys for Rocky Castellani, middleweight boxer from Luzerne, Pa., seeking release of $2,313, representing one-third of the purse for a fight with Ernie Durando in the Garden on Jan. 11.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 24 -- The fourth meeting of the Colombo Plan's Consultative Committee, called to review the results of the first year of the six-year program of aid to Southeast Asia, opened here today.

A reunion of the original members of the American Volunteer Group who fought as "The Flying Tigers" in China is being organized for next summer to mark the tenth anniversary of the squadron's disbandment.

TRENTON, March 24 -- The controversial bill for a public referendum on legalizing bingo games for religious, welfare and service organizations' benefits was reported out today to the New Jersey Senate.

The stock market edged yesterday into a dead-end position. Nothing decisive came out of the session and business slumped to the smallest since early in the month. The numbers of stocks either advancing or declining were almost in perfect balance.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 24 (Reuters) -- A new racial controversy over the relationship between native Maoris and Europeans has been aroused by an anthropological expert's warning against the development of a "brown proletariat."

RUTLAND, Vt., March 24 -- This city went "all out" today in welcoming home its favorite daughter, Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence, who recently became the first American skier to capture two Olympic gold medals and who swept all three national alpine championships. All along Center Street and the side blocks store windows and banners carried the message "Hi Andy, welcome home."
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- President Truman today nominated Angier Biddle Duke of New York to be Ambassador to El Salvador. He succeeds Howard Tewksbury, who recently resigned.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, with prices 9 points lower to 3 points higher than on Friday.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate today approved an appropriation of $100,000 for an investigation of the Office of Alien Property.
Senator Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts said yesterday that the Korean War must be ended conclusively as soon as possible, and by the United States alone if necessary.

Another collection of the kind of straightforward, uncomplicated contemporary furniture popular for today's small apartments has become available through decorators from a new showroom, Allan Gould Designs, 166 Lexington Avenue. The group, all of it designed by Mr. Gould, includes storage and seating pieces, dining and occasional tables, all moderate in price.

An increase in serious and complex personal and family problems among the 26,491 families in New York that turned for help last year to the Community Service Society was noted yesterday in its 103d annual report.
Arturo Toscanini is 85 today, and his phenomenal career as a conductor keeps rolling on.

While Senator Humphrey's labor subcommittee continues to seek some better method of dealing with communism in unions than the Taft-Hartley Act provides, it is worth noting that under its own rules Walter P. Reuther's United Automobile Workers (C. I. O.) appears to be coping successfully with the problem of Communist infiltration.
Commodity futures prices moved irregularly yesterday. Hides, vegetable oils and wool lost ground. Rubber, cocoa and sugar gained. Coffee was mixed.

Three prints from Europe, patterns printed on a durable material and in a metallic-touched design, are included in a new collection of contemporary drapery and upholstery fabrics available through decorators at Scalamandre Silks, Inc., 598 Madison Avenue.

The model for the children's playground, which stimulated controversy between a group of New Yorkers, who offered $75,000 to the United Nations for its construction, and Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who rejected the plans, was put on view yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art.

City Council President Rudolph Halley announced last night that he would cast his three votes in the Board of Estimate against all of the "nuisance taxes" the city was authorized to levy in its recent "package" deal with the Legislature.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 24 -The Jewish Agency announced tonight that it would repatriate 125 Indian Jewish immigrants after the group, which had staged a sitdown strike outside the agency's headquarters last December, returned and resumed the strike this morning.

Several dinner parties will be given before the performance of "One Bright Day" tonight at the Royale Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for Grosvenor Neighborhood House. The beneficiary maintains recreational and educational activities for adults and young people.

LONDON, March 24 (Reuters) -- Czechoslovakia's bill for defense and state security during the coming financial year shows an increase of 43.9 per cent over last year's figure, under the new Soviet-style budget, details of which were disclosed by the Prague radio tonight.

Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther's testimony yesterday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee probably forecast the end of one chapter and the opening of another in two distinguished careers. It also marked a crossroads in the United States' foreign aid policies.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The question whether Presidential electors shall be forced to support nominees of a national political convention or vote for whom they please, will be argued before the Supreme Court next Monday, under an order issued today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 24 -- The die is cast at second base as far as the Giants are concerned. No one was surprised today when Manager Leo Durocher annouced that Whistlin' Davey Williams would take over the post vacated by Eddie Stanky.

An interesting sidelight of a recent luncheon given for food editors by the United States Brewers Foundation was a superb cheese and beer mixture spread on the crackers that accompanied cocktails. Made with a sharp American cheddar, it suggested the many delectable and varied sandwich fillings and spreads that may be done with this comparatively economical, high-in-protein cheese.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 25 (AP) -- Two corporals with the United States Twenty-Fifth Division in Korea have been converting obsolete tank engines into powerful new models without plans and without factory tools.

SAIGON, Indo-China, March 24 (AP) -- The French High Command said today it had heard of no Chinese Communist troops crossing into Indo-China. But it feels sure the Chinese are giving plenty of aid and counsel to the Red-led Vietminh in their fight against the French.
The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus will open in Madison Square Garden on the night of April 4. Thereafter two performances will be given each day through May 11.

William Sutton and Thomas Kling were identified in Queens County Court yesterday, for the second time, as two of the three men who took $63,942 from the Sunnyside branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company in Queens on March 9, 1950.

In an effort to help meet the "critical" shortage of engineers, 25,000 posters urging young persons to enter the field were mailed yesterday to secondary schools throughout the country. The posters, intended for school bulletin boards, were prepared at the request of industry by the Engineering Manpower Commission of the Engineers Joint Council.

PARIS, March 24 -- The French Cabinet completed action tonight on a series of measures destined to restore confidence in the country's financial structure and in its currency. Tomorrow the proposals will meet their first parliamentary test when the National Assembly's Finance Committee takes them up preparatory to floor debate, which may begin Saturday.
The grim task of burying and rebuilding went on yesterday in the rural areas Of the six Mississippi Valley states that were devastated by the series of week-end tornadoes.

Operations last year of Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc. resulted in a record net profit of $10,148,000 of which $7,600,000 represents tax-deferred deposits made in reserve funds chiefly for investment in new and replacement ships, Albert V. Moore, president, reported yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, March 24 -- The Congress working committee, the highest authority of the governing party, today named President Rajendra Prasad as the Congress party candidate to succeed himself and Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan as the Congress party's nominee for vice president. The elections will be held in the second week of April.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- George Jessel is breathing easier now, having finally found the right man in David Wayne to play the role of Sol Hurok in the musical biography of the impresario, "Tonight We Sing."

PARIS, March 24 -- The Neo-Nazi movement in West Germany increased in 1951 and constitutes a serious obstacle to the development of democracy in that country, the American Jewish Committee declared here today.
LAUREL, Md., March 24 (AP) -Alan T. Clarke's Ala Mowlee and the Rainbow Ranch's Town Sheik shared honors on the racing program today, each winning a division of the Patuxent Purse.

Negotiations were completed yesterday for the occupancy of the former Dun Bradstreet Building, a sixteen-story structure at 290 Broadway, by the New York Division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The F. B. I. is now quartered in the United States Courthouse at Foley Square.

For the past four years, boxers competing in the intercity Golden Gloves tournament between squads from New York and Chicago have battled to 8-all ties. Last night, however, the squad from the Windy City defeated New York, 9 -- 7, in the twenty-fifth anniversary card of the competition.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 24 -- Thousands of persons crowded into the square in front of the City Hall today to demand the resignation of the Malan Government. Along with meetings held elsewhere, this demonstration protested against the threat by Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan to curb the powers of the Supreme Court because of its invalidation of a law placing Cape colored persons (those of mixed races) on separate electoral rolls.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 24 -- Commenting on the Italian riots at Trieste, Borbia, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, warned the Italian Government today that it would end up as a victim of its own policy instead of obtaining any concession from Yugoslavia if it continued to pursue its present hostile course.
DETROIT, March 24 -- Diego Rivera's "Age of Steel" frescoes in the Detroit Institute of Arts received a clean bill today from the city's Art Commission for the second time in nineteen years.
Freight rates on the bulk movement of grain from North American ports to Antwerp and Rotterdam were reduced from $14 to $12.50 a ton yesterday by the North Atlantic Freight Conference Lines.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, criticized tonight the recommendations of the Wage Stabilization Board for settling the steel dispute. His attitude raised the possibility that the members of the board would resign.
ROME, March 24 -- A dozen stuents and ten policemen were injured and many more bruised and hurt during the course of day-long demonstrations in Rome for the return of Trieste to Italy.

The Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet from London will open its first New York engagement tonight at the Warner Theatre, at Broadway and Forty-seventh Street. The theatre, normally devoted to the showing of motion pictures, has temporarily suspended its policy for the two-week engagement of the British company.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Mme. Maurice Petsche, widow of the one-time French Minister of Finance, who was sent to this country by her Government "to tell what life in France is really like," spoke today in refutation of what she considered the most common errors about her countrymen.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- Membership of the Communist party in this country has dropped to 31,608, but many of its leaders have gone underground and it is "as much if not a greater threat" than the 1941 Nazi fifth column, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation reports.

Hundreds of the biggest names in show business joined in paying tribute to singer Jane Froman yesterday by attending a testimonial luncheon given in her honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by United Service Organizations-Camp Shows, Inc.

OCONTO, Wis., March 24 (UP) -- Rescuers who had searched forty-three hours for three small children who vanished in lonely woods during a blizzard found one of them alive and two frozen to death near Lakewood today in a sequel to the week-end's storms.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 -- The Soviet Union failed again to expel the representatives of Nationalist China from a United Nations meeting.

LONDON, March 24 -- A team of United States Air Force, Army and Navy officers headed by Lieut. Gen. Lauris Norstad, commander of Allied Air Forces in Central Europe, are attending a secret fiveday conference on the air defenses of Western Europe that met at Old Sarum, Salisbury, today.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 25 -- Behind an almost complete news blackout, United Nations and Communist truce negotiators worked today on a rough outline for a solution of the problem of exchanging prisoners of war in Korea, Item 4 of the armistice agenda.

Back in the news again is Pierre La Mure's dramatization of his own novel, "Moulin Rouge." Last October, Jose Ferrer reached the point where he fixed a production schedule for the work, but found himself too preoccupied with other projects to go through with the presentation.

MADRID, March 24 -- An officially inspired editorial said today that, because of the complex questions involved, the negotiation for a United States-Spanish bilateral agreement might take "a long time"

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 24 -- The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany asked the West German Government today for $500,000,000 as part reimbursement for Jewish property expropriated by the Nazi Government.

CAIRO, March 24 -- King Farouk issued a decree today extending indefinitely the state of martial law in Egypt. This followed yesterday's decree dissolving Parliament and calling for new elections in mid-May.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- American Red Cross headquarters estimated today that more than 2,000 families in the stricken tornado area would seek help from the organization in repairing and rebuilding their homes.

City traffic authorities have urged the Board of Estimate not to extend the dime fare for private bus operators beyond next Monday unless they agree to waive franchise restrictions that now bar one- way avenues. The specific aim of the Traffic Department's plea is to revive the plan for conversion of Seventh and Eighth Avenues, which was blocked last month by objections raised by the New York City Omnibus Corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Federal income taxes must be paid on money obtained by extortion, even at the point of a gun, the Supreme Court ruled in a 5-to-4 decision today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- Herbert W. Maley, 36 years old, of Victoria, Australia, an official of Trans-Australia Airlines, may not enter this country because he is a "member of an excludable class," the Justice Department announced today.

Frank Costello would like to be retried without a jury on charges of contempt of the Senate. The Government consented yesterday, and Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan indicated he would approve the gambler's application on Monday when the trial starts.
