TOKYO, Tuesday, March 25 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,199 for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday), Eastern standard time:

There are certain things that are excellent possessions for any household. Such a device as a stove may be regarded as an essential possession, or it will be when cooked meats again appear on a budget now morosely stressing raw fruits and vegetables.

READING, Pa., March 24 (UP) -- A metal strong box in a bedroom dresser drawer in the modest home of a widow was looted of $125,300 during the week-end but $85,258 in cash was recovered here today from a cardboard box hidden beneath a pile of cement building blocks.

TRENTON, March 24 (AP) -- The Supreme Court of New Jersey today disbarred Abraham J. Isserman, formerly of Newark and now living on the West Coast, for contemptuous conduct during the trial of eleven top Communists in New York in 1949. Isserman, one of defense counsel, had been convicted of contempt.

Cotton has become a fashion "must" this year and, in this field, the biggest news is denim. This fabric, which once was confined to working clothes, is now a real city slicker. It appears in sophisticated colors for town dresses and suits; it goes merry at night in informal party clothes and in stripes or checks, it becomes svelt and chic. Yet it still appears in bold awning stripes and colors for beach and play.

" Nobody wants to kiss me, and the kids back home tease me and call me funny-face" was the plaint of Martha Stamatiadou, a 7-year- old girl maimed in the Greek civil war, when she arrived yesterday on the Greek liner Nea Hellas.

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet declared yesterday that his senior officers emphatically opposed a recommendation by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey that the number of engine and ladder companies in the city be reduced by forty-nine. They contend, according to Mr. Grumet that such a move will result in less fire protection and greater hazards.

SEATTLE, March 24 (AP) -- An 18-year-old college honor student died yesterday of an injection of bacterially contaminated blood given during an experiment connected with war research on blood preservation by the University of Washington.

NEWARK, March 24 -- Newark Airport, closed since Feb. 11 after three plane crashes that took 119 lives, may be reopened for limited military operations within a few weeks, it was indicated today after a meeting at City Hall between assistant Air Force Secretary Edwin V. Huggins and officials of Newark and Union County communities.

RANGOON, Burma, March 24 -- It is evident here that the presence of Chinese Nationalist forces in the east Burma state of Kengtung has intensified both the internal and external menace to the security of Burma.

FORT HOOD, Texas, Tuesday, March 25 -- Directed at the top level by former key commanders of the critical days of the Korean war, the largest ground and air maneuver to be waged since World War II began in the early morning hours here today.

VALHALLA, N. Y., March 24 -- One hundred maintenance and operational employes of the New York City Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity were on a modified sit-down strike today in Westchester and Putnam Counties, contending that they received only the pay of laborers and would perform no work except that of laborers.

The Standard Oil Company of California yesterday reported for 1951 consolidated net income of $173,341,211 after charges and taxes, equal to $6.05 each on the 28,673,192 capital shares outstanding. This compared with $150,804,105 or $5.26 a share in 1950.

W. Walter Williams, Washington State Republican chairman, who is taking over the direction here of the Citizens for Eisenhower headquarters at the Hotel Marguery, arrived here yesterday afternoon optimistic about Eisenhower delegates in his own state.

On record sales of $188,836,986, the Cannon Mills Company and its subsidiaries nearly doubled earnings last year although taxes more than tripled the year before, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- N. Snellenberg Co., one of the large Central City department stores here, announced today that it plans to institute Monday evening shopping hours next week. "One of the reasons for the decision is to arrest the deterioration that is taking place in the retail business in the downtown area," said Alfred Blasband, executive head of the store.

The Medical Society of the County of New York adopted a resolution last night favoring the expansion of Social Security to include self-employed physicians. The New York group is believed to be the first medical society to go on record in support of such an extension.

PARIS, March 24 -- Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, suggested today that the aim of the Soviet Union was to make of Germany an arsenal for use of the Soviet bloc, Germany getting raw materials from Eastern Europe and exporting finished goods to it.

TRENTON, March 24 -- A Superior Court order, obtained today by Lloyd B. March, Secretary of State, directed county clerks in New Jersey to halt printing ballots bearing the name of Senator Robert A. Taft for the April 15 Republican Presidential preference primary.

Harry Gross, the Brooklyn bookmaker serving twelve years for contempt and conspiracy, testified yesterday in the departmental trial of a police lieutenant that he had been apprised in advance of "every legal wiretap in Brooklyn and New York."

Your fine editorial of March 14 censuring the conduct of the Senate permanent investigating committee in their treatment of Newbold Morris, investigator of corruption in Government, might bear further comment.

Small Business Must Survive. Let's Act Together." That was the heading of an unusual full-page ad in THE NEW YORK TIMES, yesterday, placed by the Jnited Action for Small Business, Inc., 35 West Fifty-third Street. The ad made a plea for small business men to join the organization, which plans to do more than just "beef" about the plight of small business under the defense economy.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The Government today authorized major increases in production of passenger cars, washing machines and other consumer goods after July 1.

Powerful arguments for the $7,900,000,000 mutual security program are being laid before Congress by the man who, next to General Eisenhower, is most familiar with the issues and problems involved. He is General Gruenther, General Eisenhower's chief of staff and potential successor.

PARIS, March 24 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman reversed himself today, declaring that German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer "strictly speaking had not recognized the Saar Government and the Saar regime."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 24 -- Thirty-five Westchester County officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People demanded tonight that George M. Fanelli, District Attorney of Westchester, ask for a first-degree murder indictment when the grand jury meets tomorrow to consider evidence against a former Westchester County Parkway patrolman, Stanley S. La Benskey, accused of shooting two Negro brothers in Yonkers last Thursday morning.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- Bob Slaybaugh, a rookie pitcher for the Cardinals, received a serious injury to his left eye when he was knocked unconscious by a line drive in batting practice today.
DETROIT, March 24 (AP) -- Many auto industry heads are counting on a further upturn in car and truck production during this year's third quarter.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- American banks must be ready to extend consumers' use of installment credit when the nation's industry has filled the demands of defense mobilization and turns to civilian production, Thomas C. Boushall, president of the Bank of Virginia, warned here today.

The 1952 Eastern States masters pairs contract bridge championship was won by Dr. William V. Lipton of New York, and Ira Rubin of the Bronx early yesterday morning. At the close of the second and final session, played at the McAlpin Hotel, the winners finished with 397 points, well ahead of an eighty-two-pair field.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 -- Five out of six delegations voicing preliminary comments today in the United Nations Trusteeship Council on the annual report from the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands, submitted by the United States as administering authority, reflected an unusual degree of gratification with the rate of progress in the area.

" The Counterfeit Revolution," a new book by Sidney Lens, is an analysis of the sources of Stalinist strength. It will be published tomorrow by Beacon Press of Boston. Mr. Lens, who traveled through twelve countries in Europe to collect material for his book, explains why the Kremlin is able to attract some rich and famous and even intelligent men to serve its tyranny.

A public marketing of $90,000,000 of obligations of the Service Pipe Line Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Standard Oil Company of Indiana, is being planned, J. L. Burke, president of the issuing company said yesterday.
There was much befuddlement in Federal Court yesterday as Judge Edward Dimock tried to get things in order so that the trial of sixteen secondary Communist leaders might get under way on Monday.

The painting, "Epoch," by Ben Shahn, appraised at $5,000, which disappeared on Feb. 28 en route from the Philadelphia Museum of Art to the Downtown Gallery in New York and was reported on March 21 by the Railway Express as "stolen, lost or misplaced," was discovered yesterday. It had been in the basement storage vaults of W. C. Budworth Sons, picture shippers at 424 West Fifty- second Street.

Tornadoes struck with savage, destructive force in six states over the week-end. Well over two hundred lives were lost, more than a thousand persons were injured, the property damage went high into the millions of dollars. Comfortable and safe in our homes or places of business hundreds of miles away, we can scarcely picture the tragedy, the suffering, the confusion and despair that follow in the wake of such sudden rampages of nature.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 24 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has informed his top assistants at the Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe that he regards the initialing of a European defense treaty -- involving German rearmament and the start of European armed integration -- as the No. 1 priority on his military docket.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- The New York and Illinois State Athletic Commissions today signed a reciprocal agreement aimed at driving the hoodlum element out of boxing.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 24 -Henry E. Bothfeld, 21-year-old junior from Wellesley Hills, Mass., who led Princeton's hockey team in scoring this winter, has been elected captain of the 1952-53 varsity sextet, it was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics at Princeton.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Hyman Harvey Klein, wealthy Baltimore liquor dealer, denied today under oath that he even knew Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire and disclaimed any knowledge of intervention by the Senate Republican leader in a $7,000,000 tax claim against him.

MADISON, Wis., March 24 -- The Wisconsin primary campaign, the outcome of which is important to the political futures of Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold E. Stassen in the Republican party, moved into its final week today in a new burst of oratory and editorial comment.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 24 -- The American public will spend 30 per cent more for food in 1960 if offered desirable items, food executives were told here today.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Norfolk Southern Railway Company today sought authority to make a two-for-one split-up of its no-par value common stock.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 24 -- Home run clouts by Bob Cerv and by Gil McDougald gave the Yankees a 3-1 victory over Tommy Holmes' Braves today.

MEXICO CITY, March 24 -- The Mexican Army's only motorized brigade moved into the city of Oaxaca early today after clashes between Government guards and people protesting a new state tax law had left two dead and a score wounded during a week-end of disturbances.

Robert Rudolph has sold the six-story apartment house accommodating seventy-one families at 178 Rockaway Parkway in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn to an investing group in a transaction negotiated by the Advance Realty Company as broker.

SEATTLE, March 24 (AP) -- St. John's and Illinois arrived today for the resumption of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament after a roundabout plane ride. The teams will meet in the opener of the semi-final card at 10:30 P. M. (E.S.T.) tomorrow. Kansas will oppose Santa Clara in the second game.

LONDON, March 24 -- Britain, France and the United States will deliver to the Kremlin tomorrow their replies to the Soviet Union's proposals for early four-power negotiations on a p.eace treaty for a united Germany. Some time after delivery the notes will be made public.
TRENTON, March 24 -- Three bright red, double-decker buses brought a bit of Great Britain to Trenton today in a goodwill tour.

A score or more of ships operated by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., were threatened yesterday with indefinite immobilization as the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., called a strike of licensed deck personnel on all of that company's vessels.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 24 -- Dr. Frank P. Graham, United Nations Kashmir negotiator, is scheduled to leave here by air tomorrow for Geneva to draw up his report on the demilitarization of Kashmir.

ONE week from today the New York racing season will open at Jamaica, gathering momentum for a series of turf classics. But the British racing season already is rushing toward its first climax, the most terrifying horse race of them all, the Grand National.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today accused Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, of making "deliberate misstatements" regarding the Camp Crowder grain storage cases and of condemning the Agriculture Department for following a policy of which the Senator was "one of the chief architects."

ST. LOUIS, March 24 -- James P. Finnegan, former Collector of Internal Revenue and one-time close friend of President Truman, today was sentenced to two years in Federal prison and fined $10,000 for misconduct while in office. He was released on $5,000 bond pending an appeal.

PARIS, March 24 -- At the meeting of the Western European Finance Ministers here Thursday to decide the future of the European Marshall Plan Council, the United States Government will make a strong plea that the Council should not only be maintained but should become in Europe the economic and financial instrument of the Atlantic community.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- Doug Ford and Sam Snead tied for the Jacksonville open golf title today; then two hours later Snead forfeited his chance at the top $2,000 because of an out of bounds ruling in his favor.

ALTHOUGH barbarous peoples have produced a number of immortal works of literature such as "Beowulf" and the Icelandic sagas, the peaks of human culture have always been identified with urban civilizations. The cities may depend upon rural regions for their food and for the constant stream of talented and ambitious newcomers which keeps all urban civilizations vigorous, but the cities themselves are essential expressions of a high state of civilization.

LONDON, March 24 -- A telegram from the British Foreign Office went off to Washington tonight after Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden had received the Italian Ambassador Manlio Brosio to discuss the anti-British riots in Trieste.

I have wondered why there hasn't been some editorial discussion of the so-called "automobile use tax" which the Mayor intends to impose on the citizens of New York City. When you attempt to analyze the possible theory behind this tax you encounter incongruities that show its absurdity

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,200,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated March 27 and to mature June 26 were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 24 -Two Roman Catholic Church leaders denounced today what they termed an insidious tendency in this country to "secularize" the marriage bond by substituting human law for divine law in family relationships.
LONDON, March 24 -- Three abstract paintings displayed today at the Tate Gallery are hanging sideways because their owner prefers them that way.

BONN, Germany, March 24 -- The United States, Britain and France, in their replies to the Soviet proposals on Germany, will insist that a united Germany must be guaranteed the freedom to join in any multi-national military organization for the defense of Western Europe such as the European Defense Community or the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a highly placed British official said today.

ATLANTIC CITY. March 24 -- When the "terrible teens" conflict with the "roaring forties" on the battleground of the home, the family physician should be called upon to add the healing of emotions to his responsibilities. This was suggested here today at the opening of the fourth annual meeting of the American Academy of General Practice.

" Murder in the Cathedral," which arrives at the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux, is today's lone film newcomer. The British-made version of T. S. Eliot's poetic play about the murder of Thomas a Becket, for which Eliot wrote the screen play, was produced and directed by George Hoellering.

LONDON, March 24 -- Apart from British Government securities, nearly all sections of the London stock market closed on a dull note today. Losses in industrials, while widespread, were light except in textile and shipping issues, which were sharply marked down.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- It is General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's opinion that "in some things * * * we have drifted too far to the so-called Left."

Surely there is no champion in the history of sports who has achieved the longevity of Willie Hoppe. At the age of 64 Hoppe has just defended successfully his world title for three-cushion billiards, which he has held without interruption since 1947.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina declared last night that it was essential, particularly in time of crisis and danger, that the courts remain wholly free of control or influence from the Executive Branch of government.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 24 -Mr. Wilson left here this afternoon with a formula for settling the steel wage dispute that he said would be placed in operation after it was discussed with stabilization officials and parties to the dispute.

At the urging of Charles E. Wilson, director of Defense Mobilization, Mayor Impellitteri yesterday directed that the city's smoke control regulations be relaxed for six months to permit auto wreckers to resume the burning of old automobiles.

BABYLON, L. I., March 24 -- Three sailboat enthusiasts lost their lives, with a fourth presumed lost, in the state boat channel between Cedar and Grass Islands in the Great South Bay yesterday afternoon a few hours after they started to sail two fifteen-foot sloop-rigged sailboats to Babylon from a Copiague boatyard.

MOSCOW, March 24 -- Pravda branded as "ridiculous" today suggestions that the Soviet Union was opposed to holding free elections in Germany. Furthermore, it charged that the United States was seeking almost any pretext to reject the Soviet proposals on Germany because it knew only too well that they provided the basis for a negotiated settlement of the German question.

The Duquesne Light Company, Pittsburgh and surrounding territory with electricity, is stepping up its over-all $150,000,000 expansion program in order to meet the growing demands for service. Last year, according to the utility's annual report, $30,000,000 was spent on new facilities and improvements.
A comprehensive exhibition of the work of Paul Cezanne, whom many critics consider the greatest painter of the nineteenth century, will open April 4 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Miss Elizabeth Moesch, 50-year- old retired school teacher, was freed yesterday of a charge of cruelty to animals after Magistrate Jack L. Nicoll had been informed that there had been progress in the cleaning of Miss Moesch's home and dogs were no longer on the premises. She lives in a four-story brownstone house at 218 West 122d Street.

The only way one can tell that Arturo Toscanini is 85 today is to check the calendar. No one could guess it from his music. The leanness, the unflagging vitality, the rhythmic verve, which are the hallmarks of a Toscanini performance, are the attributes of a young man. But in his art Toscanini is a young man.

There is only one logical alternative to ownership by private investors and that is government ownership and domination, Jackson Martindell, president of the American Institute of Management declared yesterday before the Federation of Women Shareholders at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 24 -- President Truman sent a letter today to Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, directing him to end all emergency credit controls on bond issues of state and local governments.

While most materials used by roofing, siding and insulating contractors are in better supply than in the last year, credit needed to finance the operations of the industry is tight. Even aluminum -which has been difficult to obtain -- is in freer supply, according to manufacturers of windows and awnings at the tenth annual convention and exhibition of the National Established Roofing, Siding and Insulating Contractors Association, Inc., known as Nersica.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Striking at an increased flow of political propaganda from Soviet bloc embassies and consulates in this country, the Senate voted without debate or dissent today to deprive diplomatic and consular officers of their immunity from registration, from full accounting for and labeling of their products, and from the stiff penalties under the Foreign Agents' Registration Act.
TRENTON, March 24 -- Legislation designed to go as far as one state can to guard against disastrous plane crashes near airports was mapped tonight by a New Jersey legislative committee.
THE first channel bass of the season to be taken from the surf on the Outer Banks was brought in by Lafayette Midgett of Buxton, who took a 42-pounder at Hatteras Point.
Suggestive of tropical climates are the motifs and warm colorings of new and small collection of patterns on wallpaper and fabric, now on view at Altman's.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Aside from the issues of constitutionality and good faith that have arisen in the Union of South Africa between the Government of Prime Minister Malan and the highest court of the nation, there is an aspect of pertinent interest to Americans involved on both sides of the effort to legislate President Truman's so-called civil rights program.

President Truman's special message of March 6 urging Congress to authorize $7,900,000,000 for weapons and materials causes me to call attention to a possibility to achieve substantial savings. It is the placing with European industry of defense orders meant for use in Europe.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 -- Speeches at a closed Communist party convention in Los Angeles in 1945 advocating a "workers' revolution" were recounted today at the United States District Court trial of fifteen California Communist party functionaries.
DETROIT March 24 (Canadian Press) -- Transport Minister Lionel Chevrier said today North America's steel bill alone will soar $200,000,000 a year if the St. Lawrence Seaway is not built.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower endorsed the Administration's Mutual Security Program today but without expressing an opinion on the Administration's request for $5,889,000,000 for Western Europe in the proposed $7,900,000,000 authorization.

MIAMI, Fla., March 24 -- Roy Campanella showed consistent power for the Dodgers tonight as he continued his torrid hitting of the last few days to pace the Brooks to a 10-9 victory over the Athletics in ten innings.

A man in Brooklyn took a shower with his clothes on yesterday and then stepped into a room where the temperature was 54 degrees below zero. When he came out, his clothes were caked with ice, but he complained, "I'm warm."

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., March 24 -- The cannon that turned back the British ship Vulture during the Revolutionary War, with the result that Major John Andre was captured, has been acquired by the Memorial Museum of the Field Library here.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 24 (UP) -- Irish-bred Windy City II, last year's European juvenile champion, was withdrawn as a Kentucky Derby candidate today after he had pulled up lame after a run on the training track at Santa Anita.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March 24 -- Four Air Force men arrived at their destination today despite travel orders that had routed them on a summer excursion boat to a "camp" that was privately owned.

MANCHESTER, England, March 24 -- With 65,000 mill workers on short time already and more mills about to close down temporarily for lack of orders, leaders of the Lancashire textile industry and heads of the local labor union have appealed to the Government for prompt action in the sudden and severe slump that has hit the industrial northwest.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 24 -- President Truman called on Congress today to approve a program to bring 300,000 European refugees into this country in the next three years.
A. G. Walker, who formerly had his own real estate firm, A. G. Walker, Inc., has joined H. Clayton Smith Co., and has been elected vice president of the concern.

OSHKOSH, Wis., March 24 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, made a detailed defense tonight in this industrial center of the Taft-Hartley Act. He described the controversial labor legislation as a means of emancipation of the American working man from the grip of labor leaders.

A generation of design, embodying a change from "geometric" to "organic" treatment of the line and shape of objects, is represented in a new exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art. Arranged by Greta Daniel, assistant curator of the Department of Architecture and Design at the museum, the display opens today and will continue through June 1.

BOSTON, March 25 (AP) -- Overcoming an 83-31 deficit, Willie Mosconi, the defending champion, took sixteen safeties and fourteen scratches in defeating Willis Covington of Milwaukee, 150 -- 123, tonight, in a marathon thirty-eight-inning match in the world pocket billiard round-robin series.

LONDON, March 25 -- The welding process in maritime construction, under a cloud since two United States tankers with welded hulls broke in two last month, received an endorsement today in Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 25 -- Dr. Frank P. Graham, United Nations Kashmir mediator left here this morning by air for Geneva to write a report on the demilitarization of area which he said he hoped was "a forward step."

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Following are the texts of statements on the steel situation by Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization; Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O.; and industry members of the Wage Stabilization Board:

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that eleven United States business concerns and two missionary groups had paid nearly $800,000 "ransom" in an attempt to free twelve Americans held as hostages by the Chinese Communists.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Funds sought by President Truman for public assistance and school and hospital construction were reduced by the House of Representatives today as it passed a $1,783,242,968 appropriations bill.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 25 -- While a Westchester grand jury was beginning today an investigation of the slaying of two Negro brothers in Yonkers last Wednesday, eight representatives of eight county branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People came to the courthouse to demand that District Attorney George M. Fanelli obtain an indictment for first-degree murder.
BOSTON, March 25 (AP) -- Francis W. White, president of the

The Junior Chamber of Commerce of New York City sent a telegram to Governor Dewey yesterday urging his "direct personal intervention" to prevent what it called an "exodus" of the television industry to Hollywood.

MONTREAL March 25 (UP) -- With Maurice Richard scoring two goals, the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Boston Bruins, 5 to 1, tonight in the first game of their best-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-final series before 14,357 fans.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 25 (AP) -- Blanked until the sixth, the Indians broke loose with three homers in that frame and went on to beat the White Sox, 7 -- 5, today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- Five hours after they had breezed through the main lobby of the Secretariat Building this morning for a capsule inspection of activities in United Nations headquarters, ninety-six farm women from thirty-five Ohio counties scurried for their train this evening, convinced that all was well in the vast plant on the East River.

If ever an analogy could be drawn of a television drama being like a baseball game that breaks wide open in the late innings, it would apply to the Lux Video Theatre's production of "Julie" Monday night over C. B. S.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today new issues of bonds, debentures and common stock totaling more than $124,000,000. Included are mortgage bonds and common stock of public utility companies and bonds and convertible debentures of companies producing and distributing oil and natural gas.
The Incodel bill, having silently, swiftly and without public debate threaded the legislative labyrinth, is now before the Governor for signature or veto.

WASHINGTON, March 25. (UP) -- The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives reversed itself today and approved a bill to strengthen the Marine Corps after being told by Representative Carl Vinson that the situation in Korea might have been better today if there had been more marines two years ago.

Contrary to the conclusions expressed in your editorial of March 23, I firmly believe that the speech of Gen. Douglas MacArthur at Jackson, Miss., was a great service to our nation, and not a disservice.

The National Academy of Design will open its 127th annual exhibition with a preview reception for members and guests this evening in the Academy Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue. Twenty-four awards have been made, eleven of them going to non-members among the exhibitors, and these will be officially presented at the preview this evening.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 -- As a firm, persistent rain beat down on this city of supposedly eternal sunshine today, washing out the Yankees' scheduled exhibition game with the Reds, Casey Stengel received something of a jolt and it wasn't from the weather.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Daniel Thorner, assistant professor of economic history at the University of Pennsylvania, declined to tell the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today whether he had ever been a member of the Communist party.

MONTREAL, March 25 (UP) -- The pennant-winning Detroit Red Wings monopolized the first three individual prizes of the 1951-52 National Hockey League season as Gordie Howe and Ted Lindsay finished 1, 2 in the scoring race and Goalie Terry Sawchuk was named winner of the Vezina Trophy, final statistics revealed today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 25 -- Dr. Oscar Lange, Polish chairman of the preparatory commission for the International Economic Conference to be held in Moscow April 3 to 10, spent last night at the Polish Embassy here and flew to the Soviet capital this morning.
LONDON, March 25 -- The market for British Government securities again was the only consistently firm section of the stock exchange today, last day of the current bookkeeping account.
James Marshall, senior member of the Board of Education, asserted yesterday that there had been a "resurgence" of political interference in the work of the school board.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Governor Dewey signed a bill today authorizing a state census of uninsured drivers that may lead to a decision on whether the Administration will press for enactment of compulsory insurance for all automobile owners.

PARIS, March 25 -- Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, in opening an agricultural conference of sixteen European nations here today, declared that the formation of a common market for farm produce would be a new and important step toward European integration.

The women's coat and suit industry must broaden the scope of its market to bring sales above the break-even point, Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, warned yesterday. Concentration of selling on Seventh Avenue, with the great majority of firms waiting for out-of-town and resident buyers to come to them, he said, has subjected the trade to price pressure that has beaten down both volume and profits.

DETROIT, March 25 (UP) -- Red Kelly, Sid Abel and Johnny Wilson blasted home goals tonight as Detroit blanked Toronto, 3 to 0, in the opening game of the Stanley Cup semi-final play-offs. It was one of the roughest National Hockey League games ever played.
Eight more Brooklyn ship repair concerns were added yesterday to the Government's list of alleged violators of wage ceilings.

LOS ANGELES, March 25 -- William Schneiderman, reputed acting national head of the Communist party at the time of his indictment last July, won his first defensive maneuver as his own counsel in his trial in Federal District Court today.

The Port of New York Authority confirmed yesterday that it had agreed to an Air Force request to reopen Newark Airport "for national defense operations on a limited-use basis as soon as the Air Force sets a date."

LONDON, March 25 -- A research ship owned by the Scottish Marine Biological Association is being equipped with a built-in submarine television apparatus powerful enough to make magnified TV records of life on the sea floor of the experimental fish breeding grounds in the north of Britain.

A rich appearance, achieved through the use of light and dark woods, is exhibited by pieces in the new Tomlinson furniture collection called the Parkway Terrace Group. On view in three airy room settings at W. A. Hathaway Company, 51 West Forty-fifth Street, the group is also available through the Kresge store in Newark.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Government announced today the nation's output of electrolytic manganese will be doubled under an agreement with the Electro Manganese Corporation of Knoxville, Tenn. This is the sole American producer of the metal.

It was noted in this corner when the Ides of March were safely passed that, with this ominous date behind us, little prospect remained that memories of the Blizzard of 1888 would be effaced by anything that 1952 could produce in the way of falling weather expressed in snowflakes.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 25 -- Industrial management has failed to assume firm leadership in solving the problem of retirement policies for over-age personnel. This conclusion was contained in a study published today by the industrial relations section of Princeton University's Department of Economics and Social Institutions.

FORT HOOD, Text., March 25 -- One paratrooper was killed and fifteen were injured seriously this morning when 2,400 men of the Eighty-second Airborne Division dropped into a rock-strewn sector of the Exercise Long Horn maneuver area. The airborne infantryman plunged 1,500 feet to his death when his parachute failed to open over Antelope Mound.
BALTIMORE, March 25 (UP) -- Airlines demonstrated the single-engine airworthiness of a C-46 airplane today by having it flown for nearly two hours and landed on one engine.

Mayor Impellitteri designated Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy yesterday to act as liaison officer between the city and the Selective Service System in connection with the possible use of conscientious objectors in municipal institutions.

Newark Airport has now been closed for six weeks, as a result of three airplane accidents in less than two months. Yesterday it was announced that, by request of the United States Air Force, the field would be reopened to limited military use only, for the shipment of airplanes and other military supplies vital to the defense of Western Europe.

VIENNA, March 25 -- In the third and last of three spy trials, Agnes von Heyne, a 40-year-old German, was sentenced to four years' imprisonment today by an American Civil Affairs Court in Salzburg. She was found guilty of spying on American forces in Austria for the Czechoslovak Intelligence Service.

TRENTON, March 25 -- Protests were raised today in Bergen, Mercer and Burlington Counties against the withdrawal of the name of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio from the Republican Presidential primary in New Jersey.

The "ranch-house look" that characterized the collection of solid oak furniture designed by Architect Edward D. Stone and introduced here last spring is still apparent in new additions to the group, now available.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 25 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury was ordered today to determine if perjury had been committed by James P. Finnegan, former Internal Revenue Collector, during his trial on charges of misconduct in office.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 25 -- Sir Gladwyn Jebb, chief British delegate to the United Nations, warned here tonight that a new world war would bring chaos or totalitarianism to the West.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 25 (UP) -- After a unanimous vote, taken by the City Council today, Mayor A. Sterling Hall and Lou Perini, president of the Braves, signed a contract that will insure the Boston club training here for the next five years with the option to renew for five more years.

It is hard enough these days for a salesman to sell his product to the general public which has little knowledge of the technical details of the item one can imagine, therefore, the plight of those selling to professional men, who know all the answers!

UTICA, N. Y., March 25 (AP) -- The management of the Utica Knitting Company was overthrown tonight at a stockholders' meeting. The management was unseated when an opposition group led by E. Howard Bennett, publisher of "American's Textile Reporter," polled 55 per cent of the outstanding shares.

The steels softened yesterday under the impact of the indecision over the wage-price dispute, and the rest of the stock market promptly followed. The slip was aggravated by selling which cropped out in the rail section, and despite a smattering of demand for the oils the list failed to show any recuperative powers.

Sporadic activity for Gen. Douglas MacArthur for the Republican Presidential nomination has manifested itself in Queens, it was disclosed yesterday. Two separate MacArthur groups are at work. One is the Fighters for MacArthur, headed by Mrs. Regis Courtemanche of 144-37 182d Street, Springfield, and the other is Americans for MacArthur, headed by Alfred Benson, 125-20 150th Avenue, South Ozone Park.

Premature lifting of Governmental controls over prices, wages, materials and credit might be disastrous, for no matter how strong our military branches are they will prove of little protection if inflation hits the country, Senator John W. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama and chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Small Business, said yesterday.
SEATTLE, March 25 (AP) -- The country's basketball coaches grappled today with the problem of reducing "stalling" in games, and came up with two possible remedies.

A production entitled "All Around the Town" opened a three-night engagement at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre last evening. Most of the participants were young people who appeared to be in the best of health. It seems safe to assume that they live reasonably well-ordered lives, have been kind to their parents, are not in the habit of carrying firearms and never have betrayed state secrets to a foreign power.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- Northern and Southern textile makers fought a war of words today over whether the Government should give more defense contracts to Northern mills to cut unemployment.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres today. "The Captive City," a drama produced by Theron Warth, directed by Robert Wise and released by United Artists, is at the Criterion. John Forsythe and Joan Camden are featured. Karl Kamb and Alvin Josephy Jr. wrote the screen play from Mr. Josephy's original story.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- Federal Reserve Governor Oliver S. Powell said today state officials now are free to go ahead with state bond issues for such things as veterans' bonuses if they deem them essential.

LONDON, March 25 -- Labor party legislators, protesting against the restrictions on school expenditure proposed by the Conservative Government, took up the cudgels in the House of Commons today in defense of the welfare state they built while in office.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 25 -- Anemia must always be considered a symptom of some underlying disturbance in the body, it was emphasized here today at the annual meeting of the American Academy of General Practice. In treating the anemic, the possibility of cancer must always be considered.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- As a result of a printing error, the blue and white flag of the United Nations is shown flying at half-staff on a sheet of United Nations stamps that recently were put on sale by the post office here and hastily recalled.
Federal Judge Irving B. Kaufman imposed yesterday the first mandatory ten-year sentence in this area for a three-time violator of the Federal narcotics laws.

Narcotic addiction is the subject of two books that will be issued in the next two months. Doubleday will publish in May David Hulburd's "H Is for Heroin," the true story of Amy Burton and how she was transformed from a normal 15-year-old into a "junkie" at 17.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., March 25 -- Harold E. Stassen offered tonight to share with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower any delegates he might win in Wisconsin's Republican Presidential preferential primary election next Tuesday.

A new contract embodying wages and working conditions for news, news picture and commercial department employes of The United Press in the United States was signed yesterday by officials of The United Press and of the American Newspaper Guild, C.I.O.

MEXICO CITY, March 25 -- The People of Oaxaca, the scene of intermittent riots and gunfire from Friday to yesterday, settled down today into a virtual state of siege in an effort to bring about either the dismissal or the resignation of Gov. Manuel Mayoral Heredia of the state.

PARIS, March 25 -- The Bey of Tunis, ruler of the French North African protectorate of Tunisia, tonight was reported to have replied to new French demands for the dismissal of his nationalist Ministers with a message of protest to French President Vincent Auriol.

In firm parallel notes delivered in Moscow yesterday the United States, Britain and France assert again their determination to proceed with the creation of a new era of international cooperation in a free and united Europe that includes Germany. They reject the Soviet proposal for a new Big Four conference to draft a German peace treaty that would wreck this design.

WITH typical Maine directness, several wardens from the rugged north country are warning anxious anglers to not "hold their breath" until the ice goes out and opens the lakes for landlock salmon fishing, an event they are convinced will be later than you think this year.

BUENOS AIRES, March 25 -- The Texas Company and Socony Vacuum today concluded initial negotiations for their withdrawal from the Argentine business and industrial scene by selling their commonly owned subsidiary, Ultramar, to the Peron Government.

The Port of New York Authority recommended yesterday that a Congressional committee approve bill H. R. 3765, which would authorize twenty-four-hour quarantine inspection service for vessels entering this harbor.

Thousands of diamonds winked and glittered in the bright light of a bank's strong room yesterday, as though making up for lost time after their long imprisonment. They were the jewels of Hetty Sylvia Ann Howland Green Wilks, daughter of the famous financier, Hetty Green. Mrs. Wilks died in February, 1951, and it is doubted that she ever wore many of the valuable baubles.

The growing indignation of the American people over corruption in high places in our Government may bring about punishment of some of the persons who have abused a public trust. But will it prevent such occurrences in the future? I think not.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- An economics professor told Congressional investigators today the Federal Reserve System had "permitted or promoted" unnecessary inflation and ought to be abolished.

Controller Lazarus Joseph backed the Traffic Department yesterday when he recommended to the Board of Estimate that extension of the dime fare for private bus operators be contingent on the companies' agreement to allow one-way avenues.

Rudolph Halley, City Council President, said in his belated formal statement on city finances on March 14, as the Legislature was about to adjourn: "The people [of New York City] must assume the burden of additional taxes to the extent of $80,000,000.

ASMARA, Eritrea, March 25 (AP) -- Eritrean tribesmen began casting their first ballots today to elect a sixty-eight-member assembly to approve a new constitution federating them with neighboring Ethiopia.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Dr. Thomas W. Rogers, executive vice president of the American Finance Conference here, urged today the abolishment or "at least" the relaxation of credit controls on automobiles. Dr. Rogers spoke before the national installment credit conference, a three-day session arranged by the consumer credit committee of the American Bankers Association.

LAUREL, Md., March 25 (UP) -- Comte de Grasse, a chestnut son of Count Fleet, defeated favored Blue Danube, Mrs. A. B. Eklof's Kentucky Derby candidate, by a neck in today's featured Metropolitan Purse at Laurel.

The Oratorio Society of New York has reason to be proud of its durability. Founded in 1873 by Dr. Leopold Damrosch, it has continued to march bravely in behalf of its self-imposed duty to keep on presenting such choral masterworks as Handel's "Messiah" and Bach's B minor Mass.

A truck loaded with Scotch whisky valued at $31,395 was stolen at 1:55 P. M. yesterday from Pier 39, North River, at West Houston Street, as the driver left his vehicle to obtain customs clearance for the bonded liquor.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 25 -- The anniversary of the birth of Hans Christian Andersen will be observed on April 2 throughout Denmark, and particularly at Odense, where he was born 147 years ago.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today he had refused to grant an interview to Newbold Morris, Government clean-up man, whom he calls "wholly unfit for his job."

The Theatre Library Association will be host at a midnight reception on Saturday, April 5, when the G. Maillard Kesslere Collection of 6,000 photographs and 500 paintings is officially presented to the New York Public Library for its Theatre Collection department.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Charles E. Wilson, Defense Mobilization Director, stirred a reaction in Congress today by his criticism last night of the Wage Stabilization Board's recommendations in the steel dispute.

THE most ridiculous statement that can be made on any sports page is that any individual record will never be broken. In the excitement of the moment awed commentators forget that records are extremely perishable commodities that are made to be broken. Certain lifetime marks do have stronger qualifications for enduring but individual exploits, no matter

Charles Greenhaus, known twenty years ago as "The Boy Wizard of Wall Street," was accused yesterday with nine other men and the Monarch Radio and Television Corporation, 61 Crescent Street, Brooklyn, of being involved in a $300,000 fraudulent stock transaction. The charge was made by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 25 -- A split among Brazil's Communists was confirmed by the founding of a new Titoist Brazilian Revolutionary party, it was reported today on the thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Communist party in Brazil.
LONDON, March 25 -- About 20,000 family physicians working under Britain's National Health Service received a pay increase of nearly 25 per cent today, retroactive to 1948.
At the first annual meeting of the board of trustees of the Corning Museum of Glass yesterday at 718 Fifth Avenue, fourteen new members were elected.

NEWARK, Wednesday, March 26 -- Officials of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Workers Union, independent, ordered a strike of its 6,900 members for 7 o'clock this morning in a fight for wage increases and other changes in their contract that expired last Sunday night.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 25 -- Overly fastidious mothers who deprive their children of an important freedom -- the right to get their hands and faces "thoroughly dirty" -- were taken to task here today by a Washington psychiatrist as unwitting contributors to the growth of childhood frustrations.
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 26 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,200, for the twenty-four-hour period ended 6 A. M., Wednesday (4 P. M., Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

MANCHESTER, England, March 25 -- The trade depression that recently hit the Lancashire textile industry is as yet causing no real hardship to the many thousands of workers put on short time or temporarily unemployed.

Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, warned a group of transportation experts yesterday that unless inequities in Federal regulations were corrected and the Government's fiscal policy was reversed soon, the nation's railroads faced a possible collapse.

STUTTGART, Germany, March 25 (AP) -- Dr. Karl leinhaus, aI Christian Democrat and a fomer] Mayor of Heidelberg, wa elected] President of the Constitutionall Assembly of the new southwest/ German state, which was createdI last Dee. 9 in a plebiscite-dictated merger of Baden, WuertternbergBaden, and Wuerttemberg-Hohen-; zollern.

FOND DU LAC, Wis., March 25 -- Senator Robert A. Taft spoke today in seven communities and traveled 152 miles from Oshkosh to Fond du Lac in his chartered bus on this ninth day of his exacting two-week tour of Wisconsin.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 25 (AP) -- Churchill Downs announced today that the 1952 Kentucky derby would be televised from coast to coast. This will be the first "live" telecast of the racing classic outside the Louisville area.

City action on the new 15 per cent tax on general admissions to race tracks was rushed yesterday as both the City Council and the Board of Estimate approved unanimously a local law levying the impost Meanwhile, in Albany, Governor Dewey had yet to sign the measure passed by the Legislature in its closing hours to enable the city to levy the track tax.

BRUSSELS, March 25 -- The Association of Belgian Congo Tin Producers here entered into a contract today with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the delivery of a minimum of 7,000 and a maximum of 9,000 tons of tin a year. That is about half of the Belgian Congo's production.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Following are the unofficial translations of a note sent by the Soviet Union to the United States March 10, and the text of the United States reply, delivered in Moscow today:

The aggregate market value of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange slipped $3,109,850,701 in February, according to a compilation by the Exchange. The average market value of a share fell from $42.48 to $41.18, the lowest registered since last Nov. 30, when it stood at $40.83.
A new pictorial computer, which simplifies the difficulties in aerial navigation, was introduced yesterday by the Arma Corporation, 254 Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- Joseph L. Mankiewicz will write, direct and produce the screen version of "Jefferson Selleck," the new best-seller novel written by Carl Jonas, as the first of three pictures he has contracted to make for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer during the next five years.

MOSCOW, March 25 -- The United States, Britain and France delivered to the Soviet Union today notes on the German question that were expected to bring prompt clarification of the Russian views on the vital question of all-German elections and the formation of a united German Government.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 25 (AP) -- Gov. John Lodge told the State Highway Department today to start construction of a multimillion dollar highway across Fairfield County in the vicinity of the Boston Post Road (U. S. Highway No. 1) "without delay."
All branches of American enterprise were urged yesterday to take over the job of providing technical and economic aid to underdeveloped countries for industrial and agricultural improvements.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The United States is striking a balance between military and civilian goods production enabling it to meet requirements of the present international situation while maintaining domestic prosperity, Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, said today.

PALISADE, N. J., March 25 -- Dr. Charles P. Berkey, who has helped save many millions of dollars of public moneys, confided on his eighty-fifth birthday today that his career was the result of a "pure accident."

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation increased sales last year by 37 per cent to $237,230,000 and more than doubled its backlog, but earnings slipped under heavier operating and retooling costs, Robert E. Gross, president, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

The annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Bargain Box will be held on Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Charles Hurd and Mrs. Frederick Lewis Chapman are co-chairmen of the executive committee. Mrs. Charles M. Kinsolving is president of the beneficiary.

MADISON, Wis., March 25 -- A supporter of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, whose backers are running on a favorite-son slate under the name of Grant Ritter, said today that they had been approached to swing their support to Senator Taft.

LONDON, March 25 -- A red-haired baron who believes Roman legionnaires forded the Thames River where the House of Parliament now stands failed in an attempt to walk across the riverbed at low tide this morning. He was dressed for a stroll rather than a swim.
PARIS, March 25 -- Premier Antoine Pinay asked the French people by radio tonight to support him in his effort to save the nation's financial structure and its currency.

A man described as the "backer and head" of the Brooklyn policy ring, with a gross annual income of $2,500,000, was held in $100,000 bail last night. He is Frank Abbatemarco, 53 years old, of 485 Third Street, Brooklyn. His police record dates to 1921, and includes two years in prison on a narcotics charge.

Two hundred and fifty persons paid tribute last night to Bernard G. Richards at a dinner in the McAlpin Hotel, in observance of his seventy-fifth birthday and the twentieth anniversary of the Jewish Information Bureau he founded.
BALTIMORE, March 25 (AP) -- Is the syndicate that last month bought control of Bowie now interested in buying Pimlico and closing it, leaving Bowie and Laurel the only two mile tracks in Maryland?
AIKEN, S. C., March 25 (AP) -- Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., fired a 6-under-par 65 to win the Palmetto golf club's eighth annual pro-amateur tournament today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 25 -- Bobby Thomson was up to his old tricks today. The Staten Island Scot exploded his second home run of the Cactus League circuit and blasted the Giants to a 7-6 victory over the Cubs before 2,344 observers.

John De Venuta, convicted thief and jail-breaker, named William Sutton and Thomas Kling in Queens County Court yesterday as his accomplices in the theft of $63,942 from the Sunnyside branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company on March 9, 1950.

BALTIMORE, March 25 -- George A. Meyers, head of the Maryland Communist party, was ruled in contempt today for refusing to answer questions at his trial with five others in Federal Court on charges of conspiracy to advocate and teach the forcible overthrow of the Government.

New York City has borrowed $60,000,000 on tax anticipation notes at 1 1/2 per cent interest, City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes, due May 5, were sold by allotment to twenty-three banks and trust companies here, as follows:

The increased recognition given by the general public to the need for cooperating with the medical profession in the drive to control heart disease was hailed in the 1951 report of the American Heart Association, issued yesterday.
Henry A. Browe has been appointed to the new position of sales manager for the radio division of Admiral Corporation.

CAIRO, March 25 -- The Socony Vacuum Oil Company, which had been engaged in the exploration and development of small oil fields in Egypt, today announced that it had given notice to its 235 employes in the oil fields branch and was giving up efforts to produce crude oil in Egypt.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- The Senate suspended its jealously guarded rules today to permit an $18,000-a-year lobbyist to sit in a chair on the Senate floor to advise a Senator during debate.

Finding a temporary replacement for a star of the magnitude of Gertrude Lawrence to allow her a vacation from such a popular musical as "The King and I" was no easy task for Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, producers and authors of the show.

LONDON, March 25 -- Labor Members of Parliament met privately today and agreed on the form of discipline they will impose on themselves. The desire to preserve party unity overcame policy differences.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 25 -- The multi-place Sikorsky S-55 helicopter received today a commercial airworthiness certificate for use in scheduled airline passenger service. It was the first transport rotary-wing aircraft to receive such a certificate.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday with active months 7 to 26 points higher than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- House tax investigators developed today that Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, Republican leader of the Senate, took an active interest for more than two years in a $7,000,000 Federal tax claim against a Baltimore liquor dealer.

DANVERS, Mass., March 25 -- Three men looted an unattended armored money truck of $681,000 and escaped while the driver and two armed guards sat drinking coffee in a drug store about 10:30 A. M. today in quiet Danvers Square.

LOS ANGELES, March 25 (AP) -- Five men suffocated and a sixth plunged to his death today when flames flashed through the upper half of the six-floor St. George Hotel, almost duplicating a similar tragedy there forty years ago.
Thirty-five contract bridge teams of four played the second and final qualifying round of the Eastern States Team of Four Championship last night.
Operations of the Gaylor Container Corporation last year resulted in record sales of $85,071,000, an increase of $21,222,000 over the previous peak made in 1950, the annual report revealed yesterday.

BOSTON, March 25 -- The Celtics and New York Knickerbockers completed preparations today for the third and deciding game in their National Basketball Association first-round play-off series tomorrow night.

The tie-up of Isbrandtsen Company vessels by the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., continued yesterday with four ships immobilized and others expected to be similarly affected as soon as they reach United States ports. The union represents the vast majority of deck officers in the American merchant fleet.

Reflecting the increasing volume of business from the nation's expanding military preparedness program, gross sales of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation rose 64 per cent in 1951 to $167,581,568 from the $102,312,498 volume the year before.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 25 -- The Government and people have proved something during the last year that is of profound importance for the entire Western world. They have shown that an economy on crutches can throw away those crutches and not only stand but also walk better and with more confidence than before.

General support with minor reservations of the over-all Plan for Rezoning the City of New York, which would replace present resolutions adopted in 1916, were expressed yesterday by almost all of the thirty-three speakers at the opening of preliminary public hearings in City Hall.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 25 -- At a mass meeting today, Menachem Begin, chief of the extreme right-wing Herut party, called on Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion to recall the delegation negotiating for reparations from West Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- William G. (Big Bill) Lias, one-time Wheeling, W. Va., gambling czar, has offered to pay the Government $1,476,000 to settle a $3,000,000 tax claim against him and his concerns, informed sources said today.
MILWAUKEE, March 25 (UP) -- Milwaukee bowlers produced several major shake-ups among the American Bowling Congress high ten leaders today.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L. I., March 25 (AP) -- The Franklin National Bank today became the first commercial bank in New York State to increase its interest rates on savings deposits to the maximum allowed under a new ruling of the State Banking Department.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Tighe E. Woods, Director of Rent Stabilization, recommended to the Senate Banking Committee today that Federal rent controls be extended for two years after next June 30. The committee is considering the extension of rent, wage and price controls, which expire then under existing law.

The Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet, after a tour of the country, last night made its local debut at the Warner Theatre, which has temporarily abandoned its motion-picture policy to house the dancers from London. The huge auditorium was packed with a dressy audience, and there was all the atmosphere that is generally associated with what is technically known as a gala premiere.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad told the Interstate Commerce Commission today it wants to issue $65,000,000 worth of bonds instead of a $52,500,000 issue, proposed in January.

RANGOON, Burma, March 24 -- The Burma Government has no intention of negotiating peace with the country's Communist rebels, U Ba Swe, the new Defense Minister in Burma's reorganized Cabinet, said in an interview today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Department of Labor today certified ten new unemployment areas to the Surplus Manpower Committee as areas available for preferential treatment in the negotiation of defense contrcts.
Two automobiles that fly visited New York yesterday.

LONDON, March 25 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Italian Ambassador Manlio Brosio made "some progress" in the second day of their discussions of the riots in Trieste against Britain and the United States, the Foreign Office said today.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 25 -- Complaints and indications that certain telephones in houses and shops in Bergen County were being used before October, 1950, for gambling activities reached the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company from four sources, Aloysius J. Bittig, telephone company attorney in charge of investigations of suspected bookmaking activities over company phones, testified today in Bergen County Criminal Court.

Tradition won a battle with art at Hunter College yesterday as the Student Self-Government Association of the college passed a motion to retain the song. "Fame," as Hunter's alma mater song, reversing its decision of last semester.

A complete revision of the immigration and naturalization laws of the United States is undertaken in each of two measures that have been reported out of their respective committees to the Senate and House and are now awaiting floor action. These bills are basic proposals, bringing into one comprehensive statute all legislation on the subject.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee's inquiry into the Camp Crowder grain storage cases became a political forum today as Republican Senators tried to bring out that the Midwest Storage and Realty Company received favors because of the political connections of its officials.

Things looked blighter for burlap traders yesterday with the issuance of an invitation to bid on 51,000,000 sandbags sent out by the Corps of Engineers, United States Army. The production of the order will take 30,000,000 yards of 40 inch, 10 ounce burlap.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 26 -- Communist negotiators at Panmunjom today declined to discuss their demand for the inclusion of the Soviet Union as one of the "neutral" nations to police an armistice in the Korean war.

TULSA, Okla., March 25 -- Tulsa University today aimed for larger football crowds next autumn by offering season tickets on the installment plan -- "$2 down, six months to pay balance, no carrying charge."

BONN, Germany, March 25 -- The Western powers and West Germany have offered the Soviet Union a chance to cooperate in reuniting Germany and the West has not abandoned hope that Moscow will grasp this opportunity, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared tonight.

SEATTLE, March 25 (AP) -- Bob Zawoluk led the Redmen of St. John's to an upset 61-59 triumph over Illinois tonight in the opening game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship semi-finals. In the second game Kansas trounced Santa Clara, 74 -- 55, as Clyde Lovellette scored 33 points.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- John Foster Dulles resigned today as Republican adviser to Secretary of State Dean Acheson but emphasized he would continue to work for bipartisan agreement on basic foreign policy that is "necessary to save our nation from mortal danger."
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Rationed food in Czechoslovakia for February reached a new low mark, the National Committee for Liberation of Slovakia reported here today.

As Catholic Charities for the Archdiocese of New York urgently presses its campaign to reach its 1952 goal of $2,414,522 we learn that last year the services of this great humanitarian organization reached 438,396 men, women and children of every race and creed in the ten counties of the New York Archdiocese.

Anthony Mazza, 27 - year - old driver of a tank truck involved in an accident in which three men died instantly and three women were injured at 207th Street and Broadway Monday afternoon, pleaded not guilty yesterday to three charges in Vehicular Accident Court.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- David Dubinsky, president and secretary-treasurer of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, reported to the general executive board today that the problems of the garment industry were not reflected in gauges that the union regarded as significant.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The United States, Britain, and France rejected today the Soviet Union's proposals for the creation of an armed, unified and neutral Germany.

Proposals to change the definition of smoke for enforcement purposes met with vigorous objections at a public hearing yesterday in the Board of Health Building, 125 Worth Street. Stronger smoke-control regulations were advocated instead by representatives of women's clubs, tenants' groups and by individuals.

Five armed robbers conducted hold-ups in four West Side hotels on Monday night and early yesterday morning. The first robbery was at the Statler Hotel, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-third Street, at 11:15 P. M. There three intruders escaped with cash estimated at $600 to $2,000.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Ruth Oppenheim's Dalpark, closing with a burst of speed along the inside rail, came from last place to win the Golden Sands Purse before a crowd of 12,292 at Gulfstream Park today.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., March 25 (AP) -- Elbert N. Oakes, counsel to the trustees of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway Company, said today he will ask for a postponement of two weeks when the case is called for approval of the sale of the road tomorrow.

Communist party membership in this country is now only about 31,600, J. Edgar Hoover told a Congressional subcommittee recently. The revelations over the past few years about the extent of F. B. I. infiltration into that party, if such it can be termed, suggest that Mr. Hoover has adequate ways and means of obtaining accurate information.

Many parties were given at the supper party in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza after the premiere of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet last night at the Warner Theatre. The performance had been taken over for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service and the English-Speaking Union, beneficiaries of the fete.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- The mystery over the shooting of William F. Meade, former Republican city chairman of Philadelphia, deepened today as District Attorney Richardson Dilworth absolved Mr. Meade's friend, Miss Virginia Carroll, of guilt in the shooting.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 25 -- The piecemeal plan to build a new $4,500,000 bridge between Long Beach and Island Park over a period of twenty years was scrapped here today and plans were made to call for early bids on the proposed six-lane span over Reynolds Channel. Officials estimated that the project will be completed within a year and a half.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 25 (Reuters) -- Senator G. H. Nicholls, opening a Senate debate on Premier Daniel F. Malan's decision to override a Supreme Court ruling, today demanded that the Government resign or promise to abide by the constitution

There is less and less difference between the colonial and the contemporary house, George Nelson, architect, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Decorative Fabrics Institute. Also contributing to the panel discussion, which centered on "Fabrics in the Changing House," were Herman York of Matern York, builder's architects, and Melanie Kahane, interior decorator.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Chief of Staff to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, told Congress today that any substantial cut in material aid requested for European defense would mean "a serious disadvantage for the United States."
A silver medallion he recently received from Pope Plus XII was delivered yesterday by a Baptist minister to a Roman Catholic priest in recognition of his outstanding work in Harlem.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 25 -- Princeton University students indicated today by a 4-to-1 margin that they would like to have at least some janitorial room service in dormitories next year, but it was not clear just how many would actually help meet the costs.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Selling force spent itself in the early trade in grain futures today. With commission absorption more active and short profit-taking also in evidence, there were good recoveries from early low levels.

Coffee was the feature of commodity futures trading here yesterday. A cable from Rio de Janeiro to the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange told of asking prices in Brazil 50 to 200 points lower. Paranaguas sold 75 points off. Considerable liquidation and trade selling followed and the Exchange market closed with net losses of 15 to 39 points.

MIAMI, Fla., March 25 -- The Dodgers made it two straight over the Athletics at Miami Stadium today, 9 -- 5, and ran their Citrus Circuit winning streak to three games. Only 1,465 fans paid to see this one.

A new candy from Florida is making its appearance in stores here this week. Cobbs Honeysuckles, thin-shelled balls with a soft, pure honey center, are the product of Henry Cobbs, who has been conducting a thriving mail-order business in citrus fruits at Indian River for seventeen years.

There is less and less difference between the colonial and the contemporary house, George Nelson, architect, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Decorative Fabrics Institute. Also contributing to the panel discussion, which centered on "Fabrics in the Changing House," were Herman York of Matern York, builder's architects, and Melanie Kahane, interior decorator.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Chief of Staff to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, told Congress today that any substantial cut in material aid requested for European defense would mean "a serious disadvantage for the United States."

ROME, March 25 -- Disorders and riots broke out in Rome again today when thousands of students demonstrating for the return of Trieste to Italy clashed with the police and fought pitched battles with them in the central streets of the city.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., March 25 -- The Zoning Board of Appeals granted permission today to the owner of the historic tabernacle here to renew the lease of the Sea Cliff Summer Theatre for the 75-year-old structure, but added restrictions that would make it virtually, impossible for the well-known "straw-hat" playhouse to operate.

The importance of cooperation between parents, teacher and student when a child starts music lessons was stressed yesterday by Dr. Leo A. Spiegel, psychoanalyst. He spoke at a meeting on music and children at the Mannes Music School, 157 East Seventy-fourth Street.

PARIS, March 25 -- The main purpose of the notes on Germany that the Western powers sent to Moscow today is to prevent the latest Soviet move from impairing the progress toward unity in Western Europe and in the Atlantic community.

The second performance of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet at the Warner Theatre found the company easier, happier and even more winning than at the somewhat stuffy opening the night before. The repertoire, however, showed no signs of improvement.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A new record outlay of $24,100,000,000 by American industry for new plant and equipment is forecast for this year in the latest joint survey made by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce. The figure compares with expenditures of $23,300,000,000 by which industry set a record in 1951.

Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., earnings declined last year from the 1950 profit level despite a record-breaking sales total of $180,864,236, J. J. Russell, chairman of the board, and J. M. Kennedy, president, said in the company's annual report issued yesterday.

Mayor Impellitteri extended the city's official greetings yesterday to "Miss Israel" of 1952. The title was bestowed on Michal Harel, a 20-year-old kindergarten teacher, in Tel Aviv last September, after a nation-wide beauty contest.

GENEVA, March 26 (AP) -- Britain was the only major steel producing country in the world to turn out less steel last year than in 1950, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

A tract of twenty-four acres in Port Washington, L. I., has been sold by the Morewood Realty Corporation to the Port Homes Corporation in a transaction negotiated by the Great Neck office of J. Edward Breuer. The new owner plans to start construction immedaitely on three model homes. The property, which has an assessed value in excess of $100,000, is between Sands Point and Cow Neck Roads and immediately adjoins Sands Point.

QUINCY, Mass., March 26 (UP) -- Mrs. Edwin C. Johnson, wife of the Democratic Senator from Colorado, was sponsor of the cargo ship Old Colony Mariner launched today at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Quincy shipyard.

THE game bird population of any given area depends not entirely upon the "extent" of the area, but the available food and cover, and recent experiments indicate that sportsmen's clubs can do much to increase the wildlife yield of their covers by devoting a little time and effort to improving habitat conditions.

The American Fund for Israel Institutions, which supports and maintains a network of fifty-two cultural, educational and social welfare institutions in Israel, opened its tenth anniversary campaign in New York with a dinner-meeting last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel This is part of a national drive for $1,934,000.

Defense contractors struggling with the city's shortage of stenographers and typists may hire girls under 18 years old as office workers without fear or conflict with Federal law, the Wage and Hour and Public Contracts Divisions of the United States Department of Labor announced yesterday.

CAIRO, March 26 -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, saw the Pakistani Ambassador here today and the latter immediately sent a telegram to his Government asking it to bring the Tunisian problem before the Security Council with urgency in view of the events in Tunisia.

MADISON, Wis., March 26 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, angrily denounced today what he called "hybrid" candidates who kept the voters in the dark about their convictions and so violated "Republican principles."

The long-awaited preliminary hearings on the plan for rezoning New York City got off to a favorable start before the City Planning Commission. Some excellent statements of general support were made by the Citizens Budget Commission and the Regional Plan Association.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Clarence H. Adams of Connecticut was nominated by President Truman today to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

TRENTON, March 26 -- Legislation to tighten state regulation of airports to curb plane accidents and to give New Jersey residents a damage action procedure against pilots and plane owners was presented tonight in the Legislature.

BONN, Germany, March 26 -- A surprisingly large number of German and Allied diplomats and officials, both here and in Berlin, believe that after further diplomatic exchanges between the Soviet Union and the United States, Britain and France, Moscow will agree to some form of international control of free elections in East Germany.

Tempers flared in a special meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday as members of the Democratic majority sharply criticized Council President Rudolph Halley for allegedly promoting an unworkable fiscal program and seeking to make political capital of the city's financial woes.

A $1,250,000 radium-therapy unit employing a new principle in treating cancer by radiation, a converging beam projector, was opened for public demonstration yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. Hung from the ceiling, it looked like an anti-aircraft searchlight.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill to permit school districts in cities of less than 125,000 population to award up to $3,000 in contracts without advertising for bids. Any contracts involving an expenditure or obligation of more than $1,000 now must be advertised.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Nineteen members opened a drive to provide what they called "oil for the lamps of learning" today as the Senate approached the voting stage on a bill dealing with leases to submerged oil lands off the coasts of the United States.
