Those who came in contact with Dr. Paul Klapper during the forty years that he was active in educational activities in New York City were impressed with his determination to help not only the student but the teacher in the quest for knowledge. As first president of Queens College and as a member of the faculty of City College he stressed the need for clarified curricula that served a purpose.
The City of Chicago borrowed $18,950,000 in the public market yesterday at an interest cost of 1.986 per cent, to finance sewer, highway, bridge, street lighting and fire and police improvements.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 26 (AP) -- Tenley Albright, 16-year-old skater from Newton Center, Mass., stepped in front in compulsory school figures for senior women at the national skating championships today.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Senate Banking Committee decided unanimously today to recommend extension of price and wage controls for one year after next June 30, when the present Defense Production Act will expire. The Administration had asked for two years.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 26 -- The United States is expected to announce soon the creation in Europe of a new top-level military agency designed to relieve three senior United States commanders of many of their logistical and administrative burdens, leaving them freer to concentrate on combat readiness.
Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, urged yesterday the removal of Government controls from the production and distribution of steel.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A decision of the Georgia Supreme Court regarding the Constitutional position of the much-criticized county unit primary election system was severely criticized today by the Department of Justice, which asked the Supreme Court of the United States to intervene in the matter.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Junk boats and water taxis in New York harbor are presenting national security risks that invite in-pourings of subversive aliens and illegal weapons, and give opportunity for the export of strategic materials to Communist-controlled areas, Representative Gordon Canfield, Republican of New Jersey, warned today.

Additional trains on the main line and the Montauk Division of the Long Island Rail Road will be added next month, to relieve overcrowded conditions in morning rush hours, it was disclosed yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission, 233 Broadway.

Five persons, all in their 60's, were found dead last night of gas poisoning. Three were in an apartment at 360 Third Avenue at Twenty-sixth Street, and the two others were in an apartment at 320 Clinton Avenue in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn.

Muriel Albert, 20-year-old Toronto pianist, gave her first New York recital last night at Carnegie Hall. After she had played a while, it was plain why she had chosen the big hall for her debut; she likes to play on a big scale.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- The Soviet Union, intensifying its attack against the International Committee of the Red Cross, rejected today that organization's offer to investigate Communist charges that the United States was using germ warfare in Korea and China.
Gugler Lithographic Co, in 50 E 42d St; American Beacon Corp. in 11 W 42d St; Harry W. Graff, Inc. advertising, public relations, in 1 E 53d St -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc. brokers.
PITTSBURGH, March 26 -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., notified the steel industry today that it would insist on all the wage increases recommended by the Wage Stabilization Board.

A "decided downward trend" in teen-age narcotics addiction has left 150 vacant beds in the United States Public Health Service Hospital at Lexington, Ky., James C. Ryan, district supervisor of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics, reported yesterday.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Governor Dewey signed into law today seven bills rounding out a $234,800,000 stop-gap program of financial relief for New York City with a warning that the city administration must provide the long-range answer to its fiscal problems.

TRENTON, March 26 -- The name of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio will remain on the ballot in the Republican Presidential preference primary to be held April 15 despite the Senator's attempted withdrawal.

Mayor Impellitteri will appeal today for blood pledges when he addresses the students of the downtown division of Fordham University at a blood rally at 12:30 P. M. in the school building at 302 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce accused the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tonight of giving the Truman Administration a 9-to-1 advantage in the time allotted to witnesses testifying on the new $7,900,000,000 foreign aid bill.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 26 -- A Cornell University freshman was killed and three other college students were injured early this morning when their sedan left the Central Westchester Parkway near the County Center, plunged through thicket of trees and shrubbery and overturned in the shallow water of Reilly's Pond.
Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican of California, yesterday urged further protection of witnesses' rights, including the banning of television, at Congressional hearings.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- As rain beat down on a thoroughly bewildered Sunshine City for the second successive day to wash out this afternoon's game between the Yankees and Cardinals, Casey Stengel decided this would be as good a time as any to take inventory of his 1952 pitching prospects.

A panel of six high school students discussed the question "Can We Break the Deadlock Between East and West?" in the New York Times Youth Forum at Highland Park High School, Highland Park, N. J., yesterday and arrived by different arguments to the conclusion that war can be avoided.

DETROIT, March 26 (UP) -- Charges from Detroit quarters that Toronto players "are out to get" Sid Abel and counter charges that the Red Wings are "after" Fern Flaman rose today as the hockey rivals girded for their second battle in the Stanley Cup semi-final play-offs.
Sixteen contract bridge teams started knockout team-against-team play last night at the McAlpin Hotel in the 1952 Eastern States Team-of-Four Championship.

LONDON, March 26 -- Organized labor fired a broadside today against the financial policies of the Conservative Government, asserting that they threatened to produce heavy unemployment, inflationary wage demands and a disaster in foreign trade.

BOSTON, March 26 -- Ernie Vandeweghe caged a foul two seconds before the end of the second overtime period and the New York Knickerbockers moved into the semi-finals of the National Basketball Association play-offs with an 88-87 victory tonight over the Boston Celtics in the third contest of their best-two-of-three games series. The score was deadlocked at 79 -- all after regulation time and at 83 -- all after the first five-minute extra period.

PARIS, March 26 -- France seized the nationalist Premier and three Ministers of her Tunisian protectorate before dawn today and clamped a curfew and martial law on the country in an effort to check the disorders that have reigned there for three months.

An informal biography of Robert A. Taft by Caroline T. Harnsberger has been scheduled for April 7 publication by Wilcox Follett of Chicago. It is entitled "A Man of Courage." The book will be the first volume in the concern's new series, "Living American Statesmen."

David Crystal's spring and summer suits and dresses, viewed yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, were void of any of the season's extreme trends. Emphasis was placed, rather, on wearable variations of casual classics in fine fabrics in this selection of twenty-eight styles available at Best Co.

The quandary as to where New York City should go for increasing its future water supply continues. Logic prompts the conclusion, it seems to us, that before Governor Dewey signs the "Incodel" bill for four - state cooperation in developing further the remote Delaware watershed we should first have a firm decision from the city administration on whether it is going to use the upstate Hudson River.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 26 -- Nebraska's Attorney General held today that the state election law required that, to be valid, write-in ballots in the state's Presidential preference primary April 1 must carry the correct spelling of a candidate's last name and that an "X" must be marked in a box opposite the written name.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 26 (UP) -- President Truman prepared tonight to close the winter White House and head North into the political storms.

LINCOLN, England, March 26 (UP) -- Phariza, a 33-to-1 outsider ridden by an apprentice jockey, came up strong on the final two furlongs today to the one-mile Lincolnshire Handicap, the first half of Britain's spring betting 'double."

LAUREL, Md., March 26 (UP) -- Hi Billee, with Nick Shuk aboard, outsprinted the field at the start and raced in front the rest of the way to win the featured Capitol Hill purse by three and a half lengths at Laurel Park today.

Security holders no have failed to claim securities or cash due them in reorganization proceedings stand to lose about $25,000,000 unless they speak up, the Securities and Exchange Commission declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 26 -- Pit activity was sluggish much of the session today, but just before the close there was free local selling of wheat, which unsettled the other grains.
ROME, March 26 -- For the third day in succession, thousands of students crowded the streets of several Italian cities today and staged noisy demonstrations for the return of Trieste to Italy.
LONDON, March 26 -- Although the volume of business remained low today, the stock markets as a whole showed distinct improvement.

The state all but completed its case against William F. Sutton and Thomas Kling on bank robbery charges yesterday. The last three state witnesses -- policemen -- are to be heard in Queens County Court in Long Island City today, the ninth trial session.
MIAMI, Fla., March 26 -- Rain on Florida's West Coast not only washed out today's game with the Braves at Bradenton but separated the Dodger squad.

A corporation went to court yesterday to see if it could give money to a university against the wishes of a stockholder. The company says the gift is a matter of "enlightened self-interest," but the stockholder, who has an interest in the profits, says the company was not chartered to give away its money.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois said today that he had informed President Truman that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for the Presidency.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 27 -- United Nations and Communist staff officers squabbled today at Panmunjom over the right of either belligerent to represent the Korean people in negotiations for an armistice and the enemy representatives appeared to be building up an issue to snag the truce talks.

The ice cream sodas were "on the house," and the soda fountain also gushed champagne and high-balls yesterday afternoon at Caswell-Massey, Ltd., chemists. The somewhat untypical corner drug store at Lexington Avenue and Forty-eighth Street was holding its 200th birthday party.

Progress in studies to develop a "tame" virus with a predilection for human cancer tissue was reported here yesterday at Memorial Cancer Center during a conference under the auspices of the American Cancer Society. The conference was part of a two-week tour of major cancer research institutions arranged by the society for science reporters.

Truman Capote's first play, "The Grass Harp," a dramatization by the author of his best-selling novel of the same name, will have its New York premiere this evening in the Martin Beck Theatre at 8 o'clock.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 26 -- Representatives of the West German Government have exhibited a "desire to examine with sympathetic interest and consideration" all claims the combined Jewish organizations have made for the restitution of property and indemnification for losses suffered by the Jews under Hitler, a spokesman for those organizations said here today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 26 (Reuters) -- Group Capt. A. G. (Sailor) Malan, a relentless campaigner against Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's race segregation policy, today led a squad of his Torch Commandos into Capetown to ask for a parley with the Prime Minister.

Daily social centers at churches and programs in city parks designed for older persons should be added to the growing services for an increasing number of elderly men and women, Raymond M. Hilliard, director of the Welfare Council of New York City, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 19, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

PARIS, March 26 -- Premier Antoine Pinay's financial program, which he defended before the Finance Committee of the National Assembly today, contained provision authorizing the Government to alter the tax regulations so as to permit materials used by the United States in the construction of military bases in France to enter the country duty free.

An improvement in spring business and an average employment rise of 4 per cent by June are expected by New York business men, according to a report of a survey by the New York State Employment Service. Companies working on defense orders predict a 7 per cent increase in jobs.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- A small town investor who made $35,000 in less than two years storing Government grain testified today "on my word of honor" that his friendship with President Truman had nothing to do with his profits.

RANGOON, Burma, March 26 -- Burmese forces have launched an attack against the Chinese Nationalist troops in the Kengtung area, Home Minister Boh Khin Maung Gale announced here today. At the same time, Prime Minister U Nu reiterated the Government's policy of continuing warfare against Burma's Communist insurgents, thus rejecting Communist peace feelers.

A choice collection of spring fashions of the last century, such as might have been worn on Easter Sunday and the following summer days by New York's fashionable ladies, was shown at a press preview yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York.
THERE ain't nuthin' to umpirin'," said Bill Guthrie, a rugged individualist of the old school. "There ain't no close plays. It's either dis or dat."
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Army resolved a controversy over a contract for 1,298 hospital and laboratory microscopes today by splitting the award between Italian and American competitors.

The more carefully the Russian proposal for Germany is examined as a countermove to Western policy, the more apparent are the motives which induced Moscow to throw overboard its previous policy. Among these motives, all cunningly designed to wreck Allied plans and revive the threat of German power, not the least compelling is to prevent the internationalization of the Ruhr.

Because of the lack of religious freedom behind the Iron Curtain a bequest $5,000 for the erection of a religious school in Lithuania made a quarter century ago by Solomon Shapiro, a New York merchant, eventually will be used for an American charity.

MEXICO CITY, March 26 -- A general strike of the people of the city of Oaxaca against their Governor spread today throughout Oaxaca State. It was announced that the port of Salina Cruz would be shut down tomorrow.

Another television visit to a public school will be offered by the National Broadcasting Company next Thursday, when the "Inside Our Schools" survey will be extended to P. S. 168 at 315 East 105th Street.
PARIS, March 26 -- The calling of a conference of government technicians to draw up plans for a European agricultural pool was approved today by the ministers of sixteen countries meeting here.
LOS ANGELES, March 26 -- The Government's sixth witness in the Smith Act trial of fifteen California Communist party functionaries collapsed on the stand in Federal District Court today.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The Government today lifted its ban on white sidewall tires and increased the amount of natural rubber that may be used in passenger-car tires.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 26 -- Birth control, divorce and a "debilitating secularism" that has been worming has way into the American home, were strongly condemned here today in a statement issued at the close of the twentieth annual National Catholic Family Life Conference.

Three new films will open today at first-run theatres. "Singin' in the Rain," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical in Technicolor, with Gene Kelly, Donald O'Connor and Debbie Reynolds, is at Radio City Music Hall. Stanley Donen and Gene Kelly directed and Arthur Freed produced from a story and screen play by Adolph Green and Betty Comden.
A group of insurance executives from all parts of the country gathered in this city yesterday for a conducted tour of 200 years of American history and a peek at the probable future of the nation.
Yesterday saw sharp losses and moderate gains in commodity futures trading. Wool, hides, rubber and vegetable oils all receded, with cottonseed oil having the heaviest turnover of the year so far.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The Government today approved boosts of $6 to $12 a ton for milo gluten meal and feed which are by-products of the wet milling of milo, a variety of grain sorghum grown in the Southwest.
TOKYO, Thursday, March 27 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,201, for Wednesday's operations:

Battalion Chief Wesley Williams of the Fifteenth Battalion, the Bronx, the first Negro to be an officer in the Fire Department, will retire Tuesday after thirty-three years as a city fire-fighter. He is 55 years old and the highest ranking fire officer of his race in the country.

HARRISON, N. J., March 26 -- A strike of 400 members of the Consolidated Gas Workers Union of New Jersey, an independent organization, early today tied up the largest gas-producing plant of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company here, and late this afternoon spread to the Paterson gas works when seventy members of the same union walked out in that city.

Credit conditions in the first quarter of 1952 show improvement compared with the previous quarter, according to the quarterly survey released yesterday by the Chicago Association of Credit Men. Collections in February are up compared with November, 1951, D. A. Grant, president of the association, reported, but credit executives feel there will be a down trend in payments.

That subtle impression made in favor of business concerns by high-quality printing combined with use of fine-grade papers can be the spur to expanding paper sales, members of the National Paper Trade Association heard yesterday as they closed their forty-ninth annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A 1952 British-built Austin de luxe four-door sedan designated the Somerset was announced yesterday by the Austin Motor Company, Ltd., of England. It will go on display Saturday at the International Motor Sports Show at the Grand Central Palace. The New York delivered price is $1,795 exclusive of sales tax.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- The Prime Minister of the African Gold Coast has appealed to the United Nations to block the "expansionist policy" of the South African Government and has complained that this policy disturbs "all Africa."

Record gross revenues and electricity sales in 1951 were reported yesterday by the Ohio Edison Company, one of the largest independent operating utilities in the country. Net income, however, declined slightly from the year before because of higher Federal income taxes.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- The Coast Guard today praised Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen for refusing to abandon his crippled vessel to the stormy Atlantic last December. It said he acted in "the best traditions of the sea."
LOS ANGELES, March 26 (AP) -- There is more petroleum in sight today than ever before, the president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey told 3,000 oil scientists here last night.
The Board of Estimate buried yesterday the Traffic Department's proposal that extension of the dime fare for private bus operators be contingent on company agreement to allow one-way avenues.

Ernie Beck, Pennsylvania's scoring champion, who was picked as the most valuable player; Alan Stein, Columbia captain; John Werner, Cornell, and Captain Chuck De Voe and Fred Tritschler of champion Princeton, were named yesterday to the all-league team for 1952 by the seven Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League coaches.

A Hindu chapel was dedicated last night in a former private residence at 34 West Seventy-first Street. The residence was presented to the Vedanta Society of New York by the late Mary Morton, daughter of Levi P. Morton. who was Vice President of the United States in the Benjamin Harrison Administration.

The use of newly developed materials and techniques by decorators was urged at the opening day's session yesterday of the American Institute of Decorators' twenty-first annual conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The conference continues through tomorrow.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- The burden of income and excess profits taxes has forced Sears, Roebuck Co. to abandon further expansion of domestic store facilities, Fowler B. McConnell, president, said today. In releasing the company's annual report for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, Mr. McConnell explained that although sales of Sears and its subsidiaries last year were the highest on record, net income after taxes was down from that of 1950.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet, and final prices were 10 to 17 points net lower.

The steel wage-price controversy remained yesterday as a drag on the stock market. Prices hardly moved in the session. Without the benefit of an upswing in the railroad issues, the list would have presented a very ragged appearance.

A clothing maker in Cleveland spoke a few words the other day about men's clothing. "Men's clothing has been hard to sell," he said with some feeling, "because the old man only gets what's left of the family income."

Indicating that the Industrial Rayon Corporation is experiencing better business than the industry as a whole, Hayden B. Kline, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Cleveland yesterday its plants are operating at capacity while the industry worked at only 70 per cent of capacity in January and 55 per cent in February.

More people and more kinds of people are crossing more national borders in educational exchange programs than ever before, according to the thirty-third annual report of the Institute of International Education, which was issued yesterday from the organization's headquarters, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 26 -- New Jersey motorists are getting a "raw deal" under the present system of private, profit-operated agencies that collect motor vehicle taxes. Dr. Richard A. Lester, chairman of the Department of Economics at Princeton University, asserted in a letter to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll made public today.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Federal Reserve Board, by a split decision, has decided to dissolve the vast Giannini banking empire headed by Transamerica Corporation with more than $7,000,000,000 of deposits and half the bank loans outstanding in five Far Western states.
BERLIN, March 26 -- A new kind of East-West warfare has developed here during the last few days, with the rivals hurling Beethoven at each other "fortissimo" and "accelerando."

Invited East by the Music Educator's National Conference, the young men and women -- some sixty -- who make up the choir of Cornell College in Mount Vernon, Iowa, gave a concert yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

GUATEMALA, March 26 -- The confused and unpleasant political situation in Guatemala can be understood only in relation to its historical background. Only by knowing what has happened here can one properly gauge the importance of communism, what has happened to the United Fruit Company and why there are good reasons for hopefulness.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- On Executive groups like the Wage Stabilization Board the personnel is equally rationed among representatives of organized labor, industry and the "public." The latter, in the seductive semantics perfected during the New Deal, are known as "public members" and are supposed to act in the general national interest as distinguished from the immediate special interests of industry and organized labor.

The average citizen of the Republic of Korea is deeply conscious that he owes what he is as well as what he has to the United Nations. This sense of indebtedness and gratitude to the foreign troops in Korea for freedom and democracy is so preponderant over other feelings that the Korean public is almost resignedly indifferent to the loss of Korean lives and the destruction of Korean properties since the war.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Government today authorized smaller independent retail grocers to raise prices of frozen foods roughly a penny a package to cover cost of warehousing.

After sharp debate and a futile defense of the measure by Dillon Meyer, Commissioner of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, the Association on American Indian Affairs disapproved yesterday bills now before Congress to expand the law enforcement powers of the bureau.

Mrs. Edward Bragg Paine gave a luncheon yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mme. Draper Boncompagni, chairman, and the latter's aides serving in behalf of the spring bazaar, fashion show and tea dance for the benefit of the Youth Division of Common Cause.

Officials at the Board of Education denied yesterday that there were political connotations in the appointment of confidential secretaries to board members, even though some secretaries were active in political circles.

Barring a successful filibuster at the public hearing called for Tuesday at 9 A. M. by Mayor Impellitteri, the race track fan will be faced with a new schedule of prices when he shows up at the Jamaica course the same day. The increase will come about as the result of a proposed 15 per cent tax on general admissions to the race tracks in the local area.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 26 -- The Feb. 18 death of Millard Romaine Jr., 19-year-old Williams College honor student, was caused by a self-inflicted contact gunshot wound of the head. Dr. George T. Mullen, Northern Berkshire Medical Examiner, said during an inquest today in Williamstown District Court.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 26 -- An earnest group of young diplomats, 4 to 12 years old, met here yesterday afternoon to consider ways and means of restoring "law and security" in their troubled world.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- Lloyd Bacon, the veteran director, will wind up his contract with Twentieth Century-Fox upon completion of "The I Don't Care Girl," and then he plans to take a flier into independent production. Mr. Bacon owns the film rights to "Cabin on the Hill," the novel by Douglas Freemont, and he plans to cast it and make a package deal with a studio, with himself as the director.

With the Japanese peace treaty and the Pacific security pacts ratified by an overwhelming bipartisan majority, John Foster Dulles, the chief architect of these compacts, has accomplished the mission for which he entered the State Department and has resigned his post.

Don't be surprised if reporters covering the advertising and marketing beat soon begin to take on the appearance and mannerisms of movie critics. At nearly every meeting lately where ten or more executives in the selling business were gathered a film has been shown for the edification of those present.

NASHVILLE, March 26 -- Negro college students must be trained to participate in programs such as the Truman Administration's Point Four plan to assist underdeveloped areas if this country's role of world leadership is to be strengthened, George L. P. Weaver, assistant to the administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, declared tonight.

JERSEY CITY, March 26 -- Frank Hague, former Democratic state boss, climbed aboard the Truman bandwagon today and said he intended to take an active part in the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. Mr. Hague returned to his home here yesterday after having spent the last three months in Florida.
NEW ORLEANS, March 26 (AP) -- Complying with a police request, New Orleans' three newspapers discontinued today publication of horse racing results, selections and entries.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 26 -- The Giants said it with home runs today as they soared to their seventh victory in a row with a 9-6 triumph over the Cubs. But they lost the services of one of the "big four" on the firing line, for an indefinite period.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Legislation to increase participation in city school district elections by eliminating special qualifications for voters was approved today by Governor Dewey.

FORT HOOD, Tex., March 26 -- Green-clad Aggressor forces, despite "losses" suffered yesterday in a simulated atomic weapons attack, today cut off one regiment of the United States (Friendly) Forty-seventh Infantry Division in the south of the maneuver area of Exercise Long Horn and exerted heavy pressure in the central and northern sectors.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- High Government officials will make an effort tomorrow to devise a plan for averting a steel strike through compromising wage and price disputes in that industry.

LONDON, March 26 -- Measures to alleviate the slump in the British textile industry, the most alarming business recession in this country since the war, were announced in the House of Commons today during a debate on the acute unemployment problem in the industry.
The truce negotiations in Korea entered a new and "secret" phase yesterday as spring began to loosen the restricting grip of winter on the front lines.

A plaque marking the birthplace of Jennie Jerome, the mother of Prime Minister S. Churchill, was unveiled yesterday at 426 Henry Street, Brooklyn. The house is now owned and occupied by Joseph E. Romeo, a designer and production manager for a children's coat manufacturer.

The Fabre Line has started construction of four new freighters for its services between Mediterranean ports and ports on the United States East Coast and in the Great Lakes, it was announced yesterday by James W. Elwell Co., agents for the line.

Retail grocers in this area expect hectic merchandising conditions in the margarine industry next July when sales of the colored spread become legal in New York. Under the new law, first sales of colored margarine will be allowed July 1.

Settlement of a strike against the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company by 6,300 members of the Telephone Workers Union of New Jersey, independent, which began at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, was announced at 2:30 A. M. today by Henry Mayer, attorney for the union.

It is not only in the matter of municipal finance that the State Legislature, dominated by upstate Republicans, hampers New York City activity. An enacted bill, introduced this year by Republican Assemblyman McMullen of Kings and permitting the chief justice of the New York City Court to appoint a Deputy Commissioner of Records, has been approved by the Governor and has since been acted upon.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 26 (Reuters) -- A world-wide increase in the price of gold, speeding South Africa on its way to freedom from restrictions, was forecast today by Finance Minister Nicholas Havenga.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, filed a suit for $2,000,000 and costs against Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, in Federal District Court here today. He charged libel, slander and conspiracy.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 26 (Reuters) -- A world-wide increase in the price of gold, speeding South Africa on its way to freedom from restrictions, was forecast today by Finance Minister Nicholas Havenga.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, filed a suit for $2,000,000 and costs against Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, in Federal District Court here today. He charged libel, slander and conspiracy.

HAMILTON, N. Y., March 26 (AP) -- Colgate University announced tonight that "in simple fairness" to its new head football coach, Harold W. Lahar, it would hold "limited" practice this spring. Starting in 1953, spring drills will be eliminated, the university indicated.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Producers tried to adjust their delivery of hogs to stem declining prices today but even so the market fell to new twenty-three-month low marks. The general trade was 10 to mostly 25 cents lower than in the previous session. Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading:

MILWAUKEE, March 26 (AP) -- A missed No. 4 pin cost Basil Burchett, 46-year-old, White Pigeon, Mich., theatre manager, first place today in the singles event of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation, announced yesterday that the board planned to eliminate service on nine bus lines and one trolley car route, all in Brooklyn, on Saturdays and Sundays beginning on May 17.

CAIRO, March 26 -- The Wafd party directorate, which met tonight under the chairmanship of Mustafa Nahas Pasha, Premier for two years prior to Jan. 27, sent a note to Premier Ahmed Naguib al Hilaili Pasha, demanding immediate release from compulsory residence of Fuad Serag el-Din Pasha, secretary general of the party and former Minister of the Interior, in view of the elections set for May 18.

In her debut recital last night at Town Hall Natalie Ryshna revealed undisputed talent. The young pianist programmed pieces by Rameau and Chopin, Beethoven's D minor Sonata, Bartok's "Outdoor Suite," Persichetti's Third Piano Sonata and shorter works by Ravel and Liszt.

A 32-year-old plasterer serving seven years on his guilty plea to a narcotics violation will get an opportunity to plead not guilty to the charge as a result of an investigation by the Legal Aid Society and the United States Attorney's office.
Making their spring debut this week at the shop of Ann Roberts, 107 East Sixtieth Street, are several new offerings from the gourmet service presented under the Pot Luck label.

The Isbrandtsen Company's brief dispute with the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., ended shortly after noon yesterday, when the line agreed to the union's terms and a new two-year contract.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Chuck Davey, scholarly southpaw from Michigan State College, tonight scored a technical knockout over Ike Williams, former world lightweight champion, in 1 minute 47 seconds of the fifth round.

A new way to measure melting points will soon be in commercial use, it was learned yesterday. Disposal thermometers made of paper which instantly determine temperature from 115 degrees to 500 degrees Fahrenheit have been developed by the Army Quarter-master Corps.

Favorable conditions in the Netherlands for foreign-capitalized industries producing largely for the export market are providing a profitable way for United States corporations to hurdle growing exchange and trade barriers, it was asserted yesterday at an executive committee meeting of the New York Board of Trade's international trade section.

DANVERS, Mass., March 26 -- The police today studied the possibility that yesterday's looting of an armored truck of $681,000 here was linked to the $1,219,000 hold-up of Brinks, Inc., armored car service, in Boston Jan. 17, 1950.

A further increase last week of 1,481,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 147,596,000 barrels, compared with 146,165,000 a week earlier and 141,239,000 a year ago.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Bankers can look forward to increased consumer spending in the last half of this year and continuing through 1953, Earl I. Butz, head of Agricultural Economics Department of Purdue University, forecast today.

The belief that President Juan D. Peron is losing his popular support in Argentina was expressed yesterday by Foster Hailey of the foreign staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES at the seventh session of the in-service course for teachers on "Understanding the News About Foreign Affairs," held in The Times' auditorium, 229 West Forty-third Street.
The standards of medical care provided the sick poor of the city are threatened because of the serious shortage of nurses, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, declared yesterday.

Plans are being advanced at frequent meetings at the Pierre for the lucheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Rebecca Talbot Perkins Adoption Society, which will take place next Wednesday at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park. The occasion will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the beneficiary.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- J. Howard McGrath, Attorney General, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that there was nothing wrong with the administration of the Department of Justice and that he knew of no improprieties by any of its employes that needed investigating.

LOS ANGELES, March 26 -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma was eliminated today as a possible contender in the California Democratic Presidential primary, June 3. The possibility faded that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would be entered.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, Republican leader of the Senate, charged today the interest he took in a $7,000,000 Federal tax claim against a Baltimore liquor dealer had been "blown out of all proportion."

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- J. Howard McGrath, Attorney General, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that there was nothing wrong with the administration of the Department of Justice and that he knew of no improprieties by any of its employes that needed investigating.

LOS ANGELES, March 26 -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma was eliminated today as a possible contender in the California Democratic Presidential primary, June 3. The possibility faded that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would be entered.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, Republican leader of the Senate, charged today the interest he took in a $7,000,000 Federal tax claim against a Baltimore liquor dealer had been "blown out of all proportion."

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 26 -- President Getulio Vargas accepted the resignation of War Minister Newton Estillac Leal today in a surprise move to end the nationwide tension arising from the clashing views of senior officers on a policy toward the Communists.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, March 27 (AP) -- Grenade-hurling Allied raiders overran Chinese Red positions in the eastern Korea mountains yesterday, chased the Communists away and withdrew later under artillery cover.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Since the President has failed to deny the report to the St. Louis Post-Dispatch by its Washington correspondent, Raymond P. Brandt, that Mr. Truman made Governor Stevenson of Illinois a firm offer to support him for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1952, the report will be accepted as true.

The Board of Assessors awarded $405,000 yesterday to the Woodstock Tower, 320 East Forty-second Street, on an $826,709 claim filed against the city for damages resulting from a change of grade in front of the hotel's entrance.

Vegetable oil prices continued to swing lower yesterday. When trading closed on the New York Produce Exchange both cottonseed oil and soybean oil had set new lows for the season and the former, with volume of 1,413 lots -- each representing a 60,000-ton tank car -- may have made a new high record for one-day turnover.

NEWARK, March 27 -- Declaring that sociologically and industrially both the fit and the unfit have their limitations, Henry Viscardi Jr., executive director of the Just One Break for the Handicapped Committee of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation in New York, called for a more positive approach toward the problem of aiding the handicapped to take their place in industry.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, worked with subordinates today on plans to avert a steel strike on April 8, but decided not to talk about the proposals for the present.

LAUREL, Md., March 27 (UP) -- Cinda, a bay filly owned by Jouett Shouse, scored her second 1952 triumph in as many starts today by defeating Brookmeade Stable's Suggested by a head in the $4,500 Fort Meade purse at Laurel.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, has made it plain that the Soviet Union continues to regard as illegal and without competence the United Nations Commission named to ascertain whether conditions obtain for free all-German elections.

A great many persons stole a few moments from other activities yesterday while passing the Channel Gardens in Rockefeller Center to watch John Buckley and his assistant gardeners put out 4,000 flowering hyacinths. The flowers were displayed to welcome the sunny season in New York.

The stock market staged yesterday one of its best advances of the year as the railroads, helped by the oils, set the pace for the session. Price increases ranged from 1 to 2 points, with some showing even wider climbs. For the first time this week traders were inclined to ignore the steel wage-price problem and concentrate on other divisions of the list.

An all-time high of $6,000,000,000 now has been reached in United States private investment in Latin America, according to the current quarterly digest, Latin-American Business Highlights, issued by the Chase National Bank of New York.

A bill to restore the former size and weight limitations on fourth-class mail (parcel post) will be introduced in both houses of Congress within the next few days, the Bureau of Salesmen's National Associations announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The State Department joined today in the announcement that the United States, Britain and Italy would meet in London soon to discuss possible ways for Italy to cooperate in the administration of the zone in Trieste now controlled by the two Western allies.

LONDON, March 27 -- The British Government announced today the permanent and final exclusion from chieftainship of the Bamangwato tribe in Bechuanaland Protectorate in Africa of Seretse Khama, Oxford-educated heir to the title who married a white English girl in September, 1948.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -President Truman arrived in Washington late this afternoon aboard the Presidential airplane the Independence after a three-week vacation at Key West, Fla.

PARIS, March 27 (UP) -- The semi-official French Press Agency said tonight General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would ask to be relieved of his European command "on or a little after" April 2, and sources close to him believed the report was just about correct.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27 -- The Yugoslav Government is preparing to issue an important statement on foreign policy, including its latest views on the question of Trieste. The statement will be read by the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Leo Mattes, to the National Assembly, either when it convenes tomorrow or at Saturday's session.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Howard Hughes, managing director and principal stockholder in R. K. O. Radio Pictures, today declared in a letter to the Screen Writers Guild his "refusal to be bound by any arbitration award" in favor of Paul Jarrico regarding writing credits on the movie "The Las Vegas Story."

MADISON, Wis., March 27 -Gov. Earl Warren of California, to the despair of his delegate candidates and supporters, rolled through southern Wisconsin today in the final phase of his Presidential primary campaign steadfastly declining to identify himself with the candidacy of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

BONN, Germany, March 27 (AP) -- United States officials disclosed today they had let an accused German double agent leave Germany -- to escape West German authorities who charge that he sold his fellow-countrymen into Russian captivity.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Federal Trade Commission, for the second time, has moved against the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, charging it with "illegal" discriminatory pricing practices in the sale of gasoline to four Detroit dealers.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 27 -The Pirates started by trying to steal bases on the Giants today and ended by snapping New York's seven-game winning streak before 2,528 onlookers. The score was 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The general executive board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union announced today the establishment of a central reciprocal retirement fund to provide benefits for members who have credits in general funds but not enough in any one fund to retire.

THE New Jersey surfcasters, about ready to admit legislative defeat in their efforts to preserve the striped bass as a game fish, insist that arithmetic is one thing and biology another. And they point out that the present striped bass problem is primarily one of arithmetic.

The Alleghany Corporation at the close of last year had net assets equivalent to $151.29 each on the 236,744 cumulative 5 1/2 per cent series A preferred shares outstanding, according to the 1951 annual report. This compares with $142.25 each on the 244,544 shares at the end of 1950.

I am very displeased over the fact that the state has enacted legislation which will enable the City of New York to retain the 3 per cent sales tax and to nuisance-tax the motorist up to a maximum of $70 a year. What is more annoying was the item in THE TIMES that this program was put through with the sponsorship of our Governor.

LONDON, March 27 -- Study of provisions of the Finance Bill published today, dealing with the Excess Profits Levy on overseas companies, brought about a reversal of early gains in base metal, oil and rubber shares on the Stock Exchange here.

HARTFORD, March 27 -- Questions about the life and death of Frank Wetmore, whose widow became the wife of Dr. Donald F. Gibson, provided sensation and mystery today at a hearing by the Medical Examining Board into six charges of unprofessional conduct by the Danbury physician.
Your editorial "Judgment in South Africa" in THE TIMES of March 21 was right to the point.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -David N. Rowe, Professor of Political Science at Yale University and a specialist in Far Eastern affairs, told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today he considered Prof. Owen Lattimore to be the "principal agent of Stalinism" among workers in the Far Eastern field in the United States.

CRANFORD, N. J., March 27 -Two-year-old Joseph Behan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Behan of 205 Central Avenue drowned today when he crawled atop an eight-foot slanted dike embankment and tumbled into the Rahway River at Riverside Drive near Normandie Place. He was an only child.
For the second time in a year, members of the Artists Equity Association are contributing paintings to a bargain sale in art.

OMAHA, Neb., March 27 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee indicated today that he believed that President Truman should keep his hands off the naming of his successor as the Democratic Presidential nominee if the President should decide not to run.
GOEPPINGEN, Germany, March 27 (AP) -- Sgt. Curt Simmons, happy at the prospect of getting out of the army and eager to return to baseball, pronounced himself in good condition today.
Pale blonde furs vied with magnificent mink mutations for attention yesterday when a new collection was presented by Revillon, 11 West Fifty-seventh Street.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 27 -- Neither those who gambled away thousands of dollars nightly nor those who worked in the several Bergen County establishments operated by Joe Adonis and his associates had any fears of arrest or even of interruption, according to testimony in Bergen County Court here today in the trial of Michael Orecchio.

PARIS, March 27 -- Premier Antoine Pinay made a personal plea today to the Council of the Republic, France's advisory second house, to ratify the Schuman plan for pooling Western European coal and steel production.

PITTSBURGH, March 27 -- David J. McDonald, secretary-treasurer of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., told a union convention today that the steel workers were in "a particularly fortunate position" in their present wage dispute because they had "a rather friendly gentleman in the White House."

MONTREAL, March 27 (UP) -- Bernie Geoffrion scored once in each period to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-0 shutout over the Boston Bruins tonight and a 2-0 lead in their best-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-final hockey series.

The statement is repeatedly made in stories about the Presidential campaigns that New Jersey is the only state in which Senator Taft and General Eisenhower will run against each other. This is not so, or only in a highly technical sense.
HONG KONG, March 27 -- Prof. Ai Ssu-chi has been generally regarded as one of Red China's leading authorities on Marxism-Leninism and "thought of Mao Tse-tung."

NEWARK, March 27 -- The reopening of Newark Airport in two weeks for limited use by the Air Force appeared to be a certainty today as the City Commission here approved unanimously a recent request for resumption of activity by Assistant Secretary of the Air Force Edwin V. Huggins.

The curtain of the future was poked aside in several places yesterday by six prominent scholars, called together to tell a group of insurance executives what science could predict concerning coming events.

THE TIMES is to be heartily congratulated on its complete coverage of the recent International Chess Congress at Havana. Your editorial of March 22 was, of course, stimulating, and welcome to all lovers of chess.

LONDON, March 27 -- After a marathon debate on the crisis in the textile industries, the House of Commons adjourned at 1:27 o'clock this afternoon, having sat for three minutes short of twentythree hours.

Joseph Hudnut, Dean of the Graduate School of Design at Harvard University, was a speaker yesterday in part of a panel discussion on "A Mid-Century Survey of Interior Architecture and Design" presented for those attending the twenty-first annual conference of the American Institute of Decorators now in progress here.

This spring's group of beautiful babies is coming along now, automatically setting in motion a number of wheels, some perhaps a little lopsided. One certainly so is the "Baby's Book." Widely sold, nicely bound, with slight variations of the title, the book is the one in which are to be set down the dates of the baby's first step, the first word, first gifts and the like.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Federal Reserve Board took formal action today to break up the Giannini banking empire in five Far Western states, where forty-eight banks with 667 offices are controlled through the Trans-america Corporation.

Mayor Impellitteri called on Fordham University students yesterday to set a new nation-wide unit record by donating 3,000 pints of blood to aid United Nations forces in Korea. He spoke at a rally of 500 students of the school's City Hall Division, 302 Broadway.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, March 27 (AP) -- Gen. Sir Gerald Templer placed the 5,000 villagers of Tanjong Malim under house arrest today and cut their rice ration, angrily accusing many of them of aiding Communist guerrillas in the area, forty-five miles north of this city.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 27 (AP) -Rocky Graziano of New York, former world middleweight champion, dropped Roy Wouters of Montreal for a technical knockout tonight with an uppercut at 2:45 of the first round of their scheduled ten- round bout. Graziano weighed 164, Wouters 162 pounds.

ROME, March 27 -- In an Apostolic Letter addressed to the bishops and other clergy and the people of Rumania, Pope Plus called attention today to "the very pitiful condition of the Catholic Church" in that country.

TOKYO, March 27 -- The Japanese Government is quietly informing representatives of Western nations here that after ratification of the Japanese peace treaty they will be expected to pay and pay well for facilities used in Japan, for troops fighting in Korea or for diplomatic establishments hitherto obtained at bargain prices under the occupation regime.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 27 (UP) -- Dick Button of Englewood, N. J., the defending champion, gained a slim lead today as he launched the battle for his seventh straight crown at the thirty-fourth national figure skating championships.

The American taxpayer is paying through the nose for the low rate of return permitted to aircraft manufacturers, Mundy I. Peale, president of Republic Aviation Corporation, said yesterday in making public his company's annual report.
CHICAGO, March 27 -- Wheat showed a steady, firm tone today, but corn and oats were weak.

An enthusiastic audience of young careerists and residents of the Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, attended the second in a series of Career Girl Fashion Shows presented in that hotel last night. The shows, produced by Lynn O'Neil, are directed to the young working girls who are eager to know of the latest fashion, but are unable to attend the luncheon showings or spend hours in search of the right clothes.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- Even two successive days of rainfall for St. Pete failed to dim the luster of the Yankees today as they popped out of hiding along with the sun to polish off Eddie Stanky's Cardinals, 8 to 2.

MADRID, March 27 -- United States Ambassador Lincoln MacVeagh was understood today to have informed Generalissimo Francisco Franco of the desire of the United States Government to negotiate some arrangement with Spain that would contribute to strengthening of the Western defenses, and to have received from him an agreement in principle.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 29 to 37 points net lower than Wednesday.

GUATEMALA, March 27 -- The difficulties under which the United States-owned United Fruit Company has been struggling in Guatemala can best be understood by remembering what happened to the foreign-owned oil industry in Mexico and the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company in Iran.

Laddie Northridge, 16 West Fifty-seventh Street, displayed at the Plaza yesterday custom-made millinery that indicated this spring's hats would be soft but smart. Although there were crisp, simple suit hats, special emphasis was placed on exquisite flower trims, and many hats were designed entirely of flowers.

Draft payments by Brazil increased by $1,700,000, or 12.8 per cent, to $15,000,000 in February, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has reported. Even so, the payments amounted to only slightly more than half the December peak of $27,400,000 and were accompanied by a further reduction -- from $26,500,000 to $20,000,000 -- in the proportion of items paid promptly.

FORT HOOD, Tex., March 27 -- The first rain in many months in central Texas transformed Exercise Long Horn today from a near desert maneuver into a problem in fighting adhesive mud. Ground action continued nevertheless and actually progressed somewhat ahead of the schedule set by maneuver directors.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission ordered three large watch manufacturers tonight to stop what it called discrimination in granting allowances for advertising to their customers.

LONDON, March 27 -- The forthcoming talks on Trieste were arranged in a series of three-way conversations held during the week in London, Washington and Rome. The London phase of these conversations was concluded today when the Italian Ambassador called on Foreign Secretary Eden.

Miss Maryal Knox emerged from Wellesley College in 1901 with a degree equipping her to make pure mathematics her life work. Last night, at a dinner at Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street, she was honored for fifty years of effective coping with the highly non-theoretical problems of East Harlem.

MADRAS, India, March 27 -- Famine and drought, striking at the heart of the huge southern state of Madras, have left more than 10,000,000 Indian peasants in acute distress for food and water, State Governor Sri Prakasa declared today upon his return from a tour of the afflicted districts.

An eyewitness report on life in Russia today by Michel Gordey, foreign correspondent of France-Soir, will be published by Knopf on April 18. under the title "Visa to Moscow." Mr. Gordey, who served on the French General Staff until demobilized in 1940 and with the Office of War Information as chief editor of French broadcasts for the American Government, spent sixty-three days in the Soviet Union. His book recounts what he observed and heard there.

Mexican divorces are valid in this state, Supreme Court Justice E. L. Hammer ruled yesterday, when at least one of the parties appears personally in that country and the other is represented by authorized counsel.

The threatened tie-up of eight Bethlehem Steel Company shipyards on the East Coast was put back another thirty days last night as the shipworkers' union set a new deadline for midnight, April 29. An earlier extension would have expired Sunday night.

ANTWERP, Belgium, March 27 (UP) -- The entire crew of a British freighter quit today in protest over sailing to Communist ports less than twenty-four hours after their captain died mysteriously at sea with a bullet through his brain.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 27 (AP) -- Marty Furgol, 34-year-old professional who plays out of Lemont, Ill., equaled the course record with an eight-under-par 64 today to serve as leader in a mass assault on par in the opening round of the $10,000 Azalea open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A proposal to remove Newbold Morris, President Truman's special investigator into corruption in Government, and place the inquiry job into the hands of J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was introduced in the House of Representatives today.

A United Nations program to stimulate work on behalf of the blind over the world was described by Ernst Jorgeson at the forty-sixth annual meeting of the Lighthouse, held yesterday in its new auditorium, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

The unassailable principle that everybody ought to be interested in our public schools is well served by a bill signed into law by Governor Dewey. This law, sponsored by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore's Committee on City-School Fiscal Relations, makes the qualifications of the voter in a school-district election identical with those for a general election in cities under 125,000 population.

" The Gabriel Horn," a novel by Felix Holt, dealing with pioneer days in western Kentucky, has been purchased for filming by Norma Productions, the independent company owned by Burt Lancaster and Harold Hecht. Mr. Lancaster will star in the adventure drama.

Employers in the South are installing air-conditioning units in the houses of their night-shift workers, Herbert L. Laube, president of the Remington Corporation, told shareholders recently. He reported intallations for aircraft workers in Texas and others for textile and chemical workers in South Carolina.
MESA, Ariz., March 27 (AP) -Hank Sauer blasted a pair of two-run homers and Bob Rush twirled a three-hitter to give the Cubs a 4-2 exhibition victory over the White Sox today.

ROME, March 27 -- The United States, British and Italian Governments have decided to study arrangements for associating Italy more closely with the Allied Military Government of the British-American occupation zone of the Free Territory of Trieste.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Tall farmers from the plains, with Western hats and flashy neckties, told the Senate Agriculture Committee today a story of rather neighborly dishonesty involving grain on which the Government had made price support loans.
ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Dewey today urged "general cooperation and support" for the work of organizations trying to alleviate the sufferings of Jewish children in several European countries.

Two more of the sixteen indicted secondary Communist leaders received permission yesterday from Federal Judge Edward Dimock to leave New York and return Monday morning, several hours before the start of the trial.

The New York State Central School District composed of East Greenbush, Nassau, Schodack, Sank Lake. North Greenwich and Enatham in Rensselaer and Columbia Counties sold yesterday $935,000 of bonds due Oct. 1, 1952 to 1972, to C. J. Devine Co. and associates at a bid of 100.07 for interest of 1.80 per cent.

In the first evaluation of the two-month-old rule compelling motorists to drive with low-beam headlights, Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley asserted yesterday that it was obtaining its objective of reducing night traffic accidents.

Debutantes of the forthcoming and the past seasons, who are serving on the debutante and junior committees for the Mayfair Assemblies next winter, will be the guests of honor at two teas to be given by Miss Clementine Miller in her home at 130 East Seventy-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended March 22, 1952, totaled 719,921 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,095 cars or 1.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 28,957 cars or 3.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 2,662 cars or 0.4 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Maritime Administration said today it had granted American Export Lines extension until April 30, to decide whether to accept lower Government subsidies on the company's two $25,000,000 luxury liners, the Independence and the Constitution.

Although commercially packaged foods now figure prominently in Passover menus, much cooking in preparation for the holiday still is done at home. This year two leading manufacturers of kosher foods are introducing new recipes, one for a roll leavened only by steam, another for an easy-to-do fruit fluden.

TOKYO, Friday, March 28 -- United Nations and Communist staff officers argued again without result today over a Chinese and North Korean demand that the Soviet Union be included as one of the neutral nations to police an armistice in the Korean war.

SEATTLE, March 27 (AP) -- The choice of whether to take the ball out of bounds or shoot for a free point after a foul was taken away from the players today by the National Basketball Rules Committee of the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Military expenditures in the next several months are due to rise to a level of $5,000,000,000 a month, or about $167,000,000 a day, Congress has been advised by Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense.

BANGOR, Me., March 27 -- Maine Republicans created a housing shortage in Bangor today with an influx of 1,813 representatives to their biennial state meeting to select delegates to the Republican National Convention in Chicago beginning July 7.

MADISON, Wis., March 27 -- Three major Republican Presidential aspirants moved into the home stretch of the Wisconsin primary contest today with new appeals to attract votes from the supporters of two five-star generals, Dwight D. Eisenhower and Douglas MacArthur, whose names are not on the ballot and legally cannot be written in.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- Asian diplomats predicted today that the arrest by France of four high Tunisian Government officials would speed the presentation of the entire Tunisian case to the United Nations Security Council.

The state rested its case against the bank robbers William Sutton and Thomas King in Queens County Court in Long Island City yesterday. The defense put on one witness before adjournment for the day, and indicated it might complete its case this evening.
LONDON, Friday, March 28 -- Laborites and Conservatives crossed verbal swords in the House of Commons yesterday on the most acute issue in British politics: the welfare state versus rearmament.

ONE of the most interesting and attractive of the remarkable group of able men known as the Founding Fathers was "a lighthearted gentleman" who has escaped the secular canonization that has been the posthumous reward of some of his contemporaries. Gouverneur Morris was not the kind of hero who is often presented to school children for their emulation.

MILWAUKEE, March 27 (UP) -Orrell Anderson, Fort Atkinson, Wis., rolled into third place in the doubles division of the American Bowling Congress tourney today, after shooting the high series of the tourney -- a 722.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- The United States must clean house and adopt a policy of conservation in the preparedness program to avoid weakening the economy, Admiral W. H. P. Blandy, retired, declared today at the sixteenth annual conference of the central states group, investment bankers association of America. He now is president of the health information foundation.

The first application of the New York State Athletic Commission's working agreement with other state groups occurred yesterday when the New York board refused a request for reinstatement from Willie Pep, former featherweight champion or the world.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 27 -- By tackling its first post-war unemployment problem firmly and quickly, the Netherlands hopes to prove that economic policies that help a country to balance its accounts with the outside world are not incompatible with reasonable internal economic stability.

Milton Weill, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, which supports 116 medical care and social service institutions, reported yesterday that it had raised $14,100,000 this year. He said this sum was a "little more than $1,000,000 short" of the agency's "rock-bottom operational needs of $15,200,000."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 -- The Federal Reserve Board's decision to dissolve the Giannini banking empire, headed by the Transamerica Corporation, will be fought in the Federal courts, officers of the company asserted today.

The Senate will have the opportunity next week to take a progressive step in resolving sensibly the fourteen-year-old battle between some states and the Federal Government over control of oil lands beneath the marginal seas. It can take this step by approving Senator O'Mahoney's "interim" resolution (S. J. Res. 20), which would permit development of this great natural resource under federal auspices but with important concessions to the claims of the coastal states.

DETROIT, March 27 (UP) -- Goalie Terry Sawchuk achieved his second straight shutout tonight as the Detroit Red Wings gained a 2-0 lead over Toronto in their Stanley Cup play-off series with a 1-0 victory.

For the third time the complaint of Duane Jones, head of the agency bearing his name, against nine of his former employes has been sustained. The latest decision was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer. Judge Louis A. Valente had previously denied a motion of the defendants to dismiss the complaint and a subsequent appeal of the denial was also dismissed on Monday by the Appellate Division.
Willie (The Actor) Sutton scribbled a limerick yesterday bemoaning the $10,000 in cash seized from him by his police captors. The wad of bills was exhibited in evidence at his bank robbery trial.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, Republican leader of the Senate, testified under oath today that the sole reason he intervened in a $7,000,000 tax case was to "encourage quick and proper action by the Government."

PRINCETON, N. J., March 27 -A record-breaking performance by Ford Konno in the 1,500-meter free-style tonight gave the first title of the twenty-ninth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships to Ohio State.
CHATHAM, Va., March 27 (AP)--Spirit rites around a freshly dug-up skull and bones in a college lounge room led today to the indictment of six students on the felony charge of grave robbing.

As the lines were being drawn at City Hall yesterday for battles over new nuisance taxes and emergency financing, Mayor Impellitteri said the city would have to use all the enabling stop-gap measures signed Wednesday by Governor Dewey.

" The Dybbuk," the opera by the American composer, David Tamkin, which was the best seller of the City Center's 1951 fall season, returned to the repertoire last night as the second week of the spring season began. It impressed one again with its stageworthiness and, at its most stirring moments, with the imaginative quality of its production.

Your editorial of March 18, published on the eve of the Paris meeting of the Foreign Ministers Committee of the Council of Europe, is a masterly presentation of the American approach to the vital problem of European unification. It rightly stresses the importance and significance of General Eisenhower's appeal "to issue a call for a constitutional convention to draft a plan for a European Federation or a United States of Europe."

LONDON, March 26 (Reuters) -- The death of Sir Robert Witt, the art connoisseur who helped found the National Art Collections Fund nearly a half-century ago, was announced here tonight. His age was 80. He had been a war correspondent with Cecil Rhodes.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, explaining why he favored General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination, last night upbraided those who injected "silly, bitter and unfounded charges" into the campaign for convention delegates.

Expansion planned by Bowater Paper Corportion, Ltd., in the next two years will increase its newsprint output by 300,000 tons to 1,100,000 a year. Sir Eric Bowater, chairman of the British-Canadian concern, said yesterday as he arrived on the Queen Mary.
Eight contract bridge teams, surviving contenders of an original field of thirty-five teams, moved last night into the quarter-final round of the Eastern States team-of-four championship.

Four years ago the Community Service Society paused in the midst of its one-hundredth-anniversary observance to take a closer look at its program from the standpoint of what lies ahead. This self-examination was undertaken by a special committee appointed by the Society's trustees.

The Ford Foundation's Board on Overseas Training and Research announced yesterday that it was prepared to grant fellowships to as many as 100 American men and women who wished to pursue studies dealing with Asia and the Near and Middle East.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 27 -The pains in the neck, the aching backs and the sore feet that make up a large part of the complaints for which patients see their family doctor generally can be treated simply in office or home, specialists reparted here today at the final session of the annual meeting of the American Academy of General Practice.
JERSEY CITY, March 27 (AP) -- Jersey Central Lines today reported 1951 gross operating revenues higher than any year in the railroad's history but net earnings were below those of 1950.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) had a net income last year of $202,278,299 after charges and taxes, equal to $7.82 each on the 25,865,310 shares of capital stock outstanding, according to 1951 annual report for publication today.

Dr. Henry T. Heald, new chancellor of New York University, declared last night that faculty members should have the freedom to talk about political, matters without being subject to "irresponsible" attacks because "someone thinks they represent an unpopular point of view."

PARIS, March 27 -- French President Vincent Auriol sent two representatives today to Sidi Mohammed el Amin Pasha, the Bey of Tunis, nominal ruler of France's Tunisian protectorate, in an effort to re-establish contacts with him that were broken abruptly yesterday by the French arrest of his nationalist Ministers.

Successful outcome of three offerings of mor than $74,000,000 in new issues of common stock was announced yesterday by the underwriters. The financing was undertaken in behalf of Canadian Chemical and Cellulose Company, Ltd., American Tobacco Company and Texas Eastern Transmission Company.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Office of Price Stabilization ordered the country's 500,000 eating and drinking places to display dollars-and-cents ceiling prices for their meals and beverages, including alcoholic ones, today and directed that the prices not exceed those charged during the week of Feb. 3.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, challenged Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, today to seek trial of his $2,000,000 suit for libel, slander and conspiracy before November, when both Senators will come up for re-election in their respective states.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -Stocks of finished television sets in the hands of manufacturers represent two-weeks' production, as compared with a supply of several months that prevailed last spring.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Dewey approved today, with a strong supporting message, a bill that outlaws televised public hearings like those held by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee in New York City.

Plans are being completed for the annual spring festival of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church on April 24 and 25 in the Parish House of the church for the benefit of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.

MILWAUKEE, March 27 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today told the Milwaukee Foreign Policy Association and the Milwaukee Rotary Club at a luncheon here that he would confine all further foreign aid to technical assistance and end what he termed "handouts" to foreign countries.

In his 1946 income tax return, Samuel Ochs, a statistician for a member company of the New York Stock Exchange, claimed a medical deduction of $1,456 for maintaining his two small children in boarding school for the benefit of his wife, who was suffering from cancer of the throat.

Mayor Shlomo Z. Shragai, Israel's first elected mayor of the new city in Jerusalem, asserted last night that his nation could achieve peace with the Arab nations "if we are ready to halt the influx of Jewish immigrants, but this we would never do."

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 27 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower conferred at Supreme Headquarters today with four top defense officials in France -- Rene Pleven, Minister of Defense; Pierre de Chevigne, Under Secretary for the Army; Jacques Gavini, Navy Under Secretary, and Pierre Montel, Under Secretary for Air.

To enable patrolmen who recently performed heroic deeds to get added credit tomorrow if they participate in the promotion examination for sergeants, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan issued a special order yesterday awarding departmental recognition to 237 members of the force.

Many parties were given at the luncheon and fashion show, entitled "Along Fifth Avenue," given yesterday in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop. Miss Louise Edgar is president of the beneficiary, which is located at 938 Eighth Avenue and is maintained for the benefit of various charitable organizations.
Heavier lamb supplies have brought prices on two popular cuts to the lowest general level since February, 1951, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

Fire Commissioner Jacob Crumet reserved decision yesterday after the departmental trial of Deputy Chief Nathan Perlman, who is charged with shaking down a fire victim and paying $1,000 in hush money to former First Deputy Commissioner James J. Moran when the victim made a complaint.

SEATTLE, March 27 (AP) -- The Lovellette-powered basketball machine that wears the Crimson and Blue of Kansas set its sights on the Olympics today after routing St John's, 80 -- 63, last night in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship final.

Sears Roebuck Co. enjoys a "healthy" inventory position and is "open-to-buy," according to one of its top executives. Large chain retailers are looking forward to a good Easter business and will be in the market before May with replacement orders in soft-goods lines.

The Welfare Council of New York City and the Health Council of Greater New York were merged yesterday for more effective, economical service and to give reality to the concept that health and welfare are inseparable.

Stockholders of the Whirlpool Corporation, St. Joseph, Mich., at a special meeting here yesterday, approved a plan to merge with the Clyde Porcelain Steel Corporation of Clyde, Ohio, whose shareholders approved the plan last March 10.

MEXICO CITY, March 27 -- The first defections in the ranks of the leaders of the Oaxaca general strike occurred today after Governor Manuel Mayoral Heredia, in a new bid to bring peace, dismissed four leading officers of his State Government.

MERRIMAN, Neb., March 27 (UP) -- A 32-year-old ranch hand who killed three persons and wounded two, including an infant, in a midnight shooting spree was shot to death today by a posse that fired 1,000 shots and burned down three buildings to get him.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres today. "Lilli Marlene," a British-made drama starring Lisa Daniely and Hugh McDermott, is at the Holiday Theatre. Arthur Crabtree directed and William J. Gell produced the R. K. O. release from an original screen story by Leslie Wood.

" Coppelia" in a three-act form comprised the entire program of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet at the Warner Theatre last night, with the second of the company's ballerinas, Svetlana Beriosova, making her first New York appearance in the leading role. Dame Ninette de Valois, the director of the company, staged the work according to Nicholas Sergeyev's revisions of the Russian version by Ivanov and Cecchetti.
DENVER, March 27 -- A nine-point bargaining program, including a demand for a 25-cent-an-hour wage increase, was ratified here today by the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers.

HANOI, Indo-China, March 27 (UP) -- French - Vietnamese army headquarters tonight reported "satisfactory progress" in the biggest offensive in months against a rebel division which had thrust spearheads within twenty miles of Hanoi.

LONDON, March 27 -- Experiments at the White Sands proving ground in New Mexico show that the composition of the air is uniform in most of its constituents up to a height of thirty-five miles, the Chemical Society was told tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Service Pipe Line Company of Tulsa, Okla., applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for registration of a $90,000,000 issue of thirty-year debentures. The debentures, to mature April 1, 1982, are to be offered for public sale through an underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co.
TOKYO, Friday, March 28 (AP) -General Headquarters communique 1,202 for Thursday's operations:
CLEVELAND, March 27 -- A temporary order restraining three unions from striking against the railroads was extended to April 10 by Federal Judge Emerich B. Freed today.
