WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, said today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's chief of staff had made a strong case for a Mutual Security program but did not specifically commit himself to the Administration's $7,900,000,000 proposal.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 27 (UP) -- The Phillies' third baseman, Willie (Puddinhead) Jones, was fined $200 today for a mysterious transgression which manager Eddie Sawyer called "conduct detrimental to the club." Sawyer merely announced the fine and said, "If Jones wishes to give the details, it is up to him."
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- During the week ended March 26, member bank reserves decreased $762,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

An easing of the labor and material market in the heavy construction field was indicated yesterday when the New York State Thruway Authority confirmed that it was letting new contracts at 10 to 15 per cent below engineering estimates.

A thousand life-preservers for use on Staten Island ferryboats have been rejected for insufficient buoyancy and the Coast Guard is making an investigation into the stamp of approval given the jackets by its inspectors.
NEW ORLEANS, March 27 (AP) -- Marilynn Smith and Patty Berg trimmed par with 73's to move ahead tied with a two-stroke lead in the $4,000 New Orleans women's open tournament today after 18 holes.

Sales and earnings of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., showed a decline in the company's fiscal year ended last January, but nevertheless were the fourth highest in eighty-four years, according to the annual report released today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 27 (AP) -- Demands for the resignation of Foreign Minister Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan were made today in Parliament in a barrage of criticism of his policy respecting the disputed border state of Kashmir.

ST. PAUL, March 27 (AP) -- William L. McKnight, board chairman of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, has announced he is selling about 20 per cent of his stock in the company to avoid "forced sale" of the stock after his death to meet "confiscatory" estate taxes.

Attempts of the Communists to take over the demonstrations for the return of Trieste to Italy have been foiled by the demonstrators themselves. It now transpires that most of the violence that developed in the stormy mass meetings in the streets of Italian cities was largely due to clashes between Communist agitators and students fighting to expel them.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 27 -The Bradenton City Council officially renamed the local ball park Braves Field yesterday, but today it belonged to the Dodgers and Ben Wade.
CHICAGO, March 27 (UP) -- The Journal of the American Medical Association warned today that excessive smoking could hurt vocal cords, causing tumors that might require surgery.

Johnny Bratton, Chicago welterweight, will go out of his class to tackle Rocky Castellani, Luzerne (Pa.) middleweight in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Despite the weight difference, Bratton will be favored, probably at 5 to 8.

James R. McConeghy, a suspended policeman, was convicted of first-degree perjury last night as the result of testimony he gave last year during a trial arising from a Brooklyn grand jury inquiry into organized gambling. The verdict was returned at 11 P. M. by a blue ribbon jury int he Kings County Court.
Two television matters are to hand this morning: the reappearance of Dagmar in her own show and the debut of that old radio standby, "Gangbusters." Both leave TV about where it was.
DANVERS, Mass., March 27 -Two former convicts were hunted tonight by the police investigating the theft of $681,000 in cash from an armored truck in Danvers Square two days ago.
Differing artistic currents can be seen in five exhibitions of paintings now on view at metropolitan galleries.
" The Long Watch" at the Lyceum will be a brief one. Tomorrow night the Harvey Haislip play about the WAVES will ring down its final curtain after chalking up a dozen performances.

In explaining the Western rejection of the Soviet proposal for another Big Four conference on Germany, Secretary Acheson cites as an example of Soviet duplicity the fruitless seven-year-long discussion of a treaty for Austria and rightly makes Soviet agreement on that question a test of Soviet sincerity.

Making his second appearance of the season with the Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall, Leonard Rose, the former first 'cellist of the orchestra, chose the fine Dvorak concerto to reveal once more his superior powers as musician and executant.

Out of good impulses and sensitive perceptions Truman Capote has written a beautiful play. He calls it "The Grass Harp"; it was acted with delicacy and love at the Martin Beck last evening. Although Mr. Capote has written fiction, "The Grass Harp" is his first play -- made, as a matter of fact, from one of his novels.

PARIS, March 27 -- A resolution before the European Marshall Plan Council calling for increased production in Western Europe was held up for redrafting today after Paul R. Porter, representing the United States Mutual Security Agency, had urged that it be put into more positive form.

Plans to increase dollar exports of quality metals products, made by Sweden's 300-year-old Husqvarna Company, were announced yesterday by officials of the concern and its representatives in the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices had declined about 1/3 of per cent between mid-February and mid-March.
NEW ORLEANS, March 28 (AP) -- Patty Berg, who has played more than a dozen years of professional golf, shot a par 74 to take a six-stroke lead in the New Orleans women's open tournament today.

The Loewy Construction Company, a subsidiary of Hydropress, Inc., of New York, announced yesterday that it would supply two die forging presses and six extrusion presses, together with the required hydraulic power plants, for the heavy press program of the United States Air Force.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 28 -- Some American youngsters with normal sweet tooths soon may be catapulted into a situation somewhat more desirable than their fondest daydreams of the endless wonders at hand in the Land of Oz. Adults, however, might detect a faint note of commercialism in a new project announced here today by Blum's of San Francisco, well-known confectioners.

Officials of the Board of Transportation have once more been giving informal thought to the idea, many times proposed but never effectively adopted, of "staggering" business hours in the city to reduce the crush of peak passenger travel on rapid-transit lines during morning and evening rush periods.

EDMONTON, Alta., March 28 (Canadian Press) -- A pulp plant is to be built at Red Deer, Alta., at a minimum cost of $5,000,000. An agreement between the Alberta Government and the International Resources. Ltd., a concern backed by two Seattle financiers, was approved today in a Government order-in-council.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- With expansion goals set in steel, aluminum and other basic metals, the Defense Production Administration has turned its attention to divisions of the chemical industry, from which increased output is considered essential to national defense.
LANSING, Mich., March 28 (UP) -- Janet Backmas of Boston, Ray Blum of Nutley, N. J., and Mario Trafeli of Detroit established new North American speed-skating records tonight.

ROME, March 28 -- All hope of creating a united anti-Communist front for the municipal elections to be held in central and southern Italy May 25 seemed lost today when the right-wing Socialists turned down an offer to form an electoral alliance with the Christian Democrats, who had expected that three or four minor parties would rally to them.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Six major steel companies and the United Steelworkers, C.I.O., will meet Monday in New York to take up the wage contract dispute that threatens to shut down the industry April 8.

LONDON, March 28 -- Japanese bonds climbed to a new high level in the Stock Exchange here today on -- report (confirmed after the markets closed) that Japan was about to deposit 20,000,000 with the Bank of England as an earnest of her intention to repay her sterling bonded debt.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg has warned Congress that Russia has "several thousand" more warplanes than the United States and has developed atomic weapons that pose "the most ominous threat this country has ever known."
FORT COLLINS, Colo., March 28 (AP) -- Iowa State Teachers College moved in front in the National Collegiate A. A. wrestling tournament tonight by qualifying six men for tomorrow's semi-finals.

Those who take an interest in the furnishings of the Presidential home may wish to inspect the collection of fabrics utilized in the newly-decorated White House. Now assembled in the windows of B. Altman Co., the materials also may be bought at the store.

The Olympic trials, marking the end of the amateur basketball campaign -- the Knickerbockers are still alive on the professional end -- will begin at Madison Square Garden tonight with a double-header, starting at 7:45.

The compulsory automobile inspection bill failed to pass at this session of the State Legislature, but that does not relieve automobile owners of the responsibility of keeping their cars and equipment in good condition. This responsibility was pointed up sharply in Nassau County recently when hundreds of cars and trucks were inspected for safe driving by Interstate Commerce Commission and Public Service Commission officials.

Having practiced psychiatry for almost thirty years, I read with particular interest the letter from John J. Curran to THE TIMES published on March 19. In it he supported a legislative proposal which would require that the psychiatrist, "whenever practical, be of the same religious faith as the child" requiring treatment.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 28 (AP) -- Five or more persons were killed today in a riot sparked by a parade of Communist youths who support Soviet charges that the United States is using germ warfare in Korea. About 200 persons were reported injured.

Rocky Castellani, the Luzerne, Pa., boxer who in his last appearance at Madison Square Garden lost a fight (to Ernie Durando) and a manager (Tommy Eboli), returned last night and registered probably his most notable victory.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The proposal in Congress for extending preferential primaries throughout the country as guides to party national conventions in nominating for the Presidency and Vice Presidency was referred to the Governors of the states today for their advice.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)--A special commission studying air safety in major cities left today for a week-long tour that will take it to twelve cities in the South, Midwest and Far West.

BAYONNE, N. J., March 28 -Two sailors were asphyxiated in a fuel tank aboard the Navy carrier Enterprise at the New York Navy Yard Annex here today, and a third enlisted man narrowly escaped a similar fate when he tried to rescue them.

ALBANY, March 28 -- A three-judge Federal court rejected today by a two-to-one decision an application to halt the special election to be held in the Thirty-second Congressional District Tuesday to name a successor to the late Representative William T. Byrne.

BALTIMORE, March 28 - Although trustees of the Johns Hopkins University said today that the publicity of the Owen Lattimore controversy was "embarrassing," they do not propose to do anything about it, according to Carlyle Barton, attorney and board chairman.

MILWAUKEE, March 28 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, who seeks the Republican Presidential nomination, today opened a three-day drive here as he went into the final phase of his campaign to win Wisconsin's thirty delegates to the Republican National Convention.
CHICAGO, March 28 -- Chicago's mail order houses have started mailing their midspring catalogues and the collection of price reductions listed is the largest in many months.

HONG KONG, March 28 -- While continuing to accuse the United States of waging "bacteriological warfare" against them, the Chinese Communists were authoritatively reported today to be combating scattered epidemics in close to one-tenth of China's 2,000-odd counties.

The importance of the Wisconsin Republican primary next Tuesday rests on the simple fact that Senator Taft has staked virtually everything on winning an unequivocal victory. If he achieves it he may at least momentarily arrest the bandwagon swing away from him that began in New Hampshire and has gathered force in Minnesota and New Jersey.

BANGOR, Me., March 28 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, although missing the sweep that he registered in the primary in neighborhing New Hampshire three weeks ago, took nine and possibly eleven of Maine's sixteen Republican delegates, who were chosen today at the biennial state convention.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 28 -- Manilal Gandhi's twenty-one-day fast in protest against South Africa's apartheid laws (separation of races) ended today when he drank a glass of diluted orange juice after praying in the Mohandas K. Gandhi Memorial Home near his cottage outside Durban.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 28 -- Leo Durocher made two experiments this afternoon with his National League champions and they not only paid rich dividends but provided an appropriate flourish for the Giants 1952 farewell to Phoenix.

Eight corporate bond issues totaling $89,260,000 are scheduled to reach the public market next week. The underwriters' calendar will be varied, too, by substantial offerings of common and preferred stock and major new issues of municipal bonds.

Quality-control techniques are reducing research time as well as production time in both the defense industry and civilian manufacturing, speakers said yesterday at the Middle Atlantic Regional Conference of the American Society for Quality Control.

Once more a clear-cut victory for the forces which would protect the Adirondack Preserve from invasion has been registered. Justice Earle C. Bastow had been called upon to decide upon the validity of the Stokes Act, which prohibits the building of dams on the south branch of the Moose River.

MADISON, Wis., March 28 -The historic enmity of Wisconsin's regular Republicans toward the insurgent La Follettes was being exploited here in the last heated hours of the Presidential primary by the supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

CAIRO, March 28 -- At a formal press conference tonight, Ahmed Mortada el Maraghi, Minister of the Interior, stated that efforts were being made to smuggle explosives into Egypt and that a considerable quantity of such explosives were now in the hands of the authorities who had intercepted them.

MILWAUKEE, March 28 (AP) -- Stanley Gober, 47-year-old Kenosha, Wis., accountant, took first place in the American Bowling Congress tournament singles' division today with a 682-pin series. He went into second place in the all-events with 1,865, trailing Gene Sass of Milwaukee, who has 1,876.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A House investigating subcommittee received sworn testimony today that Hyman Harvey Klein, Baltimore liquor dealer, got preferential treatment by the Internal Revenue Bureau in the handling of a $7,000,000 tax case against him.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Frederick Vanderbilt Field, in his third appearance before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, pleaded constitutional privilege today against self-incrimination in refusing to answer dozens of questions addressed to him.

Forty-four dwellings are planned for the first section of a home colony on a portion of the Schiff estate formerly owned by Mrs. Dorothy Thackery, on Northern Boulevard and Split Rock Road in East Norwich, L. I. The property recently was acquired by a real estate syndicate known as Split Rock Ridge, Inc.
The trustees of Columbia University declared yesterday that they "would not countenance the presence of an avowed Communist on its teaching staff."

JANESVILLE, Wis., March 28 -- Janesville residents are talking -- and arguing today about the man who came to deliver a non-partisan lecture on Russia, but who branched into a political talk in behalf of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio.

An increase of up to 10 per cent in the rate charged by the Kings County Lighting Company may result from a proposed rise in natural gas cost and a wage increase sought by the Utility Workers of America, C. I. O., officials predicted yesterday after a hearing before the Public Service Commission, 233 Broadway.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- The Red Sox blasted Howard Fox, the starting pitcher, for eleven hits and all their runs today to defeat the Phillies, 9 to 7, in an exhibition.

TOKYO, March 28 -- The Japanese Government took the first step today to give legal backing to the administrative agreement between Japan and the United States for retention of American military bases in Japan after ratification of the San Francisco Peace Treaty.

When he stopped off in Stockholm this week, Prof. Oscar Lange announced that 450 delegates would attend the Moscow Economic Conference, which opens next Thursday. This estimate falls short of the 600 delegates originally expected, and considering the vast effort which was made to enlist Western participants it is evident that the high expectations the Kremlin once held have been at least partially dashed.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 28 -- Greater emphasis on the study of the Spanish language and Latin- American culture as a way of promoting hemisphere understanding and solidarity was urged today at a conference on inter-American culture and education, held on the campus of Rutgers University.

Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, producers and creators of "The King and I," and Doretta Morrow, who has been absent from the hit musical for about six weeks because of a throat ailment, jointly announced yesterday that Miss Morrow "is leaving the company."
Three exhibitions of contemporary sculpture, presenting work by five artists, are sufficiently varied in character to give a fair picture of what carvers, modelers and welders are up to today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -The Senate gave quick and unanimous passage today to a measure aimed at speeding "slum clearance and urban redevelopment projects" in New York and other areas. The measure amends existing Federal Housing laws so that partial Federal advances can be made on such projects.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue today designated Clarence R. Krigbaum, agent in charge of the bureau's Second New York Division, to be District Commissioner of Internal Revenue for New York. He was the first of the new commissioners to be named. The action was taken under the reorganization legislation recently approved by Congress.

The unpredictable record industry stands on the threshold of another revolution -- a gradual one -- according to one of the largest juke box manufacturers in the country. John W. Haddock, president of AMI, Inc., predicted yesterday that forty-five-revolutions-a-minute records ultimately will supplant entirely the standard seventy-eight r.p.m. disks that now dominate the popular music field in juke boxes.

Soviet Russia and the United States were analyzed critically yesterday by a university professor and a financier. The examinations led to a diagnosis of the former as a determined fanatic and a warning to the latter that it was in danger of succumbing to a suicide guilt complex.
The New York University's basketball team's second meeting with Fordham this season resulted in a 68-57 triumph for the Violets last night.

The proposal of the guaranteed annual wage, reduced to essentials, means private unemployment insurance paid for by employers in industries subject to cyclical unemployment, the Guaranty Survey, the monthly publication of the Guaranty Trust Company, points out in its April issue published yesterday.

ROME, March 28 -- The decision of the United States and British Governments to consider giving Italy a larger share of the responsibility for administering Zone A (the British-American zone) of the Free Territory of Trieste has not been received with as much favor by Italian public opinion as might have been expected.

BONN, Germany, March 28 -- A general treaty giving West Germany political independence and a European Defense Community treaty enlisting German strength in the defense of Western Europe will be initialed in Bonn in the second half of May, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer announced tonight.
With lawyers for both sides accelerating activities, the Duane Jones litigation, in which the original complaint was filled on July 3, 1951, is said to be advancing.

LONDON, March 28 -- Six senior representatives of the Bamangwato tribe in Bechuanaland will fly to London from Johannesburg, South Africa, April 6 to ask the British Government for the immediate reinstatement and return of Seretse Khama as their chief, it was announced here today.

Another local major ship repair concern with the expiration of its labor agreement imminent received a month's grace yesterday as the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., announced postponement of strike action against the Todd Shipyards Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union said today that the union's members were entitled to wage increases but it left the timing of any formal demand until later.

Fire and smoke in a dress shop on the eleventh floor of 1359 Broadway, near Thirty-sixth Street, added to the snarls of traffic in the garment district early yesterday afternoon. Traffic was rerouted from West Thirty-sixth Street, causing more than normal congestion in Herald Square.

MIAMI, Fla., March 28 -- Manager Chuck Dressen and Vice President Buzzie Bavasi lopped nine names off the Dodger roster today, just three days before the Brooks start the homeward journey that will plunge them into another pennant race.

There is a certain something about the word "champagne," whether it comes from the Champagne district of France, from New York State, from California or elsewhere. For those who inspect labels when they pour a drink the word is important, which explains why this country for generations has been a champagne importer.

A half century of automotive achievements and eccentricities, with prim, antique vehicles peering through dim headlamps at gaudy high-powered cars, was portrayed at a preview of the International Motor Sports Show last night at the Grand Central Palace.

NEWARK, March 28 -- Leo F. Link, 62 years old, described by Treasury Department officials as one of the leading bookmakers in the metropolitan area, was sentenced today to four years in a Federal penitentiary and fined $10,000 for evading payment of income taxes totaling $136,291 for the years 1946 to 1949, inclusive. He had been convicted on Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -International Utilities Corporation of New York filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the sale of 250,000 shares of its $25 par cumulative convertible preferred stock. Butcher Sherrerd heads the list of United States Underwriters and Nesbitt, Thomson Co., Ltd., that of Canadian Underwriters.

An industrial site of approximately forty-eight acres at the northwest corner of Talmade Road and Lincoln Highway in Raritan Township, N. J., has been sold by the Manor Real Estate and Trust Company, a subsidiary of the Pennsylvania Railroad, to the United States Envelope Company. The Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization was the broker.

FORT HOOD, Tex., March 28 (UP) -- Gen. John E. Hull, Vice Chief of Staff of the Army, said today that the Army has formed special atomic artillery units to fire atomic shells from a "heavy type of artillery."

Syndicate subscription books on six new major issues of corporate bonds totaling $168,000,000 were closed yesterday as savings banks and smaller insurance companies decided to put in order rather than wait out the bankers any longer.
Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan ruled yesterday that Frank Costello would go on trial Monday before a jury, although the gambler had sought trial without jury on charges of contempt of the Senate.

Erwin Lessner, author of "Blitzkrieg and Bluff" and "Phantom Victory," has written a novel based on his experiences in Europe which Doubleday will publish Monday. In "At the Devil's Booth," the protagonist is a Viennese newspaper publisher and soldier, both of which Mr. Lessner has been.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- Paul Jarrico, Hollywood screen writer, filed a suit for $350,000 in Superior Court today against Howard Hughes, production head and principal stock owner of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, for damages for depriving him of screen credit on the recent film, "The Las Vegas Story."

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 (AP) -- The return heavyweight title bout between Jersey Joe Walcott, the champion, and Ezzard Charles, on again, off again oftener than an English Channel swim in squally weather, will be signed and sealed here Monday for a probable June 9 delivery.

THE novel of derring-do at sea is the British equivalent of the American Wild-Western tale, and C. S. Forester's Horatio Hornblower must by now be as well known as Owen Wister's Virginian. In "Lieutenant Hornblower"* Mr. Forester goes back to the early days of his unsinkable and indestructible sailor. The tremendous battles and ambuscades of the main Hornblower tri1ogy ("Beat to Quarters," "Flying Colours," and "A Ship of the Line") still lie ahead.

PARIS, March 28 -- The survival of the European Marshall Plan council with enlarged functions seemed assured tonight after this policy had received the strong support of the United States and the concurrence of the British Government, which had proposed to limit the council's activities.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 28 -- Dr. Donald F. Gibson admitted today he had made a mistake in his gall-bladder operation on Frank Wetmore, New Milford auto repair man whose widow is now Dr. Gibson's wife.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 28 -- The man who has a good knowledge of himself can usually judge most accurately what others think of him, it was suggested in two studies that were reported here today at the twenty-third annual meeting of the Eastern Psychological Association.

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., March 28 -- A formal complaint on the Tunisian case to the United Nations Security Council was held off by its Arab-Asian bloc sponsors today after the surprise appointment of a new Premier for the French protectorate.

Today's new film opening is "Pardon My French," a romantic comedy filmed on location in France and starring Merle Oberon and Paul Henreid, at the Baronet Theatre. Bernard Vorhaus directed the Cusick International Films production from a script by Roland Kibbee. United Artists is releasing the offering.
TOKYO, Saturday, March, 29 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,203, for Friday's operations:

The all-star quartet of Charles Boyer, Charles Laughton, Cedric Hardwicke and Agnes Moorehead in Bernard Shaw's "Don Juan in Hell" makes its third visit to the local scene tomorrow when it opens at the Plymouth Theatre at 2:40 P. M.

DENVER, March 28 (UP) -- Jittery Denver residents were hopeful today that cold weather had killed a deadly king cobra missing in the city but a reptile dealer who reported its theft ordered anti-snakebite serum flown here as a precaution.

The election of T. T. Miller as vice president-marketing, and George W. Blackwood as vice president-general sales manager of Dewey Almy Chemical Company was announced by Hugh S. Ferguson, executive vice president.

VIENNA, March 25 -- The Soviet Union is binding its satellites to itself with a lengthening network of broad-gauge railroads. Recent reports that the Russian gauge already had been laid into Czechoslovakia and Hungary have not been confirmed.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use about the home:
ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill authorizing the transfer of Champlain College at Plattsburg to the Air Force for conversion into an air base.

PARIS, March 28 -- The Bey of Tunis made a complete surrender tonight to the policy of force applied in the last two days by the French protectors of his realm in an effort to end the three months of violence and the nationalist agitation there.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, 111.7 per cent of the 1947-49 average was 2.9 per cent below the index of 115 per cent prevailing before the General Ceiling Price Regulation became effective in January, 1951.

A professor of political philosophy and an economist agreed yesterday that this nation would have a fine future if we watched our step, but a college president warned that "inordinate taxation and waste" in government might "lose us the very freedom we are trying to save."

GUATEMALA CITY, March 27 -- Communism is very influential in Guatemala but it is not in control and the chances are that it is never going to get control. This is not the popular, or general, conclusion in Guatemala, and most of the experts will dispute it, but in the present circumstances it is hard for one observer to reach any other conclusion.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- A bill to ease requirements for state banks to get into the Federal Reserve System was offered today by Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, chairman of the Banking Committee.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 28 -An organization to supervise Senator Estes Kefauver's campaign in Ohio for delegates to the Democratic National Convention was set up at a state-wide meeting there today.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 28 -- While Ohio State and Yale battled for team supremacy, Michigan's John Davies accounted for the most spectacular accomplishment of tonight's upset-studded second session of the twenty-ninth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships.

Stockholders of the Copper Range Company, at a special meeting in Boston yesterday, approved a Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan of $57,185,000 to a wholly owned subsidiary, the White Pine Copper Company. Proceeds will be used to develop a copper-ore property in the Upper Michigan peninsula.

Six elderly men, who admitted they took $5 each to serve as "stand-ins" in Mid-Manhattan Court for participants in a raided East Harlem dice game, were arrested last night on charges of conspiring to obstruct justice. Meanwhile, policemen carrying bench warrants were seeking the men who allegedly used substitutes and five others who failed to return to court for arraignment.

A pulpit appeal in Manhattan churches and synagogues for volunteers for stand-by duty in Civil Defense was begun last night and will be carried on today and tomorrow. Enrollments may be made until next Friday.

Carl G. LoDolce, accused by the State Department of taking part in the slaying of Maj. William V. Holohan while on a secret mission behind enemy lines in Italy in 1944, was arrested yesterday by United States marshals at the Rochester (N. Y.) Institute of Technology, where he is a part-time student under the G. I. Bill of Rights.
Another sharp cutback in the scope of Federal emergency shipping operations was announced yesterday by the National Shipping Authority.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Signs of revival in the export business gave impetus to a broader demand for grain futures today and there were fair rallies. Italy's total purchases of wheat yesterday amounted to nine cargoes, including six cargoes, or about 2,000,000 bushels, of hard winter wheat late in the day.

Commodity futures trading was wildly irregular yesterday as traders evened up for the week-end after declines earlier in the week. Rubber, sugar and vegetable oils were mixed. Cocoa, wool and wool tops gained. Hides and coffee were lower.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 28 -- Stanley S. La Benskey of Yonkers who retired a month ago as a Westchester Parkway patrolman, was indicted on a charge of first-degree murder this afternoon by a county grand jury here. He was accused of shooting two Negro brothers, Wyatt and James Blacknall of Yonkers, outside a tavern in that city ten days ago after objecting to their presence at the bar.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -Representative Frances P. Bolton, Republican of Ohio, announced today that she had redrafted her bill to meet the critical nursing shortage after conversations with opponents of the measure, who tabled it in committee eight days ago.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Senate refused today to include combat pay for military personnel fighting in Korea in the bill it is considering to grant a general pay increase for the armed forces. The decision was made by a standing vote, the result of which was not announced following Senate custom.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 29 -- The Government-controlled Peiping radio announced this morning that Communist staff officers at Panmunjom made an official protest yesterday against a "gross breach" by the United Nations of an agreement to hold secret negotiations on an exchange of prisoners in an armistice in Korea.

After an ownership of a few days, the dwelling on lot 19 by 100 feet at 22 East Ninety-fifth Street has been resold by Fred H. Hill, operator and president of the Melfra Realty Corporation, to an investing client of Barney Bernstein, attorney. The new owner plans to occupy the house after altering it into two duplex apartments and a professional office.

The head of the house is going to get a bloodhound. This statement, first announced some time ago, has been reiterated so often that it now is regarded as truth and not, as so many of his sayings are regarded, as a form of light whimsicality.
Two bloodmobiles of the American Red Cross recorded the unusual feat on Thursday of collecting identical amounts of blood from widely-separated donors.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 -- There are days when a person can't come by a dollar and there are days when even world champions will play like tyros.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 28 -- The medicine applied by Britain's Conservative Government to cure the ills of the pound sterling is beginning to have some effect.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., March 28 (UP) -- Grimy rescue workers moved in pumping equipment today to drain the depths of an independent mine at near-by Forestville where five miners were trapped by tons of water and presumed drowned.

CLEVELAND, March 28 (AP) -- Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company said today it was considering building a floating power plant that could be towed on Lake Erie to Cleveland in case of an atomic attack.

RANGOON, Burma, March 28 -Arrangements are being concluded here that will link the engineering division of Rangoon University, Burma's only institution of higher learning, with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass.

Shipping concerns in New York were informed yesterday that the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee would begin public hearings on April 22 on the long-range shipping legislation held over from the last session of Congress.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 28 (UP) -- Dick Button, 22-year-old "Mr. Skating," proved for the seventh straight time that he had no peer in the United States as he glided to the national figure skating championship tonight.

An unmistakable note of luxury pervades "Decoration 1952," the display of the decorative arts currently on view at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The exhibit, arranged in connection with the twenty-first annual conference of the American Institute of Decorators, will be open to the public today from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. and tomorrow from 10 A. M. to 6 P. M. The admission charge is $1.50.

Further strength in the oils and rails gave the stock market a substantial lift yesterday and sent the average rate to the best level since early February. The rails were benefited by reports that the Interstate Commerce Commission would soon hand down a favorable decision on the freight rate rise application.

WITH but one exception the comment on a proposed salt water fishing license for Atlantic coastal states has been strongly negative, and the lone proponent apparently is unfamiliar with the details of the plan.
BALTIMORE, March 28 (AP) -- A mysterious offer of $750 per share for Pimlico stock today confused more than cleared up rumors that the home of the Preakness was to be sold.

ATHENS, March 28 -- The Defense Minister, Admiral Alexander Sakellarious, resigned tonight after almost the full representation of the Greek Rally party, the major Opposition and the largest single party in the Chamber, had walked out of Parliament in protest at alleged political interference by the Defense Minister in Army affairs.

Being marketing research director is no snap job in a company that sells in the consumer products field, where the dynamics of competitive capitalism operate so intensely. Men in such positions are constantly on the firing line because the cost of their research tends to appear on the profit and loss statement as just so much "overhead," no matter how much it may have contributed to sales.

MADRAS, India, March 28 -- While approaching famine-stricken villages on foot over dry, brown fields that should be green with tender young grain at this season, one became conscious gradually of a strange silence today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Although President Truman spent virtually all of today in meetings with Cabinet ministers and administrative officials, there were indications that his Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner speech to be delivered here tomorrow night, would be completed and released to the press and radio by noon tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- William M. Leiserson, labor economist, told a Senate labor subcommittee today that migratory labor conditions in the Southwest and West were a hundred years outdated, and he charged that the United States was "running away from the problem."

Following directions of Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division to reduce the waiting time for the trial of negligence and personal-injury cases, Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally, sitting in a special Calendar Call Part, called 4,684 cases filed between April, 1949, and February, 1952, and disposed of 2,850 cases.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -Following is the text of the special message that President Truman sent to Congress today urging new legislation dealing with voting by service men:
A warning that "free education in this country is starving to death" and that such starvation is contributing to the loss of our other freedoms was voiced yesterday by Dr. Willard E. Goslin.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 28 (AP) -- While Marty Furgol dipped to a 73, nine strokes off his record-equaling first round, five pursuers passed him today to tie for the halfway lead in the $10,000 Azalea open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- National labor and farm organizations joined today in support of the Administration's $7,900,000,000 Mutual Security Program as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee heard from private groups and individuals on the controversial legislation.
A plan to build a new $15,000,000 Metropolitan Opera House at Columbus Circle as part of a redevelopment scheme has been dropped because of "many difficulties,'' it was learned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 28 -- Immigration and social welfare practices in New York that permit young children of displaced persons to fall into the hands of unlicensed guardians and receive unregulated care were criticized today by Children's Court Judge George W. Smyth of Westchester.

Material shortages, high labor and material costs, and a strike at its Yonkers plant in the final quarter, adversely affected sales and earnings of the Otis Elevator Company last year, the annual report of L. A. Petersen, president, disclosed yesterday.

A group of cheerful youngsters kept an important date with Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall yesterday, for they were to receive $100 scholarship awards from the Men's League in Aid of Crippled Children, Inc.
The State Board of Regent ruled yesterday that an African documentary film sponsored by the American Museum of Natural History was indecent and should not be shown publicly in this state.

Timely advice for home cooks now planning Passover menus -and, in fact, for all those concerned with economical meals -- is included in a recent report on cottage cheese from the State Cooperative Extension Service.

BONN, Germany, March 28 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, who also is Foreign Minister, was indicated today to have undertaken a shake-up in the personnel of his Foreign Ministry as a result of charges that a large percentage of the officials were either former Nazis or "tainted" by having served under Joachim von Ribbentrop.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 28 -- The Belgrade radio reported tonight that students of the University of Ljubljana demonstrated today in the streets of the Slovene capital in protest against anti-Yugoslav riots and demonstrations in Italian cities over the Trieste question.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Moses Finley, an assistant professor of ancient history at Rutgers University, swore today that he was not now a Communist but he refused to say whether he had ever been one. He claimed the privilege against possible self-incrimination.
A suit for $3,000,000 against the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel has been started in Supreme Court by a group of banquet waiters for tips allegedly due them over a period of six years.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 28 -- The Yugoslav National Assembly gave tonight a standing ovation to the reading of the proposed defense budget, which will consume 22 per cent of the national income in 1952.

Drilling and Exploration Company, Inc., of Abilene, Tex., announced yesterday it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a new issue of 400,000 shares of common stock intended for public offering through underwriters headed by Hornblower Weeks, Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Blair, Rollins Co., Inc.

PARIS, March 28 -- Despite the many changes and rejections made by the National Assembly's Finance Committee, it was declared today by Charles Barange, Rapporteur, that Premier Antoine Pinay's appropriation bill had come through this test with a balance.

In a specially equipped room within the premature-infant unit at New York Hospital one morning this week, Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Sante of Forest Hills, Queens, spent four hours getting acquainted with their very little daughter, Lucinda.

American Airlines, Inc., lifted its 1951 revenues to $162,970,707, highest in its history, from the previous year's $118,684,700, but earnings failed to reflect the rise under the pressure of a substantially larger tax bill.
The Coast Guard began its investigation yesterday into circumstances surrounding the official approval of ferryboat life preservers that were found to be non-buoyant.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The chief of the Army's audit bureau, Col. Harry E. Reed, testified today that the secret United States polar air base in Greenland was being constructed at a cost of $1,000,000,000. Previous testimony had set the cost at only $300,000,000.

Events today: "Alcestis," Metropilitan Opera, 2; "Don Giovanni,'' New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15; Paul Weinlader, pianist, Town Hall, 3; Concert Pianists' League, Steinway Hall, 3:45; N. B. C. Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 5:30.

The Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet at the Warner Theatre last night gave us far and away the best program it has yet offered, with John Cranko's "Harlequin in April" as its principal item. From the two previous ballets by Mr. Cranko that have been shown here, it was difficult to discover why he has been rated so highly as a choreographer, but with the present piece the difficulty vanishes immediately.

TRENTON, March 28 -- The question of whether or not to legalize bingo games for welfare purposes in New Jersey was nearer a popular vote tonight when the state Senate passed, by a vote of 13 to 6, a bill authorizing a public referendum on the controversial issue. The measure now goes to the Assembly, which is expected to act on the legislation next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -President Truman, in a special message to Congress, called today for action to assure voting rights for more than 2,500,000 men and women in the armed services.
Philip Kreuger has been appointed buyer of fashion dresses in addition to his duties as buyer of misses' and junior basement dresses for the Newman-Benton chain, an affiliate of Lane Bryant, Inc.

PARIS, March 28 -- Concluding a three-day conference, the ministers representing sixteen European countries today approved the idea of the creation of a European agricultural community and a single market.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Three men of the United States Air Force are riding a floating ice island within 100 miles of the North Pole on a mission to collect weather and scientific data.
A record field of 132 women and 156 men played in the one session Eastern States Men's pair and Women's pair contract bridge championships yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 28 -- This city and near-by Linden have been spotted in a state report as responsible for more odor, gas and fume nuisances than all other Union County municipalities combined, according to a summary presented to the Chamber of Commerce of Eastern Union County by its air-pollation committee.

France's troubles in her colonial empire extend in a great arc from Indo-China to Tunisia. They are due to a conjunction of seething currents -- the rise of communism in Asia, the tidal wave of Arab nationalism in Africa, the undertow of anti-colonialism everywhere.

To an American citizen who is more concerned about the intimate welfare of our own dear country than that of foreign lands it seems very odd that the only comment that your editorial writer can make in a lead editorial on the day after dispatches from London tell of the revealment of a secret agreement regarding Asia by Mr. Churchill is that the incident is a triumph for Mr. Churchill.

Metropolitan Opera subscribers were notified yesterday that, owing to increasing costs of production and operation, the prices of their tickets for next season will go up 10 cents to 50 cents, depending on the location of their seats.

The trial of William F. Sutton and Thomas Kling on two-year-old bank robbery charges was completed in Queens County Court in Long Island City yesterday except for summing up and the charge to the jury by Judge Peter T. Farrell.

Bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined slightly in February, the average market value slipping from $98.01 on Jan. 31 to $97.88 on Feb. 29. The latter figure was the lowest since Dec. 31, when the average was $97.43.

The Library of Congress has appointed Mrs. Frances Clarke Sayers, Superintendent of Work with Children at the New York Public Library, to reorganize its extensive collection of domestic and foreign children's books. She will be on leave for this project for two months beginning Tuesday.

AKRON, Ohio, March 28 (UP) -Nine officers of the United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., at the B. F. Goodrich Company were convicted today of contempt of court, and a wave of protest walkouts shut down two rubber concerns and made 30,000 men idle.

DETROIT, March 28 -- Two staff members and four appointed committeemen of Ford Local 600, United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., lost their posts today in the continuing purge directed by Walter P. Reuther, the union's international president.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 28 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission refused today to hear any more Soviet charges of United States use of gem warfare in Korea and China.

This year marks the eighty-fifth anniversary of the Samaritan Home for the Aged, 440 East Eighty-eighth Street, and the Home naturally feels that a fitting observance of this special event is to put as much emphasis as possible on the institution's annual appeal for funds, now under way.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 28 -- The National Collegiate A. A. fencing championships started at Yale's Payne Whitney Gymnasium this morning with swordsmen from thirty-five colleges on hand to display their ability. More than 1,400 bouts were scheduled before the competition ends tomorrow night.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 28 -- Twelve men and women, representing a cross-section of the 500 Bergen County householders and small shopkeepers who had rented their telephones to bookies in 1948 and 1949 at fees ranging from $100 to $200 a month, testified today in the trial of Michael Orecchio, former chief of Bergen County detectives, who is charged with thirty-two counts of failure to suppress gambling.
ALBANY, March 28 -- Spectators lat New York's seven harness racing tracks will pay an additional fifteen per cent admission tax under legislation signed today by Governor Dewey.

NEWARK, March 28 -- The scarcity of physicians trained in newer methods of diagnosis and treatment of epilepsy and social and vocational prejudice are major problems in dealing with the disorder, Dr. Pearce Bailey, director of the National Institute of Neurological Diseases and Blindness at Bethesda, Md., said today at the close of the two-day annual conference on rehabilitation of the physically handicapped.

In a medically backward country like China, where sanitation is poor and good physicians are scarce, bubonic plague, smallpox, cholera and typhus are endemic. Now that these diseases have assumed epidemic proportions in some districts the temptation to make the utmost use of them in inflaming the Far East against the United States is too strong to be resisted by the Communist.
At the outset I want to congratulate you on your editorial regarding off-track betting.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The Board of Regents today notified all school authorities that they "are required to proceed immediately and conclusively" to eliminate from the school system persons "against whom there are evidences of guilt of subversive activity.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A denial of funds to maintain a diplomatic mission at Vatican City, unless or until the Senate approved an ambassador to that post, was written into the State Department's supply bill for the coming fiscal year by a 19-17 vote of the House Appropriations Committee today.
LONDON, March 28 (AP) -- Cambridge, with five meal back from last year's sensational crew, takes on Oxford tomorrow in their ninety-eighth annual varsity boat race.

Fourteen thousand rounds of .38 caliber pistol ammunition, one pistol and several aprons for smuggling the contraband ashore were seized yesterday by Customs officers aboard the Panamanian freighter Cali at her pier on Erie Basin, Brooklyn.

The collection of used tin cans from households cannot be relied upon in an emergency to provide substantial quantities of scrap for steelmaking. That conclusion has been reached by the steel industry's scrap experts on the basis of results thus far in test cases started recently in two New Jersey cities.

THE amount of bloom the home owner gets from his roses in summer will depend more on how and where the bushes are planted than on any other factor. That is, assuming the roses are strong and healthy to begin with.

ONLY a few people who came into direct contact with him throughout his life knew all of the facets of genius or near genius exhibited by the late Donald Francis Tovey (1875-1940). Musicians and music lovers knew him as the author of the penetrating and rather technical "Essays in Musical Analysis," models of lucid exposition that came as near to fulfilling the true function of music criticism as anything written during their time.

To those who say men's clothes never change, the following pictures offer contrary proof. Not only do they change; they come full circle. The elegant gentleman of 1900, with his Edwardian clothes, closely resembles his fashionable British cousin of today in cuffed sleeve and lapel vest, and is not too far from today's natural look.

MR. HADAS, who is Associate Professor of Greek and Latin at Columbia University, has written a companion to his "A History of Greek Literature." Like its predecessor, it is altogether admirable, scholarly without being pedantic, popular without being written-down.
A new weapon in the war against narcotics addiction has been moved into the fight in Chicago.
CHICAGO, March 29 -- Today's livestock market reported by the Department of Agriculture follows:

THE origin of the solar system and the planets is usually discussed by astronomers, cosmologists, astrophysicists and mathematical physicists. Prof. Harold C. Urey of the University of Chicago is a chemist. His approach to the subject is therefore new, even revolutionary.

WHEN we study the history of the Confederacy we wonder why the South did not collapse within a year; when we study the history of the Union we are astonished to find that it managed to keep armies in the field or to keep the Government going from year to year. It was, in fact, a very disorderly war.

AN art critic from London arriving in New York to find a battle raging in the art world between "traditionalism" and "modernism," between the artistic right wing and the left, is apt to heave a small sigh and murmur to himself: "This is where I came in," for almost exactly the same dispute is apt to break out in London whenever an occasion presents itself!
LONDON, March 29 (Reuters) -- The existence of the State of Israel has created a real danger of a split in world Jewry, the British Zionist Federation said in its annual report today.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Mark Kauffman of Life received the top honor as "Photographer of the Year" in the ninth annual "News Pictures of the Year" competition, jointly sponsored by the Encyclopaedia Britannica and the University of Missouri School of Journalism, the sponsors announced today.
The restoration of Israel was hailed as prophetic for humanity yesterday morning in a sermon by Rabbi Zev Zahavy of Congregation Ohab Zedek, 118 West Ninety-fifth Street.

Steel wage negotiations hung last week like a pall over financial markets for the second successive period. But after three days of uncertain movements, the stock market ignored the lack of a decision and began to move higher, scoring the widest gains since early March.
ATHENS, Sunday, March 30 (AP) -- Four convicted Greek Communist spies were executed early today near Athens.

BOSTON, March 29 -- A political bandwagon, flying the flag of a five-star general, appeared today to be rolling merrily through New England and on the way to Chicago for the Republican National Convention, opening July 7, where General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will be a candidate for the party's Presidential nomination.
More than half the city's police force -- and nearly two-thirds of all the patrolmen and detectives -- spent four hours yesterday taking the civil service test for promotion to sergeant.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) -- The National Boxing Association's executive committee today approved the forthcoming Jersey Joe Walcott-Ezzard Charles heavyweight title bout slated for Philadelphia in June.
HAVANA, March 29 (AP) -- Gen. Fulgencio Batista plans to proclaim himself President of Cuba next week, a Propaganda Ministry spokesman said today.
With only two weeks remaining before Easter, most retail merchants have failed to detect much of that urban sign of spring -- the desire for a new outfit or bonnet that sends sales climbing.

Fear that the young people of today cannot spell as well as those of fifty or one hundred years ago is based on sentiment rather than evidence, according to an article in the current issue of The English Record, journal of the New York State English Council. The English Record is published at Colgate University.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 29 -- To make up for at least one of the bloom-out regattas of the last two Sundays, dinghy racing was held today at the Larchmont Yacht club.

Cries of "nike." Greek for "victory," were heard for the fiftieth time yesterday as the annual Greek Games were held at Barnard College. Vying for the laurel wreath the freshman and sophomore classes engaged in athletic and dance contests with precision and simplicity.

CIDADE DE GOA, Portuguese India, March 24 -- Indian demands for the cession of Goa and the other small Portuguese west coast settlements appear to have made small headway with the contented and relatively prosperous inhabitants of this placid little port on the Arabian Sea.

The twenty-sixth annual Eastern states contract bridge championships continued yesterday at the McAlpin Hotel, when a record field of 140 pairs played the first two of four scheduled sessions in the Goldman Cup pair championship.

CINCINNATI, March 29 -- "We are Wise's heirs and we share his belief that in America, Jewish life must be primarily religious as such," Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner of Euclid Avenue Temple, Cleveland, said here this afternoon at founder's day exercises at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, in memory of Rabbi Isaac M. Wise.

A social fraternity that has outlawed pledging and blackballing, traditional practices of such organizations, has been granted recognition by the Student Council at Manhattan College, it has been announced by George Boyle, council president.

Interest increased in summer merchandise, special offers for Mother's Day and after-Easter selling in the wholesale market here last week, resident buying offices reported. Prices in all markets continued soft, but business in general improved.

CAIRO. March 29 -- British-Egyptian talks, concerning unilateral concessions by London or mutual concessions that would start off favorably the new negotiations for settlement of the long-drawn-out and bitter British-Egyptian conflict, were moving fast today.

THE author of this book, Harry St. John Bridger Philby, has just returned to his home in Mecca from a long winter journey to map the area north of the Rubh-al-Khali Desert, one of the few districts of southwestern Arabia that has escaped the attention of this pioneer explorer during the past thirty-five years.

THE yachting fraternity is notable for its production of good, practical, brass - tacks books, written for sailors by sailors and based on direct experience. There are some pure theorists, to be sure, but preponderantly the yachtsmen at their typewriters know that they are facing a sharp-eyed and sometimes skeptical audience.

MOSCOW, March 29 -- Premier Stalin, appearing fit and vigorous, tonight attended the concluding session of the Russian Federated Republic's Supreme Soviet and received a special ovation from the delegates at the close of the brief meeting.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 30 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,204, far Saturday's operations:
Paper production in this country for the first month of 1952 held close to record levels of 1951, E. W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association, reported last week.

PARIS, March 29 -- The European Marshall Plan Council formally received a new lease on life and new tasks to perform today by a decision of the finance and foreign ministers representing the seventeen countries participating in it.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Truman dramatically announced tonight that he would not be a candidate for re-election and would not accept the nomination if he were drafted by the Democratic convention.

LANSING, Mich., March 29 (AP) -- Michigan will enter the Republican Presidential campaign next week, with the state convention in Detroit's Cass Tech High School Saturday. It will be preceded by eighteen Congressional district caucuses Saturday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- E. V. Huggins, Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, today denied a statement before the Senate Preparedness subcommittee yesterday that a secret air base in Greenland would cost $1,000,000,000.
MEDFORD, Mass., March 29 -- Police Chief William J. McLaughlin ordered a strict censorship of crime news today, disclosing that witnesses to a recent $15,600 bank robbery had received death threats.

NEWCOMERSTOWN, Ohio, March 29 -- Cy Young, one of the greatest pitchers of all, celebrated his eighty-fifth birthday quietly on a farm near here today and allowed he'd not "strike out" before the century mark.

I am a native islander and have watched its gradual decline over the years with increasing surprise and disappointment. Each year the existing facilities grow shabbier, the summer visitors less numerous, and we a little more despondent about it.

There are primary elections in fifteen states in which 598 of the 1,205 delegates to the Republican National Convention are selected by the party voters. There are primary elections in seventeen states in which 590 of the 1,230 delegates to the Democratic National Convention are selected.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 29 -- Thailand will disarm and take into custody any Chinese Nationalist troops driven from Burma into this country, Premier Field Marshal Pibul Songgram said in a statement today to The Bangkok Post, United States-owned newspaper.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 29 (UP) -- A Southern white hospital announced today the appointment of a Negro physician to its medical staff. It was believed to be one of the first such appointments in the South.

The National Association of Manufacturers has launched a nation-wide effort to persuade American business enterprise to provide more adequate financial support for the nation's educational systems, both public and private. The association's action followed a resolution adopted unanimously by its 160-man board of directors, which summed up the responsibility of business men as follows: "Business enterprises must find a way to support the whole educational program effectively, regularly and now."

NORWALK, Conn., March 29 -- Insurgent independent Democrats will attempt to wrest control of this city's party organization from Paul R. Connery in the caucuses and convention here on May 19. Mr. Connery is one of the two Connecticut members of the Democratic National Committee and a veteran party leader in the state.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) -- The Department of Defense announced tonight that about 7,000 officers and enlisted men would participate in an atomic explosion test in Nevada next month.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 29 -- The economy of the young state of Israel is sick. It is suffering basically from taking in more immigrants than it can digest -- about 700,000 in less than four years, which brought the population to 1,500,000.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- The $4,000,000,000 industrial expansion under way or planned in the Delaware River Valley from Trenton to the sea has instilled in the maritime industry here an unusual degree of enthusiasm.

RICHMOND, March 29 -- Small businesses in the Fifth Reserve District trace a current slowdown due to the heavy tax payments this month but look for an early resumption of activity. Department store operators also anticipate a change for the better with the approach of Easter.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The State Tax Commission said today it expected a record number of state income tax returns to be filed this year because of the high employment and earning levels that prevailed during 1951. Total. payments were expected to yield $326,300,000 in the coming fiscal year.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 29 (AP) -- Mary Ann Dorsey, St. Paul, Minn., skater, flashed past Georgianna Sutton of Los Angeles with a dazzling free skating performance today to win the novice women's crown in the national figure skating meet.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Stabilization officials still were deadlocked tonight over the price aspects of the steel industry's wage problem.

MILWAUKEE, March 29 (AP) -- Curt Freeland, 37-year-old Indianapolis kegler, tonight rolled the second 700 series of the American Bowling Congress tournament in taking first place in the singles with 702.

IN the July, 1868, issue of "Atlantic Monthly" a reviewer wrote: "The Jarves Collection would be a thing to go from one Italian city to another to see and we hope that it shall not be very long till any person within a day's journey of New Haven shall be ashamed not to have seen it."

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- Movement of general retail merchandise this week is reported showing some improvement. Seasonable items of "soft" goods moved more easily than durables. Retailers have marked down regular merchandise again, to spur buying.

A need for greater safeguarding of democratic rights "against the divisive efforts of bigots on both the right and left" because of national and international tensions, war anxiety and "the special hysteria of an election year" was emphasized yesterday by Paul H. Sampliner, chairman of the executive committee of the Joint Defense Appeal.

The resignation of Hilla Rebay as director of the Museum of Non-Objective Painting, 1071 Fifth Avenue, and her appointment as director emeritus was announced yesterday by Harry F. Guggenheim, chairman of the board of trustees of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation.

STUDENTS of literature, l'amour and the Middle Ages are hereby alerted to the fact that three stories from Boccaccio's famed fictional commentaries, the Decameron, are set to go before the Technicolor cameras in Spain in May under the title "Decameron Nights."

THERE is a strong indication that the design of the contemporary interior is heading more and more in the direction of luxurious elegance and away from the strict Spartan look. A long-time advocate of this approach has been T. H. Robsjohn-Gibbings, whose latest collection of furniture pictured here seems his strongest statement of this thesis to date.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 29 -- Parts of the second floor of historic Raleigh Tavern here are being restored so that bedrooms will appear as they were two centuries ago when such colonial leaders as George Washington and Thomas Jefferson were guests there.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market moved irregularly and narrowly last week. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week 14 to 32 points lower than a week earlier. The most pronounced loss occurred in the current May delivery and the smallest net decline was in the distant June delivery.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 29 -- Thousands of university and high school students paraded tonight through the streets of Belgrade in an orderly and disciplined manner in protest against the Western move to solve the question of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste without the consent or participation of Yugoslavia.

Growing at a rapid rate, the Roman Catholic schools and colleges in the United States have a record enrollment of 4,000,000 students, representing an increase of more than 35 per cent in the last ten years.
CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- Twenty-six judges started preliminary selections among 1,969 dogs today as the International Kennel Club's all-breed show began.

A TEMPEST in a coffee pot has lately been brewed in Brazil, world's greatest coffee producer, by Saude, the official magazine of the National Health Education Service. "One should not be deceived by the false sense of well-being given by alcohol and coffee," said Saude, "which deprive the body of indispensable nourishment and rest."

ROME, March 29 (AP) -- Italian legal authorities were expected tonight to press a test case to extradite former United States Army Sgt. Carlo Lo Dolce before going ahead with similar action against former Lieut. Aldo Icardi.

Michael L. Hoffman in "Integration: 800-1952" (March 16) made a very good point by calling our attention to the geographical parallel between the Western European defense bloc of today and Charlemagne's Empire.

We have rarely enjoyed any of your most enjoyable articles quite so much as James Reston's treatise on Political Gamesmanship entitled "Primer of Primitive Politics" (March 2). But we're a little disappointed that Mr. Reston, obviously an old hand, omitted one of our favorite ploys.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Now that the White House renovation has been completed, Washingtonians are becoming aware of another restoration job with a particular historical significance. This is the work of preparing the dignified and formal Japanese Embassy on Massachusetts Avenue for reoccupancy as the Nipponese Legation as soon as the peace treaty is signed.

The Truman family has lived in the White House only a little over half of the seven years Mr. Truman has been President. They vacated in November, 1948, because the President and Congress decided the old mansion was sagging dangerously and needed an overhaul.

ANOTHER notable "first" in commercial airline history will be written into the books next May 2 when a pure-jet de Havilland Comet passenger transport plane of British Overseas Airways leaves London for Johannesburg on the world's first regularly scheduled passenger flight in a jet airliner.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A long-range program to assist in the rehabilitation of victims of last week's Mississippi Valley tornadoes was announced by the American National Red Cross here today.

NEXT fall may seem a long way off, but it's the plans made now that forestall an unpresentable mass of dead flowers soon after September frosts. It is possible to have plants that look well after several light frosts -- even well into November -- and these will prolong the enjoyment of color in the garden.

" I DON'T go to basketball games often any more," said Barney Sedran with a sad shake of his head. "It no longer is the game I used to know and love. It isn't basketball any more. They should call it hoop ball or volley ball. The rules are the joker in the deck. They've given the game to the big men and changed it."

THERE are nearly 150 companies issuing long-play records, and new ones are entering the field every week. With the exception of a few organizations (The Library of Congress; Harvard University) most of these companies are profit-making and can be considered "commercial."
LONDON, March 29 (Reuters) -- Crew race fans tried to duck the snow and wind by following the inter-university Boat Race on radio and television today. They failed.

LOS ANGELES -- Show a Californian an adobe brick, and the chances are he will be overcome by a nostalgic impulse to re-create the building from which it came, and hang a plaque thereon for the edification of tourists.

STEPHEN LEACOCK once remarked that Canadians were so busy explaining to the British that they weren't Americans and assuring Americans they weren't British that they had precious little time left to be Canadians. World War II and its aftermath have helped change all that. Today Canadians are so busy being Canadians they've little time for anything else.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The theory is that politics paralyzes policy, particularly in a Presidential campaign year, but like a lot of other political theories these days, this one is not operating according to the book.

THE exhibition entitled "Twentieth Century British Paintings and Water-Colors" at the American British Gallery is largely made up of work by artists who have only come to the fore during the last fifteen years. This is no surprise, for the present renaissance, which can justifiably be referred to as the "School of London,"

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 29 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, testified today that a member of his staff had been "investigating" students at the University of Syracuse in connection with a $500,000 libel suit that the Wisconsin Republic had filed against a local newspaper.

Percy G. B. Gilkes, the chief clerk of the Brooklyn Federal Court, observed his eighty-second birthday Thursday without ceremony. He said he had frowned on anniversary parties after his eightieth birthday.

Extensive work and planning are now going on in the Eastern European satellites to shift their railroad networks from the European narrow gauge to the Soviet broad gauge. This step is a logical corollary of many previous changes altering the economic systems of these countries on the Soviet model and integrating their production with that of the Soviet Union.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 29 (AP) -- United States staff members and Iranian soldiers thwarted an attempt by about 250 Communistled youths today to raid the United States Information Service's library.

PARAGUAY has paid a tribute to the Dominican Republic with a series picturing on postage items the "Faro de Colon" (Columbus Lighthouse) being erected at Ciudad Trujillo; and on air stamps, the Christopher Columbus urn in Ciudad Trujillo.

The choice stock of Chinese porcelains, pottery, lamps and other objects of art of Roland Moore, 120 East Sixty-first Street, will be liquidated at auction beginning this week. Mr. Moore's retirement from business will bring into the market on Wednesday and Thursday a large selection of porcelains of the Ming and Ch'ing Dynasties and of table lamps mounted from fine porcelain and pottery of the T'ang through the Ch'ing Dynasties.

PERHAPS many of us had been counting too heavily on "Flight Into Egypt." Since the theatre this season has been consistently taking flight from big themes, George Tabori's drama about European refugees looked in prospect like one of the major events.
MIAMI, March 29 (AP) -- Running true to form, the four top-seeded players in the Miami invitation tennis tournament advanced today into the semi-final round.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 29 -- Coach Earl H. Blaik set out today on the task of molding an Army football team that must play its most difficult schedule ever and all he had to work with was last year's squad, minus six graduating lettermen.

H. Howland Sargeant, new Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, declared here yesterday that American intellectuals had a great responsibility to defend freedom against the world-wide ultural offensive being waged by the Soviet Union as part of its propaganda warfare against the United States.
Concerning E. L. Woodward's "A Spade Is a Spade Is a Maybe" (March 16) I would like to quote from Ruskin's "Sesame and Lilies," written in 1865:

WITH the advent of April and its promise of warm spring days, garden groups here in the Northeast are scheduling special programs. An all-day meeting at the University of Connecticut-Storrs, has been planned by the Garden Department of the Connecticut State Federation of Women's Clubs for Thursday.

LIFE is the only art that we are required to practice without preparation, and without being allowed the preliminary trials, the failures and botches that are essential for the training of a mere beginner. In life we must begin to give a public performance before we have acquired even a novice's skill; and often our moments of seeming mastery are upset by new demands, for which we have acquired no preparatory facility.

WITH mail orders representing over 90 per cent of the business done by nurseries, the packaging and shipment of the plants necessarily assumes large proportions. Whether they go by Railway Express, parcel post or air freight, the nurseryman has to (a) insure the arrival of plants in good condition, and (b) offer a reasonable guarantee that they will live up to their catalogue, fanfare in the garden.

JONES BEACH, L. I., March 29 -- With attendance at Jones Beach State Park expected to pass 8,000,000 this year, completion of the $4,000,000 Marine Stadium will be a significant addition to its facilities. The new structure is to be ready for dedication by June 26.

KINGSTON, N. Y. -- This Hudson River town, now celebrating its 300th birthday, is awaiting the visit of Queen Juliana of the Netherlands next Friday as one in a series of events that will keep the festival spirit running high for the rest of the year.

IN his review of "Lincoln and His Generals" by T. Harry Williams, Jay Monaghan writes, "In mid-July, 1861, Lincoln watched the regiments of many nationalities march smartly through Washington and cross the Long Bridge into Virginia to fight the native American upholders of slavery."
So much has been written in the United States about Bevanism in Britain that perhaps a British Laborite may be allowed to comment on Bevanism when it appears in American dress.

CAIRO, March 29 -- Free elections in Egypt on May 18, in accordance with a decree dissolving Parliament, presumably will mean a larger scale renewal of the battle of the Suez Canal zone, suspended after the Jan. 26 Cairo riots.

Although the summer bathing season is still a few months away, the office of the Supervisor of New York Harbor already has established a special 24-hour-a-day boat patrol of the Long Island shore to prevent the discharge of refuse and oil from ships and small craft.

LONDON, March 29 (UP) -- The Moscow radio attacked the THE NEW YORK TIMES today as a "tool of the monopolies" and charged that the paper had sought to "distort the peaceful policy of the Soviet Government."

THERE was a report on this page several weeks ago that there was a marked trend, in the arrangement of concert series throughout the country for next season, for performances by ensembles rather than by individual artists. The big-name virtuosos were apparently still in demand, but the lesser known soloists who command modest fees seemed to be turning into a less salable commodity.

HEARTY as an old folk tale this tells of the uproar which occurred in a French village when the new miller came to take over the mill of Oye. The widow of the late miller, Puvret, all smiles and curves, greeted him graciously, prepared to leave and -- stuck in the door of the mill.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Government will try to solve the defense housing shortage with homes that could be dismantled and moved from city to city as needs change, the Housing and Home Finance Agency announced today.
AS a theatre critic who has, all too often, nothing to criticize, I was both interested and delighted by Arthur Gelb's article, "Rejuvenating the Road," which appeared in your section on March 2.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., March 29 -- Sally Kingman, 20-year- old Concord, Mass., girl, today achieved the most important victory of her short competitive career by swinging rhythmically down the one-mile Tecumseh Trail in 2 minutes 28.4 seconds to turn back a field of seventeen in the fourth annual Widener Memorial Trophy race for class C and unclassified skiers.

HARVARD -- Seminar Young men and women from Europe and Asia will participate in the 1952 session of the Harvard Summer School International Seminar. The program provides an opportunity for the students to acquaint themselves with American life. Each participant is given a chance to talk to an American audience about the problems of his own country at least once during his stay at Harvard.

New York University has bought for $18,000 a four-story private residence at 6 Washington Square North, Dr. LeRoy E. Kimball, vice chancellor and controller, announced yesterday. This gives the university control of all but one of the Colonial-Georgian structures in the 120-year-old Red Brick Row on the north side of the square.

LAUREL, Md., March 29 -- It was raining here today, but as far as Larry MacPhail and John Schapiro were concerned, the atmosphere was as soft and as pleasant as that "Rare Day in June" made famous by James Russell Lowell.
