MacPhail and Schapiro are partners in the promotion of horse racing at the Laurel race course, and today that race course was visited by the biggest crowd in its history of 41 years.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Rake lawns, and at the same time remove the accumulation of debris under hedges and shrubs. Then lawns should be fertilized, and bare or thin spots seeded. Rolling will help to level uneven turf, but the roller should be used only once when ground is relatively dry, and then lightly. Wait to spray weeds until they bloom.

A burglar who was surprised trying to pry open a law office door on the thirty-second floor of the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway, drew a building guard's fire at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning but managed to escape capture by a searching party of fifty policemen.
AUTHOR of "The Pennywinks" and "Pennywink Carnival," Electa Clark writes again of a large, relaxed family, oddly named, and of a lonely child who drops into their midst.

" RED PLUSH," Guy McCrone's trilogy, did for the Scottish upper-middle class something of what the "Forsyte Saga" had done for the English. With "The Hayburn Family" a fifth novel has been added to the Glasgow family series. It is designed to be read either alone or as another installment.

ATHENS, March 29 -- A Government source said today that the Council of Pardons had upheld the death sentence for four of the eight persons who were condemned as Red spies March 1, and had amended life imprisonment for the others. The council's decision was communicated to King Paul and the Government.
IN any form of bridge, sacrifice bidding is important and very profitable if intelligently managed. In duplicate bridge it is essential to success.

NINETEENTH - CENTURY treatments of the Revolution did scant justice to the work of Gouverneur Morris in the Continental Congress and the Constitutional Convention, and as Minister to France, because, Howard Swiggett suggests, they had to leave out the "personal interest."

THE modern young woman, aside from being a slick chick, knows a great many more answers than did her grandmother. When Grandpa talked over business and politics with the menfolks Grandma kept quiet and tended to her knitting and her cooking.
BECAUSE those behind the television scenes seem to be much more interested in the "vision" than in the "tele" aspect of their new toy, popular singers are seldom presented to top advantage on TV.

WITH her usual acute understanding of present-day teen-ager problems, Mrs. Emery discusses the effects of high school sorority life not upon the girl who is left out but upon one of the lucky ones who is chosen.
BALLET dancing, an art form heretofore but sketchily represented on television, will get a full-fledged showing on video screens under plans currently in preparation by The March of Time.
TAMPA, Fla., March 29 (UP) -- Trailing by 3 -- 0 after the first inning, the Reds rallied for their fifth straight grapefruit league victory today when they beat the Braves, 6 -- 4.
WHAT ought the well- dressed man wear? Well, he certainly ought to wear something, otherwise we would not have any men's fashions.

PHOENIX, ARIZ. THERE is a certain inescapable, even crucial, resemblance between a major league baseball training camp and the smokehouse of a big packing company in that both business are devoted, in the main, to the scientific curing and seasoning of large quantities of flesh, the most striking difference probably being that baseball prefers the hard player to the soft ham, although it is sometimes forced to put up with the latter.

Arturo Toscanini conducted Beethoven's First and Ninth Symphonies at Carnegie Hall late yesterday afternoon with a brilliance and fire that belied the established fact that he had turned 85 last Tuesday.

I have read with amusement, not unmixed with a less complimentary emotion, the laborious attempt of A. A. Milne to patronize the memory of a world-famous man, whose fictional creation, Sherlock Holmes, represented but one facet in a life that was as brilliant in its achievements as it was noble in its purposes.

MILAN -- Most travelers in Italy see Milan only from train windows, or try an eight - hour hit - and - run visit and hurry away to the antiquities. They pass up a great city of modern Italy. But more than that -- those who have experienced Milan agree that it is probably on its way to being the most significant city of Western Europe.

MADISON, Wis., March 28 (Friday) -- An estimated 1,000,000 Wisconsin voters go to the polls Tuesday in a primary that has national significance because it is a do-or-die effort for two veteran aspirants to the Presidency -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and Harold E. Stassen.

TORONTO, March 29 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings filled the net behind the aging, overweight Turk Broda tonight to beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6 -- 2, and take a 3-0 lead in the best-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-finals.
Sylvan Gotshal's letter emphasizing the innate friendliness of France toward this country struck a responsive chord.

The one-time United Nations General Assembly hall at Flushing Meadow, Queens, goes back to the ice age this fall. Contractors are laboring on a $237,000 project to restore the former World's Fair city building as the Park Department ice and roller skating rink it was before the United Nations came along.

The man came to dinner and stayed has a good counter part in German-born Henry H. Reichhold, who came to America on a vacation in 1924 and remained to build a company today commanding $150,000,000 in sales.

PARIS, March 29 -- Dr. Albert Schweitzer, medical missionary, philosopher and musician, is reported here to have turned down an offer from Hollywood producers and, instead, authorized a French film company to do his life story, free.

AT 14, Michael Windfield, loyal subject of King Charles II, was poaching on the King's land and depending on his skill with the crossbow to feed his family. Before he was 20 he had made two voyages to the New World as an employe of the Company of Adventurers of England Trading into Hudson Bay and had played a not inconspicuous role in establishing the supremacy of England's fur trade.

ALBANY, March 29 -- In next fall's general election, the wives and husbands of service personnel and their parents and children will be eligible, for the first time, to vote by absentee ballot if they are living out of the state due to military service.

EGG hunts and nature walks will divide honors with more sophisticated entertainment over the Easter week-end, which will stretch into a longer holiday for many who plan to take a week at near-by resorts. Airlines are already making reservations for the week before Easter Sunday, April 13, and they and the railroads will run extra sections to take care of the crowds.
The truce discussions in Korea dragged on under new secrecy restrictions last week, but without perceptible progress.

ARIAS from Pagliacci, Tosca, Carmen, Aida, etc.; Kurt Baum, tenor, with Austrian Symphony Orchestra conducted by Wilhelm Loibner (Remington). Lusty singing of standard arias, marked by force rather than subtlety. A good $2.19 worth of tenor singing.

NEW YORK'S clubs, like London's clubs, which set the pattern, have played an important part in the social history of the city since the oldest of the lot, the Union, was founded in 1863. Their biographies have been written from time to time, usually on a round number anniversary, like a centennial, and publication has generally been by and for the members.

THE Multiflora sweet pea being offered to the public for the first time has been called "the ultimate" in this flower. It bears six to eight, or more, full-sized florets (four is usual) on a single stem that is often eighteen inches tall.

HORSE-PLAYERS and persons who go by the Presidential election polls must have got a sympathetic chuckle out of the confusion of the movie dopesters last week. For certainly if ever expectations of the bestowal of Academy awards gang agley, they gang With the startling announcement of the "Oscar" winners for 1951.

MILWAUKEE, March 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, in two speeches here today denounced his two chief rivals for the support of Wisconsin's thirty convention delegates for "saying nothing" about foreign policy in their campaign efforts here.

The first twenty-four preludes and fugues from Bach's "The Well-Tempered Clavier" make a massive and nourishing afternoon of music. Few performers attempt to play the whole book at a single sitting (Wanda Landowska once spread it over three recitals), but one did it yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (UP) -- Patty Berg snared five birdies and an eagle for a four-under par 70 and a ten-stroke lead in the $4,000 New Orleans women's open golf tournament today. The best score of the tournament so far, it gave Miss Berg a 54-hole total of 217 -- five under par.
Bosley Crowther's article, "Hollywood Accents the Downbeat" (March 16) is excellent and informative but ignores the revolutionary precedents established in this field by David Wark Griffith.
LONDON, March 29 -- Citizens of the United States, especially Southerners, should be able to appreciate the issues of the present political crisis in South Africa.

AS THE star of "Mrs. McThing," Helen Hayes is irresistibly funny. As president of the American National Theatre and Academy, she is invincibly earnest. Since the comic fantasy is now established at the Morosco with all signs pointing to a profitable run, and the profits go to ANTA, it is apparent that Miss Hayes is triumphantly discharging her duties both as actress and theatre-up-lifter. She makes people laugh, and ANTA makes money.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- Soybeans sparked an upturn in grain prices on the Board of Trade today. Dealings became active on the advance, particularly in the bean pit. Gains ran to several cents in soybeans, but were only around a cent in other commodities.

EVER since the perceptive, erudite Bayard Taylor found travel among the Scandinavians an exhilarating experience a century ago, subsequent voyagers have returned enthusiastic about the Three Northern Countries -- the scenery, the people and their design for living.

SOESTDIJK. WHEN Queen Juliana moves about her crowded land, no motorcycle escort roars ahead. At stoplights, her car takes its place behind the others. On a visit to a provincial center, she shuns the throne-like furniture which local officials have mustered out for her and chooses an ordinary chair. On her visits to the theatre or the Amsterdam Concertgebouw to no one may proclaim the sovereign's presence to the audience.

POINT BARROW, Alaska, March 29 (UP) -- Nine stranded weather observers huddled in the fuselage of their wrecked plane on a floating island of ice only 410 miles from the North Pole today, as Navy airmen planned an attempt to rescue them before the ice broke up.

THE Gothic romance, revived in 1939 by Isak Dinesen with great success in her "Seven Gothic Tales," was a creation of the so-called romantic movement of the late eighteenth century, and it must be said that its appeal was mainly a childish one.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 29 -- Gushing Oil, Sam E. Wilson Jr.'s Kentucky Derby candidate, scored a record-breaking triumph in the Arkansas Derby today as the thoroughbreds closed Oaklawn Park's most successful meeting by setting new track marks at four distances.

Seaboard Oil Company of Delaware cleared a net profit of $6,425,299, equal to $5.26 a share in 1951, according to the annual report released yesterday. This compares with $6,106,621 or $4.99 a share in 1950.

In Moscow last Wednesday, the charges d'affaires of the United States, Britain and France called one by one at the rambling graystone building on Vorosky Place that houses the Soviet Foreign Office. At intervals of thirty minutes, the Allied diplomats stepped into the office of Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Vishinsky and read to him identical notes from their Governments.

JOHN PANTELLIS was one of the thousands of young Greeks who emigrated to America in the early part of the twentieth century. He came of peasant stock but he was intelligent and energetic and he managed to make a lot of money.

WITH the publication in 1922 of Fiske Kimball's "Domestic Architecture of the American Colonies and of the Early Republic" our architectural history was placed upon a sound basis for the first time. Using that book as a point of departure, many investigations were made into the lives of colonial architects, into the history of individual buildings and into hitherto unworked fields or unstudied regions.

Stony Wold Sanatorium will be the beneficiary of a card party to be held on the afternoon of April 25 in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Charles Stevens MacKenzie is president of the Chi Kappa Club, under whose auspices the forthcoming benefit has been arranged.

THE literary offensive conducted by American generals and admirals, and their ghosts and yes-men, since the end of World War II has been quite an operation. The picture given the public of the United States' part in the war in the Mediterranean and Europe is one of almost uninterrupted success, august infallibility in strategy and tactics, plans unfailingly carried out and wisdom and foresight guiding each brass-hatted head.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 29 (AP) -- Janet Backman, an 18- year-old high school girl from Wilmington, Mass., reigned as queen of the North American indoor ice speed skating championships here tonight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 29 -- Unable to win any of the three individual crowns, Columbia University's trio of Stephen Sobel, Daniel Chafetz and Alfred Rubin nevertheless combined to capture the three-weapon team championship as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's eighth annual fencing tournament ended today.

THE progress of the change taking place in the look of men's suits -- and the male silhouette -- is not without its sound and good-natured fury. While the man in the street may see as many variations of the two extremes, "natural" and "drape," as there are passersby and never give it a thought, among the men who make and sell these various types of suits the arguments continue loud and strong.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- T. A. Bisson, a University of California educator, testified today that he never had cooperated voluntarily with Communist objectives and never had been a Communist.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., March 29 (AP) -- Oklahoma's Sooners tonight won their second straight National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championship by edging Iowa Teachers College by a single point.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 29 -- A three-way fight for California's Republican delegates to the national convention shaped up today with the filing of candidates for the Presidential primary due to close next Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Truman's call for emergency legislation to provide for the admission of 300,000 more displaced persons went to a Congress considering how to get the whole business of immigration back to normalcy and long-range planning.

ALTHOUGH drama is widely acknowledged to be the best effort on British TV, there is a chronic shortage of new plays. This famine, which causes B. B. C. to draw mainly upon established stage successes, has also led the corporation to found what is claimed as the world's first week-end school for TV writers.

MANY home owners these days have relatively small properties. By the time they allow space for a driveway, walks, patio, service and lawn areas, and a few trees and shrubs, there is usually little room left for flowers.

WEATHERSFIELD, Conn. -- A definite objective adds impetus to motoring on a fine spring day, and Connecticut, with its combination of rolling landscapes and historic Colonial homes, makes an ideal goal for city drivers out for a day's jaunt.

APRIL, to a certain percentage of the over-all population, is a long period marked by wind, rain and generally unpleasant weather, but to several million anglers in a score of states it provides one of the most important dates on the calendar -- opening day of the trout season.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., March 29 -- Smoky, the Fire Department's Dalmatian mascot who was exiled to an animal shelter early this month because of overzealous guarding of the fire house and equipment, will be restored to the ranks of Protection Engine Company here tomorrow.

There will not be enough boys' tailored clothing in the stores this Easter to offer the consumer an adequate selection, manufacturers and retailers predicted last week. While the shortage would indicate great activity on both levels, the reverse is generally the case.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Like a good many families throughout the country, Congress needs more housing.

The Department of Justice doesn't faze the Sunbeam Corporation. Nothing short of airtight legal compulsion will halt the Chicago appliance concern's continuing relentless fight to "fair trade" effectively its Mixmasters and other small appliances.

Dr. Ryojun Kinosita, the Japanese scientist who discovered that a dye called "butter yellow" because of its color causes cancer of the liver in rats when mixed with their food, has received a grant of $3,600 from the American Cancer Society to continue his studies in the University of California at Los Angeles, Calif.

PARIS, March 29 -- Tickets go on sale Monday in the United States, France and other countries for the Twentieth Century Festival of Art to be staged here in May as a demonstration of what man can create when his mind is not subject to totalitarian constraints.
A NEW YORK psychiatrist, talking about men's habits of dress (and the reasons behind those habits), says cheerfully: "Men are coming along very nicely."

A BOY of 4, Jeff Singleton -- but everybody calls him Little Mule -- sits on the front porch with his older brother and sisters. What the children are waiting for is the death of their father, the Baptist minister; Little Mule is completely bewildered by the tension of the moment, and pretty much bored by inaction.

MADRAS, India, March 29 -- Numerous hungry peasants in the famine area of the huge south Indian state of Madras, where more than 10,000,000 persons are suffering an acute shortage of food and water because of the five-year drought, volunteered in interviews at a half dozen villages yesterday that "conditions would be much worse if it were not for the United States wheat sent last year."

An outstanding season for cottons was predicted last week by Henry Rosenfeld, one of New York's largest producers of dresses and sportswear, A promotion by the company, supported by local newspaper advertising in the large metropolitan areas, is expected to move over 500,000 dresses in the $8.95 retail category in the next three months, he said.

TODAY'S annual aster, once a homely garden flower, can provide a wealth of color from midsummer through early fall. Prettier than the old-fashioned aster and more delicate, it requires special attention. But it well rewards the gardener who is willing to exert an extra effort.

Unlike many young people today, Harry B. Cohen was not primarily interested in starting salary, pension plans, length of vacation periods and a lot of other fringe benefits when he began his business career thirty-nine years ago in Chicago.
OTTAWA, March 29 (Canadian Press) -- A Crown company will take command next week of Canada's atomic effort.

THE American college is proving the American composer's best friend. A striking evidence of this is provided by the way more and more of the colleges are holding festival-symposiums of American works. The University of Texas held its first such symposium ten days ago.

BONN, March 29 -- This is an uneasy capital. It is apparent here to the Allies and the Germans alike that one of the crucial periods in the struggle for Germany is upon them and that the whole product of four years of Allied policy and two and a half years of Federal Government policy may be in the balance before summer comes.
NEW DELHI, India, March 29 -- Reports of the presence of many Chinese Communists in western Tibet, bordering on the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, have arrived from Lucknow, the state capital.

Plain, ordinary, typical, run-of-the-harbor yacht skippers who own and navigate cruisers are sounding off with a "count us in" chorus as another pleasure-boat season is about to open. The cruiser owners are going through an evolution, perhaps a revolution.

PRESIDENT TRUMAN, who is in a position to know about such things, said the other day that eleven Army generals had served as Presidents of the United States. Superficially this seems like an alarmingly large percentage of the thirty-two individuals who have held the Presidential office, but a further analysis of the list shows that most of Mr. Truman's big brass were ordinary civilians, like you or me.

MEADOW RUES are versatile plants which will thrive in either sun at shade and be equally at home in the border or wild garden. One species, a recent introduction from Asia, is one of the most choice of rock garden plants.

LOS ANGELES, March 29 -- The Giants were on the threshold of victory today as they renewed relations with the Indians before their biggest crowd of the year, but they wound up dropping their fourth in a row to Al Lopez' clubbers from the American League, 5 to 4.

MIAMI, March 29 -- Eddie Stanky walked and scored in the first inning of today's Cardinals-Dodgers game and that run stood up all the way to give the Redbirds a 1-0 triumph and the Brooks their first shut-out defeat of the spring season.

TEN miles outside Munich, where shooting began three weeks ago of a picture on German prisoners of war in Russia, there was a complete Soviet PW camp, replete with the familiar low wooden barracks, endless fences of barbed wire, punctuated by wooden watch towers etched against a snowy vastness.

American wool buyers are gravely concerned with the balance of payments crisis in Australia, it was learned last week. The crisis injects another note of uncertainty into the market at a time when wool manufacturers here already are up to their necks in a morass of slow moving goods and labor difficulties.

FOR as long as I can remember there has been agitated discussion in female fashion circles about the overdue need for dress reform in men's clothes. Many of the top women designers were given a chance to show their ideas by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in an exhibition held a couple of years ago.

THE gardener with alkaline or neutral soil has nothing to worry about. That is, unless he lives in an area where lack of rainfall builds up soil alkalinity until it becomes a limiting factor in plant growth. What is more, except in the case of a relatively small number of plants, most of them will grow as well in alkaline soil as they will in acid soil.

SAVILE ROW is both a street in the West End of London and a generic term for the British custom-tailoring trade. On the map, it is a narrow thoroughfare scarcely as long as a New York crosstown block, with the Ministry of Health at one end and a bank at the other and seventeen tailor shops, three bombed areas and several woolen merchants in between.

The usual signs of spring were lacking in the survey of conditions for March made by the National Association of Purchasing Agents. Instead of the sharp seasonal pickup in production and orders, the trends for the month are described as indicating "more of a leveling off than a lift."

BEGINNING tonight, the deluge -- or, in other words, the prize-giving season is upon us. Over in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, along about the stroke of twelve, they will be giving out the sixth annual set of American Theatre Wing Antoinette Perry prizes (Tonys) and, from now until June the rostrum parades will be almost endless.

OMAHA, Neb., March 29 -- The big question in Nebraska today is whether the "grass roots" appeal of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, as manifested in Minnesota's write-in "miracle," can match and overcome the well-organized drive for write-in votes for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the state's Presidential preference primary on Tuesday.

NEITHER literary nor sensationally sordid in her style. H. H. Lynde writes about this country in honest, thoughtful, unspectacular, malleable prose. She belongs to the school of solid craftsmanship and vivid storytelling, the school of Cronin, Priestley and Arnold Bennett.

THOSE who say men's clothes never change will find in this section ample refutation through picture and text. The truth is that men's clothes do change but they change very slowly, almost imperceptibly. Unlike women's styles, men's clothes do not respond to the sudden dictates of a handful of designers.
DARIEN, Conn., March 29 -- George H. Morris, 14, of New Canaan, Conn., today made a clean sweep of the honors in the annual one-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club indoor spring horse show.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 29 -- Next week marks an important anniversary for the free nations of the West. On April 2, 1951, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower formally assumed command of his Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe. SHAPE, which has become as instrumental to safeguarding the peace as was wartime SHAEF to winning it, became, in military parlance, activated.

NEW DELHI, India, March 29 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Indian business men today that private enterprise was not sacred in India, and that if it clashed with the interests of the country it would be put down or eliminated entirely.

Professor Woodward's "A Spade Is a Spade Is a Maybe" presents a good example of lots of talk to excuse poor or no actions. His point that one must be vigilant concerning the anchor or foundation from which to work is correct.

Nineteen Russian refugees, including a 15-year-old girl, all veterans of more than 100 battles with Communist troops in Russia, Mongolia, China and Tibet, arrived here yesterday aboard the United States Navy transport General Taylor to end a 13,000-mile hegira across several continents.
JAMESBURG, N. J., March 29 -- Harry L. Hubbs resigned as chief of police here last night, seventeen days after winning the job back in a court battle that lasted seventeen months.

IN literature, much as in politics, France has always been crowded with movements, societies, leagues and cliques and schools from which have emerged the major artists of their time. Two factors have in general been essential for a French writer to "arrive" to belong to a coterie and be accepted for publication by one of the intellectual and prestige dispensing literary reviews.

Current United States production of aircraft as portrayed by Robert Nathan in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 2 is actually a good deal better than his comparison of 1941 and 1951 production rates by numbers would suggest.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A new drive for a Federal law requiring equal pay for men and women doing the same work with the same skills began today with the announcement by Representative Edna F. Kelly, Democrat of New York, that she was introducing a drastically revised "equal pay" bill.

THE vegetables of spring -- asparagus, dandelion greens and cabbage fresh from the fields -- are a spur to lagging appetites. But home cooks need not rely only on these newcomers to the produce stalls to add interest to the season's menus.

PARIS, March 29 -- Italy has officially advised the United States and Britain that she insists upon being treated as an "ally" rather than merely as an "interested party" in next week's three-power discussions on Trieste.

While French and American naval personnel stood at attention at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn yesterday, the slim United States destroyer escorts Clarence L. Evans and Baker were transferred to the French Navy.

HOW to use radio effectively against the evils of communism always has been one of the more difficult tasks for broadcasting. All too often frantic waving of the American flag or smug self-satisfaction with democracy has taken the place of a truly telling and penetrating counter-attack on the air against Red propaganda.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The big new reorganization plan designed to make the Bureau of Internal Revenue a "blue ribbon" tax collection agency has passed its second week of operation, with Commissioner John B. Dunlap reported about ready to tell how it is going.

Recent controversy over Brazil's firmer regulation of profits remittances on foreign capital investments is spurring consideration of a new and clearer policy to encourage those most helpful to the nation's economic progress, official Brazilian sources here have disclosed.

TEN dome lounge cars, embodying a new concept of the dome feature, have been ordered by the Milwaukee Railroad from Pullman-Standard. In these cars the dome will extend the entire length of the car instead of occupying only a small space in the center as is the case with domes now in service.

I read with great interest Leo M. Cherne's "The Biggest Question on TV Debates" (March 2), but noticed that he wrote, "One discussion program -- the University of Chicago Round Table -- ultimately disappeared from the networks."

TWO standard operas, and a virtually unknown one, provide a few more splashes in the deep operatic channel dredged by long-play. Of the three, Tosca, on a pair of Centra-Soria disks, and Rigoletto, on three Remingtons, are standard works.

Over the past few years the quickening pulse of Canadian economy has given off spectacular sparks -- booming "strikes" of uranium, oil in Alberta, iron in Labrador. The fact is, as a Bank of Montreal survey makes clear, the "boy next door" has been sprouting like a sapling.
With the steel issues leading, the stock market advanced yesterday to new highs for the recovery movement and closed strong in rather active trading. Leaders ended with gains of 1 to 2 points.

WHEN C. S. Forester, the Marryat of our time, announced that he had abandoned Hornblower for a series of modern novels, beginning with "Randall and the River of Time," this reviewer rejoiced. He felt that the Hornblower theme, if continued too long, might run thin.

IT IS safe to say that this book will upset Melville readers more than any book about his mind and art published in many years. There will be controversy in which the large amount of new material here presented, the brilliance of many of the analyses, the subtlety and soundness of many of the perceptions will be ignored as the brickbats fly.

Dramatist, Scenarist, Biographer ONE'S relatives are apt to be censorious, and a close one of mine protested to me rather explosively years ago: "When are you going to get out of that drawing-room?" To that generic locale he applied an epithet not generally used in drawing-rooms and which I omit here.

BONN, Germany, March 29 -- A West German Cabinet minister demanded today that European cooperation be coordinated with the reunification of Germany as clamor for a more positive approach to the Soviet proposals on unity increased.

ELLEN KNAUFF is the German-born "war bride" who was finally admitted to the United States last November after a three-year battle against the Immigration Service. This book is the story of that battle; and, at a time when our immigration statutes are undergoing Congressional revision, it comes as a useful reminder of the harsh procedures and the profound dangers of arbitrary administrative action that our laws presently allow and even encourage.
RECORDINGS are beginning to accomplish something that concert performances have failed to do. They are bringing a wide variety of contemporary music to the American public.

ALTHOUGH the majority of garden plants thrive in a neutral or slightly acid soil, there are several large groups which need a definitely acid location. If there is any doubt about the degree of acidity contained in the soil, a sample should be taken from various parts of the garden and sent to the local agricultural station for testing as soon as possible.

What a pity the Harvard School of Design did not exist when the World's Fair was under construction in the Flushing Meadows. They might have really "gone to town" there, instead of picking on poor, defenseless Block Island to build their assorted monstrosities.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Dan A. Kimball, Secretary of the Navy, has informed Congress of the Navy's intention "to develop the capability of delivering atomic bombs from all airplane carriers."

Cooperation and understanding in a classroom at Hunter College have resulted in the forthcoming production of "Deep Are the Roots" by Arnaud D'Usseau and James Gow, a play whose theme centers about the hope for interracial cooperation and understanding.
A fast-moving Boys High basketball team won city honors yesterday by taking the Public Schools Athletic League final at the Brooklyn College gymnasium, vanquishing Seward Park, 51 to 29.
James P. Warburg said yesterday that this country was "rapidly acquiring a vested interest in not having peace" because of its tremendous defense effort against Stalin.

WARNER BROTHERS took the wraps off its new color process on Thursday night with a screening of "The Lion and the Horse," photographed in WarnerColor, at the Academy Theatre here before an invited audience of industry people and press representatives.

TRENTON, March 29 -- The Imperial all-age stake, main event of the annual Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club spring trials, began today with thirteen braces running over the state's hunting preserve. Fifteen dogs remained to compete tomorrow.
Owen R. Jones has been appointed manager of traffic in the materials and purchasing services department of General Electric Company, succeeding Arthur W. Farmer, who has retired.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley tonight charged General of the Army Douglas MacArthur with grossly perverting the truth.

I have just returned to London from a five-year stay in the United States. During this time I was privileged to attend a small but exceedingly fine Quaker school in the Midwest, training its students for creative positions in a world community. For my graduate studies in the field of anthropology I attended a large Midwest university.

ONCE in a while, though from recent columns it may not seem often, this department's hat is off. It is distinctly doffed today, the occasion being an article by Claude M. Fuess in The Saturday Review for March 22.

BOTH of these English authors, the first an authority on modern land-use, the second a novelist and essayist who regards most modern farming as a disease of the environment, are concerned basically with the same question: How may mankind, rapidly increasing in number, keep the soil in permanent production and still eat.

SEATTLE, March 29 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower ran up a 7-to-4 margin over Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio on first reports from a preferential vote taken at Republican precinct caucuses in King County (Seattle), last night.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 29 -- Adding two more titles to its three of the previous two nights and scoring heavily all along the line, Ohio State dethroned Yale as team champion tonight as the twenty-ninth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming meet reached a thrilling close in Princeton's Dillon Gymnasium pool.

ALBANY, March 29 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill that enlists the broad powers of the State Commission Against Discrimination in the fight against racial and religious discrimination in hotels, restaurants and other places of public accommodation, resort or amusement.
New York's ten municipal golf courses, weather permitting, are slated to be opened for another season on Saturday.

COPENHAGEN -- In Denmark "Life-Seeing," not sight-seeing, gets top billing at visitors' information centers. National pride is centered on the citizenry. Civic achievements and an irrepressible hospitality are considered this country's unique product for tourist consumption.

MADRID, March 29 -- The Spanish Cabinet, in a communique issued today, announced that the rationing of olive oil would be temporarily lifted and the restricted sale of certain types of meats would be abolished April 1. This decision follows by one week the end of bread rationing.

When the news leaked out that astounding results had been obtained in treating tuberculosis with isonicotinic acid hydrazides, it was no longer possible to preserve medical secrecy. This week the American Review of Tuberculosis and Diseases of the Chest will devote most of their space to the results so far achieved with the isonicotinic acid hydrazides, given the trade names Rimifon (Hoffmann-La Roche), Nydrazid (Squibb) and Marsalid (Hoffmann-La Roche).

IT was just about a year ago that William Perlberg and I contacted Jose Ferrer to inquire if he would be available and interested in playing the leading role in a film based on George and Helen Papashvily's delightful book, "Anything Can Happen."
President Truman's announcement that he would not be a candidate for re-election was received with surprise in most political circles, and some Democrats expressed a hope that the...

FAIRMONT, W. Va., March 29 (AP) -- Fairmont State College is in new turmoil, following a $100,000 slander suit and charges that a teacher had been dismissed on false accusations that she was a Leftist and did not believe in God.

President Truman's request for action to insure voting rights for soldiers now effectively deprived of the franchise should receive immediate and favorable response. Of all American citizens certainly none deserves the ballot more than the men and women serving in the armed forces.

KANSAS CITY, Sunday, March 30 -- Coach Phog Allen got assurance that a Midwestern referee will help officiate in the Olympic basketball play-offs in New York before he agreed early today to take his University of Kansas team into the semi-finals against La Salle.
HIGHWAY hazards will get a thorough going over at the twenty-second annual convention and exposition of the Greater New York Safety Council, which opens Tuesday at the Statler and New Yorker Hotels.

AS a piano teacher and particularly as one whose pupil was presented over Station WQXR in the series "Music Talent in Our Schools," I read Mr. Downes' article as well as the letters written to your paper having a bearing on this subject, with great interest.
A DAY'S adventure for the large and amusing Toosey family is the subject of this latest addition to the publisher's Easy Reading Series.

BONN, Germany, March 26 -- A series of articles in one of the most widely circulated weekly picture magazines here contains charges that the Western Allies purposely starved the Germans immediately after the war, that they stole their patents, refused to permit them export possibilities and, after dismissing a German official who complained, tried to frame him as a black marketeer.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 29 -- Brazilian security forces, extending their hunt for Red agents through all branches of the armed forces, have identified a civilian hitherto unsuspected of Communist activities as the possible keystone of the whole structure of spying and agitating in the services, according to local press reports.

OUR wild English foxglove has a tall spike bearing many drooping, pink purple flowers that are spotted white within the lip. Although charming in open woodland, this sturdy biennial flower until special strains and hybrids were developed to give variety in color and a more attraction habit of growth.

ANDREAS FEININGER has written another stimulating book as a sequel to his "Feininger on Photography." In his new work, "Advanced Photography: Methods and Conclusions" (New York: Prentice-Hall, Inc. $7.50), to be published tomorrow, the author assumes the reader's knowledge of the fundamentals covered in the first book and takes him into the realm of creative photography based on a sound understanding of the craft.

THE Western world knows little of Mikhail Vasilyevich Lomonosov, the 225th anniversary of whose birth Russia celebrated with fervor in 1936. A very great man, his greatness was never fully acknowledged abroad even during his own lifetime.

In 1943 a young man (along with thousands of other young men) was stationed at an air base in the South. The base had been thrown together hurriedly the year before. A cadre of men arriving at the base when it was being built had had to shoo away the pigs that were rooting about.

FROM "In a Dark Garden" to "The Road to Bithynia," Dr. Slaughter has projected many best-selling historical novels against the background of his profession. This time he shows signs of writing the serious modern novel he could and should write about surgeons -- and then, in his final chapters, returns to the familiar road of melodrama.

UP to a few years ago, a man didn't bother much about the nature of the cloth that went into his clothes, He chose style and appearance first, and only incidentally wore cotton or linen, silk or wool -- the time-old natural fibers from the plant and animan world.

April is not only the month for spring showers, bursting buds and lovesick poets, but it is also the month for primaries. And if anyone is left alive who doesn't put stock in the preferential primary as a means of expressing the popular will, let him take another look at New Hampshire and at Minnesota.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The tired dollar picked up a little strength this month. The economic doctors were giving it a fighting chance against the wear and tear of inflation. New steel complications have set in, and another check-up has been ordered.
Scotland-bound for "his health," a home relief recipient of the Department of Welfare found his sailing plans rudel shattered an hour before the departure yesterday of the Cunard liner, Queen Mary.
LONDON, March 29 -- A great-hearted Oxford crew rowed or mushed its way through a blizzard this afternoon to beat Cambridge by four feet in the ninety-eighth annual University Boat Race.

BEHIND most monumental achievements are little known (and consequently little appreciated) good samaritans, Johnny Appleseeds who quietly plant the seeds that materialize publicly, much later. Such a man was Frederick Gardner Cottrell, who helped to usher in the Atomic Age.

Dedication ceremonies were held recently in a Midwestern community of 60,000 for a new treatment-training center for cerebral palsied children. The community was truly proud, for the dedication represented real teamwork.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 29 -- White Leghorn and New Hampshire hatching eggs -- about 210,000 of them from stock of excellent breeding -- will be flown to Korea to help rebuild the food resources of that war-shattered country.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- Pennsylvania Republican leaders are studying the results of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's success in the New Hampshire and Minnesota primaries for guidance in their own final alignment on the Presidential issue.

Educators were told yesterday that while they were the persons most appalled by the dangerous disjunction between our scientific knowledge and our social values," they were also the ones most responsible for the condition.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Second-class postage rates will take a 10 per cent jump next Tuesday, increasing publication mailing charges by an estimated $3,000,000 to $4,000,000 a year.

Department store sales recorded a statistical gain last week, with dollar volume 10 per cent higher than for the corresponding 1951 week, but merchants were unhappy about the slowness of business as Easter approached. In the comparable week last year, sales were off 14 per cent from the 1950 level. Seasonable weather bolstered hopes for rising sales.

THE Confederate Constitution specifically upheld slavery, and soldiers fighting for the Confederacy were certainly doing the same thing. Mr. Beard quotes what Lincoln wrote Confederate Vice President Alexander H. Stephens. In reply I'd like to quote Stephens' words on the principles of the Confederate Government. He said:

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- A Senate subcommiteee's reported plans to recommend that newspapers raise their advertising rates in order to discourage "unnecessary" advertising threatened today to provoke a fight.

I examined with some interest (dismayed interest, I must say) your pictures of what the Harvard Architecture students propose to do to Block Island. I cannot speak with much expert knowledge of architecture (although I know what I like), but I can speak as one who has visited Block Island many times and who is a devoted admirer of that unique piece of land.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Truman's announcement at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner here tonight that he would not accept renomination threw wide open the contest for the Democratic party choice for the first time since 1932.

The New York Foundling Hospital will be the beneficiary of a preview showing of "Never Take No for An Answer," the Souvaine Selective Pictures Film by Paul Gallico, with Vittorio Manunta, new Italian child star, on the night of April 24 at the Beekman Theatre, Second Avenue and East Sixty-sixth Street.

HONG KONG, March 29 -- A system of special tribunals is being established in China's urban centers to try private businessmen accused of major economic transgressions against the state in the Chinese Communist Wu Fan (Five Anti) movement.

AMERICANS woke up a couple of weeks ago to find that the country's largest private Shakespeare collection -- seventy-three volumes of folios and quartos valued at more than $1,000,000 -- had been bought right out from under them by a Swiss banker.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- With every indication that its patience with Soviet and satellite propaganda in this country was at an end, the Senate voted without dissent this week to put foreign publicists now enjoying diplomatic immunity under the rigorous controls of the Foreign Agents Registration Act.

A long-dormant proposal to rebuild the Metropolitan Opera House at a cost of $2,000,000 to $3,000,000 received renewed attention from officials and friends of the institution yesterday in the wake of news that the Columbus Circle site projected for a new home would not be available.

" WE'RE getting too American, we Canadians," says a war veteran in this new novel by W. G. Hardy, a classics professor at the University of Alberta. This "cultural annexation" is a recurring theme today in Canada, a country which has come of age economically and now seeks an authentic voice.

Waste products of cane sugar refineries and potato-processing factories may one day be used to combat the annual loss of $500,000 worth of water from Western irrigation canals to weeds alongside the lined waterways of the laboratory, says Dr. V. P. S. Kaloff, lecturer in geography at the Johns Hopkins University.

Agreeing that great strides had been made in the last twenty-five years in the detection of arsonists, experts in the subject nonetheless declared yesterday that more and better-trained investigators were needed and that the quality of fire investigation left much to be desired.

In the Sunday issue of March 23, the heading Chopin-Godowsky evoked emotions of gratitude and pride in me as it must have in many Godowsky devotees. At last one music critic has the courage of putting his foot forward in acknowledgment of the uncanny genius of Leopold Godowsky, one of the greatest musicians of all time.

NOTED for their realism, Miss Lenski's regional stories -- "Strawberry Girl," "Prairie School" and others -- have won a special place for themselves among boys and girls of 8 to 12. Now in the Roundabout America stories she presents the same kind of material for younger readers, but shorter in form, simplified in structure and in vocabulary.

RED BANK, N. J., March 29 -- Ground breaking ceremonies for a new $350,000 Presbyterian church on the former Tower Hill estate of the late Abram I. Elkus, one-time United States Ambassador to Turkey, will be held at 3 P. M. tomorrow. One of the speakers will be Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons of New Jersey, who lives in neighboring Little Silver.

NEITHER the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People nor professional Southerners will be likely to approve all parts of "The Night Thorn." Thoughtful agnostics (as unprejudiced, say, as Ian Gordon himself) will find it a vigorous, well-observed novel about the hard realities of racial segregation and integration.

EVERY day when the newspaper arrives, a girl like I immediately turns to the Financial Section to read the latest Statistics and learn how we girls can take advantage of the new trends in Finances. So, one morning I was very intreeged to note that Our President had ordered the Department of Agriculture to make a Survey on the spending habbits of American gentlemen when they are buying articles for their own consumption.
Spring, it says in Mr. Webster's book, "begins with the vernal equinox."

ONLY the humble skunk cabbage is in bloom, but hiking groups and garden clubs have already made plans for trips to wild gardens and sanctuaries. Many a calendar bears notations -- key dates for enjoying the changing pageant of the countryside -- for within a few weeks hepatica, Dutchman's breeches and other early wild flowers will be opening in sheltered locations.

A SERIES of Liberian stamps being released this week has as its theme the historical beginning of this American-sponsored Negro republic established about a century and a quarter ago on the west coast of Africa.

Small high-speed gears are now being made from nylon instead of steel by an English firm. The gears range from three-eighths inch in diameter to just over one-half inch for a spray gun. The gear box is incorporated in the gun which is made of nylon and a special plastic.

" Treasury stock," which denotes capital stock reacquired by purchase or otherwise by the issuing corporation, is primarily an accounting term as distinguished from a statutory or legal term. The courts recognize the term, however, as implying that the stock was regularly issued and paid for and found its way into ownership by the corporation.

Hold-ups are made easier by carelessness and negligence of employers who entrust their bank deposits to one person whose travel times and routes become so routinized that they can be plotted by prospective robbers.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A record total of 450 tax evasion cases, representing about $25,000,000 allegedly owed the Government by individuals and corporations, has been approved for prosecution by the Tax Division of the Department of Justice in the four and one-half months from last Nov. 1 to March 15.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 30 -- The Peiping radio accused the White House today of "utter callousness and ill will" toward American prisoners captured by the Communists in the Korean war. The broadcast, monitored here, asserted that "the American warmongers do not want all their prisoners who are now in care of this side to be repatriated."

THE fine floribundas developed during the past few years have greatly encouraged the use of this class of roses for hedges. Not only do they possess the bushiness required in good hedge material, but they produce a succession of flowers from early summer until frost.

The silence is ended. It was the silence which began with the last scratchy note of the last katydid, progressed with the brittle-dry scuffle of leaves in the roadway, deepened with the echo of owl hoot and fox bark. At its greatest depth it was a silence in which one could hear the whisper of snowflakes falling.
LONDON, March 29 -- The roll on British warships equipped with stabilizing gear has been halved, Professor A. J. Sims said this week before the Royal Society of Arts.

THE legion of Mary O'Hara's readers, enamored of the Wyoming ranch lands where Flicka and Thunderhead browsed, may feel some surprise at being invited by the same writer into pastures green in the scriptural sense. Bestseller lists attest to the current popularity of the theme of man's spiritual health. But the tradition is not a recent one.
ALBAN BERG was an unforgettable figure of a man, extremely tall, slightly stooped, with a head like Oscar Wilde's and a never vanishing, quiet smile.

A NEW hero has arisen to take his place in American folklore along with the Private Eye, the G-Man and the hell-for-leather, racket-busting District Attorney. He is known prosaically only as a Committee Counsel but could be called the "C-Man."

Crude oil may be an important commodity for which the supply soon may be considerably greater than the demand. Excluding Russia and the satellite countries, current production available to the free nations is estimated at 11,000,000 barrels a day, or some 500,000 daily more than a year ago, when Iran was producing about 725,000 barrels a day.

CHICAGO, March 29 (UP) -- Warren Druetzler, who did his running for Michigan State, defeated Don Gehrmann before 17,596 fans in the Chicago Daily News Relays tonight, and Bob Richards cleared 15 feet in the pole vault for the twenty-fourth time.

Wearied by transcontinental traveling and weakened by so much post-season basketball, St. John's of Brooklyn made a gallant bid to remain in the United States Olympic basketball team trials that started last night at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) -- About 72,000 of the nation's telephone and telegraph employes threatened today to strike next week unless they received substantial wage increases.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- The Yankees, who all of a sudden appear to have run into some rough going, caught it again today.

The lack of uniformity in retirement practices and the need for greater statistical records of company experiences in pensioning over-age workers was stressed in a study made by the industrial relations section of Princeton University's Department of Economics and Social Institutions published last week.

REMEMBER when the rubber plant and Martha Washington geranium held sway? Many plants that were popular in grandmother's day have long since faded from the public eye. But still others have reemerged to enjoy an even greater vogue.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., March 29 -- Simultaneous raids yesterday here and in near-by Nyack were revealed today to have resulted in the arrest and conviction of a strangely assorted quartette of admitted bookmakers. The prisoners included a former State Assemblyman, a former police chief, a former patrolman and a convicted gambler.

FORT HOOD, Tex., March 29 (UP) -- Defending forces, strengthened by increasing air power and reinforced armored units, stopped the Aggressor advance along the entire front of Exercise Long Horn today.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., March 29 -- Mrs. Sophia Simmons, Polish refugee war bride of a former United States Army sergeant, appeared at Paul Kimball Hospital here last night with both arms cut from self-inflicted razor blade slashes. In broken English she tried to tell hospital attaches she had killed her two children.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 29 -- One of the oldest and most famous of college humor magazines, The Princeton Tiger, made its reappearance this week under a completely revised editorial policy designed to make it a serious publication of general campus interest.

Taking advantage of a six-goal handicap, the New York Polo Club reached the final round of the Eastern twelve-goal indoor tournament last night by topping the Winged Foot Polo Club, 12 -- 11, in the feature match of a doubleheader at the Squadron A Armory.

The Kremlin will be playing for large stakes at the Communist-arranged World Economic Conference which opens in Moscow next Thursday. Stalin's objective is nothing less than to persuade the non-Communist world that it can, should, and must do business with the empire he rules.

When two ex-servicemen, Lester Rees and Oscar Levine, both Chicagoans, decided to start their own business, hand-painted plastic shower curtains were made on a job basis and were expensive. An assembly line method of producing them had not been tried as yet.
MILWAUKEE, March 29 -- The battle for Wisconsin's thirty Republican and twenty-eight Democratic convention delegates will go into its final round here tomorrow morning.

Democratic legislators will help in every way possible to find a long-range, nonpartisan solution for the financial problems facing the City of New York, Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn, minority leader of the State Assembly, promised yesterday.

THE "conflict" which Thomas Sugrue dwells upon most in this troubled and impressionistic essay resides in his own mind and memory and heart. The book is more autobiography than argument, and its colors and tones and meanings present a private history more convincingly than an objective and comprehensible criticism of how American Protestantism and Catholicism confront each other.

THE protagonist of this long and detailed novel, Baron Rudolph Von Hossmann, descendant of one of Austria's most distinguished families, owner of a newspaper chain, political liberal and amateur auto-racer, finds himself an outlaw when the Anschluss makes Austria a part of the Reich.

THE life and career of Caius Julius Caesar is spread out here without comment in a translation from the French. This is perhaps the best form for a post-war study of a man whose ambition led him to wade in blood and end a republic.

GENEVA, March 29 (AP) -- The International Red Cross Committee protested today against "tendentious and abusive" broadcasts by the Peiping radio in connection with the committee's offer to investigate Communist charges that United Nations forces in Korea were waging germ warfare

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 29 -- Big Bill Nary, who calls Los Angeles home but registers from Albuquerque, and Jimmy Clark, Virginia-born pro who plays out of Laguna Beach, Calif., moved into a fifty-four-hole first-place tie in the $10,000 Azalea open golf tournament today with 12-under-par 204 totals.

Trinity College is establishing in Hartford, Conn., one of the nation's finest libraries, merging in a new $1,210,000 building the Watkinson Library and the college collections. The new building is to be completed on May 1. The full use of the library will be available next fall.

PARIS, March 29 -- France's new program of internal reforms for Tunisia envisages the transfer of most aspects of internal sovereignty to the North African protectorate within five years but clings to the old stumbling block of previous negotiations -- voting rights for the French minority there.
More than 2,000 persons in fifty-nine groups across the country are testing a new Film Discussion Project devised by the Fund for Adult Education, an organization established by the Ford Foundation.

If anyone who is well acquainted with the island would carefully take into consideration the many God-given qualities we have here, such as location, picturesque and beautiful scenery, ideal climate, excellent beaches, finest water for swimming in this section of the country, fresh and salt water fishing -- why would it be impossible to make our island the most outstanding resort in our country?

A FEW months ago this column indulged in a heart-felt plea to mystery novelists to utilize any unfamiliar locales that they knew well -- to give the reader some surcease from the dreary round of New York. Southern California and the English countryside.

There are three major unsettled issues in the Korean truce negotiations. These are Communist demands that all prisoners of war be repatriated regardless of their wishes in the matter; the Soviet Union serve as one of the six "neutral" nations to police the truce; they have unlimited right to construct airfields in North Korea during the truce.

GRAND ISLAND, Neb., March 9 -- Senator Estes Kefauver proposed to Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma today that the winner of their Nebraska Democratic Presidential preference test on Tuesday take all of the state's national convention delegates.

Mixing his shots in splendid style, Tom Byrne of the New York Athletic Club captured the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association professional title yesterday by defeating Lou Ballato, defending champion from the home club, in the final at the City A. C.

James P. McAllister, president of McAllister Brothers, Inc., has been re-elected president of the New York Tow Boat Exchange, Inc., it was announced yesterday. The organization also named J. Warren Russell as vice president; John F. Cahir, secretary and Harry F. Pearsall, treasurer.

HARTFORD, March 30 -- United States Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, was formally entered today in the race for the Democratic nomination for President.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Truman's withdrawal as a candidate for re-election posed a big question for Republicans today -- is the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower necessary to assure a Republican victory in November?

ROME, March 30 -- Pope Pius imparted an apostolic benediction from the central balcony of St. Peters Basilica to a large crowd of the faithful who had gathered this evening for a special Lenten service at an altar erected in St. Peter's Square.

With the Olympic basketball committee having bowed to the demand of Coach Phog Allen for one Western official, Kansas will meet La Salle in one of the two Olympic trial semi-finals at Madison Square Garden tonight. In the opener, the Phillips 66 Oilers of Barltesville, Okla., will tackle the Peoria Caterpillar Diesels.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- President Truman appeared today to be a runner-up -- or at worst a third-place winner -- in any competition for flat-footed statements pulling out of a Presidential race.

LONDON, March 30 -- Nothing occurred last week either to revive public interest in the stock markets or to clear away the perplexities and uncertainties which have beset the markets in the past few weeks.

TRENTON, March 30 -- One wing of the Trenton State Prison here was virtually wrecked today in a four-hour riot by fifty inmates over the alleged refusal of a prison orderly to provide medical attention for one of the convicts.

ROME, March 30 -- The speech on the Trieste situation delivered to the Yugoslav National Assembly by Deputy Foreign Minister Mattes, was not thought in Italy to hold out any hope that the problem of the Free Territory would be solved at any time within the foreseeable future by a direct understanding between Italy and Yugoslavia.

The contract bridge pair of Bertram Lebhar Jr. and Simon Rossant of New York continued their winning pace last night and outscored fifty-one other finalist pairs to capture the 1952 Eastern States Pair championship.

MIAMI, March 30 -- The Dodgers' farewell to Miami Stadium today was on a pleasant note. They beat the Cardinals, 7 -- 2, before 11,375 fans for a citrus circuit record of 11 and 7. Today's crowd ran the total here for thirteen games to 91,077.

The Sun Oil Company plans to spend about $110,000,000 on this year's expansion designed to keep pace with the increasing demand for higher quality petroleum products, Joseph N. Pew Jr., chairman, and Robert G. Dunlop, president, inform stockholders in the pamphlet report for 1951.

Jan de Hartog's "The Fourposter" and "The King and I," by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, were named winners of the sixth annual Antoinette Perry Memorial Trophies as the season's outstanding play and musical, respectively, last night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, March 30 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill modernizing New York's archaic Sunday blue laws and abolishing the existing state-wide bans on such Sunday activities as stock car races and circuses.

SAIGON, Indo-China, March 30 (AP) -- French Union forces, mopping up in the Red River delta, tonight routed five Communist-led battalions dug in fifty miles southeast of Hanoi. Of the Vietminh defenders, 273 were killed and 105 captured.

Modern art, with the largest following in its history, is little understood by the public and must fight against "conformity," Lloyd Goodrich, associate director of the Whitney Museum, said yesterday in the closing lecture of a symposium on contemporary art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

MOBILE, Ala., March 30 -- The discovery of a giant salt dome, which resulted from an unsuccessful search for oil, is pacing this section of the Gulf Coast to the greatest industrial growth in its 250-year-old history.

MANILA, March 30 -- The heaviest migratory movement in the history of the Philippines is starting to drain the overpopulated agricultural areas of the central Visayan islands and Luzon into the undeveloped rich lands of Mindanao, the southernmost island of the archipelago.

Both the shapes and the designs applied to several vases in the new collection of crystal objects, designed by Vicke Lindstrand for the Swedish concern Kosta, impart a feeling of movement. They are available at Georg Jensen.

Private enterprise alone cannot be expected to regenerate the slums because public action is needed to remove their causes, said a report published yesterday by the Institute for Urban Land Use and Housing Studies of Columbia University.

Following are editorial comments from newspapers across the country on President Truman's announcement that he would not be a candidate for re-election, as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press:

BONN, Germany, March 30 -- The Socialist Unity (Communist) party in East Germany and its Soviet advisers are confident that in the event of free elections for German unity the party would win betwen 15 and 20 per cent of the votes cast.

A ten-ton semi-trailer truck carrying 27,000 pounds of beef arrived here Saturday afternoon with its cargo intact from Sioux City, Iowa, belying information that had come to the Federal Bureau of Investigation that it would be hijacked en route.

Basketball showmanship -- as exemplified by the Harlem Globetrotters -- attracted 35,548 persons to Madison Square Garden yesterday. With the Trotters opening their transcontinental tour against the College All-Americans, a crowd of 18,317 was on hand for the afternoon contest and 17,231 watched the teams last night.

A new Presbyterian Church was established as the Church of the Crossroadsy esterdal afternoon at the Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street. The ceremony was under auspices of the New York Presbytery.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley learned that President Truman was going to announce he would not accept renomination as the Barkleys and the Trumans were about to go to table at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner here last night.
A considerable talent for playing the violin and a rather less considerable talent for making music were displayed late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by Paul Gurevich, not yet 20 years old.

The Canadian dollar sold at a premium of 1 1/15 cent last Friday, highest since mid-December, 1934; the close was 1 cent, an advance of 7/8 cent over the preceding week and the broadest gain since Canadian touched parity with United States dollar last month.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Some Congress leaders held today that President Truman's decision not to run for re-election would make relations between the White House and Capitol Hill a lot easier than they have been for many years.

HANOVER, Germany, March 30 (UP) -- Otto Ernst Remer, boss of West Germany's neo-Nazis, stared into the future today and thought he saw a reunited Germany holding the balance of power between the Soviet Union and the United States.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 30 -- Because they have discovered that they are more Indian than Jewish, 100 Indian Jews, who came here burning with Zionist zeal two years ago, will board a plane chartered by the Jewish Agency tomorrow or the next day to return to Bombay, India.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Following are the texts of letters exchanged between Charles E. Wilson, as Director of Defense Mobilization, and President Truman:

ZURICH, March 30 -- By the time the extraordinary session of the Council of Ministers of the Office of European Economic Cooperation opened in Paris last Tuesday to decide whether -- and if so under what conditions -- the European Payments Union should continue to operate after June 30 authorities in Switzerland had definitely decided that, if only for reasons of solidarity with the rest of Europe, Switzerland must remain a member of the union.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Charles E. Wilson resigned today as Director of Defense Mobilization as a direct result of the steel price dispute, and President Truman accepted the resignation.

On March 15 THE NEW YORK TIMES published a dispatch by your Berlin correspondent, Martin S. Ochs, subtitled "Foreword Being Rewritten to Emphasize Stalinist Theories." This subtitle refers to the correspondent's account of an announcement by the firm of Dietz Verlag that they are publishing a new edition of the Communist Manifesto by Karl Marx and Frederick Engels "with historically important additions."
ST. LOUIS, March 30 (AP) -- Net income for 1951 of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad amounted to $4,173,960, a decrease of $2,173,709, or 32.24 per cent, from the preceding year.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad last year further curtailed its unprofitable passenger service by discontinuing a total of 1,367,290 train miles, according to the pamphlet report for 1951. This made a total of 2,705,098 train miles discontinued in three years.

PARIS, March 30 -- Premier Antoine Pinay, in a speech today at St.-Etienne, near Lyon, declared he would not accept the changes made by the National Assembly's Finance Committee in his bill for the financing of the budget.

TANGIER, March 30 -- Rioting broke out today in the Tangier International Zone in protest against the Treaty of Fez, which gave France her protectorate over Morocco, and against the French-enforced dismissal of the Premier of Tunisia. Four persons were killed and sixty were wounded, ten seriously.

NEWARK, March 30 (AP) -- New Jersey party leaders were stunned today by President Truman's announcement that he would not run for re-election. Many state leaders heard the President's statement at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner in Washington last night.

Carol Brice, contralto, who had not appeared on the local concert stage since 1949, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Warmly received by a large audience, the gifted artist provided for her hearers an unusual and interesting program presented with pleasing artistry and decided tonal glamour.

CLINTON, N. J. March 30 -- A 4-year-old white and liver pointer, Fast Air Delivery, became the winner of the $1,250 Imperial All-Age Stake that brought the five-day spring meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club to a close today.

NOBODY knows how many monuments to the Union soldier were erected after the Civil War in thousands of cities and villages from Maine to Minnesota. Some of them were elaborately ugly. Most of them were very much alike -- statues of a typical Northern private leaning on his rifle and staring with high-minded vacuity into the distance.

LONDON, March 31 (Monday) -- Detached from American domestic political controversies London's newspapers had nothing but kind words to say for President Truman today in commenting on his decision not to run again.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., March 30 -- Stephen Winsten, 16-year-old Swedish S. C. star, accomplished a sparkling performance of 2:09.6 to top a field of seventy in the fourth annual Widener Memorial Trophy race for Class C and unclassified skiers today. The field was the largest in an Eastern competition that season.

PURCHASE, N. Y., March 30 -- Two hundred and seven members of the Civil Air Patrol, volunteer civilian arm of the Air Force, had most of the day to sit around and reminisce at Westchester County Airport today after their annual rescue test ended in success thirty-five minutes after take-off time.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 30 -- Erwin D. Canham, editor of the Christian Science Monitor, said in a lecture at the United States Military Academy tonight that the right of press freedom belonged to the people.

Gradually, over the last several years, the legitimate theatre in New York has left the gambling depths and has emerged as a business man's risk. Because profits for its investors are classed as capital gains, it has become an attractive risk.

MILWAUKEE, March 30 (UP) -- Walter Yochim, 32, of Erie, Pa., took the singles lead in the American Bowling Congress from Curt Freeland of Indianapolis today with a 707 series on games of 227, 279, 201.
The full-skirted fashions have caught the fancy of the well-dressed woman this spring. New York and Paris endorse them and the fashion-wise accept them.
The clatter of coin boxes sounded in Chinatown yesterday as fifty volunteers solicited funds along Mott, Pell, Doyers and Canal Streets for the Red Cross.

A preview of the thirtieth annual exhibition of the Fifty Books of the Year, presented by the American Institute of Graphic Arts, will be given tonight at the Pierre Hotel. It will be offered in conjunction with a dinner in honor of the contemporary book designers whose works were chosen for the exhibition.

An appeal for financial support of an expanded program for the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventy-third Street, was made by the minister, the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, at the morning service yesterday. He announced tentative plans for remodeling the church edifice and the church house at a cost expected to be not less than $1,000,000.

WARSAW, March 30 (AP) -- The Warsaw press reported today that Poland had rejected a United States Congressman's request for documents and witnesses to the World War II massacre of 10,000 Poles in the Katyn Forest in Russia.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 30 -- Eight races were completed in a long session of sailing dinghy competition today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, with Arthur Knapp again topping the scores in his boat Agony. He tallied 221 points.
Mayor Impellitteri held out a ray of hope yesterday to city employes who are pressing for a rise in wages.

Howard S. Cullman celebrates today his twenty-fifth anniversary as a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority. He has been elected chairman, by his fellow commissioners, for eight successive years. He served for a prior decade as vice chairman. Three Governors, Smith, Lehman and Dewey, by appointment or reappointment expressed their confidence in his integrity and his leadership.

If ever there was a striking example of television's power to enable millions of persons to sit in on history in the making, it came with President Truman's surprise announcement that he would not be a candidate for reelection.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 30 -- Girls learn to tell lies at an earlier age than boys, a long term study by a widely known psychologist has indicated.

A "new inquisition" is threatening freedom-loving Christians today, the Rev. Robert C. Hunsicker, vicar of St. Paul's Chapel, said yesterday in a sermon at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Chuch, Broadway at the head of Wall Street.

Steel wage talks will get under way here this afternoon, with both sides gloomy about the chances of heading off a strike April 8. The resignation of Charles E. Wilson as Director of Defense Mobilization and the indecision in Washington over steel prices were viewed as factors that ruled out any likelihood of rapid progress toward a settlement.

William H. Harrison, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company and former head of the National Production Authority, told the Manhattan College Engineers Society yesterday that a third world war had been averted by United States preparedness.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- The Screen Writers Guild today revealed that a representative of R. K. O. Radio Pictures was attempting as late as Feb. 28 "to negotiate a settlement with Paul Jarrico" in the controversy regarding the studio's refusal to give him screen credit as co-author of a movie because he declined to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee whether he was a Communist.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- Army researchers have developed a new lightweight fully automatic rifle which they regard as a "potential replacement" for the Garand, the carbine and the submachine gun.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., March 30 -- Labor disputes have delayed the nation's atomic effort by far more than 1,500-000 man hours but officials have not reported a single Communist - inspired walkout, a survey showed today.

COLUMBIA, S. C., March 30 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes reaffirmed today his support of the candidacy of Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, after President Truman's withdrawal from the Presidential race last night. He demanded for the party a States' Rights platform devoid of all "socialistic" proposals.

Ronnie MacGilvray of St. John's, Mark Workman of West Virginia, Donald (Dudie) Moore of Duquesne and Paul Arizin of the Philadelphia Warriors were honored last night at the annual dinner of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's Restaurant, with 200 persons in attendance.

BOSTON, March 30 (UP) -- Hal Laycoe, bespectacled defenseman playing his best game of the season, paced the Boston Bruins to a 4-1 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens tonight for their first victory in three games of the Stanley Cup Hockey series B playoffs before 11,526 fans at Boston Garden.

The struggle for Germany, which is also a struggle for Europe, is approaching a crucial stage. On one side are the Western Powers, including the German Government, which seek to erect on the ruins of the last war a new and united Europe able to stand on its own feet and strong enough to be a bulwark of world peace against the new imperialism threatening it from the East.

KEBILI, Tunisia, March 29 (AP) -- Tunisia's deposed Premier, Mohammed Chenik, bitterly accused France today of applying the "law of the jungle" to this North African protectorate. He demanded that an international commission come here "to ascertain for itself the true facts."

Seventeen-year-old Conrad Ferguson of 487 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, unwittingly picked on a policeman to sell a stolen car and yesterday found himself held in $5,000 bail for hearing in Brooklyn Adolescent Court Wednesday.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- After drifting irregularly downward most of last week, with all markets unsettled by the weakness in oils and fats, combined with the generally sluggish demand for commodities, grain futures reversed their trend late in the period.

LONDON, Monday, March 31 (AP) -- The British steel industry, worried about a shortage of raw materials, has asked the United States to go easy in cutting into "traditional European sources of supply."
ROME, March 30 -- President Truman's decision reached Rome too late for publication in this morning's newspapers, the only newspapers published on Sunday.

The Philadelphia Americans blanked the Hakoah eleven of Brooklyn, 2 -- 0, and the New York Americans routed the Brooklyn Hispanos, 6 -- 0, in an American Soccer League double-header at Croke Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

The five tiers of balconies and the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera House, usually alive with many colors, were a relatively quiet blue yesterday afternoon with the uniforms of 2,000 men and women of the Salvation Army.
