PANAMA, March 30 -- Communism is threatening Panama. It is like a small black cloud on the blue horizon, unimportant at the moment, and it may blow away or take another course, but if the keepers of Panama's house are wise they will start closing the windows and preparing for a possible storm.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- Unin officials said today that ballots by some 30,000 Western Union employes were running "very heavily" in favor of a country-wide telegraph strike to back up their wage demands.

A school children's string ensemble that was five times the size of a regular symphony orchestra played late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. It was the major event of the National String Festival and Convention, a three-day gathering arranged here by the Violin, Viola and Violoncello Teachers Guild.

A Dutch Colonial home containing ten rooms and three baths on a plot 50 by 160 feet at 45 Leighton Avenue, Yonkers, N. Y., has been sold by George Alberts, steel manufacturer, to J. Stern, a New York retail merchant, in a deal negotiated by Thomas S. Burke, Inc., broker, and A. C. Gallagher Co. of Riverdale, co-broker. It has a large playroom and bar and detached garage.

CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- A 2-year-old brindle Scottish terrier, Champion Edgerstourne Troubadour, owned by Dr. and Mrs. W. Stewart Carter of Buechel, Ky., tonight was named best in show at the International Kennel Club's all-breed event.
The busy little Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet at the Warner Theatre is still bringing unfamiliar works out of its quite considerable repertoire.

Hundreds of youngsters -- and parents, too -- swarmed to the Harlem River railroad yards in the Bronx yesterday morning to serve as the city's annual unofficial welcoming committee for the big show, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus. The circus train, which had arrived in the yards on Saturday night, began unloading at 7 A. M.

MANY years ago there was a saying, long since disregarded, which went: The ability to play billiards well is the mark of a gentleman but the ability to play billiards excellently is the mark of a misspent youth.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared in his sermon yesterday at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, that goodness was more than "a static, useless conformity to a moral pattern or a copy of parental posture in quieting the voice and restraining the actions."

CAIRO, March 30 -- Egypt apparently has had no success so far -- in talks with Sir Ralph Stevenson, the British Ambassador here, concerning eventual settlement of the whole British-Egyptian conflict -- in forestalling the measures being taken in the Sudan by the British administration there to prepare the Sudanese for a self-determination vote, or in securing British recognition of King Farouk as King of the Sudan.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 30 -- President Truman's announcement that he would not seek re-election has improved the chances of Senator Estes Kefauver's campaign in Ohio for delegates to the Democratic National Convention, political observers believed today.

Today, after four years of trial and pre-trial formalities, the horse in the investment banking anti-trust trial is slated to catch up with the cart. The attendant circumstances, moreover, throw light on why the Federal judiciary is worried about the way the anti-trust trials -- there are now more than 150 going on or pending -- are threatening to submerge the judges under masses of documentary exhibits related to abstruse issues of fact.
TOKYO, Monday, March 31 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,205, for Sunday's operations:

There is no reason to question the sincerity of Mr. Truman's announcement that he will not run again, or to assume that he has made this announcement merely to encourage a movement to "draft" him at Chicago. His statement is perfectly specific: "I shall not accept a renomination."

It has been a long time since the old Rubinstein D minor has turned up in this city. Josef Hofmann made a specialty of it (he had studied with the composer) but, in the last generation, he was virtually its sole exponent, although isolated performances did crop up here and there.

BRUSSELS, March 30 -- From the Belgian viewpoint, the European Payments Union, which was established to contribute to liberalization of trade within Western Europe, has become an impediment to further progress in that direction.

Paying tribute to "the self-en- lightened people who fight the enemy from within as welt as from without," Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense, opened the New York City Cancer Committee's April Cancer Crusade at a luncheon held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

PARIS, March 30 -- Surpassing all previous records, the index of French industrial production in February rose to 153, compared with the basic index of 100 for the year 1938. In comparison with the corresponding period in 1951 the increase was 9 per cent and 21 per cent compared with February, 1950.

Broadway was agog over the week-end trying to figure out the cause for the sudden concern displayed by the Bureau of Internal Revenue in the collection of the right admission tax at "Mrs. McThing" and "Golden Boy," both put on by the American National Theatre and Academy.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 -- The Yankees, with Yogi Berra in the starting line-up for the first time in a fortnight, regained their winning touch today and triumphed over the Braves, 8 -- 6.

An appeal to strive for an "open world," in which religious, educational and cultural forces could help solve "the continuing crisis in international relations" was addressed here last night to delegates from thirty-four New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts colleges and universities.
COLORADO SPRINGS, March 30 (AP) -- Tenly Albright of Newton Center, Mass., turned in a near perfect performance last night to win the senior women's national figure-skating title.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Trade volume in grain and soybean futures was inclined to drag during much of last week, the purchases running somewhat smaller than the previous week. Average daily purchases were about 28,000,000 bushels compared with about 35,000,000 bushels the previous week and about 25,500,000 bushels the same week of last year.

LOS ANGELES, March 30 -- Luke Easter and Bob Avila of the Indians exploded their first home runs of the year today and battered the Giants into their fifth straight defeat at the hands of the Cleveland club. The largest crowd this touring road show has attracted in years, 19,239, saw the Indians win 6 to 5.

" Opera in the United States, Today and Tomorrow," was discussed by a panel of persons particularly interested in that problem late yesterday afternoon at the Juilliard School of Music. The talk followed first performances of two light operas in the school's theatre.
Novelty is the last thing to expect from that substantial instrument of conservatism, the British throne, and when a novelty is announced concerning it one may be sure that it is not on impulse.
Were I in my native city of London I should be able to voice my indignation in a letter to The Times. As it is, I must address myself to you in the following terms:

Vice President Alben W. Barkley, who at 74 years of age is the chief traveling salesman for the Truman Fair Deal, wag Franklin D. Roosevelt's spokesman in Congress and his strong right arm in pushing the New Deal legislative program through the Capitol.

There will be little apathy in political campaigns this election year if the Advertising Council has anything to say about it. One of the biggest non-partisan campaigns in the council's public-service career will be its forthcoming "register and vote" drive.

About 4,000,000 persons appeared last year in City Magistrates' Courts or were involved in some phase of their functioning, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh revealed yesterday in his annual report to Mayor Impellitteri.

Persecution of the church is more intense today than at any other time in the history of Christianity, Auxiliary Bishop Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday in a lenten sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided at the mass.
British home cooking is very much maligned, in the opinion of Mrs. Audrey Langston, Yorkshire culinary artist and loyal defender of the English table.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of remarks by President Truman this afternoon at the Democratic National Committee reception at the May-flower Hotel:

This week brings to New York the highlight of its safety year. The Greater New York Safety Council, with seventy-two cooperating agencies, civic and private, is holding its twenty-second Annual Safety Convention and Exposition. It is encouraging to note that registration is larger than ever before.

Sandy Hook pilots are preparing data for Governor Dewey in an effort to show that the efficiency of the vital harbor pilot system will be menaced if requested increases in pilot fees are not approved.

The Very Rev. Francis B. Sayre Jr., dean of Washington Cathedral, preaching yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, called for humble prayers for the power to see God in the true light and to learn the secret of eternal life.

TOKYO, March 30 (UP) -- A wounded Navy pilot, blinded by his own blood, made a safe emergency landing at a Korean emergency airstrip, guided by the radio voice of a fellow pilot who hovered behind him and checked his every move, the Navy disclosed today.

President Truman's refusal to run for re-election left the New York State Democratic political leaders temporarily without a candidate. Prior to Mr. Truman's announcement, the state organization had been united in backing him, and had spoken of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois only as a possible second choice.
CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- Radio broadcasters were told today that equipment would be ready for them if they obtained permits for television stations using the new ultra-high-frequency channels.
A team of experts from the American Public Health Association has recommended fluorination of the city's water supply as soon as possible at an estimated cost of $800,000 a year.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 30 -- President Truman's announcement last night in Washington that he would not be a candidate for re-election has not altered the pre-primary picture in this key state.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 30 -- Brazil's Communists are adopting the tactics that worked so well in Iran and are trying to rally the nationalists around them with a campaign for nation-wide demonstrations against the United States on April 21 as "The Day of Petroleum and of National Independence."
I was very much surprised to read your editorial of March 20 captioned "To Study Off-Track Betting."

" The Pearl Hunter," an autobiography by Leonard Rosenthal, will be published by Henry Schuman on April 17. The story tells how a poor immigrant boy won the world monopoly of the Oriental pearl trade for France.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- The stevedoring industry from Maine to Florida is watching with deep interest the progress of labor-management relations on this city's waterfront. For but three months have passed since Philadelphia became the first and only port on the Atlantic coast to place its dockside labor problems in the lap of an industrial arbitrator.
Five new films, including a pair of importations from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The history of Greece from ancient times to its period of liberation and on to the present was traced in pagentry yesterday as the largest Greek Independence Day parade the city has seen marched on Fifth Avenue. The event marked the 131st anniversary of Greek freedom.

A group of 246 parishioners of the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, L. I., has formally protested the increasing use of "high church" services and rituals in the cathedral, it was learned yesterday.

Postmaster Albert Goldman and Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet were honored last night by the Association of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the American Jewish Congress for their public service and defense of traditional freedoms.

A $3,735,000 improvement on the New Jersey side of the George Washington Bridge to provide a direct link to the Pali sades Interstate Parkway and traffic relief for 5,000,000 vehicles using other approaches was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- When the origins of President Truman's act of abdication last night are revealed by him or by future historians they will be traced, in part at least, to the public library of Independence, Mo., in the Eighteen Nineties and to the headquarters of the Democratic organization of Jackson County, Mo., in the Nineteen Twenties.

European reaction to the President's decision not to run again reflects the uneasiness that always follows a political shift in the United States. Although American policy in Europe has been remarkably consistent since the war, Europeans don't get over their congenital uncertainty regarding the continuity of our course.

PITTSBURGH, March 30 -- Main topic of conversation in the steel trade last week was: Will there be a strike? At the end of the week the situation was still deadlocked but with officials still hopeful of finding a solution of the price problem by Monday. Many steel users were looking over their stocks of steel and estimating about how long they could run if there were to be a shutdown.

TOKYO, Monday, March 31 -- Communist staff officers proposed today to turn back to a military truce subcommittee the unsettled question of their nomination of the Soviet Union as one of the "neutral" nations to control an armistice in the Korean war.

CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- Illinois Central Railroad had the largest revenue from operations in its history last year but net income fell sharply from the previous year, Wayne A. Johnson, president, said in the road's annual report to stockholders today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman, showing women reporters through the White House a week ago today, sensed the answer to the question she then sidestepped about spending four more years there.

The study of the Health Department made for the Mayor's Management Survey was divided into two parts. One of these, resulting in a 333-page report, was made by a staff assembled by the American Public Health Association. The other, summarized in a 234-page report, considered business management and procedures, and was made by Barrington Associates.

AMSTERDAM, March 30 -- The United States-Netherlands agreement regarding the allocation of 856,000,000 guilders from the 1,778,000,000 counterpart fund has been welcomed here as some 750,000,000 is to be used for redeeming half of the Government debt to the Netherlands Bank, which it incurred through taking over the Reichsmark balance with which the Netherlands Bank had been left after the German occupation.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Schuyler Hixson, Los Angeles Times photographer, won the 1951 contest for excellence in news photography conducted by the Associated Press Managing Editors Association, Herbert F. Corn, president, announced today.

Three major import-export trade groups have gone on record as opposed to any legislation designed to curtail sharply imports to this country. Protests against attempts in Congress to bring such legislation to the forefront by proposed additional amendents to the Defense Production Act have been filed with various Government officials, it was learned yesterday.

The simulated atom bomb attack that will bring out New York's civil defense forces on Thursday night will not interrupt an address that Gordon Dean, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, will be making here at the same time on the peaceful uses of atomic energy.

LONDON, March 30 -- Britain's foreign affairs experts still were considering today whether they could make an offer of settlement to Egypt in the British-Egyptian treaty dispute and if so what the offer should contain.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 30 -- Nebraska's Presidential preference primary Tuesday gained significance today because of President Truman's withdrawal and the contest between Senators Estes Kefauver of Tennessee and Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma.

Anna and Margaret Wald and Betty Wald Dowling of St. Petersburg, Florida, sold the two five-story converted dwellings at 50 and 52 West Eighty-seventh Street to the Greenway Property Company for investment in a deal negotiated by the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company, brokers, for cash over mortgages amounting to $30,000. The property is 44 by 100 feet and is assessed at $57,000.
If the Republicans nominate General Eisenhower the country stands to benefit in a way which has not, I believe, been much discussed.
The Metropolitan Opera Company will present Wagner's "Parsifal" three times during Holy Week -- in Philadelphia on Tuesday, April 8, and in New York on Friday and Saturday, April 11 and 12.

McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J., March 30 (UP) -- Rescue parties searched a heavy bog and swampland today for two Air Force officers missing as a result of the crash of an F-94 jet fighter-interceptor on a training flight from McGuire Field.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- President Truman's announcement that he would not seek re-election, coming a few days before both parties' White House aspirants open their Illinois campaigns for convention delegates, heightened speculation among this state's political leaders whether Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson would agree to be the Democrats' standard-bearer, as Mr. Truman is reported to have suggested.

All over the United States some 350,000 enthusiastic boys will be celebrating their own special week -- National Boys Club Week, March 31 to April 6 -- in clubhouses of their own under the leadership and guidance of earnest Boys Club executives and leaders. Appropriately, from coast to coast local merchants will be cooperating with newspapers, radio and television to help these clubs tell the rest of the country what they are doing.

European nations in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have a "terrific potential, but they need a lot of American help," the United States Air Force's first jet pilot ace, Maj. James Jabara of Wichita, Kan., said yesterday upon his return from an eleven-week tour of Europe and the Middle East.

LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- The demand for new merchant shipping tonnage continues unabated, despite the increase of 2,600,000 tons in the world's merchant fleet last year, according to the annual report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., March 30 -- The happiest dog on Long Island today is Smoky, the over-zealous 4-year-old Dalmatian who was returned to active duty as mascot of Protection Engine Company 1 here this morning after three weeks' exile to an animal shelter.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Monday, March 31 -- A special United States military courier plane known familiarly as the "Blue Plate Special" took off from Frankfurt, Germany, last midnight to carry to Washington 2,000 advance copies of the first annual report on Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

A proposal to sell the property and assets of Colonial Airlines, Inc., to National Airlines, Inc., will be voted upon by stockholders of Colonial at the annual meeting on April 16. In a proxy statement mailed to stockholders, Colonial said that National would issue seven-eighths of one share of National common stock for each share of Colonial stock outstanding on March 10, 1952, the date of the agreement.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- The House Agriculture Committee has announced that it has approved a bill which would raise the support price of cotton more than 10 per cent if this year's crop equals or exceeds the Government's 16,000,000 bale production goal.
Paul Breisach, new conductor with the New York City Opera, led his second opera at the City Center on Saturday night when he conducted the company's first "Don Giovanni" of the spring season.

NEW DELHI, India, March 30 -- Assisted by United States technical experts, the Indian Government will launch immediately sixty-five community development projects distributed all over the country. These projects, which are expected to be completed within the next three years, constitute the first stage in a comprehensive rural reconstruction program envisaged in the nation's five-year plan.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., March 30 -- The happiest dog on Long Island today is Smoky, the over-zealous 4-year-old Dalmatian who was returned to active duty as mascot of Protection Engine Company 1 here this morning after three weeks' exile to an animal shelter.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Monday, March 31 -- A special United States military courier plane known familiarly as the "Blue Plate Special" took off from Frankfurt, Germany, last midnight to carry to Washington 2,000 advance copies of the first annual report on Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

A proposal to sell the property and assets of Colonial Airlines, Inc., to National Airlines, Inc., will be voted upon by stockholders of Colonial at the annual meeting on April 16. In a proxy statement mailed to stockholders, Colonial said that National would issue seven-eighths of one share of National common stock for each share of Colonial stock outstanding on March 10, 1952, the date of the agreement.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- The House Agriculture Committee has announced that it has approved a bill which would raise the support price of cotton more than 10 per cent if this year's crop equals or exceeds the Government's 16,000,000 bale production goal.
Paul Breisach, new conductor with the New York City Opera, led his second opera at the City Center on Saturday night when he conducted the company's first "Don Giovanni" of the spring season.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Lard prices again were affected by the weakness in vegetable oils, which were under further pressure, while the demand was slow. Hog prices late in the week reached a new low at $16.90 for top hogs, and this naturally exerted a bearish influence on the market.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was still saying "no" today to the $32 question: "Will you run for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency." But he didn't sound a bit like either Harry S. Truman or General Sherman on the $64 question.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 30 (AP) -- Jimmy Clark, 30-year-old Laguna Beach (Calif.) professional who had won only $180 in Professional Golfers Association tournaments this year, took the $2,000 top money in the $10,000 Azalea Open golf tourney today with a last round 68 for a new record of 272 for 72 holes. His 16-under par performance put him 3 strokes ahead of Jim Turnesa, Briarcliff, N. Y., and George Fazio, Pine Valley, N. J.

NEW ORLEANS, March 30 (AP) -- Patty Berg of St. Andrews, Ill., won the New Orleans women's open golf tournament today despite an eight-over-par 82 that almost erased a 10-stroke lead. Her 72-hole total of 299 accounted for her fifty-sixth major tournament over a twelve year professional career.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 -- The Yugoslav Government is preparing to lodge a strong protest with Britain, the United States and Italy against their decision to hold a tripartite meeting in London concerning the future administration of zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste without informing, consulting or inviting Yugoslavia to participate.

Operations of Trans World Airlines in 1951 resulted in a net income of $8,511,000, equal to $3.50 a share, according to the report released for publication today by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman, and Ralph S. Damon, president. This compares with an adjusted net income of $7,830,000, or $3.23 a share, in 1950.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- Clement Attlee, former Prime Minister of Britain, called tonight for strengthening by "every means" the intercommunication of democratic nations to build up a community of interests between the free people.

Of the 3,000 Indian Jews in Israel, only a single group of 140 is disgruntled and wishes to return to India, according to a statement issued here yesterday by the Jewish Agency for Palestine. The statement commented on a Tel Aviv dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday telling of the dissatisfaction of a group of Indian Jews due to return to India.
Now that the Eisenhower boom is well launched by the Republicans perhaps a few words which express the opinions of a number of independent voters are in order.

BOSTON, March 31 (AP) -- Arthur Cranfield of Syracuse moved within one game of the defending champion, Willie Mosconi, tonight in the world pocket billiard championship by defeating Donald De Coy of St. Louis.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in March expanded over the previous month but the volume of business fell to the smallest since 1949 for both March and the first quarter of the year.

A large audience assembled yesterday morning in the second floor budget shop at Franklin Simon's and witnessed a lively showing of dresses of many types for women and misses, the former in half-size 12 1/2 to 22 1/2, the latter in the regulation 12 to 20.

A mock battlefield demonstration that was to have included a helicopter evacuation of a wounded man was marred yesterday at Columbia University when clearance for the plane's landing was not approved in time. Nevertheless a rally under the sponsorship of the campus Air Force Reserve Officers Training Corps netted pledges for 300 pints.

First prize in an essay contest on "What Advertising Means to Me" under the auspices of the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue, among city public and parochial high school students, has been won by Miss Philomena DiLauro of Aquinas High School, the Bronx.

PARIS, March 31 -- The French protectorate of Tunisia, facing the threat of a nationalist-led general strike tomorrow, was still without a cabinet tonight to replace the one arrested last week by French authorities.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 50 to 84 points net higher than on Friday, with the strength most pronounced in new crop months.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The Truck Tax Bureau of the State Tax Commission today processed approximately $535,000 in retroactive weight-distance taxes, due for the period since last Oct. 1 but not paid while the validity of the new tax was being tested in the courts.
I was one of those invited to the trade conference at Moscow and was inclined to attend until the conference was vetoed by the State Department.

The resignation of Charles E. Wilson as Director of Defense Mobilization brings into the open a disagreement which is older and broader than the specific issue -- steel -- which finally prompted it. Mr. Wilson has consistently taken the position that it is impossible to carry out successfully a mammoth program of rearmament except on a basis of stabilized wages and prices.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 31 -- Leo Durocher led his band of Giants through here tonight, hoping the retreat from the West Toast would bring a change when he resumes hostilities with the Indians in Denver tomorrow and figuring ahead to his pitcher for the opening of the National League season at the Polo Grounds on April 15.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath said today that he had not decided whether he would answer the questionnaire sent to him by Newbold Morris, the Special Assistant Attorney General he appointed to direct the campaign to ferret out corruption in the Federal Government.
BALTIMORE, March 31 -- Final arguments in a Communist conspiracy trial in Federal Court were heard today. The case may go to the jury tomorrow.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31 -- Premier Tito warned Britain and the United States today against taking any unilateral decisions at the forthcoming London tripartite conference to admit Italians into the administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste.

The conditions that prevail in Cuba today are far from those conditions that Dr. German Arciniegas believes them to be, judging by his letter which appeared in the March 25 edition of your prominent newspaper.

In carrying out the Government's policy of having adequately trained men serving as officers in its various services, the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point and its sister academies have been doing yeoman work on a shoestring. These academies have been providing competent men to command the ships of the United States Merchant Marine in the face of yearly nibbling at their already infinitesimal budgets.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 31 (UP) -- Willie Jones' second grand-slam homer of the training season, off Willard Schmidt in the sixth inning, fell one run short of tying the score and the Cardinals edged the Phillies, 8 -- 7, today in a game cut to seven innings to permit the Phils to catch a train.

After mulling the matter over for a couple of months, Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn, co-stars of "The Fourposter," have decided to tour in the comedy hit starting next July. Winner of the American Theatre Wing's Antoinette Perry play award Sunday night, the Jan de Hartog two-character comedy will start its cross-country trip at the Biltmore Theatre in Los Angeles and continue through next March.

Pullman, Inc., reported yesterday that it had a consolidated net income in 1951 of $10,269,939 after charges and taxes, equal to $4.69 each on the 2,192,000 shares outstanding. This compared with $9,853,089, or $4.49 a share, in 1950.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Industrial production has climbed up out of a slight low to approach the post-war peak reached one year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WEYAUWEGA, Wis., March 31 -- A helicopter carrying Harold E. Stassen ran into fog today and landed in a well digger's yard.

Ambitious plans for a star-spangled fund-raising send-off for the United States Olympic team on the week-end of July 4 were charted yesterday by the coordinating group of Mayor Impellitteri's Olympic Committee under the chairmanship of Lazarus Joseph, Controller of New York City.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 (AP) -- The National Association of State Racing Commissioners, in their eighteenth annual convention here, adopted a resolution today opposing off-track betting in any form. Two hundred commissioners from throughout the United States, Canada and Mexico are here for the four-day meeting.

Bonds called in March for payment before maturity rose sharply as a result of large retirements by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. The month's total was the largest for any month since July, 1950, and the biggest figure for any March since 1945.

TRENTON, March 31 -- The State Supreme Court upheld today the Young Women's Christian Association of Atlantic City in refusing voting membership to twelve women because of variance in "their Christian Protestant beliefs" from those of the association's members.

An elderly Italian, slightly bewildered but obviously happy, stepped gingerly up the gangway of the Home liner Argentina yesterday morning. A half hour later he was alone in his tourist-class cabin bound for Naples, Italy, and his first reunion with his wife and family in thirty-nine years.

" Miss Julie," the Swedish-made adaptation of the August Strindberg play, will have its American premiere at the World Theatre next Monday, it was announced yesterday. Alf Sjoberg wrote the script and directed the drama. Anita Bjork is starred in the importation, which features Ulf Palme, Anders Henrikson and Marta Dorff.

Macy's lost a decision yesterday in Queens Supreme Court where Justice Nicholas M. Pette ruled that it was violating the New York State Feld-Crawford law by cutting prices of articles sold intrastate where the price was set between manufacturer and retailer.

New Yorkers will receive their first introduction to potatoes from Spain if the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine gives a clean bill of health to 71,000 bags of the tubers that arrived here yesterday on the Spanish liner Habana at Pier 21, East River.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois flew away from Washington's bubbling political caldron today without giving to Democratic leaders anxious to choose a strong candidate even private assurances that he would or would not accept the Democratic Presidential nomination if it were tendered to him.

Electric Boat Company and its subsidiary earned a record $3,872,203 in 1951 as the company's productive activity increased sharply to meet its huge backlog of unfilled orders, according to the annual report released yesterday by John Jay Hopkins, chairman and president.

The Bedford Realty Company of Bellmore, L. I., has named Emile J. Clement as general sales manager; Adolph Koeppel, to direct sales in new housing developments, and Murray Keyles, as head of the acreage sales department.
The following are excerpts from the report made by the Third November, 1951, Grand Jury on its investigation of charges against Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh:

OMAHA, Neb., March 31 -- An assertion that Senator Robert A. Taft and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur were "on the same team" set off a last-minute barrage of political fireworks today on the eve of Nebraska's Presidential primary.
MILWAUKEE, March 31 -- Wisconsin Republicans were hard at work today seeking to assure a heavy vote in the state's preferential primary elections tomorrow.
Popular-priced, attractive new spring and summer fashions that one would hardly guess to be maternity clothes will be modeled informally today from 11 A. M. to 4 P. M. on Lane Bryant's fourth floor.

The Stanley Transformer Company has leased the one-story building at 11-11 Thirty-first Drive, Long Island City, Queens, and will use it for manufacturing purposes. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker.

The Port of New York Authority's distinguished service medal was presented last night to Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency, in recognition of his "devoted, inspirational and outstanding service over the past twenty-five years."

Despite the strike of many of its agents in December, 1951, the Prudential Insurance Company of America did a record volume of business last year. The company, second largest insurance concern in the United States, wrote $3,700,000,000 of new business, marking the third consecutive year that sales exceeded the $3,000,000,000 level.

WHITEVILLE, N. C., March 31 -- Bills of indictment charging nineteen Columbus County men, alleged members of the Ku Klux Klan, in three separate flogging cases were presented to a Superior Court grand jury here today.

LAUREL, Md., March 31 (AP) -- When the leader went wide at the head of the stretch in the Legations Purse here today, Mrs. James Carson's Kinsman needed no further breaks. The 5-year-old son of Whirlaway moved between horses to take command and went on to a two-and-a-half length score over Rocky Heights, the erring pacesetter.

PARIS, March 31 -- Financial officials expect the French deficit to the European Payments Union for March will be less than half that for February, which was $129,000,000 and that it therefore can be covered from the resources of the Stabilization Fund without any strain.

CAIRO, March 31 -- The Egyptian Cabinet passed tonight a decree demoting several thousand directors of Government offices, subdirectors and others, so that a boss of yesterday may become a filing clerk or bookkeeper.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- Dore Schary, vice president and production chief of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, today started a new libel action in Superior Court in Los Angeles against the Wage-Earners Committee of the U. S. A. and twelve individuals named in the complaint for damages totaling $2,304,531.65.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 22 -- A United States productivity expert crossing Eastern France by automobile this week would have several perplexing matters on which to write memoranda to his boss.

Steel industry leaders, stunned by the collapse of their negotiations with the Government for higher steel prices, put off yesterday arrangements to meet with Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., to discuss ways of preventing a national steel strike next Tuesday.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The State Social Welfare Department announced today plans for a new program of coordinated effort with the State Health Department to administer medical care of relief recipients and set standards for hospitals, dispensaries and nursing and convalescent homes.

Demonstrating that products made for the home in any country can successfully be transplanted to contemporary homes elsewhere is the usability of some Japanese ceramics now on display at Kogei, 23 East Sixty-seventh Street.

TANGIER, March 31 -- Funerals held for fifteen Moors today were followed by long processions of angry Moslem mourners. According to official figures, four persons were killed in the riots yesterday against French rule in northwest Africa and two more died during the night.
PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- Ferryboat service on the Delaware River between here and Camden, N. J., a 264-year-old institution, ended at 9:15 o'clock tonight.

The method of selecting Federal juries in this area was challenged yesterday in the case of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders who face trial on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government of the United States.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Legislation authorizing the state to spend $145,000 to assist clinics in treating and rehabilitating chronic alcoholics and to sponsor basic research on the problems of alcoholism was approved today by Governor Dewey.

The traditional American policy of subordination of the military to the civilian, which often has been under severe stress since the war, will be more heavily strained this year than ever, developments in the Wisconsin primaries indicate.
Numerous difficult engineering problems must be resolved before the city will be able to decide whether to embark on a fluorination of its water supply as a means of preventing tooth decay.

The retrial of Frank Costello, the gambler, on a year-old charge of contempt of the United States Senate got off to a fast start yesterday. A jury of nine men and three women, chosen at the morning session, heard in the afternoon the opening arguments of both sides arid testimony by City Council President Rudolph Halley, former chief counsel of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Federal tax benefits to assist a proposed $50,000,000 expansion were approved today for the Central Iron and Steel Company, a concern mentioned in Congressional "influence" testimony last year.

With shad now starting to run in the Hudson, that delicacy of spring, the roe of the fish, is ready for savoring. Admittedly, it is expensive, with prices ranging from about $1 to $1.75 a pair, depending on size. But in the brief season that the fresh roe is available (it is caught for about four weeks in the Hudson), most of those who like it will want to have it at least once.
This week offers an unusually large number of art exhibitions in a wide variety of styles and mediums.

A 720-family apartment colony at 2700-800 Bronx Park East, the Bronx, has been purchased by Milton Spitz. The property occupies two blocks bounded by Arnow. Barker and Allerton Avenues and Bronx Park East, and is assessed at $1,580,000.

TRENTON, March 31 -- Opposition of the large North Jersey counties to the Garden State Parkway as a toll route softened tonight as sufficient Republican majority votes were aligned in the Assembly for passage before final adjournment on Friday.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today three new issues of common and convertible preferred shares of public utility, finance and aircraft manufacturing enterprises. The offerings, which have a total market value of about $10,842,500, are as follows:

A new one-volume edition of the "Personal Memoirs of U. S. Grant" has been scheduled for publication by World on April 28, one day after the 130th anniversary of the birth of the general. The volume is annotated by the Civil War scholar, E. B. Long, who has also written an introduction.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Census Bureau reported today that the number of persons seeking jobs in March was estimated at 1,804,000, the lowest March level since World War II. This is 2.9 per cent of the civilian labor force. It was a decline of 282,000 in a month.
A Narcotics Term of the City Magistrates Court has been established and will begin to function on May 1 for the purpose of dealing with youthful narcotics addicts.

SOESTDIJK, The Netherlands, March 31 -- Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard had a quiet family dinner with their four daughters tonight prior to leaving tomorrow on their first official visit to the United States.

A request to be heard on the contemplated suspension of price controls on hides and skins and not on the products of these raw materials was made last week in a joint telegram to the Office of Price Stabilization by the Tanner's Council of America, the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, the National Shoe Retailers Association and the National Association of Shoe Chain Stores.

Free of their dare-devil belts, two window cleaners signaled the millennium for their trade yesterday as they stepped from the roof of a twenty-four-story building onto a $50,000 aluminumbright gondola car and rode up and down the glass-walled structure on the west side of Park Avenue between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Indictments accusing two pro-Truman leaders in Mississippi of soliciting political gifts on promises of helping contributors obtain Federal jobs were reinstated by the Supreme Court in a 5-to-4 decision today.
Investment banking syndicates continued to bid aggressively yesterday for new issues of public utility bonds up for award at competitive sale.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., March 31 (AP) -- College wrestlers will be required to wear helmets because there are "too many cauliflower ears" resulting from the sport, the National Collegiate Athletic Association Wrestling Rules Committee decided today.

The break in the cotton textile market in Japan has exerted little effect in the primary marekt in New York, observers in the textile trade said yesterday. Cotton goods here held firm to last week's prices with no important changes noted, even though the volume of trading was small.

Noting that some gains have been achieved recently, the Citizens Union declares that a major weakness in the city's efforts to solve its traffic problems is "the failure, so far, to develop an effective program of traffic supervision and enforcement by the Police Department."

ALBANY, March 31 -- The State Thruway Authority used the credit of the state for the first time today and successfully negotiated a $60,000,000 loan from a syndicate of twenty-one banks at a rate which officials said was lower than would have been available with Authority credit alone.
In a day of generally lower commodity prices, wool followed cotton to higher ground and soybean oil showed a moderate reaction from the losses of last week.

SAIGON, Indo-China, March 31 (AP) -- Some 5,000 Communist-led Vietminh fortes fought a last ditch battle on the brink of the Tonging Gulf tonight in a desperate effort to escape extermination by 20,000 French.

The Yeshivah Torah Vodaath Mesivta, an Orthodox Jewish theological seminary at 141 South Third Street, Brooklyn, faces financial difficulties that may cause it to close at the end of, or even before, the current term ending in May, its officials said yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, March 31 -- Three of the opposition political parties announced today they had formed a single list of candidates for the Mexican Congressional elections on a common platform.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 31 (UP) -- Louis Norman (Bobo) Newsom, one of the most colorful figures in modern baseball, today was headed back to the major leagues.

After almost two full weeks of trial sessions on charges of bank robbery against William Sutton and Thomas Kling, jurors who heard the evidence began deliberation on a verdict in Queens County Court in Long Island City last night.

MILWAUKEE, March 31 (UP) -- Two changes were made in the American Bowling Congress leaders today. Art Schreier, Dayton, Ohio, fired a 671 singles series to tie Fred Hebert, Milwaukee, for eighth place. Schreier's games were 211, 214, 246.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The new Soviet price reductions were obviously timed so as to make the maximum favorable impression on foreign delegates now arriving in Moscow for the world economic conference beginning next Thursday, Government officials here commented today.

BALTIMORE, March 31 -- The Merchants and Miners Transportation Company liquidated the last of its holding today, comlpeting a century, less twenty-four days, in the Atlantic coast-wise trade. The dissolution was decided on four years ago.

TEMPLE, Tex., March 31 -- A cook's helper in the Eighty-second Airborne Division walked up to a group of officers and reporters during Exercise Long Horn today, raised his carbine and killed an officer with a home-made bullet because he was "willing to do anything to get out" of the Army.

An unusual system of storage units that can be either placed on legs or hung on a metal pole is the outstanding contribution in the latest group of furnishings to arrive from Scandinavia. The collection, designed by Bjorn Engo, was manufactured by Bahus of Norway and is imported by the Vaco Company.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- In a bid to replace the Chrysler Corporation as the second largest auto producer among the "Big Three," the Ford Motor Company has filed a detailed protest against the fairness of the Federal division of scarce materials among automobile manufacturers.

After three hours of argument yesterday, Supreme Court Justice Eugene L. Brisach reserved decision on motions to submit to arbitration a suit for $3,000,000 brought against the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by a group of banquet waiters for tips allegedly due them over a period of six years.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- The Soviet Government tonight announced price reductions of 10 to 30 per cent on forty-eight principal categories of food products, including meat, butter, sugar, eggs, bread and flour.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 31 -- After little more than a week of concentrated work, the end is in sight for the first phase of the conference on West German indemnification for the victimization of the Jews by Hitler's Reich. April 5 has been mentioned as a possible date for a recess.

NEW DELHI, India, March 31 -- The Kashmir Constituent Assembly, meeting in Jammu, adopted unanimously today a resolution to "confiscate all landed estates without payment of compensation," the All-India Radio reported tonight. The seventy-five-member house greeted with prolonged cheers and acclamation Prime Minister Sheikh Abdullah's declaration: "We shall go ahead with our plans to translate new Kashmir into a reality."

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Federal Reserve Board, bowed today before a Presidential demand that its Voluntary Credit Restraint Committee stop trying to curb inflationary bond issues of state and municipal Governments. All regional committees were directed to suspend their screening of all such issues.

JERUSALEM, March 31 -- Discoveries of new mineral deposits in the Negeb Desert have enabled the Israeli Government to advance by three years its objective for economic self-sufficiency. The date set last year was 1961 but the Minister of Agriculture, Levi Eshkol, said in an interview today that trade gaps on food and raw materials would be liquidated by 1958.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Charles E. Wilson, the departing Director of Defense Mobilization, has a way of entering and leaving this town with a bang.
The United States Weather Bureau yesterday issued the following forecasts and winter sports reports for New England:

Negotiation for a truce in Korea again appears to be headed for a stalemate on the issue of the admission of the Soviet Union as a "neutral" Power to join in the supervision of the agreements. The entire proposal has seemed so preposterous and outrageous that it has been difficult to take the Communist negotiators seriously.
LONDON, March 31 -- Britain and the United States went ahead today with their plans for discussions with Italy on the administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 1 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,206, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

Battalion Chief Wesley Williams, the highest-ranking Negro fire officer in the city, who will retire today after thirty-three years of service, was honored yesterday by the Uniformed Fire Officers Association.
TRENTON, March 31 (AP) -- Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons announced tonight that Samuel P. Allcorn Jr. had resigned as special prosecutor in charge of an Atlantic County crime, investigation.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 1 -- Allied and Communist staff officers agreed today to turn over to a truce subcommittee the disputed question of inclusion of the Soviet Union as one of the "neutral" nations to supervise an armistice in the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- The nation made marked progress in its war against disease last year, registering the lowest death rate in United States history and making new inroads against the chief causes of death -- cancer and heart disease.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 31 -- An official of the Export-Import Bank today urged the nation's huge seven-and-half billion dollar packaging industry to support this Government's program for the placing of private capital abroad.
BARROW, Alaska, March 31 (AP) -- Nine men plucked from the arctic ice pack 525 miles from the North Pole told today now only ten feet stood between rescue and disaster for the rescue plane.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Truman today hailed the Institute of Inter-American Affairs on its tenth anniversary, noting how it had improved the welfare of millions in Latin America, but he said the fight must continue against hunger, poverty, disease and illiteracy in the sister republics.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 31 -- Chemicals aiding in the study of cancer and other degenerative diseases, including diseases of the mind, are now being extracted in large quantities from yeast as the result of recent advances in chemical techniques, according to reports presented here today at the annual spring meeting of the American Chemical Society.

New York State's ninety-four delegates probably will go to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago July 21 committed to none of the principal contenders for the Presidential nomination, but with W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, their "favorite son."

The horse racing season in this state will start today with the Metropolitan Jockey Club opening a meeting of twenty-four days at the Jamaica race track. The campaign will be the longest hereabouts since pari-mutuel wagering was made legal and will embrace 197 days of racing.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 31 -- Ezio Pinza has built his dream house on the side of a rocky gorge in North Stamford. The singer has spent $60,000 of earnings from shows and records to develop a ten-room home that is a blend of Colonial and modern designs and contains every electronic device he could buy or invent.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- The nation's newspaper editors will have an opportunity April 17 to show their Washington correspondents how President Truman should be questioned in a news conference.

New salvos are being fired by two of the big guns in the battle to get men to wear hats. The Hat Corporation of America, maker of Dobbs, Cavanagh, Knox, Dunlap, Berg, Byron, and C K products, is launching a campaign stressing that a hat is primarily for protec

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Judge Sarah T. Hughes of Dallas, Tex., president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, called on women today to enter a new campaign for equal pay with men with "the zeal and urgency of Susan B. Anthony."

SPRINGFIELD, March 31 -- Governor Stevenson reaffirmed tonight his declarations that he "is not a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination," that he has "no plans" beyond campaigning for re-election as Governor.
TRENTON, March 31 -- Tear gas grenades dropped down roof ventilators tonight ended the riot of prisoners in a segregation wing at State Prison. The disorder began at 1:30 A. M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, urged the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today to leave it to the military establishment to apply any cut in the $7,900,000,000 Mutual Security Program on which Congress may decide.

The three-story building containing four stores and nine apartments at 4702 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the William Carroll estate to E. Hionas and James Boyle. The property, at the southwest corner of Forty-seventh Street, is assessed at $80,000.
LONDON, March 31 -- An unofficial group of twenty-four Britons left by air today to attend the International Economic Conference, which opens in Moscow Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- The Commercial Telegraphers Union, A. F. L., today put off a nation-wide strike against the Western Union Telegraph Company until 12:01 A. M. Thursday to give Federal mediators a chance to settle the contract dispute.
The decision to proceed with a convention hail in Columbus Circle without a new opera house there was defended vigorously yesterday by Robert Moses.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, told T. A. Bisson, a University of California educator, today that Mr. Bisson always seemed to turn up "on the red side of things" when the chips were down.

ROME, March 31 -- For the second time in their country's history Italians were required today to declare their own incomes for tax purposes. Long queues of citizens were seen all day outside post-offices waiting to send their declarations by registered mail, and it is thought that there will be another noticeable increase in the number of potential taxpayers.

Planning for an expansion of its facilities, the Chase National Bank has purchased the ten-story building at 40-44 Pine Street from the Donroger Realty Corporation, of which Mortimer Tischler is president. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker and Milbank, Tweed, Hope Hadley were attorneys for the buyer.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- The United Nations Security Council will be called upon Wednesday to take up the Tunisian case.

At a time when Europe itself is moving toward closer political, economic and military integration Europe's outlying dependencies, protectorates and spheres of influence have embarked on a countermove which threatens to fragmentize and endanger various important areas.
DETROIT, March 31 -- Michigan Democrats endorsed Gov. G. Mennen Williams tonight as their "favorite - son" candidate for the Presidential nomination.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 -- Should anything untoward happen to any of Casey Stengel's Big Four mound corps between now and opening day, it is probable the Yankees can unveil an able fill-in as they demonstrated on this sunny afternoon by deftly blanking Red Rolfe's Tigers, 3 to 0.
One man did it.

The American Council of Learned Societies is running into the red $25,000 a year on the project it calls "the biggest hole in the Iron Curtain" -- its 70,000-word weekly "Current Digest of the Soviet Press."

Two officials of a union that was recently considered among the most extreme of left-wing labor organizations were held in contempt of court yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman. They had refused to produce the union's financial books and records for a grand jury investigating subversive activities and espionage.

A new "crusade" by United States importers to combat growing efforts to restrict foreign goods will be started soon, members of the United States-Austrian Chamber of Commerce were told yesterday at a meeting in the Town Hall Club.
MADRID, March 31 -- Lincoln MacVeagh, United States Ambassador, called on Foreign Minister Albert Martin Artajo this evening in what was described as a "preliminary contact."

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A committee of the International Materials Conference today recommended slightly increased allocations of critically scarce cobalt and nickel in the second quarter for thirty-seven anti-Communist countries.

In a recent editorial you criticized a bill in the State Senate granting Children's Courts jurisdiction over children needing psychiatric care for its clause: "Whenever practicable the psychiatrist shall be of the same faith as the child."

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Truman today appointed Lieut. Gen. Howard A. Craig of the Air Force as the next commandant of the National War College. Named to replace him as Inspector General of the Air Force was Maj. Gen. Bryant L. Boatner, now commanding the air proving ground at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 31 (UP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower won the chance today to acquire at least four of Minnesota's twenty-eight Republican National Convention delegates as the result of the large number of write-in-votes he received in the state's March 18 primary election.
Judge Harold R. Medina will take the investment banking suit for an airing -- the first in four years -- next Tuesday.
Transportation of bulk mail to and from Long Island was shifted last midnight from the Long Island Rail Road to a fleet of leased trucks operated by the Postal Transportation Service.

OMAHA, Neb., March 31 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Jesse D. Auton of the Strategic Air Command and his aides were killed today when their B-29 bomber crashed into a hill on a farm while coming in for a landing at Offutt Air Force Base with one engine dead.

BONN, Germany, March 31 -- A Federal Government spokesman said today there were still 120,000 homeless foreigners in Western Germany whose assimilation would take a long time unless foreign funds were available to provide work and housing for them.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (UP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott, who knocked out Ezzard Charles for the world heavyweight title last July, signed today to meet the former champion at Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium on June 5. It will be the fourth championship bout between the two.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- House tax investigators uncovered evidence today that Daniel A. Bolich, resigned assistant Internal Revenue Commissioner, lived for nineteen months in a Washington Hotel suite billed to Henry W. Grunewald, Capital mystery man.

MIAMI, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia rallied to win the men's singles in the Miami invitational tennis tournament today by beating Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.

Surprising things sometimes turn up in the annual reports of the nation's corporations, those reports in which management tells shareholders how promising everything was before taxes. Such a one appears this year in the report of the American Can Company.

The State of Israel must be kept strong and its independence perpetuated, Mayor Impellitteri declared last night at the second annual dinner of the Greater New York Committee of Children to Palestine at the Astor Hotel. The organization is a Christian committee cooperating with Youth Aliyah of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization, for the benefit of children in Israel.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Charles E. Wilson, in his final hour as Director of Defense Mobilization, declared today that the United States was fast overtaking Russia in munitions output and that this nation and its Allies now held the "balance of power" over the Communist world.

Casting a Presidential preference ballot at the opening of the Country Antiques Fair yesterday delayed visitors only a moment from getting down to the really serious business of combing the show for purchases.

Steps are being outlined by the American National Theatre and Academy to obtain an exemption, now being enjoyed by the Metropolitan Opera and the City Center, of the 20 per cent admission tax, it was reported yesterday by Robert Whitehead, managing director of ANTA's five-play series this season.

BONN, Germany, March 31 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's policy of giving priority to West Germany's integration with Western Europe over the negotiations for German reunification has produced bitter criticism and opposition within his own Christian Democratic Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- On the eve of the final meeting of its tenth session, the Trusteeship Council praised today the annual report of the United States as the administering authority for the trust territory of the Pacific Islands.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 31 -- The partition of Africa into all-white and all-black states was advocated today by an editorial in the Vaderland, the Afrikaans newspaper in Johannesburg, which usually reflects the views of Nicholaas C. Havenga, Deputy Prime Minister in the National Cabinet.

The first box of doughnuts to be sold in the current doughnut-selling drive of the Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York was purchased at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri. Funds collected in the drive will be used to help support the girls' summer camp near Saratoga, N. Y.

LONDON, March 31 -- Investment demand for British Government securities today brought appreciable gains to long-dated and irredeemable issues which finished up to 7s 6d better. Short-dated stocks fell slightly.
TAMPA, Fla., March 31 -- Chuck Dressen and his Dodgers rolled into this city this evening for the first game tomorrow of a ten-game "road trip," with only one worry.

A New York County grand jury, which for two and a half months investigated an allegation that Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh had been criminally derelict in his duties as Commissioner of Investigation in the O'Dwyer regime, reported yesterday the charge "cannot be sustained."
Politics dominated thinking yesterday on the stock market.

The Red Cross fund-raising campaign in this city has been extended through April 15 in response to an appeal for emergency relief funds for Southern tornado victims, Leroy A. Lincoln, Greater New York fund chairman, announced yesterday.
NEW LONDON, Conn., March 31 -- A powerful and compact new submarine, the U. S. S. Trigger, capable of traveling faster under water than on the surface, was officially commissioned here today.
The steady decline in liquor sales in the last few months has started a movement within the industry to fight for removal of price controls under the Office of Price Stabilization.

The promotion of Dr. Basil Rauch, executive officer of the history department at Barnard College, to the rank of full professor has been announced by Dean Millicent C. McIntosh. Announcement also has been made of the promotion of Dr. Ingrith J. Deyrup from assistant to associate Professor of Zoology.

SEVERAL thousand impatient, hopeful and problably cold-anglers will gather at Catherine Creek and other Finger Lakes' tributaries at daybreak today for the opening of the special rainbow trout season in that area, and reports received yesterday indicated that the trout were moving up these streams in good numbers.
Westinghouse Electric Corporation reversed yesterday the trend of steadily dropping price schedules suggested by manufacturers of durable consumer merchandise.

Twenty speakers representing community groups, civic associations and social service organizations gave general approval before the City Planning Commission at City Hall yesterday to proposals for residential districts included in the Harrison, Ballard Allen plan for rezoning the city.

The newly established safety bureau of the New York Shipping Association, set up to reduce accidents on the waterfront, promote safety education and prepare accident statistics, will begin functioning today, it was announced yesterday by John V. Lyon, chairman of the association.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Defense Department outlined further today the new rotation policy for troops in Korea, recently announced by the Eighth Army.
John H. Palmer has been appointed head buyer of non-food items by the Grand Union Company and Edward J. Moberg Jr. has been named non-food sales manager. Both appointments took effect yesterday.

Twelve-year-old Philip A. McDonald 3d of Arlington, Mass., received conclusive proof yesterday morning that his parents and sisters had not been joking last Friday evening when they told him gleefully that he had been chosen "Boy of the Year" by the Boys Clubs of America.

Five Department of Correction guards at the city penitentiary on Rikers Island, convicted of having been associated with a ring that smuggled narcotics to inmates, were sentenced yesterday to penitentiary or state prison terms by Judge Eugene G. Schulz in Bronx County Court.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Senate's Minority Conference of all Republican members petitioned the Senate today to pass future appropriations in a single "one-package" bill that would measure grants of money strictly against the revenues designed to cover them.

Large offerings of industrial and public utility securities lifted the total of new financing in March above that of February as well as of a year ago. But state and municipal financing showed a sharp shrinkage.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Col. David G. Sippel, until recently assigned to the Pentagon headquarters of the Air Force's Materiel Branch, has been charged with unlawfully accepting money from individuals seeking Government contracts, the Air Force announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Senate passed by a voice vote today a bill to provide about $471,000,000 annually in cost-of-living increases in military and related services pay and allowances after approving a $45 monthly combat bonus for men in Korea.

ALVIN (Bo) McMILLIN was a man of character and class. He had a delightful drawl, an infectious grin and a warm, bubbling personality. His place in football history is secure. He will rank as one of the game's great players although he never gained equal stature as a coach despite his Coach of the Year honors one season. The genuinely beloved Bo died yesterday but his death was not unexpected.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The complex structure of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization apparently did not provide any exact procedure for transmittal of the first annual report of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to President Truman, who made the general available for the post.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Legislation making a referee or other athletic official who solicits or accepts a bribe guilty of a felony and subject to a maximum five-year sentence and $10,000 fine was approved today by Governor Dewey.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 1 -- A jury in Superior Court awarded here today to the Kaiser Frazer corporation a judgment of $3,232,329 against Cyrus S. Eaton majority stockholder, and William R. Daley, president of Otis Co., Cleveland banking house now in reorganization.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Submitting the final report of his stewardship as head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, Charles E. Wilson told President Truman today that "the program you intrusted to me is now well launched."

Many parties will be given at the supper dance in the Carnaval Room of the Sherry-Netherland tonight after the performance of "Don Juan in Hell" at the Plymouth Theatre for the benefit of the New York Botanical Garden.

PALERMO, Sicily, April 1 -- Nine British oil experts, some of them from Abadan, are racing with two big American companies to find a new source of oil for Britain to replace the lost Iranian fields. They represent the D'Arcy Exploration Company of London, a subsidiary of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A majority of a panel appointed by the Wage Stabilization Board recommended today that the Borg-Warner Corporation meet with the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., to explore the possibilities of a company-wide agreement on national issues, while individual divisions of the company continue bargaining on local issues on a local basis.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 1 -- Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard took off a few minutes before noon today aboard the K. L. M. Royal Dutch Airline's DC-6 Princess Beatrix for Washington, where they are due tomorrow, to start a three-week official tour of the United States.

On one of radio's giveaway shows the other evening the mistress of ceremonies had occasion to speak to a gentleman in Arkansas, offering him a deep freezer could he answer the question propounded. "Even out there," she said, "you probably could use a deep freezer." From a New York apartment this gave a warming picture of kindly words being wafted from Eastern standard time into Central, and being received there with shrill, bloodcurdling cries.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The Navy disclosed today that a young officer had been court-martialed 139 years ago to cover up the blunder of the naval hero who first uttered the now-famous battle cry: "Don't give up the ship."

ROME, April 1 (AP) -- Italian police disclosed today they have arrested at least seven members of a narcotics ring, some of whom were gangsters deported from the United States. The police acted in cooperation with United States Federal agents.
Maurice A. Hamonneau, a former French soldier who was a close friend of the late Rudyard Kipling, died Monday in Swedish Hospital, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. His age was 61.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 1 (UP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was declared the "endorsed" Republican candidate in two Minnesota Congressional districts today by the State Canvassing Board, opening the way for his supporters to seek four national convention delegates.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 2 (Reuters) -- Marshal Stalin's replies to four questions submitted to

CHICAGO, April 1 -- The Radio Pioneers Club, whose 870 members form a central clearing house for the exchange of information and historical data about the radio industry, heard tonight a plea for increased use of the radio in the world fight for freedom.
ALBANY, April 1 -- The state ended its fiscal year yesterday with a surplus of $2,872,309, or about $553,000 more than Governor Dewey had estimated a year ago. It was the first surplus since 1949.
PARIS, Wednesday, April 2 (AP) -- France completed her ratification early today of the Schuman plan to pool the coal and steel resources of six Western European nations.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives refused today to open the way for a record vote on financing the resumption of full diplomatic relations with Vatican City.

More than 3,300 advertising and sales executives as well as advertising agency heads registered yesterday at the opening of the three-day exhibit and sixth annual symposium sponsored by the Point-of-Purchase Advertising Institute in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Today's new film opening is "Encore," a feature-length package of three W. Somerset Maugham stories produced in England for Paramount, including "Winter Cruise," "Gigolo and Gigolette" and "The Ant and the Grasshopper," at the Normandie.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Julian R. Friedman, former State Department employe, told Senate investigators today he once gave some Government notes on Japan to one of the persons arrested in the Amerasia stolen documents case.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, said tonight that his department "has been compelled to divert to Korea many of its planes, which, according to our plans, should be in the United States or Alaska in our air defense system."

The Canadian Pacific System last year had a net income of $43,307,470 after charges and taxes, equal to $2.98 a share on the ordinary stock, according to the 1951 annual report. This compares with $47,867,011, or $3.32 an ordinary share, in 1950.
Olin Industries, Inc., in its first public report of earnings yesterday, showed a net income of $12,108,673 after all charges, on total sales of $168,185,679.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- The country is "over the hump" in the period of raw materials scarcities, but the demand for many materials still exceeds supplies, Henry H. Fowler, National Production Authority administrator, said today.
Charges against the master of a tugboat that was involved in a collision that cost ten lives were dismissed yesterday by a Coast Guard examiner who ruled that his service lacked jurisdiction.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 1 (AP) -- A new Indonesian Premier was proclaimed tonight, ending a five-week crisis brought on by the previous regime's dispute over acceptance of United States aid under the Mutual Security Administration program.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Oliver S. Powell, Federal Reserve Board member, said today that the agency's 3-to-2 decision to break up the Giannini banking empire in five Pacific Coast states "does not in all respects square with the facts."

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Wednesday, April 2 -- The democratic nations were assured today by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower that "the tide has begun to flow our way and the situation of the free world is brighter than it was a year ago."
WHITEVILLE, N. C., April 1 -- Forty-four bills of indictment were returned against twenty-five Columbus County men today in Superior Court in four flogging cases attributed to the Ku Klux Klan.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill appropriating $25,000,000 to the Civil Defense Commission for the state's 25 per cent share of the cost of bomb shelters. The money will not be spent until the Federal Government appropriates funds for its 50 per cent share.

The city's new 15 per cent race track admission tax drew mixed reactions yesterday as the local horse-playing season opened at Jamaica. The prevailing temper at the source, however, was derogatory but resigned.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1 -- The Yugoslav Government protested today to the British and United States Governments against their decision to confer with the Italian Government in London this week on changes to be made in the administration of Zone A of Trieste without the participation and consent of Yugoslavia.

CAIRO, April 1 -- Foreign Minister Abdel Khalek Hassouna Pasha conferred twice today with the British Ambassador, Sir Ralph Stevenson, in a further effort to get bilateral treaty negotiations started.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- New border beds of full-blooming Dutch tulips, flaming orange and bright red, appeared in the President's private gardens today for the welcome to Queen Juliana tomorrow.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Fairly active early buying lifted prices of grain futures moderately, but demand faded on the upturns and all grains turned weak later. There appeared to be some apprehension over Korean reports on a truce agreement.

The York, Pa., City Sewer Authority borrowed $4,700,000 on revenue bonds yesterday at an interest cost of 1.832 per cent. The bonds were purchased at a competitive sale by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates at a bid of 100.0085 for interest of 2 per cent, 1 3/4 per cent and 1 7/8 per cent.
Three new issues of public utility bonds and debentures totaling $31,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates.
The grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was converted into a deluxe parking lot last night for a preview of the "Parade of Stars" automobile show.

The City Center, which provides a phase of cultural life that has earned the respect of the public, is romancing the American National Theatre and Academy, a nonprofit organization operating under a Congressional charter. The mating would bring the former's dramatic offerings to the ANTA Playhouse on the basis of a forty-week season.

Mayor Impellitteri submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate a proposed city budget of $1,469,265,101 for the fiscal year beginning July 1. It was the largest in the city's history and the sixth in succession to exceed a billion dollars. It was $128,148,888 larger than the 1951-52 budget as modified to March 15.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The White House has instructed the Department of Justice to be prepared to advise the President on powers to seize the steel industry in case of a strike.

LAS VEGAS, Nov., April 1 -- A new variety of atomic explosion, hinting at the application of nuclear fission to specialized tools of field warfare, was unleashed today as the Atomic Energy Commission began its third series of test blasts at its Nevada Proving Ground.

The new Owls Head Sewage Treatment Plant in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, designed to end much of the pollution of the waters at the city's largest ocean playground, Coney Island, will go into operation a 10:30 A. M. tomorrow, when Mayor Impellitteri turns a valve putting the machinery in motion.

MEXICO CITY, April 1 -- Ambassador William O'Dwyer said here today that the New York grand jury that investigated gambling conditions in that city had "completely distorted" Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh's part in the enforcement of gambling laws as Commissioner of Investigation during the Ambassador's administration as Mayor of New York.

With the Government holding fast in its resistance to higher steel prices, major steel producers put off for a second day yesterday their scheduled wage talks with Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 2 (AP) -- Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Senate tonight viewed his first year report from Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, as indicating his commonsense approach to the problem of European defense.

TAMPA, Fla., April 1 -- The Reds' spring stay in Tampa ended today along with a six-game winning streak as the Dodgers outscored them, 7 -- 3, before 4,372 fans. Luke Sewell will take his squad to Orlando in the morning on the first leg of the homeward trip, while the Brooks go to St. Petersburg for their final Florida game against the Yankees.

BOSTON, April 1 (UP) -- Fleming Mackell, only six days out of a sick bed, paced the Boston Bruins to a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight to even the Stanley Cup semi-final series B hockey play-offs at two games each before 11,065 roaring fans at the Boston Garden.

The trial of William Sutton and Thomas Kling on a four-count bank robbery indictment ended at dawn yesterday, a fortnight after it had started. The jury, out more than nine hours, found both guilty on all counts. Both face possible life sentences as fourth offenders.

MILWAUKEE, April 1 -- Scientists at the National Cancer Institute of the United States Public Health Service reported today on the development of techniques that make it possible to see, for the first time, single molecules of some of the basic ingredients of the building blocks of life.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Newbold Morris' demand for detailed data on the personal finances of high Government officials was reported tonight to have set off sharp protests from Cabinet members at a meeting of President Truman's official family Friday.
