LONDON, April 1 -- Prime Minister Churchill said today that if General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower should leave the Allied Supreme Command in Europe and the United States had "the slightest wish" that another American should succeed him, Britain would "certainly agree."

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The Senate approved a treaty with Canada today to help prevent international operators from defrauding American and Canadian investors with fraudulent gold or uranium mine stock and other get-rich-quick schemes.

Kirsten Flagstad sang her 193d performance at the Metropolitan last night, and because it was her farewell to the opera house she received a silver loving cup from colleagues on the stage and a tumultuous ovation from the audience that lasted for twenty-two minutes.
PARIS, April 1 (AP) -- France shifted the center of gravity for her relations with Indo-China from Paris to Saigon today with the appointment of Jean Letourneau as High Commissioner for Indo-China.

The president and secretary-treasurer of District 65, International Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America, an unaffiliated union, were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman to three months in prison for contempt of court.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- The Braves pounded Robin Roberts for thirteen hits today in routing the Phillies, 10 -- 4, with a sixteen-blow attack.

Warm weather has arrived in the New York area just in time to benefit retailers and manufacturers of men's clothing, it was reported yesterday. The favorable weather coupled with a later Easter than last year are expected to create a deluge of reorders for spring and summer suits.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 29 (by Airmail) -- The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, after careful preparation, has launched a project that leaders of non-Communist world labor believe may be the death blow to Communist influence in the French labor movement.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The closing session of the National Conference on Equal Pay held by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor voted today for four recommendations, which were as follows:

BALTIMORE, April 1 -- All six defendants in the "second-string" Communist conspiracy trial in Federal court were convicted today. The jury that heard the case for three weeks returned its guilty verdict after deliberating two hours and fifty minutes.

Robert Mueller, a pianist from Decatur, Ill., with individual gifts, made his New York debut last night at Town Hall. He made a favorable impression, though it was hard to judge the full extent of his talents from the works of his program.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, April 2 (AP) -- United States Sabre jet planes blasted ten Communist MIG's from the northwest Korean skies yesterday, probably destroyed three more and damaged ten -- the second biggest bag of the war.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The State Department repudiated today a statement by Dan A. Kimball, Secretary of the Navy, that United States naval forces would "stand on the sidelines and cheer" if the Chinese Nationalists attacked the Communist-held Chinese mainland from Formosa.
Sugar, cocoa and rubber were hold-outs against declining trends in commodity prices here yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 1 -- Support for Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut for the Democratic Presidential nomination came today from Connecticut's junior Senator, William Benton. In a statement telephoned from Phoenix, Ariz., where he has been on vacation, Senator Benton said:
A total of $351,412.61 was received in the New York Times Neediest Cases campaign for 1951-52. It was distributed to the seven philanthropic agencies that took part in the 1951-52 fund.

The protection of life and limb in virtually every phase of modern American life was discussed yesterday at the twenty-second annual Safety Convention and Exposition arranged by the Greater New York Safety Council and cooperating agencies in the Statler Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today protested the increasing use of so-called "institutional" advertising for "political" purposes.

As one of the millions of unorganized "little fellows" squeezed between the labor unions' organized minority demands and management's usually craven capitulation thereto, permit me to raise a cheer for Charles E. Wilson's brave act in resigning. The motivating reasons in back of his action seem to be only too tragically sound.

The Seafarers International Union (A. F. L.) has called attention to a loophole in port-security procedure that requires careful consideration and early action. While one may discount the charge that the nation's waterfront is "so lacking in security that an army of subversives could land * * * virtually unchallenged," it is nevertheless true that there is something lacking in the checking of possible subversives who disembark from foreign ships at our ports.

PARIS, April 1 -- Premier Antoine Pinay has obtained authority from the Cabinet to ask for a confidence vote at any time during the course of National Assembly debate on his financial program. The debate began today.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 1 -- The outlook for the supply of materials used by the country's packaging industry is, with some minor exceptions, very good, Manly Fleischmann, Defense Production Administrator, declared here today.

RED BANK, N. J., April 1 -- Dr. Theodore Brameld, professor of philosophy of education at New York University, whose scheduled address before Red Bank teachers on Feb. 1 was canceled by the local Board of Education, will speak here Thursday night at the Borough Hall Council chambers under sponsorship of the Red Bank Ministerium, made up of fourteen clergymen and Young Men's Christian Association leaders.

Anthony Guastella of Hollywood, Calif., can stop worrying about his four white shirts. They were found in a Chinese laundry in the Bronx yesterday. Mr. Guastella and his wife, Cassandra, moved to California from the Bronx last January. Several weeks ago they remembered leaving the shirts in a laundry on East 169th Street.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, April 1 -- Another attempt has been made to bomb officials of the West German Government by mail, this time directed against the delegation to the indemnity conference of Germans, Israelis and World Jewish groups here.

Cambridge University's touring squash racquets team, playing under English rules for the first time in this country, defeated a picked New York team, 6 to 0, on the University Club's courts last night. English equipment was used for the matches.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 1 -- Most women in business and industry are not there by choice but because of the necessity to meet the rising cost of living, according to Elizabeth Lee Vincent, Dean of the College of Home Economics at Cornell University.
Twenty-eight qualifying sections have been established for the fifty-second United States Golf Association championship that will he held at the Northwood Club, Dallas, June 12 through 14.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 1 -- Chancellor Collins J. Seitz handed down an opinion today in the Court of Chancery that would permit Negro children to attend the Claymont High School and the Hockessin Elementary School. He held that the facilities and educational opportunities for Negroes in the two communities were inferior in a Constitutional sense to those provided for white children.

In his first and possibly last report as Supreme Commander of the Allied forces in Europe General Eisenhower presents a clear and on the whole encouraging picture of the efforts of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to build up an adequate defense against Soviet imperialism. But he does more than that.

The defense for sixteen secondary Communist party leaders won the first round of legal skirmishing yesterday in Federal court in arguments preliminary to their trial on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

The substantial growth of direct placements of corporate securities with the larger life insurance companies has tended to limit increases in the supply of desirable bond issues available to smaller life companies and other interested investors, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly review of credit and business conditions.

Among the exhibitions and observances that will take place this year in the United States and abroad on the 500th anniversary of the birth of the Renaissance master, Leonardo da Vinca, two will open here this month.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department said today that eight of its employes at Dallas, Tex., had been formally reprimanded for accepting gifts from persons doing business with the Government.

A trade and credit union of the dollar and sterling areas dedicated to "re-creating nineteenth century conditions of expansion" in a successor era of catastrophic change, was recommended here yesterday by Barbara Ward, British Commonwealth publicist, in a luncheon talk before the Bond Club of New York at the Bankers Club.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, Wednesday, April 2 -- Following is the text of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's first annual report as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe:

THE opening day portents are still kindly, and unless the weather man decides to administer a last-minute slap at the trout fishermen conditions should be unusually fine on most of the Catskill streams on the second Saturday in April.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- Vincent Hallinan, the Progressive party's Presidential candidate, surrendered to the United States Marshal hero late today to start serving a six-month prison term for contempt of court.
A New Orleans tenor who won't sing under his real name -- Caruso -- and a Detroit baritone tied last night for first place in the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air.
Several passages in a recent address by General of the Army Omar N. Bradley provide an illuminating illustration of the increasing tendency of the military to participate in political debate.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 (UP) -- Red Schoendienst, versatile infield star of the Cardinals, will be sidelined about two weeks as a result of a pin-point fracture of the third finger of his throwing hand, X-ray examination disclosed tonight.
The invitation to lunch yesterday was tendered in a casual manner -- and its acceptance was casual, too, but with a note of suspicion because of the April 1 date.

Yesterday it was Turkey's turn to step into the fashion scene in a modern way. The famous harem trousers and bouffant hems have never really vanished from the picture, of course, but it is a new turn for a varied group of play, lounging and spectator clothes to take a hint from that fascinating country.

LONDON, April 1 -- British Government securities again were outstanding on the stock exchange today, stimulated by strength of sterling against dollar. Although best prices were not always held, there were many gains of 2s 6d (35 cents).

AMONG the legions of readers who loved Mary O'Hara's "My Friend Flicka" and "Thunderhead" only the children, millions of them, perhaps, did so because those lovely books were about horses. Adults loved them because they were perceptive and moving stories of family relationships, of a husband and wife and two sons involved in emotional crises with each other, as well as with horses on the high plains of Wyoming.
Control of the Mutual Broadcasting System now rests with the General Tire and Rubber Company, shareholders of the latter learned at their annual meeting yesterday.

The deterioration of "Author Meets the Critics" from one of the really fine programs on the air into a weekly brawl is not bringing credit to its producer, Martin Stone, or to television as a whole. The program's use of calculated sensationalism to stimulate its popularity rating clearly is getting out of hand.

A "great stirring" of the peoples of many countries is pushing their leaders into energetic efforts for their economic betterment, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday. The former First Lady arrived at La Guardia Airport aboard a Trans World Airlines plane from Los Angeles, completing a round-the-world trip begun last Dec. 31.

Net earnings of Chemical Bank and Trust Company for the first three months of this year were estimated yesterday at 96 cents a share compared with 82 cents a year ago by N. Baxter Jackson, chairman, in releasing the March 31 statement.

Mrs. Ada Patton, a 35-year-old former Army nurse, now in her senior year at Hunter College, will make her debut as an actress in the Hunter College Theatre Workshop's production of "Deep Are the Roots," by Arnaud D'Usseau and James Gow, today at 6 P. M. in the Hunter College Playhouse, Sixty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.
I read with some dismay the article appearing in your issue of March 27 under the heading "Venality Charged to French Courts."

Parents today are struggling with pressures from all sides. Their anxiety springs in part from the uncertain conditions of the world around us. It also has its sources deep in the inner tensions to which human beings are always exposed.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 1 -- The persecution of Protestants and their missionaries in Colombia and the whole problem of the Colombian attitude toward Protestantism has become an acute issue in this country.
The musk ox, which used to roam the North American Continent but is now nearly extract, may prove to be the salvation of New England, an Arctic explorer reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Nearly all tactical Air National Guard units now on Federal duty will be returned to their states between next July 1 and Feb. 1, the Air Force said today.
LONDON, April 1 (Reuters) -- Aneurin Bevan, Labor party rebel, forecast today that, before long, the Russians would be prepared to withdraw their troops from Eastern Germany.

The frontiers of American business are greater now than ever before, William Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, Inc., declared yesterday. He addressed 500 members of the Sales Executives Club of New York in the Roosevelt Hotel.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 1 (AP) -- Large makers of rubber goods must plow back 20 per cent of their profits into rubber-tree growing, according to an executive order signed recently by President Vargas.

Balloting in the national election of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., began yesterday and will continue through June 30. Only one of the six national officers of the organization faces opposition.

LOS ANGELES, April 1 (AP) -- Jimmy Carter of New York retained his lightweight title tonight with a fifteen-round victory over Mexican Lauro Salas. The decision was unanimous but Salas put up a determined battle. He had the champion on the deck in the fifteenth for a count of four.

ROME, April 1 -- In a reply to the wrong speech that Marshal Tito delivered yesterday to the Yugoslav National Assembly, Premier Alcide De Gasperi reaffirmed in the Senate today Italy's wish to live on friendly terms with Yugoslavia and to solve the problem of the Trieste Free Territory on a mutually acceptable basis by direct negotiations.

New York University defeated Upsala, 4 -- 3, at Ohio Field yesterday in the opening game of the Violets thirty-first baseball season under Coach William V. (Bill) McCarthy. Seven innings of scoreless relief pitching by Vincent Lupica marked the Violet triumph.

The talented baker and owner of Leonard's pastry shop, Morty Phillips, has concocted three additions to his line of cakes. Again he has utilized the recipe for chiffon cake popularized by General Mills. (He first employed it in a plain chiffon cake and in one frosted with strawberry icing.) His new creations are an orange sponge layer cake and two that are mocha-mousse-frosted, one with chocolate layers, the other with white.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 2 -- United Nations and Communist staff officers held their final meeting at Panmunjom today on the minor clauses of the terms for the enforcement of an armistice in Korea before turning back to the committee of generals the vital issues of Soviet participates as a "neutral" supervisory nation and of the enemy demand for the right to build airfields without limit north of the Thirty-eighth Parallel during a cease-fire.

The Sam Levenson show, presented over Channel 2 on Sunday evenings, will change its time of broadcast to Tuesdays, 8 to 8:30 P. M., beginning April 22, thus placing Mr. Levenson opposite Milton Berle on Channel 4. Mr. Levenson's current time period will be taken over on Sunday, April 20, at 6:30 P. M. by Edward R. Murrow's "See It Now."

A European army will be useless unless there is a united Europe to insure a common foreign policy to direct such a fighting force, Paul-Henri Spaak, former Socialist Premier of Belgium, said in a news conference here yesterday.
ALBANY, April 1 (UP) -- Banks in New York State underwent "strong expansion" in 1951 but heavier taxes virtually wiped out all increases in earnings, the State Banking Department reported today.
The Department of Sanitation is attracting "white wings" of a more intellectual bent, a study of personnel records showed yesterday.

The Tri-Continental Corporation, one of the country's largest closed-end investment trusts, is continuing to follow a policy of maintaining common stock risks at about 80 per cent of investment assets. The sustained investment demand that has served to bolster stock prices in the last two months, Francis F. Randolph, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Baltimore, "seems to justify a basically constructive attitude toward common stocks."

LONDON, April 1 -- Marshal Stalin's replies to the four questions submitted to him by a touring party of United States editors aroused less interest here today than anything that the Soviet Premier has said for a long time.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Creation of a state commission to investigate pre-trial procedures, trial, commitment, parole and rehabilitation of youthful offenders was urged today at an Albany meeting of the New York State Conference of the National Council of Jewish Women.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- The Greyhound Corporation announced today it has taken steps to acquire complete stock ownership of Interstate Transit Lines and Union Pacific Stages, intercity bus lines operated jointly by Overland Greyhound Lines.

A two-day meeting of the marine section of the National Safety Council, scheduled in conjunction with the twenty-second annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council, opens this morning at the Statler Hotel.
Arthur W. Wallander, whose resignation as city Director of Civil Defense was to become effective yesterday, has agreed to remain at his post until Mayor Impellitteri appoints his successor.

It was too much to expect that the Kansas Jayhawks, even with the great Clyde Lovellette, would upset the Peoria Caterpillars in the final of the Olympic basketball trials at Madison Square Garden last night. After all the national A. A. U. champions had the experience, cleverness, over-all height and other weapons, while the collegians had to depend principally on Lovellette.

YONKERS, April 1 -- Seven hundred Roman Catholic priests, brothers and seminarians assembled at St. Joseph's Seminary here today to share in one of the largest civilian blood-giving events of the New York area. The American Red Cross, which operated a bloodmobile unit in the corridors and recreation hall, said tonight that a record 600 pints had been taken from as many donors.

A payroll padding scheme, in which the names of bookmakers, policy operators and racketeers were used, was disclosed yesterday in Kings County Court with the arraignment of the head timekeeper of the Atlantic Stevedoring Company, a subsidiary of the Barber Steamship Lines, as a material witness in the borough's waterfront inquiry.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., April 1 (AP) -- The local chairman of the American Association of University Professors said today it planned to investigate the dismissal of Dr. George H. Hand, president of Fairmont State College. Dr. Hand received his dismissal notice last week from the West Virginia Board of Education.

MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, April 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio was assured this morning of twenty-four of Wisconsin's thirty Republican convention delegates to support his bid for the Presidential nomination in July.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 1 (Reuters) -- Informed circles said today that American banks might extend a $50,000,000 long-term loan to Belgium if current negotiations were successful.

Dollar sales volume of major New York and Brooklyn department stores for March was 11 per cent below that of the similar month of 1951, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. All stores covered reported losses.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A transcript of Attorney General J Howard McGrath's testimony that he had not made up his mind whether to answer a questionnaire on his personal income was under White House study today. President Truman has set an appointment for Mr. McGrath to see him at 11:45 A. M. tomorrow.
ATHENS, April 1 -- The Government tonight introduced legislation on its "pacification" program designed in broad outline to reduce the internal Communist danger through various leniency measures.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., April 1 -- Marjorie Haines of Gwynedd Valley, Pa., was selected today as the first woman rider ever to compete for this country in an Olympic equestrian event. The 24-year-old costume designer was one of four named for the 1952 Olympic dressage team at the completion of final tryouts staged in the picturesque show-ring at Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

MEXICO CITY, April 1 -- A red and black strike flag flew over the headquarters building of the Mexican Telephone Company here today as 6,000 of the company's employes throughout the country walked off their jobs at noon in a bid for wage increases ranging up to 60 per cent.
TOKYO, April 1 -- Japanese flags flew at the Imperial Hotel today for the first time in more than six years, replacing "off limits" signs that applied to enlisted personnel.

Senator Robert A. Taft emerged the victor today by a substantial plurality in Wisconsin's Republican Presidential preferential primary, but was engaged in a neck-and-neck "battle of the write-ins" with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in Nebraska.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A bloc of Democrats representing city constituencies in the House of Representatives is in an advanced stage of formation. The purpose is to oppose the frequent coalition of farm-state Republicans and Southern Democrats.

Mayor Impellitteri's proposed budget for the 1952-53 fiscal year, starting July 1, calls for expenditure of $1,469,265,101. This figure, although an increase of $128,148,888 over the current year's budget, is in itself only a bookkeeping phantom of wishful thinking. For it does not reflect the real extent of transit-operating deficit for which the day of reckoning is put off by deferred financing.

In connection with the editorial "Repercussions of Katyn" that appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 23 it seems to me that in the heat of the argument over which side did the brutal killings -- and both regimes were equally mendacious and equally capable of committing mass murder -- one overlooks the original crime perpetrated by the Soviet Government.

OMAHA, Wednesday, April 2 -- The write-in battle between General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio developed into a neck-and-neck contest early today in the Nebraska Republican Presidential primary.

PARIS, April 1 -- The French National Assembly gave its implied approval tonight to the series of drastic measures employed by the Government to check nationalist agitation in Tunisia and open the way for negotiation to establish moderate home-rule reforms in the North African protectorate.

SYRACUSE, N. Y. April 1 (AP) -- A former employe of the Syracuse Internal Revenue Bureau and her husband, also a one-time Government worker, were sentenced today to two years each in Federal prison on charges of embezzling about $23,000 in Government funds.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The gay, bantering Vice President Alben W. Barkley was keeping his new spring hat on for the time being, although his friends all over the country, he said today, were urging him to toss it into the well-known ring.

A letter to the stockholders of Colonial Airlines has been sent by a committee, of which the chairman and signer of the letter is T. P. Ansberry, asking for the election of a new board of directors and new management at the annual meeting on April 16.
FORT HOOD, Tex., April 1 (UP) -- The death toll in the Army Air Force Exercise Long Horn increased to seven today. It included six accidental deaths and one murder.

The production of items of Occidental design by the Japanese, a common procedure, has been reversed in the case of the new collection of ceramic objects that constitutes this month's exhibit in the gallery of America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

Premier Stalin's answer to the questionnaire sent to him from Rome by a group of American editors was delivered to one of their number, James L. Wick, of The Daily Times, Niles, Ohio, on his arrival in New York yesterday. One copy, in English, was forwarded to Idlewild Airport by the Soviet Ambassador in London after the party had left England.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- Gerry Coleman and Ted Williams may be back flying Marine Corps airplanes soon.

A new volume for the ever-increasing shelf about Napoleon and his life has been scheduled for April 24 publication by Doubleday under the title "Napoleon at St. Helena: The Journals of General Bertrand, January-May 1821." It is a day-by day record of the Emperor's last days by the Grand Marshal of the Palace on St. Helena, one of Napoleon's most intimate aides and for five years his constant companion.

DENVER, April 1 -- The second start of Max Lanier as a Giant today against the Indians was something less than a howling success. The southpaw gave up a pair of home runs in the third inning that led to the sixth straight defeat for the New Yorkers at the hands of their American League rivals, 7 to 4, before 17,806 fans.

Replying to questions from a group of American newspaper and radio executives, Premier Joseph Stalin has expressed the opinion that World War III is no nearer than it was two or three years ago, and that the time is now ripe for unification of Germany.

ORLANDO, Fla., April 1 -- Bucky Harris, who would rather beat the Yanks than find a hundred-dollar bill on a sidewalk, almost made it today. But in the ninth inning, with the Senators leading the Bombers by 2 to 1, the Nats' shortstop, Pete Runnels, let a ground bah go through him with the bases filled. That was all the opening the Stengelers needed.

The horses and the horse players returned to the Jamaica track yesterday. The opening of New York's 197-day campaign drew a crowd of 40,502. It is presumed that all had fresh hopes and fresh bankrolls. It is certain that they were looking for (a) winners, and (b) fun.

In a recent article in THE NEW YORE TIMES Arthur Krock commented extensively and ably on the question of whether Governor Stevenson would and should continue as a candidate for Governor of Illinois or accept a draft to the nomination for President if one were made.
PORTLAND, Me., April 1 (AP) -- Maine's Supreme Court today upheld the Legislature's ban on night racing at Scarborough Downs, the state's only running-horse racing plant.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 1 (AP) -- Hill Gail turned in five furlongs in 0:58 1/5 at Keeneland today, the fastest workout for that distance in the sixteen-year history of the track.

A selected group of ash trays and small bowls, clay sculptured in simple, free - form shapes with swiftly sketched imaginative designs are now at The Willow, 184 Fourth Street, open from 1 to 9 P. M. The pieces are made by Jerrold Friedman of California, who first took up this craft as a therapeutic device for stuttering.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A House subcommittee learned today that Daniel A. Bolich, then Assistant Commissioner of Internal Revenue, overruled New York field agents in 1949 to stop criminal proceedings in a $250,000 tax fraud case.

ALBANY, April 1 -- A drive to get at least 1,000 June graduates of liberal arts colleges to take teacher-training courses this summer -- so that they will be ready for teaching positions in elementary schools throughout the state next September -- was started today at the first meeting of a special committee named by the State Board of Regents.
The following are excerpts from Mayor Impellitteri's message to the Board of Estimate and the City Council in submitting the executive budget for the fiscal year 1952-53:

The re-establishment within the American Federation of Labor of its Maritime Trades Department, representing 200,000 marine and waterfront workers in the United States and Canada and designed to bring about stabilization of maritime labor relations, was announced yesterday.

After a year of conferences with representatives of religious, welfare, fraternal and veterans' organizations, City Councilman Charels E. Keegan, Bronx Democrat, introduced into the Council yesterday a measure designed to put the brakes on high pressure solicitation of charity funds.

Confident that the 71,000 bags of potatoes that arrived here Monday from Spain will meet all requirements of the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine, Spanish exporters have started another shipload of tubers across the Atlantic, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The Government announced today it would open hearings April 29 on a protest by the Ford Motor Company of what it called "unfair" distribution of metals among auto makers.
The futures market closed 1 point higher to 35 points lower yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with a moderate volume of trading.

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan Ryan dealt a blow yesterday to Frank Costello's defense with a rulling, in the Jury's presence, that the gambler could not have purged himself of contempt by answering, four days later, questions he had refused to answer before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee on March 15 and 16 of last year.
ALBANY, April 1 -- New York State farmers realized gross sales of $957,000,000 in 1951, an increase of 18 per cent over the preceding year, the State Commerce Department reported today.

A block of $25,840,000 of common stock of the Colorado Interstate Gas Company, a natural gas pipeline system linking the Texas Panhandle gas fields to Denver and other eastern Colorado communities, will be placed on the market today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 2 (AP) -- General Headquarters Communique 1207 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M., Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

Thirty-seven regattas were voted yesterday at the annual spring meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, which was held in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. The events will start on May 24, with contest of the Horseshoe Harbor Club of Larchmont, which also will close the season on Sept 14.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Wednesday, April 2 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower studiously refrained from mentioning atomic weapons in his 12,000-word annual report published today, but his guarded references to imminent "fundamental changes" in the armed forces as a result of the development of "new types of arms" underscore a new situation of the highest military importance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Hal Wallis and his popular money-making comedy team of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis are at odds over the proposed film "Sacred Stiff." Production was set to start yesterday morning at the Paramount Studio, but the comedians didn't put in an appearance.

The stock market seemed to take a breathing spell yesterday. The stumbling block in the path of continued advance in prices was the definite threat of a strike in the steel industry. All main sections of the list were subjected to sufficient selling to pare values down from 1 to as much as 3 points.

Though the rest of his speech was practically blotted out by those sensational few sentences toward the end, President Truman did say something else Saturday night that should not be overlooked in the excitement. "I have just got one reorganization plan through the Congress," he said, "and I am going to send up some more plans to Congress soon -- to put more of our federal officials under civil service and out of politics."

The move to get men to wear "the right clothes at the right time," sponsored by the Men's Wear Inter-Industry Council, has gained momentum since it was announced Feb. 25. To date more than 450 newspapers have requested the advertising mat service.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Gordon Dean, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today he wanted to tell the public more about what happened at Eniwetok last year but that so far he had had "opposition" from military circles.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 1 -- The Springfield Playgoers, Inc., tonight presented Olivia de Havilland in "Candida," an initial offering designed to bring Springfield back to the ranks of cities where legitimate theatre is a paying and popular entertainment.
Two all-New York contract bridge teams meet tonight in a forty-board final match for the Reisinger Cup Eastern States team-of-four championship.

Thirteen police captains, twelve of them commanders of detective districts, were promoted yesterday to the rank of deputy inspector by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan in ceremonies in his office at Police Headquarters. All will remain in their present posts.

The Society of the 307th Infantry dedicated a plaque last night bearing the names of 596 officers and men of the regiment killed in World War I. The ceremony took place in the 77th Division Club House, 28 East Thirty-ninth Street.

Judge Harold R. Medina said in Federal court here yesterday that he would like to throw out the investment banking anti-trust suit on the ground that it was "a huge struggle of the giants between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice to see who is running the securities business."
Two master sergeants retiring from the Army after more than thirty years' service each were honored yesterday at a ceremony at Fort Jay, Governors Island, attended by the entire garrison.

TORONTO, April 1 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings coasted into the Stanley Cup hockey finals tonight by defeating the defending champions, the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1, to win the best-of-seven semi-final series in four straight games.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill that will bar any recurrence of such special elections as those that brought Mayor Impellitteri and Rudolph Halley, City Council President, to office in New York City.

ROME, April 1 -- Five militant Communist intellectuals, formerly leaders of a left-wing Catholic party, have abandoned the Italian Communist party and re-entered the Catholic fold, proclaiming that they had "realized, in conformity with what the church affirms, that it is impossible for a Catholic to belong to the Communist party or to support it."

MEXICO CITY, April 1 -- Having been sharply rebuffed in its attempt for a military aid pact with Mexico, the United States Government has dropped, at least temporarily, efforts to obtain three other agreements.
Accessories of glass, straw and wood are included in the collection of new accouterments for spring entertaining now available at Bergdorf Goodman. Almost all the items are comparatively inexpensive.

A new handbook to help technical aid experts understand the cultures of underdeveloped countries they are serving is being prepared for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization by a committee headed by Dr. Margaret Mead, anthropologist of the American Museum of Natural History.

The first of a series of four Wednesday evening talks on "What Can Religion Mean to You?" -- part of a program in which the people of Chelsea will have an opportunity to study religious values on a non-sectarian basis -- will be given tonight.

With spring blouse buying now at its height, the Gibson Girl, popular earlier, is giving way to a sleeker, more sophisticated look. Its influence, however, is reflected in the puffed sleeves and demure high collars that are now in favor.

Recent moves by foreign countries to reduce imports from the dollar area are beginning to be felt sharply by United States exporters, it was indicated yesterday at a round table conference of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Statler Hotel.

PERHAPS the most heart-warming bulletin to emerge from any war is this: "The Marines have landed and the situation is well in hand." But the Marines made a different kind of landing yesterday and the result was not quite so heart-warming. They landed on Ted Williams and Jerry Coleman, a couple of retreads, and whisked them back into service.
Gen. Albert W. T. Orsborn, international head of the Salvation Army, addressed 250 guests at a luncheon held yesterday in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Although the Board of Transportation has spent $13,000,000 for new equipment to modernize its main West Side power plant in part, it has not succeeded in eliminating the heavy emissions of dense black smoke that contribute substantially to air pollution in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill appropriating $492,434,900 for the civil functions of the Department of the Army. These include work on rivers and harbors, and on flood control, done by the Corps of Engineers.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 2 (UP) -- The Tennessee Republican convention elected five delegates pledged to Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today, giving to the senator nineteen of the state's twenty representatives at the G.O.P. presidential nominating convention.

Reflecting restriction on materials, production of motor vehicles by the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation for March and the first quarter of 1952 showed sharp declines from the same periods in 1951.

Sales of vitamins and vitamin preparations in this country will total a record $300,000,000 this year, it was predicted yesterday by H. B. Burns, president of the U. S. Vitamin Corporation. A growing use of vitamins as an adjunct to medical treatment of numerous diseases was cited as a major factor in the anticipation of sales gains.

PITTSBURGH, April 2 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation disclosed plans today to build a new plant in Harrisburg, Pa., to fabricate what it called "a revolutionary, insulated, steel military shelter."

The Madison Leasing Corporation, Charles B. Benenson, president, has purchased the twenty-story office building at 347 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-fifth Street, in a deal negotiated by Vought, Ward Nicholls, brokers. The building occupies a plot 125 by 125 feet and was sold by the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company. It has a direct entrance from Grand Central Station.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- The United Nations' Disarmament Commission voted tonight to set up two subsidiary committees to consider the conflicting first steps toward disarmament proposed by the Soviet Union and the United States.

A Roman Catholic priest was killed and another seriously injured when the automobile in which they were driving down Broadway got out of control at 252d Street, the Bronx, at 8:30 P. M. yesterday and struck a surface car, a taxi and a parked automobile, the police of the Kingsbridge station reported.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 2 (AP) -Favorites swept through the first round of match play in the annual Trans-Mississippi women's amateur golf tournament today, with the defending champion, Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore, and the medalist, Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont., leading the way.

The Omaha, Neb., Public Power District sold yesterday $17,000,000 of electric revenue bonds due Feb. 1, 1954 to 1982, to a banking syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation and Blyth Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 2.1195 per cent. The winning bid was 100 for 4s, 1 7/8s, 2s and 2 1/8s.

BOSTON, April 2 (UP) -- Irving Crane of Binghamton, N. Y., beat Jimmie Mills of San Jose, Calif., 150-73, tonight to remain in the running as a challenger to Willie Mosconi in the world championship pocket billiards round-robin.

DETROIT, April 2 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, his Presidential hopes buoyed by victories in the Nebraska and Wisconsin primaries, told a Detroit audience today that all states should adopt the preferential primary system so that the people, not the political bosses, could select Presidential candidates.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., April 2 -- Breathing deeply the exciting aroma of grease paint, 225 high school students, teachers and townsfolk in cancan ruffles, red swallowtails or harem veils presented the "Westchester Follies of 1952" at the Mamaroneck Playhouse tonight.

It will help to set the stage for an appraisal of the election returns from Wisconsin and Nebraska if we note briefly the position which the spokesmen of these states in Congress have taken on the chief issue -- foreign policy -- on which Senator Taft disagrees with his principal Republican opponents -- General Eisenhower, Governor Warren and Mr. Stassen.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Legislation authorizing the Long Island Transit Authority to take title to the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road as the first step in restoring the carrier to private operation was approved today by Governor Dewey.

DUBLIN, April 2 -- The Irish Republic got its first real taste of austerity tonight when Finance Minister Sean MacEntee, introducing a record fiscal budget of more than 100,000,000 ($280,000,000), imposed the severest tax burden yet placed on this small state.

MOSCOW, April 2 -- Premier Stalin's new statement on Germany was interpreted by some diplomats tonight as indicating that Moscow would press with vigor and substantial flexibility for the earliest all-German elections, the creation of a unified German Government and the signing of a German peace treaty.
In the past months there have been many such comments as made by Oliver Hull regarding the delay in ambulance service in emergencies.
Highlights from various fashion departments at Oppenheim-Collins were presented in a style show at the store yesterday afternoon.
Women from Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx pledged $270,500 yesterday toward the current campaign of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York.

KHARTUM, Sudan, April 2 -- Britain offered limited self-rule to the disputed Sudan today in a new Constitution that would make the present British Governor General the Chief of State. The document would give the Sudanese their own Cabinet and Parliament.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Defense Production Administration approved today an expansion program for domestic and foreign operations calling for the drilling of 80,000 oil wells in this country and 10,000 abroad in the eighteen months from July, 1952, through December, 1953.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 2 -- Milton A. Gibbons, Mayor of Tuckahoe and a founder of Police Athletic Leagues for combating juvenile delinquency, was sentenced by Judge John P. Donohoe in County Court here today to serve three months in the Westchester Penitentiary at Eastview.

The stock market yesterday was unable to shake off the uncertain state brought on by the steel wage-price controversy. Although an equal number of individual stocks moved in either direction, lack of interest canceled any conclusive result for the day.

A rush-hour subway train entering Manhattan Bridge from Brooklyn had a short-circuit yesterday morning, and the resulting flash and rolling clouds of smoke frightened pasengers, causing them to smash twenty-four windows in clambering out of the packed cars.

Paula Stone and Mike Sloane, producers of the current musical hit, "Top Banana," have purchased the American stage and film rights to "Carnival in Flanders," the French motion - picture success, which will be converted into a musical for Broadway next season.

The letter of Prof. Henri Peyre, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 18, is entirely on the right lines with reference to the problem of elementary modern language teaching in this country, but it does not go far enough.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 2 -- State Highway Commissioner G. Albert Hill disclosed tonight the "preferred line" for the Fairfield County Thruway in Stamford. A switch of the east end of the route removed objections from one group, but aroused others.

That "recession" this city had last year -- the most prosperous it ever had -- turns out to have been a boom. In fact, classified employment data for the city, which became available for the first time yesterday, show that in 1951 city employment reached the highest post-war peak.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Government tonight studied punitive steps it might take to block a strike of 650,000 steel workers that would cause a shutdown of the nation's steel mills.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 2 (AP) -- Ted Williams, Red Sox slugger, and Jerry Coleman, second baseman of the Yankees -- both fliers in World War II -- today were found fit for duty in the Marine Air Corps. They will report on May 2.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, smiling broadly and obviously in happy spirits, said today that he considered the outcome of the Wisconsin Presidential primary "a very substantial victory for our position."

With the White House speeding preparations for possible Federal seizure of the steel industry to ward off a strike, major steel producers decided yesterday to hold their first negotiations this morning with Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath told President Truman today that he was unalterably opposed to the financial questionnaire devised by Newbold Morris and was prepared to resign if directed to send it to top officials of the Justice Department.

Asserting that recent developments have increased the possibility of a strike in the steel industry, the National City Bank of New York in its monthly letter on finance and economic conditions said that if the steel companies accede to the wage demands the increased cost must be passed on in higher prices for steel.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 3 (AP) -- Seven top-ranking Japanese Communists today were convicted of spying on United States occupation forces. There were sentenced to prison terms ranging from three to seven years at hard labor.

Vasily Zonov, a Soviet news expert, protested against the use of the term "Iron Curtain" in a document circulated by the United Nations because, he said, it had been coined by Joseph Goebbels, Nazi propaganda chief.

MILWAUKEE, April 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft's victory in the Wisconsin Presidential preference primary election yesterday was attributed today to the efficiency of his state organization, to his personal popularity and to the intensive campaign he waged for the support of the state's thirty Republican convention delegates.

OMAHA, Neb., April 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio demonstrated his powers by emerging victor today over the previous write-in champion, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, in Nebraska's Republican Presidential preference primary.

DETROIT, April 2 -- Richard T. Gosser, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., served notice tonight on the Wage Stabilization Board that the union was prepared to authorize strike action against the Borg-Warner Corporation unless the company agreed to speed disposition of the case, which has been before the wage board for almost six months.

VIENNA, Austria, April 2 (Reuters) -- The Austrian National Assembly adopted a resolution today protesting against the continued military occupation of the country, against military courts' still trying Austrians and against "economic exploitation" of Austria by the occupation powers.

PARIS, April 2 -- New difficulties of an undisclosed nature appeared tonight to have delayed formation of a new Cabinet in the French protectorate of Tunisia and to have dampened French hopes that the crisis would be resolved before the United Nations Security Council could begin consideration of the Tunisian complaint against the French administration.

Regina Taddia, an Argentine soprano who has been active in opera at the Teatro Colon, made her first New York appearance last night in Town Hall. Fritz Kramer was her accompanist in a program of songs by early Italian composers, operatic arias from "The Marriage of Figaro," "The Magic Flute," "L'Amico Fritz" and "La Boheme," and a group by South American composers.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 2 -- A warming sun brought a spring-like atmosphere to the Augusta National Golf Club course today, where seventy-two stars completed final practice for the start of the sixteenth Masters tournament tomorrow.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 3 (AP) -- Eighth Army communique 936, for Wednesday's operations:

The nation's gasoline stocks rose 2,035,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies at the week-end amounted to 149,631,000 barrels, a record, compared with 147,596,000 a week earlier and 142,433,000 a year ago.

MILWAUKEE, April 2 -- The proper use of insecticides to protect livestock from insect parasites would add more than a billion pounds of meat and several million quarts of milk to the annual production of vital food supplies, according to a report today at the spring meeting of the American Chemical Society.

TO thousands of salt-water anglers, the fishing season is not really under way until the first "Fishermen's Special" pulls out of Pennsylvania Station for Montauk, and the Long Island Rail Road has announced that the first of these trains would depart at 4:57 A. M. on May 17.

The statement of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York for the quarter ended March 31 showed deposits, loans and total resources less than at the end of 1951 but still above the figures reported a year ago.

The fur house of Aronowicz delights in doing the unusual discreetly. In its showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of spring and summer fur designs, it produced such novel and chic ideas as a cardigan sweater of bleached otter with white ribbed knit trim, elegant black broadtail, lavished with crisp white organdy trim and a hip length broadtail jacket wrapped in a manner suggestive of the modish middy line.

BUFFALO, April 2 -- Extradition of a former Army sergeant, accused in the slaying of his commanding officer behind enemy lines in Italy in 1944, would open the door to similar action against "millions" of United States service men suspected of offenses overseas, a lawyer asserted today.

" PISTOL PETE,"* by Frank Eaton, puts a lively lot of pages into our own Arthurian legend. It is the nostalgically rambunctious memoir of a man who was handy with a gun and a horse in the West's fabled days. Although Mr. Eaton -- known as Pistol Pete for the best of reasons -- is 91 years old now, he remembers clearly the name of every man he

Just fifteen years ago Dr. Bruno Kisch, a native of Prague and Professor of Physiological Chemistry at Cologne University, fled to escape Nazi persecution. He vowed he would never return, and settled in New York to become one of the world's foremost cardiologists.
CHICAGO, April 2 (UP) -- Johnny Lujack blew the whistle today on a football career which brought him All-America honors at Notre Dame and all-pro praise with the Chicago Bears.

ATHENS, April 2 -- Some progress toward the formation of a broadly based National Government to tackle pressing economic and social problems seemed to have been made today when both the Progressives of Premier Nicholas Plastiras and the Liberals of Deputy Premier Sophocles Venizelos expressed willingness to enter a coalition with the Greek Rally party of Field Marshal Alexander Papagos.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 2 -- The American Zionist leader, Dr. Emanuel Neumann asked Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion today: "Has Diaspora Zionism [Zionism in countries other than Israel] fallen so far short of its expected performance that it is in your eyes more of a hindrance than a help?"
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- New light on the inequality of urban incomes in the Soviet Union has become available here in a wealth of data in Soviet publications acquired recently by the Labor Department.

TRENTON, April 2 -- With Essex County opposition cleared, the New Jersey Assembly passed three measures today to set up a state highway authority to construct the Garden State Parkway as a north-south toll link to seashore resorts.

ALBANY, April 2 -- The new president of the State University of New York, Dr. William S. Carlson, said today he felt certain the fight between the university trustees and the Board of Regents over control of the state-supported colleges and institutes was "a thing of the past."

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands and her husband, Prince Bernard, landed today from a sunny spring sky in a Royal Dutch Airlines DC-6, "The Flying Dutchman," and opened a new chapter of social history in the White House.

Joe Meek, trapper, Indian fighter, pioneer peace officer and frontier politician, is the subject of a new biography by Stanley Vestal, which Caxton Printers of Caldwell, Idaho, will publish April 15 under the title "Joe Meek, The Merry Mountain Man."

The first public financing in behalf of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company in its sixty-eight years of business was undertaken yesterday in the marketing of an issue of $40,000,000 of sinking fund debentures through a nationwide banking syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today the nomination of David N. Edelstein to be a Federal district judge in New York. Mr. Edelstein, a former Assistant Attorney General in charge of customs, has been serving under a recess appointment.

Frank Costello, on trial for contempt because he refused to answer some questions of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, listened glumly yesterday in Federal Court as Judge Sylvester Ryan remarked that part of the gambler's trouble came from having "talked too much" before the committee.

Mrs. David Rumsey of New York gave a luncheon yesterday in the Ritz-Carlton Restaurant of the Carlton House. Her guests included Mrs. John Hubbard, Mrs. J. Henry Lienau, Mrs. Frederick S. Wombwell, Mrs. C. Carroll Carpenter, Mrs. Pennington Satterwaithe, Mrs. Hoppin Pool, Mrs. Arthur Ryle, Mrs. Clement Biddle of Philadelphia, Mrs. Leonard P. Morgan, Mrs. O. DeLancey Coster, Miss Elaine Ulman and Mrs. Richard Newton.

The future of the United Nations depends on the outcome of the "cold war," Emanuel R. Freedman, foreign news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday. Its fortunes, he said, will rise in direct ratio to any improvement in the political climate between Washington and Moscow.
PARIS, April 2 -- There is every indication that the highly touted Moscow International Economic Conference which opens tomorrow has died stillborn.

From the land of tulips -- and cocoa -- New York had a visitor this week. J. C. Droste, grandson of the founder and now co-managing director with his brother of the Droste cocoa and chocolate plant in Haarlem, Holland, was displaying old and new products imported here by H. Hamstra Co.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill requiring that New York City police records relating to delinquent children be kept in files separate from those of adult offenders and open to inspection only by designated persons or authorities.

Business men were assailed for timidity and lack of confidence yesterday by W. W. Wachtel, president of Calvert Distillers Corporation. Business during the second half of this year can be better than the first half if advertising budgets are increased enough to win a larger part of a huge untapped market, he declared.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 2 -- A General Motors executive said here today that efficient handling of materials is the "last frontier of cost reduction" and represents the greatest potential for profit left in business.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, April 3 -- About 30,000 Western Union employes throughout the nation went on strike this morning to force a pay rise and the company "temporarily" shut down its telegraph and money order services.
In the last-minute rush of legislation in Albany an important measure on highway financing failed to receive the attention it deserved.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -Harry S. Truman will be left ungarded the minute he steps down as President and returns to private life.
Several million American families of moderate incomes have suffered an average loss of 4 per cent in their living standards since the beginning of Communist aggression in Korea on June 25, 1950.

Wearable and versatile clothes selected expressly for women who work were shown yesterday by Saks 34th on the fourth floor. The fashion show was presented at noon for the convenience of career girls who have only a limited time in which to catch up on the latest spring styles.

SYRACUSE, April 2 -- Incredibly, the New York Knickerbockers overcame a 16-point deficit, a tremendous trick on the road, and defeated the Syracuse Nationals, 87 -- 85, tonight in the first game of the best-of-five National Basketball Association semi-final playoff series.

Five thousand copies of a "fact sheet" folder giving details on the present status of appropriations affecting the school lunch program have just gone out to all parts of the country from headquarters of Spokesmen for Children, Inc., 654 Madison Avenue.

Today's new film is "Anything Can Happen," Paramount's adaptation of the book by George and Helen Papashvily, starring Jose Ferrer and featuring Kim Hunter, Kurt Kasznar, Eugenie Leontovich and Oscar Karlweiss, at the Mayfair.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 2 -- A crucial stage has been reached in the indemnity conference of West Germans, Israelis and world Jewish groups here.

HONG KONG, April 2 -- About 10,000,000 persons are now suffering from schistosomiasis in more than 100 counties and municipalities of Kiangsu, Chekiang, Anhwei and Fukien provinces in East China, according to a Chinese Communist health official.

LONDON, April 2 -- British ship-owners, shipbuilders technical institutions and Lloyd's Register are jointly seeking a new method of measuring the tonnage of merchant ships, Viscount Runciman said here today in an address to the spring meeting of the Institution of Naval Architects.

Fifteen children ventured into the strange and awesome world of a French hotel chef yesterday. They walked past ear-high banks of fiery-hot iron stoves and observed with marked interest baskets of slow-moving, green lobsters and a frosty room filled with steaks and roasts and plucked fowl.

The third in Wanamaker's series of informal luncheon fashion shows took place yesterday in its ninth-floor dining room. Early spring and Easter costumes for misses, junior and half-size women were shown.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- A Cleveland machine tool builder urged today that manufacturers be allowed rapid tax write-offs of machine tool purchases.

LOS ANGELES, April 2 -- Assessing the results of the voting in Wisconsin and Nebraska, Paul G. Hoffman, co-chairman of the Advisory Committee to the Citizens Committee for Eisenhower, said today that one fact must not be overlooked:

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 2 -Colombia is in a state of suspended animation. Something must happen soon, but nobody can say whether it will be good or bad. However, the economic situation is improving in striking fashion and banditry at least is being held down.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Barring last-minute snags, the Federal Communications Commission will lift its ban on new television station construction within two weeks, Paul A. Walker, commission chairman, said today. The ban has been in effect since Oct. 1, 1948.
FORT WORTH, Tex., April 2 (AP) -- The airlines and the men who run the nation's airports have complained that the Air Force is trying to "put the lid on" civil aviation in many communities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -Mario Lanza will tackle the Sigmund Romberg operetta "The Student Prince" as his second and final film for the year at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. Joseph Pasternak, who produced the singer's newly completed "Because You're Mine," also will be in charge of the next picture, which has a new screen play written by Sonya Levien and William Ludwig.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Public Housing Administration advised seventy-three local housing authorities in twenty-four states today to postpone the sale on April 15 of $167,093,000 of new housing authority bonds.

Although the anti-trust division of the Justice Department believed the price - maintenance agreements of investment banking syndicates to be illegal, they did not want to take the consequences of putting the nation's financial machinery in a state of chaos by a direct attack on the syndicate system, Judge Harold R. Medina asserted in Federal Court here yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed at about the best levels of the day, with active months 25 to 52 points higher than on Tuesday.
Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman of New York was re-elected president of the National Horse Show Association for his fifth term at the association's dinner meeting at the Brook Club last night.

The squabble between Attorney General McGrath and Newbold Morris, the Justice Department's investigator into corruption, has now reached a point where the President almost certainly has to choose between them. At least, he has to choose if he is really serious -- as we believe he is -- about uncovering any evidence of wrongdoing within the executive branch of the Government.

BONN, Germany, April 2 -- The integration of West Germany into the European community is being seriously delayed because, among other reasons, the European Command of the United States Army in Germany refuses to give up some of its occupation privileges.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 2 ( ) -- First-round matches went according to form in the Everglades Club invitational tennis tournament today except for an upset victory by John Bush and Victor Brady of Yale over Tony Vincent and Frank Hart of Miami, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 --4.

CINCINNATI, April 2 -- Five hundred staff members of The Cincinnati Enquirer have pledged a total of $840,000 in a five-day campaign as the first step in an effort by the staff to buy that morning newspaper.

LONDON, April 2 -- Sharp rises in many industrial shares enlivened business on the Stock Exchange here today. Although rises were not accompanied by any marked expansion of business, dealers reported distinct broadening of interest.

A tract of forty-two acres in East Northport, formerly used as a polo field, has been sold by the Pendele estate to Cedar Hills Park, Inc., builders, for improvement with 170 dwellings. The property is on Bellemore Avenue, two blocks west of Larkfield Road.

The annual report of Gladding, McBean Co. and subsidiaries, manufacturers of clay building products, was presented yesterday by Fred B. Ortman, the president. It showed a net income of $1,585,000, equal to $3.02 a share, for 1951. This compared with $1,702,000, or $3.24 a share, in 1950.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- By a vote of 50 to 35, the Senate passed today a bill designed to give coastal states clear title to the rich oil deposits beneath their marginal seas, despite repeated Supreme Court rulings that the Federal Government had "paramount rights" to the submerged lands.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -- The Defense Department today announced a new total of 106,956 Korean battle casualties, an increase of 162 over last week's report.

In separate sealed bidding transactions yesterday, the Interstate Power Company sold an issue of $2,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and awarded a contract for the underwriting an offering of 345,833 of new common shares to the utility company's stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 26:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- Sir Herbert Broadley, deputy director of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, warned today that unless adequate help was forthcoming to check the plague of locusts now afflicting the Middle East, the tide of insects would sweep back toward its point of origin in Ethiopia and devastate areas as far south as Central Africa.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, manager of the campaign to make General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower the Republican Presidential nominee, emplaned at Idlewild Airport yesterday for a conference with General Eisenhower in Paris tomorrow.

Gross operating revenues of the American Cable and Radio Corporation system last year were the highest in the company's history, Ellery W. Stone, president, said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders. The revenues aggregated $25,360,012, compared with $22,095,138 in 1951.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 2 (UP) -- Scoring twice in the top half of the eighth to break a 1-1 tie, the Phillies downed the Braves, 3 to 1, today and snapped a five-game losing streak.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- The United Nations Security Council was called upon today to take up the "deteriorating situation" in Tunisia on the ground that it is a threat to international peace and security.

Eight Pennsylvania Railroad employes were arrested yesterday by postal authorities on charges of stealing $100,000 in watches, jewelry and cameras since last October. Charged with the systematic looting of parcel post packages, the men were held in $5,000 bail each by United States Commissioner Edward McDonald.

" Vigilance" was the watchword yesterday at the opening of the two-day session of the marine section of the National Safety Council, which is meeting at the Statler Hotel in conjunction with the twenty-second annual Greater New York Safety Convention and Exposition.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 2 (AP) -- The scene of a resumed hearing of the Government's anti-trust suit against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., shifts tomorrow to Atlantic City.
Two aggressive, hard-playing contract bridge teams last night battled it out in forty-board final match for the Reisinger Cup Eastern States team of four championship.

The $3,000 Prix de Rome Fellowship, the second to be granted by the American Academy of Arts and Letters, has been awarded to William Styron of Newport News, Va., and this city, author of "Lie Down In Darkness." The fellowship, which becomes effective in October, enables the winner to live at the American Academy in Rome for one year.
LONDON, April 2 -- Between 6,000,000 and 8,000,000 Britons will begin voting tomorrow to elect members of hundreds of city, county, town and rural district councils throughout the country.

A grim picture of the toll of death and destruction on the highways, "rising as surely as the morning sun" unless the public displays more skill, sense and respect for the law, was drawn here yesterday by Commissioner James R. McDuff of the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Treasury agents told a House subcommittee today that Daniel A. Bolich spent at least $61,817 more than he earned as a top Federal tax official from 1946 through 1950.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today pick-up and delivery charges by Eastern railroads on shipments coming from or going to points outside official territory, when the shipments travel 300 miles or less.

The National City Bank of New York announced yesterday that at the end of last month the combined total resources of the bank and its affiliate, City Bank Farmers Trust Company, were $6,024,000,000, of which the bank accounted for $5,884,000,000.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 2 -- The difficulties in applying the Group Areas Act that caused India to indict South Africa before the United Nations have induced the Nationalist Government to put forth a bill amending the act, which created machinery for dividing South African cities into racial zones for exclusive white, black, Asian and colored (mixed blood) occupation.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Initial prices in grain futures on the Board of Trade were off fractions this morning, but after the overnight accumulation of selling orders was executed pressure lessened and there was recovery all around. Commission buying cushioned the early selling and there was also buying by commercial interests of both wheat and corn.

The change of seasons, a quarterly show staged by nature to present an ever-new variation of an old old theme, having successfully survived its out-of-town tryouts, is now preparing to make its bow in the city.

Detectives of the East Fifty-first Street station admitted rather reluctantly last evening that they had been working since 9:40 A. M. Tuesday on the theft of jewelry with a retail value of $67,000 from a showcase on the main floor of Saks-Fifth Avenue. The wholesale value of the gems was given as $33,543.
William Sutton, the bank robber, was sentenced in County Court in Brooklyn yesterday to serve two separate terms of fifteen years to life for Sullivan Law offenses.

The American Bureau of Shipping's committee on naval architecture has reported that further strengthening of the T-2 type tankers is necessary to safeguard against repetition of recent casualties to this type vessel.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- George F. Kennan, the Government's expert on Russia, was sworn in today as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union and at once expressed the hope that his work in Moscow would contribute to "the reduction of existing tensions and the improvement of the international atmosphere."

A pair of Midwestern primary victories in Nebraska and Wisconsin raised the Republican Presidential hopes of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today and demonstrated to his opponents that they could have beaten him if united.

BALTIMORE, April 2 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Glenn L. Martin Company, aircraft builders, today authorized increasing its common stock from 1,509,000 to 3,000,000 shares to provide additional financing.

With 16,000 employes in the telephone installation and sales divisions of the Western Electric Company set to strike on Monday in forty-three states and the District of Columbia, a Federal mediator yesterday called company and union officials to a meeting here today.
The Metropolitan Museum will hold a preview of the work of Paul Cezanne for members and guests this evening and will open an exhibition to the public tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Following is the 50-to-35 roll-call vote by which the Senate late today passed the bill giving the states clear title to lands beneath the marginal seas:

TOKYO, Thursday, April 3 -- United Nations and Communist generals met in a sub-delegation session today, for the first time in two months in the Korean truce talks at Panmunjom, to discuss terms for enforcement of an armistice. They immediately found themselves involved in the same deadlock that has thwarted agreement previously.
The Citizens Union filed a suit in Supreme Court yesterday seeking to bar Robert J. Crews from the $9,000 lifetime position of Deputy Commissioner of Records of the City Court.

Arthur W. Wallander, city Director of Civil Defense, reminded New Yorkers yesterday that the sounding of the air raid sirens at 7:45 o'clock tonight would be the signal for a training exercise for defense workers in which the general public was not expected to take part.
New York City yesterday pledged enthusiastic official support of the nationwide drive to raise $800,000 to finance full United States participation in the 1952 Olympic games at Helsinki.

A scene savoring of the Eighteen Seventies, when "The Savoyards" was incorporated to perform the comic operas of Gilbert and Sullivan, was re-enacted yesterday in the chambers of Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill providing that the exemption from unemployment insurance coverage given to religious, charitable, scientific, literary or educational organizations might not apply to an employer whose primary activity was the productions of plays for the entertainment of the public.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The American Government and people are certain to give a particularly warm and hearty welcome to a royal visitor from a country which in good days and bad has always been a valued friend and ally. The visitor is Juliana, Queen of the Netherlands, who, accompanied by her husband, Bernhard, Prince of the Netherlands, and her Foreign Minister, Mr. Stikker, is making her first formal state visit to this country.

A collection of pieces made in Mexico, a country just entering the field of contemporary furniture design, has arrived at the new Edmond J. Spence showroom, 46 East Seventy-third Street, where it will be available through decorators after April 15.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Truman asked Congress today to appropriate $200,000 for a program of experiments with the new anti-tuberculosis drug isonicotinic acid hydrazide. The fund will be administered by the Public Health Service.
The City Planning Commission selected yesterday the site for the projected new Mid-Brooklyn High School, which will be the first new high school to be built in the city since 1942.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- Photographs published by the Chinese Communists as "proof" of the use of germ warfare by the United States were exposed today as complete frauds.

PARIS, April 2 -- Premier Antoine Pinay staked his Cabinet's life today and won in three successive skirmishes with the National Assembly over his finance program. He won by the comfortable margins of 363 to 224 on the first issue, by 387 to 219 on the second and by 370 to 207 on the third vote.

Elaine Fifield had the central role in "Coppelia" last night for the second time with the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet at the Warner Theatre, and again made a charming job of it. It is a role that must be not only danced but mimed, and not only mimed but played, and Miss Fifield does it most endearingly.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 -- The Yankees ended their 1952 exhibition campaign in St. Pete today under a cloudless sky, but the day otherwise brought very little sunshine into the life of Casey Stengel.

The grocery bill -- at wholesale, at least -- is continuing to drop. At least some of the latest decreases, which put the index compiled by Dun Bradstreet at its lowest figure since the Korean outbreak in June, 1950, will percolate to the retail level in the near future.
PEARL HARBOR, April 2 (AP) -- The Navy said today the submarine Pickerel had surfaced in recent tests at a forty-eight-degree angle, one of the steepest ever attempted.

BALTIMORE, April 2 -- Backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower got their foot into the legal door today that for fifteen years had been assumed to prevent write-in votes for Presidential candidates at Maryland primaries.

Early morning mail box collections in upper Manhattan and the Bronx have been eliminated by the Post Office Department without notice to the public, Philip Lipper, president of Branch 36, National Association of Letter Carriers, charged yesterday at a stormy protest meeting of 1,500 mailmen here.

A long-smoldering dispute between officials and employes of Youth House, the city's detention shelter for delinquent boys at 331 East Twelfth Street, has resulted in the suspension of five employes, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today he thought Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia was unnecessarily disturbed about the forthcoming talks on Trieste by the United States, Britain and Italy.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's first annual report to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization published yesterday is a balance sheet of a year of effort, with the Allies still in the red but by no means hopelessly so.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Members of the Senate Finance Committee noted rising opposition today to a pending Administration proposal to give the Treasury Department "discretionary authority" to exempt from duty imports valued up to $10.

LONDON, April 2 (Reuters) -Newcastle United, holder of the British Soccer Cup, entered the Cup final for the second year today by defeating Blackburn Rovers, 2 -- 1, in their semi-final replay at Leeds.

John M. Murtagh, now Chief Magistrate, was described as "apparently quite jubilant" at the outcome of the New York County grand jury investigation which cleared him of the charge of being criminally derelict in the performance of his duties while Commissioner of Investigation under former Mayor William O'Dwyer.

Major changes will take place in the Sunday afternoon program line-up of the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network on April 20 with the cancellation of "Television Workshop," the "Quiz Kids" and "Where Do You Stand."

DENVER, April 2 -- Monte Irvin, the potent force in the Giants' baseball fortunes, suffered a compound fracture f the right ankle today and may be lost to the National League champions for the 1952 season.
The 750 passengers on a cruise aboard the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam missed the sights of Havana but were $40,000 richer when they debarked from the vessel in Hoboken early yesterday.

Four youngsters sat in the seats of honor at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and heard their seniors say, "Well done!" The occasion was the presentation of the Exchange's sixth annual awards to the officers of the Junior Achievement companies that produced the best annual reports. It was held in the board of governors' room of the Exchange.

Rubber, sugar and soybean oil prices advanced in yesterday's commodity futures markets. Cottonseed oil was mixed but generally higher, following cotton. Other leading commodities showed losses in New York futures markets.

BONN, Germany, April 2 -- A Bundestag Committee reported today on "the great number and horrible living conditions" of German youths under 18 years of age serving in political prisons in East Germany and the Soviet Union.
CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- The Government's $2,302,701 tax claim against the bankrupt Tucker Corporation was settled today for $245,948. Federal Judge Michael Igoe approved the settlement.

Seeing Eye Dog Is Beside the 28-Year-Old, Who Expects to Do Trial Work Just seven years ago yesterday, John Sirignano Jr. was blinded when an enemy artillery shell exploded on a battlefield in Grunfeld, Germany.

Hannibal staged a strong finish to win the Experimental Free Handicap No. 1 at Jamaica yesterday.
