The 3-year-old son of Roman carried the top weight of 119 pounds, most of which was made up of a jubilant Willie Passmore, and the margin of victory was the slim one of a neck over the Apheim Stable's Quiet Step.

Maureen Connolly, Shirley Fry, Doris Hart and Mrs. Nancy Chaffee Kiner were named to the United States Wightman Cup team yesterday. They will play the British women tennis players in the annual international competition at Wimbledon, June 13 and 14.

Nine-year-old Santiago Borda of 141-33 Seventy-eighth Avenue, Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, who lost the sight of his left eye in a bicycle accident last March 15, returned to Public School 164 yesterday to find that his elementary schoolmates had made him a living example of their studies, in brotherhood.

The official opening of the "Parade of Stars" automobile show was delayed fifteen minutes at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday afternoon because of the appetites of a group of uninvited guests. While the exhibition was being assembled to occupy the grand ballroom, a luncheon party installed in the same quarters lingered over the wine and walnuts.

Most advertisements of retail furriers not only fail to supply the information most wanted by the public but in some cases are in direct violation of Federal Trade Commission's rulings. This is the conclusion reached by Mrs. Karen R. Gillespie, Associate Professor of Retailing at New York University, after a study of seventy-three fur ads in five New York newspapers.

Statistics were the chief witnesses in a long pre-trial argument yesterday in Federal Court, where sixteen secondary Communist party leaders are facing trial on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

One hundred wheel-chair cases, paraplegics and crutch-using members of the Federation for the Handicapped will give a pint of blood each for war wounded next Tuesday afternoon at Federation Headquarters, 241 West Twenty-third Street, the institution announced yesterday.

HAVANA, April 2 -- Temporary relief from the excessive and arbitrary demands of organized labor that have caused capital to refrain from further investments in Cuba is expected by United States business men as one of the results of Maj. Gen. Fulgencio Batista's coup.
LONDON, April 2 -- Britain apparently has decided not to make any public declaration of concessions to Egypt in advance of the negotiations between the two countries.

The stock market took its cue yesterday from an upsurge in petroleum issues on the Canadian exchanges as well as a burst of strength in the same division on the New York Curb Exchange. The higher course in the oils on the Stock Exchange here found no counterpart in other sections, aside from rails.

SOUTH SALEM, N. Y., April 3 -- Fifty miles from their schools in New York City, on a sprawling 300-acre farm in the northeast part of Westchester County, city youngsters are learning that the great outdoors can be a giant classroom.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 3 -- The Netherlands opened today a roundtable conference with her former colonies in the Western Hemisphere, Surinam (Dutch Guiana), and the Netherlands Antilles (formerly Curacao), to lay the juridical basis for a reformed kingdom comprising three independent and autonomous parts united in a sort of supercabinet.

Field Marshal Sir William Slim, Chief of the British Imperial General Staff, gave assurances here yesterday that the morale of British forces was "absolutely first-class" and that of the British people the same as always.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- February cash dividends by United States corporations issuing public reports were 15 per cent below those of the comparable month of last year, according to the Department of Commerce.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 3 -- By establishing new exchange controls recently the Thai Government appears to be in the process of closing down the only free currency market in Asia outside of Hong Kong.
Except for wool, which followed foreign markets, and coffee, which surged upward on a burst of Brazilian buying, prices in the New York commodity markets were generally lower or mixed yesterday.

In three new strategic appointments announced last night at City Hall Mayor Impellitteri continued his policy of giving top patronage recognition to the city's regular Democratic organizations that opposed him for election in his 1950 campaign.

THE Giants are in trouble. They are in desperate trouble. Monte Irvin did more than shatter his ankle the day before yesterday. He virtually splintered Giant pennant hopes for the season, a short eleven days away. The large and muscular Monte was the powerhouse of the Polo Grounds machine. He was their key man, the fellow who drove in the runs.

The abrupt dismissal of Newbold Morris by Attorney General McGrath, and Mr. McGrath's own subsequent resignation from the Cabinet, will take their places among the most bizarre acts of this or any other Administration.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- During the week ended April 2, member bank reserves decreased $464,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Studebaker Corporation has arranged to borrow $100,000,000 from fifteen banks headed by Chase National Bank on a V-loan revolving credit for financing defense contracts, Harold S. Vance, Studebaker board chairman, said yesterday. The credit is the largest single borrowing yet negotiated under the Defense Production Act.

" One Bright Day" will leave the Royale after Saturday night of next week. Despite the short engagement of twenty-nine performances, the author, Sigmund Miller, who made his Broadway debut with this play, must realize that the producers, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, lavished all their affection and know-how on the attraction to give the new playwright a chance.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Senate voted today to raise veterans pensions and disability payments by $173,000,000 a year to meet the increased cost of living.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- A House Interior Subcommittee approved a bill today which members said would authorize Anchorage, Alaska, to increase its bonded indebtedness to $1,000 for every man, woman and child in the city.

The new $19,000,000 Owls Head Pollution Control Plant in Brooklyn was opened formally yesterday, assuring New Yorkers of cleaner water at Coney Island, in the Narrows, and at the south shore beaches of Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The National Education Association reported today that the teacher shortage in the country's elementary schools had become worse, with only one qualified candidate available for every five classroom positions to be filled.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended March 29, 1952, totaled 725,423 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 5,502 cars, or 0.8 per cent more than for the preceding week, 30,012, or 4 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 5.019, or 0.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Retailer opposition to that part of the Customs Simplification Bill granting a degree of tariff exemption on single entries of imported articles valued up to $10 was discounted by importers yesterday as unlikely to affect eventual passage of the measure, aimed at cutting red tape.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The text of Queen Julian's address before a joint session of Congress:

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that Democratic candidates for Presidential and Vice Presidential electors in Alabama could legally be required, before they could run on the party ticket in the primary, to pledge that if chosen as electors at the general election they would cast their votes for the nominees of the Democratic national convention.
Jacob Blaustein, president of the American Jewish Committee, warned last night that hatemongers were attempting to divide the country along racial and religious lines in the current election.

It is relevant for the defense in the investment banking anti-trust suit to question a non-defendant banker about his syndicate practices, because the Supreme Court has held that in a nover-all conspiracy case it is relevant to find out how persons other than the defendants met common problems.

Assistant United States Attorney Roy M. Cohn asserted yesterday that witnesses before a Federal grand jury had testified that District 65, International Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America, unaffiliated, posted bonds for convicted Communist leaders and lost $80,000 in forfeited bail when four of them became fugitives.
Investment banking syndicates are offering new issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $11,450,000. The offerings are as follows:
Seasonal influences in the past week brought about the largest reduction in loans to business and industry by New York City banks since April, 1949.

John De Venuta, accomplice of William Sutton and Thomas Kling in the robbery of almost $64,000 from the Sunnyside branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company in Queens two years ago, pleaded guilty yesterday in Queens County Court to second-degree robbery.

Justin R. Toomey and Fred M. Fountain Jr. have formed Toomey-Fountain, Inc., a mortgage brokerage concern, with offices at 200 Main Street, Hackensack, N. J. Mr. Toomey formerly was secretary of the Northern New Jersey Mortgage Associates and Mr. Fountain is a grandson of Charles S. Fountain, who founded the realty firm of Fountain Sons in Hackensack in 1875.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands, speaking today before the Congress of the United States, advocated world cooperation "as intimate as that among the cells of one body" and even at the cost of sacrifices that involved sovereignty.
For the first time since Nov. 14, 1945 -- and for one of the few times in history -- volume on the New York Curb Exchange climbed above that of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
From Washington come reports that the White House has asked the Department of Justice to be prepared to advise President Truman on his powers to "seize" the steel industry in the case of a strike.

NEWARK, April 3 -- Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, announced here tonight that plans have been completed for a $6,000,000 marine terminal development on the south side of Port Newark Channel and along Newark Bay, to be completed in the spring of 1954.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 3 -- Principals of the four public schools of District 1 here rose in protest today against recurring charges by a citizens committee that "Communist infiltrations" were undermining the schools.

PARIS, April 3 -- The Government crisis in France's troubled North African protectorate of Tunisia went into its second week today with the pro-French Premier still unable to form a Cabinet and the country's nominal ruler taking action interpreted as withdrawal from political affairs.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, gave Congressional Atomic Energy Committee members an optimistic report today on a new and controversial atomic cannon.

ALBANY, April 3 -- Governor Dewey signed today three bills that completed his administration's program for narcotics control. The bills are designed to promote high school education on the evils of addiction and further restrict the possession and transportation of narcotics.

The New York Postmaster and the president of the local carriers' union clashed yesterday on interpretation of an "experimental" schedule that calls for later mail collection trips north of 125th Street. The effect of it is that Monday mail from that area that previously had reached its destination on Tuesday now arrives on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Reaction in official quarters to today's swift developments in the Government's stalled investigation into corruption ranged from stunned surprise to expressions of gratification that the air had been cleared and the way opened for the beginning of a formal inquiry.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was slightly easier yesterday and final prices were 10 to 33 points net lower.

CLEVELAND, April 3 -- Presidents of forty-seven Ford locals of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., adopted a resolution today supporting establishment of an administratorship over Ford Local 600 at the Detroit River Rouge plant.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Labor troubles in general and the Western Union strike in particular put a damper on speculative activity in grains today. There was not much inclination to take the initiative on either side. However, there was a fairly firm tone in wheat and corn early due to light offerings, but later the tone turned decidedly weak.

TOKYO, Friday, April 4 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, United Nations Commander, said today he believed some progress was being made in negotiations with the Communists for an armistice in Korea, with a compromise agreement still possible on major disputed issues.
Among the nearly fifty exhibitions this week deserving special attention from the gallery visitor are several group and one-man shows.

The New York Enquirer, a weekly newspaper published on Mondays but appearing on the street the day before, was sold last Monday to Generoso Pope Jr. after two months of negotiations. The announcement was made jointly yesterday by Mr. Pope and William S. Griffin, former editor and publisher. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

PHILADELPHIA April 3 -- Judge James P. McGranery of the United States District Court, newly designated Attorney General of the United States, indicated broadly this afternoon that he would not reappoint Newbold Morris as the Truman Administration's special investigator of corruption in Government.

As objections to the city's contemplated nuisance taxes flooded the offices of Council and Board of Estimate members yesterday a move grew among City Councilmen to seek alternative sources of revenue.

New Yorkers, who annually consume about 850 carloads of asparagus, now are savoring the first of this year's crop from California. The vegetable, as sure a sign of spring as the first robin, still is somewhat expensive in many stores, but with supplies increasing daily city-wide averages show a decline in price ranges (39-75 cents a pound last week to 23-59 cents this week).

ITHACA, N. Y., April 3 (AP) -- Henry Wittenberg, Olympic champion, opened his bid for an eighth National A. A. U. wrestling title tonight with a whirlwind victory over Robert Higgins of Pennsauken, N. J., at Cornell University.

A tax lien for $1,790,228, covering the years of 1942 to 1946, was filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court against Henry M. Garsson, former munitions manufacturer, of 806 Roosevelt Street, Far Rockaway, Queens. The assessment was filed by Denis J. McMahon, Collector of Internal Rev-District. It was explained that District.

The current rash of chlorophyll advertising, detailing the virtues of the green stuff and its derivatives in various products, is producing a counter-offensive by the Lambert Company, maker of Listerine Antiseptic. Lambert is scheduling a large-scale advertising campaign in local newspapers to tell of laboratory research backing up its assertion that Listerine reduces odor bacteria 95 per cent within fifteen minutes.

Thor Thors, Minister Pleipotentiary to the United States from Iceland for the last eleven years, is about to become what is probably the only triple-envoy in the Western world. A versatile man with an amazing amount of energy, he sailed last night aboard tthe Moore-McCormack liner Uruguay to present his credentials to the Brazilian and Argentine Governments.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- A slash of $4,240,638,500 in the $50,921,022,770 budget of the Department of Defense for the fiscal year starting July 1 was recommended to the House of Representatives today by its Appropriations Committee.

Human carelessness and panicky behavior in emergencies are the cause of almost all home accidents, the Home Safety Sessions in the New Yorker Hotel were told yesterday. Conducted by the Greater New York Safety Council, the meeting, entitled "Your Home -- Your, Family and You," was held in conjunction with the twenty-second annual Safety Convention and Exposition now in progress.

HAVANA, April 3 -- The Soviet Union broke off relations with Cuba late today because of the refusal of Cuban authorities to permit two Soviet couriers arriving here by plane from Mexico to enter the island with luggage unless inspected by customs authorities.
Victor H. Mardfin was elected a director of the Cuban Tobacco Company at the annual stockholders meeting held in Wilmington, Del., yesterday. Mr. Mardfin was elected through cumulative voting.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 3 (AP) -- Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore, the defending champion, was eliminated today but favorites in seven other matches triumphed in the second round of the annual Trans-Mississippi women's amateur golf tournament at the Arizona Country Club.

Good skiing will be available at a number of areas this week-end with the prospect for suntan sport most encouraging. Local enthusiasts, who have turned out heavily in recent weeks at Southern New England skilands, will have to travel once again for their activity.

The Most Rev. Joseph Alexander Fernandes, Archbishop of Delhi-Simla, India, received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Fordham University yesterday. The degree was presented by the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, university president, in the president's room on the Bronx campus.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are hundreds of students from foreign countries in the United States, and there could be many more. An increase in the number of these students could be effected by permitting them to earn their own way. This would mean relaxing restrictions on employment of foreign students who lack the money but not the will to gain technical education.

Under a nation-wide poll called "The Citizen's View of '52," American women of every political faith will have an opportunity to speak up on what they believe to be the issues of the 1952 Presidential campaign and to learn how the candidates for President stand on these issues.
MADISON, Wis., April 3 (AP) -- Stocky Bill Miller of Syracuse upset the 156-pound champion, Dick Murphy of Wisconsin, tonight to spark quarter-final action in the N. C. A. A. boxing tournament.

Greatly daring, the New York City Center Opera Company last night produced Alban Berg's "Wozzeck," thereby placing it for the first time in the repertory of an American opera company. The opera is, of course, one of the most important works in its field of the twentieth century, a work highly desirable to make available to the public, and long since overdue in that capacity in this city.

The State of Tennessee borrowed $5,000,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of bonds that were sold at competitive bidding to a banking syndicate headed by the National City Bank of New York. The bonds, sold at an interest cost of 1.451 per cent, will come due in 1962.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Under the 5-to-2 judgment of the Supreme Court today any State Legislature may empower a state political committee to require from any citizen, before he can stand for national elector in the party primary, a pledge that if successful in the primary and the subsequent general election he will cast his vote in the Electoral College for the nominees of the regular party convention.

MOSCOW, April 3 -- The International Economic Conference convened today in Moscow's refurbished Hall of Columns with about 350 delegates including one American, Oliver Vickery of San Francisco, in attendance.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 3 -- Breaking away from Jimmy McLane and John Marshall with a furious thrash up the last stretch, Ford Konno, Ohio States freshman marvel from Hawaii took the 1,500-meter free style tonight to become the first title winner of the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships.

PARIS, April 3 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, national chairman of the Eisenhower - for - President movement, flew into Paris from New York today. He told news men he would discuss politics with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Truman has declined to reverse the Loyalty Review Board of the Civil Service Commission in its decision that there exists "reasonable doubt" of the loyalty of John Stewart Service. Mr. Service has asked for Presidential reconsideration of this refusal.

If the records do not err, The Lighthouse Players' presentation last night of Noel Coward's "This Happy Breed" represented the first New York showing of the play. It is quite obvious, before much of the action is unfolded, that Mr. Coward demonstrates a great deal of admiration for the little people of the British Isles and their quiet and patient ways of facing up to life.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 3 -- The Syrian Government announced in Damascus today that under Decree No. 188, issued yesterday, the distribution of information bulletins issued by the United States Information Service, Tass, Soviet news agency and similar organs of foreign Governments must cease.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 -- Come television or advanced admission prices, the public still will turn out for motion pictures when theatres offer the kind of entertainment that the people want to see. This is borne out by a 7 per cent increase in gross business for first-run theatres in Los Angeles during the first quarter of 1952.

From neighborhood candy makers, department stores and specialty shops come home-made style, mass-manufactured and imported candies and other Easter goodies to make this year's traditional chicken, egg, hen, bunny and basket more varied and exciting than ever.

BUENOS AIRES, April 3 -- Dr. J. Hortensio Quijano, the Vice President of Argentina, died early this morning at the age of 67 following a long post-operative illness. His death confronted President Juan D. Peron with a constitutional problem, unparalleled in Argentina, that may necessitate a new election for that post.
Wilbur H. Norton has been appointed president arid a member of the boawd of directors of th R. M. .Hollingshead Corporation, camden, N. J., manufacturer of maintenance chemicals.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I want to express my appreciation for your editorial note on March 24 concerning the recent formation of a Negro Labor Committee, on a national scale, to work for the more complete integration of Negroes in the ranks of organized labor.
A jury of nine men and three women will deliberate today the contempt case against Frank Costello, the gambler, without benefit of any summing up by the defense.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your interesting editorial comment of a few days ago on the Minnesota primaries you say "the real question is whether the Republicans want to nominate a winner." With somewhat undue innocence, the editorial writer seemed to consider this merely a rhetorical question. It isn't.

HONG KONG, April 3 -- A local peasant revolt that broke out in Hupeh Province under China's new "agrarian reform" structure has produced the Chinese Communist observation that "feelings of enmity" are "still strong," even in rural areas where the landlords have been eliminated and the land has been redistributed.

The Queen of a sturdy and self-reliant European people stood before Congress yesterday and pledged her nation to a policy of international cooperation in the interest of European unity, a Pax Atlantica and a free and democratic world.

The Palestine Economic Corporation, organized to channel American equity capital and "know-how" into Israel, has raised more than $7,000,000 through the sale of its common shares in the last four years, officials of the corporation said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- A dozen major railroads today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for a board investigation of the operations of Seatrain Lines, Inc., New York City.

Mayor Impellitteri, Grover Whalen and other local burghers were making preparations yesterday to welcome Queen Juliana to New Amsterdam Monday with a ticker-tape parade, a ceremony at City Hall and a civic luncheon for 700 guests at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A sharp increase of a nervous malady associated with distemper has stricken the dog world with sudden paralysis and death. Variable airborne viruses have affected dogs sniffing along the street and animals surrounded with the best home comforts, bringing sleepless nights to their owners.

MONTREAL, April 3 (UP) -- The surprising Boston Bruins took a 3-to-2 lead in the National Hockey League's semi-final Stanley Cup play-off series by defeating the favored Montreal Canadiens, 1 -- 0, tonight on a last-period goal by Jack McIntyre.

Representatives of Bolivian miners declared yesterday that Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, had "created a situation in which our producers may now have no other choice but to accept a price for tin which will not allow the operation of a large part of the Bolivian tin mining industry at minimum levels of a fair return and will force suspension of several units."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 3 -- Moslems were on strike here today at the side of Christians to preserve the special privileges of Christian churches in Lebanon.

THE angler who likes some solitude with his fishing has a better chance of finding it on some obscure trout stream, but the man who likes a change of pace will find a lot to interest him at Enfield Dam on the Connecticut River when the shad season opens on April 19.

LONDON, April 3 -- The drastic measures taken by Britain's Conservative Government in its five months in office, and by the other Commonwealth countries, have checked the alarming drain on the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves.

The decision of the Treasury to increase borrowings on Treasury bills by $200,000,000 caused some zigzagging of short-term yields in the market for Treasury securities yesterday. At the close, however, prices were little changed from Wednesday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 3 -- All persons connected with advertising should work for the prevention of advertising abuses under the excess profits tax as well as toward bridging the gap between American management and advertising agencies.

Ferenc Molnar, playwright, journalist and novelist of international renown, was eulogized yesterday by former associates in the theatre and the Hungarian government-in-exile, at a funeral service that several hundred persons attended.

The trend to lower deposits and total resources for the first quarter of this year over the figures at the end of 1951, although still higher than a yeara go, continued yesterday to characterize the March 31 New York City bank reports.
LONDON, April 3 -- Aneurin Bevan has answered in his own words some of the questions about himself, his political aims and his beliefs.

Leaders of the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., met in Detroit yesterday in "emergency" session to "review the bargaining situation" and to "perfect plans" for several strikes set for Monday morning.

The Pennsylvania Salt Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that it has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of 155,349 new shares of common stock to be offered to the company's stockholders through subscription rights.
GENEVA, April 3 -- European employers are putting up stronger and stronger resistance to cooperation with labor for the purpose of improving productivity in European industry.

The American Vegetarian Union, Inc., and the American Vegetarian party seemed as divided as split-peas yesterday, and in something of a stew, or ferment. Jesse Mercer Gehman, union president, mailed from his Paterson, N. J., headquarters copies of a recent union resolution denouncing the party vice presidential nominee Symon Gould.

The city breaks its own laws every day, and steadily throughout the day, in the smoke that belches out of Board of Transportation power plants. The eloquent news photograph -- enough to make any citizen mad -- which we published yesterday showed dense smoke emerging from stacks of the West Fifty-ninth Street plant that helps furnish power to subways.

A nation-wide strike -- the first since 1919 -- curtailed the operations of the Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday. By mid- afternoon the company said it had partly restored service between New York and each of thirty-nine major cities.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Because of sharp cutbacks in foreign-aid exports, the National Shipping Authority announced today the withdrawal from the emergency fleet by the end of June of all vessels carrying cargoes under the Mutual Security Program.

WASHINGTON, Apjril 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today affirmed the expulsion of the New York firm of R. H. Johnson Co. from membership in the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.

The first two days of spring brought much greenery to Miss Stella Kahn, an unemployed manicurist who lives at the Walcott Hotel, 4 West Thirty-first Street. Some people call it kale, others call it lettuce, broccoli, cabbage or even beans.
A 55-year-old postman who has given sixty-three pints of blood in the last twelve years pledged his sixty-fourth pint yesterday at a Red Cross blood donation rally in Times Square.

It was Robert Casadesus' evening last night at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert. His Suite for Orchestra, composed in 1938-1939, received its first performance, and he himself was the piano soloist in the Brahms B flat Concerto.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 3 (UP) -- An enraged Billy Meyer, vowing a "new deal" for his Pirates and urged by the club president, Branch Rickey, to "go the limit," fined Pitcher Bill Werle $500, sent him back to Pittsburgh under indefinite suspension and placed him on the waiver list today for having broken training rules.

New evidence that vitamins of the B complex enter directly into chemical actions by which the body defends itself against disease and the physical stresses of living was presented here yesterday at the annual scientific meting of the National Vitamin Foundation, Inc.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Truman said today he would not be a candidate for the Senate from Missouri nor would he be a candidate for the House of Representatives.

LONDON, April 3 -- Sir Wilfrid Ayre, a leading British shipbuilder, predicted today that gas turbines eventually would replace Diesel engines in merchant ships, quite possibly as a prelude to atomic propulsion.

LAMPASAS, Tex.; April 3 -- The 5,000 citizens of this city, one of the oldest cattle centers in the state, got a foretaste today of what it would be like to be "liberated" by a Communist-led force and restored to the status of a "republic."

MOSCOW, April 3 -- Izvestia, official Soviet Government newspaper, in a new bid for diplomatic amelioration of world tensions, expressed today the Soviet Union's readiness to solve "by peaceful means" all outstanding international questions.

Magic Rose Bush Not far from this island is a garden in which grows a magic rose bush. It is not a large garden; the bush is remarkable neither in size nor in shape, but there is no doubt that it a magic rose bush.

Three six-story apartment buildings housing 125 families at 1187-97 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx, have been purchased by an investor through Louis Forman, broker. Fitch Robinson, Inc., Brooklyn brokers, represented the buyer, and Leslie Handler, lawyer, acted for the sellers. The property was reported held at $510,000.

A move to compel institutions supported in part by city funds to make their facilities available to more Negro children requiring foster care gained yesterday when the City Council's general welfare committee unanimously approved a bill designed to end discrimination in the operation of child-welfare organizations.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Truman instructed Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, today to withhold from a Senate Appropriations subcommittee files it had requested on loyalty and security investigations of employes. The President indicated he wanted the policy to apply to all executive agencies.
" Inside Our Schools," the N. B. C.-Life Magazine series that has been studying the city's educational system, is in line for praise this morning.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "With a Song in My Heart," Twentieth Century-Fox's Technicolor musical biography of Jane Froman, starring Susan Hayward as the singer, is at the Roxy. Lamar Trotti wrote and produced the offering, which was directed by Walter Lang, Rory Calhoun, David Wayne, Thelma Ritter, Una Merkel and Helen Westcott are among the featured players.

LONDON, April 3 -- Under the cloud of Yugoslavia's displeasure, representatives of the United States, Britain and Italy met here today to discuss measures for closer collaboration among themselves in Zone A of Trieste, which is under British-American military administration.

MOBILE, Ala., April 3 -- The Dodgers and the Braves battled for three hours and twenty minutes through thirteen innings today before 10,503 persons, the largest crowd ever to attend a baseball game at Hartwell Field. A few thousand spectators were in the outfield from foul line to foul line.

The explosion of two atom bombs, one under water in the Upper Bay south of Governors Island and the other 2,500 feet in the air above a Bronx intersection, was simulated last night in the second city-wide drill for civil defense forces since World War II.
Tage Erlander, Swedish Premier, arrived by air yesterday for a two-week unofficial visit that will include conferences with President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

LONDON, April 3 -- The recent Soviet note on peace with Germany reflects the successful progress of the Western Allies' negotiations with the Bonn Government toward an equal sovereign status for West Germany, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today.
Vice Admiral Oscar C. Badger, Commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier and United States naval representative on the United Nations Military Staff Committee, will retire because of age on June 30.

An eight-car Brighton Beach express of the B. M. T. subway was delayed an hour and ten minutes in the evening rush period Last night when it became stalled on an incline near Manhattan Bridge because of a power failure at an undetermined place in the train.

Premier Pinay of France is beginning to pile up comfortable majorities in support of his plan to finance the budget without increasing taxes. He has adopted the technique of presenting his program to the National Assembly one article at a time, demanding a vote on each and stating that his Government will resign if any one of the proposals is defeated.

TANGIER, April 3 -- Cavalry and tanks reached this internationalized city today from Spanish and French Morocco Invited by the Committee of Control, they will remain as long as the committee believes their presence necessary to insure order.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued tonight by Newbold Morris, relating to his dismissal by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath as the Truman Administration's Government investigator:
The Dutch Government's Order of Orange-Nassau, with the rank of Commander, was awarded yesterday to Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, vice president and acting head of Columbia University.

Although the House-Senate conference is expected to agree on a compromise bill that would give the coastal states title to submerged lands off their shores, the consensus in the oil industry is that President Truman will veto such a measure.

For the first time in many weeks, beef steaks have disappeared from the list of week-end meat specials. Wholesale prices on beef are now at or near ceiling levels, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday. Sirloin steaks, averaging a nickel a pound more than last week, are now $1.15 a pound.

EDMONTON, Alberta, April 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Alberta Conservation Board, reporting on six applications for natural gas export permits, recommended yesterday that Westcoast Transmission Company Ltd., be permitted to pipe gas from northern Alberta's Peace River region to the Pacific Coast.
BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., April 3 (UP) -- The Saratoga grand jury is investigating whether James A. Leary, Republican leader, was "involved in the protection of gambling in the upstate resort center."
WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- Following is the chronology of Newbold Morris' two-month career as Government investigator:

SYRACUSE, April 3 -- Several near fights and a near riot marked the second National Basketball Association semi-final play-off game as the Syracuse Nationals evened the series tonight with a 102-92 victory over the New York Knickerbockers.

Andree Howard's "Assembly Ball" was presented here for the first time last night by the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet at the Warner Theatre. Not only the choreography but also the setting and costumes are of Miss Howard's creation, and, logically enough, are very much of a piece.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The organized clamor by Italians demanding Trieste could only occur with the sanction and acquiescence of the Italian Government. It is reminiscent of the mobs screaming in front of Il Duce's favorite balcony. It recalls the earlier tempests over Trieste and the grab of Fiume, engineered by the truculent d'Annunzio -- an event which presaged the aggressive Italian actions against Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, April 3 --De-! partment store sales in the United! States in the week ended iViarch 39 rose 13 per cent from saies in! ithe same period of last year, thei Federal Reserve Board reported{ today.

A large expansion of this country's atomic energy production capacity scaled to cost $5,000,000,000 over a period of several years has been planned for the near future, Gordon Dean, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, said here last night.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- John D. M. Hamilton, manager of the Taft-for-President campaign in Pennsylvania and other Eastern states, announced today that his organization would not sponsor any Taft write-in at the Pennsylvania primary April 22.

WHEN the young pastor of the Zenith Baptist Church died in 1916 things looked mighty tough for his family. Ider Singleton was a widow woman with five children and no money and lots of debts. The church members helped her a little; but some of them cheated her, too. People could be just as ornery in Zenith as anywhere else in the farming country of southern Missouri.

Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma declared here yesterday that his chances of winning the Democratic Presidential nomination had not been lessened by the popular victory of Senator Estes Kefauver over him in the Nebraska primary election on Tuesday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3 -- Ray Gafford of Dallas and Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., shared the lead at the end of the first round of the Masters Tourney at the Augusta National Golf Club today.
TOKYO, Friday, April 4 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,209, for Thursday's operations:
WHITE HOUSE STATION, N. J., April 3 -- Mrs. Corinthia E. Wean, 62-year-old victim of an unusual case of mistaken identity, died early today at her home here.

The Payten Realty Corporation, Oliver H. Payne, vice president, sold the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building for thirty-eight families on plot 90 by 102 feet at 155 East Seventy-second Street to an investigating client of Riker Co.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- In a strong denunciation of the Zionist movement in this country and throughout the world, Rabbi Elmer Berger, executive director of the American Council for Judaism, held that the distinguishing features of incipient totalitarianism were "screamingly apparent" in Zionism.

Many young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons are aiding in the plans for April tea dance and cocktail party for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery to be held on the afternoon of April 24 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.

The one-story commercial greenhouses on a plot 401 by 297 feet on Searington Road in Albertson, L. I., have been sold by Charles Futterman and Arthur Sloan to Joseph Urmston and Valentino Sarra. Mitchell Smith was the broker and title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company. The property is assessed at $50,500.

TRENTON, April 3 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll condemned today as "false and misleading," a charge by Richard G. Moser, former counsel to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, that his interest in the Atlantic City crime inquiry was apathetic.

Paul O'Dwyer charged yesterday that a New York County grand jury drew an "unfair inference" as to his role during attempts to have his brother, former Mayor William O'Dwyer, return here to testify in the inquiry into police corruption during the O'Dwyer administration.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, received official notice today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had filed a $2,000,000 libel-slander suit against him.

The golf season will begin tomorrow on the ten municipal golf courses. The Department of Parks said yesterday that the courses would be opened at 6 A. M. The clubhouses, with food facilities, locker and shower accommodations and other facilities will be opened at the same time.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Truman told his news conference today that he had not yet selected a successor to Charles E. Wilson, who has resigned as head of the Office of Defense Mobilization.

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., April 3 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet for the first time tomorrow in its permanent quarters here to consider a complaint against France's administration of her African protectorate of Tunisia.
Columbia opened its seventy-first baseball season and its first under Coach Johnny Balquist with a 5-3 victory over City College yesterday at Baker Field.

The new Constitution offered to the Sudanese by Great Britain after a year of discussion and drafting is an important step toward self-government. Under its terms, which will almost certainly be accepted by the present Legislative Assembly and confirmed by the new Parliament that is to be elected late this month, Sudan will have a largely elected legislature and a responsible Cabinet.

Adlai E. Stevenson, Governor of Illinois and potential Presidential candidate on the Democratic ticket, is the subject of a biography by Noel F. Busch, senior editor of Life magazine. Scheduled for early June publication by Farrar, Straus Young, the book will be titled "Adlai E. Stevenson."

The beginning of the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders was put off until next week, or possibly even later, as pre-trial arguments continued yesterday in the Federal Court House in Foley Square.
Steel wage negotiations collapsed yesterday and 600,000 unionized steel workers got orders to strike at 12:01 A. M. Wednesday.

A custom-made-like individuality and detail marked the Gothe designs shown yesterday by De Pinna at the Plaza Hotel. The collection, given over to afternoon and evening fashions, revolved about a late - spring - into - summer theme, providing glimpses of charming silk prints, gossamer tissue ginghams, silk organdies, marquisettes and chiffon.

Operating revenues and net earnings of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., established company records last year, Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager, announced yesterday, in the annual report to stockholders.

The volume of natural gas sold by the pipeline system of the Southern Natural Gas Company increased from 140,400,000,000 cubic feet in 1950 to 175,400,000,000 cubic feet in 1951, an increase of 25 per cent, Christopher T. Chenery, chairman, told stockholders in his annual report released yesterday.

Ted M. justified the confidence reposed in him by a plurality of the 25,962 fans at Jamaica yesterday. The 6-year-old horse, owned by Clarence Buxton, won the Mapleton Handicap under a nicely gauged ride by Eddie Arcaro.

ROCQUENCOURT, April 3 -- General Eisenhower will make a farewell tour of the North Atlantic Treaty area this spring to take his leave of the Allied troops he has commanded for more than a year and their civilian and political leaders.

LONDON, April 3 -- The stock markets were good all-round today although again rises flattered actual volume of business. However, some expansion of turnover took place and for British Government securities there was continued influx of small investment orders.

The springtime urge to purchase new cars pervaded the "Parade of Stars" automobile show yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The attraction of the 1952 models on display opened many purses among visitors who came to see, then paused to buy.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 -- Following the announcement yesterday that Jerry Coleman would be lost to the Yankees after May 2, the fortunes of the Bombers took a better turn as they broke camp today when it was admitted by the club that Dr. Bobby Brown, third baseman for the past five years, was expected to report before the start of the pennant race on April 15.
BONN, Germany, April 3 -- The Soviet Union does not regard the Western notes as a final rejection of its proposals on German unity Chancellor Konrad Adenauer assured the West German Bundestag today.

Despite training in defense against the atom bomb children are still uncertain as to whether they would react properly in case of an attack, members of a student panel participating in the New York Times Youth Forum, broadcast over WQXR, indicated yesterday.
Federal legislation "with teeth" was urged yesterday as the means of obtaining a satisfactory safety and health code for waterfront and maritime workers.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 3 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, began a three-day pre-primary drive today for the support of Illinois' sixty delegates to the party's convention opening July 7.

Stockholders of the Aluminum Company of America will be asked at their annual meeting in Pittsburgh on April 17 to approve the establishment of an employe stock option plan, the company reported yesterday.
DAYTON, Ohio, April 3 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee asserted here today that he expected an uphill battle for the Democratic Presidential nomination but that he was confident of victory.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 -- The chief of the United Nations World Health Organization said today that international control of bacteriological weapons was impossible.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Truman snapped up the resignation of Attorney J. Howard McGrath today shortly after Mr. McGrath had dismissed Newbold Morris, the Administration's corruption investigator.
The three Italian-born candidates in the 1950 Mayoralty election had yesterday their first joint speaking date since Vincent R. Impellitteri defeated Ferdinand Pecora and Edward Corsi.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Daniel A. Bolich of Brooklyn, former Assistant Commissioner of Internal Revenue, refused today to testify on his large outside income, his official decisions or his sponsors in Government on the ground that any answer "might tend to incriminate" him.

A criminal information charging state income tax frauds was returned yesterday in Special Sessions as a result of an eighteen-month investigation of an alleged plot to bilk the Board of Education on "oral contracts" for school repairs.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today it now appeared that 5 per cent more American cotton would be used this season than last.

PARIS, April 3 -- Premier Antoine Pinay today asked the National Assembly for a formal vote of confidence on the question of making the credits for reconstruction in his financing program conditional upon the outcome of a bond issue.

LAUREL, Md., April 3 (UP) -- Jockey Nick Shuk had the greatest riding day of his career today as he booted home five winners, including Arthur Pilate in the feature $5,000 alowance race before a crowd of 10,652 at Laurel Park.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, which operates the Museum of Non-Objective Painting, yesterday filed plans for a new seven-story cylindrical art museum to cost $2,000,000 on Fifth Avenue between Eighty-eighth and Eighty-ninth Streets. Frank Lloyd Wright is the architect of the proposed structure, plans for which were announced about a year ago.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 3 More than three thousand delegates began arriving here today for the State Republican convention tomorrow.

The Shell Oil Company expects its profit this year to be close to the 1951 earnings of $7.20 a share, based on the first two months of this year, H. S. M. Burns, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday.

LONDON, April 3 -- A quick jump from the saddle into the United States army awaits 19-year-old Gene Weymouth of Wilmington, Del., who will ride his own horse, Possible, in the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree Saturday.

WICHITA, Kan., April 3 -- The Giants arrived today without Monte Irvin after a gloomy ride from Denver during which the players tried in vain to avoid discussing the accident that resulted in a broken right ankle for the Negro outfielder yesterday.
DAYTON, Ohio, April 3 -- Senator Kefauver declined here today to accept a proposal by Senator Russell of Georgia for a "winner take all" race in Florida.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES as a great daily paper should make it a point to present to its readers in clear and simple language just what the treaties proposed by the U. N. could mean to the people of these United States -- namely, the Genocide Convention and the Covenant on Human Rights.

Victor Feldman sold to Rose J. Meyer the six-story apartment house for twenty-seven families on plot 50 by 100 feet at 1 Manhattan Avenue, northwest corner of 100th Street, for cash over mortgages amounting to $63.450 through Charles A. Salzman, Inc., broker.

BOSTON, April 4 -- The Far Eastern Association adopted a resolution at its annual business meeting today denouncing "partisan attacks" on Far Eastern experts because of their views. The association describes itself as "a nonpolitical organization devoted to scholarly study of the Far East."
Benny DeVito, owner of a lumber yard in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, has his own ideas on how to combat a crime wave, particularly when it is directed at him.

Maurice Naccache has sold the three-story building containing a store and two apartments at 37-05 Thirty-first Avenue Long Island City, Queens, to John Dodge. The Edward A. Dangler Company was the broker. The new owner plans to occupy the store for the sale of carpets and floor coverings.
SAVANNAH, Ga., April 4 (UP) -- Steve Ridzik, rookie right-hander, pitched a no-hit game today as the Phils shut out the Cardinals, 3 -- 0.

Operations last year of the Pepsi-Cola Company and its consolidated subsidiaries resulted in a net income of $2,632,181, equal to 45 cents a share on 5,752,005 shares outstanding, more than double the $1,271,919 or 22 cents a share earned in 1950.

Tied at one game each in their best-of-five series in the National Basketball Association playoffs, the New York Knickerbockers and Syracuse Nationals will meet at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.

George Araujo, lightweight contender from Providence, R. I., made an impressive New York debut last night in scoring a technical knockout over Charley Riley of St. Louis in the ninth round of a scheduled ten-rounder at the St. Nicholas Arena.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- A special committee of the Gas Industry Advisory Council today recommended keeping in effect an order restricting extension of natural-gas service in certain areas. The council advises the Petroleum Administration for Defense on gas matters relating to the defense mobilization.

The Five Fifty Corporation has sold the six-story apartment house at 550 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, to an investing client of Lennard Sons, Inc., brokers in the transaction. The property, containing thirty-five apartments and occupying a plot about 99 by 125 feet, is assessed at $215,000.

A teacher told employers in local manufacturing and service trades yesterday that giving fair and equal treatment as well as opportunity for advancement to the increasing number of Puerto Rican employes was good business.

Cottonseed oil turnover on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday broke all previous records with 1,569 lots of 60,000 pounds each. Prices crumbled under what appeared to be forced liquidation, reaching new lows for the season, but later recovered.

Almost half of all the whisky consumed in the United States today is bootleg, Ralph T. Heymsfeld, general counsel for Schenley Industries, Inc., told liquor men and state tax administrators yesterday. The high price of liquor is driving more and more people to tax-free, bootleg whisky, he said.

In bitter contrast to the fair words now emanating from Moscow is the continued reiteration of the big lie about the use of germ warfare by United Nations forces in Korea. This big lie may seem ridiculous to us and its repetition mere preposterous nonsense.

Action by the City Planning Commission on the selection of school sites disclosed the interesting bit of information that the city is about to build its first new high school in ten years. Children born during the depression years have been moving through the high school grades.
The 6,000-ton cruise liner Silverstar, operated by the Arnold Bernstein Shipping Company, will arrive here early next month to begin a series of ten ten-day cruises to Havana and Nassau via Miami.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 4 -- The Yugoslav Communist leaders' first synthesis of their theoretical and tactical ideas for transforming the country into what they believe will be a humanistic, socialist society, as opposed to what they describe as the degenerated, reactionary and power-drunk Soviet system, has made its long-awaited appearance.

If the defense program continues and the export volume remains at its current level, net earnings from operations this year of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad will slightly exceed those in 1951, William White, president, predicted yesterday.

Wagner's "Parsifal," which has become a ritual as much as it is an opera, returned last night to the Metropolitan Opera repertoire. It was absent last year, Rudolf Bing's first as general manager and those who cherish the work asked to have it back.
LOS ANGELES, April 4 (AP) -- A former St. Louis credit union official was in prison today, accused of flying to California with a suitcase full -- $185,500 -- of embezzled funds.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 4 -- Sal Maso of Paterson, president of the New Jersey State Building and Construction Trades Council, warned American labor today "to build its defenses" against what he called a national campaign by the nation's "real estate lobby" to wipe out public housing.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- The House of Representatives overrode protests today and ordered an investigation to determine whether educational and other tax-free organizations used their wealth to promote subversive activities.

PARIS, Saturday, April 5 -- France narrowly escaped a new Cabinet crisis last night when Premier Antoine Pinay was dissuaded from resigning and decided to ask for a formal confidence vote upon the fiscal amnesty for tax evaders that he regards as the keystone of his financial program to defend the franc.

The failure of spiritual strength to keep pace with the rapid development of material knowledge may seriously "distort" the fabric of American society, John Foster Dulles, former policy adviser to the Truman Administration on foreign affairs, warned last night.

LONDON, April 4 -- Lord Ismay, wartime military secretary to the Churchill Cabinet, took office as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today at a final meeting here of the organization's Council of Deputies.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of a speech by President Truman today at ceremonies commemorating the third anniversary of the signing of the North Atlantic Treaty:

Federal mediators working here and in Detroit failed yesterday to break the deadlock in negotiations between the Bell Telephone System and the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., which threatens to call out 57,000 telephone workers in several areas of the country Monday morning.

The last of the novelties scheduled by the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet was presented last night at the Warner Theatre. It is "Khadra," choreographed by Celia Franca to music from Sibelius' "Belshazzar's Feast" in decor and costumes by Honor Frost.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 4 -- New York University used four pitchers in toppling Princeton, 4 -- 2, on three hits today at University Field in a game that was called on account of darkness after seven innings.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- An intercollegiate athletic reform program, striking at "snap courses," athletic scholarships and over-emphasis on winning, today was unanimously approved by the nation's most powerful academic accrediting agency.

Mrs. Margaret Osborne, 30 years old, on trial in Bronx County Court for first degree murder in connection with the fatal shooting of her husband. Patrolman Lloyd Osborne, 31, pleaded guilty to first degree manslaughter early this morning soon after the jury, which had been considering the case, reported to Judge Samuel Joseph that it was unable to reach a verdict.

BOSTON, April 4 -- Sherman L. Whipple Jr., president of Wiggin Terminals, Inc., of Boston, announced tonight the signing of a contract with the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., covering the handling of lumber in the port here.

BONN, Germany, April 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer met with the Allied High Commissioners today in a common effort to overcome their differences on the contractual agreement that will replace the Occupation Statute.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Truman marked the third anniversary of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here today by declaring that "we are steadily increasing our chances of preventing another world war."

CLEVELAND. April 4 -- Delegates to the Fifth Educational Conference of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., are divided in favor of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee for the Democratic Presidential nomination a survey disclosed today.

TRENTON, Saturday, April 5 -- The Assembly completed the 1952 session of the New Jersey Legislature early this morning by sending to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll a highly controversial bill calling for a state-wide referendum on the question of legalizing bingo games for charitable and educational purposes.
MOBILE, Ala., April 4 -- Two Air Force transports collided in flight north of Mobile tonight and carried fifteen crewmen and passengers to death in flames.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands presented today to President Truman a carillon as a gift of her people and also as a symbol of the small nations and the refugees whose cause she had come to plead.

A well-dressed couple posing as man and wife held up a salesman in the fifth floor offices of the Gubelin International Corporation, a Swiss watchmaking concern at 35 West Fifty-third Street, shortly before 7 o'clock last night and escaped with between eighty and 100 watches valued at about $5,000.

I am the wife of a retired college professor. We have a Carnegie pension of $125 per month plus a tiny income from our savings. There are a large number of people in the United States in this lower-income bracket. If prices go any higher how are we going to live?

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A belligerent and rampageous House of Representatives, apparently under complete control of Republicans and Southern Democrats, passed a bill tonight that would slash the State Department's requests for funds for the coming fiscal year by nearly 33 per cent. It was one of the deepest money cuts the chamber had made in years.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Still hoping to avert a steel strike, the Government none the less began drawing plans today for coping with the threatened breakdown of steel production.

PEORIA, Ill., April 4 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and opponent of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the Illinois Republican Presidential preference primary on Tuesday, charged today that under President Truman the United States had had "seven years of the worst conduct of foreign policy in the history of the nation."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 4 -- A steady stream of reports is reaching the business community here that foreign business concerns are in flight from Egypt and foreign business men in Egypt, of whom there are many thousands, are coming to Beirut.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 4 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower conferred today for more than six hours with Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., of Massachusetts, manager of the Eisenhower for President movement in the United States.

Large-scale advertising is due to break in advance of the "Go!" signal for yellow margarine, which goes on sale in New York July 1. In addition to elaborate advertising and promotion now in the works, at least one manufacturer is planning to introduce an improved product.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4 -- The Soviet Union assailed today the proposed glob 1 census of arms and military manpower as an "international spying service" devised by the United States to get data for the Pentagon and British Intelligence.

NEW HAVEN, April 4 -- With two Michigan standard-bearers leading the way, records tumbled in profusion tonight at the second session of the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships in Yale's Payne Whitney Gymnasium pool.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 4 -- Despite alarming predictions on what may happen when defense production is cut back, the outlook is not all bad, according to Arno H. Johnson, vice president and director of research for the J. Walter Thompson Company.
Mme. Paulette, one of America's top favorites among the French milliners, who has just arrived in New York for a short visit, foresees no radical changes in millinery for the coming fall season.

Jewelry, watches and other objects worth $125,000 covered a large desk in the East Fifty-first Street police station last night as detectives listened to an agile burglar tell how he had stolen the glittering loot from stores in New York and other cities.

Lewis R. Zeyher, formerly general manager of manufacturing, has been appointed vice president of manufacturing for the Daystrom Electric Corporation, Poughkeepsie, a subsidiary of Daystrom, Inc., Elizabeth, N. J.

MILWAUKEE, April 4 (AP) -- Four St. Louis stars stole the show today in the American Bowling Congress tournament. They accounted for one-two in the all-events, third in singles and a tie for third and seventh in doubles.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Truman Administration abandoned plans today for a special investigation of corruption in Government after the President held an hour-long conference with James P. McGranery, the Federal Judge designated yesterday to be Attorney General when J. Howard McGrath resigned.
Students from six New York high schools hailed the North Atlantic Treaty Organization yesterday as a project for peace because it widened the community spirit to an international scale.

A new kind of circus, conceived in beauty and dedicated to the proposition that tanbark and sawdust are common levelers, come spring, opened in Madison Square Garden last night with breath-cutting splendor.

Greater school and community cooperation to safeguard education against "irresponsible attacks" was urged yesterday at a conference of educators and citizen leaders at New York University's Washington Square Center.

Mayor Impellitteri warned the City Council yesterday that it would be held accountable by 115,000 city employes and their families for the loss of annual pay rises ranging up to $500 if it failed to enact his program of new city taxes.
Financing of the proposed $96,000,000 toll turnpike to traverse eighty-eight miles of the heavily industrialized state of West Virginia was assured of success yesterday.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday, the second day of the strike against it in most of the country, that it had restored service in forty-eight cities.

As the balmy spring breezes gently stir the trees in Central Park and the topcoat becomes an abomination, the worst winter that parts of Maine and the Adirondacks have seen in fifty years retains its iron grip. Snow in some forests is still five feet deep, making logging impossible.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, charged today that one of the Zionist movement's objectives was the creation of "volition" in American Jewish youth to go to Israel and that it might be achieved through distorted textbooks in religious schools.
Operators were active in the purchase and sale of real estate on the East Side yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Donald C. Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. said today "certain securities dealers' obtained lists of security holders of the bankrupt South Bay Consolidated Water Company, Inc., of Long Island, N. Y., by means "some of which were highly questionable."
SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 -- With filings for the California Presidential primaries closed after today, the June 3 balloting shapes up as a three-way Republican contest and a two-way Democratic race.

Mr. Morris returned to New York last night convinced that his dismissal as special corruption investigator in Washington last Thursday had ended all chance of an effective investigation during the remainder of the Truman Administration.
Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped 5 to 25 points yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, April 14 -- Though hundreds of orthodox Hindus demonstrated publicly against India's first nationwide beauty contest, newspapers throughout the country this morning treated the crowning of "Miss India" in Bombay yesterday as an event of national importance.

OSLO, Norway, April 4 -- James B. Cassidy, independent United States film producer, signed a contract here today with Tancred Ibsen, grandson of Henrik Ibsen, giving Mr. Cassidy world-wide motion picture rights to all Ibsen plays except "Peer Gynt."

Leaders of the nation's armed forces, at a noonday ceremony yesterday on the steps of the Sub-Treasury at Wall and Nassau Streets, called for a renewal of strength and of faith in the principles which have made this country great.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Representative Thomas G. Abernethy, Democrat of Mississippi whose Congressional district was wiped out by the State Legislature, announced tonight that he would seek the seat now held by Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat.

Queen Juliana of the Netherlands is expected to pay a visit today to the Hudson River town of Kingston, which was founded by her countrymen 300 years ago. Her visit will start off a full year of pageantry for a town which played a lively part in this state's history and became its first, and very nearly its permanent, capital.

LONDON, April 4 -- The international conference on Germany's debts adjourned today until May 19 to give the West German delegation an opportunity to prepare a basis for a settlement to be proposed to creditors.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The Defense Department has asked President Truman to extend the enlistment of regular Army, reserves and National Guard members for a period believed to be between six and nine months. The recommendation was sent recently to the Budget Bureau for study before its submission to the White House.

A trend back to the use of wool has become apparent in the clothing, sportswear and hosiery trades, according to Sidney Tager, vice president of Associated Spinners, Inc. Synthetic fabrics, he predicted, will lose a good part of the ground they gained in the period of high wool prices.

ALBANY, April 4 -- With substantial increases in personal income tax and business tax receipts the state's revenue for the fiscal year that closed Monday was $114,470,987 higher than for the 1950-51 fiscal year.

Foreign language specialists are needed to fill a critical manpower shortage in the new psychological warfare program of the United States Air Force. Virtually every language spoken is used by the Air Resupply and Communications Service in training specialists for wartime duty.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 5 -- Negotiations for an armistice in Korea awaited today a new move by either side to break the long deadlock over major issues, with some indications such action might be forthcoming shortly.

Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee brought his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination to New York yesterday. Although told that New York probably would have "a favorite son" candidate, the Senator expressed confidence that for him "the situation is improving."

CLEVELAND, April 4 (UP) -- The temporary no-strike order issued March 11 against three railroad unions was extended for the third time today to April 23 as the Government finished its case for a permanent injunction in Federal Court.

MADISON, Wis., April 4 (AP) -- Chuck Spieser, Michigan State light-heavyweight, posted a thirty-four-second technical knockout tonight to lead three defending champions into the finals of the N. C. A. A. boxing tournament.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4 -- The United Nations Security Council, a wanderer for the last six years, settled down today in its most elaborate, colorful home -- and its permanent one.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Brokers, manufacturers' agents, and dealers who render outstanding services to the defense effort are going to be given better treatment by the government than those who merely pass orders on to manufacturers.

Dr. Albert Einstein received his old friend Viscount Herbert Samuel yesterday morning in his study at Princeton. N. J. On Thursday evening they had attended a small private dinner at Princeton arranged by the American Friends of the Hebrew University, of which both men have been members of the board of governors since 1925.

LONDON, April 4 -- Dr. Edward C. Bullard, the head of Britain's National Physical Laboratories and one of the best known geophysicists in the country, tonight attacked several contemporary theories about the composition of the core of the earth. He said the center was certainly hot and fluid but not necessarily made of iron, nickel or any other known metal.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 4 -- A former big-time bookmaker and a minister were the principal witnesses today in the four-week-old trial of Michael Orecchio, former chief of Bergen County detectives, who is under charges of misconduct in office on thirty-two counts of failure to suppress gambling.

It is now an opportune time to relax consumer credit restraints in order to move heavy inventories of major appliances and other "big-ticket" goods, according to views expressed yesterday at final session of a two-day Consumer Credit Clinic at the Commodore Hotel.

BOSTON, April 4 -- Some fifty drivers and guards of the United States Trucking Corporation walked off the job today, tying up several million dollars in payrolls and other cash deliveries, in protest over the method of discharging three members of their union, whose armored truck was looted of $681,000 in Danvers, Mass., on March 25.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Gustav Metzman, president of the New York Central System, asked other industries today to aid the country's railroads to escape nationalization through "impoverishment" by government controls. Mr. Metzman made the request before members of the Chicago Executives Club at a luncheon meeting at which he asserted that "in effect, private management has been suspended in our industry."
FRANKFURT, Germany, April 4 (AP) -- Curt Simmons, sergeant, U. S. Army, is flying back to the United States tomorrow to become Curt Simmons, pitcher, Phillies, National League.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 4 (AP) -- After an amazing twenty-two-hole battle Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont., reached the semi-finals of the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today.

Many parties were given at the spring bazaar, fashion show and tea dance held yesterday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of Common Cause, Inc. A feature of the entertainment was a fashion showing of the latest costumes, in which several younger members of society acted as mannequins.

IN France its the chestnut blossoms, in other areas it may be the first robin or the downy bud of the pussy willow, but in our gloomy office the first authentic sign of printemps (pardon us -- spring) is the arrival of a few sheets of canary yellow foolscap signed by Sparse Grey Hackle.

The position of the Adenauer Government was sustained by the Bundestag Thursday night at the end of a heated debate on foreign policy. The argument was on whether to give priority to integration with the West or the reunification of Germany. This is the overwhelming issue in Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson will go to Brazil on a goodwill mission next month. It will be his first official mission to Latin America, and it is designed to re assure the other American states that the United States, despite its preoccupation with problems in Europe and Asia, has not forgotten the Good Neighbor Policy.

The International Union for Child Welfare is currently studying problems involved in international adoptions and is expected to make recommendations within the year for facilitating the procedure, Dr. Georges Thelin, secretary general of the group, said yesterday.

ALBANY, April 4 -- Authority for the State Public Works Department to build a new highway from Elmsford to Rye, through White Plains, was given today by Governor Dewey despite objections from the White Plains City Council and civic groups in that city.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 4 (AP) -- Merchants on both sides of the United States-Canadian border today were wrestling with the problem of retaining their international business in the face of the Canadian dollar's growing value.

PARIS, April 4 (AP) -- The French Interior Ministry said today that four Israeli citizens, all members of the nationalistic Herut party (Freedom Movement) of Menachem Begin, were being expelled from France. All the Ministry would say was that their presence was "inopportune."

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (AP) -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals today remanded for further hearing before the Federal Power Commission a dispute between two natural gas companies over which should have the right to transmit natural gas into New England.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4 -- Sam Snead's five-under-par 67 in the second round of the Masters Tourney over the Augusta National Golf Club today enabled the Professional Golfers Association champion to move into the lead by a margin of three strokes.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Spokesmen for United States shipping complained today of discriminations against flag vessels in many areas, particularly in some Latin American ports.

The American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, a Congregational Christian agency, has announced the recent appointment of a new captain for its "God's Little White Ship," the Morning Star VI, which sails on missionary errands among the Marshall and Caroline Islands in the Pacific Ocean.

In your editorial of April 3, explaining the results of the Wisconsin and Nebraska primaries, you state that in Wisconsin Taft polled "only 314,000 popular votes, compared with a total of 429,000 for Mr. Stassen and Governor Warren * * *." You also call attention to Taft's lack of a majority in Nebraska.

The wild west and the land of adventure down the rabbit hole clashed at the New York Botanical Garden yesterday when supporters of Hopalong Cassidy thundered into greenhouse No. 4 to meet Alice in Wonderland.
The following is a round-up of new product that may be of use about the house.

The stock market settled down yesterday to await the impact of the nation-wide steel strike called for Tuesday midnight. While prices were depressed an average of slightly more than a point, the retreat was orderly.
Frank Costello, the notorious gambler, was found guilty last night on all ten counts of an indictment charging him with contempt of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., April 4 -- Spurred by a threat of legal action on the part of the Interstate Sanitation Commission, the Peekskill Common Council voted tonight to award to the Villard Contracting Company of Hastings, N. Y., a $598,754 contract for the first part of a $1,000,000 sanitary sewer system for this city, the only Westchester County community that still empties untreated sewage into the Hudson River.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4 -- Four hours before the United Nations Security Council opened first hearings on the Tunisian case today, the United States delegation received orders not to vote in favor of full-dress debate.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Further long liquidation was the big early factor in the grain trade today, all cereal futures setting new lows on the current movement. The labor situation has been depressing and further weakness in fats and oils also was a disturbing influence.

Mayor Impellitteri's annual message to the City Council yesterday was a comprehensive, well-balanced and intelligent discussion of the problems facing the city. The tone was reasonable, good-humored yet on specific points stern and aggressive.

LONDON, April 4 -- During the first quarter of 1952 the drain on the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves, which were running out at a frightening rate in 1951. was considerably reduced and at the end of the quarter the reserves had begun to rise again.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 4 -- Governors of the influential Scarsdale Town Club ordered a study today of the activities of the Citizens Committee, also known as the Committee of Ten, which has been charging for the last three years that "Communist infiltrations" were undermining local public schools.

MOSCOW, April 4 (AP) -- Oliver Vickery, a San Francisco business man, told the Soviet-sponsored International Economic Conference today that free enterprise was the best system, but he believed there could be economic cooperation among all nations.

Sweden's Premier Tage Erlander spent a full day in New York yesterday making official visits and being feted at a luncheon and three receptions. Most of these were attended by Swedish-American business men and representatives of Swedish interests here.

Along with a number of other New York suburbs the residential community of Scarsdale has for some years now been the scene of attacks on the integrity of its school system. In Scarsdale's case the assault has taken the form of allegations that Communist influence has penetrated the village's schools in the guise of Communist-oriented Books and speakers.

DETROIT, April 4 -- Republican friends of Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan opened an eleventh-hour boom for him as a "favorite son" Presidential candidate today in an effort to minimize prospects for a bitter fight between backers of Senator Robert A.
