Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for a majority of the state's forty-six Republican delegates to the National Convention next July.

Warpath, owned by the Brandywine Stable, won the Ariel at Jamaica yesterday. The 3-year-old son of War Admiral prevailed in a stirring finish in which he enjoyed a margin of a half-length over Golden Gloves of the Belair Stud.

The only two books published today are from the University of North Carolina Press. One is David Mitrany's "Marx Against the Peasant: A Study in Social Dogmatism." Selling for $4.50. The other is "A Two-Party South?" by Alexander Heard, an analysis of the changes in the politics of the South. It sells for $4.75.

LONDON, April 4 -- After a dull opening caused by the swing to the left in the London local elections, the stock markets closed the week brightly, helped by the favorable interpretation of the check on the fall of Britain's gold and dollar reserves.

Thomas Kling, convicted accomplice of William Sutton, the bank robber, pleaded guilty through counsel yesterday in General Sessions to one count of a two-count indictment charging illegal possession of a firearm. An earlier plea of not guilty was withdrawn.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 4 -- In a wind-tossed battle against the Indians this afternoon, the Giants snapped out of a four-game losing streak to record their first victory since leaving the Phoenix training base and their first triumph over the American Leaguers after seven in reverse. The score was 5 to 3.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 4 -- Another fine pitching performance by Chris Van Cuyk and Clem Lagine gave the Dodgers a 7-0 victory over the Boston Braves today and evened the "road series" between the teams. A crowd of 5,785 looked on in Municipal Stadium.

The necessity for eliminating the "antiquated" requirements and restrictions in the curriculum of teaching candidates in the city colleges was emphasized yesterday by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College.

In your issue of March 24, Lyman Beeman, president of Finch, Pruyn Company, defends his company's private-cutting forest and speaks disparagingly of the near-by non-cutting state forest which forms part of the Forest Preserve. Both forests are located on the upper watershed in the Adirondacks.

Magistrate Charles F. Murphy in Mid-Manhattan Court said yesterday there was a doubt in his mind whether three child entertainers on a television show gave an adagio presentation or an acrobatic act that was in violation of law.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- T. Vincent Quinn, District Attorney of Queens County, N. Y., acknowledged today that he had accepted fees while a member of Congress for representing clients involved in tax-fraud litigation with the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

HAVANA, April 4 -- Gen. Fulgencio Batista, who seized control of the Cuban Government by military coup March 10, became the Provisional President of Cuba late this afternoon following a cabinet meeting at which a new constitution was approved.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 4 -- A sharp warning to "fanatics who endanger race relations in Africa" came today from Sir Godfrey Huggins. Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia. Sir Godfrey was speaking at the inaugural meeting of the United Central Africa Association on the plan to federate Southern and Northern Rhodesia with Nyasaland.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 4 (AP) -- Five records were hung up today in the first session of the huge Texas relays as big Darrow Hooper of Texas A. and M. pitched the shot 54 feet 73/4 inches and Charles Thomas, the Texas flier, came within an eyelash of the world record n the 200 meters.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 4 -- A move to draft Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for the Democratic Presidential nomination was started here today by Peirce Wood of Dayton, president of the League of Young Democratic Clubs of Ohio.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Army officials, conceding that compliance with Administration policy in the integration of Negro and white personnel in the service is not yet total, listed today the progress being made.
Three hold-ups -- two of them payrolls for business concerns -- occurred within an hour and a half yesterday afternoon in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The total loot was $3,136.

The Playwrights' Company finally has concluded its search for the two performers to succeed the husband-and-wife team of Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn in the local presentation of "The Four-poster." Engaged for the starring roles are Betty Field and Burgess Meredith.

The apparent ease with which repeated offenders have managed to recover their driving licenses after arrest in local communities was questioned here yesterday by police officials from New Rochelle and Nassau County, who suggested that loopholes in the regulations or slack handling of cases were responsible.

ATLANTA, April 4 -- Jerry Coleman will be ready to play second base for the Yankees when they open the 1952 championship season on April 15, and will stay with the team up to and including April 30. Then he will bid farewell to the Bombers for probably two full baseball campaigns as he hops across the United States to take up his new duties as Captain in the Marine Corps.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 4 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today won fourteen and possibly fifteen of Iowa's twenty-six delegates to the Republican National Convention in Chicago July 7. Nine delegates are believed to be in the camp of Senator Robert A. Taft and two are reported definitely "neutral."

FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., April 4 (AP) -- "Babe would have loved it," said the widow of George Herman (Babe) Ruth as she pulled the string unveiling a marker on the spot where thirty-eight years ago the Bambino hit his first home run as a professional hall player.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 4 -- On the basis of a record attendance and heavy business done at the twenty-first National Packaging Exposition which closed here this afternoon in Convention Hall, a banner year for all phases of the packaging industry was forecast by officials of many of the leading exhibitors.

Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamted Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., resigned last night as a director of the City Center because of the scheduled appearance of the New York City Ballet in Spain.

Handbell ringers will play a medley of hymns in a religious procession prior to the 11 A. M. Palm Sunday service tomorrow at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street. Eighteen robed girls of the junior choir will give a program with the bells on the church steps and lead a procession of some 300 children bearing palms into the church.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 4 (AP) -- The nation's 9,584 state-supervised banks increased their assets by $6,400,000,000 last year, Alexander Chmielewski, president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, reported today.

As chemists, engineers and physicians considered in an erudite discussion here last night whether smoke was a health hazard or merely a nuisance, a New York housewife protested: Whatever you call it, housewives won't put up with it much longer.

Distibutors of new issues of corporate bonds closed up shop yesterday with shelves virtually empty, despite the big succession of bond issues to come to market during the last fortnight. Only in the field of railroad equipment certificates are there unsold new securities remaining. This "float" is estimated at $17,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A report that copies of the magazine The Reporter, carraying an expose of the alleged China lobby in Washington, were being bought up in large lots and destroyed, was being investigated here today by the magazine's Washington representative.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Frank Nathan, Pittsburgh "promoter," collected $92,000 in "finder's fees" through three sales of surplus Government war plants and equipment, Senate investigators disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Frank Farrell, newspaper columnist, testified today that Prof. Owen J. Lattimore had interceded for a wartime German spy also suspected of being an agent for Soviet Russia.

Ever since the first small band of Danish seamen discovered the Bronx and forthwith "swallowed the anchor" our city's cosmopolitan hues have been generously streaked with salt. Thousands of seamen pass through this the nation's busiest port every week. Considering that fact, Norwegian, British and American seamen's welfare officials formed a committee several years ago to unify recreational activities for seamen in the port.

Patrolman John J. Loughlin of the West 100th Street Station, who shot a hold-up man in a robbery at 1203 Amsterdam Avenue on Feb. 27, has been cited for exceptional merit, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced yesterday.
The sharp price drops in the hide and leather market during the past few months have caused shoe retailers to place commitments with caution and hesitancy.

BALTIMORE, April 4 -- Prison sentences ranging from two to five years and fines of $1,000 each were imposed in Federal Court today on the six "second-team" Communist leaders convicted Tuesday of violating the Smith Act by conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the government by force and violence.

Distibutors of new issues of corporate bonds closed up shop yesterday with shelves virtually empty, despite the big succession of bond issues to come to market during the last fortnight. Only in the field of railroad equipment certificates are there unsold new securities remaining. This "float" is estimated at $17,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A report that copies of the magazine The Reporter, carraying an expose of the alleged China lobby in Washington, were being bought up in large lots and destroyed, was being investigated here today by the magazine's Washington representative.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Frank Nathan, Pittsburgh "promoter," collected $92,000 in "finder's fees" through three sales of surplus Government war plants and equipment, Senate investigators disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Frank Farrell, newspaper columnist, testified today that Prof. Owen J. Lattimore had interceded for a wartime German spy also suspected of being an agent for Soviet Russia.

Ever since the first small band of Danish seamen discovered the Bronx and forthwith "swallowed the anchor" our city's cosmopolitan hues have been generously streaked with salt. Thousands of seamen pass through this the nation's busiest port every week. Considering that fact, Norwegian, British and American seamen's welfare officials formed a committee several years ago to unify recreational activities for seamen in the port.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 4 (AP) -- Henry Wittenberg, America's chief Olympic hope, and three defending champions struggled into the final round of the National Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships tonight at Cornell University -- but none had a perfect record.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 -- Montgomery Clift has been signed by Alfred Hitchcock, the director, for his next independent production for Warner Brothers, "I Confess."

BALTIMORE, April 4 -- Prison sentences ranging from two to five years and fines of $1,000 each were imposed in Federal Court today on the six "second-team" Communist leaders convicted Tuesday of violating the Smith Act by conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the government by force and violence.

After a brief ownership, Chobol Navone have sold the garden-type apartment house at 3201-13 Park Avenue, the Bronx, to a client of Vogler Son, Inc., New York brokers. The property, assessed at $250,000, was sold through the Halford Realty Company, broker.

A recommendation to Mayor Impellitteri that a general city policy be formulated governing outside work by city employes will be made by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, Dr. Luther H. Gulick, executive director of the committee, indicated yesterday.

TRENTON, April 4 -- Damage to a state prison wing last Sunday and Monday by rioting inmates was estimated today at $20,000. Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, in disclosing the loss in wrecked beds, sanitary fixtures, windows and equipment, said it raised anew the discussion of replacing "the antiquated prison" with a modern institution outside the city.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The General Public Utilities Corporation of New York and its subsidiary, the Jersey Central Power and Light Company of Asbury Park, N. J., applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to sell Jersey Central's gas properties. The County Gas Company has made an offer of $13,757,385, plus certain conversion and construction costs.

A proxy bride, Mrs. Joy Slade Ritter of Portsmouth, England, arrived by plane from London at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday on her way to a trailer home in the Nevada desert. She was greeted by Kelton (Tex) Ritter, to whom she was married by proxy last March 24.

AINTREE, England, April 4 (AP) -- Freebooter, the 1950 winner, tonight was elevated to the favorite's role at 100-to-8 among the forty-eight probable starters for tomorrow's 106th running of the Grand National steeplechase.

WASHINGTON April 4 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent for the week ended April 1 to 111.4 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 3.1 per cent below that of January, 1951, the month during which the general ceiling price regulation became effective, and 1.1 per cent below the level of last February.
The Federal Government succeeded yesterday in reviving steel wage negotiations to forestall a national steel strike by 600,000 workers that is scheduled for 12:01 o'clock Wednesday morning.

" Under the Paris Sky," a French-made import written and directed by Julien Duvivier, will have its American premiere the latter part of this month at the Paris Theatre, it was announced by Discina International, distributors of the offering.

OMAHA, April 4 (AP) -- Complete unofficial returns from all of Nebraska's voting precincts showed today that more than 320,000 votes were cast in Tuesday's primary election, based on vote counts in the Presidential preference races.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- An announcement outlining the standards to be used by the Office of Price Stabilization in deciding to suspend price ceilings and reporting regulations on eligible products will be made early next week, Ellis G. Arnall, head of the price agency, said today.

KANSAS CITY, April 4 (AP) -- Tho Missouri River Basin Survey Commission completed today it preliminary organization for a comprehensive study of what to do about droughts ancl floods in the ten-state basin.
LONDON, April 4 -- Although out of power in the palace of Westminster, the British Labor party strengthened its hold today on London County Hall on the opposite bank of the Thames.

The Board of Transportation announced last night that for the seven months ended Jan. 31, 1952, the deficit of the city's rapid transit system was $14,448,488, as against $1,314,291 for the corresponding period a year ago.
A 60-year-old grocer and his son-in-law were charged yesterday with taking $1,550 in rent gouges from ten displaced persons for $20-a-month cold water flats on the Lower East Side.

JERSEY CITY, April 4 -- A temporary injunction restraining Jersey City public safety officials from interfering with the employment of five longshoremen was signed today by Superior Court Judge Thomas J. Stanton, sitting in Chancery Division here.

TAMPA, Fla., April 4 (AP) -- Two New York union organizers filed a $50,000 damage suit today, alleging that they had been held prisoner six hours in a Miami Beach hotel room and had been stripped and beaten in an attempt to make them give up a union charter.

ALBANY, April 4 -- Governor Dewey authorized today the creation of a temporary state commission to study the deficit-ridden rapid transit system of Metropolitan New York and New Jersey and try to come up with a solution for New York's transportation problems.

WITH U. S. SECOND DIVISION, in Korea, April 1 -- A crestfallen group of grizzled battle veterans -- American G. I.'s serving in Korea -- discovered today that they would soon have to don plaid skirts and fur-tailed purses and anybody who wants to make something of it can just step outside the foxhole.
EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., April 4 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today accused his opponents in the fight for the Republican Presidential nomination of failing to oppose the Truman Administration.

For many New Yorkers this is an important day; the early hours this morning will mean more than they have meant on any Saturday morning for the past five and a half months. On the city's ten municipal golf courses, weather permitting, hungry enthusiasts will cry "fore" and pound a little white pellet through a variety of maneuvers all aimed at a common goal -- to break par.

ROME, April 4 -- Because fashionable Italian women still prefer their styles imported. Rome couturiers are engaged in second spring showings this week and next. Whereas strictly Italian wares were displayed in February for American buyers and manufacturers adaptations of the Paris mode are now being shown for the local customers.
Many rewarding shows are to be found this week in metropolitan galleries. The four reviewed here -- three one-man appearances and a group -- are among those which deserve special attention.

Tornadoes killed six persons and injured at least forty-three others in the South yesterday while flood waters kept hundreds of persons from their homes in the Midwest and West, The Associated Press reported.
DUBLIN, Ireland, April 4 (AP) -- The status of American teams will come up for clarification at the Gaelic Athletic Association's annual Congress on April 13.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- A convention on road traffic, sponsored by the United Nations and aimed at standardizing traffic rules and specifications and making the international use of automobiles simpler throughout the world, came into force recently.

A WELL-SHAPED peony plant with fine foliage is easy to grow. Of course, no matter how handsome the plant may be, the gardener wants more than that -- plenty of large blooms held aloft and free from dirt. These sturdy perennials are a lifetime investment and deserve the routine care that brings top performance.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Indians from North Dakota unanimously urged Congress today to return their mineral rights on land in an oil-boom area. But they split sharply on how money from the land should be distributed.

THE HAGUE, April 5 -- The Dutch Communists usually denounce every official contact with Washington. When Premier Willem Drees toured the United States in January they accused him of being "led around by his American bosses." But when Queen Juliana arrived in Washington this week with a message for Congress condemning totalitarianism and upholding the Atlantic community, the Communists were meekly silent.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 5 (AP) -- Ten airmen were killed tonight when a B-29 weather plane exploded and crashed fifteen miles north of Sacramento. The bodies were recovered.

Top officers of six major steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., agreed yesterday to meet face to face today for the first time since Thursday, when their negotiations collapsed. The session was arranged by Nathan P. Feinsinger, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board.

Jewish storekeepers in the High-bridge section of the Bronx have refused to close their shops from noon to 3 P. M. on Good Friday in defiance of an alleged threat of boycott made by parishioners of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, 1253 Shakespeare Avenue, at West 168th Street.

ONIONS are not ordinarily regarded in terms of beauty, particularly when sets of edible kinds are being planted this month. But there are many species of flowering onions (allium) which rival more aristocratic plants in dainty bloom and clean, shining foliage.

Allan Nevins in "Why Public Men Keep Diaries" (March 23) terms the shorthand used by Samuel Pepys his "own secret." I think this affirmation is rather exaggerated. I venture to say (basing my contention upon John Egglington Bailey's "On the Cipher of Pepys' Diary") that the shorthand system he used was neither his own, nor secret.

SINCE most of the town's reviewers take a dim view of Truman Capote's "The Grass Harp," today's article is a minority report. But it is filed in the belief that Mr. Capote's casual, lyrical drama is the most creative contribution to the season and that it has something moving to say about the valor of unsophisticated people.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 5 -- Michigan took top honors today in the Southern Relays as two records were smashed on a muddy, wind-swept field. Yale's Charlton Lewis leaped 23 feet 11 3/4 inches on his first try in the broad jump to surpass the relays record by two inches. The old mark had been put on the books by Buddy Fowlkes of Georgia Tech last year.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, April 6 (AP) -- Allied planes plunged high explosives, rockets and flaming gasoline at an array of enemy targets in the southwest corner of North Korea yesterday.

The Federal Maritime Board, in its redetermination of the construction subsidy due American Export Lines for the liners Independence and Constitution, was accused last week of ignoring the spirit, purposes and intent of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 and basing its conclusions only on the law's "dead technical language."
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission moved another step today toward the time when private industry will make atomic power and fuel for profit.

AS soon as I told friends I was about to go to Europe alone with only a few hotel reservations in the way of advance planning, they exercised the privilege of friends: They made dire predictions. The facetious ones suggested that my purpose could only be to meet an Italian count.

MOSCOW, April 5 -- The Soviet Union today spelled out its bid for relaxation of world trade barriers, offering $7,500,000,000 to $10,000,000,000 in trade with the capitalist countries during the next two to three years. A substantial part of its purchases would be ships, machinery and tools.

LONDON. IT was charged against the late George Arliss that every character he touched turned to Arliss. As he favored historical roles, this gave rise to a confusion in the minds of the young and impressionable that there was, in fact, a substantial family resemblance between the Duke of Wellington, Disraeli, Alexander Hamilton, Voltaire and the founder of the House of Rothschild.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The discord that existed between recently resigned Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson and so many others outside the circle of his own appointees -- especially the military -- left many wondering about the actual state of the production program's progress.

Attacks on the public schools endanger many of the advances in education made during the last half century, according to a 260-page report prepared by the Association of Supervision and Curriculum Development. The impact of the attacks in many sections of the country is stressed in the association's 1952 yearbook, "Growing Up in an Anxious Age."

FIRST-TIME travelers abroad worry about many things, but short of being caught without a passport in deepest Hungary there is probably no situation that can worry a prospective traveler as much as being caught on a transatlantic liner "with all the wrong clothes."

A LOT of women will vicariously enjoy this easy-reading tale of a marriage that is almost -- but not quite -- perfect. When the story opens, Laurie and Martin Joyce have been wed twenty years and have a boy and a girl in their late teens.

A State Supreme Court decision that restricts the picketing rights of labor unions and could be construed as barring all picketing in jurisdictional disputes has been handed down by Justice Henry Clay Greenberg in Manhattan Supreme Court. Labor unions regard the ruling as so important that they intend to appeal it all the way to the United States Supreme Court, if necessary.

IN EARLY spring delicate colors are apt to predominate in both rock gardens and perennial borders. The white and yellow of daffodils, alyssum, Iceland poppies and primulas, with valuable blue from small bulbs and Phlox divaricata, sometimes need a more forceful note.

IN 1860, when Dostoevsky wrote "Memoirs from the House of the Dead," a record of his penal servitude in Siberia, critics greeted him as "a new Dante who had descended into Hell, the more terrible as it existed not in the writer's imagination but in reality."

It seems to me there is an unusually interesting tie-up between two of your articles of Sunday, March 23 -- William S. White's "An Inquiry Into Congressional Inquiries" and Allan Nevins' "Why Public Men Keep Diaries."

The new 15,000-gross-ton Holland-America liner Maasdam, sister ship of the company's new "economy" vessel Ryndam, was launched yesterday at Schiedam, the Netherlands, according to advices received at the steamship company's offices here.

BERLIN, April 5 -- While they make diplomatic gestures toward unity and neutrality for Germany, the Russians are reported to be preparing new measures that will force 20,000,000 East Germans into the Soviet empire.

Inspector Thomas V. Boylan, who commanded the Twenty-second Division with headquarters in Jamaica, Queens, was the only ranking police officer who weathered the recent departmental shake-up in Harlem, where he had served for eight years.
Little or no progress was reported yesterday by Federal mediators as the Monday morning deadline neared for a walkout by 65,800 telephone workers in various parts of the country.
DETROIT, April 5 (AP) -- The new car buyer this year will hear with increasing frequency about the great dollar value of 1952 model autos, despite price increases that have affected every make.

FLOWERING trees are an easy way to garden. True, some of them will need a couple of years before they start to bloom, but in the meantime they demand little care. When well located, they blossom more abundantly as the years go by.

ALTHOUGH his title calls for "wild life," Frank Illingworth has included the sledge dog and the reindeer herded by man in this account of animals of the Arctic. This is well and good, for I do not remember a better chapter about the reindeer than this one.

CLEVELAND, April 5 -- Politically bossed primaries, Senate filibusters, the Corrupt Practices Act, lobbies and McCarthyism were attacked by three United States Senators in a discussion today on "Congress, Its Morals, Responsibilities and Opportunities" at the educational conference of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O.
To meet industrial and population growth of the area, public utility companies serving southern New Jersey are preparing for an expansion program that will cost well in excess of $50,000,000.

BRUNSWICK, Me., April 5 -- Dr. James S. Coles, acting dean of the college at Brown University, was elected today president of Bowdoin College. He will assume his duties in October, succeeding Kenneth C. M. Sills, who retires after thtirty-five years of service.
AT age 85, after a lifetime of unique contribution to American education, Abraham Flexner has summed up his recollections and views on some of the great philanthropic foundations.

SEOUL, Korea, April 5 -- First Lieut. James A. Van Fleet Jr., 26-year-old pilot son of the Eighth Army's commanding general, is missing in action following a combat flight over North Korea, the Air Force disclosed today.

Each year the public schools of the nation employ in the neighborhood of 100,000 new teachers. These are, for the most part, recent college graduates, or graduates of teacher-training institutions, who are about to enter the classroom for the first time.

BONN, April 5 -- The people of Federal Germany, Europe's newest democracy, are being subjected to political strains and stresses that would gravel any electorate in the world. Simultaneously Germans are being offered unity and neutrality by the Russians, and integration with the West and security through mutual aid by the Atlantic powers.

NEW DELHI, India, April 5 -- ndia's affinity for "progressive and secular democracy" was reaffirmed by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today in a farewell message to the Turkish press delegation that has completed a tour of India.

MEXICO CITY, April 5 -- The leaders of three Mexican opposition parties reached agreement tonight that Gen. Miguel Henriquez Guzman would stand for the Presidency in the July election as the "Unity" candidate for all three parties.

SYLVIA SIEGLER, who founded and built her Show-of-the-Month Club to the point where it has become a pain in the neck to the Messrs. Shubert -- she's now contemplating a restraint of trade suit against them because she cannot buy tickets to shows in their houses -- is off on another tangent.

IT is not easy to live in that continuous awareness of things which alone is true living. Even those who make a parade of their conviction that sunset, rain and the growth of a seed are daily miracles are not usually so much impressed by them as they urge others to be.
ALTHOUGH many little plants bloom in the rock garden in early spring, none is more welcomed than the primrose. The one that is practically synonymous with spring is Primula vulgaris (or acaulis).

THE mystery novel originally flourished in English in lengths three to four times those of modern whodunits. "The Moonstone" runs to 200,000 words; Le Fanu's "Uncle Silas" to 170,000; and even Dickens' "brief" fragment of "Edwin Drood" (surely less than half the projected novel) runs more than 100,000.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., ,April 5 -- A new research camera, known as a spectograph, is ready for use by scientists of the College of Agriculture, Rutgers University.

HERE is a long, rhapsodic celebration of the place of the arts in the life of man. John M. Warbeke, one of the founders of the Holyoke League of Arts and Crafts, follows Benedetto Croce in identifying esthetic experience with a basic universal human function, and employs Croce's own term, intuition, for this function.

Business is a pleasure for eighteen women students from City, Hunter, and Queens Colleges and New York University who regularly supplement their allowances by attending parties. Saturday is their busiest day, but many of the girls also go to parties on weekday afternoons.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 5 -- A gift of $60,000 from John D. Rockefeller 3d, to the Industrial Relations Section of Princeton University, was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university. The gift virtually completes the section's campaign to obtain a total endowment of $1,000,000 by its thirtieth anniversary this June.

IT is difficult to forge a career in any phase of musical performance. It is, perhaps, most difficult in conducting. You can add complications to the difficulties by being an American who wishes to become a conductor, and you can complicate the complications by being an American Negro.

NEWARK, April 5 -- The plane crash in Jamaica this morning shocked public officials in this area and strengthened their opposition to any resumption of commercial flying at Newark Airport. The airport was closed by the Port of New York Authority on Feb. 11, after the third fatal plane crash in Elizabeth.

DALLAS, April 5 -- The imminent departure of Willie Mays for military service loomed as another blow to Giant flag hopes today. A report from Mays' home in Birmingham, Ala., said that his induction papers had arrived there and were now on the way to Willie.

Samuel Reshevsky, five-time holder of the United States championship, defeated Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires last night at the New School for Social Research in the first of the eighteen games of their long-projected chess match.

LONDON, April 5 (Reuters) -- Arsenal and Chelsea tied, 1 -- 1, in their postponed Football Association Cup semi-final played before a crowd of 68,000 at Tottenham today. The Gunners went ahead in the first half when Freddie Cox scored. Billy Gray equalized in the second half.
HYDE PARK, N. Y., April 5 -- Fala, the rakish little black Scotty who sat in on the making of history, is dead.

LAUREL, Md., April 5 (UP) -- Nick Shuk continued his riding spree at Laurel today as he rode three straight winners in the sloppy going, including Carolyn K. Stable's Hi Billee in the $15,000-added Laurel Handicap, to raise his victory list to ten in the last three days.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 5 -- Frederick J. Tritschler, junior forward from Winnetka, Ill., who set a Princeton scoring record this season, has been elected captain of the 1952-53 varsity basketball team, R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics, revealed today.

BOSTON, April 5 -- The newly formed New England Theatre Conference voted today to become affiliated with the American National Theatre and Academy and became co-sponsor of a meeting to be held April 27 to foster interest in ANTA.
Another $1,000,000,000 in machine tool orders for defense work will be placed within the next nine to twelve months, high Government officials have just indicated to leaders of the industry.

ANNUALS are the one group of plants that can be used lavishly. They grow easily with a minimum of care and give a maximum of bloom. They are inexpensive and easily obtained, and can be planted to provide masses of color, alone or to fill gaps in the perennial border.

COASTWISE passenger service to Miami and New Orleans has been resumed by the Pan-Atlantic Steamship Corporation, a subsidiary of Waterman Lines, 19 Rector Street. Two of the cargo-passenger vessels are equipped with six two-berth outside rooms, each having private shower and toilet.

NEWARK, April 5 -- Harold E. Stassen will be confronted with a dilemma in his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination when he actively opens his campaign in this state on Tuesday. His problem: how to formulate a strategy that will further his campaign without damaging the chances of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

ALBANY, Calif., April 5 (UP) -- The King Ranch's Marcador, ridden by Jockey R. L. Baird, who lost both his stirrups at the halfway mark, won the $15,000 added Oakland Handicap at Golden Gate Fields today.

MILWAUKEE, April 5 -- Wisconsin, actively interested in construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway, is pressing a campaign to get the project under way. The state has marshaled its forces, from Governor down, to press for the project in Congress, in the belief that the time for the seaway is "now or never."

PULMONARIA is one of the earliest -- and prettiest -- of spring-flowering perennials. Only a few warm rays of sun are needed for the plants to send up stems of clustered bloom in rich pink, red purple or intense blue.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The American Council for Judaism, which is strongly anti-Zionist, announced today that one of its major goals for this year would be the restoration of Judaism as a "spiritual, ethical and religious force" in American life.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aprill 5 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's friendship mission to the Arab states, arrived here today by air. It was headed by Foreign Minister Alberto Martin Artajo and Gen. Mohammed Ben Mizzian Ben Kassem, Moorish Officer in the Spanish Army, accompanied by General Franco's daughter, the Marquise de Villaverde, her husband and a party of seventeen, including the director of the official Spanish press service and the chief of protocol of the Foreign Ministry.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, April 5 (AP) -- The colonel had a word of defense today in "the case of the colonel's lady."

Between now and the national political conventions in July there will be 55 state conventions for the two parties and 13 state primaries. When they are over the full rosters of 1,205 Republican delegates and 1,230 Democratic delegates will be complete. A majority of each -- 603 Republicans and 616 Democrats -- will determine who are to be the nominees for the Presidential election Nov. 7.

MOBILE, Ala., April 5 (UP) -- One of the two Air Force transports wrecked over Mobile last night in a collision that cost fifteen lives was a mercy plane ordered aloft in the hope of saving an eight-week-old infant's life, the Air Force announced today.

WITH the closing of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet with two performances today at the Warner Theatre, the field belongs exclusively to the concert artists for the moment. Of particular interest is this afternoon's program by May O'Donnell, who does not often come forth with performances of her own.

The most serious threat to the national economy since the start of the Korean war burst into the open last week. Our free enterprise system was endangered by Government dominance in the steel labor dispute, resulting in the resignation of a top Administration official.

HOLLYWOOD'S biggest overseas production spree will dispatch fifty location units in search of unexploited scenery this year, but it seems safe to predict that none will equal either the settings or the uncommon action of a recent import, "Valley of the Eagles," which will be unveiled at the Rivoli on Friday.

Dr. Robert Morss Lovett, former Acting Governor of the Virgin Islands, asserted yesterday that the "disease of fear" was threatening the nation's schools, which he described as the "heart of democracy." He declared that the teacher must have the same rights as other citizens to profess without fear of retaliation, whatever religious, economic or political faith he may hold.
With reference to C. B. Palmer's "Apathetic Party Wins In West Parsley, L. I." (March 23) you will be, no doubt, surprised and pleased to learn what happened here in Westbury, L. I., recently.

Radio and television news departments were a beehive of activity yesterday after the plane crash in Jamaica. Station WHLI in Hempstead carried a descriptive report by radio shortly after 8:30 and, beginning at noon, broadcast recorded interviews and news throughout the afternoon.

AINTREE, England, April 5 -- Teal, an Irish gelding named for a duck and wearing No. 13, won the almost invisible Grand National Steeplechase today. Thirty-seven of the forty-seven starters fell during the mist-shrouded event, with five jockeys winding up in the hospital and one horse destroyed.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- An early attempt at a rally in grains faded out on the Board of Trade today. All cereals opened higher, but before the session was ended wheat and soybeans had dipped below the previous close. Dealings proceeded at a routine pace.

RICHMOND, Va., April 5 (AP) -- Mr. and Mrs. Cortwright Wetherill's sleek bay gelding, Adaptable, a consistent winner over brush but never a timber jumper before, proved he could learn in a hurry by winning in the twentieth running of the Deep Run Hunt Cup today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 5 -- Initiation of a cooking class for blind residents of Union County at its testing kitchen in near-by Union Township was announced this week by the Elizabethtown Consolidated Gas Company. Special pots, pans and other equipment fitted with safety gadgets will protect the class of twelve women and one man against accidents.
FORT HOOD, Tex., April 5 (UP) -- Army and Air Force units launched the eleventh "atomic attack" of Exercise Long Horn today and then prepared for a cautious week-end recess of the maneuvers.

THE title of this new book on the art of Charlie Chaplin is the kind that makes one reader, at least, all but cringe. It smacks of Arthur Machen, James Stephens, or worse. Stephen Phillips. But within a few pages one begins to applaud the author for he has already more than justified his use of such a title:

In a move to improve protection for life and property in the vicinity of the city's airports, Mayor Impellitteri summoned yesterday to a City Hall meeting at 3 P. M. tomorrow the top representatives of agencies directly interested in the crash of the U. S. Airlines cargo plane in a densely populated section of Jamaica, Queens.

WHAT would happen to the commercial airlines in the event of an all-out national emergency was spelled out in Washington last week by the Military Air Transport Service. Briefly, the plans made for full mobilization of transport planes would mean that civilian air travel would be cut to a bare minimum.

WASHINGTON. IN 1910, fires glowed all night in the glass factories of Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Indiana. And in those factories each night children worked. One boy or girl in every six that year was a laborer -- close to 900,000 working children 10 to 13 years of age, over 1,000,000 working children 14 and 15.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyle Bowman of Richmond, Calif., and Marjorie Lindsay, Decatur, Ill., reached the Trans-Mississippi golf championship final today.

Not all salesmen are as pictured in fiction, and it is sometimes a source of wonderment that more salesmen do not eventually end up as the kingpins of their companies. For here, in what probably is the largest white-collar group in the country, are men who comb the markets and understand the problems of the manufacturer as well as the retailer.

COLUMBLIA, N. J. -- A great many people have looked at a great many pictures of a New Jersey peak called Mount Tammany, but few know it by that name. Tammany is the height that forms the New Jersey wall of the Delaware Water Gap; Mount Minsi, on the Pennsylvania side of the Delaware River, is its opposite number.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman denounced the McCarran-Walter immigration bill yesterday as unfair and undemocratic and said he hoped for the adoption by Congress of the alternative Humphrey-Lehman bill with Republican support.

ROME, April 5 -- Trieste has been a name to stir the emotions and command the loyalty of Italians ever since the little Kingdom of Piedmont first raised the flag of Italian independence in the first half of the last century.

The Queens District Attorney's office and the police are cooperating in a drive to eliminate obscene literature from newsstands and confectionery stores in the borough, District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn announced yesterday.

The events of the past week have seen President Truman's promised "drastic action" against corruption in government bog down to a full stop. The chosen special agent for investigation was summarily dismissed by the Attorney General. The Attorney General was summarily dismissed by the President.

Record increase last year of 2,656,672,000 barrels in the nation's known reserves of crude oil and natural gas liquids has strengthened assertions of leading executives that for the foreseeable future the growing demand for liquid petroleum fuels will be met, provided economic incentives for development of these resources are continued.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Mrs. Owen Lattimore, wife of the Johns Hopkins University Professor, told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that she could see no conflict in sworn testimony given by her husband and one of his students, Catesby Jones.

WITH Easter only a week off, special displays, traditional and otherwise, are already on view today. In the greenhouse of the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, the theme is "Alice in Wonderland," complete with the rabbit's hole at the bottom of a tree.

CLEVELAND, April 5 -- "Hot pursuit across the Yalu River" as a last resort to force the Korean issue was advocated here today by Senator Estes Kefauver speaking at the City Club in a bid for Democratic presidential primary support.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 -- Two of golf's most celebrated players -- Ben Hogan, United States open champion, and Sam Snead, current P. G. A. titleholder, were deadlocked for first place today at the end of the third round of the Masters tourney.

PLUS signs in business, like the first robin and the first crocus, are shy creatures. They frighten easily. The greatest of inducements fails to tempt them to poke their heads around the corner until they are ready.

PERHAPS even more indicative of the real significance of 16-millimeter, non-theatrical, films than the current burgeoning of the field through schools, libraries, film societies and clubs all over the United States is the awakening of interest, evident on all sides, by novices who are anxious to learn, by seeing, exactly what is being done.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 5 -- Of all the comments upon SHAPE's first year of active existence, perhaps the most meaningful was made this week by a sturdy, red-faced French farmer named Marcel Hertault. Mr. Hertault has a rather special proprietary interest in the international headquarters of General of the Army Eisenhower. Some fourteen months ago he was seeding rye on the muddy fields where SHAPE's ramified buildings now stand.

A SELF - THREADING device that permits automatic threading of amateur movie film on any 8mm or 16mm projector is announced by Windman Brothers of Los Angeles. This novel accessory attaches easily to the projector and will cost $10 to $15 when it becomes available in about four months.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5 -- Following is the text of the United States working paper, entitled "Proposals for Progressive and Continuing Disclosure and Verification of Armed Forces and Armaments," submitted today to a committee of the United Nations Disarmament Commission:

Although the management of the Lincoln Electric Company of Cleveland, Ohio, credits the United States Tax Court with vindicating its incentive system for the payment of retirement annuities of its employes, the record of a decade of litigation shows that the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit should share the credit for what was accomplished.
The Cunard liner Mauretania will return here next Sunday from the West Indies to bring to a close the most successful special winter cruise program since pre-war days.

WHEN Clearhos Logothetis was a boy, his family raised tobacco in Central Macedonia in Greece. One day the locusts came. In two hours, the big leathery insects swarmed over the farm, devouring every leaf that meant the family's living.

ATHENS, April 5 -- The Government-sponsored bill for "pacification and leniency to convicted Communists," approved article by article by Parliament early today, is expected to be voted in total early next week.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Senate has approved a bill to set up a permanent bankruptcy procedure for farmers.
TOKYO, Sunday, April 6 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 11,211, for Saturday's operations:

NEW YORK STATE'S highway system is going to require an outlay averaging at least $180,000,000 annually for twenty years if it is to meet the increasing needs of motor traffic, according to Bertram D. Tallamy, State Superintendent of Public Works.

NEWARK, April 5 -- Operations of the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission at Robbins Reef Lighthouse that were described this week by New York City officials as a major source of pollution in the Narrows and New York Bay were strongly defended today by Herman Blank, chairman of the commission.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 5 (AP) -- The North Central Intercollegiate Athletic Conference today made three University of North Dakota football players temporarily ineligible and approved a reprimand of North Dakota's coach, Frank Zazula, for recruiting them.

With the national conventions still three months away, the race for the Presidential nomination is wide open. Both parties have a deep responsibility to democracy, and the American people are in a mood to insist on fulfillment of that responsibility. Either party will ignore it at its peril, for the American electorate has given ample proof in recent weeks that it is very much alive.

A critical appraisal of "the hot rod" of progressive education in elementary schools and the kind of students it produces was given yesterday by speakers at a conference of the High School Teachers Association.

MURPHYSBORO, Ill., April 5 -- A comedy of errors involving candidates for the Presidential nomination all but paralyzed this farmers' shopping center this afternoon. Murphysboro, population 8,976, is the Jackson County seat.

As every bacteriologist expected, the photographic "proof" presented by the Peiping People's Daily that troops of the United States dropped infected insects in bombs on Korea and China turned out to be complete frauds. A representative of this newspaper laid the "proof" before Army Ordnance officers, as well as Dr. C. H. Curran, entomologist of the American Museum of Natural History, and Dr. Rene Dubos, the distinguished bacteriologist of the Rockefeller Institute.

Disaster from the skies struck the residential heart of Jamaica, Queens, at 8:27 A. M. yesterday, when a plunging twin-engine cargo plane killed five persons -- both its crew members, two men in their homes and a police inspector in his car.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 -- Two kings who gave up their thrones met again today.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 5 -- Little Joe of Tigathoe, a 2-year-old golden retriever belonging to Mr. George H. V. Flinn Jr. of Greenwich won the Derby Stake that began the two day spring trials of the Women's Field Trial Club today.

ATHENS, April 1 -- An agreement to develop for Greece one of her major national resources, and to provide 100,000 tons of aluminum for Western defense within the next three years, is now in effect between Eleusis Bauxite Mines, Inc., and the United States' Mutual Security Agency mission in Athens.

THE year 1951 opened up bountifully and took in Rachel Carson. Ten years before, Miss Carson wrote her first book, which she called UNDER THE SEA-WIND. It is now reissued by Oxford, at $3.50, and its pages reveal the identical gifts that today have captivated readers: a scrupulous scholarship, a first-hand, warm, individual knowledge of the at least seven-story ocean, and a poetic sensibility.

RIDING up the elevator to meet C. S. Forester, one might have had a reasonably high expectancy that he was about to say hello to a celebrant -- of the secular variety, of course. Mr. Forester had a brand-new Hornblower novel between boards, this time called "Captain Hornblower."

Since the war the cost of government in New York City -- as everywhere else -- has climbed steadily upward. In 1945 the city budget amounted to about $95 for every man, woman and child in the five boroughs. This year the per capital cost is $168. And in the fiscal year 1953, beginning July 1, the figure will go to about $184.

PAUL CEZANNE, as the current Metropolitan retrospective shows, is at once the last of the old masters and the first of the moderns. The pictures on these pages show some of the old masters whose work he studied in the Louvre, the way he transformed the elements he learned into a new, personal expression, simplified and concentrated, and the impetus he gave to a variety of descendants.

THE historical novelist who wishes to win an audience usually seeks its favor in one of two ways. He fills his pages with so much love and adventure that he captures his public by enthralling it. This is escape literature as pure and simple as a "whodunit."

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 5 -- Brazil's coffee harvesting season officially comes to an end May 31, by decision of the Ministry of Finance, and agitation is mounting for higher prices for the next harvest.
Speed-boating's supreme body for rules and regulations, the American Power Boat Association, has a new ruckus, rhubarb and dissenssion on its hands. It is becoming a habit.

THE recent action of the New Jersey Legislature in appropriating funds for the purchase of Island Beach is a conservation event of the first importance. It crowns with sudden success the efforts of a small group of devoted citizens, who for years have been trying by one means or another to insure the preservation of this remarkable area of seashore wilderness.

BETWEEN three and four hundred million of the world's inhabitants are Moslems, or adherents of Islam, the religion founded by the Prophet Mohammed in 622 in the heart of the Arabian desert. Whatever the racial and national differences between them, the Moslems form a more united religious body than do the followers of any other great religion.

ONCE in a while among the mass of (for the most part) pretty sober material that regularly reaches our desk comes a communication of report that starts us off on a pleasantly rambling series of reminiscences.

Stanley Tweedie, 52-year-old driver, will have fifteen horses at the spring light harness meeting that begins at Yonkers Raceway on April 15. He hopes to dethrone Stanley Dancer, the 24-year-old two-time driving champion of the track.

American ski stock soared during the 1951-52 campaign, thanks to the showing of Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence in winning two gold medals in the Winter Olympics and the high places scored by other United States competitors in international meets in Europe.

VIENNA, April 5 (AP) -- Vaclav Nosek, Czechoslovakia's Interior Minister charged local Communist officials of his country today with covering up dishonest farming practices. He said cheating farmers were responsible for Czechoslovakia's bare cupboard.

ALBANY, April 5 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today, at the request of Mayor Impellitteri, a bill authorizing the New York City Board of Higher Education to pay the medical and hospital expenses of students injured in athletic activities conducted by schools under its jurisdiction.
Max Sherover's letter on bilingualism in THE TIMES Magazine, March 23, was most timely in stressing that educated Americans have the duty to become skilled speakers in at least one foreign language.
The following are excerpts from letters by Carol Channing, on tour as Anita Loos' fabulous gold-digger, in the musical, "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes."

FOR many years Professor of History, Language and Literature of the Netherlands at Columbia University, Adriaan J. Barnouw has published several books on Dutch history and poetry. His latest is a brilliantly written and well balanced attempt to present to the American reader the spirit of the people of the Low Countries.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 5 -- Top business leaders from throughout the Western Hemisphere will gather here April 23 and 24 for the first Inter-American Commerce Industry Conference.

GIVEN a castle with secret stairs and sliding doors and a handsome young earl who returns to claim an inheritance which his stepmother and half-brother covet for themselves, Georgette Heyer knows exactly what to do.

Furniture, paintings and other art objects, rugs and decorations of all descriptions continue to pour into the auction galleries, offering at this season of refurbishing a wide choice to the householder.

CIDADE DE GOA, Portuguese India, March 24 (By Airmail) -- With its exports of manganese bringing in dollars from the United States, iron ore going to Japan in a continual procession of ships under many flags, and its vital import needs readily available from a variety of overseas sources, the little Portuguese settlement of Goa appears to be on the way to breaking its historical economic dependance on its huge, enveloping neighbor, India.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation today to make a full check on James P. McGranery, the Federal judge who has been nominated by President Truman as successor to Attorney General J. Howard McGrath.

SEVERAL sportsmen's groups in the Eastern states have been practicing a very realistic form of conservation education by conducting training classes for youthful anglers and hunters. Those instructing the youngsters in the use of firearms and in casting techniques have been making a willing sacrifice of time that otherwise might be spent in enjoying these sports.

James Frank Oliver, who was called a "cat burglar" by the police and was said to have admitted thefts from department stores in this city, Pittsburgh and Cleveland since his release from Auburn Prison last August, was held without bail on a burglary charge yesterday by Magistrate Vernon C. Riddick in Felony Court.

" When I published the first results of my experiments on the possible conservation of wine by preliminary heating it was evident that I only made a new application of the method of Appert," wrote the generous and objective Pasteur in his "Studies of Wine." The man thus hailed as the true inventor of what we call "pasteurization" was Nicholas Appert, born in 1752.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 5 (UP) -- Texas A. and M. captured the Texas Relays crown on the mighty shot-put and discus performances of Darrow Hooper and a record mile relay victory today as three meet standards were broken and two others tied.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 5 (AP) -- Two woman politicians implored other women today to work in political parties "even though the men don't want you."

A GOOD many television broadcasters must get a grip on themselves and try to understand more realistically the nature of their own medium. Their apparent assumption that TV can live by the laws of the entertainment world or the precision methods of the advertising business is making video look childish and foolish.

SETH loved everything about his uncles' garage, even the smell of gasoline. Best of all he loved to help. He could unscrew the gas cap, bring out the oil and water and wash the windshield. One day, when his uncles were out on a towing job, he actually fixed a horn that wouldn't stop blowing, because he remembered what Uncle Jack had told him about the horn wire being grounded.

Members of the Blue Hill Troupe, one of the country's outstanding companies of amateur performers of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, will present "The Sorcerer," as their twenty-eighth annual production, on the nights of April 16, 17 and 18, and the afternoon of April 19 at the Hunter College Playhouse.

The new superliner United States will drop the shackles of the shipyard and move for the first time under her own power on the morning of May 14, when she will start her builder's sea trials. The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, which is constructing the 51,500-gross- ton liner, said yesterday that these trials would require two or three days.

THE first man who took a picture of barbed wire in crisply textured snow was a discoverer, but the second and others were imitators, Alexey Brodovitch said last week in a plea for originality. This famous art director of Harper's Bazaar made the statement before a packed audience of amateur and professional photographers at the Village Camera Club.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 5 -- The future of Thailand's new military Government will depend largely upon whether unity can be maintained between the military leaders within the Cabinet, observers here believe.

BONN, Germany, April 5 -- Western Allied and German officials expressed new optimism today that a contractual agreement designed to replace the Occupation Statute would be ready for ratification by the West German Bundestag (Parliament) in May.

PUBLISHING history will be made tomorrow when the Houghton Mifflin Company announces that its 1951 Literary Fellowship has gone to what is apparently the longest American novel ever accepted for publication.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP) -- Bipartisan economy forces in the House of Representatives asserted today that they had chopped $6,000,000,000 from President Truman's "rock bottom" spending requests for next year, and they promised more cuts.

THREE years ago we were newcomers to suburban living. It didn't take us long to realize that our lawn, lovely as it was, had its drawbacks when it came to putting it to practical use. There was the constant worry about choosing a new and different spot to place reclining chairs and tables so that no real damage would be done to the turf.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois appears to have inherited much of the support for the Democratic Presidential nomination turned loose by President Truman's decision to retire.

BELGRADE, April 5 -- The conviction of Yugoslav leaders that the Trieste question is being used by Italian political parties as a vehicle for their territorial pretensions in the Balkans explains the extraordinary violence of Yugoslav reaction to the unilateral decision of the British and United States Governments to confer with the Italian Government on the problem of associating Italy more closely in the administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste.
ALBANY, April 5 -- A bill setting up a temporary state commission to study the use of television for educational and cultural purposes was approved today by Governor Dewey.

A NEW YORK Supreme Court jury recently brought in the verdict that National Concert and Artists Corporation should pay the violinist, John Creighton Murray, $2,193. Neither side can figure exactly how the jury reached that precise figure, but it was more than the concert manager wanted to pay and considerably less than the violinist asked for.
GLASGOW, April 5 (Reuters) -- England beat Scotland by 2 -- 1 at Hampden Park Stadium today in the main international soccer match of the season.

Fill-ins for Easter and immediate delivery highlighted the activity in the wholesale ready-to-wear markets here last week, resident buying offices reported. Business was said to be seasonal and reorders were noted in all departments. The increase in retail volume has encouraged stores and heavier buying is expected.

THERE is a possibility that "Don Juan in Hell," now at the Plymouth Theatre, may turn up as a movie eventually. We have it on the word of Paul Gregory, producer of the G. B. Shaw work, that he intends to fly to England once the play is closed on May 24, to close a deal with the Shaw estate.

Sales in New York and Brooklyn department stores continued strong with the approach of Easter, and favorable weather was credited for some of the volume. Compared with the corresponding calendar week a year ago, trade observers expressed the opinion that major department stores were about even in terms of over-all volume.

IT may have been the Metropolitan Opera's successful revival of Verdi's Otello that set things off, or it merely may be that "Otello" recordings are long overdue. Whatever the reason, the last few weeks have suddenly become "Otello" - conscious, what with the first complete recording of the great opera on long-play and two abridged versions in addition.

EVEN after reading "Heaven Knows Where" twice, this reviewer must confess to hopeless confusion and an inability to make any comment save of a frivolous nature. This is not because Moira Gaskin is hopelessly untalented.

MISS Schiller's rather contrived novel centers about the doings of a wealthy pioneer in the American Northwest -- now deeply engaged in financing a pageant that will celebrate the country's past, and dreaming (almost as industriously) of his own past, when that same country was young.

In a move not usual in such cases, the local office of the Civil Aeronautics Administration issued a statement yesterday outlining the flight plan and clearance of the U. S. Airlines plane that crashed and gave at least a part of the conversation between the radio control tower at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, and the plane crew.

Mr. Nesterov's trade proposals confirm earlier indications that the Moscow conference would be the scene of a supreme Communist effort to create pressure for lifting of the crippling restrictions on Western exports of strategic goods to the Soviet Union and its satellites.

THIS is an inquiry, by the editors of Fortune, into a massive failure of American business; namely, the failure to "sell" free enterprise to the people. It is the more grievous because presently business is concerned more with selling itself than with selling merchandise.

Cortisone is now made by an intricate process from a cattle-bile acid technically known as desoxycholic acid. Originally the number of steps required was thirty-seven, and the bile acid from forty head of cattle was needed to obtain enough cortisone for a single day's dosage. Despite the improvements that have been made in the process, about twenty steps are still required.
