A "sharply" dressed man and his 19 - year - old girl friend were under arrest yesterday after the police charged they found pure heroin valued at $100,000 in the girl's apartment.

DETROIT, April 5 -- The Michigan Republican convention, successfully avoiding a floor fight between supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, approved today the selection of forty-six uninstructed delegates to the national nominating convention in Chicago opening July 7.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 5 -- Twenty-five owners of farms in the western section of Riverhead Town that are t obe acquired by the Federal Government for the proposed $22,000,000 Navy jet I Plane assembly plant and testing field protested today the low appraisals placed on their land by Federal experts.

THIS reviewer is biased. He enthusiastically admires Reinhold Niebuhr. The phrase "doctor of the soul" best describes Mr. Niebuhr's gift for analyzing sternly, and at the same time sympathetically, the dilemmas of modern man.

ACCOMPANYING the review of Edwin T. Martin's "Thomas Jefferson: Scientist" were two illustrations headed "Jefferson's Inventions." One shows a polygraph. This is definitely not an invention of Jefferson; it was invented -- or developed -- by Charles Willson Peale, that almost forgotten universal genius and painter.

THERE is a shiny, new, expectant feeling about Easter morning not quite like any other day in the year. It is this quality which Pamela Bianco catches in her beguiling little tale, "The Look-Inside Easter Egg."

IT is unfortunate that the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet has been presented the way it has on its first visit to New York, for in its own milieu it is both a more talented and a more important organization than it has been made to appear.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Social Security Administration reported today that the increased sums available to aged persons under the liberalized Social Security Act of 1950 had resulted in a drop in public spending for relief to the aged needy.

NO matter what the personality counselors say, it isn't always easy to be one's self. Especially if, like Penny, one has a glamorous, strong-minded twin sister. Penny was quite as pretty as Pam, but she wasn't so quick with her tongue, or so full of feminine strategy.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 5 (AP) -- Two former Brown University students who received jail sentences in District Court for sounding false fire alarms went into Superior Court today on appeals and came away with deferred sentences.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 5 -- Although Ford Konno took the 440-yard free-style to complete a triple victory. Yale swimmers registered a convincing revenge triumph over Ohio State tonight as the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships closed in Yale's Payne Whitney Gymnasium pool.

Factories of the future will present the weird spectacle of row upon row of robot machines tirelessly grinding out materials to house, feed, clothe, amuse, transport and protect the rapidly increasing populace of this country. In the ghostly interiors of the great production centers, human beings are destined to become fewer and fewer.

William G. Helis Jr.'s Spartan Valor, unbeaten in four starts at sunny Hialeah during January and February, gave another top-quality performance at gray, showery Jamaica yesterday and ran his earnings for the year past the $100,000 mark.

Denis Mealy seems quite delighted to discover that there are Americans who express misgivings as to German rearmament and as to the wisdom of a NATO policy which creates military strength at the expense of economic health and political stability. He calls this "Bevanism in American dress."

I have just read with considerable concern the article in THE TIMES of March 16 by Benjamin Fine entitled "Negro Education in South on Rise." AS one who has devoted twenty-five years of study and labor in this field I am moved to write you.

Town Hall "jumped" to the New Orleans rhythms of Jimmy Archey's band at sundown yesterday. The hour was a bit early for jazzmen, but the Archey ensemble is a smooth-working unit that has been together too long to let that affect the performance, and the temperature rose with each familiar selection.

New home owners can achieve quick garden effects the first year. This is done either by using mature plants and shrubs, or annuals that give almost immediate foliage and color until more permanent plantings have had time to become established.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Sow seeds of hardy vegetables outdoors. Peas head the list, followed by spinach, beets, carrots, lettuce and radish, onion seed and sets. They need no protection now other than the usual covering of soil. Sprinkle seed thinly in rows, which are spaced an adequate distance apart, after the soil has been spaded, fertilized and raked fine.
Giving a fine performance at No. 1 Archie Young scored ten goals to lead the New York Athletic Club trio to the Eastern 12-goal indoor polo championship at the Squadron A Armory last night.
MADISON, Wis., April 5 -- Heavyweight Bob Ranck led Wisconsin to the team championship and won his second straight title himself tonight to cap the fifteenth annual N. C. A. A. boxing tournament.

The New York Puerto Rican Scholarship Fund, Inc., will be the beneficiary of a concert to be given on the night of April 15 in the Hunter College Assembly Hall. Mrs. Charles H. Ridder and Dr. Rafael A. Marin are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

Last Dec. 13 President Truman, visibly aroused over disclosures of corruption in his administration, said at a news conference that he was ready to take not just drastic action, but continued drastic action. "Wrongdoers," he said, "have no house with me."
William S. White's article on Congressional investigations is a fine one. Congress is definitely assuming powers unto itself that were not granted by the Constitution.

AT the turn of the century the Florida Everglades and the vast water-wilderness of the Big Cypress Swamp that forms its western boundary were as yet unspoiled. Lake Okeechobee sparkled in the sunlight and no man-made dikes curbed its rampaging waters.

Language is no barrier to a young New York artist, who for years has traveled by himself across country, through Mexico and many of the countries of Europe. His handicap of being a deaf-mute is apparently nonexistent.
CAMP KILMER, N. J., April 5 -- The Army's stepped-up program for releasing Reservists and National Guardsmen from active duty is being felt at this post's processing center.

SEVENTEEN years ago today, Edwin Arlington Robinson died. When publicity is the watchword of these confused times, it is refreshing to recall a man who pursued his way quietly and endured baffling hardships uncomplainingly, never for a moment swerving from the inflexible purpose of his life, which was to write poetry.

I WAS very interested in reading about the American Theatre Wing's presentation of the "Tony" awards. While some of the awards were to be taken for granted. I was more than a little puzzled by some of the others. For instance, I was particularly stymied by Yul Brynner's winning an award in the "supporting actor" category.

THE novel about the immigrant in America, about the multiplicity of small racial groups here, has become compartmentalized until it is almost literally possible to look up Portuguese under P or Italian under I and run one's finger down an index list and come to c and learn that there are novels about the Portuguese in California.

A CERTAIN sheep-killing weed (Halogeton glomeratus) has been creeping across some of the Western states. Yellow fever has broken out in Brazil. Volcanoes have been kicking up from the bottom of the Pacific.

Gian-Carlo Menotti's television opera, "Amahl and the Night Visitors," will be presented for the first time by the New York City Opera Company Wednesday night at the City Center, it was announced yesterday. Chet Allen, Rosemary Kuhlman, Michael Pollock and Lawrence Winters will sing leading roles. On the same bill will be Mr. Menotti's "The Old Maid and the Thief."

A revolutionary new testing method, using radioactive materials, proves that today's new high quality motor oils, developed since the end of World War II, can actually triple the life of your car engine.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 5 (AP) -- Thee and Me, claimed for $17,500 at Hialeah Park Feb. 16, posted his first victory for Samuel H. Popkin as he streaked to an upset length-and-a-half triumph in the $7,500 Fort Lauderdale Handicap before 14,127 fans at Gulfstream Park today.

ATLANTA, April 5 -- Touching off a fifteen-hit barrage behind another commendable pitching effort by Vic Raschi, the Yankees today made it two in a row over the Crackers as they vanquished Dixie Walker's Atlanta club, 9 -- 2, in a frostbitten encounter before 2,365 onlookers.

THIS promising first novel is played out against an uptown New York slum background twenty years ago: its troubles are motivated, for the most part, by the fact that one Joseph Dante suffers from an ailment which may be either excessive pride or plain worthlessness.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 5 (AP) -- Southern California, aiming for its fourth successive national collegiate track and field championship, showed an array of talent today to swamp California, 76 1/6 to 54 5/6, in their forty-fourth annual meet.

CONTRARY to Jonathan Leonard's statement in his review of "The Geography of Hunger" by Josue de Castro, my book, "Road to Survival," is a plea for the use of social and scientific measures, including birth control, to reach a balance between human demands (hunger is not the only one) and the means of satisfying them.

THE task of re-establishing connection with the Reformation is being undertaken today by the Protestant phase of the current religious revival. To this end this anthology, edited by the minister emeritus of Riverside Church, will make an enormous contribution.

HAVANA, April 5 -- The Soviet Union's severance of diplomatic relations with the Government of Maj. Gen. Fulgencio Batista probably will have little material effect on Moscow's main objectives in Cuba, since the important element of the Communist movement went underground many months ago, according to the best information available here today.

Gone almost entirely are the days when owners of barns and fences in many towns across the land could receive free circus tickets for displaying on their properties dazzling posters advertising the "Greatest Show on Earth."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Who will investigate corruption now? This week's surprising petard that hoisted Attorney General J. Howard McGrath out of the Cabinet and Newbold Morris out of Washington also appeared to demolish the Administration's hope of doing its own housecleaning.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- There is mounting discontent among Soviet peasants because of their steadily worsening livestock position as compared with those in the collective farms, Government observers here believe.

PARIS, April 5 (UP) -- Close associates of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower described today his powerful showing in Iowa, where the Republicans elected fourteen national convention delegates favorable to the general, as "another clear call to political duty."
" AS soon as the sun started to climb today, I knew THE TIME was here. The air had a different smell, a different feel -- a sort of softness -- and there was power in the sun's brightness."
Rain that fell alternately in drizzles and downpours provided a bleak, grim background at the scene of yesterday's C-46 cargo plane crash in Jamaica, Queens.

EXACTLY sixty years ago this month, William Macbeth, a young Irishman with beguiling blue eyes and a soft, brown beard that masked the roundness of his face, left the print-selling firm of Frederick Keppel Co., where he had worked for eighteen years, and sent out an announcement: "I respectfully call attention to the fact that I have leased the store, No. 237 Fifth Avenue, for the permanent exhibition and sale of American pictures.

THE COLUMBUS CITIZEN'S first New York Theatre Party was undertaken on the premise that people who enjoy going to a show will enjoy it more if the show is playing in the vicinity of Times Square. The success of the theatre tour, conducted the week of March 16, and the comments of the travelers, have established the soundness of that premise.

NEW DELHI, India, April 5 -- Famine in vast areas of South India, where millions of peasants are never far from real hunger even in the best of times, may result in the extension of communism to districts where Communists failed to score impressively at the polls in the recent national elections despite their success in near-by constituencies.
ROCKFORD, Ill., April 5 -- This northern Illinois city of 93,000 population began celebrating its one-hundredth birth today with Tage Erlander, Premier of Sweden, as its guest of honor.
Regarding Allan Nevins' "Why Public Men Keep Diaries" (March 23), one great incitement is probably that given by Boswell:

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP) -- The Air Force partly removed today the secrecy wraps from its giant new YB-60 eight jet engine bomber -- the latest United States weapon capable of carrying atomic warfare anywhere in the world.

THE music of Easter is not so well known as that of Christmas -- and certainly not so easy to sing -- but new recordings underline that the Easter repertoire is more extensive and, on the whole, contains more important music.

HONG KONG, April 5 -- When the Chinese "volunteers" crossed the Yalu River in October, 1950, the Peiping regime launched a "resist America and aid Korea movement" throughout Communist China. Not a day has passed since then when the country has not been in the midst of some kind of frantic campaign related either directly or indirectly to this mobilization movement.
Sixteen artists have been elected to associate membership in the National Academy of Design, Lawrence Grant White, president of the academy, announced yesterday. They include:
NASHVILLE, April 5 -- The Dodgers defeated the Braves, 8 -- 7, in ten innings in Nashville's famous Sulphurdell Park today.

THE setting is Shiloh, bloody Shiloh, see-sawing, confused Shiloh, when Lincoln was still searching for his general and the South was sure it had one in Albert Sidney Johnston. Nobody really won at Shiloh. One army attacked and then turned away, back farther south; the other stood and buried the dead for both sides.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 6 -- United Nations headquarters said yesterday that epidemics of disease were sweeping China and North Korea as the result of privation and semi-starvation under the Communist regimes and Russian-inspired refusal of assistance from international relief agencies.

EVERY vegetable, grower is impatient to harvest the first produce of the new gardening year. One way of obtaining a crop early in May is to plant a perennial vegetable corner. This can include delectable asparagus, which is harvested from early May until July.

Wall Street's reaction to the Mahoney Bill, which has passed both houses of the State Legislature and is awaiting the Governor's signature, which permits the state to take over unclaimed interest and dividends on securities in the hands of brokers and deaers, avoids the pitfalls of its vetoed predecessor.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., April 5 (AP) -- One record fell as a field of more than 200 athletes competed in the seventh annual Carolina Relays today.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 5 -- Henry Wittenberg, New York City police sergeant, came out of a four-year retirement to win his eighth National Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championship as a new line-up of titleholders emerged tonight in the sixty-second annual tournament.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- Work on the new Arizona Desert Botanical and Zoological Gardens near here is progressing rapidly. It is expected that by June many of the installations will be ready for the summer tourist influx, although, because of the scope of the project, all of the exhibits will not be in place before next fall.

THIRTY years ago a young not long out of Harvard University and Greenwich Village corralled a group of writers to set down their opinions of the state of affairs in this country in the fields of their specialty.

TOM GARLAND thinks it's time someone blew the whistle on prices. What Tom thinks is important. Not because there is anything exceptional about Tom, but because there is nothing exceptional about him. Tom comes as close to being Mr. Average Worker as it is possible to find among New York's army of wage-earners.

KINGSTON, N. Y., April 5 -- The flag of the Netherlands flew above City Hall here today to honor the Queen who had come to help Kingston celebrate its 300th anniversary and leaf through the memories of its Dutch founding and early history.
AN expert player in New England once remarked, "I'm glad I never learned much about squeezes and plays like that. It saves me all those tough guesses between a squeeze and a finesse."

At 10:57 last Saturday night, President Truman made known his decision to leave the White House voluntarily on Jan. 20, 1953. He said: "I have served my country long * * * I do not feel it is my duty to spend another four years in the White House."

In this period of rising costs of Government and higher taxes, attempts by the Congress to reduce Federal expenditures usually merit applause. However, in its recent action of eliminating $85,617,740 from the administrative funds of the Veterans Administration, the House of Representatives has engaged in a classic example of the "penny-wise, pound-foolish" philosophy.

A comparison of the "Fine Arts and Commercial Art" will be made on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. in an art lecture by James Ernst, instructor at City College, at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The library series on art, under the direction of Simon Lissim, will continue on Tuesdays, same time, on April 22. There will be no lecture next week.

Most of the palms distributed today at Palm Sunday services in churches throughout the country have been "home-grown" in two states, a North American Newspaper Alliance survey reported yesterday. In contrast, before World War I, the majority of the fronds used to mark the start of Holy Week were imported.
Please permit me to make a few comments on the news item, "Business in India Warned by Nehru," in your issue of March 30.

THIS distinguished collection of fifteen short stories by the British author of "Fair Stood the Wind for France" and "The Purple Plain" invites favorable comparison with the best of A. E. Coppard or Elizabeth Bowen or V. S. Pritchett.
Gradual but steady improvement of pre-Easter sales gave encouragement to retail merchants last week.

THE Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, says that he is not at all concerned in competing for a television audience with N. B. C.'s Milton Berle on Tuesdays at 8 P. M. Bishop Sheen's inspirational chalk talks, presented by the DuMont network under the title "Life Is Worth Living," began two months ago on three stations and now are carried by seventeen.
TOKYO, April 5 -- The growing South Korean Army soon will be in a position to "stand on its own feet and secure freedom and security to the republic," Gen. James A. Van Fleet said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The recruiting of athletes, abolished by the United States Military Academy at West Point after the dismissal last August of close to ninety cadets, many of them members of Army's powerful 1950 football team, has been resumed by the service school, Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia, disclosed today.

Probably the most exciting Republican convention in the memory of the current generation of politicians was the one at Philadelphia twelve years ago, when Wendell L. Willkie, an only slightly reformed Democrat, was nominated for President on the fifth ballot.

THE publication of Dylan Thomas' new book of poems, "In Country Sleep," coincides with his second visit to our shores. These are some of the poems this foremost Welsh poet of our time has written since "The Selected Writings of Dylan Thomas."
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP) -- New bids have been made for purchase of International Hydroelectric System (I. H. E. S,) properties in New York State and New England.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 5 (AP) -- Despite a 20 per cent attendance dip and abandonment of six loops, the minor baseball leagues head into the 1952 season with guarded optimism.

THE subject of evening primroses should be approached with an open mind. The names of the plants are likely to vary, and so is their performance under differing conditions. In fact, as Reginald Farrer, the famous English plant hunter, put it, "the names seem to be in a constant state of flux."

PARIS, April 5 -- France's ambitious post-war plan to assemble the jigsaw puzzle parts of its former colonial empire into a centralized French Union with common citizenship for more than a hundred million inhabitants is seriously threatened at two focal points -- Indo-China and North Africa.

Brenda Putnam and Malvina Hoffman, portrait sculptors, have been commissioned by the Hall of Fame for Great Americans to fashion busts of Susan B. Anthony and Thomas Paine, Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, director of the memorial, announced yesterday.

A joint United States-Canadian critique and "post-mortem" last week on Convex III, the Navy's coastal convoy exercise recently completed, again emphasized the Navy's primary combat role -- control of the seas.
SPRING in 57th Street is off to a crowded start. Indeed, there is now so much in the way of first rate exhibitions that lack of space alone precludes here lengthy treatment.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 5 (UP) -- A college drama student told police today he went along on a "gentleman's agreement" while a friend kept a suicide promise at "Dreamy Draw." Then he dove his friend's body home, the student said.
Steve Owen, coach of the New York pro football Giants, spoke on the art of tackling yesterday as the two-day New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association conference came to a close.

May I, through your columns, ask people who are kindly replying to me to accept grateful thanks and appreciation for letters which I am afraid I will not be able to answer individually. I fully intend to write personally to as many as I can.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5 -- The United States made public today a plan for a stage-by-stage census of the world's military power, with disclosure of the location of all atomic plants to come in the first round.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, April 5 -- The fate of the conference on German indemnity to Israel and world Jewish organizations for Nazi anti-Semitic acts is being decided this week-end in consultations in the West German capital of Bonn.
Echoes of the recent political upheaval in Cuba were heard here yesterday when Jose Ruiz Galera, a Havana attorney, was arrested as a fugitive from a $51,000 grand larceny charge in Florida.

PROFESSOR of English Literature at Queen Mary College of the University of London, J. Isaacs is a Shakespearean scholar of well-deserved reputation. His present excursion into modern poetry, however, is not so much scholarship as it is scholar's talk, and very pleasant and pertinent talk it is.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 5 -- South Africa's bitter constitutional crisis, precipitated by Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's plan to adopt legislation to prevent the Supreme Court from testing Acts of Parliament, has begun to rock religious institutions.

THE motion picture industry was knee deep in controversy last week. In Washington, Eric A. Johnston, president of The Motion Picture Association of America, and a committee of industry leaders met with officials of the American Legion in an attempt to convince them that picketing of certain movies on allegations of Communist influence was both unwarranted and harmful to the industry and its people.

The nation's telegraph communication system continued yesterday to operate as the Western Union Telegraph Company strike moved into its third day, but the union and management made conflicting reports on the extent of service.

Even before the peepers announced that spring was here to stay, before the day lilies thrust up their prophetic fleurs-de-lis of first leafage, the fresh leaves of the celandine were spread to catch the sun. Where the celandine flourished, in fact, the illusion of spring debated the season with the snow while the peepers were still deep in hibernation.
Frank Costello, the gambler, awaited yesterday his sentencing on Tuesday for contempt of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

Moscow's World Economic Conference finally began last Thursday, and its proceedings to date have been pretty much as had been expected. Elaborate preparations made to impress the foreign delegates worked smoothly As the delegates began arriving last week they were greeted by Tuesday's price cuts, timed to show them scenes of stores filled with people rushing to take advantage of "bargains."

Religious ceremonies, while not important in themselves, may have a practical significance, Rabbi Bernard J. Bamberger said in a sermon yesterday morning at the West End Snyagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street.

AFTER a quarter century it still seems appropriate to lead off a listing of music in the jazz idiom with Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue. For this opus, when it is performed with any degree of conviction, represents the jazz spirit as no other self-conscious composition has ever done.

How much legal authority does the Government have to seize key industries in strike situations? The courts may get a chance to pass on this question if President Truman decides that the national interest requires him to take over the steel mills this week.

The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions has opened a college in France for the purpose of training democratic trade-union leaders who will counteract the work of the Communist-dominated Confederation of Labor (C. G. T.) and at the same time furnish vigorous guidance in the solution of the many pressing problems that beset French workmen. That the project is formidable goes without saying.

It will be tuliptime in New York and across the nation as Queen Juliana makes her American stop-overs. Because the visit not only coincides appropriately with the height of the bulb flower season but will inspire so many special floral displays, the Queen of the Netherlands occasionally may suspect that she has not left home.

CAIRO, April 5 -- The British Ambassador, Sir Ralph Stevenson, called on Foreign Minister Abdel Khalek Hassouna today to inform him of the British Treasury's "gesture of goodwill" in agreeing to release 10,000,000 ($28,000,000) from Egypt's blocked sterling balances now instead of later.
MOUNT VERNON, Ill., April 5 -- A victory for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the Illinois Presidential preference primary was indicated here tonight.
CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- The American League today reminded member clubs of new regulations concerning play under lights on Sundays and suspended games.

The Red Cross needed no alert to mobilize its facilities for the Queens plane disaster yesterday because the head of the Central Queens Red Cross Chapter was an eyewitness of it.

Six of these people, according to the figures presented in this informative volume, would be in their twenties or thirties.

READERS have gradually come to realize that America has produced an original and powerful literature. It is a literature distinctive enough to have stimulated an increasing, rich body of criticism, of analysis, interpretation and documentation. In "Literary America,"* David E. Scherman and Rosemarie Redlich have contributed yet another facet to our fertile literary investigations.

COLUMBIA, S. C., April 5 (UP) -- Cass Michaels, Mickey Vernon and Mickey Grasso hit home runs during a five-run sixth inning rally today as the Senators beat the Reds, 9 -- 7, for their first victory over the National Leaguers in five tries this spring.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, said today "the rolling groundswell of citizen demand for Dwight Eisenhower to be President is felt as strongly in the South as in all other parts of the nation"
BOSTON, April 5 (AP) -- Five education writers, a newspaper and a motion picture were cited here tonight for outstanding contributions to education.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 5 (AP) -- Blanking Bob Davies, the Minneapolis Lakers took a one-game edge in the semi-final series with the Rochester Royals tonight, scoring a 77-67 victory before 9,146 fans.

Not since the National Basketball Association has been in existence has there been anything like the tumultuous, punch-throwing conclusion of last night's third play-off game between the New York Knickerbockers and the Syracuse Nationals at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

THE HAGUE -- Visitors to the Netherlands are apt to expect very specific scenery in the Lowlands, including windmills, cows, canals, dikes and wooden shoes. Especially windmills. Without these upright, life-like creatures waving their arms in the steady winds off the North Sea, Holland would not be Holland.

The way to a new era of economic progress for Ireland is soon to be sought with the aid of privately-furnished American "know-how." Services of two United States organizations in the fields of management consulting and marketing research have been engaged for a three-month industrial survey aimed at rapid and substantial increase of Irish exports, particularly to the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Truman signed today a bill through which preliminary background investigations of applicants for Federal employment in the various agencies under the Atomic Energy Commission, Mutual Security Administration and Department of State would be handled by the Civil Service Commission rather than by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
TELEVISION will travel far afield next Sunday to bring into living rooms across the nation a cross-section of Easter observances.

FROM Paris comes official word that France's 1952 stamp-issuing prorgam is to include seven items with portraits of nineteenth-century Frenchmen associated with administration, literature, medicine, music, painting, science and statesmanship.

AZALEA petal blight is a devastating disease that strikes suddenly at the height of the flowering season, which is already in progress in the South. It is a disease of flowers only, with no foliage symptoms whatever. The vitality of the bush is not impaired, but the unsightly effect of blighted blossoms in massed azalea plantings can scarcely be imagined by those who have not seen it.
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, April 5 (AP) -- Republicans in Idaho directed their fourteen-delegate slate to the Republican national convention to be "honor bound" to support Senator Robert A. Taft today.

The approach of Easter has brought an upturn in the men's shirt business, manufacturers said last week. Reorders have been increasing steadily the last few days and have surpassed last year's pre-Easter demand.

BALTIMORE, April 5 -- A seven-man committee will be named Tuesday to investigate Maryland racing, according to State Senator George Della, chairman of the Legislative Council.

American Legionnaires are expected to spend $15,000,000 during the national convention here Aug. 25 to 28. Convention officials made this estimate last week as they met at the Statler Hotel to discuss arrangements and map out committee assignments.

My husband and I were delighted with Harry Gilroy's commentary on cats and made special note of his comments on the Abyssinian. Since their rarity prevents them from becoming very popular, we thought we might tell your readers what it's like to live with one.

Fire-resistant treatments for textiles -- to prevent casualties from brush rayon "torch sweaters," fuzzy "chaps" of children's cowboy suits, and other flimsy combustible fabrics -- are being developed at Columbia University under the direction of Prof. James M. Church. One of the most promising agents is polybromoallyl phosphate. The fabric is soaked in a solution of this. A subsequent heat treatment firmly anchors the phosphate. After that the fabric is flame resistant.

FOR years Broadway has heard pious platitudes concerning the sacred and significant role played by college, university, and community theatres in fostering native drams. These smug generalizations by academic and community theatre spokesmen have inevitably been accompanied by denigrating allusions to the "crass commercialism" of Broadway.

Yesterday's heavy rains, which reached 1.06 inches in the city by 5 P. M., and the crash of the C-46 plane in Jamaica, Queens, caused delays of up to two hours in plane arrivals and the cancellation of twenty-eight flights at La Guardia Airport.

THE post-war version of the 35mm Dollina, the Super Dollina II, and a new 35mm Edinex Midget Marvel have been imported from Germany by Camera Specialty Company, 50 West Twenty-ninth Street, the American distributor.

Wisconsin Power and Light Company is offering to its common stockholders rights to subscribe for 288,208 new shares of common at $17.15 a share on the basis of one share for each seven held. Subject to the prior subscription rights of the stockholders, employes may subscribe for the new common stock at the same price.

CHATTANOOGA, April 6 -- Seven innings of almost perfect pitching by Warren Spahn and two more of the same by Ernie Johnson today left the Dodgers with no hits, no runs and no love for the Boston flingers.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Trade activity on the Board of Trade was light again last week, the volume of purchases being slightly smaller than a week before and about the same as a year ago. Long liquidation was heavy at times, but apparently it was not of as large volume as usual in such periods.

Barring a last-minute break in deadlocked negotiations, it appeared certain early this morning that the nation would awaken today to a strike of 65,800 telephone workers affecting forty-three states and the District of Columbia. Such a walkout, added to the four-day-old

KINGSVILLE, Tex., April 6 -- The great cattle-raising King Ranch, the largest single beef-producing operation in the United States and perhaps in the world, is caught today in the worst drought in its ninety-nine-year history.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6 -- Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate, sent a blistering letter to Prof. Frederic Joliot-Curie today, accusing the French Communist physicist of "prostituting" science in the interest of the Cominform's "germ warfare" propaganda campaign.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N. H., April 6 (AP) -- Billy Beck, Olympic skier from Kingston, R. I., won a shortened version of the American Inferno race today in 4:14.2 for the two and three quarter mile course.

Mrs. Golda Myerson, Israeli Minister of Labor, asked yesterday for continued assistance in her country's struggle for economic independence as she addressed two groups working for the United Jewish Appeal.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- Eight doctors and a nurse at the Philadelphia General Hospital are slated to be dismissed tomorrow unless they change their minds about refusing to sign Pennsylvania's new loyalty oath, which became a requirement for all public employes April 1.

AMSTERDAM, April 6 -- The Netherlands Bank suspended all credit restrictions this week. This action was taken because of the improved foreign exchange position, the easier demand for credit and probably also to relieve unemployment.

The most attractive horse race so far this year in the 3-year-old division is scheduled for today at the Jamaica track. It's a six-furlong sprint for a $10,000 purse, and the entrants, all stakes-winners, are Tom Fool, Cousin, Primate, Armageddon, Master Fiddle and One Throw.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- The Farm Belt still is the main battleground for rival Republican Presidential aspirants this week. The main contenders clash in the Illinois primary on Tuesday and in the Kansas State Republican Convention on Thursday, with a total of seventy-two delegates at stake.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 6 (AP) -- The Women's Leadership Conference called today for a "new dynamic" in United States life -- "united action by those who believe in the power of God and the brotherhood of man" in behalf of freedom.

Trade between the United States and Brazil reached a new high of approximately $1,800,000,000 in 1951, but it may fall off considerably this year, Dr. Jose G. Torres, retiring director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau here, said last week.
HYDE PARK, N. Y., April 6 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands walked out of tiny old St. James Protestant Episcopal Church here today carrying a long palm frond after having taken communion.

Mayor Impellitteri was urged yesterday to cancel his recent appointment of Jeremiah A. Sullivan, Democratic leader in Staten Island, to a $9,000 job as a member of the Municipal Tax Commission. The Citizens Union asked also for cancellation of the appointment of Francis J. Sotile of Staten Island as a Justice of the Court of Special Sessions at $17,500 a year.

LONDON, April 6 -- Friday's statement by R. A. Butler, the Chancellor Exchequer on the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves as of the end of last month came fully up to the city's best expectations. Indeed it exceeded them because of the Chancellor's news that at end of March these reserves actually were rising again after their calamitous fall.

Cash prizes ranging from $10 to $500 would be given, under a plan proposed yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri, to city employes submitting the most practical suggestions for improving city services and effecting economies in municipal government.

Fifteen robed children carrying musical hand bells opened the Palm Sunday service yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Ninety - first Street. Standing on the church steps, the youngsters entertained church-goers and passers-by with a series of hymns played on twenty-five hand-forged bells that had been imported from England in 1947 by the minister, the Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe.

Jewish shopkeepers in Brooklyn reported yesterday that they had been visited by Roman Catholic laymen who "persisted" in requests that they close their stores for three hours on Good Friday and display signs saying this was in observance "of the death of Christ."

Let me express warm support for your editorial on New York's water supply dated March 27. My only wish, however, was that your reference to universal water metering had not been relegated to the last sentence in the next-to-the-last paragraph.

The "released time" program for religious education and Bible reading and morning prayers in public schools are part of a "well organized attempt by religious forces to regain their lost control over the state," John Haynes Holmes, minister emeritus of the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, charged yesterday in his sermon.

PARIS, April 6 -- Prompt ratification of the treaty to create a European Defense Community with a single armed force, which it is hoped will be signed in May, is expected to depend upon the kind of guarantees that may come from the United States and Britain.

The program presented to the International Economic Conference in Moscow by the president of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce, Mihail Nesterov, promises substantial relief from some pressing problem to nearly every capitalist country. Britain is offered orders from Russia sufficient to take up the slack in the textile mills of Lancashire.
The Emmanuel Presbyterian Church, 737 East Sixth Street, whose first meeting rooms were in a lower East Side hotel, celebrated yesterday its hundreth anniversary.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 6 -- Immigration is a vital element in the development of Brazil and a particularly live issue lately because of the bitter charges made that Communist agents, black market operators and general undesirables outnumber useful immigrants.

To follow the sea, according to poets since the time of Homer, is a romantic and fascinating way of life. But those who have sailed in modern merchant marines are aware of the extent to which the seaman of today, thrown back upon his own resources for recreation and amusement, is subject to tedium and boredom during his off-watch time on long voyages abroad.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 3 -- Venezuelans consider themselves and their country to be the most misunderstood and least appreciated in Latin America. Many of them have developed a distaste for United States newspapers and newspaper men, for visiting trade union delegations, for leagues for the rights of man, for militant liberals everywhere and for all who believe more or less implicitly what Venezuelan exiles from the Accion Democratica party say.

OTTAWA, April 6 (AP) -- Six companies getting set to spend hundreds of millions on pipelines for natural gas out of Alberta are coming before the Canadian Board of Transport Commissioners tomorrow to look for franchises.

TUNIS, Tunisia, April 6 -- Ten days of delicate negotiations by Salaheddine Baccouche for the formation of a cabinet in France's North African protectorate of Tunisia to replace the nationalist one ousted by the French ten days ago, appeared to be on the verge of success tonight.
United States support of the Tito regime in Yugoslavia was condemned yesterday by the Most Rev. James H. Griffiths, auxiliary bishop to the Roman Catholic military vicar, Cardinal Spellman.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade were under liquidating pressure last week, selling being induced by weak spots in the commodity list and the Western Union strike and the threat of a steel walkout.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 -- A par-equaling 72 today brought Sam Snead the Masters crown for the second time at the Augusta National Golf Club. He completed the 72-hole test under unfavorable conditions with a score of 286.

Two sports items head today's agenda: the debut of Joe DiMaggio's television show, coming after his retirement as a member of the New York Yankees, and the efforts of the DuMont network to popularize the game of indoor polo.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6 -- The United States gave the United Nations an account today of the steps taken by the government bodies to safeguard the political and civil rights of citizens and protect their fundamental liberties.

ATCHISON, Kan., April 6 (AP) -- Three men regarded as favoring Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for the Democratic Presidential nomination probably will represent the Kansas First District at the party's national convention.

DALLAS, April 6 -- Sal Maglie started against the Indians today, hoping to pitch nine innings. In bright sunlight, with the temperature in the high seventies, an overflow crowd of 11,302 looked on. Bob Lemon was Sal's mound rival. The Giants' star right-hander ran into early trouble, never righted himself and staggered through seven innings. The Indians took the ball game, 9 to 4.

The first joint talks under the auspices of the Government's wage chief failed yesterday to ease the threat of a national steel strike at midnight tomorrow. Federal officials will press their efforts to find a peace formula today, but an angry exchange of charges by top management and union spokesmen indicated that the chances for success were slight.

Governor Dewey's approval of the Mitchell-Ten Eyck Bill has sounded an opening broadside in the state's war on alcoholism. This measure constitutes the boldest action taken thus far to cope with a serious social problem in our state.

Shortly before noon yesterday 200 persons left a West Side I. R. T. train that was halted just south of the Times Square station and walked along a catwalk to the station platform. They were among several thousand passengers affected by a tie-up in the subway system.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- A medical insurance plan providing protection up to $5,000 to injured athletes was approved today and recommended for adoption by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

Four singers undertook new roles last night at the City Center when Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier" received its second production of the spring season of the New York City Opera. The singers demonstrated the strength of the company, for all four of them were good.
ALBANY, April 6 -- Legislation closing loopholes in New York's "anti-hot-rod" law was approved today by Governor Dewey.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 6 -- An alarming tendency to stress technical skills over cultural values in present day premedical education was reported tonight by Gilbert White, president of Haverford College.

A Police Department official who volunteered in 1939 to have his salary reduced 5 per cent for a year to help Fiorello H. La Guardia, then Mayor, balance the city budget, retired at 12:01 A. M. today, his sixty-third birthday.
LONDON, April 7 (Monday) (Reuters) -- The Association of British Chambers today appealed to R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, to drop an excess profits levy proposed in his recent budget.
Eleven new films, including imports from Italy, England, Israel, Sweden and Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The public was forced to "take a back seat" at the recent session of the New York State Legislature because "of the intense preoccupation of a Republican Governor and his Republican majority with the political maneuvers of their own party," it was charged yesterday by Democratic State Chairman Paul E. Fitzpatrick.

The United Nations command has again called attention to the ravages of epidemic disease in Communist China. The Peiping radio in several broadcasts has indicated the gravity of the situation and there is no reason to suppose that the United Nations statement is any exaggeration.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Candidates for Republican and Democratic nomination to various offices seeking votes in the Illinois primary on Tuesday presented late-hour pleas and arguments today in many of the state's 102 counties.
In anticipation of the Easter parade, many denizens of the toy departments in stores here already are decked out in their Easter finery.
TOKYO, Monday, April 7 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,212, for Sunday's operations:
The skipper is a "commuter" now -- and he loves it!

DURING the last two years William H. Whyte Jr., assistant managing editor of Fortune, and a squad of other Fortune editors and researchers have been conducting an investigation into the folkways of American business. Some of their interim reports caused considerable commotion when they were first published in Fortune.

Gov. Earl Warren of California, contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, arrived here yesterday for a six-day stay, during which he will make two formal political speeches and probably several radio broadcasts and television appearances as well.

LONG BEACH, L. I., April 6 -- Long Beach's bus transportation may soon be returned to private ownership. On April 15 the City Council will hold a public hearing on a plan to give the seaside city regular bus transportation during the summer months and taxicab jitney service the rest of the year.

BONN, Germany, April 6 -- West German representatives have been instructed by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to accept for negotiation most of the claims made by Israel and nongovernmental Jewish groups for restitutions and reparations, particularly the Israeli estimates of costs in resettling Jewish refugees.
CAIRO, April 6 -- Political circles here generally felt today that the Anglo-Egyptian talks had reached so critical a phase that they might easily go up in smoke at any moment.

Six paintings, four of them by artists living and working in New York, have been purchased by the National Academy of Design from its 127th Annual Exhibition, now current, for distribution to museums and other cultural institutions.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 6 -- Lebanon, according to published and other information here today, definitely has placed herself in opposition to efforts to link the Arab League states to a future pan-Islamic bloc. An Islamic consultative conference scheduled in Karachi, Pakistan, is understood to be the prelude to this bloc.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The continuing need of newsprint throughout the world and its vital significance as a weapon in the battle for minds was emphasized in a report today by a subcommittee on Newsprint of the Senate Select Committee on Small Business in its study "Newsprint for Tomorrow."

An audience of 2,200 packed the auditorium of Hunter College on Saturday night for Marian Anderson's only New York recital of the season. The event was the tenth and final concert in the subscription series directed at the college by Dr. Benno Lee.
S. M. Chartock's presentation of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, starring Martyn Green, which was scheduled for this spring, has been postponed until the fall.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period March 29 to April 4 are given in the appended tabulation:

MOSCOW, April 6 -- Diplomats here have concluded that Premier Stalin believes that all outstanding world problems are capable of settlement by discussion and negotiation and regards with an open mind suggestions for a meeting of the chiefs of state of the great powers.

Work by American artists is prominent in this week's exhibitions. On Thursday, the Museum of Modern Art will show painting and sculpture by fifteen contemporaries. Today, the Rose Fried Gallery is giving a retrospective exhibition of work by A. E. Gallatin, paintings by B. J. O. Nordfeldt will be on view at the Passedoit Gallery, and sculpture by Robert Laurent is the attraction at Kraushaar's.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Senator Brien McMahon announced tonight that the Senate-House of Representatives Atomic Energy Committee soon would hold a series of public hearings "on both peace-time uses and military applications of atomic energy."

The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared in a sermon yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine that Pilate's question, "What shall I do with Jesus which is called Christ?" still was the decisive problem facing the world.
BISMARCK, N. D., April 6 (UP) -- A Missouri River flood caught Bismarck by surprise today, chasing more than 1,000 persons from their homes and ripping houses from their foundations.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that four large publishing houses had agreed to an order prohibiting "discriminatory" pricing practices. Still at issue, however, were charges that these publishers and two others had given "unfair" competitive advantage to book clubs over retail book stores.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The American Council for Judaism went on record unanimously today in asserting that "there is no Jewish vote and that no Jew and no organization of Jews can speak for all Americans of Jewish faith."
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -- The Commerce Department reported today that the United States had spent $39,000,000,000 to help rehabilitate and rearm friendly nations since World War II.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois was advanced again today as a possible Democratic Presidential nominee as Frank E. McKinney, Democratic National Chairman, warned that no one could get to the White House unless he was willing "to work for it."
ATLANTA, April 6 -- Mishaps and ailments of varying sorts in the past few days may have thinned the ranks of the Yankees, but Casey Stengel still is far from scraping the bottom of the barrel.

HONG KONG, Monday, April 7 -- Dr. Wu Lien-teh, Chinese plague expert and onetime corresponding member of the Soviet Society of Microbiology, declared in an article published here today that the Communist bloc had been putting out a "long string of unfounded accusations" on the subject of "germ warfare."

NEW DELHI, India, April 6 -- Twenty textile mills in Amhedabad, Bombay State, have decided to eliminate night shifts next month because of the steep fall in cloth prices and over-production, according to reports from Bombay. The stoppage of one shift would mean unemployment to 30,000 workers.
Samuel Reshevsky made it two in a row of Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires yesterday.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., April 6 (UP) -- Fala, President Roosevelt's black Scottish terrier, was buried today at his master's feet in the Hyde Park rose garden. The elder statesman of dogs, who had sat at the feet of some of the world's most important men, was buried in a pine box just six days before the seventh anniversary of Mr. Roosevelt's death.

Moscow may have intended to drop a bombshell by making its $7,500,000,000 to $10,000,000,000 trade offer at the International Economic Conference last Saturday, but the actual effect is likely to be more nearly that of a dud, Washington officials concluded yesterday after twenty-four hours of intensive study of the proposals.

CLEVELAND, April 6 -- The determination of the peoples of France, Italy and other European countries to fight communism is being weakened by the fear that "a few hysterical senators and congressmen and several swashbuckling generals" speak for all America, Victor Reuther, representative in Europe for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, warned the United States Automobile Workers Educational Conference today.

WITH UNITED STATES SECOND DIVISION, in Korea, March 31 (Delayed) -- Airmail letters urging surrender are being addressed individually and specially delivered -- by planes and artillery -- to Chinese soldiers in foxholes and gun positions along this sector of the Korean front.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- In a drastic move for time to strengthen a political "screening" program to prevent employment of persons suspected of being Communists or having Communist sympathies, R. K. O. Radio Pictures will operate on a curtailed production basis for an indefinite period.

I note with considerable interest the report of Princeton University's Department of Economics, in your March 26 issue, entitled "Retirement Plans in Industry Scored." It is encouraging that at least some consideration is being given to this important subject, too long neglected.

A four-way investigation into the Jamaica, Queens, crash of a twin-engine cargo plane, which caused five deaths Saturday, was being conducted by Civil Aeronautics Board investigators yesterday as both borough and city officials planned conferences today on what could be done to increase airport safety.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- Errol Flynn will go to England in the summer for Warner Brothers, to star in "The Sea Rogue." In this adaptation of Robert Louis Stevenson's story "Master of Ballantrae," the star will play an adventurous Scotsman who becomes a pirate.

Three hold-up men, two of them armed, invaded the home of Mr. and Mrs. Murray S. Herman in the Midwood Manor section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning, roused the sleeping couple and escaped with furs and jewelry valued at $8,500 and $200 in cash.

BOSTON, April 6 -- Aided by support from citizens, groups, the American public schools have overcome their worst problems and are now defnitely on the upgrade, Roy E. Larsen, president of Time, said here today.

Felice Takakjian, in her Town Hall appearance Saturday night, played a representative program of piano music -- until the intermission. After that, several pieces by Armenian composers had their first New York hearings -- Hovhaness' "Farewell to the Mountains" and "Three Armenian Rustic Dances" by Servantziantz.
MILWAUKEE, April 6 (AP) -- Andy Varipapa, trick-shot artist and twice national match game champion, fired the highest series today in the American Bowling Congress tournament -- a 680 in the doubles.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia, called upon Republicans today to refrain from "playing politics" with the nomination of Federal Judge James P. McGranery as Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., announced today that a poll of 150 union presidents showed a majority of them believed Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois would draw the greatest support from labor ranks as Democratic Presidential nominee.
Futures prices moved ahead on the New York cotton exchange last week.

A young, strongly partisan audience attended Saturday night's Philharmonic-Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall, and cheered long and loud for William Masselos' performance of Brahms' D minor Concerto. And conductor Dimitri Mitropoulos bestowed the crowning award in the form of a kiss on the young pianist's brow.

Adrian, Hollywood designer, offers two of his outstanding models to the American home-sewer today through the American Designer series of Patterns of The Times. Here they are in Patterns 6100 and 6101.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 6 -- Matchmaker for Deer Creek, 6-year-old Labrador retriever who is a champion both in the field and on the bench, was winner of the open all-age stake that was the concluding and most important event of the spring meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club today.

LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- Britain's Labor party piled up new gains today as results came in from country-wide local elections that provided the first big test of strength with the Conservatives since the general election last October.

A visitor here recently before sailing back on the Liberte to the famed distilleries of the Charente district of France was gray-haired, dapper Maurice Hennessey. A sixth-generation member of a family that is as French now as it was Irish in 1765, he is the senior partner of Jas.

A program to improve Health Department services in New York City was made public yesterday by the Citizens Committee on Children. It warned that prompt action was necessary if the city was to stop the deterioration of services which, it said, had been "sliding downhill" for years.

The general public still is not quite convinced that business men are entirely human. A Philadelphia bank is doing its bit to correct impression. Today and tomorrow the Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank is running insertions on its March 31 statement in newspaper and bank publications which are calculated to stifle yawns inspired by an impressive but -- let's be honest -- excrutiatingly boring set of figures.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyle Bowman of Richmond, Calif., four times Oregon State women's golf champion, won the twenty - second annual women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today, 1 up, over Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., on the thirty-sixth hole.

Christ's entry into the City of Jerusalem to keep the Passover with His disciples was commemorated yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral in a two-and-a-quarter-hour ceremony that included the blessing of palms, procession of palms, chanting of the Passion according to St. Matthew and the solemn mass of Palm Sunday. The ritual was televised by WPIX.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 6 (AP) -- An all-girl crew was rescued from the racing yacht Tropicair by the Coast Guard early today after the vessel went aground on a reef.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., April 6 -- There is an abundance of peace, prosperity and clearly defined decisions out on the old Allen S. Redding place three miles south of here.

ANNANDALE - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., April 6 -- Bard College students and faculty members, joined by foreign students from twenty-one different nations, met this week-end for the sixth International Student Conference. The theme this year was "The Ground Between, An Analysis of Movement Independent of the Soviet and American systems."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 6 -- With the completion of the new Allston Burr lecture hall Harvard College has acquired a building designed especially for showing scientific experiments to large and small groups.

LONDON, April 6 -- A group of Conservative members of Parliament has been attempting to convince the Churchill Cabinet that the time has come to end the radio and television monopoly that the Government-owned British Broadcasting Corporation has held in this country for thirty years.
The passenger liners Lady Nelson and Lady Rodney, operated by Canadian National Steamships, will be withdrawn from the West Indies service after the summer season.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., April 6 (UP) -- The University of Florida student honor court resigned tonight, protesting the reinstatement of football players and other students involved in a cheating scandal.
DANBURY, Conn., April 6 -- United States Senator William E. Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that he would accept renomination at the party's state convention in June.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 6 -- A "plan of action for defiance of unjust laws" was unfolded at meetings of nonwhite persons throughout the Union today, the tercentenary of the first white settlement in South Africa.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 6 -- For the first time since Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe was activated one year and five days ago General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will meet face to face tomorrow with all his senior commanders to discuss the exact strategy and tactics they will follow if the Soviet Union should begin a war.

TOKYO, Monday, April 7 -- The Communist high command made a bid yesterday to all Chinese and North Korean prisoners in United Nations stockades to return to their allegiance after the start of an armistice in the Korean war.

BEAULIEU, England, April 6 -- "The glory of an English country house is that it is being lived in," young Lord Montagu of Beaulieu, owner of one of England's most historic estates, said today. "I intend to go on living in mine."

The policy of the Truman Administration in deploring inflation by lip service while actively pursuing measures to increase the money supply and raise prices to the consumer is, unfortunately, again in evidence.
A ground-breaking ceremony to mark the start of construction of Baruch Houses, the biggest public housing project on the East Side, will be held at 10:45 A. M. tomorrow.

BOSTON, Monday, April 7 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, refusing to accept defeat, extended the Stanley Cup hockey series B playoffs to a seventh game early today when they came from behind to beat the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 2, in a second overtime period.
BERLIN, April 6 -- Half forgotten but still defiant Berlin suns itself in another spring waiting without fear but without much hope for the next turn of the Russian crew.

The W. T. Grant Company, which operates a chain of 482 stores, had net earnings of $7,516,547, equal to $2.90 a share, for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, compared with $8,102,551, or $3.16, earned in the preceding fiscal year.

PARIS, April 6. (AP) -- Gov. Theodore McKeldin lunched with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today and discussed the possible support for the general of Maryland's twenty-six Republican convention delegates.
City Councilman Edward A. Cunningham, Bronx Democrat, said yesterday he would continue to oppose a tax of $5 a month for overnight parking in the city's streets.
CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- The governors of the Menninger Foundation, a nonprofit psychiatric center in Topeka, Kan. approved today a $1,365,000, three-year research and educational program.

The Presidential primaries which have thus far been held have had far-reaching effects upon the candidacies of many Presidential hopefuls. Candidates have been eliminated from the race, and others have been placed in strong strategic positions.

PITTSBURGH, April 6 -- Late last week the long awaited crisis had come to the steel industry, it was probable that, barring seizure by the Government, a strike would develop this week. The union and the mills are so far apart that collective bargaining over a long period would be necessary before any semblance of accord could be reached.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 6 (AP) -- A tip-in shot by Jim Pollard with two seconds remaining after George Mikan had missed a left-handed turn-around try tonight carried the Minneapolis Lakers to an 82-80 victory over the Rochester Royals and ended the Western Division play-off in the National Basketball Association.
FRANKFURT, Germany, April 6 (UP) -- Sgt. Curt Simmons, left-handed pitcher for the Phillies, left by plane today for the United States to trade in his khaki for a Philly uniform within a week.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -- One group of backers of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur for the Presidency moved tonight to split with the Fighters for MacArthur, headed by John Chapple, who said recently that his group was behind Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

When the British economic planners marked up the five continents and the seven seas into foreign exchange control areas held suited to the war-crippled pound sterling, they little dreamed that they were preparing the way for new insurgent trade "moneys" to rise out of the free market and generate values of their own.
The New York Americans and Philadelphia Nationals of the American Soccer League were winners in the first round of the annual competition for the Lewis Cup at Croke Park yesterday afternoon.

The United States and Canadian economies are so closely linked that Canada as a supplier, competitor and market must be recognized as an important factor in American business planning. This is the tenor of a special report to be issued today by the Research Institute of America to its 30,000 business organization members.

With the men's clothing industry seeking to pull itself out of an acute business slump, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., has agreed to extend contracts covering 150,000 unionized workers until Sept. 15 without any increase in wages or other improvements.

Saturday's tragedy in Queens brought to fourteen the number of persons killed on the ground in airplane crashes in the metropolitan area within the last four months. It is natural that there should be indignation as well as profound sorrow for those who are bereaved. There are increasing demands that an even closer study be given to the problem of airport hazards in a congested area.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 6 -- Yugoslavia's economic dependence on assistance from the United States, Britain and France was emphasized again last week by reports by Yugopress, the new Yugoslav news agency, that many Yugoslav industries were in serious difficulties -- this time because of alleged delays in the allocation of some of the funds granted by the United States and France last month.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation proposed that the International Wheat Agreement be changed to peg wheat export prices to the cost-of-living.

The completion of New York State's network of civil defense aircraft warning ground-observer posts, required by the Air Force to supplement its radar surveilance, was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, director of the New York State Civil Defense Commission.

This year many colleges and universities, faced with rising costs, smaller enrollments and a tendency among students to desert the humanities in favor of the engineering school, are looking at themselves as they never have looked before.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 6 -- John Geyer staged a strong finish today as the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's winter campaign ended to win the day's regatta and, by unofficial computation, claim the over-all frostbite season championship.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Gross earnings of Federal Reserve System member banks in the seventh district rose 13 per cent last year to a new high of $518,000,000, the sharpest gain in the post-war period, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said today in Business Conditions, its monthly publication. Despite higher gross earnings, however, net profits at $107,000,000 barely topped 1950 levels, the bank said.

A pictorial biography of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, "This Is Ike," is planned or Hay publication by Holt. Edited by Wilson Hicks, former managing editor of Life magazine, the book depict the general's life from childhood to the present. The first printing will be 225,000 copies.

LONDON, April 7 -- On top of the disappointment at the slowness of United States financial aid for rearmament, Britain received a shock tonight from the news that exports of American steel had been stopped because of a strike threat.

Four hundred and nineteen employes of three Brooklyn garages maintained by the Board of Transportation yesterday quit work for several hours in protest against six fellow workers being fined for refusal to carry out work assigned to them by a foreman.

LYNCHBURG, Va., April 7 -- Sam Jethroe pulled the hat trick before 5,005 fans at Municipal Stadium today by hitting a single, double, triple and home run, but the Dodgers won the game from the Braves, 8 -- 4, to even their series at four games each.

LAUREL, Md., April 7 (AP) -- Senator Joe, owned, trained and bred by Alan T. Clarke, finished a neck in front of H. H. Polk's Rocky Heights in the Ritchie Purse here today, but his number soon came down and Rocky Heights was declared the winner.

HONG KONG, April 7 -- Fifty thousand persons jammed the Peoples Stadium in near-by Canton today and shouted pro-Government rally slogans as shop assistants and workers denounced their employers for alleged economic immorality.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A temporary order restraining service payments to New York milk cooperatives was modified today to permit partial payments.

Regretfully, we must conclude that the Communist offer of immunity for returned prisoners in Korea is merely a propaganda trick and that it is designed to confuse rather than speed negotiation. We are deeply concerned for the fate of our own fellow-countrymen and the soldiers of our allies who are in Communist hands.
MONTREAL, April 7 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian port officials looked forward today to a shipping season they predicted would be good, if not better than average.

An end of automatic draft exemptions for new fathers is among fourteen recommendations to President Truman and defense officials made public yesterday by the War Manpower Council, a citizens' survey group financed by the Ford Foundation.

Today's new film is "My Son John," a Paramount drama, pro duced and directed by Leo McCarey and starring Helen Hayes, Robert Walker, Van Heflin and Dean Jagger, at the Capitol. This is a night opening scheduled for 8:30 o'clock. Myles Connolly and Mr. McCarey wrote the screen play from an adaptation by John Lee Mahin and a story by Mr. McCarey.

A double communications strike spread across the nation yesterday as 67.250 telephone workers in forty-three states and Washington, D. C., walked off their jobs while 31,000 employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company extended their walkout into its fifth day. The chief issue in both cases is pay.

Twenty-two staff members of the United Nations, including members of the United Nations Chess Club which finished second in the championship series of the Commercial Chess League, faced Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade in an exhibition of simultaneous play in the Conference Room of the U. N. Building last night.
The Federation Employment Service, 67 West Forty-seventh Street, had good news yesterday for older workers: they can do a job as well, and in some instances better, than young persons.

After three weeks of negotiations the Israeli delegation to The Hague Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany has suspended further talks, at least temporarily, on the ground that the first concrete reparation offer made by the Germans is "totally unsatisfactory." This is a regrettable development. It should not be permitted to break up a conference which still offers room for further negotiations.

The Tishman Realty Construction Company, of which Norman Tishman is president, has sold the leasehold on the nineteen-story and penthouse office building at 136 East Fifty-seventh Street to the Essex Syndicate, Inc. Reis Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Goodman Mabel for the buyer and Reuben Tally for the seller.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Spokesmen for American Waterways operators expressed opposition today to proposed legislation that would allow the Federal Government to charge tolls on waterways developed at Federal expense.

Last spring a new fabric known as "Visa," employing du Pont's new polyester fiber Dacron and made by Deering, Milliken Co., Inc., was introduced in summer suits tailored by Hart, Schaffner Marx. Distribution, however, was limited and those stores having a supply of the suits quickly sold them out.

Holding a 2 -- 1 edge in the best-of-five series, the New York Knickerbockers will be out to gain the National Basketball Association final play-offs tonight, when they resume battling with the Syracuse Nationals at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The game is scheduled to start at 8:30 o'clock.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- Municipal authorities stopped the pay this afternoon of eight doctors and a nurse at Philadelphia General Hospital who are facing dismissal for refusing to sign Pennsylvania's new loyalty oath.

PARIS, April 4 (By Airmail) -- Parisiennes are protecting themselves against April showers this year with a variety of gay new umbrellas that are delightful in their touches of feminity. Five or six gold charms dangle from a ring on a white lacquered handle. Into the gold ring on a green leather handle may be screwed a leather strap to slip on the wrist for traveling.

MONTREAL, April 7 (Canadian Press) -- Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., reported consolidated profit today of $24,508,397 for the fiscal year ended last Dec. 31, compared with $31,087,833 in 1950. Net proft was $7.99 a share, against $10.18 the previous year.

William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, declared yesterday that the attack made Sunday on the Republican-controlled Legislature by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, was just "a smokescreen to cover the Democratic disorder, confusion and distress." Mr. Fitzpatrick, in a letter to Democratic county chairmen, had charged that at the 1952 session the Republicans had sacrificed the public good to their own need for party unity.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- The Navy's new 60,000-ton super-aircraft carrier may be redesigned to include a radically new plane-launching device developed by the British, the Navy said today.

OTTAWA, April 7 -- For the sixth successive year the Canadian treasury has shown a budgetary surplus during 1951-52, according to papers tabled today in the House of Commons by Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott.

Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O.. dimmed Government peace hopes last night by announcing unequivocally that the national steel strike would begin at one minute after midnight tonight.

THE United States swept all the swimming championships at the 1948 Olympics. But there is no chance of America making that big a splash at Helsinki this summer. The recent National A. A. U. championships at Yale provided a superb show and demonstrated anew that we will have a powerfully balanced team in the Olympics.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Paul Fitzpatrick, chairman of the New York State Democratic Committee, called at the White House today to renew an invitation to the President and to transact one other piece of business.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -Unprecedented mountain snows that are now melting threaten the nation with one of the worst series of floods in more than seventy years, the Red Cross warned today.

LONDON, April 7 -- About 20,000,000 to 25,000,000 ($56,000,000 to $70,000,000) in new Government orders will be poured into the distressed British textile mills in an effort to relieve growing unemployment. In an atmosphere of political crisis, the relief measure was announced tonight in the House of Commons by R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer.
PIERRE, S. D., April 7 (AP) -Swollen by quick-melting snow, the Missouri River threatened this state capital tonight with the worst flood in seventy-one years.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 7 -- Three youthful residents of Newark were dead tonight as the result of a collision early today between a sedan and a tractor-trailer on the New Jersey Turnpike in near-by East Brunswick. Three other persons were injured, one of them critically.

LOS ANGELES, April 7 -- It wasI a recent enet of the Communist[ party in the San Francisco area] that war with Russia was inevi- table but should be forestalled until Russia was ready, a witness testified today at the Distv/ct Court trial of fifteen California Communist functionaries.

Mayor Impellitteri was accused yesterday by Councilman Edward A. Cunningham, Bronx Democrat, of "clever footwork" and of "attempting to becloud the real issue" by arguing in the Mayor's annual message that pay increases for 115,000 city employes hinged on acceptance by the Council of all proposed nuisance taxes.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt received a gold plaque in the form of a map of Israel at a dinner last night honoring Mrs. Golda Myerson, Israeli Minister of Labor, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- The Senate voted today to hold up its conference with the House of Representatives on recently approved off-shore oil legislation until it had considered naming a new set of conferees.
New issues of more than $11,000,000 of common stock will be offered today to stockholders of a Pennsylvania bank and a Western public utility company. The offerings are as follows:

The launching of the 1952 drive for support of the United Negro College Fund, Inc., will serve to focus public attention on the importance of the Fund's program for helping Negro youth in this country achieve higher education. The $1,500,000 sought as this year's goal is vital to keep in sound operation the thirty-two colleges aided.

A building with twenty-two apartments and two stores at 760-66 East 155th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Seymour M. Tannenbaum to the Foreground Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $35,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $26,000.
A 17-year-old youth was found wounded fatally on a sidewalk in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn shortly before 8 o'clock last night. Detectives said he might be a victim of a juvenile gang fight.

TANGIER, April 7 -- Spain's quick move, after the arrival Thursday of a squadron of native cavalry, to assist the police in Tangier seemed here to indicate a desire to take advantage of the March 30 riots, when the police were overwhelmed and the present regime appeared discredited.

The City of Boston borrowed $5,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of temporary loan notes, due in six and one-fifth months. The issue was bought by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 1.12 per cent discount with $1.13 premium.

BONN, Germany, March 25 (By Air Mail) -The great cartels of Germany -- the steel and coal monopolies and the I. G. Farben chemical empire which provided the fuel for Germany's peaceful economic domination of the Continent no less than for the aggressive wars of the past -- appear to have been shattered.
