WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Truman asked Congress today, as a "matter of the utmost urgency," to extend his war powers for a period of sixty days. He called for the action before the members dispersed for any Easter vacation.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, April 7 (AP) -- An Air Force plane, flying almost within sight of the North Pole, evacuated three of twelve Navy men yesterday from a floating ice island on which their own plane was disabled.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 7 -- Judge James E. Murphy of the Superior Court granted the Northeastern Gas Transmission Company an order today allowing immediate possession of sixty-six easements through Fairfield County properties to expedite the distribution of natural gas.

PARIS, April 7 (AP) -- General Eisenhower's campaign manager Continued on Page 23, Column 6 said today that if the Republican Convention were held right now the general would get 500 votes for the Presidential nomination. He said the total was mounting with every primary and state convention.

Barring the intervention of a minor miracle, the long-threatened strike of 650,000 workers in the nation's steel industry will become a fact at one minute past midnight tonight. The potentiality for damage to the defense effort and to the nation's economy that would be represented by a shut-down for any considerable period in this basic industry is so obvious that comment on it here and now would be both conjectural and superfluous.

LONDON, April 7 -- Delegates to the three-power conference on the administration of Trieste Zone A devoted their third meeting today to a study of the present organization and functioning of the British-United States Military Government of the zone.

The chancery office of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese announced yesterday that it had no previous knowledge that lay organizations planned to ask non-Catholic merchants to close their shops for three hours on Good Friday and added that it would not have approved such a campaign.

The American Woolen Company announced yesterday price reductions on six basic worsted suitings for third-quarter delivery. Ranging from 22 1/2 to 40 cents a yard below the levels of the last listing, the cuts bring American Woolen prices to the general level of the market.

I have read Herbert Pell's interesting letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 4. General Eisenhower apparently offers considerable appeal to Mr. Pell and possibly to many other Democrats. President Truman also liked him.
The Buddies League, Inc., a group of New York housewives, made a contribution of $30,000 to the Institute of Psychotherapy at the league's annual luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In a spectacular test of its maximum radius, a Coast Guard helicopter flew 100 miles out to sea yesterday and returned with a critically injured seaman removed from a Europe-bound freighter. The non-stop flight began at Elizabeth City, N. C., shortly after 10 A. M. and ended at 12:23 P. M. with the landing of the craft on a hospital lawn in Norfolk, Va.

MADRID, March 28 (By Air Mail) -- United States and Spanish economists said today that the immediate and major economic objective of the new United States policy of aid to Spain should be that of making her self-sufficient in basic foodstuffs.

This is the season for new finery -- for young and old alike. One of the most significant factors noticed in the wide selection of spring coats, suits and dresses now available in all the stores is the interpretation of grown-up trends in young designs.

Glenn McCarthy, the Texas oil and hotel promoter, has been called to task by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. Mr. McCarthy owes Equitable $34,000,000. Yesterday the insurance concern told him he must devote his full time to the Texas oil and hotel properties on which the insurance company holds Hens, or step out of the management of those holdings.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- J. Howard McGrath relinquished the office of Attorney General today and told 2,000 employes of the Department of Justice that he left public office with animosity toward no man.
Small, vivacious and with an energetic spirit that might almost classify her as an American, is Biki, the most recent of the Italian couturieres to arrive in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia, urged Congress today to create a special military education commission to determine if West Point and Annapolis produce "the best possible officers."

CHICAGO, April 7 -- A battle between Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will mark the Illinois Presidential preference primary election tomorrow.

Three weeks ago Senator Taft said of the Illinois Republican primary: "I expect to carry virtually all of the delegates and I also shall win in the preferential voting." Although this is a hazardous year for election guesses, there isn't much disposition on anyone's part seriously to dispute Senator Taft's statement in this case.

The revolver used in the killing of Arnold L. Schuster, the young man who on Feb. 18 led the police to William Sutton, since convicted as a bank robber, is in police hands. Yesterday more than 100 detectives were stirred to fresh activity by its recovery.
MONTREAL, April 7 (AP) -- Coach Lynn Patrick of the Boston Bruins will wear an entirely different ensemble tomorrow night.

GENEVA, April 7 -- Western Europe is rather skeptical toward news from the Moscow economic conference, but some of the advertised objectives of that gathering are becoming easier for Russia to attain, all the same.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- In a 5-to-3 decision upholding a provision of the McCarran Act, the Supreme Court ruled today that aliens ordered deported might be jailed up to ten years if they failed within six months to make "timely application" for departure papers.

BOSTON, April 7 (UP) -- One of two defending champions was beaten in his trial round and the light-heavyweight division put on a power display that accounted for more than a third of the nineteen knockouts as the sixty-fourth annual National Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships ended the first third of its run tonight at Boston Garden.

A companion volume to David Riesman's "The Lonely Crowd" has been scheduled by Yale University Press for May 21. Entitled "Faces in the Crowd," the book continues Mr. Riesman's researches into American character and politics.
LONDON, April 7 -- Urgent messages were received today from Britons at the Moscow International Economic Conference reporting the Chinese delegation was interested in buying textiles.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Frank Nathan, a one-time Pittsburgh produce huckster who came to Washington in 1947 "looking for some deals," swore to the Senate's Permanent Investigating Subcommittee today that he got a $57,000 fee from a surplus property transaction in 1948 for making a single telephone call.

LOWELL, Mass., April 7 -- All wool, regardless of geographical origin, has basically the same physical and chemical properties, according to research men attending a three-day seminar on wool research which opened here today at the Lowell Textile Institute.

Three new officials appointed last week by Mayor Impellitteri took their oaths of office yesterday at City Hall as scheduled despite a demand by the Citizens Union over the week-end that two of the appointments be withdrawn.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- President Truman today studied working plans for a proposed $1,000,000 library at Grandview, Mo., to house his public and private papers after he leaves office.

WHIPPANY, N. J., April 7 -- Clubs, stones and fists were used in a wild free-for-all fight today between pickets at the strike-bound Eden Mill of the Whippany Paper Company and a group described by the pickets as "a mob of strike-breakers."

TOKYO, April 7 -- While twenty-four men, former Cabinet ministers, business leaders and professors, last month meekly accepted the Japanese Government's refusal of permission to attend the current Moscow International Economic Conference, a Japanese woman, Mme. Tomiko Kora, member of the Diet's upper house, with polite disregard of such formalities as permits, visas and masculine opinion, made her way to the conference.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Persons appointed to full-time teaching positions in the evening sessions and schools of general studies under the jurisdiction of the New York City Board of Higher Education will be eligible to attain tenure rights under legislation approved today by Governor Dewey.

DETROIT, April 7 (AP) -- Jolted by the loss today of their second defense ace in two weeks, the Detroit Red Wins set out to realign their defensive set-up for the forthcoming Stanley Cup hockey final playoffs.

FORT HOOD, Tex., April 7 (AP) -- The cocky, confident Eighty-second Airborne Division, playing the part of the enemy in the Long Horn maneuvers of central Texas, had the humiliating task of having to retreat today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A 27-year-old Army lieutenant, thrice wounded in Korea and several times decorated for heroism, received the Medal of Honor today for exceptional gallantry during a Korean skirmish in which, single-handed, he killed 100 enemy soldiers.

Randy Sandy, 149 pounds, Harlem, won a split decision over Al Wilson, 146 1/2, Englewood, N. J., in the eight-round feature last night at St. Nicholas Arena. The victory was the sixth straight for the undefeated Harlem fighter.

MADRID, April 7 -- Spain formally demanded today control of the police forces in the international zone of Tangier. The Foreign Office said that notes had been handed to the representatives of the seven countries, other than Spain, now ruling that strategic North African city.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- Curt Simmons dropped out of the air today after more than a year and a half of Army service and declared he was ready to help pitch the Phillies back into contention in the National League race.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Senate confirmed today by voice vote the nomination of David Northan Edelstein to be United States District Judge for the Southern District of New York.

ELWOOD, Ind., April 7 (AP) -A rail that broke beneath a southbound Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train early today struck snake-like through a sleeping car window, missing by inches the Rev. Louis Weitzman, a member of the faculty of St. Xavier University, Cincinnati, who was in a berth.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax scandals put off today for two weeks public interrogation of Joseph D. Nunan Jr., former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, on being advised that the New Yorker had entered a hospital in Roslyn Heights, L. I.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A former Soviet foreign officer, who broke with Moscow ten years ago, testified today that the Soviet Union used the Institute of Pacific Relations as a means of gathering military intelligence and putting out pro-Communist propaganda.
In commodity futures price movements yesterday tin, hides, coffee, cocoa and vegetable oils declined, rubber and wool were higher and sugar was irregular.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- State Department officials went over Premier Stalin's latest "peace" moves in a series of meetings today, but decided that they were no more than an interesting change in Kremlin tactics.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 7 -Harold Lorentson, 13 years old, of Smithtown Branch, was acquitted at noon today by Judge D. Ormonde Ritchie in the Children's Court of Suffolk County of the charge of juvenile delinquency in connection with the murder of Lyde Kitchner, his 12-year-old classmate in the Smithtown Branch Public School on last Nov. 29.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Uncertainty in labor developments curtailed pit operations in grain futures and other products today, and there was a disposition to mark time. Corn showed independent strength at time, scoring a good rally from early low spots, but in this and other pits offerings increased on the hard spots.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The tug Sachem, which sank with all hands in Lake Erie Dec. 18, 1950, probably was swamped by an unusually big wave or capsized by ice that formed on it, the Coast Guard reported today.

New York and Queen Juliana reacted to each other like old countrymen and close cousins yesterday as the Queen and her husband, Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, paid their first formal visit to the one time Dutch village of Nieuw Amsterdam.

BOSTON, April 7 -- The growth of private schools in this country is developing a dual system of education which is harmful to American democracy, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard Univeristy, warned here today.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 7 -- Emphasis on moral training as well as on the pure technology of medicine in the preparation of the country's future doctors was urged today at the meeting here of the subcommittee on pre-professional education of the survey of medical education.

CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- An isolated chalk talk of review-of game movies will constitute a full day's practice under the new National Collegiate Athletic Association's limit of twenty spring football practice sessions in thirty days.

ALBANY, April 7 -- The State Commerce Department reported today that total deposits in mutual savings banks in New York increased $530,000,000 in 1951. The four and one-half percent gain accounted for three-fifths of the national increase in deposits during the year.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 8 -- Negotiations for an armistice in Korea reached a complete though perhaps temporary breakdown today, when, for the third successive day, a truce subcommittee met for several minutes and adjourned.
Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 to 13 points net lower yesterday than Friday.

Designs on some new drapery and upholstery fabrics in the collection now at Cheney Brothers, 509 Madison Avenue, are inspired by the plants and grasses that grow in and around the South Pacific islands. Others are derived from the butter molds and sam

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court proposed today that this country promote "peasants' revolutions" in underdeveloped areas to end economic serfdom under Point Four technical assistance programs.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The first annual report of Earl James McGrath, Commissioner of Education, on Federal aid to schools congested by United States defense activities was issued today. It showed a total of $122,740,302 spent in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1951.

Sixty families, routed from an apartment house at 1119 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, early yesterday watched from the street as police and firemen sought to subdue a tenant who had set fire to his flat and was brandishing a knife on the sixth-floor fire escape.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 7 -- Joe Adonis and four of his gambling partners were housed tonight in Bergen County Jail to await their appearance tomorrow in the adjoining courthouse as prosecution witnesses at the trial of Michael Orecchio, former county chief of detectives, who is charged with laxity toward gamblers.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 7 -- Israel suspended today negotiations on German compensation for her absorption of refugees from nazism after receiving what was termed a "totally unsatisfactory" proposal from the delegation from the Bonn Republic.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- A joint Congressional watchdog committee on the budget would save $100 for every dollar it would spend. Senator John L. McClellan told the Senate today. The Arkansas Democrat, sponsor of a bill to set up such an eighteen-member committee, said the group would "curb the wasteful and reckless expenditure of public funds."
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 8 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,213, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

Students from fifty-one colleges, representing as many member nations of the United Nations General Assembly, yesterday heard Ambassador Ahmed Shah Bokhari, Permanent Representative of Pakistan to the United Nations, describe the influence of what he termed the "Asian-African bloc."

Humble Oil and Refining Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), reported yesterday for 1951 a consolidated net income of $169,480,626 after charges and taxes, equal to $4.72 a share on the capital stock. This compares with $129,359,991, or $3.60, in 1950. Gross operating income was $951,051,052, compared with $793,417,807 in 1950.

Television and radio performers belonging, respectively, to Television Authority and the American Federation of Radio Artists have voted for a merger of their unions on July 1 if an over-all merger with three other talent unions is not accomplished by that date.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 7 (AP) -- The first four seeded players in the men's singles division of the Good Neighbor tennis championship advanced through today's first round without lifting a racquet.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 7 -- There was speculation today about a possible change of tactics by Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan the constitutional crisis when Parliament reassembles April 15 and the current political truce ends.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The power of the Alien Property Custodian over securities of two Swiss corporations was defined by the Supreme Court in decisions today.

A fast, new model of the American jet fighter that is accounting for most of the Soviet-made MIG-15's shots down or damaged in Korea has been delivered to the Air Force by North American Aviation, Inc. It is the F-86-F Sabre which is powered by the General Electric J47-GE-27 engine.

Your editorial reference of April 2 to increasing New York City pensions and bankruptcy could leave an uninformed reader with the impression that most New York City pensions are becoming too liberal. Taxpayer antagonisms created by too liberal benefits in one system should not be directed against just benefits in another. I will be explicit.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -The Army said today it had canceled its contract with a Paterson, N. J., firm accused by an investigating committee of the House of Representatives of "cheating on specifications" in supplying slippers for Government hospitals.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The President's Loyalty Review Board was reported concerned today that Mr. Truman's new instructions on the secrecy of loyalty files might, in fact, contain a threat to the confidential character of investigations, long regarded as the heart of the Government's loyalty program.

A campaign to sell more beverages across grocery counters will begin this month. The New York State Food Merchants Association, a retail grocery trade group with 5,000 members, will endeavor to promote sales of what was termed "the line which offers the greatest potential for expanding sales in the food field."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -- Top studio production executives had no comment to make today in the wake of the broad criticism of the industry's campaigns against Communist influences made by Howard Hughes, studio managing director and principal stock owner of R. K. O. Radio Pictures.
PORTLAND, Me., April 7 -- A tiny widowed Chinese mother of eight children was named today Maine's mother of the year.

A $628,000 program to increase the traffic capacity of the Manhattan approach to the George Washington Bridge by widening West 178th Street, establishing an off-street bus depot and providing a direct underpass to the Eighth Avenue subway at West 175th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

SAN ANTONIO, April 7 -- Max Lanier made his third start as a Giant today against the Cleveland Indians before an overflow gathering of 10,832 and, with any kind of a break, the ex-Cardinal might have won himself a ball game.

A loudly dressed young man who admitted to the police that he had held up forty liquor and delicatessen stores and dry-cleaning establishments since the first of the year was locked up in the West Forty-seventh Street Station last night, charged with assault and robbery.
COLUMBUS, Ga., April 7 -- The Yankees, rolling triumphantly through Georgia, met ad routed the Columbus Cardinals, a link in the St. Louis chain, today.

DONALD WETZEL'S second novel, "The Age of Light,"* is an argument in favor of love. Since love has been well spoken of in prose and verse for some time now, Mr. Wetzel's enrollment on the side of the angels is not enough to make his peculiar and uneven novel successful. And this is all the more disappointing because his first novel, "A Wreath and a Curse," was very good indeed.

Canned citrus juices are high on the United States Department of Agriculture's list of foods plentiful this month; frozen concentrated orange juice also is in excellent supply. These facts suggest that the flavorful liquids might well be utilized now not only as refreshing beverages but also as a cookery ingredient.

The four City Councilmen from Queens threw into the Council hopper yesterday a joint resolution calling upon the Port of New York Authority to halt flights at La Guardia and New York International (Idlewild) Airports at once, pending city negotiations to cancel the agency's five-year-old lease of the two fields.

ROME, April 7 (UP) -- The Vatican radio today broadcast the text of a letter by Abraham Lincoln to his Secretary of State authorizing the appointment of the first American papal representative ninety years ago.
Tom Fool staged a successful return to action yesterday. The Greentree Stable colt, the champion 2-year-old of last year, made his 1952 debut and came through with a decisive triumph.

The J. D. Schlang Company, manufacturer of jewelry, has purchased the recently completed one-story structure at 37-31 Fifty-seventh Street in Woodside, Queens, from Carl F. Gilbert, builder. After alterations have been completed the buyer will occupy the property as a factory and executive offices.

Greater protection to the public against the financially irresponsible driver is assured by legislation just signed by Governor Dewey. The new law is one of several passed at the recent legislative session that indicate progress, we hope and believe, toward compulsory liability insurance on all automobiles.

ROME, April 7 -- Communist attempts to sabotage Italian recovery were sharply underlined today by M. Leon Dayton, chief of the Mutual Security Agency mission, in a speech to the Italian Chamber of Commerce for the Americas, in which he reviewed the first four years of United States aid to Italy.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The National Production Authority cut off the flow of steel today to exporters and to manufacturers of consumer durable goods, including automobiles.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 7 -- The Scarsdale Citizens Committee, known also as the Committee of Ten, renewed today an attack on "Communist infiltration" into the public schools here. It produced an immediate reply from Archibald B. Shaw, Superintendent of Schools.

The regeneration of the Lower East Side of Manhattan moves forward another step today with an official ceremony to start construction of the $31,410,000 Baruch Houses, a low-rent project, to be built with federal aid. Bounded by Delancey Street, Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, East Houston Street and Columbia Street, with a 27.9-acre site, this is the largest public housing improvement on the East Side. It will be home to 2,194 families.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 7 -- Syria's military regime, which seized power in a coup late last year and dissolved all political parties by decree yesterday, has set out, as did Kemal Ataturk in Turkey, to create and favor a political organization that will mobilize the nation behind the regime's program.

Disputes between management and labor -- the most serious bringing almost a certainty that the steel industry will shut down operations tonight -- sent a chill through the stock market yesterday and resulted in the widest losses in a week.
Fred C. Schlemmer has been elected vice president in charge of construction of Burns Roe, Inc., engineers and constructors.

Capt. Franklin B. Weaver, suspended 30-year-old master of the Isbrandtsen freighter Flying Trader, went on trial yesterday on a manslaughter indictment in the shooting of one of his crew last October. The case is in the Federal Court before Judge Edward Weinfeld and a jury of eight men and four women.

KINGSVILLE, Tex., April 7 -King Ranch, the largest cattle ranch in the United States, in association with other private interests, will extend its beef cattle operations to Cuba and Australia in an effort to increase the world's beef supply.

Bill Oster, New York University freshman, received the first starting assignment of his collegiate career yesterday and just missed pitching a no-hitter. Facing Columbia at Baker Field, the stylish left-hander yielded only one safety in part of the Violets to a 6-to-1 triumph.

A fight for control of Colonial Airlines was indicated in a stockholder's suit filed in Supreme Court here yesterday against Alfons B. Landa, former president of the airlines, and a Washington law firm to recover more than $100,000 assertedly paid improperly for legal fees and other services.
The trial of sixteen secondary leaders of the Communist party was delayed another week yesterday as pre-trial arguments continued in the Federal Court House on Foley Square.

Officers and members of the board of directors of the Virginia Day Nursery will attend a reception and tea to be held next Tuesday afternoon in the home of Mrs. George Morton Grinnell at 57 East Eightieth Street. The occasion will be the seventy-second annual meeting of the directors.

Out of 365 days in a year (366 this year) it is surprising to note that only twenty-four are "un-days." As defined by the Commerce Department, an "un-day" is one that is undesignated for any sort of national observation.

BRISBANE, Australia, April 7 (Reuters) -- Treasurer Sir Arthur Fadden asserted today that Australia has no intention of revaluing her currency to bring the Australian pound up to par with the British pound.

MOSCOW, April 7 (AP) -- Delegates to the Soviet-sponsored International Economic Conference here proposed today the setting up of a permanent international trade organization to help break down world trade barriers -- particularly between East and West.

The Federal Court award of $3,120,743 damages to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation for breach of contract by Otis Co., a Cleveland investment banking company, was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals, which directed the lower court to dismiss the action.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today set aside, by a vote of 6 to 2, the contempt-of-court conviction of Eugene M. Brunner of Los Angeles for refusing to answer questions about membership in the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey accused opponents of civil rights legislation today of deliberately dressing up fair employment practices legislation "in the horns of the devil."

For the second week, improving consumer demand in pre-Easter sales has given department store merchants a pleasant surprise. Dollar sales volume for New York and Brooklyn department stores for the week ended last Saturday was 1 per cent higher than for the corresponding week last year, according to yesterday's "flash" report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A forty-six-family apartment house at 160 East Fourth Street, Mount Vernon, N. Y., has been sold by Sadie Grodzitsky to Wolfe Duberstein, who resold the property to a client of Abbott Adams, Inc., brokers. The Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation was the broker in the first transfer and Murray Adler, broker, handled the resale.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused again to act on an appeal that attacked the validity of Georgia's county unit system of counting votes in primary elections.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- As American Red Cross crews aided flood victims at Bismarck, N. D., and Sioux City, S. D., the organization disclosed today plans for meeting flood threats in other parts of the country.
Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers, Broadway producers, are interested in bringing to New York next fall George Batson's six-character comedy, "A Date With April," with Constance Bennett as the star.

The Norfolk and Western Railway Company last year purchased $2,013,000 of its bonds, reducing ts total funded debt outstanding at the close of the year to $41,882,000, according to the road's fifty-sixth annual report. This included City of Norfolk, Va., obligations of

A group of delicate, pencil line drawings on white tiles for coasters or hot plates by Tom Sullivan, a young illustrator and artist, may now be seen at The Stable, Inc., 924 Seventh Avenue, near Fifty-eighth Street. The decorations on the tiles are distinguished by quiet charm and expressed with skillful and original hand drawing.
LONDON, April 7 -- All sections of the London stock market followed a subdued trend today although in general price declines had no great significance.

Judge Harold R. Medina may interrupt the presentation of evidence in the Government's anti-trust suit against certain investment banking houses to require the Anti-Trust Division's lawyers either to show proof for one of the charges or to drop it from the case.

Perhaps because taxes and regulations have made business increasingly complex, perhaps because of the uncertainties ahead, perhaps because the penalties for a slip have grown more severe while the rewards for good judgment have waned, books on business are roaring from the presses.

Mindful of the liberation of their ancestors from the slave pits of the Egyptian Pharaohs more than thirty centuries ago, Jews throughout the world will celebrate at sundown tomorrow the beginning of the Passover season -- Judaism's traditional holiday of freedom.
PITTSBURGH, April 7 (AP) -- Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation disclosed today it is expanding its search for new iron ore reserves in southeastern Ontario, Canada.
Queen Juliana of the Netherlands suggested here last night that the United States might be pressing matters a bit too fast in the realm of international affairs.
LONDON, April 7 (Reuters) -- Arsenal today advanced to the final of the football association cup tourney by defeating Chelsea, 3-0, in a semi-final replay.

Reflecting the lower trend in retail business, earnings of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., for the twenty-six and fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 26 declined sharply from the corresponding periods of the previous year, according to the semiannual report issued for publication today.

BOSTON, April 7 (AP) -- A board of trial of the Massachusetts Medical Society voted today to expel Dr. Robert E. Lincoln of Medford, who has claimed a successful new treatment for the cure of cancer and other diseases.

Americans out to make a quick but illegal dollar are running arms into Burma to supply the 10,000 or more Chinese Nationalist soldiers isolated there, Sirdar J. J. Singh, president of the India League of America, said yesterday in an interview at the League's headquarters at 40 East Forty-ninth Street.

In a letter of March 24 P. G. Sheth discusses the lack of opportunities for foreign students to receive practical work experience, as well as academic training, in the United States. While a great deal remains to be done in this respect, mention should be made of the opportunities that exist for foreign students desiring practical work experience.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The $46,000,000,000 Defense Department appropriations bill for the coming fiscal year went under debate in the House of Representatives today.
Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon, said yesterday that Jews in New York did not understand the extent of anti-Semitism in other parts of the United States.

HEAVY rains over the weekend washed away the optimism of most of the trout fishermen who had been hoping for clear streams on opening day this Saturday, and most of the larger streams are high and discolored.

Plans to produce the new anti-tuberculosis drug, isonicotinic acid hydrazide, on the basis of 100,000,000 tablets a month by the end of this year, if demand warrants, were told yesterday by John E. McKeen, president of Chas. Pfizer Co., Brooklyn chemical and pharmaceutical concern.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that personal income in February was at an annual rate of $257,100,000,000, down slightly from January, but still regarded as generally stable.

City and Federal officials paid tribute yesterday to the Baruch family at a groundbreaking ceremony for Baruch Houses, the East Side's biggest public housing project. Tenancy is to begin in the summer of 1953.
Mayor Impelliteri announced yesterday at City Hall that on the advice of his physician he would leave the city late tomorrow afternoon by plane for a two-week vacation at Palm Beach, Fla.

The Missouri River is on the rampage again. Less than a year after the terrible flood that was probably the costliest disaster of its kind in American history the waters of the Missouri are once more overflowing their banks. Despite expenditure of years of effort and hundreds of millions of dollars the Missouri is still mightier than man and still untamed.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 8 -- Dr. D. J. Devos, Minister of the independent Fourth Dutch Reformed Church, charged today that 1,000 political clergymen ruled South Africa from behind the scenes. He said that they had forged South Africa's three old Dutch Reformed churches into a "lethal political machine" and carried out the instructions of the "twelve apostles" of the Afrikaner Broederbond.

Louis B. Morris, though only seventy-three, has just celebrated his sixtieth anniversary of employment with the Mosler Safe Company. He recalled that, at thirteen, he was almost fired from his first job as office boy in the New York office because he was too small to answer the wall telephone.

An examination by Merle Miller, author and a director of the American Civil Liberties Union, of the attempts by pressure groups to undermine freedom of expression in radio and television is published today by Doubleday under the title "The Judges and the Judged."

BONN, Germany, April 8 -- The battle between the Office of the United States High Commissioner in Germany and the European Command of the United States Army over the desired reduction of luxury items in the occupation costs is nearing a climax. The military is bitterly opposing any cut in the expenditures it considers necessary for morale, even though the High Commissioner calls them luxuries.
Imperial Oil, Ltd., controlled by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), had record consolidated net earnings last year of $35,951,153, G. L. Stewart, the president, reported yesterday.

Renew, owned by the King Ranch and ridden by Willie Boland, flashed great closing speed to win the Minerva Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The mile-and-a-sixteenth race for fillies and mares attracted six contestants, and the crowd of 24,975 established Renew the favorite a few minutes before post time.

If the shoes around Hanover Square shine a little brighter -- as they do, and have for fifty years -- and if the atmosphere is a little cheerier -- as it is, and has been for fifty years; then the people there can thank Tony Rubino, the bootblack. And yesterday, thank Tony they did.

The battle of the toothpastes, which started with the introduction of those containing chlorophyll, has entered a new stage, it was disclosed yesterday. Amm-i-dent, Inc., toothpaste manufacturer of Jersey City, N. J., has filed suit in Federal Court against the Rystan Company of Mount Vernon, N. Y., asking that the latter's patent claims regarding therapeutic uses of chlorophyll in dental and oral care be declared invalid.

Only the Nats wanted to return to Syracuse for a fifth game in the National Basketball Association semi-final series. The Knicks, of course, had other plans and proceeded to carry these out last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, where, by playing superior basketball, the local quintet scored a 100-93 victory that wrapped up the set.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 8 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., manager of the Eisenhower Presidential campaign, said tonight at Orly Airfield as he prepared to fly back to the United States that "I feel tha I have been talking to the next President of the United States, who is going to bring lasting, durable peace not only to America but to the world."

The spontaneous individuality and imaginative whimsy of Finnish designers are demonstrated in a display now on view at Georg Jensen, where it will remain for two weeks. The exhibition, titled "Eleven Designers From Finland." is concerned primarily with ceramic objects and glassware, but also includes the first New York story showing of the unusual trays scooped from laminated wood by Tapio Wirkkala.

Parents and teachers who think they can "analyze" a child by studying his paintings were taken to task yesterday by Victor D'Amico, director of the department of education at the Museum of Modern Art.

LONDON, April 8 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today that he was always ready for discussions to reduce international tension or promote specific agreements, but that he rejected "time-wasting contortions."
BERLIN, April 8 -- Active physical resistance to Communist rule, backed by the Soviet Army, has declined among the East Germans to the point where it is almost negligible.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, April 9 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, running far ahead of his opponents for the support of Illinois' fifty elected national convention delegates, emerged victor by a wide margin today in this state's Presidential preference primary election.

Charges that large quantities of liquor sold on military and naval reserves are for civilian consumption were made yesterday in Chicago before a retail group by Ben Josephs, president of the National Liquor Package Stores Association, Inc. He said these sales had reached such proportions that they had cut deeply into regular retail business.

English lemon cheese, actually not a cheese at all but a thick, creamy blend of lemon juice, sugar and egg, is perhaps new to New Yorkes but familiar to anyone who ever has lived in Great Britain. There the concoction is used as a filling for lemon pie, a spread for biscuits and, combined with whipped cream, as a sauce for cake.

The refusal thus far of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois to become an avowed candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination has given impetus to the New York State-instigated drive for W. Averell Harriman, who has held a number of top posts in the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations and who is now administrator of the Mutual Security Agency.

Highest departmental honors i were accorded Police Inspector Thomas V. Boylan, who was killedI Saturday in the Jamaica, Queens, i plane crash, at his funeral yester: day which was attended by many city officials.

SUMMIT, N. J., April 8---With New Jersey's Presidential preferential primary next Tuesday, Harold E. Stassen became the first Republican aspirant to campaign in the state when he gave a foreign policy address in the Summit High School auditorium here tonight.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- The International Economic Conference produced tonight its first major trade results -- a tentative agreement between a group of British individuals and a group of Chinese Communists for the exchange of 10,000,000 (about $28,000,000) worth of British products for an equal amount of Chinese goods.

United States Attorney Frank J. Parker's staff in Brooklyn started yesterday an intensive investigation into a complaint that a Suffolk County potato grower had been shaken down for $7,000 for the settlement of an income-tax case.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today new issues of bonds and debentures totaling $55,000,000. Included are the obligations of telephone and industrial companies in the United States and debentures of the Canadian Province of New Brunswick.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 8 -- An anti-United States movement within the Brazilian armed forces began to crystallize today through a formal announcement by former War Minister Newton Estillac Leal that he was a candidate for election to the presidency of the Military Club of Brazil.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The White House will be reopened to visits by the general public on April 22 for the first time since it was closed for reconstruction more than three years ago. Tours will be permitted from 10 to 12 o'clock each day, Tuesday through Saturday.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 9 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1214, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

LAUREL, Md., April 8 (UP) -- Euclid, a bay colt owned by Mrs. Ellsworth H. Augustus, opened his 1952 campaign today with a surprise triumph over Eatontown, the odds-on favorite, in the featured Howard County Purse at Laurel Park before a crowd of 10,020.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- The Screen Producers Guild, formed two years ago, is mapping plans for a large-scale promotion program to acquaint the public with facets of movie making that for various reasons now receive little or no attention.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, said today it was essential that the United States make proper use of natural resources of other nations and not squander its own.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 9 (AP) -- Two major steel companies filed suit early today challenging the legality of President Truman's seizure of the steel industry.
Plans have been set in motion to rename New York's oldest bank, restoring the name it started with 168 years ago.

Acting upon what in our opinion is almost inconceivably bad advice, the Administration has elected to "solve" the problem presented by the steel wage dispute through Government seizure of the industry.

Pearl Epstein has sold the six-story store and apartment building at 31 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, to the 31-41 Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $89,500, was sold subject to a mortgage of $51,000.

The world-wide influence of American public opinion was emphasized yesterday by Ambassador Ernest A. Gross, deputy United States representative to the United Nations, when he called it "the greatest force in the world today." Ambassador Gross addressed 300 delegates from fifty-one colleges at the three-day twenty-fifth anniversary plenary session of the Model United Nations General Assembly at Barnard College.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Newbold Morris, who was dismissed as Special Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Administration's drive to purge the Government of corruption, was invited today to testify Thursday morning before the House Judiciary subcommittee investigating the Department of Justice.

PARIS, April 8 -- The formation of a new Tunisian Government favorably inclined toward the French protectors of the North African state, an event promised daily for the last week, finally has been accomplished, according to a formal announcement tonight by the French Resident General.

ELATH, Israel, April 8 -- Six hundred inhabitants of Israel's Red Sea port were fuming today, but they also had reason to rejoice. Their water supply had failed just when the Red Sea heat was rolling in earnest, but there was word that Israeli mining technicians had just established that there was enough copper in the hills twenty miles north of Elath to begin commercial exploitation.

Fannie A. Wood has sold the one-family house containing twelve rooms and three baths on a plot 150 by 132 feet at 99 Lindenmere Drive, Merrick, L. I., to Mrs. Joy H. Newman, wife of Harry N. Newman, attorney.

NEWARK, April 8 -- The Port of New York Authority has invested $11,000,000 in capital improvements at Port Newark in the last four years, and has earmarked an additional $12,000,000 for projects scheduled to be completed within the next two year.
The board of directors of Freedom House issued yesterday fourteen "ground rules for democratic behavior" to help the voter evaluate candidates and issues in the Presidential campaign.

Stock options to key personnel are not inflationary, Arthur Dean, partner of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, declared yesterday before the National Conference of Electric and Gas Utility Accountants, meeting at the Biltmore Hotel.

PIERRE, S. D., April 8 (AP) -- Already weary from long hours of sandbagging and erecting dikes, residents of this capital city and nearby Fort Pierre braced themselves tonight for severe flood conditions.

John van Druten's "I Am A Camera" was voted "the best new American play" of the 1951-52 season yesterday by the New York Drama Critics' Circle. Mary Chase's comic fantasy, "Mrs. McThing," was runner-up.

ACCORDING to the moss-grown angling lore, bluefish at Hatteras in early April insure good catches off New Jersey in July, and a report just came in from the Outer Banks that the first blue, a 3 1/2-pounder, was taken from the surf at Hatteras Point on Sunday, which should constitute a good omen.

BOSTON, April 8 -- High school students want to know more about communism and would like to have the Russian language introduced as a course of study, a representative group of high school students declared today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The American Power and Light Company today withdrew the proposal it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of stock of its subsidiary, the Washington Water Power Company, to three public utility districts in the State of Washington. Instead, the parent company substituted for its original plan a proposal for distribution of Washington common to American's stockholders.

The speeches of Queen Juliana of the Netherlands have a flavor of their own. They are fresh, unconventional and personal -- not ready-made diplomatic addresses, not speeches from the Throne, but the utterances of an unpretentious woman of common sense and great goodwill who comes here to share her thoughts with people she knows well.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, who has become the nominal operator of most of the nation's steel industry, said tonight that he planned "no change of any kind at this moment" in the wages and working conditions of the industry's employes.

At 8:40 A. M. yesterday, just before a final flood of commuters gushed out of subway exits into the financial district, a stranger to the scene entered 35 Wall Street and was directed to the northside elevators.

LOS ANGELES, April 8 -- Garson Kanin, stage and screen writer, filed suit in Superior Court today for $2,025,000 libel against a film trade paper he said had falsely reported him as acknowledging past Communist party connections.

In a preliminary finding, Civil Aeronautics Board investigators said yesterday that the C-46 cargo plane that had plunged into the heart of Jamaica, Queens, last Saturday, had gone in "relatively steep."
Following are the parties, the issues and major actors in the steel wage-price dispute:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- J. Russell Young submitted to President Truman today his resignation as president of the Board of Commissioners of the District of Columbia, effective May 31. His term of office would have ended about the middle of June.
The special detective detail assigned to the Arnold L. Schuster murder case continued to work in secret yesterday on leads developed from the finding of the murder weapon.

Two crew members testified yesterday at the manslaughter trial of Capt. Franklin B. Weaver that they saw the 200-pound master of the Isbrandsten cargo ship Flying Trader strike 125-pound William M. Harvey, 24-year-old Negro Messman, with an improvised blackjack, then shoot him as he advanced toward the captain with manacled arms.

ALBANY, April 8 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill to reduce the number of classes on health and hygiene from which public school pupils of the Christian Science faith may be excused on the ground of conflict with their religious beliefs.

The Museum of Modern Art will open an exhibition entitled "Fifteen Americans" with a preview for members this evening and to the public tomorrow, to be current through July 6. Several examples of work by each of eleven painters and three sculptors, together with examples of lumia (moving color-light compositions) by Thomas Wilfred, whose "clavilux" has become familiar during the last thirty years.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 8 -- The Giants tonight obtained Bob Elliott, the Braves' regular third baseman since 1947, for Pitcher Sheldon Jones and about $75,000 cash. Elliott, a holdout, hit .285 in 136 games for Boston last year.

Two films will have their local premieres at first-run theatres this morning. "Bend of the River," a Universal - International Western drama in Technicolor, with James Stewart, Arthur Kennedy and Julia Adams, will open at the Paramount. Anthony Mann directed and Aaron Rosenberg produced from a script by Borden Chase and the novel, "Bend of the Snake," by Bill Gulick.

Leon Jolson, who came to this country from Poland five years ago penniless, was sworn in as an American citizen yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court and then announced he was giving $10,000 to establish a fellowship grant at Teachers College, Columbia University.

Most of the previous day's losses were canceled yesterday by the stock market as traders observed some glimmer of hope that a complete shut-down of the steel industry might be averted. The market, of course, only had the news up until the 3 o'clock closing and action was based on the tenor of the developments until that time.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 9 (UP) -- Allied fighter-bombers, carrier planes and warships hammered Communist front lines and east coast ports in Korea yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- A Brooklyn junk dealer testified today that he got a $114,000 fee in a big surplus property transaction for arranging a single appointment with former War Assets Administrator Jess Larson that "closed the deal."

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade met unexpectedly good support today, and there were sharp recoveries all along the line after the initial trading, when the markets had a heavy tone. The trade seemed to have discounted the immediate effect of a steel strike, and also the impact of the other labor troubles.

Specific illustrations of waste in the city government were offered yesterday by Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, to support his argument that the only real cure for New York's recurring financial crises would be a complete overhaul of its system of administrative management.
LONDON. April 8 -- The stock markets threw off much of their recent subdued mood and prices mostly rose.

RICHARD CUMMINGS WAKEFIELD might have been the best ballplayer of this generation. Instead, he was the biggest disappointment. But now the New York Giants, desperate for outfield help with Monte Irvin gone and Willie Mays going, have reached out frantically and clutched at Wakefield. Everyone in the sport fervently hopes that likable Dick makes good. Yet few think that he can.
On April 9 forty years ago the Children's Bureau was created by Act of Congress. It was the first Bureau devoted solely to the interests of children to be created by any Government in the world.

Six women chosen for their accomplishments in newspaper, magazine, radio or public relations work will receive 1952 "Woman of Achievement" awards from the New York Alumnae Chapter of Theta Sigma Phi, national journalism sorority, at a dinner Monday in the Barbizon Hotel.
Substantial sections of the nation's communications systems still were beset by strikes yesterday, but telephone and telegraph service did not appear to be suffering much.

MONTREAL, April 8 (UP) -- Maurice (The Rocket) Richard broke up a third-period deadlock with a spectacular money goal tonight to put Montreal into the Stanley Cup finals as the Canadiens beat the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 1, in the seventh and deciding game of the semi-finals.

The Erie Railroad, in the first three months of this year, had a net income of about $3,500,000 before capital and sinking fund charges, or $1.22 a common share, Paul W. Johnston, president, told stockholders at their meeting here yesterday. In the similar period of 1951, net income was $3,017,000, or $1.03 a common share.

Any attempt to use coercion upon us in this country to accept a form and concept of government alien to our tradition and experience would be readily resisted. Yet such a change is being suggested by the draft of the International Covenant on Human Rights, which the United Nations plans to submit to the member nations for ratification.
General approval of rezoning plans providing for "clustered" local retail stores with adequate parking space was expressed yesterday by witnesses at a City Planning Commission hearing at City Hall.

A new call for an intensified campaign to eliminate the root causes of war and clear the road for a peaceful, prosperous and free world was issued last night by President Truman through his Secretary of State, Dean Acheson. The latter, speaking before the National Conference on International Economic and Social Development, delivered an address which the President had prepared but could not find time to deliver because of the urgency of the steel crisis.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Truman named Ambassador William H. Draper Jr. today to the new post of United States Permanent Representative to the North Atlantic Council.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- William C. Bullitt, former United States Ambassador to France and to Russia, asserted today that he was advised on the highest French authority late in 1939 that "two brothers named Hiss," both officers in the State Department, were "Soviet agents."

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 8 -- The Scarsdale League of Women Voters became the first major organization in the village today to give outright endorsement to the Board of Education of District 1 in its controversy with the Citizens Committee concerning "Communist infiltration" in the schools.
BOSTON, April 8 -- Continuing opposition to nonpublic schools, prominent educators today attacked the "dual system of education" that they said had developed in this country in recent years.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- A Pennsylvania company today won a court fight to get from the Government $138,507 in cash discounts and expenses, including some charity contributions.

The head measurement of Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, was seven and three-eighths at 3:35 o'clock yesterday afternoon. It swelled briefly thereafter but then came back to its normal size, thus qualifying Mr. Hollander to wear one of President Truman's hats, as a gift of the President.
Francisco dos Santos, veteran Portuguese river pilot, will never again have an unkind word for the vagaries of the weather.
TOKYO, April 8 -- Japan is facing her worst strike since General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in 1947 prohibited a general walkout against occupation objectives.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, has called on Congress to provide money to enforce the new gambling tax law or repeal the law immediately. In fact, he said, the entire Federal tax system is "balancing precariously on the brink" of collapse through lack of funds to enforce payment.

This country must show Asians and Africans by deeds, rather than through money, that its ideals have a solid base. W. Stuart Symington, former director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and now a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Senator from Missouri, said here yesterday.
The case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted atom spies for Russia, moved into a new phase yesterday when the United States Court of Appeals denied their petition for a rehearing.

LOS ANGELES, April 8 -- What happened to Paris pawnbrokers in 1871 is rather far afield from the question of the legality of contemporary Communist activity, District Judge William C. Mathes suggested today.

One hundred and five men and women members of the Federation of the Handicapped proved that paralyzed and amputated limbs are no handicap to the spirit yesterday when they donated blood for the armed services at a Red Cross bloodmobile unit set up in their headquarters at 241 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's executive order directing Secretary of Commerce Sawyer to seize and operate most of the nation's steel plants:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Congress responded promptly today to President Truman's request for a stop-gap extension of sixty war powers that are due to expire when the Japanese peace treaty goes into force.

As scores of speakers representing organizations of city employes appeared before the Board of Estimate yesterday at the first of three public hearings on Mayor Impellitteri's $1,469,265,102 executive budget, spokesmen for the larger groups supported in general the Mayor's proposal for graduated pay increases.
ENDICOTT, N. Y., April 8 -- Arrangements were completed here today for members of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, which will be torn down after Easter to worship indefinitely in Temple Beth-El.

A wild cherry tree, which has been retouched and made into an Egg Tree, will be in full "bloom" today at the Junior Museum of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Children come to see the tree every year at this season, knowing full well that whatever kind of tree has been set up, it is still the Egg Tree.

A small group of documentary-type prints, some of which may be useful in giving a fresh appearance to a room in summer, is included in the new collection of decorating materials made by Seymour Fabrics, Inc. They are available through decorators at the concern's showroom. 450 Fourth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The American Civil Liberties Union accused four big radio-television chains and two broadcasting stations today of blacklisting performers and others on political grounds.

" If Brooklyn College were located in Dutchess County staff and students would constantly yearn for the educational and cultural opportunities of the Big city. 'If we only had its museums, its theatres, its music * * * how we could enrich the college's program!'" The "Big City" is, of course, New York; the voice is that of Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College.

ALTHOUGH the quality of unpublished books is as difficult to forecast as the outcome of Presidential elections, I feel safe in predicting that no book about politics published in this election year will cause more discussion than "The Future of American Politics"* by Samuel Lubell. Professional politicians will not dare overlook it if they value their reputations as professional experts.
An unusual indictment charging an attempted burglary for the purpose of extortion was returned yesterday in General Sessions against six persons, including suspended Detective James J. Fox.

MADRAS, India, April 1 -- Inspired and run by a youthful Y. M. C. A. worker from Chicago, an Indian-style Boys Town in an abandoned army canteen has opened up vistas of a new life to some of the thousands of homeless waifs who wander the streets of this great seaport city, scavenging food from trash bins and sleeping on sidewalks and railway platforms.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- Vincent Hallinan, Presidential candidate of the Independent Progressive party, was handcuffed today to a fellow prisoner, taken from the San Francisco county jail and sent by automobile to the McNeil Island Prison farm in Washington State.
OTTAWA, April 8 (Canadian Press) -- Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott predicted tonight in his budget speech that within a couple of years it might be possible to reduce heavy defense expenditures.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Truman tonight ordered seizure of the steel mills to avert a strike of their 600,000 workers. An order directing that the Government take over the mills was issued effective at midnight, one minute before the scheduled strike was to take place.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Before J. Howard McGrath, on April 3, sent his letter of dismissal to Newbold Morris the special assistant he had chosen to investigate corruption in the Executive Branch of the Government, he cleared it with the President.
The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., called off last night its national steel strike and directed its 600,000 members to stay at work under President Truman's seizure order.

Today is Bataan Day, the tenth anniversary of the fall of the peninsula in the Philippines and the beginning of the "Death March." It has been proclaimed a day for national observance by President Quirino in Manila, and in Washington it has been commemorated by a resolution of Congress. There will be appropriate ceremonies in this country at various points.
Following is the text of President Truman's speech to the nation last night in which he ordered seizure of the steel industry to avert a strike, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The House of Representatives, by unanimous vote, completed Congressional action today to name tomorrow as "Bataan Day," commemorating the end of the epic struggle on the Philippines just ten years ago.
Queen Juliana, visiting sovereign of the Netherlands, was herself a hostess last night at a private dinner party for members of the United Nations Security Council at the Colony Club.

A story of a shepherdess counting her sheep held fascinated thirty-four pairs of shining eyes yesterday at the regular meeting of th Baby Story Hour of the New York Public Library. Its 2 to 5-year-old members almost forgot how to wriggle, and upheld the library tradition of hushing for the half hour that has become the high point of the week for baby intellectuals of the neighborhood.

Gov. Earl Warren of California, making his first major address to a New York audience as a Republican Presidential contender, appealed last night for the nomination of a progressive candidate who would not "turn back the clock" in the nation's affairs, even if he could do so.

PARIS, April 8 -- Premier Antoine Pinay, breaking through Opposition hostility and garnering support from both Gaullist and Popular Republican groups, won a victory today for his plan of financing France's budget.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- There was backstage talk of cutting $1,500,000,000 more from the Defense Department's fund bill for the fiscal year starting July 1 as the House of Representatives began voting today on the $46,680,384,270 measure.

A syndicate of investors headed by Abraham L. Sobil, attorney, has purchased the one-story taxpayer on plot 60 by 100 feet at 611-13 Columbus Avenue, near Ninetieth Street, from David Green for cash over a mortgage of $50,000. The property is assessed at $85,000. Green Selzer were the attorneys for the seller and the sale was negotiated by Hyman Leff, broker.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The United States Court of Claims dismissed today a suit by former Judge Albert W. Johnson of Lewisburg, Pa., to have his $10,000-a-year pension restored.

An eight-story loft building on lot 48 by 80 feet at 65-69 Fourth Avenue, between Ninth and Tenth Streets, has been purchased by David S. Meister, operator, from a client of Morway Picket, attorney, in a deal negotiated by the Cross Brown Company.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- President Truman got a steak luncheon from the Supreme Court today and an invitation to address the Democratic convention in his home state of Missouri on May 26.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's address, delivered by Dean Acheson, Secretary of State in the President's absence, tonight to the National Conference on International Economic and Social Development:

A viewer should not be misled by the title of the television program called "City Hospital." The presentation is not, it is a pleasure to emphasize, another call for Dr. Kildare or one more hectic romance between a handsome interne and a lovely nurse.
Address by Queen Juliana of the Netherlands upon receiving the honorary degree of doctor of laws from Columbia University yesterday:

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 9 -- The United Nations negotiators at Panmunjom accused the Communist today of introducing a "phony issue" in the negotiations for an armistice in Korea with the demand that the Soviet Union be included as a "neutral" nation to police a cease-fire.

HAVANA, April 8 -- The first of two groups of Soviet Legation officials and servants left Havana this afternoon by plane for Mexico. There were thirteen in the party headed by Valerian Goncharov a Second Secretary of the Legation. The remaining eight or ten Russians will leave tomorrow, thus ending a curious chapter in Cuba's foreign policy.

Members of the Connecticut College Club of New York have taken over the April 22 performance of "Mrs. McThing," starring Helen Hayes, at the Morosco Theatre to raise funds for the college's alumnae and scholarship funds.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Truman told a national conference tonight that the Point Four concept of improving the lot of the neglected people of the earth would surely fail "unless scientific progress is linked with political freedom."

An advisory group of some 200 merchants is being formed to assist the Brand Names Foundation in extending its educational program through retail channels, it was announced yesterday by Henry E. Abt, president.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 8 -- Joe Adonis was cast in the unusual role of state's witness today at the trial of Michael Orecchio, former Bergen County chief of detectives who is accused of laxity in investigating gambling complaints.

FORT HOOD, Tex., April 8 (UP) -- Units of the 508th Airborne Regimental Combat Team made a practice combat jump today that was supposed to have been called off because of dangerously high winds. Two men -- one a paratrooper, the other a fighter pilot -- were killed and 221 injured.
OTTAWA, April 8 -- Holding firm to the Canadian tradition, Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott this evening laid before Parliament and the country what he asserted was a balanced budget.

The standstill agreements of 1931, which placed in moratorium certain short-term bank indebtness of German creditors, should be removed immediately from the scope of the current London international conference on German external debts, according to Andrew L. Gomory, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company and chairman of the American Committee for Standstill Creditors of Germany.

BOSTON, April 8 (AP)--Two Hawaiians and one representative each of the Ohio, California, New York and Detroit teams tonight gained finalists' berths as' the National Amateur Athletic Union boxing tournament's starting field of 138 was reduced to thirty-four survivors in ten divisions.

RICHMOND, Va., April 8 -- On the wings of three home run blasts two by Duke Snider and one by Gil Hodges, the Dodgers won their final game with the Braves today at Mooers Field, 4 --1, and the Spring series by five games to four.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 16 to 21 points yesterday. The market started 4 points higher to 3 points lower than on Monday. There was a little hedge selling early, but this was offset by price fixing mostly in old May and July.

Terms of sale for textiles should be worked out jointly between mills and apparel manufacturers, according to Jules Goldstein, secretary and counsel of the National Outerwear and Sportswear Association. Representatives of various textile and apparel trade associations will be invited to a conference soon, he said, to create a more equitable sales note than is now in existence.

The transformation of the French screen classic, "The Baker's Wife," into a Broadway musical is up in the air at the moment. In February the firm of Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin announced it had every intention of going ahead with the venture.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 8 -- Delegations representing the Bonn republic and world Jewish organizations reached agreement today on a series of improvements and extensions of West German restitution and indemnification laws that will have the effect of enlarging the categories of Jews eligible for payment and of speeding up payment in many cases.

MEXICO CITY, April 8 -- Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, who is almost certain to be Mexico's next President, has stirred up a beehive of controversy with his campaign promise that he will give women the vote if elected.

MONTREAL, April 8 -- Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company of Canada, Ltd. (controlled by Canadian Pacific Railway), reported net profit of $50,785,381 for the fiscal year ended Dec. 31, 1951, compared with $41,969,861 the preceding year.
Grace Harrington, one of the five young pianists who competed publicly for the Rachmaninoff Fund prize in Carnegie Hall in April, 1948, gave her first recital in this city last night at Town Hall.

In connection with the controversy over ownership of the submerged offshore oil lands, we read that representatives of Texas claim that their state owns the land ten or more miles off shore on the basis of some "treaty" made between the Republic of Texas and the United States under which Texas accepted admission as a state.

Herbert Hoover last night challenged a boyhood friend, Lee De Forest, the radio inventor, to produce another great invention -- a push-button with which radio audiences could get even with broadcasters of singing commercials and "huckster chatter."
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- The Government clamped ceiling prices today on all seed potatoes sold in groceries, saying large quantities" were being sold as eating potatoes at over-ceiling prices.

HONG KONG, April 8 -- Three British youths who vanished more than two months ago in a small homemade sailboat called the Tiny Tim returned to Hong Kong from Communist China today after having been virtually given up for lost.

The prospective visits of Secretary of State Acheson to Brazil and of President Getulio Vargas to this country will do more than assure the other American republics that Washington has not forgotten its Good Neighbors, despite heavy preoccupation elsewhere. The trips will newly emphasize that this country's major South American tie is to Brazil -- its overseas ally in the Second World War.

After five hours of play last night in the third game of their eighteen-game match at the Manhattan Chess Club, Samuel Reshevsky of this city and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires adjourned without reaching a decision. Forty moves had been made by each player until the adjournment.

Los Angeles County, Calif., sold $3,500,000 of juvenile center bonds yesterday, due 1953 to 1972, to Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and associates at a bid of 101.60 for interest of 1 3/4 per cent, an interest cost of 1.5971 per cent.

Anthony (Tony) Blose, 18-year- old sophomore right-hander, quelled a ninth-inning rally by Columbia to insure Manhattan College's 3-2 baseball triumph over the Light Blue team at Baker Field yesterday. The game was the season opener for Coach Dave Curran's Jaspers and marked Columbia's second defeat in three contests.
ROME, April 8 -- The Bulletin of the Catholic Clergy of Rome declared today that the use of psychoanalysis was a grave sin.

Frank Costello was sentenced yesterday to eighteen months in prison and fined $5,000 -- the heaviest penalty ever imposed here for contempt -- by Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan, who declared that the gambler's balkiness before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee "may well have prevented important disclosures."

ATHENS, April 8 -- In a letter to Premier Nicholas Plastiras to be published in tomorrow's press, Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, chief of the major opposition, declined to reconsider his previously declared intention to abstain from all parliamentary proceedings until the Government offered full redress for former Minister of Defense Alexander E. Sakellariou's alleged "defamation."

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 8 -- Calling for advancement in the wisdom rather than the technique of teaching, Clarence H. Faust, president of the Fund for the Advancement of Education, today told 300 educators meeting here what kind of educational institution should receive foundation grants.

MADRID, April 8 -- As part of its bid to enhance Spanish prestige in North Africa and to court the Arab world, the Spanish Government followed up today its request for revision of the international statute of Tangier with the announcement that it had authorized the loan of 260,000,000 pesetas ($6,500,000) to the caliphs of Spanish Morocco to finance a five-year public works program.

Steel workers in the Pittsburgh area quietly and with little visible emotion accepted last night President Truman's order for Government seizure of the steel plants. They said that they would get the mills back into full production as soon as possible.

Queen Juliana, wearing cap and gown, joined in the singing of Columbia University's alma mater song, "Stand, Columbia," at a convocation yesterday where she received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree.
Your editorial of April 1 "Men for Ships" is one to meet the approval of all Americans interested in our merchant marine and our Navy.

A provision of the Customs Simplification Bill, now before the Senate Committee, was attacked yesterday by George Hansen, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, as likely to "unleash foreign mail-order competition for American retailers."

OTTAWA, April 8 (By Canadian Press) -- Trade Minister C. D. Howe announced today initial prices that the Government-operated Canadian Wheat Board will pay farmers for wheat, oats and barley during the 1952-53 crop year.

State law forbids any city employe to strike. Under the agreement now in force between the Transport Workers Union and the Board of Transportation "the union covenants and agrees * * * to engage in no strikes or other interference with the operations of the Board." Nevertheless on Monday of this week more than four hundred transit employes quit their work for several hours in three Brooklyn garages where city buses are serviced.

Wool trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday reacted from its Monday rally, losing 3 to 4 cents a pound, but recovered and ended 1 to 2 cents below Monday's close for both grease wool and tops. Volume was estimated at about 3,850,000 pounds for wool and tops combined.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Government announced today that farmer borrowers must pay off price-support loans on about 150,000,000 bushels of farm-stored grains this spring and summer or surrender them to Uncle Sam as payment of the loans.

Most Americans have gradually become masters of the machine in the factory and home to such an extent that there is a vast store of unrecognized managerial talent in this country, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor told members of the American Management Association yesterday.

The United States Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on an appeal by Gus Hall, one of the eleven convicted Communist leaders, from his contempt of court conviction for failure to surrender to begin a five-year prison term for conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government.
In homes and synagogues tonight, special services will usher in the Passover season. Judaism's holiday of freedom will start at sundown -- 6:29 P. M. in the New York area.

LONDON, April 9 -- A pamphlet that, among other things, raises questions about the wisdom of United States leadership in world affairs was issued by the British Labor party today to serve as the basis for "a referendum of party opinion" on foreign policy.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 10 (UP) -- Allied fighter-bombers swept through clear North Korean skies yesterday to bomb and strafe Communist front lines and supply routes without interference from enemy MIG-15 fighters.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The State Department said this evening that the envoys of the United States, Britain and France in Moscow had received today the Soviet reply to the Western powers' notes on Germany.

A ban on bad weather landings and on all cargo flights at La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, was suggested yesterday by State Senator Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens. It was a C-46 cargo plane seeking a rainy morning landing at International that crashed last Saturday, costing five lives.

Striking employes of the Western Electric Company began yesterday to picket Bell System installations in 1,500 communities in forty-three states and the District of Columbia, creating the likelihood of stoppages by 300,000 telephone workers.

Many industrial concerns are managed by engineers or production men, who are straining to meet production schedules. Meanwhile such managements are paying little or no attention to advertising, relegating the responsibilities for it in some cases to assistant sales managers, assistant purchasing agents, or department engineers, who do the work "with their left hands."

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed irregular, 10 points higher to 11 points net lower than on Tuesday, with the near-by deliveries relatively firm and the new crop positions easier. Reflecting the fair volume of price-fixing, cotton futures started with gains of 7 to 11 points.

Stockholders of Western Air Lines, Inc., are being offered rights to subscribe to 165,049 shares of capital stock at $11.50 a share at the rate of three new shares for each ten shares held April 8. The offer, which expires April 22, is being underwritten by a banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad last quarter had a net profit of about $1,215,000, or nearly $1,000,000 more than in the similar period last year, Frederic C. Dumaine Jr., president, told the stockoholders at the annual meeting yesterday in New Haven, Conn.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 9 (AP) -- Gustavo Palafox, Mexican champion, scored a mild upset in the Good Neighbor tennis tournament today when he downed eighth-seeded Bob Curtis of Denver, 6--3, 2 -- 6, 7 -- 5.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 9 -- A battle between supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in his home state and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio appeared likely today on the eve of the Kansas Republican convention.

A series of promotions and shifts within the higher ranks of the Police Department was announced yesterday by Commissioner George P. Monaghan as the result of the death on Saturday of a police inspector in the Queens plane crash and the retirement of an assistant chief inspector on Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- On his return to this country today from a political planning conference with General of the Army Eisenhower in Paris Senator Lodge of Massachusetts made the penetrating statement that "the great issue of our time is the attainment of a durable peace * * *."
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Government entered the market today for pork and eggs in a move designed to strengthen producer prices of hogs and the poultry product.
