BONN, Germany, April 9 -- The Western Allied High Commissioners and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer made "excellent" progress toward the completion of a contractual agreement in a six and one-half hour meeting today in an atmosphere oppressive with present and future attacks on the whole program of West German integration in Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Not a voice was raised in dissent today as the House of Representatives voted Henry W. Grunewald in contempt of Congress for his "willful and deliberate refusal" to cooperate with a House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax scandals.

GENEVA, April 9 -- Government and international officials in Europe who have specialized in problems of trade with Communist countries are much less confident than Washington circles appear to be that the Soviet Government's current emphasis on a revival of East-West trade is mainly motivated by Moscow's reaction to the pressure of the United States-sponsored quasi blockade.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt stressed yesterday the need for the United Nations to solve Arab refugee problem and pave the way for a peaceful exchange of Israeli technicians and Arab natural resources.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Governor Dewey signed today two bills designed to help finance increased local participation in the state's civil defense effort and to encourage more landlords to furnish space in their buildings for emergency bomb shelters.

" The Brass Ring," a new play by Irving Elman, will have its New York premiere at the Lyceum Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock. Sidney Blackmer and Carol Goodner play the leading roles. Donald Wolin produced the play in association with Donald Flamm.

The election of Earle S. MacPherson, chief engineer of the engineering staff of the Ford Motor Company, as a vice president and a member of the administration committee, effective May 1, was announced yesterday by Henry Ford 2d, president
M. J. Anderson and Charles V. Kinter have been elected directors of Aro Equipment Corporation.

BOSTON, April 9 -- Ending its regional convention, the American Association of School Administrators today adopted a resolution calling for Federal aid for public schools only. Strong opposition was voiced to the use of Government money, either directly or indirectly, for the support of religious schools.

LONDON, April 9 -- To quell the restlessness in the ranks of the Conservative party Prime Minister Churchill promised today that Britain's trucking services would be "denationalized" at the "earliest possible moment."

Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, editor of The Churchman, a Protestant publication, announced yesterday that he had sent a letter to Cardinal Spellman requesting that he "issue a forthright condemnation of the attempt to force Jewish merchants in the Bronx and elsewhere to close their stores on Good Friday."

As expected, Senator Taft won handsomely in Illinois. For the first time in any preferential primary contest this year he has obtained a clear majority of the Republican ballots. In Wisconsin and Nebraska he was snowed under by the combined anti-Taft vote, although he did win most of the delegates.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Newbold Morris expressed faith today in the purposes of President Truman, who sanctioned his dismissal as head of the Administration's drive to scourage wrongdoers from the Government, but spoke scornfully of J. Howard McGrath, former Attorney General who actually discharged him.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 9 -- Forty-four persons were killed and at least 100 more were injured this morning in Santa Teresa Church when a false fire alarm caused a thousand terror-stricken worshipers to stampede and trample each other down in a wild attempt to escape.

LONDON, April 9 -- Voting ended today in a series of elections for sixty-two county councils in England and Wales, the results of which have given a lift to the spirits of the Labor party which lost the national election last October.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet representative, said today that the Soviet atomic control plan provided for the inspection "of all plants producing atomic energy, from the raw material to the fiinshed product."

World sugar prices, which had fallen on Wednesday on rumors that Cuba might add 200,000 tons to its world quota, recovered by about the same amount yesterday when the reports were denied. The close on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange was 1 to 7 points higher, with most of the active months gaining 6 or 7 points.

JERUSALEM, April 9 -- The celebration of Passover was ushered in here this morning by the ceremonious opening of the gates to King David's tomb on Mount Zion by the chairman of the Mount Zion Committee.
CHICAGO, April 9 -- Grain futures in general had a firmer undertone today, reflecting the change in the steel situation.

I strongly object to the increasing tendency of THE TIMES to refer to the Republic of Korea as South Korea. This republic, established with U. N. sanction as the only valid Korean Government, is frequently subject to misrepresentation in the press.
The steel industry charged last night that President Truman had "transgressed his oath of office" and discharged a "political debt to the C. I. O." by seizing the nation's steel mills.
Banking syndicates competed yesterday for the purchase of $31,825,000 of new marketable debt of the Consumers Power Company and the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company.

LONDON, April 9 -- Led by continued advance of British Government securities, most of the industrials improved on the stock market here today. In the gilt-edge list gains of 5s (70 cents) were common, while industrials despite small turnover moved up a few pence. Textiles were firm.

BALTIMORE, April 9 -- Unless the tooth extraction Preacher Roe will undergo in Brooklyn tomorrow has an unexpected ill effect, he will pitch the opening game of the season for the Dodgers at Boston next Tuesday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 9 -- At a meeting here tonight the American Legion returned to its attack on Sarah Lawrence College of Bronxville, accusing it of ignoring charges that one of its faculty members is a Communist.

The Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, will start today distributing pledge cards to persons in the five boroughs asking them to donate blood to the armed forces through the American Red Cross. It is part of a nation-wide campaign by the scouts.

LAUREL, Md., April 9 (AP) -- Two riders, one of them the leading apprentice of the meeting, were injured in the first race today and because of the accident apprentice Fred Ryan was astride Walter M. Jeffords' Ampola, winner of the Senate Purse, the feature event.

The Federal Bureau of Narcotics reported yesterday as a hoax the contention of a Federal prisoner that he had pleaded guilty to a narcotic violation of which he was innocent to save a younger brother from a maximum prison sentence on the same charge.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 9 (AP) -- J. M. (Suey) Eason today belatedly walked out on a ten-year contract as head football coach and athletic director at the College of William and Mary to go back to high school coaching.
Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, campaign manager for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, returned yesterday from France, where he had conferred with the general.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- A $46,207,177,554 appropriation for the Department of Defense through the fiscal year beginning July 1 was passed by the House of Representatives early this evening and sent to the Senate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- Ten Asian and African countries have asked the United Nations Security Council for a chance to be heard on the Tunisian case. They demanded the opportunity to reply to statements made before the Council last week by the French delegate that their encouragement to the Tunisian nationalists had given rise to rioting and instability in Tunisia.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, April 9 -- After a year of effort, only 220 displaced persons have been recruited into the United States Army. The quota for these aliens was set at 12,500.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- Mr. Grunewald did not plead self-incrimination or any other specific constitutional grounds for his refusal to talk. Several witnesses before Congressional committees have been freed by the courts after making a self-incrimination plea.

The Board of Education approved yesterday the book "Rommel: The Desert Fox" by Brig. Gen. Desmond Young for school libraries despite the objections of one member who criticized the biography as being filled with prejudices and hero-worship.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- A hint that a seven-year fight by R. Stanley Dollar to regain control of American President Lines might be headed for an out-of-court compromise was given here yesterday by Emmet McCormack of the Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) reported yesterday that its consolidated net income last year reached a peak of $528,461,000 after charges and taxes, or $8.72 each on the 60,571,092 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $408,223,000 or $6.74 a share in 1950.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced today a new total of 107,134 American battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 178 over last week's report.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Eric Johnston said today that, to help speed the program of improving underdeveloped areas, he would ask the State Department to invite a typical country to join in a "laboratory test" and discover how to revive the flow of American private capital into development channels.
Following is the text of the steel industry's reply to President Truman, as delivered last night over all radio and television networks by Clarence B. Randall, president of the Inland Steel Company:

For years Meyer Lipsey, a Bronx laundry supply manufacturer, has been parking his automobile in front of his place of business at 131 Lincoln Avenue, between 134th Street and Bruckner Boulevard. No one ever complained about it. The sidewalk is eighteen feet wide.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said jubilantly today that his victory in the Illinois Presidential primary yesterday "indicates the voters want a real Republican candidate who knows how to conduct the fighting campaign which alone will win next November."

MOSCOW, April 9 -- The International Economic Conference was extended two additional days today to permit time for the conclusion of several private trade agreements between the Soviet Union and Communist China and Western business men after word had been received that the Soviet Union, Communist China and East European states were prepared to increase their trade with Western concerns to $15,000,000,000 to $19,000,000,000 in the next two to three years.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., April 9 (UP) -- An earthquake shook seven states in the Southwest and Midwest today from Des Moines, Iowa, and Omaha, Neb., to Austin, Tex., swaying tall buildings as much as six inches. It was felt from Fayetteville, Ark., to Amarillo, Tex., 550 miles to the west.

Under the Executive Order issued by President Truman late Tuesday night the Secretary of Commerce is directed to "take possession" of any or all of the plants of eighty-eight private companies which manufacture all but an insignificant part of the nation's steel. The Executive Order declares that the Secretary of Commerce "shall determine and prescribe terms and conditions of employment" in the plants thus seized.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The American Fair Trade Council, Inc., and the National Association of Retail Druggists joined forces today in support of a single "fair trade" bill to set minimum prices for so-called brand name products.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Truman congratulated the Children's Bureau on its fortieth anniversary today. In a letter to Oscar R. Ewing, Administrator of the Federal Security Agency of which the bureau is a part, the President wrote:

The $341,600,000 patent-infringement suit brought by Harry Ferguson, Irish-born British farm machinery inventor, against the Ford Motor Company and other defendants after the Ford-Ferguson alliance of 1939 was broken in 1947, was settled yesterday.
SHREVEPORT, La., April 9 -- Dick Wakefield celebrated his debut as a Giant today by crashing a pinch double off the distant left field wall.

Queen Juliana, trying hard to be mistaken for a New York housewife despite an escort of Secret Service men, went shopping on Fifth Avenue yesterday for bubble bath soap, toys and teen-age clothes. The dresses were for 14-year-old Princess Beatrix, who, her mother said, "grows very fast out of everything."

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- President Truman today signed legislation to compensate United States prisoners of war in World War II who were subjected to cruel treatment or forced to work for their captors without compensation.

PIERRE, S. D., April 9 (AP) -- The muddy Missouri River had driven some 1,500 persons from their homes tonight and gushed through the near-by Fort Pierre municipal power plant. Sandbag crews fought to save Pierre from a blackout.

In a report on the Security Council meeting concerning the eleven Asian-Arab nation request for an airing of the Franco-Tunisian dispute your correspondent A. M. Rosenthal reveals that "there has been a large-sized hassle within the State Department on whether to abstain or vote in favor of a hearing."

Realistic and cautious optimism is beginning to replace "the spirit of defeatism which has been keeping us fearful," a business group was told yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Charles C. Noble, dean of the Hendricks Memorial Chapel, Syracuse University.
The State of Maryland announced yesterday it would receive bids on April 21 for bond issues totaling $20,532,000.

BUENOS AIRES, April 9 -- The overthrow of Bolivia's military junta led by Gen. Hugo Ballivian was described today by Dr. Victor Paz Estenssoro as "a revolutionary return to legality" which promises a better standard of living to Bolivian workers.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 9 (AP) -- The United States Department of Justice filed an anti-trust complaint in the United States District Court here today charging three large concerns with "combining and conspiring to restrain and monopolize the manufacture and sale of railroad highway grade crossing protective devices."

A useful new cook booklet on rice, prepared by the Louisiana State Rice Milling Company, demonstrates the versatility of this economical cereal grain. Though the title, "Seventy-five Glamorous Rice Dishes," may seem more appropriate to Hollywood than the kitchen, the booklet presents practical, easy-to-follow ways in which rice can be used in soups, salads, main dishes, hot breads and sweets.

Harold E. Stassen, stumping New Jersey for votes in next Tuesday's Republican Presidential primary, said yesterday that if elected he would restore General of the Army Douglas A. MacArthur to supreme command in the Far East as a "first step" toward ending the Korean war.

" Amahl and the Night Visitors," which we saw last Christmas Eve as the first television opera, was given its first stage production here by the New York City Opera Company last night in the City Center of Art and Drama.

Passover, the Jewish festival of freedom that commemorates the Exodus of the ancient Israelites from Egyptian bondage, began at sundown yesterday with devotions in synagogues and temples and the holding of the traditional first night seder in homes.

Rudolph Halley's excellent speech before a Citizens Budget Commission audience showed him in the role in which the City Council President can be of greatest service to the community. He hammered away at the need and the opportunity for economies in city administration.

When they said let there be lights a while ago the idea of the guardians of the traffic was, we were told, that our streets would then be safer for foot-passengers. So far as we can make out, foot-passengers are no safer than they used to be when the lights on the fronts of motor cars were dimmer.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey was denounced last night by former Gov. Charles Edison as having "created pressure" against Senator Robert A. Taft by "stacking the cards" for next Tuesday's primary in favor of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 2:

WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 9 -- A new community-backed social club for mentally retarded teenagers, which has been in operation on an experimental basis here since February, will be expanded this summer, it was announced today. Continuance of the project was approved this week at a board meeting of the North Essex Council of Jewish Women, the sponsor organization, which works in cooperation with the New Jersey Parents Association for Retarded Children.

A sudden and officially unexplained development yesterday in the Arnold L. Schuster murder case shifted the activity from police stations to the District Attorney's office and the County Court in Brooklyn.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 9 -- A member of Joe Adonis' gambling syndicate testified today in the Bergen County Court trial of Michael Orecchio, former county chief of detectives accused of misconduct in not properly investigating gambling, that there had been no "pay-off" to Orecchio.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 9 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan has called a special meeting of the Cabinet for Monday. This is interpreted as presaging early action by the Government in the constitutional crisis caused by Dr. Malan's plan to curb the power of the courts to test acts of Parliament.

Members of the Police Department who were forced out of the jobs last Jan. 1 because of the law enacted last June that requires members of the force to retire at the age of 63 won a round yesterday in their legal battle against the statute when Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber upheld the validity of their complaint.

CAMP EDWARDS, Mass., April 9 -- Twelve Air Force officers and men were killed today in the collision of two military planes over the bombing range northeast of Otis Air Force Base on Cape Cod. The planes exploded and scattered burning wreckage "like fireworks" over a wide area, according to witnesses. Six separate brush fires were started by the falling debris.

Without resuming play after having sealed his forty-first move at the close of Tuesday's five-hour session, Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires resigned the third game of his match with Samuel Reshevsky of New York yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club.

TRENTON, April 9 -- Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Republican state organization expressed serious concern here today over a mounting tide for Senator Robert A. Taft, spurred by the Ohioan's six-to-one victory in last Tuesday's Illinois primary.

Scholarships covering all expenses for four years of college and post-graduate work were presented yesterday by Daniel G. Arnstein, president of the W. A. G. S. Transportation System and the Terminal System, Inc., to two children of taxicab drivers employed by him.

FORT HOOD, Tex., April 9 (UP) -- Exercise Long Horn was called off at 4 P. M. today, eighteen hours ahead of schedule, after units of the First Armored Division reached their objective at the Colorado River.

Crew members aboard the Isbrandtsen cargo ship Flying Trader locked themselves in their quarters in fear of their skipper, it was testified yesterday at the trial of Capt. Franklin B. Weaver, master of the vessel. Captain Weaver is on trial before Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld and a jury of eight men and four women for manslaughter in the death last Oct. 25 of William M. Harvey, 24-year-old Negro messman.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- While the thumping victory of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in yesterday's preferential primary election in Illinois stole the spotlight, the demonstration put on by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson as a vote-getter in the Democratic ranks provided no little discomfiture today for the backers of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, aspirant to his party's Presidential nomination.

A "real flurry" of no-down-payment-promotions on home furnishings items retailing for less than $100 will begin immediately, installment store merchants said yesterday. They said plans were being completed to take advantage of the Federal Reserve Board's action on Tuesday that exempted from Regulation W. which sets consumer credit terms, all products selling in stores for less than $100.

After long negotiations, the trustees of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation and Local 100, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., have agreed on a compromise contract, it was announced yesterday in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Secretary of the Navy Dan A. Kimball today urged a five-fold increase in the size of the 400-man United States military assistance mission that is grooming the Chinese Nationalist fighting forces on Formosa.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Your editorial of March 10 on P. A. R. (Project Adequate Roads) concludes: "The stature of the organizations which have organized it and the gravity of the problems it will try to solve call for our hearty support."

PARIS, April 9 -- Premier Antoine Pinay, for the second time in twenty - four hours, won a victory tonight in the National Assembly that consolidated his campaign for the "defense of the franc" and the position of his new right-wing majority.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Representative W. R. Poage, Democrat of Texas, hinted today that unscrupulous persons might have spread foot - and - mouth disease through Mexico to benefit from the resultant cattle shortage.

Gov. Earl Warren defined yesterday the main issues of the coming Presidential campaign as integrity in government, solvency in government, restoration to the state and local governments of powers recognized for 175 years, world peace and the position of the United States in world affairs.

LOS ANGELES, April 9 -- A fifth undercover operative for the Federal Bureau of Investigation "planted" in the Communist party in California in recent years was introduced by the Government today as its eighth witness in the United States District Court trial of fifteen party functionaries.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury at Denver gave high praise today to the Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan, for the "corrective action" he had taken in the Government-owned grain storage program.

Cork blocks of 795 to 960 life preservers rejected last month by the City of New York's Department of Marine and Aviation were found yesterday to be undersized after careful examination, the Coast Guard said.

THE gold rush will begin in Yonkers on Tuesday. Two years ago Bill Cane, a modern Comstock, tapped a lode on the site of the old Empire City hoss racing track. He staked out a claim under the name of Yonkers Raceway and, jeepers, how the money poured in! Cane struck it rich from the start. His opening season of 1950 was fabulously successful.

The waistline, with its variable position, remains a focal point of the silhouette in spring and summer fashions. This emphasis on the midriff has been one of the primary influences in the designing of this season's foundation garments.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 9 -- The serious situation in the West German-Israeli indemnity conference deteriorated even further today, and an Israeli spokesman for the first time spoke of the "definite possibility" of his government's abandoning the talks.

" Jerusalem, the Emanation of the Giant Albion," the last work of the poet, painter and mystic, William Blake, will be issued here today in an edition that rivals the beauty of the author's only hand-colored copy.
CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Representatives of seven Midwestern colleges today accepted a general plan for a new basketball conference.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The Subversive Activities Control Board rejected today a motion to have a Government case against the Communist party dismissed on the ground that there was no Attorney General. The motion was brought by Vito Marcantonio, former Representative in Congress from New York and attorney for the party.

A substantial set of virtues was apparent during Robert Floyd's debut recital last night in Town Hall. High up on the list was the musical integrity displayed by the young pianist. All through the recital there was respect for the composer and an honest view toward the instrument.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 10 -- United Nations and Communist delegates at Panmunjom agreed tentatively today to new discussions by the staff officers of terms for the enforcement of an armistice in Korea. The aim would be to determine whether areas of agreement still existed after the breakdown of the enemy proposal for a "package" settlement of the two major remaining difficulties in the path of a cease-fire.

Net asset value of the capital stock of the Lehman Corporation increased to $73.74 on March 31, a new high for any quarter's end in the history of the corporation, Robert Lehman, president, disclosed yesterday in the interim report for the nine months ended that date.
Willard P. Cunningham has been appointed director of engineering sales for L. O. Koven Brother, Inc., Jersey City, manufacturer of tanks, mixers, boilers, special process and storage equipment.

A locksmith, believed to be one of a gang of seven that stole $428,000 in jewels from the home of Mrs. Stanton D. Sanson two years ago, was indicted yesterday on charges of burglary and grand larceny. The grand jury action was described as the first break in the unsolved case.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Continued low consumer buying -- a lull that has hurt some businesses -- was indicated today in a survey reported by the Federal Reserve Board.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture warned housewives today that dairy prices would go up this year and per capita milk production would be the lowest on record.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Truman's message to Congress on the steel dispute, and of the telegram from Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, to presidents of seventy-one steel companies informing them of Government seizure:

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 9 -- Working to iron out problems in pre-medical education that often result in poorly prepared students for the nation's medical schools, prominent educators today presented the findings of a four-day study to colleagues. Eleven member committees of the Subcommittee on Professional Education of tion of the Survey of Medical Edu- the Survey of Medical Education presented reports.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 9 -- Pro-government Bolivian troops massed in increasingly larger numbers outside La Paz late tonight to battle armed rebels in an overthrow attempt that already had killed at least eighteen and left another sixty wounded.

Fred D. Kaplan, well-known criminal lawyer and one of the leading tournament contract bridge players, has been indicted for attempting to evade $273,479 in Federal income taxes for four years, 1945 through 1948, United States Attorney Myles J. Lane announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Government's seizure of the steel mills was the seventy-first such action taken since June 9, 1941, Justice Department records disclosed today.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 9 -- Dr. Louis T. Wright, surgical director and president of the medical board of Harlem Hospital in New York, and the Rev. Harold Purcell, a Roman Catholic priest of Montgomery, Ala., received citations tonight for their contributions to interracial health programs in the North and the South.

" FANFARE FOR TWO PIGEONS,"* by H. W. Heinsheimer, is a jubilant report on the new fiddles tuning up all over America. We are on the high notes of a musical revolution. It's getting so that you can't go anywhere without enjoying a first-rate rendering of Beethoven's "Pastoral," followed, like as not, by a scrupulous tootling of Respighi's "the Fountains of Rome."

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 9 (AP) -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation today reported 1951 net profit after taxes of $1,927,639, an increase of 31 per cent over 1950. Earnings were $4.38 a share, compared with $3.37 on a net of $1,468,120 in 1950.

BETHPAGE, L. I., April 9 -- A tiny biplane, built for World War I combat duty, bounced across a stretch of spongy grassland here this afternoon and climbed into the "wide blue yonder" for one of its final flights before being placed in the Smithsonian Institution's National Air Museum.

The Government of Premier Pinay, the first Right-of-Center regime France has had since the war, has scored an impressive victory in ten separate votes of confidence on an issue which wrecked two preceding Cabinets -- the budget. This victory was made possible by evidence of a start toward economic stabilization which has enhanced M. Pinay's personal prestige to the point that he is being hailed as a second Poincare.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Retailers will have to get accustomed to the idea of shaved profits, Meyer Kestnbaum, president of Hart, Schaffner Marx, Chicago, men's clothing manufacturer, said today in a talk preceding a showing of the company's fall line.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- The Oilwell Processing Company of Houston, Tex., filed a damage suit for $2,000,000,000 yesterday against Meyer A. Mathiasen, general manager of the Mathiasen Tanker Industries, Inc., of this city.

BOSTON, April 9 (UP) -- Floyd Patterson, a middleweight, was picked as the outstanding boxer tonight as he captured the title in his division and led New York to the team title in the Sixty-fourth National Amateur Athletic Union boxing tourney.

Leading members of the worlds of society and the theatre in this country and abroad participated in the spectacular and elaborate tableaux that were features of the entertainment at the April in Paris Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the French Hospital in New York and various Franco-American philanthropies.

LONDON, April 9 -- After ten months of energetic lobbying by societies for the preservation of field sports and fauna, the Poaching of Deer (Scotland). Bill got as far as the committee stage in the House of Lords last night. Then it was postponed until after the Easter recess because the lords wanted a technical report on an adequate closed season for Scotland's most persecuted mammal.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 391,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. On the basis of a new definition of bulk terminals adopted by the Bureau of Mines and the institute, the total supplies at the week-end were 158,304,000 barrels, compared with 158,695,000 a week earlier and 147,638,000 a year ago.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 9 -- Swedish Communists, whose ranks have been reduced lately by purges within and by resignations, once more are being purged but this time by the Swedish security police. The latest Communist official to land in this police net on a charge of espionage is Arthur Karlsson, generally regarded as the head of the party's intelligence section in the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- Disagreement with President Truman's seizure of the steel industry was voiced today by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee as he opened his northern California campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.

SYRACUSE, April 9 (AP) -- A Brooklyn housewife pleaded guilty today to charges of smuggling 1,024 carats of diamonds into the United States and then testified for the Government in the trial of a Belgian indicted with her.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, by polling approximately three-quarters of the Illinois' Republican vote in yesterday's primary, widened substantially his lead over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidential nomination by gaining assured support from fifty-nine additional delegates.

LONDON, April 9 -- British sources were not perturbed by press reports from Cairo today saying that Premier Ahmed Nequib al Hilaili Pasha would refuse to enter into formal negotiations with Britain unless constitutional reforms in the Sudan were ended.

The General Telephone Corporation is "streamlining" the corporate names of its operating subsidiaries, which operate in nineteen states and serve areas with an estimated population of about 5,500,000. As a result the system, the second largest operating telephone concern in the United States, is to be known as the General Telephone Company, as the operating properties of the American and Telegraph Company are known as the Bell System.

Consolidated net earnings of the St. Lawrence Corporation and its subsidiaries in 1951 were $9,247,477, the highest in the paper company's history, the concern reported yesterday. Earnings for 1950 totaled $8,270,870.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 9 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, failed today to obtain enough valid signatures to put his name on the Republican Presidential Preferential ballot at the California primary of June 3.
Lester Markel, Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday that Americans were afflicted with six "great illusions" that impede the intelligent solution of international problems.

The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary will be aided by the show, "Of Thee I Sing," on the night of May 6 at the Ziegfeld Theatre. Mrs. Alexis C. Coudert is chairman of the executive committee that has in charge the sale of tickets for the event. Mrs. Charles J. Nourse heads the Women's Association of the beneficiary, under whose auspices the benefit has been arranged.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, drew applause from an Oklahoma farm group today when introduced as "the man who I hope will be the next President of the United States." Representative Toby Morris, Democrat of Oklahoma, made the introduction as toastmaster at a luncheon given by Oklahoma legislators for leaders of the Oklahoma Farmers' Union.
DETROIT, April 9 (UP) -- Jake La Motta, the Bronx Bull, proved tonight that his boxing days are not over as he pounded out a convincing ten-round decision over young Norman Hayes of Boston.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 9 -- A lull has settled over battle zones of Tongking as the French command redisposes units for continuation of cleanup operations against the Vietminh rebel forces in the Red River delta. Activity in Tongking during the last few days has been confined to patrol clashes, ambushes on the ground, and French air attacks against Vietminh concentrations and communications.

LONDON, April 9 -- A slump in the British textile industry has raised the number of unemployed persons in Britain to the highest level since the 1946-47 fuel crisis, the Ministry of Labor announced today.

The stock market was caught yesterday between the muddled situation resulting from the steel strike and the resultant Government seizure order, and the proximity of Passover and Easter. For the best part of the session prices wandered aimless and, at the close, there was little difference shown between the number of gains and losses.

Foreign Minister Dirk U. Stikker of the Netherlands urged yesterday that the United States help to insure the continuation of the European Payments Union by giving financial assistance to Western European countries through the union instead of making bilateral arrangements with individual countries.

The tempo of Easter began to pick up in yesterday's brisk air and intermittent sunshine, presaging the expected swarming on Sunday to midtown Fifth Avenue for the Easter Parade and to resorts, patriotic shrines and the homes of country relatives.
NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- The Indian Government has completed plans for the installation of a modern silver refinery plant in Alipore, near Calcutta, at an estimated cost of $1,200,000.

Mayor Impellitteri deserves a rest and we see no reason for criticizing his plan to take two weeks in Florida. His five-week absence for a "goodwill" tour of Italy and Israel last fall was another matter, and came in for deserved complaint. This time he has a doctor's certificate of need, but regardless of that he can beneficially use a little breather from the problems and the engagements of office.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended today the big New York securities firm of Van Alstyne, Noel Co. from trading in the New York Stock Exchange and Curb market for twenty days.

Summer yacht racing on Long Island Sound will start on May 10. That was decided last night at the spring meeting of the International class of sloops, which was held in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.
MILWAUKEE, April 9 (AP) -- The Jockey Coopers of Chicago rolled 3,012 tonight to take the team lead in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

A new work by Victor Wolfgang von Hagen, naturalist and author of more than twenty-one books on Latin America, is scheduled by Duell, Sloan Pearce-Little, Brown for May 6 publication. "The Four Seasons of Manuela" is a biography of "one of the most fascinating women" in South American history, Manuela Saenz.
Which ship was first to hoist the colors of new Japan atop the taffrail here?

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Truman stepped into a storm of Congressional protest against his seizure of the steel industry today, with a special message challenging the legislative branch to countermand his order if it should "deem some other course to be wiser."

THE big-game fishing fraternity, that jovial group of extroverts whose outlook is limited by the line capacity of a 16/0 reel and whose horizon has the profile of a giant marlin or tuna, was set solidly back on its heels (or fighting chair) when the word was received that a 1,025-pound black marlin had been legitimately boated off Cabo Blanco, Peru.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Judge Alexander Holtzoff, in United States District Court, refused today to nullify the Government's seizure of the country's basic steel industry. Three major companies had made the request for a restraining order -- Bethlehem, Republic and Youngstown Sheet and Tube.

TRENTON, April 9 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll accused Taft forces in New Jersey tonight of perpetrating "a great hoax" on the voters by pretending to withdraw from the state's preferential primary while conducting "a well-oiled campaign."

NEW HAVEN, April 9 -- Yale University displayed today part of a newly acquired collection of 3,000 rare books and manuscripts dating back to 1493 when Columbus wrote a letter in Latin describing his voyage to "India" the previous year.

The swing back to the Left in the British county council elections reflects popular dissatisfaction that living conditions under a Conservative Government are no easier than they were when the Labor party was in power. In some respects, indeed, they are harder.
NORFOLK, Va., April 9 -- The Yankees' jaunt north, now entering its final strides, is becoming more and more complicated for Prof. Casey Stengel.

Spokesmen for the city's school system told the Board of Estimate yesterday that Mayor Impellitteri's proposed 1952-53 allocation of $249,597,619 to the Board of Education would leave the public schools without adequate teaching forces and make impossible the proper maintenance and repair of school buildings.
The General Motors Acceptance Corporation has arranged to borrow $12,000,000 for nine months from the State of New Jersey at 2 1/2 per cent interest.

Adolf Teschner, 48 years old, a city tax assessor, and his wife, Rosamond, 46, were found dead of gas poisoning yesterday in the kitchen of their apartment at 66-12 102d Street, Forest Hills, Queens. The police said that they apparently had committed suicide.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, the United States Supreme Commander in the Far East, is being mentioned in official quarters here as the most likely successor to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as the North Atlantic military chief in Paris.

PARIS, April 9 -- In hinting in her New York speech Monday that the United States was in too great a hurry to unite Western Europe, Queen Juliana of the Netherlands gave very restrained expression to a view that is general in Europe.

NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- The lines were drawn for what may be the first major test between the Communists and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party for control of south India when Chakravarti Rajagopalachari, one of the nation's senior statesmen, announced tonight his Congress party Cabinet for famine-stricken Madras, India's second most populous state.

Judge Harold R. Medina and Government counsel in the investment banking anti-trust case were in dispute yesterday over whether or not Harold L. Stuart, Chicago banker and Government witness, was an "informer" in the case brought by the Government against seventeen of Mr. Stuart's competitors.

Mordecai Namir, secretary-general of the Histadrut, Israel's labor federation, and former Israeli Minister to Russia, charged yesterday that the "feudal classes" in the Arab nations were responsible "for prolonging the instability of the Middle East."

James Cox Brady's Landmark, a filly named for her dam, Oasis, won horse-of-the-day honors before 23,449 customers at Jamaica yesterday when she held on for a neck decision in the $17,675 Prioress Stakes. She was the $10.62-for-$2 second choice in a line-up of a dozen 3-year-old fillies.
Contracts for the construction of two additional tankers have lifted the American shipbuilding industry above the two-million-dead-weight-ton mark for the first time since the end of World War II.

Verdi's "Don Carlo" received its fourth and final presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. There was a new conductor in the pit and the Princess of Eboli was sung by Regina Resnik for the first time.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, the United States Supreme Commander in the Far East, is being mentioned in official quarters here as the most likely successor to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as the North Atlantic military chief in Paris.

PARIS, April 9 -- In hinting in her New York speech Monday that the United States was in too great a hurry to unite Western Europe, Queen Juliana of the Netherlands gave very restrained expression to a view that is general in Europe.

NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- The lines were drawn for what may be the first major test between the Communists and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party for control of south India when Chakravarti Rajagopalachari, one of the nation's senior statesmen, announced tonight his Congress party Cabinet for famine-stricken Madras, India's second most populous state.
Joseph C. Hoagland Jr. of New York, in a purchase for occupancy, has acquired the country estate property of Mrs. Harden L. Crawford, in Rumson, N. J. William H. Hintelmann was the broker.

Released on leave as president and director of the Ford Foundation, Paul F. Hoffman began yesterday to devote his full time to working for the nomination of General Eisenhower. As chairman of the advisory committee to Citizens for Eisenhower, Mr. Hoffman will coordinate his activities with those of Walter Williams, who is national chairman of the organization.

A new low in mark-on and a new high in operating expenses, together with increased taxes, cut sharply into net profits of the nation's department stores during fiscal 1951, according to a report issued yesterday to members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association by its Controllers Congress.

The forty-one-family apartment house at 314 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Philip Zipes, operator, from a client of Morris Crausman, lawyer. The property is assessed at $127,000.

LONDON, April 10 -- Further changes in personnel of the Old Vic Theatre here were announced this week. As the year for which Tyrone Guthrie agreed to direct Old Vic expires in June, Hugh Hunt has been appointed director for next season.

Newark Airport will reopen at 9 A. M. Monday for limited military use with flights restricted to good weather in daylight and landings and rake-offs confined to runways away from congested communities in the area.

Telephone service in many parts of the country was slowed but not halted yesterday by union picket lines as thousands of Bell System employes stopped work in sympathy with the strike of 16,000 Western Electric Company employes.

MONTREAL, April 10 (UP) -- Tony Leswick scored two goals tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens in the opening game of their best-of-seven series for the Stanley Cup.
LONDON, April 10 -- The stock markets were quiet today on the eve of the Easter holiday but prices held the all-round improvement that took place yesterday.

Plans for altering the vacant brownstone dwelling at 166 East Seventy-fourth Street into apartments were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by Rena Clark for cash over mortgages amounting to $38,000. The Maxwell Brody Company were the brokers.

BALTIMORE, April 10 -- The Yankees closed their tour north on an unexpectedly sour note today, losing to Don Heffner's Baltimore Orioles, 6 to 2. Coming on the heels of the International Leaguers 4-1 triumph over the Dodgers here last night, it was a result that brought thunderous cheers from a crowd of 4,000.

CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- Gordon Hughes, research director of General Mills, Inc., Minneapolis, has been elected president of the American Marketing Association to succeed George H. Brown, Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis Omaha Railway Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue $990,000 in equipment trust certificates. The funds would be used as part payment for eight Diesel electric switching locomotives to cost a total of $1,243,942.

Most of us have long recognized that one of the leading causes of juvenile delinquency in this city is the lack of proper, organized recreational facilities for a large number of our children. This has been particularly true in recent years as new buildings have taken up more and more of the city's "playground" space.

In tip-top condition once more after a long illness, John C. Wilson has buckled down to work on plans for the 1952-53 season. Definitely listed on his program is "The Deep Blue Sea," Terence Rattigan's current London hit in which Peggy Ashcroft was acclaimed for her interpretation of the central role.
PIERRE, S. D., April 10 (AP) -- The Missouri River surged over one-fifth of this capital city tonight, but Army engineers said the flood might have reached its greatest height.
MILWAUKEE, April 10 (UP) -- Scoring was off the pace in the American Bowling Congress today and the top ten leaders remained unchanged.

A camera was used to foil the ten-story suicide leap of a restaurant worker in Manhattan yesterday, while, in Brooklyn, a net broke the fall of a barber who jumped off a third-story window ledge of the Bedford Avenue police station.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- United States diplomats said today that the Soviet Union's latest note to the three Western Powers on Germany was a repetition of last month's effort and that it held out no more hope than the earlier communication for success of a Big Four meeting on a German treaty.

If there is one country in the Western Hemisphere that verges on being "out of this world" it is Bolivia, the landlocked Andean republic whose capital is more than two miles above the sea. Although the country is sensationally picturesque it is intensely tragic. Its tin economy has aggravated the plight of the rural workers and its politics have been a confused horror of changes by force.

An extensive collection of chairs, tables and table tops designed by an Italian, Aldo Bartolucci, and executed under his direction by artisans of Florence, has arrived at a new shop, Bartolucci Arts, 54 East Fifty-third Street. These pieces have an ornate and elaborate quality that seems somewhat akin to the contemporary French movement in the decorative arts.

BONN, Germany, April 10 -- The results of communal elections in the state of Bavaria, tabulated in percentages today although the elections took place March 30, have revealed that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's party -- known in this state as the Christian Social Union -- had scored a slender but important victory over the Social Democrats. The total votes have not yet been announced.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Truman stirred new controversy today as he sent to Congress three reorganization plans that would put under Civil Service more than 20,000 postmasters, customs officials and United States marshals, now politically appointed.

JERUSALEM, April 10 -- Last night Jews throughout the world ate bitter herbs with their Passover matzote to symbolize the bitterness of enslavement in ancient Egypt. Today thousands of Jewish pilgrims climbed the hill from the New City of Jerusalem to Mount Zion.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- A membership vote on whether the Board of Trade will be open Saturday in June, July and August appeared assured today. Grain interests favoring Saturday closings presented a petition to Everette B. Harris, exchange secretary, requesting a membership poll. It will be presented to directors for action at a meeting Tuesday.

MOSCOW, Friday, April 11 -- The Soviet Government has again asked four-power discussion of a German peace treaty and has proposed all-German elections, supervised by the four occupation powers, in the near future.

For a traditional Easter dinner, baked ham is suggested for the meat course, teamed with apple sauce and spring vegetables. Strawberry shortcake puts a festive period to the meal. Total cost of the dinner for four is $3.42 or a little over 85 cents a person.
ST. LOUIS, April 10 (AP) -- A nation-wide oil strike was threatened today by a spokesman for oil unions seeking pay increases.

The block-square structure in the heart of downtown Brooklyn formerly occupied by Frederick Loeser Co., department store, has been acquired by J. W. Enterprises, a real estate holding company. The transaction was described as a multi-million dollar deal and as one of the largest in recent Brooklyn history.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 10 -- The Syrian Government announced today that all sports clubs and Boy Scout and similar organizations must be reorganized. Relations with any religious group, church or racial or language group are prohibited. This order follows the suppression earlier in the week of all political parties in Syria.

Easter shoppers are thronging into shops and department stores in numbers to delight their hard-pressed operators. At the close of business yesterday it was apparent that Easter shopping is surpassing the most optimistic hopes of the city's retailers.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Senate gave a 60-to-0 vote of confidence today to its subcommittee that is investigating the charges through which Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, has called for the expulsion of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

The coordinated idea has been applied to the bathroom and bedroom areas of the home in a new group of fabrics called Frosty Tone. The collection, made up of sheets, pillow cases and blankets, together with towels, face cloths and rugs, all colored to match, will be available at Gimbels and Lord Taylor, among other stores, on Monday.

NEWARK, April 10 -- An improved method of treating hemophilia, a hereditary disease characterized by delayed clotting of the blood, has been developed by the Research Foundation of the Beth Israel Hospital here, spokesmen for the institution said today.

NINETY years ago last Sunday a Confederate army commanded by Gen. Albert Sidney Johnston surprised a Union army commanded by Gen. U. S. Grant near a little town called Pittsburg Landing on the west bank of the Tennessee River a few miles north of the Mississippi state line. The two-day battle which followed was the bloodiest ever fought in this country up to that time.

Seven recipients of Horatio Alger awards for 1952, given to men who have risen in the American tradition from humble beginnings to heights of achievement and service, were announced yesterday. The winners were chosen by vote of more than 3,000 educational leaders on ballots circulated by the American Schools and Colleges Association, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The winners are:

TOPEKA, Kan., April 10 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's backers in his home state added today a delegate they believe will back the general, beating off a last-ditch stand by supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio at the Kansas Republican convention.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- An unusual request by a major farm organization that $200,000,000 be lopped off Federal farm programs for the next year got a cool reception in a Senate subcommittee today.

The stock market lost some of its nervousness over the steel situation yesterday and attention shifted to the railroads and petroleums. These two sections accounted for the greater part of the show of strength exhibited during the session as trading expanded slightly.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- When Harry S. Truman, private citizen of Independence, Mo., reflects upon incidents during his service as President of the United States, he may conclude that his handling of the current dispute in the steel industry was a striking example of bad government.
Richard W. Bauman has been appointed sales manager of the Koolfoam Department of the foam rubber division of Dayton Rubber Company.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 10 -- The executive board of the Scarsdale High School Parent-Teacher Association crossed swords today with the Citizens Committee that has been denouncing "Communist infiltration" in the public schools here.

The fraudulent nature of the Soviet "disarmament plan" was demonstrated again before the United Nations Disarmament Commission on Wednesday when Mr. Malik dodged all questions regarding the precise meaning of its several provisions and in effect called upon the world to accept the plan on faith, subject to the Soviet's own interpretation.

The contraction in loans to business and industry in the New York area continued for the third successive week, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The combined statement for the reporting member banks showed a further decline of $71,000,000 which brought the outstanding total down to $7,744,000,000, the lowest since last December.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Truman said today he believed that the steel wage dispute could be settled by collective bargaining and that he would not interfere. He left open, however, the question whether he would order the Wage Stabilization Board's recommendations into effect if bargaining collapsed.

The city put up on the auction block yesterday for bidding on April 25 at 11 A. M. an entire creekful of submerged or sunken timber. After many years of keeping the creosoted planking in wet storage for building float bottoms and underwater parts of piers, the city has decided this type of storage operation is more trouble than it is worth.

A $1,000,000 grant to the new School of Industrial Management of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to carry on "research and exploration" in the industrial management field was announced yesterday by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The United States is considering a $50,000,000 loan to France to help the French textile industry buy raw cotton, it was learned today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 10 (AP) -- The Johnstown Jets defeated the New Haven Tomahawks, 4 -- 1, tonight in an Eastern Hockey League play-off game amid riotous scenes that included the arrest of the Tomahawks' captain.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, a former tenant of the White House, said today that the remodeled mansion was a great deal "more convenient and comfortable" than when she lived there.
The United States Court of Appeals granted $5,000 bail yesterday to Frank Costello until the 61-year-old gambler's appeal from his conviction of contempt of the Senate is heard on May 12.

New fabrics will be a feature of the display at Macy's next week of fashions made from patterns. Each design, made from an Advance pattern, will be in a new Everfast cotton with the Everglaze crease-resistant feature.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- Alexis Kyrou, the Greek representative on the United Nations Disarmament Commission, said today that Greece would agree to take a United States "working paper" as the basis for discussion of a world-wide arms census. Mr. Kyrou told the Commission's Committee No. 2 that the United States' suggestions constituted "a constructive project, certainly not perfect, yet perfectible."

A public exhibition of the fourteen Stations of the Cross, the carving of which in white oak, took Pietro Montana five years to complete, will be held in War Memorial Chapel on the campus of Fordham University beginning at noon tomorrow and extending through Easter week.

" Aaron Slick From Punkin Crick," the William Perlberg-George Seaton musical comedy version in Technicolor of the stage melodrama of the same name, has been scheduled to open at the Globe Theatre on Friday, April 18, it was announced yesterday by Paramount.

LONDON, April 10 -- Queen Elizabeth II went to Westminster Abbey today to perform a Maundy Thursday rite observed by her forebears since the twelfth century. She gave gifts of silver maundy money to fifty-two poor, elderly persons -- one old man and one old woman for each of her twenty-six years.

TOKYO, Friday, April 11 -- Although the Korean war continues to be a matter of scattered patrol clashes, the United Nations propaganda offensive is hitting a new high. Thirteen Allied radio transmitters are battering at Communist minds fourteen hours daily.

HAVANA, April 10 -- It pays to be President of Cuba, as a visit to La Chata, the fabulous property of Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, fifteen miles southeast of Havana, will prove to anyone fortunate enough to get special permission for a visit.
Daily mail collections from the 6,729 "drops" in Manhattan and the Bronx will be increased beginning Monday, it was announced yesterday by Vincent G. Burke, Deputy Postmaster General.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. April 10 -- Jim Monahan, right fielder, drove in three runs today as Rutgers' baseball team won its first game in five starts by beating Princeton, 6 -- 1. This was the Tigers' fourth straight loss.

MOBILE, Ala., April 10 -- Capt. Kurt Carlsen, whose unsuccessful struggle to save his ship, the Flying Enterprise, in North Atlantic gales last January thrilled the nation, left this port today in command of another freighter of the same name.

WHIPPANY, N. J., April 10 -- A surly crowd of 300 men waited outside Police Headquarters today hoping to see three men against whom charges had been brought in connection with a free-for-all fight last Monday at the Eden Mill of the Whippany Paper-Board Company.
TOKYO, Friday, April 11 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique, 1216, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Friday (4 P. M., Thursday, Eastern standard time):
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- During the week ended April 9, member bank reserves decreased $160,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 10 (AP) -- Avco Manufacturing Corporation has a backlog of defense work totaling approximately $300,000,000, Victor Emanuel, president and chairman, said today at the annual meeting.

The significance of Passover, commemorating the freedom of Jews from Egyptian bondage more than 3,000 years ago, and its symbolic meaning for those who seek to preserve their liberties today, was stressed in sermons yesterday morning in temples and synagogues of New York.

Universal sympathy is extended to victims of air disasters such as those at Elizabeth and the more recent one at Jamaica. Understandable is the outcry of people in those communities for closing of Newark, La Guardia and Idlewild airports. Such is a natural reaction after those holocausts.

Factory sales of the mass-market major appliances dropped sharply in February in comparison with February of 1951, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday. The decrease in five important appliances during the first two months of 1952, as against the first two months of last year, was even more marked.
Imports of rayon staple by this country are gaining, it was reported yesterday by The Textile Organon, statistical bulletin of the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- Judge Wilbert F. Crowley threw an important gambling conspiracy case out of court today and invited the state to go to higher courts for a clarification of the law.

New fashions out of West Germany, designed by Hans Gehringer and modeled chiefly by the striking Susanne Erichsen, "Miss Germany of 1950," were warmly received at an exclusive showing at the St. Moritz Hotel this week.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to give more than twenty Government agencies nearly a billion dollars to tide them over until July 1.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today proposing to remove from patronage rolls postmasters, customs collectors and United States marshals:

Overpopulation was defined as Japan's "No. 1 problem" yesterday by Dr. Kageyas W. Amano, a Japanese physician. He warned that the low standard of living resulting from the rising birth rate in Japan might make that country "increasingly vulnerable" to the Communists or militarists.

TRENTON, April 10 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee will have everything his own way in the Democratic preference primary in New Jersey next Tuesday, but he has yet to sell himself to the Democratic leaders who will control the thirty-two Jersey votes at the party's national convention at Chicago on July 21.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 10 -- Senator Robert A. Taft opened his Ohio Presidential primary campaign before 240 state Republican leaders here today with President Truman's seizure of the steel mills as a principal issue.
ROME, April 10 (UP) -- A Communist-inspired strike wave that began in March was spreading slowly through independent and anti-Communist unions of all Italy today.

Mendelssohn's "Elijah" was designed as a dramatic oratorio, and in the performance that he conducted at Carnegie Hall last night, Dimitri Mitropoulos took that description to heart. This was not a tame reading; it had pace and tension and impact. It was projected dramatically -- not only musically but also visually.

YONKERS, April 10 -- A Richmond, Queens, man who had lost a financial law suit against an automobile salesman drove to Delhi, N. Y., today, and, according to the police, kidnapped at pistol-point the witness in the case, motored back here tonight with him, then shot and wounded the witness and the salesman and killed himself.

Brig. Gen. Charles W. Christenberry, chief of the special services division of the Army Adjutant General's Office in Washington for the past year, has been named deputy chief of staff of the Eighth Army in Korea, he disclosed last night.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 10 -- Vietnam and Cambodia expect this year to export at least 500,000 tons of rice according to estimates based on recent surveys. If the most favorable circumstances prevail during the year, the export total might be increased to as high as 600,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Licenses will be issued for the shipment of about 6,700 bales of cotton a month to Hong Kong, British Crown Colony, up to July 31, the end of the crop year, the Office of International Trade of the United States Department of Commerce said today.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has told President Truman he wants to resign his position as Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Europe.

Evening-up operations before the holiday produced price irregularity in New York commodity futures markets yesterday. It was especially noticeable in rubber, for both the London and Singapore markets will extend the Easter holiday through Monday.
One fireman was fatally injured and three others seriously hurt yesterday when a Fire Department engine collided with a trailer truck at Horace Harding Boulevard and 108th Street, Corona, Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Truman today accepted the resignation of Archibald S. Alexander, Under Secretary of the Army, who will run as a Democratic candidate for Senator from New Jersey. He will oppose the present senior Senator from that State, H. Alexander Smith, Republican.

Andrew J. Kelly, a former deputy collector of internal revenue, was sentenced yesterday to six months in a Federal penitentiary and fined $1,000 by Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in Brooklyn Federal Court. Kelly had pleaded guilty on March 20 to an indictment charging him with having accepted a $1,000 bribe to settle an income tax case.
The first shipment of canned meat in a program scheduled to be the largest of its kind ever made between this country and Germany will arrive here around May 1.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- A House of Representatives subcommittee today sharply criticized America's allies, particularly Britain, and demanded that conditions be attached to future United States aid to make sure they did "what is necessary to strengthen themselves."

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Bills were introduced in the House of Representatives and in the Senate today to provide up to sixty days of free hospitalization a year for everyone eligible for insurance benefits under the Social Security program.

All major security and commodity markets in this country will be closed today, but the principal livestock markets will remain open. United States Exchanges will observe their usual Saturday and Monday schedules, but markets in Toronto, Montreal, London and Singapore will be closed on Easter Monday, taking a four-day weekend.

Exports of automobile parts and related products from the United States to Brazil have dropped sharply in recent months and some losses in other markets are developing, members of the Overseas Automotive Club heard yesterday at the Shelton Hotel.

TOMORROW is the big day. Although stream conditions are far from satisfactory, thousands of urbanites will be heading for the Catskills this afternoon to be certain of places on their favorite streams for the opening of the trout season at daybreak.

PARIS, April 10 -- The British Government has decided to extend a precise and blanket guarantee to the six nations of the proposed European Defense Community, promising them automatic military assistance in the event they are subjected to armed attack.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The Government today issued new ceiling regulation for bakery products that it said would probably mean a "slight" increase in average retail prices for bread, pies, cake and pastries. It may also mean some reductions, but officials did not specify in which items.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- For the first time since the outbreak of the Korean war, this country's taxpayers are to get monthly reports on the production of jet planes, tanks and other military items.

After a brief ceremony at the New York Regional Blood Center, the city's 90,000 Boy Scouts started a door-to-door blood pledge drive yesterday to bolster the bank's supply. The boys will distribute cards in the five boroughs as part of a campaign conducted on a nationwide basis.

ALBANY, April 10 -- The State Thruway Authority will have the power to control the erection of billboards or other advertising devices along the 535-mile route of the cross-state expressway under legislation approved today by Governor Dewey.

The organization of the non-white communities in South Africa for a general movement of civil disobedience indicates the swelling of a tide against the Government of Prime Minister Malan. This development should have been expected when the Government not only embarked on its proclaimed policy of apartheid (segregation) but also asserted its readiness to defy the findings of the Supreme Court and the clear implications of the Constitution.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., April 10 (AP) -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands arrived here today at 6:14 P. M. for a restful Easter vacation. She landed in President Truman's private plane, The Independence, having left New York this morning and having visited Knoxville, key city of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

The house flag of the Hamburg-American Line, once flown by the liners New York, Deutschland, Hansa and Hamburg, and not seen in local waters on a passenger liner since the days before World War II, fluttered yesterday from the after mast of the Home Lines vessel Italia.
CHICAGO, April 10 -- Grain futures had an irregular trend on the Board of Trade today, showing considerable firmness early, but reacting sharply from the tops.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Dudley Haskell have returned to 791 Park Avenue after a visit of several weeks with Mrs. Haskell's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. James Abercrombie de Peyster, in Palm Beach, Fla.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, in a letter made public today, declined to state his views on President Truman's civil rights program and related issues.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 10 -- Chinese Reds fighting in Korea are being supplied with great quantities of arms and machinery from the Skoda works of Czechoslovakia that are regularly shipped via Polish Baltic ports, information received here through certain diplomatic channels reveals.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Production of oranges and tangerines for the 1951-52 season was reported by the Department of Agriculture today at 122,900,000 boxes. This compares with 122,900,000 estimated a month ago, 121,610,000 last season and 102,986,000 for the ten-year average.

Members of the Smith College Club of New York have taken over the loge of the Roxy Theatre for the preview of the motion picture, "Belles On Their Toes," on the night of April 22 to augment the club's scholarship fund.

The $500,000,000 Ford Foundation, established with funds of the late Henry Ford and the late Edsel B. Ford, made thirty-seven grants totaling $22,331,736 last year. This was announced yesterday by Paul G. Hoffman, foundation president.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Following is an unofficial translation of the text of a Soviet note handed to the United States Embassy in Moscow yesterday by Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky:
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- By the margin of three unearned runs, the Dodgers tonight defeated the Senators, 4 -- 3, before 21,459 fans at Griffith Stadium.

What would have been a day of great rejoicing for a Polish couple, displaced persons, turned out to be one of sadness yesterday shortly after their arrival by air from Frankfurt, Germany. One of heir 4-month-old twins was fatally stricken and the other seriously affected by a rare illness, between Gander, Newfoundland, and the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on the last leg of their 3,000-mile journey to the United States.
WEST POINT, N. Y., April 10 -- The one-hit pitching of a couple of sophomores enabled Manhattan to shut out Army, 3 -- 0, in an eight-inning game at Doubleday Field today.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 -- Counsel for fifteen California Communist party functionaries on trial in United States District Court, moved unsuccessfully today for a mistrial and dismissal of their case on the ground that it was based on "entrapment."

A proposed local law to permit any city employe receiving less than $7,500 a year to hold an outside job was filed yesterday with the clerk of the City Council by Councilman Charles E. Keegan, Bronx Democrat.

LONDON, April 1 -- The publication of a stout volume of letters, memoranda and household accounts of a thousand years of Greek and Roman rule in Egypt has been proclaimed "of unique interest" by classical historians here.

LIMA, Peru, April 10 (AP) -- Most of the army reportedly remained loyal to the military regime. Its forces gathered strength at the El Alto airport, on a plateau 2,000 feet above La Paz, and launched a night attack under bright moonlight on the rebels in the capital. The army also held Miraflores barracks, denying the rebels stocks of guns and ammunition.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 10 (AP) -- Hill Gail, the Calumet Farm speedster who figures heavily in the Kentucky Derby picture, headed for home with an all-out drive today to win the $10,000 added Phoenix Handicap, opening day feature at Keeneland.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 10 (AP) -- Sgt. Curt Simmons, trim and tanned, bade good-bye to the Army today and moved quickly to resume his pitching career with the Philaephia Phillies.
I read with interest the letter in your issue of April 2 from Nathaniel Kleitman entitled "To Make Katyn Possible."

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, April 11 (AP) -- United States Air Force officers say that Communist air power is slowly outdistancing the Allies in the Korean war, and they suspect that former German Nazi jet pilots are helping to train the Reds.

Smoked hams and turkeys, traditional fare for Easter Sunday menus, are in abundant supply and lower in price. Cheaper, too, are loin pork roast and loin pork chops, but leg of lamb, also a popular choice for the festive table, is more costly, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee is getting on sensitive ground when it advocates a new "get tough" program on foreign aid. A preliminary report, already discussed with the press, suggests a general investigation of British influence on American foreign policy and the institution of "clear and precise conditions" before any foreign aid is given.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 (AP) -- Bing Crosby, singer, testified as a Government witness today in the mail fraud trial of Henry von Morpurgo.

The award of the Florina Lasker Fellowship for study leading to a doctoral degree at the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, to Mrs. Elliot Turner Studt was announced yesterday by the school's faculty doctoral committee.

California, which supplies about 75 per cent of the avocados sold in this country, is harvesting the biggest crop on record. By the time the season ends in June, growers in that state expect to have shipped to market almost 3,000,000 crates, each containing thirteen pounds of the subtropical fruit.

District Attorney Miles F. McDonald reported "progress" yesterday in the search for the killer of Arnold L. Schuster, but characterized as "grossly exaggerated" stories that the arrest of the man was imminent.
TOKYO, Friday, April 11 -- United Nations and Communist truce negotiators met for only ninety seconds today -- the shortest session since the conferences on an armistice in Korea began.
The news from the Korean truce negotiations yesterday indicated quite plainly that the next move is up to Moscow.

The first section of thirty-five dwellings was opened yesterday by Francis Abbruzzeso, builder, in his Orchard Farms colony at Elwood Road and Jericho Turnpike in Huntington, L. I. Plans call for 100 more of the Cape Cod bungalow styled dwellings priced at $10,900. Sales are being handled by Main Realty of Flushing.
EDMONTON, April 10 (AP) -- Export of Alberta natural gas from the Peace River area was approved early today by the legislature.

Contemporary Danish and German designs, as well as traditional ones from England, France and this country, will be included in a collection of 200 sterling and plated silver tea services that will be exhibited at Altman's on Monday.

BUENOS AIRES, April 10 -- Reports from La Paz said tonight that the Bolivian Army, led by its Chief of Staff, Gen. Humberto Torres Ortiz, appeared to be gradually overcoming the revolt in Bolivia. There were reports that the two principal leaders, Brig. Gen. Antonio Seleme, former Minister of the Interior, and Hernan Siles Zuazo, a leader of the Movimiento Nacionalista Revolucionario (M. N. R.), or National Revolutionary party, already had left Bolivian territory.
Mayor Impellitteri left at 5:38 P. M. yesterday aboard an Eastern Air Lines Constellation plane from La Guardia Airport, Queens, for Miami, Fla., to spend two weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, said today a "mistake" in estimating housing needs at the South Carolina hydrogen bomb plant had cost the Government $226,000 and the end was not in sight.

Harold Riegelman, who wants New Yorkers to drink Hudson River water, says in THE TIMES of March 26 that "Poughkeepsie's excellent supply is 100 per cent filtered and treated Hudson, and has been for more than seventy years."

The "Chronoscope," which is presented at 11 o'clock on Monday, Wednesday and Friday nights over C. B. S. television is a program in a class by itself. Its premise is open to question; its execution, frequently exasperating, and its commercials, almost unbelievable.

Steel mills over the nation set a new record in March by turning out 9,383,000 net tons, the largest total ever produced in one month. Output in the first quarter of this year also set a record, aggregating 27,176,327 tons.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture does not plan to restrict bone meal imports as a means of halting an outbreak of anthrax among American livestock.
Statistics of the steel industry and one of the largest banks in the country, with respect to steel profits in 1951, differ sharply from those presented Tuesday night by President Truman.

Valentin Gonzalez, known as El Campesino, the Communist general of the Spanish Civil War, has a book about his experiences scheduled for publication next Friday by Putnam. "El Campesino: Life and Death in Soviet Russia," written in conjunction with Julian Gorkin and translated by Ilsa Barea, describes incidents of the Civil War in which Russia and the Communists had parts as well as Gonzalez' experiences in Russia after the war.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 10 -- A revolt has broken out in the Republican party in Connecticut against the leadership of Gov. John Lodge and Clarence F. Baldwin, the state chairman.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 10 -- Sarah Lawrence College denied today the Westchester County American Legion's charge of "academic betrayal" for retaining Joseph Barnes on its faculty. At his office in New York, Mr. Barnes denied that he was or ever had been "a Russian espionage agent."

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A series of secret messages allegedly sent from the Chinese Embassy here to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on Formosa outlining plans to influence American foreign policy regarding the Chinese Nationalist Government was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon.
