ALBANY, April 10 -- A new route for the Thruway through Rockland County, the third proposed by state officials after earlier suggestions had met with considerable local opposition, was made public today by Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the State Thruway Authority.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Truman admitted today there was a friendly dispute within his family about his ability as a World War I artillery commander.

Impelled partly by a sincere desire for economy but partly by politics in an election year, the House has sliced almost $5 billions from the $51 billion Defense Department budget for fiscal 1952-53. A combination of Republicans and Southern Democrats has the dubious honor of having added the finishing touches to this cut, which fortunately the Senate must now review.

The division of camping of the Children's Welfare Federation, which caters each year to the needs of some 80,000 youngsters who go to 184 camps operated by voluntary organizations, has been absorbed by the Welfare and Health Council of New York City, it was announced yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- Tunisian nationalists lost today their attempt to win a hearing before the United Nations Security Council.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 -- A fictionalized treatment of intelligence sleuthing by a continental army officer that exposed the treason of Major Benedict Arnold will be dramatized by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "Betrayal on the Hudson"

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended April 5, 1952, totaled 707,142 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 18,281 cars, or 2.5 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 32,381 cars, or 4.4 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 7,093 cars, or 1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Irving Elman has a genius for cliches. His travelogue through life, "The Brass Ring," which opened at the Lyceum last evening, is composed of odds and ends that have been cluttering the cupboards for years, and represents a triumph of hack work in playwriting.

BONN, Germany, April 10 -- The Soviet note delivered last night in Moscow has caught the Federal Republic with most of its Ministers on vacation and the Bundestag Deputies scattered throughout Germany.

The Easter mood continued to brighten the city yesterday, abetted by the closing of school for the spring holidays and by the presence of warm springlike weather that filled parks and playgrounds with galloping children.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- New-bold Morris told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that his inquiry into corruption in Government had developed no evidence that would be useful to the subcommittee in its investigation of the Department of Justice because he was dismissed before he got his investigation "off the ground."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- A ticket of candidates for Democratic National Convention delegates pledged nominally to State Attorney General Edmund G. (Pat) Brown for the Presidential nomination qualified today for the California primary ballot of June 3, insuring a two-way fight, with Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee as the rival candidate.

The sacrifice of the crucified Christ on Calvary will be commemorated in prayer and meditation today as Roman Catholics and Protestants solemnly observe the traditional Three Hours Devotion of Good Friday.

Martha from Mexico, Janneke of the Netherlands and Martin from the Union of South Africa, whose fathers are on the staff of the United Nations, sold the first ticket yesterday for the first International Children's Portrait Exhibition that opens at the Grand Central Art Galleries on April 22.

Consolidated net income of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in 1951 was the highest in the thirty-one year history of the world-wide manufacturing and communications concern. Totaling $17,992,314, after expenses and taxes, earnings were equal to $2.60 a share on the outstanding capital stock, compared with a consolidated net of $15,557,339, or $2.27, in the preceding year.
TULSA, Okla., April 10 -- Larry Jansen is ready to open the season for the Giants at the Polo Grounds next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Dr. Gunnar Gunderson of La Crosse, Wis., the American Medical Association trustee who refused in December to serve on the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, appeared before the commission today as a private physician speaking for group medical practice.
DETROIT, April 10 -- The Army Ordnance Corps said today that it was "exploring" the possibility of returning the Government-owned Detroit Tank Arsenal to private operation.

BECAUSE of the rude and unmannerly interference of a certain Bobby Thomson, the planned meeting between the New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers will take place at the Stadium today, just six months and one week later than originally designed. Before Thomson butchered the script, the plot artfully contrived to have Bombers and Brooks clash at the Stadium in the first game of the world series.

Customs collections at the Port of New York reached a high for this year in March but were $5,500,000 less than those recorded in the corresponding month last year despite a noticeable increase in activity at the port.

Combat Boots of the Putnam Stable accounted for a surprise victory in the Chance Play Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Accorded only a middling chance in the field of nine, the 4-year-old son of Our Boots finished strong under a fine ride by Hedley Woodhouse to beat William Ewing's Auditing by a neck.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 10 -- The fifty guests who will partake of a bowl of stew, after the "atomic bombing" of their homes in an air-raid drill in Nassau County on April 25, had better take along their own box lunches.

A large number of members -- possibly several hundred -- of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals have resigned recently in protest against the new Metcalf-Hatch Act, which requires the agency and other publicly aided pounds to turn over stray dogs and cats for approved medical research projects.

An increase in the net production of crude oil and a moderate strengthening in sales prices of fuel oil products sold in certain areas enabled the Tide Water Associated Oil Company to increase its consolidated net income last year to $37,060,606 from $33,364,115 earned in 1950.

A good case for the practicability of trade shows is made in a survey just completed by Time Magazine on the type of person attending such expositions. Interviewed were 3,360 visitors to some of the leading shows.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 10 -- Prof. Morris S. Kharasch of the University of Chicago, whose chemical research is credited with having helped to increase the nation's grain and cotton supplies, has been chosen to receive the 1952 Theodore William Richards Medal of the American Chemical Society's Northeastern Section.

Burglars broke into four rooms of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, Fifth Ave. and Fifty-ninth Street, yesterday and from one room took a mink coat and jewelry valued at $5,600. The police said nothing was stolen from the other rooms.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 10 (UP) -- United States military equipment is pouring into Yugoslavia in a steady stream to bolster the southern flank of Western Europe, Brig. Gen. John Harmony, chief of the United States military aid mission, announced today.
NORFOLK, Va., April 10 -- Admiral Lynde D. McCormick of the United States Navy opened the headquarters here today of what is to become the greatest international naval force in history.

From advertising, there is one picture that is familiar to everyone, and very warming it continues to be. It is of the lady of the house, standing in her kitchen and with a pride that is the next thing to gloating, surveying her latest acquisition. Sometimes it is a new icebox, sometimes a new stove.

CHATEAUROUX, France, April 10 (AP) -- A thousand United States Air Force personnel are living in tents instead of barracks in this unfinished base here because of a delayed decision over who pays for what.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 2 points lower to 12 points net higher in a fairly active turnover.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 10 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami defeated Gustavo Palafox, the Mexican champion, in a quarter-final match today, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3. Palafox was the last of his countrymen to fall in the Good Neighbor tennis tourney.
Five shows by as many highly diverse artists are among the recently opened exhibitions in New York galleries.
PARIS, April 10 -- In view of the deficit in French trade, the Marshall Plan Council ruled today that France was justified in restoring the licensing of imports previously freed.

PARIS, April 10 -- Jean Letourneau, French Minister for the Indo-China States, who recently assumed additionally the duties of French High Commissioner to Indo-China, tonight declared that the French would defend that country until native troops could take their place.

SPRINGFIELD, April 10 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, who has been prominently mentioned as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, has decided to make known his political views "probably late next week," William I. Flanagan, the Governor's press secretary, said today.

Who will teach our President and many people in the Government the elementary principles of an individualistic competitive economy? This is the question which comes to my mind in reading Mr. Truman's speech on the federal seizure of the steel industry. Mr. Truman may not know economics, but his advisers should; after all, that is what they are being paid for. Mr. Truman made the following statements in his speech:

PASSAIC, N. J., April 10 -- Harold E. Stassen said here tonight in his campaign tour of New Jersey that he favored a "courageous" foreign policy of the kind "successfully carried out by Theodore Roosevelt."
BOSTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Braves today clinched the intracity title with a 5-4 victory over the Red Sox in an exhibition game at Braves Field.

A 34-year-old engineer was charged with grand larceny last night after he had admitted to an assistant district attorney, according to the District Attorney's office, that he had misappropriated most of $100,000 turned over to him last month by a South American to finance a business deal.

The dean raised his eyebrows. He asked the pleasant, sandy-haired young man across the desk to repeat his excuse for having cut a 10 o'clock American Lit class. The young man answered, "I had to help crew a dead-head milk train back upstate."

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Bartholomew A. Brickley, trustee of the International Hydroelectric System (I. H. E. S.), asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to sell two New York State properties at prices which have been bid for them.

TRENTON, April 10 -- Backers of Senator Robert A. Taft in next Tuesday's primary election continued to gain strength today as the opposing supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower appeared handicapped by lack of campaign funds.

DETRIOT, April 10 (UP) -- Jake La Motta, who only a month ago was talking about retirement, was told to-day he could have a shot at the light-heavyweight championship if Ray Robinson passes up the chance.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast a winter wheat crop this year of 946,845,000 bushels the third biggest in history.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 10 (AP) -- Willie Mays, Giants' outfielder will have to report for induction into the armed forces on May 17 as ordered, Selective Service officials said today.

TORONTO, April 10 (Canadian Press) -- The high position of the Canadian dollar is cutting into the price that Canadian companies get for their newsprint, D. W. Ambridge, president of Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., said today at the company's annual meeting.

TOKYO, April 10 -- The Japanese Government decided today to make minor modifications in its proposed "anti-subversive activities act" to head off a concerted strike of trade unions scheduled to begin Saturday.

New York State has under consideration borrowing $65,000,000 in the public market on an issue of state housing bonds, according to reports in underwriting circles yesterday. It is expected that the big issue will come to market in the near future.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and the First Boston Corporation will offer to investors today $25,000,000 of new 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the Consumers Power Company, Michigan utility, due in 1987.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The Navy said today no disciplinary action would be taken against an admiral accused of attempting to force civilian employes at the Hingham, Mass., naval ammunition depot to give up some of their Constitutional rights.

The Government completed its case yesterday in the manslaughter trial of Capt. Franklin B. Weaver. The 31-year-old former master of the Isbrandtsen cargo vessel Flying Trader is accused of having caused the death of 24-year-old William M. Harvey, a Negro messman, aboard the ship in the Eastern pacific last Oct. 25.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Truman declared categorically today that he would not accept a draft to be the Democratic Presidential nominee by the party's national convention.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association ratings, out today, show that the N. B. A. takes a dim view of Rocky Graziano's chances against Ray Robinson Wednesday night.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 10 (AP) -- Three swimmers bettered national A. A. U. senior women's indoor records in the opening of the 1952 national indoor swimming and diving competition today.

American Airlines issued figures yesterday based on a year-long study intended to show that the use of air freight for the delivery of ethical drugs cuts over-all distribution costs in half. It was said such costs by surface carrier and warehousing amount to 79 per cent of the final price of the products studied.

Gary Anderson, who will be 3 years old next Thursday, fell from a fifth-floor kitchen window at his home, 666 Ninth Avenue, near Forty-sixth Street, to a rear courtyard yesterday shortly before 11 A. M. and survived. He suffered fractures of the left leg and possible internal injuries.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 12 -- A flier in a C-46 transport was tossed out of his plane in turbulent weather over Korea recently -- and then was tossed safely back again through the same door when the plane took a heavy lurch toward him. Air Force Headquarters here related yesterday.
MONTREAL, April 11 (AP) -- The night of the time-clock confusion and the Detroit Red Wings' 3 -- 1 victory over he Montreal Canadiens became part and parcel of Stanley Cup hockey history today.

HONG KONG, April 11 -- The perennial scourge of spring famine has struck again in various parts of rural China, according to domestic Chinese Communist reports. In the famine-stricken areas hungry peasants are begging for food, living on shrubs, roots and grain-stalks, and in many cases facing inevitable death by starvation.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers:

Helen Keller will leave by plane tomorrow from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on a three-month tour of the Near East under the auspices of the American Foundation for Overseas Blind, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -President Truman told Democratic officials and party workers today that the 1952 Presidential election would be, so far as the party was concerned, a repetition of the 1949 election, but he was an important "if."
Betty Hutton, the blonde and energetic singing star of motion pictures, will head the new vaudeville show opening this afternoon at 2:40 at the R. K. O. Palace.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Air Force Headquarters said today that it would study the situation in which flight crew members had refused to fly but added that the immediate Randolph Air Force Base "sit-down" would be handled by local commanders.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 12 -The United Nations Command again served notice on the Communists today that no concessions would be made to enemy demands for inclusion of the Soviet Union as one of the "neutral" powers to police an armistice in Korea or for unlimited airfield construction north of the Thirty-eighth Parallel during the cease-fire.

Three new books on cookery, each treating a different aspect of the art, are subject for discussion today. These are not cook books of the basic type essential to every well-run kitchen. But they may be valuable supplements to standard works for those who are particularly interested in the special subjects with which these three books deal.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Glenn C. Forrester of Niagara Falls received United States Patent No. 2,591,691 this week for an "intoximeter," or method by which the police can determine the alcoholic content of a person's breath.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- The United States Court of Appeals has blocked the start next Monday of a new transcontinental air service across the southern United States.

A new "encyclopedia of places" will soon be presented to the public after five years of research, writing and editorial work and several months of production. It is he "Columbia Lippincott Gazetteer of the World," and it will be issued by Columbia University Press on April 28.

The Military Air Transport Service announced yesterday that by the end of the month the jet fighter planes produced in this country for the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Europe would be ferried abroad under their own power.
In your editorial "Nationalism in Africa" you take to task "Western-educated fanatics" for "their extreme nationalism."

Lieut. Col. Francis C. Kincannon of Eastern Air Procurement District, Martin S. Davis, Byron A. Marshall, Sanford Sandelman, Joseph Schneider, Robert E. Massa and Pasquale Venezia, in Equitable Life Assurance Society's Fordham Hill Apartments at University Heights.

The Children's Zoo, a small kraal of familiar and pettable animals in the midst of the Bronx Zoo's vast reaches of lion, tiger, crocodile and kudu land, will reopen for its twelfth season at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., April 11 (AP) -- Henry Wittenberg, National Amateur Athletic Union 191-pound wrestling champion, won his opening match tonight in district cryouts for the United States' Olympic team.

A State Supreme Court decision bearing on picketing rights of labor unions, handed down by Justice Henry Clay Greenberg, has apparently opened the way for some important tests if, as seems likely, the case is carried to the Supreme Court. The ruling was made in a suit brought by Goodwins Department Store to enjoin an A. F. L. retail clerks union from picketing its retail store on Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

When, in the eighth inning, Rocky Bridges singled into a double-play, there was no doubt about it. Baseball was back and so were the Dodgers. It was, of course, unofficial, as the Brooks and Yankees launched their week-end exhibition series yesterday at the Stadium.
TOKYO, April 11 (AP) -- Japanese candy and cookie making no longer is sweet business. It has gone sour because of American competition.
LA PAZ, April 11 (AP) -- The battle for La Paz raged through two nights under bright moonlight. Heavy cannon fire destroyed many homes in the residential and workers districts around the city.

TRENTON, April 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said here today that the prospective return of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower had encouraged his supporters fighting out a close race with Senator Robert A. Taft in the New Jersey preferential primary on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -Three Minnesota institutions, including the state university, have received Government contracts for high altitude cosmic ray research, the Navy said today.

The traditional celebration of Easter will begin in the early morning hours tomorrow and continue all day among Protestants and Roman Catholics. But tomorrow will be Palm Sunday for the Eastern Orthodox churches, which adhere to a decision of the initial ecumenical council of the Christian Church in Nicaea in 325 A. D.

LOUISVILLE. Ky., April 11 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, opening his attack on the Administration's handling of foreign policy, declared tonight that it had been conducting "rear guard actions" against communism instead of seizing the initiative.
Following are excerpts from newspaper editorials commenting on the resignation of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as Supreme Commander, Allied Powers in Europe:
The following is a round-up of several new items that may be of use around the house:

SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill., April 11 -- Thirty-three Air Force officers who had asked to be suspended from flying duty were ordered back to combat training after a hearing, the Air Force announced today.

MANILA, Saturday, April 12 -- William Pomeroy, former United States Air Force enlisted man from Rochester, N. Y., who turned Communist, has been captured by Philippine armed forces in the mountain wilderness of East Central Luzon, Army headquarters confirmed today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11 -- Thirteen Arab and Asian countries announced today that they were considering calling for a special session of the United Nations General Assembly to take up the Tunisian case.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- In the White House rose garden, three war heroes, hailed as examples of the "fiber of the American people," relived thier exploits in Korea as President Truman presented Medals of Honor to them.

LONDON, April 11 -- Now that President Truman has agreed to relieve General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as Supreme Commander of the Atlantic Powers in Europe June 1, the chief concern here as in most of Western Europe is who will be chosen to complete the task of making the democracies secure against Communist aggression.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 11 -- A publisher-Congressman, Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican of Ohio, charged here tonight that "the United States Government itself is the largest and most pernicious lobby in Washington, or anywhere else in the world for that matter."
R. H. Whidden, general sales manager of the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company since 1948, has been elected a vice president, according to an announcement yesterday by Craig Sheaffer, president.
GREAT LAKES, Ill., April 11 (AP) -- A new type of mine-sweeper, representing the Navy's first attempt to build a completely non-magnetic hull, will be launched at Manitowoc, Wis., on April 17.
Losses paid by capital stock fire insurance companies during 1951 were more than 30 per cent greater than for 1950, according to the 1952 fire index of The Spectator.
LONDON, April 11 -- Queen Elizabeth II has retained the royal family name of Windsor for herself and her descendants, it was announced tonight.

ATHENS, April 11 -- Premier Nicholas Plastiras issued a statement from his sickbed today expressing disapproval of any cancellation of permanent honorary distinctions and prerogatives of Field Marshal Alexander Papagos.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 11 (AP) -- The Chicago Town Club A team bettered the world, American and meet 400-yard free-style relay records with a time of 4 minutes 5.3 seconds in the National Senior Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor swimming and diving championships today.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -The United States will begin negotiations with Venezuela next Friday to determine whether to reduce import duties on Venezuelan oil and petroleum products, iron ore and iron.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Elia Kazan, Broadway and Hollywood director, swore before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities yesterday that he and Clifford Odets, the playwright, were former members of the Communist party, according to testimony made public by the group today.

A self-contained community of 1,200 houses priced at $11,975 is planned for a tract of 240 acres in Massapequa Park, L. I., where a furnished model was opened yesterday at Sunrise Highway and Park Boulevard. Known as Post City, the development is sponsored by the Post Acres Corporation, of which Monte Ageloff and Edward Adeikis are the principals.
Two new films arrive in town this morning for openings at first-run theatres.

The fall line of men's suits manufactured by H. Daroff * Sons, Inc., Philadelphia, producer of Botany Brand 500 and Worsted-Tex clothing, has been priced below the levels of fall, 1951, and spring, 1952, it was announced last night.

A new era of aggressive salesmanship is nearly upon us, if the planning of retail merchants is realized. Perked up by better-than-expected Easter sales, stores are prepared, to give consumers a promotional workout from now until the summer heat waves arrive.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Army found itself unable today to explain precisely what General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's request for "inactive status" would mean.
MOSCOW, April 11 (AP) -- Work is to begin this month on what is claimed to be the longest high tension electric cable lines in the world.

" AT the Devil's Booth,"* by Erwin Lessner, is a tremendous historical novel of modern Europe, a personal testament to the valor of man, who loses so many of his battles and yet manages to survive, battered, beaten, yet somehow undefeated, in the hell of Hitler and the high water of Stalin's totalitarian tide. To read it, I had to pass up three or four outstanding new books about the Civil War.
SEATTLE, April 11 (UP) -- The brothers Perricone pointed out today that they "don't want any favors." The world's only male quadruplets just want to be together when shipped overseas to Korea.

BONN, Germany, April 11 -- The emphasis on free all-German elections under the aegis of the four occupation powers is the most alluring and potentially dangerous point in the second Soviet note bidding for Germany's reunification.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -Wage contract differences that led to Government seizure of the steel industry this week appeared as far from settlement tonight as they did three days ago.

PARIS, April 12 -- (Saturday) (Reuters) -- Premier Antoine Pinay early today won support from the upper house for his "save the franc" budget designed to rescue France from the threat of economic disaster.

An errant March wind that had overstayed its visit set off a chain of events that resulted yesterday in the holding of two women in $2,000 bail each for grand jury action on charges of having stolen a wallet containing $250 from a helpful stranger.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 11 -- Iran, now that her New Year crisis is over, is facing the issue of digging into her gold reserve to keep going unless she can borrow from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development on oil in storage at Abadan.

General Eisenhower has now ended the period of speculation as to his resignation and his return to the United States. We believe that he has acted wisely, with dignity and in the best interests of his country.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -Three Cincinnati manufacturers of animal feeds are charged by the Federal Trade Commission with discriminating in price among their retail dealers.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -Farm property values jumped 125 per cent from 1940 to 1950 to hit a record $76,000,000,000 in the 1950 census of agriculture, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today.

A Brooklyn waterfront habitue is being sought as the original purchaser of the stolen .38-caliber revolver used to kill Arnold L. Schuster, the 24-year-old salesman who brought about the arrest of William Sutton, the bank robber.

The need for "clear thinking and courageous action" at a time when too many individuals are governed by their prejudices and anxieties was emphasized yesterday in a special Easter message by the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, president of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America.

LAUREL, Md., April 11 (AP) -- Maryland's only spring s. takes in which 3-year-olds can try more than sprinting, the $20,000 added Chesapeake, will match nine Kentucky Derby eligibles and four other sophomores at Laurel tomorrow.
Editorials can sometimes become pretty one-sided and unreliable.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Two officials of the Chinese Embassy here denied today that they had signed embassy cablegrams to the Chinese Nationalist Capital at Tapei, Formosa, outlining plans to influence American foreign policy regarding the Chinese Nationalist Government.

NEW DELHI, India, April 11 -- In expectation of the Japanese peace treaty's coming into force in the near future the Indian Government is briskly getting through the necessary formalities for establishing direct relations with an independent Japan.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, who became Acting Mayor early last night when Mayor Impellitteri left the city for a two-week Florida vacation, spent yesterday studying the proposed 1952-53 budget of $1,469,265,101 now in the hands of the Board of Estimate.

BUENOS AIRES, April 11 -- "This is the victory of the Bolivian people, a touching victory of the masses for their freedom despite the conspiracy of vested interests and forces," said Dr. Victor Paz Estenssoro, exiled National Revolutionary party leader this afternoon where he received the news of the apparent victory of his forces after more than forty hours of a communications blackout in La Paz.

William M. Harvey, 24-year-old messman who was shot to death last Oct. 25 aboard the Isbrandtsen freighter Flying Arrow, was pictured as a malingerer as the defense of the ship's master opened yesterday in Federal Court. The skipper, Franklin B. Weaver, 31, is on trial in Federal Court for manslaughter before Judge Edward Weinfeld and a jury.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it was planning a new billion dollar plant to produce uranium-235, a key atomic energy substance. Sites in the Ohio River Valley were being studied, it said.

Col. William J. Cullen has sold his home at 3 Douglas Place, overlooking Larchmont Harbor in Larchmont, N. T., to Jack Stern through the Thomas B. Sutton Corporation, broker. The dwelling, of stone construction, contains eight rooms and stands on a half-acre plot.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 11 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio swept four more district conventions in Kentucky today, assuring him at least fifteen of the state's twenty delegates votes for the Republican nomination for President.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 11 -- Rabbi Benjamin Schultz, a central figure in varied disputes, said today he was "wholeheartedly" assisting in the fight against "communism" at Sarah Lawrence College here and in the near-by Scarsdale public schools.

The white radiance of 10,000 Easter lily blossoms filled the Rockefeller Center promenade yesterday and, with the fall of dusk, crosses of lighted windows towered above Wall Street as the city entered the Easter week-end.

What people attain in the future will depend upon how effectively they use their present freedom, declared Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein in his Passover sermon yesterday at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street.

St. Regis Paper Company has at least an undivided half interest in oil and mineral rights on 277,000 acres in southern Alabama and the Florida panhandle, Roy K. Ferguson, president and chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday. Geologists have been consulted and a number of oil companies are discussing plans for development.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 11 -Three of the nation's a leading educators will take part in a conference at Rutgers University on May 8 when Dr. Lewis Webster Jones will be inaugurated as the State University's fifteenth president.
CINCINNATI, April 11 (AP) -- "Women are more honest than men, and they can sell things better than men," says Phil Meyers.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 -- Pierre Monteux is receiving great ovations as he conducts the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra in his farewell series of concerts after seventeen seasons as its leader.
LONDON, April 11 (Reuters) -- Arsenal stayed at the top rung in English soccer today, drawing with Blackpool, 0 -- 0, but lost its star center half, Welsh international, Ray Daniel, through injury.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, employing characteristically vigorous language, has pledged his determination to wage an intensive, ceaseless campaign for the Presidency if he is nominated by the Republicans.

A carelessly playful lion, one of ten weighing 450 pounds each, failed to look before he leaped at the circus in Madison Square Garden last night, knocking down his trainer instead of jumping over his head and brought two following lions down on top of the trainer and himself.

A shopping center, the first planned there since 1929, will be erected soon by the Montauk Beach Company on Montauk Highway (Route 27) in Montauk, L. I., according to John A. Craft, general manager of the company.

RANDOLPH AIR FORCE BASE, Tex., April 11 (AP) -- An Air Force Reserve pilot with five children said tonight he had been charged with disobedience for refusing to fly because it made his wife "a nervous wreck."

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The White House announced today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would be relieved on June 1 as Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Europe, thus opening the way for his active participation in the campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Saturday, April 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that he would resign his Army commission only if he was nominated by the Republican party for President at its convention next July.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 11 -- The National Revolutionary party overthrew the military government of Bolivia today after three days of bloody fighting.

A bill passed by the Legislature and just signed by Governor Dewey provides for billboard regulation on the 500-mile Thruway, rather than billboard prohibition, so a heavy responsibility now rests upon the State Thruway Authority. Probably no single use of the Authority's powers will be watched so critically as how the Authority exercises its discretion on billboards.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 11 -- Screen rights to "Reader, I Married Her," a novel written by Ann Green, have been purchased by Howard Welsch, independent producer and a co-owner of Fidelity Pictures.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- A German immigrant who found America a land of opportunity paid a debt of appreciation today to his adopted country. The payment was in the form of a $5,000 check, which was presented to the Treasury of the United States by the trust department of the First National Bank here.

Irving Gelfand, 53 years old, proprietor of a liquor store at 142 Havemeyer Street in the Willamsburg section of Brooklyn, lost his money and his pants for a brief time yesterday to two men, armed with pistols, who held up the store. They took $380 from his cash register and his pockets, then tied him up in the rear of the store.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended April 8, to 111.7 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 0.8 per cent below the latest available comprehensive index (February, 1952) and 2.9 per cent below the level in effect at the time of the General Ceiling Price Regulation (January, 1951).
TOKYO, Saturday, April 12 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1217, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Saturday (4 P. M., Friday, Eastern standard time):

An investing client of Barney Bernstein, attorney, bought the dwelling at 22 East Ninety-fifth Street from Fred H. Hill, operator, who bought it recently from Anna C. Marshall. The house is assessed at $37,000 and will be altered into two duplex apartments and a doctor's office. The Morgenthau-Seixas Company was the broker.

A policeman, who was making a routine inspection of a Queens supermarket last night walked into a trap set by armed robbers who were holding up the store manager and clerk, was relieved of his service revolver and bound up with the other victims. The robbers took between $600 and $900.

HOUSTON, April 11 (UP) -- Betsy Rawls of Austin, national women's open champion, ignored a misty drizzle and soggy greens today to card a record-breaking 69 in the opening round of the Houston leg of the cross-country Weathervane golf tournament.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 -Directors of the Matson Navigation Company today elected two vice presidents and a treasurer.
A decorating accessory that seems never to have gone out of style is the box, now available in new versions in stores here.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -The Secretary of the Interior, Oscar L. Chapman, announced today suspension from duty and pay of two employes of the Portland, (Ore.) area office of the Indian Bureau on charges arising from the sale last year of some Indian timber lands at Gold Beach, Ore.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Following are the text of letters sent by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to Robert A.Lovett, Secretary of Defense, and to Lieut. Gen. Paul Ely, chairman of the Standing Group of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, requesting release from military duty June 1, and Secretary Lovett's reply:

ROME, April 11 -- Jesus Christ died on the fourteenth day of Nisan, according to the Hebrew calendar, and scholars have been disputing for centuries over the exact date on the Gregorian calendar to which the fourteenth of Nisan corresponds. The claim is now made that Daniel's well-known prophecy of the "seventy weeks" [Daniel, IX, 24] points conclusively to the seventh day of April in the year 30 A. D.

Harness races at both Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways will be televised over WOR-TV each Wednesday evening beginning April 30 from 9:45 o'clock until the conclusion of the feature race. Four races each night will be televised, with Stan Lomax doing the descriptive commentary.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that hesitant domestic buyers had re-entered sugar markets in considerable number in recent weeks. As a consequence, it added, prices of both raw and refined sugar have increased.

ANTWERP, Belgium, April 11 -- The diamond polishing industry of Belgium centered in Antwerp -- with 10,000 operatives, the largest in the world -- is being driven underground by the restrictions on currency transfers, artificial rates of exchange, Government interference and smuggling.

PONDICHERRY, French India, April 2 -- Eventual cession of this tiny French colony on the southeast coast of India to the Indian Union appears to be taken for granted by many residents, although both French and some local officials and others seem interested in postponing the day of transfer for various reasons, mostly selfish ones.

PARIS, April 11 -- Television technicians of eight countries, after a four-day meeting at Unesco House, urged the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today to assume the role of a clearing house in the development of educational television.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 11 (AP) -- Dick Mayer and Skee Riegel, each in his third year as a professional, tied for the first-round lead in the $10,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament today with four-under-par 67's. Ed (Porky) Oliver of Lamont, Ill., was third at 68.
Record throngs of worshipers crowded New York's churches yesterday in reverent memory of the Crucifixion of Jesus Christ on Calvary.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., April 11 (AP) -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands ended her first day of full relaxation during her state visit to this country with an oyster roast at an old rice plantation tonight.

Operations of M. Lowenstein and Sons, Inc., and subsidiaries in 1951 resulted in a net profit of $5,632,398, equal to $4.05 a share on 1,322,689 common shares, according to the annual report released yesterday by Leon Lowenstein and Archie O. Joslin, chairman and president, respectively.

Permitting the favorite to exhaust himself in an effort to wear down another challenger, the Woolford Farm's Delegate scored a dramatic victory in the Mettlesome Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Bryan G., made top choice by the crowd of 32,859, had to be content with second place, solaced only a little by the fact that he outlasted his bitter contender, F. Ambrose Clark's Tea-Maker.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 11 (UP) -- Sub Fleet, Dixiana Farm's Kentucky Derby hope, began his 1952 campaign today by coming from behind in the stretch to score a neck victory over Harold Bockman's Happy Go Lucky in the $5,000 Claiborne Purse at Keeneland.

The New York Knickerbockers will be confronted by big George Mikan, pro basketball's outstanding player, when they meet the Minneapolis Lakers at St. Paul tonight in the first game of the best-of-seven series for the National Basketball Association title.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 11 -- Pilots and engineers at the General Mills balloon experimentation project said today they have sighted "aerial objects of undetermined origin" over Minnesota and Wisconsin.

KANSAS CITY, April 11 -- The Giants got a lot of ragged play this afternoon as they tangled with the Cleveland Indians in the home of the Kansas City Blues. The score was 4 to 3.
WHARTON, N. J., April 11 -- A quick-thinking steam shovel operator probably saved the life of a 9-year-old boy who was buried today by a slag landslide at the old Wharton Northern Railroad.

YONKERS, April 11 -- Charles Stokes, 31 years old, of Delhi, N. Y., the only survivor of a triple shooting that included a murder and a suicide here last night, was reported today by the police to be recovering in St. Joseph's Hospital from three bullet wounds.

The suspension last week by President Vargas of Brazil of a decree giving Brazilian ships entrance and clearance priority in that country's ports has evoked a "wait and see" attitude among many of the lines serving South America.

Dog owners have a particular reason this year to make certain that they obtain licenses for their pets. The new Metcalf-Hatch Law, effective July 1, will permit the state or city Health Departments to requisition and turn over to accredited laboratories and institutions any unlicensed, unwanted or unclaimed animals that have been impounded.

WHILE the local anglers are splashing happily in nearby trout streams, Maine camp operators are frowning at the thick ice which persists in defying the spring weather on the popular landlocked salmon waters and late reports indicate that even the southern waters will retain their crystal cover until the 20th.
OMAHA, April 11 (AP) -- A rolling mass of Missouri River water, fresh from an assault on South Dakota's capital city of Pierre, pointed tonight toward Sioux City, Iowa.

The purchasing value of the dollar was 56.6 cents for March, with the dollar of January, 1939, equaling 100 cents, as consumers' prices rose 0.2 per cent from February to March, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

The use of an aqueous extract of the spleen of calves, injected by vein in human cancer victims, has led to improvements in cases of early and moderately advanced malignancy, it was reported here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research at the Statler Hotel.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, April 12 (AP) -- Communist troops broke a two-day battle lull early today with a flurry of artillery barrages and infantry probing attacks across the 155-mile Korean front.

There were two changes of cast in last night's performance of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center. Jan Gbur made his debut with the company in the role of the Commandant, and Wesley Dalton replaced an indisposed Rudolf Petrak as Don Ottavio.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Truman called on the American people today to observe the 500th anniversary of the birth of Leonardo da Vinci, thereby starting a propaganda battle over the Italian genius of the Renaissance, for Russia has decided he is worth honoring, too.
Advance ticket sales indicate record season attendances at home for three major league clubs in 1952 and no significant drop from 1951 figures for the thirteen other clubs.
One youth was captured at pistol-point in Central Park and a second was being sought last night after their speeding auto caromed off a tree at Fifth Avenue and 108th Street and struck the park wall.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 11 -- Ignoring an imbroglio over the amount of salt that should be added to twenty gallons of beef stew, Public Welfare Commissioner Edwin W. Wallace stuck to his guns today and announced he would use one pound.
LONDON, April 11 -- Arthur Horner, secretary of the National Union of Mine Workers, has been dropped from the official slate for re-election to the executive committee of the British Communist party.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Advisory Committee of Citizens for Eisenhower, said here today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would probably make his first major address in this country in Abilene, Kan., his boyhood home, on June 4.

The news that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower had asked to be relieved of his command of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces to return to this country was welcomed yesterday by his political supporters and opponents.
Five exhibitions including one-man shows of painting and sculpture, together with work by modern French masters, form part of this week's art shows.

NEW DELHI, India, April 11 -- The Indians are disquieted by the firm assertions of sovereignty for the Princely State of Jammu and Kashmir by Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah, Premier of the Indian-held part of this northern territory, whose allegiance is under dispute between India and Pakistan

Denim is a twill-weave cotton fabric first made in France, and about sixty years or more ago, the cloth played a leading part in helping to develop American West and other rural areas of this country. Cowboys liked the fabric because it was tough and durable, and there are still places where shrinkable denim levis and dungarees are wanted, to insure a tight fit which cuts down the incidence of saddle sores.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- Political leaders gave various interpretations today to the results that might ensue from the campaign in Pennsylvania to nominate General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as the Republican Presidential candidate in the preference primary on April 22.

MOSCOW, April 11 (Reuters) -- British business men have concluded two barter deals of 2,000,000 ($5,600,000) each with Eastern Germany and Rumania, a spokesman for the British group attending Moscow's week-old economic conference announced today.

PARIS, April 11 -- French officials found in the Soviet note of yesterday the basis for further negotiations. But they contended that before any four-power, conference on Germany met. Moscow should make it clear what powers it would give an all German Government from the time of its creation until the signature of a peace treaty.

Fifty-two persons were killed yesterday when a New York-bound DC-4 of Pan American World Airways crash-landed and sank in the harbor at San Juan, Puerto Rico, a few minutes after its take-off. Only seventeen of the sixty-nine passengers and crew members survived.

The three-story store and apartment building at 6310 Eighteenth Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Elizabeth Stablein and Cornelia Young to the Ebinger Realty Company. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company. The property, on a plot 24 by 75 feet, is assessed at $31,500.
Probable pitchers and starting times (Eastern standard) for the opening games on Tuesday of the major-league baseball season, with last year's won-and-lost records in parentheses:

The Soviet Union's reply to the Three-Power note of March 25 concerning a German settlement does not make any significant advance. It is a reiteration and defense of the previous Soviet proposals which had already been found unacceptable. There are at least three points at which the Western Powers cannot concur, and it must be fairly obvious to the Soviet Union that their concurrence could not have been expected.
MADRID, April 11 -- United States officials were understood today to have virtually completed the draft of a Mutual Security Agency agreement for economic and military aid to Spain.

TRENTON, April 11 (AP) -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today granted permission to the Pennsylvania Railroad to discontinue two Sunday and holiday trains operating between Trenton and Stroudsburg, Pa.
GENEVA, April 11 -- The United Nations Commission to investigate free elections in Germany has sent another communication to Soviet authorities in East Germany asking for cooperation in its task.
ALBANY, April 11 (AP) -- More than 200,000 fishermen are expected to turn out tomorrow for the opening of the state trout season.
Decisions on the applications of two West Coast steamship lines for Government subsidies may soon be forthcoming as a result of action yesterday by the Federal Maritime Board.
Depriving a child of maternal care can have results so grave for his future that he should no more be deliberately exposed to such risk than to a heavy dose of tubercle infection.

The tremendous growth of the life insurance industry in this country and Canada is best illustrated by the fact that there are now thirty-seven life companies in the United States with more than $1,000,000,000 of insurance protection in force. In addition, six Canadian companies of that size do business in this country.

IN the current exhibition, "Fifteen Americans," at the Museum of Modern Art, Dorothy Miller, curator of the Museum's collection, has assmbled as highly diverse a group of artists as the series of these shows has yet produced. From the romantic and sometimes stereoscopic realism of Herman Rose's Manhattan rooftops to the completely nonobjective swirls of Jackson Pollock's intricacies it unfolds pretty much the full tale of contemporary art -- with one notable exception.

PARIS, April 12 -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden has notified the Governments of France, Italy, West Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg that the British announcement of a guarantee to protect the six proposed members of the European army with automatic military assistance will be delayed by one week.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Truman may be a political wizard, as the experts have been saying ever since he shellacked Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in 1948, but his wizardry, if that's what it is, certainly did not include the essential quality of preparing his party effectively for the Democratic nominating convention of 1952.

In 1946 Congress passed a law which for the first time recognized the existence of that particularly American institution, the lobby. As its title indicates, the Federal Regulation of Lobbying Act was not designed to prohibit lobbying but to regulate the actions of all who would influence the passage or defeat of legislation by the Congress.

JUST as wise highway travelers eat where the truck drivers eat, so might ocean travelers take cognizance of the seaman's choice of ports. For the seaman is, to a certain extent, a perpetual cruise passenger, except that he works between ports.

BONN, Germany, April 12 -- The West German Government has proposed two alternate plans for making a financial contribution to Western defense. One plan would leave comparatively little German financial support for the Western Allied forces stationed in Germany and the other none at all.

LONDON, April 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is returning to the United States on the orders of "big business" to carry out war plans, Harry Pollitt, general secretary of the British Communist party, told his comrades at the twenty-second party congress here today.
GENEVA, April 12 -- For the first time since World War II unemployment has become a significant social, economic and political problem in the industrial countries of northwestern Europe.

For the seventeenth consecutive year, Edmond W. Rickett, 83-year-old organist at the Church-in-the-Gardens (Congregational), Ascan Avenue and Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens, will play two full services of Easter music and choral accompaniment begining at 10:30 A. M. today -- a task of no mean proportions for a musician half his age.

EXCEPT for the megaphoned confidences of Messrs. Lait and Mortimer, there appears to be more pay dirt in exposure of sins of the past than of the present. Competition is keen among many localities for the reputation of having been the wickedest, with the orneriest characters and juiciest murders.

Yesterday the French National Assembly passed the 1952 budget and adjourned for a long Easter recess. The new budget won by a margin of 122 ballots, reflecting a degree of agreement which many observers would have thought impossible only a few weeks ago.

With Uncle Sam in reluctant possession of two of the nation's biggest industries and with communications disrupted by telephone and telegraph strikes, the country was suffering last week its worst attack of labor pains since 1946.

Considering the crucial foreign and domestic issues at stake in the coming elections and the uncertain texture of campaigning still to be encountered, no one should minimize the enormity of the task facing the American people in the next months or the historic nature of their final decision on Nov. 7.

THE opening of Vardis Fisher's latest novel is in the early part of the second century B. C., when a Greek named Philemon is ending a long journey from Antioch to Jerusalem. On this day devoutly frenzied multitudes are converging on their Holy City for the annual Festival of the Tabernacles, a convulsive rededication of an austere people to the myths and actualities of birth and rebirth.

The name of Dwight D. Eisenhower as Presidential candidate was first seriously raised as the 1948 election approached. Early in that year, both the Democrats and the Republicans had their eyes on the general. He said "No," to both. To the Republicans in January he wrote: "I am not available."

NASSAU -- On March 31 Nassau's winter tourist season merged into its spring season, with elaborate plans in preparation for the busiest summer on record. Closing of the formal winter season is accompanied by relaxation in dress at the more exclusive spots which require dinner jackets at most evening activities.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- Retailers, jobbers and some manufacturers have stepped up operations in a number of lines, reflecting better - balanced inventories, improved public demands for seasonable goods and better adjustment of merchandise plans to changed conditions.
Puccini's "La Boheme" will be presented both in English and in Italian at the Metropolitan Opera House next season, Rudolph Bing, the general manager, announced yesterday.

IT is an astonishing fact that until the publication of this book, one-third of which is taken up with a study of Christophe himself, there existed in the English language no single work of non-fiction describing one of the two members of the Negro race who have played an independent role on the stage of world history.

The Metropolitan Opera closed its sixty-seventh New York season yesterday. The opera in the afternoon was Wagner's consecrational drama, "Parsifal" and that in the evening -- the 150th performance of a twenty-two week period -- was Verdi's "La Traviata."

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: To ready perennials for months of bloom, remove or loosen winter coverings, push back into place any plants lifted by frost action, cut down and rake up last year's dead top growth. After top-dressing with compost or 5-10-5 fertilizer, use a hoe for shallow cultivation of soil, taking care not to disturb any perennials that are late starting.
URBANA, Ill., April 12 -- Research by the engineering experiment station of the University of Illinois has furthered industrial progress and made great strides in the field of safety.

THIS is the most comprehensive work on architecture to have been published in some years. Its scope is encyclopedic -- by reading its four massive volumes anybody could, conceivably, absorb enough information to put him well on his way to becoming an architect.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly in a narrow range during the last shortened trading week. At the close of business at the New York Cotton Exchange Thursday (the exchange was closed Friday) active futures contracts showed net advances of three to twenty-four points.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (UP) -- The six-hit pitching of Howie Fox and Andy Hansen, plus the home-run power of Fox and Del Ennis, led the Phillies to a 6-0 victory over the Athletics in the opener of their two-game city series today.

Love of strangers as well as neighbors was emphasized by Rabbi Samuel M. Segal in a sermon yesterday morning at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, as necessary for the establishing of complete freedom.
The Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., put off for the time being yesterday a threatened full-scale national telephone strike because of some progress in negotiations with the Bell System.

Laurence H. Victory, president of the New York Typographical Union No. 6, A. F. L., denied yesterday a press report that Arthur Deutsch, a former member of the union's executive committee, was representing the union at the International Economic Conference that ended yesterday in Moscow.

In a lecture which he delivered recently at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on "Dynamics of Energy Movement," Dr. L. K. Sillcox, executive vice president of the New York Airbrake Company, pointed out that we cannot count on our shale reserves to make good an inevitable shortage of petroleum.
What is the "milo" that Chester Bowles in "Asia Challenges Us Through India" (March 23) wants us to send India? Is it by chance a misprint for millet ?

OTTAWA, April 12 -- Concern over the rise in the Canadian dollar is beginning to replace the satisfaction felt when it became the top-ranking currency in the world and the subject of many encomiums abroad.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The entire organization of the American Red Cross was placed on emergency status today by E. Roland Harriman, Red Cross president, to meet flood relief needs in the Middle West.

One provocative sentence in your Sunday piece (March 30) has inspired this letter. I quote:

An armed thug who seized $30 from an East Side building superintendent was shot and injured fatally by a policeman last night as he fled along Third Avenue. The weapon, found clutched in the hand of the fallen hold-up man, turned out to be a blank cartridge pistol.

A GOOD neighbor movement which sprang up inside the radio industry four years ago is still quietly living up to its free-will obligations. It is called the Veterans Hospital Radio Guild, a group of more than 200 volunteers who visit Veteran Administration hospitals each week to encourage and teach patients to write, act, sing and produce their own radio shows.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- This is the week of the Pageant of the Bermuda Easter Lily, when the colony shows off its glorious flowers and particularly the Easter Lily for which it is renowned, in a parade of floats that has become one of the principal tourist attractions at this season.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman will not have to spend much money on entertainment after he leaves the White House, provided his idea of a good time runs to books, speeches and baseball.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 12 -- The Union of South Africa, most reluctant member of all the British Commonwealth, is ill with many fevers, and its vital strength is being sapped by divisions within itself.

The importance of the non-metallic element boron, found in abundance in the United States, is ncreasing steadily as nickel, molybdenum, chromium and other alloying agents for steel become more and more scarce, the National Geographic Society reports.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The establishment of a district commissioner's office in Chicago, May 1, to have jurisdiction over all internal revenue matters in Illinois, will be the first major step taken in the reorganization of the Bureau of Internal Revenue Commissioner, John B. Dunlap, reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio issued a "cordial invitation" tonight to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to state definite views on Presidential campaign issues.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- The International Economic Conference ended tonight after effecting substantial trade rapprochement between British business men attending the meeting and the Soviet Union, Communist China and East Europe and trade deals roughly estimated at $200,000,000.
TORONTO -- The summer vacationist who wants something different has a variety of trips available in Canada to remote northern parts of the continent.

With their pitching plentitude again emphasized in striking performances by Ben Wade and Johnny Schmitz, the Dodgers yesterday celebrated their home-coming to Ebbets Field with a second straight victory over the world champion Yankees.

With the capture of William Pomeroy, former American soldier who became a leader of the dissident "Huks," Philippine defense forces have finally written the end to a sorry story. Pomeroy, an American Communist by training, went back to the Philippines after the war, studied in Manila under the G. I. Bill of Rights, and then put his skills at the services of the Communist-led rebels.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., April 12 (AP) -- Henry Wittenberg qualified for another shot at making the United States Olympic wrestling team tonight as he beat a field of four in the 191-pound class of the district Olympic trials at Amityville High School.
A new and intensified campaign of Communist propaganda aimed at American seamen is now under way.

Dr. Martin B. Williamson (Loyola University School of Medicine) finds that wounds heal more rapidly when certain substances called "sulfur amino acids" are present in the diet. Of these cystine is especially important. It is a white crystalline substance in eggs, milk, wheat, corn and some other foods.
Although it can't be found on any map, and census takers ignore it completely, Postal Zone 46 in New York receives more mail each day than is delivered to most towns, and many small cities.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (AP) -- The Middle Atlantic District captured both the men's and women's division team titles by defeating the New York District in the eastern regional gymnastic championships of the American Turners today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- The American Association for the United Nations urged the United States today to reverse its stand on the Tunisian case and to vote to give the controversy a hearing before the Security Council.

A file of more than 400,000 letters and documents from Henry Holt Co., publishers, will be turned over to Princeton University in a ceremony tomorrow morning at the offices of the publisher, 383 Madison Avenue.

Our Civilization THOSE who regard the decay of civilization as something quite normal and natural console themselves with the thought that it is not civilization, but a civilization, which is falling a prey to dissolution; that there will be a new age and a new race in which there will blossom a new civilization. But that is a mistake.

After twenty-seven years of rigorous service as an Internal Revenue agent, Frank E. Anglim has decided to retire. In his formal application, the tall, handsome officer, a favorite around the Brooklyn Federal Building, mentioned that he was eligible because he had reached the retirement age of 55. However, to his friends, he has confided that he is "just tired."

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- House investigators revealed today that representatives, spurred by election-year pressures, were flooding the country with the greatest barrage of "propaganda" in history -- at the taxpayer's expense.

THE once academic discussion of a two-party South enters this year the curious realm of practical politics, thanks to the brightness of the Eisenhower star on the Southern horizon and the almost psychopathic distrust which many of the region's political leaders had held for Mr. Truman before his withdrawal.

Faulty engine maintenance work on the non-scheduled C-46 passenger airliner that crashed in Elizabeth, N. J., last Dec. 16, killing all fifty-six persons aboard, was blamed for the accident yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

RURAL electrification, which reached only one farm in ten twenty years ago, now extends to lighten the work and life on nine-tenths of American farms. Farmer cooperatives, with three million members, have built a million miles of new line into territory formerly neglected.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 12 -- Die Burger, the leading Nationalist party newspaper and the mouthpiece of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, today publishes the outline of a bill that, it says, the Government intends to introduce in an effort to overcome the crisis caused in its dispute with the courts.

Seizure of the steel industry by the Government after President Truman, in a highly partisan speech, upheld labor and condemned management, forestalled the strike threat that had plagued financial markets many weeks. The issues involved, however, have not been solved by this development -- but new ones have been added.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 12 -- As a result of the lessons learned during the four-day "indoor war games" of Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, a high-level military-political conference will be called in Europe in two or three months.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 12 (UP) -- Hernan Siles Zuazo labored as Provisional President today to bring order out of the confusion following the bloody three-day revolution he led in seizing the Government of Bolivia.

Spring sales of men's hats are running slightly behind last year but straw hat orders are running ahead of 1951, manufacturers said last week. Because of the late Easter this year, some producers said that post-holiday reorders might bring seasonal business to within range of last year's activity.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The staff of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee said today fears of "a change in the racial character of a neighborhood" were causing difficulties in locating public housing projects.

A FIFTEEN - YEAR period of photographic publishing on the popular level was celebrated here last week with Photography Magazine's publication of its "Crystal Jubilee Issue" and its distribution of the citations for outstanding contributions during the years 1937 to 1952.

Dogwood trees, tulips and flowering azaleas will be used to transform the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria into a pink and white garden setting Tuesday night for the Ciro Ball, annual spring dinner dance for the benefit of the New York Infirmary.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 12 -- The college rowing season in the East opened on a modest scale this afternoon as Pennsylvania and Rutgers met in their annual rivalry on the Raritan River. The Quakers, making a sweep for the sixth consecutive year, won all three event by comfortable margins.

AFRICAN violets are now bidding for recognition as America's favorite house plant. Their everblooming trait may account, to some extent, for the fact that they come first in year-round sales of indoor flowering plants.

PARIS, April 12 -- Spain's demands for increased influence in the Tangier international zone at the African approaches to the Straits of Gibraltar is interpreted here as part of a calculated attempt to turn the current French-British difficulties in the Moslem world to Spanish profit.
Stocks drifted aimlessly in quiet trading and closed mixed yesterday, with television issues the strongest.

HOME gardeners would do well to take a leaf from the notebook of the scientific farmer. The latter does not have so many growing "tricks" as he does certain general principles to which he adheres. Any gardener will profit by following them, whether he grows roses, fruit trees, shrubs, vegetables, perennial or annual flowers.

As the spotlight of world events focuses more strongly on the Dark. Continent and that hemisphere begins to yield increasing numbers of art works, it is appropriate that we should receive some of Africa's musical compositions.

THE announcement by Harry Truman that he would not run for President next November caused great consternation among the Democratic politicians. But this is as nothing to the havoc stirred up among the 1,200 members of The Lambs, that frolicsome confraternity of show people, when Bert Lytell, its popular Shepherd, or president, recently stated that he did not choose to run again when his term expired next October.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- It may appear trite to predict another close race and another good season, but I believe that the American League is a stronger and better league as it begins its fifty-second season.

THE controversy over "Red Channels" refuses to die. The incredible mischief wrought by the publishers of "Counterattack" in issuing their private list of persons whom they deemed sympathetic to communism or Communist fronts continues to be a matter of concern far transcending the broadcasting industry itself.

In one of the keenest team matches seen this season, the Ramapo Polo Club broke into the final round of the national senior indoor championship tournament by beating the 16-goal Squadron A Regulars, 13 -- 8, in the feature match of the weekly double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 12 (UP) -- Supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft won four delegate-at-large seats today in Kentucky's delegation to the Republican national convention, giving the Ohio Senator nineteen of the state's twenty delegates. General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower won the other delegate.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 12 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami kept the Indian sign over Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., with a 5-7, 6-4, 6-3, 6-0 victory in the semi-finals of the Good Neighbor tennis tournament.

The observance of World Health Day last Monday has focused attention on the great reduction in mortality that has taken place throughout the world in the last five years. These reductions have been particularly striking in some parts of South and Central America, in Southern Europe and in certain parts of South Asia.

Olin Culbertson, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, explained by wire why he failed to show up at the Beeville, Tex., annual fireman's banquet where he was to have been the main speaker. He took the wrong train.
To the Screen Editor: That neither "A Place in the Sun" nor "A Streetcar Named Desire" was accorded filmdom's highest honors serves to underline the peculiar nature of the annual Academy Awards.

ONE of the most charming facets of a hardy perennial border is its infinite variety. There is a special excitement in seeing new plants unfurl their flowers with the changing seasons. Nevertheless, the display is really carried by a comparatively few plants -- species that have either ease of culture and a long, colorful blooming period or dramatic form and color which makes them so outstanding that no substitutes can be found.

PHOTOGRAPHS in seven classifications will be displayed in the 1952 international Exhibition of this year's convention of the Photographic Society of America, to be held Aug. 12-16 at the Hotel New Yorker.

ALBANY, April 12 -- The State Bureau of Motor Vehicles today announced a stiffer policy for cracking down on persistent traffic law violators and making it harder for repeated offenders to recover suspended licenses.
THE Metropolitan Opera Association's season of 1951-52, so far as New York City is concerned, came to an end last night.

EVERY now and then we hear some speaker -- with more wit than absolute accuracy -- comment that since "the average size of household" reported by the Census Bureau is 3.7, the average American family must be made up of a mother, a father and 1.7 children.

THE latest development in the bridge business is a drive to popularize the game called Ghoulies, which name is merely a newly spelled diminutive of what used to be called goulashes and which game is merely an unaltered revival of it.

Stores were busy with Easter activity and some reorders were received in the wholesale market here last week but most of the activity was on after-Easter merchandise, resident-buying offices reported. Stores have reduced inventories and many buyers are expected, to enter the markets to complete summer purchases.

NOT everybody has a brook or pond on their property, but those who do can have some of the brightest and sweetest - smelling wild flowers, shrubs and trees growing alongside it from earliest spring to late fall. These moisture-loving plants are among the easiest to grow, and can be used galore or in restrained design by a brook or pond.

THE dignity of the traditional Georgian house calls for a planting plan that stresses its balance and symmetry. Whether the scheme runs the gamut from balanced formality to the entirely naturalistic, each planting serves a specific purpose. Individual requirements plus the architectural demands of the house are all considered in relation to existing conditions.
A SLOW-SIMMERING but little - known literary scandal came to a boil last month when an unpublished novel by Algernon Charles Swinburne started turning up, in installments, in The London Daily Mail.
