WOMEN make up such a large proportion of the best writers and editors of detective stories that it's a pity there aren't more female detectives -- women, that is, who star in their own right rather than merely serving as half of a Bright Young Couple.

HOUSTON, April 12 (UP) -- Marlene Bauer, former Midland, Tex., golfer now playing out of Sarasota, Fla., shot a record-shattering 68 in the final round of the Houston Weathervane golf tournament today but had to share top honors with Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias and Betsy Rawls.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H., April 12 -- Yale turned back Harvard and Princeton in the annual varsity ski slalom at Mount Washington today. The Elis compiled an aggregate time of 411.4 seconds for their second straight victory in the series, while the Cantabs trailed with 425.

LONDON, April 12 (Reuters) -- Manchester United took over sole possession of first place in the top division of English soccer today, blanking Liverpool, 4 -- 0. Arsenal lost to the Bolton Wanderers, 2 -- 1, and Portsmouth bowed to the Tottenham Hotspurs, 3 -- 1.

ATHENS, April 12 -- A draft law providing for the majority system in the event of new elections was being prepared today and will be presented to Parliament at the end of the Easter recess. Meanwhile, the Government will sound the opinions of various party leaders, either through the formation of an all-party advisory committee or by establishing personal contact between the Interior Minister and authorized party representatives.

In many instances young people set their hearts on a career for which they have little or no talent. But it is a hard blow when an employer or some other sincere person so informs them. As a result many refuse to take the advice and go through life battling against odds for success that are overwhelmingly against them.

HAVANA -- The coup d'etat that overthrew the Cuban Government of President Carlos Prio Socarras last March 10 will bring nothing but improvements as far as tourists are concerned, according to high officials of the regime of Gen. Fulgencio Batista.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 13 -- The growth of United Nations air power in Korea with unrelenting air assaults against the enemy during recent months has made it impossible for the Communists to sustain a large-scale offensive, though they could start one, in the opinion of Lieut. Gen. Otto P. Weyland, commander of the Far East Air Forces.

Despite the fact that major changes in the Federal income tax laws governing deductibility of bad debts were made nearly ten years ago, litigation on this subject still persists. One of the reasons for this is that so-called "nonbusiness bad debts" have become subject to new interpretations and entirely new treatment as deductions.

WHEN Granny and the youngest of the three Trent children, Sue, bought a circus horse at auction, the whole family was in for many surprises. Ballita's intelligence and tricks upset the stables, disturbed the little British village, outraged an ice-cream vender, and gave the children a special assignment.

THIS century has seen the rise of an enormous reading public and, up to 1939, a decline in the status of the Common Reader. Perhaps it is best to begin by defining the Common Reader. He differs from the writer only in his inability to write; otherwise, he has the same range of knowledge, he has imagination, and he is alive to the nature of the times we live in.

Seven major league scouts were at Ohio Field yesterday when Manhattan took the measure of N. Y. U., 6 -- 4, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference contest. The bird dogs were not at all concerned about which team won or lost. They were on hand, primarily, to look over a 19-year-old Violet freshman southpaw, Bill Oster.

" IN the year 66 of our twentieth century we shall solemnly celebrate the centenary of the birth of Kandinsky. It will then be sixty years since the death of Paul Cezanne. And just as today Cezanne belongs unquestionably to the history of art, in 1966 Kandinsky's place will be similarly obvious even to those who today are still dubious of the meaning and value of his art." I do not find this statement extravagant.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 12 (UP) -- Free for Me won the first division of the Ashland Stakes today and Real Delight captured the second as Eddie Arcaro was 50 per cent successful in his bid to make a clean sweep of the handicap races held so far at the Keeneland meeting.

Members of the Committee of French-American Wives have arranged their seventh annual Bal des Berceaux for the night of April 25 in the St. Regis Roof to raise funds for carrying on the organization's post-war program in France and relief work in the Far East. Mrs. Leonard B. Smith is chairman of the committee.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The exercise by the Executive in a crisis of authority not specified in the Constitution or in law invariably stirs new controversy over the source and extent of Presidential powers. Such a discussion flared up this week when President Truman seized the steel plants.

A SMALL tree that adds a true fairyland touch to the April garden picture is the redbud or judas tree (Cercis canadensis). The flower buds are swollen and all set to bloom any day in this part of the country.

Since man first knew the seasons he has come to the springtime of the year with awe and wonder in his heart and hope resurgent in his soul. For spring was, in every aspect, the resurrection of life and all growing things around him; and the whole sum of his experience directed his belief to sources of that life and that growth and strength, sources which lay beyond his reach and his understanding.

THE motion picture industry demonstrated again last week its desire not to give any public evidence of dissension at the policy-making level. This was evidenced by the mantle of official silence still being maintained at press time, despite the embarrassing implication of laxity in coping with Communist influences made by Howard Hughes, head of R. K. O.

Regarding John P. Marquand's "Inquiry Into the Military Mind" (March 30), those citizens who have misgivings that a military mind unfits its owner to hold a high political office might note these words of Napoleon:

BOSTON, April 12 -- The projected three-day tour next week of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio to promote his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination in Massachusetts comes at a time when the Democrats will be particularly busy in their own political vineyard.

ABOUT this time of the year one observes the beginning of a phenomenon first marked shortly before World War II but since then grown to astounding proportions. The phenomenon is this: While vacationists who were south during the winter months start migrating north, other travelers, with less money, head south for spring and summer vacations.

ALAN YOUNG is a bold signpost of two facts in the yet amorphous Motion Picture-Television relationship. A flop in the movies, he has emerged as a new TV personality. But what's even more pregnant is that, in having rediscovered his talents, motion pictures have learned from television how to use them.

Most of the leading commercial banks in New York City operated on a more profitable basis in the first quarter of 1952 than a year ago, condition statements of the banks for March 31, just published, disclosed. This improvement was accomplished despite a drop in deposits and resources since Dec. 31, 1951.

THE retrospective exhibition of A. E. Gallatin's abstract and non-figurative pictures at the Rose Fried Gallery honors a distinguished American artist whose painting life started some twenty-five years ago on a Cubist legacy and has since ascended into the chilly realm of pure geometrical form.

PARIS, April 12 -- A French-sponsored Cabinet for the North African protectorate of Tunisia was officially proclaimed in Tunis today, eighteen days after the arrest of the Nationalist Ministry that had pressed a claim for independence from France in the country's internal affairs.

A SOUNDLY documented historical romance, Roy Flannagan's fourth novel deals with a neglected period in American history when the early Virginia settlers rose up under the leadership of Nathaniel Bacon against British exploitation.

THE author of "The Low-Calory Cookbook" disclaims being a professional cook, but you need read only a few pages to realize that he must be a magician. Anybody who can take the average reducing diet and make it look better than a regular fattening diet has got something.

Portraits of George Washington and Abraham Lincoln will be auctioned on Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The sale, which will include other paintings, American and British, Currier Ives prints, American and English period furniture, antique Oriental rugs and various decorations collected by the late Bernon S. Prentice of New York and Holmdel, N. J., will be held on three afternoons, beginning Thursday.

Continued uncertainty as to i whether Western European industries can plan on receiving any sizable military production orders under pending Mutual Security Agency appropriations was pictured here last week as an obstacle to basic planning on other_forms of development.

Since the middle of last December five commercial air transport planes have crashed in the New York metropolitan area when only a few minutes away from the airports they were heading for or had just left. The last of the crashes occurred a week ago yesterday in Queens.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "Don Juan in Hell" Thursday night at the Plymouth Theatre to raise funds for the Berkshire Industrial Farm. The institution will be the beneficiary also of the "nightcap party" to be held in the Rendez Vous of the Plaza after the performance.

CAIRO, April 12 -- The Egyptian Cabinet approved today the terms of a decree law postponing the Egyptian general elections for an indefinite period. [Reuters said King Farouk had approved the Cabinet's action.]

NEW DELHI, India, April 12 -- The farewell conference between Premier Stalin and Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, India's Ambassador to Moscow, involved more of a discussion of differences between the Soviet Union and India than an exploration of world problems, according to authoritative sources here.

MONTREAL, April 12 -- A second-period goal by Ted Lindsay gave the Detroit Red Wings a 2-1 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens tonight for a 2-0 lead in their Stanley Cup hockey final before a crowd of 14,549 fans.

AS a result of the devoted and careful studies of men like Dr. Robert G. Cleland, historian and author of "This Reckless Breed of Men," a pattern of American economic development, complex yet orderly, is beginning to emerge.

MIAMI -- More glamour at lower cost is the program for this year's spring and summer vacations in Florida. Advance predictions are that Miami and Miami Beach will have more visitors between April 15 and Aug. 1 than in the NovemberFebruary period.

WHETHER the two-week-old "The Struggle for Europe" sells or doesn't, Chester Wilmot's book has already proved itself a critical success. Nearly to a man, the reviewers have agreed that the book is factual, objective and toughly reasoned.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica -- The myth of the "off-season" is rapidly evaporating in Jamaica. After the biggest winter season in its tourist history, Jamaica is now being flooded with requests from would-be spring and summer visitors.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- The Federal Power Commission has before it applications from the State of California and the Pacific Gas and Electric Company for construction of new hydroelectric projects that would add 609,000 kilowatts of installed generating capacity to northern California's total.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Truman in an executive order today empowered a Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives investigating the Department of Justice to inspect specific income tax returns. The authorization, however, contained certain limitations.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- Pravda in significant special comment today on the German question stressed that the Western powers and Soviet Union had reached agreement on two basic important German issues -- the necessity for the formation of a general German Government and the necessity for all-German elections.

A campaign picture and some slogans calling for clean government went up in the windows of a ground floor store at 281 Neptune Avenue, Coney Island, the other day, as part of an insurgent race for Democratic leadership of the Second Assembly District in Brooklyn.

RELENTLESS readers of the public prints have already discovered that the members of the New York Drama Critics Circle have handed down their official judgments for the season. For the best new American play -- John van Druten's "I Am a Camera," with ten votes out of a total of twenty-four.

THE daffodils are out at the Botanical Gardens both in Brooklyn and the Bronx. Gardeners in the suburbs of New York City report that their displays are well under way. And the dates of three shows featuring this flower are not far off.

NAPLES, Italy, April 12 -- Paolo Crescenzo, 68-year-old former railroad laborer from the West Coast of the United States, who was found last month camping in Grand Central Station, New York, with his life savings of $23,350 in some paper bags returned to his home land and his wife today for the first time in thirty-nine years.

Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman said last night it was "not likely" that the clash between democratic and totalitarian concepts would "result in open breaks" in the near future. But, he emphasized, the "struggle that is going on is of titanic proportion, and the stakes are tremendously high."

Six to seven weeks of intensive training having been more or less safely negotiated, major league baseball winds up its preliminary exhibition campaign today and on Tuesday the boys will start shooting for keeps as the curtain rises on another championship season.

THE countrymen of John Adams ought to know him better for the man, the thinker and the writer he actually was. His family has certainly not been neglected and his patriotic services in the American Revolution have been widely recognized, but there has been much misunderstanding of him from that point on.

NOVELISTS have always been intrigued by the strange, turbulent and dynamic figure of the Apostle Paul, who gave the Christian Church much of its theology and dogma. One of the earliest novel fragments extant, the apocryphal "Acts of Paul and Thecla," has the Apostle as its hero.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Florida's west coast, from Homasassa in the north down through Naples in the south, is preparing and hoping for a record summer tourist season. The main bait will be, as it always has been at this time of year, drastically reduced rates.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- A pattern for locating new defense-supporting industries inside or outside critical target zones has been adopted for the San Francisco Bay area, approved by the Federal Government and is to be put into effect immidiately.

Despite the warnings of President Truman and Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder that inflationary dangers still threaten the economy, the end of the national voluntary credit restraint effort appears imminent.
PARIS, April 12 -- One of the most surprising revelations of French post-war politics has been Premier Antoine Pinay.

With New Jersey's primary election scheduled for Tuesday, supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination appealed yesterday for a large vote in the hope of checking the drive for the nomination of Senator Robert A. Taft, which gained impetus by victories in Wisconsin, Nebraska and Illinois.

IN the summer of 1949 H. W. Tilman flew from England to China and from Shanghai went to Sinkiang, or Chinese Turkestan, to climb two mountains. He didn't get to the top of either mountain, for perfectly valid reasons which any mountaineer will understand.
What began five months ago as a contract dispute between steel labor and management became last week a fundamental debate over the Constitutional powers of the Presidency.

Traffic figures of the Civil Aeronautics Board for 1951, made available during the week, show that the domestic airlines of the United States, almost without exception, enjoyed an increased volume in all categories except freight and that they handled it profitably.

" EDWARD," Mr. Lawson tells us, "was not an especially bad little Rabbit; he wasn't especially good either. In fact he was just about like most young ones," and like most young ones, either rabbit or human, he was somewhat scatter-brained and had an aversion to education.

BREWSTER, N. Y., April 12 -- Most of the contacts made today between trout and fishermen were purely coincidental, but thousands of aspiring anglers crowded the watershed lakes and streams of Westchester and Putnam Counties, and some of them were surprisingly, successful.
SOME of the most colorful pictures in the nursery catalogues are those of the strawberries and raspberries. Looking at them, backyard orchardists find it hard to resist buying some.

Sales in New York and Brooklyn department stores went ahead of a week ago and were 3 to 4 per cent better than the corresponding calendar week of 1951. Cool weather slowed apparel sales somewhat, but the four-week pre-Easter sales compared very favorably to those a year ago despite the decline in clothing prices.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- The rudimentary roads that cut through Haiti's incredibly beautiful countryside have never been able to keep pioneering tourists away altogether, but they have certainly not encouraged widespread exploration. Now Haiti has launched a $4,000,000 program to pave its dirt roads and build new ones.

PARIS, April 12 -- Having garnered the endorsement of the advisory Council of the Republic for his program for financing the budget, Premier Antoine Pinay won a vote of 330 to 208 from the National Assembly today on the second and final reading of the bill.

AT a time when the prevailing fashion in the serious French novel is philosophic and steeped in bile, Marcel Ayme is a refreshing deviationist, working in an older Gallic tradition. Sharp-eyed, amused and infinitely curious, M. Ayme is the canny observer more interested in life as it is lived than in the hidden "whys" and problematic "shoulds" of human behavior.

A FORTNIGHT ago, there was a discussion on this page about the trend toward ensembles and the impact it might have on the new generation of recitalists as well as on the character of American musical life.
ON THE EASTERN FRONT, Korea, April 12 -- United States soldiers are running into long-haired Communist shock troops, apparently recruited for special missions and guerrilla actions.

JACKMANI hybrid clematis are in flower from June until October in Stephen Fairbanks' garden in Hingham, Mass. Two varieties that continue intermittently all summer and fall are velvety C. jackmani superba and crimson Edouard Andre.
The discussion of the current international economic conference in Moscow has thus far given inadequate attention to a factor which seems essential to an understanding of its significance.

RICHMOND, April 12 -- Current production cutbacks in the fifth district will build a stronger base for district industries and should be followed in a reasonably short order by a healthy revival, the Richmond Reserve Bank says in its monthly review.

A misdirection appears in Keith Munro's "Now Canada Comes of Age" (March 30). Apparently Mr. Munro has not had recent occasion to apply for a. vim upon his Canadian passport from the United States Consulate.

IT is with distaste that I write anything that may seem to be in the nature of religious controversy, especially as I know that, try as hard as I may to be objective and fair. I probably will not seem to be so in the eyes of Paul Blanshard and his friends.
Using anything from bent pins and worms to the best stock-made Royal Coachmen, North Jersey's fishermen crowded to the trout streams when the season opened yesterday morning.

WHEN, on a mid-October day in 1517, Cardinal Luis of Aragon, on a travel tour with his secretary, paid a visit to Leonardo da Vinci at the artist's retreat near Anaboise, France, it was a little as though the two travelers were paying a visit to an historic monument.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 12 --Ed (Porky) Oliver, playing out of Lemont, Ill., shot his second straight three-under-par 68 today to take the lead with 136 after 36 holes of the $10,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 12 -- One of the major problems in connection with the French efforts to eliminate the Communist-led Vietminh forces from the Tongking delta is the lack of a reliable administrative network loyal to the French Union and the Vietnam Government.

At a time when men "wander in the valley of the shadows with death and despair stirring about them, humanity seeks and finds courage and comfort through faith in the Risen Saviour." Cardinal Spellman said yesterday in his annual Easter Sunday Message.

THE geography of hell is still the process of being mapped. The borders shift, the shore lines erode, coral islands appear complete with new sirens, but all the men who have been there speak with a similar voice.

NOW that the bud is swelling on the willow, the plaintive moan and the chattering teeth of trout fishermen mingle with the more subtle noises of awakening Nature, for this is opening week-end in several states and a large part of our fifteen million fresh-water anglers begin the season's activities at this time.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The eleven fatal accidents during the seventeen-day Army-Air Force Exercise Long Horn, which ended in Texas this week, were the highest recorded in major maneuvers in recent years.

SOUTH AMERICA means ten republics, of which one alone -- Brazil -- is larger than the United States. It is a vast continent of contrasts, offering anything the visitor may be seeking. But since it is around 2,200 miles to the nearest capital in South America, and nearly 6,000 to the farthest, it is a good idea for the tourist to be fairly specific in his travel plans before he leaves home.

WHEN you leave Houston for the Texas Gulf Coast region, you go through a chain of small towns -- Stafford, Missouri City, Sugarland, Kendleton, Hungerford -- small towns and cotton fields and grazing lands decorated here and there by an oil or gas well.
TOKYO, Sunday, April 13 (AP) -- Eighth Army evening tactical summary 28, issued at 7 P. M. Saturday (5 A. M. Saturday, Eastern standard time):

ENCOURARGED by the success of the winter cruise season, operators of cruise tonnage are looking ahead with confidence to the spring and summer. From New York there will be many short-run cruises by the Furness liners Ocean Monarch and Queen of Bermuda, offering weekly departures to Hamilton or St. George's, Bermuda, and the weekly sailing of the Nassau of the Home Lines to Nassau.

THE vice president of a radio network was talking. "But we're a business that has to please the customers; that's the main thing we have to do, keep people happy, and, to do that, we have to stay out of trouble." The theme of Merle Miller's dispassionate report to the American people is that a high price has been paid by the radio-television industry and its advertisers "to stay out of trouble."

THE astonishment and irritation that were reportedly caused in Hollywood last week by Howard Hughes' public announcement that he was closing the R. K. O. studios because of the "Communist problem" served further to indicate the frustrating extent of a dilemma in which the motion picture industry now is.

BOSTON, April 12 -- Meeting here this week in regional convention, the American Association of School Administrators, a department of the National Education Association, analyzed and discussed the major problems confronting the nation's school system. Five thousand school superintendents, teachers and other educators participated in the discussions, forums and general meetings of this influential body of schoolmen.

The metropolitan harness racing season will start Tuesday night when the Yonkers Raceway begins the third year of operation. More than 1,300 trotters and pacers are on hand, with 600 of them stabled on Long Island.

MORE scientifically sophisticated, though esthetically less satisfying, this book is the twelve volumes of "The Golden Bough," as it were, rolled into one. Where Homer W. Smith, an eminent scientist and author of the one-time best seller "Kamongo," can emancipate himself from his materials, he speaks eloquently for the noble tradition of naturalism.

A warning to potential witnesses in the waterfront racket investigation may have been the motive behind the killing of Arnold L. Schuster, the 24-year-old salesman who helped cause the arrest of Willie Sutton, bank robber, according to one theory being pursued in police circles yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- While the Department of Agriculture says it is not proper to speak of a "potato famine," regional conditions and distribution inadequacies have brought on what the department calls "a tight situation in some areas." This will continue for a month or six weeks until the new crop comes in.

IN this beautifully conceived and executed volume, George F. Thomas of Princeton has rounded out his philosophy of spirit. In a former work, "Spirit and Its Freedom," he analyzed the activities of human spirit in general; now he turns his attention to the specific phenomena of poetry and religion.

THIS is the time when the Metropolitan Opera's bit players get their meed of credit. The season is over, and it is possible to give the figures for the number of performances sung by different members of the company.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company (The Bell System) controls virtually all of the 40 million telephones in the United States. The Western Union Telegraph Company, which handles about 200 million messages every year, has a similar monopoly in the telegraphic field.

The public is being hoodwinked every day in bars scattered throughout the metropolitan area and little is being done to stop it. An increasing number of unscrupulous tavern owners, knowing they are practically immune from punishment, are refilling empty bottles of top-quality brands with cheap, low-quality whisky. The customer then pays a premium price for a second-rate drink.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO -- The social life of both tourists and upper-class Dominicans in this city is so completely dominated by the Jaragua Hotel that it is difficult to imagine what life was like before it was built. The luxurious hostelry has specialty shops, tennis, a golf course, a swimming pool filled with tinted water, sumptuously furnished rooms, white surf breaking at the edge of its palm-studded lawns.

BOSTON, April 12 -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston reports sales in downtown Boston department and apparel stores for the three weeks ended April 5 were 14 per cent higher than in the corresponding pre-Easter period in 1951, 1 per cent higher than in the corresponding pre-Easter period in 1950, but behind the same period of 1949.

NOWHERE is it more important to hold the initiative than in the field of ideas. To be the first to present the challenge is to throw the others on the defensive. They find themselves explaining and defending and pointing out that this is not precisely what they meant. Meanwhile the original idea, true or false, takes possession and becomes not only an idea but a spur to action.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Truman's right to seize the nation's steel mills in their dispute with labor over a new wage contract will be formally challenged in the Senate here next week.
MRS. CLARK, who has worked in various Latin American countries with the Institute of Inter-American Affairs, presents in these excellent stories two picturesque aspects of South America.

When the Air Material Command at Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, published its report on Project Saucer in 1949, most newspaper men regarded it as final and relegated the "saucers" to the limbo where the sea serpent and the Loch Ness monster repose. Out of this limbo Life magazine drags the saucers again, chiefly to emphasize the possibility that they are space ships manned by interlopers from another world.

Thousands of Brooklyn residents -- young school children and their parents, high school students, merchants and educators, among them -- have embarked upon a campaign to aid the borough's cultural center, the Brooklyn Museum.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 12 -- The great mass of independent voters in the United States will decide the Presidency in 1952 and the one man who can win their votes is General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, declared here today.

VARIATIONS in the expected coloring of annual flowers when they bloom in mid-summer is, to say the least, a disappointment. When such variations occur in All-America selections, gardeners start asking why it happens in a supposedly true-breeding flower.

IN many lands today children are engaged in that Easter custom, the search for a nest of brightly colored eggs hidden in house or garden. But while this seems to be the practice wherever the holiday is observed, the dishes that traditionally come to the Easter table vary from country to country.

MANY gardeners refrain from planting a vegetable patch because they "always go away for July." They claim that "weeds will flourish and crops will go unharvested." For those who really want to enjoy the products of vegetable gardening, there are ways of getting around these obstacles.

TOKYO, April 12 -- Japan's strike in key industries, billed by labor as the greatest demonstration of its power since the early days of the occupation, fizzled out today under a combination of a Government compromise and Government firmness.

FISH in many forms -- impressionistic, fantastic, realistic and abstract -- have been a noticeably recurring motif in the decorative arts throughout this spring. Fish have been adapted to all sorts of materials, and applied to all kinds of forms. They have been shaped from bamboo shoots, or pottery, woven into tapestries, printed on textiles and paper, formed from wire or wood, or wrought of iron.

KANSAS CITY, April 12 (AP) -- Clyde Lovellette scored 31 points in leading the West All-Stars to a 72-63 victory over the East in the Shriners first benefit basketball game for crippled children's hospitals tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Responsible United States diplomatic quarters believe that the Soviet Union's latest proposals for German unification may be a step forward in the sense that Moscow now accepts at least the desirability of studying the conditions under which all-German elections might be held.
A proud little group of boys and girls sat on the Stage and in the audience of Carnegie Hall yesterday morning, where the final Young People's Concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony took place.

NEVER have there been such great advances in the control and understanding of disease as in the past fifteen years. With the discovery that plant-like organisms (molds) destroy bacteria came the era of penicillin, streptomycin, aureomycin -- weapons against nearly every bacterial infection.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C. Z. -- Although tourist traffic in Central America reaches its peak during the winter, there is such a range of climate in the countries lying between Mexico and the South American mainland that the vacation season might well be regarded as extending the year around.
The Hofstra College nine opened defense of its Metropolitan Conference championship by trouncing Brooklyn College, 15 -- 5, on the Flatbush field yesterday.

Acting Chief, Music Division, New York Public Library. IT often seems to me the word "library" is outmoded. Certainly no modern collection can confine itself to books. This is particularly true in the field of music, for the library which does not collect recordings is, to say the least, behind the times. The documentary as well as the musical value of recorded music has by now come to be generally accepted.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Dewey today approved without comment a bill that would require all physicians in the state to report to the State Health Department the name and address of any patient who appeared to be a narcotic addict.

Dr. Paul E. Steiner, University of Chicago pathologist, declared in his presidential address before the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research last night, at the Statler Hotel, that three times as many cancer victims in the United States could be cured "if present knowledge of detection, diagnosis and treatment were universally applied."
ROME, April 12 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII urged today that the world look to the risen Christ for true hopes of peace.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission, which was created by the General Assembly last January to make a final effort to bring about international atomic control and the reduction of armaments, finally got down to business this week on the first step -- the procedure to be used in taking a census of the world's armaments and armed forces.

An 18-year-old electrician's helper was booked yesterday on a homicide charge in the fatal shooting last Monday of another 18-year-old youth in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. The arrest came after the questioning of 300 youths from the Red Hook and Park Slope neighborhoods.

ST. PAUL, April 12 -- The Minneapolis Lakers had to battle right down to the closing seconds of an overtime period to defeat the New York Knickerbockers, 83 -- 79, in the first game of the final playoffs in the National Basketball Association.

THE major league baseball season will open Tuesday. If a fellow had any sense he'd let it go at that and stop short with his reputation as a prophet undented, but there are singularly silly folks in the sports writing business. They insist on opening their big mouths and deftly inserting both feet. Fearlessly, they pick pennant winners and the complete order of finish.

TABITHA, a well-brought-up Siamese kitten, was quite unprepared for her uninvited guest, Whiskers, a tiger kitten who crashed into her kitchen, ate up all her food, slept on her soft blue cushion and showed in every way that he didn't know how to get along with others.

A movement is under way to increase the price of crude oil, sponsored on the Pacific Coast by the Union Oil Company of California and east of the Rocky Mountains by independent producing organizations. A general increase of about 50 cents a barrel, roughly 20 per cent. is being sought.

TRAVEL in the Americas outside the continental limits of the United States entails border crossings, which means the traveler must prepare himself before leaving home with documents necessary to get him into some countries and to let him return to his own country.

The hearing on complaints against thirteen local ship repair concerns charged with paying over-the-ceiling wages has been rescheduled for April 23. Originally, the cases were to be heard next Tuesday.

DETROIT, April 12 -- Controls on the automobile industry's civilian operations are easing up and further relaxation is expected by many auto makers. But, say the experts, even if all restrictive regulations are removed, there is no danger the car industry will reach an over-production this year.

EVERY self-respecting American regards himself as an export on American politics; but most of us operate on the basis of cliches, impressions and dogmas which reflect imperfectly, if at all, the changing political reality. Even our best journalistic observers often stand too close to the daily detail to grasp the larger political tendencies of our time.
WYNDHAM LEWIS is the good grouser. At his best he is one of the most vital English prose writers of the first half of the twentieth century. And he is at his best at what he most thoroughly dislikes.

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 12 -- Capt. John C. Burn, pilot of the airliner that crashed in the sea here yesterday, was released from a hospital today after having been held under a police guard for several hours.

Rayon and acetate fabric prices have "hit bottom" in the current market slump and all factors point to upward revision in the near future. Only a serious break in raw material prices could cause further reduction, trade observers said last week, but they were extremely skeptical of any such developments.
A father who beat his 7-year-old son to "take the stubbornness out of him" was held yesterday on complaint of the mother on a charge of felonious assault.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Mrs. John G. Lee, president of the League of Women Voters of the United States, told today how "a real Presidential race with real issues" has made possible a national bipartisan meeting of Presidential candidates.

ROME, April 12 -- Official circles reacted strongly today to a Yugoslav note delivered to the Italian Minister in Belgrade yesterday protesting against the Italian Government's alleged support of the Committee of National Liberation in the Yugoslav zone of the Trieste Free Territory.

The value of all foreign commerce moving through New Orleans in 1951 reached a high record of $1,699,400,000, E. H. Lockenberg, general manager of the Louisiana port, reported yesterday. This represents a 35 per cent increase over 1950, he said.

THE second volume of Edward H. Carr's three-volume study of Bolshevik Russia under Lenin deals with the economic struggles of the Soviet dictatorship and the new economic organizations and controls which were emerging from them.

A new source of illumination by which materials are made to glow with cold light when an electric current passes through them was listed among a number of important recent advances in scientific research before the Chicago section of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers by Dr. C. G. Suits, General Electric director of research.

Rom Landau's "Peace May Be in Moslem Hail" (April 6) neglected to take into consideration certain factors. Racially and linguistically, the Moslem world is divided into three groups. The Arabs are Semitic.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 12 -- Fordham scored three runs in the tenth to break a 2-2 deadlock and defeat Yale, 5 -- 3, in the forty-fourth game of an old rivalry on Yale Field today.

SOME children collect odd facts with an enthusiasm that would shame a rabid philatelist. This book is for these fact-collectors as well as for young naturalists. Here author and artist show how nature anticipated some of man's most prized inventions and other ideas.

IT has been said that for the American listener the love of Viennese music is an intermediate stage in the progress from popular to classical taste. If so, a great many record-buyers are in this stage, because so many new disks are being issued to appeal to them.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association season will be opened officially on April 22 when Class A players of the district gather for one-day tournaments at the Siwanoy Country Club, Bronxville, and the Hempstead (L. I.) Country Club.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Pentagon indifference and military red tape were blamed by two Senators today for failure of the United States Army to build up a so-called "foreign legion" of alien soldiers.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., April 12 -- Representatives of the police of this village announced today that after a four-day drive they had reached their goal of $1,000 to provide artificial limbs for a legless cripple who was the victim of thievery two weeks ago.

THE big news in Soviet television circles these days is the impending start of operations of the new Kiev station, the first to be opened outside of Moscow and Leningrad. Soviet newspapers report that tests of the Kiev transmitter have been going on for some weeks, with good reception of the experimental telecasts being reported from as far as sixty miles away from the Ukrainian capital.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 12 -- Connecticut Democrats will begin next week their "boom" for Senator Brien McMahon for the Democratic nomination for President at the national convention in July. Senator McMahon has given his tacit consent to the favorite son move by Democratic leaders in this state.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 13 -- Communist truce negotiators notified the United Nations Command today that they were ready to resume secret meetings among staff officers on one of the major remaining issues on a Korean armistice -- an exchange of war prisoners in the truce.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- Economy-minded summer vacationists who yearn for a trip to Florida or the Caribbean islands will have budgeted vacations offered to them in many variations during the next few months.
ROME, April 12 -- With the inauguration of a first station in Milan this morning, Italy became the third European country to have television. The first two were Britain and France.

THE name of Captain Cook is a byword, a symbol of adventure in faraway places, but it is doubtful if many American boys and girls (or grown-ups either) have more than a vague idea as to where he actually went, what he discovered, and, least of all, the measure of his greatness.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, April 13 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, whose only son is missing in action, asked parents and wives to be proud this Easter Sunday of the men they had lost in Korea.

MITCHEL FIELD, L. I., April 12 -- Brig. Gen. Robert E. Condon, a New Yorker who was one of the founders of the American Legion, has been appointed Deputy for Reserve Affairs of the Continental Air Command here. The announcement was made today by Maj. Gen. Leon W. Johnson, commanding.

Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service, a pioneer in the training of students for U. S. diplomatic posts, will conduct a summer review program to prepare candidates for the State Department examinations in September. The program will include an optional language review at the university's Institute of Languages and Linguistics, where thirty languages are taught by electronic methods.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower pledged today to resign his commission as an officer immediately if nominated for the Presidency by the Republican party next July.

AMONG the contributing factors which make the heroine of this Southern saga such a romantic lady are green eyes, a passionate nature, a nineteenth-century divorce, presence at a murder, a love affair with a Confederate officer, another love affair with an English nobleman, and a wasting disease.

FIESTA, in Spanish, is an all-purpose word for any celebration from a children's party or drinking bout up to a national holiday with orations and parades. For the visitor to Mexico, however, a fiesta is essentially a rural fete.

In the soft glow of candlelight in the Governor's Palace at Williamsburg young Thomas Jefferson is seated at dinner with Gov. Francis Fauquier, George Wythe and Prof. William Small of the College of William and Mary.

Red Cross bloodmobile units will collect donations tomorrow and Tuesday from railroad employes in the metropolitan area in a joint effort by representatives of labor, management and the Railroad Young Men's Christian Association.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 12 (UP) -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh conceded today that he had erred in believing Iran could easily find new markets for her oil after the British owned Anglo-Iranian Oil Company was nationalized. He told parliamentary deputies the nation must "tighten its belt."

THE subject of Miss Clark's book is Rome, that city which, like God, can be patient because it is eternal; she never departs from it. Her sense of proportion and order are phenomenal, and her mind radiates from and returns to this tremendous orbit of power without losing herself in that surge and seethe of human uproar we have agreed to call movements of history.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 12 -- St Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, a landmark of Tudor-day beauty in this part of New Jersey, will celebrate its 125th anniversary on April 27.

J. DAVID STERN, who was publisher of the late Philadelphia Record, begins this unusual first novel with a narrative hook certain to catch the attention. The hero, Newton Muir, makes the headlines twice on the same afternoon: first, by breaking the world's quarter-mile track record; second, by vanquishing all the leading chess masters of New York at their own game.

NOW that the disagreeable things that had to be said about the recent season of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet have been said, it is possible to turn with a clear conscience to the pleasanter things that equally demand a voice. These have to do with the company itself and its basic character.

ONE of our favorite shrubs is the white flowering quince, Chaenomeles japonica, variety Falconet Chariot. We received our plant from the Midwest in April and planted it at once, but there is no reason why this shrub could not be set out in the fall as well as in spring.

THE prisoner of war -- and, even more so, the political prisoner -- has become a tragic hero of our time. With some estimates exceeding the 20-million mark, 1 per cent of the population of the globe currently finds itself behind barbed wire for purely ideological reasons.

LAUREL, Mo., April 12 -- G. S. Smith's Handsome Teddy, who hasn't been nominated for the Kentucky Derby, led home several hopefuls for next month's Louisville classic in the thirty-first running of the $20,000 Chesapeake Stakes at Laurel today.

IN primitive times the arrival of spring was a signal for every manner of mystic and carnal rites thanking the friendly gods for the rebirth of Nature. The evil spirits were also cajoled and threatened by rituals asking for better hunting and fishing, better crops, more children, and the minimum of droughts, floods, earthquakes and other evidences of Nature's displeasure.

Arthur W. Abbott, ice-cream manufacturer from Rye, N. Y., got the price of several thousand gallons of strawberry, chocolate and vanilla at Jamaica yesterday when his crackerjack 3-year-old colt Blue Man won the Experimental Free Handicap No. 2 and advanced another mile and a sixteenth along the trail that leads to the Kentucky Derby.
JACKSON, Miss., April 12 -- The Mississippi Legislature today authorized the state Democratic party to bolt the national party again this summer.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- While the new crop wheat deliveries hung back, most other grain contracts worked their way higher in lazy dealings on the Board of Trade today. The 1952 wheat deliveries net new seasonal lows in early trading, recovering slightly as the session progressed.

TORONTO -- A strange new situation is developing in Canada as a result of the Canadian dollar's surge in value in recent months to the point where it is actually worth more than a United States dollar.

AFTER seeing two films from South Africa within a recent month -- "Cry, the Beloved Country" and "The Magic Garden" -- American filmgoers may imagine that this unexpected source is going to produce a regular quota of unusual film material.

SAN GERMAN, P. R. -- Here in Puerto Rico the automobile can be defin 1, for all practical purposes, as a horn supported by four wheels and powered by an internal-combustion engine. The horn is enshrined in the driver's heart, and its place there is sanctified by law.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Officials guiding truce negotiations in Korea said today that an armistice probably would be agreed on fairly soon, possibly by May 1.

A display of entries in the New York City Cancer Committee's tenth annual poster and exhibit contest opened yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History with the award of prizes and trophies to winning high school students.

OMAHA, Neb., April 12 (AP) -- Spring floods, scourging seven Midwest states, had driven 10,244 families -- perhaps 30,000 to 40,000 persons -- from their homes tonight. For another 7,500 families displacement was only a matter of time, the Red Cross said.

PARIS, April 12 (AP) -- The retirement from active Army status of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was splashed as the top story in most European newspapers today. Most papers praised the retiring NATO supreme commander but few commented on his forthcoming political career.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., April 12 -- The Giants did some robust hitting against Bob Lemon and Lou Brissie today, but it was all in vain with Montia Kennedy being pelted in more ways than one when the Indians charged to victory with two runs in the ninth. The score was 3 to 2.

THE late Ida M. Tarbell used to say that San Francisco never did things by halves and was rarely reticent about either its virtues or its sins. The great graft prosecution and the events preceding it and following it, in the first decade of this century, furnished a pertinent illustration.
To a landlubber fitting-out chores may look like downright hard work. They seem the kind of drudgery that puts blisters and callouses on hands, makes muscles sore and brings charley horses.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Pirates defeated the Senators, 3 to 2, today in a cool-weather inter-league baseball game.

LONDON, April 12 -- The sweeping defeat of Conservative candidates for County Council seats in England and Wales this week set Labor spokesmen to clamoring for a new general election and proclaiming that the country, after less than six months of Tory rule, was disillusioned and ready for a change.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 12 -- Despite miserably cold and wet conditions four contests were squeezed in today to complete the season's dinghy regatta at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. It was carried over from last week-end, when there was a breeze blast.

Varied divertissements have been planned for the annual spring festival of St. James Church to be held on April 24 and 25 in the Parish House, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, for the benefit of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society. Mrs. Charles I. Morton is general chairman of the benefit committee, with Mrs. Richard S. Meredith as vice chairman.

ONCE again, the annual selection of Post stories demonstrates the high-level excellence of its contributors. Each of these twenty entries is readable down to the final gimmick; each will tell the beginning writer more about technique than he can possibly learn elsewhere.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 -- The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees has not much to show toward solving the refugee problem in the fiscal year ending June 30.

General Eisenhower, in announcing his forthcoming departure from SHAPE, cleared up one point about his status that has been much discussed, and he cleared it up with characteristic forthrightness and emphasis. He said:

It is difficult to look far ahead in times like these. You never can tell when lightning might strike. However, I believe the general outlook for organized baseball is about the same as it was a year ago. We seem to have reached norm in attendance that should not vary much.
The eight-room apartment of Mrs. James Coyle Kennedy at 1220 Park Avenue, near Ninety-fourth Street, was burglarized of $14,000 in jewels and furs yesterday, the police reported.

An Easter sky will intermittently pour cold water on the holiday plans of New Yorkers today. The wet blanket is a cloud-lined warm front being dragged across the Middle Atlantic states, and the gloomy Weather Man said the rain would continue in spells into the night.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The stabilization program -- controls, for short -- is under attack on many fronts as it comes up for enactment a third time. Congress has eighty calendar days to act before expiration of the Defense Production Act, the basis of most of the controls authority.

Two little girls, who had been awakened before sunrise yesterday to see the Statue of Liberty, knelt with their Polish-born parents a few hours later before the Easter-lily-banked altar of St. Stanislaus Roman Catholic Church, 101 East Seventh Street.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 12 -- Two more meet records were bettered in the National Amateur Athletic Union women's senior indoor swimming and diving championships today. Gail Peters, 22 years old, of Trenton, N. J., swam the 100-yard breaststroke in 1:11.7 to lower the A. A. U. record for 1:12.5, and 17-year-old Marilee Stepan, Winnetka, Ill., covered the 200-yard free-style course in 2:16.2 to clip the record of 2:16.9.

IN village after village of Southeast Asia -- on the fringe of the thick Malayan jungle, in the war-swept Red River delta of Tonkin, near the sacred golden Buddhas of Central Burma, amid Thailand's jade-colored rice fields and Bali's intricately carved Hindu temples -- a Chinese shopkeeper is busily selling soap, candles, matches and cloth to his more easy-going neighbors.
NAPLES, April 12 (UP) -- When Paolo Crescenzo returned here today he wore the same suit he had worn when he left in 1913. But his wife Angela could not recognize him.

THE author of "Winter Horse" and other stories of the outdoors here turns his attention to a familiar type -- the city boy who finds self-reliance by living close to nature. The author makes a mistake by presenting as a sissy a boy who lacks self-confidence because of a domineering father.

A FORMER British Army company commander in Burma for six wartime years cuts across race, rank and nationality in this credible first novel to show how combat long distances from the restraining ties of home affected men differently.

For the time being the threat of a strike or lockout in the steel industry, which seemed so close at this time a week ago, has been lifted. The steel workers are back on their jobs and the industry, now in Government hands, is rapidly returning to full production.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 12 -- Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, now on leave of absence from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and serving as head of the Federal Maritime Board in Washington, has been appointed dean of the School of Engineering at the institute, President James R. Killian Jr., announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Government's record in getting people put into jail for defying Congressional committees added up today to something short of spectacular. The Justice Department, which handles prosecutions, made public a tally of contempt citations that showed:

EXHIBITION games notwithstanding, the baseball season opens officially on Tuesday. Radio, as usual, will cover all games -- at home and on the road -- while television will cover all home games for the three local teams.

BOHUSLAV MARTINU, whose "Comedy on the Bridge" took the Music Critics Circle's award as the best opera to receive its premiere in New York last year, has completed the first of two more short operas that he is planning as running mates for "Comedy on the Bridge" so the three together will make a full evening's entertainment.

The progressive and humanistic tradition of German university life has been revived in the Federal Republic of Germany, Dr. Max Horkheimer, rector of the Johann Wolfgang Goethe University of Frankfurt, said yesterday.

PROOF that Florida is getting to be an all-year resort comes from statistics of the Automobile Club of New York. These show that Florida is now the destination for about 10 per cent of all routings provided to members during the spring and summer.
Once again the Army has closed the barn door after the horses have been stolen.

Anne O'Hare McCormick writes: "Nations everywhere demand change, but they are not educated to accept the conditions and cost of change. They do not understand NATO." In the same context Mrs. McCormick refers to Schuman and Adenauer as "pioneers."

BOSTON, April 12 (UP) -- Ted Williams, playing in a Red Sox line-up of rookies, brought in five runs with successive homers in two innings today as the American Leaguers beat the Braves, 12 to 7, for the first time this season in five exhibition meetings.

MESSAGE for all Easter chicks preparing this morning to try out their new finery, to the stores that sold same, and to the roosters accompanying their chicks along the Fifth Avenues: Things are looking better, regardless of the setback brought about by the upheaval in the steel industry, the telephone strike and the continuing shaky outlook abroad.

HERE is an account, by a witness who commands our respect, of what it was like to live as an ordinary citizen in Germany straight through Hitler's war. Elisabeth Hoemberg, of course, is not precisely an ordinary German citizen.

When James Landi was the varsity center on the Notre Dame football team back in the mid-1930s, he was also one of the ablest and most inquisitive students in chemistry. He was so inquisitive, in fact, that during one experiment he blew out a good-size portion of the laboratory near South Bend, Ind.

ALBANY, Calif., April 12 (UP) -- Lights Up, owned by C. H. Jones and sons of Long Beach, Calif., won the fifth running of the $25,000-added Golden Gate Mile today as Jockey Ralph Neves captured his fourth stake victory in five starts at Golden Gate Fields.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

FROM the first scilla blooming in late March to the last tulip in late May, bulbs offer a wealth of cut flower material. Except for the crocus, which has no stem to speak of, and does not last long indoors, and some of the very short-stemmed species tulips, all spring-flowering bulbs can be used effectively in the house.

There is good news from the Wheat Belt. This year's crop of winter wheat will be the third largest in our history, according to present indications. Together with the prospective spring wheat crop the indicated winter wheat supply should give us one of our most bountiful harvests.

The new series of tests to which tactical atomic bombs are being subjected in Nevada are probably of military importance, but, like many another physicist, Dr. David R. Inglis, who worked at Los Alamos, N. M., during the war and is now on the staff of the Argonne National Laboratory, views them with a skeptical eye.
A large and powerful segment of business is out to junk consumer credit controls once and for all.

BOOKS are great or not by more tests than Arthur Mizener indicates in his article "What Makes Great Books Great." Certainly his amoral concept of "moral insight" is almost meaningless, for he omits a scale of values as prerequisite to his judgment.
Ten girls will show up for the Easter Parade today wearing the same hat -- and when it's all over they'll still be speaking to one another.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 12 -- At the Moscow International Economic Conference the Russians offered to negotiate a trade agreement to give Brazil 1,000,000 tons of badly needed wheat in exchange for Brazilian products, including rice, cotton, rubber and cocoa, the newspaper Ultima Hora reported today.
MILWAUKEE, April 12 -- Ned Day of West Allis, Wis., became today the thirteenth man elected by bowling writers to the American Bowling Congress hall of fame.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., April 12 -- Shipments of tin ore from Indonesia, expected in about three months, will preclude the scheduled shutdown of the Longhorn Tin Smelter here next month, an official of the company said today.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Ellis Arnall, Director of Price Stabilization, ruled tonight that the names of all price violators must be made available for publication.

IT begins to look as though the London Coliseum has passed permanently under American rule. This huge theatre has been the home in turn of "Annie Get Your Gun," "Mister Roberts," "Kiss Me, Kate" and "Call Me Madam" and the scenes at the opening of the last named seemed to suggest that there is little immediate prospect of the place being handed back to Britain.

AMONG the evergreen shrubs at my place on Long Island, none is more attractive or more interesting the year around than Mahonia aquifolium, the Oregon or holly grape. The spiny, glossy foliage somewhat resembles holly, but the similarity ends there, for mahonia is a member of the barberry family and its manner of growth is entirely different from that of holly.

THE artistic temperament of the gardenia plant is highly overrated. Exotic though this fragrant blossom may seem, the plant's care and feeding do not demand countless days of attention, nights of worry.

LONDON, April 8 -- At a meeting of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers tonight, Dr. Norman H. Mackworth explained how excessive heat, cold, fatigue, noise and confusion affected the working ability of groups of sailors tested for stress by the Medical Research Council.

Total revenues of forty-nine iron and steel companies, representing 92 per cent of the industry's steel ingot production, rose 22 per cent in 1951 from the level of the preceding year, but their combined net profit declined nearly 13 per cent as taxes jumped 61 per cent and expenses increased 25 per cent.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- While there is a feeling of pessimism here about business conditions, members of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago believe business will be the same or better for the remainder of the year, an association survey indicated.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico this year confidently expects the greatest spring and summer tourist seasons of its comparatively brief history as a goal for American travelers. The tourist industry is already the country's biggest single dollar earner and the Government is sparing no pains to expand it further.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 -- The shutdown in the steel industry last week brought the ingot rate -- on an estimated basis -- down 51 points to 51 per cent of rated capacity. Unless confusion becomes more prevalent this week the steel rate should snap back to at least somewhere in the 90's as an average for this week.

A mother who had just given birth to her third daughter was fatally injured by an explosion in an anesthetic tank at Cumberland Hospital, a city hospital in Brooklyn, on Saturday, it was officially disclosed yesterday.

Studies pointing to a definite correlation between the growth rate of cancer and the patient's emotional make-up, indicating that measures to relieve inner tensions may slow down the cancer, and thus prolong life, were described here yesterday.

I am sincerely stunned by the President's statement that he will not be a candidate for re-election. For it is my opinion that we have been fortunate to live during the Presidency of one of the most active, honest, yet humble men ever to achieve so high a post. In scanning the political field I can find no one, other than Mr. Truman, who could do justice to the most important office in the land.
The number of new art exhibitions opening this week is proof that the season in museums and galleries still is in full swing.

General Eisenhower's decision to resign the Supreme Command of the Atlantic Defense Force is regarded from different angles in Europe and the United States. Here it is related almost entirely to the electoral contest. Across the sea it is primarily an event in the life of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 13 -- Rain washed out the final game of the Giants-Indians transcontinental tour today and sent the National League champions back to the Polo Grounds to open the championship season with a disappointing exhibition record and a couple of holes in the line-up.

An apartment house for twenty families on lot 25 by 100 feet at 26 Cook Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the 26 Cook Street Corporation to the Lounat Realty Corporation for investment in a deal negotiated by the Lane Realty Company of Forest Hills, brokers. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -David S. Ingalls, manager of Senator Robert A. Taft's Presidential campaign, said today that the Ohioan had polled more votes in the five Republican primaries already held than had all his opponents combined.

On page 173 of the recently published "Mr. President" we are afforded a brief glimpse of Harry S. Truman's much discussed experience in the retail business just after World War I. In the Army, where he served as an artillery officer, Mr. Truman had for his canteen manager a non-com by the name of Eddie Jacobson.

The American Arbitration Association said yesterday that the Wage Stabilization Board's handling of the steel dispute indicated the need for re-examining the worth of tripartite boards in deciding labor disputes.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur declared again last night that he was not a candidate for any public office. He advised voters in the May 16 Oregon primary election to "avoid wasting their votes on me."

An audience of 1,500 filled Town Hall last night for the program given by Shoshana Damari, Israeli singer who has been appearing in New York night clubs. Her accompanist was Moshe Wilensky, who composed many of the singer's modern selections and arranged most of her traditional ones.

ROME, April 13 -- A crowd of 120,000 persons assembled in St. Peter's Square cheered Pope Pius XII this morning when he spoke from the central balcony of the Basilica and fell devoutly to its knees to receive his apostolic blessing.

Against a background of gray, drizzly weather yesterday, this year's Easter bonnets seemed unusually small, white and untrimmed. Flower bedecked creations were definitely in the minority, and many women preferred neat little veils in lieu of hats to keep short curls in place amid cold crosstown winds.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Federal Communications Commission today lifted its three-and-a-half-year-old ban on the construction of new television stations, clearing the way for the long-awaited expansion of the industry.
The major work on the fifth concert of the Choral Masterwork Series that Robert Shaw and the Collegiate Chorale are giving in Carnegie Hall was Bernard Rogers' "The Passion."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 13 (UP) -- Winds of high velocity leapfrogged across a five-county area of central and southeastern Ohio today flattening buildings and causing widespread damage.

A "constant reader," I am impressed by the persistence, though not by the logic, with which THE TIMES crusades for compulsory automobile liability insurance. You have heretofore editorially and summarily dismissed arguments against such compulsion, based on experience and made by a united casualty insurance industry.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 13 -The policy crisis among Brazil's generals, which recently cost Maj. Gen. Newton Estillac Leal his post as War Minister has become acute again and is threatening to spread into the political sphere.

The sun rose officially at 5:21 A. M. yesterday over the wet, empty streets of New York. But to the brightly-dressed early-risers who overflowed the 6,200 seats at Radio City Music Hall an hour and a half later, the sunrise was dramatically symbolized by a rose-colored glow over the stage that brightened slowly to fill the enormous hall with the brilliance of a fully risen sun.

The Philadelphia Nationals gained the verdict over the German Hungarians, 2 to 1, in the Eastern final of the National Challenge Cup competition, sponsored by the United States Soccer Football Association, at Metropolitan Oval yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The record total of $41,086,275 that Seventh Day Adventists in the United States and Canada contributed to denominational enterprises in 1951 resulted from increased membership and "a general conviction" that the church should make a maximum effort, a spokesman said today.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 13 (UP) -- Military personnel, atomic scientists and news reporters began streaming into this desert gambling resort today for the first "public" test of an atomic weapon.

Forty years ago today the new British liner Titanic, halfway across the Atlantic Ocean on her maiden voyage to New York, struck an iceberg and sank with 1,500 of the 2,200 festive people who had confidently boarded the first and largest "unsinkable" ship four days earlier at Southampton.
YONKERS, April 13 -- F. B. Mollica's Musician and Grant Hodgins' Prince Adios loom as favorites to win sections of the Inaugural Pace, opening-night split feature at the Yonkers Raceway Tuesday.
A settlement covering 16,000 Ohio telephone strikers was at hand early today. Union officials expressed "cautious optimism" that other Bell System walkouts would end quickly.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -President Truman observed Easter today by attending early service at St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church and then laid a wreath in honor of the 209th anniversary of Thomas Jefferson's birth.

In a final that brought together former members of American Olympic squads, both of whom learned the rudiments of the sport in Hungary, Dr. Tibor Nyilas of Salle Santelli defeated his clubmate, George Worth, to capture the metropolitan saber championship at the New York Athletic Club last night.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- Prospects for obtaining an international cotton agreement will receive top priority in discussions at the eleventh session of the International Cotton Advisory Committee in Rome next month.

Shares of the first open-end mutual fund organized in America to invest in the securities of Canadian natural resource companies have just been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was announced yesterday by Frank L. Valenta Co., Inc., sponsors and managers of Natural Resources of Canada Fund, Inc.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 13 (AP) -- Arthur Wall Jr., 28-year-old unattached professional playing out of Honesdale, Pa., came home with a four-under-par 67 today to take the 54-hole lead of the $10,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament by one stroke.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration announced today that it would stop the issuing of receipts for Government insurance premiums after Aug. 1 to cut expenses.

AMSTERDAM, April 13 -- Refusal of Belgium to accept a Dutch invitation to a monetary meeting here of the Benelux Union caused great astonishment mainly because the reason given that "Dutch recovery is largely accidental" is considered contrary to the facts.

The lifting of the freeze by the Federal Communications Commission on the construction of new television stations was hailed last night by network broadcasters as the first step toward breaking a serious bottleneck in video programming.

The only film scheduled to open this week is "Aaron Slick From Punkin Crick," the William Perlberg-George Seaton musical comedy version in Technicolor of the stage melodrama of the same name, at the Globe on Friday. The Paramount offering stars Alan Young, Dinah Shore and Robert Merrill, Metropolitan Opera baritone.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 13 -- The mounting Missouri River flood brought fresh destruction and misery today to the three-state area surrounding Sioux City. There was an ominous certainty of worse to come.

Sophisticated citizens within sight of the air lanes between New York and Washington are soon to be startled by a ghostly apparition from another era. A thirty-five-year-old biplane resplendent with khaki paint and American Expeditionary Force insignia is being made ready for a 230-mile flight to the nation's capital.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The deadlock in the three-way steel dispute is still primarily a question of price and no headway is being made toward a solution, informed sources said today.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The American Red Cross estimated today that 19,349 families in eight states had been affected by the Missouri River flood.
MANILA, April 13 (UP) -- An American chief of the Communist-led Hukbalahap guerrillas was marched into Manila today to go on trial for his life on charges of murder and arson.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 13 -The campaign of Senator Robert A. Taft's Ohio delegate-candidates to the Republican National Convention has become involved with that of his brother, Charles P. Taft, for the Republican nomination for Governor.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 13 (UP) -- America's women swimmers appear ready to equal or improve on their 1948 Olympic record. They won four of seven events at London.
Stars of the Broadway hits, "South Pacific" and "The King and I" satirized their roles in the productions early yesterday morning at the Astor Hotel.
PROVO, Utah, April 13 (AP) -- The body of Howard Hansen, former star halfback at the University of California at Los Angeles, was brought down today from the mountain where he perished.

Forty years ago today the immaculate, fresh-painted hull of the newest and largest ocean liner afloat glided through the calm dark waters of the North Atlantic. Her 2,200 passengers and crew men, secure in the knowledge they were traveling on the safest vessel ever built, reflected on the frail, wooden craft that not so long ago had feared the course they now enjoyed.

A radio-telephone system is being installed to protect the city's water supply in the metropolitan area and at the 1,000-square-mile Catskill and Croton watersheds, the New York Office of Civil Defense and the Department of Water Supply announced yesterday.

MADRID, April 13 -- The incorporation of Tangier into Spanish Morocco appeared today to be one of the major objectives of the Spanish Government. This emerged from a week's officially inspired press campaign consisting mainly of bitter criticism of France and Britain for their opposition to Spanish aspirations.

A dollar-a-day increase in hospital charges for persons detained on medical grounds on arrival here has aroused indignation, it became known yesterday, among the major steamship lines that must foot the bills.

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 -Having so impressed a visiting Republican United States Senator with India's capacity to raise her living standards with a little help that the Senator invited him to tell his story in Washington, Sudhir Ghosh, director of Faridabad, a community development project near here, is leaving for the United States tomorrow.

JERSEY CITY, April 13 -- A spokesman for Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City, Hudson County Democratic leader, labeled today as "completely without foundation" a charge by Walter E. Edge, former Republican Governor, that New Jersey Democratic leaders, particularly in Hudson County, were "instructing their henchmen to pull the lever for Taft" in the primary election Tuesday.
Basic Army policies are, in large part, responsible for the deterioration of G-2, or Army intelligence, since World War II.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 13 (AP) -- Citizens Utilities Company will ask stockholders' approval May 13 for a proposed three-for-one split of the company's common stock.
CHICAGO, April 13 (UP) -- The White Sox topped the Cubs, 10 to 8, in the first game of an exhibition double-header today, but darkness curtailed the afterpiece with the Cubs leading, 8 to 1.

SANTA FE, N. M., April 13 -- The cut by the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives in funds for the long-range Navajo-Hopi rehabilitation program for the fiscal year 1952-53 has met with vigorous protest on the part of Indian leaders and others interested in Indian affairs here in the Southwest.

A four-engine Constellation plane owned by the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines took off sometime between 9 P. M. Saturday and 8 A. M. yesterday on an unscheduled flight from the passenger service desk of the airline company at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
CHICAGO, April 13 -- It may not be readily apparent but churches, besides being important to the moral and spiritual life of the country, also make an important contribution to business.

With the passing of Easter one realizes that summer isn't far away. And so, appropriately enough, Patterns of The Times today brings two advance patterns to assist you in getting your summer wardrobe under way. Both are sunback fashions.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 13 (AP) -- The twenty-second Institute for Education by Radio today announced winners of awards in its annual review of educational radio and television programs. The institute, sponsored by Ohio State University, will meet here next Thursday through Sunday.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 13 -- Over a constitutional crisis far graver than it looks, the two major parties of white South Africa are desperately maneuvering toward a great prize: presumed control of this Union for many years to come.

JERUSALEM, April 13 (AP) -- The carillon atop Jerusalem's Y. M. C. A. tower pealed joyous Easter hymns today, proclaiming to the thousands of Christians in this city, where the life of Jesus Christ came to an end -- and a new beginning -- that He had risen.

Four thousand five hundred persons, two thousand of them standing shoulder to shoulder in chapels, ambulatories and the Fifth Avenue porch, crowded St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as Cardinal Spellman pontificated at the solemn mass of the Feast of the Resurrection, most important feast day on the Christian calendar.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 13 (AP) -- So far as the children at the main Red Cross evacuation center here were concerned the Missouri River flood was a matter of minor importance today. They attended an Easter party given by the Sioux City Junior Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period April 5 to 11 are given in the appended tabulation:

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The following table shows, state by state, the number of television stations now on the air, the total possible under today's channel allocations and the number of applications awaiting action:

LONDON, April 13 -- The stock markets developed remarkable cheerfulness last week because of growing confidence in the effectiveness of the Government's policy for restoring the financial and economic position.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -Paramount Pictures Corporation has purchased a 50 per cent interest in the Vistascope Corporation of America, of which Sol Lesser, veteran film producer and theatre investor, is president.
Quietness prevailed in the foreign exchange market last week, observance of the religious holidays here and abroad accounting for light dealings and narrow price movements.

In commemoration of the founding, more than sixty years ago, of the Pan American Union, today is being celebrated here and throughout this hemisphere as Pan-American Day. It is a day for the exchange of ideas and for the exchange of felicitations. The sixty-odd years have been a period of growth and change, and they have been, in the field of understanding, a period of great progress.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 13 -President Truman's Point Four program for technical assistance to underdeveloped countries, announced in January, 1949, will get going for the first time on a fairly substantial scale in the Arab states and in Iran this coming summer.

DETROIT, April 13 (UP) -- Gordie Howe rapped home a pair of goals and Goalie Terry Sawchuk racked up his third shutout in professional hockey's play-offs tonight as Detroit moved within a single game of the Stanley Cup with a 3-to-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens before 14,018 spectators at Olympia.

In "Man, Money and Goods,"* Prof. John S. Gambs of Hamilton College has made an attractive bundle of the history of economic thought, wrapped up in language that even the uninitiated should be able to understand.
