Holiday travel in and out of the city yesterday reached peak conditions in spite of an early morning drizzle and leaded skies throughout the day.

BOSTON, April 13 -- New England industry, a subject of concern for economists, business men and politicians ever since the area's first stream was harnessed by man, gained a reprieve last week in the woolen and worsted situation.
CHICAGO, April 13 -- Hotpoint, Inc., disclosed today it is shipping large quantities of major jet engine components from its plants in Cicero, Ill.
PHILADELPHIA. April 13 (AP) -The Phillies swept their two-game city series with the Athletics by combining good pitching with timely hitting for a one-sided 14-5 victory today.

It is distressing to think that there may be people who will be misled by some current moves of Soviet Russian policy. False optimism and vain hopes may likely be aroused by the apparent open-mindedness and amicability to which Russian leaders are at present lending themselves.

Premier Mossadegh now admits that in nationalizing the oil industry of Iran and expelling the experienced personnel which had made it a gold mine for his country he has made at least two mistakes. One mistake has been his boast that Iran could operate the industry with its own technical talent.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- Television is the product of many minds of many lands, and scientists are endeavoring to make it even better.

ACCORDING to the experts, the attractive fights are those between operators with contrasting styles, the consummate boxer against the slugger who can knock 'em out with one punch. When the boxer is a champion of the world and the slugger is a former champion, then it becomes obvious that this must be the dream match.

ST. LOUIS, April 13 (AP) -- The Harlem Globetrotters wound up their coast-to-coast exhibition tour with the College All-Americans tonight by taking their eleventh victory in sixteen games -- a 68-56 affair.

Communicants of three store-front churches in Harlem in as many religious processions, each headed by a crucifer with a simple wooden cross, converged after their Easter parade yesterday afternoon upon a vacant lot at 325 East 101st Street, but recently cleared of trash, and held an Easter service before a flower-bedecked altar.

LONDON, April 13 -- For most of Britain this was one of the warmest Easter Sundays since the war. In the south, temperatures were in the seventies, the sun shone almost uninterruptedly and nearly everyone spent most of the day out in the open.

PARIS, April 13 -- The Rumanian Communist Government has ordered the enforced evacuation of "unproductive people" from Bucharest, and mass deportations are under way in the once gay capital that formerly called itself "the Paris of the East."
CHICAGO, April 13 -- A University of Chicago professor was accused by the police today of kicking in four plate-glass windows as he strolled down the street.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 14 (AP) -- United States Sabre jet pilots destroyed or damaged twelve Soviet-built MIG-15's Easter Sunday in a series of air battles over northwest Korea.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., April 13 (AP) -- Betty Jameson of San Antonio shot a 3-over-par 74 today to win the $1,500 Corpus Christi women's professional golf tournament.

BOSTON, April 13 -- In a bristling reply to a speech made last Monday by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, the Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, today went to the defense of the parochial school.
The Associated Press yesterday announced its entry into the field of television news-on-film.

Another month rolls by and, in passing, drops off another report card. In most respects it is a highly satisfactory report card, with A's and B's neatly written into little squares where may appear any one of the first five or six letters of the alphabet.
The chimes of St. Patrick's Cathedral heralded Easter yesterday for the first time in six years.

A program of contemporary music was presented yesterday afternoon at the Circle in the Square by the Collegium Musicum. Bernard Wagenaar's Sonatina for "Cello and Piano (1934), Norman Dello Joio's Flute Trio, Bela Bartok's "Ten Short Duets" and Paul Hindemith's "The Four Temperaments" made up the program.
The Easter Parade up Fifth Avenue now has become a television program. As might be expected, video rose to the occasion in the way it knows best.

Too many waiters are "neither beef nor mutton -- flesh, fowl or good red herring." This was the sharp indictment recently issued by three of Manhattan's old-fashioned table attendants against the "unseasoned newcomers" to their fraternity.
ROME, April 13 (AP) -- Following is a translation of the Easter address in Italian by Pope Pius XII:
Privately owned American-flag merchant ocean-going vessels of 1,000 gross tons or over totaled 1,286 as of April 1, the National Federation of American Shipping reported yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 13 (AP) -Senator Connally's decision gave Texas' Governor, Allan Shivers, another chance to say whether he would try for the Senate post. "Not that I know of." Mr. Shivers said tonight, however. "I'm running for Governor."
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- Following is a list of the channels that the Federal Communications Commission is allocating to cities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

Controller Lazarus Joseph is making an all-out effort to turn up sufficient new city revenue to make unnecessary the imposition of the proposed monthly fee of $5 for overnight parking in the public streets.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 13 -- A significant addition to the safety factor in commercial and military aviation is a new type of radar unit for surveying the surface of airports. It is being developed here for the Air Force by Airborne Instruments Laboratory, Inc.

LONDON, April 13 -- A message from William Z. Foster, chairman of the Communist party of the United States describing General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as "a reactionary jingo-militarist and an aggressive imperialist" brought 900 delegates to the British Communist convention to their feet cheering for more than a minute today.

Seven thousand worshipers filled every available seat and stood shoulder-to-shoulder in the side aisles of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at the Easter service of holy communion yesterday. It was presided over by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 13 -- The sailing dinghy skippers at the Larchmont Yacht Club today jammed through nine races in their last session of their long winter series.
TOKYO, Monday, April 14 (AP) -General Headquarters communique 1219 for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 6 A. M. Monday (4 P. M. Sunday, Eastern standard time):

The feast of the Resurrection, Christendom s most important festival, was marked with prayer and praise yesterday as preachers emphasized the central theme of their faith: that Jesus Christ rose from the dead and became "truly the Son of God."
CHICAGO, April 13 -- Independent retail food stores plan to triple their frozen foods business in the next five years, a survey released today by the National Association of Retail Grocers indicates.
FRANKFURT, Germany, April 13 -- Cpl. Alexander S. Czarnecki of Ozone Park, Queens, was reported back in American hands today after almost sixteen months behind the Iron Curtain.

BOSTON, April 13 (AP) -- Faye Throneberry, rookie centerfielder, broke up a 1-1 pitching duel with a seventh-inning homer into the right field stands today to give the Red Sox a 2-1 victory over the Braves in the final game of the city series.

All attendance records at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, were broken yesterday at three morning services, according to the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, the pastor. More than 5,000 persons attended services at 8:15, 10 and 11:30 A. M.

TOKYO, Monday, April 14 -- Resumption within a few days of secret discussions on an exchange of prisoners in the Korean war seemed likely today. The Communists were waiting for the United Nations to set the date for a meeting on this major issue of the armistice negotiations.

The Metropolitan Opera did its Easter parading yesterday aboard a train bound for Cleveland, where the company will open its annual spring tour today. Seven weeks in duration, the tour is two weeks longer than the equivalent jaunt last year.

This may be crushing news to magnolia and mint julep enthusiasts, but Southerners are the country's greatest summer consumers of iced tea with meals. This is but one salient finding of a recent Elmo Roper survey of tea-drinking habits of the populace during the season of romance and heat waves.

OMAHA, Neb., April 13 -- The Missouri River, dealing devastation in one of its most ravaging floods, struck Sioux City, Iowa, with intensified vigor today and put the levees protecting Omaha and Council Bluffs, Iowa, to test.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income for its domestic and Canadian subsidiaries of $5,459,273 for the fiscal year ended Dec. 29, 1951. This was equal to $2.33 a share on the firm's outstanding common stock, and compares with a consolidated net of $6,565,041, or $2.67 a common share, in the preceding fiscal year.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 13 (AP) -A tense and shaky Easter calm prevailed today as Bolivia's new Government, installed after a bloody three-day revolt, waited for its leader to return from exile in Argentina

HOUSTON, Tex., April 13 -Plans to erect a multimillion-dollar plant at its Baytown Refinery near here to manufacture paraxylene, a raw material for the new miracle fiber dacron, were announced here today by the Humble Oil and Refining Company.

Small pieces of furniture together with decorative accessories are included in a new group of wrought iron objects on view in the newly opened second floor galleries of We Moderns, Inc., 227 East Sixty-seventh Street. The items are comparatively moderate in price.

Helen Keller, 71-year-old deaf and blind writer, left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, last night for Cairo and a three-month tour of schools, workshops and institutions for the blind in the Middle East.
Groundbreaking for the $7,439.-! 000 Mariner's Harbor Houses, the first Staten Island project under the Federal Housing Act of 1949, is scheduled for 11 A. H. tomorrow.

The last of three concerts by the Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble, a group of chamber music players from the ranks of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, was given on Saturday evening at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The first mass check-up on Government employes through financial questionnaires has turned up wrongdoing by about one out of every 500 employes checked.

After a brief ownership, Louis J. Glickman, operator, has resold the four-story commercial building on plot 75 by 125 feet at 338-42 East Thirty-fifth Street, southwest corner of First Avenue, to an investing client of Thayer Gilbert, attorneys, for cash over mortgage financing of $300,000.

" It would be heart-warming and soul-inspiring if all Christians, both Roman Catholic and Protestant, could have celebrated Easter together in some giant union service," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday in his Easter sermon at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
ST. PAUL, April 13 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers dumped the Minneapolis Lakers, 80 to 72, tonight to even the final play-off series for the national basketball association title at one-all.

A new collection of glass and ceramic accessories with characteristics as varied as their points of origin may be found at the newly opened Chantal Art, 279 Park Avenue. Although the largest number of pieces has been imported from Italy, there are interesting objects from Germany, Austria, Belgium and Denmark as well.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York defeated Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires for the fourth time in a row early yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club. Reshevsky won in thirty-two moves. This wholly unexpected sequence of triumphs is causing wonderment in chess circles and consternation among the many friends the South American has made here.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 13 (UP) -- A decorated World War II officer said today he had been threatened with a five-year prison term for refusing to fly for his country again.

It was with surprise, not unmixed with indignation, that I read a letter by Edmund O. Austin in which he suggests what amounts to interference by the Government (through the Voice of America) in the internal affairs of the Union of South Africa. Such concern by representatives of the Government, however well meant, has in the past always been resented and has often proved disastrous, as, for example, the Braden fiasco in Argentina.

American Indians face the threat of armed searches, seizures and arrest without warrant in Indian Bureau legislation now before Congress, the Association on American Indian Affairs warned in a statement made public here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -Farmers' production expenses are expected to go up about 5 or 6 per cent this year and be the highest on record, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

With the announcement of his resignation from SHAPE General Eisenhower formally became a full-fledged candidate, and the Republicans of New Jersey have the chance in tomorrow's primary to give him his first triumphant send-off in that capacity.

TRENTON, April 13 -- A final check today by workers for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower indicated that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio might take at least twelve of the twenty-eight Republican organization candidates for district delegates in Tuesday's Presidential preferential primary.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Civic leaders who head the Chicago Crime Commission and the Big Nineteen Crime Committee criticized today police and state's attorney's investigators who are "just going alone" while a probable motive in the Charles Gross slaying remains neither proved nor disproved.

A biography of the Italian composer, Giacomo Puccini, by his close friend, Father Dante del Fiorentino, will be published on April 21 by Prentice-Hall, entitled "Immortal Bohemian." Father Dante, who was Puccini's curate and counselor in Lucca, presents many facets of the composer's personality.
Easter came to New York yesterday under lowering skies and was celebrated with characteristic, if disparate, pageantry.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Tom Connally of Texas, veteran chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, announced tonight that he did not "desire" to be a candidate for re-election.

The Soviet Union has made tremendous progress toward forming an integrated trading bloc with Eastern Europe and Communist China, data released in connection with the recent Moscow International Economic Conference indicate.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 13 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami upset Vic Seixas of Philadelphia today to win the men's singles of the fourth annual Good Neighbor tennis tournament, 6 -- 4, 8 -- 6, 9 -- 7.

A group of five hand-screened, original wallpapers in clear, definite colors, including the present popular mauve, royal blue and terra cotta tones, are now available through decorators at Richard E. Thibaut, 44 East Fifty-third Street.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Abba Eban, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, told 20,000 Israel bond purchasers in the Chicago Stadium tonight that his nation's economic independence was most important for the cause of the world democracy because "Israel is the only nation in the Middle East where representative government rules."

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 13 (UP) -- A Puerto Rican district attorney charged today that passengers aboard the Pan American Airways DC-4 in which fifty-two persons died Friday had received no warning from the crew that the plane was crashing.

Unionized cafeteria and dining hall employes at Columbia University threatened yesterday to strike at 5 A. M. tomorrow in a dispute over union recognition. A union spokesman said 800 watchmen, dormitory maids and maintenance workers would refuse to cross picket lines when the strike began.

ZURICH, April 13 -- A meeting was held here last week of twenty-four leading European bankers. The event marked the private semi-annual conference of members of the International Institute for a study of the banking business.

Religious prejudice is a challenge to a free world and all Americans should unite in a common effort to fight intolerance, Roger W. Straus, co-chairman of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, said last night.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Grain futures reached a level the latter part of last week which encouraged more buying resistance. The steel situation tended to make traders chary and many remained on the sidelines. Wheat crop news was favorable on the whole, but, with new crop wheat futures as much as 15 cents below the expected 1952 loan level, there was much caution on the selling side.

Parks Commissioner Robert Moses will soon seek the enactment of a local law designed to curb vandalism in the city's parks and playgrounds, the Park Association of the City of New York announced yesterday.
" They've robbed me of a secret I kept for a long time, my age," Mrs. Carolyn Lind Bull said rather wistfully yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -Senator Russell B. Long, Louisiana Democrat, today ordered a Senate investigation of the impact of alleged big business monopoly practices on smaller and weaker competitors. He said his subcommittee on monopoly would open the inquiry April 23 to show:
From now on it's official. The Yankees and Dodgers cleared the decks yesterday at the Stadium.

Performers -- whose business it is to provide the color, the splash and the thrills for the patrons of the tanbark arena -- find themselves thrilled at the prospect of appearing for the first time with the Big Show and also beholding the wonders of New York.

What are the essentials of a long-range financial program for New York City, to be worked out before the State Legislature convenes early in January, 1953? It is not too soon for all of us, citizens and taxpayers, city officials and state officials, to begin thinking about this question.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A Kansan whose farm was washed away in the disastrous 1951 floods will see a prosperous $50,000 farm rise in its stead.

A lower-court ruling blocking the proposed merger of the Congregational Christian Churches with the Evangelical and Reformed Church was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.
The annual pamphlet report of the Chicago Great Western Railway Company yesterday showed a net income of $2,115,214 after taxes and other charges, on operating revenues of $34,136,933.

NEWARK, April 14 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, making a last-minute bid for votes on the eve of the New Jersey Presidential preference primary, made a whirlwind tour of populous northern counties of the state today. He wound up his day with a rally here tonight at the Roseville Armory.

With the Japanese peace treaty ratified and about to go into effect, an estimated 100,000 Japanese assembled in a park in Tokyo on Sunday to express thanks to the United States for the considerate treatment and the many benefits extended to their nation. There have been numerous official expressions of Japanese gratitude, in particular by Premier Yoshida.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Chicago area television set manufacturers will not feel the full effect of the Federal Communications Commission's lifting of the freeze on new television station construction and allocation of frequency assignments until the third quarter, a survey of the industry indicated today.
BONN, Germany, April 14 -- William H. Draper Jr., United States representative to the North Atlantic Council, flew here today for a conference with John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner.

LONDON, April 14 -- The Union of Shop Distributive and Allied Workers, one of the "Big Six" of Britain's Trades Union Council, adopted a resolution today attacking the Conservative Government's economic policy. The resolution was approved almost without dissent by the 1,000 delegates representing 350,000 members at the annual conference at Margate.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 14 -- The Mississippi River pushed farther into congested residential and factory areas here today in the worst flood ever recorded in this city. The water was still rising, with the crest not due until Thursday.
Moderate but significant dollar volume gains were recorded by the city's major department stores in pre-Easter sales, trade sources reported yesterday.

Arturo Toscanini gave a party for the men of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra and their wives at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx, yesterday, to mark the conclusion of his fifteenth season at the head of this ensemble that was created for him.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., April 14 -- Three topflight air officers from Turkey today visited the Republican Aviation Corporation plant here, where the F-84G Thunderjet fighter plane, now in combat in Korea, is built. Turkey, as one of the member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, has already taken delivery of an undisclosed number of the swift jet fighters.

A rare African nerve virus has been used to treat deep internal cancers in twenty-six patients at the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, according to the annual progress report of the institution made public here yesterday.

BRUNSWICK, Me., April 14 (AP) -- Five of the ten-member crew perished today in the flaming wreckage of a crippled patrol plane that crashed in a mist in woods at the edge of the United States naval air station here.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- "Who else is there?" Democratic leaders, referring to Governor Stevenson of Illinois, have been asking each other since President Truman said he would not accept renomination. They asked it with full awareness that Senators Russell, Kefauver and Kerr were declared candidates, that Senator McMahon was about to be proposed in Connecticut, that Vice President Barkley might announce and that there is a boomlet for Speaker Sam Rayburn.
Colonial traditions long maintained by the St. Nicholas Society of New York were observed at the annual ball of the organization held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

DETROIT, April 14 -- Showing regal forbearance, Queen Juliana of the Netherlands and her husband, Prince Bernhard, submitted to a twenty-minute American-style press conference here today that broke up in a bedlam of popping flashbulbs.

Between showers yesterday gardeners at the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park planted an espaliered pear tree in the herb garden of the Bonnefont Cloister. An espalier is a railing or trellis on which fruit trees or shrubs are trained flat. The gardeners also planted in a little pot a precious seed -- one of three -- of the Mandragora, or mandrake. The pear tree and seeds have just been acquired.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Dewey today vetoed on constitutional grounds a bill designed to curb publication of "objectionable" comic books. The measure would have made it a misdemeanor to publish or "comic" books or other books, pamphlets or magazines dealing with fictional deeds of crime, bloodshed or lust that might incite minors to violence or immorality.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (UP) -- Gil Turner, unbeaten Philadelphia welterweight, scored a seventh round technical knockout over Chico Varona of Havana tonight for his twenty-fifth knockout in a string of thirty-one victories.

BOSTON, April 14 -- It will be a battle of southpaws tomorrow when the Dodgers and Braves open the National League campaign here. Preacher Roe, a 22-3 star for the Brooks last year, will go against Warren Spahn, 22-14.

Willful destruction of property in the parks is an old, continuing problem that is always with us. But today, thanks to the Park Association of the City of New York, a new remedy is proposed that bears promise of curbing such vandalism by bringing responsibility home to the young offenders and their parents.

Production of sports shirts during February continued to increase at the expense of dress shirts, according to average weekly cutting figures announced yesterday by the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers Weekly. Cuttings of shirts in February totaled 385,300 units, compared with 420,500 in the corresponding 1951 month.

With "an indicated insolvency of approximately $140,000," largely caused by the bail-jumping of five top Communists, the affairs of the Bail Fund of the Civil Rights Congress of New York have been turned over to the State Attorney General by the State Banking Department for liquidation.

Business men are slowing up in settling their accounts because of the much higher income tax bite of March 15, according to the National Association of Credit Men. This tax drain has already caused an increase in commercial borrowing.
Richard M. Crooks was nominated yesterday to succeed himself as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange. The election for members of the board is to be held on May 12.
Dick Eichhorn's relief hurling enabled St. John's to triumph over City College by 4 -- 2 at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.

LEO DUROCHER hasn't done a bit of practicing for the big job. It's been ten years since he last essayed the task and his muscles certainly have grown flabby from disuse. But the Little Shepherd of Coogan's Bluff is a man of spirit. He quails at nothing. So he'll step confidently forth today and probably perform the chore as expertly as John McGraw used to do from force of habit.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 14 -- In cold print today's flood is tomorrow's statistic, but at this particular moment in the history of the turbulent and tricky Missouri River the human misery appears almost without end.

Eastern railroad executives were willing yesterday to hazard guesses on the amounts likely to be added to operating revenues as a result of the rate rises, but balked at indicating how much of the gains might filter down to net income or to common stockholders. There are too many "ifs" concerning the cost of materials and wage rates, they asserted.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Truman reaffirmed today the unity of the American republics in resisting the menace of communism, working for lasting peace and perpetuating their common cultural and economic aims.

MEXICO CITY, April 14 -- A simple new test for the diagnosis of brucellosis in human beings, easy to perform and accurate in a high percentage of cases, has been devised by Dr. Maximiliano Ruiz Castaneda, head of the Mexican brucellosis center of the World Health Organization.

A pocket of selling hit the stock market late yesterday that swept away gains of the morning, produced one of the sharpest reversals of the year and generated the heaviest volume in almost two months.

A wildcat strike by several hundred longshoremen, reportedly led by Anthony Anastasia, Brooklyn dock boss, immobilized two cargo ships yesterday and halted work at a number of Erie Basin piers in South Brooklyn. Reports as to the cause of the walkout were conflicting and it was not known how long the men might remain idle.

Sales of the Ford Motor Company of Canada increased $4,541,693 last year but earnings dropped 24.3 per cent below those of 1950, the annual report disclosed yesterday. All figures are given in Canadian dollars.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 14 (AP) -- Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., said today that a "sellers market" for many of the company's products is "a thing of the past."

HOMER W. SMITH, a distinguished biologist, Professor of Physiology at the School of Medicine of New York University and an authority on the kidney, is a scientist with a gift for words. Twenty years ago he wrote a short book dramatizing some of his ideas, "Kamongo," which became one of the early selections of the Book of the Month Club and a favorite of Alexander Woolcott.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- The Yankees will open the American League season here tomorrow against Jimmy Dykes' Athletics.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission granted today the twelfth in a series of general increases in railroad freight rates since the end of World War II.
Except for cottonseed oil, which had another turbulent session on the New York Produce Exchange with 925 lots or 27,750 tons traded, commodity markets in New York were quiet yesterday.

In the once gay city of Bucharest tens of thousands of citizens now go about with terror and dark foreboding in their hearts. Am I one of the 200,000 "unproductive people," who are to be forcibly evicted from the city? each one asks himself. What will happen to me and my family?

The end of the "freeze" on the construction of new television stations marks an epochal turning point in the development of a medium that already has had far-reaching influences on the American scene. Great as have been the strides made by the TV industry, its biggest growth still lies ahead.

The news of the lifting by the Federal Trade Commission of the ban on the construction of new television stations was received with mixed feelings by advertising people yesterday. Some advertisers and agency men saw the increase in outlets as an aid to programs but others were quick to point out that more outlets would increase the cost of using television.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- With the Government acknowledging "no real progress" toward a settlement of the steel wage dispute, the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee announced it would start hearings tomorrow on a bill laying down procedures for seizure of a strike-threatened industry.

Two alleged arsonists went on trial in General Sessions yesterday accused of first-degree murder in the death of a detective in connection with an explosion and fire in a loft building at 9 West Eighteenth Street last Sept. 10.

Harbor and air traffic was suspended for varying periods yesterday by a heavy fog that settled over the city in the morning. The International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, was shut down from 6:20 A. M. until 12:42 P. M., and flights were suspended or delayed at La Guardia Airport from 3:58 A. M. until 10:37 A. M.

Expansion of economic cooperation between the larger and smaller nations of the Western Hemisphere was urged yesterday by Rafael de la Colina, Mexican Ambassador to the United States, who spoke at an observance of Pan-American Day.

ASHLAND, Wis., April 14 (AP) -- Formation of a "National Committee to Expose the pro-Soviet Forces Behind Eisenhower" was announced today by John Chapple, Ashland newspaper publisher and supporter of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Federal Communications Commission handed out more than 3,000 application forms for new television stations today, the first day after the lifting of its three and a half-year freeze on their construction.

With the prospect of sunny, outdoor days ahead, children in play areas from city to suburb will be in need of well-supervised and well-planned activities. Parents working with groups of children in playground or park areas or leaders of community playground activities may start their program planning early with the first edition of the new 1952 Summer Playground Notebook, which will be available on April 25.

LONDON, April 14 (Reuters) -- Manchester United blasted Burnley, 6 -- 1, to keep two points ahead of Arsenal in English League soccer. The Gunners, striving towards the double -- league championship and the Football Association Cup -- downed Blackpool, 4 -- 1. Arsenal has four games to play, Manchester three.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Federal Court Judge John P. Barnes refused today the Liberty Broadcasting System's request for a temporary order directing thirteen major league clubs and the Western Union Telegraph Company to make their games available for Liberty's "Game of the Day" broadcast.

It'll be Sal Maglie, the Giants' twenty-three-game winner of 1951, against Robin Roberts at the Polo Grounds today as a new pennant campaign opens, with Leo Durocher's National League champions squaring off against Eddie Sawyer's Phillies.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 14 -- In South Africa's constitutional struggle between the Nationalist and United parties, a struggle that will be resumed with the convening of Parliament tomorrow, there are important implications that go beyond the country's borders.

Intricate patterns in exotic colors are exhibited in a collection of four new docorating fabrics called Indra, now on view at Lord Taylor. The designs, made by Golding and created by Tammis Keefe, have been hand-screened on a cotton rayon antique satin shot with gold Lurex thread.

" Edward and Caroline," a French-made romantic comedy starring Daniel Gelin and Anne Vernon, has been booked into the Little Carnegie to follow "Pictura," it was announced by Commercial Pictures, the distributors. Jacques Becker directed the import, which features Betty Stockfield, William Tubbs, Jacques Francois and Jean Marsac.

SUFFERN, N. Y., April 14 -- As he sat with other youths around a camp fire in the woods five miles northeast of here, John Patrick Dooley, 18 years old, of 967 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, was mysteriously shot to death tonight by a stranger who disappeared immediately afterward.

Three major manufacturers of men's clothing unveiled their fall lines yesterday with prices under those of this spring and considerably below the levels of last fall. According to trade sources, this indicates that all lines of men's suits will be below present levels and just slightly above pre-Korean prices.
Leon Barzin and the National Orchestral Association, assisted by the Dessoff Choirs, performed Berlioz' Requiem at Carnegie Hall last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- A wide gap still exists between teaching and learning in all types of schools despite the time, energy and money that has been spent to narrow it, Dr. L. Thomas Hopkins of Teachers College, Columbia University, said here tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The proposed shift of duties undoubtedly will set off a fight in Congress. It did once before. Involved is control over the spending of billions of dollars.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The decision of Senator Tom Connally, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, not to seek re-election is likely to improve the chances for a revival of the bipartisan foreign policy in the next Congress.

William M. Harvey, 24-year- old messman of the Isbrandtsen freighter Flying Trader, was advancing against the ship's master wit hhandcuffe dhands threatening when he was shot and killed, the vessel's first mate testified yesterday.

" The Restless Flame," a drama by Louis de Wohl, opened last night at the Blackfriars' playhouse, on West Fifty-seventh Street. It is the story of St. Augustine, based on his autobiographical "Confessions."

LA PAZ, Bolivia. April 14 (AP) -- Bolivia, still shaken by her bloody revolt, tidied up today to celebrate Pan American Day and to prepare a welcome for Victor Paz Estenssoro, exiled leader who was expected back from Argentina tomorrow to head the new regime.

A man was killed, three persons were injured seriously, and twelve others suffered cuts, bruises and shock when a bus and a passenger car were in collision in Eastern Parkway, at Buffalo Avenue, Brooklyn, shortly before 8 o'clock last night.

The nation's steel industry lost 826,000 tons of the vital metal last week as production schedules were curtailed sharply due to the threatened strike of steel workers. Steel plants throughout the country turned out 1,294,000 tons at the reduced operating rate of 62.3 per cent.
The special Federal rackets grand jury began yesterday an investigation into "possible irregularities" in the juries that sat in the two contempt trials of Frank Costello.

Tax experts, rate engineers, lawyers and a hearing examiner sat yesterday in a hearing room of the Public Service Commission, 233 Broadway. They were in the second hour of a hearing on the $14,000,000 Brooklyn Borough Gas Company's rate structure when a layman shattered the legal proceeding: "May I say something about the rates?"
The New York Telephone Co. the sixteenth and part of the seventeenth floor for general offices in 183 Madison Ave through Cross Brown Co -- Williams Co, brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- A heavy flow of savings funds into local savings and loan associations has reduced the borrowings of these institutions from market sources by 50 per cent this year, the Home Loan Bank board reported today.
TRENTON, April 14 -- Gov- Alfred E. Driscoll signed legislation today that is expected to begin further construction of the $300,000,000 Garden State Parkway within three months.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- John Foster Dulles, Republican expert on foreign affairs, said here today that the world's troubles were caused primarily by those who thought and acted in terms calculated on a purely material basis.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, April 15 (AP) -- Fifty-four Allied tanks wheeled into position in front of United Nations lines on the central front yesterday and shot up Communist fortifications for almost two hours.

The $25,000,000 screen printing industry in the United States is faced with extinction as a result of low-cost Japanese competition, it was contended yesterday by officials of the Association of Textile Screen Makers, Printers and Processors, Inc.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., April 14 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, tonight described the New Jersey Republican primary tomorrow as "a battle of propaganda as well as a battle for delegates."
Hundreds of long-suffering residents of this suburban community are grateful for your editorial calling attention to the breakdown of bus maintenance on the city transit lines.

CAIRO, April 14 -- The powerful Wafd party headed by former Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha today denounced the Government's action in postponing the general elections as "unconstitutional" and as detrimental to Egypt's national aims.

Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and Harold E. Stassen wound up their campaigns last night with newspaper, radio and television appeals to the Republican voters in New Jersey's Presidential preference primary today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) -- Curt Simmons got a raise today for a job well done two years ago.

MEXICO CITY, April 14 -- Gen. Octavio Vejar Vasquez, provisional president of the left-wing Popular party, was arrested by military authorities today and held in the military prison of Santiago Tlaltelolco for three hours before friends arranged his release on bail.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 14 (UP) -- Three more of twelve airmen who refused to fly were charged today with disobeying a superior officer, a court-martial offense.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Dewey today designated Earl Devendorf, director of the State Health Department's Bureau of Environmental Sanitation, to work as state coordinator with the Army Engineers in studies of property damage caused by changes in levels of the Great Lakes.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- President Truman today appointed Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer as head of a stepped-up highway safety program to try and reduce the 40,000 deaths expected this year.

Recently when Giovanni Ferretti became chef at Le Vouvray Restaurant, 132 East Sixty-fourth Street, he and Lawrence Wonderling, the owner, collaborated in creating three dishes that have proved especially popular. Unlike many culinarians who prefer to keep the recipes for their specialties a secret, these two men are generously willing to share them with the home cook.
ELIZABETH, N. J., April 14 -- Two bandits robbed the Elmora Branch of the Union County Trust Company at 609 Westfield Avenue here of $15,750 shortly after it opened at 8 A. M. today.

There will be a new carrousel soon for Brooklyn, with a $100,000 whirling structure being planned for Prospect Park. Donated by the Michael Friedsam Foundation through John Burke, president of B. Altman Co., a new carrousel and building soon will replace the old merry-goround that burned down, the Park Department announced yesterday.

A new approach to the problem of restating America's basic ideals in terms more understandable at home and abroad was undertaken here yesterday by a group of scholars, business and professional men selected by the Advertising Council to explore the fundamentals of American society in a series of round-table discussions.

PADUCAH, Ky., April 14 (AP) -- Sixteen hundred craftsmen stayed away today from their jobs at the $500,000,000 Paducah atomic energy construction project. The labor trouble stemmed from a new work schedule and the dismissal of eight workers.

HAVANA, April 14 -- Fulgencio Batista, Cuba's returned dictator, has the students of the island against him and that has always been a serious handicap in Cuban politics. This opposition was shown April 6 in a spectacular fashion when Havana University students publicly "buried" the democratic constitution of 1940, for which General Batista has substituted a dictatorial statute.
JERSEY CITY, April 14 -- Haile Selassie is to have his own custom - made American land - yacht to take him and his family around Ethiopia.

The decision of Judge Holtzoff in the matter of the steel industry's petition for an injunction and the industry's apparent admission that an injunction would not lie directly against the President seem to underline modern confusion of thought.

A luxurious look, achieved partly by the use of elegant fabrics and partly with daring color scheme, characterizes four bedroom settings and two living-dining areas to go on view at Bloomingdale's today.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Airplane pilots generally want the regulation of interstate air traffic "exclusively reserved to one agency, the Federal Government."
A group of Republican Senators has drafted a resolution calling for an investigation of the White House action in seizing the steel industry.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores for March showed an aggregate loss of 6.7 per cent from the volume of the 1951 month, according to a compilation of figures for forty-five companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Volume for the first quarter of 1952 was 2.8 per cent less than that of the like 1951 period.

Representatives of several New Jersey groups and the Port of New York Authority spoke favorably yesterday on the application of the New Jersey Highway Department to the Army Corps of Engineers for permission to build a new bridge across Newark Bay between Newark and Bayonne.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Truman allocated $500,000 late today to aid Iowa and South Dakota sufferers in what the American National Red Cross described as well on the way to becoming one of the most damaging and costly flood disasters in national history.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, today rejected a proposal that a Senate Labor subcommittee he heads invite General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to testify on civil rights legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Truman is expected to present to Congress shortly a reorganization plan that would transfer flood control work and rivers and harbors improvement from the Army's Corps of Engineers to the Reclamation Bureau of the Interior Department.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- An Italian cotton company lost its United States export privileges today for the duration of export controls, the stiffest penalty the Department of Commerce can levy.
NEWARK, Tuesday, April 15 -- a settlement of the strike of employes of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company was reached here at 12:40 o'clock this morning.

Dr. Henry Alsop Riley, who has been associated with the Neurological Institute for more than thirty years, will retire as chief of the West Service of the Institute in June, but will continue as consulting neurologist. Dr. Riley will be honored Thursday night at a testimonial dinner held by his staff at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Department of the Interior reported today that researchers had found that gasoline could be produced by the hydrogenation of coal at a profit.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A nonpartisan board to survey "the entire Asiatic situation" and other phases of national defense was advocated tonight at the opening session of the Sixty-first Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution by Mrs. James B. Patton, president-general.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- New crop wheat deliveries dropped to new lows today, and May also developed weakness as longs liquidated freely, with the professional trade generally inclined to press the market. Other grains also registered sharp declines, unsettled by the drop in wheat prices, which was unexpected in view of the flood conditions which may curtail spring wheat acreage.

MOSCOW, April 14 -- It appeared probable tonight that the volume of business transacted at the Moscow Economic Conference would more closely approximate $250,000,000 to $300,000,000 than the $3,000,000,000 that was originally estimated. This became apparent as fuller figures became available on the deals that were made by the principal trading nations.

WHITE PLAINS, April 14 -- The American system of law must be "color blind" to protect Negroes' rights, Rudolph Halley, President of the New York City Council, declared here tonight at a meeting memorializing two Negroes shot outside a Yonkers tavern by a former policeman.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Truman and Lester B. Pearson, Canada's Secretary for External Affairs, reached an informal agreement today permitting the first step toward sole construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway by Canada.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- The prosecution in the trial of fifteen California Communists today was rebuffed in an effort to ask a witness what it termed "the $64 question" -- whether the Communist party advocated the violent overthrow of the Government.

A State Department order of March 20 to the staff of its Russian-language magazine Amerika to move from New York to Washington has stirred up a controversy between employes of the magazine and department officials.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- The United Nations Security Council refused tonight to place the Tunisian question on its agenda, even on the understanding that the Council would not actually discuss it unless there were "developments of a grave character" in the French protectorate.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- Stanley Kramer has purchased film rights to "The Comedian," a novelette written by Ernest Lehman and published last January in a national magazine. Mr. Lehman, who is a movie scenarist, used as his protaganist a television comedian who is regarded as a national idol, but is a first-class heel in his private life.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- Charles Gordon of Scottsdale, Pa., a World War II lieutenant colonel, appealed to the Supreme Court today for a chance to defend himself against charges by unidentified accusers that led to his discharge "for the good of the service."
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 14 -- One man was killed and nine were injured in Nazareth today in a clash between Arab Christians and Moslems in which axes, knives and stones were used.
A steady start and an easy finish characterized trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Final quotations were 63 to 72 points net lower in the active months than on Friday.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 15 -- Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy, senior United Nations delegate to the Korean armistice conferences at Panmunjom, returned to the advance camp at Munsan yesterday afternoon after a week in Tokyo. He was accompanied by Rear Admiral Ruthven E. Libby, principal Allied representative on the committee charged with negotiations on Item 4 of the agenda -- the exchange of prisoners of war.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 15 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1220 for twenty-four-hour period ended at 6 A. M., Tuesday (4 P. M., Monday, Eastern standard time):
Probable pitchers, estimated attendances, starting times (Eastern standard) and pitchers' 1951 won-lost records for today's major league baseball opening games follow:
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator Tom Connally of Texas, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, made it clear today that his decision not to seek re-election was final.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14 -- The Yugoslav-Italian dispute over the rule of Trieste took on ugly overtones tonight when 250,000 to 300,000 persons marched in an organized demonstration against Italy and the conference being held in London on the future administration of Zone A of the Free Territory, the zone administered by Britain and the United States.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- The keynote speaker and other officials of the Republican National Convention, which will open July 7 in the International Amphitheatre, will not be chosen until late May or early June, arrangements officials decided here today.

Investigators of the Department of Hospitals reported yesterday there was "no evidence of negligence" in the death of a patient Saturday from an explosion of an anesthetic at Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn.

After a season's absence, Wanda Landowska returned to Town Hall last night to give one of her inimitable recitals on the harpsichord. A capacity audience of 1,550 was present to welcome her and to listen in absorbed wonderment as she revealed the facets of her delicate art.

I should like to comment on Clarence N. Goodwin's letter of April 2 in support of Gov. Adlai Stevenson's candidacy for President of the United States. I have no quarrel with McGoodwin's appraisal of Governor Stevenson's record relative to the United Nations.

BONN, Germany, April 10 -- Western Germany's Federal and State Governments, which expect a total of 30,000,000,000 Deutsche marks (about $7,000,000,000) in tax collections for 1952, could do a great deal better through improved tax legislation, Allied sources here assert.

WNYC, city-owned radio station, said last night that it would make immediate application to the Federal Communications Commission for a television channel. It is the first concern here to signify intent to file for one of the two new channels authorized for New York City under the commission's order ending a ban on station construction.
The City of Philadelphia announced yesterday that it would receive bids May 6 on $7,700,000 of refunding bonds dated May 1, 1952, and due July 1, 1953, to 1977.

Pre-trial arguments appeared to be drawing to a close in Federal Court yesterday in the case of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders, charged with conspiring to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

MADRID, April 14 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco met this evening with Dr. Antonio de Olivera Salazar, Premier of Portugal, in Cuidad Rodrigo, a small Spanish town about twenty-five miles from the Portuguese border.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 14 -- Senator Tom Connally's decision not to seek re-election to the Senate seat he has held for the last twenty-three years is expected to transform the Texas race into a free-for-all.

Thomas P. Cullen, Assistant District Attorney in Queens, announced yesterday that the Queens grand jury had refused to return a kidnapping indictment against Mrs. Philene Kirkwood, 27 years old. Mrs. Kirkwood, a former resident of Astoria, Queens, was accused last August by her former husband, George Kreisler, a night club entertainer, of trying to slip into the Soviet Zone of Germany with their 8-year-old son, Tom.

The forty-third running of the Rosedale, split into two divisions for the first time, turned out to be a family affair yesterday at rainswept Jamaica. The first of the season's stakes for 2-year-old fillies went to Leroy Hetzel's Countess Jane and Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's Emardee.

A four-year experiment to improve planning for higher education through increased faculty participation is being backed by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, in cooperation with eleven colleges and universities in the United States and Canada.

A banking syndicate headed by Stone Webster Securities Corporation, and White, Weld Co., will place on the market today $15,000,000 of new common stock of the Tennessee Production Company, producer of oil and natural gas in the Texas Gulf area, and a subsidiary of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.

WHILE the northern trout fishermen have been stamping frigid feet and blowing on their fingers, records have been falling like coconuts in a wind on the tropical isle of Bimini, the small but busy angling resort on the fringe of the Bahamas.

Manufacturers of television equipment will have no trouble equipping the many new stations that are to be authorized as a result of ending the ban on such construction by the Federal Communications Commission on Sunday. Nor will there be any difficulty in supplying receivers for the thousands of homes throughout the country that will thus be brought into range of TV programs.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Like countless previous immigrants, the four members of the Zylka family headed West today with a promise of work and freedom. Behind them were thirteen years of terror and persecution along the weary road of the wartime refugees of Europe, and President Truman personally tried to help blur out their bitter memories as they started out.

A 33-year-old veteran lost a four-year fight yesterday when Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey ruled that he had forfeited his American citizenship when he took an oath of allegiance to Adolf Hitler in 1940 and became a Nazi storm trooper.
GRANTS, N. M., April 14 (AP) -- The state police found one of their officers shot, beaten to death and burned on the Acoma Indian Reservation today.
OMAHA, April 14 -- Flood disaster hung by a slim and weakening thread tonight over the metropolitan area of Omaha and Council Bluffs, Iowa, as the Missouri River lashed its rich valley.

Net redemptions of United States savings bonds exceeded new sales again last month, marking the twenty-third consecutive month in which the Treasury's financing of this kind has been in deficit. Purchases for the month declined from $338,000,000 to $330,000,000, while redemptions rose from $411,000,000 to $428,000,000.

Those who take their living from the arts form a strange race, with work habits that are a little frightening. They show a regrettable tendency to sleep late in the morning and then, when a normal world is relaxing at the end of day, to suddenly leap at their typewriters and pianos and invent plots or fugues until dawn.

The one-story building containing about 18,000 square feet of space at 34-30 Steinway Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by Samuel N. Horowitz Son, Inc., of New York. Queens Industrials and G. Irving Huber were the brokers.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., April 14 -- Fire in a three-story frame and stucco building at Sunrise Highway and North Village Avenue here at noon today caused damage estimated at more than $50,000 to eight stores and professional offices.

An intimate view of the sometimes hectic relationship between the literary genius of the nineteenth century and his publisher is contained in the archives of the publishing house of Henry Holt Co., formally turned over to Princeton University yesterday at a ceremony at the Holt offices, 383 Madison Avenue.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Legislation giving the State Athletic Commission broad powers to clean up boxing and rid the sport of racketeers and gamblers was signed into law today by Governor Dewey. The measure is expected to bring about the most sweeping change in the sport since the Walker Law setting up the commission was enacted in 1920.
GREENSBORO, N. C., April 14 (AP) -- Dave Douglas, Newark (Del.) professional, won the $10,000 Greensboro open golf tournament by a stroke today with an assist from the rule book.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- President Truman was quoted by a White House visitor today as saying he would veto the oil bill that provides for state control of submerged coastal lands.
STUTTGART, Germany, April 14 -- The United States Seventh Army, is probably the most efficient and powerful United States force ever established abroad in peace time.

The old song, "Night and Day," will be the chant of horse players from here in. The reason: The thoroughbreds in the New York area will have the company of trotters and pacers starting tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The season for these branches of the horse family, not to mention the lively pari-mutuel machines, runs until Nov. 15.
Shareholders of the Mexico Tramways Company have been called to a special meeting in Toronto on April 29 to consider winding up the operations of the company and its subsidiaries in Mexico.

" The Chase," Horton Foote's fourth play with a Texas background, opens at the Playhouse tonight at 8 o'clock. John Hodiak and Kim Hunter are co-starred in the production, which features Nan McFarland, Murray Hamilton, Kim Stanley, G. Albert Smith and Sam Byrd.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt replied today to recent attacks in this country against the proposed United Nations human rights pacts, warning that failure to support these "humanitarian" treaties would be "behaving exactly like the Soviets."

There are a few things that are typically and essentially American. Some of them are very good things -- corn on the cob and pumpkin pie, for example. In that category of the elements in the distinctively American good life a high place must be given to baseball.
ROME, April 14 -- One of the most expensive fires that ever raged in Italy was blown out like a candle this morning by a terrific blast from the explosion of 550 pounds of TNT.
William C. Bleboch has been elected president of the Montague Rod and Reel Company. He succeeds Paul J. Johnson who was named chairman.
Two New York business men were arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with an international swindle that may involve as much as $3,000,000.

To bring into the city treasury several millions of dollars in taxes now being lost annually because of an enforcement staff too small to catch all evaders, Controller Lazarus Joseph told the Board of Estimate yesterday he would soon ask for $4,000,000 to increase his tax-collecting personnel.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in St. Louis cleared the way yesterday for payment of $35,$88,575 in accrued interest on bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and one of its subsidiaries.

Practices by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., a non-defendant in the anti-trust investment banking case, in forming syndicates to bid on issues of bonds and in pricing such obligations for public sale were described to Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday in a trial session in the judge's chambers in the Federal Courthouse.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange finished irregular yesterday, 16 points higher to 5 points lower, with the current May delivery firmest.
In connection with the complaint of eleven United Nations members from Asia and Africa concerning the Tunisian crisis some facts seem to be worth recalling.
ALBANY, April 15 -- Savings banks will be permitted to invest a limited amount of their assets in common and preferred stock under a bill approved without comment today by Governor Dewey.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 15 -- The South African Parliament resumed today after a short Easter armistice and fell instantly into an embittered debate -- a debate that may be inconclusive for weeks -- on this country's constitutional crisis.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A joint statement, strongly criticizing the United States Government for having directed its delegation in the United Nations to abstain in the Security Council vote on placing the Tunisian question on the Council's agenda, was issued today by the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor.

By the relatively narrow margin of 1,690 votes, the city's public school teachers have approved a plan that would create new grievance machinery and give them a voice in school policy-making. The vote was 18,084 to 1,394.

TRENTON, April 15 -- In the third outbreak at the State Prison here in a month, fifty-eight prisoners barricaded themselves today in the print shop, holding two guards and two instructors as hostages.

Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra made the final concert of their New York season a rousing occasion at Carnegie Hall last night. The two works on the program, both by living composers, made a valid contrast. Both were worth the attention of any audience, and both were performed with the gleaming polish the Philadelphians have accustomed us to.

CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) -Shareholders of Arthur G. McKee Co. today approved increasing the concern's authorized shares from 300,000 to 600,000. The increase, effective May 15, will provide for a two-for-one stock split. The company's Class B stock then will be common. Purpose of the split, the company said, is to broaden the market for the stock.

Charging that "liberty is being lost by 42,000,000 lazy people" who do not vote, Raymond Moley urged Republican yesterday to get out the vote to win this year's election rather than look for a "savior."
Federal mediators announced last night that they were starting "round-the-clock" negotiations in an effort to settle the key strike of Bell System telephone employes.

It's not only in April that rainwear takes on importance. Summer showers also present a problem to the fashion conscious. The old-fashioned rubberized coat is a thing of the past at all seasons, but until now rainwear has been designed primarily for the spring and fall.
The Broadway Association has asked prohibition of parking on Broadway and Seventh Avenue from Forty-seventh to Fifty-ninth Street.

The benefit committee of the Near East Foundation has opened an extensive loan exhibition of paintings of America's Far West, feeling that the paintings, which reflect the spirit of pioneer days and struggles of the early settlers, also typify the spirit of the foundation's pioneering and self-help demonstrations in Iran, Syria and Greece.
Banking syndicates headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., bought at public sealed bidding yesterday two issues of public utility and railroad debt securities totaling $64,950,000.

DETROIT, April 15 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands, in the oblique language of visiting royalty, appeared to have cautioned the United States tonight against seeking to impress its own political and economic patterns on other nations.

In July, 1951, the House of Representatives rejected an amendment to the Defense Production Act of 1951. This amendment in effect would have required the President by proclamation to prohibit the importation of any product containing any materials subject to priorities or allocations except as the President might find such importation to be necessary or appropriate to the national defense.
Another severe sinking spell yesterday carried stocks down as much as 4 points. Targets for the attack were units in the oil, rail, automotive, tire and aircraft divisions.

Many representative members of society attended the Ciro Ball, the annual spring dinner dance for the benefit of the New York Infirmary, held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Ellen Tuck Astor and Mrs. Eugene W. Ong were co-chairmen of the benefit committee.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture reported today there were indications that the plague of rabid foxes was on the wane.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 15 (AP) -- Attorneys in a suit accusing organized baseball of violation of anti-trust laws agreed today to hold the action in abeyance until the United States Supreme Court rules on similar cases.

Shirt prices will not drop this year because there is no sign of a change in the piece-goods market, Barry T. Leithead, president of Cluett, Peabody Co., manufacturer of Arrow shirts, declared here yesterday. He spoke at a meeting of the board of directors of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the New Yorker Hotel.

NEWARK, April 15 -- A water-main gate burst and killed one man and washed two others out of a vault in which they were working eight feet below the street surface shortly after 3 P.M. today. The accident occurred at Heller and Forest Parkways.

Success in boys' apparel retailing can be achieved by adherence to merchandising practices which will serve the needs of communities in which the retail outlets are located. This conclusion, announced yesterday, was reached after a survey by the Boys' Apparel Buyers' Association, in which the operations of twenty-two selected boys' departments in medium-size stores throughout the country were analyzed.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -James G. Smyth, ousted former Collector of Internal Revenue for the Northern California district, was named in a new seven-count indictment today charging him with conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government of penalties through the backdating of income tax returns.

CAIRO, April 15 -- Archaeological circles here were taken aback today by newspaper reports to the effect that thousands of ancient objects, including pieces in "pure gold" and statues "several feet high" had disappeared from the Egyptian Museum.

The shortest "major" speeches on record for Presidential aspirants were scheduled yesterday for the annual $100-a-plate dinner of the New York State Democratic Committee, to be held tomorrow night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 15 -Keynote speakers attending the forty-ninth annual convention of the National Catholic Educational Association, which opened this morning, sharply attacked Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, for his recent statements opposing the growth of private secondary school education.

A steady, drizzling rain washed out the scheduled opening of the National League baseball season at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Giants, who closed out their 1951 flag race in quite a spectacular blaze, were thus placed in a position to do something extraordinary with the start of the new one.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 15 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee came to Florida today for an uphill fight for the state's 24 Democratic Presidential nominating delegates against the opposition of Gov. Fuller Warren.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- More than $2,000,000 worth of paintings and other art objects from the collections of the Chicago Art Institute are on view today in the windows of twenty-nine downtown department stores and shops.

A Moscow dispatch printed in this newspaper yesterday reported that the Communist-sponsored World Economic Conference held there last week had resulted, at most, in preliminary agreements for about $300,000,000 worth of trade, or about 10 per cent of the figure trumpeted loudly during the meeting itself.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 15 (AP) -- This area, still jittery from last year's record floods, took precautions today as a record Missouri River torrent surged downstream.
PINE ISLAND, N. Y., April 15 (AP) -- An eighth grade teacher has resigned amid charges that she rigged answers last June to help some of her pupils by the regents' examination.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today more than $117,000,000 of new bonds and common stock of a major oil pipeline and public utility companies. Funds will be used for the most part for the permanent financing of capital improvements. The offerings are as follows:
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Early Wynn pitched the Indians to a 3-2 victory over Billy Pierce and the White Sox today. Each club got six hits.

Solomon N. Petchers has purchased for investment the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building for 115 families at 33 Riverside Drive. north corner of Seventy-fifth Street, from 33 Riverside Drive, Inc., A. H. McRae, president, representing the builders.

NO runs, no hits, no errors -- and no game. The Giants lounged in the Polo Grounds clubhouse yesterday, peering morosely at the rain-splattered windows and at the tarpaulin-covered field that lay beyond.
CINCINNATI, April 15 (AP) -- The Cubs lost a five-run lead today but in the tenth inning Gene Hermanski's pinch-hit single gave them a 6-5 victory over the Reds in their National League opener.

A $6,000 sprint for 3-year-old fillies served as the feature of yesterday's racing at Jamaica. It was called The Delft, and Woodvale Farm's Our Dorie led from break to finish, covering the six furlongs over a sloppy track in 1:12 2-5 for a $15.20 pay-off.

Dr. Brock Chisholm, director general of the United Nations World Health Organization, reported yesterday that the loyalty and devotion of Israel's inhabitants would offset its current economic disadvantages.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -The Government announced today that steel allotments for schools, hospitals, highways and other commercial construction would be more than doubled in the third quarter of the year starting July 1.

One did not need to be an expert at three-cushion billiards to follow the proceedings at the annual meeting of stockholders of the General Electric Company yesterday. Held in the giant turbine plant of G. E. at Schenectady, the affair drew 1,821 stockholders, more than ever before.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Associate Justices Robert H. Jackson and William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court held today that the United States should abolish the Electoral College system of choosing Presidents and Vice Presidents and that direct elections for these offices would be a gain "for simplicity and integrity."

NEW HAVEN, April 15 (AP) -City Court Judge Domenic W. Celotto today continued until July 1 the case against Joe Desson, New Haven Tomahawks captain, charged with attacking Referee Mike Slowick during last Thursday's hockey game here.

Governor Dewey's book, Journey to the Far Pacific," which Doubleday had scheduled for publication later this month, has been postponed until July 14. It has been chosen by the Book-of-theMonth Club as its July selection. The book is a personal report on the people and countries the Governor visited last year.

One thing no wise man does is to glance deliberately into the household checkbook. This is the book that is maintained by the cook and cleaner, the single deposit each month being broken down and distributed to various servicing agencies, not always in the order of their demands but sometimes in the order of the vociferousness of their reminders.

The plight of victims of war and its aftermath in Europe and the Near East is likely to have dangerous religious and political repercussions in those areas, Msgr. Edward E. Swanstrom, executive director of war relief services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, declared yesterday.

BOSTON, April 15 -- Preacher Roe threw his first "gopher ball" of the 1952 season to Sam Jethroe in the third inning at Braves Field today, but the Dodger took the season's opener from the Braves, 3 -- 2, before 4.694 fans.

Having accounted for one triumph each in the play-off of the National Basketball Association final, the New York Knickerbockers and the Minneapolis Lakers will meet in the third game at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight. The contest will start at 8:30 o'clock.
Samuel Reshevsky and Miguel Najdorf finished the adjourned fifth game of the chess match at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday. The result was a draw in seventy-six moves.

New evidence indicating that the paralytic form of poliomyelitis should be one of the diseases most easily preventable by immunization was presented here yesterday afternoon by research workers from Johns Hopkins and Yale Universities.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 15 (UP) -- The brightest fireball to arise from the Nevada desert since it became the site of atomic experiments shot skyward today at the Yucca Flat proving grounds in a nuclear detonation.

The Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries increased its sales in the nine months ended with February, but reported yesterday a decline in earnings from the corresponding period of the previous year because of substantially larger tax charges.

As a "token of goodwill" pending Japan's resumption of interest payments on about $68,000,000 of outstanding dollar bonds, the Japanese Foreign Exchange Control Board plans to place $20,000,000 on deposit with the Federal Reserve Bank in the near future. A similar token deposit related to Japan's external debt in British sterling and French francs is to be made by the Japanese authorities in London.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Legislation authorizing New York to participate in the proposed $550,000,000 INCODEL project for development and use of the water resources of the Delaware River was approved today by Governor Dewey.

The National Education Association, which is in a position to know, reports that the shortage of teachers in the country's elementary schools has become worse. This report is based on a next study of teacher supply and demand, and shows only 32,443 potential teachers graduating from college this year to meet a demand for at least 160,000 new teachers in the elementary schools alone.
OMAHA, April 15 -- The surging Missouri River, which President Truman intends to see from the air tomorrow, rose higher and higher tonight in this flood-shattered midland area.

LAUREL, Md., April 15 (UP) -Nick Shuk, the leading rider at the combined Laurel-Bowie meeting, rode three more winners today, including Jack the Great in the featured Forsythia Purse, to boost his victory total here to twenty-six.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Joseph N. Pew Jr., chairman of the board of the Sun Oil Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting today that "it is obvious" that the Government had no intention of lessening the weight of its "dead hand" in business affairs.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Tage Erlander, Premier of Sweden, declared today that his Government believed it served peace better by neutrality than by joining other countries in military alliances.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 16 -The military subcommittee of generals discussing terms for the enforcement of an armistice in Korea held another session of less than a minute today and made no progress toward solution of the major outstanding issues.

A good many of your readers, after hearing one of my talks on Union Now or Atlantic Union in the past thirteen years, have been kind enough to urge me to "keep up the good work and never be discouraged." Now I have something encouraging to give them in turn.

Merchants from all over the country are here to attend the Brand Names Foundation's fourth annual awards dinner for the Brand Name Retailer of the Year at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tonight. More than 1,700 business and civic leaders are expected to attend the function.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 15 -- South Africa's system of apartheid does not merely divide the 2,600,000 whites from the 8,500,000 blacks of this country. In a nonlegal sense, there is also sharpening apartheid among whites themselves -- English-speaking whites on one side and Afrikaans, or colloquial Dutch-speaking people on the other.

The front page of THE TIMES of April 14 carries reports of a trend which is threatening to cheapen and make tawdry our whole way of life. This is the insensitive and uncontrolled commercialism of American advertising interests.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 15 -- Field Marshal Viscount Alexander, the British Minister of Defense, arrived this morning for a one-day visit to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and ranking staff officers of Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers in Europe.
DETROIT, April 15 (AP) -- A stock option plan for officers and key employes of Chrysler Corporation was approved today at a meeting of the stockholders.

ALBANY, April 15 -- A payment of $132,027,205, the largest ever made by the state at one time for one purpose, has been sent to cities, villages and other school districts for state aid to education, J. Raymond McGovern, state comptroller, reported today.

Consolidated net income of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating telephone subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 29 amounted to $365,473,297 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, Cleo F. Craig, president, announced yesterday.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 15 (AP) -- The president of the General Electric Company told stockholders today that it planned to spend $550,000,000 on expansion in a four-year program already under way.

No matter how the current strike of Western Union Telegraph Company employes ends, many problems facing the company will remain and offer a challenge to management and employes, since their own welfare will depend upon proper solutions.

Just twenty-nine years ago a young oiler signed articles on the then superliner Leviathan. He watched as the Stars and Stripes were raised to her masthead for the first time. Almost a quarter of a century later he was to serve in the engine room of another captured German superliner -- the Europa.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -The Communist party opened an attack today on the private life of Louis Budenz, former party functionary who has since become a frequent witness against communism.

The Board of Estimate has completed its lengthy hearings on the Mayor's proposed budget of $1,469,265,101 to run the City of New York for the fiscal year starting July 1. City employes were heard on the first day, and the general reaction was a reasonable satisfaction with the $39,000,000 for a graduated pay rise.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -The Screen Writers Guild today filed a petition in Superior Court in Los Angeles asking the court to appoint an arbiter to represent R. K. O. Radio Pictures in an arbitration proceedings concerning the dispute over the studio's refusal to give screen credit to Paul Jarrico as a co-author of "The Las Vegas Story."

RALPH ELLISON'S first novel, "The Invisible Man,"* is the most impressive work of fiction by an American Negro which I have ever read. Unlike Richard Wright and Willard Motley, who achieve their best effects by overpowering their readers with documentary detail, Mr. Ellison is a finished novelist who uses words with great skill, who writes with poetic intensity and immense narrative drive. "

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said last night that her recent visit to India had given her "tremendous hope" that India was going to be "the country" of Asia. She spoke at a meeting of the India League of America in the Community Church, 40 East Thirty - fifth Street.

ROME, April 15 -- The highest dignitaries of the Italian state and representatives of international culture met this morning in the small town of Vinci, seventeen miles west of Florence, to pay homage to Leonardo da Vinci on the 500th anniversary of his birth.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, April 16 (AP) -- Communist troops hit Allied lines on the western front last night and touched off an Allied artillery barrage that roared through most of the night.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP) -Stockholders of International Utilities Corporation today authorized an offering of 1,000,000 shares of new $25 preferred stock and increased from 1,200,000 to 2,500,000 the number of authorized shares of common stock.
