Additionally, stockholders approved a sale to underwriters of 250,000 shares of a new convertible preferred stock.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower clinched victory over Senator Robert A. Taft in the New Jersey Presidential preference primary early this morning after the lead had shifted several times in the bitterly fought contest.

Preacher Roe, who won twenty-two games for the Dodgers last year, pitched Brooklyn to a 3-2 victory over the Braves in Boston as the major league baseball season started yesterday. Rain prevented opening games listed between the Giants and Phillies at the Polo Grounds and the Yankees and Athletics in Philadelphia.

Unless misrepresentation in advertising is stopped the admiration of the public for the products offered will be supplanted with contempt, Mort Farr, president of the National Appliance and Radio-TV Dealers Association, warned yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -Rain washed out today's scheduled opening of the American League season at Shibe Park between the Yankees and Athletics.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 15 -- Walter Wanger, motion picture producer, today waived a jury trial and placed in the hands of Superior Court Judge Harry Borde the question of what penalty, if any, should be imposed upon him for shooting an alleged rival for the affections of his wife, Joan Bennett, last Dec. 13.

Senator H. Alexander Smith, 72year-old Republican spokesman on Far Eastern affairs, won renomination in the New Jersey primary yesterday in a one-sided victory over Carl E. Ring, Rutherford lawyer and engineer.

SPLIT ROCK, Pa., April 15 -- Followers of the "earlybird" theory were rewarded on the Tobyhanna and the Tunkhannock today, for Pennsylvania trout fishermen had a wet and windy opening, and those who failed to take trout by 9 A.M. were confronted by high, fast and discolored streams.
LAUREL, Md., April 15 (AP) -The jockey license of Carroll Bierman was suspended indefinitely today by Laurel stewards, who declined an explanation
Airy nylon frocks that could be whisked in a tub and never need an ironing provided the theme for Russeks' showing of Henry Rosenfeld summer fashions yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The United Nations was vigorously attacked tonight by O. R. McGuire, Washington lawyer, before the national defense session of the Daughters of the American Revolution Continental Congress.

VIOLA, N. Y., April 15 -- A 14-year-old boy from the lower East Side of Manhattan was taken into custody today as the slayer of an 18-year-old youth who was fatally injured last night on the summit of Half Moon Mountain.

The establishment of the Frank S. Hackett Memorial Fund, in honor of the late founder of the Riverdale Country School, was announced last night by Henry G. Hotchkiss, president of the school's board of trustees, at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A literary leviathan, the fifty-four-volume "Great Books of the Western World" prepared by the Encyclopedia Britannica and the University of Chicago, was launched last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel celebrating the publication of the work.

LONDON, April 15 -- A White Paper published tonight aligned Britain squarely with the European Defense Community. It did not commit her to membership but it promised to extend Britannia's shield to cover the West German Federal Republic and Italy just as under the Brussels treaty of 1948 Britain is committed to go to the aid of France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg in the event of an attack from any quarter.

ST. LOUIS, April 15 (AP) -- The Cardinals tonight weathered a late Pittsburgh uprising to beat the Pirates, 3 to 2, before a chilled crowd of 15,850. Red Schoendienst, returning to action after a fifteenday lay-off caused by a broken finger, hit a home run for the Redbirds and Ralph Kiner drove one for Pittsburgh.

A quiet, efficient and generally soft-spoken man -- a "sailor's sailor," who came up through the "hawse-pipe" from ordinary seaman to master of a merchant vessel -- was honored last night by the American Legion, with the award of its Distinguished Service Medal for "exceptional and highly meritorious" service.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Truman will fly over the flood-ravaged Midwest tomorrow and then confer with the Governors of seven of the afflicted states on emergency measures to cope with the growing disaster.

CAIRO, April 15 -- The Wafd party executive, which had been in emergency session since Saturday, issued tonight a manifesto accusing the present Egyptian Government of collusion with the British, violation of the constitution and conspiracy against the people.

Three automobiles, one of them driven by Federal Judge Harold R. Medina, were involved in a traffic accident yesterday at 9 A.M. on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive just south of Houston Street. As a result of the accident, according to the police of the Sheriff Street Station, two persons suffered minor injuries.
Formation of what is described as the first privately financed laboratory devoted soley to research in nuclear power was announced yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 15 -- The thirty-fourth anniversary of the founding of New Jersey College for Women was observed here today with a program in Voorhees Chapel at which Dr. Margaret Clapp, president of Wellesley College, spoke on "Education for Whom and for What?" More than 1,000 faculty members, undergraduates and alumnae attended.

Business is booming in the Arctic waters off Norway and all because of the American gourmet's preference for whale meat. Housewives in this country need not be surprised if, in the next few months, their local butchers begin filling their showcases with deleetable whale steaks, roasts and cutlets.

The younger generation, apparently, does not see eye to eye with city elders on the esthetic qualities of the Marriage License Bureau quarters in the Municipal Building. Nor, it turns out, does it approve of practical arrangements.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Long liquidation was again the predominating feature in the grain trade today, routine news receiving little consideration. In the early trading all grains showed a tendency to rally, but the buying impulse was smothered by free selling on the hard spots, and sharp declines were registered later.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 15 (UP) -- Dr. Victor Paz Estenssoro, head of the National Revolutionary party (M. N. R.), returned to Bolivia in triumph today after six years in exile and promptly announced the government would take immediate steps to nationalize the tin mines, the country's chief wealth.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- An advance of $40,000 for the preparation of plans to redevelop 6.29 acres in the Columbus Circle neighborhood was granted today to the New York Committee on Slum Clearance by the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency.

Two former United States Customs Service PT-boats were turned over yesterday to representatives here of the Indonesian Government. A similar deal was made last year. The craft will be used by the Indonesian customs in an effort to halt the widespread smuggling going on among the republic's 3,000 islands.
SEATTLE, Wash., April 15 (UP) -- The Air Force's new top secret eight-jet Stratofortress roared into the air here today on its first flight.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -A special report to the Senate Banking Committee recommends that Government housing agencies take the lead in bringing the cost of modern homes down to where the average working family can afford one.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 16 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1221 for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 15 (AP) -- Western Germany and Chile are planning to increase their commercial trade 100 per cent. Last year's $25,000,000 volume is to be increased to $50,000,000 this year.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -The Government rejected a request for an industry-wide price increase for cigarettes today but said a few small manufacturers might qualify for a slight rise.

PITTSBURGH, April 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft charged here today that President Truman "is showing the same disregard for the Constitution and the laws of the United States which he has shown in many other cases."
LONDON, April 15 -- Britain's sixth biggest union went over to Aneurin Bevan's side today in the debate within the Labor party over whether rearmament or social welfare should have first priority.

An award of $90,000 was handed down yesterday by the Board of Assessors to the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant, 310 East Forty-second Street, for damage sustained by the church in a change in street grade in connection with the East Side United Nations improvement.

A contract for $9,091,213 for the construction of the superstructure of the South Street Elevated Highway, planned as the final link around eastern, southern and western Manhattan, was awarded yesterday to the Felhaber Pile Company, Inc., by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan.

The trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders opened in the Federal Court House in Foley Square at 3:27 P. M. yesterday when Judge Edward J. Dimock began to impanel a jury to try them on charges of conspiracy to advocate and teach the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The State Department has ruled that the Italian Government had legal control over German-occupied northern Italy during the time in 1944 that two United States soldiers are accused of killing Maj. William V. Holohan.

" Carbine Williams," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama starring James Stewart and Jean Hagen, has been booked into the Capitol, where it will open after the run of the current attraction, "My Son John." The latter offering is now in its second week at that house.
DETROIT, April 15 (AP) -- Ned Garver of the Browns chilled the Tigers with only six singles today to humble them, 3 -- 0, before Queen Juliana and 43,112 other opening day fans.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- A Republican Representative accused Defense Department censors today of being either "stupid" or obstructive in their handling of testimony taken by a House subcommittee on armed services waste.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- Roland E. Harriman, president of the American Red Cros, asked the organization's chapters tonight to raise $10,000,000 to aid victims of the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers floods.

Cottonseed oil underwent another big trading day and the world sugar contract showed more than usual activity on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, but other commodity futures markets in New York were inactive yesterday.

The Apollo Boys Choir, a group of twenty-five lads between 9 and 14 years of age from a choir school in Palm Beach, Fla., gave a concert last night at Town Hall. The event was given for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.

YONKERS, April 15 -- Neither rain nor mist nor cold kept the trotters and pacers -- and the players who backed them, for better or worse -- from making their appointed rounds tonight. The opening program of the 197-night metropolitan harness racing season not only came off as scheduled at Yonkers Raceway, but, considering the atrocious conditions that prevailed, had an outstanding social and financial success.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has just authorized a 9 per cent increase in freight rates for railroads operating throughout the South and West and a 6 per cent rise for the Eastern carriers. This is the twelfth boost in freight rates since the end of the Second World War and the second within the past year.
OMAHA, April 15 -- A tremendous sense of urgency settled over this rich Midwestern metropolitan community today as the crest of the flooding Missouri River moved relentlessly southward.

In a venturesome mood, Robert Whitehead, who has given a good account of himself as managing director of the American National Theatre and Academy's Play Series, is branching out into the song-and-dance field with the first local revival of the oddly named "Four Saints in Three Acts," opening at 8 o'clock this evening at the Broadway Theatre.

Capt. Franklin B. Weaver of the Isbrandtsen cargo ship Flying Trader testified yesterday that he "did what I had to do" in shooting William M. Harvey, 24-year-old messman. The 31-year-old skipper is being tried on a charge of manslaughter before Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld and a jury.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Truman opened the 1952 baseball season today with two left-handed pitches and then bundled up in a lap robe to watch another southpaw, Mel Parnell, pitch the Red Sox to a 3 -- 0 victory over the Senators.

Increases of $300 a year to retired city workers who now receive pensions of less than $1,200 a year would be provided under a proposed local law that Councilman Edward Vogel, Brooklyn Democrat, said yesterday he would introduce in the City Council next Tuesday.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, Pierre Monteux and Alexander Smallens will conduct the majority of concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium, City College, this summer, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, the chairman of the concerts since their inception thirty-five years ago, announced yesterday.
PEORIA, Ill., April 15 -- Stockholders of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad today voted a 1,600 to 1 stock split at the annual meeting here.

SPOKANE, Wash., April 15 (UP) -- Fifteen men were killed and two injured today when a B-36 bomber crashed and exploded on a deserted farm while taking off on a routine training flight from the Fairchild Air Force base.
LONDON, April 15 -- The stock markets resumed quietly after the Easter week-end today on the note of underlying firmness that was their principal characteristic last week.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -The Airline Pilots Association, A. F. L., charged today that Federal regulations did not provide adequate safety for passengers in emergency water landings and demanded tighter rules governing safety equipment.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- The Soviet press intimated today that the Western powers should advance their own proposals as a basis for a German peace treaty provided they continued to hold objections against some of the Soviet proposals.

D. Lee Stoddard, self-taught reporter, editor, linotype operator, printer, advertising salesman and manager, columnist and publisher, received yesterday the Gold Medal award of the National Board of Fire Underwriters for outstanding public service by a weekly newspaper publisher in the field of fire prevention.

BONN, Germany, April 15 -- The United States authorities believe there is a very good chance that a contractual agreement will be completed by the end of this month and that the Western powers thus will tie the German Federal Republic to Western Europe before Russian offers of unity reach their maximum attractiveness.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A Senate investigating subcommittee asserted today that the Air Force had been lax in combating widespread off-duty gambling by thousands of young airmen stationed near Biloxi, Miss.

MEXICO CITY, April 15 -- The three opposition parties that have decided to unite in fighting the coming Mexican elections today announced their joint platform for their single list of candidates to Congress.

ST. PAUL, April 15 -- Damage to industrial firms and residences mounted into the millions of dollars today as the combined crests of the flood-swollen Mississippi and Minnesota Rivers bore down on this city.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -The Office of Price Stabilization said today that buyers of Cadillacs ranging in price up to $5,205, were scheduled to get refunds of about $25 each from General Motors.

Dr. Henry Steele Commager, Professor of History at Columbia University, told the National Social Welfare Assembly yesterday that a large and long-range public works program must be made ready to bolster the economic situation that will result in the United States from the curtailment of armament production.

People will do the strangest things to make a living. Some will fly airplanes through brick walls, others will risk their necks by climbing steeples. Some will dive deep into shark-infested waters in search of pearls, others will lie on the tanbark with their head beneath an elephant's foot.
CLEVELAND, April 15 -- Judge Freed was believed to have cast some doubt today on the legality of Federal seizures.

An engagement made several weeks ago will take Acting Mayor Rudolph Halley tomorrow to Lewiston, Me., to address the student body of Bates College on crime in government. Originally Mr. Halley was to have spent two days at the Maine college -- tomorrow and Friday -- but because of his duties as Acting Mayor in the absence of Mayor Impellitteri, now vacationing in Florida, the Council President cut the engagement to one day.

Horton Foote has written a Western with an ethical point, "The Chase," put on by Jose Ferrer at the Playhouse last evening. After three acts and nine scenes, a ruminative theatregoer is likely to wonder whether the Western without the ethic or the ethic without the Western might not be an improvement.
CLEVELAND, April 15 -- A Federal judge forbade three railroad unions today to strike against the Government, but said the courts should not be used "to impel collective bargaining."

A symposium on the relation of the director to the theatre was held yesterday afternoon at the ANTA Playhouse, 245 West Fifty-second Street, under auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy, as the fifth event of the membership drive of its Greater New York chapter.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15 -- Harding C. Bancroft, United States representative, told the Collective Measures Committee of the United Nations today that the idea of a United Nations legion was "a subject well worth exploration."

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -The Justice Department said today that President Truman had ample "inherent power" to seize the steel industry last week. The Government took over the mills when a wage dispute threatened to halt production.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 15 (AP) -- Haloid Company, manufacturer of photographic papers and supplies, today reported an increase of 36 per cent in earnings in its first quarter of 1952, compared with the same period in 1951.

An intensive investigation into the ramifications of an alleged $780,000 swindle of a Japanese export-import concern was under way yesterday as three men were held in $25,000 bail each for hearings tomorrow in Felony Court on grand larceny charges.

WOR-TV may have started something! Its experiment in putting on plays for a full hour and a half and giving five consecutive performances of the same drama is enjoying an auspicious debut this week with the station's revival of "The Trial of Mary Dugan." The show is O. K., not anything great, to be sure, but well worth the viewing.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A Senate Subcommittee investigating mobilization and military procurement accused the Department of Defense today of "working severe and inequitable hardships" on smaller business.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15 -- Tunisian nationalists announced today that they would press for a special session of the United Nations General Assembly to take up their case against France.

Charles Vance, for the last three years director of the American Theatre Wing Training Program, has resigned on the advice of his physicians, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Martin Beck, chairman of the Wing's board. The resignation has been accepted "with regret."

The rule that cost Sam Snead a tie for the Greensboro open golf title is not a new one but "one of the oldest laws in the sport," the executive secretary of the United States Golf Association said yesterday.

Like the flowers that bloom in the spring, that hardy perennial - the ice cream man -- is making his annual comeback these days on busy New York street corners, near schoolyards and in greening residential districts.

PASSAIC, N. J., April 15 (AP) -H. E. Humphreys Jr., chairman of United States Rubber Company, announced at the annual meeting today that sales increased about 4 per cent in the first quarter this year to about $220,000,000.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 15 -- An attempt to assassinate Col. Marcos Perez Jimenez of the governing junta was frustrated and fourteen plotters have been arrested, national security authoriites announced last night.

DETROIT, April 15 (UP) -- Metro Prystai scored two goals and assisted on another tonight as the Detroit Red Wings swept to the Stanley Cup with a 3-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens before 14,090 fans.

LOS ANGELES, April 15 -- The trial of fifteen California Communists was stirred today by testimony from a New Yorker that one defendant, Loretta Stack, state organizational secretary of the Communist party, was the former Lottie Keith, a prominent Eastern labor organizer of twenty years ago, a one-time member of the Russian Communist party, and a graduate of its Moscow training school in field and street warfare.

A large floor in a building supported by "pre-stressed" concrete beams, the first such construction in the United States, has just been completed in the new dining hall of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart at Harrison, N. Y.

NEW DELHI, India, April 15 -India's Communist leaders have never had it so good as they will for the next five years as a result of this country's first national elections. It irritates anti-Communist Government officials that the law compels them to support the Red opposition in a style to which neither they nor the average Indian has ever been accustomed.

FARGO, N. D., April 15 (AP) -- More than 2,500 persons were [homeless in the Fargo-Moorehead area tonight as the Red River of the North rose slowly toward a !predicted crest of more than thirty-five feet.

The round-trip voyage to the Mediterranean of the 10,000-ton Home Lines passenger vessel Homeland, scheduled to depart Monday afternoon, has been canceled and the ship will remain here until May 16, her next scheduled sailing date.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Negotiations between steel owners and labor collapsed today and Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, announced tonight that, as operator of the Government-seized mills, he would negotiate directly with the union from now on in the wage dispute.

The Canadian-American border, famous for its lack of guns, bristled nonetheless with opinions last night as four young Toronto students and four New York high school students took part in the New York Times Youth Forum.

Texture will still be a key component in the fall fabric picture but the most important news is color. This statement was made at a Fashion Group luncheon-meeting at the Astor Hotel yesterday by Miss Susan Eastman, chairman of the organization's fabrics division and fabric editor of Glamour magazine.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- William N. Erickson, 54-year-old president of the Cook (Chicago) County Board and candidate for Governor in the recent Republican primary, and two of his aides were reported to have been named in true bills voted today by the holdover February county grand jury in connection with county government payroll scandals.

DEMOREST, Ga., April 15 (UP) -- The dean of Piedmont College resigned today in protest against the college's accepting a $500 monthly grant from an association established by an advocate of "white supremacy."

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Ray Robinson and Rocky Graziano will finally battle tomorrow night for the middleweight championship of the world. Sugar Ray, born in Detroit but now an established Harlem landlord, will defend the 160-pound title against the erstwhile problem boy from New York's East Side in a scheduled fifteen-round fight at the Chicago Stadium.

Six hundred maintenance workers at Columbia University, all members of Local 241, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., prepared yesterday to join the walkout this morning of cafeteria workers, who are seeking recognition as members of the union.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation "is running down several very interesting leads" in the special Federal rackets grand jury investigation of "possible irregularities" in the juries that sat in the two contempt trials of Frank Costello, United States Attorney Myles J. Lane said yesterday.

Edmund F. Duncan, a former plainclothes man, pleaded guilty in Kings County Court yesterday to an indictment charging him with subornation of perjury. On trial since Monday, the 33-year-old defendant entered his plea after Aaron E. Koota, a special assistant District Attorney, rested the state's case. Duncan faces a maximum sentence of one year in the penitentiary.

MADRID, Spain, April 15 -- At the conclusion of a two-day meeting, Generalissimo Francisco Franco and Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, Premier of Portugal, announced in a joint communique tonight that they would intensify their political and military collaboration to cope with the aggressive policies of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Japan will recover full sovereignty and World War II will formally end in the Pacific area on April 28. President Truman signed the Japanese peace treaty today and thereby set the stage for the final act of concord in which forty-nine nations, but not the Soviet Union, have joined.

In a next-to-the-last step in the long process of restoring peace in the Pacific, President Truman yesterday signed and thereby completed ratification of the Japanese peace treaty and the three separate pacts with Japan, with Australia and New Zealand, and with the Philippines which establish a new defense system in that area.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Announcement of a return to full scale White House entertaining was, in effect, contained in a list of Mrs. Harry S. Truman's engagements issued today by Mrs. James M. Helm, social secretary.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The State Department announced today that three new Point Four technical aid projects, amounting to $11,000,000 in United States help, had been signed with Iran.

LONDON, April 15 -- An appeal for the release of her husband was sen to Premier Stalin today by the wife of Hermann Field, American architect who disappeared behind the Iron Curtain nearly three years ago. Mrs. Field, who lives in London, said in her message:
CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- Enough copper is in prospect by 1956 to support a general United States industrial production level 24 per cent higher than the present, it was estimated today.

The quick thinking of a 21-year-old woman walking her dog at 8:30 o'clock last night on the George Washington Bridge was credited with helping to save the life of a distraught 22-year-old woma nthat the stroller had noticed clutching the railing.

People in search of an explanation of "Four Saints in Three Acts" had better not look to this column. For these comments are written by one theatregoer who is just as puzzled by the performance that opened at the Broadway last evening as he was in 1934, when the opera by Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein opened originally.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Experience has demonstrated that fair employment measures can be enforced almost entirely by persuasion, if authority to invoke compulsion stands in the background of conciliation negotiations, New York and Massachusetts officials told a Senate Labor-Management subcommittee today.

The dietary intake should be reduced about 7 1/2 per cent for each decade after the age of 25, according to studies reported here yesterday at the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Eperimental Biology at the Statler Hotel.

Testimony that the Consolidated Edison Company charged the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad the same rates for electric power as charged other customers was presented yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Werner Janssen and his seventy-piece symphony orchestra of Los Angeles will begin today to put on film the first in a series of 100 dramaticized concerts of classical music for distribution to motion-picture theatres and television.
MILWAUKEE, April 16 (UP) -- The Monarchs squad of Chicago powered their way into first place of the American Bowling Congress tournament team division tonight.

Stockholders of the world's largest corporate enterprise, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, approved the largest single financing program in the utility's history yesterday and heard Cleo F. Craig, president, express the hope for an early and permanent settlement of the current strike of telephone workers.

Governor Stevenson seems effectively to have closed the door to his nomination by the Democratic party for the Presidency -- in 1952. His statement that "I could not accept the nomination for any other office this summer" than the Governorship of Illinois, for which he has just been endorsed in the Democratic primary, is clear and explicit.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Truman returned in a serious mood tonight from his survey of the flood area. He was greeted upon his arrival at 7:02 P. M. at the Military Air Transport Terminal by E. Roland Harriman, president of the American Red Cross, and they talked for a few minutes before Mr. Truman left for the White House.

General Eisenhower has chalked up another impressive victory. In the New Jersey preferential primary three Republican names were on the ballot: Eisenhower, Taft, Stassen. The figures speak for themselves. Eisenhower won 385,000; Taft, 227,000; Stassen, 23,000.

The crop of California olives now being marketed is the largest on record. As a result of this abundance, wholesale prices on the ripe or black variety dropped 20 cents a dozen cans on Monday. It is expected that reductions will reach the retail level by this weekend.

NEW DELHI, India, April 16 -The Congress party suffered its first legislative defeat since the lections when the opposition group succeeded in naming the Speaker of the Assembly of the Patiala and East Punjab States Union today.
Ancient and contemporary styles in ceramic art, both enlivened with whimsical touches, are displayed in two new collections of objects made by two members of the same family.
Projects that have discovered facts about the physical qualities of a human being and determined what can be expected of him in his community were cited yesterday by Lord Taylor.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 17 -- United Nations military authorities announced yesterday that the Chinese and North Korean prisoners held on Koje Island off the south coast of Korea would be moved to smaller stockades south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel while awaiting exchange under an armistice agreement.

SAN ANTONIO, April 16 (AP) -- Eight reserve flying officers at Randolph Air Force Base told a San Antonio Light reporter that the base was seething with discontent. They demanded a Congressional investigation of Randolph and the Air Force Reserve program.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Government task force said today that the number of unemployed workers in Detroit fell from 102,000 to 85,000 in March, partly because of new defense work.

West Virginia The State of West Virginia announced yesterday that it' would receive bids next Thursday on an issue of $30,000,000 of war veterans' bonus bonds. The issue will be dated Dec. 1. 1951, and will come due serially on Dec. I from 1952 to 1971.

Justice William C. Hecht Jr., of the Supreme Court reserved decision yesterday on a petition by the Citizen's Union to void the appointment of Robert J. Crews, brother of John R. Crews, Republican leader in Brooklyn, to the recently created $9,000-a-year life-time job as Deputy Commissioner of Records.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16 -- Connecticut Democrats formally endorsed Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, tonight as the Democratic nominee for President.

A first trade effort in the securities business to bring under one roof a conference representing all phases of the industry -- from originating underwriters to mutual fund salesmen -- has started off auspiciously with a happily-chosen title for the meeting.

Negotiations between the steel industry and the steelworkers' union have collapsed, according to an announcement by Secretary of Commerce Sawyer. This being so, Mr. Sawyer, in his own words, will "proceed promptly, but not precipitately, to consider the terms of employment," under Section 3 of the President's Executive Order providing for seizure of the industry.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 16 -- Sophomore Jim King twirled a masterful three-hitter as Columbia moved to the front of the south division of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League with a 4-0 victory over Princeton today at University Field.

MOSCOW, April 16 (AP) -- A Soviet communique said today Russia and Communist China had signed an agreement for "significant expansion of trade" over last year's level on Saturday, closing day of the International Economic Conference. No specific figures on volume were given.

ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP) -- The Cardinals exploded for five runs with two out in the seventh inning tonight to defeat their former team-mate, Howard Pollet, and the Pirates. 6 -- 5. Stan Musial led the Redbirds to their second straight victory with a home run and a double, driving in three runs.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., April 16 -- Having provided a wet and disagreeable opening day for the eastern Pennsylvania anglers, the weather man atoned for his wrongs by having the sky swept clear of clouds today and permitting a bright sun to shine from daybreak until dark, but he did nothing about an immediate reduction of stream level.

Two autobiographical accounts of attempts to conquer two dread illnesses have been scheduled for publication four days apart. On May 8 Julian Messner will issue Dr. Hinton D. Jones' "My Fight to Conquer Multiple Sclerosis." Henry Schuman will issue on May 12 "The Fight Against Tuberculosis," by Dr. Francis Marion Pottenger.
ALBANY, April 16 -- With a blast at New York City for backing "hurried and unwise" legislation affecting its retirement system, Governor Dewey made a wholesale veto today of ten city pension bills.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

At last New York City seems to be on its way toward having a convention and exhibit hall large enough to accommodate the biggest organizations in this country. A step in that direction has been taken with a federal grant of $40,000 to prepare the plans for re-development of Columbus Circle, where the hall and a private housing project are to rise on what now is mostly a slum area.

HALLANDALE, April 16 (AP) -- Mrs. G. Taylor's Black Al, speedy 3-year-old son of Alquest-Bur Black, posted his third victory of the year as he won the Attorney General Purse before 11,598 fans at Gulfstream Park today.

A study of the flow of news in and out of this country is to be undertaken by the International Press Institute through a grant of $150,000 by the Ford Foundation, it was announced yesterday by Lester Markel, chairman of the institute's executive board.

Herb Isaacson, Brooklyn College's ace southpaw, pitched a three-hitter for eight innings and checked a late C. C. N. Y. rally yesterday to lead the Kingsmen to a 6-4 victory at the winner's field. It was Brooklyn's second success in four Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference games.

Three four-story buildings at 1404-06 Second Avenue and 299- 301 East Seventy-third Street, the northeast corner, have been sold by the estate of Emma Schwartz to Morris and Henry Luskin, realty operators and builders, in a deal marking their first change of ownership since 1889.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today it had begun mailing 1952 dividend checks to veterans holding National Service Life Insurance. The checks are expected to begin going out in large volume next month.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- For the second consecutive year The Daily News-Tribune of La Salle-Peru-Oglesvy, Ill., has received the F. Wayland Ayer Cup for excellence in typography, make-up and press work.

Umberto Giordano's "Andrea Chenier," absent from the local scene since 1947, returned to the City Center stage last night. It was the New York City Opera that sponsored it during the spring season of that year. The current revival by the same company finds an entirely new set of principals, though some of the subsidiary singers were seen in the work five years ago.

The Reynolds Metals Company has always been ready to discuss aluminum requirements for defense and stockpiling with the Government, R. S. Reynolds Jr., president of the company, declared yesterday. His comment was a response to the request earlier this week by Defense Production Administrator Manly Fleischmann for an "expression of opinion" from American business on expansion of aluminum capacity.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Dewey approved today without comment a bill that will provide $500,000 in emergency state aid for education to four hard-hit school districts that serve the mushrooming community of Levittown, L. I.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A complex set of motives led to the withdrawal of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois from the Presidential campaign.

There was a 9-year-old stakes-winner at the Jamaica cavalry grounds yesterday. F. Ambrose Clark's Tea-Maker, frisky as a 2-year-old, led all the way in the $17,450 Jamaica Handicap and paid $22.40 in the role of fifth choice in a nine-horse line-up.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The American Red Cross said today latest reports showing only one death in the Midwest river floods constituted an "unprecedented safety record" in a major disaster.

VIENNA, April 16 (Reuters) -- Closing the Communist-dominated First International Conference for the Defense of Children here tonight, the president, Prof. Gustav Monod of France, declared that each June 1 henceforth would be "Children's Day" throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's announced unwillingness to accept the Presidential nominaation scrambled further today the Democratic race for a successor to President Truman. Meanwhile jubilant backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said New Jersey's primary results kept his victory wagon rolling toward the Republican nomination.

Dr. Marvin A. Stevens, medical director for the Eastern Area of the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation, commented yesterday that the reports on Tuesday at the American Association of Immunologists' meeting concerning new research into the cause of poliomyelitis were scientific confirmation of Sister Kenny's deductions of many years ago.

A "very proud" General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower widened last night his New Jersey primary margin over Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio to 158,658 with only thirteen of the state's 3,840 election districts unreported.
CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- Jim Fridley's first major league homer and Bob Lemon's three-hit pitching gave the Indians their second straight victory over the White Sox today. The score was 1 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the United States would be seriously concerned by any independent action that might undermine the European Defense Community, but he declined to say what assurances Washington would make to guard against such a threat.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 16 -- Roman Catholic schools are not divisive and do not undermine the unity of American democracy, the National Catholic Educational Association declared today in a document outlining the Roman Catholic position on public school education.

DETROIT, April 16 (AP) -- Manager Rogers Hornsby of the Browns yanked two other players for pinch-hitters but let Pitcher Tommy Byrne hit for himself in a seventh-inning rally and the strategy led to a 5-4 victory over the Tigers today.

The twentieth biennial Young Artists Auditions of the National Federation of Music Clubs will take place in the spring of 1953, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. R. E. Wendland of Temple, Tex., national chairman of the events.

Brand name products can make more friends for America than all the billions of dollars being poured into world rehabilitation, James A. Farley, chairman of the board of the Coca-Cola Export Corporation, said last night. The former Postmaster General addressed the fourth annual dinner for the "Brand Name Retailer of the Year" given at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Brand Names Foundation, Inc.

ROME, April 16 (AP) -- Budge Patty of New York and Paris, third-seeded in Italy's twenty-two-nation spring tennis tournament, raced through a straight-set victory over Luis Ayala, Chilean Davis Cup team player, today. The international star won his second-round match, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 15 points net yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Grain futures trade operations today reflected general uncertainty as to immediate price developments. Shorts in all pits took profits freely and there was a strong undertone in consequence for a time. But operators were not inclined to take the initiative on the rallies, especially as there was no evidence of any further big flour business which helped the wheat market yesterday.

Lemuel Ayers should be one of next season's busier showmen if all his present theatrical plans materialize. According to sources deemed reliable, the producer-designer has just acquired the rights to convert Rumer Godden's novel, "A Breath of Air," into a musical showpiece.

LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- The touring American Congressional committee investigating the Katyn Forest massacre heard testimony today indicating that there is at least one other mass grave -- and possibly more -- of slain Polish officers.

BONN, Germany, April 16 -- This is the thirtieth anniversary of the signing of the Treaty of Rapallo, which linked Germany and Russia after World War I and the Russians are urging the Germans to consider another "statement of independence" of the West.

PONTIAC, Mich., April 16 -- A budding actor was jailed today under a 136-year-old law prohibiting dueling in Michigan. Carl O'Brien, 22 years old, who was "unforgivably insulted" when ousted from an amateur theatrical group, demanded "satisfaction on the field of honor" from three actors.

Banking syndicates will place on the market today new issues of public utility and industrial securities totaling more than $96,800,000. Consisting of bonds, debentures, convertible preferred and common stocks, the flotations are intended to provide permanent financing for capital outlays, some of which have been financed temporarily by means of bank loans.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- The International Materials Conference reported today that the critical shortage of newsprint throughout the free world was "easing" for the first time in more than two years. The situation has improved so radically, it said, that member countries voted unanimously against a 1952 allocation.

Mrs. David Rumsey gave a dinner last night in the Ritz-Carlton Restaurant of Carlton House for Mrs. Clement Biddle of Philadelphia, who has been in New York for the last fortnight and will leave at the end of this week to open Biddlebrook Farm, her country place at Brandywine Summit, Pa.

The new Danish-flag cargo-passenger ship Estrid Torm, latest addition to the rapidly expanding fleet of the Torm Lines, arrived yesterday on her initial visit. Dressed with colorful flags and pennants, the all-white motorship docked at Pier 5, New York Docks, Brooklyn, shortly after noon.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that consumption of cotton between March 2 and March 29 averaged 36,827 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 45,152 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 39,089 for the February period this year.

A large Harlem property changed hands yesterday with announcement of the sale of two seven-story apartment houses occupying the entire blockfront at 40 to 50 Morningside Avenue between 118th and 119th Streets by the Morningside Avenue Corporation to the Estate Securities Company, operators, through Seeger Co., brokers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- On the eve of his departure tomorrow for a two months' visit in Korea and other countries, J. Donald Kingsley, Agent General of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency, provided the first over-all listing of projects through which it is hoped to reestablish a normal economy for the Korean people.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Ellis Arnall, Director of Price Stabilization, accused the steel industry today of making unwarranted and unjustified price demands that would wreck the stabilization program.

LAUREL, Md., April 16 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur scratched himself and Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland became an added starter today in tomorrow's Presidential sweepstakes in which horses will run for the candidates.

Staging the first nocturnal major league opener ever held in New York, Leo Durocher's Giants raised their 1951 National League pennant at the Polo Grounds last night and forthwith took an imposing stride toward what 17,472 cheering fans fervently hoped would produce still another flag.
LONDON, April 16 -- Chief interest in the stock markets switched today from British Government securities to foreign bonds, particularly Japanese, which made widespread and handsome gains.

Organization-backed candidates for the United States Senate and the House of Representatives won easy victories in the Republican and Democratic primaries in New Jersey on Tuesday in all but one district.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 16 -- Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois reiterated today his intention to seek re-election as Governor and asserted he "could not accept the nomination for any other office this summer."

Twenty buildings in New York, selected by members of the Municipal Art Society and the New York Chapter of the Society of Architectural Historians as of national importance, to be preserved at all cost, were named last night at the annual dinner of the Municipal Art Society at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

LOS ANGELES, April 16 -- A sedate San Francisco housewife who, as she depicted it, stumbled more or less inadvertently into the Communist party, evoked repeated mirth in United States District Court today with a breathless account of the bewildering intrigue in which she found herself enmeshed.

ABERDEEN, Md., April 16 -- The Army unveiled today the product of a successful gamble in tank production, announcing its acceptance for field service in the United States and overseas of the M-47 medium tank.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Floyd Baker's single off Ellis Kinder with the bases loaded and two out in the eleventh inning scored Irv Noren from third base with the run that gave the Senators a 4-3 victory over the Red Sox tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 16 -- A battle for dominance between "Peronism" and North American labor union ideas is foreseen at the fifth regional conference of American states that are members of the International Labor Office opening tomorrow at Petropolis, a few miles from Rio de Janeiro.
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, April 16 -- This Midwestern farm and industrial community kept a constant and lonely vigil tonight at the lower end of a giant funnel.

A religious issue arose in Federal Court yesterday on the second day of selecting jurors to try sixteen secondary Communist party leaders on charges of conspiring to advocate and teach the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

A much firmer business tone in the latter part of 1951 and continued improvement in theatre attendance this year was noted yesterday by Leonard H. Goldenson, president of United Paramount Theatres, Inc., in reporting the earnings for last year.

When the New York Knickerbockers stopped driving they stopped winning, and after twenty-three straight home victories Joe Lapchick's quintet dropped an 82-77 decision to the Minneapolis Lakers last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The defeat was a crushing blow to New York's hopes in the best-of-seven play-off series for the National Basketball Association championships.

DETROIT, April 16 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio told Michigan Republicans today that he was the one candidate for the party's Presidential nomination capable of waging the hard-hitting campaign against Fair Deal philosophy that was needed to win in November.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 16 -General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower flew from Paris to Brussels today on the first of his good-by visits to the capitals that have forces under his command. The general will give up his post of Supreme Allied Commander in Europe June 1.

TRENTON, April 16 -- Tension at the State Prison was tightened today as 1,300 prisoenrs, locked in their cells since Tuesday during the mutiny of sixty-eight convicts barricaded in the prison print shop, banged cups on their cell doors and shouted at their guards.
OMAHA, April 16 (AP) -- The Missouri River today strained mightily -- but still unsuccessfully -- to smash Omaha and Council Bluffs, Iowa, with the worst flood in their history.

Senior Girl Scouts from five boroughs met yesterday to talk over the problems of scouting and how to bring it closer to a teenager's ideal of fun and service. It was their eighth annual conference, and the program at Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place, proved absorbing to 600 younsters who took part in the sessions from 2 to 9 P. M.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- Behind the two-hit pitching of Vic Raschi, the Yankees battered two of the Athletics' hurlers with a fourteen-hit assault that gave them an 8 -- 1 victory today in their delayed league debut.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 16 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower returned this evening from his one-day farewell courtesy visit to Belgium.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 16 (AP) -- Big Mo, the Circle M Farm's filly, scored a three-length victory over a field that included four Kentucky Derby eligibles in a mile-and-one-sixteenth allowance race today at Keeneland.

Columbia University and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., vied openly yesterday for the support of the student body after 570 maintenance workers walked off their jobs in sympathy with striking cafeteria workers, seeking recognition as members of the union.

The Physicians Home, Inc., of 1270 Avenue of the Americas, near Fifty-first Street, as residuary legatee of the late Dr. Teofilo Parodi, receives more than $700,000 to "establish and maintain a home for aged physicians with a comfortable garden."

The issue of segregation, which has been defended behind "an iron curtain," must be settled by constitutional measures instituted from outside that barrier, former Federal Judge J. Waties Waring of South Carolina declared yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor by the American Civil Liberties Union in the Town Hall Club.

HAVANA, April 16 -- The attitude of a majority of the Cubans toward Maj. Gen. Fulgencio Batista's coup March 10 seems to be a mixture of confusion, resentment and hopes. Putting it into words that they might say:

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A 155-mm, self-propelled gun will be swung aboard a freighter at Norfolk, Va., Army base tomorrow morning and will mark the shipment of the millionth ton of military equipment to France under the arms aid program.
I was interested in your editorial of April 6 entitled "Canning Should Celebrate."

The auxiliary schooner Dorothy P. Sarty, her foresail and riding canvas shimmering in the early morning breeze, slipped into New York harbor yesterday and tossed her lines over a Brooklyn bulkhead. She was five days out of Fortune, Nfld., and filled to her scuppers with 800 barrels of herring.

LONDON, April 16 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, received the Spanish Ambassador, Duke Primo de Rivera, at the Foreign Office today. It is understood the Spanish Government's request for revision of the international control of Tangier was discussed.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -Robert D. Murphy, present Ambassador to Belgium, was nominated by President Truman today to be Ambassador to Japan. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee promptly met and approved the nomination, which now goes to the floor for action.

Lords Cigarettes, originally created by Lane, Ltd., will be manufactured and distributed by Larus Brother Co., Richmond, Va., beginning June 1. Described as low nicotine cigarettes, Lords will be made under the process developed by Lane, to remove the bulk of the nicotine and leave the tobacco flavor and aroma intact. They are guaranteed to contain less than 1 per cent nicotine.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today the following principal changes for the week ended April 9.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 650,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Based on the new definition of bulk terminals as adopted by the Bureau of Mines and the institute, total gasoline supplies totaled 157,781,000 barrels, compared with 158,431,000 a week earlier and 147,734,000 a year ago.

PARIS, April 16 -- British promises to aid the projected European Defense Community in repelling aggression by external enemies have raised French hopes that Britain and the United States soon will offer assurances against any defection from within the six-nation Continental defense coalition.

An exhaustive questionnaire, almost twice as long and twice as inquisitive as the one Newbold Morris used in Washington, has been circulated among a limited number of persons by the New York State Crime Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that savings by Americans last year rose $13 billion, the greatest amount since 1945.
AMES, Iowa, April 16 (AP) -- With what coach Ray Swartz calls the "most powerful team we've ever had on hand," the final Olympic wrestling trials begin here tomorrow.
CHICAGO, April 16 -- The Josef Zylka family, Polish refugees who survived the Nazi terror, had to pinch themselves today to make sure that everything really was happening.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 16 -- Two hundred and fifty New York State, New York City and Nassau County officials joined with telephone company officials and Civil Defense authorities here today in an inspection of an expensive new atomic disease-control center.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 16 -- In the rising bitterness of South Africa's constitutional crisis, J. G. N. Strauss, leader of the minority United party, threatened tonight to "meet force with counterforce" if Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Government plunged the country into "anarchy."

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- With twenty-six words two Democrats have shattered every crystal ball in which politicians thought they saw the lineaments of the party's next nominee for President. Mr. Truman used fourteen: "I shall not be a candidate for re-election.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The extent of the states' action on necessary legislation will determine what Congress should do to permit the maximum number of service men to vote this year, President Truman informed Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, in a letter today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 16 (AP) -- Victor Paz Estenssoro was proclaimed president of Bolivia today to the cheers of his revolutionary cohorts. He pledged his regime, born in strife, would work for peace between the people and the tin mining companies "exploiting the country's riches."

JOAN LOWELL stirred up one of the most uproariously enjoyable lit'ry teapot-gales of modern times when she wrote "Cradle of the Deep." That flawed epic of the hornpipe set maddened a handful of salt-water scholiasts to a livid degree. They called upon Heaven, Homer and Herman Melville to witness that she didn't know her ship's lee scuppers from a marlinspike, and otherwise suggested that her genial reminiscences of briny days were awash with terminological inexactitudes.

Operations of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in the first three months of this year continued at or near the high levels of 1951, Gwilym A. Price, president, informed 450 stockholders and guests at the annual meeting yesterday in Mansfield, Ohio.
Having just returned from Korea and other parts of the Far East, I am greatly disturbed to find more of a defeatist attitude here than three months ago regarding the war in Korea.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Big business is getting an increasingly greater share of defense contracts and small business is getting less, Telford Taylor, Administrator of the Small Defense Plants Administration, asserted today in that agency's second quarterly report.

GENEVA, April 16 -- United States industrial superiority is neither so complete nor so simply explained as commonly supposed, according to an international group of industrial economists that has recently completed a survey of productivity problems in metal working industries of the world.
The City Club of New York has asked President Truman to investigate the official actions of William O'Dwyer, while he was Mayor of New York, or to dismiss him from office as Ambassador to Mexico.
CHICAGO, April 16 (UP) -- Rocky Graziano said tonight he could have beat Ray Robinson but "the ropes got in the way."

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson asserted today that two-way trade between the United States and its European allies was important to the "defense of the free world against aggression."

EL PASO, Tex., April 16 -- First Lieut. Verne Goodwin of Peabody, Mass., who refused to accept an assignment to flight duty, has been sentenced to two years in prison without pay and to dismissal from the Air Force.

NEWARK, April 16 -- Newark Airport, closed last Feb. 11 by the Port of New York Authority after the third fatal plane crash in Elizabeth, was reopened today on a restricted basis to the Air Force and the New Jersey National Guard.

R. K. O. will re-release "King Kong" and "The Leopard Man" in the near future, it was announced by the company. "King Kong," the top half of this dual horror program was first released in 1938 and features Fay Wray and Bruce Cabot.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The identity of the successor to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization commander in Europe hinges upon war or peace in Korea.

Zone changes for ten areas of the city, largely to make the zoning conform to actual present-day use for the affected properties, were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission at City Hall. Of the areas rezoned, four were in the Bronx, three were in Queens, two in Brooklyn and one on Staten Island.

Far-reaching changes in man's ways of making a living are "imminent," and engineers should be ready to invoke the new opportunities when a future of "relative peace" finds defense production tapering off, Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, said here last night.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 16 -- Western Michigan, with a high ratio of citizens of Dutch birth or ancestry, today gave Queen Juliana of the Netherlands one of the most lavish receptions of her American tour.
Peace talks in the key Bell System telephone strike resulted in agreement yesterday on most minor issues and hope rose that the entire dispute would be settled within forty-eight hours.

Government counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial introduced documentary evidence yesterday to support a charge that the presence of a representtive of one of the seventeen defendant banking companies on the board of directors of an issuing company was a signal to other defendants that they must not seek the business of that company.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 16 -- The Bronxville branch of Citizens for Eisenhower staged the biggest pro-Eisenhower meeting thus far in Westchester County and the biggest political party meeting in the history of this community in the Bronxville Theatre tonight.

Youthful dresses featuring bouffant skirts and snugly fitted bodices were presented yesterday by Bonwit Teller in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel. Designed by Madeleine Fauth of Arkay, many of the cotton dresses could be worn now and through the summer.

Representatives of thirty-five foreign language and immigrant aid groups, pledged to fight for enactment of President Truman's recent plea for the authorization of additional immigrants into the United States, announced yesterday the formation of a national organization -- the American Committee for Special Migration.

The Gracie Square Boys and Girls Clubs of the Home Thrift Association, Inc., will be aided by the proceeds from the showing of the motion picture "Francis, the Talking Mule," on Saturday morning at the Sutton Theatre in East Fifty-seventh Street.

A six-acre tract, formerly part of the Klein farm, on Ninety-ninth Street near Horace Harding Boulevard in Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by the Klein family to the Zen Realty Corporation, an investing client of the Queens Hub Realty Company, broker in the transaction. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -The Defense Department announced today a new total of 107,371 American battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 237 over last week's report.

Communist policy is nothing if not flexible. In the grist of one day's news we learn that the British Communist party has dropped from its executive committee Arthur Horner, who holds the important post of secretary of the National Union of Mine Workers. From Italy we learn that the Communists joined with two other political groups in a village enactment of the "Passion Play."

Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, had a cheery word for increased steel deliveries yesterday in announcing that most of the traffic relief projects in this city held up last fall because of lack of this metal were under way or would be soon.

The Foreign Commerce Club of New York, in the Commodore Hotel last night elected James P. McAllister, president of McAllister Brothers, Inc., to head the club for the next year. Mr. McAllister has been first vice president for the last two years.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 16 -- A Federal ruling made yesterday that a displaced person cannot be deported for not supporting his family because the offense does not constitute moral turpitude has Middlesex County officials in a quandary.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Associated Church Press Award of Merit for "distinguished service in religious journalism, for excellence in reporting religious news, and for objectivity in interpreting what is significant in the field of religion" was presented here today to George Dugan of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Since late 1948, the Albanian Labor (Communist) party has purged more than 12,000 members, or more than 25 per cent of its total membership then, Marshal Enver Hoxha, head of the party, has revealed in a major speech that has become available here.

" Shock treatment" and fear are the basis of the Soviet Union's public relations, Philip E. Mosely, director of the Russian Instittute of Columbia University, said yesterday in an address at a luncheon of the Public Relations Society of America at the New Weston Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board, with industry members dissenting, has recommended that two major aircraft companies negotiate a union shop agreement with 26,000 workers.

The procrastination of Government officials in general and the House Merchant Marine Committee in particular with respect to the so-called Long Range Shipping Bill was criticized yesterday by Leigh R. Sanford, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Spokesmen for the Department of Defense and for the Armed Forces told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee today that abolition or reduction of existing extra pay for hazardous duty would affect the national security seriously and adversely.

Mrs. Ann Weaver testified yesterday in defense of her husband, Capt. Franklin B. Weaver, 31-year-old master of the Isbrandsten freighter Flying Trader, who is accused of manslaughter in the shooting last Oct. 25 of William M. Harvey, 24, a messman aboard the vessel. The trial is being held in Federal Court before Judge Edward Weinfeld and a jury.
CHICAGO, April 16 -- Ray Robinson gave convincing evidence tonight of the quality that has caused him to be described as the greatest fighter of our time, pound for pound.

TRENTON, April 16 -- Three men and a woman were charged by a Federal "rackets" grand jury today with conspiring to register automobiles to avoid time payments on purchase prices and sell the vehicles at substantial profits.

OMAHA, April 16 -- If the giant dams planned for the upper Missouri River had been constructed and in operation, the flood disaster on the Missouri would not have occurred, Lieut Gen. Lewis A. Pick, Chief of Army Engineers, told President Truman today.
Judith Doniger, soprano, sang a recital in Town Hall last evening. It was the second appearance there for the Julliard-trained soprano, who made her debut on Oct. 12, 1950.

Brazil is unlikely to relax recently tightened foreign exchange controls before the latter months of 1952 and a greater volume of dollar imports from this country is not to be expected, the world trade section of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York decided yesterday at 233 Broadway.

The stock market built up a comfortable margin on the recovery side yesterday, after two days of pressure, only to face a new attack in the final hour which left the close on the lower side. It was a very thin line, however, and the number of losses come close to the advances.

American Viscose Corporation will make available to the trade its new Avcoset finish for rayon on a royalty-free basis, it was announced yesterday. The first licenses were issued to the Fontaine Converting Works of Martinsville, Va., and Lesem Bach Co., New York fabric converters.

A 71-year-old-woman was burned to death and three firemen were injured in a blaze yesterday in a sixth-floor rooming-house apartment on the upper West Side of Manhattan. Fire officials said that the woman had been smoking in bed shortly before the flames were discovered.

Two Hundred and Forty-first Street and White Plains Road must seem an other-worldly spot to I. R. T. riders whose working-day subway trips take them to homes and offices along that line but short of the ultimate station.

Wage price controls should be scrapped, Jules Backman, Professor of Economics at New York University, declared yesterday. At most, he said, a loose system of selective price controls for a few items in short supply would suffice under the current armament program.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- Without some frustrations and difficulties children would growl very little emotionally or socially, Dr. Bernice Milburn Moore told members of the Association for Childhood Education International today. Dr. Moore, an official in the Hogg Foundation for Mental Hygiene, Austin, Tex., spoke at a general session of the association's annual study conference, currently meeting at Convention Hall.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the preview showing of "Never Take No for an Answer," a Souvaine Selective Pictures film from the story "A Small Miracle," by Paul Gallico on the night of April 24 at the Beekman Theatre, Second Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital.

Rejection of fiscal independence for the city's public schools and the continuation of an appointed Board of Education, has been recommended by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, it became known yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 16 -- International communism has revived here the liberation committee, which functioned during the struggle for national independence toward the end of World War II as a cover organization for a general assault on the strong pro-Western tendencies prevalent in Lebanon.

The following is the Zist of NewI Jersey delegates to the RepubZicani lVatio,zal Co,vention i Ohicago. Ina additio to te delegates-at-large, two were picked fro,l eack o! tke state's fourteen Cmzgressional Districts. In /our districts--the Sec-i ond, Fourtk, Seve;lth and iVinth-- 'the ballots )'or district delegates had uot been coutted last .ight.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- John Abt, a lawyer for the Communist party, asserted today that Louis F. Budenz committed perjury in testimony before the Subversive Activities Control Board "to give some point to his story" about Communist operations.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A resolution against "a policy of appeasement in Korea" was adopted today by the Daughters of the American Revolution with but one dissenting vote.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 16 (AP) -- A Brazilian mission is going to try soon to drum up more two-way trade with Europe. It will also look into the possibility of moving some European industries outright to this country to help fill its rapidly growing needs.

Patrick L. Langan walked out of a General Sessions courtroom yesterday a free man after having served almost twenty years of an improper thirty-year sentence for robbery. In three days he would have been eligible for parole, but yesterday's action by Judge Edward J. McCullen was a happy conclusion so far as Langan was concerned.

Members of the congregation of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, at its annual meeting Monday night endorsed the action of the vestry last fall in nominating the Rev. William Howard Melish to succeed his father, the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, as rector.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., April 16 -- The big news today in this little seaside resort (Pop. 6,040, 1950 census) was not that Eisenhower had carried Cape May County by a ratio of 7-to-2 against Taft, but that local voters had defeated a 3 per cent sales tax for the third time.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 16 (AP) -- President Kenneth H. Redmond of the United Fruit Company today reported settlement or nearsettlement of labor troubles in Latin-American countries where !the company has huge banana plantations.

AT SEA ABOARD U. S. N. S. TROOPSHIP BARRETT, April 16 -- The Navy's first fully air-conditioned troopship, the 17,600-ton Barrett, sailed at 7:07 A. M. today from Camden, N. J., for a forty-eight-hour series of tests at sea designed to try every seam and piece of machinery in the ship before she is accepted for duty.

LONDON, April 16 -- Abdul Fattah Amr Pasha, Egyptian Ambassador who was recalled by his Government last December, returned by air to London today and spent seventy minutes with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden. He brought a message to Mr. Eden from Ahmed Naguib El Hilaly Pasha, Egyptian Premier, but its nature was not disclosed.

OMAHA, April 16 -- President Truman declared today that "it's time for action" on flood control in the nation's untamed river valleys and accused an economy bloc in Congress of "wiping out some of the most important" flood control projects he had put into the budget.

Another powerful impetus to speedy formation of a European Defense Community as a framework for a European army containing German units has been provided by the British agreement to a hard and fast alliance with all the six members of the proposed Community, including Germany.

JERUSALEM, April 8 -- All Jews domiciled in Israel on July 14, when the new Nationality Act goes into effect, will receive Israeli citizenship automatically, regardless if they are subjects of other countries. Jews arriving in Israel after that date will become citizens the moment they set foot in the state.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -William A. Roberts, attorney, denied today that two deposed Chinese Nationalist Air Force officers had written controversial dispatches to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. He said the contention was "a deliberate and apparent lie."

HAMMOND, Ind., April 16 -- Inland Steel Company, in a suit filed today in the Federal District Court of Northern Indiana, charged the Government's seizure of its steel plants was "illegal confiscation of private property."
HIS father was not enamored of the ides But the boy was insistent.
COLUMBIA, S. C., April 16 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina unfolded today his blueprint for the South's dissident Democrats in selecting and supporting a Presidential candidate this year.

MADRID, April 16 -- Maj. Gen. August W. Kissner head of the United States military mission here, had a long conversation tonight with Lieut. Gen. Juan Vigon, Chief of the General Staff of Spain's armed forces. They were believed to have discussed in detail specific United States proposals for military collaboration with Spain.
ST. PAUL, April 16 -- Upper Mississippi waters reached their crest here today, promising gradual relief from the worst flood in this city's history.

CHICAGO, April 16 (UP) -- Barney Peller, a Cincinnati fight promoter, today filed a triple damage suit against International Boxing Club officials, charging anti-trust law violations. Peller asked for $300,000 damages.

The Tanners Council of America, a trade association serving 90 per cent of the country's leather industry, is moving its executive and general offices from the leather district of lower Manhattan where it has had quarters at 100 Gold Street.

The Toubin Holding Corporation sold the forty-family house at 1535 Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx, to Max Friedman, operator, who resold it to a client of Emanuel Goldberg, attorney, for cash over first mortgage of $85,000. The property is assessed at $130,000. Max Fluss was the broker and title was insured by the Metropolitan Title Guaranty Company.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 17 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique, 1222, for twenty-fours ended 6 A. M. Thursday (4 P. M., Wednesday, Eastern standard time):
BOSTON, April 16 -- Twenty hits rattled off Dodger bats at Braves Field today, including five straight by Duke Snider and Roy Campanella's first home run, and the Brooks won, 14 -- 8.

OMAHA, April 16 -- Omaha's forecast Missouri River flood crest of 31.5 feet does not mean that the river will necessarily be that deep at Omaha. Nor do other readings up and down the river refer to actual depths.

Thin-legged little girls in neat skating costumes glided and pirouetted yesterday on the melting ice of the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park while grimier and more carefree urchins waded bare-foot in the brown water of The Pond a few yards away.

MUNICH, Germany, April 16 (AP) -- Angry words between a Jewish defense lawyer and Presiding Judge Josef Mulzer, a former Nazi, marked the opening day of the fraud trial of Philip Auerbach, 45-year-old former leader of Munich's Jewish community.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the United States did not support a move to put the bitter French-Tunisian dispute on the agenda of the United Nations Security Council because it believed the two Governments should be given a chance to settle the dispute between themselves.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Price Stabilizer Ellis Arnall announced today he is prepared to suspend price controls on raw wool, cattle hides, burlap, some edible fats and oils, and inedible tallows and greases. Mr. Arnall, in a luncheon address at the National Press Club, said these items "do not seem to require close price supervision at present," because they are selling considerably below ceiling prices.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 16 -- A wave of demonstrations against Italy and indirectly against the United States and Britain, whose representatives are meeting in London to discuss the association of the Italian Government in the administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste, has spread to all the major cities and towns of Yugoslavia.

The General Electric Company, the country's largest electrical manufacturer, urged Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, yesterday to await Congressional action before raising wages or introducing the union shop in seized steel mills.

Coffee trading provided the only appreciable volume in New York commodity futures markets yesterday. The turnover was 43,500 bags and prices declined 13 to 25 points on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The May position was especially weak and the differential between May and July had narrowed to 4 points by the close.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Governor Dewey gave his implied backing today to the detailed questionnaires being sent out by the State Crime Commission in its attempt to look into the financial activities of persons in political life.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Senators are apprehensive that television and radio fans will get angry if their favorite programs are blacked out this fall for election campaign speeches. They asked the radio and television industry today to leave some open program spaces in the months ahead for political campaigning.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- Japan will become eligible to apply for United Nations membership in eleven days, but she still has not made up her mind whether to join the waiting list of Soviet-vetoed countries.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Truman said today at his news conference that the Soviet Union could show it really wanted peace by signing an Austrian treaty and accepting the United States proposal on arms limitation.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, April 17 --Brazil is preparing "revolutionary" legislation to improve conditions of farm workers, President Getulio Vargas declared here today in a speech opening the fifth regional conference of American states who are members of the International Labor Office.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 17 (Reuters) -- Pakistani women, shunning Western influence, are returning to Mogul times for inspiration in dress and jewelry.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- With the world hovering on the brink of disaster because of Communist aggression, the United States is confronted with an alarming shortage of scientists, technicians and men of military and working age, the seventh annual Conference on Higher Education was told here today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Honesty in government was emphasized by speakers as the American Society of Newspaper Editors opened a three-day session today, attended by more than 300 editors and executives.
I am in complete agreement with your editorial of April 1 on "Men and Ships" and with the letter from Francis D. O'Connor of Portland, Me., in THE TIMES of April 10.

Average share prices on the New York Stock Exchange at the end of March were the highest since Aug. 31, 1946, the Exchange reported yesterday. The March 31 figure was $42.78, which compared with $41.18 at the end of February and $42.79 on the 1946 date.

" Jane" isn't faring as well as anticipated at the Coronet. Consequently, the Theatre Guild is planning to withdraw S. N. Behrman's drawing-room comedy, suggested by a Somerset Maugham story, on Saturday night of next week.

Officials of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis requested parents and doctors yesterday to discontinue the therapeutic use of gamma globulin this summer so extensive tests can be conducted to see if the blood fraction serves as a preventive for paralyzing poliomyelitis in children.
