A sharp decline in picketing at telephone exchanges around the country strengthened expectations yesterday of a quick settlement of the key Bell System strike, the eleven-day-old walkout of 16,000 Western Electric employes.

NEWARK, April 17 -- Internal Revenue Collector John E. Manning filed today an income tax lien of $340,486 against the assets of Joseph Stacher and his wife, Miriam, of 215 North Wyoming Avenue, South Orange.
AMES, Iowa, April 17 (AP) -- Three 1948 Olympic team members moved to the second round of the final United States Olympic wrestling trials today.
Combat Boots, a grandson of Man o' War on the maternal side, got up in the last jump and defeated Ted M. in the mile-and-sixteenth Alcedo Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

The Consolidated Edison Company notified the city yesterday that the Defense Electric Power Administration had authorized it to proceed with its $3,700,000 program to improve smoke-control installations at its Hell Gate, Waterside and East River generating plants.

MEXICO CITY, April 17 -- Charges against Gen. Octavio Vejar Vasquez for having disobeyed orders were upheld today, and the general, who is provisional president of the opposition left-wing Popular party, was formally committed for trial by a Mexican military court.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- If the Government would plan the Missouri River "valley authority" solely as a flood control project, the Rock Island Railroad, which serves part of the vast valley area, would support the project, J. D. Farrington, president, said today at a stockholders' meeting.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Ruth Steinhagen, 22-years-old, who shot and wounded Eddie Waitkus, Philadelphia Phillies first baseman, in 1949, was adjudged sane today and freed of a charge of assault with intent to kill.
OMAHA, April, 17 (AP) -- In lesser degree, the Omaha- Council Bluffs drama today was being repeated downstream almost as far south as Kansas City.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 17 (AP) -- The annual meeting of the National Association of Collegiate Commissioners which opened today probably will produce no verbal fireworks before Saturday morning.

The North American Company, once one of the nation's largest public utility holding companies, which unsuccessfully fought the constitutionalty of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1945, is going out of business.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr., Democrat of Missouri, has asked the Federal Trade Commission to make public a staff report on "an international oil cartel" which he said has been "classified as a secret document."
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution adopted today a resolution titled "Graft" which charged a "shocking and dangerous" failure in national leadership.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- During the week ended April 16, member bank reserves increased $566,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17 -- John Blandford, director of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East, said today that he was now in the process of completing negotiations with the Kingdom of Jordan on a program providing jobs and dwellings for Arab refugees there.

This is the time of year for all variety of ruts. First of all, the spring is notorious as the season when each member of the human race gloomily believes that each new day will be but a repetition of the old, that he is following -- in the dictionary definition of the word rut: a groove in which anything runs -- a regular course.

CLEVELAND, April 17 -- John E. Janowitz, a former Communist who served as an undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, named today several union leaders, nearly all of them in the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union, independent, as being Communists.
LAUREL, Md., April 17 (AP) -- President Truman isn't running for the job of Chief Executive but Truman's Choice won today.

Secretary of State Acheson performed an important service in calling attention to the inconsistency between the official United States policy of encouraging trade between the nations of the free world and the legislative restrictions on such trade in existing Congressional enactments. His answer to the Italian note protesting such restrictions pointed out that we cannot continue urging our allies to reduce or eliminate their trade barriers while we still maintain or even increase our own.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 17 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist Government accused the opposition United party today of "befouling" South Africa abroad and making "inciting" statements that might lead to violence at home.
TOKYO, Friday, April 18 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,223, covering Thursday operations:

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Faye Throneberry, 20-year-old rookie outfielder from Scranton, hit a 410-foot home run with three men on bases today as the Red Sox beat the Senators, 9 -- 2. His drive in the sixth inning went into the Washington bull pen, far out in centerfield.

KANSAS CITY, April 17 -- The race to restore this city's levee system, battered by last July's flood, appears to have been won and Kansas City expects to stay dry as the approaching Missouri River flood crest passes.

Deputy Fire Chief Nathan Perlman, one of the top-ranking officers of the city's uniformed fire-fighting force, was dismissed yesterday by Commissioner Jacob Grumet. The Commissioner found Perlman guilty on two charges of shaking down a Bronx merchant after a fire in March, 1950, and on one charge of giving $1,000 soon after that to the then First Deputy Commissioner James J. Moran "to influence his action and judgment."

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Chief of Staff to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and one of his possible successors in the European army post, arrived from Paris today to make several addresses. He declined to say anything about General Eisenhower's political course nor would he discuss the succession to command of Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe.

DETROIT, April 17 (AP) -- Les Moss and Bob Nieman hammered home runs in the last two innings to spoil Hal Newhouser's comeback debut and keep the unbeaten Browns in first place with a 3-1 victory over the Tigers today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina, in an attack on President Truman today, accused him of writing history to suit himself and of playing into Russian hands with a "wrong statement" about the Polish-German boundary.
Spring and summer fashions from Leather and Tweed, Inc., 575 Madison Avenue, were shown yesterday at a luncheon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel.

Exotic color combinations and textured surfaces distinguish some of the materials included in two new groups of decorating fabrics. One extensive group may be ordered through decorators from Knoll Associates, Inc., 575 Madison Avenue. The other, also sold through decorators, is available at Silkar Studios, Inc., 38 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) The General Services Administration, which buys supplies for civilian agencies of the Government, announced plans today for channeling Federal procurement contracts into areas where there is unemployment.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- The board of trustees at Philadelphia General Hospital ordered the dismissal tonight of five internes, a junior resident physician and a nurse for refusing to sign Pennsylvania's new loyalty oath.

BONN, Germany, April 12 -- Next month, probably on May 6, the West German Parliament will start debating a measure, almost certain of passage, whose purpose is to accomplish one of the most staggering share-the-burden plans undertaken by any country since the war.

UTICA, N. Y., April 17 -- State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi outlined here today a community program to find jobs for thousands of textile workers made idle by the removal of most of the city's textile industry to the South.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, April 18 (AP) -- Communist infantrymen hit Allied lines on the Western Korean front with five probing attacks Thursday, but all were repulsed.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Representative Richard Wigglesworth, Republican of Massachusetts, today criticized exemption of the shoe industry from a new Government manpower policy intended to channel defense contracts into "distress" unemployment areas.

MADRID, April 17 (AP) --Madrid's Mayor Jose Moreno Torres, Count of Santa Marta de Babio, announced today that he had canceled a scheduled visit to New York next month at the request of New York's Mayor Impellitteri.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- The grain futures market had several sinking spells again today, but buying resistance appeared to stiffen rather automatically on the setbacks, with fair rallies from the low spots. Not much initiative on the long side was indicated, however, and the demand tended to fade on the hard spots.

KANSAS CITY, April 17 -- Three hundred small church-related liberal arts colleges are confronted with their worst financial crisis in 100 years, it was declared here today at the annual meeting of the National Catholic Educational Association.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Following is an unofficial transcript (with most of the replies in paraphrase) of President Truman's extraordinary news conference today. It was his 300th and the first of his eighth year in the White House. Members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, many of whom have often differed with him, joined in the discussion.

Sixteen Mexican newspaper and magazine writers arrived here from Detroit yesterday, guests of General Motors Corporation and American Airlines. They had arrived in Chicago on Easter Sunday and continued to Detroit on Tuesday evening, for tours of automotive enterprises.
PARIS, April 17 -- Premier Antoine Pinay, after a week of rest on the Riviera, left today for Paris where tomorrow he will start the active phases of his campaign for the defense of the franc.
ALBANY, April 17 -- The Court of Appeals affirmed unanimously today the constitutionality of New York State's "vagrancy" law. No opinion accompanied the decision.

LONDON, April 17 -- Chairborne clerks and spit and polish guardsmen of the British Army's Eastern Command reached for their rifles and raced to three points outside London before sunrise today to repel imaginary enemy paratroopers.

Concerted action on the part of the motorman of the train, a local policeman and a member of the city transit police saved a 5-year-old girl from possible death yesterday morning on the Brighton line of the B. M. T.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Ray Robinson is willing to defend his world middleweight championship against anybody they can get for him. But as far as invading the light-heavyweight ranks to tackle Joey Maxim for the latter's title, Sugar Ray definitely is opposed.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Truman said today that the Presidency was the greatest office in the history of the world, a continuing office, and no man should consider himself the indispensable occupant of it. That was why he had decided not to seek it again, he explained.

The comparatively new medium of silk-screen printing has attracted much talent to its service. The Serigraph Gallery is the principal agent for this work and, this week, it is holding its thirteenth annual exhibition.

At the investment banking trial here yesterday, Government counsel continued to present documents intended to show that the defendant bankers controlled the financing decisions of corporations on which such bankers served as directors.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Senate Democratic leader, Ernest W. McFarland of Arizona, said today that Congress was doing so much investigating it sometimes overlooked its job of legislating.
CAIRO, April 17 (Reuters) -- The Government announced tonight a big new export drive in cotton to run hand-in-hand with a big new austerity drive at home.

Only a new Administration "with nothing to hide and nobody to protect" will have the vigor and the will to investigate and prosecute wrongdoing in Washington, Gov. John Davis Lodge of Connecticut told the Women's National Republican Club last night.

RAHWAY, N. J., Friday, April 18 -- Two hundred fifty prisoners at the New Jersey Prison Farm here were holding nine guards as hostages early today after a riot broke out in a dormitory last night fifteen minutes before the "lights out" signal.

The Queens Committee on Community Aviation Problems disbanded for all practical purposes yesterday after Borough President James A. Lundy had accused the group of dallying in its "investigation" into the April 5 cargo plane crash in Jamaica.
The New York Knickerbockers will attempt to even their series with the Minneapolis Lakers tonight in the fourth game of the final play-offs for the National Basketball Association championship.
LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- Delegates of forty-six countries met in London today to debate revision of the international wheat agreement which fixes the price and quotas of the controlled wheat market.
PITTSBURGH, April 17 (AP) -- Irving W. Wilson, president of the Aluminum Company of America, said today the company will need higher prices to counterbalance any increase in wages.

Paul B. Jones, a suspended patrolman who was assigned to District Attorney Miles F. McDonald's special rackets squad, was found guilty yesterday in Kings County Court of attempted extortion. The all-male jury returned its verdict after deliberating only one-half hour.

Leaders of the Republican organization in New Jersey increased their efforts yesterday to solidify the state's thirty-eight convention delegates behind General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower on the basis of his substantial victory in last Tuesday's primary.

Market places of the nation made their plans for the summer yesterday. The New York Stock Exchange board of governors voted to close on Saturdays between May 31 and Sept. 27, inclusive, as it has done for the past several years. The New Orleans Cotton Exchange announced that it would trade in cotton futures while daylight savings was in effect, between the hours of 8:30 A. M. and 1 P. M., Central standard time.
Macy's New York has again changed its famous -- and controversial -- price policy statement on savings of 6 per cent for cash.

ALBANY, April 17 -- The Court of Appeals, in a 4-to-3 decision, ruled today that a hospitalization service was not required to pay benefits to a member who received a $35,000 award in a negligence action resulting from an accident.
CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP) -- The Cubs were helpless before the pitching of Lefty Ken Raffensberger today, and bowed to him and the Reds, 3 to 0.

Today's new film arrival is "Aaron Slick From Punkin Crick," a William Perlberg-George Seaton musical comedy version, in Technicolor, of the stage success of the same name, at the Globe. The Paramount offering stars Alan Young, Dinah Shore and Robert Merrill. Adele Jergens, Minerva Urecal and Martha Stewart head the supporting cast.

The Soviet Government scored a propaganda, success among "borderline" peoples of the free world at the International Economic Conference just concluded in Moscow, in the opinion of A. Wilfred May, executive editor of the Commercial and Financial Chronicle.

Gerard W. Purcell, ousted fireman and former financial and recording secretary of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, was linked yesterday with a second lucrative racket when he was charged with pocketing "between $100,000 and $125,000" netted through the high-pressure sale of raffle books.

Commercial breads that require only a few minutes' baking before they are ready to serve are short cuts in themselves and they also may be utilized to shorten preparation time on other foods. These brown-and-serve breads, rolls and biscuits are readily available in groceries and bakeries.

NEW DELHI, India, April 17 -- A serious shortage of steel is expected this year as the Government has been forced to drastically curtail imports because of the high world price, official sources said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- Federal Judge Louis E. Goodman dismissed today as faulty one of a series of grand jury indictments growing out of the Internal Revenue Bureau scandals in the northern California collection district.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- A report that morale of the United Nations troops in Korea was "exceptionally high," with those soldiers right at the front having the highest morale of all, was given today by representatives of the National Jewish Welfare Board on their return from an inspection trip.
No one bothered to turn in a fire alarm when smoke was seen billowing from the roof of a nine-story building at 154 Hester Street at noon yesterday.

Sir Anton, a baby sea elephant, died yesterday. Thousands of miles from his native isle -- a victim of civilization. The six-month-old Antarctic native, resembling a sea lion, died on a Slick Airways plane en route from Los Angeles to Copenhagen, Denmark.

A Federal court jury of eight men and four women will be asked today to decide whether 31-year-old Capt. Franklin B. Weaver committed voluntary manslaughter when, about 3:25 A. M. last Oct. 25, he shot and killed a messman aboard his ship, the Isbrandtsen freighter Flying Trader.

Convinced that the remaining historic residences of Washington Square are safe from the threat of razing, at least for the immediate future, the Washington Square Committee for the Preservation of the Rhinelander Buildings has dissolved itself.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- President Truman indicated today that he believed he or any United States President had the theoretical power to seize newspapers and radio stations to protect the national welfare in war or great emergency.

With the Dodgers meeting the Giants at Ebbets Field and the Yankees entertaining the Senators at the Stadium, baseball's second round of opening-day ceremonies will be staged in the two major league circuits today.

An important forward step in the defense of the Associated States of Indo-china has been taken this week. The Vietnam Army now has its own Vietnamese General Staff and its own Vietnamese Commander in Chief, Brig. Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh. Up to this time the Vietnamese troops have been under the French command organization.

The winds that whip around the Cape of Good Hope are blowing up into a man-made tempest that may determine the fate of the whole narrow fringe of white civilization on the edge of the Dark Continent -- the Union of South Africa.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 -- The Eisenhower - for - President backers in the production end of the motion-picture industry are making a poll on a "top echelon" level to determine the general's political strength, it was learned today.

Prospective jurors in the trial of the sixteen secondary Communist party leaders were confronted yesterday with the ethical question of whether they could give a fair verdict if they believed, before the testimony started, that the Communist party advocated the forcible overthrow of the United States Government.

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, advised the public last night that it "might just as well stop reading anything in the papers about atomic energy or atomic bombs" because information leaking through the wall of secrecy is sure to be "misleading."
The letter of Suburbanus published April 9 is indicative of the fact that there has been much heat but little light cast on the general topic of off-shore rights.

Intercoastal steamship operators are expected to announce today freight rate increases substantially the same as those granted to the rail carriers on Monday by the Interstate Commerce Commission, it was learned here yesterday.

Tom Fucarino, proprietor of the United Nations Barber Shop on Third Avenue near Forty-fourth Street, discussed yesterday his victorious struggle with the United Nations (no connection with the barber shop) over his use of their common name.

Railroad men must join in a battle against improper Government regulation, William White, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, told members of the New York Railroad Club, meeting last night at the Hotel Commodore.

LONDON, April 17 -- Foreign bonds again dominated business in the stock markets today. In particular, Japanese loans again were in keen demand and most made fresh gains despite heavy profit-taking. German stocks, too, were active, and there was more inquiry for other European issues, notably Greek and Hungarian bonds.

LOS ANGELES, April 17 -- A leadership group of Communists at the party's national training school in New York State in 1939 were told that their number included the President, Governors and Congressmen of the United States of the "near future," it was testified in United States District Court today.

BOSTON, April 17 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that he would not have seized the steel industry at this time had he been in the President's place, but he dismissed as "ridiculous" Senator Taft's assertion that the seizure constituted a valid case for considering the impeachment of Mr. Truman.

Directors of the Western Maryland Railway, at their organization meeting yesterday in Baltimore, elected W. Arthur Grotz as president, effective May 1. He succeeds Eugene S. Williams, who becomes chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The State Department denied as "false" today a charge that the Voice of America had refused to broadcast messages by Billy Graham, evangelist, and the Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- The Indians ran up their third straight victory over the powerless White Sox, 5 -- 3, today with a seventeen-hit blast off five pitchers that supported the steady seven-hit hurling of Mike Garcia.
GENEVA, April 17 -- Europeans are again becoming worried about United States tariffs.

Three policemen who allegedly engaged in a street fight Wednesday night after an argument that started in a bar in Queens were suspended from the force early yesterday morning by Fifth Deputy Police Commissioner Martin H. Meaney.
The Eastern outdoor track and field season will start today with the opening of the sixth annual Seton Hall Relays in Newark Schools Stadium.
Madison, Wis., announced yesterday that bids would be received May 6 on an issue of $5,000,000 of bonds dated May 1, 1952 and due May 1, 1956 to 1972.

William S. White's dispatch on the Union of South Africa was of more than ordinary interest to me. I am a South African who was born and grew up in Port Elizabeth in the Cape Province. I mention my home town because in some way it is a synthesis of all four of the provinces which make up the Union.

Connie Ryan, a nuisance to the Giants while with the Braves and the Reds, continues to plague them as a member of the Phillies. The 32-year-old second baseman, who broke into the major leagues as a Giant ten years ago, yesterday spoiled the daylight debut of the 1951 National League champions by smashing a game-deciding homer.

The board of directors of the National Dairy Products Corporation yesterday named L. A. Van Bomel chairman and E. E. Stewart president to succeed Mr. Van Bomel, who had been president eleven years. Thomas H. McInnerney, founder of the company and chairman since 1941, was named chairman emeritus.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 17 (AP) -- Nationalization of Bolivia's tin mines appeared remote today as President Victor Paz Estenssoro's new revolutionary Government began to hedge on the economic problems confronting the country.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Negroes are being frozen out of ordered jobs in such Government projects as the construction of the hydrogen-bomb plant in South Carolina despite President Truman's establishment last December of a top-level committee to enforce the anti-discrimination clause in Federal contracts, a Senate Labor-Management subcommittee was told today.

FEW people in this imperfect world, I imagine, can be entirely satisfied with their faces. It is so easy to think of desirable improvements, a straighter nose or a more classically modeled jaw, which would alter our appearance for the better. But would facial perfection really be such a good thing? Most women would probably admit, to themselves at least, that it would.

Following are the texts of addresses made by Democratic leaders at the annual dinner of the Democratic State Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, and the letter President Truman a sent to the committee:

WORCESTER, Mass., April 17 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio opened his Massachusetts primary campaign today by asserting that the National House of Representatives had a "valid case" for considering the impeachment of President Truman for his seizure of the steel industry.

Privately-owned American-flag shipping will continue to get maximum consideration in the assignment of export cargo, and no fears need be entertained of Government-owned ships being used as "rate busters," Walter E. Maloney, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, said yesterday.

OMAHA, April 17 -- The crisis was at hand tonight as men and machines continued to try to bottle up the flooding Missouri River now pouring more than 245,000,000,000 gallons of water past the twin communities of Omaha and Council Bluffs, Iowa, each day.
ALBANY, April 17 -- The State Motor Vehicle Bureau will put into effect on May 1 a new validating system to prevent forging of state driving licenses, Commissioner James R. MacDuff said today.

New York University won its second Metropolitan Conference baseball game by defeating City College, 14 -- 4, at Ohio Field yesterday. Vince Lupica, the Violets' rangy pitching ace, yielded only five hits over the route.

TRENTON, April 17 -- A State Prison employe, one of four hostages held by sixty-nine-rebellious prisoners holed up in the prison print shop, was released tonight because he apparently had suffered a mild attack. He carried with him a note from the prisoners asking for another meeting with penal officials.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, said tonight he was not entering the Presidential preference primary in Pennsylvania, scheduled next Tuesday, "because that primary has never had the slightest influence on the delegates selected from Pennsylvania."
WASHINGTON, April 17 -Elimination of the Office of Defense Mobilization, top emergency preparedness agency, is under serious discussion at the White House.
BOSTON, April 17 -- Having polished off the Braves today for the third straight time, the Dodgers headed happily for home, eager to tangle with the Giants in the Ebbets Field opener tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board awarded an increase of five cents an hour today to more than 1,000 workers employed by the Todd Shipyards Corporation at San Pedro, Calif.

TOKYO, Friday, April 18 -- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom accepted today the enemy proposal for a reopening of secret talks among the staff officers in an attempt to negotiate the exchange of prisoners after an armistice in Korea.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., April 17 (UP) -- Franklin D. Roosevelt's "dream house" and 500 acres of the famous Hyde Park estate have been sold, a real estate broker disclosed today. The sale reduces the estate to a few acres.

As the people of the Midwest struggle to ward off disaster from swirling river floods New Yorkers, in the security of distance, cannot help but feel a sense of deep sympathy. There is little that we can do, directly, but we can make our sympathy actively helpful through the Red Cross.

Chester G. Gifford, executive vice president of Schick, Inc., has been elected president, it was announced yesterday. Kenneth C. Gifford, former president, will continue as chairman. The election of Mr. Gifford and William J. Ryan, secretary-treasurer, as directors was also announced.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 17 (AP) -- Gulfstream Park stewards today suspended Nunzio Pariso for sixty days and recommended to the Florida State Racing Commission the jockey be suspended for life for "having in his possession and attempting to use an electrical mechanical device" on Violinist in the second race today.

One of the more popular pastimes in this election year is to gauge the influence of television on the techniques of political campaigning. If a viewer wants to see for himself the various methods that might -- or, for that matter, might not -- be used, he should tune in the C. B. S. series entitled "Presidential Timber" (10:30 P. M. Fridays).

NEWTON, N. J., April 17 -- The western New Jersey streams received their share of the rain early in the week, but the majority of the popular trout waters in this area, including the Pequest and the Paulins Kill, although a trifle high today, were clear and warm enough to give the fly fishermen an early break.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce and operator of the seized steel industry, summoned a group of steel industry executives to meet with him tomorrow morning as a possible prelude to a Government-ordered wage increase for the steel workers.

BONN, Germany, April 17 -West German restiveness under United States trade restrictions came into the open today when the powerful Foreign Policy Committee of the Federal Bundestag demanded the restoration of trade with the nations of the Soviet bloc.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- The United States delegation has now reached agreement with other leading delegations on the next steps to be taken within the United Nations if and when there is an armistice in Korea.

First public distribution of securities of Gustin-Bacon Manufacturing Company, a leading manufacturer of glass fiber products, will be made today by a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. The offering covers 261,900 shares of the company's common stock priced at $21.50 a share.

Mary and her little lamb had some successors last night. They were Joseph Nardilillo and Bozo, his big red horse. At about 8 o'clock nine patrons were lined up comfortably at the bar in the Step Inn Bar Grill, 3708 Twelfth Avenue in the Boro Park Section of Brooklyn, sipping beer or other refreshment and talking about the fine summery weather. Then -- in walked a horse.

A review of declared and prospective candidates for the Democratic nomination for President took place last night at the $100-a-plate dinner of the Democratic State Committee for W. Averell Harriman, Director of the Mutual Security Administration, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 17 -- The Federal Government was sharply criticized here today for its "ineffective" defense housing program and for enacting restrictions making it "next to impossible" for many people to buy homes.

VIENNA, April 17 (AP) -- A Communist-sponsored commission demanded in a turbulent news conference today that the United States be arraigned in a Nuremberg-style war crimes trial on the charge that American troops have committed hundreds of atrocities in Korea.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended April 12 rose 11 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by cities follow in terms of percentage changes from corresponding periods of 1951:

About the only good news for shoppers this week-end is in the vegetable department where several items have declined an average of 4 cents a pound. Costs on most other perishable foods either are unchanged or they have advanced since last Friday. Butter is up 2 cents a pound, pork is higher and the usual post-Easter drop in egg prices has not occurred.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved in a modest range yesterday and closed 20 points lower to 3 higher than on Wednesday, with May lagging.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, introduced a series of bills today intended to equalize hazard pay for all members of the uniformed services, regardless of rank, to reduce other extra pay now drawn by personnel stationed overseas and to abolish the present premium of $100 a month paid to medical and dental officers.

A new study by D. W. Brogan, Professor of Political Science at Cambridge University and author of "The American Character," will be published by Harper on May 7. "The Price of Revolution" is a study of political violence in dealing with economic and social conditions.

TOKYO, Friday, April 18 -- A great fire that raged out of control for twelve hours today destroyed 5,000 houses in Tottori [cross on map] and left possibly 27,000 of the 61,000 population homeless, the Kyodo News Agency reported.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant, Secretary of Defense, expressed a "deep hurt" here today at the "lack of respect" shown by civilians toward men and women in uniform. She addressed the thirty-third annual meeting of the Associated Church Press, an organization composed of more than 100 editors of Protestant periodicals.

The seasonal downtrend in business and industrial loans in the New York area was arrested during the past week because of demands from corporations producing defense materials and those companies listed in defense supporting roles.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- In the light of troubled world conditions that may last for generations, nothing is as important to individuals or society as a whole as strong families, Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman, Professor Emeritus of Social Philosophy at the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, said last night.

Daniel P. O'Connell, Albany Democratic leader, has written President Truman suggesting Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, for the Democratic nomination for President. Mr. O'Connell wrote that Mr. Ewing would be the best possible choice from the viewpoint of vote-getting strength in New York State.

A super-strong, multi-use yarn called Totarn, made of cellulosic filaments, has been in existence since 1947 but not until yesterday at a press breakfast at the Plaza Hotel were its discoverers, the American Silk Mills, ready to talk about it.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- California's Alien Land Law, which since 1920 has barred aliens ineligible to United States citizenship from owning land in this state, was declared unconstitutional by the State Supreme Court today. The tribunal, in a four-to-three decision, found it in conflict with the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

First National Bank of Chicago, Ill., reported, as of March 31, 1952, total deposits of $2,077,672,572 and total assets of $2,307,695,446, compared, respectively, with $2,477,371,530 and $2,683,238,600 on Dec. 31, 1951. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $498,790,721 against $703,403,996; holdings of United States Government securities to $568,644,344 against $694,896,394; and loans and discounts to $1,092,889,608 against $1,147,902,122.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 17 -- If the Nationalist Government goes ahead with legislation to circumvent the courts Torch Commando will call a day of protest "to bring the country to a virtual standstill," L. Kane-Berman, national chairman of the organization, said here last night.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The task of getting the news of Government for the public and putting officials to legitimate question has again become unusually difficult, a recurring phase. In the name of "security" public servants and their activities are being more and more secluded from the press, and therefore the people.

ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP) -- The rookie-studded Pirates won their first game today by beating the fumbling Cardinals, 5 -- 3. St. Louis committed three errors and two Pittsburgh runs were unearned. Joe Muir, a rookie southpaw, was the winner.

Motorists using the Kew Gardens interchange in Queens, the gateway to and from main Long Island highways, will be plagued by a series of detours that will add to the irritation of congested travel -- at least through this year.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Truman asserted today that the Governors in the flood area had been dragging their feet on control measures for twenty-five years and he was trying now to get the present Governors to lift their feet off the ground and help get the Pick-Sloan control plan implemented.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today denounced as "baseless" and "ridiculous" certain charges made against it during the current trial of seventeen investment bankers in New York City.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- A spokesman for the National Grange said today that bigger price supports for farmers now might endanger the entire support program.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- Miss Mildred Fairchild, chief of the women's and young workers division of the International Labor Office, reported today on her arrival from Geneva that steady progress was evident in a number of countries on vocational training for women. She said the trend was noted during the recent session of the United Nations Status of Women Commission in Geneva, which she attended as a representative of the labor office.

A price protection policy on television receivers was announced yesterday by Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation to guard dealers against depreciation of their inventories as a result of the changes brought about by the prospective opening of ultra high frequency stations.

The Block Drug Company, Jersey City, will launch a two-month national advertising campaign on Monday to introduce a new Ammi-dent toothpaste, which, in addition to being ammoniated, will contain chlorophyll. Melvin A. Block, president, said yesterday that the product is the only chlorophyll dentrifrice guaranteed not to stain.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- Arriving here coincidentally with the West Coast visit of Queen Juliana of the Netherlands, the Dongedyk, a motorship of the Holland-America Line, was welcomed today by city, state and chamber of commerce officials on her maiden trip.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The National Production Authority today relaxed its inventory restrictions on copper construction materials to permit the manufacture of some thirty building materials.
ROME, April 17 (AP) -- Yugoslavia's two star tennis players, Dragutin Mitic and Milan Branovic, said today they had decided not to return to their Communist homeland.

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 17 -- Aggressive management in New England textile mills can meet Southern competition by concentrating on flexibility of operation and specialization in production, Rudolph M. Ashner, industrial consultant, declared today at a meeting of the National Association of Cost Accountants.

Buyers were offering 6.2 cents a pound, duty paid, for sugar yesterday, but sellers withdrew and prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange reflected their hesitancy. In the No. 6 domestic contract May, the spot month, rose 18 points. Other deliveries were 2 to 4 points higher and volume was 18,150 tons.

VANCOUVER, B. C., April 17 (Religious News Service) -- An attack on the separate school system as a threat to democratic traditions was made here by British Columbia's Education Minister, W. T. Straith.

Attempts by the State Board of Mediation to end the three-day-old strike of cafeteria workers at Columbia University were temporarily thwarted yesterday when university officials said they "would be unable to attend" a conference at the board's offices this morning.

LEWISTON, Me., April 17 (AP) -- Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council of New York, said here tonight he was convinced that a link between policemen in Brooklyn and bookmaking organizations could be proved.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended April 12 totaled 690,660 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,482 cars, or 2.3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 87,329, or 11.2 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 16,725, or 2.4 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 17 -- State Highway Commissioner G. Albert Hill has postponed to May 1 his decision on the Fairfield County Thruway route in Stamford. He was to have made the announcement today, but deferred action on a request from Mayor Thomas F. J. Quigley.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee today called on the "big four" running the defense mobilization and stabilization programs to report to it Monday.
CLEVELAND, April 17 (UP) -- Two new powerful drugs now are being used to reduce and control high blood pressure, the annual meeting of the American Heart Association learned today.

Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the advisory committee of Citizens for Eisenhower, declared yesterday that world peace hinged on a change in the attitude of the Kremlin and that the one man in the world best fitted to effect such a change was General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Net income of the Davison Chemical Corporation for the nine months ended on March 3 declined to $1,388,000 or $2.16 a share from $1,774,000 or $2.76 a share for the previous year's period, despite the 15 per cent increase in sales to $34,099,000 from $29,566,000.

CLEVELAND, April 17 -- An appeal for more lay leadership to enlist in the fight against heart disease was made today by Dr. Irving S. Wright of New York after his installation as president of the American Heart Association.

LOS ANGELES, April 17 -- President Truman's latest nominee for the Federal bench here, Ernest A. Tolin, was denounced by two fellow judges as "unclean" and unqualified at an unusual hearing by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee here today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee won a strong ally today in his bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination when Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois endorsed him as "by all odds the best available candidate of our party."
MOBILE, Ala., April 17 (AP) --Two white men were acquitted in Federal Court today of charges of beating a Negro fellow worker at Brookley Air Force Base last July.

Although liquor package store operators still show a marked preference for well-known, top-quality brands, a trend toward lower price "private label" whisky is becoming evident here and there around the city, a survey has revealed.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- A little fellow, hardly any bigger than Phil Rizzuto, toppled the world champion Yankees at Shibe Park today before 3,860 fans.

True to his word, the President has sent up three more reorganization plans to Capitol Hill, and there are reports of others in the making. Mr. Truman has evidently determined at last that the final year of his Administration shall be marked by a burst of effort to give effect to some of the major governmental reforms recommended by the Hoover Commission.
ALBANY, April 17 -- Legislation enabling out-of-state airlines using airfields within New York to be sued for damages resulting from accidents was signed into law today by Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A live exhibit on the art of whistle-stop campaigning was presented at the National Museum today by the head curator of the Department of Political Science, one Harry S. Truman of Missouri.
MIAMI, Fla., April 17 (UP) -- Thieves extorted $15,000 in diamonds from Dan Richter, a wealthy jeweler, today with a trick plot to kidnap his 6-year-old son.

The American Red Cross reported yesterday that 952 pints of blood for the fighting forces in Korea had been collected Wednesday in the Greater New York area. Personnel of the U. S. S. Mission Bay at Bayonne, N. J., contributed 272 pints, while the Underwood Typewriter Company and Commercial Union-Ocean Accident Company at 1 Park Avenue donated 211 pints.
The stock market came under a new barrage of selling yesterday, but managed to pare early loses to some extent before the close.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra began the final week of its 110th season at Carnegie Hall last night, and it had the protean Artur Rubinstein as soloist in two works. This surely must have sent the audience home content, thinking not only of vacation plans but perhaps also of the need to sign and deliver the renewal notice for next season's subscription.

It is a pleasure to welcome to these shores again one of the chief architects who are now building a new and united Europe -- Jean Monnet of France. French Cabinets have come and gone, but French foreign policy has none the less been able to develop new and history-making projects to give practical expression to the European unification movement now approaching a climactic stage.

LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) -The Financial Times suggested today that Britain invest sterling in American oil, minerals and cotton. These are "large unexploited potentials" that could pay Britain good dividends in her dollar earning drive, the paper said.

HANOI, Indo-China, April 18 (AP) -- French union forces, backed by United States-supplied bombers and artillery, launched a surprise assault today on Vietminh troops who had infiltrated within eighteen miles of this north Indo-China capital.

A Foley Square courtroom housing the anti-trust trial of certain investment banking houses became a forum again yesterday for disputing a ruling by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the bidding of bankers for 700,000 shares of Pacific Gas and Electric Company stock in a single syndicate in 1945 was intended to defeat competition.
Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, earned a total of $566,200 in salary, director's fees and bonus last year, or $56,000 less than his compensation in 1950.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Retention of New York as headquarters for a decade and the establishment of a major Midwest office that might become the permanent headquarters of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., were recommended here today by the council's special Committee on Headquarters Location.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 18 -- Cornelis C. van der Star, a 37-year-old hero of the Pacific war, set out today to emigrate to the United States by sailing vessel -- as his Dutch forebears did three centuries ago.

DETROIT, April 18 -- Five thousand day-shift employes of the Government-operated Detroit Arsenal heard confirmation today of reports that the Army had ordered the Ordnance Corps to turn over its tank production facilities here to private management.

Two important political developments yesterday followed Thursday night's dinner of the Democratic State Committee for W. Averell Harriman, director of the Mutual Security Agency, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Those who favor the retention of shooting galleries and penny arcades in the Times Square area would scatter sand along Broadway and turn it into a boardwalk, the City Planning Commission was told yesterday at City Hall.

The story of a lifetime of hope lay buried yesterday in the hundreds of bundles, cartons, trunks, barrels and oddments of furniture that lay piled in front of the tenement at 145 West End Avenue from which 82-year-old Mrs. Juana Martinez disappeared last month.

NEWARK, April 18 -- Production in the Anheuser-Busch, Inc., brewery here was halted at 5:30 A. M. today by a strike of 170 brewing department employes. Operations in the bottling, warehouse and delivery departments, which have more than 400 other employes, were not affected.

Clergymen have been asked by the New York City Cancer Committee of the American Cancer Society to join in a national appeal in synagogues and churches today and tomorrow to aid the fight against cancer.
CADILLAC, Mich., April 18 (UP) -- Some potato farmers are dodging price ceilings during the current shortage by providing a high- priced towing service for potato trucks.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 18 -Twenty Princeton University undergraduates faced disciplinary action tonight after 500 of them had caused an uproar early today in the heart of the town of Princeton in a "spring fever" demonstration that disrupted traffic and littered streets with water and pillow feathers.
It was in 1924 that the lustrous Julia Warlowe ended her stage career, but the intervening years have not yet dimmed for many the recollections of a long-ago Juliet and Rosalind.
Everything was all right at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, except the result of the ball game, in which the Senators beat the Bombers, 3 to 1.
Following is the text of President Truman's address today at ceremonies dedicating the new headquarters of the American Veterans of World War II (AMVETS), as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The stock market attempted yesterday to size up the Government's decision in the steel wage-price impasse and came out a little on the better side despite the absence of actual news on the situation during trading hours.
The board of directors of the Protestant Council of the City of New York made public yesterday a statement protesting appearances of commercial advertising in the Easter Parade in Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The White House minimized today President Truman's remark yesterday implying that he had the power to seize newspapers and radio stations in an emergency.

Former Police Capt. Joseph C. Workman was portrayed yesterday as an official who used his high station as a Brooklyn precinct commander to exact $5,000 a month in tribute from merchants and business establishments.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A Republican move to block the use of appropriated funds to enforce President Truman's steel industry seizure order of April 8 threw the Senate into turmoil today. The intensity and strategy of the first skirmishes indicated that a major battle of this election-year session was building up.

A remarkable feature of the President's remarkable press conference with editors from all over the country was that out of forty-eight questions only three dealt with foreign affairs. Mr. Truman himself introduced the subject in replying to a query on what he considered the paramount issue of the 1952 election.

A cross-section of the music of Artur Schnabel was put on display last night at the Museum of Modern Art, where the Artur Schnabel Memorial Committee sponsored a program devoted to the late pianist-composer.
Your editorial of April 7 entitled "The Airport Problem" fails to give consideration to at least two important elements of the problem.
FORT HOOD, Tex., April 18 (AP) -- An angry rancher who protested because his fences were torn down during Exercise Long Horn, the armed forces maneuver that ended a week ago, was a "spy."

THE trout fishermen, especially those who spurn the worm, should find the situation materially improved on most Catskill streams over the weekend and, barring a downpour, the majority of the streams should be clear and only slightly high.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark. April 18 -- In the studio of his home in a residential quarter of Copenhagen, Henrik Starcke is putting the finishing touches on the model he has made for a single statue to adorn the Trusteeship Council chamber at United Nations headquarters in New York.

VIENNA, April 18 -- Two naturalized Canadians seized at gunpoint today a Yugoslav Airlines plane to enable their mother and 13-year-old sister to escape from their Communist homeland after the Yugoslav Government had denied exit visas to them.

An article by your Science Editor, Waldemar Kaempffert, in his Sunday, April 6, column mentioned the desperate measures of the Australian Commonwealth to stamp out their wild rabbit menace with germs and poisons.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- An Air Force general said today he hoped the action of a few "won't-fly" officers will not "becloud the fine record" of 4,000 reservists involuntarily on active duty.

As pleasant to find as a bottle of rare vintage wine is Herz salami, appearing here again after several years' absence. Its tough casing, chalky with mold, is labeled "made in Holland," for that country now prepares for export this fine meat product that originated in Hungary.

CLEVELAND, April 18 -- A United States Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security ended a two-day inquiry here today after Jacob Epstein, a C. I. O. leader at the plant of the White Sewing Machine Company, had refused to repeat under oath a public rejection of the Communist party.

Alexander V. Royce has succeeded John W. Hanes as a voting trustee of the stock in the Glenn L. Martin Company, held by Mr. Martin, the aircraft plant's founder and chairman. The New York member of the law firm of Chadbourne, Wallace, Park Whiteside will represent Smith, Barney Co., underwriters in the company's recent refinancing.

Geisinger Rau, operators, sold the four-story apartment house for five families on lot 20 by 100 feet at 113 East 109th Street to Lewis Lubitz for investment. The sale was for cash over a first mortgage of $9,000.

Mozart's charming opera, "Bastien and Bastienne," is seldom performed except by a boys' choir -- as it was last evening by the Columbus Boychoir at Carnegie Hall. It seems appropriate that the opera should be done by boys of 12 or thereabouts, for the composer himself was 12 when he composed it.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- A high United Nations official recently returned from Korea said today that reports of a quick truce seem to him to be largely "Wishful thinking."

MEXICO CITY, April 18 -- The United States has indicated its intention of withdrawing from the Inter-American Committee on Social Security in a move interpreted by most Latin-American countries as an unwarranted attempt to exert pressure on them to accept a subsidiary status for the committee within some United Nations agency.

President Truman in his press conference with the nation's newspaper editors made an oblique and perhaps ambiguous answer to a question of first importance growing out of his recent seizure of the steel industry in the name of Government. The question was: "Mr. President, if you can seize the steel mills under your inherent powers, can you in your opinion also seize the newspapers and/or the radio stations?"
Following is a list of those aboard the nonscheduled C-46 that crashed near Los Angeles yesterday, as made public by North Continent Airlines :

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- International Hydroelectric System, Boston, today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve amended offers totaling $25,600,000 for four of the properties it controls.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP) -- Ninth-inning homers by Sid Gordon and Willard Marshall, on successive pitches, gave the Braves a 3-2 victory over the Phillies today and turned Russ Meyer's two-hit shutout into a four-hit defeat.

The citizens of Utica, N. Y., have shown intelligence and zeal in promptly naming a committee to implement a plan presented by the State Industrial Commissioner, Edward Corsi, for state and community cooperation in fitting into new jobs former textile mill employes made idle by the removal of most of the city's textile mills to the South.

ARMONK, N. Y., April 18 -- Biardable Allegro, orange and white setter owned by Tony Imbesi of Bedminster, Pa., and Georgia Goldie, pointer owned by Henry Berol of Chappaqua, N. Y., won the derby and the puppy stake, respectively, that began the twenty-fifth anniversary meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club today.

Forced into overtime by Pep Saul's free throw eight seconds before regulation time ended, the New York Knickerbockers outscored the Minneapolis Lakers in the five-minute extra period and gained a 90-89 victory before 5,200 fans at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

LONDON, April 18 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden will seek ways out of the present impasse with Egypt over the future of the Sudan next week in consultations with Sir Ralph Stevenson, Ambassador to Egypt, and Sir Robert Howe, Governor General of the Sudan, both of whom he summoned to London today.

Events today: Mannes Orchestra, concert for children, Mannes Music School, noon; Herman Silvers, flutist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Hufstader Singers, The Cloisters, 3; Concert Artists Guild, Steinway Hall, 4; Manon," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15: Martha Schlamme, folk singer, Town Hall, 8:30.

The remarks of a Mutual Life Insurance Company executive before the University of Buffalo business administration conference the other day furnish support for the proposal that Securities and Exchange Commission registration requirements for top-grade securities be streamlined so as to involve a minimum of paper work and waiting time.
PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP) -- Bobby Friend, 21-year-old sophomore righthander for the Pirates, shut out the Reds by 3-0 today on five hits before a home-opening crowd of 29,874 fans.

Parents are pushing today's boys and girls into a freedom and a sophistication the youngsters would prefer to postpone, according to a study of 700 college freshmen presented last night at the seventh annual conference of the Girls' Clubs of America at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

PRINCETON, April 18 -- The first step to melt opposition to the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower among the thirty-eight New Jersey delegates to the Republican National Convention was taken tonight when sixty-four of the seventy-eight delegates and alternates were guests of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll at a dinner at the Nassau Tavern.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- It is "high time" that the Federal Government gave active support to projects to promote the emotional and spiritual well-being of children as well as their physical welfare, Mrs. Frances Clarke Sayers, Superintendent of work with children at the New York Public Library, said last night.

Acting Mayor Rudolph Halley expressed approval yesterday of Mayor Impellitteri's action in canceling an invitation to Jose Moreno Torres, Mayor of Madrid, to attend the United States Conference of Mayors here on May 15.

Fighter aircraft intercepted two trans-Atlantic commercial planes and an Air Force cargo plane on Thursday during a nation-wide alert of the country's air defense forces, the Air Force disclosed yesterday. The interception was ordered after authorities had failed to receive word that the planes were approaching continental limits.

PARIS, April 18 -- Lord Ismay, Secretary General of the new, centralized headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here, said today he did not know who would succeed General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme commander of the treaty forces and that no nation had yet been asked to nominate a replacement.

ROME, April 18 -- Pope Pius XII severely condemned today the "new conception of moral life" or what he termed "morality according to situations." He said this concept maintained that right intentions took precedence over eight behavior and that every man was free to act according to the dictates of his individual conscience when faced by any particular situation.
There'll be big doings at the Jamaica Race Track today. The Wood Memorial will be run, and all fourteen entrants are candidates for the Kentucky Derby that now is only two weeks away.

Representatives of three major religious bodies made a joint appeal yesterday for a major revision of United States immigration and naturalization laws. The organizations represented were the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America; the Synagogue Council of America and the National Lutheran Council.

ALBANY, April 18 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill that would have required the immediate suspension without pay of any public officer indicted for a crime "concerning the conduct of his office or the performance of his official duties."
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP) -- Playing before the home folks for the first time this year, the revitalized Browns beat the White Sox, 7-1, today for their fourth straight victory.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan asked Congress today to repeal the sliding scale of farm price supports on six basic farm commodities -- corn, wheat, cotton, rice, peanuts and tobacco.
A collection of poems by Robert L. Peters is the only book published today. "The Cry of the Wanderer" is issued by William-Frederick at $1 in a paper cover edition.

LOS ANGELES, April 18 -- A nonscheduled airline's transcontinental passenger plane from New York City lost its bearings in an early morning overcast and crashed into a low hillside in suburban Whittier Heights today, killing all on board. The plane carried a crew of three and twenty-six passengers, most of them from the Eastern Seaboard.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 18 (AP) -- A group of Camden bankers is criticizing New Jersey investment practices under State Treasurer Walter T. Margetts as "dangerous, essentially unsound and in the last analysis not in the public interest."

HAVANA, April 17 -- The only safe prediction for the next year or two in Cuba is that it is going to be a difficult and perhaps dangerous period. Governing Cuba even in the best of circumstances is an extremely difficult proposition; governing her in authoritarian fashion while large elements of the populace are disaffected is going to be doubly difficult.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Truman lashed Congress with mockery today for drastically reducing defense appropriations. He warned that he was ready to summon a "special turnip day" session of Congress from now until January in order to get the funds restored.

Even Soviet Russia is celebrating the five hundreth anniversary of the birth of Leonardo da Vinci, probably because it conceives him as a victim of Renaissance capitalism, though it was such capitalistic rulers as the Duke Of Milan and Francis I who encouraged and maintained him. If genius expresses the aspirations of its cultural environment, then Leonardo is Renaissance liberalism incarnate.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 18 -- Paul A. Walker, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, warned educational broadcasters here today to use the 242 educational television channels allocated by the commission this week or they might go to commercial interests by default after one year.
Equity financing is about to take the spotlight of the new-issue market. About a dozen deals have been groomed for marketing, including several stand-by offerings to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce and operator of the seized steel industry, announced today that he would raise the steel workers' pay next Monday or Tuesday. It is probable that President Truman will direct him to give the full amount recommended by the Wage Stabilization Board.
TOKYO, Saturday, April 19 (AP) -- Text of General Headquarters communique 1224 for Friday:

Rumors, some of them later denied, sent coffee into a decline in yesterday's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. May futures ran through a range of 81 points and December through 95 points and the close was highly irregular, 20 points lower to 20 points higher, on 45,250 bags.

The gentleman being ushered in leaned heavily on a cane held in his right hand. His left arm was in a sling, his face was swollen and he seated himself gingerly. It was only then apparent that the visitor was our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn, considerably the worse for wear.

The twelve-day-old key strike of 10,000 equipment installers, members of the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., in forty-three states and the District of Columbia against the Western Electric Company, manufacturing subsidiary of the Bell Telephone System, ended early today when the disputants reached an agreement on a new one-year contract.

PARIS, April 18 -- Delegates to the rehabilitation meeting of Government officials and veterans' leaders held this week at the United Nations Economic, Social and Cultural Organization's house today approved a seven-point program affecting 1,980,000 disabled veterans of seven countries. It proposed:

The Federal Government is trying to work more closely on standard specifications with the country's technical societies and associations, according to William S. MacLeod, director of the standards division, Federal supply service of the General Services Administration in Washington.
OMAHA, Saturday, April 19 -- A new flood threat to Omaha developed suddenly last night when the mighty Missouri blew out a sewer line running under the dike.

One longshoreman was killed and another was wounded last night when two masked gunmen opened fire in a lower West Side bar and grill, the police reported. Thomas Plunket, 39 years old, of 333 Marlboro Road, Englewood, N. J., was slain and a companion, Roy Townsend, 41, of 364 West Seventieth Street, was shot in the leg.
The state of Connecticut has been asked to decide whether a United Nations diplomat, a new resident of the state, may continue to use New York license plates on his car.

OMAHA, April 18 -- Thousands of workers, some at planning boards and "nerve centers" in office buildings and the others working through the night in the mud or the water-soaked levees, appeared today to have stopped the "Mighty Mo" at Omaha and Council Bluffs.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Prospective travelers in rocketships who have worried about landing may find an answer in United States Patent No. 2,592,873, granted this week to Dallas B. Driskill of San Francisco. His solution is an arrangement of giant tubes, into the first of which the landing rocketship flies.

The Ever-Ready Embroidery, Inc., of New York has purchased the one and two-story buildings at 223-229 Orient Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., from Louis Sanderson and will occupy them in an expansion move. The George J. Wolf Realty Company was the broker. The property contains 18,000 square feet of space.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent over the week ended April 15, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Mrs. Florence A. V. Twombly, last surviving grandchild of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt and widow of Hamilton McK. Twombly, who died April 11 at the age of 94, divided her estate between her two daughters, it was learned yesterday when her will was offered for probate.
Five new art exhibitions of diverse character deserve attention from gallery visitors this week.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Britain has added her voice to complaints from Europe that United States tariff restrictions may weaken the defense of the West.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois endorsed today the United Nations defense of South Korea and said that it had demonstrated to the Soviet Union the willingness of the free world to use armed force to stop aggression.
ITHACA, N. Y., April 18 (AP) -The president of the New York Curb Exchange said today that taxes would have to remain at a high level regardless of what administration was in Washington.

The three-story dwelling at 98 Visitation Place, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Roman Catholic Church of the Visitation to a client of the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, broker in the transaction. The new owner plans to convert the building into six apartments.

NEWARK, April 18 -- New York City entries captured two of the three Eastern high school championships decided at today's opening session of the sixth annual Seton Hall relays. The two-day carnival at Newark's Schools Stadium is the first big rendezvous of the Olympic year outdoor track and field season in the East.

Construction contracts showed an increase in March over February for the thirty-seven states east of the Rockies, according to the monthly report of the F. W. Dodge Corporation. The March total of $1,321,254,000 was 49 per cent above February and 4 per cent ahead of March, 1951.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- The Cubs chased their nemesis, Harry (The Cat) Brecheen, and pushed across four runs in a ninth-inning rally to open their home campaign with a 5-4 triumph over the Cardinals today.

Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, and the heads of eight film companies received scrolls honoring the film industry as teaching aid in the nation's class rooms last night at a dinner commemorating the fifteenth anniversary of Teaching Film Custodians.

AMES, Iowa, April 18 (UP) -- Forty-seven of the nation's top amateur wrestlers survived two more rounds of the trials today and will battle through two rounds tomorrow for eight places on the United States Olympic wrestling team.
LAKE CHARLES, La., April 18 -- In decisions supporting freedom of the press, a judge today acquitted five Louisiana newspaper men accused of defaming sixteen public officials and three gamblers.

Recommending that the problem of the striking cafeteria workers at Columbia University be considered from the "point of view of the students' interests," the Columbia Student Council urged the administration last night not to allow unionization of the employes and to give as many of the jobs as possible to the undergraduates.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Ellis Arnall, price stabilizer, promised today to keep his office doors open to reporters and to answer their questions as fully as possible about Office of Price Stabilization activities.

ALBANY, April 18 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill increasing harbor pilotage fees in the Port of New York after receiving notification that the pilots and shipping industry had reached agreement on the rate to be charged.

Under active evening up in the May delivery, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange averaged lower yesterday, closing within a few points of the lowest levels of the current reaction, at net losses of 10 to 34 points.

As it seems to do to most things, spring brings about changes on-the dining table. New accoutrements for salads, cold meats and other warm-weather dishes, are now available in the form of condiment sets, many of which might later grace a table set out of doors.
CLEVELAND, April 18 (AP) -- Bob Feller pitched the Indians to their fourth straight victory today -- a six-hit 5-0 shutout over the Tigers, before a home opener crowd of 56,068.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 18 -- Catholic educators were warned today against permitting "Deweyism" or a "soft" curriculum to enter their school programs.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution closed the organization's sixty-first Continental Congress today without voting a resolution favoring United States withdrawal from the United Nations, but with an official statement of views tending strongly in favor of such action.

The selection of jurors progressed slowly yesterday in the United States Court House on Foley Square in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders on charges of conspiring to advocate and teach the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 18 - The Government announced in advance for the first time today the exact date and time it was going to set off an atomic explosion.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -The recently authorized railroad freight rate increases will go into effect on May 2 except on grains, which will take their rate rise on May 17. The rail industry today completed the necessary filing of notices with the Interstate Commerce Commission, setting those effective dates.

A new simplified phase of air travel from Canada to the United States, involving "the preclearance" of baggage at Toronto and thus allowing passengers to disembark quickly at destinations in this country without clearing customs on landing, has been termed a great success by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

BUFFALO, April 18 -- A statement in which Carl G. LoDolce, of Rochester, former Army sergeant with the Office of Strategic Services, allegedly confessed that he murdered Maj. William V. Holohan behind enemy lines in Italy in 1944 was introduced in evidence today in Federal District Court.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 18 -- Representatives of the Western powers have suggested to the Yugoslav Government that repeated demonstrations in front of their embassies and legations in connection with the London conference on the Trieste question have become tiresome.

Plans for the establishment of an annual Robert Morrison MacIver Award for students in the social sciences were announced last night at a surprise testimonial dinner for the sociologist at the Blitmore Hotel.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- A sharp controversy erupted here today at the annual National Conference on Higher Education when Dr. T. V. Smith, Professor of Citizenship at Syracuse University, defended secularism in many of the country's colleges and universities.
BONN, Germany, April 18 -- One of the most urgent of the many tasks that face the organizers of the new West German Army is the development of an officers corps of about 22,000 men.

Generalissimo Franco of Spain and Premier Salazar of Portugal conferred for two days this week in an ancient castle turned into an inn not far from the border between the two countries. Such meetings are so few and far between that the encounter has given rise to considerable speculation.

New evidence showing how the basic units of all living matter, protein molecules, are built up out of simple materials called amino acids was presented here yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 19 -- All the disputed issues in the negotiations for an armistice in Korea were turned back today to staff officers for further exploration to determine what areas might exist between the Communists and the United Nation views.

A tract at 136th Street and Sixty-fourth Avenue in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, has been purchased by the North Kew Gardens Hills Development Company for improvement with seventy-five dwellings. Work is to be started at once on the first section of twenty semi-detached houses which will be priced at $11,990.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 18 -- Two masked thugs broke into a new ranch-type home in fashionable Wykagyl Park here at 4:30 A. M. today, awoke the three occupants, slugged one, bound and gagged all three and escaped with $26,500 in jewelry, furs and cash.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, April 18 (Reuters) -- The Southern Rhodesian Government has decided to sell all the country's gold on the free market for dollars to help fight off the country's adverse trade balance.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, said today that the marketing of a more nutritional type of bread had been blocked by a Government agency, which promptly denied the accusation.
PARIS, April 18 -- Jacques Griffe inaugurated the midseason fashion shows with middies for the beach, princess frocks for afternoon and a slightly heightened waistline for evening.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Presdent Truman told a group of Protestant editors here today that when "things go wrong" in government the fault can usually be traced to an uninformed citizenry.

BOSTON, April 18 -- Leaders in the chemical, electronics, metals and fibres fields emphasized the importance of research in industry today in a series of panel discussions held under the sponsorship of the Boston Chamber of Commerce.
The Hawaiian Pineapple Company will soon join the ranks of producers of frozen juice concentrates, known as the fastest growing infant in the food industry.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 18 -Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio carried his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination into industrial central Massachusetts today, pledging to the American working man, "without qualification, a return to honesty and integrity" in government.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 18 -- Despite the Government's assurance that it stands for freedom of the press, the presses of this country's largest and most influential newspaper, La Razon, continued to remain silent tonight. Earlier today La Razon's editor, Guillermo Cespedes, had asked Cesar Aliaga, Minister of Government, for protection.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, April 18 (AP) -- The Armco Steel Corporation has shelved plans for $45,000,000 to $50,000,000 worth of construction "because of taxes and the uncertainties resulting from the wage-price situation in the steel industry."

Sweeping policy changes designed to make missionary work in India more effective have been recommended by the India Committee of the Division of Foreign Missions in the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. The proposals, formulated by representatives of thirty Protestant foreign mission boards and nine related groups, will go out to the council's membership today.

NEW DELHI, India, April 18 -- The Communists, with newly won political allies, have succeeded in toppling the pro-Nehru Government in Patiala and East Punjab States Union (commonly called "Pepsu"). It was the Reds, first victory in a doubtful state since the recent general elections. It gave them an important new bridgehead in northern India.

In a speech to the American Veterans of World War II President Truman yesterday lashed out at the movement in Congress to slash funds for our national security programs by means of the meat-axe technique, and in effect called on all veterans to use their influence to head off this move in order to prevent another world war.

Ninety happy children in starched party dresses and best suits took the sun yesterday at Central Park's Tavern on the Green for a round of egg rolling, spoon races and balloon blowing. Many of them were so young they could scarcely remember their fathers, all of whom were killed in World War II or in the Korean conflict.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Truman today issued an executive order directing all Federal departments and agencies to prepare plans for continuing their essential functions in Washington and elsewhere in case of an attack upon the United States.

PARIS, April 18 -- Premier Antoine Pinay returned to Paris today refreshed by a week's holiday on the Riviera and determined to obtain immediate results from his drive to bring down prices, which he calls the vital feature of his program to defend the franc.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Civil air authorities acted today to compel nonscheduled air lines to tighten their operating procedures and end certain "lax" practices.

For the first time, the final judging in the annual American Theatre Wing Concert Award contest ended in a tie yesterday at Town Hall. Helen Clayton, lyric soprano and former WAVE, shared top honors with John McCollum, tenor and former fighter pilot in the Navy.

On consolidated sales of $63,396,261, which were 6 1/2 per cent below the corresponding period a year ago, the Monsanto Chemical Company had a net income in the first quarter this year of $5,389,241 after taxes and all charges, according to the report issued yesterday by Charles Allen Thomas, president.

CLEVELAND, April 18 -- A report that a newly developed drug with broad remedial powers is available for the treatment of high blood pressure was denounced as "misleading and potentially dangerous today by Dr. David Grob of Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, at the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the American Heart Association.
DARMSTADT, Germany, April 18 (AP) -- The Stars and Stripes of World War II, unofficial newspaper of the United States armed forces, celebrated its tenth anniversary today.
