Maurice van Praag, who is retiring at the end of the season after thirty-six years as personnel manager of the Philharmonic-Symphony, yesterday afternoon received a gold medal and from the full orchestra a fanfare before its concert at Carnegie Hall.

PEARL HARBOR, April 18 -- Lieut. Marion C. Kilpatrick, former skipper of the Navy salvage ship Reclaimer, stood cleared today of charges made by a small group of enlisted crewmen aboard the vessel that the crew had been under pressure of adherence to picayune regulations.

Textile and apparel inventories in the hands of retailers have been brought down to normal levels in the last twelve months, according to Louis M. Bernstein, merchandise administrator of Macy's, New York. Primary textile markets, he said yesterday, will experience upward pressure on prices in the second half of 1952, reversing the present trend which has about "hit bottom."

It was perhaps never so written in the stars, but throughout a long and dreary winter it had become the firm conviction in Flatbush that the Giants had something coming to them the first time they invaded Ebbets Field. And yesterday, after 3 hours 50 minutes of tense struggling under a warm and sunny sky, it happened.

Roland La Starza, 191 3/4 pounds, Bronx, scored a technical knockout over Joe McFadden, 188 1/2, Winston-Salem, N. C., in the fifth round of a scheduled ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night before 2,815 fans. This was La Starza's fiftieth triumph in fifty-one fights.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands warned today at a civic luncheon that if it wanted to survive, humanity could not wait too long "to unite into one great efficient community."

LONDON, April 18 -- The stock markets ended the week today on a very firm note. After looking slightly dull in places at the start of trading, they strengthened under the lead of British Government securities. These funds closed with a fairly general rise of about two shillings six pence (35 cents).

With an excellent campaign for victory over communism well started with the Marshall Plan, Point Four program and proposed further economic aid abroad, it would seem most unwise to curtail it and risk the catastrophe of defeat in this global contest for the sake of saving only a few cents out of each tax dollar.

BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- Clyde (Dutch) Vollmer regained his timely hitting form and singled in the run that enabled the Red Sox to open their home season with a ten-inning 5-4 victory over the Athletics today.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, April 18 -- A United Nations mission to study and plan the technical education of the South American Indians to help them raise their level of life is soon to begin work in Bolivia, Ecuador and Peru. Formal announcement of the project will be made here tomorrow at the fifth regional conference of American States who are members of the International Labor Office.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- The free nations of the world can bring about the elimination of imperialistic communism and avoid a third world war by planning collectively so as to keep "our military and economic strength in balance over a long period," Percy C. Spender, Australian Ambassador to the United States, declared here this afternoon.

New Yorkers, unfamiliar with the primary laws of other states, particularly those of Wisconsin and Illinois, in most cases do not know that the primary laws of those states do not contain the safeguards that the New York primary statutes do.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18 -- "Branded Woman," a short story about pioneer settlers in Arizona written by Hal G. Evarts, has been acquired by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and will be produced in the fall, with Jean Hagen playing the lead role.

Truman Capote's first play, "The Grass Harp," a dramatization by the author of his best-selling novel, will terminate its local run at the Martin Beck Theatre after the evening performance of April 26, the thirty-sixth showing.

ROME, April 18 (AP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris fought his way into the semi-finals of the Rome international tennis tournament today with a strong finish over Italy's American-schooled champion, Fausto Gardini.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 18 -- The Venezuelan and United States Governments opened negotiations here today to reform the reciprocal trade treaty that has existed between the two countries since Sept. 6, 1939. Venezuela asked for reconsideration of the treaty last year, stating that it prejudiced Venezuela's interests in view of new economic conditions here.

Many people in the advertising departments of retail concerns tend to drift off into other fields because merchants lack the foresight to provide a continuing program of sound training and study for them, according to Paul Hollister, corporate publicity advisor of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

After a second session yesterday of the adjourned sixth game between Samuel Reshevsky and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires in their eighteen-game match at the Marshall Chess Club, the New Yorker won in 61 moves.
The following is a round-up of household hints, derived from various sources, that may be of use to homemakers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18 -- "Branded Woman," a short story about pioneer settlers in Arizona written by Hal G. Evarts, has been acquired by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and will be produced in the fall, with Jean Hagen playing the lead role.

Truman Capote's first play, "The Grass Harp," a dramatization by the author of his best-selling novel, will terminate its local run at the Martin Beck Theatre after the evening performance of April 26, the thirty-sixth showing.

ROME, April 18 (AP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris fought his way into the semi-finals of the Rome international tennis tournament today with a strong finish over Italy's American-schooled champion, Fausto Gardini.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Some weapons of modern warfare are so terrible that civilization might be imperiled by their use in another conflict, Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, warned the American Society of Newspaper Editors as their convention continued here today.

Two suspended Internal Revenue collectors and a member of the New York State Police were indicted yesterday by the special Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury on charges of extorting $7,000 from a Suffolk County farmer in an income tax case.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The National Production Authority reached back today into the World War II days to revive a system for granting priorities for deliveries of machine tools for defense contractors.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 18 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan gave an unqualified pledge to South Africa today that next year's general election would be held on schedule and that his Nationalists would "subject ourselves to the people's will."

Representatives of fifty-one Hi-Y chapters of the Brooklyn and Queens Young Men's Christian Association took over the City Council chamber as a one-day youth "government" yesterday and, after considerable discussion, acted on a variety of new "laws" for the city.
HATBORO, Pa., April 18 (UP) -- Two wing tanks fell from a Navy jet training plane today, narrowly missing two houses and injuring a 5-year-old girl.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped from 2,178,075 to 1,907,952 shares between March 14 and April 15, the Exchange reported yesterday. Neither total included short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.

BONN, Germany, April 18 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, has appealed informally to Army and Defense Department authorities in Washington urging them to persuade Army authorities in Europe to give up Occupation privileges such as housemaids and special trains paid for by the West German Government.
The sixty-nine prisoners barricaded since Tuesday morning in a print shop of the Trenton State Prison surrendered yesterday afternoon, releasing their three remaining employe hostages unharmed.

MOSCOW, April 18 (AP) -- The magazine Bolshevik, which expresses Soviet communism's political policies, emphasized today that further strengthening of the Soviet state apparatus, the Army, and the intelligence service was a continuing necessity.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Truman revised some ancient symbolism that he found today on an eightenth century musical clock and two candelabra, gifts from President Vincent Auriol of France. Nobody present knew offhand what goats and roosters signified in old France, but Mr. Truman associated them with the Democratic party in general and Democratic factions in Jackson County, Mo., in particular.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, April 19 (AP) -- Allied troops on the central Korean front yesterday assaulted and captured hill positions from which Communists forces had poured down hot fire for a day and a half.
LA PAZ Bolivia, April 18 (UP) -- President Paz Estenssoro today clarified his position on the vital question of nationalizing the tin mines, Bolivia's main source of wealth.

TOKYO, Japan, April 18 -- The Japanese trade unions today called the largest and most effective strike since World War II with an estimated 1,000,000 workers laying down their tools in protest against labor legislation proposed by the conservative Government to take effect when Japan regains her independence late this month.

Dr. Thure Viltrup of Copenhagen was scheduled to fly to London early thi smorning with the body of a baby sea elephant that died on Thursday after a sea and air journey from its place ture on Campbell Island, 300 miles 300 miles south of New Zealand.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Rain in the dry area of Texas and Oklahoma, and a forecast for more in west Texas, started the wheat market off on a sharply lower basis this morning, but there was a gradual recovery as commission absorption cushioned the initial selling wave.
Army and Coast Guard personnel got together at Governors Island yesterday in a test of their possible cooperation in the event of an aerial bombing attack on New York City.
Many dinner parties were given last night at the annual "Gay Thirties" dinner dance in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.

A midnight meeting in a midtown hotel between Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City and a "notorious" waterfront gangster in an effort to obtain labor peace on Jersey docks was revealed yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 18 (UP) -- Cold Command, C. V. Whitney's second-string Kentucky Derby candidate, scored a thrilling head triumph over Calumet Farm's Hill Gail, the Midwest's top hope for victory in the Churchill Downs classic, in today's Dixiana Purse at Keeneland.

MILWAUKEE, April 18 (AP) -- Steve Nagy, 38, went on a spree today in the American Bowling Congress tournament. He helped produce one meet record, and placed himself in the top spot in the doubles and all-events.

Three members of a $3,000,000-a-year international combine that sold narcotics and counterfeited money were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman to serve two years in prison and to pay $2,000 fines each for conspiracy to violate the narcotics laws.

If Americans this spring are more Italy-conscious than ever--tourist bureaus assert all former records are faning---the Italians naturally are getting more conscious of the Americans. Here are some of th things they say about us thee days in various fascinating categories.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- United States foreign policy was criticized and defended here tonight by speakers at the closing session of the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

TOPEKA, KAN. IN thirty-one states of the Union delegates to the national Presidential nominating conventions are chosen by state conventions -- or, in a few instances, by state committees -- of the major parties. In only seventeen states are the national delegates chosen -- and, by extension, the people's Presidential preferences indicated -- by some form of the primary system.

" As we were gently sailing down the still clear water, we heard the noise of a rapid in which we were about to fall. I have seen nothing more frightful, a mass of large trees entire with branches, real floating islands came from Pekitanoui, so impetuous that we could not without great danger expose ourselves to pass across.

Twelve hundred representatives of newspapers and news agencies throughout the United States and Canada, including editors, publishers and other executives, will be in this city this week to attend their annual Newspaper Week gatherings.

ONE summer day shortly after the premiere of "Tosca," the great Giacomo Puccini was driving his car at high speed in the vicinity of Lucca when he crashed into a ditch, dumping himself and his mistress, the wife of a traveling liquor salesman, onto the highway.

THE theatre for the last ten or fifteen years has been dominated by ballet. Not only has it been the sort of entertainment that the public wanted most to see but, warned by this sun of popularity, nourished by streams of gold, it has developed and expanded its own scope and, further, has exercised a dominant influence on other forms of theatrical activity.
When a promotion that starts out as a publicity stunt increases advertising and creates interest in a whole group of products, it leaves the field of press agentry and enters the realm of marketing.

THE appalling facts of the Robert Vogeler and William Oatis cases supply the background for this novel, the Literary Guild selection for May. "Trial by Terror" is a work-manlike job as both reporting and adventure story-telling, but the conflict between its two aspects is its undoing as a novel.

SOME time hence four men -- the candidates for President and Vice President from our two major political parties -- will ceremoniously board special campaign trains, flanked and followed by coveys of political advisers, secretaries, ghost writers, body servants, oddly assorted flunkies and radio, television and newspaper correspondents.

Answering the letter in your columns of April 6 as to the absence of reference to cats in the Bible, in connection with Harry Gilroy's article "The Cat: From Egypt to Here," my authority states that the cat is not mentioned in the Canonical books.

SAN FRANCISCO. ANEW and promising development in regional theatre is taking place this month on the West Coast. The Northern California and Nevada Theatre Council, in cooperation with its parent body, the American National Theatre and Academy, will sponsor a full week of dramatic events to be given on the picturesque Monterey Peninsula, beginning today and continuing through next Sunday.

If Senator Robert A. Taft had had his way before the United States entered the Second World War Hitler would have been the undisputed ruler of Europe and, in effect, of the Western world. If Senator Taft had had his way after the Second World War Stalin would today be the ruler of all Continental Europe and, to a large degree, of the Western world.

TWO seasoned freelance photographers share their experiences, information and enthusiasm in two new books which set out to advise amateurs how to take pictures that sell. Pin-money is the theme of Harrison Forman's "How to Make Money With Your Camera" (New York: McGraw-Hill. $3.50), to be published Thursday.
Don Gehrmann and Peter L. Waters yesterday were named as the recipients of the New York Track Writers Association's annual merit awards.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 19 -- For several thousand years, Jews of Yemen, the little Arab Kingdom on the shores of the Red Sea, have celebrated weddings and other important occasions with dances both grave and gay.

MANY handsome perennials are content to flower in shaded areas of the garden. By shade I do not mean dank, murky corners, where overhanging evergreens and heavily - leaved, low - branching trees create perpetual gloom.

EXCITING new chrysanthemums await the gardener's selection this year. They represent a wide variety in type, height, flower size, form, color and time of bloom. For the old method of hit-and-miss propagation has given way to planned, scientific breeding by noted hybridizers.

The Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research is not given to endorsing treatments that purport to "cure" cancer. It avoids the word "cure." Last week it issued an interim report in which it optimistically summarized the remarkable results of its attempts to shrink human tumors with viruses.
HONG KONG, April 19 -- One out of every ten foreign Roman Catholic missionaries left in Red China is in a Communist jail, according to a report released here today by the Catholic Welfare Center.

BONN, Germany, April 19 -- About 40,000 young men in West Germany will come of age next year and of these about 26,000 are expected to be fit for conscription to service in the new German army. How to change these young men into soldiers is one of the basic problems of those planning the Federal Republic's contribution to the European Defense Force.

Senator Estes Kefauver, candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, declared here yesterday that if he had it to do over again, he would vote against the Senate confirmation of former Mayor William O'Dwyer as Ambassador to Mexico.

Employers are missing an opportunity to improve labor relations by not explaining to employes more thoroughly in simplified terminology the provisions of pension and other benefit plans, management observers contend.

St. Johns' University strengthened its hold on first place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference by defeating N. Y. U., 5 -- 4, at Dexter Park yesterday. The triumph was the Redmen's third in league play and their fifth over all.
PITTSBURGH, April 19 (AP) -- Herman Wehmeier, aided by three Cincinnati home runs, pitched the Reds to a 9-to-3 victory over the Pirates today.

" AMERICA," wrote Francis Parkman, "owes Robert Cavelier de la Salle an enduring memory, for in this masculine figure is the pioneer who guided her to the possession of her richest heritage." Parkman, of course, left an enduring monument in his epic, thirteen-volume work, "France and England in North America."

American buyer interest in the Canadian International Trade Fair, June 2 to 13 in Toronto, is expected to reach record proportions this year. Recent Canadian trade figures indicate that a great many American manufacturers are looking to Canada as a ready source of supply and this year's fair is promised to be the largest and most complete display of Canadian industrial might ever shown.

THREE more Russian notables and the French novelist Victor Hugo (1802-1885) have been postally honored by the U. S. S. R. A. 1-ruble stamp is for the 125th anniversary of the birth of Petr Petrovich Semenov-Tianshan-ski (1827-1914), explorer and geographer to whom Czar Alexander III gave the privilege of adding "Tianshanski" to his surname because of his researches in the Tian Shah Mountains.

DAVID O. SELZNICK who has been absent from the active production lists since 1948 and "Portrait of Jennie,'' may return to the fold, it was learned last week. Reached the other day, Selznick admitted that he was seriously discussing a co-production deal with Giuseppe Amato, Italian producer of "Tomorrow Is Too Late," an arrangement, incidentally, which would also involve the services of Jennifer Jones (Mrs. selznick).

The Dodgers, unbeaten this season, notched their fifth victory, and second in succession over the Giants, 11 -- 6, at Ebbets Field yesterday. Nine homers, five by the Brooks, featured the contest. Bob Porterfield pitched the Senators to their second straight over the Yankees, 2 -- 0, at the Stadium.

OUT of the normal six-month garden season here in the Northeast, three can be made reasonably work-free. Nor need the other three, two at the beginning of the season and one at harvest and clean-up time, entail any drudgery. Happily, energy and enthusiasm are greatest in the spring, when the most pronounced effort must be expended is the garden and grounds are to pay dividends.

A combination of adverse factors turned department store trade softer than usual for the first post-Easter week. Volume was estimated off 10 per cent from that for the corresponding week last year. In addition to the customary letdown after the holiday sales, two rainy days at the start of the week cut trade.

A CAMPAIGN biography is not supposed to be a literary masterpiece, and this one is no exception. Its purpose would appear to be to depict the senior Senator from Ohio and peripatetic candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination as a man of wit and humor, stalwart Americanism, warm affections and unswerving principle.
BUTLER, Md., April 19 (AP) -- Pine Pep, owned by Mrs. William Clothier Jr., of Philadelphia, became the fifth horse since 1898 today to win two straight American Grand National steeplechases.

Charging that the Republican-controlled Legislature had foisted a series of unfair nuisance taxes on New York City for partisan advantage in next year's Mayoralty election, Robert F. Wagner, Borough President of Manhattan, called yesterday on Governor Dewey to call a special session of the Legislature to consider a realistic fiscal program for the city.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The rubber industry was freed of all but skeleton controls by the Government today. Beginning Monday the National Production Authority will drop all restrictions on the consumption of natural rubber with the exception of controls over pale and sole crepe rubber, which are still in short supply.

MADRID, April 19 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco told the Spanish people today that it was the feeling of national unity that permitted Spain to defeat the machinations of her "traditional enemies" to overthrow the present Government after the end of the civil war.

The Old Guard of the City of New York paraded in City Hall Plaza yesterday afternoon at its annual review and swearing-in of military officers. Deputy Mayor Charles Horowitz greeted the officers of the society, who received the oath from Lieut. Col. C. Pemberton Lenart, assistant to the Adjutant General of New York.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 19 -- The project for an economic union of the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, known as Benelux, has stopped dead in its tracks. This is the upshot of an exchange of notes between the Dutch and Belgium Governments revealing a serious disparity of views on how to proceed from the present stage of "preunion."

IT'S cherry blossom time, the annual signal that parks and botanical gardens are rapidly losing their stark winter appearance. Forsythia, magnolia, daffodils, species tulips, rhododendrons and many other plants are joining the spring pageant of color.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 20 -- United Nations truce negotiators told the Communists today that the conferences on terms for enforcing an armistice in the Korean war were heading toward a dead end unless the enemy produced a new proposal.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- The eighth session of the Human Rights Commission got down to work this week in a new setting -- the UN's permanent Manhattan home on the East River -- and immediately found itself faced with some old familiar issues.

A LABOR of love that was six years in preparation, this two-volume history of the Vincentians in the United States is an impressive monument to the industry and scholarship of Daniel T. McColgan and to the society of Catholic laymen it commemorates.
Plans to train Indonesians to man their own merchant marine are being developed by the new nation This is reported here by the International Transport Workers Federation.

IN 1782 the Clark family and their neighbors, the Browns, floated by flatboat down the Tennessee River, poled up the Ohio and the Cumberland to French Salt Lick, now part of Nashville. Nine-year-old Andy Clark would have greatly preferred to go overland with his Uncle Aswell, who was a Long Hunter and therefore everything that Andy wanted to be.

ON May 1 a host of solicitors will start tramping Cincinnati streets, going from house to house asking for donations to help support four of the city's cultural prides -- the Cincinnati Symphony, the Cincinnati Summer Opera, the Cincinnati Art Museum and the Taft Museum. Their goal is $290,000 and they hope to reach it by May 27.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The United States and its allies will continue to insist on a unified Germany to be associated in a Western European defense plan, Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today.

ERSKINE CALDWELL'S latest novel illuminates some shadowy corners of backwoods Maine, where the conflict between old-stock "petered-out" Americans and the more vigorous-blooded "foreign element" can be a troublesome as a jug of hard cider at a wedding. Caldwell followers willing to make the trek north will find the journey rewarding, although hardly a pioneering experience: the ingredients are standard Caldwell and to this reviewer at least they are beginning to run thin.

IN the treasure house of Italy the city of Florence is the most dazzling jewel. Its beauty is visible on the outside as well as inside the rich galleries and palaces. Nowhere are its medieval aspects more in evidence than along the northern banks of the Arno River.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Set out woody plants as soon as possible. Prepare soil deeply and enrich it for grape and ornamental vines, bush and tree fruits, deciduous and evergreen shrubs and rose bushes. After filling in soil carefully around roots, mulching is the last step. AND IF THERE IS TIME: After rose bushes are pruned, apply a balanced commercial fertilizer.
The signers of the Declaration of Independence averaged 44 years of age, a researcher reports.

IF occasionally this seamy side of London made itself felt, there was, as compensation for the visitor, the varied pageantry of London life which could be seen free and for nothing. For those who enjoyed a glimpse of the aristocracy, Hyde Park had great rewards for the casual stroller.

AGNARLED old crabapple tree dominates our Vermont garden. Two generations of children have learned to climb through the angular branches and worn a permanent notch in the limb where a series of swings have hung.

CAMDEN, N. J., April 19 -- The Navy's newest and fastest troopship, the U. S. N. S. Barrett, slipped proudly into her berth today in the Camden shipyard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation with the brooms of victory prominently displayed from her masts fore and aft.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 19 -- The Government will not assist the reopening of the newspaper La Razon by guarding its building against possible violence, President Victor Paz Estenssoro disclosed today.

IT is Laraine Day's contention, after five years of marriage to Leo Durocher, that "baseball wives are people" and, in a chatty book whose tone is set by its title, she sets out to prove it. A corollary theorem is that baseball players are people too, at least away from the diamond.

WHITE PLAINS, April 19 -- Vaulting to victory in the show's last stake event, the palomino gelding, Injun Joe, from Harry Williams' Millarden Farms at Annville, Pa., tonight gained the open jumper championship at the twentieth anniversary Secor Farms Riding Club Horse Show. Pat Dixon rode Injun Joe to a 12-point score.

ONE two-year-old I know goes into a spasm of sheer delight whenever he sees a patch of clover or queen anne's lace. His reaction is the rule, not the exception, for children just naturally love flowers. Although David is a little young to start a garden of his own, by the time he's five, he'll be ready to try his hand at the game.
DERBY, Conn., April 19 -- Three crews from the United States Naval Academy combined to score a stunning success in beginning another rowing year against Yale on the Housatonic River today.

Some of the folks in Richmond (Texas), U. S. A. are going to be mighty put out if people who read your section last Sunday got the idea from Horton Foote, author of "The Chase," that Richmond is a town of his imagination. I don't know about those characteristics he names describing other Texas Gulf Coast towns, but they certainly seem to fit Richmond snugly.

A teen-age girl in Lancaster, Pa., was so determined to finish reading a stack of comic books at one sitting that she took fifteen pills to keep her awake all night -- and was hospitalized in the morning.

The 1952 appeal of the Bishops Fund for the Victims of War will open today in the 386 parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York with the reading of a special letter from Cardinal Spellman.
NEW Handel recordings range from a version of Messiah that sells for $6.57 to Mischa Elman playing three of the Violin Sonatas.
Concern over the implications of the steel wage-price controversy, combined with a host of other bearish factors, unsettled financial markets last week.

The couple Mr. Raskin wrote of in "Life With Tom and Mary Garland" is far from "average." They are not "average" if they can live in six rooms rent free. The "average" New Yorker cannot put aside money for defense bonds weekly. They are not "average" if they can feed four adults and two children on meat for $6 a week.

Keith Munro's interesting summary of Canadian economic and political progress, "Now Canada Comes of Age" (March 30) did not cover in great detail the problem of under-population which greatly hampers further development.
Three men, all college presidents, told 150 college-trained women yesterday that while women had made great strides in education, they still faced many problems.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- Oregon's electors were watching this week the beginning of the state's Presidential primary campaign. The primary election May 16 will provide, according to one point of view, an answer to this question:

BOSTON, April 19 -- Doroteo Flores, a 30-year-old mill weaver from Guatemala, surprisingly outran 156 rivals today to win the fifty-sixth annual Boston A. A. marathon. He was the first Central American to win the world's most honored road race.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- Omar (Turk) Lown made his 1952 pitching debut with a four-hit performance and Hank Sauer and Frankie Baumholtz drove in five runs with homers as the Cubs beat the Cardinals today, 8 -- 1.

Prices of men's fall clothing generally will be $2 to $5 below spring levels and about $5 to $8 lower than fall, 1951, according to indications of the dozen or so men's clothing companies that have already announced new prices.

Mothers of the Gowanus Houses development in Brooklyn will form a baby buggy brigade at the project's main crossing at Hoyt Street tomorrow at 8 A. M. to support their demand for a traffic light there.

Electronic devices for regulating traffic are to be tested at the approaches of the Delaware River Bridge at Penn and Linden Streets in Camden, N. J. Plans for installation of the mechanism have been announced by Ransford J. Abbott, New Jersey's Highway Commissioner, as part of a program to eliminate bottlenecks during heavy summer traffic.

THE theory that a woman in her forties is not necessarily a doddering crone but, on the contrary, may still be in a position to wreak a certain amount of havoc, has worked its way into the women's-magazine school of fiction. In "All That Heaven Allows" Edna and Harry Lee have met this situation head-on.

IN the good old days of a year or two ago theatregoers, used to complain that the theatre was tossing away its finest asset by not reviving the best plays of the past. No one can fairly make that complaint this year. At least thirteen of this year's productions have derived from past theatre literature or previous theatre successes.

A vacant square block at Ninth' -treet and Castle Avenue in Spring Valley, N. Y., formerly owned by the HUlman estate, has been chosen by Friedman Brothers of Passaic, N. J., for their newest home colony. The land was purchased from Jack Hart through the Orland Agency, broker.

A COMMON question in the minds of strawberry and raspberry growers is whether or not to apply fertilizers to the planting in the spring of the fruiting year. The answer to the question in regard to raspberries is yes.

MANY chemical weedkillers are now on the market. When applied under proper conditions and at suitable concentrations, they eliminate weeds, leaving the crop plant relatively unharmed. These chemicals are useful when the crop is resistant to them and the most prevalent weeds are susceptible.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise in his sermon yesterday morning at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, decried the reliance of crowds who fill abuses of worship upon attendance at religious services as the real means of attaining peace, justice and truth.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Millions of tons of snow began melting rapidly some weeks ago in the upper reaches of North and South Dakota and in Montana, and as a result all of the states lying in the basin of the mighty Missouri River have faced, are facing or soon will face another flood of disaster proportions.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 19 -- Brilliant three-hit pitching by Walt LeCates enabled Army to shut out Harvard, 3 to 0, in the first game of an Eastern Inter-collegiate League double-header on Doubleday Field today. In the second encounter Harvard pounded out ten hits in routing the cadets, 11 to 0.
WINONA, Minn., April 19 (UP) -- Hundreds of persons fled their homes along sections of the Mississippi River today as a record flood crest hit the Winona dikes.

Since the title of Edward Crankshaw's article, "Should We Do Business With Russia?" (April 6) was couched as an interrogation, I take it that it would not be an intrusion for me to give a brief answer.
Both interesting and informative, Rom Landau's "Peace May Be in Moslem Hands" (April 6) was a brave attempt to analyze that area of the world.

A compromise pilotage fee, worked out under terms of the bill signed by Governor Dewey raising the tolls in the Port of New York, was viewed yesterday in local shipping circles as a "monument" to cooperation.

WOULD you prefer for President a blacksmith, or a maker of lance-points? Or will you pick a man who lives on a hill as against a son of Arthur or of Anastasius? How about someone from Varenne in Normandy? The conventions will pay a lot of attention to these men come July -- that is, of course, if you take the literal meaning of some of the names mentioned as important candidates.

Cotton prices last week moved mostly downward, with short-lived strength developing on the scale-down. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week with net declines of 58 to 101 points,, following advances of 3 to 24, points in the previous holiday week.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- Selling pressure knocked grain prices down on the Board of Trade today. The market didn't have much rallying power, although some late support entered wheat on trade reports Sweden and Brazil had bought some cash wheat.

THE recent announcement of an International Sculpture Competition organized and conducted by the Institute of Contemporary Arts, 17 Dover Street, London W. 1, England has created widespread interest and the responses have overreached the wildest anticipations.

The number of buyers in the wholesale market here last week increased as merchants started to replenish summer stocks, resident buying offices reported. With the high comparative figures of 1951 not out of the way, stores were beginning to feel optimistic and were placing better orders.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- In the majority opinion by which the State Supreme Court this week outlawed the California Alien Land Law as contrary to the Fourteenth Amendment to the Federal Constitution considerable space was devoted by Chief Justice Phil Gibson to a discussion of the United Nations aspect of the case.

LONDON, April 19 -- Britain's leading atomic scientist denied today that security restrictions on nuclear physics information was a serious barrier to scientific progress but expressed concern at the trend in this direction.

Students from twenty New York high schools will put into action their ideas about running the legislative branch of the United States Government at a two-day Model Congress at Hunter College, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street on Friday and Saturday.
PARIS, April 19 -- In a speech he will make at the opening of the Lyon International Fair tomorrow Premier Antoine Pinay will appeal to workers as well as to merchants and manufacturers.

DANBURY, Conn., April 19 -- A repetition of last year's fight by the Citizens - Taxpayers Association of Danbury to block across-the board salary increases for Danbury's public school teachers appeared in the making today.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Several hundred fraudulent "education" institutions are being operated in many sections of the United States in a diploma racket that is believed to run into millions of dollars annually, and the Federal Government is virtually helpless to end the practice.
Collectivization of agriculture in the Eastern European satellites of the Soviet Union has been almost completely stagnant since mid-1951, a review of recent data from those countries indicates.

ALBANY, April 19 -- President Truman's seizure of the steel industry has posed a serious problem for the state Workmen's Compensation Board by placing some 50,000 steel workers in a "shadow zone" where the board may or may not be able to pay them benefits.

Following is a list by Congressional districts of the Republican and Democratic candidates for delegates to the national conventions, to be voted on at the New York State primary election on Tuesday, with two delegates to be elected in each district:

WE stopped in at the Museum of Modern Art one day recently to see a small model of a new kind of children's playground, designed by the Japanese-American sculptor and designer Isamu Noguchi and architect Julian Whittlesey.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 19 -- Adherents of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, preparing for the Utah convention here April 26 that will send fourteen delegates to the Republican gathering in Chicago in July, were publicly predicting a clean sweep for their candidate today while privately admitting that the amateur-led supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower have been showing unexpected strength.

YONKERS, April 19 -- The largest crowd ever to watch a harness racing program at Yonkers Raceway -- 30,351 -- tonight saw Major Hal score a three-length victory in the first half of the White Plains Pace in 2:06, fastest time of the meeting.

The regular White House press conference is an institution that came to full flower under Franklin D. Roosevelt. Unlike Presidents Coolidge and Hoover, to whom dealing with the press was an ordeal, F. D. R. apparently enjoyed it. When he died correspondents wondered how his successor would handle the barrage of questions.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 19 -- General Eisenhower's successor as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe will face a multitude of problems -- both psychological and practical -- in carrying on the buildup of Western defense forces. Where one type of problem ends and the other begins will be a difficult decision for the new Supreme Commander to make.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 19 (UP) -- Seaward and Jockey Steve Brooks passed three horses coming into the last bend today and went on to score a two-length victory over the favored Ruhe in the $13,200 Ben Ali Handicap at Keeneland before a crowd of about 14,000.
" If everything goes all right," said Sol Rutchick early yesterday afternoon at the Jamaica Race Track, "I'll put Master Fiddle and Count Flame on a plane for Louisville on the 24th."

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Political statistics estimated today that upward of 1,100,000 voters, representing nearly one-fourth of Pennsylvania's eligible Republican and Democratic electors would cast ballots Tuesday to indicate their choices for President and elect sixty district delegates to each party's national convention.

LYNN, Mass., April 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio closed a three-day campaign tour through Massachusetts tonight with an appeal to "a whole generation of Americans who have grown up under New Deal and Fair Deal Administrations," to support the Republican party's program for a return to the principles of liberty and peace.

LITTLE by little, especially with the resumption since the war of exhibitions of work by European artists, we have been getting the over-all picture of the development of the modern movement filled in.

ROME, April 19 (UP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles showed the seriousness of his "comeback" today when he withdrew from a doubles match in which his team was winning so that he could "save himself" for the singles.

" PRIVATE HENRY BARRY, aged 31, stood on the deck of a troopship in Boston Harbor. * * * The sun was hot and all the seagulls in New England had Come to see us off. They dove into the harbor and perched in droves along the pier and on the fishing boats.

THE biggest year-round tourist attraction in the Caribbean, the Gulf of Mexico and the near-by Atlantic Ocean is sport fishing. Florida promoters began to recognize that fact at least thirty years ago. Ten years later, when the depression hit and competition for tourist dollars became particularly keen, resorts operators began to offer all sorts of prizes for the biggest fish caught off their shores.
Black marketeering in a staple, the potato, has shifted from the city racketeer to friendly old Farmer Brown.

IN this day and age the insatiable and dispassionate realism of John Taylor Arms, whose prints and drawings are on view at the Public Library, Knoedler's and Kennedy Co., might merely seem anachronistic were it not for two important qualifications.
Two longshoremen, witnesses to the killing of another longshoreman in a Greenwich Village tavern on Friday night, were held in $50,000 each yesterday as material witnesses.

POLYMUSIC has started a cycle of music by Gabriel Faure, and recently has issued the first two disks of the series. They may prove of exceptional interest to some listeners, and may help to establish Faure on a wider plane than heretofore.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., April 19 -- After a feud of many years, sport and commercial fishermen using the beaches around Montauk have finally got together and signed an agreement to set aside certain sections of the beaches for the use of each group. The agreement, signed this last week will be operative for the rest of 1952.

GREAT NECK, L. I., April 19 -- The St. John's University nineteenth annual invitation rifle tournament, conducted on the ranges of the Kings Point Academy today, was won by St. Johns. The nominal host outscored six rivals with a total of 1,424, and captured honors for the third consecutive year.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Democratic Presidential nomination, already turned down in advance by the retiring President, two members of the Supreme Court and the Governor of Illinois, was up for grabs this week in what looked like a continuing free-for-all fight right down to the Chicago nominating convention on July 21.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Republicans pick 224 and the Democrats 168 national convention delegates in the coming week. Most of them will be named in the New York and Pennsylvania primaries on Tuesday.

Look west in Madison Square Garden on any afternoon or evening and you will see Nate Eagle. He is the red-coated gentleman with silk-beaver topper who stands behind a microphone and bellows the adjectival barrage that calls attention to the wonders to be worked by each succeeding performer in the three rings.
The recent wave of airline disasters in which hundreds of lives were lost is causing serious concern to the insurance industry and its policy-holders as well.

EL PASO, Tex., April 19 (AP) -- The commanding officer of Biggs Air Force base says Lieut. Verne Goodwin, sentenced to two years' imprisonment for refusing to fly, did not mention his wife's health in asking to be grounded.

The New York Athletic Club captured its second major indoor polo championship of the month when it turned back the Ramapo Polo Club, 11 to 9, in the final round of the national senior tournament at the Squadron A Armory last night.
ALBANY, April 19 -- A bill that would have barred public officials who refuse to waive immunity and testify before grand juries from retiring on pensions was vetoed today by Governor Dewey.

In the "Science in Review" section of THE TIMES for April 13 I find myself quoted to the effect that tactical atomic bombs are wasteful. Here is an example of how even a well-intentioned quotation may be so brief as to be misunderstood out of context.

PARIS, April 19 -- One question asked in almost every NATO capital as General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower travels around Europe on his farewell tour is, who will succeed him when he relinquishes his SHAPE command in June?

LONDON, April 19 -- Although officials are maintaining a discreet silence regarding General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's successor as Supreme Commander, Allied Powers in Europe, part of the British press appears to be seeking actively to crystallize public opinion in support of Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Chief of Staff. In fact he is the favorite of the officials, too, in confidential conversation.

Mrs. Maria Ravelli of 87 Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, stands barely 4 feet 6 inches but she is worth her weight -- about 135 pounds -- in wildcats, a would-be purse snatcher discovered at 7:30 yesterday morning.

IT is strange that John Coffee Hays (1817-1883) should have so long escaped the attention of the biographer. His personality and exploits are stamped deeply upon the histories of two states, Texas and California, whose sons have never been backward in memorializing the achievements of the pioneers.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors closed its convention tonight with a declaration by its retiring president that the powers of the President of the United States "do not include the power to violate the Constitution."

As with almost every development in television, the lifting of the "freeze" on the construction of new video stations has raised many questions in the public's mind. Here are some of those questions together with such answers as can be given now:

THE complete correspondence between Richard Strauss and Hugo von Hofmannsthal, published recently by the Atlantis Verlag (Zurich) under the tactful editorship of Willi Schuh, comes as a highly illuminating artistic document. The earlier volume containing some 180 letters dating from 1908 to 1918 cannot be compared with it.

The following is a factual report on an intelligent parent's advance preparations for a railroad journey with his small son and how the plan worked out. It is presented here not so much for the advice it contains as for the consolation it may afford other parents facing the same problem.

From automobiles to cracker packages, American industry is spending $100,000,000 a year on the design and redesign of its products and their containers, Walter F. Margulies said here yesterday. His firm, Lippincott Margulies, has conducted a survey of industrial design firms like itself and of the staffs of the big corporations.
After six months' intensive research in distribution of fashion apparel, American Airlines has begun a nationwide campaign to increase air shipments of women's wear.

THIS beginner's guide to the stars and primer of astronomy represents the pictorial method of teaching at its best. It is almost certain to become standard equipment among amateur star gazers. H. A. Rey's text is well organized and far more simply written than one would think possible in such a difficult subject.
ONCE a man becomes an ex-President of the United States people can be fairly sure they won't see him again in the White House unless he is sight-seeing or invited there by the current tenant.

ARMONK, N. Y., April 19 -- Travel Top, a 5 1/2-year-old orange and white pointer dog owned and handled by Harry Townshend of New Haven, Conn., took the open all-age stake that occupied the second day of the Southern New York Field Trial Club's twenty-fifth anniversary meeting today.

Fritz Kreisler has just given his priceless Guarnerius violin to the Library of Congress and to the people of the United States. In response to such generosity we can only return our humble thanks. This is one of the greatest violins ever made, given to us by one of the greatest violinists who ever lived.

MONEY lust, passion and moral degeneracy are the sordid ingredients of this case history of two partners in murder. Few fictional tales of horror can match in malevolence the true story of Martha Beck and Raymond Fernandez, "The Lonely Hearts Killers," who were executed at Sing Sing on March 8, 1951, for the murder of Mrs. Janet Fay, an elderly widow.

THERE is something about an island that appeals to the imagination. Usually the name bears out the enchantment -- witness the Hebrides, Capri, Curacao, Madeira. The Channel Islands, however, had no such exotic aura for me when I first saw them as pink dots on a blue and yellow map in a sixth-grade geography.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 19 (AP) -- The Evangelical Confederation of Colombia, a group of seventeen Protestant denominations, listed today twenty-three alleged persecutions of Protestants, including the burning of homes, in eight provinces since Feb. 15. It said that this series of alleged abuses had topped thirty months of similar persecution.
The "man who came back" might well be the tag for Walter W. Weismann.
TO the continuing and lively discussion about just how deep are the inroads that television has made on the radio audience, the current Hooper ratings have added a small but significant fact.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 19 -- In a four-day session here this week the National Catholic Educational Association made a vigorous rebuttal to criticisms of the parochial schools. The meeting held categorically that there is a place for parochial-school education in this country and that the concept of parallel school systems is well within the American tradition.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- In an earlier day, when life was much less complicated for the makers of United States policy, the influence of America was exerted automatically on the side of almost any colonial people trying to achieve independence. Americans were very conscious that they had once been under colonial rule themselves, and the spirit of '76 was one of the mainstays of our foreign policy.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 19 (AP) -- The National Association of Collegiate Commissioners tonight pledged its "wholehearted support" to enforcement of regulations governing intercollegiate sports as set up by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, and agreed that the "undesirable trends" which followed World War II were rapidly disappearing.

THERE is certainly no visible change in the economic situation of the modern dance, but there are so many signs of fresh creative activity that it is difficult to resist the perhaps irrational belief that we are on the first dim edge of a new coming to life.
THERE is rejoicing in Erin. That fine gentleman, the late Sir George Oliver Colthurst, it is announced, has put in his will that the Blarney Stone shall never be removed from Blarney Castle.

OMAHA, April 19 -- The upper Missouri River valley will stay wide open for floods such as the one now ravaging the basin until some means of storing the water or otherwise holding it in check is worked out, river experts agreed today.

SINCE the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra concludes its 110th season this afternoon, the presumption is that it is here to stay. It may be guessed that over the years, from the modest first concert in 1842 through the more than 100 concerts of its 1950-52 season, the orchestra has given pleasure and satisfaction to thousands of patrons.

TOKYO, April 19 -- Negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war slowed to a virtual standstill this week despite expressions of hope from Washington that some new twist in the talks -- the nature of which is not conjectured here -- might yet bring results by May 1.

World champions? A Hollywood casting director would have shrugged off the Yankees with a polite "not-the-type" dismissal yesterday at the Stadium, after Casey Stengel's singularly silent offense had been completely muffled by Bob Porterfield of the Senators.
DENVER, April 19 (UP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson attacked General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight for the Administration's $7,900,000,000 "globaloney" mutual aid program.

The possibility of using fluorides in table salt as an alternative to fluoridation of drinking water to protect the teeth against cavities has been raised by Dr. Gunnar Santesson, a Swedish physician who until recently was working at the University of California Medical Center, San Francisco, and who studied sixteen groups of hamsters.

A MAJOR improvement in rail service to Mexico City will be made this summer when National Railways of Mexico places in service a de luxe lightweight Diesel-powered streamliner now being built in Switzerland. Delivery is expected in late May or early June.

The Missouri Valley floods of 1951 were catastrophic. The Missouri Valley floods of 1952 are already being described as the worst in history. With incredible force hundreds of billions of gallons of water are pouring daily from the upper reaches of the broad Missouri, coursing through the channels, battering at the levees, inundating cities, overflowing farmlands.

A bust-length portrait of Abraham Lincoln, painted from life by Thomas Hicks in Springifeld, Ill., after Lincoln's nomination for the Presidency, was purchased at auction here yesterday for $18,000 by Oscar B. Cintas of Havana, former Cuban Ambassador to the United States.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 19 (AP) -- Two Springfield, Mass., juniors broke meet records at the Payne Whitney pool tonight, but the New York City Boys' Club captured the senior team crown and the Boys' Club of Boston took the junior title in the national boys' club swimming championships.

THE great thing about the late Senator Arthur Vandenberg was that he was a pretty good symbol of America in the Thirties and Forties. In the Thirties, like the United States, he was isolationist, boastful, inexperienced in the field of foreign affairs, idealistic, contradictory, fiercely suspicious and dogmatic, and often hypocritical.

RIDER HAGGARD, the creator of Allan Quatermain, the Horatio Hornblower of fifty years ago, was born in 1856 and died in 1925. He wrote sixty books, besides a large two-volume autobiography. He was knighted, not for his books, but for his services as an expert on agriculture.
WHILE sitting in a movie some night, don't be too surprised if a neighbor raises a gadget to his ear and suddenly dashes from his seat and makes off in the direction of a telephone.

A NEW model of the $1,350 German-made 16-mm Arriflex camera is to be imported by the Kling Photo Supply Company. In addition to many unique features and convenient handling, the camera's most ingenious device is a mirror reflex system that permits viewing and focusing through the lens while the camera is in operation.

Sweltering in 80-degree heat in their barricaded dormitory and believed to have little food and water, the 232 beleaguered prisoners at the New Jersey State Prison Farm at Woodbridge, near Rahway, went into their third day of mutiny last night. It appeared, however, that they were nearing capitulation.

TRENTON, April 19 -- The state budget law for the next fiscal year, providing $210,683,627 for departmental operations, debt service, highway building and school and welfare grants to counties and municipalities, has been signed by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

Five years ago a group of students at Rutgers University organized a fraternity in which persons of all colors, creeds and nationalities were eligible for membership. This was an experiment in social living, designed to test the principle of broad fraternity participation.

KNOWING virtually nothing about mathematical physics or celestial mechanics and relying wholly on Egyptian, Babylonian, Chinese, Mayan and other texts and legends, Immanuel Velikovsky produced "Worlds in Collision," a sensational success. In the effort he convinced himself and a goodly number of literati that the planet Venus was once a comet, which had twice crashed into the earth with dreadful results.

The last paragraph of Peter Kihss' "Man Against the Locust" (April 6) is misleading. The locusts mentioned in the New Testament were not insects but the bean-shaped fruits of the honey locust tree (genus Robinia).

Most truck deliveries of food to Columbia University stopped yesterday as teamsters honored the picket lines of cafeteria workers seeking union recognition. Administrators worked long hours to keep supply lines open.

THE spring crop of free guide-booklets and pamphlets for vacation planners continues to flourish. Pennsylvania's Calendar of Events, covering the rest of the year, can now be obtained from the State Department of Commerce at Harrisburg.

Jokes circulating in Europe today include a few that are simply "a laugh for a laugh's sake." A number of others serve as ideological and political weapons. Many are recognizable as merely new versions of old stand-bys. Here is a selection by Times correspondents.
AMES, Iowa, April 19 (AP) -- Iowa and Oklahoma wrestlers tonight dominated the championship finals of the United States Olympic trials at Iowa State College.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 19 (AP) -- River Divide Farm's Mass o' Gold captured the $7,500 Hallandale Purse today, as Gulfstream Park closed Florida's most successful thoroughbred racing season.

The fervid gardener can scarcely wait to get a fork into the soil. His soil. His garden plot, which he knows is waiting so eagerly for his attentions. He knows exactly what he is going to do this year and how he is going about it. He has his seeds and his plans. And now he has spring.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- Izvestia, the Government newspaper, characterized the conclusion of a peace treaty with Germany today as an "urgent matter," and demanded the "most rapid" action to end the present German schism.
SPRING often seems to be a round of one chore after another. It is therefore a relief to recall some things that need not be done. Neglecting nonessential tasks is a great timesaver.

PARIS -- The French Ministry of Tourism has issued its official list of prices, which should give 1952 visitors to France an indication of how well they should line their pocketbooks before setting out. The franc for the moment is still 347 to the dollar, and the black market rate is fluctuating between 400 and 450.

PEREZ GALDOS died in Mandrid in 1920. His grandfather had been an officer of the Inquisition. He, on the contrary, was a militant liberal in the novel ("Dona Perfecta," "Gloria," "Angel Guerra," etc.) as well as the drama ("Electra," "Papa Juan," "Sister Simona"), who came to be the champion of the struggle against the medieval spirit of the monarchy.

SPRING is a season of false starts and promises. A few warm days coax magnolia, spicebush and species tulips into bloom, but when Saturday and time for gardening arrive, a frost may have turned the edges of magnolia brown and the tulip heads may be folded tight against the cold.
Something like 28 per cent of the Bolivian tin industry -- now under threat of nationalization by the revolutionary government of Victor Paz Estenssoro -- is owned by United States investors.

NASTURTIUMS, either climbing or bush type, single or double flowered, are an excellent annual for cutting. The lucky owner of a greenhouse, however, has to steel himself to pull out his flowering plants only a few weeks before it is time to sow seeds indoors.

The auction offerings in New York this week are at the season's floodtide. In the galleries, nearly all of which have scheduled sales, are the outpourings of many estates -- valuable platinum and diamond jewelry and antiques, paintings and Currier Ives prints, near-antiques and a large miscellany of reproductions, and the many classifications of what might be called decorative objects and home appointments.

Fordham put on a mighty display of power against Columbia yesterday, defeating the Lions, 13 to 5, at Fordham Field. The Rams, in rare batting form, collected sixteen hits to romp to one of the easiest victories over their rivals in years.

How a young artist solved the problem of earning his living and pursuing his art career at the same time will he related by 25-year-old Leon Frankston, teacher-artist, at the New York Public Library's free art lecture on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
Princeton's seasoned track team overwhelmed Columbia, 86 -- 54, yesterday at Baker Field for its fifth straight dual meet triumph of the outdoor campaign.

A FOURTH anniversary was observed last week by "Hollywood Screen Test," television's second oldest dramatic program, which began as a shoe-string operation in search of spats. It is still no prestigious production, but can be credited with prolonging the life of a thin "gimmick" -- to lure an audience -- on which the show was founded.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- The big boom in building since the end of World War II has sparked an amazing growth in financial institutions which foster expansion of home ownership.

IN Emporia, this week, they're dedicating a William Allen White memorial library on the campus of the State Teachers College. Only a few weeks ago, in impressive ceremony, a new building for the William Allen White school of journalism was dedicated on the campus of Kansas University -- the college White attended but from which he failed to graduate, having fought a losing bout with solid geometry.

FOR the minute patch of soil hat goes with a "garden apartment," herbs may seem a rather unusual choice of plants. But there just isn't enough space to grow vegetables, and a garden doesn't seem like a garden to me unless it produces an edible crop. Besides, I like herbs.
ATLANTA, April 19 (AP) -- Southern Negro Democratic leaders said today that they would support a Southerner as a Presidential candidate if he were a liberal.

" HIS eyes are sharp and sparkling. He speaks with fervor and gaiety, sometimes with a cunning smile. Impassioned yet playful, always ready for a joke, he tells me a story in which every word is an image and where there is no border between fact and fiction."
MADRID, April 19 -- United States diplomats are observing close secrecy in the current negotiations for a Hispano-American agreement on economic and military cooperation.
Milton Katims, who once played viola in the N. B. C. Symphony, led that orchestra in a concert at the Belasco Theatre yesterday afternoon.

RUSH JONES has only one interest, his wild mare, Tumbleweed. When his horse truck overturns and Tumbleweed runs away into the mountains of southwestern Colorado, chance brings Rush to the ranch of Tracy Bender, another lonely man with an obsessive interest in a wild horse.

YOU may recall W. Stanley Moss as the secret agent, on temporary leave from the Coldstream Guards, who made off with General Kreipe, commander of the German troops in Crete. He wrote about the tour de force (or de finesse), in diary form, in "Ill Met By Moonlight."

THE author of the spectacular "Rome and a Villa" is a young American lady, by the name of Eleanor Clark, who has a dark, classic, fierce handsomeness that may easily be considered Italian. There isn't any Italian in her though, except that she did go to schools in France and Italy when she was very young.

LEBEC, Calif. -- Spring thaws in this Tehachapi Mountain area are expediting work on a six-year state program to restore one of the most picturesque outposts in the annals of the United States Army, Fort Tejon. The aim is to complete the work by 1954, when the one hundredth anniversary of the establishment of this landmark in the "winning of the West" will be observed with appropriate ceremonies.
TOKYO, Sunday, April 20 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,225, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Sunday (4 P. M. Saturday, Eastern standard time):

A short, rather rotund man with a ready smile and a round, guileless face has been poking his nose into the nooks and crannies of the New York waterfront whenever and wherever there is any hint of labor trouble.

PARIS, April 19 -- This week's news from Bucharest that 200,000 citizens are being forcibly evacuated from that once merry capital as "unproductive people" serves as a reminder that within the monolithic Soviet Empire, as in George Orwell's "Animal Farm," "all animals are equal but some animals are more equal than others."

Juvenile delinquency is on the rise in the city, the state and the nation. It increased 20 per cent in New York City last year over 1950, 20 per cent in the state and 10 per cent in the country as a whole.

HOME-GROWN vegetable varieties should be chosen for top quality. After all, they are grown for the family, who certainly deserve the best. An illustrated catalogue from a favorite seed house is a good guide to follow for those whose orders have not yet been placed.

The conventions are only three months away. Last week political observers were thumbing the history books to find precedents for the extraordinary situation in the Democratic and Republican Presidential campaigns.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Thanks to television, the people of the United States are going to see and hear more of a national political campaign this year than at any time in history.
Federal mediators attempted yesterday to devise a peace formula to end the one remaining dispute between the Western Electric Company and the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O.

Increasingly this past week it has become clear that United States policy on foreign trade is moving into the center of attention among the key problems affecting our national security. Italy has protested against the discriminatory impact of a law which requires that our Government buy domestic goods in preference to the same commodities made abroad unless the latter are 25 per cent or more cheaper in price.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A nine-month extension of the enlistments of many volunteers in the armed forces, whose regular terms were to expire in the year starting July 1, was announced today by the Defense Department. About 125,000 men are affected, the department said.

AMONG his countless distinctions, probably there's none dearer to the heart of Ellery Queen than his reputation as a discoverer of new authors. To find bright, shiny unpublished talent is as great a delight as an editor can know; and Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine has consistently published an astonishing number of first stories of the highest quality.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The so-called "stay-down strike" of a handful of flying officers, although written off as a tempest in a teapot by Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the Air Force, has attracted widespread public attention.
VOCAL music is prominent in the record releases of the week, with new disks by George London, Victoria de los Angeles, Blanche Thebom, Leonard Warren and the late Maria Cebotari.

If familiarity has not bred contempt, it has certainly bred apathy. For one year, two, or three years after Pearl Harbor men and women in uniform were everybody's heroes. Hotel rooms could always be found for them, or tickets to concerts and shows. They were made the stars of quiz programs and the guests of celebrities.

Nine home runs, one short of the National League record, were belted at Ebbets Field yesterday. The Dodgers got five of them, one with the bases full, and defeated the Giants, 11 -- 6, running their winning streak to five games.

MOZART'S comic opera, "Cosi fan tutte," will be released in the fall by Columbia Records. Eleanor Steber and Richard Tucker, who took leading roles in the Metropolitan Opera's revival last season, will be featured in the recorded version.

The argument over the President's Constitutional powers set off eleven days ago by Mr. Truman's seizure of the steel industry, was broadened and deepened last week. Through his Secretary of Commerce, the President declared that he would give the the steelworkers a wage increase this week.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Point Four program for improving the under-developed areas of the free world was given new meaning this week by President Truman's press conference remark that it could be the means of keeping the economy of the United States on an even keel for the next twenty-five years.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 19 -- The Minneapolis Lakers and New York Knickerbockers resume their National Basketball Association play-off series tomorrow night, and Laker followers are asking:
LAWRENCE, Kan., April 19 (AP) -- Four records were broken and another was tied as Olympic-conscious athletes computed in the twenty-seventh annual Kansas Relays today.

Percy G. B. Gilkes, who is observing his sixtieth anniversary today as a Federal Government employe, calculated yesterday that he had signed his name to official papers "nearly 1,000,000 times" since he became a United States District Court clerk.

WITH the publication of these two excellent histories, the Putnam series on major league baseball clubs is nearly complete. Only the Phillies, Athletics, Browns and Senators remain unchronicled, a lack a prudent publisher might well hesitate to remedy.

The Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association will open its 1952 season with a one-day tournament at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N. Y., on Monday, May 5. From then until closing day, Oct. 5, more than thirty types of tournaments will be scheduled.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Instead of the predicted scarcity of consumer durable goods, merchants are reported to be so heavily stocked that the wisecrack in the trade is "I can get it for you retail."

LAUREL, Md., April 19 -- Three Rings, Mrs. Evelyn L. Hopkins' "dry track" gelding that hadn't taken a big race for the past two seasons, made a brilliant run through the Laurel stretch today to win the $23,250 Bowie Handicap by two lengths.

LONDON, April 19 -- Testimony that Premier Stalin's elder son, Jacob, knew of the bloody suppression of an "uprising" of Polish officers imprisoned by the Soviet Union was presented to the United States special Congressional committee investigating the Katyn massacre during four days of hearings here.

BURLINGTON, N. J., April 19 -- The Rheem Manufacturing Company, which has twenty-two other plants throughout the country, was identified this week as the concern selected to operate the Army ordinance department's new steel shell casing factory on the sixty-nine-acre property formerly occupied by the Aluminum Company of American on the Delaware River front here.

GRAZ, Austria, April 19 (AP) -- A Yugoslav lawyer described today how he and five other persons escaped from Yugoslavia yesterday with the aid of a kitchen knife, a pistol that would not fire and a revolver for which they had no ammunition.

Manhattan scored its second triumph yesterday in the three starts in the Metropolitan College Baseball Conference when it defeated City College, 4 -- 1, at Van Cortlandt Park. This was City's fourth straight defeat in conference play.

JERSEY CITY, April 19 -- Mayor John V. Kenny's suggested remedy for gangsterism on the waterfront -- an "all-out war on racketeers" -- is already under way, a City Hall spokesman said today. He added that it would swing into high gear after May 6.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Congressional action looking to possible impeachment proceedings against President Truman because of his seizure of the steel mills was demanded of the House of Representatives today by Representative George L. Bender, Republican member-at-large from Ohio.

Events of this past week have given further acceleration to the campaign movements. In the Republican camp the direction is being made progressively more clear. On the Democratic side, while the tempo has been stepped up, the direction is somewhat more confused. Two things have happened.

France's contributions in trained manpower, war production, military bases and communications will be the keystone of Europe's ground defense until the European army is formed, Jean Monnet, top economic planner of the French Government, said in an address here yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Mass., April 19 -- It would cost the United States $250,000,000 a year to support a 1,700-plane air force such as Russia is furnishing to the Communists in Korea, Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, chief of staff of the United States Air Force, said today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP) -- For the second straight day the Braves rallied in the ninth inning to defeat the Phillies today. Boston put together three singles and a sacrifice to outslug Philadelphia, 9--7, before 9,466 at Shibe Park.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Pennsylvania led home favored Princeton and Columbia on the Schuylkill today for its third successive victory in the Childs Cup regatta, oldest of all American trophy rowing races.

IT is really quite easy to kill a man, even two men, on the island of Capri. But is it wrong to kill, can anything be right or wrong, in this pagan sanctuary where Ohio housewives, English colonels, Italian duchesses, Swedish athletes and Chicago heiresses throw off their clothes, manners, customs, codes and gnawing Northern consciences?

OVER and over again, the contemporary poet has declared his abhorrence of rhetoric. He uses song and speech to come as close as he can to the world that is flowing away from him every moment, to catch the very pulse, the dazzle or the dark weight, of what is immediately present.

THE Washington Senators had a rakish look when they arrived at the Stadium to open the Yankee season. No team was more direly in need of a rakish look than the bedraggled Senators. So they dusted off an old one they had discarded and hoped no one would notice the difference. The restoration was achieved by returning to the roster that large and distinguished gentleman, Louis Norman Newsom yclept Bobo.

IN a bill which Representative Hale Boggs of New Orleans has introduced in the House, the Post Office Department is asked to issue in 1953 a stamp for the 150th anniversary of the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France by President Jefferson in 1803.

CAIRO, April 19 -- Egypt's leading suffragette, smart and handsome Mme. Doria Shafik, who holds that the Prophet Mohammed believed in equal rights for men and women, went to the Minister of Information today to demand that he protest to Premier Ahmed Naguib El Hilaly Pasha against the sheikhs and ulemas, authorities in Islamic law, of the old town of Damietta.

A brush fire that spread through part of the seventeen-mile-square Earle Naval Ammunition Depot at Earle, N. J., was brought under control late yesterday afternoon by firemen from a score of Jersey shore communities. A Navy spokesman said no ammunition was stored in the area of the blaze and that there bad been "no great danger" at any time.

MIAMI BEACH -- Next to the national tournaments, the most highly rated competitions conducted by the American Contract Bridge League are its regional tournaments, and the most colorful of these is the Southeastern Championships, which have been in progress here during the past week.

Whatever may be the ultimate outcome of the United States Supreme Court's decision in the leading case on tests of validity of family partnerships (337 U. S. 733), its effect in bringing about new legislation has been noteworthy. Much of the amended legislation on the subject, contained in the Revenue Act of 1951, is traceable to this litigation.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Indisputable evidence has reached here that the Chinese Communists publicly acknowledged the natural origins of epidemics sweeping parts of China well before their propagandists began attributing the ailments to germ warfare by the United States.
MEXICO CITY, April 19 (AP) -- Mexico has made good on her boast that she would get her nationalized oil industry clicking all on her own -- and without the help of a United States loan.

Chief Judge John T. Loughran of the State Court of Appeals was the recipient yesterday of the first annual Fordham Law Alumni Medal of Achievement to be awarded to an outstanding graduate. The presentation was made at a luncheon attended by 700 persons at the Biltmore Hotel.

ONE of the oldest of domesticated fowls, chicken, is eaten -- and highly esteemed -- in practically every part of the world. It was in recognition of the universality of the barnyard fowl, that the Poultry and Egg National Board and the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council chose "Chicken International" as the theme for their annual spring dinner held here last week.
Michael A. C. Hume has joined the administrative services staff of Arthur Anderson Co., certified public accountants.
OMAHA, April 19 -- Flood fighters snuffed out a grave threat to a major low-lying section of Omaha today as the rampaging Missouri River drove its record flood tide downstream.

IN veterans hospitals near New York City, gardening has earned its place as a therapeutic occupation for patients. Herbs have proved a particularly popular group of plants because of their homey and intimate quality.

THE summer music center, at which talented young people gather at beautiful country spots for six or eight weeks and combine study with swimming, boating and other activities of a vacation, is becoming a fixed and expanding feature of the nation's musical life.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 19 (Reuters) -- A Chicago business man, William Dunn, has offered to buy "Vacation Village" here--a $5,000,000 tourist resort built by Billy Butlin, famous in Britain as an operator of summer resorts. Bankruptcy proceedings are in progress on the project, which collapsed for a lack of funds.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 19 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has postponed his projected trip to Scandinavia because of a throat infection, a spokesman said today. The brief announcement said that the Supreme Allied Commander was running a temperature but that his condition was not serious.

Harvard University has established a $1,000,000 fund from the bequest of the late Allston Burr to help support a new development in the tutorial and advising system of Harvard. Income from the fund will contribute toward meeting the salaries of some of the faculty members who will serve as advisers and tutors of the three upper classes. Beginning next fall the advising of sophomore, junior and senior students will be centered in the residential houses.

LONDON, April 19 -- Iran's economy has proved itself to be far more resilent than British and American experts believed possible when the expulsion of British technicians forced the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company's great refinery at Abadan to shut down six months ago.
SMITHTOWN, L. I., April 19 -- Marshall Field's brown mare Lucky Miss and brown gelding, Brigadoon, took the top honors in the Smithtown hunter trials on the Goetchius Estate today.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., April 19 -- The Connecticut anglers had perfect weather for their opening day, with the majority of the popular trout streams reasonably low, clear and running a temperature that gave the fly fishermen an opportunity to put a few trout in their creels.
