MOST gardeners include both annual and perennial flowers on their spring planting lists. The majority of the annuals will he sown outdoors between now and the first of July. Some perennial plants are also set out in the garden now, while others should wait until later in the year.

THE elegant Pinky was a most unusual cat. Employed as a mouser in the Ballet Theater, he had a great reputation as a balletomane, but was a sad failure at his job, because he was terrified of mice. When a mouse wrecked the dress rehearsal of a new ballet and the leading ballerina sprained her ankle, Pinky was promptly fired.

EASTER has come and gone. To retailers and purveyors of soft lines, maintenance of the better showing that they enjoyed just before Easter would have been proof positive that the turn has been reached, and that the predictions of better business for the balance of the year was about to become a reality.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, April 20 (AP) -- Allied warships and carrier-based planes battered Communist targets on North Korea's vulnerable coastlines yesterday as snow, hail and rain brought ground action to a virtual halt.

The news that Yenching University in Peiping has finally been closed by the Communists should cause little surprise. After all, Yenching stood as the symbol of most of the things that the Chinese Communists detest. It was a free university. It was a friendly university. It was endowed by American-given funds. It had a record of heroic resistance to the Japanese.

MOST gardeners are born, not made, and the urge to grow something starts early in life. Young Peter had it but he felt handicapped because he hadn't one of those mysterious green thumbs that people talked about.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Truman's demand for restoration of military funds slashed by the House of Representatives won scant support in key Congressional quarters today.

THE practice of rewarding authors by giving them prizes recently reached a high water mark in Italy. The Premio Letterario Venezia (three million lire, or a little over $4,800) is open only to authors who have not previously won prizes -- a condition which probably disqualifies a good 50 per cent of Italy's professional men of letters.

Hunter College took forty-seven of sixty-three bouts to win the Stuyvesant Fish Trophy in the women's intercollegiate fencing tournament on New York University's East Building strips yesterday. The Hunter victory broke a three-year domination of the tournament by N. Y. U.

MEXICO CITY, April 19 -- A slow ferment, impossible to measure and difficult to assess exactly, has become apparent on the Mexican political scene in recent months. It is still too early to hazard a guess as to its final outcome, but the coming months of the the slowly heating campaign for the Presidential election on July 6 may indicate a definite trend.

At Panmunjom last week the feeling was that a critical stage in the ten-month-long Korean truce negotiations was approaching. Actually, the chief news was the record-breaking brevity -- and apparent futility -- of the sessions. On Thursday, the United Nations and Communist negotiators took just twenty seconds to inform one another that they had nothing new to say about the two unsettled issues on truce enforcement.

The news that Yenching University in Peiping has finally been closed by the Communists should cause little surprise. After all, Yenching stood as the symbol of most of the things that the Chinese Communists detest. It was a free university. It was a friendly university. It was endowed by American-given funds. It had a record of heroic resistance to the Japanese.

THE cause of the non-scheduled passenger airlines could not have been helped any by the Civil Aeronautics Board's official report last week of the cause of the first of the three air crashes in Elizabeth, N. J. Faulty maintenance work on one

MOST gardeners are born, not made, and the urge to grow something starts early in life. Young Peter had it but he felt handicapped because he hadn't one of those mysterious green thumbs that people talked about.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Truman's demand for restoration of military funds slashed by the House of Representatives won scant support in key Congressional quarters today.

THE practice of rewarding authors by giving them prizes recently reached a high water mark in Italy. The Premio Letterario Venezia (three million lire, or a little over $4,800) is open only to authors who have not previously won prizes -- a condition which probably disqualifies a good 50 per cent of Italy's professional men of letters.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 19 -- Connecticut Democrats have named a committee of five members of the State Central Committee to call on Senator Brien McMahon in Washington and urge him to announce his candidacy for the nomination for President.

LONDON. "DOWN with the hated British imperialists" -- these words were screamed yesterday in Persia, are being repeated today in Egypt, and tomorrow may be buzzing in other dark and secretive bazaars. The cry is familiar now to British ears, the passion behind it is acknowledged, its meaning is only too clear.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Truman addressed a new plea to Congress today for prompt approval of the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project as a joint United States - Canadian undertaking.

BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox observed Patriot's Day with a four-run first inning and Lefty Maury McDermott's seven-hit pitching for a 6-1 victory over the Athletics in the afternoon game after taking this morning's contest, 11 -- 2.
GLASGOW, April 19 (Reuters) -- Motherwell today won the Scottish soccer cup for the first time with a 4-0 victory over Dundee before a crowd of more than 100,000 at Hampden Park Stadium.

This garden, designed by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and exhibited at the 1952 International Flower Show, was aimed at the home owner with a limited budget and amount of time. The brick walk, for example, reduces the lawn area and so cuts down maintenance of turf. The bricks set along the side of the lawn eliminate the time-consuming chore of edging.

Another claimant as the "oldest golf course in the nation" has been discovered. The United States Golf Association has received evidence that the Foxburg Country Club, Foxburg, Pa., "may be the oldest golf course in existence in the United States."

Good news came from the polio front last week. On the strength of researches conducted in the Lederle Laboratories there is good reason to believe that a modified or weakened living virus will make an effective polio vaccine. Drs. Hilary Koprowski, George A. Jafrvis and Thomas A. W. Norton of the Lederle Laboratories fed such a virus to twenty-six children, offered for experimentation by their parents, and immunized them against one type of polio.

THE schism that has existed over the years between the motion-picture industry and other business interests in this hub of Southern California commerce appeared to have been reconciled in a festive session of mutual admiration last Tuesday night when the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce paid its first public tribute to the movie industry.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Details of major discoveries made by archaeologists of the Universities of Chicago and Pennsylvania -- including the unearthing of two temples built more than 4,000 years ago in the land of the Sumerian gods -- were disclosed today.

DURING much of World War II Ray Brock was stationed in Ankara and Istanbul as correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Last year Brock, now a free-lance, returned to the scene of his wartime exploits and their wider environs, and the result is "Blood, Oil and Sand," dealing with Turkey, the Arab countries and Israel, Iran, Pakistan, North Africa and the Balkans.

IN ADOPTING sterner measures for dealing with the restoration of driver licenses which have been suspended or revoked for traffic violations, Commissioner James R. Macduff of the New York State Motor Vehicle Bureau has set out to make motoring safer by keeping unfit drivers off the road.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board reported today that A. F. L. unions won more than twice as many representation elections as they lost during the last half of 1951, while the C. I. O. gained a lesser number.

YALE University is an American phenomenon. In the period from 1871 to 1921 it was doubtless more American than phenomenal, encompassing as it did in academic spirit and student body the American middle-class way of life in the age of its fullest flowering.

Two primary elections, important to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, leading contenders for the Republican nomination for President, will be held on Tuesday in New York and Pennsylvania.

NEW DELHI, India, April 19 -- The remarkable progress that has been made in the last three months on the four-year development program for India charted with United States assistance may be taken as an indication of the Indian Government's anxiety to raise the living standards of the immense population before Communist blandishments take a firmer hold on the depressed masses.
The union shop, over which labor and management have been waging war for more than a hundred years, is back as a do-or-die issue in steel, aircraft, railroads and other strategic industries.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The effects of bad political forecasting in the Presidential campaign of 1948 and the means of preventing a recurrence in 1952 were discussed at length today by newspaper editors, publishers and officials on the final day of the 1952 convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.
Former internes and resident physicians of Mount Sinai Hospital, which this year is celebrating the 100th anniversary of its founding, joined yesterday in a day-long round of alumni activities.

Power cruiser racing, for the most part latent and dormant in recent years, is being face-lifted and overhauled for a general perking up this season The American Power Boat Association's new hard-working and fast-punching vice president for cruisers, William Edgar John of Rye, had another meeting the other day, jointly including the cruiser racing commission and the cruiser technical committee.

THE impression given by John Bainbridge's interesting and fact-filled book is that there is no more fascinating subject than the story of mutual fire and casualty insurance. And Mr. Bainbridge, a talented man in the field of arranging ideas, history, statistics and critical judgment into a smooth and readable whole, comes as close as is technically possible to proving his point.

MARTHA GRAHAM'S series of six performances at the Juilliard School of Music is, of course, the principal event of the week. She has reconstituted her company and will appear with them for the first time in two years. One ensemble work, "Canticle for Innocent Comedians," is brand new, and one long solo, "The Triumph of St. Joan," is new to New York.

UNTIL recently the Kremlin and its doings made few if any appearances on American sports pages. That situation has been changed now that the Soviet Union is in training for the 1952 Olympic games at Helsinki. Today sports writers and the fans who follow them are scrambling to find out about a host of Ivans, Vladimirs and Natashas who will wear Stalin's colors in the competition this summer.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 19 -- Strong "second choice" sentiment for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination was disclosed here today among Stassen candidates for delegates from Ohio to the national convention.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 19 -- Another Taft - Eisenhower battle for Presidential nomination votes is shaping up for the Arkansas Republican State Convention here next week-end.

DESPITE the uncertain world situation, which has kept many students from planning overseas trips this summer, the student travel picture seems to be improving. Travel officials now report that interest is increasing and an eleventh-hour rush is developing.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 19 -- A French communique today reported "favorable progress" in a new operation launched by the French and Vietnamese forces yesterday to clear Vietminh forces from the Tongking delta.

MILWAUKEE, April 19 (UP) -- Two members of the national champion E. and B. team of Detroit, which took the lead in the American Bowling Congress tourney yesterday with a 3,115, came back today to take two runner-up berths among the minor event leaders.

The New York law just signed by Governor Dewey, permitting the state's savings banks to invest in a limited way in the common, preferred and guaranteed stocks of corporate enterprises, marks a significant widening of the investment functions of thrift institutions.

BOSTON. WHEN he first arrived in New York as a very young man, Guthrie McClintic had accepted his mother's belief in reincarnation and considered himself -- quite seriously -- the reimbodiment of Edwin Booth.

BERLIN, April 19 -- With new emphasis and urgency the East German Government and its political parties are calling for mass strikes and "tremendous" demonstrations" in West Germany against Bonn's signing of a contractual agreement with the West.

NEWARK, April 19 -- Manhattan, Fordham and Villanova each won two titles today, as the sixth annual Seton Hall Relays ended at Newark Schools Stadium. Georgetown took the other featured baton-passing event of the East's first major outdoor track and field carnival of the Olympic year.

IT is summer, 1950, in Pelican Hollow on California's shore. Outdoors in the mists and pines, and indoors in the new homes, ramshackle or smartly finished, a few artists are attempting to make their lives creative and meaningful.

ST. LOUIS, April 19 (AP) -- Joe Dobson and the White Sox ended the Browns' winning streak at four games today with an 8-3 victory. The defeat pushed the Browns out of their first-place tie with Cleveland and dropped them to second.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 19 (AP) -- Orders have come to Mather Field to stop disciplinary action against six Air Force officers who had refused to fly, Capt. Jack Rose said today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 19 (UP) -- The University of Michigan's distance medley relay quartet broke the two-and-a-half-mile record in the revival of the Ohio track relays today.

If James Warburg is sensitive to the charge of Bevanism I gladly concede him the honor of having been wrong about NATO policy long before Aneurin Bevan. But I still maintain that MacArthurism is the strategic complement of Mr. Warburg's attitude -- not, of course, that he shares General MacArthur's views on domestic or foreign policy.

BEETHOVEN: Piano Concerto No. 4 in G; Friedrich Wuehrer and Austrian Symphony Orchestra under Karl Randolf (Remington). Competent solo playing and understanding orchestral accompaniment, not too well recorded.

Four months ago Joe Falari, a 24-year-old shipping clerk, broke his back in an automobile accident on the lower East Side. Within the hour, he was on the operating table in Bellevue Hospital. The findings were definite: His spinal cord was severed and he faced the future with his legs powerless and without sensation.

THIS book seems to have been taken out of the works before it was quite finished. What we get is a good idea, a great many details about a hotel for squirrels, an excellent but extraneous drawing of the Grock, the famous European clown (with explanation of same stuck in on the page opposite) but no story.

Representatives of concerns handling 80 per cent of all perishable foods passing through the Port of New York will meet this week to attack market bottlenecks and inefficiencies that have been plaguing the city more than a decade. Preliminary steps will be taken in a program that is expected to restore this city to its former position of being the most efficient food distribution center in the world.

CLEVELAND, April 19 (AP) -- With a twelve-hit attack that included home runs by Larry Doby and Luke Easter, the Indians scored their fifth victory in a row today by whipping the Tigers, 7 -- 5, before 11,829.

I have the text of Dr. Conant's address of April 7 to the American Association of School Administrators, and intend to discuss the attack which he made on nonpublic schools. He made no distinction among nonpublic schools of all types.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Expressions in the state primaries of preferences among aspirants for Presidential nominations are of much more importance indirectly than directly. Their effect on the controlling group of delegates to the national conventions who come uninstructed or with an endorsement of "favorite sons" for trading purposes is the great stake for which the candidates and their managers contend in the primaries.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 19 -- Business tightened its belt a little in the first quarter of 1952, the spring bank call reports here this week showed. Principal bank items on March 31 showed ddecreases from Dec. 31, but only loans lagged below a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The private papers of the late Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, to be published Tuesday, disclosed today that during one dangerous deadlock with Russia President Truman talked about telephoning personally to Premier Stalin "to see what he could do with him."

FROM the moment when the Vicar of Steventon records the birth of another girl to the moment when Jane Austen herself lays down her pen with a flicker of laughter, the Austens are as real as the people next door.

PARIS, April 19 -- Jean-Marie-Francois de Hautecloque, French Resident General in Tunisia, continued consultations here today with members of the French Cabinet in search of a formula to transform the present uneasy truce maintained by martial law in the French protectorate into a permanent settlement with the Tunisian nationalists.

SIXTY color prints of wild flowers and nature subjects photographed by Jeannette Klute are on view through May 4 in the Corner Room at the American Museum of Natural History. A three-year harvest of vacation and week-end picture-taking, the prints, all of which were made by the Kodak Dye Transfer Process, include such subjects as Indian pipes, ferns, trillium, jacks-in-the-pulpit and mushrooms and toadstools.

AS a neophyte playwright, it was with much interest that I read John T. Dugan's article in your section on April 6 on the hypocrisy present in the "holier than thou" attitude prevalent in the college theatres, which have produced only the barest minimum of original plays.
OPERATIONS aren't so much any more. It takes a spectacularly unsuccessful one to hold the floor. Nowadays a virus infection is the thing -- especially one you can refer to mysteriously as "virus X."

Bills to impose four new city taxes with a total estimated annual yield of $19,500,000 to $23,500,000 have been drafted by Mayor Impellitteri's aides and are scheduled for introduction in the City Council tomorrow.
Sunday driving was anything but a pleasure yesterday as a combination of warm, sunny weather and the return of Easter vacationists jammed bridges, tunnels and highways in the metropolitan area.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., April 20 -- The surging Missouri River bore down on St. Joseph today, and airmen fought a day-and-night battle to save a huge air force installation at Fort Leavenworth, Kan.
Federal mediators sought last night to "mop up" the two remaining strikes of Bell System employes, after all other telephone walkouts had been settled.

The Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector emeritus of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, preached yesterday morning what he said would probably be his last sermon. Because of ill health he spoke seated in a chair before the altar.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, April 20 -- This industrial city of 44,000 was bursting with pride and bustling with activity today as thousands of visitors from far and wide arrived for the second day of "Freedom Fair," an elaborate exposition of democracy in action.

In spite of a number of optimistic statements that seem to have found their way into the press in the last few days there is no real reason to expect a quick settlement in Korea. Mr. Cordier, of the United Nations Secretariat, was right and wise in advising against false hopes upon his return from the embattled Far Eastern area.

DUNKERQUE, France, April 18 -- A new tourist class, with fiftyfive berths, is being added to the passenger capacity of the new French liner Flandre, now being completed here for her maiden sailing to New York on July 23.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 -- Steel output last week was estimated at 97 per cent. That rate was up 37 points from the revised rate of 60 per cent in the week before. An increase of a few more points is expected this week as mills rebound to normal operations under Government seizure.

Around the circuit there is a feeling that Casey Stengel has a magic touch, that everything he touches turns to gold, that his Yankees have achieved three consecutive world championships because of the manager's hidden powers -- and that when Casey runs out of luck he will run out of pennants.

MOSCOW, April 20 -- Echoing in even stronger terms the note of urgency struck yesterday by Izvestia, Pravda insisted today that the fate of Germany was being decided at the present hour and that the choice was between a reunited, sovereign German state or Germany's continued status as a divided country in which the seeds of a new European war were being sown.

ROME, April 20 -- The campaign for the provincial and municipal elections, which will be held in central and southern Italy on May 25, got under way today with a tremendous outpouring of oratory. The "battle of the posters" has been raging for several days and its intensity is constantly increasing.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 20 -- Labor delegates to the fifth regional conference at Quitandinha, near Rio de Janeiro, of the American states that are members of the International Labor Office are considering challenging the right of Venezuelan delegates to represent the workers of their country.

A few days ago this newspaper received a dispatch from its correspondent in Saigon reporting that the Associated States of Indo-China could be expected to have substantially more than half a million tons of rice for export in this calendar year. This is not the sort of thing out of which sensational headlines are made.
STAMFORD, Conn., April 20 -- This city's 30,000 enrolled Republicans will hold a Presidential preference vote as a sidelight to Connecticut's primary election on April 28.

ROME, April 20 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman of Australia and Jaroslav Drobny, expatriate Czech star, advanced to the men's singles final while British Commonwealth players won the women's titles today in Italy's "Spring Wimbledon" tennis tournament.

The American Federation of Labor has named a five-man commission to "study and evaluate" the recent report of the state board of inquiry that investigated the longshoremen's wildcat work stoppage last fall on the New York waterfront.

The Little Green Book -- more formally, the city's vestpocket "Official Directory," out today -- is put out single-handed by a little gray man, himself a pocket-size encyclopedia about the city government. Customers can get the 696-page 1952 Green Book for $1, or 25 cents below cost, at The City Record office, Room 2213, Municipal Building.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A renewed drive for Congressional approval of the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project as a joint United States-Canadian undertaking faces its first test this week with prospects apparently good for favorable action.
A wardrobe of fresh summer fashions for your little girl is brought to you today in three patterns created by Advance for Patterns of The Times.

Robert Whitehead, managing director of the American National Theatre and Academy's Play Series, was certain yesterday that "Sunday Breakfast" would be the fifth and final offering of the season. May 21 will see the Emery Rubio-Miriam Balf collaboration installed at the ANTA Playhouse. Leading actors will be selected soon and rehearsals will get under way this week, Stella Adler directing.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, was still hopeful today of achieving a settlement that would get the Government out of the steel business soon.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that farm prices "can * * * never hit bottom again" if the Government supplies "adequate" price supports and intelligent leadership to the nation's farmers.

Included in this week's art shows is a loan exhibition at Knoedler's of American silver owned by Yale University, to be shown for the benefit of the Associates in Fine Arts at Yale. The display opens tomorrow evening with a gala preview from 8-10:30 P. M., admission to which will be $6. Thereafter, admission will be $1.

A man wielding two knives was shot and killed yesterday by an off-duty patrolman at Tiffany Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, after the man had slashed another man, threatened two others and charged at the patrolman.

The Atlantic Union Committee announced yesterday a board of judges to select the American statesman who will receive the committee's Atlantic award this year. The judges are Russell Davenport, former Ambassador Joseph C. Grew, Bishop Henry W. Hobson of Southern Ohio, Joseph H. McConnell, president, National Broadcasting Company; Malcolm Muir, publisher of Newsweek; former Under Secretary of State William Phillips and former Assistant Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

BONN, Germany, April 20 -- German and Allied negotiators will launch tomorrow a series of daily meetings aimed at completing by the first week in May the contractual agreement that will establish the political sovereignty of the West German Federal Republic. The signing of the agreement, which will bind West Germany to Western Europe and inflict a signal defeat on Soviet foreign policy, is to be accompanied by diplomatic pomp and circumstance.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- A Senate mobilization subcommittee investigating an alleged lucrative black market in defense-vital aluminum today named nineteen witnesses to testify at its public hearings.
TRENTON, April 20 -- State conventions of both major parties will convene here Thursday noon, with deliberations conditioned by factional differences related to the coming Presidential election.

CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP) -- The home-run slugging Indians ran their unbeaten string to seven games with 3-2 and 7-2 victories today over the floundering Tigers, who lost their sixth and seventh straight.

RYE, N. Y., April 20 -- A party of Sunday fishermen on a chartered trip out of New Rochelle weathered a minor shipwreck this afternoon when the sixty-five foot fishing boat the Ilse III struck a rock in Long Island Sound and stove a hole in her side. The forty-seven passengers and three crew members were rescued promptly and no one had to be lashed to a mast.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that under certain circumstances the President would have the power to put radio and television stations off the air.
The League of Composers last night presented the first of two "Evenings of New Works by Young Composers" at the Museum of Modern Art.

CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP) -- Preparations for a strike, increased rail rates and the costs of government control will decrease the steel industry's earnings during the second quarter of this year, Steel Magazine said today.

Bette Davis, who ordinarily essays film roles with considerable emotional content, tried her hand at broad farce on Jimmy Durante's Saturday night program over N. B. C. For the moment she is not too serious a rival to Lucille Ball.

The need for applying the "basic values of democracy" and the "high moral principles of the great religions" in our everyday life, "if our success in achieving peace among ourselves is to lead to a wider conception of brotherhood throughout the world," was emphasized last night by Benson Ford, vice president of the Ford Motor Company.

Wool prices, which have fallen to the pre-Korean level, will become steady and prices of men's clothing for next fall, which are being set now, will represent the low for the year. Such was the forecast made yesterday by Jerome I. Udell, chairman of the board of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., producer of Gramercy Park clothes.

The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, in its most generous contribution toward the advancement of creative activities and research into all fields of knowledge, announced yesterday the award of 191 fellowships with grants totaling $860,000.

SIEMREAP, Indo-China, April 20 -- Here in Northwest Cambodia one of the world's big jobs of archaeological conservation is begging to be filled. Involved is the unearthing of the 1,000-year-old Khmer monuments and the preservation and rehabilitation of the Khmer ruins already exposed to view.
Robert Erickson and Lockrem Johnson shared the Composers' Forum concert on Saturday evening at the McMillin Theatre.

The Eastern States Health Education Conference at the New York Academy of Medicine on Thursday and Friday will be broadcast over WNYC. Two morning sessions will be carried from 10:30 o'clock to noon and two afternoon meetings from 2:30 to 4. The general theme of the conference is "Deprivation and Stress in Relation to Health and Disease."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- Christopher O'Brien, who resigned last month as West Coast director of Actors Equity Association because of a controversy within the organization, received an ovation today when he made a farewell talk before some 300 members.

The ninety-voice Roman Catholic choir of the United States Military Academy at West Point sang the musical setting of the solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. It was Refice's "Missa Choralis."

TOKYO, April 20 (AP) -- Japan's most prominent woman leeader appealed today to Mrs. Matthew B. Ridgway to ask the general to bar American servicemen from Japanese brothels and "isolate immoral United States troops."

LONDON, April 20 -- The stock markets continued their progress upward last week with such success that they may now be said to have fully recovered from the shock of the budget and the 4 per cent bank rate.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Results of a public opinion survey showing that General Eisenhower would lose approximately half of his Presidential support if he took specific stands on major issues were circulated by Prof. Kenneth W. Colegrove of Northwestern University's Political Science Department.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP) -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands made out of her American state visit a great contribution to better understanding between the United States and Western Europe, a United States State Department spokesman said today.

In 1951 membership in the Associated Hospital Service of New York -- the Blue Cross Plan -- rose to 4,923,453 with the enrollment of 440,842 persons, according to the group's annual report issued yesterday.

It was interesting to note in a United Press item in THE TIMES, under the dateline of March 29, that a Negro doctor had been appointed to the medical staff of Mount Sinai Hospital at Miami Beach, Fla. The statement was also carried that this "was believed to be one of the first such appointments in the South."

CASTILE, N. Y., April 20 -- A strapping farmhand who was swept over a waterfall and trapped for thirty hours on a narrow ledge halfway down a 200-foot gorge said today he had almost despaired for his life when found by Boy Scouts.

ONCE upon a time there were Three Bears and -- wait a minute. Let's start in with the Papa Bear. His name is George Halas and he has gained fame and wealth with all his Little Bears. Strictly speaking, though, they aren't little. They're big and fearsome, scaring both children and other football teams. The Papa Bear, you see, owns and coaches the Chicago Bears.
General Eisenhower's refusal to make political statements, and answer questions about his views on public matters while he is in uniform is doubtless correct.

The outlook for retail business is good but stores must do an aggressive job of selling, displaying and merchandising to take advantage of the opportunity, Barry T. Leithead president of Cluett, Peabody Co., manufacturer of Arrow shirts, said yesterday.

The eight-game New York series of the chess match between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires ended last night at the Manhattan Chess Club with the undefeated Reshevsky holding a 7-1 lead and ten games to follow in Mexico City and San Salvador.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 20 (AP) -- A tour of the United States and Canada by twenty-five European industrial research scientists and administrators was announced today by the Southwest Research Institute here.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 21 -- United States Sabre jet pilots reported they shot down seven Russian-built MIG's over North Korea today in an aerial dogfight that produced America's eleventh jet ace.

The Toy Guidance Council ended yesterday its three-day meeting devoted to the selection of toys to be included in the Toy Yearbook which will be distributed by more than 1,200 retailers throughout the country. The 64-page book, with descriptions of about 250 toys, will be distributed without charge in October to 4,000,000 parents, schools, child guidance clinics and educators.

Burglary of the apartment of Dr. Rudolph Heinemann, art expert, on the twenty-ninth floor of the Ritz Tower Hotel, was discovered early yesterday morning. The intruders took jewelry, furs and cash estimated at $14,000 in value.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Informed officials said today the Government has decided its controls over installment buying are no longer needed -- at least for the time being -- to fight inflation.

TOKYO, Monday, April 21 -United Nations truce delegates accused the Communists today of refusing to acknowledge that important problems remained to be solved before an armistice agreement could be negotiated in Korea. The enemy also was charged with holding out for unconditional acceptance of Chinese and North Korean terms as a prerequisite to settlement.

Objection to inclusion of Represenative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and W. Averell Harriman, director of the Mutual Security Administration, in a list of acceptable candidates for United States Senator arose yesterday at the closing session of the state convention of the Americans for Democratic Action.
Mara Linden, a soprano from Illinois, made her debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- Steve Bilko's first home run of the season with Enos Slaughter on base in the fifth inning gave the Cardinals a 2-1 decision over the Cubs today.

One of the most phenomenal debuts in the Paris couture has been that of Hubert de Givenchy, the young six-foot-six giant who caused cables to flash the reports of his fashions at the last Paris openings. At the age of 25 he has received international recognition.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 20 (AP) -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's Government announced tonight it had resumed production of motor oil at Iran's great Abadan refinery. It predicted that within six weeks Iran would no longer need foreign motor oil.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- A Federal Trade Commission hearing examiner found today that LaSalle Extension University of Chicago was "fully within its rights" in advertising and awarding law degrees and proposed that complaints against the university be dismissed.

BOSTON, April 20 -- The New England Region of the American Jewish Congress called attention today to continued "riots" in some sections of Boston directed chiefly against Jewish youths and asked that the Boston police receive a race relations training program.

DUBLIN, April 20 -- This was a big day in the little village of Croghan, in north Roscommon. The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, came to the place where his grandmother was born to dedicate the rebuilt 150-year-old parish Church of St. Michael's.

ARMONK, N. Y, April 20 -- Windy Hill Saturna, 4-year-old white and orange pointer owned by Dr. Morris Block of Norwalk, Conn., and handled by Tony Valeri, gained a leg on the Top Turnure Memorial Trophy in the amateur all-age stake that brought the annual meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club to an end today.
SIEMREAP, Indo-China, April 20 -- New interest is focused today on Northwest Cambodia as a result of the flight of the Nationalist leader, Son Ngoc Thanh, from Phnom-Penh on March 10.
Last week the Interstate Commerce Commission authorized a 9 per cent increase in freight rates for the railroads operating in the South and West and one of 6 per cent for the carriers in the East.

A program of chamber music by four contemporary Netherlands composers was presented yesterday afternoon in Room 213 of the New York Public Library. The event was sponsored by the Committee for Netherlands Music, and Bernard Wagenaar, its president, made the introductory speech.
Five new films, including importations from England, Italy and Spain, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The board of directors of the Society of Friends of the Touro Synagogue of Newport, R. I., designated as a national historic shrine in 1946, met yesterday and approved a suggestion by the group's president, Dr. Bernard C. Friedman, that the society make an effort to raise its membership to 1,200 in the next year. The present membership is 985.

France is now trying to find a new formula to meet Tunisian aspirations for self-government. It seems obvious that success will depend on whether the French can be more generous and sympathetic in their approach than they nave been in the past.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft's bid for the Republican Presidential nomination disclosed today that petitions were being circulated nationally calling upon General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to answer twenty-one questions on current political issues.

ATLANTA, April 20 (AP) -- Representatives of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today that none of the avowed Presidential candidates had yet "demonstrated any genuine concern for civil rights."

Today at the New York Academy of Medicine, ceremonies are being held marking the tenth anniversary of the Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York. This little known but invaluable health resource is devoted to scientific investigation and research related to the various problems of health that affect the people of New York City.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- Two contract negotiations, one a major film distribution agreement and the other involving the renewal of a long-term association with a star performer, were concluded over the week-end.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The State Social Welfare Department spent $1,300,000 more on public assis- though the average number of persons on relief each month was 67,000 less, Raymond W. Houston, acting Commissioner of Social Welfare, reported today.

A bridge of charity between the East and the West whose significance far transcends the amount or value of relief materials involved is maintained by the Bishops' Fund for Victims of War in order that there may be an unceasing flow of aid to oppressed peoples overseas.
Newspaper executives arriving here yesterday from all parts of the country for the annual observance of Newspaper Week reported the nation was enjoying prosperity despite some economic soft spots.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Major criminal offenses in the United States rose 5.1 per cent from 1950 to 1951, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reported today.

Two four-story apartment houses on plot 53 by 101 feet at 237-39 East Seventy-fifth Street were sold by the Juldin Realty Corporation to the Onda Realty Corporation, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. E. Furhman, M. A. Spinrad and A. E. Kallman were the brokers in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $68,000.

Your recent editorial on "nationalism in Africa" speaks of "fanatics," "extreme nationalism" and "a French reform program providing increased autonomy for the protectorate" of Tunisia. In the news section of the same issue your special correspondent in Paris reports the arrest of Hedi Nouira, "a moderate and the only major nationalist leader to escape earlier arrest."
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., April 20 (AP) -- Coroner Denzil Ferguson recommended a homicide charge tonight against an A. W. O. L. soldier from New York in the death of a conductor aboard a speeding train.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 20 -If President Truman wants to support his crack about primary elections being "eyewash," he probably can point with some justification to this week's voting in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

CAIRO, April 20 -- The Egyptian Cabinet issued today a decree putting into effect the wholesale investigation and purge of the Egyptian Government and Egyptian public life that had been awaited ever since Ahmed Naguib El Hilaly Pasha became Premier.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, disclosed today that in 1951 he had asked the then Attorney General J. Howard McGrath, to investigate Newbold Morris. This was long before Mr. Morris was appointed to head the Federal corruption inquiry.
TOKYO, Monday, April 21 (AP) -General Headquarters communiqu 1226, covering Sunday's operations:
All creeds and all sects are united in the fight to conquer cancer. Churches and synagogues throughout the country are devoting prayers to the success of the Cancer Crusade.

PHULU, Indo-China, April 20 (AP) -- French Union forces tonight were systematically wiping out two Vietminh regiments trapped in a V-shape area between the Canal des Rapides and Colonial Highway No. 1 leading northward to Red China.
Anaconda Copper Mining Company has reported a net income of $50,216,838, or $5.79 a share, for 1951, against $46,689,645, or $5.38 a share, in 1950. The gain was 7.55 per cent.

PARIS, April 20 -- Premier Antoine Pinay declared today, in opening the International Fair at Lyon, that the essence of his program was "the fierce determination to defend the franc, to maintain full employment and to increase French exports."
BOSTON, April 20 (AP) -- A pinch homer by Billy Goodman with two on in a four-run seventh inning gave the Red Sox a 6-3 decision over the Senators before 21,208 at Fenway Park today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 20 -- A partial survey of the Democratic state organization's candidates for delegates to the party's national convention has revealed "surprisingly strong" support for Gov. Frank J. Lausche for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Eugene H. Hanhart, State Chairman, said here today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -- The Boston Braves took advantage of a wild throw by outfielder Del Ennis today to score the run that gave them a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and an even split in a Shibe Park double-header. The Phils won the opener, 4 -- 3, when Ennis smashed a tenth-inning triple with Willie Jones on base.

The Rev. Dr. Kenneth D. Miller, president of the New York City Mission Society, speaking yesterday before the fifth annual communion breakfast of the St. George Association of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, described the city as a "city of wistful pagans."

Announcement of the 1952 Guggenheim Fellowship awards again calls attention to the imaginative scope of the work of this foundation. It knows few, if any, boundaries. In today's list are citizens of the United States, Canada and the British West Indies. Later this year there will be another series of awards for the Caribbean, Central and South America, and the Philippines.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $56,077,640,228. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

High winds and temperatures together with low humidity readings spread forest fires yesterday in New York State and in New Jersey. The blazes destroyed at least one home, killed much wild life, but only three of the hundreds of volunteer and professional fire fighters were injured.

Individuals who seek to divorce religion from education by imposing a "monolithic educational philosophy" on the youth of the United States were sharply denounced yesterday as "totalitarian" enemies of democracy by the Very Rev. James A. Pike, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

This country needs a new type of missionary in the Far East, the Rev. Dr. James H. Robinson, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of the Master of 360 West 122d Street, declared yesterday in a guest sermon at the Riverside Church.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 20 -- The United States embassy here submitted to the Foreign Ministry a draft for a proposed bilateral agreement designed to break the "blockade" of American books in Israel.

In his appeal for a better deal for members of city departments other than the Fire and Police Departments, with reference to pensions, R. L. Van Name has taken an odd stand. How can one argue on the one hand for the benefits received by policemen and firemen for his own group and on the other hand state that the pensions given to the protective forces are "over-liberal"?

A first novel by George Williams, Associate Professor of Creative Writing at Rice Institute, Houston, Tex., will be published on April 29 by Abelard Press. "The Blind Bull" is a story about a Texan, who, while recuperating from a Japanese guerrilla's bullet, thinks back over his life to find a reason to live.

A variety of contemporary treatments of ceramic objects are included in the forty-eighth Annual Crafts Exhibit, which opens today in the Art Gallery of the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel. More than sixty members of the New York Society of Craftsmen are represented in the display, which will continue through May 2. Many of the objects are for sale.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., April 20 -- An engineering operation that made possible the Normandy beachhead in World War II is expected to propel a New York City pier out of a clay pit two miles north of Haverstraw into shore at Fifteenth Street and the Hudson River, thirty-two miles away, in late July or early August.

The four-story apartment house for thirty-five families on plot 125 by 147 feet at 118-65 Metropolitan Avenue, Kew Gardens, Queens, has been sold by the Stenmark Realty Corporation to Irving Klein, investor, who insured title with the City Title Insurance Company. It is assessed at $135,000 and was sold through Philip Levin and Benjamin Govern, brokers.

IN July of 1949 the senior Senator from Michigan wrote in a letter to his wife: "I get so damned sick of that little band of G. O. P. isolationists who are always in the way that I could scream." Arthur Hendrick Vandenberg, who ten years before had been one of the most outspoken and convinced isolationists in this country, had come a long way. The well-meaning but shortsighted politician had become a farsighted statesman.

An underwriting syndicate, headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., will offer to investors today a new issue of $4,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of Cornell - Dubilier Electric Corporation due on March 1. 1972. The debentures bear 3 7/8 per cent interest and are priced at 100.

The American Council on Education for Journalism took a stand yesterday in favor of a broad liberal education for potential journalists as against a purely vocational training program in junior colleges.

AMSTERDAM, April 20 -- In talks with well informed quarters last week the impression was given that the Belgian rebuff to the Dutch appeal to accelerate the monetary, and thus the economic, union was considered a most serious development in Benelux relations
Martha Schlamme, Vienna-born soprano, appeared at Town Hall Saturday evening in a program of "Folksongs of Many Lands."

Higher pay for striking cafeteria workers at Columbia University was made an issue by union leaders for the first time yesterday. The workers who remained idle for the sixth day, previously had asked only for recognition as members of Local 241, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

C. Wilson Randle, dean of the School of Business at Western Reserve University, apparently has been doing a lot of work in his spare time. The result is a 740-page book that may well be the standard text on collective bargaining for years to come.*

In your editorial of April 10, as well as in Arthur Krock's column of April 11 and Edward H. Collins' column of April 14, THE TIMES has advanced uncritically the steel industry's argument that it is profit after taxes rather than before taxes which should be considered in setting steel prices.

" My Name is Legion," an hour-long play telling how the suffering and courage of Clifford W. Beers nearly fifty years ago brought into existence a mental health movement that now embraces the nation, had its premiere presentation here last night.

DETROIT, April 20 -- The list price of the Henry J. passenger car was reduced today by Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, the first price reduction in automobiles since the current wave of price increases began several years ago. Prices were lowered in amounts of from $100 to $168.

The mutineers at the New Jersey State Prison Farm in Woodbridge were still holding out this morning in the second-floor dormitory in which they had barricaded themselves Thursday night. At 2 A. M. today they passed the mark set by the sixty-nine rioters at Trenton State Prison who capitulated last Friday after a seventy-seven-hour siege.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 20 -- Working swiftly, labor leaders have established a Central Organization of Bolivian Workers (Central Obrera Boliviana) to unify workers "in the fight for nationalization of mines and railroads, and agrarian reform," the newspaper El Diario reported today.
PITTSBURGH, April 20 (UP) -Big Ted Kluszewski terrorized the Pirates' pitching staff today as Cincinnati won both games of a double-header before 23,732 fans, 8 -- 6 and 12 -- 2.

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet defended the "basic honesty, decency and integrity" of his department and Representative Christopher C. McGrath advocated wage increases for the firefighters in talks yesterday morning to 2,000 members of the Holy Name Society of the New York Fire Department.

In her debut piano recital last night in Town Hall, Barbara Berkman played prettily through a program consisting largely of Bach's E minor Toccata, Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 333), Schumann's "Carnaval" and Mana-Zucca's Sonata in A flat.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 20 -- The success of an Iowa State College educational television program presages ultimate large-scale television attempts to provide general and specific education in the fields of agriculture and home economics, the closing session of Ohio State University's Institute for Education by Radio-television was told here today.
Foreign exchange markets were quiet last week due in part to the iholiday on the Continent on Monda which was carried into this market resulting in a narrow price movement.

" Blessed are the peacemakers," words taken from the Sermon on the Mount, constituted the theme of the morning sermon yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, in commemoration of the seventh anniversary of the organizing conference of the United Nations that opened in San Francisco on April 25, 1945.

ST. LOUIS. April 20 (AP) -- The White Sox couldn't score on Ned Garver, Brownie ace, in the opener today, but came back with a bang against St. Louis in the finale, 10 to 2, after dropping the first one, 8 -- 0.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 20 -- To match the steady build-up of the North Atlantic Treaty Allies' ground forces in West Europe, the Allied tactical air forces have been reorganized by Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, into two major commands, each capable of supporting in a war one of the two army groups in West Germany.
MEXICO CITY, April 20 -- A wave of anger has swept this city over an appalling series of road accidents in which more than 200 lives have been lost in less than two months.

One of the most beautiful, if not the most famous, trees in the city was in full bloom yesterday. It is a pear tree now taller than six-story building and it rises from the back yard of 265 West Eleventh Street.

On a tour of delicacy shops recently, the delegate from this department noted several new foods, ready-to-use accompaniments that might well add interest to spring meals. Equally important, they relieve the home cook of at least some of the chores of preparing lunch or dinner.

Advertising men are going to sit by to watch the battle developing between television and the movies, two very important means of communication on the American scene. They will be interested in the outcome because it will determine, in the long run, the potential pulling power of video, a new giant, which at present reminds them of Primo Carnera in the ring, strong and hulking, but a sucker for a left hook.
" I guess it's about time," observed Sal Maglie, as he tightened his belt and straightened his cap, "that somebody gave these fellows a shave and cut them down to size."
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 20 -- Another "class" in the "military school of atomic education" is scheduled to be convened in the Nevada desert this week.

ALBANY, April 20 -- One hundred seventy-five years ago today the State Assembly met in the city of Kingston and adopted New York's first Constitution. In observance of this anniver sary, the State Education Department has put on exhibit in its law library here a display of historical records and prints relating to the Constitution, including the original manuscript copy of the document itself.
The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday that it had made grants of $2,001,098 for the first quarter of this year.

ST. PAUL, April 20 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers started slowly and then gained a full head of steam tonight to score their third victory in the National Basketball Association final play-offs at the expense of the New York Knickerbockers, 102 -- 89. The Knicks have won two.

The New York State Commission Against Discrimination announced yesterday that seventy-one complaints had been filed with it in the first quarter of the year. In the same period the commission closed eighty cases.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 20 (AP) -- Navy and George Washington University tied with 141 points today, but the middies won the Middle Atlantic dinghy eliminations on the basis of more races won.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Long liquidation of grains and soybeans was heavy last week, with substantial declines being registered in all pits because of favorable weather and crops news, the unsettled state of outside commodities, and uncertainty over the steel situation.

The steel dispute makes it necessary for Congress and the public to re-examine the responsibilities and duties of the Wage Stabilization Board with special reference to its tripartite makeup (equal representation for labor, industry and the public) and its job of dealing with disputes in addition to wage stabilization matters.

Pittsburgh Coke and Chemical Company, owner of 34 per cent of the common stock of Great Lakes Steamship Company, Inc., proposes to acquire the rest of the outstanding stock of the steamship company through an exchange offer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- Although framed ostensibly in a liberal spirit, the McCarran and Walter omnibus immigration bills now pending in Congress are highly restrictive in character and violate not only democratic principles but also recognized standards of decency and humanity, Arthur Greenleigh of New York told delegates at this afternoon's session of the Conference of Nongovernmental Organizations.

In its Annual analysis of the causes of street and highway accidents the Travelers Insurance Company again shows that the great killer on the road is speed. Of those killed in traffic last year, 49 per cent (13,730 persons) were killed by motorists exceeding the speed limit. Injuries due to the same cause numbered 570,000, or 39 per cent of the total.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A temporary sales tax on items other than food, housing and those already subject to Federal excises was urged today by the Committee for Economic Development if the levy was found necessary to achieve a balanced budget in the fiscal year 1953. The report is supposed to reflect the views of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, although it has not been officially approved by him.

The Western Union Telegraph Company, the largest privately owned written communications system in the world, is negotiating for the acquisition of the private line and teletypewriter exchange service of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, it was learned yesterday.

The current epidemic of prison riots is a natural consequence of the country's prison systems and is not likely to subside until the human element is fully recognized, according to a report released yesterday by the Medical Correctional Association.

Acting Mayor Rudolph Halley called yesterday for added support of the Red Cross blood program. He emphasized that the need for additional blood for the armed forces was great and said as many New Yorkers as possible should contribute to the Red Cross blood bank.

Fortune Pope, head of a newspaper and of radio stations specializing in the Italian language, said yesterday he would apply to the Federal Communications Commission for a television station to operate here on Channel 31. The same channel is being sought by WNYC, city-owned radio station.

Two clerks of the Metropolitan Tobacco Company plant at 649-661 Warren Street, Brooklyn, were held up and robbed of $15,055 in cash and $38,000 in checks at 2 P. M. yesterday. The men, Frank Garzillo and Walter Poock, were in a company automobile on their way to deposit the funds in the Chemical Bank and Trust Company branch at 50 Court Street.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, through personal solicitation and a telephone campaign, continued today to press a state-wide drive for their choice in tomorrow's Pennsylvania Presidential preference primary.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 22 -- The official Peiping radio took issue today with reports from Washington that an armistice in the Korean war might be expected quickly. It charged United States authorities with engendering "artificially inspired optimism" to divert the attention of the United Nations from the conduct of the truce talks at Panmunjom.

Members of The Associated Press heard yesterday an encouraging report from General Gruenther, Chief of Staff at SHAPE and possible successor to General Eisenhower. The news he brought from Paris was that the West European nations are making their full contributions to the defense effort, that in his view Germany will soon make its contribution as well, and that the Western defense capacity is rising fast enough to enhance the chances of preserving peace.

LONDON, April 21 -- Consultations with United States and French representatives on the drafting of a reply to the Soviet note proposing conditions for the reunification of Germany will take place here this week at the Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A group of the nation's top air officers held conferences today with Secretary of the Air Force Thomas K. Finletter on the cases of fliers who had refused to fly. They clamped a tight secrecy ban, however, on their decision.

JACKSON, Mich., April 21 -- A force of 200 state troopers, throwing tear-gas bombs and firing submachine guns, restored a measure of order in Jackson State Prison today after twenty hours of rioting by mutinous convicts.

BOSTON, April 21 (AP) -- Irish Bob Murphy, 182 1/2, Boston, rang up a unanimous decision over Reuben Jones, 180, of Richmond, Va., tonight in a ten-round boxing bout which was one-half of a double feature bill in Boston Garden.
Two youths who took part in the beating of a cab driver early yesterday were arrested by Brooklyn police after a chase in which seven shots were fired and one policeman fell and broke his elbow.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Free liquidation of May contracts was evident in wheat, corn and oats today, with prices for these contracts weak relative to the deferred deliveries. In wheat there was some buying against export sales, but buyers otherwise were not inclined

One hundred and forty wild animals and birds made the air at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, ring with roars, yowls, screeches and other sounds yesterday as they arrived in a leased Slick Airways plane from London. Accompanying them was Howard Berry, head of the primate department of the Woodland Park Zoo, Seattle, Wash., where most of the animals are going.

Three or four dozen fires were lighted and extinguished yesterday at the fire school of the Consolidated Edison Company in Astoria, Queens, to demonstrate to sixty Coast Guard reservists the most modern types of fire-fighting equipment and procedures.

The International Rescue Committee, which made possible the escape of 1,400 persons from Communist-dominated countries and resettled them in the United States and Canada, will end its seventeen-year existence on May 15 unless funds become available immediately.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 21 (AP) -- E. L du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., today reported that sales in the first three months of 1952 had totaled $382,600,000, an increase of approximately $2,000,000 over the total in the first three months of 1951.

LONDON, April 21 -- The British Government has instructed its charge d'affaires in Peiping to ask the Chinese Communist Government for detailed information about United States, Australian, Canadian and United Kingdom citizens reportedly detained in China, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today in the House of Commons.

The United States will display its full Olympic might in track and field to New Yorkers in a streamlined special meet at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island, July 6, the day before the first contingent of athletes takes off for the international games at Helsinki.

Asserting that "improved driver behavior" had resulted from initial tests of the combined green-red traffic signal as a substitute for the yellow caution light, Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday that the system would be extended to 900 more intersections on thirty major thoroughfares in the five boroughs.

HENRY IRVING, the greatest English actor of the nineteenth century, had a passion for precise detail and spectacularly massive effects. He would have liked the biography which his grandson, Laurence Irving, has written of him. In all probability no actor has ever been honored before by such a book -- an exhaustive, scholarly, objective, sympathetic work which might just as well have been published in three volumes as in one.

OTTAWA, April 21 (UP) -- Queen Juliana, following a coast-to-coast tour of the United States, arrived here by plane today for a six-day unofficial visit to her wartime home before returning to the Netherlands.

Chester T. Lane, attorney for Alger Hiss, former State Department official convicted of perjury, charged yesterday that the testimony of Whittaker Chambers, principal witness against Hiss, "is false" and that "his fraudulent plot now stands exposed."

A banking syndicate headed by Hornblower Weeks, Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Blair, Rollins Co., Inc., will place on the market today $4,100,000 of common stock of Drilling and Exploration Company, Inc., a twenty-three-year-old enterprise that has just entered the natural gas business in Louisiana.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- A Negro labor leader told a Senate group considering fair employment legislation today that the Federal Government itself "is one of the best examples of racial discrimination in employment."
The General Electric Company captured the grand prize and two others at the annual safety-in-the-home dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

Two passengers, who were born in this country but have lost their United States citizenship for violating laws covering Americans abroad, were among 775 persons who arrived here yesterday on the American Export liner Constitution.

Contemporary designs are included in a group of coordinated patterns displayed in the new Alma Barr International Collection of wallpapers. They are available at the Wallpaper Shop, 793 Madison Avenue.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 21 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, chief of staff of Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers in Europe, said tonight that "cold war" tension throughout the world would last for a long time. He told members of the United States Military Academy's first and second classes that there would be unlimited opportunities for the services of West Point graduates in the allied command for many years.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- President Truman today allocated $250,000 for flood relief in Montana, bringing to $1,250,000 the total he has transferred from Federal disaster funds for five flood-stricken states.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 21 (AP) -- Michael Orecchio, accused of letting gambling flourish while he was Bergen County detective chief, today denied the allegations in twenty of twenty-five counts of the misconduct indictment against him.

Benefactions averaging more than $1,000,000 a year have been made from the Charles Hayden Foundation in the fifteen years since the death in 1937 of the financier and philanthropist for whom the fund is named. A report issued yesterday, the first ever made by the trustees, contains a summary of the principal gifts and shows current resources of $51,942,724, including $4,258,700 allocated for projects but not disbursed.

The wide disparity between sums spent for manufacturing research and those spent for market research is creating new pressures on marketing generally in many fields, Allan R. Wilson, sales and distribution consultant, said yesterday at the spring conference of the New England Chapter of the American Marketing Association in Boston.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Agriculture Department's inspection system was sharply criticized today as the Senate Agriculture Committee resumed hearings in the so-called grain shortage cases. Members of both parties indicated their belief that more efficient inspections might have prevented losses the Government would sustain on grain stored in private warehouses.

MIAMI, April 21 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee told Southern voters today that he was not a "sectional candidate" in his bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and several hours later the representatives of a national labor union with 100,000 members voted unanimously to support him.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Defense forces assigned to holding the North Atlantic Treaty nations' vital right flank in the Mediterranean sector are in "desperate" need of additional air power, Admiral Robert B. Carney said today.
PROVIDENCE, April 21 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano, 189 3/4, stopped Gino Buonvino, 196 3/4, of Italy, in their scheduled ten-round fight tonight in the Auditorium.
CHICAGO, April 21 -- The 1952 Washington Award for notable technological contributions to the public welfare was presented here tonight to Dr. Henry T. Heald, Chancellor of New York University.

New York and Pennsylvania -- the two states with the largest blocs of delegates at the national conventions -- will hold their Presidential primaries today. In neither state is public interest exactly at white heat, because in neither state are there numerous delegate contests.
GENEVA, April 21 -- The Swiss Communists, who campaign under the name of the Labor party, took a sharp defeat in yesterday's national referendum on the repeal of the national sales tax.

LONDON, April 21 (Reuters) -- Hurtling along at eight miles a minute, twice the speed of conventional aircraft, the British Comet opened the world's first jet airliner service today with a trip to Rome and back in 4 hours 46 minutes' flying time.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 21 -- A former German officer whose regiment had been named by the Soviet Government as the perpetrator of the Katyn Forest massacre during World War II denied today the Russian version of the mass murder of Polish officers.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- If the courts ever squarely face the broad constitutional issue posed by President Truman's seizure of the steel industry, instead of narrowing the question to whether it can be seized by a subordinate on an executive order, the probability is that the final opinion will produce dissents in the Supreme Court, and that dissents will also appear in the court below.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., April 21 -- Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh of Barnard College told the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Inc., tonight at the dinner opening their conference that mothers would do a better job for their families if they exercised their minds and talents outside the home.

Floyd D. Odlum, chairman, told yesterday's annual meetinf of Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation in San Diego that its merger with Kaiser-Frazer and Atlas Corporation was dependent on Kaiser-Frazer's ability to hold or increase its share of the peacetime automotive market.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 21 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan and Frank Strafaci, each a double-winner here, and Billy Joe Patton, last year's runner-up, tied for the North and South amateur golf tournament medal with two-under-par 70's today.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 21 -- Jean Letourneau, French Cabinet Minister for the Indo-China States, arrived here today to take over his new post as Minister Resident in Indo-China. The post will incorporate functions formerly performed by French High Commissioners, with M. Letourneau directing French civil and military affairs.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Mrs. Marianna von Moltke of Detroit, a former German countess, today lost a Supreme Court fight to upset her four - year prison term for espionage during World War II.
Your editorial on this latest Queens plane crash is sound, but an important fact is being overlooked.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Government said today that employment last month showed no gain over March, 1951, despite new defense hiring.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter President Truman sent to Vice President Alben W. Barkley today opposing proposals to forbid use of Government funds for operation of the seized steel mills. Mr. Barkley was addressed as "Mr. President" because he is the presiding officer, or President, of the Senate.

Capt. Richard Beadon, an expert on pin-point navigation on the high seas, has retired after twenty-nine years of service with the Western Union Cable Company, K. B. Mitchell, vice president of international communications, announced here yesterday.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 22 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,227, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

LONDON, April 21 -- Field Marshal Viscount Alexander, British Defense Minister, will confer soon with Rene Pleven, French Defense Minister, Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- The United Nations Human Rights Commission adopted today two of its most controversial measures, one guaranteeing the right of peoples to plan their own destinies and the other promising to them protection of their natural resources from foreign exploitation.
LONDON, April 21 (Reuters) -- Manchester United today virtually clinched the English League soccer championship by whipping London's Chelsea team, 3 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld, 7 -- 0, a finding that the Richfield Oil Corporation of Los Angeles had violated the anti-trust laws by requiring 2,965 Western service stations to buy only from Richfield.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company asked yesterday for a $5,000,000 rate increase to offset wage rises granted to its 10,000 employes. At the same time the last battle in the national telephone strike was being fought out between Western Electric and Bell Laboratories and the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Clark Gable today won a divorce from the actor on testimony that Mr. Gable had told her "I don't wish to be married to you or anyone else."
PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP) -- Phil Cavarretta's Cubs spoiled Ronnie Kline's major league pitching debut tonight by whipping the Bucs, 7 to 1, in the season's first night game at Forbes Field.
Although pork prices advanced slightly last week, the meat still is relatively reasonable in cost, and supplies are abundant. So says the United States Department of Agriculture.
The newspaper, radio and television clientele of The United Press is larger now than ever before, Jack Bisco, vice president and general business manager of the news gathering agency, said yesterday.

James R. McConeghy, a suspended patrolman who was found guilty last month of first-degree perjury, received yesterday in Kings County Court a two and one-half to five-year suspended sentence. The court also imposed a $1,000 fine.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 21 (AP) -- Jack Cowart, former official of the Agriculture Department, went on trial in Federal court here today on a charge of accepting $1,374 for doing a favor for a Texas concern.
BANGKOK, Thailand, April 21 (AP) -- Thai bandits shot and killed an American woman missionary and wounded her husband Friday in a raid on the couple's church in northeastern Thailand.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- A relaxation of price controls in the "foreseeable future" on all products but those helping to stem inflation was predicted here today by Thomas W. S. Davis, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP) -- C. R. Ince, vice president of the St. Joseph Lead Company, predicted today that there would be plenty of zinc to meet national demands this year despite Government forecasts of a shortage.

The selection of a jury to try sixteen secondary Communist party leaders appeared to be drawing to a close in Federal Court yesterday, the fifth day of questioning of prospective jurors. The jury probably will be completed today.
Jack Hoffman Co, in 12 W 32d St; Kroll Gormac, in 21 W 19th St; H W Embroidery Co, in 133 W 25th St; Nylon Trim Corp, in 23 E 20th St; Autobridge Co, in 142 W 24th St -- L. V. Hoffman Co, brokers.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court today rejected five requests that it step into a controversy over a reorganization plan for the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- Following is a list, made public today by the State Department, of Americans held in prison or under house arrest by the Chinese Communists. (The list includes the organization with which each person was connected, the place of imprisonment or house arrest and the next of kin, where available.)
Georgia-born John Mize, terror of major league pitchers for nearly two decades, said between chomps of tobacco yesterday that this is his last season for lugging the big stick to the plate.

Boys carrying lighted candles on a "treasure hunt" for lead pipe in an abandoned tenement were believed to have started a briefly spectacular three-alarm fire early last night that burned through three buildings at Second Avenue and 100th Street.

Even though the fledging nation of Pakistan has been flourishing in nearly every endeavor, tax concessions for encouragement of new industrial enterprises are an important feature of the country's 1952-53 fiscal policy, it was asserted yesterday by Mohammed All, Pakistani Ambassador to the United States.
Cottonseed oil again was active yesterday as other commodity futures markets showed lagging tendencies. Except in the case of coffee and the vegetable oils, the tone was generally better.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 21 -- The atomic weapon to be exploded here tomorrow at the atomic test site on Yucca Flat will be the most powerful tested in the continental United States. It will also be more powerful than the two bombs that devastated Hiroshima and Nagasaki as well as the two atomic bombs tested at Bikini in the summer of 1946.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,400,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated April 24 and to mature July 24 had been opened at the Federal Reserve banks today.

Vic Raschi lacked sharpness yesterday at the Stadium. But the big right-hander was up against the Athletics, who rarely heat him. Despite six walks, a hit batsman, seven safeties and failure to finish, Raschi pitched the Yankees to a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphians. Not since Aug. 13, 1950, have the A's conquered Vic, whose record over them now is an imposing 22-2.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Army said today that Brig. Gen. John H. Michaelis, training deputy at the headquarters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in Paris, would return in August to become Commandant of Cadets at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

Episcopalians throughout Long Island began preparations yesterday to honor the Right Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Bishop of the Long Island Diocese, on the tenth anniversary of his consecration to the Episcopate on May 1, 1942.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 21 -- The command of the National Revolutionary party's Popular Militia announced today that no immediate attempts would be made to recover more than 10,000 rifles and light machine guns distributed to it during the fighting that overthrew ten rays ago the military junta ruling Bolivia.
LONDON, April 21 -- Most of the leading industrials tended to improve on the stock market today although trading generally was on a modest scale.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Next Move led all the way to capture the $30,000 added Firenze Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Under the guidance of Eric Guerin, the 5-year-old daughter of Bull Lea-Now What completed the mile-and-a-furlong test two lengths ahead of Joe W. Brown's Thelma Berger.

Your editorial of April 15, following the excellent report of C. L. Sulzberger on the previous day, brings again to light the prolonged tragedy of Rumania. The deportations from Bucharest are indeed the cynical summing up of a policy which the Soviet occupation has enforced in my country during the last seven years

The State of Washington announced yesterday that it would make a further public borrowing of $1,000,000 to finance war veterans' compensation. Previously the state borrowed $75,000,000 for this purpose out of a total authorization of $80,000,000.

NEW DELHI, India, April 21 -- India will send an official delegation to Japan to explore possibilities of enlisting the cooperation of Japanese industrialists in the establishment of a pig-iron plant in India. The plant is one of the high priority projects in this year's development program.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 21 (UP) -- Court-martial charges against two Reserve officers who refused to fly, were dropped today, but Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, said it was not a sign that he had adopted a "soft" attitude.
