Warnings against expecting the new drugs for the treatment of tuberculosis to achieve "miracles" were sounded yesterday at the opening session of the spring conference of the State Charities Aid Association at the Statler Hotel.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 21 (AP) -- In a later briefing, Dr. Graves and others of his staff also disclosed that:
Presidents James B. Conant and A. Whitney Griswold were guests of honor last night at the Harvard-Yale Regatta centennial dinner at the Harvard Club.

The three five-story buildings at 162-66 West Seventy-sixth Street, occupied as rooming houses, have been purchased by Jacob Goodman Co., operators, from the Guardian Union Corporation. The property, assessed at $90,000, had been held by the seller since 1932. The Charles F. Noyes Company and George A. Bowman were the brokers. Fletcher Brown were attorneys for the seller and Samuel D. Muney acted for the buyer.
LONDON, April 21 -- All sections of the British Labor movement paid tribute tonight to Sir Staf ford Cripps, particularly for his handling of Britain's post-war economic troubles.

Fresh forest and brush fires broke out yesterday in the tinder- dry northeastern states, engaging thousands of professional and volunteer fighters. Many weekend fires continued to burn yesterday. Others that were extinguished left a toll of several thousand acres of blackened, burned-out woodland and some property damage.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 21 (AP) -- Bermuda sailed off with all honors today in the first day of an international yacht race meeting. The races were contested in an eighteen-mile breeze.
A 70-year-old retired World War I sergeant was enrolled yesterday by his former commanding officer as a four-day-a-week volunteer civil defense worker.

Critics of private education were answered strongly yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe, minister of the Brick Presbyterian Church, when he asked the churches of the nation to increase their interest in education.

Plans for a new community of sixty-five to seventy-one family ranch and Cape Cod homes have been announced in connection with the purchase by Bethpage Ranch Homes, Inc., builders, of fourteen acres of land on Broadway, near Ellen Street, Bethpage, L. I. The property was sold by Jerry Leibowitz and Charlotte Deutsch in a deal negotiated by Samuel Berasch, broker.

MASTER MICKEY MANTLE sprawled in a corner of the Yankee Stadium dugout just before the home opening, the picture of lazy contentment. His hat was tilted over his eyes and he chewed his gum with methodical unconcern. This was just another ball game and he was a full-fledged big leaguer.
Congratulations on your excellent editorial of April 15 on television's future.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., April 21 -- Walter Starr, 14 years old, of 63 Main Street, was rescued from a ledge 30 feet from the top of High Tor on the west side of this village at 6 o'clock tonight while several hundred persons watched from St. Peter's Cemetery at the foot of the mountain. The boy was caught under a 200-pound boulder that had rolled onto his right leg.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 21 -- The scheduled detonation tomorrow of an atomic bomb on Yucca Flat, some eighty miles north of here, indicates that the United States now has an armory of several types of atomic weapons, with still others under rapid development.
The futures market closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and 10 to 43 points lower than on last Friday, with old May showing the most weakness.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, April 21 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft opened his home state campaign for Ohio's fifty-six delegates to the Republican National Convention today with a promise to slash Federal taxes 15 to 20 per cent by 1954 if elected President.

BOSTON, April 21 (AP) -- Julio Moreno's clutch pitching and Pinch-hitter Sam Mele's long fly to center with the bases loaded in the eighth gave the Senators a 3-2 victory over the Red Sox at Fenway Park today.

A million garments made of Lorette, a blend of 55 per cent Orlon (a du Pont acrylic fiber) and 45 per cent wool, will be available to the public in July. The new fabric, introduced last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Deering, Milliken Co., Inc., textile concern, will be used by 125 manufacturers of sportswear, dresses, robes, suits and children's wear.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Government began using a new standard today for determining whether to permit price increases on certain products.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 21 -- A political rapprochement between the Yugoslav and Greek Governments has progressed uninterruptedly in recent months according to Yugoslav sources. The purpose of improved relations is to create a political atmosphere that would enable the two governments to make a quick military decision if peace should be threatened in the Balkans.

Olivia de Havilland, who made her local stage debut last year as the teen-age Juliet in Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet," returns to the Broadway footlights tonight as the 33-year-old Candida in Shaw's comedy-drama of the same name at the National Theatre. Tonight's performance will start at 8:15.

Don Miller, Fordham right-hander, blanked Queens College on three hits as his mates pounded out an 8-0 victory on the Rose Hill diamond yesterday. It was Miller's third triumph of the season, against one setback.

BERLIN, April 21 -- Two young employes of the East German Foreign Office who slipped into West Berlin last week came out of hiding and received the press today in the offices of a political refugee group here.
ALBANY, April 21 -- The League of Women Voters took a sampling of opinion here tonight on what domestic and foreign issues will lead in the 1952 Presidential campaign.

A gasoline truck caught fire yesterday while refueling a four-engine overseas airliner at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. Even though an airline mechanic leaped into the burning trailer truck and drove it 150 feet away, the $1,000,000 plane was virtually wrecked in the blaze.

National legislation for enactment of fair labor standards that equal those in union contracts of the major industries was urged last night by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit, and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today criticized a series of resolutions adopted last week by the Daughters of the American Revolution convention in Washington. The resolutions, she felt, were voted on without sufficient discussion and without full understanding of their implications.

Robert A. Vogeler, the American business man who served seventeen months in a Hungarian prison as a "spy," has written a full account of his ordeal in "I Was Stalin's Prisoner," which Harcourt, Brace will publish May 1. Mr. Vogeler also tells of other Americans who became Soviet prisoners, William Oatis and the four United States fliers, and outlines three courses of action open to the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The State Department made available today a list of sixty-two Americans it believed to be held under arrest and some sort of confinement in Communist China. Forty-two of these were persons reported imprisoned, while the remaining twenty were listed as under house arrest, which means their movements were restricted to their residence or to a compound.

HONG KONG, April 21 -- The British-American Tobacco Company, long a fixture on China's mainland, is liquidating its "head offices and branches" in China, according to two public notices published by the Shanghai Liberation Daily.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 21 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, a long-time Socialist statesman and frail but powerful "Mr. Austerity" of Britain's Laborite post-war campaign for economic recovery, died tonight. He would have been 63 years old on Thursday.

The Little Orchestra, encouraged by the Town Hall Music Committee, presented the first of two post-season performances at Town Hall last night. Vivaldi's "Juditha Triumphans" was put on in concert form under the direction of Thomas Scherman, and next week Bizet's opera, "The Pearl Fishers," will receive similar treatment.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The prospect of early committee action on expulsion charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, all but disappeared today.
Dr. William S. Carlson, president of the State University of New York, praised yesterday the Fashion Institute of Technology for showing other colleges how to function without tuition from students.

" Maytime in Mayfair," a British-made romance with music in Technicolor, starring Anna Neagle and Michael Wilding, which arrives the the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux, is today's lone film newcomer. The Wilcox-Neagle offering was produced and directed by Herbert Wilcox from a script by Nicholas Phipps.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 142 additional battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 33 killed, 107 wounded, 1 missing and 1 injured. The following casualties were reported for New York (none was listed for New Jersey and Connecticut):

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois said today that the nomination of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio as the Republican Presidential candidate "inevitably" would cause "grave apprehension" in the Free World and "grave peril to the future of the United States itself."

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, charged on the floor of the Senate today that Mrs. Leon Keyserling, wife of the chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, has been a member of the Communist party and of "an unlimited number" of Communist-front organizations.

An order requiring Columbia Univeristy to show cause why it should not recognize the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., as bargaining agent for striking cafeteria workers was signed yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr.

Producers will have some extra lead for sale as the month ends, trade reports indicated yesterday. Such a situation, in which lead of domestic and foreign origin remains unsold, has not been experienced in the metal market since early 1950, when consumers were working off heavy inventories.

Dr. Leonard Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, said yesterday that the program of the Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York, Inc., was evidence that tax money could be invested profitably in research in the basic medical sciences.
The text of the address of Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther at the luncheon of The Associated Press at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday follows:

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 22 (AP) -- Communist shore batteries, well-concealed along northeast Korea's craggy coast, are giving Allied warships a hot time these days. The United States Navy said the enemy batteries were firing with increasing accuracy and greater range. They have shelled American warships nearly ten miles at sea.

Wooden bowls, platters and servers of the kind used by the Oceanic Islanders of the South Pacific, from a collection now in the Peabody Museums of Cambridge and Salem have been adapted for use in the contemporary home by Joseph Pelkey.

Negotiations with rioting inmates at New Jersey State Prison Farm at Woodbridge, near Rahway, were adjourned at 9 o'clock last night until 9 A. M. today on orders of F. Lovell Bixby, Deputy Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue collected $56,100,000,000 in all kinds of taxes last year -- the largest tax haul in the nation's history.

The stock market moved again to the higher side yesterday but with considerable caution. It was generally a further expression of optimism evidenced late last week, although the new recovery was hedged.
W. Averell Harriman, Administrator of the Mutual Security Agency, will announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency formally at a press conference in Washington today.

Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther declared yesterday that the projected contractual agreement that will bind West Germany to the Western Powers would create an "increased bastion of strength" for the democracies. He said the outlook was "very good" that the pact would be signed next month at Bonn, Germany.

The post-war housing developments of our large American cities are nothing but "sanitary slums" to architect Frank Lloyd Wright, who was seen here on his return from Europe last week. They do not in any way conform to his concept of what modern architecture should be.

A new approach to the problem of "chronic driving violators" was disclosed yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh as he announced that eleven motorists had been referred to the New York University Center for Safety Education for psychological tests to determine their "driving personalities."

The progress of design and the versatility of knitting machines were apparent at the Knitting and Allied Crafts Exposition that opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace. Higher speeds, more designs and low-cost operation were offered by the principal machine producers showing new models.

A young detective, severely injured last Sept. 10 in an explosion and fire that killed his partner and two suspected arsonists, testified yesterday in General Sessions Court that the fifth-floor garment loft where the blaze had been set had been "saturated with gasoline."

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- A "babe in the woods" business man testified today that he had agreed to pay $25,000 to a lawyer sight unseen after being told that it was the only way to close a Government surplus property deal.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., April 21 (UP) -- A new threat of rains came tonight to the vast farmlands in the flooded valley of the Missouri River and a wind shift at LaCrosse, Wis., threatened to send the Mississippi in waves against its dikes.
For about an hour yesterday morning pain of body and mind took a long-awaited holiday in the sun-splattered parade grounds of Bellevue facing the East River on Twenty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Robert D. Murphy, taking the oath of office today as the first post-war United States Ambassador to Japan, said he would do everything in his power to bring the two countries to a closer understanding.

He was "Old Man Austerity" himself, in his looks, his career and his life. There was nothing ordinary about Richard Stafford Cripps. He was either ahead of everyone else or striking off at a tangent, but he was never one of the crowd.

New York and Pennsylvania will hold primary elections today, and the results of the New York election will enable General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, to lessen the lead of his opponent, Robert A. Taft, in delegates elected to the Republican National Convention.

Things grow in Brooklyn, and the people who live there aren't going to let anyone forget it. They have now added to churches, trees and baseball teams a hands-across-the-sea note in putting up a plaque at 426 Henry Street to mark the birthplace of Jennie Jerome, the mother of Prime Minister Winston Churchill.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 21 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist Government won its first victory over the United party today in South Africa's constitutional crisis.

The annual meetings of a number of organizations and agencies combine to make this Newspaper Week. In this large group of persons concerned with the business of editing and publishing there is continuing examination of the position, function, duty and opportunity of the press in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- Following is the 44-to-31 vote by which the Senate approved an amendment to keep the President from using funds in a supplemental appropriations bill for operating the seized steel mills:

Enrolled members of political parties who registered last year are eligible to vote today in New York City. In addition to the choice of delegates to national conventions the various parties, including Liberal and American Labor, will also choose their state committee members, and in some places county committee members will be named.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 21 -- Japan and Brazil have nearly completed negotiations for a commercial agreement to expand trade between them. This is part of a vigorous campaign by the Japanese to win back their pre-war markets in South America and to gain new ones.

Many parties will be given at the April tea dance and cocktail party for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery on Thursday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. So much interest has been evinced in the fete, it will be held in the main ballroom of the hotel instead of the Terrace Room as previously announced.

Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, has taken steps to ascertain the extent to which the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and employing stevedores in the port have adopted the recommendations of the board of inquiry that investigated the wildcat dock strike of last fall.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (UP) -- Justices of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, hearing an appeal in a first degree murder case, criticized attorneys today for "bringing American criminal jurisprudence into a sorry state" by "encouraging litigation" through numerous appeals.

ANOTHER week-end like the last one and the trout fishermen will be sending presents to the weather man. For a short succession of such bright days will bring on the emergence of that wispy insect known to the impatient purist as the "Iron Fraudator" and the happy song of the dry fly fisherman will be heard on the stream.
UTICA, N. Y., April 21 (AP) -- The Oneita Knitting Mill said today it would shut down temporarily its yarn mill in this city, which is plagued by an unemployment problem.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Supreme Court paved the way today for the Government to jail five defense attorneys for their stalling tactics during the conspiracy trial of the eleven convicted Communist party leaders.

The United States has produced a turbo-prop power unit suitable for the immediate use of commercial airliners. Because of the priorities accorded the military services, however, the unit will not be available for a while for civilian use.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- The Giants, having regained their composure with their signal victory over the Dodgers yesterday, continued to perform in the manner of champions tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Justice Department today supported former Attorney General J. Howard McGrath's contention that he knew nothing about Newbold Morris' connections with surplus tanker deals before the New Yorker was appointed Government corruption investigator.

So many "if," "and" and "but" bids were submitted yesterday for Maryland's proposed issue of $20,532,000 of bonds that the state decided to call off the sale and try again on a more modest basis within a fortnight. The new sale is to be related only to $11,032,000 of school bonds.

The proposed $60-a-year fee for overnight parking of automobiles in city streets met a quiet death in the Board of Estimate yesterday when the board, in executive session at City Hall, decided to "forget" the impost. The levy had been estimated to yield $12,500,000 a year.

The New York office of Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., announced yesterday the successful inclusion in its production program of a new hydropress. The press is one-tenth the size of the conventional giant machines, yet is capable of exerting up to three times their pressures in the fabrication of sheet-metal parts for aircraft.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Despite a contention advanced today by President Truman that denial of funds required to carry out his steel industry seizure order might paralyze the Government in an emergency, the Senate voted 44 to 31 against permitting use for operation of the mills of any money in a pending $2,610,000 supplemental appropriations bill.

One obstetrician says the results he has observed among forty patients delivered by the "natural" or "educated" childbirth method have been "sufficiently startling and apparently sufficiently satisfactory" to warrant much wider trial of the method with mothers-to-be.

William J. Crowley, a 33-year-old suspended member of the New York State Police, pleaded not guilty yesterday when arraigned before Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn Federal Court on an indictment charging that he had plotted to extort $7,000 from Anthony Struk, a Suffolk County farmer, in an income tax case.
The text of the report of the board of directors of The Associated Press, read at the organization's annual membership meeting yesterday, follows:

The outcome of the struggle for power now going on in Bolivia means a great deal to the Western Hemisphere. That is why the situation is being watched with some anxiety and why an effort must be made to understand the complicated forces at work.
LONDON, April 21 -- Prime Minister Churchill arrived back in Parliament after a chest cold today wearing a hearing aid in his left ear.

The outcome of the struggle for power now going on in Bolivia means a great deal to the Western Hemisphere. That is why the situation is being watched with some anxiety and why an effort must be made to understand the complicated forces at work.
LONDON, April 21 -- Prime Minister Churchill arrived back in Parliament after a chest cold today wearing a hearing aid in his left ear.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Truman today nominated Stanley Andrews, a former Arkansas editor, to be administrator of the Technical Cooperation Administration, which operates the Government's Point Four program of technical assistance for under-developed countries.
Although still lagging far behind Great Britain in ship construction, the United States had more merchant tonnage on the ways in the first quarter of this year than at any time in the last two years.
Pink predominated in the showing of fashions from Milgrim's, 5 West Fifty-seventh Street, at a lucheon at the St. Regis Roof yesterday.

BONN, Germany, April 22 -- The French High Commissioner, Andre Francois-Poncet, lifted today the week-old ban on the German newspaper Deutsche Saarzeitung, published in the French zone, and thus helped the West German Chancellor avert yet another crisis over the Saar.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, April 23 (AP) -- Communist shore batteries on North Korea's east coast opened fire on the United States battleship Iowa yesterday, but failed to score any hits on the big warship.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 22 (AP) -- Two Walker cup golfers. Dick Chapman and Jimmy McHale, lost their first-round matches on the eighteenth green today in the North and South amateur tournament. Otherwise form stood up well.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, who is due back in the United States about June 1, will stay most of the time at Denver, until after the Republicans have nominated a Presidential candidate at their Chicago convention opening July 7.

Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, candidate for the Republican nomination for President, won seven of the nine contests for delegates to the Republican National Convention against candidates favoring Senator Robert A. Taft in yesterday's New York State primary election.

Three major tax bills in Mayor Impellitteri's city financial program, designed to produce new revenues of $17,500,000 to $21,500,000, were introduced in the City Council yesterday amid indications that at least part of the program might face a stiff fight.

President Truman's nomination of Stanley Andrews as head of the agency which administers United States Point Four aid to underdeveloped countries focuses attention again on that important area of our foreign policy. Mr. Andrews has had varied experience as a newspaper editor, Government administrator and Army officer, much of his work having been related to food and agricultural problems here and abroad.

LONDON, April 22 -- Britain's economic survey for 1952, issued today by the Treasury, makes it clear that the country is counting upon continuing United States economic support for its defense program, which, it is said now, will take longer than the three years originally envisaged for its completion.

LONDON, April 22 -- In seeking the formula for allaying French fears regarding West German participation in the European Defense Community diplomats of the United States and Britain are trying to avoid unduly offending German sensibilities. This is not an easy task but considerable progress toward a formula has been made.

As a foundation veritably "pulled up by its own bootstraps" the New York Community Trust, 250 Park Avenue, New York 17, has made an impressive record since it started in 1924 with total grants of $20. Through the administration of charitable funds in such a way that a "dead hand" is never permitted to rest upon them the Community Trust listed resources totaling $19,178,448 at the end of 1951.

A second tax lien, one for $1,556,205, was flied yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court against Henry M. Garsson, former munitions manufacturer, of 806 Roosevelt Street, Far Rockaway, Queens. The assessment was filed by Denis J. McMahon, Collector of Internal Revenue.

LONDON, April 22 -- The stock markets became dull today, the hesitancy shown by British Government securities yesterday spreading to nearly all markets. Although details of the issue of 150,000,000 of fresh stock by the nationalized electricity industry were not available until after business hours, rumors of the loan, coupled with the tone of the Government's economic survey for 1952, deterred buyers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Mother M. Katherine Drexel, 93 years old, founder of a Roman Catholic Order of Sisters, was honored today with a $1,000 award by the Alliance of Catholic Women at a luncheon attended by 4,000 in Convention Hall.

Return of the major life insurance companies to the public market to buy new prime-risk corporate bonds was seen in underwriting circles yesterday as Equitable Life Assurance Society put in an order for some of the new first mortgage bonds of the Alabama Power Company.

NEW ORLEANS, April 22 (AP) -- Louisiana Democrats officially elected Judge Robert Kennon, their party nominee, as Governor today. Other Democratic state officers chosen in earlier party primaries were also officially elected in today's general election.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York elected Edmond J. Moran to a one-year term as president at its annual meeting yesterday in the Maritime Exchange. Mr. Moran, who is president of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, Inc., succeeds John F. Gehan, executive vice president of American Export Lines.

Detective Howard Phelan, who survived an explosion and five- alarm fire that killed three men and wrecked a nine-story loft building at 9 West Eighteenth Street, recalled yesterday on the witness stand in General Session that one of the suspected arsonists walked out of a gasoline-drenched loft where the blaze started with a carton of cigarettes and a book of matches in his hands.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, urged the Senate today to kill the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on the grounds it was not needed and its continued existence would soon lead to "the same mess" divulged in "influence" charges last year.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Grain futures had the sharpest rally in some time today, reflecting commission buying on the theory that bear developments have been overplayed, with short covering broadening on the rally.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 6 points higher to 6 points lower on active months yesterday.
ALBANY, April 22 -- A program to promote the employment of physically handicapped persons in state jobs was begun today by the Civil Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it was negotiating with two commercial concerns to continue jointly financed research aimed at bringing atomic power into industrial use.
VIENNA, April 22 (AP) -- William N. Oatis went to jail a year ago tomorrow.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 22 -- The first major test of the Paz Estenssoro Government's hold over Bolivia's workers started today when 870 miners and workers at the American Smelting and Refining Company's installation at Corocoro went on strike.

Emphasizing the continuing growth of commercial aviation and its economic importance, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, predicted yesterday that, "in the years ahead," almost all long distance and a major part of the medium distance common carrier passenger traffic would move by air.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, first Chief of Staff of the Air Force, now retired, told the Senate Preparedness subcommittee today that the "stretch-out" in military aircraft procurement was a serious and inexcusable risk to the national security.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 23 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,228:

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Treasury Department informed the Senate Finance Committee today that it would not press for the restoration of the controversial provisions eliminated by the House of Representatives from a bill for simplification of customs administration and procedure.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today opened hearing into the "management, accounting, financial and other practices" of the Norfolk Southern Railway Company and the Norfolk Southern Bus Corporation.

The International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net income of $6,797,876 after taxes and all charges in the first quarter this year, equal to $2.23 a share on 3,046,641 shares, according to the report issued yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- The reeling Tigers suffered their eighth straight loss today as Saul Rogovin's steady hurling and Nelson Fox's timely hitting gave the White Sox a 2-0 decision.

The election of Dr. Elizabeth G. Salmon, Associate Professor of Philosophy at Fordham University, as president of the American Catholic Philosophical Association was announced here yesterday. She is the first woman ever to be elected to this office.

Much has been said and written pro and con about the inherent power of the President to take any action necessary for the general welfare of the country. Strangely enough, there has been little if any discussion of what seems to me the most vital aspect of the question.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, formally inscribed his name today on the growing roster of Democratic Presidential aspirants. A formal announcement of candidacy was issued from his office in the old State, War and Navy Building.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Five thousand, five hundred and forty-four persons -- no record but an unusually good crowd -- went through the White House during today's 10 A. M.-to-noon reopening for public tours.

Fifty Korean girls will receive scholarships to study in American colleges next year under a joint plan of Finch Junior College and the Korean Government, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Roland De Marco, president of Finch.

JERSEY CITY, April 22 (AP) -- Roger W. Straus, chairman of American Smelting and Refining Company, told a stockholders' meeting here today the company had the opportunity of developing in Peru what may be one of the great copper mines of the world -- the Toquepala project and the near-by Quellaveco copper property.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- John J. Bachmann, a Federal accountant, told the Senate Agriculture Committee today that a Commodity Credit Corporation inspector had failed in two checks to discover a $400,000 shortage in Government-owned wheat and grain sorghums stored in the Plains Grain and Storage Company, Inc., warehouses at Amarillo, Tex.

James Pease, who has been one of the most versatile and dependable members of the New York City Opera Company, assumed the title role of "Wozzeck" for the first time at the City Center last night, and he managed it impressively.

HONG KONG, April 22 -- Still showing effects of the strain, 41-year-old Father Robert W. Greene of Jasper, Ind., a Roman Catholic priest who is a Maryknoll missionary, recounted details here today of an eleven-day nightmare that he had experienced in Kwangsi Province while under Chinese Communist arrest on "espionage charges."

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- Clarence B. Krigbaum, a tax official for thirty-two years, has won civil service approval as District Internal Revenue commissioner for New York under the newly reformed tax set-up, the agency announced today.

New issues of public utility, industrial and railroad securities totaling more than $40,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings include preferred and common stocks of public utility companies, first mortgage bonds and common stock of coal and chemical enterprises and equipment trust serials of a railroad. They are as follows:
A 70-year-old woman, dazed and bewildered amid the confusion of the big city, received the sheltering protection of the law yesterday.

THE body was discovered in the private garden of the Grand Prince himself. Fra Augustino had been stabbed in the back. Since he had been employed by the Grand Prince as a secret diplomatic agent his murderer might have been motivated by mysterious reasons of state and diplomacy. On the other hand, Fra Augustino had not led an exemplary life. Personal enemies might well have desired his death.
OMAHA, April 22 (AP) -- The Red Cross estimated today that 3,618 families affected by floods in forty- four counties of five Midwest states would need rehabilitation assistance.

Six men were arrested last night and charged with criminally receiving stolen property. One hundred thousand dollars in stolen goods was recovered in a round-up by more than twenty detectives on the East Side.

Operations of all departments of Gulf Oil Corporation and consolidated subsidiaries were up over a year ago. S. A. Swensrud, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting. The company's net crude production increased 28 per cent over a year ago, refinery runs and distillate fuel oil sales rose 4 per cent, respectively, and domestic sales of gasoline were up more than 6 per cent.

At the request of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L. President William Green has named a commission of five labor leaders to "study and evaluate" the report of the State Board of Inquiry which investigated the wildcat strike of dockers in the port of New York last fall and reported its recommendations to State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi three months ago.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 22 -- Parliamentary opposition to Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist Government opened today a seemingly hopeless rearguard action against his powerful drive to put above South Africa's Supreme Court a "higher" court dominated by the Nationalist themselves.

A 21-year-old college chemistry student was found dead in bed in his Brooklyn home last night with a nearly empty test tube and a note to his mother on a chair near by. The police believe that the youth mixed and swallowed a poisonous potion and they listed the death as an apparent suicide.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- The National Science Foundation announced today the award of forty-one research grants, totaling $406,660 in the biological and physical sciences.
The revolt of 231 prisoners who barricaded themselves in a dormitory of the New Jersey State Prison Farm at Woodbridge, near Rahway, came to an end at 4 P. M. yesterday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 23 -- The United Nations Command informed the Communists at Panmunjom yesterday that Chinese and North Korean prisoners in the Allies' hands had been transferred to six new camps following the two bloody riots in the stockades on Koje Island, off the south coast of Korea.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 22 -- Mrs. Reinert Torgerson of Cherry Valley, one of the district's top-flight players, began another season today by winning low-gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club with a score of 80.

CINCINNATI, April 22 (AP) -- Two walks and a triple by Joe Adcock spoiled the major-league pitching debut of Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell tonight and the Reds took a 2-to-1 decision from the Cardinals. It was the fourth straight Redleg triumph.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- Yugoslavia has agreed to grant five scholarships or fellowships to students from trust territories in Africa or the Pacific islands administered under the United Nations, it was announced here today.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 22 (UP) -- Walter Wanger, Hollywood film producer, who threw himself on the mercy of the court, was sentenced today to four months in the Los Angeles County Jail for shooting the agent of his wife, Joan Bennett.

The problem of "guilt by association" of the yesterday prevented completion of the jury in the trial in Federal Court of sixteen secondary: Communist party leaders. They are charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of Government in the United States by force and violence.

The United Defense Fund will seek $19,451,340 this year to finance the defense-related programs of its six member agencies, according to an announcement yesterday after the organization's annual meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 22 -- Senator Estes Kefauver told a group of Southern voters today, "I don't intend to pick up my marbles and go home if the Democratic party platform this year includes a strong civil rights plank."
TORONTO, April 22 -- The deft hands of a Toronto surgeon have reshaped the life of Marty Kornbloom, a 4-year-old boy from Los Angeles.

Mrs. Edward Lasker's Hull Down revealed abundant closing powers in winning the Omaha Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Competing against six others in the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature, Hull Down thundered home on the outside to take first money by a head over Abe Levinson's High Bracket.

Recently increased interest among department stores in the advantages of remaining open more than one evening a week has stirred more opposition than enthusiasm among the smaller department stores, it was demonstrated yesterday at a meeting of the National Retail Dry Goods Association's smaller-stores division at the New Yorker Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower may not have assured himself of very many delegates in the Pennsylvania primary election today, but by getting about three-quarters of the total Republican vote he certainly did not do himself any harm.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- United States, British and French officials finished today preliminary plans for a renewal of a three-power economic aid program for Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Truman today requested Congress to approve a constitution for the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico that would grant the island possession the maximum degree of self-government short of statehood or complete independence.

The expanding interest of the United States in international affairs has given rise to area studies in many of our universities and to interdepartmental majors in our colleges, which have brought together the resources of various departments to collaborate for the better understanding of the geography, history, civilization, literatures and of the economic and political problems of various more or less well-defined regions of the earth.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, disclosed today that he had drafted a policy under which fliers would be suspended from flying duties "only under the most unusual circumstances."

The Texas Company, in the first three months of 1952, increased its earnings, crude oil production, refinery runs to stills and product sales over the initial quarter a year ago. The election of a new president and chairman of the executive committee also was announced here yesterday at the annual meeting of the concern.

The Territory of Hawaii borrowed $6,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of bonds to finance public improvements. The issue, which will come due from 1955 to 1972, was bought at competitive sale by a syndicate headed by Bankers Trust Company and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100,609 for interest of 2 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1.15 per cent to 2.05 per cent.
The strike of cafeteria workers at Columbia University, who are seeking union recognition, entered its second week yesterday with both sides determined to remain firm in the dispute.

Three new films will arrive in town today. "Mara Maru," a Warner Brothers adventure, starring Erroll Flynn and Ruth Roman, is at the Warner. Gordon Douglas directed and David Weisbart produced from a script by N. Richard Nash and a story by Philip Yordan, Sidney Harmon and Hollister Noble.
This season's bumper crop of brides will find an enchanting selection of bridal attire awaiting them in retail stores and shops. Rarely have the styles been as pretty or varied.

Loyalty Day has been proclaimed for May 3 by John Cashmore, Brooklyn Borough President. In his proclamation Mr. Cashmore urged all Brooklynites to display the American flag on the day and invited veteran, patriotic, civic, religious, fraternal, union, business and educational groups to participate in the pro-American Loyalty Day activities under the auspices of the Brooklyn Council, Veterans of Foreign Wars.

Efforts were continuing last night to end a strike by 6,000 distribution employes of the Western Electric Company now in its third week. Settlement would conclude the final phase of a national telephone strike.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A bill authorizing the St. Lawrence seaway and power project as a joint United States-Canadian undertaking was reported to the Senate today by its Foreign Relations Committee but without the customary recommendation for passage.

ST. LOUIS, April 22 -- Fred Saigh, owner of the St. Louis Cardinals Baseball Club, was charged with income tax evasion in a Federal grand jury indictment returned today. He was accused of evading a total of $49,620 in taxes on $108,823 of unreported income for the years 1946 through 1949.

ALEXANDRIA, La., April 22 (UP) -- Louisiana Republicans hold their state convention tomorrow and a stormy session is expected as rival Taft and Eisenhower factions step up their battle for control of the state's fifteen delegates to the national convention.
Dr. T. Kennard Thomson, member of the American Society of Civil Engineers for sixty-four years, unfurled the society's centennial banner yesterday at its clubhouse, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday that he expected the Federal Bureau of Investigation to include New York City crime statistics in its next natonal summary of crime totals and trends. The New York figures have been rejected since 1948 as too inaccurate.

The steel wage dispute raises many questions, one of which is how Government officials reach their decisions. Governor Arnall threw a revealing light on the soundness of his conclusions in his talk before the National Press Club.

Twelve police officers, ranking from deputy chief inspectors to lieutenants, were questioned yesterday by the extraordinary grand jury that opened a new phase of its investigation into crime and official corruption on Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Certificates of necessity for accelerated tax amortization of 255 new or expanded defense facilities, involving the proposed investment of $366,854,000, were approved by the Defense Production Administration in the period from March 27 to April 3, the defense agency announced today.

Some business and psychological adjustments by industry will be necessary as the economy of the country changes from a sellers' to a buyers' market, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, said yesterday in an address to the National Notion Association at the Vanderbilt Hotel.
The room of marble and carved oak that houses the Public Catalogue in the New York Public Library's Fifth Avenue building received a modern addition yesterday -- steel and aluminum card cabinets.

After touring the country since last October, Olivia de Havilland has come to town in Shaw's "Candida," which opened for a limited engagement at the National last evening. Miss de Havilland is a beautiful, modest and sincere lady whose enthusiasm for the stage is much appreciated in this neighborhood.

In his address to the members of The Associated Press General Gruenther touched on an aspect of the program of European defense that is causing concern in Allied capitals. It is expected that the six-nation treaty creating the European army will be ready for signature next month, but the weeks between now and then are "definitely anxious ones," said the Chief of Staff at NATO headquarters.

Eberstadt Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co. have bought the 50 per cent interest of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), in the Attapulgus Clay Company and will hold it for investment, they have announced. The other 50 per cent interest is owned by the Atlantic Refining Company.

ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP) -- The Indians' winning streak was stopped at seven games tonight as Southpaw Tommy Byrne pitched the fast-moving Browns to an 8-3 victory. It was Cleveland's first defeat of the season. Last August Byrne broke the Indians' thirteen-game string here.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., April 22 -- More than 2,000 soldiers and airmen crouched in deep foxholes amid the Joshua trees and cactus of this desert area today as an atomic bomb exploded 3,000 to 3,500 feet in the air a few miles from them.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- The second game of last Sunday's double-header between the White Sox and the Browns at St. Louis was ruled today as a suspended game under a new American League regulation.

Spot sugar jumped 10 points yesterday, but the market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange merely held firm. A sale of 75,000 bags of Puerto Ricans for first-half-of-May delivery was reported at 6.4 cents a pound. There were said to be 135,000 more bags of Puerto Ricans and 13,500 tons of Philippines available at the same price.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 22 -- The special committee of the United States House of Representatives holding hearings on the Katyn Forest massacre of thousands of Polish officers during World War II heard further testimony today that Germans were not responsible for the deed as charged by the Soviet Union.

Five defense lawyers who harassed Federal Judge Harold R. Medina during the nine-month trial of the eleven convicted Communist leaders have been ordered to surrender tomorrow to begin their contempt of court sentences.
Up in the Bronx, where there are more people than in Boston, Pittsburgh or St. Louis, is a country hamlet of 300 families.

United Nations officials participated yesterday in the opening of the first international Children's Portrait Exhibition, arranged to support the aims of the United Nations in "the promotion of unity, peace and integration among the nations of the world."

EMPORIA, Kan., April 22 (AP) -- The William Allen White Memorial Library at Emporia State Teachers College was dedicated today by Gov. Edward F. Arn to perpetuate the journalist's "great faith in the power of the printed word."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- The executive board of the United Nations' International Emergency Children's Fund, confronted with a financial crisis in connection with projected assistance programs, will try to resolve the difficulty by moving to unfreeze nearly $7,000,000 allocated for use in Communist China.
Sale of the General Aniline and Film Corporation, now under control of the Office of Alien Property, was demanded yesterday by minority stockholders at the company's annual meeting here.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- The Chrysler Corporation objected today to a Ford Motor Company proposal that the Government readjust its metals allocations to auto-makers, giving more to the big three and less to independent manufacturers.

Mordecai Sandberg, whose oratorio "Ruth" was presented at Town Hall three years ago, was represented there by a new oratorio last night. It was "Ezkerah" ("I Remember"), a two-hour work composed as a memorial to the six million European Jews destroyed by the Hitler regime.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 22 (AP) -- Bermuda's team of one-design yachts took a 2-1 lead over the United States today in the series for the Amorita Cup, winning the afternoon race after losing the morning sail.

Many reservations have been made for the Easter card party under the auspices of the Service Club of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church this afternoon at the Colony Club for the benefit of the Youth Consultation Service.

Gloucester-bound after an eighteen-month cruise around the world, the brigantine Yankee sailed through the Narrows and up the East River into Long Island Sound yesterday, her billowing white sails and slim spars a compelling picture against the hazy, industrial background of the port.
City College's baseball team notched its first victory in eight starts this season by defeating Long Island University, 6 to 1, at Babe Ruth Field in Macombs Dam Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

A 40-year-old veteran policeman was arrested by Federal authorities yesterday on a charge that he was the mastermind of the robbery last April 29 of $14,000 in cash and more than $15,000 worth of blank American Express travelers checks from a safe in the Brevoort Post Office station at 1203 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn.
In addition to the financial measures, a variety of other bills and resolutions were introduced in the City Council yesterday, These included:

Despite a protest by the President that such action would "paralyze the Government in an emergency," the Senate voted 44-31 on Monday against permitting any of the funds being voted in a pending appropriation bill to be used for Government operation of the recently seized mills of the steel industry.

As the time for the return of General Eisenhower draws near the nations of the North Atlantic alliance face the responsibility of choosing a new Supreme Commander of the Allied forces in Europe. The decision is an important one because on the vision, wisdom and driving force of the new Commander will depend in a major degree the future progress of the whole Western defense system.
An intensified drive by the city to require compliance by shipping concerns with its smoke regulations was described yesterday by William G. Christy, director of the Smoke Control Bureau.
PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP) -- The Cubs scored eight runs in the fourth inning tonight as they routed the Pirates, 13 -- 2, before a crowd of 9,321.

LONDON, April 22 -- For the first time in ten years British cotton spinners are to be allowed to make private purchases of raw cotton. Hitherto they have had to buy all their supplies from the Raw Cotton Commission, the bulk buying agency set up by the former Labor Government after the war.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The United States, Britain and France are consulting on a new joint declaration that will announce their principles for preserving the projected European army from attack or disintegration.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- Congress swiftly and unanimously approved legislation today providing an extra $25,000,000 for relief of the flood-tricken Missouri Valley area.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 22 (AP) -- The United Textile Workers, A. F. L., were asked today to get out and work against Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 23 -- The Allied Council for Japan, established six years ago as an advisory body for the supreme commander, held its final meeting this morning, winding up after 164 sessions with an angry denunciation by the Soviet member of the United States occupation and the "illegal" San Francisco peace treaty restoring Japanese independence.

Bill Sanford, right-hander, yielded only three hits, two of them of the scratch variety, as Hofstra topped Wagner College, 1 -- 0, yesterday at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference baseball game. The victory was the second in as many circuit starts for the defending champions.

Those people in the metropolitan area who get their television by sticking up an aerial, pushing in a plug, and turning on the set, don't know what the lure of television can be. Way upstate, particularly in the Adirondacks, television sets are rare. Good reception is rarer. The distance from the nearest stations in Schenectady and Syracuse is farther than the experts say television waves should carry.

MILL VALLEY, Calif., April 22 -- The Quadrennial Methodist General Conference, opening its sessions tomorrow in San Francisco, will be asked in a resolution adopted here today by the Methodist Federation for Social Action to lay major emphasis for the next four years on a crusade for world peace.

THE balmy weather of the last few days has swept the ice from many of the southern and central Maine lakes and most of the streams in these areas are providing fair fishing, but the northern lakes are still ice-locked, and reported to be clearing very slowly.

WASHINGTON April 22 (UP) -- A. St. Louis lawyer testified today that he had lent former Representative Raymond Karst, Democrat of Missouri, $4,000 of a $25,000 fee from a Government property sale and expected to split the total fee with the late Robert E. Hannegan, former Postmaster General.

DALLAS, Tex., April 22 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois called tonight for a policy of peace that would give this nation "realistic hope" of halting Communist imperialism without appeasement and the arms race without war.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Larry Jansen, whose spell over the Phillies almost matches the one the Yankees' Vic Raschi holds over the Athletics, enabled the Giants to make a clean sweep of their two-game series here by hurling the Polo Grounders to a 4-1 triumph over Eddie Sawyers faltering Phillies tonight.
OSLO, Norway, April 22 -- The Soviet Union has turned down a Norwegian offer of a three-year trade treaty, a Foreign Ministry official has revealed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- The Hollywood American Federation of Labor Film Council in an open letter sent today to Representative Donald Jackson sharply rebuked the California Republican and member of the House Un-American Activities Committee for his criticism of move unions on the communism issue during a talk last Wednesday before the Los Angeles Kiwanis Club.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Air Force has completed successful launchings of a jet fighter plane from the belly of the huge long-range bomber, the B-36.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Wednesday, April 23 (UP) -- Scores of mud-covered soldiers temporarily saved the multi-million-dollar Sherman Air Force Base at Fort Leaven-worth, Kan., from the flooding Missouri River early today when they succeeded in plugging a large hole in the field's soggy dike.

A group of major Jewish organizations announced yesterday their support of the Humphrey-Lehman immigration bill, which, they said, would provide "genuine Americanization and humanization of our immigration law." The group warned that the McCarran-Walter immigration bills, if adopted, would "abandon our country's finest traditions by dropping an Iron Curtain around our shores," and called the bills discriminatory against racial and nationality groups.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Government, a year after it began the presentation of its case before the Subversive Activities Control Board, where it is petitioning to compel registration of the Communist party and its members under provisions of the Internal Security Act of 1950, is expected to complete its ease tomorrow.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 22 (AP) -- Hill Gail, Calumet Farm's No. 1 Kentucky Derby nominee, will not run in Thursday's Blue Grass stakes at Keeneland.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 22 -- The appointment of Stephen T. Crary, Assistant Professor of Religion and Biblical Literature at Smith College, as Chaplain of the College was announced today by Benjamin F. Wright, president. He succeeds William G. Cole, who is leaving to be Chaplain at Williams College.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Following is the 47-to-29 Senate vote today that turned back a proposal to deny use of any Government funds for operation of the seized steel industry. The direct vote was on a motion to suspend the rules and consider the ban. A two-thirds majority was, required to carry the motion.

Budgets for child welfare and education in New York are being "jeopardized" in favor of other expenditures that are "largely of a political nature" and many of which could be eliminated without loss to the city, Leonard W. Mayo, national authority in the field of child welfare, charged yesterday.

The stock market staged yesterday a reversal of form. Rallying efforts of the last few sessions were dampened as the list fell under selling mainly in the railroads and oils. Fairly heavy pressure in the afternoon reduced prices on the averages 0.83 point although much wider inroads developed in some units in the two most prominent groups.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Hughston M. McBain, chairman of Marshall Field Co., struck at Government price and wage controls today at the annual meeting of stockholders. He termed them extremely timeconsuming, costly and unnecessary. He charged they resulted in little or no actual benefit to the public, industry or the national economy.

A Roman Catholic layman and a Southern Baptist leader shared the platform at Carnegie Hall last night at a public rally on "religious liberty" arranged by the Metropolitan Committee for Religious Liberty and the Protestants and Other Americans United for Separation of Church and State.

The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Minneapolis, large grain and feed producer, has jumped into the chlorophyll producing field with both feet, it was announced yesterday. It has purchased the Keystone Chemurgic Corporation, Bethlehem, Pa., maker of both chlorophyll, and xanthophyll and Clorophyll, Inc., with a plant at Neodesha, Kan.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., April 22 -- An atomic bomb of the latest design, more powerful than the two wartime bombs that destroyed the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki and believed to be the most powerful of the fifteen tested so far on the continental United States, was exploded here at 9:30 A. M. Pacific standard time today [12:30 P. M. Eastern standard time].
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight that President Truman's Administration had done nothing to deter the Russians from openly attacking the free world.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- The national headquarters for general "is sweeping" Vermont Eisenhower said tonight that the General "is sweeping" Vermont town caucuses in which delegates are chosen for the Republican state convention.

PARIS, April 22 -- A letter attributed to Habib Bourguiba, interned leader of the nationalist Neo-Destour party in France's North African protectorate of Tunisia, in which M. Bourguiba allegedly outlined his negotiations with the Axis powers for the independence of his country during World War II, has been published here.

The investment the Yankees made in Johnny Sain as insurance in the 1951 pennant drive began paying 1952 dividends yesterday. The former Brave came up with a three-hitter in his first start of the campaign and beat the Athletics, 3 to 1.

The biennial exhibition of the Brooklyn Society of Artists opened last evening at the Brooklyn Museum with a preview at which prizes and awards were announced. From today until June 1, the exhibition will be open to the public, coinciding through the major part of the time with the celebration of Better Brooklyn Month.

Versatile, quick to prepare and delicious are adjectives the Buitoni Macaroni Corporation has used -- and rightly -- to describe the new meal-in-a-package it is introducing to food writers at a luncheon today. Shoppers will find the macaroni dinner with marinara sauce and Parmesan cheese at Macy's, Gimbels and Bloomingdale's.
" To Be Continued," opening at 8 o'clock this evening at the Booth, will introduce William Marchant to the ranks of Broadway authors. He has been knocking at the door for quite a while.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 22 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its 1952 season with a Class A one-day tournament over the Siwanoy Country Club course today.

Connie Simmons and Al McGuire will be in the starting line-up tonight when the New York Knickerbockers meet the Minneapolis Lakers in the sixth game of the National Backetball Association final play-offs at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The contest will start at 8:30 P. M. and will not be televised.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The power of the State Department to deny or revoke passports without revealing the reasons or granting the individual a hearing was argued in a test case before a special three-judge Federal court today.

The item "Airmen in Texas Who Refused to Fly Face Trial," which appeared April 15, is, to my way of thinking, of great interest to the American people. Many would like to become articulate on the subject.

A Fire Department spokesman announced yesterday that the department would obtain eighty-nine fire masks on July 1 bringing the total available to 387, and that on that date, the department would ask for a "budgetary modification" so that 111 more masks could be bought by the end of September.

Censorship and other restrictions on news coverage in the Communist dictatorships have not been successful in suppressing "genuinely big" news breaks in those countries, Earl J. Johnson, vice president and general news manager of The United Press, declared yesterday.

The Department of Health, alarmed over the increasing number of people who are living in cellars because of the housing shortage, announced plans yesterday to crack down on landlords renting such squalid accommodations. The agency defines a cellar as a place where more than haft of the distance between the floor and the ceiling is below street level.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The consumers' price index, a wage regulator for millions of workers, went up one-tenth of one percentage point between mid-February and mid-March. It was the first increase in three months.

Recent recommendations of the National Wage Stabilization Board, President Truman's seizure of the steel industry and a guaranteed annual wage program were main topics of discussion at the opening yesterday of New York University's fifth annual Conference on Labor.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The first major break in emergency price restrictions imposed after the outbreak of the Korean war was ordered today by the Office of Price Stabilization.

The Tammany leadership of Carmine G. DeSapio suffered two defeats in yesterday's primary election. On the Middle West Side, DeSapio supporters failed to defeat Robert B. Blaikie for election to the Democratic State Committee, and in the Park Avenue area the ticket of Lloyd K. Garrison and Mrs. Dorothy Schiff defeated the Tommy incumbents for the same offices.

Recent recommendations of the National Wage Stabilization Board, President Truman's seizure of the steel industry and a guaranteed annual wage program were main topics of discussion at the opening yesterday of New York University's fifth annual Conference on Labor.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The first major break in emergency price restrictions imposed after the outbreak of the Korean war was ordered today by the Office of Price Stabilization.

Chris Van Cuyk and Preacher Roe, both left-handers, pitched the Dodgers to a double victory over the Braves at Ebbets Field last night. The scores were 2 -- 1 and 3 -- 1, with Roy Campanella and Duke Snider contributing the winning hits in the respective contests.

MILWAUKEE, April 22 ((UP)) -- Jack Kibbee, Fort Worth, Tex., who celebrated his twenty-sixth birthday with the second highest series ever rolled in the team division of the American Bowling Congress, a strike-studded 744, scored a 672 today to take over third place in all events.

A request that the City Planning Commission write into any new zoning law it adopts a provision that all affected property owners be notified by mail of petitions pending before the commission for area zoning changes was made yesterday by Paul Friedman of the Citizens Union.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, former chairman of the International Development Advisory Board, charged yesterday that the Truman Administration had "ignored" this country's fundamental ties with its Latin-American neighbors.

The Tammany leadership of Carmine G. DeSapio suffered two defeats in yesterday's primary election. On the Middle West Side, DeSapio supporters failed to defeat Robert B. Blaikie for election to the Democratic State Committee, and in the Park Avenue area the ticket of Lloyd K. Garrison and Mrs. Dorothy Schiff defeated the Tommy incumbents for the same offices.

THE most delicate and sensitive bit of mechanism in the world of sports undoubtedly is the thoroughbred horse. He is prone to all the ills, ailments and diseases which afflict mankind, plus a few of his own. Nor can he go running to his mother with the querulous complaint, "I have a pain in my tummy." The first talking horse has yet to be foaled.

Corporation Counsel Denis M. Hurley confirmed last night that Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker, had been transferred at the end of last week from the Rikers Island Penitentiary to the Tombs City Prison, and that he had indicated a willingness to "talk."

Television brought the atom bomb blast into millions of homes yesterday, but viewers were kept on tenterhooks because of the erratic quality of the pictures. Most set owners saw the highlights of the test; others missed the show.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 22 -- The gloom with which Israelis have been watching prices spiral upward and their real incomes contract since the beginning of the new economic policy on Feb. 13 was broken yesterday. A Ministry of Commerce spokesman announced that "price rises have come to an end and a period of stabilization will set in."

LONDON, April 22 -- Official delegations representing the Negroes of Nyasaland and Northern Rhodesia annouced tonight their withdrawal from tomorrow's conference on establishment of a Central African federation with Southern Rhodesia. It seemed possible the conference might be canceled.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 22 -- Vietminh casualties climbed toward the 2,000 mark today as French and Vietnamese troops continued their encircling attacks aimed at driving the Communist-led Vietminh forces out of a Tongking delta pocket fifteen to twenty miles northeast of Hanoi.

New Yorkers and our neighbors in New Jersey need to be reminded from time to time how important all forms of transport are, not only to our prosperity but to our very existence as a great commercial center. Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, did this yesterday in a speech before the Queens Chamber of Commerce.

DURHAM, N. C., April 22 (AP) The retirement of John W. (Jack) Coombs, one-time major league pitching star, who has been baseball coach at Duke University for he last twenty-four years, was announced today.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- The twentieth annual convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors today heard industry leaders advance a series of constructive merchandising and sales practices designed to increase the sales of cigars and sundries.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- House Republicans vigorously attacked President Truman today and argued that Congress should not create twenty-three new Federal judgeships for the President to fill.

With world production of tin ahead of consumption, the supply situation has eased considerably and relaxation of the container-control order is expected within a matter of days, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, board chairman of the Continental Can Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders, held at the Biltmore Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- A reminder of the past crept into the atomic news today at the time the Atomic Energy Commission was setting off the atom bomb in Nevada. The Columbia Broadcasting Company announced the discovery here of what appeared to be an Ice Age elephant tusk, estimated to be 50,000 years old. Dr. Thomas Clements, paleontologist at the University of Southern California, made the identification.

JACKSON, Mich., Wednesday, April 23 -- Warden Julian N. Frisbie agreed early this morning to "go along" with all eleven demands for prison reforms put to him by mutinous convicts in the State Prison of Southern Michigan near here.

" Better Brooklyn Month," the period through May 21 in which Kings County residents will raise funds for the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, got under way last night with previews of two exhibitions and a dinner at the institute for friends and trustees.

Martha Graham last night opened a series of six performances at the Juilliard School of Music, and it was an occasion of high distinction. After a period of two years, during which she was largely inactive, she has returned to the field in superb form, both as a performer and as a creator.

Two corporations and three individuals were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of creating an artificial reduction in egg supplies and increasing prices by conspiring to acquire October, 1949, egg futures in excess of the deliverable supplies of eggs, and of conspiring to reduce the quantity of deliverable eggs.
Short-term buying by retailers, under fire recently by manufacturers, was defended yesterday by William Burston, manager of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Senate rejected today a Republican proposal that funds be denied generally -- from present, past and future appropriations -- for financing President Truman's seizure of the steel industry.

RHYL, North Wales, April 22 -- More than 700 women delegates to the National Conference of Labor Women, which opened today in this bleak and windswept seaside resort, devoted most of their first session to a lively attack on the Conservative budget.

A new collection of eleven wallpaper designs, sold by the square rather than the roll, will be available at Gimbels on Monday. Measuring fourteen inches square, the paper is sold in units of twenty-six sheets. Each unit is said to cover about 15 per cent more wall space than the usual single roll of wallpaper.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 23 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower scored a landslide victory in yesterday's Pennsylvania Republican Presidential preference primary and ap peared early this morning to be picking up delegate strength in the Pittsburgh-Alleghany area, the only part of the state in which Senator Robert A. Taft had challenged him directly.

Two corporations and three individuals were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of creating an artificial reduction in egg supplies and increasing prices by conspiring to acquire October, 1949, egg futures in excess of the deliverable supplies of eggs, and of conspiring to reduce the quantity of deliverable eggs.
Short-term buying by retailers, under fire recently by manufacturers, was defended yesterday by William Burston, manager of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Senate rejected today a Republican proposal that funds be denied generally -- from present, past and future appropriations -- for financing President Truman's seizure of the steel industry.

BOSTON, April 22 (AP) -- Backed by a fourteen-hit attack that included three homers, Bill Henry, rookie left-hander, today hurled the Red Sox to a 10-5 victory over the Senators. Henry, who made his major league debut with a victory in Washington last week, gave up nine hits today.

RHYL, North Wales, April 22 -- More than 700 women delegates to the National Conference of Labor Women, which opened today in this bleak and windswept seaside resort, devoted most of their first session to a lively attack on the Conservative budget.

A new collection of eleven wallpaper designs, sold by the square rather than the roll, will be available at Gimbels on Monday. Measuring fourteen inches square, the paper is sold in units of twenty-six sheets. Each unit is said to cover about 15 per cent more wall space than the usual single roll of wallpaper.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 23 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower scored a landslide victory in yesterday's Pennsylvania Republican Presidential preference primary and ap peared early this morning to be picking up delegate strength in the Pittsburgh-Alleghany area, the only part of the state in which Senator Robert A. Taft had challenged him directly.

Although Averell Harriman seeks elective office for the first time in announcing his candidacy for the Presidency, he is one of the best known and most distinguished figures on the national and international scene. It would be difficult for the Democrats to find a man more representative of the liberal tradition of the party in domestic policy or with broader experience in foreign affairs.

LONDON, April 23 -- British explanations to African Negroes have not succeeded in overcoming snags in the plan for a central African federation embracing Nyasaland, Northern Rhodesia and Southern Rhodesia.

A fashion showing, dramatizing the research facilities of the Brooklyn Museum and their stimulus to the fashion industry, was presented by Martin's last night against the background of the Museum's Sculpture Court.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 23 -- Three times today and tonight South Africa's minority parties -- the United and Labor -- fought to delay the Malan Nationalist Government's bill to strike down the Supreme Court as the highest constitutional authority of this country. Three times they lost.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 -- The Screen Writers Guild today lost its first legal contest with Howard Hughes head of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, in Superior Court in Los Angeles when Judge Roy L. Herndon denied a petition to force Mr. Hughes to submit to arbitration a dispute involving screen credit for Paul Jarrico, a screen writer, who was a noncooperative witness before the House Un-American Activities Committee last spring.

Robert Whitehead, managing director of the current play series of the American National Theatre and Academy, announced yesterday the signing of Anthony Ross and Phyllis Povah for the leading roles in "Sunday Breakfast."
LAUREL, Md., April 23 (AP) -- Sammy Boulmetis brought home his fourth winner of the afternoon when he drove Mrs. Henry H. Hecht's Attention Mark to a nose decision in the Anacostia Purse today.

In the two states -- New York and Pennsylvania -- which will send the largest delegations to the Republican National Convention General Eisenhower has won new and impressive victories and demonstrated again the immense popular support which his candidacy commands.

An upsurge of nationalism in the Middle East has proved to be a dangerous stumbling block in the West's struggle against communism, Herbert L. Matthews, a member of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday.

Playing host to the Olympic Games, as the Finns see it, offers more business opportunities than a boom in tourist trade. The Finnish Foreign Trade Association in Helsinki, where the Olympics will be held July 19 to Aug. 3, is preparing to give free services to American business men who plan to visit Finland during the Games.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 23 (AP) -- The chairman of McCrory Stores Corporation said today that the company plans to open new stores at Arlington, Va., and Lexington, Ky., and also to enlarge stores at Hanover, Pa., and Columbia, S. C. R. F. Coppedge said first quarter sales would compare favorably with the same period last year, but that it is too early to make predictions for the rest of the year.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 16, the Federal Reserve Boardannounced today:
Ben Hogan left no doubt yesterday that he intended to defend the United States open golf championship at Dallas, June 12-14, by formally filing his entry.

Mayor Impellitteri's proposed budget of $1,469,265,101 for 1952-53 was approved unanimously last evening at an executive session of the Board of Estimate. The board left unsettled, however, its attitude toward extension of the 3 per cent sales tax after June 30.

PARIS, April 23 -- France decided today to propose a conference of European countries to consider setting up a transport pool as a supplement to the Schuman plan for a steel and coal pool, the European Defense Community and the agricultural pool that is soon to be discussed.
The cotton market turned irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were 17 points lower to 12 points higher than Tuesday on active months.

WASHINGTON. April 23 -- House tax investigators dug today into the finances of Joseph D. Nunan Jr. of New York, former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and traced to him and his wife almost $160,000 that was neither explained nor reported for tax purposes during a six-year period.

The 1952 Award of Merit of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, announced yesterday by Paul Manship, president, has been granted to Rico Lebrun, modern school painter of Los Angeles. The award, which is made annually for outstanding attainments by a non-member of the academy or its parent body, the National Institute of Arts and Letters, carries with it a cash prize of $1,000.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Communist party brought forth with a flourish today a 1944 letter in which Harry S. Truman, eight months before moving into the White House, said he appreciated "most highly" a political article in the Communist newspaper, The Daily Worker. The party is defending itself before the Subversive Activities Control Board.

Many parties will be given at the fourth annual spring frolic and tea dance for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York to be held tomorrow afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. C. Herbert Appleby, Mrs. Middleton Rose and Mrs. Robert B. Reed head the arrangements committee for the event, and among their aides is Mrs. Miles Oakley Bidwell.
In your issue of April 12 Hadj Taieb writes of the "French colonial system."

HONG KONG, April 23 -- More than 200,000 peasants and soldiers were reported today to have started work in central China on a project designed to trap the floodwaters of the Yangtze River in a 355-square-mile "detention basin" just above Tungting Lake.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the Western Allies were in consultation on ways both to prevent any country from dropping out of the European Defense Community and to give its members the guarantees of the bigger North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Squeezed between rising production costs and dwindling profit margins, newspapers must increase their advertising revenues if they are to stay in business.
