This was stressed yesterday by speakers at the annual meeting of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NAPOLEON BONAPARTE'S last years were one long book review. At St. Helena he read prodigiously. All that he read he liked to annotate or to comment upon to the dwindling number of courtiers and steadfast campaigners. A few, as they listened, were of course keeping diaries to make books of their own.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Federal, state and local cigarette taxes were attacked as detrimental to the nation's economy today by speakers at the twentieth annual convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Red Rolfe of the Tigers is a proud manager today. He is proud of his players, who, in the face of an eight-game losing streak, have given him a rousing vote of confidence in a secret meeting.

ALBANY, April 23 -- The Court of Appeals today unanimously upheld the contempt citation of Bartholomew Nicastro, retired New York City plainclothes man who refused to testify before the Brooklyn Grand Jury concerning his personal finances.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Laughingly but firmly Mrs. Harry S. Truman today scotched a move to "throw her hat into the ring." She tucked the "hat" under her arm and went home to the White House.

LONDON, April 23 (UP) -- Spain was revealed today to have directed a second note to the United States, Britain and France demanding re-organization of the Tangier security and police controls. At present the area is internationally administered.

The six-story dwelling with automatic elevator on lot 25 by 102.2 feet at 7 East Eighty-fourth Street has been purchased by the Asia Institute, Samuel Barlow, chairman, from Alice Simon, Max Hofmann and Marcus Katz in a deal negotiated by Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers, who said the sale was made for a reported price of $115,000.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Truman decided today that economic and military aid to the Netherlands should not be terminated because the country permitted the shipment of strategic oil exploration equipment to Communist Poland.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower not only left other Republican Presidential aspirants at the post in Pennsylvania's popularity primary yesterday, but also added to his strength at the nominating convention by capturing six of the eight delegates from the Pittsburgh Allegheny County district.

PARIS, April 23 -- Bonn's decision to break off the Saar negotiations and the attack by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on the French position was made known too late in Paris for official comment tonight. Earlier in the day officials had been reticent for fear of influencing the course of the Bonn debate but indicated that they saw no reason for a change in the French position.

Despite Soviet attempts to interfere, the protracted negotiations for a "peace contract" with Germany and a treaty establishing a European Defense Community with a German military contribution are now nearing completion. It comes as something of a shock, however, to learn that one of the remaining stumbling blocks is the insistence of the American Army Command in Germany on pre-empting a large share of the German financial defense contribution for the perpetuation of occupation privileges.

A New York County grand jury urged yesterday that all bus, taxicab drivers and others who transport passengers for hire be required to obtain special chauffeur licenses. The permits, it was recommended, should be issued annually and only after the applicants had undergone mental and physical examinations.

The railroads and oils continued yesterday to exert sufficient pressure on the stock market to bring about a further reversal of form. It was another uneventful session with little positive action in either direction, although in terms of individual issues the market leaned definitely lower.

RAHWAY, N. J., April 23 -- Inmates of the New Jersey State Prison Farm at Woodbridge, near here, began cleaning up debris and litter today in the two-story dormitory that was held by 231 mutinous prisoners from 9 P. M. last Thursday to 4 P. M. Tuesday.

LONDON, April 23 -- Sam Spewack, who has had one Broadway success after another, presented a new play tonight called "Under the Sycamore Tree" to a London audience that did not quite know whether it was art or just pure American corn.
CAIRO, April 23 -- Egypt, which is generally regarded as being in a backward and underdeveloped state is sending some Point Four aid in reverse to the Western Hemisphere.

There will be general welcome of the announcement by the Consolidated Edison Company that it has won permission from the Defense Electric Power Administration to go ahead with its program to improve smoke installations in the company's Hell Gate, Waterside and East River generating plants.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Hog prices were generally steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower today. Cattle were about steady on lower grades and steady to 50 cents up for better offerings. Sheep were steady to weak. Department of Agriculture reports on today's trading:

The Long Lines Department of the American Telephone Telegraph company sent two busloads of supervisory employes to Philadelphia yesterday after a resumption of picketing of long-distance traffic centers there by Western Electric strikers.
Dwellings dominated the trading in Long Island areas in real estate transactions reported yesterday.

The Police Department is about to lose the full-time services of a veteran detective with such an uncanny gift for tracing the positive identity of dead persons whose bodies were destined for impersonal, numbered graves that he has won the professional respect of the Army and the Graves Registration Command.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 23 (AP) -- Bermuda took a 3-1 lead over the United States in the Amorita Cup series for International one-design yachts today by winning the fourth race 20 to 161/4. The leaders need one more victory to win the best-of-seven series.

Those advertisers and agency people who haven't recognized that there has been a marked change in the buying habits of New Yorkers in the last couple of years are few and far between. Many do not know the details, however, and will be interested in the results of a study made by The Pulse, Inc., for Joseph Jacobs Advertising and Merchandising, Inc.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 23 -- Arturo Maschke, president of the Central Bank of Chile, admitted today that since January the Chilean Government had not sold a single ton of copper from the 20 per cent -- 80,000 tons -- of the total Chilean production of the 400,000 tons yearly retained by the Government for sale to other than United States consumers at premium prices.

ALEXANDRIA, La., April 23 (AP) -- While supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft vacated the state Republican convention for a technical debate today, backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower raced back to the meeting room and elected four delegates to the national convention.

The Fort Hamilton Arena in Brooklyn, was revealed yesterday to be outside State Athletic Commission jurisdiction because it is an Army post and therefore can operate its weekly boxing programs any night it chooses.

Sales of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation in the first quarter were $57,962,000, the second highest total recorded, according to Theodore E. Mueller, the president. He reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau reported today that 1,255 gamblers registered and bought betting tax stamps last month, bringing the nation's total of admitted gamblers to 18,913.

LONDON, April 23 (AP) -- British troops marched today into the palace of the one-eyed Sultan of Lahej, who acquired forty-two wives in the last year and lost two cousins by mysterious deaths in the last week. Lahej is in the West Aden Protectorate.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Two New York companies were among six small business concerns to get loans totaling $1,306,800 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on recommendation of the Small Defense Plants Administration, the latter agency reported today.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 23 -- Mrs. Chlorinda Seagraves Johnson, who is active in social life here and admits she does not like to sew, proved herself a talented fashion designer today with her collection of Seagraves Originals, shown for the first time at Hess Brothers.

Hudson Guild Neighborhood House held its annual open house yesterday to display its varied activities for young and old of the Chelsea district. The doors will be open to visitors again today at 436 West Twenty-seventh Street.
CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -Four prominent physicians were honored tonight by the American College of Physicians.

Enlarged talk of depressions that is unwarranted by the actual facts has proved injurious to the soft goods market, Leo Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, Inc., asserted yesterday. Business men, he said, appear to be preoccupied with prospects of disaster, when the only thing they are experiencing is a period of modest business difficulties.

SURFCASTERS, especially the striped bass specialists, have never been known for their quick reaction to what many are inclined to term "meddling" in their sport, but when they finally react the detonation often has something of an atomic quality, and it is quite definitely a chain reaction.

CINCINNATI, April 23 (UP) -- Umpire Scotty Robb was fined and "disciplined" by National League President Warren Giles today for pushing Manager Eddie Stanky of the Cardinals during an argument here last night.

" A Reappraisal of the Republican Party" by Roland N. Stromberg, Professor of History of the University of Maryland, will be published by Public Affairs Press of Washington, D. C., on July 7, the day on which the Republican convention will open in Chicago.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower turned down yesterday a request from the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., that he intervene on behalf of eighty-five striking cafeteria workers, seeking union recognition from the university.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 23 -- A witness at the United States congressional committee hearing on the Katyn Forest massacre in World War II caused a sensation today when he took an oath with a Nazi style salute.

Operations of the Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries in the first three months of this year resulted in a consolidated net profit of $3,352,979, after providing $8,665,861 for taxes, R. S. Reynolds Jr., president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars joined representatives of the shipping industry today in indorsing a bill aimed at expanding the United States Merchant Marine.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) -Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, today denied charges by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that he had made malicious, untrue, or libelous statements about the Wisconsin Republican.

ALTOONA, Pa., April 23 (UP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and a Democratic Presidential candidate, said tonight that President Truman's military budget "can be reduced without jeopardizing our national security."
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Truman has dropped his plan for transferring flood control and other civil functions of the Army Engineers to the Interior Department, the White House said today.

For keeping down the accident rate of automobiles and trucks they operate, twenty-one newspapers received safety awards and thirty-seven received certificates of merit at yesterday's meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 24 -- United Nations and Communist negotiators bickered their way through another session at Panmunjom today without progress toward an armistice agreement...
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The House of Representatives rebuffed President Truman today by defeating a bill that would have let him appoint twenty-three new Federal judges.
A warning against "overselling" mental health to the country was sounded yesterday by Dr. C. Douglas Darling, a well-known psychiatrist.

Dr. Harry M. Archer, perennial medical guardian of the city's firemen, observed his eighty-fourth birthday anniversary yesterday. True to his custom of the last fifty-seven years, he spent part of the day ministering with gruff solicitude to sixteen members of the Fire Department who suffered from smoke inhalation, cuts or sprains at a fire at 91-93 Chambers Street.

Members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association will vote today on a resolution attacking President Truman's seizure of the steel industry and his statement implying he had similar power to seize the press. According to the proposed resolution, no such power over the press exists, and any effort to seize the press will be resisted and defeated.

The Board of Transportation is ready to start the construction of the proposed Second Avenue subway line this summer and it has a promise of the necessary materials, but a shortage has developed in the personnel needed to prepare the plans for the project, it was disclosed yesterday.

MIAMI, April 23 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee spent an hour deep in the Florida Everglades today and afterward announced that as candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, he was "in firm support" of the $225.000.000 central and southern Florida flood control project.
ROME, April 23 -- Treasury Minister Giuseppe Pella presented to the Chamber of Deputies today the largest budget in Italian history.

Blind children often can lead a more satisfying and adequate life than many youngsters who have no handicap, Dr. Roma Gans of Teachers College, Columbia University declared last night at a conference sponsored by the New York Association for the Blind.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, in a bid for the District of Columbia's six delegates to the Republican National Convention, brought his Presidential campaign to the capital tonight with a plea for a second-to-none air force as the greatest adjunct to his proposed new foreign policy.

LONDON, April 23 -- All British fast patrol vessels such as motor torpedo boats and motor gunboats are to be equipped in the future with a new high-power Diesel engine known as the Deltic instead of the lend lease V-12 Packard gasoline engine now in use.
ST. LOUIS, April 28 (UP) -- Fred Saigh, president of the St. Louis Cardinals, indicted on charges of income tax evasion, placed his baseball future at the mercy of Commissioner Ford Frick today.
The Parks Department called the attention yesterday of nature lovers -- and anybody else, for that matter -- to the spectacular performance that spring was putting on in Central Park.

Denial of an earlier report that a large national roaster had bought all the certificated coffee held in licensed warehouses -- the aggregate yesterday was 116,918 bags -- sent the May delivery price below 52 cents on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Volume was 19,250 bags, and the close was 5 to 15 points lower.
Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday that "without an energetic and almost ruthless enforcement of traffic laws business in many sections of the city would come to a standstill."
HOUSTON, April 23 (UP) -- The eight top-seeded players in the River Oaks invitation tennis tournament advanced today. At least four are bound to fall tomorrow in the quarter-finals play, however.
BONN, Germany, April 23 -- The negotiations between France and West Germany on a settlement of the Saar's future have broken down and events are moving toward a showdown on this issue.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 23 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower had his first political conference today since he announced ten days ago that he would leave his North Atlantic Treaty commander's job June 1.

An Oslo dispatch to this newspaper supplies an illuminating example of the contrast between Soviet propaganda and Soviet action with respect to international trade. While the recent International Economic Conference was going on in Moscow, Soviet spokesmen talked long and brightly about their great interest in long-term trade relations with the West.

BUFFALO, April 23 (AP) -- More than $1,000,000 in law suits against the owner of the tug Sachem have been wiped off the Admiralty Court calendar as contesting parties reached an out-of-court "general agreement." The vessel sank Dec. 18, 1950, in Lake Erie, causing the death of her twelve crew members.

An exhibit here of Pakistani products, raw materials and handicrafts, one of the methods by which the United States Government is encouraging foreign trade, won the praise yesterday of Pakistan's new Ambassador, Mohammed Ali. The display is in two street- level windows of the building occupied by the New York regional office of the Department of Commerce, 2 West Forty-third Street.

Assistant Fire Marshal Bernard J. Reilly testified yesterday in General Sessions that Al Keshner on trial for first-degree murder had agreed to a $1,500 pay-off to Jacob Weiss, a suspected arsonist killed in the explosion and fire that wrecked a loft building at 9 West Eighteenth Street last Sept. 10.

LONDON, April 23 -- The British Government expects the United States to match London's guarantees of mutual support to members of the projected European Defense Community between now and July. This will take Congressional and Presidential action.

The Second Regional Wage Stabilization Board opened its action against thirteen local ship repair concerns yesterday for alleged payment of over-the-ceiling wage rates, but there was little more than procedural argument at the first day's four-hour session.
CHICAGO, April 23 -- A reactionary price trend developed in the grain market today, all cereals selling off sharply from fairly strong initial quotations.

Twenty-three cousins have established their right to share the $1,250,000 estate of Mrs. Bertha M. Voss, recluse who was found dead in her $42.50-a-month apartment at 118 West Ninety-first Street on March 18, 1949. An order to that effect was signed yesterday by Surrogate William T. Collins.
ALBANY, April 23 -- The Court of Appeals upheld unanimously today the ban on submetering of electricity ordered by the Public Service Commission in July, 1951.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- To the small group in Pennsylvania that usually comes to Republican National Conventions with a hand-picked delegation the popular preferences expressed by their fellow partisans in the Presidential primaries of that state are only a factor in their ultimate decision.

Molle Parnis' collection of summer fashions, shown yesterday in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was designed with the young and pretty woman in mind. Skirts were full and fairly danced over many petticoats, fabrics were sheer when the dress was keyed to a party occasion and colors were crisp and gay or geared to summer shadows when they were in the black and dark gray classification.

Food writers received earlier this week a handsome introduction to the newest in pastry ideas -- an ice cream parfait pie with a filling that is quick and practically fool-proof to do. The scene for the presentation, which included a colorful parade of waiters toting delectable examples of variations possible with the basic pie recipe, was the Pierre Hotel.

In a proxy contest at the annual meeting on Tuesday, control of the American Hard Rubber Company passed to a slate of nine directors sponsored by the independent stockholders' protective committee. a body comprising most of the concern's larger stockholders.

Geneva, April 23 -- Belgium notified the United States and other governments participating in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that tariff concessions granted to the United States on industrial wax will be withdrawn in retaliation for United States increases in duties on fur for the manufacture of hats.

ALBANY, April 23 -- The showing made by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the New York primary elections was termed "a stunning victory" today by Governor Dewey. The Governor also cited the general's successes in Pennsylvania and Vermont as evidence of popularity.

Yeshiva University announced yesterday the establishment of a graduate department of mathematics offering courses leading to the degrees of Master of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy. The new department will be part of the university's Institute of Mathematics, headed by Dr. Jekuthiel Ginsburg. Courses leading initially to the Master of Arts degree will begin in September.

Rudolph Halley's decision to vote against the sales tax at the 3 per cent rate is an irresponsible act. The gravity of his irresponsibility is increased by the fact that he is, at the moment, sitting as Acting Mayor and should be leading the Board of Estimate in sound administration of New York City's finances.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Army's highest-ranking observer at yesterday's atomic test in Nevada, Gen. John E. Hull, today described the troop exercise held in conjunction with the bomb blast as a "complete success."

A four-alarm fire in an abandoned theatre in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn was brought under control last night after it had frightened 2,500 patrons of a neighboring motion picture house and had caused a diversion of some B. M. T. trains.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- A Protestant group disputed today a statement from the National Catholic Education Association that Roman Catholics believed in and would support the public school system.

The appointment of Capt. Dolores Liberty Dubinsky, United States Marine Corps, as inspector-instructor of the Women's Reserve Classification Platoon, Marine Corp Reserve, activated this week at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.

RHYL, North Wales, April 23 -- Warning of the dangers facing the world. Clement Attlee, former Prime Minister of the Labor Government, took issue with the Bevan wing of the Labor party tonight and reaffirmed his support of Britain's rearmament effort, which the Bevanites want to see reduced in favor of maintaining full social services.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 399,000 barrels last week, whereas light fuel and heavy fuel oil stocks reversed their downward pattern and showed sharp increases, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Miss Regina Resnick, dramatic soprano at the Metropolitan Opera, was one of three Hunter College graduates to receive an award for outstanding achievement at the college's homecoming reception for the class of '42 last night at the college, Park Avenue and Sixty-eight Street.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 24 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,229, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Thursday (4 P. M. Wednesday, Eastern standard time):

Nelson Rockefeller's blunt criticism of the Truman Administration for "ignoring, neglecting, and underestimating'' our vital ties with Latin America must be taken seriously. There is no better friend of Latin America and no greater expert on that region in the United States than Mr. Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The next offering of public housing authority bonds will not be any larger than usual because of the postponement of the sale of $167,093,000 of new bonds that had been scheduled for April 15.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

TWO children were dead of carbon monoxide and smoke poisoning and three others were in serious condition last night in two hospitals after a fire in a four-story brick building in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. It was believed that a defective oil heater had exploded and caused the one- a arm blaze.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 23 -- The International Tin Study Group estimated today world mine production in February at 12,500 long tons, down 600 from January and the lowest figure in twelve months.
KANSAS CITY. Mo., April 23 (AP) -- A dike broke at Sherman Air Force Base at Fort Leavenworth, Kan. tonight, flooding the $3.500.000 field after a week-long fight to save it.

The fossilized and stone-set evidence of a mystery at least 120,000,000 years old was presented here yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History for amateur and professional crime-solvers to ponder.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Vernon M. Harris, a Kansas grain dealer, testified before the Senate Agriculture Committee today that two Federal surplus property officials at Kansas City, Mo., and another grain dealer had demanded 35 per cent of his net profits as a condition for obtaining for him renewal of a lease on grain storage facilities at Camp Crowder, Mo.

JOCKO CONLAN is a bellicose little fellow with a low boiling point, a caustic wit and a ready retort for any ball player who questions his authority. Jocko Conlan not only is an umpire but he is one of the very best in the business. The occupational hazards of his trade daunt him not a bit. However, one ball player finally found a way of silencing Jocko.

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., April 23 -- The United Nations' Human Rights Commission recommended today that the demands of dependent peoples for self-government be helped along through United Nations-supervised plebiscites.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- The Harvard Advocate, unofficial college literary magazine, revealed today that The Warren Press of Boston had refused to print any further issues because the concern considered some of the material in the March and April issues obscene.
James E. Reardon, former plain-clothes policeman who had close ties with Harry Gross, Brooklyn gambler, was arrested last night on charges of having perjured himself before a Kings County grand jury.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today new issues of bonds and common stock valued at more than $14,800,000. The offerings will include public utility mortgage bonds and stock of industrial research and liquefied petroleum gas enterprises.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 23 (AP) -- Hobart Manley of Savannah, Ga., the defending champion, moved briskly along to the quarter-finals of the North and South amateur golf tournament today with a pair of impressive victories. Other favorites also survived the two rounds, but several won by narrow margins.

Columbia and Pennsylvania battled to a 5-all tie in an Eastern Intercollegiate League southern division baseball game that was called after eight innings by wet grounds and darkness at Baker Field yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Senate voted, 39 to 36, tonight to send back to committee a measure to dissolve the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the Government's lending agency.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., April 23 -- Voters here in the largest incorporated village in New York State chose a Democrat for Mayor today but preferred to keep Republicans in the majority on the Board of Trustees.

On their way to and from their annual convention in San Francisco on May 5-6, members of the National Federation of Financial Analysts are to visit fifty corporations doing an annual business in excess of $10 billion. They will travel by special train from Chicago.

CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- In the largest income tax evasion case here on record, Poncet Davis of Akron was charged in a grand jury indictment today of dodging $738,249 in taxes in a four-year period.
I recently read that the last D. P. admitted officially here had secured a position paying a weekly wage. This happened to a man not under 35 years of age, who landed in our city just week or so ago.

Mounting their most explosive attack of the campaign, the Giants blasted the Braves, 9 -- 5, yesterday, for their fourth straight victory. Leo Durocher's charges made only eight hits to Boston's eleven, but the blows included four home runs, a triple and a double, and added up to a total of twenty-three bases.

At a time when the airlines of the nation are trying to cope with the most distressing series of accidents in the history of commercial aviation it is a pleasant relief to note the unique and happy safety record of Colonial Airlines. Recently this company started its twenty-third consecutive year of operation without a single fatality or even serious injury to passengers or crew members.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 22 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's South African Government officially challenged today a passage in a dispatch of THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent published April 16 dealing with an accident to the son of an American resident in this country.

A jury of six men and six women was sworn in at 4:50 P. M. yesterday to determine the guilt or innocence of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders, charged with conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force and violence.
JACKSON, Mich., Thursday, April 24 -- Southern Michigan prison's rioters agreed today to end their mutiny after the Governor of Michigan accepted their eleven-point reform demand.

" Of making many books," observed the writer of Ecclesiastes, "there is no end." Some twenty-one centuries later, the end is not yet; men still are finding things to say, old things to be said in a new way, mostly, but now and then some new thing is written and put between boards to be read, pondered and debated (and perhaps made into a play or motion picture).

The temporary authorization granted to the Seatrain Lines, Inc., to operate a common-carrier water transport service between New York and Savannah, Ga., has been extended indefinitely by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

DALLAS, April 23 (AP) -- A group of Reserve officers at Randolph Air Force Base at San Antonio, Tex., were reported today to be demanding a public apology from the Air Force for "illegal charges" brought against men who have refused to fly.

A rash of racketeer-infested unions has cropped up in the metropolitan area in recent months, causing intense concern to the bona fide labor movement, employers and Government law-enforcement agencies.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- Humanity in "revolt," rather than communism, was singled out here tonight by the Bishops of the Methodist Church as the basic problem confronting mankind. As major deterrents to the achievement of full democracy in this country, they cited recurring threats to freedom of thought and racial tensions.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of $75,000,000 of twenty-five-year debentures due May 1, 1977, intended for public offering through underwriters headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.

The average market price of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose 43 cents in March, the Exchange reported yesterday. This took the average to $98.26, against $97.83 at the end of February. It was the highest level since the $98.29 recorded last Oct. 31.

MONTREAL, April 23 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Stanley Woodward defended today investment of United States capital in Quebec, and observed that "denunciation of foreign capital, trusts, and unions have become a commonplace tactic" in that province only in recent years.
Martha Graham last night gave the second in her series of six performances with her company at the Juilliard School, and again it was a wonderfully rewarding evening.

In a crowded auction gallery here yesterday, successful competitors for about half a dazzling collection of diamond bracelets, brooches and other valuable ornaments that had belonged to the late Mrs. H. Sylvia A. H. G. Wilks paid $196,340 for eighty-eight pieces of jewelry.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) -- President Truman's program to keep Government information involving national "security" from the public is actually making it harder for Federal agencies to withhold news, an official in charge of policing the program said today.

LONDON, April 23. -- The stock markets stood up well today to news of an unexpectedly large issue of 150,000,000 of stock by the nationalized electricity industry, and the Government's economic survey. British Government securities were priced lower as a precaution but little selling developed and by the end of the day most of the early losses had been halved.

Lower Manhattan's financial shipping, City Hall and court districts were shrouded with smoke for hours yesterday afternoon as scores of firemen battled to confine a fire that destroyed the upper floors of a loft building extending from Chambers Street to Reade Street, between Church Street and City Hall Park.

GUATEMALA, April 23 -- Twenty-seven amendments to the Guatemalan labor code were approved by Congress this week and will go into immediate effect. The code amendments were the subject of heated controversies in Congress in April, 1951, after the labor committee presented eighty amendments for discussion.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) -- The Defense Department reported today that United States battle casualties in Korea totaled 107,666 through last Friday, an increase of 295 over the previous week's summary.
ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) -- Bobby Cain outpitched Bob Feller tonight in a unique duel in which the Browns defeated the Indians, 1 to 0 and took over first place in the American League.

The 1,500,000 Frenchmen living in North Africa make it necessary for France to maintain her present control there, Paul Reynaud, former French Premier and one of the most influential leaders in the National Assembly, said yesterday at a news conference here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23 -- The executive board of the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund today approved-subject to the availability of funds -- an extensive list of emergency and long-term projects in Asia, Europe, the eastern Mediterranean area and Latin America, for a total of $4,744,000.

The United States should not consent to the reunification of Germany until Russia returns the eight to ten billion dollars in reparations from current production taken from the Eastern Zone, the former American commander of the Berlin garrison declared yesterday.

ALBANY, April 23 -- New York University received authority from the Court of Appeals today to evict tenants from three apartment houses to be used as dormitories for students and instructors participating in new or expanded classes at the School of Law.

Although "To Be Continued" looks brilliant, it sounds dull. It looks brilliant because Guthrie McClintic has produced it with elegance and cast it with taste. To represent the studio living room of a house on East Tenth Street, Donald Oenslager has filled the stage at the Booth Theatre with a spacious and opulent set that is somehow restful and soothing.

As time goes by the public has become more and more aware that the so-called Social Security Law is not what it was thought to be. The law is so drawn that unless the taxpayer is fully and currently insured the benefits are considerably cut.

The State of Oregon borrowed $46,000,000 in the public market yesterday at 1.7099 per cent interest on war veteran's compensation bonus bonds, due serially from 1953 to 1972. The borrowing will finance bonus payments averaging $420 and running to a maximum of $600.

The changes in attitude toward handicapped youngsters in the last quarter century and what these changes mean to science, the community and organizations set up to help such children, were discussed yesterday at the annual meeting of the council of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 23 -- Yesterday's atomic bomb blast at the Nevada Desert Proving Ground near here marked the beginning of a new type of ground warfare, in which the Army still is learning its military A-B-C's.

There are signs of approaching summer on the attractive grounds of Gold-water Memorial Hospital, a municipal hospital for chronic diseases on Welfare Island, and in its thirty-two modern, sunlit wards. In the Volunteer Office there is an additional indication of the season -- frequent mention of summer vacations.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Representative James P. Richards of South Carolina, Chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, called on W. Averell Harriman today to withdraw from the Presidential race or resign as Mutual Security director.

In his first start last Saturday, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's gray 2-year-old colt Native Dancer won with four and a half lengths to spare. Yesterday at Jamaica, in the $14,950 Youthful Stakes, he did even better. The runner-up was six lengths back at the end of five furlongs run in 0:59 2-5.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- Charles Codman Cabot, Boston lawyer and former justice of the Massachusetts Superior Court, has been elected president of the Harvard Alumni Association for 1952-53. He will assume office on Commencement Day, June 19.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals has been asked to reverse a ruling by the Federal Power Commission that it does not have jurisdiction over gas sales by the Phillips Petroleum Company.

The International Longshoremen's Association. A. F. L., after a three-month silence, issued an attack yesterday on the report of the State Board of Inquiry that investigated the twenty-five-day dock strike of last fall. Simultaneously, Joseph P. Ryan, president of the union, was urged not to cooperate in any way with the State Industrial Commissioner, Edward Corsi, who is seeking to assure implementation of the board's recommendations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 23 -- The Barton Company will manufacture chocolate novelties and specialties in Israel for sale in its fifty-two shops in New York, Detroit and Newark, Stephen Klein, president of the American chocolate manufacturing concern, said tonight before his return to the United States. He said he expected sales to total $100,000 in the first year.

Your April 21 issue carried a letter from Prof. James Tobin of the Economics Department, Yale University. He criticized your editorial of April 10, Arthur Krock's column of April 11 and Edward H. Collins' column of April 14 for arguing "that it is profit after taxes rather than before taxes which should be considered in setting steel prices."

Nine "Edgars," statuette busts of Edgar Allen Poe awarded annually for achievement in the mystery writing field, were presented last night at the sixth annual dinner of the Mystery Writers of America at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, said today that most volunteer civilian ground observers in twenty-seven states would be placed on twenty-four-hour duty effective May 17.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., April 23 (AP) -- Joseph C. Grew, former United States Ambassador to Japan, said tonight that the Kremlin "has clearly miscalculated the influence of the women of the free world."

WASHINGTON. April 23 -- The Government announced today that steel price ceilings would be increased nearly $3 a ton next week, leaving to the companies the decision whether to put the rises into effect.

An appeal for support of the Greater New York Fund and the 423 local health and welfare agencies dependent upon the fund for part of their maintenance was made yesterday by representatives of three religious denominations at a luncheon of volunteer workers from business concerns at the Astor Hotel.

Describing the last twelve months as a banner period for the International News Service, Seymour Berkson, general manager of the news-gathering agency, said yesterday that its achievements were a symbol of "the growing desire of newspaper editors everywhere to give their readers improved coverage of the news and the news behind the news."

LONDON, April 23 -- For the first time since 1939, a German flag was among those unfurled at Stratford-on-Avon today in honor of Shakespeare's birth 388 years ago. Other new flags were those of Yemen and Vietnam. This is the first time the Vietnamese flag has been flown publicly in Britain.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 23 -- Joao Neves da Fontoura, the Foreign Minister, said today that the United States no longer could take the support of the Brazilian people for granted with the Communists assiduously fanning anti-American feeling as they are. He advised that Brazil be treated as an equal if her support was desired.

BOSTON, April 23 -- The Yankees dropped their first game with the Red Sox today before a crowd of 15,336 at Fenway Park. The count was 3 -- 1. Lou Boudreau's rookies had absolutely no respect for Allie Reynolds, hero of two no-hit games last season.

The veteran civil service employee who takes over on June 1 as first District Commissioner of Internal Revenue for the metropolitan New York area said yesterday that "a Government official who betrays the people is just food for Joe Stalin."

Final returns from Tuesday's primary election in New York State, besides consolidating sentiment behind General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination, carried with them several important undertones.

KALIMPONG, India, April 23 -- Public agitation against the Chinese Communist occupation of Lhasa, capital of Tibet, has risen to the point where the Tibetan Government has been forced to make official representations to the Chinese authorities asking them to remove a large part of their garrison lest there be an uprising, according to the latest reports received here.

" Loyola -- The Soldier Saint," a Spanish-made dramatization of the life of the founder of the Jesuit Order, is today's new film at the Holiday. This is a night opening scheduled for 8 o'clock. Rafael Duran appears in the title role, with Manuel Luna and Maria Rosa Jiminez among the featured players.

A seventh game will be needed to decide the championship of the National Basketball Association. By defeating the Minneapolis Lakers, 76 -- 68, last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment. Armory, the New York Knickerbockers forced this best-of-seven series right down to the wire.
Three student fellowships of $3,000 each have been awarded by the Metropolitan Museum of Art for a year's study at the museum.
A "streamlined" parade was promised yesterday for Armed Forces Day, May 17. as members of the Armed Forces Day Committee met at luncheon in the University Club.

Real estate sales in the Bronx during the first quarter of this year averaged 106 per cent of assessed valuations, one point above the fourth quarter of 1951, according to the Taxpayers Service Company. There were 2,524 transfers, an increase of 3 per cent above the previous quarter.

ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP) -- The Robert Cains bubbled with excitement today after the young left-hander had outhurled one of baseball's best pitchers to give the Browns a 1-0 triumph over the Indians last night.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP) -- Michigan's record breaking distance medley relay team, Army's great miler, Dick Shea, and Cornell's hurdling captain, Meredith Gourdine, are expected to dominate tomorrow's opening competition in the fifty-eighth annual Penn relay carnival at Franklin Field.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Liquidation was heavy again today, especially in the May deliveries of wheat, corn, oats and rye, but there were some indications that this selling had run its course. There was considerable commission absorption on the extreme declines, with shorts also inclined to take profits.

MONTREAL, April 24 -- Negotiations are under way for an issue of $90,000,000 of debentures by the Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., to be offered in the United States and to be guaranteed by the parent company, Aluminium, Ltd., Nathaniel V. Davis, president of Aluminium informed shareholders at the company's annual meeting here today.

Two years ago a group of the inhabitants of Ambon, Ceram, Buru and other islands that were once part of the "Great East" in the Dutch East Indies proclaimed the independence of the South Moluccan Republic. They did this in protest against the creation by the predominantly Javanese Indonesian Republic of a unitary rather than a federal Indonesia.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -Leo A. Rover, defense attorney, urged the Supreme Court today to reverse the murder conviction of Oscar Collazo, Puerto Rican revolutionary who tried to assassinate President Truman, asserting that the late Federal Judge T. Allan Goldsborough erred in his instructions to the jury.

MANILA, Friday, April 25 -- Unless some kind of political miracle happens, observers see little chance that the Philippine Senate will ratify the Japanese peace treaty before Congress adjourns May 21.

RICHMOND, Va., April 24 -- To weld employe's interests more closely to their work, Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, proposed today to sell stock to employes on an installment plan.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Congressional investigators developed today that Joseph D. Nunan Jr. had collected a $24,985 legal fee for speeding a tax decision in 1947 less than six months after he had quit as Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

A damaged clock worth $3 sold for $30 and forty tons of old Olympic Games programs brought $175 as waste paper yesterday at a Customs Service auction of abandoned and unclaimed merchandise. The sale was held in the Appraiser Stores, 201 Varick Street.

An authorized biography of Tito by Vladimer Dedijer, a Yugoslav Government official who was a comrade-in-arms of Tito in the wartime underground movement in Yugoslavia will be published in the fall by Simon Schuster. "Tito Speaks: An Authorized Biography" describes secrets of political intrigue, the fight against the Nazis, the author's vise to power and when he first doubted Russia's good faith.

BOSTON, April 24 -- For four hours and through eleven innings the Yankees waged grim battle with the Red Sox at Fenway Park today before a ladies' day gathering of 18,014, but they toiled in vain. For, with dusk fast enveloping the scene, Bob Kuzava walked over the run that gave Lou Boudreau's squad a 3-2 victory.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today the reappointment of Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg to serve another fourteen months as Air Force Chief of Staff.

The American Federation of Labor does not accept paid advertising in any of its publications and no one is authorized to solicit in the name of the A. F. of L. for any publication, according to George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the labor organization.

Barton's Bonbonniere will continue to manufacture its line of Continental chocolates in its plant in Brooklyn, the company announced yesterday in amplifying an announcement in Tel Aviv on Wednesday by Stephen Klein, president, that Barton's would produce candies in Israel.

Newbold Morris, who was ousted as a Special Assistant Attorney General a few hours before President Truman accepted on April 3 the resignation of J. Howard McGrath as Attorney General, proposed last night a Federal Department of Investigation to end corruption in Government.

The underwear industry is emerging from a period of depressed sales activity and all signs point to fuller utilization of productive capacity, manufacturers said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Underwear Institute in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Truman's news conference today, with his replies in paraphrase. (Direct quotation of the President's remarks is forbidden except with special permission, which was not given for today's conference.)
Interference that could disrupt reception of video programs in all parts of the country has recently become a distinct possibility.

The future of "The Shrike," in which Jose Ferrer and Judith Evelyn are starred, is hanging in the balance. The problem confronting the management is this: Up to now, no replacement is in sight to carry on for Mr. Ferrer. On June 6 or thereabout he will be heading for London to act in the film transcription of "Moulin Rouge," an assignment that will keep him busy through August.

The preparations of the home for summer may involve a paint job on the exterior as well as the interior of the house. Among new paints now available are some that might be used on out-of-door furnishings.

EDITH SIMON'S "The Golden Hand"* is one of the finest historical novels I have read in recent years. Nearly as elaborate and intricately detailed as a Gothic cathedral and as rich with glowing colors as a stained-glass window, this enormous panorama of medieval life asks much of its readers. It asks patient application for many hours, willing adjustment to its leisurely pace and prolonged immersion in its evocation of another world.

In a day-long session yesterday the Board of Estimate authorized the drafting of $1,355,800 in plans for $26,300,000 in new school construction as part of the Board of Education's speed-up building program, and approved contracts for architects' services for the Columbus Circle slum-clearance project.

Nothing has happened for quite a long time as admirable as the new production at the Circle in the Square -- in Sheridan Square, to be precise. Tennessee Williams' "Summer and Smoke" opened there last evening in a sensitive, highly personal performance.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 24 (AP) -- Some excellent team work at the starting line enabled Bermuda to defeat the United States in the sixth race of the Amorita Cup series for international one-design yachts today.

The Board of Education deferred action yesterday on a proposed plan that would create new grievance machinery for teachers and give employes a voice in school policy. The measure will come up again at next Thursday's meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- During the week ended April 23, member bank reserves decreased $343,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The principal changes reducing reserves were an increase of $357,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and a decrease of $136,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit.

PARIS, April 24 -- The headquarters of Gen. Charles de Gaulle issued tonight a warning to the public to "beware of false rumors" that, it said, were multiplying in advance of the coming Senatorial elections.
